title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILWORTH, J. RICHARDSON
description: DILWORTH-J. Richardson. The Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend, J. Richardson Dilworth, an esteemed member of the Board of Trustees for more than thirty years. Dick Dilworth joined the Rockefeller Board in 1960 and was named a Trustee Emeritus in 1992. In 1993, in recognition of his outstanding service to the University community, he was awarded the honorary degree of Doctor of Science. Dick was a trusted friend and advisor to five Rockefeller University presidents. He will be remembered for his generosity of spirit, wise counsel, and the enormous personal integrity that guided all aspects of his long and productive life. Dick Dilworth's contributions of time and talent had a profound impact on all facets of life at The Rockefeller University. He played a key role in the development of much-needed housing for students and faculty and the construction of new laboratory buildings that transformed the south end of the University's campus into a modern biomedical research complex. As treasurer and chairman of the finance and investment committee, he ensured the financial health of the insitutions and oversaw a fourfold growth of the Univeristy's endowment. We will miss the keen intelligence, astute judgement, and inspiring optimism that Dick brought to every problem. His influence and legacy, however, will be felt throughout the University for many years to come. Friend, advisor, philanthropist, and cherished leader, J. Richardson Dilworth was an enlightened partner in the struggle against human disease. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Elizabeth and their beloved children, Joseph, Charles, and Alexandra and their families. Torsten N. Wiesel, President Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Board of Trustees, and David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee Board of Trustees

title: Wharton's Passion, Written in the Snow
description: IN the stillness of a Berkshire winter, when icicles hang languorously from the sugar maples and the walled Italian garden is submerged in snow, the extraordinary house that Edith Wharton built for herself here nearly a century ago seems frozen, literally, in time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISBERG, BARRETT G.
description: KREISBERG-Barrett G. The Trustees of The Harkness Foundation for Dance mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague Barry Kreisberg. Barry served the Foundation with distinction and dedication for twentyfive years. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving wife Luisa who has been steadfast in her support of his Foundation activities, his son Joel, daughters-in-law and his cherished grandchildren. Theodore S. Bartwink Etta Brandman William A. Perlmuth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, BRENDAN
description: GILL-Brendan. Chairman Emeritus and previously President and Chairman of the Municipal Art Society of New York. Our Board, staff, members and supporters send our sympathy to Anne, to Brendan's seven children and eleven grandchildren. Not just our Society, but all of New York will miss Brendan's voice and his great heart. Philip Howard, Chair Brendan Sexton, President Board of Directors The Municipal Art Society

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEIN, GITTIE
description: DEIN-Gittie. My sister, our Gittie, we are here, your spirit is everywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFF, SUZANNE BOOTH
description: DORFF-Suzanne Booth. Age 50, Fargo Lane, Irvington, New York, died December 31, 1997 after a long illness. She lived in Irvington since 1978 with her family and was very active in community and school affairs and in life itself. She most recently participated in the family construction business. She was also a certified yoga instructor in Irvington. Those wishing to pay their respects are invited at 10AM to 12:30 PM with a memorial service 12:30 P.M. on Saturday, January 3, 1998 at the EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY. She is survived by her loving husband, John, and children, Christopher, Julia and Zachary, sisters Diane Booth and Valerie McGrory and brothers Michael, Douglas and Stephen. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society of Westchester, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, New York.

title: Coffee Prices Decline Slightly; Silver Hits a Five-Month Low
description: Coffee prices fell yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York on signs that roasters are amply supplied.

title: Disabled Skiers Get Aid From Volunteers
description: Margaret Chandler was 62 years old when she first went skiing. Not that it was a particularly daring thing to do for a woman in her 60's. But factor in a boating accident the year before that had left her paralyzed from the waist down. Then consider the merit of her effort.

title: French Police Press the Search for a Fiat in Diana Crash
description: French investigators are continuing their search for a white Fiat that may have brushed the Mercedes carrying Diana, Princess of Wales, just before the crash that killed her and two others, the authorities said today, after reports about the Fiat resurfaced in the French press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMAN, RICHARD
description: ELMAN-Richard. Beloved husband of Alice, loving father of Margaret and Lila, brother of Leonard. Treasured friend. Services Friday, January 2 at 1 P.M. at Temple Isaiah, Stonybrook Road, Stonybrook, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRINGER, VICTOR J.
description: BARRINGER-Victor J. 7/22/21-12/ 22/97. Gentleman, scholar, sailor, after a courageous battle with emphysema and cancer. A graduate of Dartmouth College he served in the USMC in World War II. He was wounded and decorated for action throughout the Pacific theater. Rest in peace, dear friend.

title: Kenya's President Takes Lead as Ballot Counting Drags On
description: The counting of ballots in Kenya's general election dragged on today, as more reports of irregularities and violent incidents at counting stations added to questions about the fairness of the polls.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Na Tao Journal; Asia's Wealth Ebbs, but Laos Is Too Poor to Care
description: This is one Southeast Asian country that has mostly dodged the economic crisis that is sweeping through the region. It is too poor to feel the pain.

title: F.D.A. Approves Test That Predicts Recurrence of Breast Cancer
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the first gene-based test for predicting whether a cancer will recur, one for breast cancer that is based on how many copies of a particular gene a patient has.

title: U.S. General Says Conflict With Iraqis Is Still Possible
description: The commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf region said today that the American military buildup in the area had in all likelihood thwarted the threat of hostilities by Iraq, but warned that a military confrontation remained a possibility.

title: State, Not Religion, Must Lead Fight for Poor; Faith Isn't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on Monday about an incident in which a United Airlines jetliner hit severe air turbulence over the Pacific misspelled the surname of an airline official and misidentified his organization. He is Tony Molinaro, not Molinari, and is a spokesman for United, not for the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: As Woman's Execution Nears, Texas Squirms
description: Texas put 37 men to death this year, the most executions in any state in any year in the modern era of capital punishment. But even for a state with the nation's busiest execution chamber, the looming lethal injection of prisoner No. 777 at the Mountain View Unit here is a milestone. The condemned inmate is 38-year-old Karla Faye Tucker, who would become the first woman executed in Texas since the Civil War. She is scheduled to die on Feb. 3 for her part in the pickax slayings 14 years ago of Jerry Lynn Dean and Deborah Thornton, a crime that is still known as one of the most lurid in Houston's history.

title: Bills' Levy Ends an Era By Retiring As Coach
description: Marv Levy, at 72 the oldest head coach in the National Football League, retired yesterday after 12 seasons of leading the Buffalo Bills. After two meetings in the last week with Ralph Wilson, the Bills' 79-year-old owner, Levy parted with the team he guided to four consecutive Super Bowls, an unmatched record. The Bills lost all four.

title: Man's Arrest Is Linked to Slaying of Officer
description: For nine years, the shooting death of Police Officer Michael Buczek in Washington Heights on Oct. 18, 1988, has remained unsolved. But the arrest of a man in Lawrence, Mass., Saturday night has led the police to think they are one step closer to a solution.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge's Ruling Could Allow Baby Bells to Expand

title: Cable Giants Aren't to Blame for Rising Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: New Year's Day
description: NEW YORK

title: The Year of Living Smugly
description: Perhaps the most striking thing about 1997 was its power to divert. The robust economy, the continued decline in crime and the blessed respite from terrorist violence on home soil gave the nation an opportunity to focus on intensely personal news events with little overarching import -- the death of Princess Diana, the ''nanny'' trial and the birth of American septuplets.

title: Editorial Observer; Leaving Blank Pages in Yet Another New Diary
description: Every year about now, I feel the urge to keep a journal. Perhaps it is caused by the impending neatness of the calendar or by a seasonal flirtation with personal amendment. But I recognize in this urge all my worst instincts as a writer, the very things I have trained myself over the years to disregard. I walk past the stacks of blank books -- gifts of nothingness -- that proliferate in bookstores at this season, and I can almost hear their clean white pages begging to be defaced. They evoke in me the amateur, the high-school student, the miserable writerly aspirant I once was -- a young man who could almost picture in the flow of ink onto the woven fibers of the blank page the watering of some eternal garden.

title: State Crimes Shake Turkey As Politicians Face Charges
description: Two leading figures in Turkey's biggest modern political scandal may be tried for crimes they claim to have committed on behalf of the state, a senior judge ruled today.

title: If Only Injuries Would Heal, If Only the Hall Had Depth
description: Seton Hall will enter 1998 faced with old problems that gored them badly in a 78-65 loss to Miami in a New Year's Eve matinee at Continental Arena today.

title: Transit System Starts Its Plan of 11 Rides For the Price of 10
description: Subway and bus riders got their first taste of volume discounts at midnight last night when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority began selling 11 rides for the price of 10.

title: Wanted: Maverick Lite
description: To the Editor:

title: Penn State Is Forced To Rely on McQueary
description: To understand how much Penn State quarterback Mike McQueary will miss his favorite receiver in Thursday's Florida Citrus Bowl game against Florida, let McQueary put it in perspective.

title: Computer Error Cuts Off Some Entitled to Medicaid
description: The State of New York is scrambling to reprogram a computer that improperly denied medical insurance to at least hundreds of welfare recipients last month, officials said yesterday.

title: Currents; THROW PILLOWS -- Color as Electrifying And Sweet as a Dream
description: Barbara May's pillows, which have appeared in a Toni Braxton video, create live-video lipstick colors and iridescence by layering silks. An inside pillow case is taffeta. The outside, looser, cover is sheer organza. The pillows come in 16- and 22-inch squares, at $100 and $150, exclusively from Escabelle, 273 Lafayette Street (Prince Street); (212) 941-5925.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBIN, ADA
description: EBIN-Ada. Beloved wife of Milton. Devoted mother of Linda Ebin and Ron Stutz. Dear sister of Anne Phillips. Graveside service is at 12 noon, today, at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Memphis, TN.

title: Role in 'Rent' as a Path to Self-Acceptance
description: A matinee performance of ''Rent'' has just ended. Wilson Cruz, who plays the seductive transvestite Angel in the Broadway musical retelling of ''La Boheme,'' makes very slow progress through the autograph-seekers thronging the corridor from the stage door of the Nederlander Theater to the street.

title: Currents; FURNITURE AND GLASS -- What Will Be Found at the End of History
description: He sold his first gift certificate to Courtney Love, for $500, over the phone. But that was after he had the name for the shop. ''Very 'Ice Storm,' '' is how Stephen Saunders, owner of the End of History, described its 1950's, 60's and 70's furniture, glass and ceramics. ''Venetian glass is my big love,'' he said. It shows. The shop's display director, Duke Todd, has arranged hundreds of glass pieces by color and shape, rather than price, age or manufacturer. Most are less than $300. At 548 1/2 Hudson Street (Perry Street); (212) 647-7598.

title: A Choreographer Who Sees Ballet as a Silent Film; After Male Swans, 'Cinderella' in Wartime
description: The bar at the Piccadilly Theater was quiet and disheveled in the middle of the morning, fresh boxes of liquor stacked on the countertop, the too-bright light exposing frayed threads along the edge of the carpet. Matthew Bourne sat back on an upholstered bench and closed his eyes for a moment, listening. The clomp of rehearsing dancers could be heard, faintly, from deeper inside the theater.

title: Bones Near Palisades Tied to Missing Woman
description: Some scattered bones, discovered by accident near the Palisades Interstate Parkway earlier this week, were identified yesterday as the remains of a woman who had been missing for more than a year, the Bergen County Sheriff's office said.

title: Investment in Vietnam Dropped Sharply in 1997
description: Vietnam reported yesterday that new foreign investment totaled $4.5 billion in 1997, about half that of a record $8.6 million in new projects licensed the year before. ''We can see a reduction in foreign investment,'' said Nguyen Nhac, the Deputy Minister of Planning and Investment. The amount of capital that was put to work in already licensed projects increased $800 million over the 1996 level, to $3 billion last year, and other companies increased investments in established businesses by $1 billion.

title: Though Bruised, Davis Carries Broncos' Hopes
description: Terrell Davis is a small 210 pounds, if that is possible, with a baby face fired by frequent smiles. He wears braces, which he often worries will capture food and make him look goofy in television interviews.

title: Armed, Ex-Patient Surrenders in Queens Hospital
description: A disgruntled former patient armed with a revolver took a security guard hostage in Jamaica Hospital Medical Center in Queens last night, paralyzing the hospital's emergency room for two and a half hours, the police said.

title: Victim's Family Sues Georgian Diplomat
description: The family of a teen-ager killed last year in a drunken-driving accident involving a diplomat from the Republic of Georgia today filed two civil lawsuits seeking damages against the diplomat.

title: The Neediest Cases; For Young Mother, a Dream Renewed
description: LaShoun Turnipseed popped another Hershey's Kiss into her son's eager mouth and pronounced it the last. ''You're going to be mad at me when I say no,'' she told Darice, 13, ''but that's the way it's going to be.''

title: Public Eye; Pop-ups to cow skulls: big books that tell their stories graphically.
description: IT appears to be the Age of the Big Book, with evidence of literary gigantism seen in the sheer heft of recent works by Don DeLillo, Thomas Pynchon and David Foster Wallace. But a new breed of image-intensive books are tipping the scales even more than their text-based cousins -- and elevating graphic designers to new levels of authorship.

title: Franconia Journal; He's a Monkey, a Helper and Now a Legal Resident
description: The three-story town house on Hyacinth Street is virtually indistinguishable from hundreds of others here in this corner of Fairfax County, all with their neatly trimmed little yards and now with colorful decorations celebrating the holidays.

title: Last Night? It's History. Think 1999.
description: In scurrying to find the biggest and best year-end party last night, many revelers no doubt realized that it's time to start thinking about what to do the night the calendar turns to 2000. With the millennium two years away, concert promoters and party planners are beginning to think seriously about putting on huge millennial blow-outs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a proposal by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to ease zoning rules on the development rights of 25 Broadway theaters included an outdated affiliation for Jack Goldstein, an industry representative who commented. He is executive director-elect of the Theater Development Fund. The coordinator of the Broadway Initiative, a nonprofit organization, is now Anne Zimmerman.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The cure for obesity may be worse than the condition.''

title: New Study Reduces Death Risk From Fat
description: Obesity increases the likelihood of premature death but not as much as many medical experts had suspected, according to the largest study ever conducted on the health risks of the condition.

title: AMERICAN MOBILE IS BUYING ARDIS FOR $100 MILLION
description: The American Mobile Satellite Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Motorola Inc.'s Ardis data-messaging business for $100 million in stock and cash. The purchase price will be paid half in American Mobile stock and half in cash, Renate Neely, an American Mobile spokeswoman, said. The Ardis network covers more than 425 cities in the United States, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, the companies said. American Mobile and Ardis provide access to data that allow users to send and receive messages instantly. For example, Sears, Roebuck, an Ardis customer, uses the network to dispatch its field technicians, and the technicians use the network to order parts and to send updates from the field, John Bornstein, an Ardis spokesman, said.

title: Not Just a New Year: A 100th Birthday for a Unified City
description: When the ball dropped above Times Square last night, it not only ushered in 1998, but it also marked the 100th anniversary of the consolidation of the five boroughs into the city that is now New York.

title: Helping Hand Replaces Hands-Off Role in Asia
description: Financial crises that threaten to melt down countries by the fistful are becoming a standard feature of the global economy. And as they occur, the governments of the big industrial countries find themselves dragged into the role of rescuing a market system that in theory at least is supposed to cure itself.

title: A Gas Prospector Files Chapter 11
description: The Trinity Gas Corporation has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, two weeks after the Securities and Exchange Commission accused it of making fraudulent claims about natural gas discoveries in Colombia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASSMAN, RON
description: GASSMAN-Ron. December 29, 1997, Bedford, New York. Temple Shaaray Tefila mourns the sudden passing of Ron Gassman, Ron was a Founding Member, Past President, Director and Dear Friend of our congregation. Our hearts are with his wife Marian, and daughter Lauren as we mourn this tragic loss. Funeral Wednesday at 11AM at the Temple. The Board of Trustees

title: Dominique de Menil, 89, Dies; Collector and Philanthropist
description: Dominique de Menil, a connoisseur, art collector and creator with her husband, John, of the Menil Foundation in Houston, died yesterday at her home in Houston. She was 89.

title: A U.S. Judge Strikes Down Parts Of '96 Telecommunications Act
description: A Federal judge yesterday struck down major sections of the 1996 act that deregulated the telecommunications industry, saying that the law unfairly kept the regional Bell telephone companies out of the long-distance business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, REV. JOHN P.
description: DONAHUE-Rev. John P., C.S.P. On December 31 at age 75, was a native of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Fr. Donahue served in the U.S. Army Tank Corps '42-'46; wounded in action three times, suffering the loss of his right eye. He was awarded The Purple Heart with one Bronze Oak Leaf Cluster and the Belgian Forragere. Ordained a Paulist priest on May 11, 1957, he served in South Africa and at Paulist foundations throughout the U.S., as a parish priest, in Newman Centers, and as a Chaplain. Walter Reed U.S. Medical Center was his last location of priestly service. Funeral arrangements are incomplete at this time.

title: Warren Mehrtens, 77, a Triple Crown Jockey
description: Warren Mehrtens, 1 of only 10 jockeys to win thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown, died Tuesday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 77.

title: Dancing With Angelfish
description: SURE, we could have flown to Costa Rica for our vacation, but the grandparents don't winter there. They winter in Florida. Paved Florida. ''C'mon down,'' said Jerry and Sheron Weiner, two of the most generously doting grandparents a kid could ever have. ''We've got heated swimming pools!''

title: Balloons Launched in Global Race
description: In the final hours of 1997, two lone pilots sharing a taste for hazardous adventure, ascended in their balloons from St. Louis and Loves Park, Ill., each hoping to become the first balloonist to circle the world nonstop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYNE, SYLVIA
description: MAYNE-Sylvia. Beloved mother, grandmother and friend died on December 30, 1997. With a passion for life and a love of family and friends, her gifts will inspire those who knew her. She was an ardent supporter of the Metropolitan Opera, The Holocaust Museum, United Jewish Appeal, and Temple Sinai. Survived by her sons Ronald, Gary and DeBare, daughter-in-law Lucille and granddaughters Sarah and Julia. Services will be held at Temple Sinai, Roslyn Heights, at 9 AM, January 2. Contributions can be made in her name to Temple Sinai.

title: Data Suggest Another Year Of Expansion
description: The uninterrupted economic expansion that began with the end of the Persian Gulf war -- already the second-longest in peacetime this century -- is almost certain to reach its seventh anniversary in early spring, analysts said today in assessing the final batch of statistics published in 1997.

title: NUEVO ENERGY TO SELL GAS PIPELINE AND STORAGE ASSETS
description: The Nuevo Energy Company said yesterday that it would sell the rest of its natural gas-gathering pipeline and storage assets and take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $26 million related to the sale. Nuevo is selling the assets -- a pipeline in St. Louis, a gas storage operation in Kansas and a gas-gathering system in Texas -- to focus on finding and producing oil and gas, Robert King, the company's chief financial officer, said. Nuevo sold its interest in a West Texas gas plant to a unit of the Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company for $25 million in the second quarter, resulting in a pretax gain of $2 million. Nuevo's shares rose $1.125, to $40.75.

title: Bonds Rise At Year's End; '98 Promising
description: The bond market ended 1997 on a high note yesterday, strengthening prices and leaving the yield on the most widely followed United States Goverment security near the lowest level in more than four years.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; At One With Their Standards
description: Extraordinary performers, the usual repertory: pretty much the story of this collection of new piano recordings. Two of the featured musicians appear as men on the way from one point in their careers to another. Yevgeny Kissin exchanges his image of spectacular adolescent for that of responsible (and hardly less spectacular) adult. For Murray Perahia, the shift is from young master to old(er) master. Add to them Alfred Brendel, who in performances of Beethoven's Bagatelles and other shorter pieces presides, by way of age and accomplishment, over his two colleagues.

title: A Frankenstein Monster Ended Up Being a Lamb
description: CLONE

title: Van Horn Is Forced to Face Issue of Race
description: To Keith Van Horn, the color of his skin has never been an issue. And it would please him if other people would just drop the subject.

title: Merged Indonesian Banks To Be Opened to Investors
description: Six Indonesian state banks will be combined into two in 1998, and banking will be opened to foreign investors, the Government press agency Antara said yesterday. The consolidations, which had been expected, may hasten the shrinking of consolidation of Indonesia's battered banking industry.

title: City Comptroller's Wife Has Heart Operation
description: Carol Hevesi, the wife of the New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, underwent surgery yesterday to replace a faulty heart valve.

title: Hospitals In Cities Fear Medicare Cuts
description: Hospitals in New York City and other urban areas around the country will be disproportionately hurt by a new Medicare policy that will reduce revenue starting Thursday and may force cuts in mental health and other services, hospital officials and members of Congress said today.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSHANDLER, FRANK
description: GROSSHANDLER-Frank. Survived by wife Frances Mai; children: Michael, Karen and Joseph; parents Ruth and Jordan; and brother George. Services at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, Long Island on Friday, January 2 at 11 A.M.

title: Same Old Rangers Start Second Half of Season
description: The start of the second half of the Rangers' season did not provide much reason to believe that things will be markedly better than they were in the first half.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREITZER, SHIRLEY WOLFF COHEN
description: DREITZER-Shirley Wolff Cohen. On Wednesday, December 31, at age 85, of New York and Palm Beach. Devoted wife of the late Albert J. Dreitzer, and, for 39 years, devoted wife of the late William I. Cohen. Loving mother of Stephanie C. Rosen Halpern and Cathleen C. Cavell. Dear sister of Ethel W. Freeman and Annette W. Katz. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth, Carolyn, Pamela and Katherine Rosen, Benjamin and David Cavell, and loving stepgrandmother of Rachel Cavell. Services Friday, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment, Old Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Iranian Film Rocks Hotbed of Tradition
description: Finally, the Quds Cinema in this provincial capital can boast, '' 'Snowman' in Isfahan -- at the same time as in Teheran.'' But as so often in Iran, what lies behind the marquee is a more complicated tale.

title: Hollywood and History
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Angela's Champion
description: Jerome W. Marks retired as a State Supreme Court justice in 1992, but retirement didn't agree with him. He missed the action in and around the courthouse. He missed the challenge of the law.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARISON, DAVID
description: BARISON-David. Sept. 26, 1964Jan 1, 1995. Birth is a beginning And death a destination And life is a journey. Mom and Dad.

title: Never at a Loss for Words on Rap
description: When Rakim takes the microphone, hip-hop becomes the most self-reflexive art form this side of Conceptualism. Rakim raps about rapping, the entire process from putting pen to paper to moving a crowd from the stage; all the while, he reminds listeners that he's a master of his profession. For him, hip-hop is a self-contained universe, a world of microphones to burn through and stages to conquer, and he rarely raps about anything else. Yet that's no limitation, since he has an apparently bottomless store of metaphors and similes for what he does. As Rakim describes it, rapping is an addiction, a craft, a weapon, a science, a career and a religion; sometimes he calls himself an emperor or a god.

title: Four-Star Stand-In At the Philharmonic
description: Marilyn Horne was dressing last night for a tranquil, nonworking New Year's Eve. She was to be a guest of Deborah Borda, the executive director of the New York Philharmonic, in Ms. Borda's box at Avery Fisher Hall for the annual New Year's Eve Pension Fund Benefit Concert. Valery Gergiyev was to conduct the orchestra in works by Tchaikovsky, Mussorgsky, Ravel and Bizet, with Olga Borodina, the mezzo-soprano, and Samuel Ramey, the bass, as guest artists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELSON, DAVID
description: FOGELSON-David. The Trustees, and Staff of The Jewish Museum extend condolences to the Fogelson and Liman families and heartfelt sympathy to David's daughter, and Life Trustee, Ellen Liman, his daughter-in-law, Phyllis Fogelson, and his grandchildren. Both David and his late wife, Gertrude Fogelson, former Honorary Board Chair, were generous and devoted members of the Jewish Museum family for decades. David's kindness and charm touched all who knew him. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Philip A. Laskawy, President Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, SUSAN
description: ROTHENBERG-Susan. We at the National Jewish Outreach Program are shocked and deeply bereaved by the sudden and untimely passing of Susan Rothenberg, our dear friend, beloved co-worker and brilliant computer expert. For most of the 9-1/2 years that she was with NJOP, she and her dear sister, Phyllis Romanski, worked virtually full time as volunteers. Must of NJOP's success in reaching unaffiliated Jews (which she once was) must be attributed to her dynamic personality, soaring intellect and generous spirit. Over the years, she became a knowledgeable, committed and passionate Jew, who, among her myriad responsibilities, edited the ''Ask the Rabbi'' column on our website. We will profoundly miss this totally giving human being. Condolences to the entire famly. May her memory be a blessing for all. Services Friday, January 2, 1998, 9:45 AM, at Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: QUADRAMED TO ACQUIRE 2 HEALTH CARE SERVICE PROVIDERS
description: The Quadramed Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two companies that provide services and products to the health care industry for a total of $37 million in stock. Quadramed, based in Larkspur, Calif., develops software products and services for health care providers. The acquired companies are Rothenberg Health Systems Inc. and Healthcare Research Affiliates. Rothenberg Health is a privately held provider of health care information systems. Its primary product is software that helps health care providers adjudicate, process and pay claims. Healthcare Research Affiliates is a consulting company specializing in quality standards for the managed-care industry. Shares of Quadramed rose $2, to $27.50.

title: Charter School Imperiled By Surprise Resignations
description: One of New Jersey's 13 charter schools may close on Monday because of the surprise resignation of three of its four staff members. The problems at the Gateway Charter School in Jersey City mark a setback for the state's new charter school system, which was established in 1997 with the backing of numerous officials. Charter schools are financed with public money but operated by private individuals approved by the state.

title: Almost Homeless Again: Writer and Dog on Edge
description: The book ''Travels With Lizbeth'' propelled its author, Lars Eighner, to acclaim. Perhaps more importantly, into a home.

title: A Human Face for Swiss Banks; Unlikely Mediator for Dispute Over Jewish Assets
description: Hans J. Baer seems tailor-made for representing Swiss banks in their bitter struggle with Jewish organizations over the recovery of assets belonging to Holocaust victims.

title: Currents; TALKS ON DESIGN -- A Look Back at Midcentury
description: Don't know your Knoll from your Nelson? William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street, is offering four free talks on midcentury design. Eric Silver, head of 19th- and 20th-century decorative arts at Doyle, will speak on Jan. 12; David McFadden, chief curator of the American Craft Museum, Jan. 19; Andrew Lin, co-owner of Lin-Weinberg Gallery, Feb. 2, and Thad Hayes, a designer, Feb. 9. Lectures begin at 6:30; reservations required: (212) 427-2730 ext. 219.

title: Western Wireless Gets Ownership Waiver
description: Federal regulators today granted the Western Wireless Corporation's application to exceed the 25 percent cap on foreign ownership, clearing the way for the Hong Kong-based Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. to buy, indirectly, a 19.9 percent stake in a Western Wireless unit.

title: Decidedly Un-Communist Goals For the Young of Central Europe
description: Vladimir Kreidl, 23, is a gifted young economist who has the faraway air of a scholar, yet is at home in the elegant furnishings of the investment bank where he keeps excruciatingly long hours.

title: Our Towns ; Announcing The Arrival Of the Airport
description: IN the good old days, Newark Interna tional Airport was How to put it? -- ''How about rinky-dink?'' Amy Miller said. ''That's what I used to say.''

title: Bridge; Shooting for the Olympics, The Asian Games a Start
description: Is bridge a sport? That is not a trivial academic question, for on it hinges a matter of great importance to bridge players: the eventual inclusion of bridge in the Olympic Games.

title: A Night the World Comes to the Crossroads of the World
description: Bill Grant had New Year's Eve choreographed to the smallest detail.

title: Officers Facing Added Scrutiny Over Shootings
description: The police officer who fatally shot an unarmed Brooklyn man on Christmas Day has been involved in more shootings than any other officer on the city's 38,000-member force, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday, and the discovery has caused police officials to begin monitoring any officer who uses gunfire on three or more occasions.

title: Belk Plans to Merge 112 Concerns Into One
description: The Belk department store chain's 112 closely held companies plan to merge into a single concern, to cut costs and compete better with larger United States chains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHUGH, SUSAN MANNING

Anthony McHugh, mother of Mary Mckeon, James McHugh, Andrea Courtney, Kathleen Martin, Robert McHugh, Alicia Zec. 11 grandchildren. Sister of Alice Auld, Lt. Col. John Manning, Kevin and Rev. James Manning. Calling hrs. Fri. 3-7 P.M. at Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church St., Guilford. Mass Saturday 11:30 A.M. St. Margaret Church, Madison.

title: Germany Will Finance Computer Chip Project
description: Siemens A.G. and Motorola Inc. are planning a joint venture in Dresden, Germany, to develop a new and less expensive computer chip in what will be Europe's largest semiconductor project, the German Government said yesterday.

title: Two Times Square Sites Are Suddenly Much in Demand
description: With real estate prices climbing at a dizzying rate as the resurgence of Times Square continues, developers once loath to build are now jostling over two prime development sites for two towers of nearly one million square feet each.

title: Building That Collapsed Is Gone; The Questions It Raised Remain
description: Laboring throughout the night and early morning yesterday, workers removed the remains of a collapsed six-story building on 42d Street, clearing away a potential impediment to the Times Square New Year's Eve celebration.

title: Holiday Sales Varying Less Among Regions
description: While the holiday shopping season usually means strong sales in one area of the country and terrible disappointments in others, this Christmas was oddly consistent from region to region, new figures show, reflecting in part a strong national economy.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the parodist and editor Veronica Geng on Friday omitted a survivor. He is her brother, Steve Geng of Manhattan.

title: Hopes for Peace Talks Dim As Israel Extends Settlement
description: Despite American calls for a ''timeout'' in settlement building, Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai of Israel shoveled cement into a hole today for a new extension of this Jewish settlement in the hills north of the Palestinian-ruled town of Ramallah.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALIN, MILDRED
description: MALIN-Mildred. My beloved aunt. I think of you every day. I miss you. Freya

title: Emotion Fills Courtroom As Judge Calls for None
description: On the day of the Oklahoma City bombing, Ashley Eckles, who was 4 1/2, cried and made the plea that most working mothers eventually hear: ''Mommy, please don't go to work today. Please stay home and play with me. I need you.''

title: Silences That Add to the Tumult
description: Over the last few years the pianist Chick Corea has entered the new world of jazz, hiring some of the best young musicians around to take him into serious territory. His new band, Origin, a sextet, performed at the Blue Note on Tuesday night, and if anything underscored the musical revolution jazz has undergone in the last 15 years, it was the differing rhythmic sensibilities on stage.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Miniaturizing a Red Maple

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ROBERT LEE
description: FELDMAN-Robert Lee. Prominent New York Physician, Robert Lee Feldman, passed away on December 27th at his winter home in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Dr. Feldman practiced Obstetrics and Gynecology in his Fifth Avenue office where his patients included many Hollywood personalities, national dignitaries and members of the international diplomatic corps. In the 1950's and 1960's, Dr. Feldman was an active researcher and early proponent of numerous pioneering medical procedures and products; the Birth Control pill, the Rubin Infertility test and Estrogen replacement therapy. A native of Brooklyn, New York, Dr. Feldman graduated from Johns Hopkins University in 1939 and from New York University Medical School in 1943. Dr. Feldman proudly served as a Captain in the medical corps of the United States Army from 1943 through 1946 under the command of General George S. Patton. He is survived by Cecile Feldman, his wife of 47 years; two brothers, George and Raymond Feldman, four children, Ronald, Richard, Peter Feldman and Susan Miller and; three grandchildren, Katelyn Miller, Lily and Phillip Feldman.

title: German Ex-Monopoly Wants a Switching Fee
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said it wants to charge customers a one-time fee if they switch to a competing telephone company after its monopoly on voice services ends today. The company filed a request this week with the new German regulator for telecommunications and post, which said that Deutsche Telekom had proposed charging customers about 85 marks, or $47, if they switched carriers.

title: NOTEBOOK
description: LAKERS

title: AROUND THE BLOCK WITH: Yoshio Taniguchi; A Modest Someone Redoes the Modern
description: FOUR weeks ago only a handful of New Yorkers had ever heard of him. But henceforth, the name of Yoshio Taniguchi will be inextricably linked to one of the city's most prized cultural treasures. With the announcement on Dec. 8 that the 60-year-old Japanese architect had won the high-profile competition to nearly double the size of the Museum of Modern Art, most people are still trying to figure out who the dark horse is. Mr. Taniguchi would be happy if they remained in the dark.

title: That Flurry of Falling Brick? It's Coincidence, Chicken Little
description: Over the last three days, New Yorkers could be forgiven for thinking that the sky was falling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTON, MICHAEL F.
description: BARTON-Michael F. December 30, 1997. Age 39. Beloved son of John and Anne. Loving brother of John P., Christopher, Marianne, and Eugene. Dear uncle of Jaclyn, J.P., and Caroline. Graduate of Molloy High School, Class of '76. Trader at Smith Barney and Associate Director at Swiss Bank Corp. Reposing at Frederick's Funeral Home, Inc., 192-15 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Thursday 2-5 and 710 P.M. Funeral Mass on Friday at St. Kevin's Church at 9:45 A.M. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Brother Terence Fund at Molloy High School, 83-53 Manton Street, Briarwood, New York.

title: Bumpy Ride, But a Victory For UConn
description: The third-ranked Connecticut women's basketball team quickly stopped thinking about the future -- a showdown against top-ranked Tennessee on Saturday -- and began to concentrate on the present today during its Big East game against Rutgers.

description: To the Editor:

description: FOOTBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABOUAF, SAM JUSTIN
description: ABOUAF-Sam Justin. December 30, 1997. Beloved son of Jon and Denise Abouaf and little brother of Evan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Thursday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Service on Friday, 11:30 A.M.

title: FIRST DATA SELLS BILL COLLECTION UNIT FOR $155 MILLION
description: The First Data Corporation sold its bill collection unit yesterday to an investment partnership formed by affiliates of Centre Partners Management L.L.C. and Weiss, Peck & Greer L.L.C. for $155 million. First Data, based in Hackensack, N.J., said it would record an after-tax loss of about $60 million in its fourth quarter to reflect the sale. The unit that was sold, Atlanta-based Nationwide Credit Inc., is expected to report approximately $120 million in revenues in 1997. First Data's shares fell $1 each, to $29.25.

title: 4 Newspapers in Western U.S. to Be Sold
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said today that its Kearns-Tribune Corporation unit would sell four newspapers to TPC Holdings Inc. for an undisclosed price as the company focuses on its cable television business.

title: In Ewing's Absence, the Knicks Turn to Larry Johnson
description: Larry Johnson is becoming more than a paper clip or a rubber band for the Knicks, more than just a temporary method of holding everything together in Patrick Ewing's absence.

title: Sports of The Times; Levy Merits More Fame Than Blame
description: BUNDLED in a blue Bills parka in the Buffalo chill, Marv Levy always looked and sounded more like a not-so-nutty professor who had somehow wandered onto the sideline. And with a Phi Beta Kappa key from Coe College in Iowa and a master's degree in English history from Harvard, he often provided his players with historical and professorial perspective on life in pro football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMITT, ZIG
description: SCHMITT-Zig, 52. Died at his home in East Hampton, NY, on Monday, December 29, of brain cancer. A native of Miami Beach, Zig was born on December 21, 1945, the first son of Lila Greenspan (Heatter) and W. Gordon Schmitt. Zig attended schools in Miami Beach, and then The Hill School in Pennsylvania. He graduated Harvard College with honors in 1968, and was awarded a Master's degree from the Harvard School of Education the following year. Zig married Jill Keefe in 1969, and they lived in Manhattan, Coral Gables, and Amagansett, Long Island, before their divorce in 1982. Zig is survived by their daughter, Molly Schmitt, 24; and his brother, Dr. David Schmitt (Lettie Bien), and niece, Maggie Schmitt. After graduating from the University of Miami Law School, Zig joined the Riverhead, NY law firm Twomey, Latham & Schmitt, in 1978. In 1980, he was appointed Town Attorney of East Hampton. His well-regarded term enacted significant environmental legislation at a time of bitter political and ideological conflict between land developers and residents. After his term, Zig joined the Law Offices of Leonard Ackerman, in East Hampton, where he remained Of Counsel. Zig led his family's successful investigation of the mysterious death in Miami Beach of his youngest brother, Michael Heatter, in 1982. Thereafter, he litigated a trust dispute on behalf of his family, securing a landmark ruling at the Illinois Supreme Court in 1986. These experiences forged his character and talents to the great benefit of the friends and family who valued his counsel in the years that followed. An uncommon scholar, Zig's insatiable literary appetite and his avid analysis of problems and situations provided his principal pleasures. He delighted in bestowing stimulating gifts upon his friends, and he was a generous contributor to charitable and educational organizations. He spent his last year in the company of Jackie Worth, of Sag Harbor, and died at peace, content with his life. Services: 12:30 PM, Friday, January 2, at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons, East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jewish Center of the Hamptons.

title: Modern Is Urged to Play Solomon in Paintings Dispute
description: In a personal appeal to the Museum of Modern Art, the family of a Jewish Viennese art dealer whose prized painting by Egon Schiele was taken from her by the Nazis before World War II has asked the museum to keep the painting in New York when its exhibition ''Egon Schiele: The Leopold Collection'' closes on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ESTHER SOMER
description: COHEN-Esther Somer. We have lost a woman of dignity, grace and compassion. Our dear mother passed away December 30. Pre-deceased by her beloved husband Leo and dear son Nick. Survived by her loving children Barbara and Robert, adored grandchildren Linda, Peter, Lisa and Tom and cherished greatgrandchildren Briana, Cory, Kyle and Nicholas.

title: Son of Robert Kennedy Dies In Colorado Skiing Accident
description: Michael L. Kennedy, the 39-year-old son of Robert F. Kennedy, died yesterday afternoon in a skiing accident in Aspen, Colo., officials said.

title: $319.5 Billion in Securities Offerings Sets a Record
description: Wall Street completed a record year for underwriting financial securities with a turbulent but robust fourth quarter. The securities industry raised $319.5 billion in American stock and bond offerings despite the qualms caused by the spreading financial crisis in Asia.

title: SENATE IMPERILS JUDICIAL SYSTEM, REHNQUIST SAYS
description: In an unusual rebuke, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today criticized the Senate for failing to move more quickly on judicial appointments, saying that the ''vacancies cannot remain at such high levels indefinitely without eroding the quality of justice.''

title: Cold? What Cold? Bucs Prepare for the Packers
description: Surrounded by reporters today, Warren Sapp was cordial enough until someone asked about the weather conditions the Buccaneers are likely to face on Sunday in Green Bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ANCONA, CAROLYN TILLES
description: d'ANCONA-Carolyn Tilles. On December 29, 1997. Widow of the late Benjamin d'Ancona. Her courage in the face of long term and severe disabilities was very special. Her intelligence and her musical and acting talents were considerable. She is survived by her brother, Bud Tilles, her niece and nephews, Wendy, Daniel, and Peter Tilles. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Arthritis Foundation, 122 East 42nd Street, New York, N.Y. 10168.

title: Currents; FURNISHINGS -- Paris Comes to 22d Street
description: What's beyond Bed and Bath and newer than Old Navy? For those shopping the Sixth Avenue strip from 17th to 23d Street, an unlikely block of design shops is gaining ground on 22d Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. The latest arrival, 145, is direct from Paris. One owner, Gerald Barnard, had a stall at the Marches aux Puces in Paris before opening here in November. He haunts his old hunting grounds to furnish the New York store. Recent inventory included a pair of French 1930's walnut bedside tables in the Cubist style of Pierre Chareau, at $1,800. The shop also has a green thumb. Mr. Barnard's partner, Gary Guerrette, runs a floral arrangement business that plans entire events, like a recent benefit at Sotheby's, or delivers flowers with one day's notice (minimum order, $75). The shop stocks unusual garden furniture, too. ''Very off-the-cuff, romantic, less rigid, more imaginative pieces,'' Mr. Barnard said. ''So I don't get too caught up in high-style French.'' Always a danger. At 145 West 22d Street; (212) 807-1149.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, JERRI
description: JARCHO-Jerri. Beloved daughter of Joyce and Irving, and Joe Handelsman. Dear sister of Gail Berman and Lauren Messinger. Dearest aunt of Danny, Ivan and Charles. Best friend to Pattie, Brigid and Marty. A bright light has been extinguished from our lives. Visiting hours are January 1, from 7 to 9 PM. Services at 12 Noon, January 2, 1998, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: House Proud; A Modernist Jewel, Rescued From Disgrace
description: WHEN Frederick and Cynthia Riebe and their two children pulled into an oak-lined driveway to check out a contender on a house-hunt here, they found a place hit with an ugly stick. Someone with vague architectural aspirations had tried to sandwich a watered-down likeness of a classical portico between horizontal lines more appropriate for a California ranch. The results were reminiscent of a trailer park on a bad-tire day.

title: A Promising Debut on Broadway
description: Times Square is in the midst of a spectacular rebound that has sent a flood of new business into the Broadway theaters. So when Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced a new initiative that would give the theater owners tens of millions of dollars in new development rights, it did seem that once again the rich were getting richer.

title: One Pianist, Three Sets And Two Distinct Styles
description: The pianist Larry Goldings played three sets at Smalls on Tuesday -- his fourth in a run of Tuesday nights there -- and the first two were open to different compositional directions, including experiments with free, unmoored rhythms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULTER, MICHAEL
description: COULTER - Michael. Michael passed away on December 27, 1997 after a brief illness. Michael was born March 19, 1943. He was involved in the arts for most of his life, assisting, nurturing and supporting artists like Jack Smith, Andres Serrano and Laurence Fishburne. Although originally from the Bronx, Michael spent most of his life on the Lower East Side. Michael's spirit will be greatly missed by all of his friends. A Memorial Service will be Friday 11AM, Jan 2, 1998, at the Marcus Jackson FH, 132 St, 8th Ave NYC.

title: Metro Business; Tops Appliance Says President Has Quit
description: Tops Appliance City of Edison, N.J., yesterday announced the resignation of its president, Philip M. Schmidt, and said his duties would be absorbed by senior management.

description: DAVIDMAN-Edna. On Dec. 31, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Larry. Beloved mother of Ellen Yuder and Gail (Allen) Goldberger. Grandmother of Robin (David) McFadden, Andrew Yuder, John (Julie) Yuder, Michael (Alexis) Goldberger, and Lynn Goldberger. Greatgrandmother of Jake and Derick McFadden. Services 10AM, Friday, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the symbolic status of Silicon Valley referred incorrectly to the origin of the term for the region. It first appeared in a headline with an article by Don C. Hoefler in Electronic News on Jan. 11, 1971; he did not coin it in 1972.

title: Currents; CD MUSEUM GUIDE -- A Sleek, Lively Word in Your Ear
description: There comes a time in every visit to the Getty Museum when, after checking out the views (''Down there -- isn't that O.J.'s house?'') and the merchandise (paperweights from leftover terrazzo, $4.95; T-shirt, $12.95, above), you're ready to look at art. The high-tech audio guide may surprise you. Gone are those clunky recorders that drag visitors from room to room. Key objects are identified by number. Enter it on the keypad, and the sleek CD player serves up lively discussion by artists (also in Spanish). FRED BERNSTEIN

title: 500 Attend Funeral of Man Killed by Police Officer
description: Grief vied with anger and private sorrow mingled with public outrage yesterday at the funeral of William J. Whitfield, the unarmed man who was shot to death by a New York police officer last Thursday.

title: To Usher In the New Laws, Quiet the Dog, Quit Smoking
description: The owners of dogs that bark in New York City will face tougher sanctions, female golfers in Connecticut will gain new privileges at their country clubs and smokers in New Jersey will pay higher tobacco taxes, as dozens of new laws take effect today in a mixed bag of new taxes, rights and prohibitions.

title: Tax Agency Hints At Inquiry on Leak On Scientologists
description: The Internal Revenue Service indicated yesterday that it would open an investigation into the disclosure of the confidential closing agreement that granted tax-exempt status to the Church of Scientology.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MIRAMAR MINING CORP., Vancouver, British Columbia, said it would cut ore production at its Con gold mine in Canada's Northwest Territories by 50 percent and lay off 130 employees because of lower prices for gold and high operating costs.

title: Indians in Mexico Go Home To Where Gunmen Killed 45
description: Carrying a cracked statue of the Virgin Mary that they had reassembled in the name of peace, about 1,000 people marched here today from a nearby refugee village to pay their respects to the 45 Tzotzil Indians gunned down in a massacre nine days ago.

title: Court Permits Building On Sensitive Lands
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday cleared the way for developers to build a shopping complex on 475 acres of environmentally sensitive land near the Atlantic City Expressway. Deciding the case on procedural grounds, the court said that a conservation group waited too long to challenge the project.

title: State, Not Religion, Must Lead Fight for Poor; Bowery Mission Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Shows Obesity Poses Less of a Risk Than Thought
description: The largest study ever conducted on the health risks of obesity has found that it increases the likelihood of premature death but not as much as many medical experts had suspected.

title: Arts Abroad; Maybe Spain's 1898 Defeat Was No Great Loss After All
description: Heading diligently into the centennial of the Spanish-American War, Spain is ready to feel less pain when remembering the Maine. A new spin on history says the loss of Cuba, Puerto Rico and the Philippines was not such a disaster after all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXBERG, STANLEY D.
description: WAXBERG-Stanley D. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Stanley D. Waxberg. To his family and loved ones, we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Sandra W. Meyer Dies at 60; Pioneer Marketing Executive
description: Sandra W. Meyer, a pioneering marketing executive who was part of the inspiration for the long-running Broadway drama ''The Sisters Rosensweig,'' died on Tuesday at New York University Hospital. She was 60 and the cause of death was breast cancer, her family said.

title: Fickle Yankl the Blacksmith Weds, but Is He Made of Iron?
description: At the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater, the vehicle creaks, but the ride packs enjoyment.

description: BANKS-Alan. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. Died Dec. 29, 1997. Funeral services will be held Friday, January 2, 1998, 1 PM at Park Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Dartmouth Wins Big One For Coach
description: How was the holiday? For the Dartmouth skaters, it was sublime. At the Sheraton/USAir tournament in Burlington, Vt., the Big Green won its most significant victory under its new coach, Bob Gaudet. This was a 4-1 decision over a tough Big East opponent, Providence, in the championship game at Vermont's Gutterson Fieldhouse.

title: Man Wanted by Swiss Is Ordered Jailed
description: A Federal magistrate ordered a Manhattan artist jailed yesterday pending a formal request for his extradition by the Government of Switzerland in connection with a financial fraud case in that country.

title: Israeli Annual Growth Was Slowest in the 90's
description: Israel's economy grew by an estimated 2.1 percent in 1997, the slowest annual rate this decade, and it shows no sign of picking up next year, the Central Bureau of Statistics said yesterday. The growth in output fell short of the 2.5 percent that the Finance Ministry had expected, but exceeded a 2 percent earlier estimate by the statistics bureau.

title: A Risk for Freedom and Baseball
description: Around 7:30 on the morning after Christmas, Orlando Hernandez, one of the best pitchers ever on the Cuban national baseball team, and seven companions got into a small sailboat with four oars. They loaded four cans of Spam, bread, sugar and drinking water onto the craft and guided it into the calm azure Caribbean water off the Cuban coast.

title: Currents; MICRODECOR -- Mouse Proud
description: It's just a hole in the wall, but it's home. ''It's taken him a long time to get his house just the way he likes it -- he's not unlike any of us,'' Gore Verbinski said of the mouse in the film he directed, ''Mouse Hunt,'' in theaters now. In it, Nathan Lane and Lee Evans try to renovate an inherited mansion, but it's a mouse living in the walls who's made the old house home. With the help of Linda DeScenna, the production designer, the mouse (one of 60 trained mice) sleeps in an old medicine tin, tucked under a cotton gauze comforter, with a strapless wristwatch for an alarm clock. The bedside table is a thumbtack box where he keeps his treasures: buttons and foil balls. There are postage stamps for art; the old master is a postcard of Hawaii. ''It's what he dreams about every night,'' Mr. Verbinski said. ''When he sits in his bed and looks out over his room, he can see all the objects he's gathered over his life. He's kind of a collector.''

title: Economic Scene; It's not easy to know when and how to act to protect the planet.
description: WHAT a difference a quarter-century can make.

title: Currents; FOLDING SCREENS -- Hand-Painted Wallpaper That Moves Around
description: ''I think they're so practical,'' said Maggie Wells, a New York painter who is designing, building and hand-painting folding screens. ''You can rearrange rooms, hide computers.'' An architect friend commissioned her first screen three years ago. She now has a portfolio of 20 designs, both modernistic-geometric and expressionistic-ornate. Usually, the screens are made of thin birch plywood on wooden frames, and light enough to move easily. Ms. Wells stencils and paints them with gouache, then uses matte varnish to make them washable. She sells her screens exclusively through her studio. Orders can be filled in six to eight weeks. She also accepts commissions. Prices are $950 (inset) to $1,500 (above); (212) 925-2286.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SANDRA W.
description: MEYER-Sandra W. We mourn the death of our beloved mother, sister, daughter and aunt. She will always be loved and remembered for the extraodinary person she was. The family will be receiving visitors at 271 Central Park West, apt 11W on January 5, 6 and 7 from 10AM to 2PM and from 4PM to 8PM. In lieu of flowers charitable contributions may be made to the Sandra W. Meyer Foundation, 150 East 77 St., apt 2E, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Bowl Games
description: Ratings by the New York Times computer. All times Eastern. By FRANK LITSKY

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an author's gift to a small library in Maine misidentified the publisher of The Library Journal, which monitors library budgets across the nation. It is Reed Elsevier Business Information, not the American Library Association.

title: Metro Business; On-Line Retailer Closes
description: On Manhattan's Upper West Side, virtual-reality shopping will be more virtual than real from now on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, FELENSTEIN, JOAN
description: MEYERS-FELENSTEIN-Joan, of Rockville Centre, NY, on Dec. 31. Widow of Milton Felenstein, loving wife of Rubin Meyers, devoted mother of Wendy Braunstein, Marsha Fields - Shapiro, and Robert Felenstein. Adoring grandmother of Joshua, Michael, Timothy, Matthew, and Melisa. Proud great-grandmother. Sister of Stanley Ruby. Funeral Friday January 2, 11:30AM, Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre.

description: Manhattan

title: Jurors at Unabom Trial Will Hear About All 16 Bombings, Two Sides Agree
description: Jurors at the trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski will be told not just about the four bombings with which the defendant is charged here but about all 16 bombings that prosecutors attribute to the Unabomber.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPPELMAN, MORRIS
description: KOPPELMAN-Morris Today on your birthday, we wish you love and miss you as always. Nina

title: Michigan Approaches the Summit, and Hopes to Hang On
description: Week by week they climbed, in a season that the University of Michigan Wolverines began with a metaphor and a commitment. As summer ended, they struggled to restore credibility and end a frustrating succession of four four-loss seasons. Their coach, Lloyd Carr, inspired by a book he had read, compared the task his players faced to an expedition that climbed Mount Everest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFT, NORMA PIKE
description: TAFT-Norma Pike. Age 75, died Dec 31, 1997 after a long illness, borne with her customary dignity, grace and good humor. Devoted wife for 54 years of Nathaniel B. Taft, national health care lawyer, beloved mother of Charles E. and Stephen P., and adored grandmother of Benjamin, Joshua, and Matthew, loving sister of Bertram N. Pike, retired CFO of The John Hancock Mutual Life Co. Awardwinning Westchester County television host for 17 yrs, receiving praise from Vice President Gore, Ex-Vice President Quayle, Senator Moynihan, Senator D'Amato, Secretary of Defense Cohen, ExGovernor Cuomo, Bob Dole, Elizabeth Dole, Lloyd Bentsen, Lamar Alexander, and two dozen other national and Westchester notables. Past President of The Jewish Community Center PTA, past Vice President White Plains Beautification Foundation, Member of President's Council and White Plains Auxillary of White Plains Hospital Center, member of The Thames Society of Connecticut College, Womens Club of White Plains, College Club of White Plains, YWCA of Central Westchester, Congregation Kol Ami of White Plains, and its Sisterhood, columnist for The Harvard Law Record, author of one act musical satire and Shakespearean scholar, lecturer and actress. She was the winner of the 1937 Essay Contest of The New York Times, on the Sesquicentennial of the Adaption of The U.S. Constitution. She enriched the myriad of lives she touched. Funeral 10 A.M. Jan 2nd at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY. Instead of flowers, please contribute in her memory to either Congregation Kol Ami, or The White Plains Hospital Center.

description: I always pass on good advice,'' Oscar Wilde wrote a century ago in ''An Ideal Husband.'' ''It is the only thing to do with it. It is never any use to oneself.''

description: RICHARDSON-Adele. On December 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Alexander D. Richardson. Loving mother of Robert. Cherished grandmother of Robert and James. Rest, dear Spirit. description: SCHEINMAN-Alan. Happy Birthday. We will always miss your love, special smile, and sense of humor. In our hearts forever. Love, Roni, Greg, Sandy, and Jarret.

title: Another Year Of the Bull; Dow Up 22%
description: When the closing bell sounded yesterday afternoon, it signaled the end of a spectacular year on Wall Street -- the first time the Dow Jones industrial average had ever registered three consecutive superb years in its 100-year history.

title: Duramed Shares Surge for 2d Day
description: Shares of Duramed Pharmaceuticals Inc. soared 26 percent yesterday, rising for the second consecutive day after the Food and Drug Administration approved its Estradiol hormone-replacement drug.

title: Judiciary Report: Congress Is Prodded
description: Following are excerpts from the 1997 Year-end Report on the Federal Judiciary by William H. Rehnquist, Chief Justice of the United States:

title: Currents; BARWARE -- Crystal Strung With Threads of Color
description: Salviati, Venice's oldest operating glassworks, has introduced Stringa, crystal barware by Johanna Grawunder. Stringa is Memphis gone minimal: colorful strings of glass thread the high-modern shapes. A boxed pair is $50. Information: Salviati, 41 Madison Avenue (26th Street); (212) 725-4361.

title: Eight Injured as Helicopter Hits Building
description: As the Liberty tours helicopter made its final approach over the icy waters of the Hudson at twilight yesterday, Murray Williamson, a tourist from New Zealand, thought to himself that the pilot was coming in too fast. Seconds later, the helicopter's rotor shredded the side of the small building Mr. Williamson was standing in, eight people received minor injuries, and another black mark had been inflicted on the city's embattled helicopter industry.

title: Facing Term 2 With 'Godfather,' Part One
description: On the eve of his second, and by law his last, term as Mayor of New York City, Rudolph W. Giuliani sauntered into a Times Square office tower last night with hundreds of his closest advisers, friends and fund-raisers and watched not only the traditional midnight ball drop, but also what the Mayor called an educational film: Francis Ford Coppola's 1972 mob epic, ''The Godfather.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, OLIVE
description: RODGERS-Olive. 85, of Pembroke Pines, FL, formerly London, died December 30, 1997. Beloved mother of Barbara Chernow, Derek Rodgers, Yvonne Bossom. Beloved sister of Marjorie Sherman of London. Survived by five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral private.

title: Airlines Criticized for Plans to Flag Suspicious Travelers
description: On New Year's Day, airlines around the country will begin using a computerized screening process to determine which passengers should have their baggage inspected for explosives and whether the passengers who are singled out actually checked their bags and boarded a plane.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SHARES OF CMC PLUNGE 45% ON LOSS OF MICRON BUSINESS
description: The stock of CMC Industries, a contract manufacturer, plunged more than 45 percent yesterday after the company said it was losing its biggest customer, Micron Electronics Inc. CMC, based in Santa Clara, Calif., provides contract manufacturing services to original equipment manufacturers in the telecommunications, computer and electronics industries. CMC assembled, tested and shipped personal computers for Micron, a PC manufacturer two-thirds owned by the chip maker Micron Technology Inc. Micron attributed its decision to end the manufacturing relationship to changes in the PC marketplace. Micron's business accounted for 40 percent of CMC's fiscal first-quarter revenue. Shares of CMC dived $4.9375, to $5.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, JEAN L.
description: COOK-Jean L. The Trustees of The Browning School and the entire Browning community mourn the passing of Jean L. Cook, wife of Charles Cook, Headmaster Emeritus whose 60-year affiliation with Browning included 36 years of distinguished service as Headmaster. She was a strong, caring and important part of the Browning community for many years. We extend our deepest condolences to the family. Allan L. Gropper, Chairman Stephen Clement, III, Headmaster

title: State, Not Religion, Must Lead Fight for Poor; Independent Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Is Fueling Cities' Strong Growth, Data Show
description: The Census Bureau today offered fresh evidence of the impact of immigration on the country's population in this decade, reporting that several major metropolitan areas -- notably New York, Los Angeles and Chicago -- grew strongly even as many longer-term residents left for other parts of the country.

title: Close to Home; The Genes for a Big Renovation Job
description: MY father will turn 75 this year, and he takes great pride in still being able to bend briskly and touch his toes. It is impressive, especially considering that it has been some decades since he was able to look down and actually see them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACKENSON, LEON
description: NACKENSON-Leon. We mourn the passing of Leon Nackenson on Dec. 24, 1997. A devoted husband to the late Eva, father of Caryl and Gary, grandfather of Julie, Edgar and Henry. A company executive with Louis Dreyfus for thirty-five years, Leon was also an avid bridge player, opera buff, tennis enthusiast and world traveler. He left an indelible mark on those he came in contact with; his goodness and sincerity were always apparent. He leaves us with a lifetime of wonderful memories.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GALT, MICHAEL TRISTAN
description: GALT-Michael Tristan. January 2, 1995. My dearest Michael, I love you today and always. Stephanie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, ALAN
description: BANKS-Alan. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. Died December 29, 1997. He is survived by his beloved brothers and sisters-in-law Morris and Janet Dittman, Jack and Anita Dittman and his loving nieces Arlene Dittman and Elaine Mack. Funeral services will be held Friday, January 2, 1998, 1 PM, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Some Lush Vineyards, but No Yield
description: Back in 1993, it looked like a perfect opportunity: a marriage between Napa Valley vintners and an ancient wine-making industry that had recently been liberated from Communism and the former Soviet Union.

title: Spate of Killings Puts Cloud Over Talks on Ulster Peace
description: Tension over the future of the fragile peace talks in Northern Ireland rose today after a Catholic man was shot dead and five others were wounded in a pub in Belfast during New Year's Eve festivities by masked Protestant paramilitaries.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: THE AGENDA ; A Replay Of Themes That Won An Election
description: Standing coatless at a turning point in his mayoralty yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani chose to take a customary path into his second term, reiterating the very issues that have proven so useful in propelling him to national prominence over the last four years.

title: U.S. Used Special Authority to Admit Cuban Ballplayers
description: The authority that Attorney General Janet Reno invoked on Wednesday to clear three Cubans, including two star baseball players, into the United States is rarely used and was the subject of lengthy debate within the Administration this week.

title: Smokers Stock Up To Beat Tax Rise
description: Smokers from around the state went on a buying spree on New Year's Eve, stocking up on tobacco products in anticipation of yesterday's 40-cent increase in the state cigarette tax.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: INAUGURAL NOTEBOOK ; Saving Protests for Police
description: Protesters, usually an integral part of New York's political landscape, were only a minor presence at yesterday's inauguration. Although he could have led a couple of hundred supporters within a block of City Hall, the Rev. Al Sharpton held a rally in front of Police Headquarters, out of sight of Mr. Giuliani and the inauguration's spectators.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs: Round 2
description: SATURDAY 12:30 P.M.

description: Judie Bamber and Kurt Kauper

title: Environmental Tasks in 1998
description: President Clinton paid little attention to environmental issues when he first came to office, moved to higher ground as time went on and now has a fairly rosy reputation among conservationists. Profiting from shrewd political advice, he successfully beat back Republican assaults on the country's basic environmental laws and acted decisively to protect Yellowstone National Park, California's redwoods and Utah's wilderness. Although his overriding task in 1998 is to win Senate consent to the treaty on global warming, he and the agencies under his command will have plenty of other chances to build on his earlier record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, ELSIE BEATRICE
description: COLEMAN-Elsie Beatrice. Aged 101. Died Dec. 31, 1997, at Victoria Home in Ossining, NY. Beloved member of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York. Chapter member of King Edward VII. Memorial service at 11 AM, Saturday, St. Paul's on the Hill Church, Ganung Drive, Ossining. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Victoria Home.

title: Officer Is Injured When Car Is Hit
description: A police sergeant driving to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's inauguration yesterday morning was critically injured when a drunken driver struck his car broadside in the East Village in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Needlework As Teacher And Preacher
description: Samplers, those charming, antique embroidered panels sporting carefully stitched alphabets and biblical verses, appear innocent. Actually, they represent a more complex reality: limited educational opportunities for young girls, and then only for the well to do. And their messages carry a strong moral undertone: be obedient, long-suffering and loyal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, JERRI
description: JARCHO-Jerri. Beloved daughter of Joyce and Irving, and Joe Handelsman. Dear sister of Gail Berman and Lauren Messinger. Dearest aunt of Danny, Ivan and Charles. Best friend to Pattie, Brigid and Marty. A bright light has been extinguished from our lives. Visiting hours are January 1, from 7 to 9 PM. Services at 12 Noon, January 2, 1998, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. All donations can be made to Cancer Care.

title: Michigan Grasps Victory, and Claim to No. 1
description: The University of Michigan stood one play from the possibility of securing its first national football championship in 49 years. Beneath the darkening skies here, and everywhere Wolverines live, a perfect season was reduced to an excruciating finish: the sight of Washington State's Ryan Leaf, the most productive passer in the history of the Pacific-10 Conference, maneuvering for one last shot at the end zone.
