description: KAHNG-Dr. Anthony. On December 30, 1997. Beloved father of Kathy and Shaz. Dear husband of Dr. Young-Hee Lowe. Funeral services private.

title: Busby Redeems Himself As the Seminoles Romp
description: This time last year, Thad Busby led then top-ranked Florida State into the Nokia Sugar Bowl for what was supposed to be a national championship coronation. Three poor quarters later, to a chorus of boos, he was yanked from a 52-20 loss to Florida, the eventual national champion and the Seminoles' hated in-state rival.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Zeke Berman

title: PRO FOOTBALL; Resurrection Without Rice
description: It would seem downright blasphemous for San Francisco 49er receiver J. J. Stokes to say that it is better for him that Jerry Rice is out for the rest of the season. But it might not be wrong. Not that Stokes would say that, either.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: INAUGURAL NOTEBOOK ; She Also Does Frostbite
description: Mayor Giuliani had just started his inaugural address when the brittle cold took its first casualty on the dais. The victim was not one of the dozens of political dignitaries or mayoral appointees, but Karl Vetter, 9 years old, the winner of a citywide essay contest who, only 13 hours earlier, had helped drop the ball above Times Square to usher in the New Year.

title: Optimism Bolsters Israeli Stocks
description: Share prices on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange closed higher today, on optimism that the Government would pass its 1998 budget and that there would be a cut in interest rates as early as February.

title: Bond Prices Climb in Australia
description: Australian bonds rose in the first trading session of 1998, amid optimism that cooling Asian economies will take the heat off domestic growth, and keep any risk of accelerating inflation at bay.

title: Cabdriver, 35, Is Killed While Picking Up Fare
description: A 35-year-old cabdriver was shot to death early yesterday while picking up a fare in central Newark, the police said. It was the first homicide in Newark in 1998, after a year in which the homicide rate fell by more than 40 percent.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: INAUGURAL NOTEBOOK ; Quiet Family Time, This Time
description: Donna Hanover, who in 1997 was rarely seen in public with her husband, Mayor Giuliani, made a striking reappearance at his inaugural.

title: Pedestrian Traffic Light May Help Ease Gridlock; Discourage Use of Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALL BANKS POSE POSSIBLE SETBACK IN KOREA BAILOUT
description: South Korea has cleared a crucial hurdle in its effort to stabilize its battered economy, paying off or extending a large portion of debt it owes foreign banks. But the Korean Government was forced to repay some of the debt because smaller lenders have been unwilling to extend their loans.

title: Energy for a Power Source; The Keys to Electricity: Cost and Cleanliness
description: No matter what effect they have on the coal industry, the Kyoto accords on global climate change will probably not revive the nuclear power industry. Even some reactor makers agree with the energy experts on this one.

title: '97 Record At Box Office But Studio Costs Soar
description: It was a record year at the box office for Hollywood, but the news was not quite as rosy as it seems.

title: Residential Real Estate ; Demand for Town Houses Sends People Far Afield
description: As in other segments of Manhattan's strong residential market, demand for town houses has increased, pushing prices up and an already limited supply down. That in turn is nudging some prospective buyers out of traditional strongholds like the Upper East Side into other parts of the city, including downtown.

title: Plans Are Announced For Composting Plant
description: Construction is to begin this summer on a composting plant capable of recycling tons of organic waste into topsoil each day.

title: Richard Elman, Novelist, Poet And Teacher, Is Dead at 63
description: Richard Elman, a novelist, poet and critic who taught for many years at the Bennington College Summer Writing Workshops in Vermont, died on Wednesday at Stony Brook University Hospital on Long Island. A resident of Stony Brook, he was 63.

title: More makers of consumer goods are delivering samples of their products right to the front door.
description: CONSUMERS may be wondering about the boxes of dog food and packets of flavored tablets for coffee that have been showing up in their mailboxes and newspaper bags lately.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SANDRA W.
description: MEYER-Sandra W. The Board of Directors, musicians and staff of the Orchestra of St. Luke's note with great sadness the passing of our longtime Board Member and friend, Sandra W. Meyer. A highly successful businesswoman and committed supporter of our city's cultural life, she was involved, over the course of her remarkable career, with many of New York's leading organizations. We are especially appreciative for her dedication to the Orchestra of St. Luke's. During her many years of service as a Board Member she worked diligently as a member of the Development and Planning Committees. Her intelligence, creativity and constant concern will be treasured by all of us who had the privilege of being associated with her. Indeed, it is a special honor to be able to consider her a close colleague and dear friend. For the remarkable person that she was, and for the extraordinary contribution that she made, the Orchestra of St. Luke's will be forever grateful. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. M. Bernard Aidinoff, Chairman Marianne Lockwood, President

title: Hours After Ball Was Dropped, Times Sq. Bounces Back
description: On the morning after Times Square held a New Year's Eve party for 500,000 revelers, the neighborhood seemed subdued, but hardly hung over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLMAN, SARA
description: PEARLMAN-Sara. Loving wife of the late Isaac, beloved mother of Judie and Howard Wexler, and Sandee and Stephen London. Adored grandmother of Stacey and Michele, Robyn, Matthew. Donations to The Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street, NYC, 10022, Attn: Development Office. Services on Friday, 12 noon, from Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 11403 Queens Boulevard (76 Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: B. G. Kreisberg, 72, President Of Harkness Dance Foundation
description: Barrett G. Kreisberg, president of the Harkness Foundation for Dance and chairman of the New York State Board of Real Property Services, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Fizz and Punch in Russian and French Favorites
description: Most years, a classical music fan in New York City who wants to avoid hearing either Strauss waltzes or Viennese operetta on New Year's Eve has to do some careful planning. But it seems almost as if several of the city's cultural institutions agreed to give listeners a welcome reprieve at the end of 1997. Concertgoers could choose between the five Beethoven Piano Concertos at the 92d Street Y and Bach's six ''Brandenburg'' Concertos at Bargemusic. At the Metropolitan Opera, Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' displaced ''Die Fledermaus,'' and at the New York Philharmonic, which usually offers a Straussfest on New Year's Eve, Valery Gergiyev conducted a program of Russian and French music.

title: Government to Ask for Donations of Gold Jewelry : Self-Help Glitters in Thailand
description: BANGKOK  Faced with the cold reality that foreign investors will not return anytime soon, the Thai government will ask Thais next week to hand in their gold jewelry to help bail out their nation, according to the country's finance minister.

title: For Clinton Health Care Planner, a New Drubbing
description: For more than two years, Ira C. Magaziner had managed to keep his head down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFF, SUZANNE BOOTH
description: DORFF-Suzanne Booth. Age 50, Fargo Lane, Irvington, New York, died December 31, 1997 after a long illness. She lived in Irvington since 1978 with her family and was very active in community and school affairs and in life itself. She most recently participated in the family construction business. She was also a certified yoga instructor in Irvington. Those wishing to pay their respects are invited at 10AM to 12:30 PM with a memorial service 12:30 P.M. on Saturday, January 3, 1998 at the EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY. She is survived by her loving husband, John, and children, Christopher, Julia and Zachary, sisters Diane Booth and Valerie McGrory and brothers Michael, Douglas and Stephen. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society of Westchester, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, New York.

title: The Knicks' Big Engine Who Thinks He Can
description: Patrick Ewing, his right arm encased in an elbow-to-fingers cast, sat alone at a table, with cameras and recorders whirring away. He had no guarantees this time, no bold predictions like his annual one of winning the championship that has eluded him for 12 years.

title: Financial Services Consolidate, but Regulation Is Still Fragmented
description: In April, Bankers Trust, the nation's seventh-largest bank, agreed to buy Alex. Brown & Sons, a securities firm. That deal initiated a buying spree on Wall Street, culminating in the announcement in September that Travelers Group was buying Salomon Brothers Inc., adding more clout in bond trading and investment banking to an already flourishing combination of brokerage and insurance businesses.

title: Honors
description: * Lee Garfinkel, chairman and chief creative officer at Lowe & Partners/ SMS, New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was selected as honorary chairman of the 1998 International Andy Awards sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York.

title: Killings in Ulster Jar Planned Peace Talks
description: Tensions over the future of the fragile peace talks in Northern Ireland grew yesterday after Protestant paramilitaries killed a Catholic man and wounded five others in a pub on New Year's Eve. It was the third sectarian killing in the province in a week.

title: Metropolis: Glimpses Of the First 100 Years
description: Happy birthday to us. New York, New York, is a century old as of yesterday. On New Year's Day 1898, after decades of negotiating, infighting and deal making, as well as some fairly close votes in both general elections and the State Assembly, ''The Greater New York City,'' as it was initially called, came into being.

title: Israeli Woman Critically Hurt by Gunfire in West Bank
description: An Israeli woman was critically wounded in the West Bank early today when a car she was riding in was raked with gunfire on a road winding between Palestinian villages.

title: Cruel Winter Warning to Homeless As New Year Brings Freezing Wind
description: The sky told a lie yesterday. It was so blue and clear, so seemingly benign that surely the sun was somewhere above the city casting out some warmth. Surely this first taste of winter was just a cruel illusion.

title: Southern to Buy Generator
description: The Southern Company has agreed to acquire the coal-fired State Line Generating Station in Hammond, Ind., from Commonwealth Edison for $68 million. Commonwealth Edison is a unit of the Chicago-based Unicom Corporation. Southern, based in Atlanta, is an electric utility holding company with 1996 revenue of $10.32 billion. Under a 15-year power purchase agreement, Southern will supply power to Commonwealth Edison. Southern will spend $65 million to help the 490-megawatt plant maintain safety.

description: DAVIDMAN-Edna. On Dec. 31, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Larry. Beloved mother of Ellen Yuder and Gail (Allen) Goldberger. Grandmother of Robin (David) McFadden, Andrew Yuder, John (Julie) Yuder, Michael (Alexis) Goldberger, and Lynn Goldberger. Greatgrandmother of Jake and Derick McFadden. Services 10AM, Friday, Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Israeli Foreign Minister Says He'll Quit in Budget Dispute
description: Foreign Minister David Levy declared today that he was quitting the Government in a dispute over the 1998 budget, creating yet another crisis for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and forcing him to delay the crucial budget vote until Monday.

title: Rebel Attack On Villagers In Burundi Kills 160
description: Rebels attacked a village and a military camp on the outskirts of the Burundian capital early this morning, killing at least 150 civilians and 10 soldiers in what officials described as the biggest rebel assault in that country in recent years, a senior military commander said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PAUL FRANCIS
description: SMITH-Paul Francis. Of Massapequa, NY, on Dec. 31, 1997. Loving son of Gerard Joseph and Angela Marilyn Smith. Beloved brother of Maura Ann Baker, Gerard J. Smith, Jr., Elizabeth Lee Sullivan, and David W. Smith. Devoted Uncle to many nieces and nephews. Paul was a lifelong fan of the New York football Giants. Reposing at Massapequa FH Inc., 1050 Park Boulevard (at Clark), Massapequa Park, Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass on Monday 9:30 A.M., St. Martin of Tours RC Church, Amityville, NY. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Hatch Defends Senate Action On Judgeships
description: Responding to the unusually pointed complaint of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist about the Senate's slow pace in confirming Federal judges, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee today defended the Senate's performance and said the courts themselves were partly to blame for their heavy caseloads.

title: Reebok Adds Another Agency
description: Reebok International has further expanded its agency roster by naming Berlin Cameron & Partners in New York to handle advertising for its running category, which includes shoes, apparel and equipment. The assignment, with billings estimated to be as much as $30 million, was most recently inactive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUVEN, ANNE
description: STRUVEN-Anne. On December 30, 1997. A Founder and former President of Trademark Service Corporation. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Loving and cherished mother of Lynn and Justin Cogut. Dearest grandmother of Craig and Deborah Cogut, Stephen and Paula Cogut and great-grandmother to five great-grandsons. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MARIE
description: O'CONNOR-Marie. On December 31, 1997. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Elyse, Leigh and David. Funeral private.

title: More Kurds Reach Italy; Northern Europe Upset
description: As a second ship packed with hundreds of Kurdish refugees in less than a week was intercepted off the Italian coast today, Italy found itself caught in a crossfire between its northern European neighbors and Turkey over its open door policies toward such immigrants.

title: Look Who's Not Talking Now: The Nets
description: Something was wrong with this picture. Jayson Williams not trying to stir things up on the eve of a game with the Knicks? Tonight, the Nets' human quote machine said his team did not need that anymore. The team's play, Williams said, speaks for itself.

title: Police Install Cameras in Washington Sq. Park
description: The New York City Police Department, expanding on a crime-fighting experiment that civil libertarians call Orwellian but law enforcement officials call justified, has installed two video surveillance cameras in Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village.

title: Sports of The Times; For One Day, Rose Bowl Still Rules
description: YOU can't win the game and lose the championship. This is the golden rule in the goofy, convoluted world of college football.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Big Fun in Snow Upon Tiny Skis
description: ''Yo, whatsamatta, you forget your skis?'' shouted the wise guy from the chairlift. Funny how my skiboards -- tiny skis only barely longer than my boots -- seemed to turn every skier into Henny Youngman. I'd heard this particular one-liner so many times since I bought my Kneissl Bigfoots five years ago, I just continued to snake my way down the side of the Tecumseh trail of Shawnee Mountain in Pennsylvania, without even bothering to turn around.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Erzsebet Baerveldt

title: Energy for a Power Source; Coal May Become A Better Choice
description: Amid the rolling hills of northeastern Wyoming, a towering five-story plant is using heat and pressure to turn the low-grade coal that abounds here in the 9,700-square-mile Powder River Basin into high-quality fuel -- and, in the process, make that coal less a hazard to the environment.

title: Moscow Journal; Ruble Is Streamlined, Trimmed Down by 3 Zeros
description: This is not the way Lena Usikova planned to usher in the new year. Clutching a fistful of dollars she had rescued from a hiding place in her three-room apartment, the bleary-eyed schoolteacher pawed the fresh snow as she waited for her grocery store to open for business.

title: For Vegetable Lovers
description: If you've made a resolution to eat healthier this year, now's the time to start. But why consider it penance? These restaurants offer vegetarian dishes that are full of flavor and don't make you feel as if you're munching a pasture. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTINI, PARVIN
description: VALENTINI-Parvin. On January 1, 1998. She is survived by her son and daughter, Edward and Jennifer, her mother, and her seven brothers and sisters. Family will receive friends today 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street.

title: Charter Schools Won't Save Education
description: The charter school movement has swept the country, offering what many say is a simple, low-cost answer to the educational crisis. If bureaucracy and rigidity are to blame for failing schools, then why not contract groups of educators and businesses to run their own schools, using public money?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAYTEN, STEPHANIE HOFFMAN
description: CAYTEN-Stephanie Hoffman, 41, of Exeter, N.H., on December 30, 1997. Beloved wife of Thomas, mother of Gareth Rhys (3) and Cordelia (5). Attorney, Chairman of the Board of Nurture and Nature Childcare Center and Board Member of Riverwoods, died in her sleep and is in heaven.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Cars of the Year: Oft Forgotten
description: NOW think hard: What do the 1971 Chevrolet Vega, the 1973 Citroen SM, the 1983 A.M.C. Renault Alliance and the 1998 Corvette have in common?

title: Wilson and Battelle Gain Berths on the U.S. Team
description: The United States ski team showed off its depth in the freestyle moguls today, the one Alpine event Americans have dominated since its inception as an Olympic sport in 1992.

title: Guess Who Came to Dinner
description: Before he began teaching art history at Hanover College, a small liberal arts institution in southern Indiana, John Franklin Martin had heard that it owned several ''interesting'' paintings, which hung on the walls of a dormitory dining room. When he joined the faculty in 1995, he realized that they were two of the most important early paintings by the Pre-Raphaelite artist Edward Burne-Jones, which art historians had thought were lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMAN, RICHARD
description: ELMAN-Richard. Beloved husband of Alice, loving father of Margaret and Lila, brother of Leonard. Treasured friend. Services Friday, January 2 at 1 P.M. at Temple Isaiah, Stonybrook Road, Stonybrook, New York.

title: Hurdles Ahead for South Korea
description: Two events this week may help South Korea climb out of its financial hole. Large private banks in the United States, Europe and Japan agreed to let Korean banks and business firms postpone repayment of their overseas loans. These banks might even agree to extend new loans. If the agreement holds, it will ease South Korea's repayment burden, thereby eliminating an immediate threat of default.

title: Miscellany
description: * Ingalls, Boston, and the Media Edge, New York, a media services agency owned by Young & Rubicam Inc., formed a strategic broadcast media buying alliance and agreed to cooperate on business development.

title: Cubans Could Benefit By Staying in Bahamas
description: The road to the major leagues for the latest pair of Cuban defectors may go through the Bahamas and none of the Latin countries their predecessors have used.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIST, HARRY
description: GEIST-Harry. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of its cherished member. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, daughters and the entire family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus David Werber, President

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: The Mayor's Second Term
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's compact inaugural address started his second term on an optimistic note yesterday. Understandably, it contained a good bit of self-congratulation, and that is all right. He has had a good run. But both Mr. Giuliani and the city must look forward. As outlined, the Mayor's new agenda for consolidating New York's gains had strong positive points and some troubling aspects. As a political text, it also provided hints about how he intends to package himself as a candidate for statewide or national office.

title: 'Let's See if We Can Make the Changes Last': Excerpts From Mayor's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from the inaugural address yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Dozens of Fur Coats Given to the Homeless
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals has donated dozens of fur coats to the homeless.

title: Comfort vs. Style in Town Clash on Porches
description: All Deborah Thompson really has is time, and a place to spend it.

title: Must Sexuality Be a Radical Subject?
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Years After Mexican Uprising, Indians' Celebration Is Muted
description: At midnight four years ago to the day, bands of masked guerrillas, some armed, others carrying only sticks, streamed from the mountains and jungles of southern Mexico.

title: When AIDS Steals a Parent; Group Offers Outlet for Grieving Students at a Bronx School
description: Marco Barreto has a certain image that he likes to present to the world. A 17-year-old senior at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx, he seems to have his hand in everything from sports and drama to student clubs. He is the president of the school's chapter of the National Honor Society, and talks about having a career in medicine one day.

title: OUTDOORS; Flying Squirrels Double As Nocturnal U.F.O.'s
description: Aliens live among us. They have big black eyes, speak in a strange, high-pitched tongue and glide through the air like little U.F.O.'s. There is evidence that they consume massive quantities of nuts. Lots of them are out there. If you look up, you might see one, but generally they stay in a part of the world that many of us shun. And they come out mostly at night.

title: Favorite Game for Kennedys Took Deadly Turn on Slopes
description: His friends and relatives knew him as a fearless and expert skier. But when Michael L. Kennedy, the 39-year-old son of Robert F. Kennedy, died in a skiing accident here on Wednesday, he was pressing conventional limits by playing a game that Kennedys have engaged in for generations, football on skis.

title: Taylor's Record Runs Lift Florida
description: It was the final game of a distinguished career for Florida's Fred Taylor, whose record-setting performance today against Penn State would be one he won't forget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFT, NORMA PIKE
description: TAFT-Norma Pike. Congregation Kol Ami of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member, and conveys sincere condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark Hershey, President

title: Fummmble! No Word On the Final Second
description: I spent 3 hours and 18 minutes yesterday worrying about Keith Jackson.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: THE POLICE ; An Old Debate: Hire More Police, or Manage the Current Force Better?
description: In proposing that New York City increase the size of its Police Department to an unprecedented level, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani reawakened a longstanding debate over whether the city should hire more police officers to fortify public safety -- or whether it could achieve the same gains by better managing the sprawling force of more than 38,000 that it already has.

title: Entering From the Wings: Drama's Daring Upstarts
description: What kind of vitamins are they feeding the prolific gang at that tiny entertainment powerhouse, the Drama Dept.?

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Franz Ackermann

description: MEYERS-FELENSTEIN-Joan, of Rockville Centre, NY, on Dec. 31. Widow of Milton Felenstein, loving wife of Rubin Meyers, devoted mother of Wendy Braunstein, Marsha Fields - Shapiro, and Robert Felenstein. Adoring grandmother of Joshua, Michael, Timothy, Matthew, and Melisa. Proud great-grandmother. Sister of Stanley Ruby. Funeral Friday January 2, 11:30AM, Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARLICK, HAROLD
description: GARLICK-Harold. Died peacefully Tuesday, December 30, 1997 at his home in Boca Raton, FL. A long-time resident of New York, Harold and his wife moved to Florida in 1993 where he established his permanent residence in Boca Raton, FL. He was formerly the President of Garlick Funeral Homes, also on the Board of the Jewish Funeral Directors of America, a Kentucky Colonel. He was a member of the Knights of Pythias, Veritus Lodge and other Pythian lodges. He is survived by his dearly beloved wife Eileen, his nephews Saul, Jonathan and David Garlick, and his great nieces and nephews. Services will be held Sunday, January 4th at 12PM at Garlick's, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. Contributions are to be made to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGLER, MURIEL
description: SIEGLER-Muriel. In Lake Worth, FL. Beloved wife of the late Henry Siegler. Loving mother of Richard and Brenda. Adoring grandmother of Lauren and Eric Muhlheim. Great-grandmother of Henry Muhlheim. Funeral services Sunday, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon. NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to Pediatric Cancer Foundation, 405 Tarrytown Road, Suite 572, White Plains, NY 10607.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, IDA
description: LEFKOWITZ-Ida. Devoted wife of the late Morris, beloved mother of Blanche and Jerry. Proud grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Yikes! The Party's Over but There's Still Time to Unwind
description: Enough cheer. Enough extended family, frenzied shopping, high-fat parties, confetti and champagne. The holidays are officially over, and there is one lazy weekend left for rest and recuperation. Those who choose to convalesce by renting a video or two may want to consider these movies, released in recent months.

title: Rangers Seek Answers For a Lack of Scoring
description: It may smack of rationalization, considering the Rangers have the National Hockey League's heftiest payroll, but as they headed for a game at Tampa Bay after the club scored a late goal Sunday to beat the Boston Bruins, 4-3, several Rangers talked of the league's newfound parity.

title: Modernizing Britain, the Tony Blair Way
description: After his triumphant success in rebranding the British Labor Party as ''New Labor'' and leading his party to a resounding victory last spring, Prime Minister Tony Blair is now heavily engaged in efforts to ''rebrand'' Britain itself. He wants Britain to reflect his own self-image as a great modernizer.

title: 'Mainstreaming' Disabled Students Has a Price; A Case in Vermont
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Oppenheimer to Expand
description: Oppenheimer & Company has signed a 16-year, $71 million lease to expand its offices by 50 percent at the World Trade Center, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTEL, JACQUES
description: ARTEL-Jacques. Born January 18, 1914 in Rostov-on-Don, Russia. Died December 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Janet Ann Bissell Artel. Devoted father of Catherine Lee Pietrogallo, Marie Christine Wallace and Alexis Artel. Also survived by five grandchildren and five nieces and nephews. He fled Russia with his mother and brother to France where he served in the French Army during W.W. II. In 1946, he came to the United States, a country which he loved very much. Friend to many people, cared for all, especially loved children. He died peacefully after a full and interesting life. Memorial service will be held at the First Reformed Church, Hastingson-Hudson, New York at 11 A.M., on January 17th, 1998. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the First Reformed Church or to the Tolstoy Foundation of Valley Cottage, New York.

title: Legislators to Weigh Curbs on Casino Cheaters
description: Connecticut is facing a relatively new problem people who try to cheat casinos -- and state legislators will consider a number of new proposals this year in an effort to combat it.

title: Traditions Collide in a Chelsea Parish
description: In the 1940's, a priest at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in Chelsea won fame with his crusade against mob control of the city's waterfront. In the 1980's, another Xavier priest risked formal censure by criticizing the Archdiocese's treatment of gay Catholics.

title: Year of Tiger, Japanese Days of Calm
description: New Year's is Japan's most glorious season, a time of cold, brilliant air, festive visits to shrines and much lying around the house doing nothing. When I lived in Tokyo for three years in the early 1990's, I always adored it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISBERG, BARRETT G.
description: KREISBERG-Barrett G. The Trustees of The Harkness Foundation for Dance mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague Barry Kreisberg. Barry served the Foundation with distinction and dedication for twentyfive years. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving wife Luisa who has been steadfast in her support of his Foundation activities, his son Joel, daughters-in-law and his cherished grandchildren. Theodore S. Bartwink Etta Brandman William A. Perlmuth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINCLAIR, ALEXANDER J. HUSBAND OF FLORENCE (NEE MURPHY)
description: SINCLAIR-Alexander J. Husband of Florence (nee Murphy), loving father of Colin, Craig, Candace and Conall. Brother of Walter. Beloved grandad of Cara and Meghan. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St, NYC, Friday, 25 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass, St. Francis Xavier Church, Sat., 9AM.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: INAUGURAL NOTEBOOK ; Take It Off! Take It Off!
description: For many elected officials and other V.I.P.'s, it was not enough to just cast aside the blankets that awaited them on their chairs. In a display of New York bravado and hardiness, several even shed their outer clothes, if they wore them at all.

description: WALSH-James D. On New Year's Day, 1998. Born February 25, 1910, in New York City. Memorial Mass Jan 7, 6 PM, Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82 St, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations: Marymount Manhattan College, NY, or Noble Horizons Village Fund, Salisbury, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILWORTH, J. RICHARDSON
description: DILWORTH-J. Richardson. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Community Service Society of New York deeply regret the death of their Honorary Life Trustee, J. Richardson Dilworth. In his fourteen years of devoted service to CSS, he held many offices including President and Vice Chairman of the Board. His work on eight board committees illuminated both his fund-raising skills and dedication to improving the lives of poor New Yorkers served by CSS. Our heartfelt condolences to his family and the uncounted friends he helped in a lifetime of philanthropy. David R. Jones, Esq., President Stephen R. Aiello, Ph.D., Chair

title: The Neediest Cases; Persevering, A Family Finds a Way, And a Home
description: An 18-month odyssey that included nights in shelters, hotels and a burned-out building ended yesterday, when Robert Maisonet, Debbie Garcia and their three young children woke for the first time in their own apartment.

description: Last night, the Mayor set aside time to say thank you to his constituents, visiting five boroughs in five and a half hours.

description: GROSSHANDLER-Frank. Survived by wife Frances Mai; children: Michael, Karen and Joseph; parents Ruth and Jordan; and brother George. Services at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, Long Island on Friday, January 2 at 11 A.M.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: They were both named Oksana, they both won gold medals in figure skating at the 1994 Olympic Winter Games and they both had blond-from-a-bottle hair. Even Dick Button, a two-time Olympic champion, said last year that he had spoken to Oksana Grishuk for several minutes, believing she was Oksana Baiul.

description: DREITZER-Shirley Wolff Cohen. On Wednesday, December 31, at age 85, of New York and Palm Beach. Devoted wife of the late Albert J. Dreitzer, and, for 39 years, devoted wife of the late William I. Cohen. Loving mother of Stephanie C. Rosen Halpern and Cathleen C. Cavell. Dear sister of Ethel W. Freeman and Annette W. Katz. Loving grandmother of Elizabeth, Carolyn, Pamela and Katherine Rosen, Benjamin and David Cavell, and loving stepgrandmother of Rachel Cavell. Services today, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment, Old Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611

description: As is the case every year, many of the better videos of 1997 in no way resembled major motion pictures. Here is a sampling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGCOPE, THOMAS M. III
description: LONGCOPE-Thomas M. III. Died on December 30th, in Essex, Connecticut. Husband of Elizabeth (Lefferts) Longcope. Memorial service at 2:00 P.M., Tuesday, January 6, Essex Meadows, Essex, CT. Contributions to Alzheimers Association, Chicago, IL.

title: MY MANHATTAN; Don't Let Up On Holiday Letdown
description: One would think that the passing of the holidays would bring with it a measure of the joy and peace that the season itself habitually fails to deliver. If you are anything like me, the last few weeks -- during which you have searched for ''one of a kind'' gifts in the same five superstores as everyone else in North America, spent far too much on a bunch of ingrates, relived childhood traumas in a nontherapeutic milieu and once again failed to secure a date for New Year's Eve with Kate Winslet -- have left you in a highly nervous condition, ready to be wheeled around the grounds of a rest home with a blanket draped over your legs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELENKO, JESSE F. JR.
description: JELENKO-Jesse F. Jr. On Dec. 24, 1997, after a brief illness, in Edina, MN. Born July 28, 1913. He was past president of J.F. Jelenko & Company, a leading producer of dental products. He is survived by two children and four grandchildren. Services will be held Sunday January 4, at 1 P.M., at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

title: Judge Upholds Ban on Race By Teamster
description: A Federal judge has rejected an appeal by Ron Carey, the president of the teamsters, to overturn a decision last month disqualifying Mr. Carey from running again for re-election this spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, RUTH W.
description: KAPLAN-Ruth W. Loving wife of Arthur B., and mother of Peter and Donald. Hers was a life of love and tenderness.

title: AT INAUGURATION, GIULIANI OUTLINES POLICE EXPANSION
description: On an Inauguration Day cold enough to break midtown water mains, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wrapped himself in the warmth of familiarity yesterday, saying he wanted to add 1,600 officers to what is already the country's largest municipal police force and vowing to use his second term to build on the successes of the first.

title: Home for Holidays, a 21-Year-Old Man Is the Year's First Homicide Victim
description: Lashawn Israel Chambers liked to look out on the waters of the East River from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, watching the ships go by. ''I'm going to be something,'' he told school friends he grew up with in the Walt Whitman Houses in Fort Greene. ''I'm going to get out.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA
description: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, has named Scott M. Bresky president of Chase Investment Services Corp., the retail brokerage operation of the bank. Mr. Bresky has been servinng as the interim president since September. He succeeds Leonard Malkin.

title: Abroad at Home; Emotion, Not Reason
description: The cases of Terry Nichols and Theodore Kaczynski highlight a striking difference between the United States and many countries whose values we otherwise share, from Europe to Australia. They have abandoned capital punishment as a piece of savagery unjustified by any gain in public safety; we are executing more prisoners than we have for decades.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I didn't win the election.''

title: Mixed Reception
description: The market for initial public offerings was mixed in 1997. There were 620 offerings, 200 fewer than in 1996, and many of them did not repeat the price explosions of the previous few years. Below is a chart of the five biggest winners and losers.

description: 'Strange Days'

title: A Low-Profile Cost-Cutter Assumes a Key Role for Chrysler
description: Chrysler's previous president, Robert A. Lutz, is a former Marine who flies fighter jets for fun and sometimes uses his pocketknife to stir cream into his coffee, licking the blade afterward. Stepping into his shoes is Thomas T. Stallkamp, who became the company's president today.

title: New Video Releases
description: Hoodlum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, WILLIAM G., JR.
description: GROSS-William G., Jr. On December 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth B. Gross. Dear father of Jane L. Miller, Diane A. Kingsley and William G. Gross, III. Also survived by brother Robert Gross and four grandchildren. Visiting Friday, 79PM at Doyle B. Shaffer Funeral Home, 45-09 Little Neck Parkway, Little Neck, NY. Service Friday evening, 8PM. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery Saturday, 10AM.

title: Police's Use of Deadly Force In New York Is Low for Nation
description: Despite a Hollywood-inspired perception that the New York City police are quick to use gunfire to fight crime, F.B.I. statistics show that city officers actually shoot civilians far less frequently than their counterparts in other major cities.

title: THE INAUGURATION OF RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI: INAUGURAL NOTEBOOK ; Frozen Out by Mayor Is No Figure of Speech
description: They say you can't tell the players without a scorecard, but it was easy to tell which politicians were in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's favor -- and which were not -- based on the dais seats they were assigned yesterday at the inauguration.

title: How to See Movies With a Twist
description: So you've paid your $8.75, fought your way to buy a $4 bag of supercharged popcorn, struggled up six flights to your theater and finally found a seat -- in the back row. Looking down -- way down -- to the screen, you count your blessings. You could be sitting up front.

title: Kabila Pledges He Will Hold Congo Election in Early 1999
description: In a move aimed at easing doubts about his rule both at home and abroad, Congo's President, Laurent Kabila, announced late on Wednesday that his Government would organize national elections early in 1999.

title: Capturing a Master's Enduring Power
description: Many pianists play the five piano concertos of Beethoven. But not many have played them all in one evening, as Anton Kuerti did on Wednesday in two successive concerts for sold-out houses at the 92d Street Y with the Jupiter Symphony, conducted by Jens Nygaard.

title: Detroit Braces for the Rerun Of a Divisive Murder Trial
description: Nearly five years ago, residents of Detroit were deeply divided by a highly publicized, racially charged trial in which two white police officers were accused of beating a black drug user to death.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the collapse of the Selwyn Theater building on 42d Street referred incorrectly to the hiring of engineers to inspect the site. Two engineers had been hired weeks earlier by a development company, Tishman Realty and Construction, and a subcontractor, Big Apple Construction and Demolition, to work on a neighboring project. Last Monday was not their hiring date but rather the day they inspected the Selwyn building, which collapsed on Tuesday.

title: A Master at Making Gangsters Likable
description: CAGNEY
