description: * Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Cleveland, to BBDO Chicago, part of Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been at Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications, Cleveland, a unit of Wolf Group. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: South Korea Over a Hurdle To Stabilize Weak Economy

title: Move to Buy Stake In Paper Cup Maker
description: Fonda Group Inc. has formed a holding company that will acquire a 48 percent stake in Sweetheart Holdings Inc., the paper cup company, for an undisclosed amount from American Industrial Partners.

title: Metro Business; Petrie Retail to Sell 469 Clothing Stores
description: Petrie Retail of Secaucus, N.J., said on Wednesday that it planned to sell its 420-store G&G/Rave chain by June 30 as part of its reorganization to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Lemaire Disputes Penalty In Overtime
description: Jacques Lemaire clapped in a derisive manner at Referee Kerry Fraser as the Devils' coach was the last of his team to leave the ice today following New Jersey's loss in overtime to the Florida Panthers.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Deal in Eye-Care Field
description: Vision Twenty-One Inc., a manager of eye-care practices, said that it had acquired MEC Health Care Inc. and LSI Acquisition Inc. from Lasersight Inc. for $6.5 million in cash and $6.5 million in stock. MEC Health Care, which is based in Baltimore, administers vision plans for health maintenance organizations and others. It had estimated 1997 revenue of $8.7 million. LSI Acquisition has a 25-year service agreement to manage the ophthalmic business of the Northern New Jersey Eye Institute of South Orange, N.J. The clinic had estimated revenue of $4 million in 1997.

title: Panasonic Names Warwick Baker
description: Panasonic, a subsidiary of Matsushita Electric Industrial Company in Secaucus, N.J., named Warwick Baker O'Neill in New York to handle advertising for its electric shavers. That advertising was previously handled by Poppe Tyson in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, which is being acquired by True North Communications Inc. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $8 million.

title: Tennessee Braces Itself as Osborne Prepares for Final Bow
description: Tom Osborne raised a few eyebrows in early preparations for Friday's Orange Bowl Classic when he hoped aloud that a right knee infection would not prevent Tennessee quarterback Peyton Manning from playing against his Nebraska Cornhuskers.

title: Benes Gives Up Fight for Contract
description: Andy Benes, the pitcher whose effort to re-sign with the St. Louis Cardinals as a free agent was fouled up by a deadline problem on Dec. 7, decided yesterday to abandon his legal fight to enforce a five-year, $30 million contract.

title: A Group Portrait of Pittsburgh, Forged of Smoke and Sentiment
description: This city got its name when the British christened Fort Pitt in 1758 for William Pitt the Elder, then Prime Minister. He was especially distinguished for having broken with tradition: he refused to enrich himself when he was paymaster of the British forces.

title: Rejected Unabom Plea
description: To the Editor:

title: A Kennedy Family Pattern: Triumph and Tragedy
description: The death of Michael Kennedy in a New Year's Eve skiing accident is but the latest blow for the third generation of America's most prominent political family, which has been scarred by drugs and death, alcoholism and sexual improprieties, marriage travails and even criminal charges.

title: A Busy New Year for a Malaysian Debt Collector
description: PETALING JAYA, Malaysia  It's New Year's Eve, and Tony Chan is making the rounds.

title: Pedestrian Traffic Light May Help Ease Gridlock; Walkers Are the Culprits
description: To the Editor:

title: A Magnate As Hard As a Diamond
description: Like an expedition following a cracked compass, ''Rhodes'' takes a full two hours of meandering to find its way. But when this three-part ''Masterpiece Theater'' manages to get on track by Monday night, it delivers a forceful and flavorful account of the career of the bloody-handed visionary who conquered the world's diamond trade and much of southern Africa at the turn of the century.

title: Hand on Bible And Eyes On the Prize
description: NEW YORK had all its lame ducks in a row yesterday.

title: New York Stock Exchange Faces Reality of Heart Attacks
description: One morning last March, Patrick Grieve, a 48-year-old clerk, complained to a colleague on the New York Stock Exchange floor of tingling in the bottom of his feet. Just after the opening bell, Mr. Grieve collapsed and died of a heart attack.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Moomba believes in chic recycling. That's why some of the walls are made of soybeans and carpet trimmings, if I have that right, and others are embellished with recycled rice paper.

title: World News Briefs; Solo American Balloonist Races Across Atlantic
description: Racing along at speeds up to 161 miles an hour, Steve Fossett's Solo Spirit balloon reached Europe yesterday evening barely two days after ascending from St. Louis, Mo., where Mr. Fossett began his latest attempt to circle the world nonstop.

title: Movie Clock Today
description: An extra edition for the weekend. Arts & Ideas, page B20.

title: Wrong Call on Parole
description: To the Editor:

title: Toledo Journal; After 5 Centuries, a Mecca for Translators Again
description: This city's medieval gates and cobblestone alleys are still largely intact, so when Miguel Larramendi goes to work at the Toledo School of Translators, he is walking in the footsteps of his distant predecessors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTEL, JACQUES
description: ARTEL-Jacques. Born January 18, 1914 in Rostov-on-Don, Russia. Died December 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Janet Ann Bissell Artel. Devoted father of Catherine Lee Pietrogallo, Marie Christine Wallace and Alexis Artel. Also survived by five grandchildren and five nieces and nephews. He fled Russia with his mother and brother to France where he served in the French Army during W.W. II. In 1946, he came to the United States, a country which he loved very much. Friend to many people, cared for all, especially loved children. He died peacefully after a full and interesting life. Memorial service will be held at the First Reformed Church, Hastingson-Hudson, New York at 11 A.M., on January 17th, 1998. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the First Reformed Church or to the Tolstoy Foundation of Valley Cottage, New York.

title: Pain and Circumcision
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARLICK, HAROLD
description: GARLICK-Harold. Died peacefully Tuesday, December 30, 1997 at his home in Boca Raton, FL. A long-time resident of New York, Harold and his wife moved to Florida in 1993 where he established his permanent residence in Boca Raton, FL. He was formerly the President of Garlick Funeral Homes, also on the Board of the Jewish Funeral Directors of America, a Kentucky Colonel. He was a member of the Knights of Pythias, Veritus Lodge and other Pythian lodges. He is survived by his dearly beloved wife Eileen, his nephews Saul, Jonathan and David Garlick, and his great nieces and nephews. Services will be held Sunday, January 4th at 12PM at Garlick's, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. Contributions are to be made to your favorite charity.

title: Suspense Is Rising in Israel Over Impasse on the Budget
description: Israel shut down for the weekend today in high suspense over whether Foreign Minister David Levy, who has threatened to resign from Israeli governments eight times in the past, would finally make good on his vow this time.

title: The Neediest Cases; Their Joy Louder Than Silence, Deaf Children Frolic at Center
description: The room was packed with romping children, but an uncanny silence filled the air. The only sound was that of tearing paper and a few errant squeals as the 50 or so youngsters, all of them deaf or hard of hearing, unwrapped their holiday gifts at the Rhinelander Children's Center on the Upper East Side.

title: Mets Promise Isringhausen That He Won't Lose Pay
description: The Mets have assured Jason Isringhausen that elbow surgery will not cost him salary and service time this year, according to Steve Phillips, the team's general manager, who hopes Isringhausen will decide not to have the career-threatening procedure immediately.

title: Buffed and Polished Blues
description: The blues is theoretically perfect on New Year's Day: there's nothing so reassuring as its melancholy to counteract the previous night's naive wassailing optimism. And one needs something measurable after all that chaos; the music's predictable cadences soothe the nerves. An early set on Thursday night by the singer and guitarist Big Jack Johnson at Chicago Blues did all that and too much more; it went over the line into formula.

title: Next Stop on the St. John's Learning Curve: Seton Hall
description: Is St. John's the team that played an eyesore of a loss to lightly regarded Niagara? Or is it the resilient bunch that drained its free throws down the stretch in a victory at Notre Dame?

title: In New Jersey, a Delicate Industry Unravels
description: Behind a nondescript facade on a quiet street here, huge looms with thousands of needles are noisily working their magic in rhythm, transforming rolls of plain fabric into delicate designs that will one day adorn a fancy nightgown, frilly underwear or a little girl's party dress.

title: German Poll Shows Pessimism About Jobs
description: Most Germans do not believe Chancellor Helmut Kohl's assertion that the labor market will improve in 1998, though analysts said they were being too pessimistic. In a survey of 1,000 Germans conducted by the market-research group Emnid for the N-TV network, 42 percent said they expected unemployment to rise this year, compared with only 22 percent who expected a labor-market improvement.

title: Police Say Boy Killed Man Who Attacked Mother
description: A 13-year-old boy stabbed a man to death with a kitchen knife yesterday in his family's Bronx apartment after the man tried to rape the boy's mother, the police said.

title: How a Marxist Hotbed Eased Right; Recalling New York's Intellectual Life as Contact Sport
description: ''I became radical because I thought I had good reason to become radical. I became liberal because I thought I had good reason to become liberal. And then I became conservative because I thought I had good reason to be conservative. It seems to me perfectly natural.''

title: Treasuries Rise Sharply On Prediction Of Slowdown
description: Treasury prices rose sharply on expectations of slower growth yesterday, after a manufacturing survey suggested that Asia's financial crisis was beginning to drag on the United States economy.

title: An Essay Contest? It Used to Work
description: With the end of the millennium threatening to provoke storms of banalities, why not ask the erudite and enlightened to offer some profundities to guide us into the unknown? That, at least, is one inspiration for an international essay contest that has just been announced in Weimar, Germany. Another is that Weimar will hold the rotating title of European Cultural Capital in 1999 and would like the world to take note.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, EDWARD A.
description: BAILEY-Edward A. Member of the New York State Bar Association for over fifty years. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Devoted father of Pamela, William and Edward. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Brian, Dorothy and Teresa. Dear brother of Vincent and Richard. Loving uncle of Doris Stahr. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, NYC, Saturday and Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 11 AM, at St. Joseph of Yorkville Roman Catholic Church, 404 East 87th Street, NYC.

title: Kenya's President Headed For Victory in Chaotic Vote
description: President Daniel arap Moi, the master politician who has led this country for 20 years, appeared headed toward a victory today in Kenya's flawed and chaotic elections, with all unofficial tallies showing him comfortably in the lead.

title: RALLY'S AND CHECKERS DRIVE-IN COMPLETE STOCK SWAP
description: Rally's Hamburgers Inc. has completed a stock swap with the largest investors of Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc., giving the company a 27 percent stake in Checkers and the investors about 44 percent of Rally's stock. The stock swap allows the two fast-food restaurant chains to cut costs by combining accounting, legal and finance operations. Rally's exchanged an unspecified number shares for 19.1 million shares of Checker stock held by CKE Restaurants Inc., Fidelity National Financial Inc. and Giant Group Ltd.

title: In the Offing, Another Hall In Carnegie's Basement
description: A venerable but largely forgotten piece of New York stage history -- where concert pianists played the works of a Viennese contemporary named Brahms and David Belasco, Agnes Moorehead and Spencer Tracy once trod the boards -- is being auditioned for a comeback at Carnegie Hall.

title: Adult Book Store Gets A Temporary Reprieve
description: An adult book and video store in Saddle Brook can remain open temporarily even though it violates a state law that requires such businesses to be at least 1,000 feet from a residential area, school, church, park or bus stop, an appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: SHARES OF LONG-DISTANCE PHONE CONCERNS FALL
description: Shares of the AT&T Corporation and other long-distance phone companies fell yesterday during the first market session after a Federal court struck down the portions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 that prevent the companies spun off from AT&T in the 1980's from offering long-distance services. Shares of AT&T fell $2.50, to $58.8125, as almost 10.1 million of its shares were traded. The No. 2 phone company, the MCI Communications Corporation, fell 12.5 cents, to $42.6875, and No. 3 Sprint dropped 62.5 cents, to $58. Late yesterday, the three companies and others asked the court to delay the decision from taking effect. The Government said that it would also appeal the ruling, issued Wednesday, because it left little incentive for the so-called Baby Bells to open their local markets to long-distance companies.

title: California Federal Stock Offering Delayed
description: California Federal Bank's initial public offering of stock has been delayed as savings regulators review the plan, the institution's chairman said today.

title: From Science to Art to Science to Cyber-Art
description: Throughout history, technological advances and artistic innovation have gone hand in hand. Without the advent of slow-drying oil paint in the 15th century, Renaissance painters would not have used such subtle coloring and shadows. Without printing, professional novelists may not have emerged. Without certain instruments, some musical classics would not exist. Liszt, for example, could never have composed the ''Annees de Pelerinage'' if the piano hadn't replaced the harpsichord.

title: Will Lack of Running Game Stop the Niners?
description: Rarely has a Super Bowl contender lacked what the 49ers now do: a running game. Garrison Hearst, the team's workhorse runner, will miss the divisional playoff game against the Minnesota Vikings on Saturday with a still healing collarbone. Are the 49ers worried? Of course not. They may be the most confident organization in sports.

title: Investors See Their Own Kodak Moment
description: Shares of the Eastman Kodak Company rose more than 5 percent yesterday in what analysts described as a combination of start-of-year buying and investor reaction to stepped-up cost-cutting.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Unabom Suspect: Sick, or Skillful and Evil?
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Man Is Accused Of Sexually Abusing Girl
description: A 57-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing an 11-year-old girl at a Bronx public housing complex, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABRUNA, VINCENZA
description: LaBRUNA-Vincenza. On Dec. 31 at 93 years old. Beloved wife of the late Nunzio. Devoted mother of the late Josephine and Joseph. Survived by Vincent (Nina, Victor, Lynn). Loving grandmother of Joseph (Jerri) Vincent (Donna), Michael (Tammy) Vincent (Lucille) Anthony (Diane) and ten great - grandchildren. Campbell Funeral Home. 288-3500.

title: Unabom Suspect: Sick, or Skillful and Evil?; Treat Victims Equally
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy Futures Slide as Temperatures Rise
description: Natural gas and other energy prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as warmer weather in the Northeast and Midwest increased expectations that demand for heating fuel would decline.

title: Colombia's Spectrum of Sorrows
description: When Americans think of Colombia's problems, they think of cocaine. To Colombians, however, drugs are only one of many burdens. Colombia's institutions are besieged by a seemingly endless guerrilla war, paramilitary death squads, an army supportive of the paramilitaries and defiant of civilian authority, and hundreds of thousands of peasant refugees crowding the cities. Political violence now kills more than 10 Colombians a day.

title: Sports of The Times; On the Wrong Side Of the River Yet Again
description: THE introduction of Keith Van Horn to the Knicks and the intensification of a long-dormant basketball rivalry was excellent news for everyone except the man who started at center last night for the team from the New York side of the Lincoln Tunnel. For Buck Williams, it was another cruel twist, the coming to one more intersection of his fate and bad luck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SANDRA W.
description: MEYER-Sandra W. The Board of Trustees of Guild Hall of East Hampton mourn the irreparable loss of Sandra W. Meyer, an exemplary public citizen and long time trustee whose distingished service as Chair of the Guild Hall Strategic Planning Committee was responsible for the resurgence of eastern Long Island's cultural center and museum. We wish to express our deepest sympathy to her family. Henry Korn, President Melville Straus, Chairman of the Board

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bad Year, Good Month For French Auto Makers
description: New-car registrations in France rose for the second month in December, although sales for the full year suffered their worst drop in more than 20 years. A total of 155,720 cars were registered in December, an increase of 7.9 percent from the corresponding month a year earlier.

title: With a Trigger-Happy Leader, Earthlings Battle Aliens
description: Tricia O'Neil is not the star of ''Babylon 5: In the Beginning,'' but she has the movie's most exhilarating moments, as President of the Earth Alliance, sending her planet's soldiers into space battle against a superior alien enemy with some inspiring words. The speech begins with ''We stand at the twilight of the human race,'' uses phrases like ''though Earth may fall'' and ''we step forward the last time'' and ends with ''May God go with you all.'' O.K., it's not exactly the St. Crispin's Day speech at Agincourt, but it has a touch of grandeur.

title: STOCK OF BINGO OPERATOR FALLS AFTER OFFICE IS SEARCHED
description: The shares of Multimedia Games Inc. fell 24 percent yesterday after Federal agents searched its offices for evidence that its electronic bingo game used on Indian reservations might violate gambling laws. The search on New Year's Eve caused Multimedia Games to halt play of its Megamania games temporarily, and they have not resumed at three bingo halls in Oklahoma. The company operates satellite-linked bingo games nationwide. Megamania is installed at more than 50 Indian bingo halls in 10 states. Justice Department officials in Oklahoma said the game violated the Indian Gaming Act because it was a style of slot machine, which is prohibited. The company and tribes say it is legal. Shares of Multimedia fell $3.50, to $11.0625.

title: U.S. Undermines War Criminal Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis in Asia and Rail Delays Hurt Manufacturing in December
description: Manufacturing activity slowed in December as the economic crisis in Asia and rail traffic delays in the United States hurt orders and production, a report released today showed.

title: Derby Hope Favorite Trick May Now Lose His Trainer
description: Joseph Lacombe, the majority owner of Favorite Trick, the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, has begun interviewing prospective trainers in the expectation that the undefeated colt will have to be moved to a new barn by the end of this month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARR, KRISTEN ANN.
description: CARR-Kristen Ann. In the five years since your death, your radiance has inspired your family, friends, and many others to acts of love and generosity. Our thoughts are with you and them. Marilyn and Seth

title: Havas Shares Rise on Report of Merger Plan
description: The shares of Havas S.A. rose 2.4 percent today after a press report revived speculation that its parent company, Generale des Eaux S.A., may merge it with Canal Plus, another subsidiary.

title: ACQUISITION ALLOWS BANK TO MOVE INTO SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Centura Banks Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Pee Dee State Bank for $40 million in stock, expanding into South Carolina. Since being created through a merger in 1990, Centura, based in Rocky Mount, N.C., has made about 20 acquisitions and expanded its assets to $7.1 billion. Pee Dee, based in Timmonsville, has six branches in South Carolina and $141 million in assets. Shares of Centura slipped 25 cents, to $68.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UGHETTA, FRIEDA
description: UGHETTA-Frieda. On December 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Casper. Devoted mother of Marianne Brew, William C. and the late Henry L. Ughetta. Also survived by 19 grandchildren and 28 great-grandchildren. Friends may call at The Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York, Sunday 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial St. Pius X Church, Monday at 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLYEA, ALEX
description: POLLYEA-Alex. Of New York City. On December 28, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Jessica. Loving father of Eric and Alexandra Pollyea. Dear brother of Pauline Strausberg. Service at the Church Center for U.N., 777 UN PLaza, 44th Street and 1st Avenue, New York City, at 11:30 A.M. Interment Cyprus Hill Cemetery. Friends who wish may contribute to Association: Lorris Junec 24, Rue Leon Croc, 914 Orsay, France in his memory. For further information, please call Westchester Funeral Home (914-337-4585).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, CHARLES
description: KINGSLEY-Charles. It is with deepest sympathy that we mourn the passing of our friend, Charles. We will miss his warmth, kindness, and generosity of spirit. He made each of us feel truly welcome and important and we have vivid, loving memories of happy days spent with him, Emily, and Jason at their home in Chappaqua. Charles will be dearly missed, but lovingly remembered. The Sesame Street Writers

title: A Poised Van Horn Leads Nets past Knicks
description: His hair sticks up in the back. He wears his tube socks hiked up to his knees.

title: Defenders Make a Slam, Declarer Takes a Beating
description: A small man with a large sense of humor died a week ago after a brief illness, and will be greatly missed by the New York bridge community. His name was Norman Kurlander, 59, and he was the owner-manager, with Keith Garber, of the Bridge Haven Club, 65-55 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park, Queens. Kurlander was an active tournament player who won many regional titles and a quarter of a century ago finished second in the National Men's Teams, an event that no longer exists.

title: Osborne's Farewell A Picture Of Power
description: Tom Osborne's final Nebraska football team understood the political reality. The Cornhuskers knew that perfection might not be enough to end his 25th season as head coach with a national championship. So the Huskers did the next best thing.

title: SHELL OIL SEEKING TO SELL REFINERY IN WASHINGTON STATE
description: The Shell Oil unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group has hired Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Turner Mason & Company to help sell its refinery in Washington State as part of an agreement to remove antitrust hurdles to a merger of Shell and the United States refining and gas station businesses of Texaco Inc. Tesoro Petroleum, Valero Energy, Clark Oil and Refining and Ultramar Diamond Shamrock are among the companies that will be contacted to see whether they want to buy the plant, said Malcolm Turner, chief executive of the Turner Mason refining consulting group in Dallas. The refinery is in Anacortes, Wash., about 60 miles north of Seattle. The purchase price of the Anacortes plant has been put at $110 million to $170 million.

title: Youth Served as Van Horn Leads Nets
description: His hair sticks up in the back. He wears his tube socks hiked up to his knees.

title: TWO-MAN SHOW: A special report.; Rank and File of Albany Chafing at Their Bit Parts
description: When Bill No. 8624 hit the Assembly floor on the last day of last year's legislative session, Assemblywoman Sandra Galef was slipping into sleep, a victim of the Legislature's all-night march to recess. She glanced wearily at an innocuous one-line description of the bill, then voted yes. It passed 147-2.

title: Rhyming on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Sundstrom Comes Back, But Lindbom Is Hurt
description: Just as one Swedish forward gets ready to come back to the Ranger lineup, another replaces him on the injured list. The returning player is Niklas Sundstrom, who might play Saturday night when the Rangers visit the Capitals for the first time in Washington's new MCI Center. Sundstrom, a wing on Wayne Gretzky's line, has not played since sustaining a broken finger on Dec. 5.

title: Tennessee and UConn Playing for Fun Now
description: It is the biggest game so far in the women' basketball season: undefeated Tennessee (14-0), ranked first in the nation, against undefeated Connecticut (12-0), ranked third. When they clash at 4 P.M. today in Knoxville before a national television audience, it will be their seventh meeting in four years in the sport's rivalry of the 90's.

title: Man With Fake Gun Is Shot by Officer
description: A Newark man holding a model handgun was wounded by a Jersey City police officer on Thursday, the police said today.

title: Shares of Apple Computer Rise Sharply
description: The shares of Apple Computer Inc. rose 24 percent today amid optimism that the company, the maker of Macintosh computers, will have surprise news at next week's MacWorld Expo in San Francisco.

title: Barstool Rebels Defy California's Ban on Smoking
description: The regulars at the Studio Lounge in Hollywood are cab drivers, retired government employees, old soldiers. The white-haired guy at the end of the bar, Jim Fults, served in Korea.

title: A Wayward Bear Is Caught in a Tree
description: A 300-pound female black bear, first spotted Thursday wandering suburban West Orange, was captured today in Little Falls.

title: Aqueduct Signal Briefly Cut
description: The New York Racing Association briefly cut off its television signal from Aqueduct to local cable viewers yesterday as part of an ongoing financial dispute over in-home simulcasting with New York City Off-Track Betting.

title: MAKER OF POLYESTER FIBERS TO SELL ITS PACKAGING UNIT
description: Wellman Inc., a maker of polyester fibers, agreed yesterday to sell its Creative Forming Inc. unit to a group of managers and M&I Capital Markets Group Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Creative Forming, which accounts for 2 percent to 3 percent of Wellman's revenue, makes packaging from resin. M&I Capital Markets Group is a venture-capital firm in Milwaukee. Costs associated with the sale will reduce fourth-quarter earnings by an unspecified amount, Wellman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, ALFRED J., JR.
description: ANDREWS-Alfred J., Jr. Age 90. On January 1, 1998 of Hattertown Road, Newtown, Connecticut. A retired interior decorator. Services Monday, January 5, 1998, 7 PM, at the Honan Funeral Home, 58 Main Street, Newtown, Connecticut.

title: Liberties; The Toon Gap
description: A friend of mine called after a holiday dinner.

title: Election on Feb. 3 To Fill Four Seats
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today set a date of Feb. 3 for a special election to fill a Congressional seat vacated by the Rev. Floyd H. Flake in Queens and three State Assembly seats, one in Brooklyn and two in Nassau County.

title: Group Assisting Paula Jones Says It's Target of Intimidation
description: The Rutherford Institute, a conservative legal organization, has accused President Clinton's lawyers of threatening its nonprofit status in retaliation for helping Paula Corbin Jones in her sexual misconduct case against him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BESSIE
description: GOLDBERG-Bessie. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Sidney Freedman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTER, THERESA A.
description: KANTER-Theresa A. Age 94. Died January 2, 1998 in Great Neck, New York, leaving daughter Anita, grandsons Carl and Marc, four great grandchildren and her brother Myron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISBERG, BARRETT
description: KREISBERG-Barrett. The entire School of American Ballet family notes with sadness the death of Barry Kreisberg. Chairman of Faculty Peter Martins and President Larry Alan Smith join the Board, Faculty, Staff and Students in their condolences to his family and his colleagues at Harkness. We shall all miss his towering presence at our parties.

title: In All-Too-Familiar Ritual, Kennedys Gather for a Burial
description: Once again, the Kennedys converged on the family's oceanside compound in Hyannisport to bury a family member before his time. Today, they came to mourn Michael L. Kennedy, son of Robert F. Kennedy and nephew of President John F. Kennedy, who died while skiing in Aspen, Colo., on New Year's Eve.

title: Light on the Music, Heavy on the Gunfire
description: It takes a particularly strong brand of chutzpah to set about remaking ''The Magnificent Seven'' for television. That 1960 film about the end of the Wild West era was one of the last of the great old-style Hollywood westerns, featuring a cast that today looks unmatchable: Yul Brynner, Eli Wallach, Steve McQueen, James Coburn, Charles Bronson and Robert Vaughn.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Asian and Rail Problems Slow U.S. Industry's Pace

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, REGINA ELKES
description: KOHN-Regina Elkes. On Dec. 31, 1997. Wife of the late Harry Imre Kohn. Mother of Imre R. Kohn and the late Mary McDougald Kohn. Grandmother of Sarah and Jeremy. Memorial arrangements to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTH, GEORGE
description: NORTH-George. Born on July 28, 1927 in New York City, died Wednesday, December 31, 1997. He was the son of Mr. and Mrs. North who are now both deceased. George last resided at the Dunn Avenue IRA in Corinth, NY. Concerned friends or family should call the Capital District DSO Director, Michael Dillon at 518-581-3038.

title: Powerful Claim to Get Osborne a Final Title
description: Tom Osborne's final Nebraska football team understood the political reality. The Cornhuskers knew that perfection might not be enough to end his 25th season as head coach with a national championship. So the Huskers did the next best thing.

title: Keeping Watch in Washington Square
description: The sun was bright, the wind was tame, the pigeons looked fat and happy. And the two new surveillance cameras trained on the chess players, dog walkers and other users of Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village yesterday captured much of the scene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILROE, HELEN MARGUERITE.
description: KILROE-Helen Marguerite. On January 2, 1998. Beloved sister of Mary Purcell and the late Catherine C. Dunne. Also survived by her nieces and nephews Eileen Ehntholt, Kathleen Dunne, William Purcell, Patricia Barnes, Sheila Sechler and John Purcell. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20 Street) NYC, Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10AM, Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, New Rochelle, New York.

title: How to Energize Education
description: Why did two businessmen get involved with school choice scholarships -- private vouchers to help 2,300 low-income students attend the schools of their choice in New York and Washington? Why didn't we just ''adopt a school'' or buy computers for classrooms, or simply write our checks to the public school system itself?

title: Bauer of Germany Joins Bidding for Unit
description: Heinrich Bauer, a privately held German publishing company, has joined the bidding for Reed Elsevier's IPC consumer magazine unit, according to a statement from Britain's Office of Fair Trading. Earlier this week it was reported that Cinven Ltd., Emap P.L.C., and Bertelsmann of Germany had also placed bids for the magazine unit.

title: Unabom Defense Sets Fall-Back Strategy
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski's lawyers notified the prosecution today that if he is convicted, they plan to try to spare him a death sentence by arguing in the penalty phase of his trial that he is mentally ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, KATHRYN CAMERON,
description: MILLER-Kathryn Cameron, 71. Died January 2, 1998. K. was born on April 25, 1926 at the home of her parents Ewen Charles Donald Cameron, and Jeanette Rogers Cameron in AuSable Forks, New York. She attended the Madeira School, Vassar College, and later the Powers Modeling Agency School of Photography in New York. After college K. was a ski instructor at Whiteface Mountain in Wilmington, NY. In 1953, with her partner Arto Monaco, K. started the Land of Makebelieve Amusement Park in Upper Jay, New York. In 1955 K. married William Thomas Eldred of Hanover, NH. Mr. Eldred was the founder and publisher of Ski Magazine. K. worked as Fashion Editor for Ski Magazine. Mr. Eldred died in 1965. In 1958 K. married William Henry Miller. Bill was the owner of Miller Auto Company in White River Jct., VT. K. is survived by her husband Bill Miller, her son Cameron Eldred, her daughter Jane Eldred, a step-son Garfield Miller, a stepson Justin Miller, and ten grandchildren.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't want to spend all day picking up butts off the floor. Nobody is paying attention to the law.''

title: J.G. Williams, 84, a Legend As Naturalist And Guide
description: John George Williams, a self-taught naturalist who gained international renown as a safari guide to the bird life and other fauna of eastern and central Africa, died on Sunday at Leicester General Hospital in Leicester, England. He was 84 and lived in Rutland, Leicestershire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGLER, MURIEL
description: SIEGLER-Muriel. In Lake Worth, FL. Beloved wife of the late Henry Siegler. Loving mother of Richard and Brenda. Adoring grandmother of Lauren and Eric Muhlheim. Great-grandmother of Henry Muhlheim. Funeral services Sunday, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon. NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to Pediatric Cancer Foundation, 405 Tarrytown Road, Suite 572, White Plains, NY 10607.

title: Water Main Ruptures, Creating A Huge Sinkhole on Fifth Avenue
description: A century-old water main ruptured under lower Fifth Avenue early yesterday, creating a car-swallowing, curb-to-curb sinkhole and watery chaos in a bustling neighborhood whose streets resembled Venice for a few hours. Then, as the rivers receded, a gas main broke and the crater spewed forth a tower of orange flames.

title: TORCHMARK TO SPIN OFF WADDELL & REED MUTUAL FUND UNIT
description: The Torchmark Corporation, the insurance and financial services holding company, filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to spin off its Waddell & Reed Financial mutual fund subsidiary in an initial public offering worth as much as $586.5 million. Torchmark, based in Birmingham, Ala., announced it would sell a stake in Waddell in November. The filing did not include the number of shares to be sold, the price or the stake new investors will own after the offering. Waddell is the exclusive distributor of 36 mutual funds: 17 under the United Group of Mutual Funds, 8 Waddell & Reed Funds and 11 TMK/United Funds.

title: Stocks Rally After Bonds Rise Sharply
description: Stocks rose yesterday, bolstered by a rally in the bond market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SAMUEL
description: MILLER-Samuel. Devoted father of Jean and Bette, revered fatherin-law of Richard and Robert. Beloved grandfather of Sarah, Micah, Ilana, Julia and Michael. Cherished friend of Elaine. Beloved brother of Lester and Anita and the late Pauline. Funeral services 12:30, Sunday, January 4, Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park, Hackensak, NJ. Shiva will be observed at 400 Park Avenue, Leonia, NJ.

title: Touching Up a Faded Polaroid; Will Push to Revive Sales Restore Luster?
description: You would think the Polaroid Corporation's design engineers would just concentrate on coming up with ever better cameras and such. Instead, one group is off trying to design store display cases that are shopper friendly but shoplifter proof. Another is experimenting with ways to equip Polaroid's instant films with security tags that set off sirens if someone tries to sneak film out.

title: French Culinary Excess
description: To the Editor:

title: COTELLIGENT BUYS TWO COMPUTER-CONSULTING SERVICES
description: Cotelligent Group Inc. has bought two companies that provide computer-consulting services for an undisclosed price to expand its business in the Atlanta and Seattle areas. The businesses that were acquired -- Diversified Business Systems Inc. of Atlanta and Pyramid Technical Services Inc. of Bellevue, Wash. -- provide staff for computer programming and networking services. The two acquired companies had combined 1997 revenue of $16.2 million, the company said. Cotelligent, based in San Francisco, had revenue of $146.7 million last year. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Cotelligent shares closed unchanged at $19.125.

title: Pain and Circumcision
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Wilvers, 65, Ad Executive; Put 'Plop, Plop' With 'Fizz, Fizz'
description: Bob Wilvers, a former advertising executive, died on Dec. 10 at his home in New Milford, Conn. He was 65.

title: South Korea to Take Over and Sell 2 Big Insolvent Banks
description: The South Korean Government will acquire the nation's two biggest insolvent commercial banks next month and sell them to foreign investors, under a plan announced today aimed at helping satisfy a promise to open financial businesses to outsiders.

title: Steelers and Patriots Will Run, if They Can
description: The Steelers and the Patriots will meet on Saturday in what should be a classic playoff confrontation that might normally favor the running game.

title: Helen Wills Moody, Dominant Champion Who Won 8 Wimbledon Titles, Dies at 92
description: Helen Wills Moody, arguably the most dominant tennis player of the 20th century and the first American-born woman to achieve international celebrity as an athlete, died Thursday at a convalescent home in Carmel, Calif.

title: S.E.C. Charges A Former Broker
description: A former broker at Smith Barney Inc. was charged today by Federal regulators with failing to invest customers' checks worth $245,459 and falsely telling the clients he planned to buy stocks with their money.

title: Puzzle in Mexico Killings: What Did Officials Know?
description: ''We are priistas,'' Augustin Jimenez Perez, a 43-year-old farmer, said proudly in this village of red-dappled coffee plants and, more recently, houses burned to their muddy floors.

title: Chess; Karpov Wins First Game In Title Match Vs. Anand
description: Anatoly Karpov of Russia, considered to be over the hill lately because of second-rate tournament results, made a terrific comeback in Game 1 of his International Chess Federation World Championship Match to defeat his challenger, Viswanathan Anand of India.

title: Pain and Circumcision
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Undermines War Criminal Effort; Legal Expectations
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Is Arrested In Shooting of Cabdriver
description: Responding to a tip from Newark residents, the police arrested on Thursday one of the two men wanted in connection with the killing of a cabdriver, the police said yesterday.

title: Lawmakers Approve Repeal Of Law Regulating Gypsies
description: New Jersey's last-known vestige of official discrimination, an 80-year-old statute permitting municipalities to regulate ''roving bands of nomads, commonly called Gypsies,'' is about to be repealed.

title: Czechs' New Day
description: At a somber swearing-in ceremony in the Prague Castle today, President Vaclav Havel ushered in a new era for the Czech Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORMAN, FRANCIS D.
description: MOORMAN-Francis D. Of New York City and East Chatham, New York, died in New York Hospital, January 1, 1998. Survived by his companion of 35 years, Thomas C. Cracovia. A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: MEDICAL RESEARCH TO GET MORE MONEY FROM GOVERNMENT
description: In his new budget, President Clinton plans to seek a substantial increase in Federal spending on biomedical research, and members of Congress from both parties say they are virtually certain to approve an even bigger increase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELENKO, JESSE F. JR.
description: JELENKO-Jesse F. Jr. On Dec. 24, 1997, after a brief illness, in Edina, MN. Born July 28, 1913. He was past president of J.F. Jelenko & Company, a leading producer of dental products. He is survived by two children and four grandchildren. Services will be held Sunday January 4, at 1 P.M., at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALD, RUTH L. FISH.
description: WALD-Ruth L. Fish. Loving cousin of Leila Seigel and the Holden family. Funeral service Sunday, 11:30 A.M., ''Plaza Memorial Chapel,'' 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Sybase Shares Plunge 25% On Forecast
description: Shares of Sybase Inc. lost a fourth of their value today after the company, a producer of data-base management software, said that it would report fourth-quarter results well below Wall Street analysts' estimates.

title: What Next, Locusts? Fifth Ave. Endures Flood, Then a Gas Fire
description: First the water. Then the fire.

title: Unabom Suspect: Sick, or Skillful and Evil?; Hypocrisy in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime in City Down in '97 By 9.1 Percent
description: New York City's crime rate dropped 9.1 percent last year, continuing the city's decline in violent felonies, which began in 1991.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Pataki Presses for Law On Sex Offenders
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he would propose legislation allowing New York State to confine violent sex offenders in mental hospitals even after they have served their criminal sentences.

title: A Portfolio Manager Quits a Russian Fund, Best Performer in 1997
description: The best-performing mutual fund of 1997, the Lexington Troika Dialog Russia fund, has lost one of its two lead portfolio managers, signaling further turmoil at the Moscow-based company that oversees the popular fund.

title: Mother Freed, Finds Child In Hospital; Sitter Charged
description: A Bronx woman was released from Westchester County Correctional Facility yesterday, only to learn that her young son was in the hospital and her babysitter was in jail, charged with violently shaking the toddler on New Year's Day, the police said.

title: Journal; Ring Out The Old Celebs
description: Nostalgic for 1997 already?

title: The Stars Need a Break, And the Islanders Provide It
description: Not often does a battered Stanley Cup contender get a team as forlorn as the Islanders to get well on. But the Dallas Stars could not have ordered a better rehabilitation assignment tonight as they skated to a 2-1 victory that was not anywhere as close as the score.

title: Year's End Is No Holiday In a Snow-Crazy Aspen
description: The skiing accident that killed Michael L. Kennedy on Wednesday came at a time of year when vacationers transform this relatively quiet mountain town of 5,400 residents into a crowded, noisy, often tense city of nearly 40,000, some of them well-known entertainers and wealthy corporate executives.

title: Rockies Re-sign Reliever Ruffin
description: The Colorado Rockies re-signed the left-handed relief pitcher Bruce Ruffin to a minor league contract, bringing back the team's career saves leader.

title: French Culinary Excess
description: To the Editor:

title: Christmas Tree Fire Kills 5-Year-Old Girl
description: A 5-year-old girl was killed and her cousin and aunt were injured Thursday when their Christmas tree caught fire, officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., the maker of Hellman's mayonnaise and Knorr soups, changed its name to Bestfoods and spun off Corn Products International, a business it has owned since 1906.

title: VODAFONE TO SELL STAKE IN PACIFIC LINK COMMUNICATIONS
description: Vodafone Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sell the stake it holds in Pacific Link Communications Ltd. to two companies for a total of $160 million. Vodafone will sell its stake in Pacific Link Communications Ltd. to Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. The company also agreed to sell its stake in related holding and finance companies of Pacific Link to the First Pacific Company. Pacific Link, Hong Kong Telecommunications and First Pacific are mobile telecommunications companies based in Hong Kong. Vodafone's combined holdings constitute a 35 percent stake in Pacific Link and its related companies. First Pacific owns the remaining 65 percent, which it plans to sell to Hong Kong Telecommunications for $626 million.

title: The Threat to Telephone Competition
description: The Federal judge who threw out key sections of the 1996 Telecommunications Act on Wednesday misread history, Congress and the Constitution. If it stands, the ruling will undermine Congress's attempt to inject competition into a market now controlled by the regional Bell monopolists.

title: INSIDE
description: Defense Rests in Bombing

title: Sports of The Times; The Skills Of the Future, Success Now
description: Kordell Stewart was one of the last players left in the Pittsburgh Steelers' locker room on a frosty New Year's Eve afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JAMES D.
description: WALSH-James D. The Foley Square Heads, an association of former Assistant United States Attorneys for the Southern District of New York who served in the Thirties and early Forties, mourns the passing of a beloved colleague and friend who participated in our activities and helped bond our members together. We shall miss him and we extend our deepest sympathies to the Walsh family. The Foley Square Heads

title: Unabom Suspect: Sick, or Skillful and Evil?; South Africa's Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: With Malaysia Bleeding, Bill Collector Finds Work
description: Holiday preparations are under way here, but visits from Tony Chan bring little joy. In fact, people often call the police when they know he is on the way; others draw the curtains and pretend they are not home.

title: Religion Journal; New Groups' Adherents Bolster Churchgoing Data
description: Since the late 1960's, many mainline Protestant denominations have reported losing hundreds of thousands of members, while Roman Catholics' attendance at Mass also declined from an earlier peak before leveling off.

title: Two Rally to Victories in Cross-Country
description: Two United States cross-country ski racers became the comeback kids today at Mount Van Hoevenberg, the site of the cross-country events for the 1998 Chevy Truck United States Ski Team Gold Cup.

title: Camry and Accord Race for Sales Title
description: The biggest car race of the year was held on dealer lots in December. Who won? It's anyone's guess.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVINE, BURTON J.
description: LAVINE-Burton J. Beloved husband of Marian. Devoted father of Steven and Lauren. Loving son of Goldie Jean Lavine. Dear brother of Joyce Simon. Cherished uncle and loyal friend to many. Vice President of Marketing, Zenith Distributing Corp of New York City. Adjunct Professor of Marketing at Baruch School of Business, New York University and C.W. Post. Served on the boards of the United Jewish Appeal and Long Island chapter of the American Cancer Society. Services Sunday 1PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the above charities.

title: Heartache Frequently Visits Parents With Multiple Births
description: Like so many other parents, they sent out a birth notice: ''Mario and Jane Simeone proudly announce the birth of their new arrivals!'' It listed the names of their triplets, the birth weights, lengths, and birth date: June 21, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIRESTER, HARRY M.
description: FIRESTER-Harry M. On December 31, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Eva, devoted father of Philip and Joanne Firester and Elaine and Dr. David Lesser. Dear brother of Sadie Copperman, Rose Haber and Gertrude Firester. Cherished grandfather of Jami, Donna, Glenn, Leonard and Sharon. Loving great-grandfather of Lauren, Daniel, Alexander, Griffin, Jason, Jesse, Oliver and Alexis. Services Sunday, 1 PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI. Donations may be made to the Long Island Hearing and Speech Society at LIJ Medical Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, STEPHANIE
description: ROBBINS - Stephanie. Beloved mother, grandmother, sister and good friend to so many. You will always be remembered as our Lion Queen. We love you and will miss you for all time. David, Pam and Julian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: Pataki Urges Confining Violent Sex Offenders After Prison Terms End
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would propose legislation allowing the state to confine violent sex offenders in mental hospitals even after they have served their criminal sentences.

title: A Fallen Star Tries to Rise And Shine Again
description: ''We would never have done this interview years ago,'' said Rick James, lounging on a leopard skin couch in the sunken living room of his plush new home here in a gated community near Los Angeles. ''Back then, I'd be in my room for an hour. Then I'd come out, spend a couple minutes with you, and go back to my room and smoke cocaine again. You'd be here the whole night and you'd say, 'We didn't talk much, but we saw the smoke, the redness in his eyes and the freaks running around buck naked.'''

title: An Infrastructure Summit
description: Perhaps inspired by the holidays, regional politicians have been promising us gifts in the form of discounts and tax cuts. Joseph Bruno, the New York State Senate majority leader, made the latest offer when he suggested devoting a chunk of Albany's $2 billion surplus to tax cuts. Unfortunately, this seasonal generosity tends to emphasize current gratification at the expense of long-range needs. Chief among these needs, and essential to the New York metropolitan area's economic future, are smart, well-aimed investments in infrastructure -- its schools, roads and mass transit.

title: After 9 Witnesses, Nichols Defense Rests
description: In a surprise move, lawyers for Terry L. Nichols today presented only nine witnesses, including Mr. Nichols's wife and ex-wife, to plead for his life before resting their case in the second Oklahoma City bombing trial. They had promised to call 60 people; prosecutors had called 55.

title: Of Mice and Men, Release 2.0
description: Sunset flared against the dun hills of the Silicon Valley. Lennie spoke quietly in the gathering twilight of a wooded grove, ''Tell me again, George.''

title: The Nets Have All The Grit
description: The Knicks allowed the Nets to slip into their coveted blue collars tonight.

title: Currencies of Malaysia And Indonesia Plunge
description: Southeast Asian currencies fell yesterday, with the Malaysian ringgit tumbling to a record low and the Indonesian rupiah sinking 11 percent. The Malaysian ringgit fell 2.5 percent to 3.9753 to a dollar from Wednesday's close of 3.875 to a dollar. It was the ringgit's weakest price since it was floated in 1973. The Malaysian benchmark stock index lost more than two-thirds of its value in United States dollar terms last year.

title: Prof. Richard Allen Lester, 89, Expert in Wage and Labor Issues
description: Richard Allen Lester, an economist who specialized in wage and labor issues, and a dean of the faculty, emeritus, at Princeton University, died on Tuesday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 89.

title: French Insurer to Sell Its Unit in Britain
description: Groupe des Assurances Nationales S.A., France's fifth-largest insurer, will sell its British unit, GAN Life Holdings P.L.C., to the Life Assurance Holdings Corporation, to help meet European Union conditions for receiving state aid. The price is $:253.5 million ($419 million) and up to $:46 million in deferred payments, depending on the performance of GAN Life.

title: Jinxed Bomber At Last on Duty In Persian Gulf
description: Out here in the Persian Gulf, along a desolate runway surrounded by desert sands and scrub brush, one of the most costly and contentious weapons programs in the history of the United States has quietly reached a milestone many thought it would never see.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERLING, ROBERT C.
description: HAMMERLING-Robert C. On Jan. 1, 1998 of Rye, NY. Devoted husband of the late Rev. Margaret Doolittle Lesser. Beloved father of Robert C. Hammerling Jr. of Upper Montclair, NJ, Katharine D. Gendron of Greenwich, CT, and Elizabeth Brooke Hammerling of Sausalito, CA. Adored stepbrother of Alan Ward of Newbury, MA and Richard Ward of Paris, France. Dear grandfather of Haley, Hayden, Heather and Hayes. The family will receive friends Monday, 7-9 PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. A memorial service will be held on January 6, 10 A.M., at the Rye Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Cancer Support Team, 32 Rye Ridge Plaza, Rye Brook, New York 10573.

title: No Casino Favoritism
description: To the Editor:

title: Friends Say Ferraro Will Seek D'Amato's Seat
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro has told friends she will seek the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato this year, and she asked her advisers to assemble today in New York City to plan for an official announcement tomorrow, her supporters said.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; A Ban Holds
description: Some conservative Islamic leaders have fought the ban, but Egypt's highest court ruled not only that the Health Ministry's ban was medically sound but also that there was no basis in Islamic law or in the Koran for such a practice. BARBARA CROSSETTE

title: Toll-Free Information For Five London Sites
description: Five major tourist sites in London have set up a joint toll-free information number for the United States. Calls to (800) 806-7187 with a touch-tone telephone bring a choice of recordings about the Tower of London, home of the British crown jewels; Hampton Court; the Banqueting House at Whitehall; the State Apartments at Kensington Palace, and Kew Palace and Queen Charlotte's Cottage. Right now, the recordings say, the apartments at Kensington Palace are closed for renovation, as is Kew Palace (but not Queen Charlotte's Cottage). Information on contributions to a memorial fund for Diana, Princess of Wales, is given as part of the Kensington Palace message. The recordings note seasonal activities at the palaces. They do not give the price of admission, because of the shifting exchange rate, but note that tickets to the Tower of London, the best known, are sold at all stations on the underground subway system.

title: Kwan's Top Worries: Health and Confidence
description: Four years later, figure skating again is sending out an orthopedic distress signal. But this one is coming from Michelle Kwan's toe instead of Nancy Kerrigan's knee.

title: A Turn for Gay Men?
description: To the Editor:

title: Spiritual Authority
description: PRESENCES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOODY, HELEN WILLS
description: MOODY-Helen Wills. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on January 1, in Carmel, Calif. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: The Lives They Lived: Brandon Tartikoff; Forever 19
description: b. 1949 When Brandon Tartikoff, at age 31, became president of NBC Entertainment in 1980, the network was last in the ratings. He took it to No. 1,kept it there for 68 straight weeks and became an industry legend. He died after a long battle with Hodgkin's disease last August, at 48, in Los Angeles.

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; A Touch of Spice
description: They don't serve falafel for lunch or dinner at the Eastern Star Deli. But the mixture of fava beans, ground celery seeds, garlic, salt, pepper and parsley, formed into balls and served fried and sandwiched in a pita pocket, is a breakfast standard among the Egyptian cab drivers who eat there, said Mike Attef, who helps out behind the counter. Other favorites include fava beans, fried eggplant and the pickled radish stalks known as felt. For Westerners who prefer something more familiar but no less authentic, there is hollowed-out bread stuffed with scrambled eggs and bits of Egyptian pastrami spiced with garlic and cumin. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: Jennifer Liddy, Justin Green
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Liddy and Justin Timothy Green, lawyers in New York, were married there yesterday at the Church of Our Saviour. The Rev. Matthew Pomilio, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: HOCKEY

title: Judge's Order Clears Way for Limelight
description: After nearly a year and a half, the Limelight is coming back, as a result of a State Supreme Court decision last week.

title: Depicting a Cruelty of Epic Proportions
description: When Cecil Rhodes arrived in 1870 in the Cape Colony, Britain's toehold on the southern end of Africa, it was a small agricultural backwater. When this son of an English country vicar died 32 years later, his company controlled the world monopoly on diamonds. And thanks to his ruthless quest for wealth, Britain controlled a million square miles of the African continent.

title: With Space Tight, Outdated Factories Find New Roles
description: AFTER languishing on the sidelines as the wallflowers of the real estate industry, outmoded industrial buildings, vacant for years, are being pursued by investors and developers who are profiting by dressing them up and dancing them around again.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Winter Antiques Show

title: Will Doing 65 on the Road Ease Gridlock in Trenton?
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that Governor Whitman almost never changes her mind. Why, then, did she suddenly agree last month to consider increasing the speed limit to 65 miles per hour?

title: Eight Killed In 6 Incidents Over 12 Hours
description: A spate of shootings and one stabbing in New York City over a 12-hour period that started Friday night ended with eight people dead and three others wounded in six separate incidents, the police said.

title: Bucs' Forecast: Many Obstacles To Overcome
description: Here is the bad news for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers: the game-time temperature at Lambeau Field on Sunday for their playoff game against Green Bay will be in the 20's with a windchill factor of about minus-10 degrees; the massive Packer defensive tackle Gilbert Brown is angry, and defensive end Reggie White is feeling completely healthy for the first time this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, BRENDAN
description: GILL-Brendan. The Board of Directors and members of The Victorian Society in America wish to epxress our appreciation of Brendan Gill, longstanding Board member and currently a member of our Advisory Council, for his constant help, enthusiastic preservation efforts and indomitable spirit. His vision helped to shape The Society and will continue to be a guide in our future endeavors. John Simonelli, President

title: The World; In Africa's Harsh Climate, Fruits of Democracy
description: WHEN this country's National Assembly met recently to consider the Government's proposed budget for 1998, members of the opposition Republican Rally voted unanimously against the bill.

title: Turning To the Index
description: Charles Schwab & Company has converted two of its actively managed government bond funds to broad-based bond index funds.

title: Debra Sussman, Steven Fletcher
description: Debra Laurie Sussman and Steven Charles Fletcher were married on New Year's Eve at Fiddler's Elbow Country Club in Far Hills, N.J. Rabbi Ellen Lewis officiated.

title: When Children Grieve
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Queasy About Broadway; What the Audience Won't Watch
description: BEFORE the show opened, people worried: Would anyone really spend scarce entertainment dollars and leisure time on a show about deformity and a pathetic and unrealizable yearning for love and normalcy?

title: Topics of The Times; A Moral Fable In the Wee Hours
description: We were intrigued to learn that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani ordered a post-midnight showing of ''The Godfather'' as part of the New Year's festivities in Times Square. The decision speaks for His Honor's cinematic taste and political broad-mindedness. We can imagine some of his Italian-American constituents being uncomfortable with his celebration of this Mafia fable.

title: Ailing Seton Hall Erases St. John's Inside Game
description: The story of Seton Hall's upset of St. John's yesterday could be summarized in Shaheen Holloway's big toe -- badly swollen, black and blue with flecks of blood.

title: Commercial Property/Mack-Cali Realty Corporation; From Two Family Firms, a 'Super-Regional REIT'
description: NOT long ago they were family-run New Jersey real estate companies that competed head to head in the suburban office market in the northern part of the state.

title: Abandon Ship: Fashion Follies of the Year
description: SUPPOSE last year's fashion shows were really held on a sinking ship.

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; Just Veggies, Please
description: No eggs. No milk. No butter. No problem.

title: Applause for the Past, Wishes for the Future
description: LET year-end reflections on professional theater in New Jersey begin, as they must, in praise of the Emily Mann era at the McCarter in Princeton. No mere reiteration of the accolades of seasons past, the acknowledgment of a triumphant 1997 takes in the innovativeness essential to an artistic director's calling. Ms. Mann's mission, ever more accomplished, is the very model of regional theater leadership. For it reflects a body of work, a force, an aura that has nothing to do with the success (or failure) of any single production.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ROBERT L.
description: FELDMAN-Robert L., M.D., The Mount Sinai Alumni records with sorrow the loss of their longtime colleague and friend. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary

title: The Lives They Lived: Jolie Gabor; Mother Dahling
description: b. 1900 She wanted to be an actress but ended up running a successful costume-jewelry business. Her most stunning achievements, however, were her three daughters, Magda, Eva and Zsa Zsa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTTON, IONE U.
description: SUTTON-Ione U. January 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George W. Sutton, Jr. Loving sister of Alice Ulrich Jennings of Lansing, MI. Devoted aunt of Richard L. Spaulding, John Jennings, David Jennings, Robert Jennings, Eleanore McGrain and Helen Lockwood. Her career spanned many years in New York in both the Wall Street community and as Treasurer of the Museum of Modern Art. The family will receive friends on Tuesday, January 6, 1998, 3-5 and 6-8 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Memorial service Wednesday, January 7, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Contemporary yet Classic: Fine Craftsmanship for Everyday Functions
description: GAIL M. BROWN is an independent curator who for several years has been on a mission to provide contemporary American decorative artists with as much exposure as possible. To enhance her crusade, she has organized ''Artful Crafts That Work,'' a fascinating exhibition featuring 50 functional objects by 12 artists who, she said, ''communicate the spirit of unbridled, unrestrained imagination.''

title: A Lure for Athletes and Pilgrims
description: WHEN athletes and spectators pour, as they soon will, into the city of Nagano, the host of the Olympic Winter Games, they will encounter snowy mountain ranges, a live volcano and the chance to experience death and rebirth -- symbolically -- in one of Japan's greatest Buddhist temples. The temple is supposed to bring a lifetime of good luck, and its underground vault is the only cultural site in Japan that my children count as a rival in significance to Tokyo Disneyland.

title: The Enola Gay Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, ETHEL WENDELL
description: MITCHELL-Ethel Wendell. Of Darien, CT. on December 22, 1997. Wife of the late Richard Henry Mitchell, Jr. Mother of Wendy Hoyt Mitchell Horton and Judith Wendell Mitchell Prohaska. Grandmother of two. Funeral Service at St. Luke's church, Darien, CT., on Monday, January 5, 1998 at 11 A.M. Interment Spring Grove Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 1175 Post Rd. E. Westport, CT. 06880.

title: College Credit for Helping Others
description: THE postcard-pretty campus of Sarah Lawrence College here, with its neo-Gothic buildings and landscaping, is not the only place where a senior, Benjamin Provo, has pursued his studies. Mr. Provo, a theater major, worked with schoolchildren in the Yonkers public schools as a requirement of his academic program and received credit for it.

title: Ships Upon Untamed Seas
