title: Deals and Discounts
description: RIVIERA CRUISES -- Windstar Cruises is offering two-for-one fares on its summer French and Italian Riviera cruises on board the new sail cruiser Wind Surf. Reservations for the special offer must be made by Feb. 28. The half-price fares are $2,368 a person, double occupancy, including port taxes and fees, making the total for two people in a stateroom $4,736. There are 21 sailings in the program, departing from May 9 through Sept. 26. The itinerary departs Nice on Saturday and visits Portofino, Portoferraio and Portovenere, Italy; Monte Carlo; Cannes, and St.- Tropez. The 312-passenger Wind Surf, which begins service May 2, will have an alternative restaurant with rotisserie dining, and a spa that occupies nearly 10,000 square feet. In late December, the sailings departing May 23 and May 30 were nearly full. Reservations: (800) 258-7245.

title: The Lives They Lived: Bernard Vonnegut; The Rainmaker
description: b. 1914 Fifty years ago, Vonnegut, a physicist, discovered a cloud-seeding method for prompting rain that is still used to control drought. He was also an expert in other meteorological phenomena, including lightning, thunder and tornadoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, RUTH (NEE ANHANG)
description: SCHNEIDER-Ruth (nee Anhang). It is with great sadness that we record the passing of Ruth Schneider in New York on December 10, 1997 (11 Kislev 5758) after a 28year battle with scleroderma. Despite the near-constant pain and suffering, she courageously and with great determination led an active and productive life and taught in Winnipeg, Toronto, Israel and New York. She is survived by her loving and devoted husband Dr. Samuel Schneider, her loving children Solomon Bernard and Stephanie Cheryl, her loving mother Mina of Toronto and three loving brothers, William of Montreal, Jacob of Toronto and Abraham of Winnipeg, and their families. She was laid to rest in Toronto on December 12, 1997. She will be deeply missed and never forgotten. Contributions may be made to the Scleroderma Federation, New York University Medical Center and Yeshiva University.

title: Black-White: Everyday Slights
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: Magdalena the Sinner

title: TECHNOLOGY; Conventions Without Travel
description: A two-day academic conference at Drake University, ''Contemporary Theory and the World Wide Web,'' will not meet in Des Moines until November. But in the virtual world, the conference has begun a year early.

title: Sports of The Times; So What Was It, Exactly, That Michigan Did That Was Wrong?
description: THE coaches broke the rule, or whatever it was. Admittedly, it was an unwritten guideline, but those radicals, those free-thinkers, those bomb throwers, those long-haired anti-establishment types, those anarchists, collectively busted it.

title: EAGER AND FLUSH, MANY STATES PLAN YET MORE TAX CUTS
description: With the economy refusing to cool, with most states sitting on sizable surpluses and with gubernatorial and legislative elections scheduled in a majority of states, tax-cut fever is once again sweeping the land as legislatures prepare to open their 1998 sessions.

title: The World; One Korean Certainty: No More Business as Usual
description: AN age-old Korean practice, common among housewives, draws together a group of acquaintances to pool their cash savings and trust one among them to manage the pool profitably. Often, that means providing the money to a credit-starved business at a high interest rate.

title: The Lives They Lived: Albert Shanker; Labor's Love Lost
description: b. 1928 He recalled hearing ''about Roosevelt, Churchill and Hitler'' while growing up. ''I'd think about all they'd done and then invent roles for myself in history.'' In time, Shanker created his own role. He became one of this century's greatest labor organizers.

title: Elizabeth Stewart And Rob Bragin
description: Elizabeth Stewart, the daughter of Myo Stewart of Rosslyn, Va., and Dr. James J. Stewart of Stuttgart, Germany, is to be married today to Rob Bragin, a son of Beatrice and Irving Bragin of Lakewood, Calif. Rabbi Stanley Levy is to officiate at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: Blackboard: Registration; Who Wants to Visit The Bursar, Anyway?
description: Typical scenario for registration at a typical college: stand in line to pick courses and hope they are still available when your turn comes; stand in another line to get the tuition bill, and another to pay it. Financial aid? Another line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLON, JOSE ''TONY''
description: COLON-Jose ''Tony''. December 31, 1997. Past President of EAL Metro Chapter, Exec. Board Kennedy Democrats, Exec. Board Queens Valley Home Owners, Past Adjutant VFW, Albertson, LI. IAM Shop Steward, JFK. Survived by his beloved wife Gloria, sons John and Richard and their families. Viewing today at Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, from 3-8 PM. Service Monday 10 A.M., Queen of Peace R.C. Church, Flushing.

title: Report of Officers' Role in Subway Death Is Challenged
description: Three witnesses have rebutted allegations that six New York City police detectives chased a Crown Heights man inside a Brooklyn subway station last month shortly before he ran in front of an oncoming train, a law enforcement official close to the case said yesterday.

title: Steelers Lose Gamble, But Win Game Anyway
description: Bill Cowher knew it was a dumb gamble moments after he called for it: an attempted dive into the end zone, with his Pittsburgh Steelers nursing a 1-point lead and needing just a field goal to all but clinch a playoff victory over the New England Patriots.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  A.T.H.
description: A.T.H. Your 75th birthday. I miss you. Our love abides. H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, MARJORIE
description: FRANK-Marjorie. On January 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Leonard, devoted mother of Steven and Robert and daughters-inlaw Diane and Jeannie. Cherished grandmother of Tracey, Lorie, Erin and Lisa. Services Monday, 2:45 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Testing and Repairing Door Chimes
description: IT is not particularly difficult to troubleshoot door-chime malfunctions, because the components are simple and the system operates on low voltage.

title: A Year Of Peaks, Valleys, Lessons
description: Who would have thought it? The New York Giants go from last to first place in the National Football Conference East, making the playoffs with first-round home-field advantage. Who would have thought it? The New York Giants lose in the first round with home-field advantage.

title: The Lives They Lived: Allen Ginsberg; Birth of a Beatnik
description: b. 1926 He was the modern Walt Whitman -- he heard America singing, swearing, howling, going mad. He sang of himself: gay, spiritual, funny, crude, shocking, wise. He was a popular poet when poetry wasn't popular in America.

title: Blackboard: Gray Matter; Retired Professors Found a College For Their Peers
description: Northfield, Minn., is home to an unusual brain trust: among its 14,700 residents are about 150 retired professors, many from Carleton College and St. Olaf College, both in town.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Sports of The Times; Paradise's Refrigerator: Lambeau Is More Than Tradition
description: WHEN the Tampa Bay Buccaneers knew they would be here today, Coach Tony Dungy talked about how they were going up to Green Bay to play the Packers ''at Lambeau Field.'' Pro football coaches and players usually mention traveling to play in a city, not a stadium. But when they're coming to Green Bay, they almost always add ''at Lambeau Field,'' their voices deep with dread.

title: The War's Human Side
description: Alongside the exhibition of Mort Kunstler's Civil War paintings, the Nassau County Museum of Art will explore the human side of the war through artifacts and memorabilia. Long Island's role will be highlighted through poignant documents like the letter written by a soldier, John Carman, sent home to Merrick. ''I am tired of a soldier's life,'' he wrote, ''and I want to get to Long Island.''

title: Washington Monument To Undergo Restoration
description: The Washington Monument will be closed for several months beginning Jan. 12 for the installation of a new elevator and other improvements, the first step in a two-year restoration that will be the most extensive since its opening in 1888.

title: The Lives They Lived: Alexandra Danilova; Master Class
description: b. 1903 Alexandra Danilova, whose nickname was Choura, emigrated from Russia with George Balanchine and was his inspiration for Terpsichore in ''Apollon Musagete'' in 1928 -- a work that changed the face of classical dance. Danilova, also a noted teacher, was on the faculty of the School of American Ballet, a New York City Ballet training ground, from 1964 to 1989.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Lifting Weights, Not a Glass
description: THE SETTING: It is barely an hour into 1998. Uptown is partying, but near City Hall the streets are desolate. The only real sign of life is on the third floor of a tenement on Park Place, where Hardcore Muscle is open, as it always is, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.

title: ON THE MAP; A Factory Where Explosives That Won Two Wars Were Made
description: Today it is a landscape of disuse: a patchwork of weedy, dilapidated buildings and woods where deer and wild turkey graze.

title: N.B.A. Violence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, ALAN
description: BANKS-Alan. Dancer, choreographer, teacher. Died December 29, 1997. He is survived by his beloved brothers and sisters-in-law Morris and Janet Dittman, Jack and Anita Dittman and his loving nieces Arlene Dittman and Elaine Mack.

title: Wendy Hu, Daniel Frost
description: Wenlan Hu and Dr. Daniel Allen Frost were married on Thursday at Jerusalem Lutheran Church in Columbiana, Ohio. The Rev. W. David H. Conrad performed the ceremony.

title: Why Not Keep Schools Open on All Holidays?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Heady Mix Of Beethoven And Business
description: AT THE FRONT OF THE PROGRAM BOOK FOR A new recording of Beethoven piano concertos stands a cognac ad. ''Hennessy and Music: Perfection in Harmony,'' reads the headline; two paragraphs expanding on that theme follow. Art and commerce meet again. They always will.

title: Owner Has Mixed Emotions
description: COYOTES 2, ISLANDERS 1

title: PRO BASKETBALL: On the Day After Their Showdown, the Knicks Win and the Nets Lose; Kemp Gives Van Horn A Lesson
description: The Nets are certain there will be many more nights like Friday night, when Keith Van Horn was brilliant in rallying New Jersey past the Knicks.

title: Robin Uris, Timothy Ireland
description: Robin Nancy Uris, the daughter of Jean Lloyd Insolia of Salem, S.C., and Robert G. Uris of Moorestown, N.J., was married on Friday to Timothy Ireland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Ireland of East Fallowfield, Pa. The Very Rev. Richard S. Wyzykiewicz performed the ceremony at the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul in Philadelphia.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: INSIDE THE TITANIC. By Hugh Brewster. Illustrated by Ken Marschall. Madison Press/ Little, Brown. $18.95. (Ages 5 and up) This large-format illustrated account of the Titanic is told through the experiences of two boys on board who survived. The artist has been painting the ship for years and was a consultant on the current film.

title: A Work in Progress
description: MARK'S VILLAGE INN is under renovation, and therefore still a work in progress. But the steaming Irish soda bread, interesting wines, and first-rate lamb suggest a kitchen in perfect working order.

title: Niners Make a Statement by Pounding Vikings
description: The 49ers have existed almost in the shadows in recent weeks, as they breezed through their cotton-soft division schedule and as the Green Bay Packers evolved into the team to beat. San Francisco has home-field advantage through the playoffs, and more Pro Bowlers than a grocery store has heads of lettuce, but the team is talked about as if it is only a matter of time before it loses to the Packers.

title: Good Things Can Also Come In Annoying Packages
description: JANUARY IS THE CRUELEST month for the record producer who specializes in historical reissues. He goes to endless pains to put together a scrupulously researched, lavishly appointed boxed set containing the Complete Recordings of Artist X. It arrives in the stores just in time for Christmas, and within days the air is blue with the curses of irate perfectionists for whom nothing is ever good enough. (What happened to the unreleased alternate take of the 1954 remake of ''My Funny Valentine''? Why wasn't Artist Y chosen instead?)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEMAN, DANIEL E.
description: APPLEMAN-Daniel E. January 2, 1998. Director of the Cranbrook Institute of Science in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan. Survived by his wife Peggy, his daughter Rebecca, his brothers Michael and Gerald, and their families. Memorial Service at a later date. Tributes may be made to the Cranbrook Institute of Science or the charity of choice.

title: Home Lessons For Children Ready to Read
description: I knew that education had a way to go in this country when I heard of a third-grade teacher who told a gathering of parents that she was transforming their children into avid writers by making writing fun and leaving it to the parents to drill spelling and grammar.

title: Ideas & Trends; Why Pedestrians Play Chicken to Cross the Road
description: IT says something about New York City that while street barricades are erected in other countries by aroused citizens against the police, the barricades here are put up by the police against the pedestrian.

title: Rent-a-Thin-Blue-Line
description: Car 54, where are you? Thanks to a shooting boom in New York -- the shooting of movies and television shows, not crime victims -- casting agents are receiving lots of requests for police officers to step before the cameras. The requests are for real officers, not actors.

title: The Lives They Lived: Ben Hogan; The Pain In Perfection
description: b. 1912 Considered by many to be the finest player in the history of golf, Ben Hogan, who started life as the son of a Texas blacksmith, went on to win four U.S. Opens, two Masters tournaments, two P.G.A. championships and one British Open.

title: The View From/Hastings-on-Hudson; Toys That Do More Than Merely Amuse
description: THIS is the time of year when children are playing with their holiday toys, but there is a group of youngsters for whom the mere act of being able to play at all is something of a miracle.

title: STUDENT LIFE: Headlines From the Fall Semester; Howard Women March
description: When 250 women boarded five Howard University buses heading to Philadelphia, their participation in the Million Woman March was recorded by a contingent of reporters from the campus newspaper, The Hilltop. The paper published a special women's issue, which included a dozen articles on the march.

title: New and Noteworthy in a Flood of Catalogues
description: OUT of the holidays, into the catalogue season, with page after enticing page to dazzle the winter-bound gardener. How to sort them all out?

title: Blackboard: Lessons of Rehab; Better Learning Through Chemistry
description: CAN a 45-year-old felon transform her life simply by learning chemistry?

title: SOAPBOX; Population Bomb
description: NEW JERSEY is the most densely populated state in the country, with more than 1,000 people per square mile. Population density is far from evenly distributed, however, ranging from 188 per square mile in Salem County to 12,023 in Hudson County. Twelve counties have densities below the state average, and eight -- Sussex, Warren, Hunterdon, Burlington, Salem, Cape May, Cumberland and Atlantic -- have densities under 500. These are the ''rural and environmentally sensitive areas'' noted in the State Plan. If we are to maintain a diversity of land uses and life styles in our state, these areas must be protected to balance the above-average densities elsewhere. The purported goal of the State Plan is to prevent sprawl, meaning the migration of jobs and population from urban to rural counties.

title: The Lives They Lived: Karl F. Koopman; Batman
description: b. 1920 Curator emeritus at the American Museum of Natural History, Koopman was the most knowledgeable bat expert of his time.

title: Ceci Neumann, Robert Conklin
description: Cecilia Mari Neumann, a daughter of Kathleen and Gerard A. Neumann of Saddle River, N.J., was married on New Year's Eve to Robert Ward Conklin, the son of Gertrude and Robert E. Conklin of Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Bennett A. Brockman performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Databases Are Building For Political Shifts of 2002
description: KURT C. SCHLICHTING, a sociology professor at Fairfield University, sat at the computer in his tiny office and played king, reapportioning the state's Congressional districts to demonstrate MapInfo, a software program used in marketing that also has political applications.

title: American Weaver Revives Old Laotian Art
description: Among the more exotic casualties of the Indochina war, the long-nosed lion-elephant, the eternal Naga serpent and the magical Mom bird appeared to be on the verge of extinction in Laos.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Feud Over Judicial Nominees
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist rebuked the Senate for failing to move quickly enough in confirming Federal judges. In his annual year-end report on of the state of the judiciary, the Chief Justice said continuing inaction on nominees was threatening an overburdened court system. Nearly 1 in 10 seats on the Federal bench are now vacant, Mr. Rehnquist said. Orrin G. Hatch, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, defended the Senate's performance and said the courts themselves were partly to blame for their heavy caseloads.

title: Hispanic Program Celebrates Holiday Of Three Kings Day
description: WITH Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa taken care of, there remains Three Kings Day. The New Rochelle Public Library is celebrating the Hispanic holiday Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. with a free program of Latin American songs and dances performed by the Alma Solana Troupe. There will be post-concert refreshments and a chance for children to try their luck at breaking the pinata.

title: Latter-Day Saints
description: MOTHER TERESA Beyond the Image. By Anne Sebba. Illustrated. 297 pp. New York: Doubleday. $24.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREITZER, SHIRLEY WOLFF COHEN
description: DREITZER-Shirley Wolff Cohen. The Directors of the Dreitzer Foundation express sadness at the death of our co-director. We extend our sympathy to her daughters Stephanie and Kathleen and to the entire family. Judith D. Wallach, Chair

title: Classy Parcells
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Airline Seats
description: To the Editor: Your headline, ''Two Airlines Installing More-Comfortable Seats'' (Nov. 9), is a terrible tease. Halfway through the article, after we've been told that ''American and United put most of their efforts into their premium seats, in business and first class,'' comes the coup de grace for the majority of travelers: ''What the airlines are not doing is increasing the legroom in coach.''

title: POSTINGS: Brochure Demystifies Restoration Rule; Getting Approval To Fix a Landmark
description: Help is at hand for owners of landmarked properties daunted by the Restoration Rule (Section 2-17c, Title 63: The Rules of the City of New York) when it comes to restoring anything from facades to finials. Or for that matter, anyone interested in turning into an architectural sleuth.

title: Mexico's Interior Minister Is Replaced in Aftermath of Massacre
description: A massacre in an Indian township that provoked nationwide outrage rattled Mexico again today as President Ernesto Zedillo replaced his Interior Minister, ordering his successor to to find a ''sure process for peace'' in the southern state where the killings took place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYNE, SYLVIA
description: MAYNE-Sylvia. We mourn the untimely passing of our longtime cooperator, Sylvia. Our condolences to Gary and Ron. We'll miss her smiling face. The Sandpiper at Westhampton Beach, Inc. Judy Rosenblum, President

title: Blackboard: Mouse Pals; For Student Teachers, Virtual Friends
description: Student teachers are often among the loneliest people in academia, wiping an endless succession of runny noses and sharing lunch hours with their young charges. In the course of a day, there are few opportunities to share ideas, commiserate or just socialize that come without repeated rounds of telephone tag with professors or supervisors.

title: Mr. Break-It And Mr. Fix-It
description: Twenty-five years ago today, New York newspapers reported the purchase of the Yankees by a group of out-of-towners whose leader proclaimed: ''I won't be active in the day-to-day operations of the club at all. I can't spread myself so thin. I've got enough headaches with my shipping company.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, ALEXANDRA
description: MORGAN-Alexandra, 20. Interment, Jan. 6, 3PM, Lakeview Cemetery; service 4PM, First Presbyterian Church, New Canaan.

title: 'Paintings in the Little,' Showcases of an Intricate Art Form
description: MINIATURE paintings make demands. They invite close scrutiny and, en masse, draw viewers into their world.

title: Ms. Prendergast, Mr. Rubenstein
description: Amy P. Prendergast, the daughter of Nancy Prendergast of Park Ridge, N.J., and John Prendergast of West Caldwell, N.J., was married in New York last evening to Richard M. Rubenstein, a son of Amy and Howard Rubenstein, both of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: The Lives They Lived: Murray Kempton; Gentleman Of the Press
description: b. 1917 As a prize-winning columnist for The New York Post and, later, New York Newsday, Murray Kempton brought incongruous elegance to the city beat.

title: Channels, Channels Everywhere, but . . .
description: WITH another hundred or thousand cable channels arriving on everybody's television set any minute now, programmers are assuredly at work cloning proven audience pleasers to fill up the spaces. The shows, which can be quickly reproduced by child labor in Hollywood sweatshops, should run forever if they have not already run forever. The quality may be a little ragged, but the ratings are guaranteed.

title: China, the Oldest Culture, in Mega-Tomes
description: THE first book in a projected 75-volume series on Chinese culture being published by Yale University Press in New Haven is described by staffers there as an effort to pierce China's other great wall, that of Western neglect for the world's longest-lived culture.

title: Some Forget, but Titanic Was City-Bound
description: THE world's most famous shipwreck lives on in a Broadway show, a Hollywood blockbuster, and, of course, that silent, freezing hulk at the bottom of the sea off Newfoundland. But there are also reminders of the Titanic, and of the gripping effect its sinking had on New York, in various spots around the city.

title: Billion-Dollar Louvre Project Nears Completion
description: THE inauguration of I. M. Pei's glass pyramid at the Louvre Museum in 1989 was such a watershed that it seemed hard to imagine that it marked only the first stage of a $1.2 billion project to modernize the great palace of art. Still ahead lay a task that was less visually spectacular than the pyramid, but no less important to the Louvre -- refurbishing and expanding its galleries and reorganizing its immense collection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, REVERA (REVA) MYERS
description: HIRSCH-Revera (Reva) Myers. Died at 94 in Tucson, AZ. Formerly of Lawrence, NY. Widow of Dr. Sidney Hirsch. Loving mother of Dr. Robert and Harriet and Ann and Dr. Burton Sklarin. Beloved grandmother of Julie and Tom Brown, David Hirsch, Laurie and Matt Ember, Richard and Debbie Sklarin, Dr. Peter and Ila Sklarin and beloved great-grandmother of Sydney and Jamie Ember, Jeffrey and Adam Sklarin, Emma and Samuel Sklarin and Renee and William Brown. Sister of Hilda Myers Podoloff and the late Dr. Harvey Myers. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERSON, LOUISE ASTOR VAN ALEN
description: SAUNDERSON-Louise Astor Van Alen. December 30, 1997 in Santa Barbara, CA. Born 1910 in New York City. Daughter of the late James L. Van Alen and Margaret Post Van Alen Bruguiere. She is survived by Alexander Saunderson, her beloved husband of 50 years; a brother, William L. Van Alen; 3 nephews, James Langley Van Alen, William L. Van Alen, Jr., and James Laurens Van Alen, II, and a niece, Cassandra Ludington. Her loving nature and wit brightened the lives of everyone she knew. A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M. on January 9 at All Saints by the Sea Episcopal Church in Montecito. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Music Academy of the West, 1070 Fairway Road, Santa Barbara, CA 93108.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about places that opened or closed in 1997 referred incorrectly to the Elk Candy Company. It closed in March at 240 East 86th Street but reopened in November at 1628 Second Avenue, near 84th Street.

title: Topics of The Times; 007 Won't Take American Express
description: Now that the trade in movie-related lunch boxes, dolls, sunglasses, albums and anything else creative minds can think of has become a multibillion-dollar industry, it is probably only a matter of time before Hollywood bestows an Oscar on the most brazen movie tie-in product. One formidable nominee debuts tomorrow, when the Bank of Scotland introduces a James Bond Visa card.

title: Friends Say Ferraro Seeks D'Amato Seat
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro has told friends she will seek the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato this year, her supporters said yesterday.

title: The Lives They Lived: Doc Cheatham; Doc's Trumpet and Me
description: b. 1905 Over eight decades, Adolphus (Doc) Cheatham played jazz with everyone from Bessie Smith to Billie Holiday. But it wasn't until his 70's that he became a star in his own right.

title: Parents Win Long Fight as Program for Gifted Is Restored
description: Ever since it was announced two years ago that the popular program for gifted students at P.S. 9 on 84th Street and Columbus Avenue would be dismantled, parents have fought the plan. They have held candlelight vigils, staged protests, conducted letter-writing campaigns and testified at school board meetings.

title: Q and A
description: World War II Bombers

title: Jennifer Allan, Simon Kassabian
description: Jennifer Nicole Allan and Dr. Simon George Kassabian were married on Friday in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. The Rev. Lawrence McDonnell performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Food; Bay Watch
description: In the past, when fate, conquest or immigration threw disparate cultures together, their cuisines would circle each other like cats. Each would flaunt its appearance and obvious attributes. And over time, they might form a nodding acquaintance. But it could take generations, sometimes centuries, before they would share each other's cooking secrets.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Regional Bells Gain Ground In Long-Distance Wars
description: A Federal judge in Texas attacked the core of the 1996 act that deregulated the telecommunications industry. The judge ruled that major sections of the law were unconstitutional because they made it particularly difficult for the regional Bell telephone companies to sell long-distance services. If the ruling withstands appeals by the Government, it could allow the Bells to connect long-distance calls for the first time since the 1984 breakup of AT&T. SETH SCHIESEL

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Dec. 21 about Durham Cathedral in England described a door knocker incorrectly. It is a copy of a brass knocker made in 1140; the original is on display in the cathedral's treasury.

title: The Lives They Lived: Carl Maxey; Type-A Gandhi
description: b. 1924 Maxey learned the insults of prejudice firsthand and, as a civil rights lawyer in Spokane, Wash., set out to correct them. He had settled there as a young lawyer after a Dickensian childhood; he raised his family there, and committed suicide there, in June.

title: Welcoming The Future
description: A new year and debutante balls are reasons to celebrate.

title: Russia's Church-Run Campus Has a Secular Goal
description: In the cozy top floor of the Vysoko Petrovsky monastery, where Russian Orthodox monks once immersed themselves in ancient manuscripts, Natasha Nikolayeva and her classmates were taking their final exams in Russian housing law recently. The icons that adorn the walls of the tiny lecture room comforted Ms. Nikolayeva, who came from Ukraine to study here.

title: 3 Views on Jews In Great Neck
description: The Rev. Gary Maier, of All Saints Episcopal Church on Middle Neck Road, commented that the building of new synagogues in Great Neck helped convince many of his parishioners to move ''out of town to places like Locust Valley and Lattingtown'' because ''they felt they were in a ghetto here.'' Webster's defines ghetto as, ''In certain European cities, a section to which Jews are, or were, restricted; the word is also applied, often in an unfriendly sense, to any section to which many Jews live.''

title: The Original 'Valley' Girl
description: IN 1963, recovering from a radical mastectomy and 44 years old, Jacqueline Susann made a pact with God: Give me another 10 years to become a best-selling author and I'll die in peace. God was more than generous. In the next 11 years, not only did three of Susann's books land on the top of the best-seller list, but the first of them, ''Valley of the Dolls'' (1966), with sales of 29 million, ranks with the Bible as one of the most widely distributed books of all time. Susann, however, didn't live up to her end of the bargain. Once she had fame, she wanted respect, and respect was much harder to come by. Critics attributed the astonishing success of ''Valley'' to relentless marketing. Susann herself, with her skintight pink and purple Pucci outfits, spiky false eyelashes, gutter mouth and crass careerism, was considered something of a joke in literary circles. Truman Capote called her a truck driver in drag, and then apologized to truck drivers. An article in Harper's ventured that she was ''a national phenomenon and we are stuck with her.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOWENS, BERNARD H.
description: STOWENS-Bernard H., 81. Died Dec. 31, 1997 in NYC, peacefully in his sleep. Born April 11, 1916 in NYC, he attended CCNY and Johns Hopkins University. During W.W. II, he worked as a physicist on the Manhattan Project at Oak Ridge, TN., and later helped in the development of the earliest computers and computer projects at Sperry Rand Corp. Became a V.P. at Dunlap and Associates, and worked for Scientific Time Sharing and Shearson Lehman before retiring at 79. A Renaissance man, quiet and extremely intelligent, he loved new technology and computer programs, acting, physics and mathematics, music, literature, building and repairing things, theater, opera, ballet, the visual arts and poetry. Married in 1941, he is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Doris, devoted children, Susan and David, brother and sisterin-law Daniel and Lamya Stowens, sister-in-law Gladys Dubovsky, brother-in-law and sister-in-law Herbert and Simone Dubow, and many other friends and family members. Losing him will leave an emptiness in our lives and in the lives of everyone who knew him. He was a wonderful human being and we will always remember him with love. Memorial service Sun., Jan. 11, 2:45PM, Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St, NYC.

title: Brodeur Reappears To Spark the Devils
description: DEVILS 4, MAPLE LEAFS 2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DOROTHY
description: MILLER-Dorothy. On January 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving stepmother of Ira, Martin and Jerry. Dear stepgrandmother and step-greatgrandmother. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her name can be made to Plays For Living, Inc., NYC.

title: The Lives They Lived: Alfred D. Hershey; Hershey Heaven
description: b. 1908 In his famous ''blender experiment'' of 1952, the biologist Al Hershey provided a crucial link to the understanding of DNA's role in carrying genetic information. Taciturn and never given to self-promotion, he always believed that the experiment was the thing.

title: Five Characters in Search of an Ending
description: THIS is going to be an interesting year for Cynthia Fromer, Melva Max, Jonathan Phillips, Ginnie Gardiner, Gerard Papa and their fans.

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; Advice on Starting the Day Off Right
description: Marilyn S. Hirsch, a nutritional consultant in North Brunswick, recommends a regal approach to the morning meal. ''It's the old saying, eat breakfast like a king, lunch like a prince, and dinner like a pauper,'' said Ms. Hirsch, who has been telling clients how to eat for 21 years. The problem, Ms. Hirsch said, is that, ''people in this county do just the opposite.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMINA, ROSEMARIE
description: DIMINA-Rosemarie. On December 27, 1997. Cherokee Village, AR. Formerly of College Point, Queens. Beloved wife of Frank, mother of Thomas and Jack Dean, Ursula Hoskins and Frank Dimina II. Grandmother of Erin Dean. Memorials to: ''Lutheran Women's Missionary League'' 800252-5965. Service in late January, at St. John's Lutheran Church, College Point (718-463-4790).

title: The Nation; The Age of the Sage (Or Is It Money Talking?)
description: NAPOLEON really ought to have been an American, because no society has ever gone as weak at the knees over people with titanic egos. Chutzpah and the love of celebrity have always been big with us, and luckily, from the days of Miles Standish, there have been plenty of both.

title: A Refrain for Volatile Times: I'm Buying for the Long Term
description: The reverberation of Asia's problems into other markets around the world has made the past year exceeding difficult for investors in emerging-market funds.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; State Must Stay Competitive
description: REMEMBER the ''vision thing,'' President Bush's awkward description of why political leaders should prove they are thinking beyond the next election? Well, as Gov. George E. Pataki heads into 1998, the year he will defend his record, he has an opportunity to demonstrate his grasp of the vision thing for New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, JANE S. (NEE ROSENBLUM)
description: POLLACK-Jane S. (nee Rosenblum), on January 1, of Short Hills, N.J., beloved wife of Dr. Harold A. Pollack, devoted mother of Kerri and Kevin Pollack, dear sister of Richard Rosenblum, loving daughter of Marjorie and the late Leo Rosenblum. Funeral services at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, N.J. on Sunday, January 4 at 2:15 P.M. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, N.J. Donations may be made to Jane S. Pollack Memorial Fund, payable to University of Pennsylvania, Trustees' Council of Penn Women, 3533 Locust Walk, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6226.

title: The Nation: Trial and Error; The Client's Always Right. Even if He's Not.
description: THEODORE J. KACZYNSKI, the hermit standing trial on charges that he is the Unabomber, has told his defense team that he believes satellites control people and place electrodes in their brains. He himself is controlled by an omnipotent organization which he is powerless to resist, he told the lawyers. So it was with some reluctance that they finally agreed last week not to mount an insanity defense.

title: Crime in Mexico
description: To the Editor: I read the article on crime in Mexico City with disbelief. In 1978, on my third trip there, my pocket was picked on a crowded city bus: my tightly held, albeit canvas, purse was slit from behind. In addition to my passport, credit cards, driver's license and traveler's checks, the thieves got my return airline tickets and tourist visa. The bureaucracy kept me in the country far longer than anticipated. When my lamentation to the newspaper Excelsior was published, I received dozens of letters from Mexico offering sympathy and pleas not to judge Mexicans by my experience. I did not, and have returned many times.

title: Maturing Prodigies Gear Up for the Long Haul
description: YOUTH IS WASTED ON THE young, it is said. But such has never been the case in music. Think of Mozart, if no one else. The truth is, audiences love prodigies and always have.

title: A Slow Way Back
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed William Borders's evading the shocking truth that he was walking to Dover Plains when he reserved a room at the Old Drovers' Inn (''Out for a Walk, From 57th Street to Connecticut,'' Nov. 23). To hike the Appalachian Trail, my husband went to a local travel agency to book the train to Gainesville, Ga. (the nearest station to the trail's southern end at Springer Mountain). The travel agent asked, ''And when should I book a return?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, ETHEL C. (NEE COHEN)
description: PHILLIPS-Ethel C. (nee Cohen). On December 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Lloyd Jay; loving mother of L. James (Mary Ann) and Anne; dear grandmother of L. Jeffrey and Lindsey. Memorial service Tuesday, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, NYC. Contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: For Love or Money
description: Last year's ''Washington Square'' has yet to reach TV, and who needs it? Not with THE HEIRESS (1949), William Wylers's retitled, superlative version of Henry James's novel and its Broadway adaptation by Ruth and Augustus Goetz. On a brilliantly technical tapestry of Old Manhattan -- in photography, decor and costuming -- this bitter tale of a plain maiden, her coldly protective father and a greedy young suitor throbs to life, with Olivia de Havilland, Ralph Richardson and Montgomery Clift. Not to mention the stunning musical score by Aaron Copland. -- SUNDAY at 2 P.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: The Lives They Lived: Jacques Cousteau; Dive, He Said
Our Towns; Watching 'Megan's Law' In Practice
description: THE last time Rudy Hopkins let someone stay at his house, few people noticed. After 30 years of this, no one kept track. Most likely, it was just another of Rudy's persons-in-need, a stray teen-ager, probably, who had run away from home or drugs or trouble.

title: A Return to Vietnam to Visit the Ghosts of War
description: IN June 1965, a confused 27-year-old addressed a letter to Lyndon B. Johnson, asking the President why he was about to be shipped to Vietnam.

title: The 92d Street Y and a Vacant Lot Go Up Against History
description: When the 92d Street Y spent $1.05 million in late 1996 for a vacant lot on East 92d Street near Lexington Avenue, neighborhood residents were curious about the community center's plans for that prime spot in the middle of the Carnegie Hill historic district.

title: Ms. Dyer, Mr. Knoblauch
description: Diana Gurnee Dyer and Loring Ward Knoblauch Jr. were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, Conn. The Rev. Robert L. Ficks 3d performed the ceremony.

title: The Neediest Cases; Immigrant's Medical Career Is Now Just a Memory
description: George Petrenko comes from a long line of doctors. His grandfather was a surgeon, his grandmother was a psychiatrist and his mother was a dermatologist. Most of his relatives in Ukraine are physicians, as well.

title: U.N. Discord Is Music to Iraq and a Threat To Security Council Credibility.
description: With the United Nations' chief weapons inspector going to Iraq in two weeks for another round of negotiations over Baghdad's refusal to allow full access to suspect sites, the Security Council appears to be more paralyzed than it has been on any other issue since the end of the cold war.

title: New York, New York
description: This year, New York City's five boroughs celebrate the centennial of their consolidation into the greater metropolis. Test your knowledge of some of the places, people and events associated with the city.

title: Niche Providers Out of the Shadow of Megamanagers
description: AT a time when big Wall Street houses are acquiring smaller rivals to build the critical mass they believe is needed to compete, two highly regarded managers have chosen to follow the David model, not the Goliath.

title: Habitats/33 Mercer Street; Finding a Buyer for a Loft: In the End, It Was Karma
description: PATTI BELLANTONI was living in California and feeling desperate. Her SoHo loft -- zoned for artists only -- had been unoccupied and on the market for over a year with three real estate brokers.

title: Rutgers Studying Expectations Of Expectant Mothers
description: Two Rutgers University professors are trying to determine what changes first-time mothers-to-be expect in their lives and how their expectations meet with reality once they have given birth.

title: The Parent Trap
description: When Mothers Work

title: Exploring Busoni, As Anchored by Bach Or Slightly at Sea
description: A CENTURY AGO IN Berlin, the young Arthur Rubinstein played for many of the leading musicians -- Josef Hofmann, Joseph Joachim -- but he regretted to the end of his days that he did not play for Ferruccio Busoni. ''He was the one person who might have oriented my talent in a better direction -- a man with a broad view, both artistically and culturally, a genuinely great human being,'' Rubinstein wrote in his memoirs. He called Busoni ''a shining example to all musicians for the noble way in which he pursued his career so uncompromisingly, for the high standards he set for his own compositions and for his general culture, so rare among artists.''

title: Here Comes Everyman
description: PURSUIT OF A WOMAN ON THE HINGE

title: Christine McMaster, Stephen Sander
description: Christine McMaster and Stephen Marc Sander were married last Sunday on the island of Hawaii. The Rev. Mary Alice Rubin, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Kona Village Resort in Kailua-Kona.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 4, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Infertile Foreigners See Opportunity in U.S.
description: Raelene, a 34-year-old Australian whose ovaries were ruined by cancer treatments, tried for two years to find a woman in Australia who would donate eggs to her. But to no avail.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Winner by a Neck

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: Tropic of Orange By Karen Tei Yamashita. Coffee House Press, paper, $14.95.

title: The Formula for Sun City Moves East and North
description: THE first commercial developments are rising outside the gates of the sprawling Sun City retirement community here, three years after Del Webb Corporation started building its only East Coast venture.

title: Who's No. 1? Results Are in, and They're Split
description: Tom Osborne celebrated a championship in his pajamas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANZER, RITA MAY (NEE KOTIN)
description: GLANZER-Rita May (nee Kotin). Thursday, January 1, 1998, at Fairfax Hospital. Wife of Seymour D. Glanzer, mother of Lawrence (Mary Anne) Glanzer and JoAyn Glanzer; sister of Louise (Micki) Hoffman. Also survived by one granddaughter, Meredith Glanzer and several nephews and nieces. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 4, at 2 P.M. at Ives-Pearson Funeral Homes, 2847 Wilson Boulevard, Arlington, VA. Interment private. Contributions may be made to the Breast Cancer Research at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY.

title: Carin I. Knoop, Perry L. Fagan
description: Carin Isabel Knoop, the daughter of Arlette Douffiagues Galland of Dallas and Erhard Paul Friedrich Knoop of Eutin, Germany, was married on Monday to Perry Lawrence Fagan, a son of Betty and A. Lawrence Fagan of Fairfield, Conn. Judge Mark S. Tolle of the Criminal District Court in Dallas officiated at the Dallas Country Club.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; More Smoking Curbs
description: On Jan. 1, California became the first state to prohibit smoking in bars, gaming clubs and hotel lobbies. The ban is the second and final phase of a 1994 law meant to protect the health of employees from the dangers of secondhand smoke. The first phase banned smoking in restaurants, offices, manufacturing plants and other indoor work places.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SAMUEL BECKETT'S HIDDEN DRIVES Structural Uses of Depth Psychology. By J. D. O'Hara. University Press of Florida, $49.95.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-9

title: Food Fairs in Boston And Philadelphia
description: Boston Cooks, a nine-day event from Jan. 31 to Feb. 8, includes a Kitchen and Culinary Expo at the Hynes Convention Center on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, with displays on housewares, appliances, recipes, techniques and kitchen design. Exhibition booths will offer cooking demonstrations, a nutrition center and food sampling. Admission is $7.50. Information: (617) 439-7700.

title: Anne S. Kelley, Michael Looney
description: Anne Schofield Kelley, the daughter of Carol W. Kelley of Washington and Michael J. Kelley of Henderson, Nev., was married on Wednesday to Michael Alan Looney, a son of Mary and Robert Looney of Crofton, Md. The Rev. Gordon Forbes performed the ceremony, and the Rev. Kristen Fishbaugh-Looney, the bridegroom's sister-in-law, took part in the service at the Westmoreland Congregational United Church of Christ in Bethesda, Md.

title: Blackboard: Dress Code; Tongue Stud Standoff
description: The principal wanted a soccer coach to stop wearing her tongue stud. The school board refused to back the principal, saying the school's dress code applied only to students. So the principal quit.

title: A Jazzier Approach To Jewish Traditions
description: WHEN people hear the name Hasidic New Wave, they usually laugh, Greg Wall says. Maybe they're expecting a band like 2 Live Jews, who made a rap parody album called ''As Kosher as They Wanna Be.''

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; A Deadly Game
description: America's most prominent political family suffered yet another loss when Michael L. Kennedy, the son of Robert F. Kennedy, was killed in a skiing accident on a mountain above Aspen, Colo. Mr. Kennedy, 39, collided with a tree while playing football on skis. The game has been a staple of Kennedy vacations for decades, despite warnings about its risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INTRATER, FRIEDA
description: INTRATER-Frieda. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Arnold and the late Kenneth. Loving grandmother of Marc, Michelle and Nadia. Services today 9 AM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Blackboard: Moonlighting; Student Athlete Also Tackles Criminals
description: Greg Jenkins is literally the big man on campus at Indiana University, whether he is sporting street clothes, football jersey No. 62 or his police uniform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MENIL, DOMINIQUE
description: De MENIL-Dominique. The Trustees and staff of Dia Center for the Arts note with great sadness the passing of our beloved Trustee, Dominique De Menil. We'll miss her guiding hand, keen judgement and generous spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathies and condolences to her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Dominique inspired us and we will all miss her. The world has lost a guiding light. Board of Trustees Charles Wright, Chairman Michael Govan, Director

title: Doctor's Work Ties Genes to Disease
description: IT began as an on-the-spot inspiration. It has become a life's work. ''As a junior faculty member at N.Y.U. Medical Center, I was asked to give grand rounds to discuss a very rare genetic disease with a high cancer incidence,'' Dr. Michael Swift of Scarsdale said, referring to the teaching tours conducted for medical students. ''It was one that had been discussed very well the previous two years, including by the person who named the disease.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Kennedy Obsession The American Myth of JFK. By John Hellmann. Columbia University, $29.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Prague Acts to Curb Overcharges by Cabbies
description: The Prague city government has recently taken steps to tackle the problem of taxi drivers who overcharge tourists.

description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: A K A JANE

title: POSTINGS: 200 Apartments for People 62 and Over, and 112 Homes; In Queens by the East River, New Housing
description: The faded green sign at the corner of Third Avenue and 150th Street in the Whitestone section of Queens still says, ''Cresthaven Country Club, Straight Ahead,'' with an arrow pointing in the direction of the East River. But a new sign, across the street from the old one, tells part of today's story: ''Luxury Homes Coming Soon.'' Also coming is rental housing with some support services for people 62 and older.

title: On Language; Transparency, Totally
description: Openness was just not good enough. Scrutability didn't measure up because that word is better known by its turnaround, inscrutability, and to use it seems laboriously couth, even ept and kempt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, JESSE W.
description: HELLER-Jesse W., 81, handsome, charming, wise, funny, affectionate, irascible. Jesse earned his Doctor of Law Degree at Harvard Law School, served as an Intelligence Office in WW2, and practiced law in NYC. As Masonic Officer, he worked tirelessly for underprivileged children. He was a leading member of the Forest Hills Jewish Center. Jesse was predeceased by his parents Anna and Morris, brothers Irving and Arthur, niece Toni, and friend Norman Green. Venice Importing, the company founded by his father and built by his brothers, provided him with the means to give generously to many charities. Uncle Jesse is survived by his nieces and nephews Bette and Ronald Wagner, Susan and Buzz Warren, Dvorah and Dr. Joel Gorman; his greatnephew and niece Ian and Debra Warren; and his sister-in-law Dr. Hana Heller Ettinger, who together with her husband, Samuel, were the backbone of his support system. Services today at 1:30PM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills.

title: Go West. Or Maybe It's East.
description: As they huddled against the cold last week on freezing midtown streets, New Year's Eve revelers had something new to ponder while awaiting the dropping of the ball: directional signs, pasted to the back of local ''Walk/Don't Walk'' signs courtesy of the city and the Times Square Business Improvement District.

title: Victoria Barnes, Timothy Lovely
description: Victoria Alexandra Barnes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. V. Lee Barnes of Greenwich, Conn., was married there on New Year's Eve to Timothy Andrew Lovely, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Lovely of Smoke Rise, N.J. The Rev. Carolyn Margolies, a Congregationalist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; Working Up an Appetite
description: There are 7.8 million breakfast stories in the Garden State. Here are a few of them.

title: Building a Village, Providing for a University
description: ONE hundred and ten years ago, John Ward Melville was born in Brooklyn, New York, more than 60 miles away from the tiny Long Island farming community that he would one day change forever.

title: Ideas & Trends: Festivity's Not Hot; There Went the Holidays. Whoopee.
description: YEAR after year, talk-show hosts and other celebrity soothers and healers warn against expecting too much from the holidays, lest either the immediate disappointment or the Jan. 2 withdrawal cause an emotional crash. Now, they can declare victory.

title: The Lives They Lived: Leo Rosten; Talking Tachlis
description: b. 1908 Leo Rosten probably made Seinfeld safe for TV and bagels acceptable on the Delta Shuttle. Although Rosten was primarily a humorist, his larger purpose was to help us understand our social selves.

title: Miss Siderias, Mr. Stavropoulos
description: Calliope Maria Siderias, a daughter of Despina Siderias of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., and Chios, Greece, and the late Constantine Siderias, is to be married today to Peter George Stavropoulos, the son of Nancy Stavropoulos of New York and the late George Stavropoulos, the fashion designer. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the Dean of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York, is to perform the ceremony at the cathedral.

title: The View From/The Betsy Ross Arts Magnet School in New Haven; Now It's Boys Doing Dance, Sixth Grade and Up
description: IF one were to survey a group, even a very large group, of sixth-grade boys about their career aspirations, it's a good bet that not even one would say dancer. Even if the question were changed to what do the boys like to do after school, dancing is very unlikely to be mentioned.

title: The Lives They Lived: John P. Snyder; The Earth Made Flat
description: b. 1926 A gifted amateur with a pocket calculator and a spare bedroom for a study, Snyder solved one of the most vexing map-making problems of the century.

title: Automotive Treasures Behind the Barn Door
description: POKING around in barns can yield satisfying results. There is no telling what somebody may be storing in there. An antique sleigh like the one at Sunshine Salem Farm here seemed to await the fine hand of a master craftsman to restore it to life.

title: The Lives They Lived: Martin Schwarzschild, Eugene Merle Shoemaker, Lyman Spitzer Jr. & Clyde W. Tombaugh; Four Stars of The Cosmos
description: Martin Schwarzschild, b. 1912, and Lyman Spitzer Jr., b. 1914, were strongly grounded in physics. Eugene Shoemaker, b. 1928, was a geologist. Only Clyde Tombaugh, b. 1906, was ''just'' an astronomer, an amateur who worked his way into the profession without any formal training. Together, though, they embodied astronomy's 20th-century evolution from stargazing to such fundamental questions as the origins of the universe and the creation (and extinction) of life on Earth.

title: Stow Those Stilettos
description: To the Editor:

title: The Focus Is Christian
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Futurists Keep One Eye on the Market; Casting a Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairway Wants Riverside Parking With a 10-Year Meter
description: The parking lot for the uptown Fairway, the huge discount supermarket on West 133d Street, is often nearly as jammed as the checkout lines. To stock up on everything from disposable diapers to canned goods to meat to produce, many shoppers bring their cars. The parking, along the Hudson River from 131st to 133d Street, is an integral part of the store's success, say the owners.

title: Headed North, But Why?
description: We're moving to Vermont. There's elbow room up there. Living space. My wife will drive to work through cornfields and pastures. We'll watch the sun set over Lake Champlain before we sit down to dinner.

title: The World: Central Asia's Paper Tiger; The Cult of Personality and Pipe Dreams
description: STAND on any street corner in this low-rise Central Asian town and you cannot miss the jowly, well-fed face of Saparmurad A. Niyazov.

title: A Call for Leaders To Lead in the Arts
description: ''Arts Centers Open Doors for Hire to Survive'' (Nov. 30) is stronger on scapegoats than on analysis.

title: The Lives They Lived: Harold Robbins; Smutty Plots, Clean Prose
Binge Nights: The Emergency On Campus
description: Getting in to see John Casteen III is no easy matter. As president of the University of Virginia, one of the nation's premier colleges, he is often on the road, raising money for a $750 million capital fund drive that does not end until the year 2000. When he is on campus, he is tightly scheduled. Early in the morning, appointments begin to back up in the elegant waiting room outside his Madison Hall office. Alumni, faculty, undergraduates, doctoral candidates, state legislators, bankers, the student reporter from The Cavalier Daily -- they all want a few minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGLER, MURIEL
description: SIEGLER-Muriel. In Lake Worth, FL. Beloved wife of the late Henry Siegler. Loving mother of Richard and Brenda. Adoring grandmother of Lauren and Eric Muhlheim. Great-grandmother of Henry Muhlheim. Funeral services Sunday, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon. NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to Pediatric Cancer Foundation, 405 Tarrytown Road, Suite 572, White Plains, NY 10607.

title: Tickets and tours
description: Americans who are suddenly struck with the Olympic spirit (and who have the gold and silver to indulge it) can still find tickets and even tour packages for the Winter Games, to be held in Nagano, Japan, Feb. 7 to 22. The official United States ticket seller for the XVIII Winter Games is Cartan Tours, 1334 Parkview Avenue, Suite 210, Manhattan Beach, Calif. 90266; (800) 818-1998, fax (310) 546-8433.

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; On the Run
description: There are 7.8 million breakfast stories in the Garden State. Here are a few of them.

title: Idealism, Past and Present
description: The end of the cold war aroused fears among some who conduct foreign policy that Americans would tire of shouldering the world's problems. Superficially, those fears appear well founded. Surveys show that Americans are put off by news of distant conflicts and prefer not to become involved. Look again, however, and a different picture emerges. It turns out that Americans crave engagement in the world's crises, but not in the way they are defined by some leaders in Government, academic institutions and the news media. As a new year dawns, it is worth remembering that citizens want the United States to assert its global leadership, but in a more nuanced and coordinated fashion than in the past.

title: Langella's Reprise
description: To the Editor:

title: A 2d Try for East End Land Tax
description: WHEN Governor George E. Pataki vetoed a bill last fall that would have allowed the Town of East Hampton to impose a 2 percent transfer tax on real estate, town officials were dismayed and environmental groups were furious.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Appointees Retained

title: The Lives They Lived: James M. Fox; Some of His Best Friends Were Crooks
description: b. 1937 From the height of the cold war to the dawn of the age of international terrorism, Fox dedicated his life to the F.B.I. As head of the New York office, he was the quintessential G-man, with a difference.

title: The N.F.L., All of It, in Stats and Profiles
description: EVEN Andy Robustelli himself doesn't remember scoring five touchdowns when he played for a great Los Angeles Rams football team in the early 1950's. ''I know I scored a few, but I don't remember how many,'' the Hall of Fame defensive end from Stamford said in an interview.

title: In Praise of Radicals
description: To the Editor:

title: Going to Bat for Latino Ballplayers
description: WHAT pushed Julio Pabon into quitting his well-paid job was frustration -- the hair-pulling kind -- that, once again, Latinos had been left out. Mr. Pabon has been promoting the needs of Hispanic people for 25 years. In the 70's, it was police brutality. In the 80's, he was Director of Latino Affairs, working for Andrew Stein, then the President of the City Council.

title: The Lives They Lived: Curt Flood; Baseball's Last Martyr
description: b. 1938 As a center fielder for the St. Louis Cardinals, he won seven Gold Gloves and batted over .300 six times. But Curt Flood will forever be remembered as the man who challenged baseball's reserve clause, which prevented players from moving to another team unless they were traded. He lost his battle in the Supreme Court in 1972, but the players won the war three years later when an arbitrator threw out the reserve clause.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of 1997 sports champions last Sunday misidentified three National Collegiate Athletic Association fencing winners. The men's saber champion was Keeth Smart of St. John's; the women's foil champion was Sara Walsh of Notre Dame, and the men's foil champion was Cliff Bayer of Penn.

title: Essay; Schoolyard Brawl
description: With welfare reform and the budget deficit defused as issues, public education is shaping up as the next point of contention between Democrats and Republicans. The debate will require fancy footwork, given that educational financing and policy are local matters in which the Federal Government plays only a minuscule role. The shift will be especially awkward for Republicans, who have generally viewed ''local control'' as the be-all and end-all and have denounced even enlightened Federal initiatives as preludes to a Government takeover.

title: The Lives They Lived: William J. Brennan Jr.; A Justice for All
Judge Weighing New Jersey's Spending on Urban Schools Offers Few Clues on Ruling
description: Judge Michael Patrick King spent the fall visiting 10 schools, listening to 100 hours of testimony and wading through the convoluted history of school financing lawsuits that began 28 years ago. Now it is up to him to decide by Jan. 20 whether New Jersey's urban schools, which already spend more per pupil than those in any other state, need to spend billions more to provide the ''thorough and efficient'' education guaranteed by the State Constitution.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: A Third Incarnation For a Temple of Rock

title: Chiropractors' Problem: What Price Acceptance?
description: For chiropractors in New York, 1998 has been touted as the year of the back, the year when insurance companies and managed-care organizations are finally being forced to confer legitimacy on their oft-maligned profession.

title: As They Peer Ahead to the Super Bowl, the Chiefs Will Be Looking Again to Thomas
description: It was a typical bright, sunny Miami morning, and Derrick Thomas decided that it was no day for school. He was 14, and on this day he decided that hanging out with his ''boys'' would be more fruitful than reading or writing or arithmetic.

title: Bulls and Bears of '97
description: Though the Dow dipped 7.72 points on the market's final day of 1997, closing at 7,908.25, the average still posted a gain of 22.6 percent for the year -- the first time the Dow posted three consecutive years of gains exceeding 20 percent . . . . Bonds rallied on the last day, pushing the yield on the long bond down to 5.92 percent...Though 800 Japanese traders clapped their hands in unison three times as part of the traditional closing ceremony on the floor of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the ritual was about as useful as clapping with one hand. True, the benchmark Nikkei index closed 1997 on a positive note, rising 3.27 percent on the final trading day, but it lost 4,102.61 points, or 21.2 percent, for the year. In addition, more Japanese business failures are expected, with the Government indicating that it may take a more hands-off approach in big bankruptcies. . . . For the year, the yen lost 13 percent of its value against the dollar, a boon to Japan's exporters.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: On the Day After Their Showdown, the Knicks Win and the Nets Lose; Mills Steps Out of Background To Produce Push to Victory
description: No one knew what was lurking beneath the scout-badge exterior of Chris Mills. Who could? Mills had blended into the background of the Knicks, a pleasant but hardly noticeable wallflower even in Patrick Ewing's absence.

description: There are 7.8 million breakfast stories in the Garden State. Here are a few of them.

description: BIE-COMNENE-Irene. On January 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Rolf Bie-Comnene and the late Aurelio Corsani. She was the proud daughter of Nicolas Petrescu Comnene. Friends may call on Saturday, January 10, 1998, 2-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Service following on Sunday, January 11, 1998, 3:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A light-hearted, disarming western, an adroit, ultra romance from Hollywood's golden era, a wartime semi-documentary and a crackling adventure add to the seasonal glow of films on television this week.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Tijuana Bibles

title: Devon Martin, John Sargent 3d
description: IN September 1993, Devon Joan Martin and John Stephen Sargent 3d met as Fulbright scholars at Oxford University, a place they describe as rainy, removed and romantic.

title: Seats Need Improvement At New Arts Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Perspective, Plus Titles, Helped Kelly Become Dean of Managers
description: Tom Kelly is not so old that he cannot remember the uncertainty he experienced following the 1986 season. ''My coaches and I didn't have jobs,'' he said. ''We were sitting on pins and needles waiting for Andy to call.''

title: Having Second Thoughts In the Air
description: I TOOK an oath I'd never write one of those heartfelt New Dad stories (''Taking Tots to the Tetons,'' ''The Kids in Kenya''). That was before my wife and I had twins. Twins, naturally, made me think twice about travel. But coming to parenthood late in life, I figured I'd be in a walker when the nippers went off to college. So we scratched off a planned trip to Angkor Wat and a paddle down the Amazon and set our sights on West Virginia, home of the mother-in-law. I wasn't worried. I still relied on denial as a useful strategy. What was the point in fretting? Lots of people carted their kids around.

title: Streetscapes/The Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West 57th Street; From Women's Clubhouse to WNET to $75 a Night
description: LAST year the hotelier Ian Schrager announced plans to fix up the old Henry Hudson Hotel, at 353 West 57th Street -- but not too much. He says he wants to charge only $75 a night.

title: Still High on Low-Flying Technology Stocks
description: TECHNOLOGY is in a slump. Wall Street has been getting nervous about the sector, and it has been hit hard by the Asian crisis. But Michael Murphy, long a fan of the field, is as high on it as ever.

title: Q&A/Thomas Lux; If Poetry Is Puzzling, Who Is to Blame?
description: IF poetry baffles you and makes you feel stupid, the problem could be the poet's, not yours. That is the message from Thomas Lux, a published poet who is co-director of the Sarah Lawrence College writing program.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BESSIE (BETTY)
description: GOLDBERG-Bessie (Betty). Beloved wife of the late Max, devoted mother of Howard and Barry and mother-in-law of Joan and Deanna. Dear sister of Dorothy Rappaport. Loving grandmother of Jonathan, Andrew, Elyssa, Keith and Lauren. Services on Sunday at 10 A.M., ''Riverside-Nassau North'', Great Neck.

title: Bombs Away! A Story of the Suburbs
description: COLIN McKERNAM, making some extra money working as a land surveyor over his holiday break from Colorado State University, stomped a boot on the frozen mud and turned away from the tripod that held his scope. Just up the hill, a light snow had frosted the trees that still made a natural barrier around the small, cleared plateau where missiles had once been hidden on their launchers, waiting for nuclear doomsday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIMETZ, OSCAR
description: NIMETZ-Oscar. On January 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Gertrude, loving father of Michael, dear friend to many. Service Monday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Inhabiting a Realm Amid Water and Earth
description: Dale Chihuly: Seaforms

title: A Disease That Responds to a Diet of Foods Free of Gluten
description: A YEAR ago, Macie Rosenthal, at 1, withered before her parents' eyes. She threw up several times a week and failed to grow as a healthy toddler should. Her golden ringlets drooped, and her cheeks were lean and pale. Her stomach bulged like that of a starving child, and she was too weak to stand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, HERBERT
description: GROSSMAN-Herbert. On December 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Sandra. Devoted father of Robin, Lynne and Laurie. Dedicated father-in-law of Matthew, Allen and Jeff. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Jeffrey, Jackson and Joseph. Dear brother of Helen Graf. Loved and admired by all who knew him. Brilliant, honest and dynamic with much wisdom and integrity. Well known in the pharmaceuticals industry as a pioneer in marketing and strategic planning. At the time of his death, Herbert Grossman was President and Chief Executive Officer of Beacon Laboratories in Wayne, NJ. He will be dearly missed but lovingly remembered. Contributions to the American Heart Association or charity of choice.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Each year, as we contemplate which lives of accomplishment to include in this issue, we face the question of how to take note of celebrity; in 1997, that question was unusually difficult. Ideally, our aim is to give notice to people who, though not well known, made a difference. In some years, however, the deaths of famous figures so punctuate the news that to omit them feels unfinished -- and at times the past year seemed to carry the culture of celebrity to a new pinnacle. Even before the shock of Gianni Versace's murder had abated, the Aug. 31 death of Diana, Princess of Wales, set off another shock wave, one that still echoes on newsmagazine covers. Then, only six days later, the death of Mother Teresa elicited still another wave. For this fourth annual issue, our celebrity question reverberated.
