description: WALD-Lew. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Honored father of Eddie. Beloved grandfather of Eric, Jaime, Candice and great-grandfather of McKenna. Mourning will be observed at the family home. Interment at Mt. Ararat, Tuesday, 1 PM.

title: Lucky Knicks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MARIE
description: O'CONNOR-Marie. The Administration, Staff and Sales Associates of Charles H. Greenthal Residential Sales and the Greenthal Group of Companies mourn the sudden passing of our respected colleague and friend, Marie O'Connor. Her professionalism, charm and kindness touched all who knew her. To her beloved family and many friends we extend our heartfelt condolences. William West, President Jonathan West, Executive V.P. Joyce West, Executive V.P./Dir. Corinne Pulitzer, Sr. V.P.

title: The Lives They Lived: John H. Sengstacke; Citizen Sengstacke
description: b. 1912 He was the visionary publisher of The Chicago Daily Defender, an influential newspaper in black communities nationwide. Sengstacke bedeviled Roosevelt and Truman and had access to the White House until his death. But he avoided publicity, preferring to let the clout of his paper do the talking.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Better Than Never
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer would be laughing. Just think, a book published 40 years ago in Yiddish in The Jewish Daily Forward is making a ripple in English -- nearly seven years after the author's death in 1991.

title: 3 Are Charged With Robberies at A.T.M.'s
description: Three young people were arrested in Brooklyn on Friday in a series of robberies in which victims were forced to withdraw cash from automatic teller machines at gunpoint, the police said yesterday.

title: Holdsclaw's Defense Makes a Difference in Unlikely Rout
description: Whenever the Tennessee and Connecticut women's basketball teams have shared the same court, the games -- from the tip-off to the final buzzer -- have been thrilling, usually because of what was at stake.

title: Unlikely Twist: G.I.'s Warm to Bosnia
description: Staff Sgt. Paul Correale noticed the elderly woman in black with the toddler when the two turned to watch his patrol from 50 feet or so away. The child waved a tiny, pink-mittened hand in greeting.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is a political business and a political town. If I weren't doing the politics, I wouldn't be doing my job. I'm not here to practice medicine.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ELI MORRIS
description: LEVINE-Eli Morris. Died January 1 at the age of 87, after a long illness. Professor of Chemistry from 1932 to 1976 at Yeshiva University. Chairman of the Chemistry Department. Survived by Naomi Scheinerman, Maqueline Rubinoff and Metica Lubin. Interment in Israel. Shiva will be observed through Tuesday evening at 1406 Avenue N in Brooklyn.

title: New Rules Vexing for Clinics
description: Wrapped in a purple overcoat, Maria Rivera sat quietly last Tuesday in the waiting room of the Betances Health Unit, a neighborhood clinic on Henry Street. Like many Betances patients, Ms. Rivera receives Medicaid, and like many, she was unaware that the state has plans to change the way she gets health care.

title: 3 Views on Jews In Great Neck
description: While the article emphasizes that there has been no change in the commercial activities on Saturday, both the Reverend Maier and Rabbi Davidson bemoan the growth of the Orthodox population. The Rev. Maier states that his parish has rapidly dwindled because of all the Orthodox Jews moving into the neighborhood, making his congregants feel that ''they were in a ghetto here.''

title: A Wily Upstart That Did a Lot Of Things Right
description: THE NEWS ABOUT THIS season has sent the established network powers into denial. They surely wish it were not true, but the results of the November ratings sweep made it almost impossible to refute:

title: A Year of Reliving The Consolidation
description: A CITY this big demands an exhibition this big. As New York marks its 100th anniversary as a five-borough city, the Museum of the City of New York has opened a yearlong exhibition titled ''The New Metropolis: A Century of Greater New York, 1898-1998.'' The objects, texts, images and maps in the show (a cartoon by Homer Davenport is at left) are arranged in four sections showing what New York City was like just before consolidation; the city in the early years of consolidation; the stories and daily lives of residents in the five boroughs, and issues facing the city today with interactive mapping and a video exhibit on New York as seen in television programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, KALMAN DONALD, M.D.
description: ROSNER-Kalman Donald, M.D. in his 91st year, of Jackson Heights, Queens. Passed away December 29, 1997 at South Shore Health Care Center after a long illness. Dr. Rosner was on the staff of Physicians Hospital for 40 years. Retired Chairman of Department of Anesthesiology. Fellow of the College of Anesthesiologists. Veteran of W.W. II, obtaining rank of Major in Medical Corps. Beloved husband of Dorothy of Jackson Heights, N.Y., loving father of Florence Raskin of Smithtown, NY, Diane Geringer of Oceanside, N.Y., and Dr. William Rosner of New Haven, CT. Devoted grandfather and great-grandfather.

title: A Pocketful Of Guides
description: FOR the New Year, here's a modest but value-packed harvest of free or inexpensive booklets for travelers. Two are likely to inspire the wish to see more of the United States, closer up. Others round up practical information for all sorts of travel; two are of value for traveling abroad.

title: Street Beats Teammates During Her Comeback
description: A second day of fog at higher elevations on Whiteface Mountain forced the cancellation of today's downhill and super giant slalom events on the final day of the 1998 Chevy Truck United States Ski Team Gold Cup, the qualifying event for the Winter Olympic Games in Nagano, Japan.

title: First Test for Britain's Camelot: Welfare Reform
description: Putting his promise of national transformation to its hardest test, Prime Minister Tony Blair has taken aim at what the Labor Party considers its greatest monument and many Britons view as the nation's proudest postwar institution: the welfare state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYKOFF, SARA NEE PUTTERMAN
description: BOYKOFF-Sara nee Putterman. On December 27, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Irene B. Duke and Eleanor B. Schmetterling. Loving grandmother of David, Amy, Judith, Abbie and Nancy. For info ''Wein & Wein'' 800-322-0533.

title: A Family's Lives Animate Their Work, and Vice Versa
description: ON A RECENT afternoon, Emily Hubley was cooking chicken and asparagus for dinner guests, planning her son's 8th-birthday party, calming a pet cockatiel and welcoming her daughter home from kindergarten. And during the lulls, she was conferring with her mother, Faith Hubley, about the retrospective of their family's animated films that opens this month at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: STUDENT LIFE; Headlines From the Fall Semester
description: Every four years, a new generation of students enters college, ready to learn new ideas, explore new experiences and fight for new causes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, CHARLES R.
description: KINGSLEY-Charles R., 69. Of Chappaqua, NY. On December 28th the world lost a wonderful and remarkable man. Beloved husband and best friend of Emily Perl Kingsley. Adored father and hero of Glenn (Jennifer), Todd (Michelle), and Jason. Fun-loving grandpa and magician to Samara, Ethan, Spencer, Samantha, Rebecca and Jack. Loving brother of Albert (Dolores) and Isabel. Devoted son-in-law of Alan Perl and Sue Lipton. Charles worked tirelessly to champion the rights of people with developmental disabilities. He served as past President and long time Board member of Westchester ARC and was a former Board member of the National Down Syndrome Congress. He founded and directed J.M. Charles Painting Corp., of Elmsford, NY. His unique ability to relate to people from all walks of life was Charles' special gift. His warmth, generosity and caring were felt by all who knew him. He was a truly special person whose compassion and commitment have made the world a better place. A memorial celebration of Charles' life will be held on January 18th, time and place to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Westchester ARC, 74 Westmoreland Avenue, White Plains, New York 10606 would be appreciated.

title: A Fearless Michael Kennedy Is Remembered at Funeral
description: In a packed, wooden Roman Catholic church, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d eulogized his brother Michael L. Kennedy today as an amazing, fearless athlete, a friend of the poor and a shrewd campaign manager who quietly guided both him and their uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, to election victories when the odds looked grim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, MARTHA (NEE GEMUNDER)
description: GOTTLIEB-Martha (nee Gemunder) on December 21, 1997. Loving wife of Philip. Devoted mother of Joan Bland. Grandmother of Hillary and James. Formerly of NYC.

title: Four Arrested in Drug Sting
description: Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agents and Mount Vernon police officers recovered more than $1 million in cash and arrested three men and one woman Friday night in a drug sting in northern Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; A Bullish Public
description: You wouldn't know it from the recent so-so holiday shopping season, but American consumers told pollsters last week that they haven't been this confident about their economic future since mid-1969. The unemployment rate is down to 4.6 percent, incomes are edging up and the stock market finished a third straight year in which returns at least doubled historic norms. ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLESTER, FRITZ
description: COLLESTER - Fritz. Theatrical agent, friend. A dedicated, kind, thoughtful man who cared deeply about his actors' lives. His loss diminishes us all. Mark Hall Amitin

title: STUDENT LIFE: Headlines From the Fall Semester; Date-Rape Drug Scare
description: Like several other campuses across the country, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, which share a campus in the Finger Lakes community of Geneva, N.Y., had a scare involving Rohypnol, the ''date-rape drug.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SLESNICK, WILLIAM E.
description: SLESNICK-William E. Memorial service will be held in Rollins Chapel at Dartmouth College on Saturday, January 17 at 1:30PM.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Trouble With Turbulence
description: Airline passengers, tucked in an aluminum cocoon with movie screen, meal service and reclining chairs, can forget that they are six miles up and cruising at over 500 miles per hour. But those onboard a United flight from Tokyo to Honolulu got a cruel reminder when their plane hit turbulence so severe that one passenger was killed and scores were injured. ''We say it all the time: aviation is the safest form of transportation,'' said Herbert B. Armstrong, assistant dean of the school of aviation and transportation at Dowling College in Oakdale, L.I. ''But we're really not supposed to be flying, and if something goes wrong, you can get hurt.'' MATTHEW L. WALD

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Park Hill, Yonkers; Vintage Homes on a 300-Foot Plateau
description: ONE day while driving up Broadway looking for houses, Steven Green, a Manhattan developer, made a right turn and found a neighborhood in Yonkers he had never seen before. ''I don't want to make it sound like karma or something,'' Mr. Green said, ''but I don't know what caused me to turn that way.''

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; The Coffee's On. And On, and On
description: There is a legend about how coffee was discovered, the Encyclopedia Americana says. A long-ago goatherd in Ethiopia noticed that his goats, after eating the berries from a particular tree, would ''cavort about in an unusually frisky manner.''

title: Amid Anxiety, Glimpses of Hope; Southside Adapts to a New, Uncertain World of Welfare
description: Of all the dire predictions about the dismantling of the nation's welfare system a year ago, perhaps the most disturbing was that more children would suffer from neglect, hunger and abuse in the chaos of households cut off from benefits. Child welfare experts feared the worst. New York City officials foresaw many more children entering foster care.

title: In Praise of Radicals
description: To the Editor:

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Giuliani Redux
description: Starting his second four-year term as Mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani replayed themes that re-elected him and propelled him to national prominence. He promised to hire more police officers because ''first and foremost as our city enters the 21st century, we have to build on what has worked for us, and what has turned us around.'' The inauguration began a year-long celebration of the centennial of Greater New York.

title: Q&A/Eileen Ogintz; On Taking Vacations With the Children
description: WHILE some travel writers focus on what to take when visiting Bali or the Galapagos Islands, Eileen Ogintz tends to stress the importance of remembering juice boxes and the pediatrician's phone number. Her ''Taking the Kids'' column is carried in more than 50 daily newspapers and on America Online, offering advice on where to go, what to take and what to do if things don't go as planned (and they never do).

title: The Lives They Lived: Woolworth's et al.; Icons Die, Too
description: Companies, logos, flagships, arenas: They come, they go -- and their loss is not so different from that of a person.

title: Black-White: Everyday Slights
description: To the Editor:

title: Assisted-Living Stocks Begin to Fulfill Promise
description: WILL 1997 go down as the year when the winners finally outnumbered the losers in the assisted-living industry?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXBERG, STANLEY D.
description: WAXBERG-Stanley D. On December 21, 1997. Beloved husband of Nikki and uncle of Marvin Waxberg. Memorial services are on Thursday, January 8, 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: George Lazenby as 007
description: To the Editor:

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Rock On, Sir
description: Knighthood, like the monarchy itself, is an odd British relic, a creak from the attic of the past. So there was a musty logic in the knighting of Elton John ''for services to music and for charitable services.'' After all, Mr. John -- sorry, it's Sir Elton now -- made his 15-minute dent in the year by sprucing up a song from his past for Princess Diana's funeral: ''Candle in the Wind,'' written a generation ago in memory of a goddess from that generation, Marilyn Monroe. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: The Lives They Lived; Make It New
description: Luther Simjian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVINE, BURTON J.
description: LAVINE-Burton J. Beloved husband of Marian. Devoted father of Steven and Lauren. Loving son of Goldie Jean Lavine. Dear brother of Joyce Simon. Cherished uncle and loyal friend to many. Vice President of Marketing, Zenith Distributing Corp of New York City. Adjunct Professor of Marketing at Baruch School of Business, New York University and C.W. Post. Served on the boards of the United Jewish Appeal and Long Island chapter of the American Cancer Society. Services Sunday 1PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the above charities.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Aid for Medicaid Children
description: President Clinton made a big political commitment to health care for children last year, and Congress agreed to make a big financial investment in a new health insurance program for children.

title: The Lives They Lived: Jeff Buckley; His Father's Son
description: b. 1966 Buckley was the son of Tim Buckley, the folk-rock singer who died of a drug overdose in 1975. Jeff inherited his father's dark, elfin good looks and ethereal voice. His first record, released in 1994, won wide acclaim; he was about to make his second in Memphis when he drowned in a river that feeds the Mississippi.

title: Casseroles, the Ultimate In Winter Comfort
description: WINTER is the time for casseroles. There is an almost infinite variety of ways to cook meat, fish or poultry slowly in the oven with seasonings and vegetables. Here are some suggestions.

title: Drudgery of Turkish Trading Becomes a Delight
description: FROM the time the Istanbul Stock Exchange was established in 1986 until less than three years ago, it was housed in a dark, dingy room that resembled the Little Rascals clubhouse more than a modern trading institution. Transactions were recorded with felt markers on giant sheets of paper taped to walls.

title: Brendan Gill's City: Isaac Bashevis Singer's Coffee Shop and Sightlines for a Pretty Ankle
description: BRENDAN GILL, who died eight days ago, at the age of 83, was, truly, a man about town, as a writer, preservationist and critic of art and architecture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, PEARL
description: HIRSCH-Pearl. December 24, 1997. Treasured and beloved by her husband Sidney and her sons Sanford, Howard, Brian Davis, Mark and Bert Hirsch and their wives. Cherished by her sisters, brother, grandchildren and greatgrandchild. Respected by all who were privileged to know her.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry; Captured Images
description: The point of departure for THE PROFILE MAKERS (Marian Wood/Holt, $23), a radiant collection of poems by Linda Bierds, is a group of six glass-plate negatives from the Civil War era. Discovered years later by an unnamed narrator, they have been ''revived as greenhouse windows.'' Each portrays members of the narrator's family posing for ''my cousin, Mathew Brady's aide,'' in a camp ''thick with families, the fields / a hail of scattered tents.'' The six poems that describe the photographs, ''our faded wisps of family, / reversed to smoky filaments,'' are dense and haunting meditations on loss, death and the pull and ache of memory. They also provide a powerful elliptical structure for the rest of the collection, which focuses on the pioneers of captured images and the fragile machinery they employed: Van Leeuwenhoek's early microscope, the acid etchings of Rembrandt, the cave paintings at Altamira and the dashes and dots of Samuel Morse, to name a few. The tightly coiled imagery that distinguishes Bierds's fifth volume of poetry is often as surprising as it is beautiful, both in small details like ''the ferreting snouts of radishes'' or ''a wash of claret at the window'' and in larger moments: ''My mother swallowed, saw the shutter spiral down, / her face a blend of dust and wonder -- / that she might gather over glass, that she might claim, / across the flecks of bromide salt, some bygone self.'' Scott Veale

title: A Silent Bond That Is All in the Fingertips
description: It is surely the most intimate commercial transaction between adults short of . . . well, you know. Yet massage can seem as impersonal as a shoeshine. Because, whatever else it may be, massage is not about talking.

title: Masters Give Dogs a Bad Name
description: DEBBIE WILCOX, Naugatuck's dog warden, sees the way some people treat dogs, and it disturbs her as much as when dogs bite people. Rather than pay $70 or $80 to euthanize an animal, some owners dispose of them like old, ruined furniture, she said. In one incident, Ms. Wilcox recalled, ''I saw the car pull up, and they threw the dog out of the back onto the street, shut the door and took off. When they do that, we get them.''

title: The Lives They Lived: Joanie Weston; The Blond Bomber
description: b. 1935 In the 1950's, roller derby was a national rage. The San Francisco Bay Bombers ruled the sport, and Joanie Weston was their star. She was a gifted athlete, perhaps the best of her era -- she once hit eight home runs in a softball game. But the stigma attached to roller derby assured that she would never gain the recognition she deserved.

title: Black-White: Everyday Slights
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking a Break From the Games
description: MOST people now know that the spine of mountains running through Nagano, one of Japan's few landlocked prefectures, will be the site of the slaloms and slap shots, bobsleds and biathlons of the 1998 Winter Olympics. But below and beyond Chubu Sangaku, the Japan Alps, in the center of Honshu, Japan's largest island, are a number of cultural and historical attractions offering glimpses of a more traditional Japan.

title: Sampling of Flavors From Southeast Asia
description: It is always a pleasure to begin a New Year with an upbeat dining experience. Taipan in Westport provided this on several levels.

title: In Old England, A Silicon Fen
description: THE rooms at Mount Pleasant House are filling up with new faces, furniture and ideas. Month after month, the five-story building, whose smoky green glass blends into the leafy texture of this ancient university town, is kept busy as yet another high-technology venture installs itself to produce new software or a growing company leaves for bigger quarters.

title: The Lives They Lived: David (Duke) Zeibert; Power, Medium Rare
description: b. 1910 The man behind the power-lunch place for two generations of Washington insiders worked his way up from busboy to arbiter of the Beltway.

title: Blackboard: Secrets Of The Grave; Archeology Students Examine Tombstones for Clues to a Town's Social Order
description: A CEMETERY may seem as final and unyielding a place as any on earth. But Prof. David Small of Lehigh University sees a cemetery as a place of endless change, with as much to offer the living as the dead.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 21 about training for state troopers in handling domestic violence cases referred incorrectly to the abuse in the first marriage of Maureen L., one woman who spoke to the troopers. It ended in physical violence, but she was not beaten during the marriage. The article also misstated the date of her second marriage. It took place in 1994, not 1990.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Giant Creatures, Up Close

title: The Backwater School
description: The Art of Giovanni Antonio Da Pordenone

title: When to Park Where in 1998
description: Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended this year in New York City. Street-cleaning rules, including those at parking meters, are suspended in most communities in New York on Wednesdays and Saturdays. Motorists should follow posted signs carefully to avoid tickets.

title: Word for Word / Last Meals; For the Condemned in Texas, Cheeseburgers Without Mercy
description: BURGERS top the entrees. Twenty-two men chose double cheesburgers, 15 opted for single cheeseburgers, 9 for hamburgers. Next most popular were steaks, typically T-bones, with 27 requests, and eggs (10 requests, most for scrambled). Most desired overall is a side of french fries (56 requests). Ice cream is the most popular dessert (21 requests), Coca-Cola the most popular beverage (13, just edging out 12 requests for iced tea). And 24 inmates declined any last meal at all.

title: Recitals Leading Way Back Into the Season
description: SINCE it usually takes a while for the concert season to return to full speed after the holiday break, the annual series at the New Canaan Library in January called Notes in Mid Winter is especially welcome.

title: Art to Ease the Waiting
description: When Miriam In Der Muhlen, a 35-year-old music executive, went to the doctor the other day, she was greeted with an unfamiliar sight. In the waiting room of Mercer Street Medical, an artist was hanging his painting.

title: Managers Wanted: Will Train. Start Immed. Bonu$.
description: WHEN Clint Prescott lost his job managing a country club in Oregon in July, he was exasperated. Even after 25 years in the private club industry, he was not about to hunt for another job at a member-owned club where, he said, internal politics could again put his job in jeopardy. ''I wanted one or two bosses, not 500,'' he said.

title: Amid All the Illusion, Satire With Real Bite
description: THE PERSIAN GULF WAR MAY have failed to drive President Saddam Hussein of Iraq out of office in 1991, but it certainly didn't hurt the popularity of its most vocal proponent, President George Bush. The war proved an instant political windfall, spiking up his approval ratings and banishing forever any lurking suspicions that he may have been, God forbid, a wimp.

title: A Free Bachelor's. No Kidding.
description: This academic year, the price of college again rose faster than inflation. Tuition was up 5 percent, double the inflation rate. It now averages $13,000 annually at private institutions, where a four-year bachelor's degree averages upwards of $52,000.

title: 3 Views on Jews In Great Neck
description: The article ''In Great Neck, New Orthodox Synagogues'' [Dec. 14], took what was ostensibly an article about the new Orthodox synagogues in Great Neck and provided a forum for ''Orthodox bashing.''

title: Ingenious Tools That Guided Many A Mariner Home
description: NOWADAYS, FIXING LONGITUDE AND latitude at sea can be done with the click of a button through satellite navigation. But that removes the human factor in pinpointing one's place on earth -- something always present when mariners used instruments of celestial navigation like 19th-century sextants in brass and 18th-century octants in ebony and ivory.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about ways for individuals to invest in institutional mutual funds misstated the amount of client assets controlled by the 5,000 fee-based financial planners for whom Charles Schwab & Company provides technical services. It is $100 billion, not $100 million.

As a moderate, she became a vocal critic of her own party in the Reagan era. b. 1923 Jean Westwood was chairman of the Democratic National Committee for five months in the 1972 Presidential campaign of George McGovern.

title: Hang Five (Or a Phone)
description: Surf's up: flashy, surfer-style cases for cellular telephones and beepers have hit the streets. Goneo, a licensee of Body Glove, the wet-suit maker, has come out with Cellsuits ($24.99) and Beepsuits ($14.99), made of colorful, water-resistant neoprene and bearing the Body Glove hand symbol.

title: Heather E. Sarg, C. J. C. Hallows
description: Heather Elizabeth Sarg, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Sarg of New York, was married last evening to Sgt. Christopher John Chatfield Hallows, the son of Sally Hallows of New York and Michael C. L. Hallows of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. John Fitzpatrick performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. John the Baptist in Savannah, Ga.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERICSON, RAYMOND
description: ERICSON-Raymond. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Raymond Ericson, associated with The Times from 1960, until retiring in 1981.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the power of the Assembly Speaker and the Senate majority leader over the New York State Legislature omitted the given name of a Democratic Assemblyman from Ithaca who is critical of the situation. He is Martin A. Luster.

title: Partial-Birth Abortion Ban
description: The Assembly recently overrode the Governor's veto of a bill that bans ''partial-birth abortions.'' Should the ban be law?

title: Trouble in the House
description: SAKIBEH MUSTAFA made herself some tea and threw a couple of mint leaves she had just plucked from her backyard into the steaming cup. Then she sat at the dining table to listen to her youngest daughter, 19-year-old Egrah, play a slow Led Zeppelin song on the guitar.

title: Fine Dining at the Dump? The Birds Keep Coming Back
description: Call it Chez Offal.

title: At Ground Zero, Workers Slog On in 15-Foot Crater
description: Evacuated residents went home to retrieve essentials, shoppers and workers filtered back into side streets and scores of emergency workers toiled in a huge crater on Fifth Avenue near 19th Street yesterday as the Flatiron district struggled to recover from the flooding and flames of water and gas main breaks.

title: Staci Perelman, Jason Butler
description: Staci Lyn Perelman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Perelman of West Caldwell, N.J., was married last evening to Jason Matthew Butler, a son of Helena and John N. Butler of Flanders, N.J.

title: In Search of Gorillas and Ghosts
description: The lives of three researchers in Africa -- and the death of one of them -- will be the centerpiece of trips to that continent this year. One tour focuses on the primate rescue efforts of Dian Fossey and Jane Goodall. The other seeks to recreate the march that brought Dr. David Livingstone's body 1,300 miles across what is now northern Zambia and Tanzania.

title: Keeping a Beloved Team's Memory Alive
description: VINNY DZIK, an autistic 8-year-old child from Portsmouth, Ohio, loves the Hartford Whalers. His room is painted in Whaler blue and green, and the walls are covered with Whalers' posters, flags and pennants.

description: ACADEMIC DUTY

description: To the Editor:

title: Casseroles, the Ultimate in Winter Comfort
description: WINTER is the time for casseroles. There is an almost infinite variety of ways to cook meat, fish or poultry slowly in the oven with seasonings and vegetables. Here are some suggestions.

title: The Lives They Lived: Ruth Clark; The Right Questions
description: b. 1917 When she put her ear to the ground, people listened. The exit polls she devised made it possible to decode elections. Newspaper editors took her advice to find ''News You Can Use.'' She helped explain democratic politics -- after living through politics of a very different kind.

title: A Life of Beginnings
description: THE MOORING OF STARTING OUT The First Five Books of Poetry. By John Ashbery. 389 pp. Hopewell, N.J.: The Ecco Press. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAURENCE, RICHARD ALAN
description: LAURENCE - Richard Alan. 1953-1981. Richard left us with a treasury of beautiful memories never to be forgotten. His love and compassion will forever be imprinted within our hearts. Lovingly remembered, Mom, Dad and Wendy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SANDRA W.
description: MEYER-Sandra W. The National Alliance of Breast Cancer Organizations marks with sadness the passing of our constant supporter and much admired friend. Her grace and courage have been an inspiration to us all. Amy Langer, Executive Director The NABCO Board of Directors

description: WARSAW TO WRIGLEY

description: GREENBAUM-Jean. On December 31, 1997. Beloved mother of Carole and Philip (Lynne). Loving grandmother of six.

title: Political Points
description: To the Editor:

title: The Enola Gay Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: A Politician Wins Notice By Winning The Lottery
description: As he wrestles with the knotty problem of computer clocks rolling over disastrously at the approaching millennium, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., chairman of the House Science Committee, might be entitled to the nickname of Congressman from the Year 2000.

title: In America; Death Penalty Dilemma
description: Texas's bloodthirsty criminal justice officials have a dilemma. A Bible-quoting, Jesus-loving, reasonably normal looking woman named Karla Faye Tucker has been sentenced to death. Ordinarily the death penalty is no big deal in Texas, where liberals are required to carry visas and compassion is virtually illegal. It's a state that has shown itself perfectly willing to execute the retarded and railroad the innocent. But the scheduled execution of Ms. Tucker is another matter. Even in Texas, government officials are squeamish about zapping a woman.

title: DIARY
description: ROSY OUTLOOK

title: Body Language
description: WASTED A Memoir of Anorexia and Bulimia. By Marya Hornbacher. 298 pp. New York: Harper Flamingo. $23.

title: See the Movie, Covet the Souvenir
description: A LUXURY liner plunges into the briny depths off Newfoundland, an extravagant era's crowning achievement done in by an iceberg. You walk away with Leonardo DiCaprio's corduroys. But wait. Someone has beaten you to them, not to mention his bib-front, band-collar shirt and six-button wool vest with welt pockets and side vents. If only you had called the J. Peterman catalogue sooner, you could have owned these fashionable pieces of movie history, for just $9,000. But you waited to buy your ''Titanic'' souvenirs, and now you're sunk. Well, not completely.

title: Comeback Player Of 1997: Nasdaq
description: The movements of stock markets are often ephemeral, on the front page one day and forgotten the next as prices fluctuate. We remember the 1929 crash because it foretold disaster, but the 1987 one, which did not, is already fading from memory.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEDRIS, MARIE M.
description: GEDRIS-Marie M. On January 6, 1998 it will be a year since you're gone. We all love and miss you. All our love, Anastasia and Rudolph.

title: State's First 2 Flu Cases Identified in Hackensack
description: If you think you have already battled a case of influenza this winter, you may be right. But officially, the first two cases of influenza were reported by the Hackensack University Medical Center late last month when the first cases of this year's flu strain were diagnosed in a Garfield boy and a North Bergen girl, both 1 year old.

title: The Lives They Lived: Col. John R. Boyd; A Fighter on Many Fronts
description: b. 1927 Col. John Boyd's name has become synonymous with moral and physical bravery. He was an architect of the military reform movement in the Department of Defense in the 1970's and 80's.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, IRVING
description: SCHNEIDER-Irving. Age 91, died January 1, 1998. Devoted husband of Ethel, beloved father of Anne Evans, cherished grandfather of Suzan Hochberg and Richard Evans and great-grandfather of Isabelle and Julia Hochberg. Reknown theatrical and bankruptcy attorney. We will miss his guidance, generosity and humor.

title: The Lives They Lived: Dr. Donald D. Flickinger; The Escape Artist
description: b. 1907 Flickinger first gained renown during World War II for parachuting into the jungles of Burma to save downed airmen. He went on to help develop life-support systems for high-altitude flight and space travel.

title: For the Stars, a Fitting Room of Their Own
description: IMAGINE it as a steadycam shot, the way Michelle Pfeiffer might: through the two sets of double glass doors that the doorman pushes and pulls open for you, then a sharp right and a left into a white-sycamore wood-paneled elevator. It ushers you to the top floor, then there's a long runway walk to women's evening wear, and a narrow doorway slips you into a pale, polished space, as pure and private as the inside of a shell.

title: Meredith Pearlman and Joshua Davis
description: Meredith Eve Pearlman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Pearlman of Madison, N.J., is to be married this morning to Joshua Victorsohn Davis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton M. Davis of Manhattan. Rabbi David H. Lincoln is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOLOMON, AMY MARCUS
description: SOLOMON-Amy Marcus. Once in love with Amy Always in love with Amy

title: Fashion's New Rule
description: The year 1997 was when fashion halted the self-destructive course that began two decades ago as designers encouraged women to discard the rules and do their own thing, a credo that proved unmanageable for most. The best designers reversed the trend with an all-black silhouette that is being widely worn this winter. This disciplined look has cast an authoritative shadow over the many lengths and shapes of coats, as seen here, without re-establishing dogmatic fashion dictates.

title: Deadly Bacteria a New Threat To Fruit and Produce in U.S.
description: Anna Grace Gimmestad, 16 months old, was just beginning to put her infant stamp on the world. She would parrot the whir of a helicopter, pause on each stair step to kiss her parents through the banister.

title: Reviving the Tired Image of the 'Latin Other'
description: DECADE AFTER DECADE, gringo New Yorkers fall in love with Latin music. Suddenly they realize it's all around them: on the radio, booming from car stereos, wafting out of bodegas, drawing audiences that fill Radio City Music Hall and Madison Square Garden. Manhattan, it has been said, is the northernmost island of the Caribbean, and Latin culture pervades the city, from salsa to santeria to rice and beans. Intricate Latin rhythms give musicians something to marvel at and figure out while everyone else is dancing; the singers' fervor, grace and humor challenge the language barrier.

title: Yuji Yoshimura, 76, a Master Of the Ancient Art of Bonsai
description: Yuji Yoshimura, a master bonsai grower who taught and nurtured the classical Japanese art in the United States, died on Dec. 24 at Medway Country Manor in Medway, Mass. A resident of Norfolk, Mass., he was 76 and formerly lived in Tarrytown and Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLITZ, LESTER MURRAY, M.D.
description: KARLITZ-Lester Murray, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted father of Jeffrey and Gloria Karlitz, Ellen and Louis Rothman. Dear brother of Edith Wald. Adored grandfather of Allison, Lori and Wendy Rothman and Paul Karlitz. For information, call the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 516-487-9600. Service time to be announced.

title: Korean Art, Inventive, Intricate, Meticulous.
description: IN recent years Koreans, artists and dealers alike, have been making very visible inroads into the American art world.

title: STUDENT LIFE: Headlines From the Fall Semester; Alabama's 'Machine'
description: It sounds like a John Grisham plot.

title: With New Beetle Come Wistful Hints of Old Flame
description: When Melissa Jess tools around Phoenix in her 1962 red, white and blue-striped Volkswagen Beetle -- painted to resemble the car in the 1969 movie ''The Love Bug'' -- she talks to it as sweetly as she can.

title: Losing Their Marbles
description: The Elgin Affair

description: To the Editor:

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; Less Risk From Obesity
description: Losing weight -- the perennial New Year's resolution -- may make you more attractive and less prone to disorders like diabetes and high blood pressure. But it will not have a marked effect on your life span, according to a study of more than 300,000 adults. In fact, the study found, obesity's effects on mortality decline as people grow older, until by age 74 there is no relationship between being obese and a higher risk of dying. GINA KOLATA

title: The Lives They Lived; Life Is Short, Art Is Long
description: When Roy Lichtenstein, the Pop master, died unexpectedly in September at the age of 73, it happened that the sluggish market for his work got a jolt, while the death of Willem de Kooning earlier in the year, at 92, caused a brief dip. The lesson is obvious. Death is not necessarily a great career move.

title: Some Inadvertent Tosses Out the Fiscal Window
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald: You know, Hem, the rich are different.

title: A Classically Riveting 'View From the Bridge'
description: THE PERSON IN THE box office may tell you that ''A View From the Bridge'' has a playing time of 2 hours and 15 minutes, but pay no attention. It seems to be no more than 45 minutes, which would include the 15-minute intermission, the only thing about this revival of the Arthur Miller classic that drags.

title: Black-White: Everyday Slights
description: To the Editor:

title: The Debs Come Out Like Stars
description: ''BRING on the girls!'' said a man entering the Basildon Room in the Waldorf-Astoria on Monday night, where a long line had formed to congratulate the latest crop of that hardy winter perennial, the international debutante.

title: Southern Comfort
description: LANDSCAPES OF THE HEART A Memoir. By Elizabeth Spencer. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: Random House. $24.

title: The World: New World Audit; Fail-Safe Strategies In a Market Era
description: THE setting was the White House Situation Room. It was the second crisis meeting of the day in the famous underground briefing center, where, in Hollywood's imaginings, vast screens illuminate the day's catch from spy satellites and orders are barked through secure links to American outposts around the globe.

title: Deaths From Traffic Accidents Down Statewide in 1997
description: The number of fatal accidents on New Jersey roads fell about 5 percent in 1997, offsetting an increase the year before, the State Police reported last week. From Jan. 1 to Dec. 29, 773 people were killed on the roads, said Trooper Al Della Fave, a spokesman for the state police. The figure was 806 for the same period in 1996, compared with 773 for all of 1995, he said. He could not explain the increase in 1996 but said the reduction in 1997 was due largely to a State Police campaign to curb aggressive driving. The campaign used a $450,000 Federal grant to pay for additional patrols and telephone lines to report reckless drivers to State Police dispatchers. Some 35,000 tickets resulted, about one-third of them for speeding, Trooper Della Fave said.

title: Black-White: Everyday Slights
description: To the Editor:

title: Did the Patriots Conceal the Real Nature of Martin's Injury? It Appears So
description: What makes New England running back Curtis Martin so good is the strength in his lower body. With powerful legs and a low center of gravity, Martin can either outrun defenders or run through them.

title: Lisa Brown, Kevin Cullen
description: Elizabeth Merrill Brown, the deputy counsel to Vice President Al Gore, and Dr. Kevin Joseph Cullen, a cancer specialist and researcher, were married yesterday in Washington at the home of the bride's mother, Elinor Farquhar. Judge John C. Godbold, a senior judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Montgomery, Ala., officiated.

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; Down the Hatch
description: There's nothing quite like starting the day by bellying up to the bar and downing a shot. At Aquarius Health Foods in Teaneck, the bellies are taut, the bar is deep green and the shots are of liquefied wheat grass.

title: Cutting Loose in Cajun Country
description: DAYLIGHT is still an hour away in Elton, La., and already the oaks are thick with humidity. The air, the trees, even the houses have a strange languor even though it is winter. Fog hovers in the dense brush, along gravel roads and wood-plank bridges and sloughs, and when I step from my car into the driveway of the Bertrand family farmstead, even my breath seems different -- more fluid than three hours ago when I crossed from Texas into Louisiana.

title: Indoor Boat Show Takes Float Out of the Flotilla
description: It might be an anachronism of sorts to stage a boat show when the snow flies. But the New York National Boat Show, in its 88th edition this year, opened its doors yesterday to a thousand reminders of summer days.

title: 'Chorus Line' Remains Legend With Kick, Relating Stage Stories
description: ''A CHORUS LINE'' has been performed everywhere, on all levels from amateur to professional.

title: Long Days on the Picket Line at Car Dealer
description: TO Joe Giordano, the seven days of Christmas were like the previous 140 days. A shop steward at King O'Rourke Cadillac in Smithtown, Mr. Giordano has been walking a picket line for 20 weeks.

title: Nagano
description: Getting around Nagano using anything other than feet these days takes about twice as much time as normal -- at least. To be sure, congestion is nothing new to Nagano, the funnel through which most weekend skiers pass on their way to the Japan Alps, the breathtakingly beautiful mountains that will be home to the 1998 Olympic Winter Games from Feb. 7 through 22.

title: Not Fair to Ewing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STUDENT LIFE: Headlines From the Fall Semester; The Chelsea Ban
description: Students returned to Stanford this year to find their campus transformed by media frenzy over the enrollment of Chelsea Clinton. The student paper, The Stanford Daily, received its share of attention when the editor in chief, Carolyn Sleeth, dismissed a staff member for violating the paper's ''No-Chelsea'' policy.

title: Can One Die Not in Pain, Not in Fear?
description: DR. PETER SELWYN learned to care for people who were dying in the early days of the AIDS epidemic, when he worked in a large drug abuse treatment center at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. ''I learned by being there,'' Dr. Selwyn said. ''I found myself immersed in the epidemic in the Bronx. I felt drawn to something I couldn't walk away from.''

title: Church Is Making Dreams Come True
description: THE Memorial Economic Development Corporation in Roosevelt, which helped bail out Nassau County in a crisis in 1993, is now helping the Town of Hempstead.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's policy on small schools misidentified the sponsor of a conference at which Dr. Crew expressed his support for them. The sponsor was New York Networks for School Renewal. (New Visions for Public Schools is one of four partners in New York Networks for School Renewal.)

title: S Words
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lives They Lived: Sanford Meisner; The Proof Is in the Protege
description: b. 1905 He came out of the Group Theater and was among a handful of truly great acting teachers. A sophisticated former actor and classical musician, he ran the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theater in Manhattan for almost a half-century.

title: The Lift Tick
description: Now it's possible to tell time and beat the ski-ticket lines, too. Swatch has a watch that can be programmed for a day's, a week's or a season's worth of skiing: a simple swipe of the wrist at a turnstile allows the skier to pass right through.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: PROSPECT: The Journey of an Artist

title: Unabashedly Continental With Feeling
description: RESTAURANTS that have opened in recent years on the Island tend to be narrow, specialized, targeted. They are not Italian anymore but Tuscan, Sardinian or Sicilian. American spots often define themselves as Californian or Southwestern. It is therefore a mild surprise to find that Hugo's, a newly opened restaurant in the Southdown Shopping Center in Huntington, is unabashedly Continental.

title: The Lives They Lived: Laura Nyro; Five Songs to Freedom
description: b. 1947 There were great female songwriters before Laura Nyro (pronounced NEER-o), just as there were great black ballplayers before Jackie Robinson. But after the week of Nov. 29, 1969, when she had sole authorship of Nos. 2, 3 and 10 on the pop charts, female songwriters were in the big leagues to stay.

title: Seeking Water on Moon In New NASA Mission
description: Twenty-five years after the last Apollo astronaut left the Moon, a small unmanned spacecraft is ready to embark on a return trip, the first mission since then designed expressly for lunar exploration. One of its priorities is to answer the question, Is there water on the Moon?

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: United Nations Of Queens
description: ELIAS CORNER +

title: In the Region/Long Island; Next Role for Otto Kahn's 126-Room Mansion: a Spa
description: IT is the second largest private residence ever built in the United States. Yet the 109,000-square-foot French chateau-style castle known as Oheka, which stands high on a hill here off Jericho Turnpike, is in so secluded a setting that even many local residents are unaware that it's there. Surrounding it is an enclave of about 300 houses and a 168-acre golf course.

title: Applying Brushstrokes to the Civil War
description: MORT KUNSTLER'S third-floor studio overlooks the jeweled waters of Oyster Bay, a blue-gray panorama stretching to Connecticut and beyond.

title: Black-White: Everyday Slights
description: To the Editor:

title: Climbing Toward the Domain Of the Independent-Movie Elite
description: IF YOU'RE A SMALL independent movie company these days, it pays to function like a guerrilla unit: know the terrain, adjust to conditions, take acceptable risks but don't overstep. Get lucky and you may do more than just survive; you may come up with ''Eve's Bayou,'' a little film produced and distributed by Trimark Pictures that has earned critical acclaim, made more than $13 million at the box office since it opened in early November and promises to make a bundle more in video stores.

title: The Art of the Journal
description: To the Editor:

title: Cunningham Is Eager After Taking a Break
description: First they knocked him end over end, then they pumped him up. Late in the game, Randall Cunningham said, some of the victorious 49ers bumped shoulder pads with him and said he could do better than being a backup in this league.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Vita Needle Company, where the work force includes many retirees from various occupations, misstated the year it was founded. It was 1932, not 1934.

title: Architects Of Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Koreans, Patriotic for Now
description: In recent weeks, there has been much made of the South Korean people's national sense of duty and shared sacrifice in the face of their country's deep economic woes, caused by the banking crisis. Mothers have exchanged their babies' 100-day gold rings for Korean won, and office workers have pooled their foreign change for the same purpose.

title: A Fine Idea, All Say, but Too Big?
description: On the surface, the plan to create a Jewish cultural and social center on West 67th Street for assimilated and upscale young Jewish people seems like the sort of place a neighborhood might welcome. But an ad hoc group of neighbors, many who are powerful figures in the news media, business and art worlds, are fighting the project, saying it will worsen congestion on a once-quiet street.

title: A BUCK FOR YOUR THOUGHTS
description: Here's a deer that can go on your wall with no need for shooting or taxidermy. It's a poster of a white-tailed buck from a painting called ''Legend Maker,'' by Carol Decker, a wildlife artist from Branchville. The poster, available from the state Division of Game and Wildlife, commemorates the first Garden State Deer Classic, held in 1989. In the annual fall event, awards are given to those who have bagged the biggest deer in three categories: with shotgun, muzzle-loaded rifle or arrow. While the overall size of the poster is 28 by 22 inches, much of it is the title at the top and a list of sponsors at the bottom. Many people cut the written portion off and frame the picture of the buck, standing in fallen leaves in a forest with a light coating of snow.

title: Today's Futurists Keep One Eye on the Market; Wisdom of Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VREELAND, THEODORE DEMOTT
description: VREELAND-Theodore DeMott, 78. Of Austin, Texas, formerly of Princeton, New Jersey, died on Christmas Day, 1997. Private services are planned.

title: STUDENT LIFE: Headlines From the Fall Semester; Dancing Permitted
description: Students attending Wheaton, a nondenominational Christian college in the Chicago suburbs, were once barred from playing cards, going to the movies or listening to jazz. These restrictions were lifted years ago, but a ban on dancing remained.

title: Riley and Checketts Go Another Round in Their Disagreement
description: Their acrimonious split is more than two years old, making up only a chapter in the evolving saga of the Knicks in the 1990's. Yet after reading January's issue of GQ magazine, you get the feeling Pat Riley and Dave Checketts want to rumble all over again.

title: Blackboard: NASA for Kids; Flying With Their Feet on the Ground
description: When professors at the University of Nebraska at Omaha introduced dozens of middle school students last fall to their gleaming 28-foot-long mock space shuttle, called Maverick, they issued a stern warning: This is not a carnival ride; you will learn something.

title: A Poe Clings to an S.R.O
description: There is a certain house in the East Village that some neighbors believe is haunted. It is on 10th Street. The doors are peeling and the address ''104'' looks as though it was written in blood.

title: Good Time To Consider Refinancing
description: IT has been said before and may be said again, but it seems that right now really is a good time to think about refinancing your mortgage.

title: Children's Books
description: HERE IN SPACE

title: In a Far Desert, a Startling Trove of Art
description: THE BLEAK DESERT THAT SURROUNDS THIS TOWN stretches for hundreds of miles in every direction, with only an occasional fly-infested truck stop to break the monotony of sand dunes and forlorn camels. Nukus itself is unimpressive, a Soviet-style town with negligible charm or culture. And even for those who bother to penetrate this far into the desolate heart of Central Asia, it is easy to overlook a shabby wooden building that bears a small sign proclaiming it to be an art museum.

title: It's Andrew Cuomo's Turn at Bat, And Some See Makings of Slugger
description: Not long ago, as Mario M. Cuomo lunched with friends at the Rainbow Room atop Rockefeller Center, someone asked him why he had no plans to run for office again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SAMUEL
description: MILLER-Samuel. 79. January 2, 1998. Devoted father of Jean Wilson and Bette Gromis, revered father-in-law of Richard and Robert. Beloved grandfather of Sarah, Micah, Ilana, Julia and Michael. Cherished friend of Elaine Miller. Beloved brother of Lester and Anita and the late Pauline. Funeral services 12:30, Sunday, January 4, Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park, Hackensack, NJ. Shiva observed at the Wilson residence through Wednesday evening.

description: PETE CARROLL finally emerged from the stark coach's office in the visitors' locker room at Three Rivers Stadium.

description: GARSKY-Sam. Dear Sam, To my Beloved Husband, you are gone but not forgotten. We all miss you very much, your daughter, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. You are remembered in our thoughts and in our mind. You will live forever in my heart. Love, your broken hearted, Betty.

title: Endpaper -- The Lives They Lived: Roland Topor; A Graphic Wit
description: b.1938 Best known for his drawings, this Parisian enfant terrible born of Jewish refugees from Warsaw applied his macabre vision with equal ease to novels, theater, opera, television and film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISBERG, BARRETT
description: KREISBERG-Barrett. The entire School of American Ballet family notes with sadness the death of Barry Kreisberg. Chairman of Faculty Peter Martins and President Larry Alan Smith join the Board, Faculty, Staff and Students in their condolences to his family and his colleagues at Harkness. We shall all miss his towering presence at our parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, RUTH
description: COHN-Ruth. Beloved wife of Stephen. Devoted mother of Nancy Richer and Betty Simpson. Dear grandmother of Jared, Amanda, Natalie and Erica. Services 12 noon, Monday, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, LI. In lieu of flowers, contributions to American Institute for Cancer Research.

title: Asian Tremors Leave Sector Managers Shaken but Optimistic
description: PORTFOLIO managers who deal with emerging markets can be forgiven if they do not remember 1997 fondly. During the past 12 months, these developing outposts of capitalism, long noted for volatility, registered swings that bordered on the seismic.

title: Melissa Kimmel, Robert Saperstein
description: Melissa Wendy Kimmel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram R. Kimmel of New York, was married last evening to Robert Andrew Saperstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Saperstein of Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Lee M. Friedlander officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDWELL, DOROTHY (NEE ALEXANDER)
description: CALDWELL-Dorothy (nee Alexander). Of Ridgewood, NJ, formerly of Edgartown MA, died January 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late William A. Loving mother of Tonia Cohen of Ridgewood NJ, Alix McArdle of Newbury MA and William Caldwell of Cohassett, MA. Adoring grandmother of four. A private family committal service will be at a later date. Donations in Mrs. Caldwell's memory should be made to the Martha's Vineyard Hospital Foundation, Oak Bluffs, MA 02557. For more information, contact the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood NJ.

title: Dec. 28-Jan. 3; The U.N. Says It's Time to Pony Up
description: Here's a club to join. Not feeling lucky? Never mind: the dues reflect economic position, on a sliding scale. And don't worry. The bill might be high, but there's always the option of not paying.

title: N.J. EATS: Good Morning, New Jersey. What's for Breakfast?; Beyond the Bagel: When the Usual Just Won't Do
description: At a glance, the dish looks like a scrambled egg concoction. But the fluffy yellow morsels are ackee, from the flowers that grow on a Caribbean fruit tree. The color, taste and texture are indeed like that of creamy scrambled eggs. The ackee is served sauteed and mixed with salty cod, with a bit of onion and tomato. Ackee and codfish, a common dish for lunch and dinner throughout the Caribbean, is one of the breakfast options at Apple's Caribbean Cuisine in Montclair. Other choices, most $5, are codfish with cabbage, okra or callaloo, a spinachlike green; ackee and bacon; sauteed beef liver, and mackerel served with green bananas. The breakfasts include the dense Jamaican bread called hard dough bread and a selection of fried dumplings, boiled green bananas, fried plantain or yams. There are also pancakes and eggs and the like, served with grits and salmon cakes, listed under ''American breakfasts.'' But 90 percent of what Angela Appleby, owner of the restaurant, serves is from the Caribbean list. ''Jamaicans eat big breakfasts,'' she said. They certainly do. CARL SOMMERS

title: In Charge of What?

Companies come up with all kinds of titles, many of them confusing, for the people you need to reach. What are these labels, and what do these workers really do? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Dandy's Handiwork
description: ''How many charming talents have been spoiled by the instilled desire to do 'important' work!'' Max Beerbohm once wrote. ''Some people are born to lift heavy weights. Some are born to juggle with golden balls.'' Beerbohm (1872-1956) was a born juggler who kept the various spheres of his talent balanced from his first publication of sketches while a student at Oxford. As his numerous self-portraits attest, he played the Edwardian dandy, affecting a lazy amateurism while in fact producing a huge corpus of work -- some 500 theater pieces for The Saturday Review, volumes of essays, parodies, stories and ''Zuleika Dobson,'' a novel so fantastic that it qualifies as a subgenre in itself. However, Beerbohm was most prolific as an artist. His more than 2,000 caricatures range in style from loose, Daumier-like impressions of Mark Twain and Lord Tweedmouth to carefully composed scenes depicting entire literary cliques, accompanied by incriminating anecdotes noted in Beerbohm's minute, exquisite cursive. N. John Hall's handsome MAX BEERBOHM CARICATURES (Yale University, $45) reproduces 213 of the best of these, many in color. Hall's witty commentary is supplemented by Beerbohm's own prose as well as contemporary observations by the likes of Virginia Woolf and E. F. Benson. Often the explications rival the caricatures in hilarity: Aldous Huxley is recalled by David Cecil as a ''piece of macaroni'' and by Lytton Strachey as a ''piece of seaweed.'' Beerbohm claimed to know everyone in London, and he pilloried most of them, but generally he did so with such good humor that most forgave him. More entertaining than conventional histories of the period, Hall's collection animates an era of eccentrics, many of whose priceless peculiarities would, but for Beerbohm, have been erased by time. Sarah Harrison Smith

title: Yellowstone Wolves and Diversity
description: In nature as in culture, diversity can be a difficult concept. Understanding it is one thing, accepting it another, especially when diversity means not only acknowledging a pre-existing cornucopia of difference -- the very ampleness of the world -- but also accommodating an adjustment to the status quo. A case in point is the reintroduction of gray wolves in Yellowstone National Park. Thirty-three wolves were released in 1995, and their number has now reached 97. Population expansion is one measure of the wolf program's success, but a better one is the wolves' impact on the natural diversity of the park.

Nash was from the Creggan Estate in Derry, an occupied, bloody battleground for the Irish Republican Army and the British Army, with the Royal Ulster Constabulary and Protestant paramilitary groups close at hand.

title: A Rare Tournament Format Makes the Players Work
description: Some manufactured products fail, it is said, because they are too reliable. The same is true of one method of team play in bridge tournaments: the board-a-match format, which was standard half a century ago, has almost disappeared at the local level because the best players almost invariably win. The almost-expert players prefer Swiss teams or even a knockout because they do not have to work so hard, concentrating on every trick, and with a little luck they can sometimes collect a title.

title: John L. Miller, 93, School Superintendent
description: John Lewis Miller, who was superintendent of the Great Neck, N.Y., public schools from 1942 to 1970, died at his home in Great Neck on Dec. 22. He was 93.

title: An International Fugitive Goes Free
description: An American court should be extraordinarily careful before turning a suspect over to a foreign tribunal for trial. That sensible principle, however, led to a mistaken ruling on Dec. 17 by a Texas judge who freed a Rwandan wanted by an international court for genocide and crimes against humanity. The judge released Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, ruling that there was no constitutional basis to turn him over to the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. His release was based on faulty reasoning.

title: Draped in Darkness, Mahler's Sixth Still Holds Appeal
description: ''Popular'' hardly seems the word for so dark a creation, but in recent years, Mahler's Sixth Symphony has become one of his most often performed works. It seems, in fact, to have challenged the Fifth as the work against which aspiring Mahlerians test themselves.

title: Ethiopian Imprisoned in Arizona Dies Following a Hunger Strike
description: An Ethiopian convicted of murder in Arizona has died after a hunger strike that he called in protest of his prison diet, state officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, MARCELLA STARK
description: ROBBINS-Marcella Stark. 73, formerly of Rockville Centre and New York City. Died unexpectedly January 3 at her home in Ithaca, NY. Loving wife of Allan. Beloved mother of Peter, Helen, Anne and Jim. Adored Nana of Rebecca and David. Cherished aunt, greataunt and great-greataunt. Funeral services were Sunday, January 4, at the Herson Funeral Home, Ithaca.

title: Man Arrested as Fire Levels His Shop and Another
description: A struggling immigrant businessman was charged yesterday with setting fire to his own tire-repair shop in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, triggering a huge explosion that leveled the shop and a car-repair garage next door, heavily damaged a third business and shattered windows in a row of nearby houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBLER, SALOMON
description: LEIBLER-Salomon. Loving husband of Sulamith. Dear father of Myriam and Jerry, Debby and Michael, Helen and Rich. Adored grandfather of Gabriel, Marc, Sara, Rebecca, David, Daniel, Matthew, Lauren and Caryn. Devoted brother of Nathan. Born February 23, 1924. Died January 3, 1997. Dearly loved by all who knew him.

title: College-Essay Angst Is a Symptom of Affluence; Frowning on Fortune?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Girls Are in Hospital After Being Struck by Car
description: Two 10-year-old girls were hospitalized, one in critical condition, after the bicycle they were riding was struck by a car yesterday afternoon on a residential street in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said.

title: Love Affair With Mutual Funds Shows No Evidence of Weakening
description: The mutual fund industry just finished its biggest year ever. A record amount of money flowed into long-term funds -- that is, stock and bond funds combined. Total assets spread among stock, bond and money market funds now top $4 trillion. Even after three straight years of torrid growth, Americans show few signs of slowing down in their drive to accumulate assets for retirement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELIGSON, BERNARD W.
description: ZELIGSON-Bernard W. Beloved husband of the late Helene. Devoted father of Marilyn (Robert) Lefcort, Laurie and Sheryl. Adored grandfather of Melissa and Stephen. Loving brother of Sally and the late Goldie.

title: Rudy Crew's Critics
description: With more than a million students, New York City's school system would be difficult to manage in the best of circumstances. Add in deteriorating buildings, stubborn unions and rapid turnover at the top, and the job seems insuperable. Yet critics are already blasting Chancellor Rudy Crew for not moving fast enough, though he has been in office for only two years.

title: Congressional Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPOLITANO, ANNA (NEE ALFIERI)
description: NAPOLITANO-Anna (nee Alfieri) on January 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Arturo; loving mother of Vincent and Joseph. Also survived by three grandchildren, Arturo, Christopher and Vincent. Reposing at R. P. Drago Funeral Home, 43-10 30th Avenue, Long Island City. Funeral Tuesday, 8:45 AM, St. Rita's R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. Entombment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5 7-9 PM

title: On Taxes, Count on Congress for More Discussion but No Big Changes
description: The Republicans and the Democrats have signaled that this year they are set to repeat the performances that led to the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997. Unfortunately for taxpayers, that legislation has been described by many experts as a badly drafted mess that, while promising simplicity and fairness, actually adds complexity and creates burdens for many people, especially those with modest incomes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYD, ROBERT G.
description: BOYD-Robert G. Of Madison, NJ, on December 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Judith Hyde Boyd and the late Jean Stephenson Boyd. Father of Robert G. Boyd, Jr. of North Carolina, Stephen R. Boyd of Pennsylvania and Gregory P. Boyd of Virginia. Also survived by 11 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, 65 South St, Morristown, NJ, on Friday, January 9, 1998, at 11 AM. For information call Wm. A. Bradley & Son, Funeral Directors, 345 Main St, Chatham, NJ. Those who wish may contribute to the Morristown Memorial Hospital Health Foundation, in memory of Robert G. Boyd, 100 Madison Ave, Morristown, NJ 07962-1956.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLITZ, LESTER MURRAY
description: KARLITZ-Lester Murray, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted father of Jeffrey and Gloria Karlitz, Ellen and Louis Rothman. Dear brother of Edith Wald. Adored grandfather of Allison, Lori and Wendy Rothman and Paul Karlitz. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: NETANYAHU'S HOLD ON POWER IS HURT AS MINISTER QUITS
description: Contending that he had no further place in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's right-wing coalition, Foreign Minister David Levy resigned today, leaving the embattled Government with a razor-thin majority in Parliament.

title: In the Publishing Industry, the High-Technology Plot Thickens
description: After a tumultuous two years of declining sales and heavy returns of unsold titles, the publishing industry is facing another sluggish year with hopes that high-technology electronic sales and old-fashioned good writing will provide some relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, HOWARD
description: GILMAN-Howard. On January 3, 1998. President of the Howard Gilman Foundation and Chairman of the Board of Gilman Paper Co. Beloved son of Sylvia and the late Charles Gilman. Brother of the late Charles Gilman, Jr. Friends may call at at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Monday, January 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services on Tuesday, January 6, 11 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65th St.

title: Doing the American-Opposition-to-Big-Government 2-Step
description: Americans have long complained about abuses by the Internal Revenue Service. Taking aim at an easy target, in 1997 Washington finally did something about the complaints: With the reluctant support of President Clinton, the House passed, 426 to 4, a ''Taxpayer Bill of Rights,'' setting the stage for what is likely to be an equally lopsided vote in the Senate in 1998.

title: Euro Transformation Will Touch Every Ledger and Purse
description: Absent a huge political or economic calamity, the European single currency, the euro, will make its debut on Jan. 1, 1999. Banks have begun overhauling their computer systems, and many big companies are already making plans for the switch. But the magnitude of the transformation is only beginning to sink in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWELL, BLANCHE (NEE RAUCH)
description: POWELL-Blanche (nee Rauch). Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Joan and Arnold Kerzner of Belmont, MA. Dear grandmother of Jeffrey, Leslie and Stephen. Also survived by many loving friends. Donations in her memory to NCJW Forest Hills Section.

title: Phone Companies Race To Find Their Suitors
description: There was a time when following the telecommunications industry meant following the actual business of telecommunications. Those days, like rotary telephones, are long gone. In 1997, takeovers became almost as important to this industry as dial tones. Clearly beating out the year's No. 2 telecommunications story -- the failure of any regional Bell company to offer long-distance service -- mergers, proposed and actual, became the biggest story in one of the nation's most dynamic industries (notwithstanding a Federal judge's bombshell ruling six hours before the year's end that invalidated broad swaths of the Telecommunications Act of 1996).

title: Debate Starts Over Prospect of Budgets Without Deficits
description: With growing optimism that the Federal budget deficit can be eliminated within a year or two, the Clinton Administration and Congress are edging toward addressing the nation's longer-term fiscal problems, most notably the looming insolvency of the Social Security system.

title: An Actor's Persona Fascinates by Being Forgettable
description: I like Oliver Stone movies, but I never saw his ''Nixon'' when it was in the theaters in 1995, and I never rented it on video. As the child of good California Democrats, I grew up hating Nixon. When I was in my 20's and he was President, he gave me more reason to hate him than I ever wanted. When he died I didn't want to think about him anymore.

title: Where Microsoft Wants to Go Today
description: The upbeat, bouncy television commercials set to rock music show all-American scenes of consumerism, happy people of all walks of life using Microsoft products. They end with the uplifting question: ''Where do you want to go today?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FINKELSTEIN, BERNARD
description: FINKELSTEIN-Bernard January 5, 1986 Pappy dearest, you enriched our lives forever. Your family.

title: Fiber Optics Venture
description: The Williams Companies, a natural gas pipeline concern, is expected to announce today that it will once again offer a fiber optic network to telephone companies that are seeking added capacity because of strong demand.

title: Big Tobacco on the Line In Congress
description: The next few months may well decide the financial and legal future of the tobacco industry.

title: Draw Is Agreed in 3d Game Of Karpov-Anand Title Match
description: It is not clear why Anatoly Karpov, with the minimal advantage of the first move, did so little yesterday in Game 3 of his International Chess Federation World Championship Match against Viswanathan Anand, the challenger. He varied from his play in Game 1, but in a tame way that quickly produced a draw yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, MILTON
description: SPRUNG-Milton. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of Charles (Rebecca), Barry (Mindy), and Helene (Meir). Dear brother of Harold (Reva) Sprung and Pauline (Zachary) Gronowitz. Loving grandfather of Elie, Ari, Nina, Shana, Morgan, Jessica, Shelby, Eytan, Noam and Ezra.

title: As U.S. Toasts the Good Times, Optimism Does Not Go Unchecked
description: SO far, the Asian financial crisis has hit the Boeing Company with all the force of a wispy feather. An Indonesian airline delayed delivery of three planes for less than a week, and some Asian airlines have talked about giving up options to buy new jets. But not one actual order has been canceled, and the Boeing assembly lines are straining to keep up with demand.

title: Style Empire's Busy Czar, So Nice Underneath It All
description: As she breezes into her office, Chelsea Stevens greets her staff with a trilling voice and a stream-of-consciousness message Martha Stewart might envy. ''This morning before breakfast, while I was restocking my trout pond and milking my goat, I realized how much I wanted to tell all of you how much I appreciate all the hard work you do,'' she begins. ''But then later, when I was airing out my quilt and making prosciutto jerky, I reminded myself we can always work harder!''

title: 1997 HIGHLIGHTS
description: Homespun Suitor Wins Fight for MCI

title: Jazz, Honors and Politics; A New Museum Pays Tribute to Musicians but Stirs Criticism
description: To Mayor Emanuel Cleaver, the new Kansas City Jazz Museum, which opened in a historically important but long abandoned neighborhood here in September, is a symbol of optimism and hope. With a vivid, contemporary design and a collection centered on four jazz giants -- Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Ella Fitzgerald and Charlie Parker -- and a live jazz club included under its roof, it is the first major museum in the country devoted to jazz, intended to serve both as a monument to the music that flourished here in the 1920's, 30's and 40's and as a spur to redevelopment in the neighborhood that nurtured it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Chance of Surplus Has 2 Parties Salivating
description: It is a Congressional election year, so more talk than action can be expected in Washington. But when it comes to economic issues, there will be plenty to discuss, and the debate could help shape the nation's agenda for years to come.

title: The Resonance of Other Faces, Other Memories
description: If you happen to be a cable-news producer panting after viewers on a slow news holiday, there's nothing like a big-name death. Michael L. Kennedy's fatal accident caught the attention of every television news operation, but MSNBC was by far the most persistent, moving from the ski slopes in Aspen, Colo., where the risk-taking family disported, to the church were it went to mourn and the cemetery where it has gone to bury and be buried. The station devoted hours and hours to exhibiting the Kennedy clan like icons and the Kennedy clips like an interminable scrapbook.

title: Sports of The Times; A Tired Levens Leaves The Defenses Weary
description: WHEN the Packers lost Edgar Bennett to Achilles' tendon surgery before the season began, Dorsey Levens suddenly was the reigning Super Bowl champions' workhorse running back.

title: 1997 Sets the Bar High
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 20 percent in 1997, for the third consecutive year, something that had never happened. Can the financial markets ring up another stellar year? Part Two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLYEA, ALEX
description: POLLYEA-Alex. Of New York City. On December 28, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Jessica. Loving father of Eric and Alexandra Pollyea. Dear brother of Pauline Strausberg. Service at the Church Center for UN, 777 UN PLaza, 44th Street and 1st Ave., New York City, Monday, January 5 at 11:30 A.M. Interment Cypress Hill Cemetery. Friends who wish may contribute to Association: Lorris Junec 24, Rue Leon Croc, 91400 Orsay, France in his memory. For further information, please call Westchester Funeral Home (914-337-4585).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAB, CHARLES LLOYD
description: McNAB-Charles Lloyd. On January 3, 1998. Memorial services will be conducted at the Joseph T. Kennedy Funeral Chapel, 117 West 72nd Street, New York City, on Tuesday evening, January 6, 1998, at 6:30 PM. Reverend Johanna-Karen Johannson will be officiating. In lieu of flowers, donations in Charles' name can be made to the Lively Arts. To those who knew Charles, they were aware that ballet was his passion. Donations to this art will be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYER, SAMUEL
description: BAYER-Samuel. Of Flushing, NY. Retired CPA. Beloved husband of the late Edna Bayer. Devoted father of Harriet Cannon and Franklin Bayer. Cherished grandfather of Howard and Jeffrey Cannon. Graveside service 1 PM, today, at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: INSIDE
description: Focusing on Social Security

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORT, JEFFREY DAVID
description: PORT-Jeffrey David. 38, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Woodbury, NY, died January 3, 1998 of Aids Dementia Complex. Beloved son of Nathaniel and Rose Port; loving brother of Dr. Michael and Jacqueline Port. Devoted uncle of William, Lindsey, Allison and Tyler. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to be made in his name to ''A.M.F.A.R.'', American Foundation for Aids Research in New York City. Services will be held 2:15 PM, January 5, 1998 at Star of David Memorial Chapel & Cemetery, North Lauderdale, FL.

title: For a Change, Detroit May Feel Sticker Shock
description: The nation's auto makers and car dealers will probably find themselves working harder this year just to sell the same number of cars and trucks that they sold last year. For shoppers, that could mean lower prices.

title: Editorial Observer; Look! What's That Stuff Falling From the Sky?
description: An old newsroom joke is that three examples make a trend. Manhattan, therefore, is in the midst of an absolute fad of falling-concrete incidents.
