On Madison Avenue, on the Upper West Side, in midtown and the theater district, pieces of buildings are breaking off and hitting the sidewalk like, ahem, a ton of bricks.

title: High Hopes in a Tough Season
description: It was an Upper West Side upbringing for Kyoko Ina, complete with Central Park for a sandbox, weekends at the Bronx Zoo, the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. Her mother had been a swimming champion, her grandfather had run in the Olympics, so it was inevitable that on one visit to Rockefeller Center the ice rink would grab the family's attention as much as the Christmas tree.

title: Deaths of Brown and Foster Merit Investigation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALT, DOROTHY
description: ALT-Dorothy. On January 3, at age 95. Wife of the late Mannie Alt. Mother of Stanley A. and Susan Alt and the late Bernard Alt. Grandmother of five; great-grandmother of five. Services Monday, January 5, 12:45 PM, Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: 1998 SPOTLIGHT
description: OCT. 24 The 20th anniversary of President Carter's signing of the Airline Deregulation Act, which eliminated controls on domestic air fares. The act has encouraged competition as discount carriers have proliferated, but the system it created has led travelers to sometimes scratch their heads as they wonder why they paid $1,000 for a flight that cost their neighbor $100.

title: Waiting for Millennium 'Panic Level' to Rise
description: For several years, technological doomsayers have bleated a dark prophecy of computerized chaos to be brought on by the inability of many computers to interpret dates after 1999. Repair your programs now, they intoned, or be prepared for your systems to freeze in millennial ice.

title: The Broncos Knock Down A Late Pass And a Dream
description: Time was slip ping away the drive, the game, the season for the Kansas City Chiefs. It was the final seconds and the Chiefs, deep in Denver Broncos territory, trailed by 4 points. Click, click, click. A ball of confusion. Tick, tick, tick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, DR. ROBERT E.
description: KAHN-Dr. Robert E. Of New York, formerly of Tenafly, NJ. On January 3, in London, while attending the theater. Loved and survived by mother Irene Kahn, son Joseph Laboy Kahn, sister Joan K. Barrow, nephew and niece Richard Katz and Sue Ann Kates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROVER, HAROLD E.
description: OSTROVER-Harold E. On December 29, 1997. Loving husband of Sheila and the late Lorraine. Beloved father of Meryl and Lewis, father-in-law of Al, and adored grandfather of Leeland. A devoted father of Adrienne and Michael, Michelle and Tom, and Suzanne, caring grandfather of Matthew, Becca and Gabe. Interment on January 2, 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADOLF, SOPHIE
description: PADOLF-Sophie. Beloved wife of the late Frederick; loving mother of Judith Egosi, Stanley Padolf and Laurie Mokriski. Adored grandmother of Alexander Padolf, Charles and David Mokriski. Funeral service Monday, 1 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery. For information call Plaza Memorial Chapel 1-800-227-3974.

title: Pataki, Keeping It Simple, Gains the High Ground
description: When George E. Pataki took office as Governor three years ago this week, his Democratic foes derided him as a puppet of Republican kingmakers, an empty suit whose victory was a fluke, a programmed politician with no vision and no hope of winning a second term. A budget crisis here, a minor scandal there and he would be history, they said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIPILLO, ROBERTA A. (SCHULTHEIS)
description: DIPILLO-Roberta A. (Schultheis). 53, on January 4, 1998. Loving wife of Dr. Frank W. DiPillo; loving mother of Danielle, Frank V., loving stepmother of Dr. Mark, Dr. Steven and Michael. Loving daughter of Charles Schultheis, Sr.; loving sister of Charles H. Schultheis, Jr. Beloved grandmother of four. Services will be held Thursday, January 8 at 10 AM at Our Lady of the Mount Church in Warren, NJ. Cremation will be private. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 at Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd, Watchung, New Jersey.

title: Hot Market For Initial Offerings Tapers Off
description: Despite a few fireworks early in the year, the market for initial public stock offerings ended 1997 with few of the price explosions of the previous few years.

title: Islanders Ask, Where Did All The Promise Go?
description: Six consecutive losses were tough enough, but the seventh was, as Doug Houda said, ''brutal, brutal.'' The Islanders are mired in their worst slump of the season, one whose misery meter was ratcheted up another few notches during Saturday night's 2-1 loss here against the Coyotes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIR, RUTH
description: BAIR-Ruth on January 4, 1998. Wife of the late George Bair, mother of Dr. Stuart Bair, grandmother of Jessica, Joshua and Aaron Bair; sister of Daniel M. Friedenberg. Graduate of Teachers College, Columbia University, former president of Hadassah, Scarsdale. Memorial service will be held at 12:15 PM Monday, the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NY. Interment at Mt. Pleasant, Valhalla, NY following services.

title: 'To Make the Team Better,' Devils Send Guerin to Oilers in Arnott Deal
description: It has become standard procedure on the Devils. Once a player holds out, he is finished as a member of General Manager Lou Lamoriello's team. Yesterday, Bill Guerin became the latest Devil to be dealt after a contract dispute, following such players as Pat Verbeek, Sean Burke and Kirk Muller, who were traded in recent years.

title: Tibetan Mandala Shimmers and Is Gone
description: Yesterday was a day made for strolling or bicycling outdoors, but for those of a different bent, it was a day to wait in line for a few hours in the hope of coming away with a bit of cosmic wisdom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESHEN, STELLA (JACOBS)
description: LESHEN-Stella (Jacobs). On January 3, 1998, in her 97th year. Devoted mother of Herbert and Geri Jacobs, Rochelle and Marvin Schwartz, and the late Roslyn and Leon Gray. Dear sister of Frieda and Harry Gensler. Cherished grandmother, great-grandmother and great-great-grandmother. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Gutterman's Inc, 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was high drama: the brother having to come to this decision. It is a kind of benevolent Cain and Abel story.''

title: 1997 HIGHLIGHTS
description: Companies Continue The Rush to Combine

title: Darrell Halloran, 47, Coach Who Had Best Record at Pace
description: Darrell Halloran, the basketball coach at Pace University, collapsed at halftime of a game against American International College at Pace's Civic Center Gymnasium in Lower Manhattan on Saturday afternoon and was pronounced dead shortly afterward at New York Downtown Hospital. He was 47.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Sports of The Times; Searching To Bridge Racial Divide In Athletics
description: BRETT FAVRE was cruising yesterday at Lambeau Field. The Green Bay Packers' nimble quarterback was peppering Tampa Bay with classic bullet passes, moving, maneuvering. Finally, Favre executed a surprise run on a 2-point conversion attempt and scored. In the exuberance of the moment, Farve jumped up and tried to dunk the football over the crossbar. He didn't make it.

title: 3 Women Held In Kidnapping Of a Driver
description: Three women who kidnapped a driver at a traffic light in Queens and forced him at gunpoint to withdraw money from an automated teller machine were arrested yesterday after the victim overheard them making plans to attend a nightclub and went there with detectives to find them, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: A Reckoning in Asia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: Dollar's Gains Expected to Continue
description: The collapse of Asian currencies against the dollar grabbed the headlines last year. But against other currencies, too, the dollar made remarkably powerful gains, and many analysts think the rise will continue.

title: Heart of Unabom Trial Is Tale of Two Brothers
description: In the courtroom here where Theodore J. Kaczynski is on trial for his life, Monday morning is expected to bring a singular image of brother facing brother.

title: Abroad at Home; The Noble Experiment
description: Practicality has been a feature of American life from the start, and a reason for the country's success. Americans on the whole eschewed ideology. We judged ideas by whether they worked. When they didn't, we tried something else.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, WYATT EMORY
description: COOPER-Wyatt Emory. 5 Jan. 1978. Daddy and Carter within us always. Gloria and Anderson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MENIL, DOMINIQUE
description: De MENIL-Dominique. The Trustees and staff of Dia Center for the Arts note with great sadness the passing of our beloved Trustee, Dominique De Menil. We'll miss her guiding hand, keen judgement and generous spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathies and condolences to her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Dominique inspired us and we will all miss her. The world has lost a guiding light. Board of Trustees Charles Wright, Chairman Michael Govan, Director

title: 1997 HIGHLIGHTS
description: STOCKS

title: Back to Hip-Hop Basics
description: Comebacks and nostalgia tours are beginning to proliferate in hip-hop, as they already do in rock, but rap's current stars have veered from its original course. Hit factories like Sean (Puffy) Combs's Bad Boy Entertainment brand artists' images with Versace couture and their music with yesterday's Top 40 melodies. Conversely, the show presented by the rapper KRS-One at Tramps on Friday night took hip-hop back to its beginnings as street poetry created by young people who made style history in outfits no fancier than an Adidas sweatsuit and an excellent pair of sneakers.

title: Tracing Bout of Illness to Small Lettuce Farm
description: At the dusty elbow of a ragged road named Lovers Lane sits a corrugated tin barn, dull gray and green against the dun-colored hills of central California.

title: American Papers Expect the Good News to Continue for Their Bottom Lines
description: Surveys of newspaper readers show that many think that papers are run by sourpusses who live only to print bad news. Those readers might be surprised to see how downright cheerful and sunny most editors and publishers have been lately about their industry's money-making performance.

title: 1997 HIGHLIGHTS
description: Asian Economies Come Down to Earth

title: Strains Seen As Brazilians Tighten Belts
description: To foreign investors, Brazil's President became a hero last year when he responded to market turbulence by taking painful measures to bolster the nation's fiscal soundness and to stave off a collapse of the currency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAEBER, MARY
description: SCHWAEBER - Mary. Beloved wife of the late Judge Martin Schwaeber; devoted mother of Betty DeBear and Pat Schwaeber. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother; loving sister. Services will be private.

title: The Year's Top Media Buys: Most Wanted 1997 -- The Annual Numbers
description: While Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones and Paul McCartney -- music greyhairs all -- made brief appearances atop the charts when their albums were released, the world of rock, hip hop, country and pop adamantly belonged to youth last year. Hanson, Leann Rimes and Jewel, none older than 25, were among the leading artists.

title: Considering How to Stop Casino Cheats
description: State legislators will consider a number of proposals this year to combat a relatively new problem in Connecticut: people who try to cheat casinos.

title: Trust to Buy Hotel Chain For $2 Billion
description: The Meditrust Companies, a real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it would buy La Quinta Inns Inc. for $2.1 billion in cash and stock in a move to expand its real-estate holdings with its first hotel purchase.

title: Diary's New Day
description: Metropolitan Diary now appears Mondays in The Metro Section.

title: Business World
description: Business Day's annual survey of the economy, markets and industry examines whether the prosperity enjoyed by Wall Street and Main Street in 1997 can continue for another year, and whether problems like the Asian financial crisis will endanger economic growth.

title: Asian 'Bird Flu' Isn't Similar to 1918
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions Over Demand as Digital TV's Network Premiere Nears
description: The most significant revolution in television since the medium's creation starts this summer, when the networks begin commercial broadcasts of digital, high-definition television and retailers begin selling the new wide-screen sets.

title: Is Tokyo Ready, or Willing, to Take On a Broad Overhaul of Industries?
description: A decade from now, 1998 may be remembered as the Year of Reckoning for Japan.

title: National News Briefs; Pennsylvania Crashes Kill 10 People in 2 Towns
description: Two Pennsylvania towns, 45 miles apart, spent the weekend coping with 10 deaths in a pair of strikingly similar auto accidents: a missed turn, a plunge into frigid water and 5 lives lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMESON, HENRY B.
description: JAMESON-Henry B., D.D.S. 85. Formerly of Syossett, NY, died January 2, 1998, in Fredericksburg, VA. Survived by son Charles and one granddaughter. Services 11 AM, January 6, 1998 from Mullins & Thompson Funeral Service in Fredericksburg, VA with burial to follow in Oak Hill Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIOLO, JANE A.
description: TRIOLO-Jane A. of Chatham, New Jersey and New York City on January 2, 1998. Longtime companion of the late Joseph A. Kaplan. Sister of Mrs. Joseph O. Valgenti and Ms. Hilda G. Triolo. Aunt of Ms. Dorothy Jane Valgenti, Ms. Joanna Valgenti-Ernst and Frank J. Valgenti. Funeral services at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street, Chatham, on Tuesday, January 6, 1998, at 11 AM with visitation at 10 AM.

title: 'L.A. Confidential' Wins National Critics' Awards
description: ''L.A. Confidential,'' a nouveau noir film about crime and corruption during the postwar boom years, finished its sweep of the year-end critics' awards by being named best picture by the National Society of Film Critics yesterday.

title: Conditions seem ripe for more and more turbulence on Madison Avenue.
description: MADISON Avenue has just experienced what may be the busiest back-to-back years in its history as 1997 followed in the frenzied footsteps of 1996. Again, accounts with billions of dollars in billings shifted among agencies at a dizzying pace, dozens of large creative and media assignments underwent consolidation, high-profile executives switched jobs frequently, and big agency companies acquired scores of smaller shops.

title: Mariucci Gives the 49ers an Edge as They Prepare to Stop the Packers and Favre
description: San Francisco Coach Steve Mariucci spent most of this morning watching film of his team's spectacular victory over Minnesota on Saturday. It was rated G -- for great. By smacking around a solid Minnesota team, 38-22, San Francisco proved that it is more than capable of stepping up its game.

title: What Sharpton Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKARZEL, YEMNA HELEN
description: MOKARZEL-Yemna Helen. Died January 2, 1998. Daughter of Salloum and Helen Kalil Mokarzel. She is survived by her sisters Mary Mokarzel and Alice Jaoudi, and many loving nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her sisters Rose Tanous and Lila Hatab. She attended Columbia University School of Journalism; she served for a time as Lebanon correspondent for the Lebanese American Journal (the English version of Al Hoda Daily, established 1898). Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington and 66th. Donations may be made in her name to Catholic Near East Welfare, 1011 First Ave, NYC.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Travelers Should Expect Costs to Rise Again
description: Because of the strength of the United States economy, travelers have been filling airplanes and hotel rooms to levels not seen in years. With no immediate end to the boom in sight, experts generally expect travel costs to rise by as much as 7 percent in 1998, several percentage points more than the current general inflation rate.

title: Equity Offerings Are Set
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Pastor Resigns From a Divided Chelsea Parish
description: The pastor of a Roman Catholic church in Chelsea who became the focus of a bitter parish conflict by seeking to mute some of its independent-minded, progressive traditions resigned yesterday after 15 months, likening himself to a man who had caught a bus for Detroit but wound up in Kansas City.

title: Since 70's, the World Has Become Safer for Consumerism
description: The 1997 movie ''The Ice Storm'' gave Americans a bleak view backward to the early 70's and, as a vivid aside, reminded them how far many consumer products have come since then.

title: Brahms Lore Galore and a Myth Debunked
description: JOHANNES BRAHMS

title: Signs of Recovery, but the Hard-Hit Brace for 'Ugly' Year
description: In a new ritual of Thailand's hard times, people who call themselves the ''formerly rich'' have been gathering every weekend in a carnival atmosphere to sell their status symbols: expensive cars, designer clothing, thousand-dollar watches, even a light airplane.

title: Cambodia Coup Leader Battles Instability
description: Six months after leading a coup in which he ousted his coalition partner, Cambodia's leader, Hun Sen, is still struggling to consolidate political and military control in a country that is less stable than ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHATZKY, EMANUEL
description: CHATZKY-Emanuel. On January 2, Deerfield Beach, FL. Dearly beloved husband of Leonore. Devoted father of Joel and Barbara. Loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Daniel, Stacie and the late Debra, and Mark and Michelle. Dear brother of Jerome. He'll remain in our hearts forever.

title: What's New at the Store
description: Like consumers who vow each year to snuff out a smoking habit or to make fewer trips to the refrigerator, manufacturers of everything from cars to computer software have lofty goals for new products in 1998. Some items are truly innovative while others may be just silly enough to work.

title: Fed Awaiting Clear Signs At Crossroads
description: Case 1: The economy continues to expand briskly this year. The unemployment rate remains low, and employers have to raise wages to attract the workers they need to keep up with demand. To maintain profit margins, companies start pushing prices higher, and before long inflation again becomes a threat to destabilize a business expansion that is nearly seven years old.

title: Restaurant Patron Sought In Death of Injured Man
description: A Long Island man who spent two weeks in a coma after being punched in the face during an argument in an East Village restaurant died over the weekend, and the police said yesterday that they wanted to question the man suspected of throwing the punch.

title: Next Lesson for Nets: How to Win on Road
description: When, John Calipari wonders, will his team take the next step? It eats at him, befuddles him, angers him, wears him out.

title: Essay; Respect Your Adversaries
description: The first guy I ran into at Sally Quinn and Ben Bradlee's New Year's Eve party was Bruce Babbitt.

title: College-Essay Angst Is a Symptom of Affluence; Schools Should Interview
description: To the Editor:

title: In One Play, Houston Becomes a Driving Force
description: Allan Houston slipped out of his old skin as if he were shrugging off an overcoat Saturday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, ETHEL C. (NEE COHEN)
description: PHILLIPS-Ethel C. (nee Cohen). On December 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Lloyd Jay; loving mother of L. James (Mary Ann) and Anne; dear grandmother of L. Jeffrey and Lindsey. Memorial service Tuesday, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, NYC. Contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Speculation About Pol Pot Stirs Cambodia's Uncertainty
description: Unconfirmed reports are circulating here and in Cambodia that the Khmer Rouge founder, Pol Pot, may have fled his jungle stronghold in that country, perhaps to take refuge in China.

title: 'Postman' Sinks; 'Titanic' Sails
description: Nearly two dozen films have opened in recent weeks, but as far as anyone here is concerned, there are only two movies, at almost opposite ends of the box office, that have stirred the town's attention.

title: College-Essay Angst Is a Symptom of Affluence
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas Mayers, Stamford Mayor And Retailer, 88
description: Thomas Crawford Mayers, a retired department store executive and former Mayor of Stamford, Conn., died on Dec. 20 at a nursing home in Stamford where he had lived since 1995. He was 88.

title: This Time, Cowher Hopes to Head Off the Hoopla
description: Defeats may have taught Bill Cowher more than victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILIDES, MICHAEL CHARLES
description: FILIDES-Michael Charles. Of Boston, MA, December 25, 1997. Father of Melissa and Daphne. Longtime friend of Kathe Andress. Graduate Phillips Acadmey, U. of Penn and Wharton School. Former owner of the Nardest Gallery in Boston. Service private.

title: Chinese Face Uncertainties From Asia's Financial Chaos
description: The numbers look good. It's what they hide that is not so pretty.

title: Stocks Romp Smartly On; Will Nothing Stop the Bull?
description: IN the 1990's, the performance of the American stock market has been nothing short of amazing, particularly in the last three years. Over that stretch, investors in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have seen their money more than double. That had never happened before in so short a period.

title: Touchy Issue of Bigger NATO: Spy Agencies
description: As NATO membership for three Central European nations draws closer, officials in Washington and Western Europe are scrambling to deal with one of the most sensitive aspects of the alliance's expansion: the trustworthiness of intelligence agencies in the former Soviet-bloc countries.

title: U.S. AUTO MAKERS SHOWING INTEREST IN FUEL EFFICIENCY
description: Having fiercely but unsuccessfully opposed a global warming treaty and other environmental initiatives last year, American auto makers are stepping up their research into cleaner, more fuel-efficient cars and making ambitious plans for bringing their advanced designs to market.

title: Herds Thinned by Rare Deep Snow in New Mexico
description: Ellen Robey waited this weekend for a salvage truck to haul away the last of the dead calves piled on her ranch 30 miles south of here.

title: 5th Ave. Still Drying Out After Main Break
description: Dan Esch was asleep in his basement apartment early Friday morning when his roommate said something about a flood. He opened his eyes and saw his cat's litter box floating through the bedroom with the cat inside. Books, shoes and a pair of pants were floating, too.

title: An Interview With Kim Dae Jung
description: In his first interview since he was elected president of South Korea on Dec. 19, Kim Dae Jung said Sunday that he had warned the outgoing government to take some emergency steps on the economy but that "it disregarded every one of my proposals."

title: The Neediest Cases; Coins on the Sidewalk Teach a Lesson in Compassion
description: Pennies discarded on the sidewalk may seem like grimy germ colonies to some, but Richard Kaye sees them as the building blocks of a small fortune. ''It's amazing to me that people would rather drop a penny on the ground than take it,'' he said yesterday. ''It's such a shame.''

title: Degrees of Success Define Two Careers
description: Ed McCaffrey won his share of games at Stanford. He reached the playoffs with the Giants. He won a Super Bowl XXIX championship ring with the San Francisco 49ers. He is a Denver Broncos receiver now, and he is on his way to the American Football Conference championship game. He is one step away from Super Bowl XXXII.

title: From Charred Ruins, a Church Reborn
description: The parishioners of St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church stood shoulder to shoulder in June and wept. Octogenarian descendants of Italian immigrants and teen-agers from the Dominican Republic watched in horror as flames consumed their century-old church in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JAMES D.
description: WALSH-James D. On New Year's Day, 1998. Born February 25, 1910, in New York City. Beloved father of Mary Grace Erbacher, Deirdre Lambe and Kitty Errett, devoted grandfather of six and greatgrandfather of five. Funeral Mass Jan. 3, 11 AM, St. Mary Church, Lakeville, CT. Memorial Mass Jan 7, 6 PM, Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82 St, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations: Marymount Manhattan College, NY, or Noble Horizons Village Fund, Salisbury, CT.

title: When Dying Is as Hard as Birth
description: My sister, mother and husband died within nine months of each other last year. The cause of death: morphine. Each of them, while terminally ill with heart disease or cancer, was gently pushed over the edge because a close family member, acting as proxy, agreed to the use of morphine, which eased pain but also hastened death. This process of death by sedation, called ''double effect'' in the medical profession, is the physician-assisted death that occurs every day, but is largely ignored in the current debate on death and dying in America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CECHURA, RADIM
description: CECHURA-Radim. On January 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Deborah. Devoted father of Michael and Lukas. Loving brother of Vaclav, Jiri, the late Libusa, and brotherin-law of Vera, all of Prague. Taken much too soon, he will live in the hearts of his family and friends in the United States, Austria and the Czech Republik. Funeral Mass Monday, 11 AM, St. Cecilia's Church, Englewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. For further information, contact the Barrett Funeral Home, Tenafly, NJ.

title: As More Traps Loom, 1997's High Scores for Banks May Be Hard to Repeat
description: Bankers used to inhabit a staid, predictable world, one marked by a golf-course-like serenity that was occasionally interrupted by their proclivity for making extraordinarily bad loans. While bad lending habits persist, banking is no longer a chummy stroll around the links.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, JANE S.
description: POLLACK-Jane S. The Trustees' Council of Penn Women mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague Jane S. Pollack. The Trustees' Council of Penn Women

title: Oil Prices Expected To Be Firm
description: An underpinning of the economic boom of the 1990's has been the relative steadiness of oil prices. While big oil-producing countries have been frustrated by an inability to raise prices, American drivers, and hence the whole economy, have benefited from steady costs at the pump.

title: 1998 SPOTLIGHT
description: APRIL 1 Japan's ''big bang'' - a sweeping deregulation of the financial sector that opens the door wider to domestic and foreign competition - is scheduled to get under way with the start of the new fiscal year.

title: Progress on Health Costs, But Nagging Woes Persist
description: Five years after the Harry and Louise television commercials helped kill the Clinton Administration plan for Government-nurtured managed competition in health care, competition is thriving in the marketplace. But the buyers and the sellers are still struggling to find a way to manage the health care monster in a way that assures both high quality and affordable costs.

title: Packers Get Desired Result Despite Subpar Performance
description: The Green Bay Packers can now say they have reached that true championship level where a team can overcome its foibles and still win.

title: Kenya's Leader Wins a 5th Term, But Opposition Candidates Gain
description: President Daniel arap Moi was officially declared the winner of Kenya's presidential election today, giving a final term to a 20-year-old administration widely criticized for corruption and mismanagement.

title: How the Mighty Have Fallen, and Sometimes Profited Anyway
description: Looking back over a year in which many high-profile executives abruptly left their jobs, one question seems hard to shake: Can't anybody play this game?

title: Op-Ed Columnists
description: Beginning today, the Op-Ed columnists will appear on the following schedule:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, GORDON ''BUDDY.''
description: BENDER-Gordon ''Buddy.'' Age 58, of East Brunswick, NJ, engineer with Structure Tone Inc. of NYC, on January 2, 1998. Services were Sunday in Mt. Sinai Memoriral Chapels, East Brunswick. Burial Knollwood Park, Ridgewood, NY.

title: 1998 SPOTLIGHT
description: NOV. 1 By this day, the broadcast television networks have pledged to begin broadcasting digital television, much of it in high-definition. But some of them will probably start months earlier, with the start of the fall season. Television manufacturers intend to put the first high-definition television sets on sale starting in August or September.

title: Modern Refuses To Detain 2 Schieles
description: Pleading legal restraints, the Museum of Modern Art has turned down appeals from two families to hold on to two Egon Schiele paintings whose provenance is clouded by Nazi wartime plundering, choosing instead to ship them as planned to their next destination in Barcelona, Spain.

title: New Jersey, Megan's Home, Limits 'Her' Law
description: Months ago, Alaska posted a list of its 1,600 paroled sex offenders on the World Wide Web. California provides information on about 64,000 offenders on CD-ROM at any county sheriff's office or big-city police department. And three months ago, Connecticut began letting local police stations release the names, addresses and pictures of paroled offenders to anyone who calls.

title: Koznick Makes Believer of Herself
description: Kristina Koznick will ski against the world's finest slalom racers here on Monday morning, but before she dons her helmet and the rest of her requisite plastic armor, she will sit in the warmth of her hotel room and compose a letter to herself.

title: Buoyant Stock Market Keeps Mergers in Pipeline
description: Telephone companies, regional banks, Wall Street firms, hotels and casinos, oil and gas ventures, radio and television stations -- the list is almost endless as a growing procession of industries is caught up in the enthusiasm for takeovers.

title: Campbell Takes Risks Seeking Ranger Rewards
description: It is hard enough to be Brian Leetch this season, but it hurts more to be his partner on the Rangers' defense. Leetch's original mate, Jeff Beukeboom, suffered a broken left ankle on Dec. 16 and will probably not be back until late this month. Ulf Samuelsson, who replaced Beukeboom on Leetch's right flank, sprained the medial collateral ligament in his right knee on Saturday night in a 3-2 victory in Washington. Usually a quick healer, Samuelsson might return in two weeks.

title: Howard Gilman, Executive And Philanthropist, Dies at 73
description: Howard Gilman, the chairman of the Gilman Paper Company, who was a philanthropist and a collector of photographs and other art, died on Saturday on an estate near Jacksonville, Fla. He was 73 and lived in midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, HERBERT J.
description: SIEGEL-Herbert J. January 3, 1998. Husband of Jacqueline (nee Rappoport) of Wyncote, PA. Services and interment will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, W. HARCOURT
description: WOODS-W. Harcourt. Age 85, of Short Hills, NJ, on Saturday, January 3, 1998. Husband of Mary Morrow Britten Woods and the late Mary-Alice Caldwell Woods. Father of Whitney Woods Taylor, Kendall Woods, W. Harcourt Woods, Jr., David M. and Peter M. Britten and Margaret Britten Sorge. Also survived by eight grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, January 6, 1998, in Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave, Short Hills, NJ, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Overlook Hospital, Summit, NJ 07901, Christ Church or the International Tennis Hall of Fame, Newport, RI 02840.

title: College-Essay Angst Is a Symptom of Affluence; Require S.A.T. Essay
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Urged to Crack Down on Ulster Prisoners
description: The outbreak of violence in Northern Ireland has drawn calls for asserting greater Government authority at the province's top-security prison, where paramilitary groups exercise largely uncontested internal control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILWORTH, J. RICHARDSON
description: DILWORTH-J. Richardson. On December 29, 1997. Beloved husband, devoted father and proud grandfather. Memorial service will be at 12PM, Saturday, January 10, in the Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, NJ. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers will officiate. A reception will be held afterward at Prospect House on the University Campus. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Melissa Dilworth Gold '61 Visiting Artists Fund at Milton Academy, 170 Centre Street, Milton, MA. 02186. Melissa Dilworth Gold died in a helicopter accident in 1991.

title: In Place of the Abused; A Doctor Works in the Grim World of Battered Children
description: Dr. Linda Cahill spends her days dealing with the darkest part of people's hearts, the part that allows mothers to batter their sons, fathers to molest their daughters, trusted friends to beat their young charges.

title: The Chief Justice and Mr. Hatch
description: No one has ever accused Chief Justice William Rehnquist of bleeding-heart tendencies. It was thus extraordinary for him to get into a confrontation last week with Senator Orrin Hatch and other conservative Republicans over what the Chief Justice said was an inexcusable holdup by the Senate over President Clinton's nominations for the Federal bench. Mr. Hatch, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, dismissed the criticism, blaming President Clinton for the delays and the Federal judges for the problem of overworked courts. His response was disingenuous. The vacancies in nearly 1 out of 10 seats on the Federal bench result from obstructionism by certain members of the Senate.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAKE, DONALD LEWIS
description: LEAKE-Donald Lewis, M.D. Surgeon, oboist, died December 31, 1997 at home in Rolling Hills, CA. He was 66. Dr. Leake attended USC and was Fulbright Scholar in Brussels (1956), principal oboist with Robert Shaw Chorale (195455), San Diego Symphony (195459), and other ensembles. He performed world premiere solo obo works by Milhaud, Kraft, Parker, Volkert, Zador, and Linn, and recorded extensively. Dr. Leake also dedicated his life to medicine, serving 26 years as Chief of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, HarborUCLA Medical Center. His pioneering use of biomaterials in craniofacial reconstruction broadened the scope of his specialty. Dr. Leake is survived by his wife, Rosemary, his son John, daughters Catherine and Elizabeth, sonin-law Soren Germer and granddaughter, Alexandra. Funeral services will be held at Green Hills Memorial Park, 27501 S. Western Ave., Rancho Palos Verdes, CA, Wednesday, January 7 at 3 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, EVELYN
description: KRAMER-Evelyn. On January 2, 1998. Wife of Seymour. Mother of Ann and Mark. Loving grandmother of Michael and Daniel. Sister of Joseph Feldman. Her's was a life of love and tenderness.

title: Plan Will Save Theaters
description: To the Editor:

title: George W. Irving, 87, Biochemist Who Led Study of Food Additives
description: George W. Irving Jr., a food-safety expert who led a major Federal study that found most food additives to be safe but recommended limits on added salt, died on Dec. 27 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 87.

title: Waters Off Guatemala Offer a Fine Catch of Sailfish
description: The west coast of Guatemala seems to smolder, as an eternal cloud of smoke rises from fields of burning sugar cane. At times, even the 13,000-foot peak of Volcano Fuego, which looms above the coastal villages, fades to a mere shadow, choked off in a browning haze.

title: College-Essay Angst Is a Symptom of Affluence; Writing, Down the Tube
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; Campaign of '98, Promise of '71
description: TWENTY-SEVEN years ago, when Bella S. Abzug emerged from the feminist movement to become a nationally known Congresswoman representing Manhattan, she had no doubt that her election marked the start of an era. By the century's end, Ms. Abzug assumed, women would routinely hold senior elected positions across New York State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGO, DR. FRANK W.
description: LONGO-Dr. Frank W. On January 2, 1998. Family will receive friends on Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Coxe Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck. Funeral mass Tuesday 10 AM at Our Lady of Sorrows RC Church in White Plains followed by an interment at Fairfield Memorial Cemetery in Stamford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, STEPHEN G.
description: BERRY-Stephen G. December 31, 1997. Suddenly while on vacation in Ireland, Steve, of Croton-OnHudson, NY and Columbia University, NYC. Sadly missed by his wife, Mary (O'Neill), his parents Pat and Gerry (Exton, PA); his father-in-law, Tony O'Neill; his brother-in-law, Declan and family; his sister-in-law, Joan, and friends and colleagues in the U.S. and Ireland. Return to New York Tuesday, January 6, to Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY. 914-769-0001

title: 2 Systems May Help Pilots Detect Turbulence
description: To the Federal Aviation Administration, the problem seems almost insurmountable: every year, a dozen or so airplanes hit turbulence so severe that the cabins of big jets suddenly resemble roller coasters. Passengers and flight attendants suffer broken bones, concussions and, once in a while, like Dec. 28 on a United Airlines flight from Tokyo, death.

title: Pataki Wants to Speed Cuts In Property Tax for Elderly
description: Taking a first, potent step into an election year, Gov. George E. Pataki will call for accelerating scheduled property tax cuts for most elderly New Yorkers, so they will get the full benefit in the months before the November election, rather than in 2001, aides said today.

title: Judicial Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: FIFTH THIRD IN $904 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR STATE SAVINGS
description: Fifth Third Bancorp agreed yesterday to acquire State Savings, a privately held savings and loan holding company based in Columbus, Ohio, for $904 million in stock. State Savings has assets of $2.8 billion and 53 offices in Ohio and Arizona. Fifth Third, a bank holding company based in Cincinnati, agreed to pay State Savings 11.1 million shares of Fifth Third common stock. Shares of Fifth Third rose 50 cents yesterday, to $82. David E. Reese, chairman of State Savings, will become a director of Fifth Third and will oversee the bank's Arizona business, which will have 10 branches and $500 million in assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, KARL, HEINZ
description: MOHR-Karl-Heinz, age 29. Performance Analyst at J.M. Hartwell, L.P. of New York City suddenly on Sunday, January 4, 1998. Beloved son of Michael and Angela (De Blasio) Mohr. Loving brother of Marina. Dear nephew of Maria Pia De Blasio, M.D., and Enzo and Maria De Blasio. Loving cousin of Nello and Anna De Blasio. Funeral Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, on Thursday at 9:30 A.M. Mass of Christian burial St. Frances de Chantal at 10 A.M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Visiting on Tuesday, 7-9:30 P.M. and on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M.

title: A Big Western Bell Rides East to Buy Connecticut Phone Company
description: Expanding far beyond its home territory in the West, SBC Communications Inc., the nation's largest local telephone company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, the local telephone company for nearly every Connecticut resident, for $4.4 billion in stock.

title: Trying to Cope When a Partner or a Loved One Is Chronically Depressed
description: IT is not at all easy to live with and love a person who is chronically depressed. Stress, conflicts, arguments and misunderstandings are far more common in close relationships with depressed people, and depression and the sexual problems that usually accompany depression are the main reasons couples seek marital counseling.

title: New Markets Pages
description: Beginning today, Business Day is reorganizing its coverage of the markets for easier reading. The new format, appearing Tuesdays through Saturdays, will be found today on pages 6 and 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, MILTON C.
description: RABINOWITZ-Milton C. January 5, 1998. Husband of Ellen. Father of Charles and Caren. Grandfather of Jamie and Brynne. Brother of Lillian Simon. A graduate of Harvard Law School and a practicing attorney in the metropolitan area. He was a member of the Westport Masonic Lodge and Rotary Club. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, January 6, 1998, 2-5 and 7-9PM with service at Frank E. Campbell, Wednesday, January 7 at 1:30 P.M.

title: Magnets Can Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: What's on Doctors' Pens?
description: Prudent doctors head for the sink to wash their hands before examining their patients. But their good hygiene may last only as long as they keep their hands off their pens.

title: Insurers Suggest Tuning For No-Fault System
description: Representatives of the insurance industry told lawmakers yesterday that the state should fine tune the no-fault insurance system, and not scrap it completely.

title: By Design; Twin Sweaters Add Glamour
description: The updated twin set is an ideal choice for the resort-bound traveler, and what makes it new is a skin-baring camisole or halter instead of the crew-neck pullover.

title: Christmas Tale With Renaissance Spirit
description: In most fireplaces the embers of the Yule log have grown cold, and on virtually every city block at least one discarded fir tree hugs the curb. But at a handful of churches and musical organizations, there is still something to be said about Christmas. Music Before 1800, which presents visiting early-music groups at Corpus Christi Church throughout the year, offered a Festival of Lessons and Carols on Sunday afternoon, performed by the house chorus -- that is, the Choir of Corpus Christi Church, renamed Music Before 1800 Productions for such occasions. Jeffrey Johnson was the reader, Harvey Burgett played the organ accompaniments, and Louise Basbas conducted, sometimes from a chamber organ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARLITZ, LESTER, M.D.
description: KARLITZ-Lester, M.D. It is with profound sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, longtime friend and former Governor of our Board. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Fresh Meadow Country Club Steven Howard, President Allen Kaplan, Secretary

title: Billie Dove, Damsel in Distress In Silent Films, Is Dead at 97
description: Billie Dove, one of the most beautiful stars of silent films, died on Dec. 31 in the hospital of the Motion Picture and Television Fund in Los Angeles. She was 97 and lived in the fund's retirement community.

title: Study Identifies Disorder Afflicting Body Builders
description: SOME body builders appear to be suffering from an emotional disorder that is, in effect, the opposite of anorexia. Despite their very muscular bodies and tiptop shape, they are convinced that they look puny.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on Sunday about the Showtime series ''Dead Man's Gun'' misidentified the lead actor in the season premiere. He is Ted Shackelford. Edgar Thurlow is the character he plays.

title: Giuliani Says He May Not Sign Major Ban on Tobacco Ads
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani indicated for the first time yesterday that he might not sign legislation that would give New York City one of the most restrictive bans on outdoor tobacco advertising in the country.

title: Biggest Malaysian Bank Raising Interest Rate
description: Malayan Banking Bhd. said yesterday that it would raise its base lending rate to 10.35 percent effective today, from 10.25 percent. The bank, Malaysia's largest, last changed the rate on Dec. 3, raising it from 9.75 percent. Other Malaysian banks tend to follow the lead of Malayan in setting their interest rates.

title: Enter Stage Left, Assured and Sparkling
description: The New York City Ballet concluded its annual long engagement of ''The Nutcracker'' with two Sunday performances at the New York State Theater. At the matinee, it was a pleasure to discover that the old magic was still there. Indeed, George Balanchine's version of Tchaikovsky's holiday classic had additional sparkle because of the debut of Pascale van Kipnis as the Dewdrop, the leader of the Waltz of the Flowers.

title: City Says MGM Is Studying A Site on Governors Island
description: Officials from MGM Grand Inc. have taken a tour of Governors Island and expressed an interest in developing an entertainment center on part of the island, city officials said last night.

title: Gingrich Calls for Tax Cuts Tied to Any Budget Surplus
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that any budget surplus produced this year should be used to reduce the national debt and to pay for the first of a series of annual across-the-board tax cuts.

title: Disneyland for Deadheads: Ultimate Nostalgia Trip; Rock Group Lives in Memory and Master Plan
description: If the red-brick warehouse in this Marin County town were open to the public, it would be a haven for one-stop shoppers. Its endless shelves are lined with everything from toothbrushes to golf balls, dog collars to stamps, skis to motorcycle parts, baby rompers to electric lanterns. But this is not a supermarket. It is the headquarters of Grateful Dead Merchandising, where the golf balls are tie-dyed and the dog collars are emblazoned with the head of Jerry Garcia. A thousand packages of Grateful Dead items are shipped from this warehouse each day, bringing in an annual gross of $50 million to $60 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, J. GIBSON
description: MORRISON-J. Gibson, 82, of Saddle River, NJ and Axton, VA. on 11/16/97. Surviving are his son Andrew H. Morrison and his daughter-in-law Sheppard. Also survived by his grandchildren Vicky an Gregory, all of Axton, VA. A memorial service will beheld on Thurs., Jan. 8, 1998 at 2 PM at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. Interment is private. Mr. Morrison was predeceased by his wife Betty Magee and his sister Ruth A. Morrison. For information CC Van Emburgh Inc., Ridgewood, NJ.

title: Family and Police Seek Missing Times Square Reveler
description: For the last few years, Lawrence R. Andrews and a half-dozen or so of his friends have journeyed from Brewster, N.Y., to Times Square to ring in the new year. They followed a routine familiar to suburban revelers: Hop on an evening train. Go to some bars. Celebrate with the masses as the ball drops. Go home feeling merry.

title: Rick James Still Enjoys Singing . . . and All That
description: Rick James savored every minute he was onstage at Tramps on Saturday night. He was touring for the first time since he served a three-year jail sentence for assaulting a woman, and he was performing in New York City for the first time since 1991. He sang a song he wrote for the Temptations, ''Standing on the Top,'' about how fleeting fame can be, and he wasn't shy about mentioning his former cocaine addiction or alluding to his jail time. ''But I'm back again,'' he insisted, and he set out to remind the audience just what made him a multimillion-selling star in the late 1970's and early 80's: crisp, irresistible grooves and songs about sex and getting stoned.

title: German Churches, Ever Giving, Ask to Receive
description: When Gert Holle began to prepare to become a Lutheran minister more than eight years ago, he braced himself for arduous studies followed by hard work and modest pay.

title: AUTO MAKERS PLAN CUTS IN EMISSIONS OF SPORT VEHICLES
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that this autumn it would start selling sport utility vehicles and Windstar mini-vans that would produce as little air pollution as cars. The Chrysler Corporation, after initially expressing reservations, said this evening that it would match that move in its most popular sport utility vehicle.

title: The Bad News About Bailouts
description: Suppose your brother-in-law announced to the whole family at Christmas that he had lost a bundle on Wall Street, couldn't meet his margin calls and didn't have the money to meet either his credit card bills or his mortgage. Would you bail him out?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITZER, RUTH
description: SITZER-Ruth. The Officers, Members of the Board and Administration of OHEL, BAIS EZRA and The Lifetime Care Foundation for the Jewish Disabled mourn the passing of the beloved wife of Morris, mother of Phyllis Zachter, wife of our Executive Committee Chairman Mel Zachter, mother of David and sister of Meyer Smith. The Sitzer family are selfless and devoted friend of OHEL's children and helped build our Professional Care and Counseling Center. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moishe Hellman, OHEL President David Jacobson, BAIS EZRA Pres Moshe Zakheim, Chairman of the Board David Mandel, Chief Exec Officer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ROBERT S.
description: BROWN-Robert S. of Providence, RI and Great Neck NY on January 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Erika. Devoted father of Kenneth, Carita (Marshall) Dornfeld and Neil (Leslie) Brown. Loving grandfather of Ethan, Jeremy and Aidan. Services on Wednesday January 7 12:30PM at Temple Beth-El, Old Mill Road Great Neck NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to VNA Foundation to Benefit Hospice Program, Box H, Annex Station, Providence, RI 02901

title: 14-Month Sentence In Fraud Conspiracy
description: A man from North Salem, N.Y., was sentenced yesterday to 14 months in prison for his role in a scheme to bilk fashion models and other investors of more than $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANACKI, CHARLOTTE
description: BANACKI-Charlotte. On January 4, 1998. Beloved aunt of Justin Ruiz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Tuesday January 6, 5-9pm. Memorial Mass Wednesday, 1 pm at St Jean Baptiste, Lexington Ave at 76th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be directed to Rev. Ann Williams.

title: Calipari Predicts a Division Title Run
description: Coach John Calipari was enjoying himself today. NBC television was filming his practice session for a feature on young teams on the rise, and he was so excited that he did not force the crew to bleep out a single segment. A crew from MTV was waiting in the wings to interview his players when practice broke up.

title: MacManus Unit Wins Ryder Account
description: Ryder TRS Inc. said yesterday that it had named the Troy, Mich., office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles to handle its national account, which had been handled since 1986 by Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of WPP Group. Though billings have not been determined, trade publications estimated them at $20 million.

title: Excerpts From Remarks By Gingrich on the Budget
description: Following are excerpts from remarks and questions and answers by Speaker Newt Gingrich to the Cobb County Chamber of Commerce yesterday in Marietta, Ga., as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: Mondelo To Replace Parreira
description: The search for a head coach has ended for the MetroStars. They will announce in a day or two that ALFONSO MONDELO will be their fourth coach as they start preparations for their third season in Major League Soccer, which will release its 1998 schedule at noon today.

title: New Leader Takes Over Construction For Schools
description: The School Construction Authority, the $4.7 billion agency in charge of fixing the city's crumbling schools and building new ones, began the new year with its third president in three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURG, RONALD
description: BURG-Ronald. Of Roseland, NJ, on January 4, 1998. Husband of Mary Limbach Burg, brother of Herbert, godfather of Elizabeth and Edmond Dwyer. Funeral service in the Farmer Funeral Home, 45 Roseland Avenue, Roseland, New Jersey, on Wednesday at 11 AM. Visiting tonight, 7-9 PM.

title: French Unemployed Turn Their Ire on the Socialists
description: Elected six months ago after promising to do something about France's stubborn 12.4 percent unemployment rate, the Socialist-led Government has not been able to, and has emerged from the holiday season on the defensive against the jobless themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILWORTH, J. RICHARDSON
description: DILWORTH-J. Richardson. On December 29, 1997. Beloved husband, devoted father and proud grandfather. Memorial service will be at 12PM, Saturday, January 10, in the Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, NJ. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers will officiate. A reception will be held afterward at Prospect House on the University Campus. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Melissa Dilworth Gold '61 Visiting Artists Fund at Milton Academy, 170 Centre Street, Milton, MA. 02186. Melissa Dilworth Gold died in a helicopter accident in 1991.

title: A Struggle That Tests and Feeds the Soul
description: Kevin O'Day, a choreographer, and John King, a composer, wanted to form their own modern dance company. Mr. O'Day had created dances for the New York City Ballet and other troupes. Mr. King had created scores for the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and other downtown groups. They consulted older and wiser colleagues, eager for advice about whether to go ahead with the project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTY, MINNA R.
description: McCARTY-Minna R., 88. Died peacefully January 5, 1998 at home in Manhattan. Travel Counselor Pres, Park Plaza Travel, Inc. Member 41-74 Club. Red Cross Volunteer overseas WW II. Deeply admired by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAEBER, MARY
description: SCHWAEBER-Mary. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation extends heartfelt sympathies to fellow Trustee, Henry (Pat) T. Schwaeber, on the loss of his beloved mother, Mary. A warm and caring relationship has come to a close, leaving behind many precious memories. Our condolences to all the family. David Taub Chairman of the Board David Glaser, President

title: A Guy Thing, A Magazine Thing
description: Can you tell the men's magazine from the women's magazine? Can you tell the players without a masthead?

title: 'Bird Flu' Reveals Gaps in Plans for Possible Global Outbreaks
description: For decades, United States and World Health Organization officials have warned that an influenza pandemic rivaling one that killed more than 21 million people worldwide in 1918 and 1919 could strike without warning.

title: Palestinians Protest to CBS News Over a Report on the West Bank
description: Protesting a report that appeared on the news program ''60 Minutes'' a month ago, the Palestinian Authority told CBS News yesterday that CBS would ''no longer be given unrestricted access to either our officials of government or the territories under our control.''

title: Woodwinds Help Weave Lilting Melodies
description: A concert on Sunday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art offered an upscale session of caroling around the tree, the music coming from a chamber symphony composed by Michel Corrette, who described it in the 18th century as ''containing the finest Christmas carols, French and foreign, with variations.''

title: Order That Explodes Into Unruliness
description: Cacophony can be fun. That was demonstrated in ''Unfinished Symphony,'' the musical and choreographic ruckus that Yoshiko Chuma presented on Saturday night at St. Mark's Church in collaboration with the School of Hard Knocks, a collective of dancers, musicians and artists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIRD, IRENE D.
description: BAIRD-Irene D. Of Bellerose, NY, Jan. 4, 1998. Beloved wife of John T. Loving mother of Christopher J., JoEllen Baird and Moira Kriete. Survived by eight brothers and sisters. Cherished grandmother of two. Friends may call Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York (at City Line). Funeral mass Thursday, 9:45 AM at St. Gregory The Great R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERSON, LOUISE ASTOR VAN ALEN
description: SAUNDERSON-Louise Astor Van Alen. December 30, 1997 in Santa Barbara, CA. Born 1910 in New York City. Daughter of the late James L. Van Alen and Margaret Post Van Alen Bruguiere. She is survived by Alexander Saunderson, her beloved husband of 50 years; a brother, William L. Van Alen; three nephews, James Langley Van Alen, William L. Van Alen, Jr., and James Laurens Van Alen, II, and a niece, Cassandra Ludington. Her loving nature and wit brightened the lives of everyone she knew. A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M. on January 9 at All Saints by the Sea Episcopal Church in Montecito. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Music Academy of the West, 1070 Fairway Road, Santa Barbara, CA. 93108.

title: Aetna Names Official to Health Care Unit
description: Aetna Inc. said today that it would choose Daniel J. Messina to replace the chief financial officer of its health care unit, whose abrupt departure last month touched off concern among investors.

title: Chance for a Deal Soon In N.F.L. Talks Is 50-50
description: Negotiators for the National Football League and the players union have been working around the clock in recent weeks to extend the collective bargaining agreement, which expires in 2002. This deal could be extremely important because it is tied to the pending contract with the television networks.

title: Yanks Cooling On Knoblauch
description: Chuck Knoblauch, the All-Star second baseman who is expected to be traded by Minnesota, will not be joining Derek Jeter in the Yankee infield unless the Twins alter their trade demands, George Steinbrenner said yesterday.

title: Bullied No More, Wizards Rap Knicks
description: Chris Webber used to lift off from the dotted line, dunk with flair and scowl and preen until someone took a picture. Then a certain veteran power forward who measures his vertical leap by sliding a credit card under his Nikes would grow perturbed and flex his forearms.

title: Victim Testimony Sends Juries Wrong Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Gotham Takes On Redken Assignment
description: The Cosmair unit of L'Oreal S. A. said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Gotham Inc. in New York by naming that agency to handle television advertising for its Redken hair care products, with billings estimated at $7 million. The account has been handled in-house for the last year.

title: Patterns
description: A Second Effort in Shoes

title: The Chess Column
description: Because of the International Chess Federation World Championship Match between Anatoly Karpov and Viswanathan Anand, the chess column by Robert Byrne will not appear today. The column will resume after the match ends.

title: CLINTON WILL SEEK BALANCED BUDGET IN '99 INSTEAD OF '02
description: President Clinton said today that he would propose a balanced Federal budget for 1999, three years ahead of schedule, signaling a halt and perhaps an end to the deficit politics that have confined the dreams of a generation of Presidents and lawmakers.

title: Public Lives
description: NEW TODAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILNER, LOUIS
description: WILNER-Louis. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Louis Wilner, beloved father of our devoted members Mark and Beth Wilner. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Improving City Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Theatrical Art That Rises Up From Ruins
description: Styles and forms that once obsessed a culture never disappear any more than one's own private desires or traumas do: they keep coming back in new costumes, and if you don't want to be stuck responding the same way over and over with exactly the same results, you'd better discover how to make something different -- and just as powerful -- from them.

title: Unabom Trial Halted Abruptly As Suspect Battles His Defense
description: In a bizarre beginning to what promises to be a highly unusual proceeding, the trial of the accused Unabom killer, Theodore J. Kaczynski, was halted just before it got under way this morning, when Mr. Kaczynski said he had ''very important'' complaints about his lawyers.

title: U.S. Balloonist Falls About Three-Quarters of a Globe Short
description: The Solo Spirit sank into a Russian wheatfield today after its pilot abandoned his quest to become the first to ride a balloon around the world nonstop.

title: Foreign Minister of Mexico Is Named Finance Minister
description: In a surprise appointment that gives Mexico's booming economy an energetic spokesman well known to international investors, President Ernesto Zedillo today named Jose Angel Gurria his Finance Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACK, LISA
description: MACK-Lisa. Cherished daughter of Arien Mack and the late Robert Mack, passed away on Thursday, January 1, 1998. Her loveliness, her affection for all living creatures, her love of truth and knowledge, and her extraordinary courage will continue to enrich the lives of all who knew her. The memorial service will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Family Center, 385 Highland Avenue, Somerville, MA. 02144.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASOWITZ, JACK
description: CASOWITZ-Jack. Died January 4, 1998 at the age of 93. Devoted husband of Betty. Loving father of Pearl, Barry, Paul and the late Harold. Beloved grandfather and great-grandfather. Your beautiful and joyful neshama comforts and protects us and lights our way.

title: Clinton's Remarks on Prospects for the First Balanced Federal Budget in 30 Years
description: Following is an excerpt of President Clinton's remarks on the budget and answers to reporters' questions today, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.

title: U.S. Signs New Manager For Brookhaven Lab
description: The Energy Department signed a five-year contract yesterday with Brookhaven Science Associates, a new group of scientists, to manage and operate the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: VALUEVISION PLANS TO MERGE WITH DIRECT MARKETER
description: Valuevision International Inc., the television home-shopping service operator, agreed yesterday to merge with the National Media Corporation, a direct-marketing company based in Philadelphia. The combined company will have estimated annual sales of more than $500 million. Valuevision, of Minneapolis, will own about 55 percent of the new company, and National Media shareholders will own 45 percent. Shareholders of National Media will receive one share in the new entity for each share now held. Valuevision shareholders will receive 1.19 shares for each share held. The new company will have about 58 million shares outstanding. Valuevision's stock fell 37.5 cents a share yesterday, to $3.50; National Media was down 18.75 cents, to $3.25.

title: European Inquiry Set On Ties Among Airlines
description: The European Commission will expand its antitrust review of trans-Atlantic airline alliances to include Air France's links to Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines, a commission official said yesterday. The investigation is part of a review into whether trans-Atlantic alliances may inhibit competition and lead to higher fares. The review began in response to a proposed alliance of British Airways and the American Airlines unit of the AMR Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, MARIA SHEFELUK
description: LLOYD-Maria Shefeluk. Born in Minneapolis, Minn on June 8, 1922. Her parents, both deceased, were Thomas and Catherine Shefeluk. She began studying violin at age five. She attended Minneapolis College of Music, where she studied with Harold Ayres, then concertmaster of the Minneapolis Symphony. She subsequently won a scholarship to the Curtis Institute of Music, where she studied with Efrem Zimbalist, William Primrose, Marcel Tabeteau, and Gregor Piatagorsky. Her orchestral experience included The Baltimore Symphony, The Brooklyn Philharmonic, and the Westchester Philharmonic. She was concertmaster of the Tanglewood Opera Orchestra, The Champaign/Urbana Symphony, and the Lake George Opera Orchestra. She was also violinist with the Walden String Quartet in residence at the University of Illinois. She toured extensively with her husband, tenor David Lloyd, and supported his many endeavors in the Operatic and Musical field. She is survived by her husband and her son, David Thomas Lloyd, and has joined her other son, composer Timothy Cameron Lloyd. A memorial service will be held at 2:00PM on Sunday, January 18th, 1998 at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73rd Street, NYC, NY. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the performing arts organization of your choice in her name would be appreciated by the family.

title: Victim Testimony Sends Juries Wrong Message; Popular Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIGER, ELINOR (NEE HAMBURG)
description: TIGER-Elinor (nee Hamburg). Aged 89, died December 31, 1997 at her home in West Orange, New Jersey. BA Wellesley College 1930; MS NYU 1932. Married to Howard Lang Tiger in 1932. Survived by a sister, Joan H. Weisl of NYC; two daughters: Madeline Tiger of Montclair, NJ and Barbara Tiger Rubens of Santa Monica, CA.; seven grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Private interment. No flowers. Donations may be sent to the UJA, Wellesley College, The Ethical Culture Society, or Planned Parenthood of NJ.

title: Institute for Spinal Injury Rehabilitation Converts to Profit-Making Status
description: The Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation, a prominent treatment center for victims of disabling spinal cord and brain injuries, has converted to a for-profit company as a prelude to a nationwide expansion of its treatment and research missions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE NAVE, LOUIS
description: DE NAVE-Louis. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor. Devoted father of Connie and Donna. Loving grandfather of Christopher and Michael. Reposing Scotto Funeral Home, 106 1st Place (Near Court Street), Brooklyn until Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, Sacred Hearts and Saint Stephen's Church, 9:30 AM. Visiting hours from 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: Two tables in the special Business World section yesterday listing the most active common stocks of 1997 on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market carried an incorrect label. The figures for total trading volume of each stock were in millions of shares, not millions of dollars.

title: Taxes and Chicken Little
description: To the Editor:

title: Misdiagnosing Courts' Problems
description: Chief Justice William Rehnquist and Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah provided an unusual exchange last week over the state of the judiciary. But Senator Hatch's diagnosis of the maladies of the Federal courts is incorrect, and he ignores two problems that Congress itself could remedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALKOWITZ, AL
description: SALKOWITZ-Al. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member, Al Salkowitz, and extends heartfelt condolences to his family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Philip Adler

description: SKELTON-Charles Thomas. With deep sorrow we mark the passing of our dear friend and companion. Charles Thomas Skelton, formerly of NYC, Westport, Connecticut and Chaplin, Conn. He is survived by two daughters, Linda Huffman of Memphis, Tenn., and Janet Voorhees of Santa Fe, N.M., four grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. The Duthie Family, Evelyn, Leslie and Carol

title: Puerto Rico Tackles Issue Of Stray Dogs' Suffering
description: Among the 135 dogs at the Pro-Animal Safety Association's shelter here is Blondie, a mixed-breed recovering from mange who leaps into the back seat of her caretaker's car when she anticipates a ride.

title: Risks of Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Research Funding
description: Only a year or two ago, the nation's research community was in despair over a potentially bleak future. Congress and the Administration had agreed to balance the budget by the year 2002, threatening huge cuts in science and other ''discretionary'' programs. But now champions of research in both political parties are vying to pump large sums into the politically popular biomedical sciences. It is a startling turnabout that could save American research from mindless cutting -- or dangerously distort its priorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, STEPHEN G.
description: BERRY-Stephen G. Dec. 31, 1997. Suddenly while on vacation in Ireland, Steve, of Croton-On-Hudson, NY and Columbia University, NYC. Sadly missed by his wife, Mary (O'Neill), his parents Pat and Gerry (Exton, PA); his father-inlaw, Tony O'Neill; his brother-inlaw, Declan and family; his sisterin-law, Joan, and friends and colleagues in the U.S. and Ireland. Return to New York on Tuesday, January 6, to Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY. 914-769-0001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLER, JAMES J.
description: ENGLER-James J., of Manhattan, died December 20, 1997 at age 81. Born in Dubuque, Iowa, he was a violinist and vocalist with big bands in the 1930's, a film and stage actor in the '40s and '50s, appearing in both the stage and screen versions of ''Winged Victory,'' and later was a successful cosmetics company executive. He is survived by his wife, Lynne C. Engler, and his daughter, Carla L. Engler, both of Manhattan, two brothers, Donald, of Fort Pierce, FL, and Irvin, of Dubuque, and a grandson, James Wylie Deitch. He is still so loved, and will be missed incredibly by us all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BENJAMIN A.
description: LEVINE-Benjamin A. On Sunday, Jan. 4, 1998 at George Washington University Hospital. Husband of Ruth D. Levine; father of Judith L. (Elliott C.) Lichtman and Felice J. Levine; brother of Janet de Vries and Sarah Grossman. Also survived by his grandchildren, Julia Lichtman, Sarah Lichtman (Edward) Spector and Rachel Levine; his sisters-in-law, many nephews and nieces. Services will be held at Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Road, NW Washington, DC 20015, on Tuesday, January 6 at 10 A.M. and a memorial service at Temple Sinai, 131 Washington St., Lawrence, N.Y. on Wednesday, January 7 at 2:15 P.M. Interment Judean Memorial Gardens. Contributions may be made to the Religious School Endowment Fund at Temple Sinai, Washington, DC.

title: With Crime Falling, Police Deserve a Raise; Surveillance Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: Group Tries to Organize Workfare Recipients
description: A community group and a public employees' union yesterday began trying to enroll 10,000 workfare participants in an organization to improve working conditions, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, PEARL SARA (FADER)
description: GOLUB-Pearl Sara (Fader). On January 3, 1998, of Riverdale, NY, beloved wife of the late Irving, devoted mother of Harvey, Eugene B., and the late Morton, also survived by ten grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Relatives, friends are invited to graveside services Thursday 10:30 A.M. at Crescent Burial Park, Route 130 at Union Avenue, Pennsauken, New Jersey (Section E). For further information contact Berschler Funeral Home: 609-665-5401.

title: Nagging Worries on Asia Deflate a Rally on Wall St.
description: The first signs were bullish. The Dow Jones industrial average crept above 8,000 points early yesterday after European markets rallied overnight. Financial and technology stocks soared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIE, RUTH
description: BRODIE-Ruth. Died 1/3/98. She is survived by her daughter, Susan Aminoff and son, Hal Brodie, and her three grandchildren, Matthew Aminoff, Johanna Aylsworth, and Sam Brodie. Her determination and courage were an inspiration to us all.

title: James Lees-Milne, 89, Saved Country Houses
description: James Lees-Milne, a British architectural historian and author who played a key role in the preservation of that ornament of British life, the historic country house, died on Dec. 28 in Tetbury in the county of Gloucestershire in western England. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDELKEN, GEORGE T. SR.
description: WENDELKEN-George T. Sr., age 81 of Toms River, formerly of Oradell and Manhattan, NY died Saturday, January 3, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Helen P. (nee McEnery). Devoted father of Ellen Dinneen, Gene, Don and the late George, Jr. Survived by four brothers and one sister and seven grandchildren. Funeral Wednesday 9:30 from Volk Leber Funeral Home, 268 Kinderkamack Rd., Oradell, NJ 201-261-1088. Mass at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, Ridgewood 10:30 AM. Burial George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Four Still Standing Prove Change Is Good
description: This axiom in pro football remains dance with what brought you, do not rock the boat, do not fix what is not broken; repeat the 16 weeks of the regular season. Do not change.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ENTERING MOTOROLA ISRAEL VENTURE
description: The Ampal-American Israel Corporation said yesterday that it would buy a one-third interest in a Motorola Inc. wireless-communications business in Israel for $110 million, as a springboard for other telecommunications and high-technology investments. Ampal, a New York unit of Israel's Bank Hapoalim B.M., said in November that it was discussing such a deal with Motorola. Through the new business, Ampal and Motorola Israel Ltd. will coordinate and operate services that Motorola Israel had provided by itself, Ampal said. Using Motorola's iDEN technology, a single handset lets a user to make phone calls, communicate via two-way radio and send messages and data.

title: Nowen Carving Turns With Aplomb
description: Ylva Nowen walked triumphantly past the emptying bleachers on her 28th birthday, not looking the least bit remorseful for spoiling the party.

title: Metro Business; Use of Hotel Name Limited
description: The Wyndham Hotel Corporation of Dallas is barred from using the Wyndham name in Manhattan, a judge has ruled in New York State Supreme Court.

title: State Plans Millions For Internet in Schools
description: The Education Department said yesterday that it would give $3.75 million to 40 school districts this year to expand Internet access. The state will spend an additional $4.2 million this year to train teachers in technology, as well as $40 a student to support distance learning by computer, said Julia A. Stapleton, director of the State Office of Educational Technology.

title: Sworn for 5th Term, Kenya's President Vows to Fight Corruption and Poverty
description: At a lavish swearing-in ceremony to celebrate his fifth term as President, Daniel arap Moi promised today to do a better job than he has of tackling Kenya's extensive official corruption and endemic poverty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMANN, SANDRA (NEE SCULLY)
description: FRIEDMANN-Sandra (nee Scully) on January 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the Honorable William D., Appellate Division Supreme Court of the State of New York, Second Judicial Department. Loving mother of Dana Bahrey and William, Jr. Cherished grandmother of Caitlin, Ashlee and Billie. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Service Wednesday 8 PM in Chapel. Cremation private.

title: Gallic Dentist's Success
description: THE idea of a dentist hammering a wrought-iron tooth into an empty socket in his howling patient's jaw is enough to make any survivor of root-canal therapy wince. But not long after Julius Caesar conquered Gaul, an enterprising dentist practicing near Paris performed just such an operation. Nearly two millennia later, the remains of the prosthetic tooth are still snugly embedded in the remains of the patient.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They've eulogized me at least 18 times in the last 18 months, and look, I'm still here.''

title: Union Complains About Tax Processor
description: Union officials yesterday accused the state of compromising taxpayers' privacy by hiring a company to help process income-tax returns, union officials said.

title: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY BUYING BRITISH SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: Platinum Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Learmonth & Burchett Management Systems P.L.C., a London-based software concern, for about $70 million in stock. The transaction is expected to be accounted for as a pooling of interests. Platinum, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., makes network-management and other software products. Learmonth, which will be operate as a unit of Platinum Technology, has begun concentrating on the United States market for its business software products. Shares of Platinum Technology rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to $28.375.

title: Flirting Male Crabs Found to Wave Claws in Unison
description: SOMETHING in nature tries to keep similar individuals in step with each other, whether they be pendulum clocks, subnuclear particles, flashing fireflies or cells in living organs. Now, it seems, male fiddler crabs a-courting have joined the growing list of animals that synchronize behavior with each other.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, JOSEPH HANLON
description: HIGGINS-Joseph Hanlon. Passed away January 1, 1998, in Laguna Hills, CA. He was 80. Mr. Higgins was a Credit Manager for Dun & Bradstreet for many years.
