He is survived by his wife Jeanette of 25 years, one son, Roger Higgins, daughters, Carol (Michael) Tampa, Donna (Joe) Licari, Diane (Stan) Kosek, Betty (Jeff) Lane, niece Joette Higgins and nephew Duane Garrett. Memorial services will be Thursday, January 8, 1998, 11 AM, the Pacific View Mortuary in Newport Beach, California.

title: Accounts
description: * Software A. G. Americas, Reston, Va., to Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., to handle its account, which had recently been inactive. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINALE, ALEXANDER
description: FINALE-Alexander. Six years today. Always remembered, deeply missed. Your loving sister Fannie.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day on Dec. 22 about a planned merger of interactive advertising companies included one such company erroneously. Katz Millennium Marketing will not be among the companies combining to form 24/7 Media. The president and chief executive of Katz Millennium, Jay Friesel, is leaving to join 24/7 Media as executive vice president for sales and administration; Katz Millennium remains part of the Katz Dimension unit of Katz Media Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPMAN, NATHAN P.
description: KOPMAN-Nathan P. Age 79. Died January 5, 1998. Devoted husband of Julia and the late Shirley. Beloved father of Michael (Rosie) and Cynthia (Harold) and stepfather of Larry (Ashley). Cherished grandfather of Spencer, Jacob and Emma. Served his country honorably as a Lieutenant. in WW II and later in civilian life as an IRS Appellate Officer. He leaves a legacy of integrity and strength to be emulated by all who knew him. Shiva will be held at the Kopman residence. For further information call I.J. Morris Inc. 800624-8282

title: Q&A
description: Aspirin and Oranges

title: Free-for-All, Driven by Ideology and Special Interests
description: As unpalatable as they may have been to big-spending Democrats and tax-cutting Republicans alike, the rules of the game in Washington have been clear since the Federal budget deficit began spiraling out of control in the early 1980's: consideration of nearly every issue would be limited by the politics of austerity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREILICH, JULIUS
description: FREILICH-Julius. 91, passed away in Los Angeles, CA on January 2, 1998. Surviving are his beloved wife, Edith, sons Dr. Michael (Judith) Freilich and Dr. Robert (Carole) Freilich, five grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Services will be held on January 6, 1998 in Miami Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALKOWITZ, ABRAHAM
description: SALKOWITZ-Abraham. Beloved husband of the late Fae. Devoted father of Eileen and Ira Salk, and Vivian and Ronald Feinberg. Loving grandfather of Matthew and Susan, Kenneth and Leslie, Jon and Robyn, Daniel, Russell, Bruce and Jenny, Gail and Kent and great-grandfather of Sarah and Claire. We shall all cherish the memory of you forever. Service Wednesday 10am at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Nk, NY.

title: Quotas Are Necessary
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics and Peace in Israel
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel easily survived a budget vote yesterday and predicted that his Government could stay in power through the year 2000. But the resignation of Foreign Minister David Levy over the weekend was a damaging blow, to Mr. Netanyahu and to American peace diplomacy. With the loss of Mr. Levy, the Israeli Cabinet's leading dove, and the five parliamentary votes he controls, Mr. Netanyahu's margin for political survival has become even more precarious, and more dependent on right-wing and religious parties, than it has been for the past 19 crisis-prone months.

title: Cloutier May Provide Richter Rest Sooner Than Expected
description: When he first mapped out the season's potential pitfalls, Ranger Coach Colin Campbell circled the last week of January and first week of February as the most treacherous stretch.

title: Fog Delays Thousands at La Guardia
description: A shroud of dense fog generated by the springlike January warmth socked in La Guardia Airport for most of the day yesterday, cutting visibility to half the length of the runways and inconveniencing tens of thousands of travelers whose flights were delayed, diverted or canceled, the airport's operator said.

title: Dirty School Furnaces
description: New York City schools continue to rely on Dickensian, coal-fired furnaces whose sooty output represents a potential health risk for students, especially those with respiratory problems, and a nuisance to surrounding neighborhoods. Found in nearly a quarter of the city's 1,100 public schools, the coal furnaces produce tons of filthy ash and require almost constant attention from caretakers who do little more than shovel anthracite from morning until night.

title: Sports of The Times; A Basketball Sister Act, Miles Apart
description: THE first weekend of the new year doesn't get any better than this. On Saturday, Tamika Catchings played before a record crowd and a national television audience. On Sunday, courtesy of the same network, her older sister paid a visit to Tamika's dormitory television screen from Champaign, Ill., where Tauja Catchings's University of Illinois team crushed Colorado.

title: Was Freud Wrong? Are Dreams the Brain's Start-Up Test?
description: NEW measurements taken from sleeping people explain, at least in part, why dreams tend to have such bizarre but vivid story lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIPILLO, ROBERTA A.
description: DiPILLO-Roberta A. The Board of Regents, Administration and staff of The Long Island College Hospital note with sorrow the untimely passing of Roberta DiPillo, beloved wife of Dr. Frank DiPillo, Chairman, Department of Medicine, and member of our medical staff since 1956. We extend condolences to her large and loving family. John Wren, Chairman, Board of Regents Donald F. Snell, President and CEO

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: 5 Freed in Killing of American in Mexico
description: Calling their leader a ''modern Robin Hood,'' a judge has released without trial five men who prosecutors say confessed to kidnapping and killing an American businessman last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, MARILYN
description: COSTEllO-Marilyn. The faculty, staff and students of The Curtis Institute of Music mourn the passing of Marilyn Costello, head of the Harp Department from 1961 until the present, and principal harpist of The Philadelphia Orchestra from 1946 to 1992. Gary Graffman, President and Director

title: Super-Jumbo Or Super-Dumbo?; 2 Big Aircraft Makers Are at Odds Over Need for a 600-Passenger Jet
description: The question inevitably arises whenever airline executives gather these days: Does the world need a brand-new passenger jet larger than the 747?

title: Redefining the Season Called Resort
description: It's January, but if you can get past the sales racks in the stores, what you'll see are warm-weather clothes. It may be midwinter in most of the country, but this is resort season in the retail world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRIN, SYLVIA
description: ZIRIN-Sylvia. Devoted wife of the late Lester. Beloved mother of Nola and Harry Steinberg and Marjory and Douglas Rice. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Peter, Sarah and Dara. Services today 1pm at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI

title: Bills Name Phillips, Who Alters Staff
description: The Buffalo Bills yesterday named the defensive coordinator Wade Phillips to replace Marv Levy as coach. Phillips immediately cut about half of Levy's staff, including Dan Henning, the offensive coordinator.

title: Jay Leno Benefits As Seinfeld Exits NBC
description: Having just lost its biggest weekly comedy star in Jerry Seinfeld, NBC has moved quickly to sign its biggest nightly comedy star, Jay Leno, to a new long-term contract.

title: Democrats Urge Easing Property Taxes
description: Democratic legislative leaders yesterday proposed easing property taxes, putting them at odds with Gov. John G. Rowland's plan to cut the state income tax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOROKER, ABRAHAM
description: TOROKER-Abraham on January 4, 1998. Loving husband of sixtyseven years to Mae. Devoted father of Rita Frankel Strochak, Elly and Larry Tron. Most loved grandfather to Edmond, Patricia, Cathy, Andrew, Marc and Suzanne, great grandfather to Jared, Alexandra, Samantha, Shelby, Glenna, Austin, Sloan, Hannah and Rebecca. You were an inspiration to us to the very end. Services Tuesday, 9:30 AM at The Riverdale Temple.

title: Victim Testimony Sends Juries Wrong Message; Justice, Maldistributed
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 LARGE MAKERS OF FACTORY-BUILT HOMES TO COMBINE
description: The Oakwood Homes Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Schult Homes Corporation for $22.50 a share, or $101 million, combining two of the country's largest makers of factory-built homes. The purchase will give Oakwood manufacturing plants in markets where it owns retail distributors. Shares of Schult, based in Middlebury, Ind., jumped $1.75 yesterday, to $22.25, on the American Stock Exchange, where trading was halted pending the announcement. Oakwood's shares closed unchanged at $33.125. Schult, founded in 1934 as the Sportsman Trailer Company, is the oldest manufactured-home company in the United States. Oakwood, of Greensboro, N.C., had revenue of $1.07 billion in the fiscal year ended in October.

title: David Brinkley, now an Archer Daniels spokesman, returns to network television.
description: A NEW series of commercials using the former ABC News anchorman David Brinkley as spokesman began appearing on network news programs this past weekend, including Mr. Brinkley's former weekly discussion program, ''This Week.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, SR. M. HENRY, O.P.
description: MURPHY-Sr. M. Henry, O.P. Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, New York, January 4, 1998. Survived by niece Patricia Murphy and nephew Hugh Murphy, and three great nieces. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday 10 A.M. in Our Lady of The Rosary Chapel, Rosary Hill Home. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Dawn of a New Year, and Thailand Sinks Deeper Into Gloom
description: The New Year began on a dark note today as Thailand announced that it would ask the International Monetary Fund to ease the terms of its $17.2 billion bailout package and as its currency, the baht, fell to a new low of less than half its value last summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIPRESS, NATHAN
description: SIPRESS-Nathan. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum Ellen R. Saxl, President

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Test Kitchen column of the Dining section last Wednesday about an electric grill misspelled the surname of the celebrity who promotes it. He is George Foreman, not Forman.

title: The Insect in Winter: Snug as a Rugged Bug
description: THERE are good reasons that insects, not people, are the dominant form of multicellular life on earth. Not the least of them is the ability to survive extreme environmental stress, particularly the harsh winters in the temperate and polar regions.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Anne Simon; The Science Adviser to Whaaat?
description: PROPOSITION: The creator of a cultishly adored television show is writing a new script when he hits a snag. His character, a beautiful woman scientist whose big eyes luminesce like high-beam headlights whenever anything weird happens, which is often, discovers something in an organism that instantly convinces her it is extraterrestrial.

title: Do Breast Self-Exams Save Lives? Science Still Doesn't Have Answer
description: IF examining her own breasts once a month is not actually the lifesaving tool it is cracked up to be, Estelle Bolofsky does not want to hear about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HYMAN R.
description: COHEN-Hyman R. On January 4, 1998 of Jericho, LI. Beloved husband and best friend of Miriam, devoted father of Mark and Synde, Richard and Beth. Dear brother of Shirley Sparagon, cherished grandfather of Zachary and Jordan. Services today, 12:15 PM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI

title: Airline's Chief and Newark's Booster; Success of Continental Is a Challenge to New York's 2 Airports
description: More passengers used Newark International Airport in 1997 than ever before, according to preliminary figures -- about 30.8 million. But what you make of that information depends on your perspective.

title: Miami Hopes New Manager Is a Sign of Recovery
description: In the six weeks since he took over as Mayor of Miami, Xavier Suarez has moved, in his words, like ''a meteor the size of Texas.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan to Try to Save Banks By Buying Stakes in Them

title: Shrinking Breast Tumors
description: Italian researchers have reported the successful use of chemotherapy to shrink large breast tumors down to a size where they can be removed surgically in a procedure that avoids the trauma of mastectomy.

title: On the Prowl Again, For Diamonds and Mink
description: Eartha Kitt has been a star since the early 1950's. But it wasn't until her brittle purr was used in a seat-belt fastening campaign, reminding New York City cab riders that ''cats have nine lives, but you have only one,'' that a performer synonymous with champagne and caviar attained a hot-dog level of mass recognition. Or as Ms. Kitt growls coyly in her cabaret act which opened at the Cafe Carlyle on Friday evening, ''With my champagne taste and your beer bottle budget, you will have to work on something better than a zircon.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MACARI, LEOPOLD M.
description: MACARI-Leopold M. 1912 1978 20 years have passed. Always in our hearts and thoughts. Your Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXBERG, STANLEY D.
description: WAXBERG-Stanley D. On December 21, 1997. Beloved husband of Nikki and uncle of Marvin Waxberg. Memorial services are on Thursday, January 8, 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Boards are getting stingy with increases in dividends, but investors don't seem to care.
description: AS stock prices soar, American corporations are getting more stingy with dividend payouts to their shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELLIN, NEWTON H.
description: BELLIN-Newton H. January 6, 1984. You will live in our hearts always. We miss you. Your Loving Family

title: INSIDE
description: Jury Weighs Nichols's Fate

title: After Fist Meets Teeth
description: DOCTORS at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center say they have found a way to get a fighter who cuts his hand on someone else's teeth back on the street quicker, a good thing from at least a medical point of view.

title: Even Microsoft's Internet Browser Defends Itself
description: ONE of the odder aspects of the Justice Department's case regarding the Microsoft Corporation's Internet Explorer is the way the product can speak for itself. It will probably not testify in its own defense in courts of law, but it can deliver serious propaganda in the court of public opinion, as my wife discovered over the holidays when she accidentally clicked the browser's ''Microsoft'' button and was treated to the headline ''D.O.J.'s Request for New Court Order Shows Internet Explorer is Integrated.''

title: Ferraro Enters Battle to Take D'Amato Seat
description: With a plea to her Democratic rivals to renounce the type of attacks that scuttled her last campaign for the Senate, Geraldine A. Ferraro stepped back into the political arena yesterday, assailing Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for partaking in ''the politics of smear,'' and denouncing his record on environmental protection and education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAN, CLEVON
description: PRAN-Clevon. Died December 25, 1997, in Seattle, WA. Memorial service and burial were held on December 30th and 31st in Chicago. Painter artist (educated, Art Institute of Chicago), exhibits-Chicago, New York, Oslo, Stockholm. Public relations Chicago International Film Festival. Film Production Assistant, New York City; Art Teacher for children, Art Institute Chicago and Pullman, WA. Loving wife of Peter Pran; devoted daughter of Lillie Pearl Edgerson. Leaving also sisters Amelie (Herbert) Miller, Owenette, Renee, Regina, Deanna, and brother William (Juanita); brothers/sisters-in-law Odd Sigvart, Helge, Elisabeth Pran (Oslo). Greetings to dear friends in cities where she/Peter lived-Chicago, New York, Seattle; and in America and the world.

title: With an Eye on the Public, Scientists Choose Their Words
description: WHEN Dolly the sheep, the first animal cloned from a cell from an adult, was introduced to an astonished world, the scientists who created her did not call the process cloning. They used a much less loaded term. They called it ''nuclear transfer,'' and another euphemism of science was born.

title: The Return of Geraldine Ferraro
description: The children of New York voters are already studying Geraldine Ferraro's path-breaking nomination for Vice President in history classes. But her presence on Walter Mondale's failed 1984 ticket was a watershed in more ways than one. Before then Ms. Ferraro was a Democratic Congresswoman who was known as one of the party's rising stars. Since that defeat she has foundered politically, most notably in losing a messy primary for the same Senate nomination six years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, JOHN A.
description: ADAMS-John A. On January 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Penny. Devoted father of John and Stephanie. Reposing at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73rd Street, on Wednesday, January 7 from 4-6 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service at the Church on Thursday, January 8, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, it would be appreciated if contributions were sent to the American Cancer Society/Pancreatic Research-John Adams Memorial, C/O Steve Dickinson, 1599 Clifton Road, Atlanta, GA 30329-4215.

title: Rosy Budget Forecast Is No News to Investors
description: Wall Street greeted President Clinton's plan to propose a balanced Federal budget next year with a resounding yawn yesterday -- but that does not mean the financial markets are not interested in the size of the Federal deficit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHN, DOROTHY
description: KUHN-Dorothy. On January 2nd. Devoted sister of Eleanor Poster and Barbara Al-Bayati. Survived by five nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue between 20th and 21st Streets. Visiting hours Tuesday, 7-9 PM. Funeral service Wednesday, 1 P.M., All Saints Church, 230 East 60th Street, New York City. Interment Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Tarrytown, NY.

title: Despite Defection, Israeli Premier Wins Budget Vote
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today handily cleared his first Parliamentary challenge since his Government was shaken by the resignation of his Foreign Minister, winning approval for the 1998 budget by a vote of 58 to 52.

title: A Nation's Identity Debated / Monument to the Millennium : What's in a Dome?That Is Britain's Question
description: LONDON  The ring of giant steel masts soars above the banks of the River Thames like the superstructure of a futuristic building, or a massive theme-park attraction. Just which it will turn out to be, or whether the project is merely Britain's biggest white elephant, is a matter of increasingly fevered debate here.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS BELOW $17 A BARREL. For the first time in more than two years, crude oil fell below $17 a barrel. Analysts said warm weather in the Northeast and Midwest, reducing the demand for heating, had helped pull the price lower. February crude oil ended at $16.89 a barrel, down 54 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MENIL, DOMINIQUE
description: De MENIL-Dominique. The Trustees and staff of Dia Center for the Arts note with great sadness the passing of our beloved Trustee, Dominique De Menil. We'll miss her guiding hand, keen judgement and generous spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathies and condolences to her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Dominique inspired us and we will all miss her. The world has lost a guiding light. Board of Trustees Charles Wright, Chairman Michael Govan, Director

title: Worthy Women, Unredeemable Men
description: PARADISE

title: Israeli Prime Minister Clears Initial Hurdle
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu handily cleared his first Parliamentary challenge since his Government was shaken by the resignation of his Foreign Minister, winning approval for the 1998 budget.

title: Turk-Kurd War Begins to Spill Refugees Into Europe
description: A surge of Kurdish refugees fleeing aboard rusty boats from Turkey to Italy has again focused European attention on the 13-year-old war between Kurdish rebels and the Turkish Army, one of the world's longest and most intractable civil conflicts.

title: Dutch Grocery Chain Is Expanding in China
description: Royal Ahold N.V., a Dutch food retailer, said yesterday that its 50-50 Chinese joint venture in Shanghai had acquired 22 supermarkets of the Yaohan Liancheng Supermarkets Company, making Ahold the No. 1 foreign operator of supermarkets in China, with projected sales in 1998 of $100 million.

title: Mehta & Isaly Investment Firm Splits
description: Mehta & Isaly, a New York-based investment research firm, has split up, Samuel D. Isaly, one of the company's partners, said yesterday.

title: With a Delightful January Like This, Who Needs Spring?
description: It would be difficult to underestimate the general giddiness that has greeted the great heat wave of January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, MILDRED (NEE DIAMOND)
description: EDELMAN-Mildred (nee Diamond). Wife of the late Solomon, mother of Judith Lynn, grandmother of Amy Lynn Heon and Elizabeth Lynn, sister of Geraldine Stern, mother-in-law of Norman Lynn and great-grandmother of Gregory and Jennifer Heon. Funeral services were held.

title: Renaissance Girl's Crystal Ball
description: Two postcards from Renaissance Weekend, last week's deeply earnest seaside schmooze for Democrats in Hilton Head, S.C.:

title: Investments in Long-Term Mutual Funds at Peak
description: Americans made more new investments in long-term mutual funds last year than ever before, as a resurgent market for bond funds spurred further growth in an industry whose expansion over most of the last four years has been driven by the popularity of mutual funds that invest in stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARR, RUFUS TUCKER SR.
description: CARR-Rufus Tucker Sr. Of Scotland Neck, NC formerly of Long Island, died January 3 at his home. Mr. Carr retired as Vice President of Joshua L. Bailey & Company in New York City. Graveside services will be conducted Tuesday, January 6, at Trinity Episcopal Church Cemetery in Scotland Neck, NC. He is survived by his widow Julia Wright Clark Carr; two sons Rufus Tucker Carr, Jr. and John Clark Carr all of Scotland Neck. Mr. Carr was the last surviving son of Margaret Boylan Carr and Claiborn M. Carr, Sr. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Scotland Neck Rescue Squad, P.O. Box 13, Scotland Neck, NC 27874. For information contact Letchworth Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, THEODORE W.
description: GEORGES-Theodore W. President and owner of Indian Walk Shoes, on January 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Cherished father of Stathis and Steven Georges. Devoted father-in-law of Sandra and Soula Georges. Adoring grandfather of Alexander, Sophia and Elena. Friends may call at Riverdale FH, Inc, 5044 Broadway (at 214 St), NY NY Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral services at the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, Thursday 10AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 319 East 74 St, NY NY 10021, St. Michael's Home for the Aged, 3 Lehmann Terrace, Yonkers NY 10705 or to the charity of choice.

title: Foreign Affairs; A One-Word Strategy
description: Saddam Hussein must be feeling pretty cocky right now. Yes, he's learned all the lessons from Gulf War I: Don't make yourself an easy target. Cooperate with U.N. inspectors just enough so that the U.S. can't bomb you, but not enough so that they'll ever find the germ weapons you're making in your palaces. It's a strategy that has the White House tied in knots. Very clever, Saddam. Very clever. But if Saddam is going to play smart, then it's time the U.S. did too -- with a strategy that would rattle Saddam's cage and shake up the entire Middle East chessboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, HOWARD
description: GILMAN-Howard. On January 3, 1998. President of the Howard Gilman Foundation and Chairman of the Board of Gilman Paper Co. Beloved son of Sylvia and the late Charles Gilman. Brother of the late Charles Gilman, Jr. Friends may call at at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Monday, January 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services on Tuesday, January 6, 11 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65th St.

title: Facing Loss off the Court
description: They will remember Darrell Halloran as the coach who howled like Bobby Knight during practices, but then hugged them tighter than some parents do. They will remember him as the coach who returned from road games at 2 A.M. and shunned sleep to review videotapes. They will remember him as the coach who displayed equal warmth while chatting with the Pace University president or with a school custodian.

title: With Crime Falling, Police Deserve a Raise
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest Cases; A Lifetime Overcoming a Weak Heart
description: Every now and again, Mary Patterson runs into an old acquaintance on the street and takes great pleasure in watching the person's face drain of color. ''I thought you were long dead,'' they invariably tell her.

title: Young Will Confirm His Resignation This Week
description: George Young will confirm in a news conference later this week what has long been expected -- that he is resigning as Giants general manager to accept a high-ranking position with the National Football League.

title: Bond Yields At the Lowest In Decades
description: Long-term interest rates fell to their lowest level in almost 30 years yesterday as weekend comments by the chairman of the Federal Reserve convinced investors that the prospect of falling prices could force the Fed to cut interest rates soon.

title: Young & Rubicam Hires Media Officer
description: Paul Woolmington, the top media executive at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, is joining Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York in the new position of president and chief media officer for international media operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWITZ, TESS
description: ABRAMOWITZ-Tess. On January 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Naomi and Neil, Lynn and Elliot, Myra and Arnold. Adored grandmother of Jeremy and David, Randi and Robin, Melissa and Phillip. Dear great-grandmother of Jacqueline. Funeral services today, 11:30 a.m., at Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills.

title: Report Says Brawley Personally Responded to Investigators' Questions in '87
description: For the first time in the defamation trial of three former advisers to Tawana Brawley, testimony emerged today that Ms. Brawley herself may have spoken about the events surrounding her alleged rape and abduction more than 10 years ago.

title: Madden Runs Fox's Show, but NBC's Trio Works
description: You could not choose two more dissimilar sets of announcers than those who will call Sunday's National Football League conference championship games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, WILLIAM C.
description: BERMAN-William C. Beloved and devoted husband who was care giver to his dear Alzheimer-afflicted wife Fanny, for 12 years until her passing in 1992. cherished, adored and loving father of Marilyn Grosfeld. Devoted, proud, and greatly admired ''professor of life'' grandfather (''Poppie'') of Scott. Adored, best friend and father-inlaw of Sonny Grosfeld. Those who knew him will always have fond memories of his intense loyalty, devotion and unconditional support of family and friends; his business acumen and take-charge leadership qualities which served him well as past president of both the amalgamated and Wynmoor Cooperatives; his inquisitive, inventive genius; his quick wit, sense of humor and ''impish'' charm; his common sense approach to and lust for life. We thank him for always being there for us-our Renaissance man. We will miss him forever. Service to be private on Tuesday, January 6, 1998.

title: Panel Seeks H.M.O. Overseer For California, a Bellwether
description: Grappling with the future of managed health care in the nation's most populous state, a special advisory commission recommended today that California establish a new agency to oversee the administration of health maintenance organizations and enact a wide range of measures intended to protect consumers and improve care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHATZKY, EMANUEL
description: CHATZKY-Emanuel. On January 2, Deerfield Beach, FL. Dearly beloved husband of Leonore. Devoted father of Joel and Barbara. Loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Daniel, Stacie and the late Debra, and Mark and Michelle. Dear brother of Jerome. He'll remain in our hearts forever.

title: TCI Resolves Long Dispute With Estate of Company Founder
description: In an arrangement that would give its chief executive greater control of the company, Tele-Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had reached a complex resolution of its dispute with the estate of the founder of the company, Bob Magness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ZACHARY
description: SHAW-Zachary. On December 17, 1997, of heart failure, at age 90. Devoted husband to Elizabeth, and father to Stephen. Long time teacher of woodworking, photography and jewelry at progressive schools: The Modern School in Stelton, NJ and the Peninsula School in Menlo Park, CA. Donations to Peninsula School, 920 Peninsul Way, Menlo Park, CA. 94025, where there will be a memorial on January 18, 1998 at 2 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, SARAH LESSIN
description: MANDEL-Sarah Lessin, 89. On January 4th. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Charles Mandel. Adored mother of Marian Bauer and Dr. Mark (Sheryl) Mandel. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Diane (Eric) Orlinsky, Lauren (Daniel) Zinman, Karen Mandel, Adam Mandel and David Bauer. Loving great grandmother of Rachel and Charles Orlinsky. Mrs. Mandel was an educational pioneer and community leader. She was assistant principal of PS 124 Bronx and principal of PS 187 Manhattan. Also vice president of Assistant Principals Association and a member of the executive boards of New York Principals Association and Jewish Community Chest. She was treasurer and trustee of Riverdale Temple; a founder of Hadassah and honored by countless organizations. She was a mentor to thousands of children and teachers who were inspired by her wisdom, patience and compassion. She will be dearly missed. Services Wednesday January 7th, at 12 PM Riverdale Temple.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCY
description: THE DOLLAR JUMPS AGAINST MAJOR CURRENCIES. With the outlook for the American economy better than that of most of the world, the dollar surged 1.2 percent against the German mark and almost 1 percent against the Japanese yen. The dollar also rallied against other Asian currencies.

title: In Meeting of Powers, Devils Are Dominated
description: Dallas came into New Jersey tonight as the top team in the National Hockey League. The Devils, who are considered as good as any team in the league, hardly measured up in their first meeting with the Stars this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZENTNER, LEE
description: ZENTNER-Lee. 73 years old on January 4, 1998 of unexpected complications from Parkinson's disease. Formely of Cleveland and Scarsdale. Former Hadassah President, business woman, mentor. Fiercely loved and loving mother of Lesley Dormen and Scott Dormen, wife of David Zentner, cherished mother-in-law of Maria Wagner Dormen and Quentin Byrne Spector. Inspiring friend, adored sister-in-law and Aunt. Your glamour and charm seduced us, your generosity and dignity enlarged us, your ready laugh and sly humor delighted us. We hold you close, remember you always, will miss you forever. Cremation private. Contributions may be made in her name to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, HARRY J.
description: KING-Harry J. Died December 30, 1997, in his 90th year, husband of the late Fidelia Bettes King, survived by his three children, Joan Dreyfus, Fidelia Rice, John King, and five grandchildren. Fordham Prep '23, Fordham College '29, Fordham Law '33, tennis pro at Sleepy Hollow Country Club, society writer at Herald Tribune.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHELAN, MARY AGNES (MAGGIE, NEE O'NEILL)
description: WHELAN-Mary Agnes (Maggie, nee O'Neill). Of White Plains, NY. Formerly of Scarsdale, New York. Peacefully at home on January 2, 1998. Loving and devoted mother of Anne-Marie and Christopher. Beloved sister of J. Kevin O'Neill, of Harbor Springs, MI., and Thomas F. O'Neill of N. Kingstown, RI. Memorial Mass at St. Pius X Church, Palmer and Mamaroneck Roads, Scarsdale, NY, on January 10, 1998 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Rosary Hill Home, 600 Linda Avenue, Hawthorne, NY 10532, would be appreciated.

title: OLYMPICS: Nagano 1998 -- A Scar That Helped Skating; Skating's Popularity Has Jumped Since Attack on Kerrigan in '94
description: Even now, four years later, Nancy Kerrigan's coach said he gets a sinking feeling every time he even thinks of Detroit.

title: SARA LEE SELLING 9 PLANTS TO NATIONAL TEXTILES
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it would sell nine United States yarn and textile plants to National Textiles L.L.C. of Winston-Salem, N.C., as part of a plan to focus on selling brands like Hanes underwear instead of making them. Analysts said the sale price was $450 million, with expected cost savings of $150 million. Sara Lee's 3,865 plant workers will be hired by the closely held National Textiles, which is expected to be a key Sara Lee supplier. Shares of Sara Lee fell $1.5625 yesterday, to $55.50. The company said the plant sales would eliminate its yarn-production capability for underwear and virtually eliminate its textile production for clothing like T-shirts. National Textiles, a new company, is headed by Martin Granoff, vice chairman of the American Apparel Manufacturers Association.

title: Pisa Journal; A Long List on How to Stop a Tower's Slight One
description: As if a girdle of steel cables around its base, 830 tons of lead ingots stacked on the rim of its foundations and a steel fence skirting its perimeter were not enough, the alluringly leaning tower of this maritime Tuscan city appears about to suffer further indignity.

title: Temporary Return From Paris
description: ELIZABETH ROHATYN, who resigned in September as chairwoman of the New York Public Library and moved to Paris to join her husband, Ambassador FELIX G. ROHATYN, is unexpectedly back in New York for medical reasons. The prognosis is excellent, according to a statement from the American Embassy in Paris. Mr. Rohatyn will shuttle back and forth to be with his wife.

title: Islanders Are Piqued By Picks
description: Two Islanders had been expected to be among the players named to the National Hockey League's World All-Star team this afternoon.

title: Along Fifth Avenue, Bracing for a Tedious Recovery
description: Scott Smith, who is much better known these days as the Guy Whose Car Was Swallowed Up by the Street, had two interesting telephone conversations yesterday, neither of them pleasant.

title: After Emotional Appeals, Bomb Jury Weighs Penalty
description: Prosecutors invoked images of the dead a child who will never climb a tree, a father who will never cradle his newborn -- and defense lawyers invoked a biblical tale of mercy as they made their final arguments today over whether Terry L. Nichols should be executed for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Giuliani Names Director for Police Task Force
description: Nearly five months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani created a task force to try to improve relations between the police and citizens, he named a permanent executive director for the group yesterday, but the appointment generated criticism from some members of the panel.

title: A Proud Day on Island of the People
description: IF you're a Buchananite or some other type who thinks the gangway to America should have been yanked from under immigrants a long time ago, don't waste your time reading any further. You're going to hate hearing about how Marise Elibert from Haiti became an American yesterday, and was so moved by the naturalization ceremony that about all she could say was, ''I feel proud.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, ROBERT W.
description: WRIGHT-Robert W. Of Toms River on January 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Lee J. (nee Bertolini). Devoted father of Richard W. Wright, Kim I. Wright and Karen L. Haynes. Stepfather of Ronald Sebring. Brother of Dorothy Hambacher. Grandfather of 3. Funeral services Wednesday at the Silverton Memorial Funeral Home, 2482 Church Road, Toms River 10 A.M., arrive at the funeral home 9 A.M. Interment Ocean County Memorial Park, Toms River, New Jersey. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Sports of The Times; That's Entertainment, Just Not Enough of It
description: THE noise from that many-headed beast, the Madison Square Garden crowd, was like a slow-developing roar from within a wind tunnel. There had been scattered boos at different points in the first half last night -- after, say, an errant pass or a shot that hit neither steel nor glass nor net, or the Wizards scoring a virtually uncontested hoop -- but now, with about two minutes to go in the half, Knick fans let loose this volley of hoarse anguish of, nearly, pain. For in fact they had been wounded.

title: Netscape Reports Losses, and Its Shares Tumble
description: Shares in the Netscape Communications Corporation lost more than a fifth of their value today after the company said it would report losses for both the fourth quarter and the year.

title: 324 Victories Get Sutton To Hall at Last
description: Don Sutton, who pitched 324 victories in a 23-year career, finally overcame the curse of longevity yesterday and was elected to the Hall of Fame.

title: Corporate Name For Stadium
description: The high school football season in Jefferson County, Colo., will have a distinctly professional feel from now on. School officials have approved a plan to sell the name of the county stadium to the regional telephone company US West Communications Group for $2 million over 10 years.

title: Isringhausen Will Lose Season to Elbow Surgery
description: Jason Isringhausen, once viewed as a cornerstone of the Mets' organization, said last night that he would have reconstructive elbow surgery shortly, a procedure that would prevent him from pitching for the 1998 season and possibly beyond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUESTEL, MAE
description: QUESTEL-Mae. On January 4, 1998. Actress and voice of Betty Boop and Olive Oyl. Wife of the late Jack Shelby. Mother of Richard Balkin and the late Robert G. Balkin. Grandmother of Melissa Balkin Dubizh, Miranda Swados Balkin and Julia Balkin. Services Wednesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Samsung to Slash Its Overseas Production
description: Samsung Group, South Korea's second-largest conglomerate, said today that it would cut electronics production in China and Southeast Asia by 40 percent as part of a worldwide retrenchment.

title: In Confronting Depression, The First Target Is Shame
description: If the common yet still mysterious ailment known as clinical depression has another powerful symptom along with a despair that approaches the suicidal, it is shame. And that is the symptom that ''Dead Blue: Surviving Depression'' is out to attack.

title: Metro Business; Video Center Is Set For West Harlem Site
description: Broadway Video, a production company owned by Lorne Michaels, the producer of ''Saturday Night Live,'' announced yesterday that it would open an 8,600-square-foot, $1.1 million video duplication center in West Harlem at 3280 Broadway at 132d Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, SANDRA W.
description: MEYER-Sandra W. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation extends its most heartfelt condolences to the family of Sandra Meyer. As a member of the Foundation's Advisory Board, Sandra offered invaluable and wise counsel at every opportunity in the pursuit of conquering this disease. Her passing is a great loss to us all. Evelyn H. Lauder, Founder Deborah Krulewitch, Secretary Susan B. Hirschhorn, Development Consultant

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, BARBARA KILBY
description: AUERBACH-Barbara Kilby, 77. Of Brookline, MA. Died on Friday January 2 after a long illness. Ms. Auerbach was a graduate of Radcliffe College who had a career in market research and a deep love of the cultural and intellectual life of NYC, where she lived most of her life. Ms. Auerbach, widow of psychoanalyst Johann G. Auerbach is survived by her only child Stephanie. She will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEL, JONAS
description: STIEL-Jonas. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELMAN, CECIL ''SPIKE''
description: ABELMAN-Cecil ''Spike''. Past Vice President of Lehrer McGovern Bovis. Died January 5 at age 81 after a long illness. He is survived by his four children and seven grandchildren. Ceremony to be private. Any tributes to be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JACK
description: SCHWARTZ-Jack. Beloved and devoted husband of Cynthia, father of Martha, Lise, Eric, and Karl, father-in-law of Albert, Cathy, and Helen, grandfather of Rebecca, Daniel, Sarah, Rachel, and Anna. Devoted uncle, cousin, and friend to many. He led a full and interesting life and left his mark upon the world. Services today 1 P.M at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Police Exonerate 2 Men Jailed In 1992 Slaying
description: Two men in prison for the 1992 killing of a retired police sergeant did not commit the crime, police officials said yesterday, adding that new information had surfaced leading them to arrest three other suspects in the murder.

title: 'Proposals' Is Closing
description: ''Proposals,'' a comedy by Neil Simon, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The show, directed by Joe Mantello, will have run for 76 regular performances; it had 11 previews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVALER, FREDERIC
description: KAVALER-Frederic. On January 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Rebecca, loving father of Matt and Joshua. Dear brother of Arthur and nephew of Ruth Solow. Memorial services on Wednesday, January 7, 2:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76th Street.

title: One Word From a Corporate Ex-Wife: Half
description: A LOW point in the previously decorous life of Lorna J. Wendt came two Decembers ago, when she found some jottings from her husband and learned that he planned to divorce her after Christmas. Within days she was simultaneously interviewing her own divorce lawyers and meeting with caterers for the annual corporate Christmas party that her husband, a General Electric executive, had asked her to give one last time.

title: Finding Some Answers
description: Science Times recently ran a list of thought-provoking questions (in italic below) that were offered by a wide-ranging group of scientists and researchers and posted on a World Wide Web site that is called Edge (http://www.edge.org).

title: Owner of Sands Casino Files for Bankruptcy
description: The company that owns the Sands Hotel and Casino filed yesterday for bankruptcy protection. But executives said the 21-story resort here would remain open while working out a recovery plan. The Sands will be able to cover its annual operating expenses, but cannot meet the interest payments on its $182.5 million in long-term debt, said Jim Wise, a spokesman for the owner, Greate Bay Hotel and Casino Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICKLIN, FAY
description: RICKLIN-Fay. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Fay Ricklin, beloved mother of Gwen M. Greene, a member of the Wall Street Division Steering Committee, co-chair of the Wall Street Women's Forum and an exemplary leader in our organization. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Internet Phone Service Pact
description: A telephone company owned by Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics heir, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell phone service that travels over the Internet to members of Japan's largest on-line service. The company, RSL Communications Ltd., based in Bermuda, intends to announce the agreement today with a subsidiary of Fujitsu Ltd.. The unit, known as Nifty, has about 2.5 million subscribers. The agreement will enable Nifty customers to make international telephone calls over the Internet using RSL's technology.

title: Hartford Courant Picks Philadelphian As Top Editor
description: Four months after asking its top editor to step down, The Hartford Courant today named the managing editor at The Philadelphia Daily News to run its paper.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Metro Business; Utility Sets Tests at Plant
description: Northeast Utilities said yesterday that technicians were expected to begin conducting weeklong tests today on the containment building of Millstone 3, one of the company's idled nuclear power reactors in Connecticut. If successful, the company said that the tests would help clear the way for restarting the reactor in March. ''The purpose of the test is to insure that the containment building can maintain its integrity,'' Richard Gallagher, a Northeast spokesman, said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TODAY'S MAN INC., Moorestown, N.J., the men's apparel retailer, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after obtaining financing to pay off its creditors.

title: Sony Will Buy 5% of Nextlevel
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that it would buy 5 percent of Nextlevel Systems Inc. for about $188 million and would help Nextlevel develop and distribute set-top devices for digital cable television.

title: Kwan Will Skate at Nationals
description: Michelle Kwan skated impressively during training today at the national figure skating championships, and both her coach and her father said she would compete in Thursday's short program.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the New Jersey section on Sunday for performances of Berlioz's ''Childhood of Christ'' at the Park Theater in Union City -- with final performances tonight at 7 and Sunday at 2 -- misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is (201) 865-6980.

title: MOODY'S GIVES FORD MOTOR A NEGATIVE RATINGS OUTLOOK
description: The ratings outlook for the Ford Motor Company was changed to negative from stable by Moody's Investors Service because of weaker than expected auto markets in Asia and Latin America, increased competition in Europe and North America and the spinoff of Ford's 80.7 percent stake in Associates First Capital, the rating service said. Ford bought the consumer finance business in 1989 for $3.35 billion and sold 19.3 percent of it to the public in 1996. It recently valued its stake in the unit at $18 billion. Last October, Standard & Poor's lowered Ford's corporate credit rating and its senior debt rating because of the pending spinoff.

title: Drug Profits Support Colombia's Rightist Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: A Japanese Plan to Save Banks by Buying a Piece of Them
description: Borrowing a chapter from America's rescue of its banks during the Depression, the Japanese Government is drafting a law to bail out banks in this country by taking a stake in them.

title: Detective Work and Science Reveal a New Lethal Bacteria
description: People in the United States are sickened by their food once a year, on average. But the food poisoning that suddenly appeared in White City, Ore., in December 1981 was something else.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Lieut. Gen. Thomas Samuel Moorman on Dec. 28 referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of stars he earned. He added his third star in 1961, not his fourth.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Byron's Attraction to Life Beyond the Boundary
description: ON A VOICELESS SHORE

title: The Minimalist; The Orange-Fennel Powerhouse
description: IT isn't often that you can combine a handful of winter staples and create a fairly novel, fresh-tasting dish that is easily varied, stands on its own or forms the base for other foods. Yet, a simple melange of fennel and orange does all of those, and without a lot of effort.

title: Group Joins With Family In Searching For Reveler
description: When a Fordham University student, Patrick McNeill, disappeared after a night of drinking in Manhattan last February, hundreds of friends and neighbors from Port Chester, N.Y, converged on Manhattan to search for him. He was later found drowned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, KARL, HEINZ
description: MOHR-Karl-Heinz, age 29. Performance Analyst at J.M. Hartwell, L.P. of New York City suddenly on Sunday, January 4, 1998. Beloved son of Michael and Angela (De Blasio) Mohr. Loving brother of Marina. Dear nephew of Maria Pia De Blasio, M.D., and Enzo and Maria De Blasio. Loving cousin of Nello and Anna De Blasio. Funeral Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, on Thursday at 9:30 A.M. Mass of Christian burial St. Frances de Chantal at 10 A.M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Visiting on Tuesday, 7-9:30 P.M. and on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 22 about the writer Jan Morris misstated the nationalities of the first climbers to reach the top of Mount Everest, about which the writer reported in 1953 as a correspondent for The Times of London. They were Edmund Hillary, a New Zealander, and Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa guide from Nepal; they were not British.

title: Liberties; Good Night, David
description: I don't think the First Amendment should cover the President's thighs. Something should, but it needn't be the Constitution.

title: WATSCO MAY SELL ITS MANUFACTURING AND STAFFING UNITS
description: Watsco Inc. said yesterday that it was considering the sale of its manufacturing and temporary-staffing units to concentrate on its faster-growing business of distributing air-conditioning and heating products. The Miami-based company said the units, Watsco Components Inc. and Dunhill Staffing Systems Inc., are expected to account for less than 8 percent of 1998 revenue. Last year, Watsco Components had $23 million in revenue and Dunhill Staffing Systems, about $45 million. Watsco said it would also consider spinning off the units to shareholders. The move comes after a third-quarter earnings disappointment attributed to weakness in the manufacturing business. Watsco shares rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $25.375.

title: Wells BDDP, roiled by management changes, loses its third big client in two months.
description: WELLS BDDP in New York has lost another large longtime client as the agency continues to grapple with turmoil in the executive suite.

title: Public Shaming: Rating System for Schools
description: To prod schools to improve, states and districts have tried any number of strategies, from ordering the full-scale replacement of curriculums to dismissing principals to imposing layers of standardized tests. But over the last few years, an increasing number of states have begun to embrace a more emotionally charged approach: public shaming.

title: John H. Yoder, Theologian At Notre Dame, Is Dead at 70
description: John Howard Yoder, a Mennonite theologian whose writings on Christianity and politics had a major impact on contemporary Christian thinking about the church and social ethics, died on Dec. 30 at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind. He had turned 70 the day before.

title: With Cloutier Still in Goal, the Rangers Win Again
description: Mike Richter's vacation was extended last night. But he briefed his understudy, Dan Cloutier, then saw the lesson reap dividends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, JACOB, M.D.
description: WEISS - Jacob, M.D. Central Brooklyn Medical Group, was saddened to learn of the passing in Florida, of Jacob Weiss, M.D. Jack was a long time internist with our group who was greatly respected and loved by both patients and colleagues. Alexander Ellman, M.D. Medical Director Central Bklyn Medical Group P.C.

title: Sonny Bono, 62, Dies in Skiing Accident
description: Representative Sonny Bono, whose unexpected career in Republican politics followed an equally unexpected -- and successful -- career as a singer and television star with his former wife Cher, was killed on Monday afternoon when he crashed into a tree while skiing in South Lake Tahoe, Calif. He was 62 and lived in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Digital Equipment in Sequent Collaboration
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Sequent Computer Systems Inc. said yesterday that they would collaborate on a new version of the Unix operating system to run on the Intel Corporation's forthcoming 64-bit microprocessor, code-named Merced. Digital and Sequent said they would aggressively recruit additional partners and licensees.

title: A Cleaner Family Truck
description: The Ford Motor Company's decision to reduce smog-causing emissions from its popular and profitable sport utility vehicles and Windstar minivans is a surprising and smart move. These vehicles are considered to be ''light trucks'' under Federal law and are allowed to meet far less stringent pollution standards than cars, even though most are used for family transportation. With light trucks now representing more than 40 percent of passenger vehicles sold, the weaker emissions standards are a serious threat to clean-air goals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, ROBERT D.
description: CHAPMAN-Robert D. Born on December 21, 1915; of Palm Beach Gardens, FL.; passed away January 4, 1998. Bob was a NYC book and magazine production executive before retiring to south FL. He is survived by his beloved wife Helen, his two sons Vance and Geoffrey; four daughters Robin, Janice, Linda and Kimberly; five grandchildren and his sister Delores Bredon. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM, Thursday, Jan. 8 at Trinity United Methodist Church in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. In lieu of flowers, friends who wish may make a memorial donation to American Heart Assoc or American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, HOWARD
description: GILMAN-Howard. On behalf of the entire New York University Medical Center community we note with great sorrow the passing of Howard Gilman, a longtime benefactor and good friend. He established the Howard Gilman Foundation AIDS Research Laboratory at the Medical Center and has helped our scientists in their quest to understand one of today's most challenging diseases. Howard will be missed deeply. We offer our sincere condolences to his family and friends. E. John Rosenwald, Jr., Chairman Board of Trustees NYU Medical Center Noel L. Cohen, M.D., Interim Provost and Dean NYU Medical Center

title: High-Profile Skiing Deaths Put Spotlight on Head Injury Prevention
description: Although death and injury rates show that skiing is relatively safe, two high-profile skiing deaths in less than a week are focusing attention on safety as never before.

title: The Reason Behind No Angell Rhyme
description: A friend writes, as they might say at The New Yorker magazine: We were surprised that the fat year-end issue did not carry a slightly singsongy poem by ROGER ANGELL, an editor who has long been responsible for building the annual page-filling rhyme around well-known names. How else to explain mentioning Schools Chancellor RUDY CREW in almost the same breath as the actress ELIZABETH SHUE?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOSLEY, H. EVERTON, JR.
description: HOSLEY-H. Everton, Jr. In East Lyme, CT., January 3, 1998. Husband of the late Margaret Brown Hosley of Elys Ferry Road, Lyme. Father of Barbara C. Bell, Southport, CT.; David F. Currier, Branford, CT.; Henry E. Hosley, III, Old Lyme, CT.; Richmond B. Hosley, Lyme, CT.; Charles S. Hosley, Lyme, CT.; and Catherine H. Vouwie, Manchester, MA. Brother of Ethelyn Hosley, Mount Dora, Florida. Also survived by nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Memorial service at First Congregational Church, Old Lyme, CT, Saturday, January 10 at 3 PM. Memorial gifts may be sent to The Yale Class of 1938, PO Box 209010, New Haven, Connecticut 06520-9010 or to the Nature Conservancy, CT. Chapter, 55 High Street, Middletown, CT. 06457.

title: TV Notes; NBC Snags 'Titanic'
description: NBC pulled off the best movie deal in recent network history this week, landing the runaway hit movie ''Titanic'' for the relatively paltry sum of $30 million.

title: Hurricanes Are Rising As Huskies Fall Flat
description: When the University of Miami went into a zone defense against Connecticut 10 minutes into tonight's game, Huskies Coach Jim Calhoun expected his team to pick the Hurricanes apart.

title: Sips; From the West Coast, A Beer Not for Feeble Palates
description: IF Bill Owens, the publisher of Beer, the Magazine, had to choose only one beer to drink, it would be from the Anderson Valley Brewing Company in Boonville, Calif. ''They're the best,'' Mr. Owens said.

title: Hot Truck Sales Make Ford's and Chrysler's Day
description: Two big American auto makers saw their sales of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans reach records last month, even as their car sales skidded.

title: A Chief Is Searching For a New City Order
description: For Chief Allan H. Hoehl of the New York City police, a quest to impose order on Manhattan's willful chaos is moving from dream to reality. Take the peaceful New Year's Eve celebration. Or the pedestrian barricade experiment in midtown.

title: Gambling Industry Scoffs at Mayor's Plan for Governors Island
description: Officials of MGM Grand Inc. may have nibbled at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's idea for a casino on Governors Island, but most other gambling executives are writing it off as an impossible long shot, industry experts said yesterday.

title: From 12 Hours of Bach To 20 Years of the Arts
description: It began 20 years ago today, when two men living across the hall from each other in an Upper West Side apartment building rented a ramshackle movie theater on Broadway and 95th Street and staged a free, 12-hour marathon of Bach music for the neighborhood.

title: DiTech Hires Kovel Kresser
description: The DiTech Funding Corporation, a mortgage banking company in Irvine, Calif., has named Kovel Kresser & Partners in Santa Monica, Calif., to handle its account, which had been handled for two and a half years by Ken Roberts Productions in Newport Beach, Calif. Billings were estimated at $20 million. J. Paul Reddam, president of DiTech, said that Kovel Kresser was awarded the account after a four-month review that also included Roberts and Luminaire in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOREMAN, MARGARET (NEE HEYDECKER)
description: FOREMAN-Margaret (nee Heydecker), 79. Of North Granby CT, formerly of Pelham Manor, N.Y. Widow of Charles W.L. Foreman. Died Sunday, Jan. 4. She leaves a daughter Judy Foreman of Cambridge, MA., and a son William Foreman of Ludlow, VT and three grandchildren. Memorial services will be held Saturday, January 24 at 2 PM, at the Simsbury United Methodist Church, 799 Hopmeadow St., Simsbury CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Salvation Army, 855 Asylum Av, Hartford, CT 06105

title: CLINTON PROPOSES OPENING MEDICARE TO THOSE 55 TO 65
description: President Clinton proposed a significant expansion of Medicare today, to allow hundreds of thousands of early retirees, laid-off workers and uninsured Americans between the ages of 55 and 65 to enroll in the Federal health care program for the elderly.

title: Senators' Tour Includes Resort Stay
description: In an opportune, midwinter mix of business and pleasure, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, and four of his colleagues are on a five-country tour of Latin America this week to review American troops, international trade and anti-drug programs.

title: Long Bond's Yield 5.72%, a New Low
description: Bond prices ended higher for the fourth straight session yesterday, pushing yields further into record-low territory and inducing more corporate borrowers to sell debt.

title: East German Steroid Champions
description: Germany's thorough attempts to prosecute those who committed crimes during the East German dictatorship have now entered the world of sports. Four trainers and two doctors at a Berlin swimming club have been indicted for injuring the swimmers in their care by administering performance-enhancing anabolic steroids, and future indictments may reach the former Communist Party Central Committee. While this is certainly not the worst crime of the old East German Government, Germany is right to attempt to try people whose pursuit of Communist glory damaged the health of thousands of athletes, many of them children.

title: Jack of All Tongues
description: To the Editor:

title: INNKEEPERS TO BUY 8 RESIDENCE INN BY MARRIOTT HOTELS
description: Innkeepers USA Trust said yesterday than it had agreed to acquire eight Residence Inn by Marriott hotels for $59.5 million. Innkeepers, which is based in Palm Beach, Fla., is a real estate investment trust that owns upscale, extended-stay hotel properties. Residence Inn by Marriott, a unit of Marriott International Inc. with headquarters in Bethesda, Md., would continue to manage the properties, and Innkeepers plans to invest an additional $3 million for renovations. The hotels are in Ontario, Calif.; Orlando, Fla.; Louisville and Lexington, Ky.; Winston-Salem, N.C.; Indianapolis and Fort Wayne, Ind., and Columbus, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTEFANO, PAT
description: DISTEFANO-Pat, 43. From complications of a brain tumor, January 1st at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. Mr. Distefano worked for the last four years of his life as a casting director for Hopkins Smith Barden Casting. Before this he worked as an actor, appearing in such plays as ''Blue Dahlia'' and ''Search And Destroy'' in L.A., and also as a producer for the Pacific Repertory Theater. He is survived by his parents, Pat and Antoinette of Las Vegas, and his sister, Linda Lackey of Los Angeles. A memorial service will be held on Friday, January 9th, at 4:00 P.M., at St. Monica's Church in Santa Monica (701 California Avenue).

title: Head of Women's Tour, Named To Post Last Month, Steps Down
description: In an embarrassing setback for women's professional tennis, Ric Clarson, who was appointed chief executive officer of the Corel WTA Tour last month, abruptly informed tour officials yesterday that he had had a change of heart and would not accept the $250,000-a-year post.

title: Woods Can't Wait to Hit the Fairways This Week in Mercedes Tourney
description: For Tiger Woods, another season of great expectations starts this week.

title: YACHT RACING: WHITBREAD ROUND THE WORLD RACE -- A Sailor's Journal; Fleet Heads Across the Antipodes
description: The nine-boat fleet in the 31,600-nautical-mile Whitbread Round the World Race left Sydney last Sunday on Leg 4, the 1,270-nautical-mile hop to Auckland, New Zealand. As of yesterday, Swedish Match led, with Toshiba 0.7 miles behind in second.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEREFF, HENRY DAVID
description: SHEREFF-Henry David. In loving memory of Henry David Shereff. We regret to announce the death of Henry David Shereff, January 6, 1998 at 78 years old. Born May 25, 1919, son of Solomon and Leah. Beloved husband of Meta. Beloved father of Stephen, Sidney and Charles. Beloved brother-inlaw to Anna, Shirley and Rose. Beloved father-in-law to Sharon. Beloved grandfather of Rachel. He graduated from Townsend Harris High School and CCNY. He served in the USAAF during W.W. II and was honorably discharged with the rank of Master sergeant. After the war he went to Columbia University Law School and graduated in 1947. He was accepted to the NY Bar in 1948. He worked as a Staff Attorney to the NYS Revision Commission. He then joined Berlack, Israels & Liberman where he became a managing partner and stayed until 1971 when he founded his own firm Shereff, Friedman, Hoffman & Goodman. He worked there specializing in corporate tax and agricultural cooperative law. He wrote numerous articles and three books for the Practicing Law Institute. He wrote one law textbook for the ALI of the American Bar Association. He reestablished Townsend Harris High School for which Queens Borough President Claire Schulman declared April 26, 1991 Henry D. Shereff day. He received the Founders Award from the Townsend Harris High School Alumni Association on June 23, 1988. He was also on the Board of Directors of the Columbia University Law School alumni Association. In his spare time he enjoyed deep sea fishing, handball, jogging and oil painting. His great spirit and love of life will be deeply missed and remembered by everyone who knew and loved him. There will be a service at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial chapels at 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, New York, Thursday, January 8, 1998 at 1 P.M., followed by burial at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, Queens.

title: Calendar
description: Indian Cooking Classes

title: Arnott Gets Ready With Barest of Practice
description: Jason Arnott had hoped that his first real contact with his new teammates would involve more than shooting pucks into an empty net. But with only a handful of Devils participating in today's optional practice, Arnott will have to wait until just hours before Wednesday night's game at Continental Arena against the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Whitman Lures Builders to Tainted Sites
description: As crews demolished the contaminated remains of an 83-year-old factory behind her, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill today that is intended to entice developers to build on thousands of pollution-tainted industrial sites around the state.

title: Carnegie Hall Announces 1998-99 Season
description: Carnegie Hall will open its 1998-1999 season with a gala Gershwin concert on Sept. 23 by the San Francisco Symphony under its music director, Michael Tilson Thomas, the hall's executive and artistic director, Judith Arron, said in announcing the schedule yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, IDA S.
description: ROSEN-Ida S. Age 91. Of Manchester, N.H. on January 4, 1998 after a short illness. Born in Chelsea, MA. Daughter of Jacob and Sarah (Goldberg) Horenstein. Widow of Israel A. Rosen. Survived by two sons, Morton R. Rosen of Manchester, N.H., Charles E. Rosen of New York City; two brothers, Michael Horenstein, Everett, Mass. and Wolfe Horenstein of Marblehead, MA., three grandchildren and a great granddaughter. Preceased by her daughter Marcia M. Rosen. Funeral service Tuesday, 2PM, Temple Israel, Manchester, N.H. Burial in Anshai Sfard Cemeter, Danvers, Mass. Memorial donations to the Marcia Rosen Fund, C/O Community Partners Inc., PO Box 363, Biddeford, ME. 04005.

title: Broker Charged With Stock Manipulation
description: Monroe Parker Securities, a brokerage firm that had close ties to the often-sanctioned penny-stock broker Stratton Oakmont, has been charged by regulators with illegally making $4.4 million through stock manipulation on the Nasdaq small-capitalization market.

title: Unisys to Drop Personal Computers and Take $1.1 Billion Charge
description: Cleaning up the remains of Unisys's failed strategies, Lawrence A. Weinbach, the company's new chief executive, said yesterday that the ailing company would get out of the personal computer business and write off the value of its 1986 acquisition of the Sperry Corporation.

title: The Neediest Cases; Giving Order to a Boy's Tangled Life
description: John Turco has never met a piece of furniture he did not want to pounce on. The sofas in his mother's house, their legs broken, list like sinking ships. The dining room chairs are long gone, shattered beneath his 200-pound frame. His brand-new bed ''is now history,'' as his mother put it.

title: Licensed Goods See Sales Increase
description: The retail sales of licensed merchandise in North America rose 1 percent in 1997 to $73.2 billion, according to the 21st annual licensing industry survey by The Licensing Letter, a newsletter published by EPM Communications in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, SR. CHRISTINE
description: O'CONNOR-Sr. Christine. Beloved member of the Sisters Of Charity died on January 4, 1998. Reposing Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., at Riverdale - On - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10 A.M., at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment in St. Joseph's Cemetery.

title: Accounts
description: * Outrigger Hotels, Honolulu, to Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown, Orlando, Fla., to handle its account, which had been handled by Peck Sims, Honolulu. Billings were estimated at more than $4 million.

title: Flight to Replace Cruise to See Pope in Cuba
description: Two weeks after opponents of Fidel Castro pressured Roman Catholic Church officials into canceling a three-day cruise to Cuba to see Pope John Paul II, the Archdiocese of Miami announced today that it would charter a plane for the pilgrims.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KALKSTEIN, IRVING
description: KALKSTEIN-Irving One fine man. Always remembered. Martin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATEMAN, DR. JOHN
description: BATEMAN-Dr. John. The Columbia University Department of Physical Education and Intercollegiate Athletics mourns the passing of John Bateman, who represented Columbia so well as a student-athlete, coach, and alumnus. Co-captain of the 1937 Columbia Football Team, he returned to his alma mater as assistant football coach and served for 10 years, earning the friendship and respect of the young men who played for Columbia. Even after becoming head coach at Rutgers, he returned to Columbia many times for alumni functions. Just 2 months ago, he was the only coach to attend the Homecoming reunion of his 1947 Columbia team. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Anita and their family.

title: Eldredge Is on Target For a Fifth U.S. Title
description: Todd Eldredge, whose only luck in previous Olympic years was no luck at all, continued his recovery from an early season injury tonight by winning the short program at the national figure-skating championships.

title: Grammy Nominations Yield Surprises, Including Newcomer's Success
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced the nominees for the 40th annual Grammy Awards yesterday in Manhattan, and along with the usual Grammy suspects (Tony Bennett, Babyface, Sir Georg Solti, the polka king Jimmy Sturr), there were many surprises.

title: New York Area Airports Hobbled by Fog, Again
description: Fog engulfed the New York metropolitan region early yesterday morning, forcing planes to sit still on the runways at some local airports for the second day in a row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, WILLIAM C.
description: BERMAN-William C. Beloved and devoted husband who was care giver to his dear Alzheimerafflicted wife Fanny, for 12 years until her passing in 1992. Cherished, adored and loving father of Marilyn Grosfeld. Devoted, proud, and greatly admired ''professor of life'' grandfather (''Poppie'') of Scott. Adored, best friend and father-in-law of Sonny Grosfeld. Those who knew him will always have fond memories of his intense loyalty, devotion and unconditional support of family and friends; his business acumen and takecharge leadership qualities which served him well as past president of both the Amalgamated and Wynmoor Cooperatives; his inquisitive, inventive genius; his quick wit, sense of humor and ''impish'' charm; his common sense approach to and lust for life. We thank him for always being there for us-our Renaissance man. We will miss him forever. Service to be private Tues., January 6, 1998.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RALLY CONTINUES. Comments by an official of the German central bank that the dollar's value is not an issue for it helped push the dollar to a four-month high against the mark. The dollar also rose against most Asian currencies but ended little changed against the yen.

title: Revised Tobacco Ad Ban Nears Signing
description: A day after suggesting that he might not sign a bill banning outdoor tobacco advertising in most of the city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani worked out an agreement with Speaker Peter F. Vallone of the City Council yesterday that keeps the legislation intact but extends to six months the time businesses have to comply with the ban, aides to both men said.

title: Bugel Out in Oakland; Belichick Could Be In
description: Bill Belichick may be in. Tyrone Willingham is out. Joe Bugel is definitely out. Tommy Tuberville may be in the mix. In other words, let the coaching carousel begin.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's a sad statement that there are people who would oppose naming the school after a great human being and a great citizen. Don't tell us this has nothing to do with race. We're not fools.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYDJU, STEINAR
description: RYDJU-Steinar. Born May 20, 1940. Husband of Meredith, beloved father of Lisa, Kari and Erik. Brother of Audhild Olafson. Served in Royal Norwegian Navy. Private service to be held in Los Angeles.

title: Vouchers Do Nothing to Improve Public Schools; Charter Schools Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Vallone Urges Lower Tuition for CUNY's Best
description: The Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, is proposing that the City University offer half-price tuition for two years to students who maintain at least a B average in high school and college, saying that such a policy would encourage academic excellence and hard work.

title: Smithsonian Alters Plan For Israel's Anniversary
description: Heading off criticism that it was planning an unbalanced celebration of Israel's 50th anniversary, the Smithsonian Institution said today that it would scrap the proposed events and develop new ones.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: In a Twist Worthy of an Opera Plot, a Tenor Is Thrust From Obscurity
description: Few roles in opera require more vocal maturity and psychological understanding than the tormented title character of Britten's ''Peter Grimes.'' Yet on Monday night in the Metropolitan Opera's current production of the work, the role was assumed compellingly on just two weeks' notice by Anthony Dean Griffey, a promising tenor of only 30. Mr. Griffey had been on standby for the part when the scheduled tenor, Chris Merritt, withdrew.

title: After Land-Mine Triumph, a Crusade Against Small Arms
description: Buoyed by their surprising success in achieving a treaty to ban land mines, a range of nongovernmental groups from academic institutes to human rights and aid agencies are now girding for a campaign against assault rifles and other light weapons, which inflame ethnic and nationalist wars around the world.

title: A Wink and a Prayer: Netanyahu's Hope
description: The lead item on Israel's Channel 2 news program this evening was that Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai had failed to attend a scheduled meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, instead visiting with troops in southern Lebanon.

title: Newark Airport's Lure
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Carnage, Algeria Shuns Aid Offers
description: As reports mounted that Islamic militants were committing atrocities against Algerian civilians, France and its European Union partners struggled today with Algerian Government resistance to any attempt to bring international pressure to bear to stop the killings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, MARIE
description: LLOYD-Marie. The Board of Directors of the William Matheus Sullivan Foundation acknowledges with great sadness the death of their friend and colleague, Marie Lloyd. She played a significant part in the growth and effectiveness of the Foundation in nurturing the careers of young American singers, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, her son and her grandchildren. We will miss her generous spirit and good company.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY/Ron Alexander
description: Metropolitan Diary now appears Mondays in The Metro Section.

title: Getting More Foul Shots Is Knicks' Big Concern
description: John Starks's and Jeff Van Gundy's animated disagreement on Monday night was well documented, with the television cameras recording the moment. The two put that problem behind them before the game was over, but it is what they may have agreed on, not their disagreement, that is a problem that could linger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUESTEL, MAE
description: QUESTEL-Mae. On January 4, 1998. Actress and voice of Betty Boop and Olive Oyl. Wife of the late Jack Shelby. Mother of Richard Balkin and the late Robert G. Balkin. Grandmother of Melissa Balkin Dubizh, Miranda Swados Balkin and Julia Balkin. Services Wednesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: When an Auditor's Hats Clash; KPMG Case Shows Varied Duties Can Create Conflicts
description: Accused of being too cavalier about conflicts that might impair their ability to get tough with clients, the nation's auditors argue that they should be allowed to police themselves, just as they always have.

title: Orthodox Neighborhood Reshapes Itself
description: Years ago, a Hasidic businessman, now the garrulous father of 14, had made enough money as a salesman to flee Borough Park for a leafy suburb with grand, commodious houses.
