But he stayed put, expanding his Brooklyn home forward, backward, upward and even downward until it morphed into an urban mansion, complete with household staff and voice-mail system (press 3 for Shlomo, 4 for Shuli).

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PRICES PLUNGE. A 5 percent drop wiped out the gains of the last four trading sessions as volatility continued. Analysts said Latin American growers would meet American demand. But bean prices are still about 42 percent higher than they were a year ago.

title: Arts Abroad; Living With a Shortage of Everything but Desire
description: Five years ago, when she was still living in Havana and working at a magazine that had ceased publishing because there was no longer paper to print it, Zoe Valdes mentioned to a friend that with so much time on her hands, she was writing a novel. The title, she told him, was ''La Nada Cotidiana'' -- a literal translation for which might be ''The Nothingness of Daily Life.''

title: Budget Opportunities; Mr. Clinton's Deficit Coup
description: President Clinton's surprise decision to propose the first balanced budget in a generation may not by itself have much impact on taxes, spending or the economy. But it was a shrewdly symbolic move to transform the way these issues are debated politically. By moving three years ahead of schedule to eliminate the Federal deficit, the Administration will be on firmer ground to oppose reflexive Republican demands for tax cuts. The prospect of a balanced budget has also cleared room for Mr. Clinton to promote disciplined plans for meeting neglected needs.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Washington Post Posts Changes

title: Sports of The Times; A Dream That Wasn't So Dumb
description: HIS hair whiter and longer than when he pitched during those 23 years in the major leagues, his face looking somewhat lined and tired -- after all, it had been a long trip, 324 career victories and an emergency airplane stopover in Washington on his way from Atlanta to New York yesterday morning -- Don Sutton sat at a dais in the front of a large room in a midtown Manhattan hotel. This was for a news conference called in his honor. And if his face appeared to be drawn from the journey -- journeys, as it were -- his eyes were aglow. After all, the day before he had been told that, in his fifth year on the ballot, at age 52, he had been elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop Videos; Backstage Fantasies With Rock Stars
description: The all-access backstage pass: those who have owned them save them like rare stamps. They are laminated keys to a world where pop stars are no longer performing. They are themselves. In the fantasies of fans, that means committing depraved and illegal acts for some bands, riding in limousines and gorging on Champagne and caviar for others, and discussing guitar pedals and writing new songs for still others. But the truth is that backstage is more often than not a boring place, where eating bad food and waiting around are the typical rituals leading up to a big show.

title: Remains of Crash Victim From '44 Will Be Buried
description: A coffin with the partial remains of a United States Army corporal whose plane crashed into the mountains of Tibet in 1944 will finally be returned home today, officials said yesterday.

title: Budget Opportunities; Medicare Expansion
description: President Clinton's proposal to open Medicare to early retirees and laid-off older workers is a worthy effort to boost coverage among two vulnerable groups. The plan could face cost problems but is probably the best that can be done, given the failure to achieve more comprehensive health insurance reform in 1994.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Calendar column of the House & Home section on Thursday about a preview dinner at the Outsider Art Fair on Jan. 22, to benefit the Museum of American Folk Art, misstated the telephone number. It is (212) 977-7170.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, W. HARCOURT
description: WOODS-W. Harcourt. The Board of Directors and staff of the International Tennis Hall of Fame mourn the loss of our friend and board member. A warm, gracious and committed supporter of tennis, hockey, will be deeply missed by all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Mary, and family. William F. Talbert, Chairman Emeritus John R. Reese, Chairman Jane G. Brown, President

title: Police Officer Dismissed 2 Years After Conviction
description: Two years after he was convicted of attempted assault on a Korean greengrocer, Officer Rolando Baquadano was dismissed on Monday from the New York Police Department.

title: Cocaine Shipped to Newspaper
description: The Miami Herald's crime reporters did not have far to travel for the big story of the day today, when United States Customs agents seized two boxes containing cocaine and heroin addressed to the newspaper's business desk.

title: Reporter Visits Pol Pot, Still Held by Khmer Rouge
description: Khmer Rouge guerrillas in Cambodia have allowed a Thai reporter to meet briefly with their imprisoned former leader, Pol Pot, dispelling rumors that he had fled abroad from their jungle hideout, The Bangkok Post reported today.

title: ENRON GETS $130 MILLION FOR RETAIL ENERGY STAKES
description: The Enron Corporation sold 7 percent of its retail energy business to two pension funds for $130 million to offset the cost of expanding retail energy sales. Enron, the natural gas and electricity company based in Houston, completed arrangements with the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Board and the California Public Employees' Retirement System to sell stakes in its Enron Energy Services unit late last year to cover losses related to start-up costs. Enron has said it may sell as much as 15 percent of the unit over the next several years. Enron Energy Services was created last spring to provide natural gas and electricity to consumers in states like California that are preparing to deregulate. Enron shares fell $1.25 yesterday, to $38.75.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Loss of One Firm Means Major Shifts in Tenants
description: Once the law firm of Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom decided to move to Times Square rather than renew its lease at 919 Third Avenue, the script for that building's future had to change. Now, instead of one major tenant after the turn of the century, there are likely to be several.

title: Why Move to Vermont? Why Shouldn't We?
description: To the Editor:

title: Vouchers Do Nothing to Improve Public Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Historians Warming To Games Of 'What If'
description: When the gun-twirling sharpshooter Annie Oakley toured Europe with Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show in 1889, one of her stunts was to shoot the ashes from the tip of a lighted cigar clenched between the teeth of a volunteer. At a performance in Berlin that year, the volunteer was the impetuous young Kaiser Wilhelm II, who leaped to the stage and offered to play the stooge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLIN, SIDNEY
description: WOLIN-Sidney. On January 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Susan, devoted father of Lauree Mitchell, James and Ronald. Services Friday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Luminous Path Navigated by Stage Lights
description: Last spring, Cherry Jones allowed herself to be seduced by temptation, just to see what it was like. The current high priestess of New York theater stepped off the stage and took a role in a big-budget feature film, ''The Horse Whisperer,'' directed by Robert Redford.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREYDBERG, VI
description: FREYDBERG-Vi. Dear Mom, thinking of you, loving and missing you everyday. You'll always be the sunshine of our lives. Happy Birthday with all our love for ever and ever. Judy and Sue.

title: Whittle's Schools Getting Investor Infusion
description: With its fledgling network of for-profit schools still at least three years away from turning a profit, the Edison Project said yesterday that it had secured an infusion of $56 million from investors to help pay for continuing start-up costs.

title: Ultramar in Venture With Petro-Canada
description: The Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation and Petro-Canada will form a refining and marketing joint venture for Canada and the Northern United States, the companies said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, FLORENCE
description: LIEBOWITZ-Florence. Temple Israel of Lawrence, New York mourns the death of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to her family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, DANIEL BERTRAM, SR.
description: GROSSMAN-Daniel Bertram, Sr. 72, on January 5, 1998 in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Danny Grossman and Dana Hammond, grandfather of Oliver, Miles, Jonathan and Nicky Hammond. Funeral 11 AM, Saturday, January 10, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either St. Peter's Episcopal Church Building Fund, PO Box 336, Del Mar, CA 92014 or Scripps Clinic, Division of Chest Medicine, 10666 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA 92037.

title: TV Notes; Still Kicking After Football
description: Every January three networks wait for the end of the regular football season so they can ride in and steal away all those viewers addicted to ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' in the fall.

title: About New York; 3 Kings Visit East Harlem, Bearing Hope
description: A TOUCH of royalty graced East Harlem yesterday, when the Three Kings emerged on East 106th Street in flowing capes and robes of shimmering red and gold. Cheers and applause greeted their arrival, as they strode down streets where the morning fog hovered like a mystical blanket.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Professors Who Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFETY-KLEEN REJECTS LAIDLAW IN FAVOR OF A LOWER OFFER
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation said yesterday that it had formally rejected an offer by Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc. to buy the company in favor of a bid with a lower current value. Laidlaw, a waste management company based in Columbia, S.C., made a hostile bid in early December to buy Safety-Kleen at $30 a share, consisting of $15 in Laidlaw stock and $15 in cash. The total value of the deal would be about $2.1 billion. Safety-Kleen, a hazardous waste management company based in Elgin, Ill., said it preferred a $27-a-share all-cash offer from the SK Parent Corporation, a new company formed in part by the Philip Services Corporation, a hazardous waste company based in Hamilton, Ontario. That deal is valued at $1.9 billion. Safety-Kleen had 1996 revenues of $923.1 million.

title: Four Business Groups In Japan Urge Tax Cuts
description: The heads of Japan's four leading business organizations called on the Government yesterday to approve further tax cuts for individuals as a way to increase consumer confidence. ''Permanent tax cuts are needed to provide the impetus for growth,'' said Shoichiro Toyoda, head of the Japan Federation of Economic Organizations.

title: Small-Stock Fans Hoping For a January Effect Rally
description: Fans of small-company stocks are beating the drum once again.

title: Turkey's Top Court Weighs Move to Ban Islamic Party
description: A new judge took over as chief of Turkey's highest court today as it prepares to issue what may be its most important decision in the country's modern history.

title: BRANDYWINE REALTY BUYS 23 PROPERTIES FOR $229 MILLION
description: Brandywine Realty Trust said it had agreed to acquire a 23-property portfolio from GMH Associates Inc. and other partners for $229 million. Brandywine, based in Newtown Square, Pa., has more than 90 commercial and industrial properties. GMH Associates, of Wayne, Pa., is a private real estate company. The other partners include Whitehall Street Real Estate L.L.P. VII and the General Electric GE Capital unit. The portfolio, with a total of 1.9 million square feet, consists of office properties in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland and Ohio. Brandywine stock rose 31.25 cents a share, to $25.625.

title: By the Book; Yucca Fries and Other Delights
description: TACKLING so large and complex a subject as Latin American-influenced cooking in America in a single cookbook seems a nearly impossible task.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIPRESS, NATHAN L.
description: SIPRESS-Nathan L. On January 4, 1998 in his 94th year. Husband for 56 years of the late Estelle. Father of Linda, David and Ginny. Arrived in this country from Russia in 1914 and became the proprietor of Revere Jewelers. Services at 5:30pm, Wednesday, January 7 at Frank E, Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Instead of flowers, please send contributions to Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79 Street, NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELSH, DOROTHY M.
description: WELSH-Dorothy M. Of Livermore, CA. Formerly of New York City. On December 24, 1997. Wife of the late Walter. Dear mother of Adrian. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 1-4 and 6-8 PM Friday. Graveside service Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Saturday, January 10, at 10 AM.

title: Nets Are Now Positioned To Make It a Real Rivalry
description: It is not the Lakers and the Celtics. It never has been. It is not even Knicks-Bulls, or Heat-Bulls, for that matter. Not yet, at least. But whereas the Knicks used to be able to laugh off the Nets rather easily, that is not the case anymore. A rivalry is budding between the cross-river teams, who will play for second place in the Atlantic Division tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Trial Begins For Woman In the Death Of Her Baby
description: The way prosecutors told it in court yesterday, Karlie DiTrapani killed her baby minutes after secretly giving birth to him in a bathroom of her Brooklyn home, after a pregnancy that the unmarried college student had fearfully hidden from her family.

title: Weaker Yen Pushes Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks rose today, led by exporters like the Bridgestone Corporation that stand to benefit from the yen's weakness against the dollar.

title: Tahiti for Him, Caribbean for Her
description: NICOLE CONTOS, whose fiance left her at the altar and then left (by himself) on what was to have been their honeymoon in Tahiti last month, is trying a 90's variation on the Dorothy Fields lyric: Pick yourself up, dust yourself off and start all over again -- at a resort. She leaves for the West Indies on Friday. ''I'm going to move on with my life,'' starting with the four-day vacation, paid for by a tequila importer. ''At first I said no,'' she said. ''I was worried everyone was going to jump on the plane and follow me.''

title: Francisco Rodrigo, 83, Filipino Who Defied Marcos Dictatorship
description: Francisco Rodrigo, one of the old-time campaigners against the dictatorship of Ferdinand E. Marcos, died on Sunday after decades of unbending dissidence, a Philippine newspaper reported today. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, JOHN A.
description: ADAMS-John A. On January 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Penny. Devoted father of John and Stephanie. Reposing at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73rd Street, on Wednesday, January 7 from 4-6 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service at the Church on Thursday, January 8, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, it would be appreciated if contributions were sent to the American Cancer Society/Pancreatic Research-John Adams Memorial, C/O Steve Dickinson, 1599 Clifton Road, Atlanta, GA 30329-4215.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFF, HELEN
description: LIFF-Helen. One week before her 76th birthday. Beloved wife of Ben for 55 years. Loving mother of Madeline, Mark and Michael. Adored grandmother of Jessica, Alan, Jeremy, Lauren, Stephanie and Noah. Services Wednesday, 10AM, Parkside, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue.

title: Test Kitchen; Future Kitchen: The Heat Is Easier to Take
description: THE hearth of the American home kitchen -- warmed for generations by either gas flame or electric coil -- is in for a shock. The kitchen of the very near future is likely to draw its heat from sources as diverse as electromagnets and visible light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ROBERT S.
description: BROWN-Robert S. Of Providence, RI and Great Neck, NY, January 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Erika. Devoted father of Kenneth, Carita (Marshall) Dornfeld and Neil (Leslie) Brown. Loving grandfather of Ethan, Jeremy and Aidan. Services Wednesday, Jan. 7, 12:30PM at Temple Beth-El, Old Mill Road Great Neck, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to VNA Foundation to Benefit Hospice Program, Box H, Annex Station, Providence, Rhode Island 02901.

title: With the Focus on South Korea, Thai and Indonesian Aid Falters
description: As the United States has focused on rescuing South Korea, the emergency programs to stabilize Thailand and Indonesia have begun to unravel, raising new fears about the effectiveness of the International Monetary Fund's prescriptions for stabilizing large regions of Asia.

title: Name-Change Survey's Results
description: For the fourth consecutive year, the number of corporate name changes increased primarily because of corporate revampings, an annual survey reported.

title: China Will Allow 3 U.S. Clerics to Visit Tibet, Group Says
description: American religious leaders traveling to China to investigate religious persecution will be permitted to visit Tibet on their trip, members of the delegation said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Washington Post Posts Changes
description: The bulletin-board memos at The Washington Post yesterday announced that ROBERT G. KAISER would step down as managing editor on June 30. The executive editor, LEONARD DOWNIE JR., said that Mr. Kaiser would be an associate editor and senior correspondent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: BASKETBALL; Artest Can't Lift a Lackluster St. John's
description: Back in the mid-1980's, a regular-season contest between St. John's and Louisville represented a marquee clash of tradition-rich programs at the top of their games.

title: Islanders Work Hard, But Slide Continues
description: The Islanders, surprisingly, showed none of the telltale signs of a slumping team tonight. They had every excuse to hang their heads against the Pittsburgh Penguins, but they didn't.

title: QWEST TO CARRY APEX INTERNET DATA FOR $260 MILLION
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it would transmit Internet data for Apex Global Internet Services on its fiber optic network. The deal is valued at $260 million, but Qwest could get as much as $575 million over the life of the 20-year contract, said Robert Woodruff, Qwest's chief financial officer. Qwest, which is based in Denver, will receive a 19.99 percent stake in Apex, and Apex, based in Dearborn, Mich., will make monthly cash payments to Qwest. Qwest is building a 16,000-mile fiber optic network. Its shares rose 43.75 cents yesterday, to $65.9375, after gaining $5.125 on Monday, when it obtained a 288-mile fiber optic cable in the Northeast.

title: Friends Pay Tribute to a Poet of Motion
description: Jeff Duncan is better known as one of the founders of Dance Theater Workshop than as a modern dance choreographer. But Duncan, who died in 1989, was a solid and even poetic creator of dances, to judge by two pieces presented in ''A Tribute to Jeff Duncan'' on Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y.

title: Mostly White City Honors Dr. King, Amid Dissent
description: Two weeks before the country celebrates the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a national holiday, the debate over what to call the new high school in this increasingly diverse but still predominantly white city illustrates just how much race continues to divide and haunt the land.

title: Vouchers Do Nothing to Improve Public Schools; Parents Lack Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Seizing the Initiative
description: In his proposals to open Medicare to hundreds of thousands of people 55 to 64 years old, President Clinton has again found a way to appeal to voters while showing concern for middle-income families and putting Republicans on the defensive in an election year.

title: Rusedski Advances
description: Greg Rusedski of Britain advanced to the second round of the $1 million Qatar Open with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Spanish clay-court specialist Juan Albert Viloca yesterday. (AP)

title: INSIDE
description: Surprise: Apple Is Profitable

title: McIlvaine to Join A.L. Team as Scout
description: Joe McIlvaine, who was let go as the Mets' general manager last July, said last night that he would join an American League team as a scout.

title: Bomb Jury Adjourns Without a Decision
description: Looking upset, the jurors weighing the fate of Terry L. Nichols adjourned today on their second day of deliberations without reaching a decision on his sentence for conspiring to bomb the Federal Building in Oklahoma City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, PEARL
description: GOLUB-Pearl. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the passing of Pearl Golub, beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother. We offer our sincere condolences to her sons, Harvey (Roberta) and Eugene (Arlene), and the entire Golub family. We hope that your loving memories of Pearl will ease your sorrow during this time of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Executive V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILWORTH, J. RICHARDSON
description: DILWORTH-J. Richardson. On December 29, 1997. Beloved husband, devoted father and proud grandfather. Memorial service will be at 12PM, Saturday, January 10, in the Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, NJ. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers will officiate. A reception will be held afterward at Prospect House on the University Campus. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Melissa Dilworth Gold '61 Visiting Artists Fund at Milton Academy, 170 Centre Street, Milton, MA. 02186. Melissa Dilworth Gold died in a helicopter accident in 1991.

title: More Time for the Elderly To Apply for a Tax Break
description: The leaders of the State Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki agreed yesterday to extend the period for elderly New Yorkers to apply for the state's new property tax break, after complaints that thousands of people had missed deadlines for the program.

title: Off the Menu
description: 'Dove' Seeks a Home

title: Safety Bill Focuses On Highway Ramps
description: Nearly 10 months after an 8-year-old Newark boy was fatally struck by a car while crossing the street near his school, a New Jersey assemblyman has introduced a bill to prohibit the construction of highway access ramps and schools within 1,000 feet of each other.

title: Mihaly Igloi, 89, Hungarian Who Coached Great Runners
description: Mihaly Igloi, a tyrant of a track coach who fled to the United States during the 1956 Hungarian revolution and coached some of the world's leading middle-distance runners, died on Sunday in Budapest. He was 89.

title: Hampshire Securities Sued Over Acquisition
description: A minority shareholder has sued the Hampshire Securities Corporation and its controlling shareholders, contending the investment bank's agreement to be acquired by Gruntal & Company disproportionately benefits the controlling shareholders.

title: A New Home For an Outcast Ad
description: The restaurateur WARNER LeROY has found a new use for the vacant Russian Tea Room on West 57th Street (slightly to the left of Carnegie Hall, as the radio commercials used to say). The facade has become billboard space for an anti-fur attention-getter that was deemed too racy for Times Square: a huge photograph of the actress PAMELA LEE, wearing only fake fingernails.

title: Science and Clarity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURCH, WILLIAM PRESTON
description: BURCH-William Preston. Of Hilton Head Island, Savannah and Garden City on January 5 , 1998. Beloved husband, devoted father and proud grandfather. Survived by his wife Peggy Judd Burch, his brother Elliott of Newport, his three sons, Michael, Peter and Preston and two granddaughters, Katherine and Kristine. Son of the late Preston M. Burch. Longtime executive with Gulfstream Aerospace. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to the American Heart Association, PO Box 23407, Hilton Head Island SC 29925

title: The Barrier Chief Seeks a New City Order
description: NATURALLY, the pictures in Chief Allan H. Hoehl's Police Department office are perfectly hung and evenly spaced, and two of them illustrate both the dream and the ironbound reality of his unending quest to impose order on Manhattan's willful chaos.

title: News in U.S. Can Be 'Rumor' in Seoul, and Lead to Jail
description: What is most striking about Richard Choi is not so much that he is in a jail, wearing his prison uniform and wondering whether he will get the full five-year sentence for ''spreading rumors.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MARCY (NEE HABER)
description: ROSENBERG-Marcy (nee Haber). Adored wife of Harold. After a very long and valiant fight, passed away peacefully Monday night. Services on Wednesday, at 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sampling 19 Different Brands
description: WHEN I recently tasted 19 unsalted butters, I found that while prices vary wildly -- from $1.79 to $9 a package -- the differences in flavor were most often subtle. The exceptions were Echire ($9 for about nine ounces) and Plugra ($4.95 for eight ounces), which had an intense, fresh flavor. But one of the least expensive butters -- Land O Lakes ($1.85 for eight ounces) -- was much better than many of the expensive ones. Over all, half the butters I tasted were bland or had off-flavors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, BARBARA C.
description: STERN-Barbara C. On January 5, 1998, of Somers, NY. Formerly of New York City and Coral Gables, Florida. Wife of the late Milton Haselkorn and Caryl Stern. Beloved mother of Jacob and David. Loving mother-in-law of Meg Senuta. Loving sister of Judith Post. Devoted grandmother of Joshua and Isaac. Services and interment private.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a plan to strengthen Japanese banks misidentified the country's biggest foreign debtor in some editions. It is Hong Kong; South Korea is the fourth-biggest.

title: Lewis Agrees To Fight Briggs
description: Two weeks after a proposed unification bout with Evander Holyfield unraveled, Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, has agreed to fight Shannon Briggs on March 28 in Atlantic City.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Faltering I.M.F. Bailouts Raise New Fears About Asia

title: Inquiry Begun on I.R.S. Audit, Lawyers for Clinton Accuser Say
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones said tonight that investigators from the Office of the Inspector General of the Treasury Department had begun an inquiry into the circumstances of an Internal Revenue Service audit of Ms. Jones and her husband, Stephen.

title: Apple to Post Quarter Profit Of $45 Million
description: Apple Computer's acting chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, stunned Wall Street analysts this morning by reporting that Apple would register a $45 million quarterly profit on revenue of $1.575 billion.

title: 49ers' Defense Shows Its Age, in a Good Way
description: When Gary Plummer takes a step, his body creaks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALKOWITZ, ABRAHAM
description: SALKOWITZ-Abraham. Beloved husband of the late Fae. Devoted father of Eileen and Ira Salk, and Vivian and Ronald Feinberg. Loving grandfather of Matthew and Susan, Kenneth and Leslie, Jon and Robyn, Daniel, Russell, Bruce and Jenny, Gail and Kent and great-grandfather of Sarah and Claire. We shall all cherish the memory of you forever. Service Wednesday 10am at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Nk, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBANK, HELEN KIRKPATRICK
description: MILBANK-Helen Kirkpatrick, 88. Journalist, war correspondent and author, died Monday, Dec. 29, 1997, at her home in Williamsburg, VA. The daughter of the late Lyman B. Kirkpatrick, Sr., and Lyde Paull Kirkpatrick, she was born in Rochester, New York, October 18, 1909. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Smith College, Mrs. Milbank was a foreign and war correspondent for the Chicago Daily News from 1939 to 1947. She published two books and numerous articles dealing with international politics. A memorial service will be held at 11 A.M., on Saturday, January 10th, at Bruton Parish Church, Williamsburg, Virginia. A second service and burial will follow at a later date in Nelson, New Hampshire.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed acquisition of Southern New England Telecommunications by SBC Communications misstated SBC's status among the nation's local telephone companies. It is the second-biggest local phone company; the biggest is Bell Atlantic.

title: Jet Damaged by Turbulence Is to Be Retired
description: United Airlines said today that it was unlikely'' to fly passengers again on the Boeing 747 that was so badly shaken in turbulence over the Pacific last month that one passenger died and scores of others were injured.

title: Restaurants; Sushi for Novices, Without Loss of Face
description: ''PLEASE don't embarrass me. Promise that you'll eat everything, even if it seems weird. Don't forget to buy the sushi chef a drink. And if he offers you the salmon skin, be sure to express your undying gratitude.''

title: WHX HAS NO PLANS TO RAISE HANDY & HARMAN BID
description: The WHX Corporation said yesterday that it did not plan to increase its bid of $30 a share for Handy & Harman, the metal and auto parts company. Handy & Harman cited its overfinanced pension plan and undervalued precious metals inventory last week when it rejected the WHX bid of $543 million in cash and assumed debt. But WHX said its offer already took account of the pension plan and inventory. Both companies are based in New York. The statement by WHX, owner of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company, leaves Handy & Harman shareholders the choice of tendering their shares below the current market price or siding with management in refusing the bid. Handy & Harman shares, which have traded above $30 since WHX made its bid on Dec. 15, fell $1.1875, to $31.9375, yesterday.

title: Vouchers Do Nothing to Improve Public Schools; Nothing but a Gimmick
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVALER, FREDERIC, M.D.
description: KAVALER-Frederic, M.D. The Board of Directors, volunteers and staff of the American Heart Association/New York City Affiliate mourn the passing of Frederic Kavaler, M.D., former Board President. His contributions to cardiology and science touched the lives of so many. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Gayllis R. Ward, Esq., CPA, Chairman of the Board Diane M. Sixsmith, M.D., Pres. Richard I. Levin, M.D., Immediate Past President Michael L. Weamer, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGENER, LOUISE V.
description: BURGENER-Louise V. Age 50. Of Schooley's Mountain, Long Valley, New Jersey, Boston, MA and Saint Thomas, USVI. Monday, January 5, 1998. Wife of Forrest L. Mother of Jenny B. Timan of Long Valley. Sister of Marjorie Huhn of Milford, PA. Mass of the Resurrection will be offered on Friday, January 9th, 10:15AM at Our Lady of the Mountain Church, Schooley's Mountain, Long Valley, N.J. Interment German Valley Rural Cemetery, Long Valley. Friends may call at the Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., 8 Hilltop Road, Mendham, N.J. Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Memorial gifts may be made to Saint Hubert's Giralda Animal Center, 575 Woodland Road, Madison, N.J. 07940.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISBERG, BARRETT G.
description: KREISBERG-Barrett G. Mercy College mourns the passing of Barry Kreisberg, friend and Board member, and extends deepest sympathies to his beloved family. Francis G. Ronnenberg, Chairman Jay Sexter, President

title: Coaches' Longstanding Ties Enmesh Packers and 49ers
description: The ties between the staffs of the Green Bay Packers and the San Francisco 49ers are so close that Sunday's National Football Conference championship game between the teams could be played in a big backyard after a family dinner.

title: Mannheim Journal; Anatomy on Display, and It's All Too Human
description: Until recently, this mid-sized industrial city wasn't known for much more than its ice-hockey team. But that was before the Runner, the Muscleman and the Expanded Body.

title: People
description: * Tim Blett, executive vice president and automotive director at W. B. Doner & Co., Southfield, Mich., was promoted to the new position of president for Doner Automotive, overseeing the agency's new Mazda North American Operations account.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEORGES, THEODORE W.
description: GEORGES-Theodore W. President and owner of Indian Walk Shoes, on January 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Cherished father of Stathis and Steven Georges. Devoted fatherin-law of Sandra and Soula Georges. Adoring grandfather of Alexander, Sophia and Elena. Friends may call at Riverdale FH, Inc, 5044 Broadway (at 214 St), NY, NY Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral services at the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, Thursday 10AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral, 319 East 74 St, NY 10021, St. Michael's Home for the Aged, 3 Lehmann Terrace, Yonkers, New York 10705 or to the charity of choice.

title: Temptation; Curds Too Enticing For Anyone Who's Used To Sitting on Tuffets
description: KIM DONG OK was born in a village in the South Korean province of Kangwon known for its tofu. As a child, she learned how to make more than 100 dishes using the tender bean curd.

title: Florida Utility Makes a Move Into New England With Deals
description: In a deal that could help bring down electricity rates and provide more low-cost power in New England, FPL Group Inc., a large Florida utility company, announced yesterday that it was acquiring all of the nonnuclear generation plants of the Central Maine Power Company for $846 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, HARRY M.
description: GROSS-Harry M. On January 5, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth. Loving father of Daniel. Dear father-in-law of Linda, brother of Henry and Milton Rubin. Adoring uncle of many nieces and nephews. Services on Wednesday, 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: NAGANO 1998: LIVING HIGH TRAINING LOW; Conditioning Method Stirs Fairness Debate
description: Tourists can't book Rooms 156 through 160 at the Hotel Rantasipi Laajavuori. Few would, even if they could.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in Business Day on Dec. 18 with an article about the settlement of a libel suit brought against Business Week by Julian H. Robertson, the Wall Street investor, cited the agreement imprecisely. The magazine acknowledged that predictions about the investment performance of Mr. Robertson's company, in a 1996 article, had proved inaccurate, and that an assertion that Mr. Robertson had stopped meeting with corporate managements was incorrect. The magazine did not concede that the article itself was inaccurate.

title: Key Officer Resigns Post at McGraw-Hill
description: Jeffrey P. Williams, a Wall Street banker who for years advised the AT&T Corporation, has left the McGraw-Hill Companies after just 15 months at the financial services and information company.

title: The Family That Shaped Modern India
description: For sheer color, a history of India seems made for television, yet it also seems too big and unmanageable to fit into a few hours on a small screen. All that colorful ceremony amid a pall of misery; the ravishing ideals ravaged by sectarian slaughter; the aspirations to democracy undermined by politicking, corruption and flirtations with dictatorship. And spilling over the screen, the dangerous masses, worshipful, suffering, cruel. Floods of humanity and floods of hatred.

title: Speedier Brawley Trial Sought
description: After a day of often-repetitive testimony in the defamation trial of three former advisers to Tawana Brawley, Justice S. Barrett Hickman issued a stern warning today for the lawyers to move the case along.

title: Vouchers Do Nothing to Improve Public Schools; A Page From Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Gillette Expands Ties to BBDO
description: The Gillette Company in Boston expanded its relationship with BBDO Worldwide in New York yesterday by naming that agency to handle creative and media duties for Duracell batteries in 16 countries in North America and Western Europe. They had been handled since 1983 by the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group in New York. Billings were estimated at $90 million.

title: Federal Express to Raise Shipping Rates
description: The Federal Express Corporation said today that it would increase rates for shipments within the United States an average of 3 percent to 4 percent on Feb. 15 and would expand its international service to include cheaper freight delivery.

title: School Vote In the Bronx Is Proposed
description: The United States Justice Department has proposed settling one of New York City's most extensive school board election fraud cases in years by letting the disputed winner run again for her seat in a special election to be held under carefully controlled conditions, including outside monitoring.

title: Journal; Let Them Not Pray
description: Lost in the big news stories of Christmas/Hanukkah week -- all those chickens meeting their maker in Hong Kong, all those gorgeously dressed extras meeting their maker in ''Titanic'' -- was an annual Pew survey on the state of religion in America.

title: Dairy Farmers Must Finance Their Subsidy, Italy Insists
description: They are called ''milk fines,'' and for more than a decade these penalties have been paid by Italian governments to the European Union to allow Rome to subsidize Italy's unprofitable dairy industry. The payments have become a symbol of Italy's insistence on maintaining costly farm production and jobs at consumers' expense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLSKY, BERNARD M.
description: SKOLSKY-Bernard M. Bernie read the obits in the Times first thing every morning. He said, ''Every life is a story.'' Here is his: he was born in Poughkeepsie, raised in Millerton, got his MA. from Albany, did graduate work at Columbia, wrote a TV quiz show, taught English and Journalism in Smithtown for 27 years, did newspaper work including writing a weekly column with a delicious sense of humor. He loved music, books, acrostics, and most of all his family. According to his wishes there was no funeral. Instead there will be a celebration of his life on his birthday, May 23. Survived and loved by Mindy, Mark, Nina, Jim, & Zachary; also Vivian, Bob and family; and all the former pupils whose lives he touched.

title: Metro Business; Trust Buys New York Sites
description: The Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, N.Y., said that it has agreed to acquire two office properties and a 32-acre plot in Westchester County for about $110 million.

title: Sauce to Soup, White With Foam
description: MOST people use their espresso machines for an express purpose -- to make espresso and cappuccino. But inventive chefs have discovered that the foaming nozzle on a high-powered espresso machine can do double-duty in a creative kitchen. It can produce low-fat flavored foams for topping soups and desserts, and it can make cloud-like sauces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE MENIL, DOMINIQUE
description: de MENIL-Dominique. Dominique de Menil was a great friend and a constant source of hope and courage for the Children's Storefront School in Harlem. She understood what we do and her infinite compassion and practical ways of dealing with oppression were visionary and kind. The children, the head master, Ned O'Gorman, and the Trustees owe her so much. We will find the world less filled with light now that she is gone. We send love to her children who have brought, as their mother did, their love and their support to this school.

title: From Alternate to Favorite
description: Four years ago today, Michelle Kwan followed Nancy Kerrigan off the ice after a training session at Cobo Arena in Detroit, and happened upon the knee-whacking heard round the world. ''I thought somebody had kicked Michelle,'' said Frank Carroll, who coaches Kwan.

title: Protesters Seek to Bar Whitman From Church
description: Dozens of anti-abortion advocates have protested a decision to allow Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to take part in an Inauguration Day interfaith prayer service in Newark's largest Roman Catholic church.

title: A Conference (Hangout?) On ABC's Of Jazz
description: The next few days are good ones for those looking for jazz lessons: the International Association of Jazz Educators opens its stalls at the Marriott Marquis Hotel today for a four-day stay, and along with the conference come some 7,000 jazz educators, musicians and business people from 35 countries. It will also be a good opportunity to examine the state of jazz, because this is the biggest jazz conference ever. One can talk to musicians from Kazakhstan, or to musicians who play in two different state-financed German big bands. Teachers from all 50 states will attend, as will some of the more important musicians in jazz, including Billy Taylor, David Sanchez, Pat Martino, James Moody and Mark Turner.

title: Protestant Threat Imperils Peace Talks in Ulster
description: The Northern Ireland peace effort was under pressure tonight from two Protestant groups threatening to withdraw from the talks scheduled to resume in Belfast next Monday.

title: Philip Morris Considered Proposing Ad Curbs in '93
description: Four years before the $368.5 billion tobacco settlement proposal was conceived, officials of the Philip Morris Companies suggested breaking with the rest of the industry to propose the sort of cigarette advertising restrictions now embodied in legislation pending before Congress, a company document shows.

title: Herald Tribune Fills Post
description: The International Herald Tribune named Ann M. Blinkhorn president of IHT North America yesterday.

title: What, Me Elderly?
description: After I awakened at 6:30 A.M., as usual; after I did 15 minutes of stretching exercises and weight work, as usual; after I power walked on hilly terrain for two miles, as usual; after I had a hearty breakfast, as usual; after I wrote for four hours, as usual; after I ate lunch, ran errands and shopped for dinner (which, as usual, I would later cook for my wife and me after putting in three more hours of writing), an ominous letter arrived from the Department of Health and Human Services. ''Official business,'' it said under the return address. ''Penalty for private use, $300.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALL, WILLIAM
description: PALL-William. Our heartfelt sympathy to the Pall family on the loss of their beloved son, William. We know his appreciation of fine art and his ability to see the beauty in life made him a special human being. Our deepest condolences to his father David, his step-mother Helen, his wife Olivia and his children Alexander and Caitlin. Saul B. Katz and Roy J. Zuckerberg Co-Chairmen, Board of Trustees John S.T. Gallagher and David R. Dantzker, M.D. Co-Presidents and Co-CEOs North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: With Age, a Softening Of Radical Ideologies
description: The conventional wisdom about political ideology and personal growth has always held that as we age we inevitably cast off our youthful dreams of changing the world and become increasingly conservative.

title: Wine Talk; California Cabernets Join the Gold Rush
description: THE $100 bottle of California cabernet sauvignon, while hardly commonplace, is no longer the exotic rarity it was a few years ago. As a group, the cabernets are now the most expensive wines California has ever produced. A few devil-may-care grape-squeezers have already vaulted well over the $100 barrier. At Diamond Creek Vineyards in the Napa Valley, Al Brounstein, the owner, has priced his 1994 Lake Vineyard cabernet at $250 a bottle.

title: Records Detail a False 1992 Murder Confession
description: Under arrest for two robberies in Central Park five years ago, Anthony Moore told his interrogators that he wanted to make a deal. In exchange for leniency, he would provide information about the unsolved murder of a retired police sergeant two months earlier who had interrupted a robbery in lower Manhattan.

title: Miscellany
description: * Asher/Gould Advertising, Los Angeles, was renamed Asher & Partners.

title: CBS and the P.L.O. Agree On Resuming Coverage
description: After a lengthy telephone discussion last night, Don Hewitt, the executive producer of ''60 Minutes,'' and Bassam Abu Sharif, the Palestinian official who had announced restrictions on CBS News in Palestinian-controlled areas, said CBS would be treated the same as other news organizations.

title: Message by Pataki to Outline Proposals to Improve Schools
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's annual address to the Legislature will offer an array of proposals intended to improve the academic performance of students, including intensive English courses for immigrants and remedial summer classes for low-achieving fourth-grade students, according to his aides.

title: Key to a Cozier Bankruptcy: Location, Location, Location
description: Elizabeth Warren, a professor at Harvard Law School, calls it ''the single biggest scandal in the consumer bankruptcy system.'' But none of its many critics seem able to change it.

title: Service Unions To Merge in Bid For More Clout
description: In a move expected to expand labor's political influence and recruitment efforts across New York State, the largest union of health care workers in New York City is merging with the Service Employees International Union, the nation's fastest-growing labor organization.

title: Indonesia Offers Budget With High Hopes
description: Indonesia introduced an optimistic budget today that avoided the tough austerity measures that financial analysts say are necessary to restore confidence and revive the health of the troubled economy.

title: TITAN TO ACQUIRE DBA SYSTEMS FOR $37.5 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Titan Corporation will buy DBA Systems Inc. for $37.5 million in stock as it seeks to enhance its military intelligence business, the companies said yesterday. Titan, a manufacturer of information technology and electronics systems and products based in San Diego, will acquire DBA's 4.42 million shares outstanding by exchanging 1.37 Titan shares for each DBA share, or a total of 6.06 million Titan shares. DBA shares rose $1.375, to $7.50, and Titan shares fell 25 cents, to $5.9375. DBA, based in Melbourne, Fla., will become part of the Titan Information Technologies Corporation, a new wholly owned unit that is expected to have annual revenue of about $140 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BAY NETWORKS INC., Santa Clara, Calif., agreed to buy 9 percent of Netspeak Corp. of Boca Raton, Fla., for more than $37 million to gain access to technology enabling computer networks to handle phone conversations.

title: TV Notes; Death on Skis, Again
description: A second celebrity death on the ski slopes provided another nearly all-consuming story for the nation's all-news cable channels yesterday.

title: Latin American Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: In Nassau, County Officials Play Musical Chairs to a G.O.P. Tune
description: The leadership of this populous town changed hands today with the seamless efficiency that has become a hallmark of one of the most powerful local Republican Party organizations in America.

title: TREX MEDICAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE FRENCH DENTAL IMAGER
description: The Trex Medical Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Trophy Radiologie, a French maker of dental X-ray systems with revenue of $70 million. Terms were not disclosed. Trophy, based near Paris, makes a dental imaging system that uses 90 percent less radiation than a conventional dental X-ray to generate images instantly on a computer monitor. Trex, based in Danbury, Conn., makes mammography equipment and digital breast biopsy systems. In the 12 months ended Sept. 30, Trex earned $14.7 million on $229 million in revenue.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Some newly issued stocks that flopped may deserve a second look.
description: NEW stocks seem more forlorn than neglected initial public offerings. Aimed at the moon, they fall with a thud, struck down by disappointing news or the sudden unpopularity of their business. They are left to languish in anonymity with few on Wall Street willing to give them a second look.

title: Vouchers Do Nothing to Improve Public Schools; Not a 'Thin Reed'
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating Well; One Teaspoon At a Time, Butter Returns
description: SOME people were never fooled. Butter is, in fact, better. Its silken, rich qualities could never be duplicated by the most ingenious food chemist whipping up the latest alternative. And beyond that, as science now confirms, the hardened and greasy colored vegetable oil known as margarine is even worse for your heart. Trying not to be smug is difficult.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, RANDOLPH, M.D.
description: ROSENTHAL-Randolph, M.D., after a devastatingly swift illness. Husband of Hilda; father of Charles and Roy; father-in-law of Jane; grandfather of David and Laura; brother of Helen Pall; brother-in-law of Evelyn Myers, Israel and Harriet Miller; loving uncle. A practicing psychiatrist for forty-eight years, past president of the Nassau Psychiatric Societyauthor of many scientific papers. Dedicated to his family, friends and profession. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, Thursday, January 8, at 12 noon.

title: Messinger Backs Green, Ferraro's Foe for Senate Nomination
description: Two months after failing to become the first female mayor of New York City, Ruth W. Messinger returned to public view yesterday to endorse one of the two men opposing Geraldine A. Ferraro's attempt to become the first female Senator from the state.

title: 4 Asian Currencies Plunge to Record Lows
description: The Indonesian, Malaysian, Thai and Philippine currencies plunged to record lows again yesterday as they have each trading day of the new year. The Indonesian rupiah, for instance, has lost 26 percent of its value this year, after a 56 percent decline last year made it the world's worst-performing currency. Yesterday, the rupiah tumbled as much as 14 percent, to 8,100 to a dollar -- its lowest level since it began trading in 1971.

title: Food Stuff
description: A Neuhaus Store Opens Late, But in

title: The Paradox of Genetic Privacy
description: Genetic testing, despite its promise, is provoking a sense of moral crisis in the United States. In the popular imagination, genes are thought to contain the code to an individual's fate, and the idea that someone might crack our personal code and use it against us is unsettling. Our fears, however, are producing a spate of ill-advised laws that will have serious unintended consequences in America's private insurance industry.

title: Karpov Wins Game 4 and Leads Match
description: A disorganized Viswanathan Anand was run over by Anatoly Karpov's superior positional grasp and lethal endgame technique yesterday in Game 4 of their International Chess Federation World Championship Match in Lausanne, Switzerland. With 2 1/2 points, Karpov needs only two draws to win the series and the $1.3 million prize, and perhaps get a match with Garry Kasparov, the world's highest-rated player.

title: Westchester Legislature Is to Be Led by Democrat
description: The Westchester County Legislature, with its new Democratic majority, has elected a Democratic chairman for the first time in its history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRIGAN, PAUL DUNN
description: BERRIGAN-Paul Dunn, Brigadier General, Corps of Engineers, U.S. Army, Retired. In San Francisco, January 2, 1998. Husband of the late Mary Fay Berrigan. Survived by his beloved first cousin, Mary Dunn Schreiner of Boston, his faithful housekeeper, Rosita Corpuz, and eleven nieces and nephews. A graduate of the United States Military Academy, class of 1927. Memorial contributions may be made to the West Point Fund, USMA, West Point, New York 10996. For service information, please contact McAvoy O'Hara Evergreen Mortuary of San Francisco at 415-668-0077.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the appointment of an editor at The Hartford Courant referred incorrectly at one point to the newspaper's publisher. Marty Petty is a woman.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Ban on Leaf Blowers Is Voted, and Noise Ensues
description: To the mostly Hispanic gardeners who use it, it is a labor-saving tool of their trade as vital as the truck or the telephone. To the mostly affluent Angelenos who have led a 12-year campaign to ban it, it is a noisy, filthy contraption that fouls the air and shatters the calm of their well-kept streets.

title: Vouchers Do Nothing to Improve Public Schools; Education Isn't Cereal
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; Despite the season, there are still some bargain air fares to several warm weather destinations.
description: AIRPLANES traditionally have fewer passengers in winter, except on flights to warm weather destinations, so a number of carriers are trying to lure passengers by offering bargain fares to Europe. But this year some carriers are also offering bargains to sun spots in Florida, the Caribbean and Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRKWOOD, MURRAY DELMAR
description: KIRKWOOD-Murray Delmar died at his home in Rowayton, CT on January 4, 1998 at age 86. He held degrees from Pomona, Oxford as a Rhodes Scholar, Harvard and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. He taught government at Harvard, and Political Science at Pomona before the Second World War. During the War he rose to the rank of Major serving in the first Special Services known as the 'Devil's Brigade'. Following the War he joined ITT, becoming Director of Public Relations and later Vice President for Public Relations of ITT World Communications. He remained active as a writer and supporter of the arts throughout his life and was secretary of the American Oxonian. He is survived by his wife, Viviane Bertolami Kirkwood, of Rowayton, CT, and five children: John M. Kirkwood, MD of Pittsburgh, PA; Anne Kirkwood Weitman of Brooklyn, NY; James H. Kirkwood of Geneseo, NY; Ellen Kirkwood Wood of Lizella, GA; and William T. Kirkwood of Bethpage, NY as well as eleven grandchildren, and seven nieces and nephews.

title: World News Briefs; Mexican Judge Softens Words That Raised Ire
description: A Mexico City judge says she meant to be ironic when she characterized a man accused of murdering an American businessman as a ''modern Robin Hood,'' adding that she intended to poke fun at what she viewed as a flawed Government case against the accused killer and his accomplices.

title: The Chef
description: IT is cold for so much of the year in Sweden, where I grew up, that fresh herbs are like the tourists: they arrive for that brief period in summer when the weather is congenial and the days are long, and then they slip away before dark. Even so, the herbs that do manage to flourish in Sweden are the cold-resistant ones like parsley, chives and, of course, dill. I must have been 13 before I saw fresh basil for the first time.

title: $25 and Under; A Neighborhood Bar That Isn't What It Seems
description: JIMMY ARMSTRONG'S SALOON looks like any other neighborhood bar, with a few arty touches thrown in: lots of dark, polished wood, stained glass, carvings and paintings that you can barely make out in the dim light. Everybody there seems like a regular, stopping in for a dose of conviviality on the way home.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Chairman of Republican National Committee Fights 'Litmus Test' on Abortion
description: Seeking to avert a bitter internal battle, Jim Nicholson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today urged the party to scuttle a resolution denying money to candidates who oppose banning late-term abortions.

title: Jerry Zaks Will Help Direct 'Capeman'
description: Producers of the new Paul Simon musical, ''The Capeman,'' said yesterday that the director Jerry Zaks had been hired to help get the show into shape for its Jan. 29 opening.

title: Cousins Held in 2 Four-Year-Old Murders
description: Two 21-year-old cousins were arrested yesterday and charged with committing two murders on a Harlem street four years ago, the police said. The arrests were made by the Police Department's Cold Cases Squad, which investigates unsolved murders.

title: Is It in New York, the Bistro of My Dreams?
description: WHEN I lived in Paris, I would often walk from my apartment on the Rue du Cherche-Midi through the touristy commotion of St.-Germain-des-Pres -- past the sprawling cafes where a cup of coffee costs the price of a meal -- to a tiny bistro on the quay.

title: Coaxing Flavor From Lesser Cuts
description: FOR many cooks, even some of the most accomplished, the guiding principle is simplicity. This means buying high-end ingredients and then doing as little as possible to them. Such an approach holds sway, for example, in a good steakhouse, where a tender cut like a porterhouse is served as simply as possible to preserve its pristine flavor.

title: What if Huge Asteroid Hits Atlantic? You Don't Want to Know
description: If a huge asteroid should crash into the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, say goodbye to Broadway, the beach house on Long Island and just about everything else on the East Coast as far inland as the foothills of the Appalachians.

title: Toni Morrison's Mix of Tragedy, Domesticity And Folklore
description: Early in Toni Morrison's new novel, ''Paradise,'' a young mother, Mavis, beset by unbearable circumstance, abused by her husband, leaves her infant twins in a Cadillac on a hot day with the windows up, and the babies die. It is a terrible moment, wrought in the full glare of Ms. Morrison's uncompromising gaze, at that nexus of parental feeling where love and destructive power meet. Those moments have appeared before in Ms. Morrison's work, most notably in ''Beloved,'' her novel about a former slave who kills her baby rather than have her live a life of slavery.

title: Economists Ask Loan Curbs in Crises
description: Citing the rapid buildup in short-term foreign loans as the major cause of the Asian crisis, American, South Korean and Japanese economists have called for new ways to curb such lending and borrowing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOB, EZEKIEL ''KIM''
description: JACOB-Ezekiel ''Kim''. Age 84 of Chicago, formerly of Brooklyn Heights, N.Y. Jan. 6, 1998. Husband of the late Ethel Charlotte Jacob. Father of Robert Jacob and Elizabeth Jacob Cohen. Grandfather of Charlotte Jacob, Anne Jacob and Jonathan Cohen. Memorial gifts may be made in his name to Brooklyn Heights Synagogue, Capital Campaign, 131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, HOWARD
description: GILMAN-Howard. With great sadness, the Board of Directors and staff of Career Transition for Dancers note the loss of our dear friend, Howard Gilman. He loved dance and he loved dancers. He knew that our art form could only flourish in the long run if individual artists could also flourish, both during and after their dance careers. The lives that have been changed as a result of his caring and generosity are innumerable. We shall miss him. Cynthia Gregory, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSKAY, SHIRA
description: RUSKAY-Shira. On Jan. 6, 1998. At the age of 52. A remarkable woman. Accomplished in the fields of Special Education, Law (Assistant U.S. attorney), and Social work. Since 1989, A Clinician and Social Work Coordinator for the Visiting Nurse Service Hospice, who also maintained a private practice. Above all, Shira was a woman with a beautiful soul, who connected and enabled scores of others to connect to that which is abiding, truthful and meaningful. Those who grieve include her husband John, her dear children, Darone Moshe and Ilana Sara RuskayKidd, her son-in-law Scott RuskayKidd, her parents, Rabbi. Sidney and Hilda Greenberg, her sisters, Reena Keren Adena Greenberg, and countless other relatives, friends and colleagues. Funeral Thursday, Jan. 8, 11:30 A.M. at the Society For The Advancement of Judaism, 15 W. 86 Street. Contributions may be made to establish The Shira Ruskay Professional Development Fund at Visiting Nurse Service Hospice, 107 East 70 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: DEATH PENALTY RULED OUT AS NICHOLS JURY DEADLOCKS IN OKLAHOMA BOMBING CASE
description: Terry L. Nichols escaped the death penalty today after a deeply divided Federal jury said it could not decide just how active a role he had played in planning the bombing that killed 168 people at the Oklahoma City Federal Building.

title: Search Is On For Jacobs
description: Where have you gone, Franklin Jacobs?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, WILLIAM J.
description: REDMOND-William J. Of Essex Fells, New Jersey. On January 5, 1998. Son of Richard R. and Jane W. (nee Williams). Brother of Richard R. Jr., Scott T. and Timothy J. Grandson of John R. and Clair E. (Driver) Redmond, and Richard L. and Suzanne S. Williams. Also many aunts and uncles. Funeral Service St Peter's Episcopal Church, 271 Roseland Avenue, Essex Fells, New Jersey, on Thursday, 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Essex Fells Foundation of Educational Excellence, P.O. Box 174, Essex Fells, New Jersey 07021, would be appreciated. For information, call the Dancy Funeral Home, Caldwell, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECHERT, ROBERT C.
description: BECHERT-Robert C. Of Stamford, CT, on January. 5. Father of Betsy Bechert Hogarth, Kimberly Bechert-Piratzky, Charles F. and Robert M. Bechert. Brother of Nancy Cross, Beverly Lett, James R. and Thomas E. Bechert. Loving companion of Betsy Gardner Hess. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Predeceased by one brother, Fred, and one granddaughter, Shelby. A memorial service will be held Sat., January 10, 11 AM, at the First Congregational Church, Stamford, CT.

title: Sports of The Times; The Kind Of Evening Cassell Likes
description: HE started the game with an aching right shoulder. He left it with a cramped calf muscle and his left shoulder in worse shape than his right. In between, Sam Cassell took 26 shots, scored 34 points, had a running rankout war with Patrick Ewing, put the Nets in position to win in overtime, was beaten on defense for the decisive basket by Chris Childs and was walloped to the floor to end the game.

title: Yes if by Land (No if by Sea): Lighting the Way To Atlantic City
description: A lighthouse may seem an all too apt symbol for Atlantic City, but the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority chose to place one alongside the landlubbing expressway leading to the center of town. Far from warning people to keep a safe distance, the 90-foot sculpture is meant as a welcoming beacon and the centerpiece of a $140 million downtown revitalization project.

title: Mexican Governor Resigns in Aftermath of Indians' Massacre
description: The embattled Governor of the southern state of Chiapas resigned today, the latest high-level politician to fall in the aftermath of the killings of 45 Indian villagers by a pro-Government paramilitary gang in a mountain hamlet in his state in December.

title: Politicians Ignore Labor Chief at Their Peril
description: DENNIS RIVERA made the transition yesterday from being merely powerful to being dangerous to ignore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSNER, BERTHA
description: KASSNER-Bertha. Died January 7, 1998 at the age of 100 in NYC. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Kassner. Loving mother of Henrietta Feinerman, Bella Baron, Rita Ulman, the late Lila Rosenberg and sister of Max (and Georgia) Zimmer. Devoted mother-inlaw of William Feinerman, the late Daniel Baron, Reuben Ulman, Saul Rosenberg. Adored grandmother of 13 and great grandmother of 15. Funeral service Thursday January 8 at 10 A.M., at United Hebrew Community, 201 East Broadway. Shiva at the Kassner residence at 477 FDR Drive, Apt 206M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, ILSE
description: SCHINDLER-Ilse. Born Poland, September 1, 1920. Died January 6, 1998. Survivor of the Holocaust. Survived by nephew Horst (Esther) Schindler and family of Sao Paulo, Brazil; Nephew Joel (Gayle) Schindler, of West Orange, New Jersey; Great nieces Abbe Schindler, of New York City, and Margalit Schindler, of West Orange; Cherished friend of Marisha (Myra) Krupkin, of New York City, Barbara and Michael Krupkin and family, of Ocean, New Jersey; Tzita Blum; Irene Lowenthal; Thea Oppenheimer and a large circle of caring friends and colleagues. Also sister of the late Ernst Schindler, of Sao Paulo and Herbert Schindler, of Elmira, New York. Ilse was a dedicate employee of the National Handbag Association for more than thirty years, and a volunteer at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center-Dept. of Pediatric Psychiatry for the past 11 years. Graveside services Thursday at 1:30 PM. Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey. Contributions can be made to: Presbyterian Hospital, to be directed to: The Child Psychiatry Fund, att: Dr. Richard Gaines, Babies' Hospital, 619 N., 622 West 168 Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: Missing Parts May Prompt U.S. Inspection of Some Boeing 737's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is considering an emergency order to inspect some Boeing 737's because preliminary findings from a crash in Indonesia on Dec. 19 showed that parts were missing from the plane's tail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, ARTHUR
description: LEIBOWITZ-Arthur. Beloved husband of Terri. Loving father of David and Maria and Gary. Dear brother of Rita Kimmel. Adored grandfather of Stefanie. Cherished uncle of Dan Kimmel and Bonnie MacEntee. Services ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park, Brooklyn today at 12:30 P.M.

title: Hospices Are Best Hope in Caring for the Dying; Mental Health Setbacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOWENS, BERNARD H.
description: STOWENS-Bernard H., 81. Died Dec. 31, 1997 in NYC, peacefully in his sleep. Memorial service Sunday, Jan. 11, 2:45 PM, Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, DR. RANDOLPH
description: ROSENTHAL-Dr. Randolph. To a dear friend who will be sorely missed. Belle Hammerschlag

title: Union Leader For Teachers Is Leaving Post
description: Sandra Feldman, who as head of New York City's powerful teachers' union for longer than a decade has wielded enough political clout to help pick chancellors and even mayors, has decided to step down and devote herself full time to her other job as head of the nation's second-largest teachers' union, officials within the New York union said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Brings Tobacco Case

title: Indonesia Leads Deeper Dive of Asian Currencies
description: Indonesia's battered currency plumbed new depths today and its stock market tumbled after the nation drew blunt criticism from the United States for not doing enough to reform its economy and satisfy conditions for a $40 billion International Monetary Fund aid package.

title: The Nets Miss the Mark When It Counts the Most
description: After suffering through his team's heartbreaking 89-88 overtime loss to the Knicks at Madison Square Garden, Nets Coach John Calipari wondered if he had a team of ''40-minute'' players.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CRYSTAL OIL CO., Shreveport, La., an oil and natural gas holding company, agreed to buy Petal Gas Storage Co. from CMS Gas Transmission and Storage Co., an affiliate of CMS Energy Corp., for $29.2 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLHAGEN, STEPHEN
description: MOLLHAGEN-Stephen. On Jan. 7, 1998, beloved son of Stanley and Kathryn Mollhagen, brother of John Mollhagen and Jane Mollhagen Mott, all of Kansas. Memorial service Saturday, January 10, 1998 at 2:30 P.M. at The Parish Hall of the Church of the Ascension, 12 West 11th Street, New York, N.Y.

title: Tempers Erupt In Brawley Case
description: The defamation suit against Tawana Brawley's former advisers broke into shouting matches between lawyers yesterday. Justice S. Barrett Hickman seemed to make no progress in his effort to speed up the trial.

title: Hospices Are Best Hope in Caring for the Dying; Don't Blame Morphine
description: To the Editor:

title: Proposal for Human Cloning Draws Dismay and Disbelief
description: A physicist has announced that he wants to raise money to open a clinic to clone humans, but experts said yesterday that they were skeptical that he could succeed. And, many added, his announcement may undercut public support for legitimate research on cloning that could advance medical progress.

title: President Plans On $21 Billion For Child Care
description: A day after proposing an expansion of the Medicare program, President Clinton said today that he wanted to spend $21 billion in grants and tax breaks over the next five years on child care.

title: Design Notebook; Havana's Aged Chariots of Chrome
description: IN the exotic-car sweepstakes, even the bulletproof, see-through Pope mobile will have competition when the Pontiff visits Cuba on Jan. 21. No country, not even a state of mind like Los Angeles, has a more nostalgic collection of post-World War II American cars than the Caribbean nation, to judge by the two- and three-tone specimens that time and history have left behind and running on the dilapidated streets of Havana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, LISA WELLING
description: FISCHER-Lisa Welling, on January 6, 1998 of Plandome Heights, NY. Beloved wife of Joseph. Dear mother of Lisa, William and the late Joseph. Also survived by grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Fall Worldwide As Asia Tremors Linger

title: Giuliani and Safir In Mixup on Crosswalks
description: The fate of the widely criticized pedestrian barriers in midtown was the subject of considerable municipal confusion yesterday.

title: Message Received
description: Sure, there will be problems of pride and precedence when 646 arrives as Manhattan's new area code. Arrivistes will be branded with scarlet numbers, mossbacks will become chic, and I predict a thriving black market for healthy 212's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASHKOW, MICHAEL
description: LASHKOW - Michael. Retired Lieutenant. New York City Fire Department. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Loving father of Justine and Germaine Walsh. Also survived by two grandchildren, Patrick and James Walsh. Reposing at R.P. Drago Funeral Home, 43-10 30th Avenue, Long Island City, New York. Funeral on Friday at 9 A.M. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph R.C. Church 9:45 A.M. Interment at St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Please make donations to American Heart Association and New York Fire Fighters Burn Center.

title: Legal Advocate, or Illegal Conspirator?; Lawyer for a Drug Suspect Is Accused of Abetting His Client
description: At the time, the phone conversation seemed innocuous: Pat V. Stiso, a criminal defense lawyer in the Bronx, was talking to a client in prison, assuring the man that he was looking out for his interests.

title: Unlikely Twosome Is on Top
description: NORTHEASTERN AND YALE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEYER, ELIZABETH
description: FEYER-Elizabeth. On January 6th, 1998, age 93. An extraordinary woman. Survived by Emery, her beloved husband, and by Tom, Cathy, Andrew and Laura; Ronnie, Alan, Barry and Marta; Fiorenza and Olga.

title: Asia Turmoil Seen Leading To Stormy Times for Stocks
description: Investors, after having thrived for three years on a great bull market, may be in for a little more turbulence.

title: Now, a Road Test for Wall Paint
description: As shopping chains like Restoration Hardware try to recreate the allure of quirky old-fashioned hardware stores, the real thing must struggle to come up with novel ways to impress its customers.

title: The Best of '97: Looking for the Future While Listening to the Past
description: All through 1997, music watchers awaited a bandwagon. Grunge lumbered toward irrelevance, while gangsta rap lost heart as its heroes were gunned down; it was time for something new. But no bandwagon gained much traction: not electronica (which found new fans but not a mass audience), not bubblegum (as the Spice Girls wore out their welcome and Taylor Hanson's voice changed), not ska-pop (an American revival of a British ska revival), not Christian pop (in Kirk Franklin's hip-hop gospel and Bob Carlisle's soft rock), not guitar-strumming women (like Jewel and Sarah McLachlan), not tortured-soul British rock (like the Verve and Radiohead).

title: Rented Seat of Power in Westchester
description: When Andrew J. Spano arrived last week to take over the helm of Westchester County government, he found that he had inherited little from his predecessor's once-elegant office except a few dusty cabinets and a couple of ill-tended potted plants. The sumptuous leather couch and handsome walnut desk and matching chair and refrigerator were gone.

title: Rutgers Presents Bannon With First League Victory
description: Winning a Big East game for the first time will not rank among Kevin Bannon's life-changing milestones, but an 81-49 ambush of Seton Hall by Rutgers tonight was enough to grant the Scarlet Knights' first-year coach some much needed relief.

title: In America; Schumer's Big Challenge
description: Twenty-four hours after Geraldine Ferraro's glitzy campaign debut at the Sheraton New York Hotel, Representative Charles Schumer sat in a quiet restaurant, not far from Madison Square, and talked over lunch about the legislative record he has compiled.

title: ABC Assigns Donaldson And Roberts to Old Beats
description: In a move to regain lost viewers, ABC News is putting two of its best-known personalities back on their former beats in Washington, assigning Sam Donaldson to the White House and Cokie Roberts to Congress, effective immediately, executives said yesterday.

title: Tubing Rides a Wave of Popularity
description: As long as ski resorts have attracted fun-seekers, there has been more than one way of getting down the mountain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLK, FREDERIC P.
description: POLK-Frederic P. Of Scottsdale, AZ., Tuesday, Jan. 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Sandy (nee Adelsohn). Devoted father of Robert, Scott and Shari. Loving brother of Lewis. Dear nephew of Mrs. Chuddy Polk. Funeral from the BernheimApter - Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Ave., Maplewood, NJ, Thursday, January 8, at 12 noon. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: AIDS Relief Foundation, Fred Polk Foundation, (Both C/O B.B.S.I, 11811 North Tatum Blvd., Suite 1085, Phoenix, AZ. 85028), Oheb Shalom Cantors Music Fund, or the Mayo Clinic Scottsdale Oncology Unit, 13400 East Shea Boulevard, Scottsdale, Arizona 85259.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUDNER, BERNICE
description: BRUDNER-Bernice. On January 6, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Louis Brudner. Loving mother of Richard and his wife Roberta. Dear grandmother of Matthew and Jonathan. Sister of Vivian Strausbourger. Loving aunt and great aunt. Resident of New York City and Hollywood, Florida. Funeral Riverside Memorial Chapel, Friday, January 9, 10 AM.

title: Dangerous Recreations
description: Death during recreation is nearly always accidental, and an accidental death is, by definition, a preventable death. The recent skiing accidents that killed Michael Kennedy and Sonny Bono would never have happened -- or so it is easy to say after the fact -- if Mr. Kennedy had not been playing football and Mr. Bono had stayed out of the trees. In the aftermath, the risks seem unacceptable.

title: Not Enough Green For Big Pink
description: Maybe LINDA MESCH decided ''It Ain't Me, Babe.'' Her $149,500 deal to buy Big Pink, the secluded, salmon-shingled ranch house in West Saugerties, N.Y., where BOB DYLAN recorded more than 100 songs in the 1970's, has fallen through. The owner, MICHAEL AMITIN, said Ms. Mesch, a former disk jockey on Long Island, had been unable to arrange the necessary financing.

title: True North is working to regain momentum after a legal battle with Publicis over Bozell, Jacobs.
description: ONE of the most popular ploys an agency can offer an advertiser is to promote a product as ''new.'' Now an agency holding company is promoting itself the same way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPIEL, CHARLES I.
description: POPIEL-Charles I. Jan. 7, 1998. Husband of Phyllis (nee Lubin) of Rockville Centre, New York. Father of Laurence S. Popiel, Richard G. Popiel and Janet Kozarsky. Brother of Ezra Popiel and Martin Popiel. Also survived by four grandchildren. Graveside services on Friday 1 P.M., New Montefiore Cemetery. Platt Memorial Chapels, Cherry Hill, New Jersey.

title: Police Search for a Manhattan Doctor Who Left a Note Before Disappearing
description: The police searched for a second day yesterday for a prominent Manhattan doctor who left his Central Park West apartment early Monday morning and did not return. He left a note, according to a family member, in which he wrote of his despondency and how his family would handle his finances.

title: SEAGATE EXPECTS TO POST A SUBSTANTIAL OPERATING LOSS
description: The disk drive maker Seagate Technology Inc. said yesterday that it expected to post a substantial operating loss in its second quarter as lower prices for its goods and slack demand hurt revenues much more than the company had originally expected. The announcement was the second warning from Seagate about its second quarter, which ended Jan. 2. It had earlier predicted marginal profits for the quarter, and analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation were looking for the company to post earnings of 3 cents a share.
