Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said its second-quarter revenues from drive operations were significantly less than previously anticipated. The company made its announcement after its shares fell $1.25 each, to $20.625.

title: Plato and the Unabomber
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Merger In Health Care Is Called Off
description: Phycor Inc.'s $6.8 billion acquisition of Medpartners Inc., announced only two months ago, was called off late yesterday, officials from both companies said.

title: Cuban Ballplayers Leave for Costa Rica
description: El Duque and his Cuban traveling party took off on their second trip in two weeks last night, leaving the Bahamas for Costa Rica after overcoming a problem in government documents that had delayed their departure, a person involved in the planning of the trip said.

title: Food Without Fear
description: Can a society achieve an environment free of risk? And at what cost?

title: Swiss Banks' Moral Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Penalty Sought In Teen-Ager's Killing
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they would seek the death penalty against a 24-year-old Camden man who shot and killed a teen-age boy during a botched robbery at the Deptford Mall in August.

title: Metro Matters; Only in Albany Is a Surplus Reason to Fret
description: IT'S an election year. There's a budget surplus. What could be more dangerous?

title: Scarves in the Tavern; Socks in the Diner
description: Michael Redpath, a furniture designer in Rockaway Park, Queens, has found a way to preserve urban architecture without all the complications of landmark status: he makes furniture portraits of his favorite buildings. There's the Stardust Dine-O-Mat in Times Square in the form of a three-drawer bureau (below left) and the 40-inch-tall dresser based on P. J. Clarke's (the tavern on 55th Street and Third Avenue), with air-conditioner drawer pulls. ''I have even done some houses where people grew up,'' he said. From $800 to $2,200. Information: (718) 318-1620.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSCHWEIGER, LEO
description: BRAUNSCHWEIGER-Leo, on December 31, 1997. Beloved husband of Flora for sixty years. Loving father of Leonard and Mark. Dear brother of Celia, Claire and Hannah. Father-in-law of Leslie. Uncle of many nieces and nephews. He, along with his late brother Max, were the owners of the Hudson View Market for forty years. He was a life member of Isachar Widows and Orphans Benevolent Society, founded in 1857. Services were held Sunday, January 4, 1998.

title: Report Shows Urban Pupils Fall Far Short in Basic Skills
description: Schools in the nation's cities are a picture of despair with more than half the fourth and eighth graders there failing to reach minimal standards in reading, mathematics and science, according to one of the most comprehensive urban educational studies ever conducted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELTMAN, JANET
description: WELTMAN-Janet. Of Stamford, Connecticut, on January 7. Loving wife of William. Loving mother of George. Loving sister of Jerry. Loving grandmother of Rachel. Loving mother-in-law of Deborah. A graveside service will be held at 2 PM, today at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, New York.

title: Seeking to Open a Door to U.S., Iranian Proposes Cultural Ties
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Close to Home; Tearing Down In Order to Build
description: TEARING down a wall is easy. Or at least the standard wall in a modern home -- half-inch Sheetrock over 2-by-4 studs. I have ripped down a few, and I can outline the procedure. First, I poke a hole in the Sheetrock with a short knife, a serrated eight-inch blade that looks like it should be in a museum of horrible felonies. The proper name for it is keyhole saw, and I use my father's.

title: Hospices Are Best Hope in Caring for the Dying; Give Patients a Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: District Attorney Enters Dispute Over Artworks
description: The Manhattan District Attorney moved yesterday to prevent the Museum of Modern Art from returning to Austria two paintings from a recent show whose provenance is clouded by Nazi wartime plundering. He said he would begin a criminal investigation into ownership of the artwork.

title: McIlvaine to Twins
description: Joe McIlvaine, fired as general manager of the Mets last July, was hired as a special scout by the Minnesota Twins yesterday. McIlvaine has a long-standing friendship with Terry Ryan, general manager of the Twins. BUSTER OLNEY

title: Robust Sales News Snaps 4-Day Bond Rally
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds snapped a four-day rally yesterday, falling under the weight of robust housing and auto sales data, a weaker dollar, a growing corporate-debt supply and talk that the market's ebullience may be overdone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, DIANE M. (NEE ORLOWSKA)
description: GILBERT-Diane M. (nee Orlowska), 64, at home in Redding, CT on Jan. 4, 1998. Wife of the late John F. Gilbert. Survived by 2 sons John A. Gilroy (and wife Lynn Vacanti) and Andrew T. Gilbert; a daugher Elizabeth A. Gilbert and two grandchildren, Rose and Alexandre Vacanti Gilroy. A mass will be celebrated Friday, Jan. 9 at 11a.m. Call 203-544-8461 for details.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM IN DEALS TO SELL AND BUY PROPERTIES
description: Lomak Petroleum Inc. said yesterday that it was selling oil and gas properties valued at $54 million and that it had bought three oil properties for about $39 million in cash and stock, increasing its oil reserves by more than 30 percent. The sales to several purchasers include interests in 526 oil wells in the San Juan and Appalachian basins and will eliminate its interest in the San Juan Basin. The company also sold a minority interest in an Appalachian gas field. Most of the sales by the Fort Worth-based oil-and-natural-gas production company were completed before the end of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, MARIA
description: LLOYD-Maria. The Board of Directors of the Marcella Sembrich Opera Museum mourns the death of our great friend, Maria Lloyd. Her husband, David Lloyd, is a former President of our Museum in Bolton Landing (New York) on Lake George, and Mrs. Lloyd was an invaluable supporter of our efforts for many years. We offer our condolences to her family and also to our friends and colleagues in the musical communities that gather each summer at Lake George, where her absence will be a heartfelt loss.

title: Calendar; Souvenirs, Glass and Camps
description: Collectibles From the Arts

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Hospices Are Best Hope in Caring for the Dying; Comfort and Closure
description: To the Editor:

title: 8th Grader, 13, Dies in Queens After Stabbing at Apartment
description: A 13-year-old girl was stabbed to death yesterday in her Queens apartment, the police said.

title: Market Place; A small company with big ideas is paying a lot to promote its stock at the expense of its holders.
description: IN this era of soaring stock prices and initial public offerings that catch investors' imaginations, some companies find it easy to raise capital to pay for research and development of ideas that may take years to produce profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOLKIN, JOSEPH LOUIS
description: SHOLKIN-Joseph Louis. Of Brookline, on Monday, December 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Solveig (Eskedahl) Sholkin and the late Florence (Levitan) Sholkin. Devoted father of Susan Cahen of Cleveland, Ohio and Louise Goldberg of Wellesley, Massachusetts. Also survived by 6 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Brother of the late Murray Sholkin and Jean Berkowitz. A Memorial Service for Mr. Sholkin will be held Saturday, January 10, 1998 at the Holiday Inn, 1200 Beacon Street, Brookline, Massachusetts at 2 PM. Information: J.S. Waterman & Sons-Eastman-Waring F.H. Boston, Massachusetts. Contributions in Mr. Sholkin's memory may be made to International Helping Hands, P.O. Box 60, Newton Highlands, Massachusetts 02161 or the Joseph L. Sholkin Scholarship Fund ''Class of 35'', Dartmouth College, Dartmouth, N.H.

title: Solving and Preventing 'Sick Building' Illnesses
description: THE bedroom is often the scene of the crime. Dr. Adrienne Buffaloe, a specialist in environmental medicine, reels off a list of innocent-sounding potential irritants: ''There are the perfumes, the cosmetics, the hair-care sprays on the vanity; the synthetic carpet sprayed with a stain resistant.'' Then there are cedar closets, mothballs, leathers treated with tanning agents and dyes and even stuffed animals sprayed with flame retardants.

title: Accuser in Sex Case Planning to Attend Clinton Deposition
description: Paula Corbin Jones plans to be facing President Clinton when he is questioned under oath by her lawyers in preparation for the trial of her sexual misconduct lawsuit against him, her spokeswoman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, HAZEL K.
description: CLARK-Hazel K. Former alumni office director at Deerfield Academy. On December 29, 1997 in Rancho Palos Verdes, CA. She was the widow of Chester A. Clark, mother of John of Palos Verdes Estates, CA. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 9, at the South Deerfield Congregational Church at 3:30 P.M.

title: U.S. Leaders Plan to Grapple A Hot Potato: Social Security
description: To one camp, Social Security is an inviolable promise to provide all workers the foundation of a comfortable retirement, and the program's looming financial problems should not be an excuse to dismantle what is in many ways the Federal Government's premier antipoverty program.

title: Metro Business; School Signs Lease For Child Center Site
description: New York University Medical Center has signed a long-term lease for its Child Study Center in a luxury rental building under construction at the northwest corner of First Avenue and 33d Street, just opposite the medical complex.

title: Dr. Thomas Frist Sr., HCA Founder, Dies at 87
description: Dr. Thomas F. Frist Sr., who was widely regarded as the father of the modern for-profit hospital system, died at his home in Nashville on Sunday. He was 87.

title: Dueling Campaign Speeches
description: The biggest question raised by Gov. George Pataki's State of the State speech yesterday was what he saved to say when he announces for re-election. This speech was supposed to be about the challenges New York State has yet to meet, but its agenda was both modest and overly focused on campaign headlines.

title: Religion Backfire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wisconsin Welfare Chief Chosen for New York City
description: The architect of a Wisconsin welfare program that has pushed more people off public assistance than in almost any other state in the country was selected yesterday to run New York City's sprawling social service agency.

title: President Khatami Addresses America
description: Americans accustomed to Iranian clerics fulminating against the United States may have been pleasantly surprised to encounter Mohammed Khatami on CNN last evening. The new Iranian President spoke admiringly of American civilization, sprinkling his comments with respectful references to the Pilgrims and Abraham Lincoln. He called for cultural and education exchanges between Iran and America. But for all the friendly gestures, the hard edge of Iran's hostility to America was still present. By the end of Mr. Khatami's interview, with Christiane Amanpour, it was clear there would be no quick healing of the rift between Teheran and Washington.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: NORTHWEST PIPE TO PAY $39 MILLION FOR 2 TUBE COMPANIES
description: The Northwest Pipe Company plans to buy closely held Southwestern Pipe Inc. and the P&H Tube Corporation for $39 million to expand into new tubular products lines. The Houston-based Southwestern Pipe and P&H Tube, based in Bossier City, La., had combined 1997 revenue of about $41 million. Northwest Pipe, a maker of welded steel pipe for water transmission, construction, agricultural and industrial uses, had net income of $10.4 million on revenue of $135.2 million in 1996. The acquisitions will allow Northwest, which is based in Portland, Ore., to enter the mechanical and structural tubing markets. Shares of Northwest Pipe fell $2.875, to $20.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROTA, DONIA RUDOY
description: SIROTA-Donia Rudoy. January 6, at The Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged. Long time resident of Brooklyn and Co-op City. Beloved wife of Charles; sister Rachel; children Shirley and David, four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Services will be held at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Rd., L.I. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Donations in her memory to JHHA would be appreciated.

title: E.P.A. Study Identifies Pollution Risks Plaguing Nation's Waterways
description: In the first comprehensive analysis ever conducted of contaminated sediments in the nation's rivers, lakes and coastal waters, the Environmental Protection Agency has identified widespread risks to human health and the environment, especially in the New York region.

title: Bridge; How Adopting a Baby Cost a Player a Share in a Title
description: A happy event caused one of the metropolitan area's top players to lose a title last month. Before the final event in the New York Winter Regional Championships at the end of December, Jared Lilienstein of Manhattan and Glenn Milgrim of Forest Hills, Queens, were tied for the lead in the New York Player of the Year Race, after being partners throughout the year, and wanted to stay that way.

title: Public Eye
description: MEDIEVAL and spiky, and with the quality of twisted ironwork and ruined priories, a strange family of typefaces has moved from the graphic avant-garde to mainstream advertising and packaging. Inspired by Jonathan Barnbrook's 1992 typeface called ''Manson,'' lettering that at once evokes a poster for ''The Omen'' and the Irish Book of Kells figures in ads for the sporty new Lexus GS sedan.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Award-Winning Plants

title: Unusual Naval Alliance Shows Off, and Arabs Glare
description: Two search-and-rescue swimmers secured a collar to the figure bobbing stiffly in the waves, crisp commands echoed up and down the fo'c's'le, and the victim was smartly hoisted on board.

title: Derby Favorite Settles Into a New Barn
description: Favorite Trick, the early favorite for this year's Kentucky Derby and a winner of all eight of his starts last year at age 2, was moved yesterday to the barn of the trainer Bill Mott, who will be asked to continue the success of the colt's original trainer, Pat Byrne.

title: FRESH AMERICA TO BUY CLOSELY HELD ONTARIO TREE FRUITS
description: The Fresh America Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Ontario Tree Fruits Ltd. for an undisclosed amount of stock, to enter the Canadian produce-distribution market. The Toronto-based Ontario Tree Fruits is one of Canada's largest distributors of fresh produce; it will sell about $100 million in fruits and vegetables in Canada and the Northeastern United States this year. Fresh America said the acquisition, which will include assumption of an undisclosed amount of debt, would add to its 1998 earnings. The Houston-based company has purchased six distributors since last August, providing about $171 million in annual sales. Shares of Fresh America rose 12.5 cents, to $20.

title: Bounteous King of Delta Blues
description: B. B. King's first set at the Blue Note on Tuesday night was filled with play and imitation. Mr. King, seeing a daughter of his in the audience, said, ''Hi, Michelle,'' but in a woman's voice; he played a woman's role a half-dozen times during the show. During one tune of deep heartbreak, Mr. King sang, ''She had the nerve,'' then sniffed as if about to cry, ''to kick me out.'' Nothing he did was to be taken for what it was. After some 50 years of playing the role of the blues man, Mr. King, enormously inventive as a person, has understood every angle of every tune, and it is all a playground for him.

title: TMP Worldwide Makes Acquisitions
description: TMP Worldwide in New York, which specializes in yellow pages and recruitment advertising, said yesterday that it had acquired the yellow pages advertising unit of Earle Palmer Brown in Philadelphia, as well as four agencies overseas that specialize in recruitment advertising. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, HENRY
description: ROSENBLATT-Henry. On January 7, 1998. Master musician, vocal instructor and authority on Jewish liturgical music. Loving son of the late renowned Cantor Josef and Taube Rosenblatt. Survived by his brother Ralph Rosenblatt, his sisters Nettie Reiss, Sylvia Gruber, nieces and nephews and his many students and admirers. Services Fri, Jan 9, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHAN, GERALDINE M. (NEE BROWN)
description: BOHAN - Geraldine M. (nee Brown), on January 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Richard K.. Loving mother of Linda and Peter Fasold. Dear sister of the late Warren M. and George M. Proud grandmother of Peter and Stephanie. Wake Friday, 2-4PM and 79PM, Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, New York City. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, 10:00 AM, Immaculate Conception Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBAUM, HERMAN
description: ROSENBAUM-Herman. We deeply mourn the passing of our former President, Herman Rosenbaum, beloved husband of Nancy Rosenbaum. Beloved father of Carol Rabin and Bunny Sable. Young Israel of Flatbush Sheldon J. David, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, ELIZABETH C.
description: NEWMAN-Elizabeth C. March 9th, 1916-January 8th, 1997. Loved. Remembered. Missed. Your Family

title: Further Revamping Planned by DuPont
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company is starting a new round of restructuring, including layoffs, aimed at shrinking corporate bureaucracy and making its business units more autonomous, its chief executive, Charles O. Holliday, said today.

title: Federal Deficit Will Fade Away in '98, Budget Office Predicts
description: The Congressional Budget Office projected today that the Federal budget deficit would be all but eliminated this year, continuing a deluge of good fiscal news that has both political parties eager to begin dividing the spoils.

title: CAPSTAR HOTEL IS IN $150 MILLION DEAL WITH MEDALLION
description: The Capstar Hotel Company has acquired six hotels from Medallion Hotels in Texas, Oklahoma and Kentucky for $150 million and says it will continue to buy upscale properties. Capstar, a Washington-based hotel owner and manager, said it would spend about $25.5 million renovating the properties bought from the New York-based Medallion. It will operate them under nationally known hotel brands, including Hilton, Sheraton, Renaissance and Westin. The hotels are in Houston, Dallas, Austin and Midland, Tex; Louisville, Ky., and Oklahoma City. Shares of Capstar rose 68.75 cents, to $34.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTH, ABRAHAM A.
description: BARTH-Abraham A. Of Bay Harbor Island, FL. Beloved father of Susan Jacobus and Richard Barth; brother of Betty Elman; and grandfather of Sheri Jacobus, Kevin Jacobus, and Ronald Barth. Graveside services 12:30 P.M. on Friday at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J. For more information call 305-948-9900.

title: Balanchine's Old 'Jewels,' City Ballet's New Facets
description: ''Jewels'' is the flashy title of an unflashy ballet, but the beauties and subtleties of this so-called three-act plotless work by George Balanchine were just right for the opening of the New York City Ballet's repertory season on Tuesday night.

title: Russians Lament the Crime of Punishment
description: Prisoners almost always swear they are not guilty. In Russian pretrial detention centers, many inmates insist that they no longer care about proving their innocence.

title: Islanders Believe, but the Losses Mount
description: Rick Bowness has been down this road before. The Islanders' loss to the Penguins on Tuesday night wasn't the first time a team of his had lost for the eighth straight time. And today wasn't the first time he was answering questions about his job security.

title: U.S. Brings First Charges in Inquiry on Tobacco Companies
description: The Justice Department yesterday brought the first criminal action in its long investigation of the tobacco industry, accusing a biotechnology company of engaging in a scheme with a major cigarette maker to produce tobacco that had twice the nicotine level of the regular leaf.

title: Hospices Are Best Hope in Caring for the Dying; Medicine Isn't a Business
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL PRICES SLIP. Heating oil prices fell to their lowest level since 1995, dragged down by mild weather in the Northeast, the biggest market for the fuel, and by a report that showed a substantial rise in inventories last week. Heating oil for February delivery fell 0.43 cent, to 47.33 cents a gallon.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Even if we gripe and argue and cry, it's not going to make it any better. It was probably a pretty hard decision for them to make. We're still going to get a punishment.''

title: Replacing Coal Furnaces
description: To the Editor:

title: Rite Aid Stock Split
description: The Rite Aid Corporation said today that it would split its stock on a 2-for-1 basis and increase its regular quarterly dividend to 10.75 cents on a post-split basis. Rite Aid, a drugstore chain operator, said both the new dividend and stock split would be distributed Feb. 2 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 20. The stock split doubles the number of shares outstanding, but halves their per-share value. On a pre-split basis, the new dividend will be 21.5 cents, up from the previous 20 cents a share. The stock rose $2.0625 today, to $61.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: First Black Sextuplets Belatedly Win Public Notice
description: If it had not been for the McCaugheys, the Iowa family who made medical history with the November birth of septuplets, all of whom survived, the world might not have known about Linden and Jacqueline Thompson. Then again, because of the McCaugheys, much of the world may never know about the Thompsons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVESEN, THEODORE B.
description: LEVESEN-Theodore B. On January 7, 1998. Devoted companion of John Cubba. A memorial service will be announced at a later time.

title: FOREST OIL IS IN $231 MILLION DEAL FOR 13 PROPERTIES
description: The Forest Oil Corporation said yesterday that it would buy 13 Louisiana oil and natural gas properties for about $231 million in cash and stock, complementing its holdings in the Gulf of Mexico. Forest, a Denver-based oil and gas production company, said it would buy the properties from an unidentified private company for $216.7 million in cash and stock valued at about $14 million. The acquisition will increase its earnings and cash flow per share, the company said. The company said it was considering asset sales of $50 million to $100 million to help pay for the acquisition. Shares of Forest Oil fell 6.25 cents, to $14.125.

title: Hospices Are Best Hope in Caring for the Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORMAN, FRANCIS D. (FRANK)
description: MOORMAN-Francis D. (Frank). Hall of Famer, Ad Executive, Youngest Naval Commander, U.S. Water Polo Guru, died in New York Hospital on January 1, 1998, after a fall-induced coma at the age of 81. He was born July 7, 1916, with his identical twin, Silas Mercer Moorman, MD. Frank graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy and Harvard University. (In 1940, he was National Champion in the 100 Meter Backstroke). Even before World War II, Frank tried to join the British Armed Forces. As an American, he was denied, so he joined the U.S. Naval Reserve. He swiftly rose in rank to become the youngest Destroyer commander in Navy history. After the war, he built a notable career in advertising, first at The French Line as Public Relations and Advertising Director, and then as Director of International Advertising for L.W. Froelich. Frank was a hyper-active member of the New York Athletic Club for 61 very involved years. As Captain of its Water Polo team he led them to three National championships, in '55, '56, '57. He also covered Olympic Water Polo for the Associated Press. As a writer for Swimming World, he alone selected the 14 Best Players and 10 Best Referees in the world, throughout the '70's and '80's. As the world's leading authority on the game, he was inducted into the U.S. Water Polo Hall of Fame in 1981. In 1990, he became the first winner of the coveted U.S. Water Polo Award. A member of the Water Polo Committees of the AAU and the USOC, he also served 7 terms as First Vice President of U.S. Water Polo, Inc. An inveterate trencherman, he revelled in memberships in the Commanderie de Bordeaux, the Chevalier du Tastevin, the Conferie de la Chaine des Rotisseure, the Wine and Food Society, and the German Wine Society. He travelled, happily and tirelessly, to every continent in the world. He is survived by his companion of 35 years, Thomas C. Cracovia, and cousins, Mary Davis and Libby Conner of Richmond, Virginia. Donations can be made to the Moorman Scholarship Fund at Phillips Exeter Academy of The American Cancer Society. For information regarding a memorial service, call (212) 802-5623.

title: Camry Holds Off Accord For Title of Best-Selling Car
description: After a race to the wire, the Toyota Camry beat the Honda Accord for the title of the nation's best-selling car in 1997, leaving the Ford Taurus in third place and ending its five-year reign as the top seller.

title: Sports Official Is a Candidate For Rutgers Job
description: With his contract as president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority expiring at the end of the month, Robert E. Mulcahy 3d has emerged as the top candidate to be the new athletic director of Rutgers University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, THOMAS J.
description: STANTON-Thomas J. Of Montclair on January 6, 1998. Husband of Jane. Father of Louise Stanton, Thomas III, Patricia Stanton, Charles, Katherine Stanton-Paule, John, Robert, and the late William. Brother of the Honorable Reginald Stanton, John Stanton, Louise Longhurst, Katherine Kramer and the late Joyce Fennelly. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Funeral from Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, Saturday 9 A.M. then to Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair where at 10:30 A.M. a Mass of Christian Burial will be offered. Interment Immaculate Conception Cemetery. Visiting hours 7-9 Thursday and 2-4 and 7-9 Friday. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the St. Vincent's Nursing Home Auxiliary, 45 Elm Street Montclair, New Jersey 07042.

title: THE MARKETS: AROUND THE WORLD
description: FRANCE REBOUNDS. JAPAN LANGUISHES. HONG KONG SINKS. With yesterday's 5.9 percent drop, Hong Kong stocks are barely 500 points above the low reached after October's plunge. Japan is also slumping. But European stocks, as shown by the rebound in France, are in pretty good shape.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 26 about the effect of South Korea's economic turmoil on Korean immigrants in New York referred imprecisely to costs at Columbia University's American Language Program, where students from Korea form the largest group. A full year's tuition is $12,693; the $30,000 figure represented not only tuition but also room and board.

title: At I.B.M., a Departure Ignites Management Shifts
description: The I.B.M. executive who built the company's computer services into its second- largest and fastest-growing business line, said yesterday that he would take a leave of absence for medical reasons. The departure set in motion a series of job changes that put a number of younger executives into more prominent roles at the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: FORTRESS GROUP IN $61.75 MILLION DEAL FOR HOME BUILDER
description: The Fortress Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Whittaker Homes, a privately held home-building company, for $61.75 million in cash and assumed debt. Fortress Group, based in McLean, Va., is also a building company. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, it reported income of $4.8 million on revenue of $293.4 million. Whittaker Homes, based in St. Charles County, Mo., generated 1997 revenue of $90 million and earnings of $8.2 million before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, Fortress Group said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTHUR, EDITH M.
description: ARTHUR-Edith M., 87, of NYC, on January 6, 1998 in Greenwich, CT. Beloved wife of Samuel Arthur, mother of Michael Arthur of Los Angeles, CA, Jane Kramer of Rye, NY and Stephen Arthur of Aspen, CO, grandmother of Dr. Susan Danziger, Emily Kramer, Kate and Leslie Arthur.

title: A Priest Fights 'Defenders' Of His Faith In Bosnia
description: With the mists of early morning drifting up the mountain valleys, exposing glimpses of terra cotta roof tiles and tiny houses, villagers followed their priest to 30 Croatian homes today.

title: Hospices Are Best Hope in Caring for the Dying; Good Value Is Key
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: Rowland Calls For Increases In Spending For Education
description: Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed spending an additional $93 million on education in the next fiscal year, including funds for computers, library books and 300 reading teachers in the state's neediest school districts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, SAM
description: LEVITT-Sam. Of Boca Raton, FL. passed away at the age of 83 on January 6, 1998. He will be remembered as a devoted Husband to Pearl; loving father (and father-inlaw) to daughters, Mona, Tanya and Ann and sons, Mark and Arthur; caring grandfather to Eileen, Michael, Jennifer, Jason, Stuart, Jeffery, and David; and greatgrandchildren: Paige and Brooke. He will be in our hearts and thoughts forever. Funeral services will take place at Gutterman Funeral Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury. 10:45 A.M., on Thursday, January 8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, GERTRUDE
description: LANG-Gertrude, on January 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harry E. Lang. Devoted mother of Helene Stern and the late Dorothy Mayer. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Billionaire Selling 60 Broad St. Tower
description: Only a few years ago, lower Manhattan was devastated by layoffs, bankruptcies and a recession that left empty one out of every four floors of the district's office towers.

title: Busy Federal Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Headset-to-Helmet System Isn't Perfect
description: At key points during this Sunday's National Football League conference championship games, will quarterbacks Steve Young, John Elway, Kordell Stewart and Brett Favre hear every play that coaches send them electronically through their helmets?

title: Disney Policy on Directors Is Criticized
description: The College Retirement Equities Fund, part of the world's largest pension fund, has asked the Walt Disney Company to place a majority of outsiders on its board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANGER, GERMAN
description: MANGER-German on January 7, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Madeline. Loving father of Joseph and Rose Marie Manger. Dear grandfather of Eric and Gretchen Manger Immerman. Cherished uncle of Rudy and Otmar Manger. Also survived by his sister-in-law Beate Manger and many nieces and nephews in Germany. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Visiting hours Thursday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 10PM. Funeral Mass Friday, 10:30 AM at Mary's Nativity R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alpine Learning Group, Inc., 230B Woodland Ave., River Edge, NJ 07661.

title: Miami Mayor Warns Paper To Be 'Nicer' Or Lose Ads
description: Escalating his war of words with The Miami Herald, Mayor Xavier Suarez has threatened to pull the city's legal advertising from the newspaper unless it becomes ''a lot nicer to me, my people, my citizens and my city.''

title: Bettis Is Ready to Renew The Battle of the Backs
description: Jerome Bettis, the Pittsburgh Steelers' usually cheerful running back, suddenly found himself annoyed yesterday with the Denver Broncos' Terrell Davis, his chief rival for the title of the American Football Conference's No. 1 running back.

title: Police Acted Properly In 1992, Prosecutor Says
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that the police and prosecutors had acted properly in obtaining incriminating statements by a man accused of a 1992 murder and robbery and using them to convict him and to charge a man as an accomplice, even though investigators now believe the two had nothing to do with the crime.

title: Miscellany
description: * Targetbase International, a unit of the Targetbase Marketing division of M/A/R/C Group, Irving, Tex., bought a 25 percent stake in Intelligent Database Marketing, Middlesbrough, England, and London, with an option to acquire the remaining 75 percent in the next two years. Terms were not disclosed.

title: By Way of Fitzgerald and Sinatra
description: There is hardly a jazz singer alive who doesn't pay lip service to the greatness of Ella Fitzgerald. Yet few of her descendants have much grasp of a style whose essence was an easygoing fluency, a dialogue between flowing lyricism and dynamic improvisation that made these distinct two elements of jazz singing seem indivisible. One who does is Carol Sloane, the Boston-based jazz singer who opened a two-week engagement on Tuesday evening at Rainbow and Stars, where she is accompanied by a superb jazz trio led by the pianist Bill Mays.

title: In the Rematch, Knicks Floor the Nets in Overtime
description: Almost all the basic needs for the Knicks were confined to a few seats on the sideline for the finish.

title: The Cardinal Rules At Le Cirque
description: ''Am I allowed in?'' JOHN CARDINAL O'CONNOR asked when he noticed the sign on the brass post spelling out the never-changing dress code at Le Cirque 2000, the restaurant at 455 Madison Avenue that is as well known for its A-list lunch bunch as for its carefully dressed duck. ''I don't have a necktie or a jacket.''

description: In percent

description: SMITH-Gladys R. Of Manhattan on January 7, 1998. Dear aunt of Madeleine and John Butler, grand aunt of John Jr., Mark, Anne Baladron, Mary Harkins, Joan Manaster, Peter and Paul. Funeral services were held privately.

title: Mae Questel, 89, Behind Betty Boop and Olive Oyl
description: Mae Questel, a rubber-voiced veteran of stage, screen and vaudeville who played Woody Allen's mother in ''New York Stories'' and was the cartoon voice of Betty Boop and Olive Oyl, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Council Speaker Proposes Cut to City's Income Tax
description: The Speaker of the City Council, Peter F. Vallone, called for a $500 million cut in the city's personal income tax yesterday, seeking to bolster his candidacy for governor by portraying himself as a champion of the middle class who gives ''money back to the people.''

title: Holzman Is Hospitalized
description: Red Holzman, the Hall of Fame coach who led the Knicks to their only two National Basketball Association championships, has been admitted to Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. At the request of the Holzman family, a hospital spokesman said last night there would be no details released on his condition.

title: Realigning Forever: That's Where the Old Folks Play
description: CELEBRATION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, DANIEL BERTRAM, SR.
description: GROSSMAN-Daniel Bertram, Sr. 72, on January 5, 1998 in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Danny Grossman and Dana Hammond, grandfather of Oliver, Miles, Jonathan and Nicky Hammond. Funeral 11 AM, Saturday, January 10, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either St. Peter's Episcopal Church Building Fund, PO Box 336, Del Mar, CA 92014 or Scripps Clinic, Division of Chest Medicine, 10666 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA 92037.

title: Canada Apologizes To Indigenous Tribes
description: For the first time, the Canadian Government has formally apologized to its 1.3 million indigenous people for 150 years of what Indian groups charged were paternalistic programs and racist schools that devastated their communities as thoroughly as any war or disease.

title: An Artist's Illuminations From the 18th Century
description: Votives to read by? In a way, yes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, BEN C.
description: MORRIS-Ben C., 67. Died Monday, January 5, 1998 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Savannah, Georgia. Mr. Morris, an artist and fashion designer, had taught at the Savannah College of Art and Design since 1983, where he was well known and respected by faculty, staff, and students alike. Born in Defuniak Springs, Florida, Mr. Morris earned both a Bachelor's Degree and a Master's Degree from the State University of New York at Stony Brook, having also studied at Florida State University, Syracuse University and in Pavel Tchelitchew in Rome, Italy. His teaching experience prior to the Savannah College of Art and Design included Parsons School of Design, the Art Students League of New York, and Florida State University. Mr. Morris began his career as design assistant to M. De Givenchy at Hubert De Givenchy in Paris, and was later with Lily Dache in New York City. He worked as a fashion illustrator with The Philadelphia Bulletin, Women's Wear Daily & The New York Times. He also produced his original wallpaper, which was sold to a major manufacturer and is still being printed. As a freelance illustrator, Mr. Morris' clients included Elizabeth Arden, Lord & Taylor, Bloomingdale's, and Christian Dior. Mr. Morris joined the Savannah College of Art and Design in 1983, where he served as chair of the foundation department, and later the fashion department, a program he helped to develop. Mr. Morris is survived by his longtime companion, Don Mondanaro of Savannah, and several cousins. Remembrances may be made to: The Savannah College of Art and Design, Professor Ben Morris Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 3146, Savannah, Georgia 31402-3146.

title: Memorial Statue Removed in Nassau
description: A little more than a year ago, Michael Alfano, a sculptor from Levittown, proposed a sculpture as a memorial to a girlfriend who was killed by a drunken driver. The Nassau County Traffic Safety Board quickly accepted the idea and decided to put the work on the wide lawn in front of the county courthouse here.

title: Under Fire, Hostos Chief Resigns Post
description: Bowing to lingering criticism, Dr. Isaura Santiago Santiago resigned yesterday as president of Hostos Community College, the bilingual college in the Bronx that trustees of the City University of New York attacked last spring for allowing students to graduate without a good grasp of English.

title: A Jazz (That's Right) Violinist
description: A little while ago, Regina Carter made a rare defection in these days of niche marketing and cultural specialization. She's a jazz violinist of great control, improvisational flexibility and wide range; among her credits are a place in Wynton Marsalis's ''Blood on the Fields'' band to a five-year membership in the adventurous String Trio of New York. Two years ago, she made her first of two albums under her own name, and they're light rhythm-and-blues affairs, aimed at the smooth-jazz radio format. A smart business decision needs no explanation; it's just that there's practically no crossover between the two audiences, and it can be hard to live down the taint of jazz's blander shadow-world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLENS, EVELYN
description: POLLENS-Evelyn, born February 4, 1904, Bronx, NY died in New York City. Much loved sister, aunt, teacher, friend, long an Assistant Principal in New York City schools. Beloved and admired for her intelligence, for her fierce love and concern for family, for students, for fairness and decency in the world. Survived by sister and brother-in-law, Diana and Jack Siegel, nephews and nieces, John Siegel, Peter and Sima Siegel, Michael Goldman and Eleanor Bergstein, and by her dearest friend, Mary Bannister. Services Sunday, January 11, 1998, 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam

title: Frustration and Deadlock As the Panel Splits 3 Ways
description: For two tense days, jurors wrestled over sentencing Terry Nichols to death. Behind closed doors, voices were raised, tears were shed, votes were held, and, on three occasions, pleas for help were sent to the judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIMPELSON, REV. JUDITH L.
description: GIMPELSON-Rev. Judith L. Dedicated and cherished special education teacher. Beloved daughter of Morris and the late Clara Gimpelson. Loving sister of Audrey Aronow. Devoted aunt of David and Rebecca. Soul mate to Rev. Victor Fuhrman. Service Friday January 9, 12 noon at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINANT, ROBERT T.
description: WINANT-Robert T. On January 6, 1998 of Douglaston, NY. Retired NYC Police Dept. Loving husband of the late Joan M. Winant. Cherished son of Agnes and the late Robert Winant. Devoted father of Jeanne LaFrance, Christine Winant-Czap and Barbara Morgan. Brother of Donald and the late Richard Winant. Also survived by five grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY on Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial in St. Anastasia R.C. Church, Friday 9:45 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOGAN, NATHAN
description: KOGAN-Nathan, 91. Passed away Jan. 6, 1998 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, Winifred and his daughter Jane Kogan of Provincetown, MA. He was a retired attorney from New York City and formerly a cellist with the Ft. Lauderdale Symphony, and greater Miami Opera under the Baton of Emerson Buckley. He was the legal counsel for the Violoncello Society of New York City and President of the Chamber Music Associates at the 92nd Street ''Y''. He will be missed by many loving relatives and friends.

title: Making Books; The Agent Has Many Faces
description: The maximum disturbing and unraveling word for an author's agent to hear is ''no.'' So in the ceremony of book publishing, the relationship that is most culturally challenging and polarizing is the one between writers' agents and publishers. Even the most optimistic in the industry believe this coming year will likely see more dreaded conversations between the two than ever before.

title: Economic Scene; Korea will suffer, but the banks that lent the money won't.
description: FIRST Mexico. Then Thailand and Indonesia. Now, South Korea.

title: Growth Rate Slowing Sharply in Korea
description: South Korea said yesterday that high interest rates and a plunge in its currency would cause its economy to grow much more slowly than forecast a month ago, when a $60 billion bailout from a group led by the International Monetary Fund was arranged. The Government plans to announce today that the economy may grow as little as 1 percent in 1998, not the 3 percent it predicted in December, according to a member of the Government's I.M.F. task force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMANN, JAMES F.
description: SELIGMANN-James F. On January 5, 1998 at age 79 after a long, brave battle with illness. Beloved husband of Ursula (Buchholz), cherished brother of Dr. Arthur Seligmann, Robert Seligmann and Jean S. Levine. Loving and loved uncle of nine nieces and nephews. A member of the New York Publishing community as a literary agent, he served in WW II with the 88th Division Signal Corps. A lover of music from classical to country. A man of unique humor whose witty lyrics delighted everyone. He will be missed. Services private. Memorial contributions may be made to Development Fund, The Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 W. 106 St, New York, New York 10025.

title: Board Extends Crew's Contract by a Unanimous Vote
description: With the divisive search process that brought Dr. Rudy Crew to New York City in October 1995 a distant memory, the Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to extend his contract as Schools Chancellor through July 1999, the latest date permitted under law.

title: U.S. Warning To Indonesia: Comply on Aid
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it was ''crucial'' for the Indonesian Government to begin complying with terms of its $40 billion financial bailout. Several officials said emergency aid to help the country escape its crisis could be cut off if President Suharto ignored the warnings.

title: All the Pet Essentials, Fisherman Sweaters to Futons
description: The well-appointed dog is a fact of urban life, and Blue Ribbon Dog in New York is there to provide chic essentials, from Czech Cubist-style citrus-green rubber dog bones to futons covered in a choice of 12 different types of mattress ticking ($175 to $300).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUFFANTI, PAUL
description: GUFFANTI-Paul. On Jan. 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Olga. Devoted father of Paul Jr. and Arthur. Fond brother of Theresa Craven. Dear father-in-law of Carole Ann. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York on Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian burial at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, on Saturday, at 10 A.M.

title: Arrest in Cabby's Killing Was Mistake, Police Say
description: A man who was arrested New Year's Day in the killing of a livery-cab driver was charged by mistake, the Newark police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKELVEY, JEAN T.
description: McKELVEY-Jean T. We are immensely saddened by the death of Jean T. McKelvey of Rochester, New York, a superb teacher, arbitrator of labor disputes and mediator. She was the first woman president of the National Academy of Arbitrators and that recognition opened the door for others. She was a remarkable teacher, recognized where ever she went for the quality and warmth of her work, for her earned reputation throughout the country. Being a ''McKelvey Student'' is a badge of honor. We are the poorer for her passing but her influence will live on for many years. Milton Rubin, President, National Academy of Arbitrators

title: SCOPUS ENDS 3-MONTH BID TO BUY CLEAR WITH COMPUTERS
description: Scopus Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had ended its plan to buy Clear With Computers Inc., deciding instead that a marketing agreement better serves the two companies. In the three months since Scopus agreed to buy Clear With Computers with its stock, shares of Scopus shares have fallen 18 percent. That reduced the value of the transaction to $75.8 million, based on the closing price of Scopus yesterday, from $92.1 million when the companies announced the agreement. Scopus agreed in October to buy Clear With Computers to bolster its line of software that automates customer-support services. Shares of Scopus fell 31.25 cents, to $13.375.

title: Turf; Now, the Six-Figure Rent (Yes, Rent)
description: THE uncarpeted living room of the spanking-new penthouse feels like a conference room with windows on the universe: 30,000 cubic feet enclosed by plate glass and wallboard, a box bigger than the average suburban ranch house. Along with five bedrooms, the apartment comes with salmon-colored marble slabs in the hallways, steam showers in the dark-green- and cream-colored marble bathrooms -- and a microwave barely big enough to pop corn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENZEL, CAROL L.
description: WENZEL-Carol L. Former business manager of Historic Deerfield, Inc. Survived by sister, Jacqueline Riccio of Sarasota, FL. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 31, at 11 AM in the First Church of Deerfield, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELIG, SHERETA R.
description: SEELIG-Shereta R. Of Old Brookville, L.I. on January 5, 1998. Survived by friend Vincent Tancora, also, many dear friends and neighbors. First licensed woman insurance broker in New York State. Will be missed by all. Memorial services at a later date.

title: Campbell to Start Rested Richter Against Washington
description: Tanned -- well, maybe not -- but definitely rested and ready, Mike Richter will be back in goal tonight when the Rangers face Washington in a crucial conference game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REPETTO, RICHARD E.
description: REPETTO-Richard E. Of Garden City, New York, on January 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Joan, Loving father of Jeanne King, Christopher, Susan and the late Robert. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Saturday, 9:45 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Donations to Children of Bellevue, Inc. Attn: Noreen Cosgrove, Bellevue Hospital Center, 462 First Ave, NY, NY 10016 appreciated.

title: Grim Face of Gay Life: A Papal Aide Is Killed
description: It might have been just another murder, except that the person who died, apparently in an encounter Sunday night with a homosexual lover, was a Gentleman of His Holiness, one of a select group who receive dignitaries when they arrive at the Vatican.

title: Securities Broker Enters Guilty Plea
description: A Massachusetts securities broker, Robert D. Gersh, has pleaded guilty to Federal charges related to the misappropriation of about $4 million from investors who believed they were buying municipal securities.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about Orthodox Jews' transformation of Borough Park in Brooklyn mislabeled a set of fertility statistics. The figures for births among women aged 35 to 44 referred to the total per 1,000 over their lifetimes, not per 100,000. For every 1,000 women aged 35 to 44 in Borough Park, 3,800 children were born, according to the 1990 census; for Brooklyn the figure was 2,000, and for New York City 1,750.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sips column of the Dining section yesterday about beer made by the Anderson Valley Brewing Company in Booneville, Calif., misstated the price for six 22-ounce bottles. It is $17.52 plus $16 shipping to the East Coast, not a total of $16.

title: Government by Increment: Pataki Speech Takes Few Chances
description: President Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign showed that for an incumbent blessed with a healthy economy and strong poll numbers, an election year is the season for government by increment, not bold action. And Gov. George E. Pataki has learned the lesson well.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS SHARPLY. A meeting of a key Japanese Vice Minister of Finance with American officials last night sparked talk that the two countries would intervene in the foreign exchange market to support the Japanese yen. That fear prompted dollar selling for yen and German marks.

title: Two Who Solved The Puzzle of Love
description: EMILY MINDEL didn't have a clue as to why 18 across (''poet Dickinson'') in the crossword puzzle in The New York Times yesterday was her own name. But Ms. Mindel, a 24-year-old law student and experienced combatant on the daily battlefield of anagrams and antonyms, suspected something when 14 Across (''Microsoft chief, to some'') turned out to be BillG, which fits her boyfriend, BILL GOTTLIEB.

title: Korea Electric to Offer Corporate Bonds
description: The Korea Electric Power Corporation agreed to sell 100 billion won ($57 million) of three-year corporate bonds today, paying an annual interest rate of 19 percent. The company, a state-owned utility monopoly, was able to sell the bonds at a yield six percentage points below the market rate of 25 percent. Even so, it is unlikely that Kepco, as it is known, could generate a 19 percent return on capital, underscoring the price corporate Korea is paying for the country's financial crisis. Few foreign investors bid for the bonds at 19 percent, traders said, because the cost of hedging against currency riskswould bring the actual return below 10 percent. The won has weakened 50 percent against the dollar in three months.

title: Police Say Subway Crime Was Undercounted by 20%
description: The Police Department's crime statistics have underestimated crime in the subways by about 20 percent a year for many years, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday, and the department has implemented a series of measures intended to improve the accuracy of the statistics.

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: Kaczynski Can't Drop Lawyers Or Block a Mental Illness Defense
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski tried publicly to dismiss his lawyers today because they would not abandon assertions that he is suffering from mental illness. But the judge at Mr. Kaczynski's trial on charges that he was the Unabomber said the effort to change lawyers was too late and ordered that the trial begin on Thursday.

title: The Neediest Cases; Grandmother Struggles to Care for 2 Abandoned Grandchildren
description: One July day in 1992, when Earl was 5 and Yvette was still an infant, their mother left them with a baby sitter and did not come back.

title: First Answers Are Due For Season of Questions
description: When David Duval and Gabriel Hjertstedt step to the first tee Thursday at the Mercedes Championships, one of the most anticipated seasons in PGA Tour history will begin.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Time Inc.'s Take on Teen-Agers; Yes, From the House That Luce Built, a Girls' Magazine
description: Tips on the latest ''zit zapper,'' hair spray and eye shadow. His and her horoscopes. Articles such as ''Can You Really Tell If Someone's a Virgin?'' and ''Six Star Couples' Secrets for Everlasting Love.''

title: Enough Transit Studies!
description: To the Editor:

title: No Execution for Terry Nichols
description: By failing to reach a unanimous decision in the penalty phase of the Terry Nichols trial, a Federal jury has spared Mr. Nichols's life and handed the sentencing decision to Federal District Judge Richard Matsch. Judge Matsch may imprison Mr. Nichols for life or impose a lesser sentence, but he does not have power to impose the death penalty.

title: Kenah Will Defend 800 Title in Millrose
description: For years, Rich Kenah could not get invited to run in the big races in the Chase Millrose Games, America's blue-ribbon indoor track meet. He was good, but not considered good enough to run against some of the world's best.

title: Critic's Notebook; Barking at the Barricades in a City of Twilight Zoning
description: Electing a mayor is a cultural as well as a political statement. This is especially true when a candidate enters our lives pledging to work toward an intangible abstraction called quality of life.

title: 3 Inmates and 4 Guards Slashed at Rikers Island
description: Three inmates and four correction officers were injured in two slashings at Rikers Island yesterday. The incidents did not appear to be related, correction officials said, but both occurred in a building where there had been another fight among inmates a day earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMRIE, LUCIA
description: COMRIE-Lucia. Of Staten Island, Jan. 6, 1998. Wife of the late Edward G. Beloved mother of Connor McDonald, Curtis and Roberta G. Comrie and Tara Macleod. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island, Saturday. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Good Counsel Church 10am. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery. Visiting Friday 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to New York Public Library would be appreciated.

title: Pataki Says He Delivered on Promises; Experts Aren't So Sure
description: Gov. George E. Pataki used his election-year address to the Legislature today to remind New Yorkers that he had delivered on the major campaign pledges he made four years ago: creating jobs, reducing crime, cutting taxes and shrinking the welfare rolls.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day yesterday, about Wells BDDP's loss of a longtime client, referred incorrectly to the status of another client, TAG Heuer U.S.A. While TAG Heuer U.S.A.'s parent company last month named Bartle Bogle Hegarty in London as its worldwide creative agency, the American unit recently decided to stay with Wells BDDP.

title: Karpov Keeps Lead With Draw
description: Anatoly Karpov, leisurely and without taking risks, tried to wear down Viswanathan Anand in Game 5 of their International Chess Federation match, but accurate defense brought about a draw in 55 moves yesterday in Lausanne, Switzerland. Karpov, leading his challenger by a 3-2 score, needs only one draw to win the six-game contest, collect $1.3 million and become first in line to play a title match with Garry Kasparov.

title: Turks Clash Over Defense of Virginity Tests
description: Outraged Turkish feminists are demanding the resignation of the Cabinet minister in charge of women's affairs after she defended the traditional practice of subjecting women to virginity tests.

title: Essay; Nobody's Business
description: Your right to privacy has been stripped away. You cannot walk into your bank, or apply for a job, or access your personal computer, without undergoing the scrutiny of strangers. You cannot use a credit card to buy clothes to cover your body without baring your soul. Big Brother is watching as never before.

title: Canada's Indigenous Tribes Receive Formal Apology
description: For the first time, the Canadian Government has formally apologized to its 1.3 million indigenous people for 150 years of what Indian groups have charged were paternalistic assistance programs and racist schools that devastated their communities as thoroughly as any war or disease.

title: Rolston and McKay Help Devils Regain Lead in the East
description: Brian Rolston's lengthy meeting with Coach Jacques Lemaire and a new four-year contract for Randy McKay paid dividends for the Devils tonight. Rolston and McKay played with inspiration, and each scored to help the Devils gain to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Continental Arena.

title: Personal Shopper; Finials Take Their Curtain Call
description: WHEN are curtain rods more interesting than the curtains? When they have decorative finials resembling everything from a ram's head to a Faberge egg. Russell Bush, a Manhattan interior designer, even suggests drilling a hole in a baseball or tennis ball for an unusual touch in a child's room. The right finial can also perk up a four-poster bed or stretch the height of a bookcase to make it look like a floor-to-ceiling built-in.

title: AT HOME WITH: Valdir Cruz; A Fragile World Through a Lens
description: FOR anyone looking at Valdir Cruz's beautiful, silvery photographs of the remote Indians of the Amazon rain forests, it is difficult to shake the notion that they are images of ghosts populating ghost towns.

title: Mets Talk to Spehr
description: The Mets are negotiating with Tim Spehr, a veteran catcher who would give the organization depth in the minors. Spehr, 31, has never had more than 87 at-bats in any of his six seasons in the majors. The Mets will continue their pursuit of someone who can fill in at the position until Todd Hundley recovers from elbow surgery, expected to be sometime in mid-season. BUSTER OLNEY

title: Moving Pictures
description: So you always wanted to direct and star in your own movie but just didn't have a few million to spare. Now, for the price of admission to the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, you can make a flip book of yourself in action: one minute and it's in the can. For $2, you can buy a printout that becomes 40 flippable pages. Clamp them with an alligator clip, and voila! The Video Flip Book exhibit, created by the museum with a bow to S. H. Pearce & Company software, is unique, said Carl Goodman, curator of digital media. But it may multiply, said Rochelle Slovin, the director: the National Science Foundation has granted the museum $1.3 million for traveling exhibitions. WILLIAM S. NIEDERKORN

title: Short Program: 2 1/2 Minutes of Compulsory Terror
description: Just in case the Tara Lipinski-Michelle Kwan rivalry wasn't urgent enough, organizers of the Olympic trials have brought gunslinger symbolism to the skaters' short-program duel by scheduling it for Thursday at high noon.

title: William Kelly, 92, Founder Of Temporary Jobs Company
description: William Russell Kelly, who as founder of Kelly Services Inc. turned temporary work into an industry -- and a way of life for many Americans -- died Saturday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., the company announced. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, ALAN
description: FRANK-Alan. Beloved husband of Cookie. Devoted father of Kim, Scott and Greg. Our heartfelt sympathy to the Frank family on the loss of this special person. His warmth, love for friends and family will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences. The Carmel and Getreu Family

title: PATAKI PROPOSING HEALTH CARE PLAN FOR YOUNG PEOPLE
description: Positioning himself for a re-election campaign this fall, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed a major expansion of health insurance for young New Yorkers as well as an acceleration of tax cuts and an expansion of anti-crime measures that he said had already enabled him to lead the state to ''the dawn of its greatest day.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section yesterday misstated one of Vladimir Ashkenazy's orchestral affiliations. He is the chief conductor of the Czech Philharmonic, not the Prague Philharmonic.

title: Lazard Banker to Join Pritzker Concern
description: J. Ira Harris, a top investment banker at Lazard Freres & Company, has left the firm to join the Pritzker family's investment company as a vice chairman, the Pritzkers and Lazard said today.

title: Trenton Schools to Stay Under State Control
description: The Newark public schools made significant progress during the last school year but will remain under state control for at least the next three years, state education officials said yesterday.

title: Solution to School's Racial Imbalance Still Elusive
description: The long legal feud over the racial imbalance at Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood, N.J., is now in its 13th year, but New Jersey's Board of Education said today that it would need more time, possibly several months, to search for a solution.

title: For One Night, Knicks Show Grit and Poise
description: They embraced for several seconds, an impromptu group hug at midcourt. John Starks clapped his hands at warp speed. Chris Childs smiled. Allan Houston nodded his head in satisfaction. The horn had sounded, the building was rocking and the Knicks had taken flight.

title: Families' Anger at Outcome Is Scalding
description: The most painful thing, the families of victims of the Oklahoma City bombing said, was not that Terry L. Nichols had escaped, for now, death by lethal injection.

title: Earnings at Morgan Stanley And Lehman Top Forecasts
description: Two big Wall Street firms -- Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. -- reported quarterly earnings yesterday that substantially exceeded analysts' forecasts, undercutting, at least for the time being, fears that the spreading credit problems in Asia have hurt the profits of big securities firms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, CONSUELO
description: FORD-Consuelo. On Jan. 5, 1998. Sister of Phyllis Ford, aunt of Consuelo Regina Newland. Grandmother of Stephanie E. Francis. Sister of Trudy Francis, and many cousins and other relatives and friends. Secretary of Chapter 23, NARFE, President, Sons and Daughters of Barbados; Director of Baruch College Alumni; Officer of Black Alumni, CUNY; past President of St. Nicholas Columbiettes, member of the NY Chapter Columbiettes. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72 St. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 10 A.M., St. Gregory's Church RC. Interment in St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to: St. Josephs Indian School and United Negro College Fund.

title: SBC Emerging as a Bull in the F.C.C.'s China Shop
description: By persuading a Federal judge to strike down vital elements of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 last week and by agreeing on Monday to acquire Connecticut's main telephone company for $4.4 billion, SBC Communications Inc. is clearly emerging as the iconoclast of the telecommunications industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEREFF, HENRY DAVID
description: SHEREFF-Henry David. The Directors and members of the Townsend Harris Alumni Association are deeply saddened by the death of Henry Shereff, a founder and past president of the Alumni Association, and a member of the Townsend Harris Hall of Fame. Gentle, kind and generous, Henry Shereff was one of the driving forces behind the re-opening of Townsend Harris as a leading public high school in New York. To his wife, Meta, and their three sons and granddaughter we send our love and condolences. Those wishing to contribute to a scholarship fund being established in his memory may do so by sending a check to the Townsend Harris Alumni Association, Box 1274, Gracie Station, New York, NY 10028.

title: U.S. Greets Iran's Overture, but Insists on Governmental Talks
description: In his ''message to the American people'' today, the Iranian President called for ''dialogue and understanding between the two nations,'' in particular ''the exchange of professors, writers, scholars, artists, journalists and tourists.''

title: Murder and Grit Move Downtown
description: Amid the flood of long goodbyes for ''Seinfeld,'' let's remember that the show was not all things to all people. No one ever called ''Seinfeld'' multi-ethnic, a fact the Fox network shrewdly exploited for several years by counterprogramming the fast, gritty, multiracial police drama ''New York Undercover'' against it. That series picked up enough younger and black viewers to make it the network's most successful ''Seinfeld'' competition ever, a demographic hit if not a ratings blockbuster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMBERGER, CHARLES M.
description: HEMBERGER-Charles M. You are and always will be my best friend in the world. Deepest sympathy to the whole family. Arth

title: Seinfeld Meets a Really 'Super' Salesman
description: All the attention Jerry Seinfeld has received since disclosing that he will end production of his hit NBC sitcom has made him a kind of superhero in the media. So it may be appropriate that the American Express Company will soon introduce a television commercial in which Mr. Seinfeld is paired with Superman.

title: Japanese Pour Money Into Postal Savings
description: Japanese savers poured a net 3.34 trillion yen ($24.9 billion), a record, into the state-run postal savings system in December as the collapse of two private banks sent depositors looking for safety. That figure was more than double the inflow in the corresponding month last year, the Government said.

title: Two Are Charged in a Scheme To Ride Free on Metrocards
description: Last August, some 1,000 computer hackers attending a conference in SoHo declared that finding a way to beat the Metrocard was one of the ''holy grails'' of computer hacking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, GEORGE C.
description: PALMER-George C. Age 75, of Bayport and Davis Park, LI, on January 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Althea H. Palmer. Dear father of John, Robert, Susan Palmer Austin, Catherine Palmer Roy, Virginia Palmer Beaulac, Thomas and Christopher and stepfather of Pamela Kurey, MD and David Henrich. Fond brother of James Palmer, Anita Wright and Nancy Knapp. Also survived by eleven grandchildren and two stepgrandchildren. Reposing at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Highway, West Sayville, Friday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 p.m. Religious service Saturday 11 a.m. at Bayport United Methodist Church, Middle Road, Bayport. Interment St. Ann's Cemetery, Sayville. Please make contributions in his memory to Bayport United Methodist Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSIN, SYDNEY
description: GOSIN-Sydney. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Sidney Gosin, beloved father of Barry Gosin, a dedicated leader and generous supporter of UJA-Federation. We extend our sincerest condolences to Barry, his wife Jackie, and their daughters, Brooke and Brie, as well as to Mr. Gosin's beloved wife, Irene, his sons, Howard and Richard, his daughter Sandy Lupo, and the entire Gosin family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Senate Passes Bill On Rent-to-Own Stores
description: The State Senate approved legislation yesterday that proponents said would prevent businesses that rent household goods and electronic equipment from taking advantage of consumers.

title: Now You Can Hear One About the Farmer and . . .
description: The term chamber opera, or even opera without a modifier, covers considerable ground these days. ''The Shoulder,'' an amusing new work that is running through Jan. 17 at Dance Theater Workshop, is billed as a chamber opera, but barely touches on the conventionally operatic.

title: Mexican Judge Accused; She Freed 5 in Slaying
description: The District Attorney, in a formal complaint filed here, accused a judge today of ''shocking carelessness'' in her handling of a case in which she quietly released five men who had confessed to kidnapping and killing an American businessman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURT, ANN SCHREIBER
description: KURT-Ann Schreiber. Died on 1/8/ 98. Loving wife of the late William, beloved mother of Diane Kurt Hamdan, dear sister of Ruth Grady and Raymond Schreiber. Visiting at Thomas M. Quinn and Sons Funeral Home, 35-20 Broadway, L.I.C., NY 11106 on Sun, 2-5, 7-9:30 PM. A memorial mass will be celebrated on Feb. 6, 1998 at 7:30 PM, St. Elizabeth of Hungary Church, E. 83 St, NYC. Interment Dunnellon Cemetery in Dunnellon, FL.

title: South Koreans Appear to Get Debt Extension
description: The world's leading banks have tentatively agreed to extend payment on as much as $28 billion in short-term loans to South Korea that come due on March 31, a crucial precursor to easing the country's financial crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, LILEN
description: SANGER-Lilen. On January 8, 1998. In loving tribute to Lilen Sanger. Cherished mother of Sirgay. Loving mother-in-law of Judy. Sister-in-law of Ethel. Grandmother of Terry, Vicky. Great grandmother of James. Adoring aunt of Mitzi, Patricia, Liam, Cyrena, Stephany, Jonathan, Elizabeth, Gail, Mary Bryna, Diane and Michael. Great aunt of Priscilla, Elizabeth, Margaret, Erik, Cory, Sean, Evan, Regan, Geoffrey, Wendy, David, Kevin, Lorie Dru, Jared, Amy, Aaron, Jaron, Julia Anne, Jeffrey, Margot, Meredith, Jonathan, Matthew and Amanda. She adored the spouses of her family, Lou, Bill, Lee, Simmel, Judy, Carla, Mark, Yakov, Larry and Francine. Her distinguished career as the first and only American woman to own a distillery in Scotland continued with her as Chairperson of the Women's Alcoholic Beverage Association in the United States. She was known for her many philanthropies. In particular, Greek war relief, Israeli medical education, and the Harvard Medical School. Her generosity, warmth and panache kindled light in everyone and will live always in memory. Family and friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street, on Saturday, 5-8PM, with Service Sunday, 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Harvard Medical School.

title: SYBRON TURNS DOWN CASH OFFER FROM GENCORP
description: Sybron Chemicals Inc. rejected an unsolicited cash offer yesterday of $38 a share, or about $215.5 million, from Gencorp after a group of shareholders that owns 45 percent of Sybron's stock said that it would not sell its shares. Sybron, a specialty chemical company based in Birmingham, N.J., accepted an offer last month of $34.50 a share from the investor group for the 55 percent of Sybron it did not already own. The group includes Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd. and two members of Sybron management -- Richard M. Klein, the company's president, and John H. Schroeder, an executive vice president. Separately, Gencorp said that its offer would remain open until Jan. 21. Gencorp, based in Fairlawn, Ohio, makes aerospace and defense systems, auto parts and polymer-based products.

title: Unabom Chaos Grows on Talk Of Suicide Try
description: After apparently trying to kill himself on the eve of his trial, Theodore J. Kaczynski threw his case into chaos today as he asked to be allowed to represent himself.

title: FIGURE SKATING ; Eldredge Wins Title After Fall
description: After being asked repeatedly why he had never attempted a quadruple jump in competition, Todd Eldredge launched one tonight during his long program at the Olympic trials. He fell hard on the quad toe, but he did not tumble out of first place as he won his fifth national title.

title: Allied Textile Shares Jump on Takeover Talk
description: Shares in the Allied Textile Companies P.L.C. jumped yesterday as the company disclosed it is in talks about a possible bid for the company from a group including some of its senior management. The announcement came as the company, based in Huddersfield, England, reported its pretax profits for the full year.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Yves Klein

title: Taking Oath And Adulation
description: This crowd of 700 prosecutors, defense lawyers and judges wasn't litigating, it was honoring a New York institution -- the Manhattan District Attorney, ROBERT M. MORGENTHAU, 78. The occasion was his swearing-in ceremony at Surrogate's Court.

title: U.S. Mediator Seeking to Get Mideast Talks Restarted
description: The American mediator for the Middle East, Dennis Ross, shuttled between Israeli and Palestinian politicians for the third day today in search of a new formula to bridge the steadily widening gap between them and enable negotiations to resume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHBEIN, ELI
description: FISHBEIN-Eli. Suddenly in FL. Cherished husband of Myrna, beloved father of Sarah and Steven Epstein, Elisa and Clint Greenbaum, Kalman and Susie Fishbein, loving ''grandpa'' of Jake, Lauren, Kate, Augusta, Craig and Danielle Rose. A UJA benefactor and an AMIT Friend. Service Sunday 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue. His standards were high. Those who knew him will remember him warmly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGEN, JOAN EDITH
description: DEGEN-Joan Edith. Beloved wife of the late Jerome; loving mother of Jill and Glen Pohs and the late Jon Benson Degen; adoring grandmother of Lara and Jamie Pohs; devoted sister of Jerold and Sylvia Granatoor; loving aunt and cousin. Graveside service Sunday, 10:30AM at Cedar Park Cemetery. Donations in her memory to American Diabetes Association or American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: New Jersey Senate Passes Measure That May Raise Milk Prices
description: The State Senate approved a measure today that is likely to increase retail milk prices by at least 10 cents a gallon in New Jersey as well as trigger similar increases in New York and Pennsylvania.

title: Another Reason To Await Spring
description: Where'd everybody go?

title: N.Y.U. Faculty Sues To Block Mt. Sinai Deal
description: The Faculty Council of the New York University medical school sued yesterday to block a proposed merger of the N.Y.U. Medical Center and the Mount Sinai Medical Center. The suit seeks a larger role in the negotiations and says the merger would damage their institution's prestige and threaten its survival.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIE, COMNENE, IRENE
description: BIE-COMNENE-Irene. January 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Rolf Bie and the late Aurelio Corsani. She was the proud daughter of Nicolas Petrescu Comnene. Friends may call on Saturday, January 10, 1998, from 2-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Service following on Sunday, January 11, 1998, at 3:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Health Plan Is Ambitious, But Critics See Problems
description: The ambitious health care plan for children that Gov. George E. Pataki announced with such fanfare in his State of the State address on Wednesday is less a set of blueprints than a concept -- and one already under dispute in Albany.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about a stock promotion by the Semiconductor Laser Corporation, misstated a term of an arrangement between the company and Marketing Direct Concepts. The marketing firm received 40,000 shares of Semiconductor Laser stock, not 150,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, THOMAS J.
description: STANTON-Thomas J. Of Montclair on January 6, 1998. Husband of Jane. Father of Louise Stanton, Thomas III, Patricia Stanton, Charles, Katherine Stanton-Paule, John, Robert, and the late William. Brother of the Honorable Reginald Stanton, John Stanton, Louise Longhurst, Katherine Kramer and the late Joyce Fennelly. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Funeral from Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, Saturday 9 A.M. then to Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair where at 10:30 A.M. a Mass of Christian Burial will be offered. Interment Immaculate Conception Cemetery. Visiting hours 7-9 Thursday and 2-4 and 7-9 Friday. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the St. Vincent's Nursing Home Auxiliary, 45 Elm Street Montclair, New Jersey 07042.

title: An Artist's Library, Seen as a Self-Portrait
description: If you're one of those people who can't stand Georgia O'Keeffe's work, then a visit to her adobe home in Abiquiu, N.M., might help change your mind a bit. Short of that, a more convenient alternative -- far less deadly than it sounds, believe me -- is to see the exhibition of books from her Abiquiu library now at the Grolier Club in Manhattan.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.
