title: Market Place; Sometimes not even a nifty product can save an investment in a new and untried company.
description: NOTHING gets investors more excited than a new company that builds a better mousetrap. But sometimes investors are the ones who get trapped, when they forget there is more to making a successful new business than building a high-technology gizmo.

title: UNION PLANTERS AGREES TO BUY CB&T OF TENNESSEE
description: The Union Planters Corporation agreed yesterday to buy CB&T Inc. for $95 million in stock, giving the company more bank branches and customers in central Tennessee. CB&T, a closely held bank company based in McMinnville, Tenn., does business through the City Bank and Trust Company, a bank with $268 million in assets and nine branches. Union Planters, the Memphis-based bank holding company, has $18.5 million in assets and branches in eight states. Its shares fell $1.50 yesterday, to $62. Union Planters has completed six acquisitions in the last year. Seven more are pending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYANT, MINNIE DICK
description: BRYANT-Minnie Dick. Age 94. Passed away (as she lived) with dignity, on January 8th, surprising no one by waiting for a warm day in winter before joining her late husband Harry. Mrs. Bryant defined liberated woman decades before the phrase ever appeared in print, and leaves a legacy of love, laughter and strength to all who knew her, including her children Muriel and Julius Fielo, Albert and Marcia Bryant, Aileen and Meyer Osofsky, Barbara and Harvey Danowitz and Marjorie Bryant; her grandchildren Michael Fielo and Barbara Ciccone, Helene and Bill Webb, Robin and George Kuhn, Arthur Bryant and Nancy Johnson, Rikki Bryant and Eric Brenner, Larry and Wai-Lin Osofsky, Randy Osofsky and Stephen Kessler, Alan and Deirdre Osofsky, Gary Simon and Jennifer Seron, A. Jay and Joanne Baum, Paul and Dorothy Baum, and Richard and Margaret Baum; her twenty-one great-grandchildren; her sister Ida Senzer, and countless friends and other loved ones. Memorial services will be held at 12:15 pm today, Friday, January 9th, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY. Shiva will be observed through Monday, January 12th at 400 East 56th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Chemotherapy Foundation, at 183 Madison Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: As Clinton Eats Up Contributions, New York Party Says It's Starving
description: The chairwoman of the New York Democratic Party asserted yesterday that President Clinton's fund-raising trips to New York were undermining her efforts to prepare the state party for a critical election year, and she asked that national Democrats either share the fruits of Mr. Clinton's trips or stay out of New York this year.

title: Skip Away and Favorite Trick Win Honors
description: Skip Away won the Eclipse Award yesterday as North America's champion older horse of 1997, and the undefeated Favorite Trick was voted the best 2-year-old. And, in a homestretch duel for racing's ultimate honor, the two stars were identified as finalists for the title Horse of the Year, which will not be disclosed until Feb. 10.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about an interview with the President of Iran, Mohammad Khatami, reported that the interviewer, Christiane Amanpour of the Cable News Network, did not ask Mr. Khatami about Iran's refusal to cancel a decree that the novelist Salman Rushdie had insulted the Prophet Mohammed and should be put to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELENSKY, JEWEL
description: ZELENSKY-Jewel. On January 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Samuel, dear sister of Lucille Jason, loving aunt and great-aunt of many nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grandnephews. Cherished friend. Service Fri, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Oxford Health Announces Plans to Revamp Its Management
description: Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed care company, announced a series of moves yesterday intended to bolster the depth of its top management. The company said it would hire a new chief executive and appointed Albert A. Koch, a well-regarded turnaround specialist, as its temporary chief financial officer.

title: A Background Check Far From Ordinary
description: On Feb. 27, 1995, a Swiss lawyer filled out an application to open a Citibank account in Geneva for an obscure company from the British Virgin Islands known as Capricorn Trading.

title: To Have, to Hold And to Publicize
description: Flash: 2 World Trade Center is looking for 55 couples for a Valentine's Day marriage marathon on the 110th floor observation deck. (Hint for the mathematically challenged: 55 times 2 is 110.) But wait. Even in Manhattan, the stunt capital of the world, doesn't this one sound familiar? Remember 1989, when 14 couples tied the knot on 14th Street? Or 1997, when several dozen said ''I do'' on the 80th floor of the Empire State Building?

title: Sports of The Times; Selection of U.S. Team Is Not Quite Finished
description: THE soup cans are already on the production line chicken noodle, tomato, clam chowder, Michelle, Tara, Nicole. It seemed like a bright idea to use the three national figure skating champions to advertise the well-known soup brand, the one that Andy Warhol used to paint.

title: Youth Aiding an Officer Was Shot by Him on New Year's Day
description: Raheem Dawkins, a 16-year-old from Brownsville, Brooklyn, does volunteer community service at his local police precinct and wants to be a police officer. So when he saw an off-duty officer being attacked in a Manhattan subway station early on New Year's morning, he didn't hesitate; he jumped in to help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMANN, JAMES F.
description: SELIGMANN-James F. On January 5, 1998 at age 79 after a long, brave battle with illness. Beloved husband of Ursula (Buchholz), cherished brother of Dr. Arthur Seligmann, Robert Seligmann and Jean S. Levine. Loving and loved uncle of nine nieces and nephews. A member of the New York Publishing community as a literary agent, he served in WW II with the 88th Division Signal Corps. A lover of music from classical to country. A man of unique humor whose witty lyrics delighted everyone. He will be missed. Services private. Memorial contributions may be made to Development Fund, The Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 W. 106 St, New York, New York 10025.

title: Strong Finish to Christmas Season Cheers Retailers
description: In a remarkable turnaround from a weak season, American retailers reported strong December sales yesterday, aided in huge part by shopping that occurred after Christmas.

title: Publicis to Expand Canadian Operations
description: Publicis S.A. said yesterday that it would expand operations in Canada by acquiring a 75 percent share in a Toronto agency, SMW. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Cook's 65 Takes Lead, With Woods 7 Behind
description: If John Cook needed excuses today, he had plenty of them.

title: A Number of Deals Are Made in Europe
description: There were several developments yesterday involving advertisers and agencies in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, ANN
description: MUFSON-Ann. 7/3/35-1/9/97. We think of you, love you and miss you every day. You will be in our hearts and minds forever. Laura, Bnnett, Dan, Steve, Agnes

title: Ever-So-Slight Rise in Temperatures Led to a Record High in 1997
description: The vast pool of warm Pacific water called El Nino, coming on top of an underlying global warming trend, lifted the earth's average surface temperature in 1997 to the highest levels ever recorded, Government scientists reported yesterday.

title: Spot Gold Price Is Under $280 Briefly in London and New York
description: For the first time in more than 18 years, the spot price of gold dropped below $280 an ounce in both London and New York yesterday as the fear of sales by central banks and low inflation continued to undermine the outlook for this precious metal.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREGER, RICHARD J.
description: FREGER-Richard J. Of Roswell, GA., passed away on January 6, 1998 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Linda. Devoted father of Jonathan of Venice Beach, CA., and Jennifer of Evanston, IL. He was a lingerie designer for Vanity Fair Intimates. Memorial service will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, on February 13, 1998 at 1:15 PM.

title: Uncharted Territory Ripe for Exploration
description: ''A submerged continent'' is what the late Howard Gilman, one of the pre-eminent collectors of 19th-century photography, called this vintage field. And the phrase is apt. While the 20th century teems with vivid images and audiences to view them, the 19th century still presents a challenge. Its material is much harder to ferret out and find appreciators for. While sophisticated techniques and freedom of approach make 20th-century camera work easily accessible to viewers and collectors, 19th-century images can seem formal and dull, their poses static, their invention limited.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Robert M. Hunt, a former newspaper executive, misspelled the surname of a surviving sister and misstated one of his titles. His twin sister, in Volcano, Hawaii, is Priscilla Fowler, not Sowler. Mr. Hunt was a former president and chief executive of The Chicago Tribune Company -- not of the parent Tribune Company.

title: Kittles Finds His Touch To Lift Nets Past Magic
description: John Calipari had never said the name. But it was obvious to anyone who has seen the Nets recently that their coach was referring to Kerry Kittles when indicating frustration with a certain player for not wanting to take a shot with the game on the line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSNER, BERTHA
description: KASSNER-Bertha. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Bertha Kassner, beloved sister of our Trustee Max and Georgia Zimmer and aunt of Joel and Karen Zimmer. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMRIE, LUCIA
description: COMRIE-Lucia. Of Staten Island, Jan. 6, 1998. Wife of the late Edward G. Beloved mother of Connor McDonald, Curtis and Roberta G. Comrie and Tara Macleod. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island, Saturday. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Good Counsel Church 10am. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery. Visiting Friday 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to New York Public Library would be appreciated.

title: Raising Money Uptown, Clinton Creates a Tie-Up
description: Portions of uptown Manhattan were barricaded yesterday while President Clinton trolled for money in exclusive haunts on the Upper West Side and Park Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, DANIEL BERTRAM, SR.
description: GROSSMAN-Daniel Bertram, Sr. 72, on January 5, 1998 in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Danny Grossman and Dana Hammond, grandfather of Oliver, Miles, Jonathan and Nicky Hammond. Funeral 11 AM, Saturday, January 10, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either St. Peter's Episcopal Church Building Fund, PO Box 336, Del Mar, CA 92014 or Scripps Clinic, Division of Chest Medicine, 10666 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA 92037.

title: Murdered Child's Mother Gets 5-Year Probation
description: The mother of Justina Morales was sentenced to five years on probation yesterday after earlier admitting she had agreed with her boyfriend's determination to kill her daughter. But the judge imposed an unusual condition: if the woman, Denise Solero, becomes pregnant again, she must inform the Probation Department so a court can determine if she is fit to care for the child.

title: International Diplomacy Enters a Dispute Over 2 Paintings
description: The Austrian government protested today against the detention in New York City of two paintings by the Viennese expressionist painter Egon Schiele that had been part of a show at the Museum of Modern Art and were scheduled to be returned here.

title: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work
description: The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget ''is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged'' and that surpluses should start piling up soon.

title: Stately Entrance, Then an Air of Mystery
description: Irene Hultman Dance presented nothing but previews of coming attractions on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. Most of the bits and pieces by Ms. Hultman, a Swedish choreographer, had moments of austere elegance. There were agitated passages as well. But while movie theaters show a complete feature after the previews, Ms. Hultman offered nothing but excerpts, and so her program lacked coherence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILWORTH, J. RICHARDSON
description: DILWORTH-J. Richardson. On December 29, 1997. Beloved husband, devoted father and proud grandfather. Memorial service will be at 12PM, Saturday, January 10, in the Princeton University Chapel, Princeton, NJ. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers will officiate. A reception will be held afterward at Prospect House on the University Campus. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Melissa Dilworth Gold '61 Visiting Artists Fund at Milton Academy, 170 Centre Street, Milton, MA. 02186. Melissa Dilworth Gold died in a helicopter accident in 1991.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ethereal Energy in a Company's Debut
description: There was an excited sense of occasion to the opening of the three-week Altogether Different festival on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Now in its 12th year, the series has provided an important showcase for dance that is out of the mainstream of New York modern dance by virtue of its experimentalism or newness. One certainly could not get much newer than O'Day Dances.

title: All the Comforts of Rome: Robert Adam's England
description: Do you like Hermes scarves? Would you like to live inside one? In late 18th-century Britain, a pivotal time and place in modern history, some rich people evidently had such a living space in mind. They built stately houses with floors, ceilings, walls and doors that were all seemingly fashioned out of elegant silk squares.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fear of Chaos in Indonesia Gives Asia Markets a Jolt

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANYI, GEORGE R.
description: LANYI-George R. Eight painful years. Mother, John, Paul and Dad.

title: O Say, Can You Savor the Crabs? Evermore
description: Cal Ripken Jr. is the very personification of this city's hard-working, blue-collar modesty. Cal Ripken doesn't brag, and neither does Baltimore. Neither one wants to; neither one has to.

title: What Can Consumers Do to Insure Food Safety?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, ARTHUR
description: FIELD-Arthur. At rest in Stanford, CA. Native of NY, NY. Age 78. Attorney. Survived by his beloved wife of 46 years, Marilyn Field, devoted sons Howard and his wife Patricia, and Donald, adored grandchildren, Aaron, Matthew and Alison. Dear brother of Sydelle Glickman and her husband Arthur. Dear brother-in-law of Edward Dorson and his wife Annelise. Funeral services today, at Willow Glen Funeral Chapel 408295-6446. Interment in the Home of Peace Cemetery in Colma, CA.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Sherry Markovitz

title: Classical Musicians Team Up With Actors In the AIDS Battle
description: Some say that given the fluidity of today's economy and the pace of technological change, people should no longer cling to the idea of having one job for life.

title: Canadiens Struggle to Arena And Then Sail by Islanders
description: Considering the Montreal Canadiens' travel problems today and their injury-depleted roster, it was not preposterous to think that the Islanders actually had a chance to win tonight for the first time in nine games.

title: The Bad Seed
description: The physicist Richard Seed thinks he has a nifty idea. Now that scientists have cloned a sheep, producing a lamb genetically identical to its parent, Dr. Seed thinks it is time to clone a human child that would be the identical twin of its parent.

title: New Accusations Aimed at Chinese Swimmers
description: Luggage belonging to a Chinese swimmer was seized yesterday by Australian custom officials who said it contained a substance labeled as human growth hormone. If the label is correct, the incident would reinforce the widely held belief that China's female swimmers have been using banned bodybuilding drugs.

title: Progress, and Lots of It, in Public Health
description: Arriving on Sunday is a 10-hour medley of hits from the history of science. ''A Science Odyssey'' celebrates a century of achievement in medicine, physics, astronomy, brain research, the earth sciences and life sciences and all manner of inventions.

title: Korea and I.M.F. Lower Targets for Growth
description: The South Korean Government and the International Monetary Fund agreed at the fund's board meeting in Washington on Thursday to lower earlier growth targets to reflect the more dismal outlook on the country's economic performance this year, the Korean Ministry of Finance and Economy announced today.

title: Talks on Arena Lease Coming
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has finally called the Nets about their lease.

title: Hoffa's Camp Is Impugning U.S. Monitor
description: Aides to James P. Hoffa, the front-runner in the race for president of the teamsters' union, have begun a campaign attacking the integrity of a new Federal election monitor who is investigating whether Mr. Hoffa engaged in improper fund-raising during a previous run for the presidency, in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSKO, GEORGE
description: KUSKO-George. The Board of Directors and members of the Van Cortlandt Workmen's Circle Community House deeply mourn the passing of George Kusko, husband of our devoted Board member, Helen. Our sincere condolences to Helen, their children, Bruce and Vicki Lea and their grandchildren, Jonathan and Daniel. A memorial meeting will be held on Sunday, January 11, 11 AM at 3990 Hillman Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVITT, PAUL V.
description: DEVITT-Paul V. Age 64. Died on January 6, 1998. Memorial Service on Saturday, January 10, at 3 PM, Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Avenue and 29th Street, where he was on the staff. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Marble Collegiate Church, or The American Cancer Society.

title: Kenyans Identify Virus Fatal to Hundreds
description: Medical researchers said today that a disease that has killed at least 300 people in northeastern Kenya is Rift Valley Fever and not the deadly Ebola virus, as doctors here had feared.

title: INSIDE
description: Detention of Art Protested

title: Colombia's Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMGARDEN, MICHAEL
description: BLOOMGARDEN-Michael. Devoted husband of the late Barbara. Beloved father of Alan and Carol. Dear brother of Barry. Loving father-in-law of Kathie. Cherished grandfather of Cailey and Sarah. Services are today, 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: ASIAN MARKETS TUMBLE.
description: Except for South Korea, most of Asia's stock markets have plunged in the New Year, giving up the gains made last month. Yesterday, Indonesia dropped 12 percent, Singapore 7.1 percent and Hong Kong 3 percent. South Korean stocks rose 3.6 percent.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'About Painting III'

title: A Ravenous Forest Fire Doused by Testosterone
description: Hollywood has always been better at drowning people (see ''Titanic'') than at incinerating them. And ''Firestorm,'' a chintzy-looking thriller about smoke jumpers in the Far West, suggests that the techniques for staging large-scale movie conflagrations have only gotten sloppier since the burning of Atlanta in ''Gone With the Wind.'' In fact, this movie's infernal special effects are so unconvincing that pyrophobes need not fear.

title: A Ghost Caught on Tape: The Transparent Variety
description: The sound is strident and sinister, far creepier than the spooky organ chords that sometimes accompany it. It's a noise you imagine a raven might make when being strangled or perhaps that of a scythe slicing swiftly through something unmentionable. Yes, there's nothing like the sound of household tape being pulled off its roll to bring on a case of the Gothic shudders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADERMAN, BESS
description: LADERMAN - Bess. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member, Mierle Ukeles on the loss of her beloved mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Spielberg and Crichton Face Trial Over 'Twister'
description: Trial proceeding are set to begin here on Monday in United States District Court over whether Steven Spielberg, the author Michael Crichton and Warner Brothers and Universal Studios plagiarized their 1996 hit movie ''Twister,'' directed by Jan De Bont. A St. Louis screenwriter, Stephen Kessler, contends that the film is based on his script ''Catch the Wind.''

title: An Opulent Estate, Quietly Bought in England's Countryside
description: When Asif Ali Zardari arrived in this quiet English village as the new owner of the sprawling Rockwood estate, he was so taken with the village pub, the Dog and Pheasant, that he told the pub owner he wanted to buy it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, GWENDOLEN (MRS. DON B)
description: WILSON-Gwendolen (Mrs. Don B). Almost 88. Died unexpectedly, but quickly Saturday, January 3, 1998 at NYU Hospital after short illness this Fall. This followed a long, and very full active life throughout the world. An ardent New Yorker at heart, she was active in many local organizations, including The National Board of Film Review, The Tudor City Resident Association and the DBE. She will be sorely missed by her daughter Brandon (aka Jill), her son-in-law Steven and her two young grandsons Blake and Kyler. Memorial service on Saturday January 17, 4 PM, Church of the Covenant (Presbyterian Church USA), 310 East 42nd Street, New York City, 10017. Donations in her name to The Humane Society of the United States, POB 97019, Washington, D.C. 20077-7273.

title: Huskies Run Away In 2d Half
description: UCONN 101, ST. JOHN'S 48

title: Dean X Johnson, 42, Composer, Conductor and Choral Arranger
description: Dean X Johnson, a composer, conductor, arranger and pianist whose choral works have been performed and recorded by more than 70 choirs around the world, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 42.

title: Tanker Operator Stops Takeover Effort
description: Frontline Ltd. said yesterday that it had abandoned its bid of 3.22 billion kronor ($400 million) for a rival tanker operator, ICB Shipping A.B. of Sweden, because the crisis in Asia is clouding the outlook for the industry. Frontline said it did not plan to sell the 51.7 percent capital stake and 31.4 percent voting stake it built up in the target company. ICB's shares have declined 17 percent since the offer was made on Sept. 1. ICB's board rejected Frontline's offer.

title: In Iran, Power Is Broadly Defined
description: On Wednesday night, Americans saw a President of Iran who praises America's political heritage and its martyrs like Lincoln. Mohammed Khatami was not just putting on a show for his American audience. He has written a history of Western political thought, much of it devoted to the Anglo-American liberal tradition, and, unlike so many of us who quote Tocqueville, he has actually read him.

title: File Suggests A Possibility Of Deception On Tobacco
description: While Federal officials say the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation denied in 1994 that it had developed tobacco with high nicotine levels, an internal company memorandum shows that the cigarette maker had stockpiled two million pounds of such tobacco in 1990 and was planning to test it on smokers.

title: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work
description: The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget ''is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged'' and that surpluses should start piling up soon.

title: New Data Suggest Universe Will Expand Forever
description: Examining the distant light from stars that exploded before the Sun was born, astronomers have determined that the universe has apparently been expanding at a slow, steady rate since the beginning and is destined to expand forever.

title: On the Trumpet, Yelping, Crying and Then Silent
description: Next week, Blue Note Records is releasing ''Hubsongs,'' an album of the music of Freddie Hubbard, played by two of the better trumpeters working in jazz, Tim Hagans and Marcus Printup. It's a good idea to have two such radically different soloists working on the same material, and if the record suffers a bit from adherence to jazz formula, the live performance of the two trumpeters at the Iridium on Tuesday night didn't.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Blind Faith'

title: When Pocket Money, Literally, Is All That One Has Left
description: Last month, Ron Rogers received a $1,700 royalty check for an old hit song. It was the only money that Mr. Rogers, a struggling songwriter, had made since his recording studio on Sullivan Street failed in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMIETANA, THOMAS (TONY)
description: SMIETANA-Thomas (Tony). On January 8, 1998. Survived by two brothers and one sister. Also survived by long time companion. Reading Supervisor for the New York Lighthouse for the Blind. Reposing, Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday, at 10:00 A.M., Blessed Sacrament Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELSERE, ARTURO
description: BELSERE-Arturo. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, Jan. 13 at 1 PM at The Garment Center Congregation, 205 W. 40th St, NYC.

title: Leaf-Blower Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Is Accused Of Beating a Colleague
description: A lawyer for minority police organizations charged that a black narcotics officer was beaten during an undercover operation by a white member of his team whom he had known for six months. The lawyer said that the attack was deliberate and reflected a culture of bias in the Police Department. Police officials said the white officer had merely mistaken his colleague for a suspect.

title: In a Rush of New Films, Some Unsung Virtues
description: It's getting to be ridiculous the way Hollywood, gearing up for the Academy Awards derby, saves its most prestigious movies for release late in the year, especially around Christmas. After a 10-month drought, suddenly there are too many titles to choose from. It gets even more complicated after New Year's when, in the post-Christmas doldrums, worthy films that were out of release suddenly reappear for brief engagements to remind academy voters of their existence.

title: Uncertainty Over Earnings Batters Stocks for Third Day
description: Uncertainty about the prospects for earnings growth of American companies touched off another wave of selling across Wall Street yesterday, pushing stocks lower for the third day in a row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, RUTH
description: COOPER-Ruth. On January 6, in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Alex. Devoted mother of Sheila Cooper-Hanna and Roger. Cherished grandmother of Zachary Cooper. Loving sister of Belle Walker and Herman Springer. A private celebration of her life will be held by her immediate family. She will always be treasured and remembered by her family and many dear friends.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Abstraction'

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Little Lights Of Broadway

title: Born in a Dancer's Therapy, The Definition of Outsider
description: Art rarely strays far from life, from the feelings and character of the person who makes it. But sometimes it sticks so close to individual experience as to become a virtual shadow, different in substance but identical in outline.

title: No Ewing. No Starks? And Bulls Are Next
description: The Knicks were pasted to a Chicago Bulls game film after practice today, studying it as closely as a detective dusting for prints. About the same time, Patrick Ewing's car disappeared from the parking lot at SUNY-Purchase. He had hung out with the team, but there was no need to attend a film session for the star whose wrist is locked in a cast.

title: Scant Justice In the Killing Of a Daughter
description: BEAR in mind the wall inscription above the judge's head when considering whether justice was done yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. ''Law,'' it said, ''is the embodiment of the moral sentiment of the people.''

title: New Video Releases
description: Children of the Revolution

title: Miscellany
description: -- Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, renewed its sponsorship of the Rugby World Cup for the next two tournaments, in 1999 and 2003. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Joint Trial to Be Sought In Oklahoma in Bomb Case
description: As lawyers prepared recommendations for Judge Richard P. Matsch of Federal District Court on the sentencing of Terry L. Nichols in the Oklahoma City bombing conspiracy, prosecutors in Oklahoma City said today that they wanted a joint trial for Mr. Nichols and Timothy J. McVeigh on 160 charges of first-degree murder, early in 1999.

title: Switzer Is Out, Report Says
description: Barry Switzer, who took the majority of the blame for the Dallas Cowboys' 6-10 season and failure to reach the playoffs for the first time since 1989, has reached an agreement with the owner Jerry Jones to step down as coach, The Associated Press reported last night.

title: A Sad Life, Through Thick Glasses, Wittily
description: THE WORLD MORE OR LESS

title: New Charges in Beating Linked to a Heart Attack
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager accused of beating a teacher's aide in November was charged with manslaughter after autopsy results linked the beating to the man's fatal heart attack, according to an indictment released by the Kings County District Attorney's office yesterday.

title: ANTIQUES
description: There'll Always Be a France

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: CBS Use of Gordeyeva Goes Way Beyond Ice
description: With last night's coverage of the United States Figure Skating Championships, ABC's Peggy Fleming began her 21st year as one of the event's analysts. Thirty years ago, she easily won Olympic gold in Grenoble, France, long before pixies like Tara Lipinski and Michelle Kwan came to dominate the sport.

title: Malaysian Deficit Narrows in Quarter
description: Malaysia's current account deficit narrowed to 1.9 billion ringgit ($410 million) in the third quarter of last year, from 5.7 billion ringgit in the preceding quarter, the state news agency Bernama reported yesterday. The deficit is also narrower than the 2.8 billion ringgit deficit recorded in the third quarter of 1996, the news agency said, citing the Department of Statistics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIPPEL, REV. DAVID E.
description: SIPPEL-Rev. David E., S.J. Beloved brother of Marcia Barnes. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel, Murray-Weigel Hall in Fordham University, Fri. 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 11:30 A.M., Murray-Weigel Chapel. For information Farenga Bros Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.

title: What Can Consumers Do to Insure Food Safety?; Organic Labeling Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work
description: The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget ''is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged'' and that surpluses should start piling up soon.

title: ARDEN REALTY IN $614 MILLION DEAL FOR 50 PROPERTIES
description: Arden Realty Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 50 office and industrial properties from the AEW/LBA Acquisition Company for $614.5 million in cash and securities, increasing its presence in Southern California. The properties contain 5.2 million square feet and are in San Diego, Orange, Los Angeles, Ventura, Riverside and San Bernardino Counties. The shares of Arden, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., fell $1 yesterday, to $29.875. AEW/LBA Acquisition is a joint venture between Layton-Belling & Associates, a real estate investment and management company based in Newport Beach, Calif., and AEW Partners L.P., a Boston-based real estate investment and advisory firm. The purchase will increase Arden's holdings by about 50 percent, to 125 properties and 16.1 million square feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENDELL, JASON JOSEPH
description: RENDELL-Jason Joseph. Of Dover suddenly on Monday, January 5th, 1998. Beloved son of Kenneth William Rendell of Dover and Diana J. Rendell of Newton. Devoted brother of Jeffrey Harry Rendell of Newton. Also survived by a stepmother Shirley McNerney of Dover and a sister Julia Louis Rendell also of Dover. Other family members include two uncles Robert Christopher Rendell and Joe Angelo, and an aunt Mary Ellen Cobb Rendell. A Funeral Service will be held in the Marsh Chapel at Boston University on Saturday, January 10, 1998 at 11 A.M. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend. For information J.S. Waterman and SonsEastman-Waring 495 Commonwealth Avenue Boston, Massachusetts 02215.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEENEY, JIM
description: FEENEY-Jim. All his long term friends and colleagues at ABC Sports mourn the death of ''Doc'' who passed away on January 6, after a long and valiant battle. His strength throughout his ordeal strengthened each and every one of us at ABC Sports. To know Jim was to experience the true meaning of ''first class.'' A pioneer in the world of Network Sports Television, he served in many capacities during his career at ABC which started in 1959. Jim graduated from Notre Dame in 1958 and kept the fighting Irish with him right up to the end. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Barbara, and his daughter Barbara Colleen, who devoted every ounce of energy to Jim in his final days. The time and place of a Memorial Service will be announced in the near future. ''Doc,'' we'll see you on the first tee.

title: HOUSE OF GRAFT: Tracing the Bhutto Millions -- A special report.; Bhutto Clan Leaves Trail of Corruption
description: A decade after she led this impoverished nation from military rule to democracy, Benazir Bhutto is at the heart of a widening corruption inquiry that Pakistani investigators say has traced more than $100 million to foreign bank accounts and properties controlled by Ms. Bhutto's family.

title: N.J. Airport Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Diplomatic, Not Ambassadorial
description: So Bill Clinton has apparently picked somebody else to be the Ambassador to Mexico. That did not stop MAURICE SONNENBERG, an investment counselor whose name surfaced fairly late in the search for potential nominees, from sending in his R.S.V.P. for the buffalo-chili pit stop on the President's money-raising marathon yesterday in Manhattan. Mr. Sonnenberg was in the lunchtime crowd that filled the Dakota apartment of JANE ROSENTHAL, the president of ROBERT DE NIRO'S TriBeCa Productions, and her husband, CRAIG M. HATKOFF.

title: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work
description: The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget ''is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged'' and that surpluses should start piling up soon.

title: Guardian Insurance's Plan Adds to Downtown Rebirth
description: After scouring Manhattan for nearly two years, the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America signed a letter of intent yesterday to move its headquarters and 1,500 employees to 7 Hanover Square in lower Manhattan from Union Square.

title: Jack F. Grimm, 72, Is Dead; A Seeker of Oil and Legends
description: Jack F. Grimm, a flamboyant West Texas wildcatter who found his share of oil in Texas and Oklahoma but had less luck searching for Sasquatch in the Pacific Northwest, the Abominable Snowman in Nepal, the Loch Ness Monster in Scotland, Noah's Ark in Turkey and the Titanic in the North Atlantic, died on Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Abilene, Tex. He was 72 and had insisted to the end that he really had discovered the ark and had been the first to find the Titanic.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, WILLIAM JAMES
description: BURKE-William James. Bill passed away in his sleep on January 7 after a year long bout with cancer. Bill was born on August 30, 1927. After living most of his first 50 years in and around New York, he spent the last 20 years of his life living in Irving, Texas. Bill was a veteran of W.W. II and the Korean War and a graduate of Fordham Law School in NYC. His spirit and love of life were infectious, whether it was enjoying a good drink, having a smoke, or telling an offcolor joke at the most inopportune time, he always enjoyed himself and made sure those around him did the same. His sense of humor was undeniable. Bill was preceded in death by a brother, James Edmund Burke, and five sisters: Rose Browne, Marion McGrath, Jean Frances Burke, Ruth Burke and Eileen Burke. He is survived by his loving wife Eleanor, sons James and Peter, daughter-in-law Debbie, grandchildren Cody and Taelor, sister Jeanne Muller and Frances Todd and a great number of loving family members including his loving if not obedient dog Gonzo. There will be only one quite like Bill Burke. He will be deeply missed.

title: Wild Selling Sends Stocks Tumbling on Asia Markets
description: Southeast Asian markets tumbled further today after a panicky selloff Thursday, frightened by a worsening crisis in Indonesia, relentless currency turmoil and a leading bond-rating agency's downgrading of some Thai debt to nearly junk status.

title: Sports of The Times; Accorsi Can Always Refer to the Log
description: WITH a Giants banner and 19 mostly successful seasons behind him, George Young had talked and answered questions for a half-hour in the Stadium Club but now he turned to introduce the ''best man'' to succeed him, Ernie Accorsi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELSON, LEONARD R.
description: MICHELSON-Leonard R. Beloved husband for 57 years of Josephine. Devoted father and best friend of son Leslie and daughter Nancy Ben-Dror. Beloved grandfather of Emily, David and Daniel. His character and indomitable spirit were a source of great joy and inspiration to all. May this very good man rest in eternal peace. Service at 12 noon Sunday, January 11, 1998, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: Algeria Killings: Brutal Ritual Defies Logic
description: There is an air of gruesome ritual to the Algerian conflict. Each year, with the onset of Ramadan, the killing intensifies, and with the massacres come unresolved questions about responsibility and an international outcry. But the ritual cannot mask the fact that the war has changed character.

title: Cisneros Asserts Innocence in Case Involving Ex-Mistress
description: Henry G. Cisneros, President Clinton's first Housing Secretary, came to Federal court here today to assert his innocence, rejoining his former mistress in a criminal case over whether the couple had conspired to mislead Federal agents about their relationship.

title: Newark Airport Record: A Million Tons of Cargo
description: The volume of cargo passing through Newark International Airport exceeded one million tons for the first time last year, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ellsworth Kelly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICARIELLO, SUZAN
description: PICARIELLO - Suzan. Beloved friend, colleague, sister, daughter, wife and mother. Died in a plane crash in Indonesia December 19, 1997. Memorial mass St. Andrews R.C. Church, Foley Square, New York, January 12th at 10AM.

title: Yanks Sign Strawberry, With Many Incentives
description: Although Darryl Strawberry insists he is beyond the proving stage in his baseball career, the veteran outfielder yesterday signed a one-year contract with the Yankees that challenged him to show he is once again capable of being a productive player.

title: Rangers Pay As Leetch Accidentally Sits One Out
description: Last week, in a game against Washington, Rangers Coach Colin Campbell made a point by sitting Brian Leetch for about 11 minutes. It was a hint to the captain to improve his play. It seemed to work, even last night, when Leetch scored on the first Ranger shot to give his team a 1-0 lead against the same Capitals at Madison Square Garden.

title: AT&T to Pay $11.3 Billion For Teleport
description: In an attempt to ride the current turmoil in the telecommunications industry back into the local phone business, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Teleport Communications Group Inc., one of the nation's largest alternate local telephone companies, for $11.3 billion in stock.

title: Aston Becomes a Lab For Ford's Technology
description: SOMETHING about Aston Martin seems to foster experimentation. Modified by Q, the gadget guru in Her Majesty's Secret Service, a model DB5 often saved Agent 007's hide with an ejector seat, wheel hubs that shredded villains' tires, machine guns hidden behind the lights and a screen that deflected bullets.

title: What Can Consumers Do to Insure Food Safety?; Company Took Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEREFF, HENRY DAVID
description: SHEREFF-Henry David. The Directors and members of the Townsend Harris Alumni Association are deeply saddened by the death of Henry Shereff, a founder and past president of the Alumni Association, and a member of the Townsend Harris Hall of Fame. Gentle, kind and generous, Henry Shereff was one of the driving forces behind the re-opening of Townsend Harris as a leading public high school in New York. To his wife, Meta, and their three sons and granddaughter we send our love and condolences. Those wishing to contribute to a scholarship fund being established in his memory may do so by sending a check to the Townsend Harris Alumni Association, Box 1274, Gracie Station, New York, NY 10028.

title: German Church Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPLETE BUSINESS AGREES TO ACQUIRE C. W. COSTELLO
description: Complete Business Solutions Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire C. W. Costello & Associates, a privately held company based in Weathersfield, Conn., in a stock swap valued at more than $70 million. Complete Business, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., is an information technology consulting business. Under the agreement, Complete Business will give Costello shareholders 1.7 million shares of Complete Business stock in exchange for 12 offices in Chicago, Tampa, Fla., Charlotte, N.C., Columbus, Ohio, and the New England area. The Costello offices manage about 200 accounts that generate annual revenue of about $70 million. Complete Business's shares rose $1.50 each, to $42.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVESEN, THEODORE B.
description: LEVESEN-Theodore B. On January 7, 1998. Devoted companion of John Cubba. A memorial service will be announced at a later time.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Peregrine Revising Deal With Zurich
description: Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to revise the terms under which the Zurich Insurance Company, Europe's fourth-largest insurer, will buy a stake in one of Asia's biggest investment banks.

title: Barington Capital to Acquire Most of D. H. Blair's Assets
description: Barington Capital Group L.P., a New York investment bank, agreed yesterday to acquire most of the assets of D. H.Blair & Company, a brokerage firm under investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work
description: The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget ''is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged'' and that surpluses should start piling up soon.

title: Metro Business; Reckson Buys More Sites
description: The Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, N.Y., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy six office and industrial properties on Long Island for $62 million, its second acquisition in the New York metropolitan region this week.

title: WTA Is Ready To Name New Chief
description: Stung by the decision by Ric Clarson, the 40-year-old PGA Tour vice president appointed last month to be chief executive officer of the Corel WTA Tour, board members of the women's professional tennis tour moved swiftly this week. The WTA Tour is expected to introduce Bart McGuire, an Oregon-based lawyer who has been the tour's business and legal adviser for the past decade, as its c.e.o. on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, HOWARD
description: GILMAN-Howard. The partners of Grant Thornton LLP express their deepest sympathy on the passing of Howard Gilman, a dear client, a patron of the arts and a great philanthropist.

title: Police Cover-Up Is Asserted In Beating of Black Officer
description: A lawyer for minority police organizations charged yesterday that a black undercover narcotics officer was beaten in a buy-and-bust operation in Brooklyn last month by a white member of his team whom he had known for six months, and that supervisors had destroyed and changed reports to cover up the incident.

title: Master at the Noble Art of Supplying Water
description: THE call about the water-main break came at 5 in the morning -- a bad break, flooding lower Fifth Avenue. And on the half-hour drive from his New Jersey home into the city, with his waders and hard hat in the trunk, Douglas Greeley worried the worries he always has when he gets such a call: Will they be able to shut down the leak quickly? Will somebody drown? Is a building going to cave in?

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul Shambroom

title: The Neediest Cases; Son Needs Help in Dealing With Father's Death
description: The ground was torn open like a dirty wound and, Jonathan Lindao remembers, his grandmother tried to leap into the hole, wailing as his father's coffin disappeared into the earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLIN, SIDNEY
description: WOLIN-Sidney. On January 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Susan, devoted father of Lauree Mitchell, James and Ronald. Services today 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, NORMAN
description: DIAMOND-Norman, Dr. On January 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Martha and Dr. Michael Diamond, Miriam Diamond-Barber, Dr. Elaine Diamond-Ford. Devoted brother of Joan Diamond. Cherished grandfather of Jessie Diamond. Professor on the staff of New York Medical College, affilliated with the Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital. Medical Officer for 24 years with the New York City Fire Department, affiliated with The City of Hope. Services Friday, in Florida.

title: Excerpts From Statements in Court
description: Following are excerpts from statements yesterday by Ramzi Ahmed Yousef and by Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy of Federal District Court in Manhattan. The transcript was provided by the court.

title: Sorry I Left You, Dr. J Tells the Nets
description: Even in the setting of what was basically a class reunion, 22 years after the fact, Julius Erving still stood out. That is pretty much guaranteed when you happen to have been the greatest player of your generation, not to mention the signature superstar of a flamboyant rebel league.

title: Bonds Up 5th Time in 6 Sessions As Foreign Money Seeks Refuge
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday for the fifth time in six sessions, in a rally driven largely by foreign investors seeking refuge from the turmoil of Asian markets. The rally advanced after a Federal Reserve official suggested that the Asian crisis could lead to lower United States interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, BARNETT
description: SCHNEIDER-Barnett. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth-El, Cedarhurst, New York, and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of its member. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Allan Kroningold, President

title: Franklin Jacobs Has Been Located
description: Howard Schmertz, the meet director of the Chase Millrose Games, said on Wednesday that he could not find Franklin Jacobs, the 5-foot-8-inch high jumper who set a world indoor record of 7 feet 7i inches in this meet 20 years ago. Schmertz wanted to honor him at this year's Millrose Games on Feb. 13 in Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSKAY, SHIRA
description: RUSKAY-Shira. The Trustees and staff of The Jewish Museum express profound sadness at the death of Shira Ruskay, an exceptional person much admired for her beauty and spirituality. Our sincere condolences to her husband John, a former member of The Jewish Museum Board through his position as Vice Chancellor of The Jewish Theological Seminary of America. We mourn this loss with our friend and colleague John and convey our condolences to his and Shira's children Doron, Ilana and her husband Scott, and all of their family and friends. Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Philip A. Laskawy, President Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: Queens Democrats Scramble to Be Named Candidate for Congress
description: As Democratic officials in Queens prepare today to select their candidate for one of the borough's Congressional seats, the maneuvering to succeed former Representative Floyd H. Flake in Washington has intensified, with several aspirants scrambling for last-minute support.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Messages Woven, Sewn Or Floating in the Air
description: Fiber art is an unalluring name for one of postwar America's more fruitful esthetic trends. As a movement, it coalesced in the late 1960's and 70's, when many artists were turning their backs on male-dominated forms like painting and sculpture to explore low-art, craft-intensive materials, textiles chief among them.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Metro News Briefs column yesterday about state control of some New Jersey public school systems misidentified the one that would remain under that control. As the article said, it is the Newark system, not Trenton's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, ESTHER
description: LEFKOWITZ-Esther. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of our esteemed member and extends to the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Stanley Lewis

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am a terrorist and I am proud of it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, LAWRENCE R.
description: KAHN-Lawrence R., 85. Died on Dec. 18, 1997 in Bandon, OR. Longtime resident of New Rochelle, NY. Survived by his wife, sculptor Helen Beling; daughters Kathe Mayer and Victoria Tierney, and by three grandchildren. Mr. Kahn was past president of the New York Society of Security Analysts, and served on the Board of Trustees of the Phi Beta Kappa Associates and the George Junior Republic. He was a graduate of CCNY and Columbia University. Donations in his name may be made to the George Junior Republic, 218 Freeville Rd, Freeville, NY 13068 and to the Women Business Owners Fund, 1979 E. 55th St, Cleveland, OH 44103. Memorial service to be held in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCK, EDWIN AUGUSTUS
description: BUCK-Edwin Augustus. Age 69 of Mendham, NJ on January 6, 1998. Husband of Joan Banghart Buck. Father of Karen, Stephen and Linda. Brother of Robert Buck and Jane Hellawell. Memorial gifts may be made to NJ Conservation Foundation, Far Hills, NJ.

title: President Names 15 for Nation's Top Civilian Honor
description: President Clinton today announced that he would award the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor, to an eclectic group of 15 notables, including Brooke Astor, the New York philanthropist; Sol M. Linowitz, the international lawyer who has served in a variety of special diplomatic posts; Prof. Robert Coles, the Harvard psychiatrist and author, and Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, who died last year.

title: Solution Announced to an Obscure Environmental Problem: the Television
description: The Federal Government and the electronics industry agreed today to fix an environmental problem that is found in almost every American home -- and one that almost nobody knows about.

title: OLYMPICS: WINTER SPORTS
description: MEN'S SLALOM

title: Pesky Knights Topple Blackbirds
description: FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON 110, LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY 100

title: Mexican Restaurants
description: New York has never been known for its Mexican restaurants. In the last decade, though, as the number of Mexican immigrants has increased, little Mexican restaurants have opened around the city. They offer the sort of authentic street fare that cities like Los Angeles and Chicago have long taken for granted, and they provide a counterpoint to the handful of more ambitious restaurants that offer grander Mexican cuisine. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: A top woman executive who abruptly left Thompson re-emerges at D.M.B.& B.
description: A TOP woman executive who recently left one big agency in a stormy exit has joined another, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, as part of that agency's efforts to better interpret consumer behavior and thereby improve the marketing of brand-name products.

title: Judge Wins Mostly Praise for His Low-Profile Style
description: After a Federal jury deadlocked over the sentencing of Terry L. Nichols, some families of the victims of the Oklahoma City bombing lashed out at the judge, Richard P. Matsch, calling him a weak man who gave too much leeway to the defense.

title: S.E.C. Says Brokerage Firm Engaged in 'Yield Burning'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had accused Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, a large regional brokerage firm, and a former employee, of defrauding investors and the State of Arizona in a 1992 municipal finance deal.

title: What Can Consumers Do to Insure Food Safety?; Myth of Rotten Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: In New York City, 1997 was an extraordinary year for restaurants. It was a time when talented chefs and restaurateurs had the courage to reconsider the notion of what makes a restaurant great.

title: U.S. Pursues Deportation Of Haitians
description: The Government's immigration lawyers and judges are continuing to pursue deportation cases against Haitian immigrants, despite a Presidential order issued two weeks ago to exempt as many as 20,000 Haitians from strict new deportation rules for at least a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, REV. EDWARD F.
description: CLARK-Rev. Edward F., S.J. Former President of St. Peter's College. Beloved brother of Rev. Francis X. Clark, S.J. Dear uncle of Barbara Vittoria, JoAnn Mahoney, Patricia Weishaar, and James Clark. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Loyola Hall, Fordham University, Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at the Fordham University Church, Saturday, 10:30 AM. For information, call Farenga Bros. Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERRENDER, GIRARD, M.D.
description: OBERRENDER-Girard, M.D. The Lenox Hill Hospital Alumni Association deeply regrets the passing of Girard Oberrender, M.D., esteemed member of the Department of Otolaryngology since January 1, 1921. He has remained on the Honorary Staff to the present time. He died on January 7, 1998 at the age of 104 and is survived by his son and daughterin-law, Girard and Marty Oberrender. Dr. Oberrender received the Distinguished Alumnus Award in 1983 from the LHH Alumni Association. He was a dedicated physician, teacher and mentor. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Peter Bruno, M.D., President LHH Alumni Association Peter Baiocco, M.D., Secretary LHH Alumni Association

title: Pizzeria Owner Gets 17 1/2 Years in Drug Case
description: The owner of a pizzeria in Mount Laurel was sentenced yesterday to 17 1/2 years in prison for using his business as a front for selling hundreds of thousands of dollars a week of heroin and cocaine.

title: Residential Real Estate; Queens Hotel Converted To Complex for Elderly
description: The Midway Hotel, built to accommodate visitors to the New York World's Fair of 1964-65, is a fixture along the Horace Harding Expressway in Queens. Now it is nearing the end of a transformation to rental housing for the elderly.

title: Algeria's Unending Civil War
description: For the first time since the outbreak of widespread Algerian political violence in 1992, it seems possible that outside investigators may be allowed to examine who is responsible for the slaughter and how better to protect the civilian population. Pressure for such an inquiry has mounted as a new wave of killings has left as many as 1,000 Algerians dead since the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan on Dec. 30. It is vital that the international community continue to press for an exacting and unflinching investigation.

title: Devils' Owner Courting Nets?
description: Some of the seven owners of the Nets will meet in Manhattan this morning with John McMullen, the Devils' owner, but he did not specify the subject, according to people with knowledge of the gathering.

title: Observer; Horatio Alger's Children
description: I want to be a dynamic corporation boss. Then the newspapers would run my picture wearing this incredibly expensive suit. It would be a hand-stitched suit. I would know what hand-stitched means.

title: Man Held in Fatal Fight At First Ave. Restaurant
description: Detectives investigating the case of a 46-year-old man who fell into a coma and died after having been punched in a fight in a restaurant have arrested a 22-year-old man on charges of manslaughter, the police said yesterday.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Wang's World In a Love Story

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, PHYLLIS
description: WALLACH-Phyllis. The officers and members of the United Federation of Teachers mourn the loss of a revered officer, a remarkable teacher, a respected pension expert and a beloved colleague and friend. She served her union and all its members brilliantly as a teacher member of the Retirement Board where her caring concern for members drove every decision. Her dignity, her dedication, her wisdom and her patience in advising UFT members will be remembered personally by the thousands she helped at crucial points in their lives. We will sorely miss her counsel, her knowledge and her infinite common sense. Our deepest sympathies to her husband Victor, her children, Barbara, Rebecca, and Steven, and her daughter-in-law, Ilana. Sandra Feldman, President United Federation of Teachers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUFFANTI, PAUL
description: GUFFANTI-Paul. On Jan. 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Olga. Devoted father of Paul Jr. and Arthur. Fond brother of Theresa Craven. Dear father-in-law of Carole Ann. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York on Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian burial at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, on Saturday, at 10 A.M.

title: Transit Agency Planning To Reprogram Turnstiles
description: Concerned that people are figuring out how to alter their Metrocards to get free rides, transit officials said yesterday that they would reprogram all 3,000-plus subway turnstiles by next week. But the change could make it harder for passengers to swipe damaged Metrocards, transit officials acknowledged, inconveniencing what they said would be a small fraction of riders.

title: The Extra Kick of Sailing in Winter
description: Weather: Temperatures in the mid-30's; winds westerly at 15 to 25 knots with frequent gusts to 30-35 knots; wave height, 2 feet or greater; water temperature, 48 degrees.

title: Two Promising Picks in Mexico
description: Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo, has announced two crucial Cabinet changes in recent days that encourage hopes for greater democracy and accountability. He named a new Interior Minister, replacing Emilio Chuayffet with Francisco Labastida Ochoa. Mr. Chuayffet represented the worst traditions of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. Mr. Zedillo also appointed Jose Angel Gurria to replace Guillermo Ortiz as Finance Minister, the Cabinet's top economic position.

title: Fighting Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Two Brokers Plead Guilty
description: Two more employees of A. R. Baron & Company pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that they helped swindle investors out of $75 million.

title: Owen Bradley, Country Music Producer, Dies at 82
description: Owen Bradley, a producer, musician and songwriter who helped establish Nashville as the creative center of country music, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Nashville. He was 82.

title: How Amazing, the Way I Learned to Drive
description: As anyone who has successfully weathered the application process at the Department of Motor Vehicles can vouch for, there are few things as satisfying as learning how to drive a car sufficiently well that a representative of the state is led to utter the two sweetest words in the D.M.V. vocabulary: ''You passed.'' As someone who has taken three such tests over several decades, I am living proof.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, SAM (PEARL)
description: PERLMAN-Sam (Pearl). On Wed., Dec. 31, 1997. Many people lost a friend and community activist in the passing of Sam. He was a strong voice against injustice and for the rights of those who were under-served or voiceless, from veterans to the homeless, tenants to the rights of animals. He will be missed. He would want it known how much he loved his daughters, Marcy and Edina, his grandchildren, Java, Levi, NikiLee and Remi and his sister Bea. A Memorial will be held Sunday, January 11, 1998 at 11:00 AM at the Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23rd Street.

title: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work
description: The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget ''is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged'' and that surpluses should start piling up soon.

title: German Rubber Purchase
description: The M. A. Hanna Company agreed today to buy the German rubber and plastic processor Melos Carl Bosch G.m.b.H. & Company to expand its rubber compounding business in Europe. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The transaction is first rubber-compounding purchase in Europe by Hanna, which is based here. Melos, with a plant in Melle, Germany, makes rubber compounds used in the manufacture of wire and cable, sports equipment and cars. It had estimated 1997 sales of $30 million.

title: More Fallout From Lamp Fire
description: A year to the day after his music-filled apartment was destroyed by fire, LIONEL HAMPTON, the jazz vibraphonist, filed a $30 million lawsuit against the importer of the halogen lamp blamed for starting the blaze and two retailers. Actually, his lawyers filed the papers; Mr. Hampton, 89, was on tour in Bern, Switzerland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, WILLIAM B.
description: WARNER-William B. Died on January 5, 1998 at home after a short illness. He was 81 years old. Born in Bad Axe, MI. Mr. Warner lived for many years in Brooklyn and Garden City, NY, moving to Mattituck, NY in 1986 and to Lake Wales, FL in 1995. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Polytech and of Stevens Institute in 1940. Mr. Warner was employed at Consolidated Edison, NY from 1946 retiring in 1983. Prior to that he was employed at Westinghouse Electric. Surviving are his loving extended family; his wife Margaret Vanston Warner, six daughters, two sons, 8 grandchildren, 2 great grandchildren and many friends. Mr. Warner was predeceased in 1995 by his wife, Marian Carleton Warner. Funeral services are Saturday, January 10, at 10 A.M. at the Church of the Good Shepherd, Lake Wales, FL, and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the American Theatre Organ Society Scholarship Fund, C/O Dorothy Van Steenkiste, 9270 Reeck Road, Allen Park, Michigan 48101-1461.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Go Easy on the Butter
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast Forward: Laser or DVD?
description: In its spate of prognostications for 1998, the video business has elongated its view all the way to the year 2001. By then, according to projections issued by the I.T.A. (formerly the International Tape/Disk Association, a trade group), the growth of laser disk will have shrunk to almost nothing. By contrast, the group says, quantities of compact digital video disks (DVD's) will have ballooned from 5.5 million in 1997 to nearly 400 million in 2001 and the number of DVD players, now about 350,000, will have jumped to 6.5 million.

title: Time Is Right: Young Leaves Giants for N.F.L. Job
description: George Young stepped down after 19 seasons as the Giants' general manager today, asking that he be remembered for a body of work that brought the team two Super Bowl championships, but more significant, restored the luster to a once-slumbering franchise.

title: Anand Wins to Tie Match And Force a Blitz Playoff
description: Viswanathan Anand mustered some hard-hitting positional maneuvering to topple Anatoly Karpov in the critical Game 6 of their International Chess Federation match yesterday. Karpov only needed a draw to win the series, pick up $1.3 million, and, very likely, a title match with Gary Kasparov, but the ingenious Indian grandmaster would not let him have it. He'd just as soon take on Kasparov himself.

title: The Queen of Ethnic Nightmares; Cultural Politics Mires Statue of Borough's Namesake
description: Among the homeless of New York, there is none more conspicuous than Catherine of Braganza. The Portuguese princess stands five stories high and is bronzed, bejeweled and highlighted with gold leaf. She cost about $2 million to create.

title: Broncos' Quiet Line Plays Judge And Jury
description: They sit in their own corner of the Denver locker room. They run their own kangaroo court where infractions are punishable with fines: $5 for mental mistakes in practice, $10 for talking to the news media, up to $3,000 for a ''prima donna'' transgression. The Broncos' offensive linemen began lowering their profile and administering the fines last season as a way to create an all-for-one mentality. In becoming Denver's taciturn five justices, they have also become an increasingly tough bunch to get to know. Even to their teammates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOPATO, DR. ESTHER W.
description: LOPATO-Dr. Esther W. On January 7, 1998, after a long and determined battle with illness. She lived her life with gusto, guts and a sense of humor. She treasured her family and friends, and served her community with tremendous energy and devotion. Survived by her children Leslie and David, their spouses Skip Getz and Barbara Lopato, and her beloved grandchildren Ariana and Misha. Funeral services at Garlick Funeral Home, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn, today, 12 Noon. Contributions may be made to the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation, Esther W. Lopato Fund, Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn, New York 11238.

title: What Can Consumers Do to Insure Food Safety?; Farm Workers' Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: Storms Punish Vast Region From the South to Canada
description: A storm system that had hovered over the Plains states socked the Eastern Seaboard yesterday, swelling rivers and flooding roads in the South, pelting New England with freezing rain and knocking out power to more than a million people in upstate New York, New England and eastern Canada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLHO, RELLY RACHEL
description: MOLHO-Relly Rachel. On January 7, 1998 in New York City, age ninety-two. Adored wife of the late Vitalis Molho and beloved aunt of Renee Conforte McKee. Funeral at 11:15 AM, Friday, January 9th, Riverside Memorial, 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTLER, LESLIE B.
description: COTLER-Leslie B., 59 years. Passed peacefully after a long battle with cancer. Loving husband of Harriet (nee Young). Cherished father of Jennifer, Richard and Robyn Cotler and Rebecca and Rodney Nenner. Son of Esther. Brother of Howard. Grandfather of Michael, Jonathan and Benjamin. Services at Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55 St., N.Y.C., 10 AM Friday. Donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Foundation in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUKEY, ELIZABETH RAPP
description: TUKEY-Elizabeth Rapp, 77. Died peacefully January 6 in Princeton, New Jersey from breast cancer. Preservationist, antiques expert, guider of the young. Cherished wife of husband John, beloved by sister Phyllis Anscombe, three nephews, one niece, two grandnieces. The lifelong blessing of her manifold gifts to family and friends mitigates our profound sorrow. The funeral service will be Saturday January 10, 1:30 P.M. at Trinity Episcopal Church, Princeton. Interment private. For information Kimble Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made, with mention in memory of Elizabeth Tukey, to ''The UVa Fund,'' P.O. Box 3446 (Attn: J. Wright), Charlottesville, VA 22903.

title: Whitman Agrees to 65 M.P.H. Limit on Many Roads
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders reached agreement today on the broad outlines of a plan that would increase the speed limit on large stretches of roads in the state to 65 miles per hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILER, HANNA
description: WEILER-Hanna. On January 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Weiler. Loving mother of the late Henry Weiler. Devoted grandmother of Pamela and Andrew. Dear mother-in-law of Eileen Weiler Judell. Sister of Lilli Levi and great grandmother of Deanna. Will also be greatly missed by Selma and Norton Charkin. Graveside service is at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, New Jersey today Friday, January 9, 11 AM.

title: Lumbering Brawley Lawsuit Is Stirred by Surprise Witness
description: A surprise witness testified today in the defamation case against the former advisers of Tawana Brawley that she had seen a black girl creep furtively into a plastic garbage bag and lie down on the ground on the same November day Ms. Brawley was discovered in that position.

title: AT&T Deal Provides Path to Local Service
description: AT&T has agreed to acquire Teleport Communications for $11.3 billion in stock.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Notable Notes'

title: FIGURE SKATING ; Upheaval at the Top: Kwan Nearly Perfect As Lipinski Tumbles
description: After a fitful night of tossing and turning, Michelle Kwan slept through her early-morning training session today. The spark of her absence kindled a bonfire of speculation. Had she withdrawn from the Olympic trials with a toe injury? No, she had not. Not only did Kwan later skate the short program, but seven of the nine judges also rated her presentation as perfect.

title: No Laughing Matter for 'Saturday Night Live' Anchor
description: Norm Macdonald, the sarcastic comedian who has been the anchor for the mock-news show ''Weekend Update'' on ''Saturday Night Live'' for four years, was replaced in his role on Wednesday, and he did not respond well. He fired off some comments about his NBC employers that may get him removed from the show altogether, network officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADFORD, JOHN CARROLL
description: BRADFORD-John Carroll. Retired Art Director, died at St. Vincent's Hospital on December 30, 1997 at 4:30AM of lung cancer. Mr. Bradford was VP and Art Director of Family Circle Magazine from 1970-1987 and was a member of The Art Director's Club of NY and The Society of Publication Designers. He lived at One Fifth Avenue and at 105 Buell Lane, East Hampton. Mr. Bradford, son of Fern Harden and Carroll Bradford, was born in Terre Haute, IN on June 27, 1924 and grew up in Dixon, IL. where he graduated from Dixon High School in 1942. He attended the University of Illinois from 1942-1943, the University of Minnesota from 1943-1944 and received his Bachelor's degree from the University of Illinois in 1948 in graphic design and architecture. He served in the U.S. Army Infantry from 1943-1945 in the European theater where he was awarded the Bronze Star. Mr. Bradford was a designer and later an Associate Director of design at Marshall Field and Co. in Chicago from 1949-1959. He was Art Director of Rockmore Advertising in NYC from 1960-1962 and was Art Director of CBS-Columbia Records from 1962-1964. From 1965-1970 Mr. Bradford was Art Director for Harlan Quist Books and was Art Director for Family Circle Special Publications. During the '80's he designed some award winning architecture books for its Rizzoli Publications. Surviving are a nephew, Bradford Guthrie of Englewood, CO., a niece, Paula J. Guthrie of Aurora, CO., and many friends who were his family. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, January 22, at 5:30 PM at the Art Director's Club, 250 Park Avenue South at 20th St. Memorial contributions may be made to the East Hampton Historical Society, 101 Main Street, East Hampton, New York 11937.

title: Consumers Trimmed Debt in November
description: Consumer borrowing unexpectedly declined in November, the first drop in more than four years, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Freezing the Schiele Paintings
description: When its exhibition of works by the Austrian painter Egon Schiele closed on Sunday, the Museum of Modern Art prepared to ship the contents of that exhibition back to its owner, the Leopold Museum in Vienna. But two of the Schiele works will now be staying in New York for the foreseeable future. These paintings -- ''Portrait of Wally'' and ''Dead City'' -- are claimed by heirs of their former owners, who were forced to abandon them when the Nazis entered Austria. On Wednesday the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, issued a subpoena that requires the Museum of Modern Art to hold these works until an investigation of their ownership has been completed.

title: Where Business Rules; Forging Global Regulations That Put Industry First
description: The gilded Palais des Nations in Geneva is a perfect setting for the elite group of industry executives and government regulators who regularly meet there to establish worldwide auto safety regulations for the next century. A sign marked ''Private'' prevented anyone not part of the official 90-member delegation from entering the last gathering held in November.

title: MARKETS TUMBLE AND RUMORS SWEEP INDONESIA CAPITAL
description: Fears of economic collapse and political turmoil shook Indonesia Thursday, with the currency and the stock market suffering their worst one-day losses, and with a wave of panic buying that emptied grocery shelves and forced some shops to close early.

title: National News Briefs; Defense Secretary Backs Renaming No. 2 Officer
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen has recommended the reappointment of the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Joseph W. Ralston, a Pentagon spokesman said today. General Ralston withdrew last year as a candidate for the chairman's job because of an adulterous affair in the 1980's.

title: Let Unabom Suspect Choose His Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Phones Suharto, Insisting on Commitment to I.M.F. Plan
description: In a measure of Washington's growing concern that the Asian crisis is worsening, President Clinton called President Suharto of Indonesia tonight to insist that his country put in place commitments to overhaul its economy, White House officials said.

title: TOYS 'R' US PLANS ANOTHER $1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the nation's largest toy retailer, said yesterday that it would buy back $1 billion of its stock. The company, based in Paramus, N.J., has already repurchased about 28 million shares under a separate $1 billion stock buyback announced in 1994. About $94 million of stock remains to be purchased under that program. Toys ''R'' Us had 288.7 million shares as of Nov. 1. The stock fell 56.25 cents a share yesterday, to $30.375. Separately, the company adopted a ''poison pill'' defense tactic intended to make hostile takeovers prohibitively expensive. The move would be triggered if an unwanted suitor acquired a 15 percent stake.

title: Corrections
