description: An article yesterday about an effort by Manhattan's District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, to bar the Museum of Modern Art from returning two Egon Schiele paintings to their lender in Austria, pending settlement of an ownership dispute, misstated part of a comment by a member of one family claiming ownership. Reacting to the news, Henry S. Bondi said, ''You know what Lenin said: Trust is good, control is better'' (not ''Justice good'').

title: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR WOES.
description: The Australian dollar fell to an 11-year low against the United States dollar, reaching 63 cents before rebounding in early trading yesterday. Australia, a major exporter to Asia, will suffer because of the economic slowdown expected there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, GREGORY W.
description: MURRAY-Gregory W. Age 32. Of Newtown, Connecticut, January 7, 1998. A Buyer for Lillian Vernon of New Rochelle, New York. Services Monday, January 12, 1998, 10 AM, at the Trinity Episcopal Church, Newtown, CT. (at the Flagpole). Calling hours are at The Honan Funeral Home, 58 Main Street, Newtown, Sunday, 2-5 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLD, BEATRICE
description: GOLD-Beatrice. Jan. 8, 1994. Our memories of you dear Mother are strong & vivid in our hearts & thoughts. You are with us every day...deeply loved & missed. Your children, San, Joel, Stephen

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: California Sues Farm Over Lettuce
description: The State of California yesterday filed a civil suit against a lettuce processor whose greens were linked to a 1996 outbreak of food poisoning that sickened at least 61 people in the Midwest and the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUDNER, BERNICE
description: BRUDNER-Bernice. On January 6, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Louis Brudner. Loving mother of Richard and his wife Roberta. Dear grandmother of Matthew and Jonathan. Sister of Vivian Strausbourger. Loving aunt and great aunt. Resident of New York City and Hollywood, Florida. Funeral Riverside Memorial Chapel, Friday, January 9, 10 AM.

title: MASTERMIND GETS LIFE FOR BOMBING OF TRADE CENTER
description: Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the man who masterminded the World Trade Center bombing five years ago, was sentenced yesterday to spend life plus 240 years in prison. And he defiantly proclaimed in court that ''I am a terrorist and I am proud of it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUSCHETTI, MARK
description: FUSCHETTI-Mark. A memorial service for Mark will be held on Saturday, January 10th. 1 PM, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, West 20th St. Bet: 8th & 9th Aves.

title: From the Latest Gadgetry, Creaks and 'Ah-ROO-gahs'
description: In an era when computers make it possible to create a limitless variety of sounds, what kinds of musicians would take the time to create their own new acoustic instruments? Some of the answers were seen and heard at ''Gravikords, Whirlies and Pyrophones,'' a concert on Wednesday night that inaugurated an exhibition (through Jan. 16) of experimental instruments at the World Financial Center's Winter Garden. A book and CD with the same title were released last year by Ellipsis Arts, which sponsored the concert.

title: Producer Prices Stay Tame, With 1.2% Drop Last Year
description: Producer prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December and 1.2 percent in the full year, the largest annual decrease in a decade, the Government said today.

title: IDEX AGREES TO BUY GAST MANUFACTURING FOR $118 MILLION
description: The Idex Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Gast Manufacturing Corporation for $118 million. Idex, based in Northbrook, Ill., makes fluid-handling and industrial products. Gast, a privately held company based in Benton Harbor, Mich., makes compressors, vacuum pumps, air motors and other products. The company has annual sales of about $100 million. Idex said it expected the acquisition to add to earnings during the first year of ownership. Idex's shares slipped 18.75 cents yesterday, to $34.3125.

title: Drugs or Alcohol Linked to 80% of Inmates
description: Illegal drugs and alcohol helped lead to the imprisonment of 4 out of 5 inmates in the nation's prisons and jails, a three-year study has found.

title: Measure to Raise Fees On Eel Fishing Gains
description: Hoping to discourage glass-eel fishermen from flocking to the Jersey Shore by the thousands, as they did last year, the Assembly passed a bill yesterday that would steeply raise licensing fees and enhance enforcement powers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, HERBERT
description: BERMAN-Herbert. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of our former Vice President Herbert Berman. During his tenure he served as Chair of the Finance Committee and provided leadership on behalf of the handicapped and disadvantaged. He was a dedicated Zionist and a true friend. We extend our sincere condolences to his beloved wife Daisy and the entire family. The Honorable Alan G. Hevesi, National President Michael J. Lazar, Chair, Bnai Zion Foundation Mel Parness, Executive V.P.

title: Leaf-Blower Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOGAN, NATHAN
description: KOGAN-Nathan. Cellist, attorney, friend and mentor of our Society. Your many years of dedication is legendary. Zara Nelsova, President Violoncello Society

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David. ''It avails not, time nor place-distance avails not, I am with you, you men and women of a generation, or ever so many generations hence, just as you feel when you look on the river and sky, so I felt, I too lived. Brooklyn of ample hills was mine, I too walked the streets of Manhattan Island, and bathed in the waters around it, I too felt the curious abrupt questionings stir within me.'' W. W. Whitman. Happy Birthday, Big D. Love, Peter, Peggy, Carey and Tom

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SABA PETROLEUM CO., Santa Maria, Calif., an energy company, said that it would hire an investment banker to help the company figure out how to increase its value.

title: Metro Business; Film Company Plans Studio in New Jersey
description: The movie production company that made the 1996 Academy-Award winning film ''Sling Blade'' has signed a 50-year lease for a 30-acre tract in Harrison, N.J., where it plans to build the largest film studio in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORMAN, DOROTHY HEALY
description: FLORMAN-Dorothy Healy. Of Fort Lauderdale, died January 6th in Fort Lauderdale. NYC native. Retired from Eastern Airlines in 1982. Alumna of Mt. St. Vincent College, NYC. Survived by sons Nils K. Jr., Miami; Mark, Fort Lauderdale; daughter Cynthia Hamre, Eden Prairie, MN; grandson John Hamre. For information Fred Hunter's Funeral Home, Fort Lauderdale.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Water Tower For Peace

title: N.F.L. Conference Championships
description: SUNDAY 12:30 P.M.

title: United Nations Journal; Iraq's Man Is at Home In Hostile Territory
description: Nizar Hamdoon, the voice of Iraq in the United States, is relishing a little downtime between crises. He doesn't expect the lull to last long, perhaps two more weeks.

title: Collision Averted Over Airport
description: A mistake by an air traffic controller nearly put two jumbo jets on a collision course in dense fog over Kennedy International Airport Wednesday, Federal Aviation Administration officials said yesterday.

title: For Drug Addicts: Treatment, Not Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: HICKS, MUSE, TATE IN DEAL TO SELL ITS GHIRARDELLI UNIT
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. has reached a tentative agreement to sell its Ghirardelli Chocolate unit to the Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Spruengli A.G. for an undisclosed price, according to documents filed with the Federal Government. Federal antitrust authorities have approved the transaction. The approval means the deal is valued at more than $10 million. A spokesman for Hicks, Muse declined to comment. Ghirardelli Chocolate, based in San Leandro, Calif., makes premium chocolates and produces cocoa powder and chocolate chips for bakers, coffee companies and food-service companies.

title: Tainted Journalist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders Unabom Suspect To Cooperate in Psychiatric Tests
description: After an extraordinary stop-and-start week in the Unabom trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski, the judge today scheduled a mental evaluation of Mr. Kaczynski and told him he would be sent to a Federal psychiatric institution for observation if he did not cooperate.

title: Bricks Falling at School Critically Injure Girl, 16
description: Moments after a dismissal bell sent children surging out of an elementary school in Brooklyn yesterday, bricks fell four stories from construction scaffolding, critically injuring a 16-year-old girl and sending dozens of other children into a panic.

title: Texas Tobacco Lawsuit Is Delayed as a Settlement Is Discussed
description: A Federal judge yesterday delayed the start of jury selection in the lawsuit filed by the State of Texas against the tobacco industry as parties in the case sought to resolve disputes that have impeded negotiations for a settlement.

title: Mets' Reed Just Wants to Be Ignored
description: Preferring anonymity, Mets pitcher Rick Reed found a haven in Ohio this off season. Reed and a friend donned camouflage and disappeared into the woods of Lawrence County, in search of white-tailed deer.

title: When Juries Lose Their Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSKAY, SHIRA
description: RUSKAY-Shira. The administration, faculty, students and boards of the Jewish Theological Seminary record with sorrow the death of Shira Ruskay, beloved wife, mother, daughter and sister. Our hearts go out to her husband, our friend and former vice chancellor John Ruskay; her parents, JTS alumnus Rabbi Sidney and Hilda Greenberg; and her entire family on the loss of this exemplary woman. May her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, ITA
description: LIBERMAN-Ita. Beloved wife of the late Abraham, devoted mother of Clare Chamow, and motherin-law of Arthur, dear sister of Morris Lieberman, and Hilda Hase, loving grandmother of Beth, Ruth and Lori and great grandmother. Services Sunday 10AM at ''Parkside Memorial Chapel'', 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Seeking to Halt Rutgers Skid, The Governor Sends In a Play
description: The Rutgers University football team has stumbled for years, but when it lost every game this last season, New Jersey's powerful sports and political establishments decided that enough was enough.

title: For Drug Addicts: Treatment, Not Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Sexes, Equality Under the Law and Under the Hair Clippers
description: It may pale beside the right to vote, expanded employment opportunities or corporate-subsidized child care, but a new law signed yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave women in New York City hope for liberation from a lingering, undeniably pesky manner of oppression.

title: INDONESIAN RUPIAH REBOUNDS.
description: The rupiah, which plunged 26 percent in value on Thursday, recovered, as investors welcomed efforts by the United States to insure that Indonesia's economic overhaul stays on track. The rupiah, which hit a record low of 10,550 rupiahs to the dollar, rose to 8,150.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, NANCY MILLER
description: ELLIOTT-Nancy Miller. Jazz photographer extraordinaire. A rare and special soul has joined G-d's flock above. Now reunited with her beloved Buck Clayton, heaven will surely swing. Danny-mite

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, LILEN
description: SANGER-Lilen. Died on January 8, 1998 at New York Hospital in her 91st year from complications following emergency surgery. It was her first major illness. She was the cherished mother of Sirgay and mother-in-law of Judy. The loving sister-in-law of Ethel and grandmother of Terry and Vicky. The great-grandmother of James and adoring aunt of Mitzi, Patricia, Liam, Cyrena, Stephany, Jonathan, Elizabeth, Gail, Mary Bryna, Diane and Michael. Great aunt of Priscilla, Elizabeth, Margaret, Erik, Cory, Sean, Evan, Regan, Geoffrey, Wendy, David, Kevin, Lorie Dru, Jared, Amy, Aaron, Jaron, Julia Anne, Jeffrey, Margot, Meredith, Jonathan, Matthew and Amanda. She loved the spouses of her family; Lew, Bill, Lee, Simmel, Judy, Carla, Al, Mark, Yakov, Larry and Francine. Her interest in her family organization, The Independent Family Society, founded in 1914 was lifelong. She attended most of its 800 meetings. She was distinguished as the first and only American woman to own a distillery in Scotland. She produced the finest highland malt whiskey in Pitlochry, which aged in port barrels while being used as ships' ballast, sent around the world, and then bottled by her firm. With humor and style she and her late brother Abbe, brother-in-law Irving and sisters, Mildred and Pearl became well-known figures at the Savoy in post war London, bringing American energy and optimism to national and overseas trade. Their best known brands were Kings Ransom and House of Lords. For 40 years she directed and ran International Distributors and International Brands with hundreds of loyal devoted employees in the U.S. and U.K. The loss of her family associates led to the sale of the busness in the 1970's. She was chairwoman of the Women's Alcoholic Beverage Association. She was known for her philanthropy to the Harvard Medical School Israeli medical education, the Fifty-fifth Street Synagogue, the Flatbush Jewish Center, and Greek War Relief. Family and friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Saturday, 5-8 PM, with service Sunday, 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Harvard Medical School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNROE, DOREEN EUNICE (NEE FACEY)
description: MUNROE-Doreen Eunice (nee Facey) on January 8, 1998 went home to be with the Lord. Viewing and funeral service will be held on Sunday, January 11, 5-7pm, St. John's Methodist Church, 2105 Stuart Ave, Valley Stream. Interment Monday Pinelawn Cemetery

title: Gleefully Rattling Around the World
description: The Knitting Factory recently started to book weeklong engagements in its cozy basement space, the Old Office, and it was an incalculably smart bit of farm-team thinking. Some bands, used to one-nighters, will make quantum leaps in the fluidity of their sound, and probably find themselves audiences to fill the larger space upstairs. Pachora, a quartet of young musicians who are all movable parts in the downtown improvising scene, is an example. At its late set at the Old Office on Thursday, the second night of a five-night stand, the band showed considerable growth since making its first recording last year; the elastic music was full of beckoning pleasures that can only be learned the hard way.

title: Missed Communication Deflates the Rangers
description: After calling up two defensemen from their farm club yesterday, the Rangers will have more than enough healthy players for a 20-man roster when they visit Montreal tonight to play the Canadiens. Their second challenge will be to keep five skaters in front of their goalie when they are supposed to be at even strength.

title: Intensity Enhances Virtuosity
description: Roger C. Jeffrey took risks on Thursday night at Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts. This talented young dancer from Twyla Tharp's company could easily have assembled an evening that revealed his technical virtuosity. Instead he presented himself as a choreographer and dance producer. His program, called ''Subtle Changes,'' featured his choreography. Yet because he did not perform in it, the emphasis was on Mr. Jeffrey as creator rather than interpreter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, IRVING
description: GOLD-Irving, 86. Housewares Executive. Husband of Rhoda. Father of Arol Shack, Janet H. Gold, Marjorie Falk. Grandfather of 5. Services on Sunday, January 11, at 2 P.M. at the B'nai Jeshurun in Pepper Pike, OH.

title: The Universe, Ad Infinitum
description: New data from two teams of astronomers lend support to the idea that the universe will continue to expand forever and is potentially infinite.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about corruption in Pakistan misstated the year that the brother of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was killed. It was 1996, not 1986.

title: Zoeller Signs Endorsement Deal
description: Sport-Haley signed Fuzzy Zoeller to a one-year contract to endorse the company's clothes, his first sponsorship agreement since he was dropped by Kmart over remarks he made about last year's Masters champion, Tiger Woods.

title: Journal; The Price Is Right
description: No one who has known and admired David Brinkley -- and that includes me -- can be anything other than saddened by his new, undignified TV role as corporate spokesman for Archer Daniels Midland. But at least Mr. Brinkley waited to retire from broadcast news before he entered the commercial arena. What's his colleagues' excuse?

title: An Award-Winning Defense In a Non-Tournament Deal
description: Almost all the great deals that appear in bridge columns and books are played in major championships. But ''many a gem of purest ray serene'' occurs in the obscurity of the rubber bridge table and never comes to light.

title: 49ers' Fiery Mood Is Dampened a Bit By Tight End's Injury
description: San Francisco 49ers Coach Steve Mariucci said his team's practices in preparation for Sunday's National Football Conference title game with the Green Bay Packers have been feisty and spirited.

title: Already, Schiele Case Is Reining In Art World
description: When Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau served a subpoena on the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday ordering it to hold two borrowed Egon Schiele paintings with disputed ownership that were about to be returned to Austria, he was making an audacious move. Artworks are usually immune from such actions.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If he's not going to cooperate, he will be on a plane and I will fly him to a psychiatric institution immediately.''

title: FIGURE SKATING ; Ina and Dungjen Defend Their U.S. Pairs Title
description: Kyoko Ina and Jason Dungjen skated cleanly and won their second consecutive national title in pairs skating tonight as their main rivals, the three-time champions Jenni Meno and Todd Sand, withdrew because Meno sprained her ankle.

title: Michigan's Woodson Says He's Jumping to N.F.L.
description: Charles Woodson made formal yesterday a decision that his coach, among others, had expected for weeks. Almost a month after winning the Heisman Trophy and on the last day that underclassmen could apply for the National Football League draft, Woodson announced that he would give up his final year of eligibility at the University of Michigan.

title: National News Briefs; 2 Officials in Miami Are Accused of Bribery
description: Federal prosecutors have accused two Miami-Dade County officials of accepting bribes to favor a California businessman.

title: In Praise of Uncertainty and Other Underappreciated Concepts
description: After The New York Times asked scholars what they thought was the Most Overrated Idea and published their answers here last fall, one philosopher proposed an encore: the Most Underrated Idea. Here are the results, compiled by Janny Scott.

title: Queens Democrats Select Legislator for House Race
description: Paving the way for his likely election as New York's newest Congressman, Gregory W. Meeks, a 44-year-old Assemblyman, was selected yesterday by Queens Democratic officials as their party's candidate to replace the Rev. Floyd Flake.

title: Community Autism Cases To Get Official Scrutiny
description: State and Federal health officials met yesterday to begin to determine whether there is an unusually high rate of autism in Brick Township, after parents responding to a survey reported 24 cases among children ages 3 to 7.

title: Colombian Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Employment at Record Level
description: The strong economy generated 370,000 new jobs last month. With December's gains, a record 64.1 percent of all Americans are working. Business Day, page D1.

title: Mayor Plans System to Help Small Firms Insure Workers
description: The growing problem of the uninsured is likely to receive yet more political attention next week: aides say Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to announce a program in his State of the City address that could make it easier for small businesses to offer insurance to employees.

title: ANXIETIES ON ASIA PUSH U.S. STOCKS DOWN NEARLY 3%
description: The stock market suffered its worst drop since the plunge of late October yesterday, driven down by huge waves of selling on fear over how deeply America's economy could be hurt by Asia's festering financial crisis.

title: U.S. to Suspend Road Building In Many National Forest Areas
description: The Clinton Administration plans to suspend construction of logging roads in the back country of most national forests, a major environmental step that would effectively preclude logging on some of the nation's most rugged and pristine public land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOYCE, MARY (NEE PETRIE)
description: KOYCE-Mary (nee Petrie). Of Morristown, NJ, on Thursday, January 8, 1998. Wife of John P. Koyce, Jr, mother of Patricia Wanniski of Morris Twp, NJ, sister of Donald, John, Alexander,and Robert Petrie. She was a secretary at Dancer Fitzgerald & Sample Advertising Agency in New York City from 1948-1960. Funeral Mass on Monday, January 12, 1998 at the Church of Christ the King, New Vernon, NJ at 11AM. Hours of visitation at the Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Ave, Morristown, NJ on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Foreign Affairs; Backlash At the Pump
description: I like to think of the world as four different gas stations. At the Japanese gas station, gas is $5 a gallon, four uniformed men wait on you and wash your windows, and you drive away at ease. At the American gas station, gas costs $1 a gallon, you pump it yourself and four homeless people mug you around the corner and steal your hubcaps. At the European gas station, gasoline costs $5 a gallon, one person who works only 32 hours a week and has six weeks' vacation waits on you, and four people living on generous unemployment insurance are playing boccie ball across the street. At the Communist gas station gas costs only 50 cents a gallon, but there is none. The four attendants have sold it all on the black market for $5 a gallon.

title: Witness Who Undercut Brawley's Account Is Treated Softly
description: Under cross-examination, Tawana Brawley's former neighbor repeated her testimony today of watching a black girl hop furtively into a garbage bag and lie down on the ground on the same day November day Ms. Brawley was found in that position.

title: COPPER PRICES SLIDE.
description: Copper prices have been falling on concerns that the economic crisis in Asia, the biggest regional buyer of copper, will continue to weaken demand for the metal. On the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, March copper fell 0.55 cent, to 75.30 cents a pound.

title: 370,000 Jobs Added to Rolls In December
description: Riding a strong economy, the nation's employers added 370,000 new jobs to their payrolls last month -- far beyond expectations -- and at year's end, employment reached record levels, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: AETNA IS REDUCING FERTILITY BENEFITS
description: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, on April 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNIK, JACK
description: SKOLNIK-Jack. Beloved husband of Edythe and father of Barney, Peter, and Gail Maletz. Loving grandfather of eleven. Friday in Boca Raton, FL. Services Sunday at 2:30, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam at 91st Street.

title: Mother and 2 Infants Found Dead, and Use of Stove for Heating Is Implicated
description: The bodies of a 27-year-old woman and her two infants were found in a Queens apartment yesterday, and officials said preliminary indications were that they had been asphyxiated days ago when fires in a kitchen gas stove apparently left on for heat consumed the oxygen in the apartment.

title: Albright Right-Hand Man Finds Spotlight's on Him
description: When James P. Rubin, the State Department's chief spokesman, got word that CNN had refused to provide an advance copy of its interview this week with the Iranian President, he lost patience. ''Oh, really? Who says?'' he asked one of his deputies, and threatened to start dialing CNN editors himself.

title: CARIBINER INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE RIGHT SOURCE
description: Caribiner International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Right Source Inc., a provider of marketing support and training services, for $17 million in cash. Caribiner will also assume $2.4 million in debt. Right Source, which has offices in South Carolina and Connecticut, had revenue of $22 million for the nine months ended Sept. 30. Caribiner, based in New York, produces meetings, events and training programs, as well as related services. For the 12 months ended Sept. 30, Caribiner reported income of $18 million on revenue of $342 million. Caribiner said it might pay up to an additional $17 million in cash and stock if Right Source meets certain performance goals during the coming year.

title: Christmas Refunds Made Easy
description: Our products are guaranteed to give 100 percent satisfaction in every conceivable way. Please help us help you to help you! Check off what strikes you as a good reason for returning the item(s) you do not want, even if it is not the real reason.

title: Not the Usual Jazz Routine: Exploration Is the Point
description: The saxophonist Steve Wilson gave a lesson in small-group arranging on Wednesday night. Mr. Wilson, who is playing at the Jazz Standard through tomorrow, deftly avoided the mind-numbing jazz routine of theme, exposition and theme. He opened his set with part of his ''Trans African Suite,'' itself a long-form composition. He played ''Step Lively, Watch the Closing Doors,'' which worked with a cuing system and radical tempo changes. And his tune ''Wish You Were Here'' opened up into freedom; he performed a ballad accompanied only by Kevin Hayes on piano.

title: Beijing Journal; Delectable Materialism Catching On in China
description: In her neat gray turtleneck, metal-frame glasses and black-and-white Swatch watch, Sang Yan, 27, well educated and thoughtful, could easily fit in on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: Keeping a Clamp on the Bubble; Call It Overdue, but Japan Credit Squeeze Inflicts Pain
description: Surrounded by piles of cardboard boxes in her cluttered office, a middle-aged businesswoman remembered angrily how her bankers once tried to force money on her, urging her to take out a loan to buy a golf club membership as an investment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David January 9, 1931 to May 6, 1997. We miss you. We have so much to tell you. We love you. Happy Birthday. Nancy, Jennie, Gabe

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZACHER, ISRAEL
description: ZACHER-Israel. Today on your 75th birthday, we miss you and think of you every day. Sonia

title: Beliefs
description: ''He is the most important Jewish thinker of the modern period,'' said Rabbi Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, HERBERT
description: BERMAN-Herbert. The Officers, Board of Directors and the Staff of the America-Israel Friendship League, deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Herbert Berman, a long time supporter and Treasurer of our organization. His life of dedication to the Jewish People, the State of Israel and to many other worthy civic and philanthropic causes will forever serve as a source of inspiration to all of us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Daisy, his children Sara, Debra and Nathaniel and the entire family. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, President Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman of the Board Stanley A. Urman, Senior Executive Vice-President Ilana Artman Executive Vice-President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDE, PHILIP
description: ENDE-Philip. Of Spring Valley, N.Y. Beloved husband of Hilda. Devoted father of Frances and Alan Datz, Edythe and David Fagenson and the late Myron Ende. Loving grandfather of Felice and Mark Leader, Jason Datz and Zachary and Alexander Fagenson. Great-grandfather of Harrison and Shelby. Services ''Gutterman - Musicant'', corner Passaic and Park St., Hackensack, New Jersey, on Sunday at 1:15PM.

title: Sir Michael Tippett, 93, Composer of Many Styles, Dies
description: Sir Michael Tippett, whose distinctive and sometimes perplexing music made him the best-known British composer since Benjamin Britten, died on Thursday at his home in London. He was 93.

title: Hyundai Hopes To Raise Auto Exports by 15%
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's largest auto maker, hopes to increase exports by 15 percent this year as it braces for a slump in domestic sales. With the economy expected to fall into recession and car sales forecast to dip 20 percent, Hyundai is gearing up to increase sales abroad, especially in the United States, which accounts for one-quarter of foreign sales.

title: $197 MILLION PAID FOR NESTLE'S CONTADINA
description: The Del Monte Foods Company paid $197 million for its recent purchase of the Contadina brand of canned tomato products and some related operations from Nestle S.A.'s United States unit. Terms of the transaction, which were in a Del Monte Foods securities filing, were not previously disclosed. The purchase was completed on Dec. 19. The San Francisco-based Del Monte Foods, which is owned by the Texas Pacific Group, doubled annual sales of its canned tomato brands to $400 million with the purchase, as it received Contadina's pizza sauce and bread crumbs business, as well as two tomato-processing factories. Texas Pacific is an investment partnership that includes the financier David Bonderman.

title: PATRIOT AMERICAN AND WYNDHAM ADD TO HOTELS
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. and Wyndham International said yesterday that they had acquired the Wyndham Emerald Plaza Hotel in downtown San Diego for $71.2 million. The 436-room hotel, Patriot American's second owned property in the San Diego market, will continue to be managed by Wyndham International. The hotel was purchased from Southwest Value Partners, a private Arizona partnership.

title: For Drug Addicts: Treatment, Not Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Report a Lead In Death of Dominatrix
description: The police investigating the July death of an Upper West Side woman they described as a dominatrix said yesterday that they were seeking to question a man whose photograph was found among her belongings.

title: Russia's Public Enemy No. 1 Takes Charge in Chechnya
description: If all goes as planned, Saturday will qualify at least for a footnote in the long, garish history of Russian politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROGOFF, IRA, PH.D.
description: PROGOFF-Ira, Ph.D. Author, professor and psychotherapist, died Jan. 1, 1998, in New York City, after a long illness. A memorial service will be held Sunday, Feb. 1, 3 PM, at The New Synagogue, 171 W. 85 St., Dorot Bldg., NYC. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman officiating. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Dept. of Community Medicine, St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 W. 11 Street, NYC 10011, or to The Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, Johns Hopkins Outpatient Center, 601 N. Caroline Street, Baltimore, MD. 21287.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEVIN, JOHN W.
description: NEVIN-John W. On January 9, 1998. Age 73 of Westchester, PA. Formerly of Flushing, New York. Husband of Agnes (nee Gregory) Nevin. Father of Christine, Maura, Marie, Andrea and Ellen. Six grandchildren; also one brother and one sister. A Funeral Mass will be held Monday, January 12 at 11 A.M., at Sts. Peter and Paul Church in Westchester, Penn. Interment St. Agnes Cemetery, Westchester. Viewing Sunday afternoon, 2-5 PM at the Alleva Funeral Home in Paoli, PA and also 9-11 AM Monday morning in the church. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Peter's College, Jersey City, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSTEIN, PAULINE
description: LIPSTEIN-Pauline. Beloved widow of Adolph. Loving mother of Fred and Eddie. Adoring grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Judge Orders New Vote For Bronx School Board
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered that a special election be held in May in a Bronx school district where the United States Justice Department had accused poll workers of committing ballot fraud to help secure the election of a white majority on the local school board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, CATHERINE M. (NEE COLLINS)
description: COX-Catherine M. (nee Collins) of Kingsbridge, on January 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George, loving mother of Margaret Ann Blaney. Reposing Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 North Broadway, Tarrytown, New York, on Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Church of the Transfiguration, Tarrytown, on Monday at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Budget Surplus Is Burning a Hole in California's Pocket
description: His state again flush after years of scarcity, Gov. Pete Wilson of California today presented the most optimistic budget of his seven years in office, with billions of dollars of proposed new spending for education, water supply systems, roads, bridges and prisons.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Execution in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Race to Unseat D'Amato Is Turning Nasty Unusually Quickly
description: Ten months before the election and less than a week after Geraldine A. Ferraro entered the race against Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the campaign has already attained a pitch of nastiness not usually seen until fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: At Web Site, Whitman To Discuss State of State
description: Gov. Whitman's State of the State Message on Tuesday will be available on the Internet, the Governor's office said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column yesterday about a swearing-in ceremony for the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, misstated the length of his service. He is starting his seventh term, not his fourth.

title: U.S. Aides Warm Up to Informal Iran Ties
description: After a few days of reflection on the Iranian President's address to the American people, senior officials are changing their tone and embracing the idea of cultural exchanges that fall short of a formal, Government-to-Government dialogue.

title: Conjuring Programs To Capture and Keep Chamber Audiences
description: A handful of agendas, both philosophical and practical, lie behind the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's ''Musical Evolutions,'' a three-week exploration of the stylistic ferment in late 19th- and early 20th-century composition that opens this morning.

title: Iranians Receptive To Opening To America
description: President Mohammad Khatami's ''message to the American people,'' delivered in a television interview the other night, has begun to play well in Iran.

title: Jones Bids Switzer a Fond Farewell
description: The turbulent and mostly successful Barry Switzer era officially ended in Dallas today when the Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, announced the coach's resignation and outlined demanding criteria for his successor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, THOMAS J., JR.
description: STANTON-Thomas J., Jr. The executives and staff of Reliance Group mourn the loss of our board member Thomas J. Stanton Jr. who, for more than thirty years, generously shared his knowledge and wisdom with his colleagues. As a leader in civic and educational affairs, he will be missed throughout our community. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Bouygues of France Said to Fend Off Bid
description: The shares of Bouygues S.A. surged more than 4 percent yesterday amid renewed takeover speculation after a report said it had been threatened with a hostile takeover. The stock closed at 708 French francs, up 29, on the Paris bourse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSIN, SYDNEY
description: GOSIN-Sydney. On behalf of our entire organization, we wish to express our profound sorrow to our esteemed partner, Barry Gosin, on the passing of his beloved father, Sydney. We would also like to extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire family, most especially Irene, Sydney's wife. May his memory be a blessing. The Partners of Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc. William Cohen Ira Fishman Ronald Goldberger Aaron Gural Jeffrey Gural James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post Arthur Rosenbloom

title: Corrections
description: The children's event listing in the Spare Times column of Weekend yesterday misidentified the show today and tomorrow at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street, in Manhattan. The performance, at 10:30 A.M. and noon, is by Tuckers' Tales Puppet Theater, not Professor Putter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, GEORGE C.
description: FURMAN-George C., 88. Of Bellport, New York, died at 7:30 PM, at Brookhaven Health Care Facility. Former Director of Fleet Bank of Eastern Long Island until his retirement five years ago, was President of Banker's Trust & Co. in the early forties which later evolved into becoming the Patchogue Bank, changing its name to Island State Bank in the seventies. As Chairman of the Board he instituted its merger with United Bank of New York, later merged with Norstar Bank and now Fleet Bank. A graduate of Albany Law School of Union University in 1934 and Member of the Suffolk County Bar Association for sixty-six years he served as a Suffolk County Assistant District Attorney for ten years, Chairman of Brookhaven Town Ethics Board, Brookhaven Town Attorney for the Assessor's Office (before Brookhaven Town had a Town Attorney's Office). He was also the original incorporator, co trustee and attorney of the Manor of St. George Museum, site of the famous Revolutionary Battle and raid by Gen. Tallimadge, which the museum is still operating today free of admission charges and self supporting from investment vehicles arranged by Mr. Furman. Recently he was feted by the Patchogue Chamber of Commerce at their annual dinner meeting, for his ten years of service as President of the Chamber. United Methodist Church of Patchogue has also recognized his leadership and support as past President of the Board of Trustees and made construction of the Wesley Education Wing possible for 400 Sunday School Children in 1964 and recently contributed their grand piano in memory of Daisy C. Furman, his mother. A graduate of Patchogue High School in 1927 and Cornell University in 1932, he will be remembered as the basketball team captain that led both schools to many championships. Mr. Furman is survived by his three children, Joel M. Furman, Esq. of Patchogue, NY, George H. Furman II of Cookeville, TN and daughter, Gail Moore of Rutland, VT. He is also, survived by six grandchildren, George C. Furman II, Andrew W. Furman, Jacqueline Moore, Thomas Moore, Susanne Moore, Wendy Moore, and four great grandchildren, Zachery Gauthier, Katie Gauthier, Allison Gauthier and Kiel Furman. For information Lucia and Orlando Funeral Home, 326 East Main St., Patchogue, NY. Viewing will be at the deceased's waterfront home, 6 Rogers Ave., Bellport, NY Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. with a reading of service at 8 P.M. Funeral services will be held Monday at 11 A.M. at the United Methodist Church, Rev. Gary Betts, officiating. Interment will follow immediately thereafter at the Cedar Grove Cemetery, Jennings Avenue, Patchogue, NY and the public is invited. Flowers may be sent to the residence at 6 Rogers Ave, Bellport, New York.

title: Ice Brings New Woes To Much of Canada
description: Canada's harsh ice storm wreaked fresh havoc across five eastern provinces, halting air travel and shutting the country's busiest rail corridor. And once again, three million people had to endure a day without power. For many of them, it will be days before the power is restored. The death toll from the five-day onslaught rose to 10.

title: Evidence in Crash of a 737 Brings Inspection of Boeing
description: Part of the tail of the Boeing 737 that crashed in Indonesia three weeks ago appears to have separated from the plane before impact, possible evidence that the crash occurred because fasteners were missing, aviation officials said today.

title: The Faces Change, but the Rivalry Endures
description: It took 44 points and 33 shots from you know who. It took 34 minutes from Steve Kerr. It took everything the Chicago Bulls had to offer and still the Knicks were huffing and puffing on their tail. Michael Jordan realized the hard truth:

title: The Unabomber Travesty
description: The Justice Department made the wrong call last month when it rejected an offer by Theodore Kaczynski, the accused Unabomber, to plead guilty in exchange for a life sentence. Now the chaos and legal confusion unfolding in the courtroom in Sacramento, Calif., should make the extent of that error inescapably clear. Attorney General Janet Reno needs to back away from this pointless quest to impose the death penalty and see if the defense is still amenable to a life-in-prison deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, IDA
description: KIRSCH-Ida. On January 9, 1998, in her 101st year. Beloved mother of Sylvia and Leslie Berger, Lillian and Bernard Frankel, Robert and Angie Kirsch. Cherished grandmother of Leonard and Diana Frankel, Paul and Barbara Frankel, Joel and Jodi Berger, Bonnie and Scott Canner, Alecia and Charlene Kirsch. Adoring greatgrandmother of Jordana, Carly, Ilona, Justin, Peri and Lauren. Former Matron of the Eastern Star, President of the Liberty Ladies Auxiliary. She lived with grace, dignity and good humor and was loved and respected by all. Services Sunday, 11 AM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Why Fill the Stage if the Seats Are Empty?
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposal to award 25 or so of Broadway's landmark theaters the right to earn $100 million for the sale of their ''air rights'' (giving other buildings in the area their nonexistent upper floors, surely an idea worthy of ''Alice in Wonderland'') would be a sizable windfall for the owners of these venerable playhouses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSTEN, GRACE ELISH
description: KIRSTEN-Grace Elish. On January 8, 1998 in her 98th year. Psychotherapist, lecturer and author. Loving mother of Dr. Maurice E. Sherman and his wife Jane. Adored grandmother of Susan (Les) Morgenstein and Lynn M. Sherman. Great grandmother of Charles. Cherished sister of the late May Markewich, the late Dewey Elish and the late Karl Elish. The family is very grateful to Dr. Stanley Mirsky for his many years of devoted care. Contributions can be made in Grace's name to Temple Beth Emeth Shaari Zedek, 83 Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, NY 11226. Graveside services Sunday, January 11, 1:30 PM at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY

title: Washington Meets Hollywood As Sonny Bono Is Laid to Rest
description: With a military honor guard in a church filled with Hollywood and Washington dignitaries, friends paid a sometimes lighthearted tribute today to Sonny Bono, the singer, actor and Congressman who was known for his self-deprecating wit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, CANON JOHN WEBB
description: GRAHAM-Canon John Webb, E.D., Q.C., B.A., LI.B., D.S.Litt., U.E. Peacefully at home, on Friday, January 9, 1998 in his 86th year. Beloved husband of Natasha. Loving father of Ann Grahman Calderisi and Ted Rogers. Caring fatherin-law of Loretta Rogers. Dear brother of Betty C. Graham. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Edward, Melinda and Martha Rogers and Rafe Calderisi. Great-grandfather of Chloe Rogers. Step-father of Norman Nicholas Campbell and Tanya O'Neil. Predeceased by his wife Velma Rogers Graham. A true gentleman with a distinguished service in the law, business, the military, his church and public service. The family will receive friends at the Humphrey Funeral Home-A.W. Miles Chapel, 1403 Bayview Avenue, from 35 P.M. and 7-9 PM on Sunday, January 11, 1998. Funeral service Monday, January 12, 1998, 11 o'clock Grace Church On-The-Hill, 300 Lonsdale Road (bet. Ave Road and Spadina Road). Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to The John Webb Graham Library, Trinity College, Univ. of Toronto would be appreciated.

title: Owens Corning to Cut Staff and Shut Plants
description: Owens Corning said today that it would dismiss 2,200 people, or 9 percent of its work force, close several plants and report earnings for 1997 well below analysts' estimates because intense competition in the home-insulation business had caused prices to fall.

title: A Trip Into Kurdish History Takes Over a Life
description: On a dusky September day in 1991, the photographer Susan Meiselas found herself in the Kurdish town of Paveh, in Iran, where she happened upon a small photographic shop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, BERTHA
description: GOTTLIEB-Bertha. Round Dune mourns the death of our cherished member and longtime neighbor. To her sons, Samuel and Robert, we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memories bring comfort to all who mourn.

title: From Suspect To Samaritan For Youth, 16
description: Eight days after being shot by an off-duty police officer he was trying to save from a beating or worse, a 16-year-old police buff was visited at his hospital bedside by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and praised as a good Samaritan in a case in which he was initially viewed as a possible suspect.

title: Managing Managed Care
description: The polls that show widespread satisfaction with managed-care health plans also suggest a growing suspicion that they sometimes let profit blur their medical judgment. A task force appointed by Gov. Pete Wilson of California has now issued a sophisticated blueprint of consumer safeguards. Equally interesting is an eight-page letter sent to Mr. Wilson by the chairman of the task force, Prof. Alain Enthoven of Stanford, that points to issues the divided group was unable to address.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEIBERT, MOLLYE
description: ZEIBERT-Mollye. On January 7, 1998 in Ridgewood, New Jersey. Dear Aunt Mollye, we loved you and will miss you greatly. She was the beloved sister of Larry Zeibert and the late Jack, Irving and David Zeibert and the late Edith Freedman. She was the devoted aunt of Joyce Apsel, of Ridgewood, Seymour Freedman of Jerusalem and the late Jacob Freedman of Troy; Terrilynn Sanker, Raymond Zeibert, and the late Sharon Wolkin. She is survived by 14 grand nephews and nieces. Ms. Zeibert began her lifetime career in retail in the Up-to-Date in Troy, she was a dress buyer in Alexander's and for over forty years at Abraham & Strauss. She was something of a legend, known for her integrity. honesty and devotion to her work. A lifetime member of Beth Tephilah Synagogue, she was honored by National UJA for fundraising work. Funeral services held in Troy. Contributions to American Heart Association or Lighthouse for the Blind. Memorial observance through Sunday at home of Joyce Apsel in Ridgewood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, DANIEL BERTRAM, SR.
description: GROSSMAN-Daniel Bertram, Sr. 72, on January 5, 1998 in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Danny Grossman and Dana Hammond, grandfather of Oliver, Miles, Jonathan and Nicky Hammond. Funeral 11 AM, Saturday, January 10, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either St. Peter's Episcopal Church Building Fund, PO Box 336, Del Mar, CA 92014 or Scripps Clinic, Division of Chest Medicine, 10666 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA 92037.

title: Collapse of Equity Sale Leaves Peregrine Investments in Crisis
description: A swashbuckling symbol of the Asian boom of the 1990's, the Hong Kong investment bank Peregrine Investments Ltd., was fighting for its life today after the collapse of a deal to sell a $200 million minority stake to Switzerland's Zurich Insurance Company.

title: Man Flees Test Scam Trial But Is Caught at the Border
description: After hearing from a judge that he faced a possible prison sentence of 10 years if convicted, a man accused of running a nationwide scheme to sell answers to graduate school entrance exams left a courtroom in lower Manhattan earlier this week and was arrested yesterday morning trying to cross the border into Canada.

title: Corrections
description: The Doctor's World column of Science Times on Dec. 9, about a study showing that magnets relieved pain in patients who had had polio, included a researcher's erroneous description of the role of Magnaflex Inc. The company, a distributor of Bioflex magnets, provided them; it did not manufacture them.

title: Steelers Plot the Way to Win: Stop Davis
description: In their last heavy practice before Sunday's American Football Conference championship game against Denver, the Steelers worked out this afternoon in a driving rainstorm with strong wind gusts and plummeting temperatures.

title: Lloyd's of London Profit Seen Dipping in 1997
description: Lloyd's of London is expected to post 1997 profit of $:462 million ($747 million), down from an estimated $:622 million in 1996, as premium income declines, according to Chatset, a group of Lloyd's analysts. While the forecast for 1995 profit was raised 4 percent, to $:1.06 billion, the estimate for 1996 was lowered 6 percent, to $:622 million. Lloyd's, the world's oldest insurance market, reports its accounts three years in arrears to allow claims for the period to be calculated.

title: INSIDE
description: Tracking Ancient Starlight

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Tumble in U.S. As Asian Worries Mount

title: A Night of Russian Sound and Fury
description: Valery Gergiyev is a muscle man among today's conductors; you feel he is lifting the music like some heavyweight and then hurling it at you. There is not much sense of it speaking for itself, or even of the orchestral players speaking for themselves -- though the New York Philharmonic did not seem at all chafed or inhibited at the orchestra's concert with him on Thursday evening, in a program to be repeated this afternoon and on Monday. On the contrary, the musicians were galvanized, and the brass, in particular, played with spectacular force.

title: Miami on the Hudson
description: When the week began, tourists had finally retreated to tourist repositories around the world, making room in New York for the rain. Duelists in the umbrella wars faced off on sidestreets and on the narrow pavements of Lexington Avenue. Polite umbrellists remembered that an umbrella is only a large hat, easily tipped as a courtesy to other pedestrians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARIES, PETER L.
description: ARIES-Peter L. A lifetime resident of Westchester County died Friday, January 9, 1998 at his home in Ossining, NY. He was 60. He was born May 28, 1937 in Yonkers, NY to the late Ernest J. Aries and the late Gladys Friedman Aries. He was a graduate of Riverdale Country School and Hobart College. On June 12, 1960 he married Florence Sue Lazar. Mr. Aries was a prominent member of a family well known in real estate in Westchester County dating back to the turn of the century. At the time of his death, he was the Chairman of the Board of Aries Deitch and Endelson, Inc. Hartsdale, NY, a firm specializing in shopping center development, leasing and management throughout New York State and several other states. Mr. Aries was the founder and first president of the Building Owners and Managers Association of Westchester County (BOMA). He was a member of Dunwoodie Lodge of Masons. He was a lecturer at the New York University Real Estate Institute, and was active and well known in the International Council of Shopping Centers (ICSC). He was the author of numerous articles for real estate publications. In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sons, Richard Aries of Agoura Hills, CA., and James Aries of New York City, a daughter, Nancy Aries Koff of Briarcliff Manor, NY, a sister, Linda Aries Friedman of White Plains, NY, three grandchildren: Garrett and Jamie Aries and Zoe Koff, a daughter-in-law, Elise Aries, and a son-in-law, Ronald Koff. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon on Sunday at 10AM. Interment will be at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, NATHAN
description: FINKEL-Nathan. Dear husband of of Molly Barshofsky. Daughters Jeanne and Iris and Stephen Gullo. The entire Finkel and Jolson families.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''The Book of David'' by David Rosenberg on Dec. 25 referred imprecisely to the Biblical quotation ''To everything there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.'' It is from Ecclesiastes, not Psalms. The review also omitted the author's line breaks in his translation of a Hebrew verse from the 23d Psalm. It should have read, ''The Lord is my shepherd / and keeps me from wanting / what I can't have.''

title: Panic in Indonesia Replaced by Political Anxiety
description: President Suharto of Indonesia faces a widening political challenge, with the economic crisis leading to increasingly open calls among his people for him to step down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVITT, PAUL V.
description: DEVITT-Paul V. Age 64. Died on January 6, 1998. Memorial Service on Saturday, January 10, at 3 PM, Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Avenue and 29th Street, where he was on the staff. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Marble Collegiate Church, or The American Cancer Society.

title: Clinton Seeks An Increase In Work-Study
description: Declaring the nation ''on a roll,'' President Clinton today proposed new spending to help one million students work their way through college by performing community service.

title: Small-Business Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Mikado' Survives Some Updating
description: You can usually count on productions by the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players to be colorful and lively. And the company's ''Mikado,' which opened on Thursday night at Symphony Space, is no exception. Moreover, the playing of the orchestra under Jeffrey Kresky, if not faultless, was stylish, which is more important.

title: When Juries Lose Their Trust; False Confessions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODES, ANNE R.
description: HODES-Anne R. At age 88. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Horace L. Hodes. Loving mother of Ruth Rabin and Dr. David Hodes. Adored grandmother of Betsy Rabin Gabay, Laura and Elizabeth Hodes, and the late Thomas Rabin. Great grandmother of Thomas and Benjamin Gabay. Valued community leader of the Manhasset School District and member of the Congregation Temple Beth El of Great Neck, she maintained high standards. Funeral Services Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, New York, 12:30 PM, January 11.

title: Allies in Corruption
description: The tens of millions of dollars illicitly obtained by the family of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan could not have been collected without the help of a network of Western and international intermediaries and accomplices. The corruption detailed yesterday in articles by John Burns of The Times was made possible by companies that paid bribes to do business with Pakistan, banks that profited from Bhutto-related accounts, and lenders and political patrons -- including Washington -- willing to look the other way. In the last few years, some of these institutions have begun to take steps to combat corruption, but the Bhutto case shows how much more needs to be done.

title: Microsoft Dealt Setback as TCI Chooses Java For Cable Box
description: In a blow to the Microsoft Corporation's hopes of dominating the next generation of cable television, Sun Microsystems Inc. announced yesterday that its Java programming language had been selected by Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, to run digital set-top boxes.

title: Sports of The Times; Mind, Spirit And a Yen To Coach
description: EVER the existential contradiction, Phil Jackson left Madison Square Garden yesterday wearing a camouflage hat that was a metaphor for his Montana retreat while carrying The New York Times under his arm. He walked out into the city of his awkward but time-honored youth, a man who delights in tormenting the Knicks but admits that deep inside him beats the heart of New York.

title: Officer Is Arrested On Sex Assault Charges
description: A police officer was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually assaulting a 15-year-old girl and attempting to sexually assault a 17-year-old girl in Queens last month, the police said. The officer, 33-year-old Jose Velazquez, a six-year veteran who works as a housing officer in lower Manhattan, was suspended from the force.

title: Karpov Wins Twice To Retain Chess Title
description: Anatoly Karpov made mincemeat out of Viswanathan Anand in the two final tiebreaker games and won their International Chess Federation match in Lausanne, Switzerland, yesterday. He has earned $1.3 million and retained his title, and is in a good position to challenge Garry Kasparov to see who is the world's strongest player.

title: Mexican Government Steps Up A War of Words in the South
description: The Government's efforts to calm the turmoil in Chiapas State seemed to be in disarray today. Just as the southern state's new Governor was holding a cordial meeting with a leading Catholic bishop, the armed forces accused the prelate of aiding armed Zapatista rebels.

title: Calipari Challenges Kittles to Be Tougher
description: Kerry Kittles is no longer a promising rookie; that burden belongs to Keith Van Horn. And he is not the veteran star, the go-to guy, that Sam Cassell is, or the stable force that Kendall Gill is.

title: Cook Enjoys Lead but Hates All the Rain
description: After today, John Cook was more concerned about the weather than his golf game.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP., Oak Brook, Ill., a manufacturer of emergency and environmental vehicles, purchased Saulsbury Fire Equipment Corp., a maker of stainless-steel-body fire and rescue trucks, for an undisclosed price.

title: Workfare Study Finds High Penalty Rate
description: Nearly half of the welfare recipients in Delaware's new work program have been financially penalized for violating the rules, according to a study released this week.

title: A Dying Promise
description: To the Editor:

title: For Drug Addicts: Treatment, Not Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Put Up Good Fight, but Jordan Wins Again
description: It was the way Michael Jordan kept hitting his shots as the Knicks kept hitting flesh. And it was obvious that no matter what the circumstances, the color of this rivalry had not faded without Patrick Ewing.

title: The Neediest Cases; Easing the Burden of Raising a Granddaughter
description: Sitting in her rambling Harlem home of the last 60-odd years, Laura Levine said it felt like only yesterday that her granddaughter Nadia had come to live with her.

title: Affirmative Action's Unlikely Foes
description: At first glance, Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom would seem an unlikely pair to lead the conservative charge against racial preference in America.

title: Inventing the Notion of Race; Some Scholars Say the Label Evolved Recently, As a Tool of the Vanquished as Well as the Victors
description: Who invented race? Scientists who drafted charts of ''mental capacity'' and ranked them by color and ethnic origin? Europeans who colonized the New World and enslaved Africans? Nonwhites who sought to deal with their conquerors? Or has the idea of natural racial groupings always existed?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LOWELL
description: GORDON-Lowell. Friends and family mourn the loss of our beloved friend and colleague, Lowell Gordon, who passed away on January 8, 1998 at South Nassau Community Hospital. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, at 10 AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUDNER, BERNICE
description: BRUDNER-Bernice. Mother of our lifelong friend, Ricky Brudner. We offer our sincere condolences on your loss to Ricky, Roberta, Matthew and Jon. With love, Peter, Mary, Nicholas, and Kathryn Kalikow

title: Ah, Winter, a Season Both Mild and Gentle, but Fickle
description: Spiro Catchesis, the co-owner of Playland Market, a grocery store in Rye, N.Y., paused at work yesterday to wax poetic about the surprising warmth of January. ''Winter is nonexistent, except when I look up at the trees and see their leafless branches through the fog.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, ALAN ROBERT
description: HOROWITZ-Alan Robert. Beloved son of Esther and the late Harold Horowitz. Devoted brother of Beth Horowitz. Father of Julie and Matthew. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ Sunday 10:45 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HERMAN
description: KLEIN-Herman. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Herman Klein, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Georgette, and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Harry Laufer, President

title: Cries to Halt Publication of Holocaust Book
description: Many scholars call it the ultimate enigma of the Nazi era, indeed perhaps of modern history: How did the Holocaust happen? And why in Germany?

title: The Jobless Rate Rises in Germany
description: Germany's jobless rate unexpectedly rose to a postwar high of 11.9 percent in December, casting doubt on the pace of the country's economic recovery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISHKIN, MICHAEL
description: MISHKIN-Michael. Of Pound Ridge and NYC, on January 8th, 1998, in Stamford, CT. Father of Richard, Andrew and Dr. Robert Mishkin. Brother of Claire Markham. Funeral services will be held at 12:30 PM, Sunday, January 11, at Jewish Family Congregation, Smith Ridge Rd., South Salem, NY. Memorial contributions to Jewish Family Congregation, PO Box 249, South Salem, New York or to the American Cancer Society.

title: Official's Prison Visit Defuses Threat to Ulster Talks
description: Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary appeared to have averted an imminent crisis in the peace effort today as she visited a high-security prison and persuaded Protestant paramilitary prisoners not to try to disrupt the formal peace talks, which are to resume here on Monday.

title: National Guard Is Sent to Aid Ice Storm Victims Upstate
description: Gov. George E. Pataki mobilized National Guard troops and state rescue workers today in one of the state's largest emergency responses ever as a relentless blast of sleet, snow and freezing rain paralyzed cities, villages and towns across a huge swath of upstate New York for a fourth day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, ISRAEL S. (I. SAUL)
description: JARCHO-Israel S. (I. Saul). Beloved son of the late Morris and Marsha Jarcho, dear brother of Arthur and Edythe Jarcho, and the late Julia and David Joseph, loving uncle of Robert and Steven Jarcho, Norma Hart and the late Arlene Ingerman, caring greatuncle of the Hart and Ingerman children. The family will receive at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, January 10, 1998, 7-9 P.M. Services at the Chapel, on January 11, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations in remembrance to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: About New York; City Trekkers, Take a Walk On a Wet Side
description: DOCTORS reported this week in The New England Journal of Medicine that regular walks reduced the chance of cancer in men. What do they know? Absent from their study was some footnote, like in those car rental ads, disclaiming in microscopic print, ''Walks Not Valid in New York City.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DONALD ROY
description: KAPLAN-Donald Roy. God's Love We Deliver honors the memory of our dear friend, Donald Roy Kaplan. Donald was a person of caring and conviction, with a gift for analysis and a quick wit, whose contributions spanned the history of God's Love We Deliver. From encouraging and advising our founder, to joining the Board of Directors in 1994 and becoming our Treasurer in 1995, he greatly helped us in our work of feeding homebound men, women and children living with AIDS. We are deeply grateful for Donald's guidance and we will miss him. Richard E. Feldman, Board Chair Kathy Spahn, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELDON, EDNA ETHER
description: SHELDON-Edna Ether. 1898-1998. Longtime resident of New York City. Collector of postcards and Americana. Died at her daughter Edna's home in San Diego on Thursday, January 8. She is survived by her daughter Edna V. Deodato, and her son Ronald L. Wohleking, of El Paso, and 13 grandchildren. As matriarch of her family, her legacy lives on. She will be interred next to her late husband, Bert Temple Sheldon.

title: Devils Beat The Worst, And First Is Theirs
description: Doug Gilmour got two goals, and Martin Brodeur stopped every shot but one. When the Devils are rolling, as they are right now, that is almost a fait accompli.

title: Criminal Case Being Brought Over Lettuce In California
description: A county district attorney in California yesterday filed criminal charges against a salad processor whose lettuce was linked to a 1996 food poisoning outbreak that sickened at least 61 people in the Midwest and the Northeast.

title: Bomb Kills Basque Aide
description: A car bomb killed a Basque city councilman from Spain's governing party today, and the Government blamed Basque separatist rebels for the attack.

title: Schools Brace for Young Parents, and Babies
description: It looks like any ordinary New York City high school, except for the strollers lining the hallway and the childish finger paintings adorning the walls. Then a visitor comes upon the centerpiece of the whole place: four rooms that have been turned into jolly nurseries, with all manner of toys, high chairs, refrigerators, books -- and babies.

title: TRIQUINT IS IN $39 MILLION DEAL WITH RAYTHEON
description: Triquint Semiconductor Inc. agreed yesterday to pay the Raytheon Company $39 million in cash and stock for the Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit operations that Raytheon acquired last year from Texas Instruments Inc. Triquint Semiconductor, based in Hillsboro, Ore., makes radio frequency, analog and mixed-signal integrated circuits. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., is a leading miliatry contractor. Raytheon's sale of the MMIC business, expected to close this month, was part of an agreement with the United States Government in connection with Raytheon's 1997 acquisition of Texas Instruments' Defense Systems and Electronics business.

title: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL TRUST ADDS TO PROPERTIES
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust, headed by the billionaire financier Sam Zell, said yesterday that it had purchased 15 apartment properties for about $294.4 million in separate transactions. The properties contain 4,645 apartments and are in 10 states. Equity Residential also said it had sold six properties for $28.5 million. The acquisitions closed in late 1997 and capped a year in which the Chicago-based company bought 257 properties with 70,201 apartments for a total of $4.1 billion. Equity is the United States' largest apartment owner, and owns or has investments in 489 properties in 35 states.

title: Tainted Journalist?; No Impropriety
description: To the Editor:

title: State Program Informs About Unsafe Chemicals
description: Two environmental groups offered qualified praise yesterday to state officials for taking steps to better inform the public about unsafe chemicals produced by public and private industries in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ACAD, FRIEDA
description: ACAD-Frieda. Of Howell, NJ and formerly of Brooklyn, on January 8, 1998. Devoted wife of Henry Acad. Funeral services Sunday at 10 A.M. at the Freeman Manalapan-Marlboro Funeral Home, 344 Route 9 North, Manalapan, NJ. Burial 12:30 P.M. in Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, New York.

title: City College Supported F.D.R., Not Marx
description: To the Editor:

title: Infrared Map Helps Astronomers Measure Cosmic Energy
description: A bright glow of infrared light that suffuses the heavens, detected and mapped by an American spacecraft, has given astronomers a kind of fossil record of the total energy generated by nearly all the stars that have shone since the beginning of time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOHN J.
description: SMITH-John J., on January 9th, 1998. Beloved husband of Nora E. (nee Dooley). Devoted father of Brian L., Susan M., Nora Ann Babos, and Sean R. Loving grandfather of Kristen, Patrick, Daniel, Clair, and Sean Babos. Brother of Rose Smith and Margaret Keyes. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30 AM, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Visitation Saturday, 7-9, and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9, at McLaughlin & Sons, 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn. Interment St. Charles.

title: Lipinski's 4 1/2 Minutes To Reclaim The Judges
description: Todd Eldredge shares a coach and a training rink with Tara Lipinski, and a day after winning his fifth national title, Eldredge expected to share a few private moments with his crestfallen training partner.

title: Louise Weiss, C. L. Pennington
description: Louise Esther Weiss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Weiss of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Locke Pennington, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Pennington of Wynnewood, Pa. Rabbi Judith Lewis officiated at the Americas Society in New York.

title: The Sound of Music as a Tool for Lessons About Prejudice
description: Take a minor song, once sweetened by a chorus of children in a now-obscure Rodgers and Hammerstein musical. Follow a director's vision to give it raw truth, angst and pain. What results, in a new scene, is now a climactic moment, the emotional fallout of a confrontation between an immigrant father and his 21-year-old American-born son.

title: Playing the Outsider and Feeling Right at Home
description: WHEN ADAM ALEXI-MALLE SAYS HE likes performing in Mike Leigh's dark comedy ''Goose-Pimples'' because it's ''un-formula-ish,'' he hasn't chosen the word casually. This polyglot has many languages to choose from. ''Let's see: I speak English, Italian, French, Spanish -- all fluently,'' said the actor, 33, with candid directness about his abilities and no trace of an accent. ''Russian, conversationally, because I studied in Moscow, and German -- but if you study musicology, you must know some, of course.'' Of course.

title: Another Familiar Name Quits Downtown Pittsburgh
description: REFRIGERATORS, power generators and railroad air brakes were all made here by Westinghouse. But by late 1998, the corporate headquarters that once housed more than 1,000 employees will be home to only 60 as Westinghouse, which acquired CBS Corporation two years ago, completes its transition into a pure media company.

title: January 4-10; This Couple Can't Get Any Privacy at All
description: It has been praised as a celebration of human anatomy and denounced as a lurid use of human corpses as if they were sculptors' clay. In any event, the ''Human Body World'' museum exhibition in Mannheim is one of the hottest cultural events in Germany. Since it opened two months ago, 245,000 people have seen the show, which is made up mostly of plastic-preserved human corpses that display their inner workings with almost surreal insouciance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARNOVSKY, BORIS
description: TARNOVSKY-Boris, 79, cancer. Survived by beloved wife Patricia, dear sister Valentina Figaredo, daughters Lynn and Ann, five grandchildren. NYC native, San Francisco resident. At his request no services.

title: MAKING IT WORK; Calls in the Night
description: CAB calls seem to come from another era, a time when a guy in a tux would skip to the curb with a doll in a satin evening gown. The doorman would throw a switch, a light would go on outside, and a cab would swing over. Fred and Ginger were off for a night on the town.

title: POSTINGS: A 400,000-Square-Foot Office Building on Jersey City's Riverfront; Hartz Rolls Dice on a Speculative Project
description: By June, Hartz Mountain Industries expects to start work on a 400,000-square-foot office building on Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront, the first such speculative project since the reshaping of this once gritty industrial strip began 12 years ago.

title: At W.H.O., 2 Physicians Lead the Race For Top Job
description: In the most important election to take place in the United Nations system since the choice of a new Secretary General in 1996, the World Health Organization will replace its Director General later this month. The campaign has been intense, with seven candidates in the running.

title: Herbert Berman, 74, a Lawyer And a Leader in Jewish Causes
description: Herbert Berman, a New York tax and corporate lawyer long active in civic and Jewish causes, died on Thursday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 74.

title: Debating 'Accelerator Alley'
description: Along busy Washington Street, known as Accelerator Alley, neighborhood residents are clamoring for more stop lights. On the street, they say, several pedestrians, including three children, have been hit by cars in the last 18 months. But city officials say empirical studies are the only way to determine whether there is a need to install new lights.

title: A Mezzo in a Class by Herself
description: IN 1991, COMMENTING ON THE current generation of opera singers, the great soprano Birgit Nilsson said that the voice of the American mezzo-soprano Dolora Zajick was ''the only one existing today without any competition in the world.''

title: The Nation: Not Quite Seconds for Everyone; The Fat's in the Fire, Again
description: THE editors of the august New England Journal of Medicine gave their guilt-plagued overweight readers a New Year's gift. Losing weight, they wrote in their Jan. 1 issue, is ''an ill-fated New Year's resolution.''

title: It Is Better to Give Than to Receive
description: Vartan Gregorian's gift for judging a contribution relative to the job at hand -- and how much it hurts the giver -- is legend (''It Is Better to Give Than to Receive,'' by Claudia Dreifus, Dec. 14). In the early 1980's, my independent, specialized press published a little-known work by William Faulkner from the New York Public Library's collection of manuscripts and donated the sales of the limited edition to its treasured rare-book collection. At a reception in the trustee's room, we presented a check for $20,000 (but it felt like a million; we were months behind in rent and other expenses).

title: Art for Art's Sake (Except, of Course, for the Social Rivalry)
description: THE SETTING: A cocktail party, last Thursday night, for the Apollo Circle, the new junior committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The committee, which has long provided social entry into the charity circuit, is a bit of a departure: anyone can join for a $1,000-a-year fee (a fact sniffed at by traditionalists). The party was held in an exquisite Fifth Avenue apartment, one of five buildings real estate brokers consider the most desirable in the world. The artwork: top of the line 20th-century.

title: Sleek for the Feet
description: ''I usually wear Gucci,'' said Marc Kirshner, a shopper trying on a pair of chocolate brown shoes at the Prada store at Madison Avenue and 70th Street. ''But these are sort of anti-Gucci. They're so understated.'' He was referring to Prada's take on the latest in men's loafers: pared-down and minimal, with barely visible top-stitching, an extended vamp and nary a trademark detail. Variations began to appear last fall.

title: Sports of The Times; Quarterbacks Depend On a Wing and 2 Legs
description: FOR both Brett Favre and Steve Young, today's Packers-49ers showdown is more than just the National Football Conference championship game. It's the ticket to ride to another Super Bowl.

title: Barbados Retreat, English Country Style
description: IT'S 5 o'clock on a Saturday evening in March. Sipping a rum punch, I amble out onto my balcony, only for my eye to detect movement on the roof of one of the cottages across the tropical gardens. I look again. The lean, golden body, the long, curling tail, the black face -- could I be dreaming? Is it a monkey? There were no monkeys here five years ago when I made my first visit.

title: At a Dog's Height, Doggerel
description: In another place, trees and dogs might be considered natural allies. But not in this city.

title: U.S. Declares Five Counties Disaster Area
description: President Clinton declared five upstate New York counties a Federal disaster area yesterday after a historic winter ice storm crippled the region's power system for what could prove to be weeks, spawned bridge-closing floods and turned churches, schools and even a prison into emergency shelters for thousands of people.

title: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
description: HARD COVER

title: Even Private School Students Can Get in a Poolroom Brawl
description: They attend some of the city's most prestigious high schools, like Friends Seminary in Manhattan and the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn. But boys will still be boys, it seems.

title: HUFF AND PUFF
description: In a cruel blow, California ushered in the New Year with a ban on smoking in the holy of holies -- bars -- and as usual in these skirmishes there's strong opposition. Well, at this point, mostly there's just Raymond Sasso, president of Forces (Fight Ordinances and Restrictions to Control and Eliminate Smoking), a two-year-old California group dedicated to puffer justice. Sasso, 45, admits that there's not much he can do -- he recently sent out a tart ''European advisory'' to urge tourists to boycott the Golden State -- so he's putting his hopes on civil disobedience. ''Police have better things to do,'' he says, citing rumors that the law will be widely ignored, ''than give someone a ticket for smoking in a bar.''

title: The Diversity Doctor
