description: VIVODH ANAND's house is right on the border between Glen Ridge and Montclair. His living room is in one town, his dining room in the other. It is a quirk of geography that is also an apt metaphor for a man who has spent his entire life straddling cultures.

title: A Couple of Kingmakers Talking Shop
description: Ralph reed and george stephanopoulos, the most famous 36-year-olds in American politics, are in career transition. After six years in the service of Bill Clinton, Stephanopoulos quit his job as senior adviser to the President in 1997 to write his memoirs, teach at Columbia University and serve as resident talking head for ABC News. The same year, Reed left his job as executive director of the Christian Coalition to start a campaign consulting firm for ''pro-family, pro-life, pro-free-enterprise'' candidates.

title: Classical Briefs
description: KODALY: 'PEACOCK VARIATIONS'; BLACHER: 'PAGANINI VARIATIONS'; ELGAR: 'ENIGMA VARIATIONS'

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 28 about living in Fresh Meadows, Queens, misstated the positions of two brokers who supplied information on housing prices. Paula Hellman and Pamela Dickman of First Choice Real Estate are employees, not partners.

title: January 4-10; A Grim Holy Month
description: In Algeria's civil war, at least 600 villagers -- perhaps 1,000 -- from the western hills have been slaughtered since Dec. 30, the start of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. Most reports blame Islamic fundamentalists who have been fighting the military-backed Government for six years, although critics accuse the Government of indifference or even complicity in the killings. Some experts believe the villagers were targeted for ritual sacrifice in the Muslim holy month of fasting because they had moved away from earlier support for the fundamentalists. CRAIG R. WHITNEY

title: YANNI TAKES MANHATTAN
description: * Starting Wednesday, Yanni -- the shaggy-haired New Age instrumentalist from Greece -- will perform 10 sold-out concerts at Radio City Music Hall, part of an 18-month, 200-concert world tour. * Half a billion people have seen his 1994 special, ''Yanni: Live at the Acropolis.'' * Yanni's ''Tribute'' video is based on Yanni concerts last year in India and China, where not all were thrilled. Five watermelon farmers near the Taj Mahal -- who wanted extra compensation for letting fans trample their land -- threatened to set themselves on fire in protest . . . but backed down. * Also anti: the No Yanni Organization, a Web-based group that calls Yanni's music ''evil.'' * No matter. Ed Micone, executive producer at Radio City, says he could sell out 20 Yanni shows: ''It's phenomenal! It's huge! I don't even think he's scratched the surface yet.''

title: Feathering Their Nests
description: THE natural world is full of hyperactive home builders.

title: Carrying On an Inventive Print Workshop
description: ON a cul-de-sac not far from the Robert Moses Causeway is a gray-shingled, two-story Victorian cottage with white trim and a small porch. It is unique among the Cape Cod-style homes in this West Islip neighborhood. The little house with a large catalpa tree in its front yard was the former gardener's residence of a nearby estate -- and the birthplace and current headquarters of Universal Limited Art Editions.

title: Pippen Gets Off to Fast Start in His Return
description: The Bulls' Scottie Pippen swished a jump shot against the Golden State Warriors last night with 10 minutes 47 seconds left in the first period. This would hardly be news under normal circumstances, but last night's circumstances were not normal.

title: CONTRABAND WOMEN -- A special report.; Traffickers' New Cargo: Naive Slavic Women
description: Irina always assumed that her beauty would somehow rescue her from the poverty and hopelessness of village life. A few months ago, after answering a vague ad in a small Ukrainian newspaper, she slipped off a tour boat when it put in at Haifa, hoping to make a bundle dancing naked on the tops of tables.

title: Ideas & Trends: Black and White Is Back; Color 'Em Wrong
description: IT used to be chiseled in granite: Viewers and readers of newspapers and magazines, especially if they are young, don't much care for black and white. They don't want it. They don't like it. Please take it away.

title: Experienced Hand in a Familiar Setting
description: ALEANNA gives early promise that it will stop the never-ending parade of restaurants at 1034 Broadway in Woodmere and become a perennial. It was deja vu time as I entered. Yes, it looked different, with its warm, country-European flair, but this was definitely the same spot that had recently been the short-lived G. Roberts Steakhouse. Older memories of Italian restaurants -- the casual Caffe Milano and the more traditional La Rondinella -- also surfaced.

title: A Prestidigitator With His Own Journal of Oddities
description: THE SUBJECT OF A forthcoming issue of Jay's Journal of Anomalies, its creator, Ricky Jay, said recently, will be cheating at bowling, half a dozen or so pages of text about scams involving alleys and pins. Mr. Jay is, of course, the sleight-of-hand artist and cardsharp who will reprise his peripatetic one-man show, ''Ricky Jay and His 52 Assistants,'' for 10 weeks beginning Wednesday Off Broadway.

title: Sports of The Times; Matching Expectations, Earning Olympic Berths
description: EIGHT 6.0's.

title: Ailing Player in Cart Shares Nike Event Lead
description: The golfer with the pronounced right leg limp, the one bucking the PGA Tour in an effort to change a 103-year-old rule that requires all golfers to walk the course, made quite a case for himself today.

title: On Foreign Policy, Congress Is in Touch
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie Finkelstein And Alan Rosen
description: Leslie Beth Finkelstein, a daughter of Nora and Neil A. Finkelstein of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married last evening to Alan L. Rosen, a son of Sondra and Walter Rosen of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: January 4-10; Indonesia's Crisis Deepens
description: Just when Washington thought it had contained the Asian contagion in Korea, it erupted again -- this time back in Indonesia. President Suharto's Government promised wide reforms when the International Monetary Fund came in with an economic bailout package in October. But Indonesia has now backtracked on those commitments, especially rules that would impinge on the multibillion-dollar Suharto family enterprises. All week the Indonesian currency fell like a rock, and residents of Jakarta began to hoard food.

title: University Seeks Older Women For Study of Their Health
description: The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey needs to find 1,000 women who are aged 60 to 79 and are willing to commit some time for the next eight years to help further the knowledge of the effects of hormone treatments and other factors on the health of older women.

title: Beyond Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Beach Considers 6-Acre Super Block
description: A PLAN that could revitalize Long Beach with the construction of a hotel and convention center on a six-acre beachfront site has stirred up residents who said they were unaware of the full scope of the project.

title: 'Cancerscam'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONK, JACOB
description: BONK-Jacob, 77. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. On January 1, 1998, at Delray Community Hospital in Delray Beach, Florida. He is survived by Bernice, his wife of over fifty years, children, Arnold and Helen Bonk of Fairfield, Conn., Suzanne and Jay Tepper of Scotch Plains, New Jersey, and Loren and Stuart Daitch of Merrick, New York and eight grandchildren, Allison and Jason Bonk, Sam and Sara Tepper, and Jilian, Zachary, Alexander and Sydney Daitch. He was a Holocaust survivor from Warsaw, Poland. After arriving in New York in 1950 he manufactured womens and childrens millinery for over 30 years, and was an active fundraiser for the State of Israel. Jacob lived in Brooklyn and Cedarhurst, New York before retiring to Florida. Services were held January 2, in Delray Beach. The family request donations in his memory be made to National Jewish Medical and Research Center, 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, CO. 80206 or The Holocaust Museum in Washington, D.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURNER, MAC
description: GURNER-Mac. Do go gentle into that good night...Dream and sleep in peace. Love, Freddy and Jack Gurner

title: There's No Justice in the War on Drugs
description: Twenty-five years ago, President Richard M. Nixon announced a ''War on Drugs.'' I criticized the action on both moral and expediential grounds in my Newsweek column of May 1, 1972, ''Prohibition and Drugs'':

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 23 about the relationship between sexual promiscuity and the AIDS epidemic referred imprecisely to the views of Prof. Kendall Thomas of Columbia University Law School. He says that while he does not believe that promiscuity is the essence of gay sexuality, he does believe, as the article stated, that any attempt to fight AIDS by demonizinging the culture of sexual freedom is doomed. And he says AIDS is spread by unsafe sex, not by multi-partner sex.

title: How to Support Nonprofits, and Possibly Make a Profit
description: HOSPITALS and universities have long issued bonds, but in recent years a growing set of other nonprofit groups -- from museums to Y.M.C.A.'s -- have also turned to debt. For investors, the change means more chances to get tax-exempt yields, but also to run aground on risky bonds put forth by financially struggling institutions.

title: Screen Savers
description: Chic or geek? Those who can't imagine lugging their laptops around in computer tote bags -- and are prepared to spend up to half again as much as a new laptop might cost -- can now turn to the likes of Bulgari, Prada, Gucci and even the classic briefcase maker Hartmann.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, JAMES P., SR.
description: NOLAN-James P., Sr., of Northport, NY, on January 8, 1998, 83 years of age. Founder of the Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home. Devoted husband of the late Anne T. (nee O'Rourke). Loving father of James P., Jr., (Pamela), Jeanne A., Thomas P., (Carolyn), and Peter J. (Laure). Cherished grandfather of Jemina, Michael, Patrick, Megan, Mark, Brian, Erin and the late James. Visiting at the funeral home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport. Funeral mass Monday, 11 AM, at St. Philip Neri Church, Northport. Interment at Parish Cemetery. Donations may be made in his memory to the United Leukodystrophy Foundation, 2304 Highland Drive, Sycamore, IL 60178, or to V.N.S. Hospice of Suffolk, 505 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768. Hours Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM.

title: How Much Is Enough In Saving for Retirement?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Funds Report; Emerging Markets: Nice Concept, Bad Outcome
description: SOMETIMES linguistics reveals a lot about attitudes. Consider the group of countries now known as emerging markets.

title: Do You Need a Safe? At What Cost?
description: A HOME safe can be an important investment for homeowners with expensive jewelry, rare coins, important documents or other hard-to-replace items.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: ENGLAND

title: Megan Watson, Thomas Kelly
description: Megan Mallory Watson, a daughter of Mary and Paul R. Watson of Midland, Mich., was married yesterday to Thomas More Kelly, a son of Elizabeth and Joseph P. Kelly of New City, N.Y. The Rev. Len Wilkuski performed the ceremony at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Midland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, HERBERT
description: BERMAN-Herbert. We express our sincere condolences to Daisy Berman on the passing of her beloved husband, Herbert. As Golden Founders of the Medical Center, their generous support of our Pediatric Unit and the Jesselson Heart Center has played a vital role in helping to provice comprehensive, state-of-the-art care to the people of Jerusalem. May Daisy, Nathaniel, Sara, Debra and their families have warm and loving memories of a very special and caring individual. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Mrs. Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President Women's Division Sidney Adler, Treasurer Dr. Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: The Nation; Disrupting the Unabomber Trial, but to What End?
description: AFTER Theodore J. Kaczynski threw the Unabom trial into chaos and apparently tried to hang himself last week, his lawyers said it was proof that the defendant was too mentally ill to be able to endure hearing himself described in court as crazy.

title: January 4-10; Pffffft
description: Steve Fossett, a 53-year-old American adventurer, set out from St. Louis to become the first to ride a balloon around the world nonstop.

title: A Show of Efficiency vs. a Show of Extravagance
description: THE future of the automobile is definitely green.

title: Cally Siderias, Peter Stavropoulos
description: AN only child, Peter Stavropoulos grew up in a rarefied old-world household on the Upper East Side. He could hum along with most major operas by the time he was 10, and like his father, the late fashion designer George Stavropoulos, he could make a handkerchief look like a flower growing out of his front pocket.

title: Why We Go on Vacations
description: THE ping of sunlight bouncing off the shutters woke me. The groans of swollen Honey Belle oranges at the end of their stems drove me out of bed. I went downstairs and picked an orange from the tree, tilted my head back and squeezed the juice into my mouth in one long stream, as if from a wineskin.

title: Puerto Rican Jaunt On a Java Theme
description: WE climbed like sidewinders, slowly spiraling up one curve after another, relentlessly, in a fine, warm rain. The road was just wide enough to accommodate two cars, its macadam striated here and there with ribbons of terra cotta earth, shed from the hills during miniature mud slides. Above and on either side grew a protective canopy of dense, dripping greenery. Three thousand feet below us the sun shone on the beaches, bars and casinos of the tourist's Puerto Rico. In our rented Hyundai, my friend Marguerite and I had left all that behind for a western pocket of the Cordillera Central, the island's mountainous interior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, JOHN G.
description: WALKER-John G. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John G. Walker, associated with The Times from 1932, until retiring in 1969.

title: Pool Project Is On, Sans Southampton
description: SOUTHAMPTON officials have been planning to build an indoor swimming facility for more than a decade, but in a stunning turn of events two institutions it enlisted to share costs announced they will proceed -- without the municipality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LA FAYE, ROBERT
description: La FAYE-Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert La Faye, associated with The Times from 1961, until retiring in 1974.

title: Deer vs. People: The Debate Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, CANON JOHN WEBB
description: GRAHAM-Canon John Webb, E.D., Q.C., B.A., LI.B., D.S.Litt., U.E. Peacefully at home, on Friday, January 9, 1998 in his 86th year. Beloved husband of Natasha. Loving father of Ann Grahman Calderisi and Ted Rogers. Caring fatherin-law of Loretta Rogers. Dear brother of Betty C. Graham. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Edward, Melinda and Martha Rogers and Rafe Calderisi. Great-grandfather of Chloe Rogers. Step-father of Norman Nicholas Campbell and Tanya O'Neil. Predeceased by his wife Velma Rogers Graham. A true gentleman with a distinguished service in the law, business, the military, his church and public service. The family will receive friends at the Humphrey Funeral Home-A.W. Miles Chapel, 1403 Bayview Avenue, Toronto, from 3-5 P.M. and 7-9 PM on Sunday, January 11, 1998. Funeral service Monday, January 12, 1998, 11 o'clock Grace Church On-TheHill, 300 Lonsdale Road (bet. Ave Road and Spadina Road) Toronto. . Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to The John Webb Graham Library, Trinity College, Univ. of Toronto would be appreciated.

title: N.F.L. PLAYOFFS: CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS -- A CASE OF THE KILLER D's; For Broncos, Steelers, 49ers and Packers, Defense Is the Path to the Super Bowl
description: Green Bay, San Francisco, Denver and Pittsburgh did not arrive in today's National Football League conference championship games without violent defense. And none will reach Super Bowl XXXII without it.

title: Hall Snaps Back From Blowout
description: Before today's game, Villanova Coach Steve Lappas tried to offer Seton Hall's first-year coach, Tommy Amaker, a bit of encouragement. Trying to keep Amaker's spirits up after a humbling defeat at Rutgers on Wednesday, Lappas told him to hang in there.

title: Concierge to the Literary Pack
description: ANYONE who heads into the wilds of New York night life is bound to stumble across Clifford Streit, a Zelig-like character who has forged a career out of nurturing the tender egos of some of Manhattan's beautiful people. Mr. Streit calls himself a manager, and his clients are all easy on the eyes: they are mostly authors who used to be models, and models yearning to write. Mr. Streit's world runs on an up-to-the-moment modification of Darwin's theory of evolution: survival of the prettiest.

title: From Gurus to Sitting Ducks
description: EARLY one morning last July, five of the media industry's most powerful executives gathered around a table before a select audience in a windowless conference room at Idaho's Sun Valley Lodge. It was a formidable lineup: Rupert Murdoch, Gerald Levin, David Geffen, Barry Diller and Edgar Bronfman Jr. And because this was the annual conference run by the investment firm Allen & Company, the atmosphere was aggressively casual -- just five guys in chinos and polo shirts chatting about world domination.

title: Another Issue, Another Private Meeting With Babbitt
description: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has said that his biggest mistake in the Wisconsin casino controversy was meeting with one of the lobbyists involved in the fight. If so, it appears to be a mistake he repeated on another occasion on a different issue.

title: Mystery of Welded Metal Sculpture
description: THE sculptor Al Landzberg is intrigued by intersections. To him the point where two forms meet is as complex and mysterious as a poem. He fools the viewer, revealing a honeycomb where the eye perceived a straight line. Sculpture, he says, demands motion -- the locomotion of the observer, who is advised to walk around a work in order to know it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARATZ, BARBARA L.
description: KARATZ-Barbara L. On December 29, 1997. Wife of William W. Karatz and the late V. Theodore Low. Mother of the late Joyce L. Furth. Grandmother of Nicholas, Joshua and Owen Gutfreund. Great grandmother of Charlotte and Willa Gutfreund. Sister of the late Robert R. Lansburgh and Rosalee Leeds. Sister-in-law of Ruth Lansburgh. Interment private. Memorial service Sunday, January 11th, 4 PM, at The Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be may to the Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, New York or the Barbara Karatz Book Fund at The New York Public Library.

title: Richard Hamming, 82, Dies; Pioneer in Digital Technology
description: Richard Wesley Hamming, who discovered mathematical formulas that allow computers to correct their own errors, making possible such innovations as modems, compact disks and satellite communications, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Monterey, Calif., where he lived. He was 82.

title: A Day With No Spending Has Its Satisfactions
description: To the Editor:

title: Starting From Scratch, Ferraro Is Far Back in Raising Money
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro announced that she would enter New York's United States Senate race in a brief, exuberant tour across the state last week. But for the next few months, she will have to lead something of a cloistered existence -- hunkering down in a makeshift office, phone in hand, appealing for campaign contributions from wealthy people, many of whom she has never met. Hour after hour, one entreaty after another, a political supplicant telemarketing her way through the day.

title: Autissier Faces New Test: 62 Days and 2 Opponents
description: One of the most famous of all athletes in France slipped into New York City virtually unnoticed last Wednesday. She was in her sailboat, the 60-foot sloop PRB, as she passed the Stature of Liberty into New York Harbor, so who could have seen her?

title: 'Bible Society Reaches Out'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Shifting Certainties In the Abortion War
description: I'M pro-choice,'' Leslie Singman says. ''Always was and always will be.'' Mrs. Singman, a 35-year-old saleswoman from Potomac, Md., grew up believing that no child should be an unwanted child. She sends money to the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League, and never thought to question her views -- until she got pregnant and saw her daughter on the ultrasound screen.

title: Lace Curtains, Very French and Very Cozy
description: VOILA! -- which is subtitled Bistro Francaise -- in Fairfield is the kind of discovery you like to keep to yourself. It is so tiny (15 tables) and cozy (inside a frame house with a fieldstone fireplace dominating a single L-shaped dining room) and the food so exactly right, that you fear any avalanche of popularity might ruin its charm.

title: The World In a Cup Of Coffee
description: AS far as Francesco and Andrea Illy are concerned, there's nothing like a bunch of artists in their cups -- or rather, on their cups. On Tuesday, the Italian company Illycaffe had a party for the most recent addition to their set of artist-designed coffeeware: Robert Rauschenberg's cups and saucers covered with maps of New York, Moscow, Berlin, Mexico City, London, Stockholm and Rio de Janeiro.

title: The Hollywood Stock Market: You Can't Lose
description: AS the swooning Dow led you to wonder whether the only difference between Wall Street and the Titanic is that one of them had a band? If so, then maybe you are ready to open an account at the Hollywood Stock Exchange, where shares of the movie ''Titanic'' (ticker symbol: TITAN) are rising faster than those of Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANDEWELT, BELLE
description: ANDEWELT-Belle. Love to talk to you again. We all say hello, when you see me again, I'll be a little fatter, a little grayer and not so handsome.

title: History Reveals Itself in Strange Ways
description: SO, what'll it be: Must See TV or the History Channel? For more and more people, this is not a silly question.

title: Chernobyl, Help for a Deadly Legacy
description: IT took only a few seconds for one of the nuclear reactors at Chernobyl, Ukraine, to explode on April 26, 1986, and start spewing radioactive material into the atmosphere. But the toxic legacy of the incident will last for decades, if not generations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIEFFELIN, G. RICHARD
description: SCHIEFFELIN-G. Richard of Tampa, FL, and Billings, MT. Loving father and friend to many, died January 3rd of Leukemia. Dick committed his life to providing philanthropic support and academic/career counseling to more than two thousand eight hundred students over the past forty years. A graduate of St. Paul's School and Hobart College, he assisted students attending many colleges and universities, including Yale, Harvard, Hobart, Princeton, Columbia, University of Tampa, University of South Florida, University of Montana, Montana State University and Rocky Mountain College where he recently received an honorary doctorate. Dick is survived by his three sons: David Schieffelin, his wife Stacey and their daughter Sydney McKay of Glen Cove, NY; Peter Schieffelin Nyberg and his wife Judy of Durham, NC, Monte Reynolds-Schieffelin of Tuscon, AZ; his brother Dr. John W. Schieffelin and his wife Marion of Lafayette, CA; his niece Cynthia and her husband Barry Lawson of Key West, FL; his nephew John Schieffelin of New Orleans, LA. Dick requested that no funeral services be held locally but wanted loved ones to remember him as he lived with humor, with heart and with an unselfish commitment to help others. A scholarship fund has been established in his memory. Donations should be addressed to the G. Richard Schieffelin Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O David Schieffelin, 84 Highland Road, Glen Cove, New York 11542.

title: French Police Evict Jobless Protesters From Government Offices
description: A day after promising emergency funds for the worst hit of France's 3.1 million unemployed workers, France's Prime Minister today ordered the police to eject jobless protesters from public offices they had occupied since last month to press demands for higher benefits.

title: A New Breed In Medicine: 'Hospitalist'
description: THERE was a time when Paul Tortorice knew his regular doctor would be with him every step of his hospital stay. But when the 61-year-old Wall Street executive recently entered Winthrop-University Hospital after jabbing chest pains, a doctor with whom he was barely acquainted prescribed medications, ordered and reviewed tests and approved his discharge 13 days later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIRDLER, HELEN BRYANT
description: GIRDLER-Helen Bryant, 88. Of Boca Raton, Florida. Died on Monday, January 5 at Boca Raton Community Hospital. Mrs. Girdler was born in St. Louis, Missouri, lived for many years in Montclair, New Jersey and moved to Florida in 1964. She is survived by her two sons, R. Bryant Girdler of Boca Raton, Florida and John B. Girdler of Panama City, Florida. She is also survived by five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be directed to Boca Raton Community Hospital. The family appreciates your heartfelt thoughts and remembrances.

title: Washington Discovers Christian Persecution
description: I was appalled by some of the revelations in Goldberg's article. It is unconscionable that American Christians would even raise a debate about whether to work toward mitigating the atrocities committed against their brethren in repressive countries. Does anyone question the propriety of condemning the plight of Soviet Jews or Bosnian Muslims? Do Christians in our society really harbor such an egregious self-loathing?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTER, THEODORE G.
description: RITTER-Theodore G. Suddenly in Seattle, December 30. Mass and interment in NY, January 10. Survived by sister and brother-in-law, Doris and Robert Rutzel, a nephew and three nieces.

title: 49ers' Rookie Coach Stands Up to the Rush
description: Surrounded, unable to retreat, with hostile forces closing in, the San Francisco 49ers' coach, Steve Mariucci, had no choice but to surrender to the questions this week.

title: Ranger Game Is Postponed
description: The Rangers boarded their airplane yesterday, ready to go to Montreal for last night's game against the Canadiens. But before they could take off, a series of telephone calls brought word that the game was postponed because of weather problems in Montreal.

title: Truly Untouristed, The Falkland Islands
description: The Falkland Islands, the British dependent territory about 250 miles off the southeastern coast of Argentina, considers itself one of the least visited places on earth. (Only 65 Americans turned up in 1996, for example.)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Drugs you sell once and they are gone. Women can earn money for a long time.''

title: The Gambler
description: THE old man was born under a bad sign. His mother's innards ruptured while trying to birth him into this world. He made it, she didn't and that's about where his luck ended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, CONRAD
description: SIEGEL-Conrad. On January 2. Devoted father of Howard and Leslie. Grandfather to Trevor and Chelsea. Brother of Allie and Ray. Brother-in-law to Marlene. He will always be with us. Services in Boca Raton, FL. on January 18. Private service in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEIGER, PHILIP
description: GEIGER-Philip. January 11, 1978. Even though you left us 20 years ago, your legacy of warmth, wisdom, humor and kindness lives on in our hearts and our minds. The clarity of your insights grows almost exponentially. The generosity of your spirit is a daily beacon of enlightenment. And the sound of your unique laughter rings delightfully in our ears. We thank you. You are forever a part of us. The Geiger Family

title: Woman Ascending A Marble Staircase
description: Julia Flesher Koch, a young woman of manners and social ambition from Conway, Ark., much admired in her Upper East Side circle for marrying one of the richest men in America, made her New York society debut last month when she ascended the stairs of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in an explosion of flashbulbs and expectations. It was what the Met calls ''the party of the year,'' the annual benefit for its Costume Institute, and Julia Koch, 34, a former Adolfo assistant who literally dressed Nancy Reagan in the old court designer's knitted suits, was co-chairwoman -- a position held in the past by both Pat Buckley and Jacqueline Onassis.

title: At 10 or at 90, an Actress Is Every-Brahmin
description: MABEL TIDINGS BIGELOW is a memorable fictional character you might like to meet in the person of the enchanting Cherry Jones, who plays her to the core of Mabel's singular being in the Lincoln Center Theater production of ''Pride's Crossing,'' Tina Howe's bittersweet feminist comedy currently at the Mitzi E. Newhouse.

title: Young, Meet Old
description: More young people these days seem to be fascinated with all things retro. No wonder that the 44th annual Winter Antiques Show, the opening of the winter social season, is making a big effort to court young collectors who have a taste for the traditional -- and money to spend on things like a Queen Anne bureau, circa 1710 (below). On Friday, organizers will hold the second annual Young Collectors Night, expected to draw at least 500 people, twice as many as last year.

title: An Unsung Artist
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET TIMING
description: TUESDAY

title: Giving More Leeway To Gifted Students
description: The article ''Student Denied Credit in Math Acceleration'' [Nov. 23] really gives insight into how misunderstood gifted students really are. Policies which prohibit or even just discourage gifted students from taking accelerated classes are misguided, regardless of whether they claim to be based on concerns about emotional maturity or simply that ''There's no reason to rush.''

title: POSTINGS: Architecture Exhibit on 'Courthouses in Historic Contexts'; Designs for Justice
description: Models and renderings of 16 new courthouses from around the nation are part of an exhibit called ''Precedent and Invention: New Courthouses in Historic Contexts'' opening at the new United States Court House at Foley Square on Thursday.

title: Playing Iran Against Iraq Won't Work for U.S.; Cold-War Warmth
description: To the Editor:

title: Callas Sings Bob Dylan? Could Be
description: FIFTY YEARS AGO, THE LP RECORD WAS introduced, the tape recorder began to be generally available, and the first pieces of electronic music -- ''musique concrete,'' to use the term devised by the first explorer of the medium, Pierre Schaeffer -- were created. Fifty years before that, the recording industry was being born: in 1898, a year after the company that is now EMI was established, Deutsche Grammophon came into existence. So the century of recorded music is neatly divided at its halfway point, by technological changes that altered the nature of how music was heard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLONER, FRED (POPPY)
description: POLONER-Fred (Poppy). On December 27, 1997. Husband, Father, Grand-father, Uncle, Friend. A Sweet, Kind, Gentle Man.

title: Unloved Armory's Demise Looms
description: The 14th Street Armory, the subject of protests over its use and groans over its drab appearance, is apparently not long for this world. The two leading plans for development of the site both call for the demolition of the gray building.

title: Checkups for School Construction Sites
description: New York City building inspectors will visit about 150 school construction sites in the next few weeks in an attempt to prevent the kind of accident that critically injured a 16-year-old girl on Friday when two bricks fell from a scaffolding at Public School 131 in Brooklyn, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Party Faithful
description: The Christian Coalition

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGEN, JOAN EDITH
description: DEGEN-Joan Edith. Beloved wife of the late Jerome; loving mother of Jill and Glen Pohs and the late Jon Benson Degen; adoring grandmother of Lara and Jamie Pohs; devoted sister of Jerold and Sylvia Granatoor; loving aunt and cousin. Graveside service Sunday, 10:30AM at Cedar Park Cemetery. Donations in her memory to American Diabetes Association or American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROGOFF, IRA, PH.D.
description: PROGOFF-Ira, Ph.D. Author, professor and psychotherapist, died Jan. 1, 1998, in New York City, after a long illness. A memorial service will be held Sunday, Feb. 1, 3 PM, at The New Synagogue, 171 W. 85 St., Dorot Bldg., NYC. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman officiating. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Dept. of Community Medicine, St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 W. 11 Street, NYC 10011, or to The Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy, Johns Hopkins Outpatient Center, 601 N. Caroline Street, Baltimore, MD. 21287.

title: Making The Effort, But Not The Plays
description: It was as if the Chicago Bulls' Michael Jordan was playing in some suburban sector of Madison Square Garden on Friday night.

title: New Security Checks On Domestic Flights
description: Checking in for domestic flights may take longer beginning this month because some passengers will be selected for inspection of their baggage and identification papers based on a secret screening formula adopted by the Federal Aviation Administration. The new procedures will make check-in for domestic flights more like that for inter national departures, including matching some passengers to their checked baggage.

title: Luxury Houses: Strong Market, Low Inventory
description: A BLUE-CHIP investment for generations, real estate in high-income areas of the North Shore is experiencing a boomlet that is helping make six-figure salaries more common for top realty agents. Their only complaint is often a lack of inventory.

title: Parolee, 19, Is Charged In Killing Of Student, 13
description: A 19-year-old parolee was arrested yesterday on charges that he fatally stabbed a 13-year-old Queens honors student as she waited for her mother to return home, the police said.

title: How Much Is Enough In Saving for Retirement?
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Judge Not
description: IT may come as a surprise that one of our most cherished freedoms -- religious liberty -- has been lost in New Jersey, and that a Religious Freedom Restoration Act is needed to put things right. A bill with just that purpose is pending in Trenton, and who can be opposed to religious freedom? The New Jersey Religious Freedom Restoration Act seems well on its way to passage.

title: The Wolverines Deserved It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: Given Disney's meticulous planning of its town, a more fitting name might be Calibration. The company should stick to what it does best: animating movies, not communities.

title: How Much Is Enough In Saving for Retirement?
description: To the Editor:

title: Turks Fear an Oil Disaster as the Bosporus Gets Busier
description: Before dawn on Tuesday, winds from the Black Sea pushed a thick fog bank down the Bosporus, forcing officials to close it to all traffic. Giant oil tankers lined up at both ends until the fog lifted in midafternoon.

title: Imitating Salons of Yore
description: THE term salon music has acquired a slightly unsavory connotation. For most people, it suggests something like the soothing tunes heard in elevators and bank lobbies or the innocuous harp solos that filter through the Plaza Hotel at tea time. A century or two ago, however, salon gatherings were society high points attended by distinguished writers, artists and composers.

title: Sketch Pad
description: Say ''Meadowlands'' and what comes to mind is likely the sports complex, or maybe a glimpse of a plain of reeds as foreground to smokestacks or an office complex. But John R. Quinn looks very closely at the valley of the Hackensack River in ''Fields of Sun and Grass: An Artist's Journal of the New Jersey Meadowlands,'' published by Rutgers University Press ($22.50 paperback, $50 in hardback). Readers may see the vista, in words and sketches (there are 200 drawings), from the summit of Snake Hill, 200 feet above Secaucus. Or in a horizonless thicket of 12-foot-high reeds, an American bittern on its nest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, GERALDINE KEISER
description: ROSENBERG-Geraldine Keiser. Beloved wife of the late Allan H. and mother of Claudia (Tony) and James. Loving sister, grandmother and aunt. Died Saturday in Florida. Graveside service at 2 PM, Sunday, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: Both Deserved It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Foreign Policy, Congress Is in Touch
description: To the Editor:

title: A Memo to Michael: Watch Out for Sonics
description: The new power forward is not only punctual, but he also has yet to misplace his airline ticket. The veteran point guard is still a hand grenade in baggy shorts, but he no longer detonates his own team. The Seattle SuperSonics still have issues. But for once in a great while, they can be smoothed out on the gym floor rather than on a long couch.

title: Auriemma Unsatisfied With UConn Victory
description: CONNECTICUT 94, WEST VIRGINIA 74

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Zachary Rosenbaum, Lori Shalotsky
description: Lori Ellyn Shalotsky, a daughter of Helene and Charles Shalotsky of Chatham, N.J., was married last evening to Zachary David Rosenbaum, a son of Barbara and Michael Rosenbaum of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi William B. Horn officiated at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston.

title: The Museum Party
description: In Buzz, a Fifth Avenue party for the Apollo Circle committee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. How did the partygoers feel about their counterparts at MOMA? With reports from Greenwich Village, the East Village, Washington Heights, Chelsea, Bushwick, Cobble Hill and Sheepshead Bay. (Miles Ladin for The New York Times) PAGES 6-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, LILLY LANGSAM
description: SHAPIRO-Lilly Langsam. Died on January 5th, 1998, leaving a void in the lives of all she touched. A Hunter College graduate, she was a brave, intelligent and generous woman. Predeceased by her sister, Helen Schleien. She is survived by a brother, Kenneth Langsam, devoted daughter, Susan Garfield, two sons, Robert and William Shapiro and 6 grandchildren.

title: A Regular Gig on the Far Side of Celebrity
description: PRISCILLA HERDMAN AND TWO OF HER best friends sit around her oak dining-room table and laugh, drink jasmine tea and eat homemade carrot bread. Outside, corn skeletons rattle in the wind. Black clouds knuckle against the hills.

title: Hat Dancers
description: Is it 1998 or 1948? It's hard to tell, with the number of young women donning cocktail hats for a festive night out, just as women did 50 years ago. With bits of feathers, beads, sequins or netting, the hats are being worn uptown and downtown, adding an extra dash of glamour to evening party attire.

title: The Promised Land
description: Paradise

title: The View From/Constitution Island; In 1838 Two Sisters Create a New World in an Isolated Outpost
description: IMAGINE two teen-age girls, plucked from the social world of upper-class Manhattan, set down in a cottage on a virtually barren island because their father has lost his fortune. A few years later, most of the furniture and china they had brought with them has to be sold because money troubles worsened. Instead of mahogany beds, linen dresses and lovely parties, there is wood to chop, cheap towels that are stitched into dresses, and a boat that must be rowed to the mainland for provisions.

title: Passing the Clues Along With the Salt
description: DOWNSTAIRS at Il Giardino Ristorante on Friday and Saturday nights, Murder to Go Theater caters to cravings for crime with supper on the side. No, it isn't take-out, and it isn't just another dinner theater offering a streamlined ''42d Street,'' an unabridged ''Star-Spangled Girl'' or perhaps the revue of the month. But then, in standard dinner theater, first you eat.

title: Playing Iran Against Iraq Won't Work for U.S.; Exchanges Have Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, GLADYS R.
description: SMITH-Gladys R. Of Manhattan on January 7, 1998. Dear aunt of Madeleine and John Butler, grand aunt of John Jr., Mark, Anne Baladron, Mary Harkins, Joan Manaster, Peter and Paul. Funeral services were held privately.

title: Blind Newsdealer Could Use Training for Wider World
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rainbow Of Life
description: THE panic set in when I saw him stuff the fourth book of bird pictures into his backpack. My partner, Joe, and I were setting off for a long-awaited vacation in Trinidad. And in terror, I pictured us traipsing through the island in checkered shorts and black nylon knee socks all week long, binoculars dangling from our necks, looking a bit like Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Howell 3d on ''Gilligan's Island.''

title: BEST SELLERS: January 11, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Railroad Schemes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARIES, PETER L.
description: ARIES-Peter L. You were an inspiration to me because you never gave up hope. Peter ''A'' was my devoted business partner for over ten years and my cherished friend forever. I will always remember the wonderful experiences we shared working together at Aries Brandenberg Company (ABC) as the Peters of ''A'' and ''D'' team. I will never forget you. Rest in peace, my friend. Love, Peter ''B'' Brandenberg

title: Graffiti Foe Finds Swastika
description: Councilman Anthony Weiner has made fighting graffiti in his district something of a crusade, so he has become accustomed to finding spray-painted vengeance on the door of his Brooklyn office. So accustomed, in fact, that his staff keeps a can of white paint handy to banish graffiti.

title: In Ambitious Berlin, Art, Too, Is Being Reunified
description: BERLIN IS AN ART CITY, AND A city of art on the move. In the four and a half decades between the end of World War II and the fall of the Berlin wall eight years ago, the treasures of the old Prussian state collections remained on whichever side of the border they found themselves in May 1945. The divided city thus acquired two separate museums for virtually everything -- to the detriment, in every case, of one side or the other. The reconciliation of these halves will consume much of the Berlin cultural budget until at least 2010.

title: Food; Simmer Down
description: Somehow, over the centuries, the word ragout (which in 17th-century France meant anything that stimulated appetite) has come to signify a dish of sturdy consolation. Nearly any simmered food, be it meat, vegetable, fish or fowl, can be called a ragout, although in France, it is generally assumed that the main ingredients will be of a uniform chunk cut into slightly smaller than bite-size pieces.

title: Our Towns; Dream House In Bad Dream: Double Taxes
description: FROM Old Clump Mountain, you can see two ski slopes, most of the Catskills and every star in the sky. Elinor Burkett and Dennis Gaboury fell for it right off. They followed a two-line classified ad in the Sunday Times to the mountain and scooped up the 172 acres for sale that same day.

title: Wherever Whitman Goes, Abortion Debate Follows
description: As Governor Whitman's inauguration approaches, she is being attacked on both the national and the local fronts for her decision last year to veto state legislation banning what opponents call partial birth abortion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWE, BERNICE
description: ROWE-Bernice. Beloved wife of Irwin. Devoted mother of Marla and Jay. Cherished daughter of Mary and Jack Hazan. Adored sister of Caroline (Leonard Fried) and Mona (Stanley) Faust. Loved aunt of Jeff, Mara, Kenneth, Lori, Robert and David. Dear greataunt of Kenny and Ryan. Services today, 11:30 AM, at ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: More Time to See Mount Athos Treasures
description: The Greek exhibition of the treasures of the Mount Athos monasteries has been extended by four months, until April 30, because of its enormous success. The Museum of Byzantine Culture in Salonika said it had received more than 500,000 visitors since the exhibit's opening last June, and the crush has forced the relatively small museum to close its doors at times, turning away eager crowds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, DIANA P.
description: HILL-Diana P. of Princeton, NJ, on January 8, 1998. Born September 11, 1911, in Cork, Ireland. Wife of the late W. Martin Hill, CMG; survived by a son, Colin, daughterin-law, Margaret, and four grandchildren. Funeral service at All Saints Church, Princeton, on January 13 at 11:30 AM.

title: Three Weeks to Enjoy the Third B
description: Brahms's four symphonies, the core of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's Brahms Festival beginning this weekend, are monuments of the literature. So are the two concertos chosen for performance, with undeniably eloquent soloists: Garrick Ohlsson today in the Second Piano Concerto and Gil Shaham next weekend in the Violin Concerto.

title: Deer vs. People: The Debate Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Metaphors for the Wilder Side of Human Life
description: FOR as long as art has existed, it has always harbored a menagerie. Animals' long-held claim on the artistic imagination means there can never be anything fashionable about choosing the genre. Recently, however, exhibitions on the theme of animals have been close upon each other's heels in New Jersey, group shows packed with participants as well as solo turns. If this doesn't exactly point a new trend, it might signal a new urgency, for, these days more than ever, animals are us.

title: IN BRIEF; Utility Taking Measures To React to Power Problems
description: The state Board of Public Utilities issued a final report Dec. 30 listing 26 measures to be taken by General Public Utilities, the state's largest electricity company, in response to complaints after storm-related power problems last year. The utility had already begun work on several key recommendations issued in the fall, a board spokesman said.

title: Theater District Air Rights Rouse Fear of Overdevelopment
description: When Mayor Giuliani disclosed his new plan to redevelop Eighth Avenue, he presented it mainly as an innovative way to preserve the adjacent Theater District. But groups like the Clinton Special District Coalition and the Queens Civic Congress are worried that the plan to allow the substantially wider trading of air rights, will open residential neighborhoods across the city to runaway development.

title: He Paints, He Sculptures, He Legislates
description: Pipe Dream

title: INSIDE
description: Quake Near the Great Wall

title: Indonesia Opposition Chief Calls on President to Resign
description: Indonesia's leading opposition figure, Megawati Sukarnoputri, called on President Suharto today to step down when his term ends in March and told a chanting crowd she was ready to succeed him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELIG, YETTA
description: ZELIG-Yetta. On January 8. Beloved mother of Irma, Abby and Herb Ruder. Devoted grandmother of Antoinette, Beth, Joseph, Michele and Karen. Loving aunt of Malcolm Epstein. Forever in our hearts.

title: Ulster Is Downcast as New Violence Clouds Talks
description: The people of Northern Ireland, both the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority, say they fear that after four months of relative calm the sectarian killing here is on the verge of erupting again.

title: Repairs, Upkeep and Upgrading
description: FOR homeowners, there are a number of tips on improvement, maintenance and repair that experts say could help avoid unexpected expense and unnecessary grief during the coming year.

title: Identity and Vulnerability in Childhood
description: ''Children: In Reality and Fantasy''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Last Trolley

title: January 4-10; No Death Penalty for Nichols
description: A newspaper cartoon had Terry L. Nichols sporting a T-shirt that read: ''I survived the Oklahoma City bombing.'' Mr. Nichols escaped the death penalty after a deeply divided Federal jury in Denver failed to decide just how active a role he played in planning the bombing that killed 168 people at the Oklahoma City Federal Building in 1995. Judge Richard P. Matsch will sentence Mr. Nichols later, but only a jury could have imposed the death penalty -- the sentence already given to his co-conspirator, Timothy J. McVeigh. State prosecutors in Oklahoma City said they want to try both men on first-degree murder charges next year.

title: On Your Own in St. Lucia
description: SINCE St. Lucia's first all-inclusive resort opened 14 years ago, the number of hotels offering the formula -- one price covers room, meals, drinks, activities and sightseeing -- has grown, now accounting for around a third of the more than 3,500 guest rooms on the island, according to the St. Lucia Tourist Board.

title: The Tax Shelter on Wheels
description: The Freshstart Venture Capital Corporation is unique among publicly traded companies in offering shareholders a way to defer capital gains taxes on their other investments.

title: A Health Center for Lesbians
description: Joyce Hunter doesn't seem like the sort of person who would be afraid of her doctor. She does AIDS research. She has a Ph.D. in social welfare and a no-nonsense attitude. But visiting a physician, she said, was often a fearful experience.

title: Staying Alive Without Commercial Runs
description: WHILE the major difference between regional theater (Art) and tryout house (Commerce) is increasingly disregarded, an alternative route to the afterlife of a not-for-profit production becomes ever more apparent. Recent stagings by major theaters in the metropolitan area are having extended lives without commercial runs.

title: Curse of the Vacant Driveway
description: MY car was losing oil at the rate of about a quart a mile. At every stop it left a dark pool on the parking spot, a treacherous slick just waiting to send some unsuspecting shopper crashing to the ground. In the end the awful fact had to be faced, and the sick vehicle was towed into the dark canyons of the repair shop. It was really serious, they said, no chance of obtaining the parts for a couple of days. And they gave me a ride home in the tow truck.

title: White Plains Center for Culture Makes Gains
description: THIS is a city rich in history and shopping dollars, a retail hub known as the birthplace of New York State. But even its boosters admit to a lackluster quality here, a blandness in place of charm and color, a silence where applause and laughter should enliven the night.

title: A Hand Up For a City's Walking Wounded
description: WHEN the Rev. Jim Watson and his wife, Tammy, arrived in Bridgeport in 1993 to start a rescue mission, few gave them much chance of succeeding. Those familiar with the city told the couple -- who had run a rescue mission in Fairmont, W.Va. -- about Bridgeport's reputation for violence.

title: Return of the American
description: THE DEEP GREEN SEA

title: The Stingy Decade
description: To the Editor:

title: New in '98, From Coneflower to Impatiens
description: WHAT'S new in annuals and perennials? Each gardening year begins with enticing offerings of a plethora of seed catalogues.

title: Model Trains Take A High-Tech Track
description: AT the Eli Whitney Museum in New Haven, electric trains whiz over an intricate layout with familiar features, like New Haven Harbor. Visitors settle into seats to operate the trains, while faraway fans can view the exhibition -- and even run two of its nine working trains -- on their computer screens.

title: Ansonia Restaurant Failed for Specific Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Figures on Parade

title: Fatima Ramos, Kenneth Marcuse
description: Fatima Maria Ramos, a psychiatric nurse, and Kenneth Ways Marcuse, a lawyer, were married yesterday at Bridgewaters in New York. Justice Frederic S. Berman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: El Nino Throws Travelers a Curve Ball
description: EL NINO, the oceanic oscillation that changes the world's weather every several years, has already disrupted many a vacation. The hurricane that devastated Acapulco a few months ago was probably a manifestation of El Nino. The more serious effects predicted worldwide include drought and even famine in some developing regions. With the current El Nino appearing to be the most pronounced such occurrence of the century -- and perhaps the most widely discussed -- travelers are turning to meteorologists before making reservations.

title: Man, 27, Dies After He Is Shot by a Jealous Boyfriend, Police Say
description: A 27-year-old Staten Island man died yesterday after being shot in the stomach Friday by his former girlfriend's jealous lover in Brooklyn, the police said. Investigators said that the victim had been on his way to the woman's apartment to give their 3-year-old daughter a belated Christmas present.

title: Performances Spun From a Big Heart
description: IT IS NO SURPRISE THAT many present-day enthusiasts of singing are unfamiliar with the Danish tenor Aksel Schiotz. He effectively stopped performing 50 years ago and died in 1975, in Copenhagen. But Schiotz was a remarkable artist, and his distinctive timbre and superb powers of interpretation have secured cult status for him among connoisseurs of the voice.

title: The New Tobacco Tax
description: Cigarette taxes have doubled, to 80 cents a pack; the money will go to schools and health care for uninsured. Will the change discourage smoking?

title: In Asia, Stocks Melt Faster Than in '29
description: It's not hard to catch an orange if someone throws one to you. But it gets more difficult if you're juggling eggs at the time.

title: On Foreign Policy, Congress Is in Touch
description: To the Editor:

title: Nearly Perfect Kwan Wins Olympic Trial
description: Skating a confident, heartfelt long program tonight, Michelle Kwan regained the national figure skating title that she lost a year ago in a fit of panic. Her routine may be remembered as the greatest performance ever by an American skater at the national championships.

title: Backtalk; The Drug-Use Genie Is Out of the Vial
description: The East German swim coach was incredulous over the question: why do his record-setting female swimmers speak with such low-pitched voices?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, BERTHA B.
description: GOTTLIEB-Bertha B. 1912-1998. Devoted wife and mother. Wife of the late Peter. Loving mother of Samuel and Robert. Sister of Rhoda Hooper. Brother of David Barish. A very special woman.

title: He Was Destined to Rule but Sentenced to Exile
description: Kundun

title: Getting the Bugs Out of the Beetle and Boomers Back In
description: THINK back 30 years to a different time when Volkswagen Beetles in every hue took long-haired young men and women in jeans and sandals on the road. It was a time when the lighters weren't just for cigarettes and when a generation of drivers were more worried about war than highway accidents.

title: Belgians Speed Trip To Brussels by Train
description: Travelers can get from London and Paris to Brussels faster now that the Belgian National Railways' upgraded tracks allow trains to reach speeds of up to 186 miles per hour. The trip between Paris and Brussels aboard a high-speed Thalys train has been cut from about two hours to less than 90 minutes. The run between Brussels and London takes about two hours and 40 minutes via Eurostar, also known as the Chunnel train. The journey used to take three hours and 15 minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMBERGER, CHARLES M.
description: HEMBERGER-Charles M. On January 6, 1998 of Secaucus, New Jersey, age 41. Owner of Gartners Hardware in Manhattan. Devoted son of Gloria Hemberger and the late Charles. Dear brother of Janice Heltai and Joyce Gomillion, beloved friend of George Arevalo. Services were held Friday, January 9 at Epiphany R. C. Church, Cliffside Park, New Jersey. Donations can be sent to the Ryan White Foundation.

title: To the Rescue of the Hemlocks: Armies of Ladybugs and Fungi
description: Scientists are preparing trial assaults on a parasite that has been slowly killing hemlocks throughout the Northeast. And the test armies are two exotic varieties of ladybug.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Money & Business/Section 3 (2 Parts)

title: More Tests for E. Coli
description: To the Editor:

title: Reunion on the Web For the Class of '78
description: WHEN the Staples High School class of 1978 reunion committee met last fall to begin planning its 20-year celebration, the focus was on finding a way to streamline the task of tracking down 555 people spread out across the country.

title: Touring Asia on Mouse-Back
description: After a little hemming and hawing, the Asia Society, founded in 1956 by John D. Rockefeller 3d, has been noodged onto the Internet. Several Asia-related institutions had been asking the Manhattan society, known for its scholarship and art exhibits, if they could electronically link their Web sites to the society's.

title: Old Fuss and Feathers
description: AGENT OF DESTINY

title: New Scare Tactics, Low on Blood and Gore
description: HORROR FILMS HAVE WAXED and waned in popularity over the last 70 years, but the genre has proved almost as indestructible as the monsters who populate its haunted castles and subterranean tombs. At the moment, horror is on the rise again, though some of the purveyors of the new breed of horror movies will go to almost any length to avoid the label. ''I don't like to describe it as a horror film,'' said Charles Roven as he talked about the new movie ''Fallen,'' which he produced.

title: Liberties; Grow Up, Harry
description: Everything that follows is perfectly obvious, but I can't stop thinking it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENBERG, IRMA STRAUSS
description: FREUDENBERG-Irma Strauss. January 5, 1998, age 94. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. She will be missed by her many friends.

title: Ancient Rituals Of Geishas Explored
description: THE geisha, in her lavish kimono and her stylized, theatrical makeup, has been a misunderstood and mysterious woman in the Western World, but the Japan Society may remedy that to some extent. Arthur Golden, author of the novel ''Memoirs of a Geisha,'' and Jodi Cobb, photographer for the book ''Geisha: The Life, the Voices, the Art'' (both published by Knopf) will tap their extensive research in a talk about the geisha at the Japan Society tomorrow evening. (Two of Ms. Cobb's photos from the book are at left.)

title: How Much Is Enough In Saving for Retirement?

title: Drama! Ceramics! Pixels!
description: A benefit for the New Victory, Rauschenberg's new cups and an artist's new computer-designed pad.

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: At a recent town meeting charged with modifying our centuries-old town center, many residents held the view that quirkiness and randomness were essential characteristics of our town's design and that any modifications should respect those qualities.

title: Gunmen At Luxor Not Known As Radicals
description: Just two weeks ago, the relatives of Karam Mohammed Ismail had become so worried about their missing 18-year-old son that they prepared to place an advertisement in a local newspaper.

description: ANYONE who thinks the editor of Cosmopolitan magazine should live a life of leopard print and mirrored ceilings would be sorely disappointed visiting the home of Bonnie Fuller.

title: Losing a Son and, Finally, Burying Him
description: STEVE BASSETT died quietly in his sleep on New Year's Day, sometime before the morning nurse looked in on him at the nursing home in Mendham. He was 17, going on 38.

title: Archives Yield Aid for Claims On Holocaust
description: After World War II, Holocaust survivors and relatives of victims pressed insurance claims against German and Italian companies, which denied many of them because the claimants lacked death certificates, policy numbers or other documentation.

title: Ms. Robelot, Mr. DeCarvalho
description: Dorothy Jane Robelot, a co-anchor of the CBS program ''This Morning'' in New York, and Mario Rui Goncalves DeCarvalho, a cameraman for CBS News, also in New York, were married yesterday at the Trinity United Methodist Church in Greenville, S.C. The Rev. Dr. Colin Goode, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, in which George Paul Robelot, an evangelical missionary and a brother of the bride, took part.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Under the Red Flag Stories. By Ha Jin. University of Georgia, $22.95.

title: Jack Conway, 80, Leader in War on Poverty
description: Jack T. Conway, who as an official of the Johnson Administration worked to establish Head Start and several other Great Society programs, died on Tuesday morning at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGGART, HENRY JOSEPH
description: TAGGART-Henry Joseph, 75, passed away on Monday, January 5, 1998. He was a resident of Bal Harbour, FL., formerly of New York City. Beloved husband of Shirley and brother of one surviving sister Elizabeth McNamara, and uncle of Christina, Frank and Robert. A memorial mass will be scheduled at a future date. He will be deeply missed.

title: Democrats, In Control, Divide Spoils
description: IT is official. Never before has there been a Democratic County Executive and a Democratic-controlled Board of Legislators in Westchester.

title: Mutual Funds Report; There's Strength in Diversity
description: RAY POLESE, a savings plan administrator at Lucent Technologies, decided to take the plunge with his own money about a year ago. He sold all the fixed-income investments in his personal 401(k) retirement plan and put the money into three stock funds and Lucent stock. ''I started to listen to our financial education programs,'' Mr. Polese, 49, said. ''If you have time before retirement, you should be more aggressive.''

title: A High-Tech Park's Quandary
description: IN the early 1980's the city of New Haven, Yale University and the Olin Corporation had a dream. They would create the Science Park Development Corporation, a nonprofit center for nurturing high-tech businesses in buildings near the Dixwell/Newhallville neighborhood.

title: The Nation: Crying Need; Day-Care Quandary: A Nation at War With Itself
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON last week unveiled a $21 billion package of Federal grants and tax breaks in what he called ''the single largest national commitment to child care in the history of the United States.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHSTEIN, DAVID
description: HOCHSTEIN-David. Beloved husband of Irene. Father of Vivian and Jacqueline. Grandfather of Raymond, Jessica, Alison, Lauren, Yardley and Zoey. Father-in-law of Michael and Joel. Brother of Bernard and Annette. He was a gentleman and scholar, and will be missed by his family, friends and brokers. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, 9:45 AM, Sunday, January 11, 1998.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: THEATER DISTRICT

title: A Little-Known but Big Player In the World of Americana
description: THE CHIPSTONE FOUNDATION, a collection in Milwaukee that has been a powerful buyer of American furniture in recent years, is now a seller too. On Friday, three of Chipstone's 18th-century Philadelphia Chippendale pieces -- a rococo high chest with matching dressing table and chair, all exuberantly carved -- will be auctioned at Christie's in New York. The price expected for the set is $1.5 million to $2.5 million.

title: January 4-10; Cleaning Up Sport Vehicles
description: Worried that sales might be hurt by growing public awareness of light truck pollution, the Ford Motor Company said that all of its sport utility vehicles, including the Ford Explorer and Lincoln Navigator, would be low-emission vehicles for the 1999 model year. This will make them roughly as clean as new cars, at a cost of a little more than $100 a vehicle. Chrysler said that it would make clean-running Jeep Cherokees and Grand Cherokees, but not a cleaner version of the highly popular Dodge Durango. General Motors and foreign auto makers said they would study the issue.

title: January 4-10; A Netanyahu Ally Quits, Leaving His Coalition Shaky
description: In their endless disputes, members of Prime MInister Benjamin Netanyahu's coalition regularly threaten to quit, and the one who has threatened most often has been Foreign Minister David Levy. So it was a surprise to everyone when he actually did it.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: RUSSIA'S WAR

title: New Manager Hits Pavement on 14th
description: Not much more than a decade ago, Union Square was an area to avoid. The park itself was a drug buyer's delight, encircled by gutted buildings. South of it, 14th Street, east and west, was seedy, and toward nightfall, carried an air of menace.

title: New Options for Hiking, Biking
description: A MAILBOX bulging with travel brochures, like one stuffed with seed catalogues, carries the message that it will soon be time to be outdoors, whatever the weather now. The walking and bicycle tour choices are wider this year, reflecting Americans' rising interest in viewing things close up, and taking healthful trips. For those who want to hike or bike in new places, it is time to pore over the options and send deposits.

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: After reading and enjoying Pollan's article, I will never again criticize the color of my neighbor's house. I found the rules of the town disconcerting. Stepford wives and sheep come to mind.

title: January 4-10; Don't Take Our Picture. Please.
description: There is surely only one city on Earth where people could, like Sinatra, think it a big deal that they saw a man dance with his wife. And it isn't Chicago.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Where the Game Matters Most

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: People opt into planned communities because they buy into a concept. The covenants, conditions and restrictions (CC&R's) are the means of implementing the concept. While residents give up some ''freedom'' (e.g. to paint their homes orange or erect bizarre structures), what they get in return is the elimination of the architectural haphazardness, lack of infrastructure and general chaos that is present in most fast-growth urban sprawl. Disney should be applauded, not castigated, for insuring that residents get what they paid for.

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: I found little to celebrate as I read Michael Pollan's article ''Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation'' (Dec. 14), about Celebration, Fla. The community spirit touted by Disney is more about real-estate cynicism and opportunism masked by clever public relations playing into utopian daydreams than about the true spirit of civic participation. Diversity does not mean the choice of false architectural styles in the middle of a reclaimed swamp. Nor does it mean corporate engineering of the ''American hometown.''

title: Another Aspect Of Sports Agent
description: The otherwise interesting and factually correct piece [''Sports Agents as Stars in Their Own Right,'' Nov. 30] left out an important fact in the career of Eric Fleisher and the entire profession of agent in the world of basketball.

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: I read Pollan's article twice. Well done, Mr. P., for showing both sides of the town of Celebration, which still comes off as a kind of plastic, nonplace to live.

title: QUICK BITE/Red Bank; A World Tour That Is Flavorful and Affordable
description: A regular at the Eurasian Eatery, across the street from the landmark Count Basie Theater in Red Bank, once commented that the restaurant's varied menu would be appropriate for the cafeteria at the United Nations.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Catholic Churches Expanding to Meet Parish Needs
description: AFTER almost a century of serving a seven-square-mile area in this eastern Nassau County community, the St. Kilian Roman Catholic Church on Conklin and Elizabeth Streets had become much too small for the needs of the parish.

title: A Studio in Harrison Will Boost Local Movie Making
description: New Jersey's motion picture industry continued to grow in 1997, when 78 feature films were shot here, up from 68 the year before, according to the state Motion Picture and Television Commission. Those numbers can only get bigger, officials say, with plans announced last week by a Manhattan-based production company to build a major film studio in an old pump factory in Harrison. The Shooting Gallery, which produced, ''Sling Blade,'' will spend up to $100 million to create a 100,000-square-foot sound stage, a back lot with permanent subway, hospital, lagoon and courtroom sets, post-production facilities and offices, all available to other production houses, said Larry Meistrich, the Shooting Gallery's founder. He said the project will be a joint venture with Joseph Supor of Lodi, owner of the 30-acre property. They hope to break ground in March, he said.

title: Confused or Not, the X-Philes Keep Coming
description: ON A CROWDED CHRISTMAS shopping day, Barbara Fincher and her sister politely vied for space with another determined shopper at the ''X-Files'' shelf of an independent bookstore in suburban Louisville, Ky. Ms. Fincher, 55, has been a self-described ''X-phile'' for the last year and a half.

title: Q&A/Charles Petschek; Philanthropy Rooted in Music and Israel
description: ALMOST three decades after he died, William Petschek's name lives on in the worlds of music and mathematics, both in the United States and Israel.

title: The Capitalist; Giving Russia The Business
description: ''You've got to be the dumbest lawyer in Eastern Europe,'' I needled Daniel Arbess when we met in 1991. The 30-year-old Canadian-born lawyer from the Wall Street firm White & Case was helping the reform Government of Czechoslovakia solicit bids from foreign investors interested in buying state-owned enterprises. ''Smart'' lawyers worked for the foreign investors who controlled the money, but Arbess harbored a more subtle agenda. By helping the Czech Government, he hoped to boost economic reform in the region as well as make money for himself and his law firm -- and the strategy worked. White & Case made a profitable niche for itself by taking the side of former Soviet-bloc countries as they completed their traverse to capitalism.

title: When Bad Writing Happens to Good Sex
description: A new terror has been added to the lonely life of the novelist: Britain's most dreaded literary prize. Writers are now said to be resorting to the use of Latin or three suggestive dots rather than risk a passage that could earn them The Literary Review's Bad Sex Award.

title: Democrats Lift Ban on Gifts From Noncitizens in U.S.
description: Democratic leaders today lifted their party's self-imposed ban on donations from noncitizens who are legal permanent residents, declaring that the year-old attempt to distance the party from campaign fund-raising abuses had been a mistake.

title: Ottawa
description: Ottawa's position as seat of the federal government means that its people are officially bilingual and professionally courteous. And its location on the border of the stolid English-speaking Province of Ontario and -- just across the Ottawa River -- the more expressive French-speaking Province of Quebec make this gracefully proportioned city, with its modest charms, quin tessentially Canadian.

description: SEIGEL-Pauline Moroch. Born New York, September 3, 1914. Died Friday, January 9, 1998 after a brave battle with illness. Beloved wife of Samuel E., adored mother of Florence (Ralph) Belkind and Elaine (Martin) Schwartz. Loving grandmother of Dennis, Deborah and Alison Schwartz. Service at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, Sunday, January 11 at 1:30 PM. Interment at the J&B Moroch Family Circle plot at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

description: RECENTLY, in an uncharacteristically bold move, I left the house. In fact, I visited London, for the third time in two years.

title: VIEWPOINT; Doing the Right Things Right
description: FEWER than 40 years ago, successful companies tended to be centrally directed conglomerates; Harold S. Geneen of International Telephone and Telegraph and Charles Bludhorn of Gulf and Western stood out among the best-known business leaders of their day. Such executives looked to military leaders like Patton and Eisenhower as role models. They led huge enterprises by using stringent financial controls and authoritative discipline.

title: Washington Discovers Christian Persecution
description: Concerning Jeffrey Goldberg's article ''Washington Discovers Christian Persecution'' (Dec. 21), we need to apply the same standard of outrage and activism wherever any innocent group of people is prevented from reasonably expressing its opinions or faith.

Reposing at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Our Lady of Sorrows R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 24 and 7-9 PM.

description: TITELBAUM-Anna. Beloved wife of the late Moe. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Dr. Jules and Susan Titelbaum, and Elaine Moss. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services today, 12 noon, at the Yablokoff Kingsway Memorial Chapel, 1978 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

description: ROGERS-Martin C., M.D. of Stamford, CT on Friday, January 9, 1998. Husband and best friend of Ilene Sprung Rogers, beloved father of Juliet and Erika. Funeral service will be held Sunday at 1 PM at Gallagher Funeral Home, Stamford, CT.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Golf Course-Housing Proposal Lands in the Rough
description: HOUSING built in conjunction with an exclusive golf course is fairly common in the South and Southwest. And a few have been built or are under construction in the Northeast, including two in Connecticut -- River Highlands in Cromwell and Silvermine Woods in Norwalk -- and Purchase Estates in Purchase in Westchester County, where an 18-hole golf course and a dozen of a projected 73 houses have been completed.

title: Cars Available! But With More Strings Attached
description: TAKING the kids to Walt Disney World? That rental car in Florida will cost you at least 15 percent more this year. Your trip to Boston was delayed and you can't pick up the car you reserved? You may be charged a no-show fee. Think you are racking up airline frequent-flier miles when you rent a car? Think again.

title: At Play on the Yachts of the Rich and Rowdy
description: IT was all about the Other Woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERRENDER, GIRARD F., M.D.
description: OBERRENDER-Girard F., M.D., The Board of Trustees and Medical Staff of Lenox Hill Hospital express their sorrow at the passing of Girard F. Oberrender, M.D., Honory Consulting Physician. Dr. Oberrender, who joined the Dept. of Otolaryngology in 1921, served with great distinction as its Director from 1945 to 1959. A highly respected and nationally renowned ear, nose and throat specialist, he was one of the country's first voice experts. Throughout his illustrious medical career, his deep commitment to his patients and to Lenox Hill Hospital was unwavering. Dr. Oberrender was a devoted and gifted educator who trained several generations of otolaryngologists, enthusiastically sharing with them his knowledge and love of medicine. The entire Lenox Hill Hospital family honors the memory of this truly exceptional physician who exemplified the highest standards of his profession. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President and CEO Stephan A. Obstbaum, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHBEIN, ELI
description: FISHBEIN-Eli. AMIT is deeply grieved by the sudden passing of the beloved husband of our devoted Regional Vice President, Myrna Fishbein. A person of warmth and compassion, Eli Fishbein contributed so much to the furtherance of the AMIT Mission of Saving the forgotten Children of Israel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his dear wife Myrna and to his children Sarah and Steven Epstein, Elisa and Clint Greenbaum and Kalman and Susie Fishbein and the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Style; Overexposure
description: Am I the only person who thought it was a yawn when Dirk Diggler finally unsheathed his prosthetic shillelagh in the final scene of ''Boogie Nights''? If that's what passes for a ''money shot,'' well, keep the change. It seems to me that it's been about a century now since Burt Reynolds first made the world safe for Mark Wahlberg's latex-assisted frontal nudity. Burt, as you will recall, was the first male celebrity to pose unclothed for a major magazine (Cosmopolitan). He did so on a bear rug and with a hand held strategically over his private parts.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Boxer
