description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; A Path That Goes Nowhere
description: THE city's Parks Department, supported by the Central Park Conservancy, has undertaken a number of admirable improvements in Central Park, from the reseeding of the Sheep Meadow and the Great Lawn to refurbishings of the Bridle Path and North Meadow. At the risk of sounding greedy, I add one more jewel in desperate need of polishing -- the Reservoir running track.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, A. THOMAS
description: TAYLOR-A. Thomas. A. Thomas Taylor died on January 8, 1998, at his Pebble Beach, CA home. Mr. Taylor was a prominent businessman, having served on the Board of Directors of several major corporations such as the Ford Motor Company. During his business career he was a Chairman of Deltec International Corporation and the Pebble Beach Corporation. Mr. Taylor was a 1932 graduate of Yale University. He and his late wife, Geraldine Swift Taylor, were active in many charitable activities in the Chicago and Pebble Beach communities. He was a member of the Cypress Point Club in Pebble Beach and the Old Elm Club, Onwentsia Club and Shoreacres Club, all in the Chicago area. He is survived by his daughter, Geraldine O'Connell of Lake Forest, IL; son, Thomas Taylor of Telluride, CO, Gus Taylor of Milwaukee, WI, and Richard Taylor of the Virgin Islands; sister, Jane Richards of Belvedere, CA, and brother Richard Taylor of Cool, CA. Memorial services will be held on Monday, January 12, at 4 PM at The Church of the Forest in Pebble Beach. Memorial services will also be held at the First Presbyterian Church in Lake Forest, IL on January 16, at 4 PM.

title: A Scene for All Seasons
description: Summertime, and the gardening is easy. It's the other three seasons that are the real challenge. Or so says Edwina von Gal, the garden designer who transformed 11 acres of East End potato field -- surrounding a weathered wood house by Deamer & Phillips Architects -- into a lush setting (with her associate, Bob Rumsey). A hole that had been dug for a pond -- and little else -- greeted her when she began the project five years ago. Now there is a meadow and a cherry orchard, swamp grasses and day lilies, towering maples and cutting gardens. Von Gal's landscape segues from the manicured (nearest to the house) to the wild (around the pond), offering a spectacle of color and foliage year-round. While flower beds are part of the design, the key to creating this Arcadia from scratch is what von Gal calls a ''basic skeleton'' -- the right trees and shrubs, whose bone structure is ''critical to those seasons when you don't have the fancy dressing of flowers and leaves.'' Indeed, von Gal loves gardens in winter. ''You're seeing things naked, in their true identity.''

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: The ''Sanford and Son'' reference made by the homeowner in Celebration seems more a reference to the Redd Foxx character's occupation, not his race. He bought and sold junk. Much of this junk was piled inside and outside of his television home, where most of the action was set. Far from racist, the comment really speaks to the popularity of this very funny old sitcom.

title: Sports of The Times; A Pittsburgh Pioneer Remembers the Early Days
description: THE first thing you notice about Ray Kemp is his hands; huge hands that engulf yours when you shake them. ''Farmer's hands,'' he said Friday evening. They milked cows, pushed plows. As a football player, Kemp used his hands as weapons to slap opponents' leather helmets and knock offensive linemen silly.

title: In America; Mistakes Were Made
description: Oops!

title: Commercial Property/The Lodging Industry in and Near Hartford; A New Downtown Hotel, and Plans for More in Area
description: PLANS for a new 300-room, full-service hotel in downtown Hartford are the latest example of a market that has rebounded in recent years, with new investment being used to upgrade several existing hotels in the area and hotels newly opened or on the drawing boards in at least six other central Connecticut towns.

title: Around the World In 80 Strokes
description: Dorothy Moller is a 70-something, golf-playing widow from Paradise Valley, Ariz., who has an 18 handicap and $49,000 to spare. So today she's boarding a Concorde jet for what's being billed as the first around-the-world luxury golf tour. On Wednesday, Moller will tee it up at the Iguacu golf course in Brazil. A few days later, it's the Olivier Breaud golf course in Tahiti, followed by two courses in Dubai, three in Thailand and one during a refueling stop on New Caledonia. Twenty-two days; 14 countries; 252 scheduled holes of golf for a passenger list of 78 duffers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DONALD
description: KAPLAN-Donald. Died January 7, 1998. Age 53. Devoted partner to the late Craig Bonavita. Beloved son of Charles and Charlotte Kaplan. Loving brother to Joan Weiss and Cheryl Seawell. Father of Andrew. Cherished uncle to Laurie Tosti, Michael Weiss and David Weiss. Great-uncle to Jake, Joey, Rebecca and Amaranth. Incomparable friend and entertainer to many. Graduate of Harvard University Class of 1966. Graduate of Columbia Business School Class of 1968. Former investment banker at Salomon Brothers and Drexel Burnham Lambert. Board member and contributer to God's Love We Deliver and the Church of St. Luke in the Fields. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Thursday, January 15, 6 PM, 487 Hudson Street, NY, NY. Donations can be made to God's Love We Deliver and/or St. Luke's Church in lieu of flowers.

title: O.K., Everybody: Lampshades on Heads!
description: The office party: you love it or you loathe it. Be it a going-away party, a baby shower for a co-worker or a holiday celebration, it can be a genuine good time or an occasion for intense embarassment. What are the unusual styles of celebration in your office -- and the results? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, EUGENIE
description: WOLF-Eugenie of Ridgefield, CT. On Jan. 2, 1998. Formerly of Chappaqua, NY. Beloved wife of Arnold S. Wolf. Loving mother of Michael E., Andrew N. and Susan W. Hovey. Memorial service Sun., Jan. 18, 2 PM at Temple Shearith Israel, Ridgefield, CT. Contributions to Mount Kisco Senior Group, POB 150, Mt. Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 28 about the Vita Needle Company, where the work force includes many retirees from various occupations, misstated the number of Americans age 65 and older who had jobs in 1995. It was 3.7 million, not 3.8 million. The article also misstated the percentage of people in that age group who held jobs in 1995 and 1985. It was 11.7 percent in 1995, not 2.9 percent. It was 10.4 percent in 1985, not 2.5 percent.

title: 'Painterly Photos' by a Mother and Daughter
description: EIGHT-YEAR-OLD Molly Testwuide, a third grader at the Brookside Elementary School here, carries a camera around with her most of the time. She takes pictures in unlikely places. Shopping in the Limited store in Manhattan recently with her mother, Julie Betts Testwuide, a professional artist and photographer, and her sister, Emily, 10, she said: ''I looked up because I was bored. All of a sudden I saw a round staircase.''

title: Library for Children in New Rochelle
description: DON'T tell David McCabe that the newly opened Huguenot Children's Library in Huguenot Park here will ever be affected by budget cutbacks. The lawyer, who works in Manhattan and lives here, says simply: ''I won't let it happen. I have poured my heart and soul into this project, and so, too, have countless other New Rochelle residents.''

title: Seeing Red, in a Private Collection of Old Fire Engines
description: In 1968, Harold (Whitey) Swartz, a Pleasantville firefighter, bought his first used fire engine, a 1928 Ahrens-Fox pumper, for $500. Now fire marshal of Atlantic County, Mr. Swartz, 61, says he owns the largest collection of antique firefighting equipment in the state. His dozen fire engines range from a 1780 hand-pumper to a 1955 ladder truck. He also has 200 fire helmets, 500 toy fire engines, 15 fire hydrants, badges, patches, uniforms, axes, extinguishers, hoses, a brass poll and a female dalmation named Cinders.

title: A Dane Who Came and Conquered New York
description: ON A CHILLY NEW YORK evening, Nikolaj Hubbe was holed up in his deliberately spare Upper West Side apartment, a study in white with high ceilings, drinking hot tea and nursing a scratchy throat. The winter season had just begun at New York City Ballet, and Mr. Hubbe, a versatile principal dancer, is one of the company's busiest members. He seemed happy to have a few minutes just to sprawl in a big leather chair.

title: Indonesia's Downward Spiral
description: Despite a generous international bailout last year, Indonesia is sinking deeper into financial chaos and political paralysis. This weekend, emissaries from the Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund are traveling to Jakarta for urgent meetings on the crisis. They should insist that Indonesia fulfill its pledges to carry out tough economic reforms. Beyond that, they need to make clear that the markets there have collapsed as much from concern over President Suharto's corrupt brand of crony capitalism as from other underlying ailments.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Personal Demons
description: The most famous Vienna resident to be preoccupied with sex and death may have been Sigmund Freud, but Egon Schiele (1890-1918) was a close second. Schiele's demons had their day on paper and canvas instead of in therapy. In the decade before he died of the Spanish influenza, Schiele evolved a unique brand of Expressionism and produced some of the finest drawings and watercolors of the century. His angular, intense and erotic portraits of himself and his loved ones -- often depicted nude or exposing themselves -- earned him the labels of an unparalleled draftsman and a difficult artist for viewers. EGON SCHIELE: The Leopold Collection, Vienna (Dumont Buchverlag/Museum of Modern Art/Yale University, $60) includes color reproductions of 152 works along with critical commentary by Magdalena Dabrowski, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art. The typical anguish of the figure in one work ''is nevertheless communicated in an image of great formal discipline,'' she writes. ''Only Schiele would have been capable of combining the two.'' The book also contains an unusually provocative contribution from the collector who amassed the artworks over many years, Rudolph Leopold. Though some might disagree that toward the end of his life Schiele was ''years ahead of Picasso'' in depicting three-dimensional volumes, few would argue with Leopold's assertion that the artist managed to elevate his own troubles ''to the level of universal truth.'' Ted Loos

title: Streetscapes/National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts; A 5th Avenue Donor Who Loved to Create Museums
description: FROM an early age, Archer Huntington wanted to create museums. For his 10th -- and last -- he donated his town house at 1083 Fifth Avenue to the National Academy of Design in 1940. Now Dr. Annette Blaugrund, the new director of what is now the National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts, has begun a capital plan to both preserve and reorganize the three-part building.

title: LIFE BY DESIGN; Experience Can't Be Cloned
description: Cloning is a twist of nature; the only way to end an argument about it may be another twist. When I asked a friend the other day, ''What's wrong with wanting to reproduce yourself?'' he replied, ''If you don't know what's wrong with reproducing me, nobody does.''

title: Looking for an 11 O'Clock Fix
description: Thank God it was Friday, the end of a very bad mid-October week for the men who run Channel 2 News in Orlando, Fla. They looked beat. They were beat. And they were reminded of it every morning, before 9, when the overnight Nielsen ratings were dropped on their desks by a smiling newsroom clerk. If only there were something to smile about. Channel 2's local-news ratings had never been so low. ''Worst numbers I've seen since I've been here,'' said Bill Bauman, the general manager of Channel 2, WESH-TV, an NBC affiliate. Bauman, a veteran newsman with a reputation for producing top-quality local news, was hired last year to remake the station's programming and take it from No. 2 to No. 1 in the exploding Orlando market. Instead, the Nielsen sheets he was scanning that Friday made it quite clear: Channel 2 News was rapidly sinking from view.

title: VIEWPOINT; Public Television Needs More Than Virtue
description: WHEN Congress wrote the rules for broadcasting, it required commercial broadcasters and public broadcasters to serve the public interest.

title: When Management Goes in Circles, or in Metaphors
description: CALL me hubristic, call me crazy, call me Woodrow Wilson -- but, reluctantly, I may have to go to war to put an end to all vacuous management books by writing a lethally stupid one of my own.

title: Susan Brophy, Gerald McGowan
description: Susan Anne Brophy, a legislative liaison at the White House, and Gerald S. McGowan, the American Ambassador to Portugal, were married yesterday at the Cosmos Club in Washington. The Rev. Andrew Merrow, an Episcopal priest, officiated with the Rev. Kathleen Mulvihill, a Presbyterian minister who is a sister of the bridegroom.

title: BENEFITS
description: Cross-Channel Culture

title: MEN'S SUPER GIANT SLALOM: Maier Cruises
description: Hermann Maier took a big step toward winning the men's World Cup yesterday in Schladming, Austria, leading an Austrian 1-2 sweep in a World Cup super giant slalom.

title: Backtalk; Twins, but With Little Resemblance
description: ''I hate individual sports; it's all you, you, you,'' said the soccer player, cocking an eyebrow at the gymnast. ''But, hey, if it floats your boat, O.K.''

title: A Typeface That Sells
description: To the Editor:

title: DIARY
description: WHEELS

title: Introducing the Bug That Conquered Detroit
description: A SMALLER, cheaper car is making the biggest waves at this year's auto show. Volkswagen's New Beetle has aroused far more curiosity than far-out concept cars that can't be bought at any price.

title: F.Y.I.
description: An Officer's House

title: Where Immigrant Dreams Prosper, at a Profit
description: ROSENDO STEWART left Colon, Panama, 19 years ago, hoping to prosper in the United States. For years he worked two jobs in New York, as a cabby and a doorman, but could not unlock the door to his dream through hard work alone.

title: Deer vs. People: The Debate Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime
description: Jane Austen's distaste for the frivolous pursuits of polite society in 19th-century Bath has been well documented. So it is both a surprise and an amusement to find this famously reserved author throwing herself into the mad social whirl in JANE AND THE WANDERING EYE (Bantam, $22.95). For this diverting mystery of manners, the third entry in a genteelly jolly series by Stephanie Barron, the game heroine goes to elegant parties, frequents the theater and visits fashionable gathering spots -- all in the discreet service of solving a murder.

title: Photographs That Fed Picasso's Vision
description: ANOTHER FACET TO PICASSO? TYPING HIS name, I already see weary readers, breakfast bagel in one hand, reaching with the other to turn the page. I am reminded of an old New Yorker cartoon from the time when the Pachelbel Canon seemed as ubiquitous on the radio as ''Stairway to Heaven.'' The cartoon showed a demented inmate below a loudspeaker with the caption ''Prisoner of Pachelbel.'' This still being Picasso's century, we are all doomed, I am afraid, to remain his prisoners as long as new sides of his career keep turning up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAVIN, DR. MILTON S.
description: TRAVIN-Dr. Milton S. Died January 7 at age 85. Respected oral surgeon, retired. Dear husband of the late Lois. Beloved father of Sandra and brother of Harold; fatherin-law of Peter and brother-in-law of Astrid. Services on Monday, 11 AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Ave. and Prospect Park, Brooklyn, (718633-0400). In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Restoration Will Close Monument For 4 Months
description: The Washington Monument will close on Sunday for four months as part of a restoration project expected to last at least two years.

title: Lia Manoliu, 65, Olympian And Romanian Sports Figure
description: Lia Manoliu, a worldly woman who threw the discus for Romania in six Olympic Games and won the gold medal in 1968, died on Friday in a hospital in Bucharest. She was 65.

title: Rivka Dear, Doni Lindenberg
description: Rivka Ilana Dear, a daughter of Rickly and Councilman Noach Dear of Brooklyn, was married on Wednesday evening to Doni Lindenberg, a son of Ellen and Dr. Leslie B. Lindenberg of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Zelik Epstein performed the ceremony at Congregation Shaare Zion in Brooklyn.

title: Penalties Doom Devils
description: PENGUINS 4, DEVILS 1

title: Dim Days Behind It, Armory Is Again Host to Track Stars
description: It may have been dank, dingy and grimy, but for generations it was home to New York City's young track hopefuls.

title: Microsoft Strikes Deal On Software For Cable TV
description: Microsoft Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television provider, announced yesterday that Microsoft would license a consumer version of its Windows operating system to control a future generation of at least five million set-top boxes that Tele-Communications plans to begin deploying in 1999.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BRUCH: VIOLIN CONCERTO NO. 1; 'SCOTTISH FANTASY'

title: Nets Beat Themselves: One Period at the Beach Is One Too Many
description: The Nets took a quarter off here at Continental Arena tonight. The price? A rare home loss, 108-101, to the streaking Minnesota Timberwolves in a game in which New Jersey almost rallied from a 14-point halftime deficit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTAL, DIANA
description: KRISTAL-Diana. On January 9, 1998, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Alexander, loving mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, sister, and aunt. You were our princess. Burial private. Alene, Laura, Julie, Victor, Sam

title: Too Early for Jordan to Go
description: Michael Jordan has this way of palming the basketball with his right arm outstretched -- as if he were about to pass it over his opponent's head before bringing it back like a yo-yo and deciding to shoot or dribble.

title: See Spots Run
description: On Sunday night in Central Park, a flashing red light bobbed up and down near the Sheep Meadow, dancing through the trees. At a whistle, it moved close to the outline of a man and stopped. Two more bobbing lights appeared far away. U.F.O.'s? Not exactly. Dogs, wearing clip-on bicycle taillights, the latest canine must-have. Bill Ty, visiting from Alaska, said the light was a great way to keep track of his amicable golden retriever, Gus, a search dog in training. (He's worked two avalanches.) Gus sometimes enters rough territory, but nothing like Manhattan, where the light alerts motorists, bikers and 'bladers that he's around. At bike shops, the lights start at about $9.99. ''I've seen four go by tonight,'' Mr. Ty said. ''Soon it will be tough to tell which one's Gus.'' Not to fret: Gus was on a leash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, DANIEL BERTRAM, SR.
description: GROSSMAN-Daniel Bertram, Sr. 72, on January 5, 1998 in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Beloved husband of Kathryn, loving father of Danny Grossman and Dana Hammond, grandfather of Oliver, Miles, Jonathan and Nicky Hammond. Funeral 11 AM, Saturday, January 10, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Del Mar, CA. In lieu of flowers, contributions to either St. Peter's Episcopal Church Building Fund, PO Box 336, Del Mar, CA 92014 or Scripps Clinic, Division of Chest Medicine, 10666 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA 92037.

title: Handling Erosion On Fire Island
description: Contrary to what David M. Edelstein writes [Letters to the Editor, Nov. 23], there is no conflict over ''ownership of ocean-front property'' connected with the state's implementation of its Coastal Erosion Hazard Area Management Program. When that program is in effect, rebuilding of houses in the primary dune area, if destroyed or seriously damaged by flooding, is possible only with a variance from the plan administrator (the state or municipality). This program must be in place, under state and Federal law, for New York to participate, along with the Corps of Engineers and Suffolk County, in the much needed beach preservation effort for Fire Island.

title: Wartime Pomp Revived
description: A new generation has rediscovered and is collecting and wearing wartime 1940's fashion. The clothes of this often-shunned period of style have gained a cult following, including major designers from Europe and New York, who shop antique fairs for old clothes and accessories and then incorporate details into their runway shows. Hallmarks of the period that are reappearing (along with pompadour hairstyles) include decorative colored gloves, hats with personality, men's leisure jackets and women's fox ''chubby'' coats with wide shoulders and flaring sleeves. Designers have tried before, unsuccessfully, to revive the war years' look, when Paris was silenced and Hollywood glamour ruled fashion.

title: Clinton Repeats His Opposition To Possibility of Human Cloning
description: President Clinton, reacting to statements by an Illinois physicist that he intended to clone a human being, said today that mainstream scientists viewed the practice as ''untested and unsafe, and morally unacceptable.'' The President said it should not be done.

title: A Trail Leads From the Past Into the Future
description: A block from her office in the United States Custom House in Philadelphia, Helen Mahan Forester, a community planner with the National Park Service, stands on the western bank of the Delaware River. Gazing north, she can see not just smokestacks, abandoned industrial plots, nightclubs and marinas, but also a continuous 40-mile circuit of bridges, roads, riverside embankments, public parks, wildlife refuges, bike paths and hiking trails, linking 17 riverfront communities in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, from Washington Crossing to Camden.

title: Choose One: Koufax or Sutton?
description: The general managers were given a choice. They could have either of two pitchers, and they could make their selection knowing what the pitchers would do in their careers. One pitcher would pitch for 12 years, having a poor-to-mediocre first six years, then a spectacularly good last six years. The other would pitch for 23 years and win 324 games.

title: At Your Service, at Your Door
description: THE word home comes from some old German and Greek words that mean, roughly, the place where you lie down. But these days, in an increasingly competitive service market, home is also a place where you can receive assistance from a range of professionals.

title: Two Artists, Two Surveys of Life Works
description: BERNHARD GUTMANN and Reuben Nakian each made a deep impression on the visual arts in Connecticut. Gutmann, who died in 1936, is a forgotten figure today, but in 1922 he was the primary founder of the Silvermine Guild. Nakian lived and worked in Stamford for 40 years until his death in 1986, and became the sculptor most identified with the aims of the Abstract Expressionist painters.

title: Late Surge by Lopez Leads Red Storm Over Hoyas
description: Injuries to opponents are not on St. John's wish list, but the relief was obvious yesterday after the Red Storm finally took advantage of such an opportunity in a 66-60 victory over a short-handed Georgetown team in a Big East contest televised throughout most of the country.

title: The View From/Essex; Gift of the Indians, Going for Sale
description: THE witch weather vane still flies over the main factory building and the water tower, a landmark around Essex, bearing the familiar yellow label of the E. E. Dickinson Company. Yet since last May, the buildings where witch hazel was produced for more than a century have fallen silent, empty of people.

title: Old House's Future Debated
description: The landmark Bowne House, a 337-year-old Dutch colonial farmhouse in Flushing and the oldest standing home in the city, has a history of being mired in controversy. So perhaps it comes as no surprise that there is division among trustees over the future of the building, which is deteriorating.

title: Stirrings in the Phone Market
description: Two events last week raised hopes that the 1996 Telecommunications Act, which was intended by Congress to bring competition to local telephone markets, was not passed in vain. SBC Communications, the parent of Southwestern Bell and Pacific Bell, proposed to take over Southern New England Telecommunications, the local phone company for Connecticut. Then, AT&T proposed to buy Teleport, a New York company that provides local phone service in more than 60 cities. Yet these are modest moves. So far, the 1996 act has spawned more court suits than competition.

title: Now, Steelers Are Obstacle to Elway's Hopes
description: Heading into Sunday afternoon's American Football Conference championship game, Denver quarterback John Elway is clearly the sentimental favorite in his showdown with the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOO, DOEN T.
description: LOO-Doen T. On January 9, 1998. Beloved wife of the late W.Y. Loving mother of Diane Woo, Lawrence, Harold and Donald Loo. Cherished grandmother of Daniel J. Woo, Katharine, Derek and Melinda Loo. Great-grandmother of Christopher Woo. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 Street, on Monday, January 12, 2-5 PM and 79 PM, with service at Frank E. Campbell, Tuesday, January 13, at 11:30 AM.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Tax Ups and Downs

title: A Dutch Director Who Follows the Lead of Strange Details
description: AFTER HE MADE HIS mark in Dutch theater as an actor, writer, designer and director, it seemed natural for Alex van Warmerdam to try his hand at cinema. But he hesitated. He knew the theater intimately. Indeed, he was literally born into it: his family frequently lived above the provincial theaters where his father worked as a stage manager. But filmmaking remained something of a mystery to him.

title: Q&A/Richard O'Connor; Depression and Ways to Keep It at Bay
description: THE holiday season -- full of anticipation and celebration -- is over, and the winter doldrums have hit. Richard O'Connor, a Lakeville psychotherapist, says this is normal. Those who suffer from depression, however, are more likely to feel seriously let down, making January and February busy months at therapists' offices.

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: Are some of the disgruntled inhabitants of Celebration now realizing that to privatize all is to sell all, and that the price may have been too high?

title: Raising the Bar on Fees
description: Mutual funds are using funny math to justify their cost increases, but it's no laughing matter for shareholders, who have to foot the bill.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Near Downtown New Brunswick, More Housing
description: FIVE years ago two developers began transforming 6.6 cleared acres not far from New Brunswick's reviving downtown into housing. The original concept called for an enclave of for-sale town houses.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; Where Russian Herring Sits Alongside the Cerveza
description: The Taste of Europe looks a bit out of place at Broadway and West 173d Street.

title: Workers' Efforts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, LILEN
description: SANGER-Lilen. Died on January 8, 1998 at New York Hospital in her 91st year from complications following emergency surgery. It was her first major illness. She was the cherished mother of Sirgay and mother-in-law of Judy. The loving sister-in-law of Ethel and grandmother of Terry, his wife Abbie, and Vicky. The great-grandmother of James and adoring aunt of Mitzi, Patricia, Liam, Cyrena, Stephany, Jonathan, Elizabeth, Gail, Mary Bryna, Diane and Michael. Great aunt of Priscilla, Elizabeth, Margaret, Erik, Cory, Sean, Evan, Regan, Geoffrey, Wendy, David, Kevin, Lorie Dru, Jared, Amy, Aaron, Jaron, Julia Anne, Jeffrey, Margot, Meredith, Jonathan, Matthew and Amanda. She loved the spouses of her family; Lew, Bill, Lee, Simmel, Judy, Carla, Al, Mark, Yakov, Larry and Francine. Her interest in her family organization, The Independent Family Society, founded in 1914 was lifelong. She attended most of its 800 meetings. She was distinguished as the first and only American woman to own a distillery in Scotland. She produced the finest highland malt whiskey in Pitlochry, which aged in port barrels while being used as ships' ballast, sent around the world, and then bottled by her firm. With humor and style she and her late brother Abbe, brother-in-law Irving and sisters, Mildred and Pearl became wellknown figures at the Savoy in post war London, bringing American energy and optimism to national and overseas trade. Their best known brands were Kings Ransom and House of Lords. For 40 years she directed and ran International Distributors and International Brands with hundreds of loyal devoted employees in the U.S. and U.K. The loss of her family associates led to the sale of the busness in the 1970's. She was chairwoman of the Women's Alcoholic Beverage Association. She was known for her philanthropy to the Harvard Medical School Israeli medical education, the Fifty-fifth Street Synagogue, the Flatbush Jewish Center, and Greek War Relief. Family and friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Saturday, 5-8 PM, with service Sunday, 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Harvard Medical School.

title: WEB OF INFLUENCE -- A special report.; Casino Inquiry Pushes Babbitt From the Pinnacle to the Brink
description: His strange predicament weighs heavily on Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt these days. Even though he is tanned after several days of hiking near the Grand Canyon, the weariness is still evident in his face and demeanor.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Plainsboro, N.J.; The Woes and Benefits of Growth
description: WITH sprawling office parks and tightly packed garden apartment complexes, Plainsboro, N. J. is trying to catch its breath after nearly 30 years of rampant development. Since 1970, the 11.8-square-mile Middlesex County township has grown tenfold, from 1,600 people to 16,000.

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: Disney's Celebration shows us that the esthetic of a downtown Main Street is a desirable amenity in the building of community -- a lesson for towns throughout the country that are losing investment to car-oriented strip development at the edge of town. What we need is increased investment in our existing town centers.

title: The Coda Is Teamwork and Leadership
description: WHAT could a garment industry executive possibly learn from an orchestra?

title: Closed Charter Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, RUTH
description: ADLER-Ruth. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ruth Adler associated with The Times from 1934, until retiring in 1980.

title: Divided Episcopalians Install Leader Who Urges 'a Compassionate Heart' in Members
description: In a ceremony rich with ecclesiastical processions, the music of church choirs and the scent of incense at the Washington National Cathedral today, the Episcopal Church installed Bishop Frank T. Griswold 3d as its presiding bishop, or top officer. Bishop Griswold, a cleric educated at Harvard and Oxford who was spiritual head of the Diocese of Chicago, takes the church's helm at a time when its unity is being severely tested by stark ideological divisions among Episcopalians.

title: Bonnie Takes a Mine Tour
description: Bonnie Raitt, the singer and celebrity environmentalist, traveled to Montana last month to perform two benefit concerts on behalf of advocates who oppose development of new gold mines in the state. In a P.R. move, the McDonald Gold Project -- a controversial proposal for a mine near the Blackfoot River, a world-famous trout stream -- invited Raitt to tour the mine site and learn how McDonald supposedly plans to neatly and cleanly extract and process 980 million tons of ore from two buttes that rise only a mile or so from the river. Jim Jensen, executive director of the Montana Environmental Information Center, called the invitation ''a silly public relations ploy.'' Silly it arguably was, but as often happens when greens, their foes and the stars meet, the silliness came from all directions. Here's a look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, HELEN
description: ALTMAN-Helen, 90. Beloved wife of the late Ollie. Adored mother of Joyce and 9 grandchildren. 9 great grandchildren. She was a fabulous lady and will be greatly missed.

title: High-Quality Sushi and Sashimi at Gentle Price
description: SUSHI and sashimi are the filet mignon and rack of lamb of Japanese cuisine. They are delicacies, these small, meticulously prepared one- and two-bite fish morsels created by skilled hands and served by serene kimono-clad waitresses.

title: American Program, A Conductor's Debut
description: THE New Haven Symphony is proceeding apace with guest conductors, the Scottish-born Stewart Robertson making his debut with the orchestra on Saturday at 8 P.M. in Woolsey Hall, while one of the ensemble's alumni, the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman, returns as guest soloist.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Crafts Chain to Close Disappointing Location

title: Italian With Spice
description: AFTER a stint at Yale College and Harvard Medical School, our pediatrician decided to come home to New Jersey. Does that make him a reliable source on restaurants? I'm not sure, but when one of my son's teachers recommended the same restaurant (and she was reading ''Under the Tuscan Sun,'' by Frances Mayes), I listened.

title: Mutual Funds Report; In Search Of A Foothold In Rocky Times
description: AS stock and bond markets around the world became more volatile last year, mutual fund investors sought safety. But they did not always get it.

title: Visiting Nurses And Provincialism
description: The article (''The Hospitals of Tomorrow, Taking Shape Today . . . With New Networks a Major Factor,'' Dec. 28) quotes the president of the Connecticut Hospital Association: ''there is an element of provincialism in our towns -- nobody wants to see their local hospital go away.''

title: Tracey Ullman
description: Tracey Ullman appears this month in ''Tracey Takes On,'' on HBO.

title: Strengthening Ranks Of Family Missioners
description: WHEN Jean Walsh and Joe Regotti, a married couple, fly to Mexico with their two young daughters later this month, it will not be for a midwinter holiday at a sunny resort.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Strong Performers Look at '98
description: THOUGH United States stock fund managers turned in a terrific average return of nearly 24 percent for all of last year, the final quarter was much trickier to navigate. They had to contend with ever-growing problems in Asia and the resulting stock market turbulence worldwide -- and many managers fared poorly at year-end.

title: Harold Bromley, Aviator Lacking Lindbergh's Luck, Dies at 99
description: Harold Bromley, an early aviator who repeatedly tried to make the first nonstop flight between the Pacific Coast and Japan but was foiled in his bids to become the Lindbergh of the Pacific by a series of misadventures, died on Dec. 20 at a nursing home near his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHR, WALTER
description: ROHR-Walter. Beloved husband of the late Hede. Loving father of Linda Kamins and Nancy Schwartz. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jason, Danny and Eric. Services ''Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapel'', 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, 10:30 A.M. on Sunday.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Town-Building Is No Mickey Mouse Operation
description: Celebration is the ultimate expression of selling your soul to the company store. One can only hope that among the children of the town, there are a few who will not succumb, but like Huck Finn, ''light out for the territories.''

title: Corrections
description: A review on Dec. 14, about ''The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II,'' by Iris Chang, misstated the publisher and the price for another recent book, ''The Rape of Nanking: An Undeniable History in Photographs,'' by Shi Young and James Yin. The publisher is the Innovative Publishing Group; Triumph Books is the distributor, and the price is $60, not $75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, MARTIN
description: KRAMER-Martin. January 7, 1998, born June 6, 1907. Inventor, mentor, teacher, (aeronautics and math, East New York Vocational High School; insurance, Columbia University). Retired, Northport, FL, community leader, founding chair education center, organizer of Peace Day. He offered a clarity of thought, ingenuity, and unbounded generosity, which guided the careers of his family, friends and students. Survived by Esther Kramer, wife of 62 years, daughters, Nancy Paige, Fredrica Kramer, sons-in-law, David Paige, Michael Keane, grandchildren, Tara and Daniel Paige, Edmund Keane.

title: What's This? Reserved Seats At the Movies?
description: LAST Sunday evening in front of the Ziegfeld Theater on West 54th Street, Karl Weiss, 64, a retired stockbroker, shook his head angrily and paused to see whether his wife was as annoyed. ''After 30 years in this great town, to get to the Zieg and find out they're trying to sell tickets like it's a Broadway show is a shame,'' he said, as he searched through a crumpled newspaper for times at other movie theaters. ''Pretty soon they're going to be charging that much.''

title: In Bridgeport, Beating Guns Into Church Bells to Curb Killings
description: Beside the altar of Blessed Sacrament Church here, where poinsettias still flaunt a Christmas red, the Rev. Paul F. Merry found a gift today: a gun.

title: H.M.O. Premiums Rising Sharply, Stoking Debate on Managed Care
description: Health maintenance organizations in the New York region are asking customers to pay larger -- in some cases much larger -- premiums this year after several years of holding down prices to spur enrollment in an area that long regarded managed care with suspicion.

title: Bowness Gets Warning As Isles' Slide Hits 10
description: HURRICANES 2, ISLANDERS 1

title: Laws Relax Building Codes In Renovating Old Houses
description: The law that unified building codes statewide in 1977 required not only that all new buildings meet certain standards, but also that existing buildings also be brought up to code if they underwent major renovations. One result was that homeowners and commercial developers were discouraged from some rehabilitationjobs because of the high cost of, say, widening a century-old hallway from its original 40 inches to the new 42-inch minimum, said William Connolly, the state director of codes and standards.

title: Miss O'Connell And Mr. Revelant
description: Christina O'Connell, a daughter of Doris O'Connell of Port Washington, N.Y., and the late John J. O'Connell, was married on Friday to Paul Revelant, a son of Rosemarie and John Revelant of Boiceville, N.Y. Msgr. Walter E. Simmons performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter of Alcantara in Port Washington.

title: Nancy Schondorf And Adam Riess
description: Nancy Joy Schondorf, a daughter of Phyllis and Jay Schondorf of Riverside, Conn., was married last evening to Dr. Adam Guy Riess, the son of Doris and Michael Riess of North Topsail Beach, N.C. Rabbi Mitchell Hurvitz officiated at the Hyatt Regency in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSIN, SYDNEY
description: GOSIN-Sydney. On behalf of our entire organization, we wish to express our profound sorrow to our esteemed partner, Barry Gosin, on the passing of his beloved father, Sydney. We would also like to extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire family, most especially Irene, Sydney's wife. May his memory be a blessing. The Partners of Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc. William Cohen Ira Fishman Ronald Goldberger Aaron Gural Jeffrey Gural James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post Arthur Rosenbloom

title: The Nation: Balancing Act; Not So Fast: Here Comes the Budget Crunch
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON displayed his deft political touch last week, calling for the first balanced budget in three decades and in the process taking credit for solving a problem that has dogged Washington since the early years of the Reagan Administration.

title: Nichols's Life Was Saved By a Handful of Holdouts
description: In vote after vote, a majority of jurors raised their hands to sentence Terry L. Nichols to death, but they were blocked by a few determined holdouts, said two jurors in the second Oklahoma bombing trial.

title: Ladies' Night, 1998
description: LAST night, the Tropicana Casino presented Atlantic City's first all-female boxing match. Every fighter -- not just a token pair on the undercard, but everyone wearing gloves -- was was a woman.

title: Of Princes, Palaces And a Pink City
description: ''A JOURNEY of a thousand miles begins with a single step.''

title: On Language; Trunk Show
description: A hot phrase in retailing is trunk show. It is to the selling of clothes and jewelry what the tailgate party is to eating out in the parking lot at sports events.

title: An Old-Time Prescription: Medicine and Friendship
description: They sat at the dining room table, patient and doctor, underneath a framed picture that read, ''God Bless Our Home.''

title: Looking to Israel for High-Technology Buys
description: ORNA BERRY, Israel's 49-year-old Chief Scientist, thinks she knows why her country has produced so many high-technology companies.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN; Boat Builders Seek a Home
description: Floating the Apple, which opened on West 42d Street in March 1994, has had quite a run. Its original three-month engagement lasted nearly four years, spawned a road show and generated countless cheers.

title: Detroit Turns a Corner
description: For anyone worried about global warming, last week's most heartening news came from an unlikely source -- the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. All three auto makers announced that they were nearing production of marketable cars that will rely less on gas-burning engines and more on exotic power sources like fuel cells. Because conventional engines account for one-third of America's output of carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas, this was a revelation of potentially enormous significance.

title: Parking at the Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Blowers, Earplugs, Angst in Suburbia
description: IT began long ago with the buzz of the humble power mower, the first tool to harness gasoline to beat back the suburban garden. Now, gas engines roar from every corner of suburbia, powering every conceivable tool, from chain saws to hedge trimmers to Weedwackers and, most audible of all, the beloved and reviled leaf blower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICARIELLO, SUZAN
description: PICARIELLO - Suzan. Beloved friend, colleague, sister, daughter, wife and mother. Died in a plane crash in Indonesia December 19, 1997. Memorial mass St. Andrews R.C. Church, Foley Square, New York, January 12th at 10AM.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE UNRULY QUEEN: The Life of Queen Caroline

title: Colorblind
description: One Christmas day seven years ago, I'd gone over to the Henry Horner Homes in Chicago to visit with Lafeyette and Pharoah, the subjects of my book ''There Are No Children Here.'' I had brought presents for the boys, as well as a gift for their friend Rickey, who lived on the other side of the housing complex, an area controlled by a rival gang. Lafeyette and Pharoah insisted on walking over with me. It was eerily quiet, since most everyone was inside, and so, bundled from the cold, we strolled toward the other end in silence. As we neared Damen Avenue, a kind of demilitarized zone, a uniformed police officer, a white woman, approached us. She looked first at the two boys, neither of whom reached my shoulder, and then directly at me. ''Are you O.K.?'' she asked.

title: The Professor and the Prostitute
description: Down on Knickerbocker Avenue, out on the Flushing Avenue stroll, in the rubble-strewn lots and burned-out buildings of Bushwick, they love Rick Curtis. A whole lot, in fact.

title: It Was the Year of 'Let's Make a Deal'
description: A FEW years ago real estate executives were coining slogans like ''Stay alive till 95'' and ''Find something to do until 20-02'' that expressed the difficulty of operating in a market that was sluggish at best. Today, nobody has the time to think up clever sayings. They are too busy making deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOHN J.
description: SMITH-John J., on January 9th, 1998. Beloved husband of Nora E. (nee Dooley). Devoted father of Brian L., Susan M., Nora Ann Babos, and Sean R. Loving grandfather of Kristen, Patrick, Daniel, Clair, and Sean Babos. Brother of Rose Smith and Margaret Keyes. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 9:30 AM, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Visitation Saturday, 7-9, and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9, at McLaughlin & Sons, 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn. Interment St. Charles.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 11, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Mutual Funds Report; Dazzling Returns Bring a Cash Surge to Junk Bonds
description: Junk bond funds were among the best-performing bond funds last year. So, unsurprisingly, they are getting an influx of cash.

title: January 4-10; A Message From Teheran
description: President Mohammed Khatami of Iran wanted to send a message to the American people, and he used an interview with CNN to deliver it: a call for cultural exchanges with the United States as a way to break through years of distrust. But the message played better in Iran than in America.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the relationship between lawyers and their clients misspelled the name of a Legal Aid lawyer. She is Christina Swarns, not Swars.

title: Threatened Creatures Slowing Some Construction to a Turtle's Pace
description: With the economy healthy, building is going on all over the the state, but in some instances the building of homes, commercial developments or roads is in conflict with the desire to protect the animals and plants that help give the state its special character. It is the job of the state Department of Environmental Protection to see that the animals and plants can live with the construction that keeps the state moving and growing, but it often takes time to work out the details.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Jack Frusciante

title: W. H. Conzen, 84; Led Expansion of Schering
description: W. H. Conzen, the former chairman and chief executive of the Schering-Plough Corporation, died on Dec. 21 at his home in Lynchburg, Va. He was 84.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Caring Man Emerges From Fear
description: David Burstine does not cherish many childhood memories, but one stands out in his mind: the night eight years ago when the police whisked him away from his wrathful, crack-addled grandmother.

title: Mutual Funds Report; A Little Caution in the Wind
description: MANY mutual fund investors were relieved to shut the door on 1997 -- and the volatility it wrought -- with smart gains.

title: Ideas & Trends: Don't Shoot; The Culture of Cops and Guns
description: THE statistics do not hit with, say, deadly force. But they do have the power to stun slightly, at least for a public soaked in television police dramas: it turns out that police across the country do not fire their guns much -- in a single day or a full career. And New York City police officers kill civilians less often than those officers in virtually all other major cities.

title: Zapped Again!
description: BUNNY MODERN

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: The World; Democracy, Apparatchik Style
description: SINCE Central Europe emerged from Communism, the nuts and bolts of democracy have been installed across the region. There are elections, newspapers galore, political parties of all kinds, growing numbers of television channels and radio stations in just about every city.

title: Mutual Funds Report; A Bad Case of Index Anxiety
description: SAY you're a horse. Maybe you're even a pretty good horse -- hard working, well trained. But you serve a sadistic master who decides that every day you are to race one-on-one against Cigar, the greatest race horse of the decade. ''You've got to be kidding me,'' you want to say, except that you're a horse, so you can't talk, Mr. Ed notwithstanding.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Jackie Brown

title: The Greek's Glasgow
description: YOU have to hand it to 19th-century Glasgow, the confident, entrepreneurial Second City of the Empire: It produced two impressively eccentric architects.

title: Word for Word / Sonny Bono; The World According to the Guy Who Wore the Furry Vest
description: SONNY BONO, killed last Monday at age 62 when he slammed into a tree while skiing, was a footnote to pop music history who became a footnote to the Sixties who became a footnote to television history who became a footnote to American celebrity who became a footnote to American political history.

title: The Revolution Will Be Merchandised
description: TO call Chalonne McLeod a fan would be to understate the depth of her devotion. Miss McLeod, 15, wore a navy blue WUSA sweatshirt manufactured by Wu Wear, the clothing line of the megaselling hip-hop group the Wu-Tang Clan, which has confirmed that hard-core hip-hop can make mainstream dollars. The Wu-Tang logo, a bat with wings spread, was in her ears and on a chain around her neck. It was also carefully painted on her long, blue fingernails.

title: Tubbies Say, 'Eh-oh.' Parents Say, 'Uh-oh.'
description: THE NARRATOR, THE unseen voice of adult authority, was quite clear about what Tinky Winky -- the purple Teletubby with the triangular antenna sticking out of his head -- was doing.

title: Q&A: Eve Epstein; Overcoming the Fear of Public Speaking
description: ACCORDING to The Book of Lists, the greatest fear in America is that of speaking in public, surpassing even the fears of death and taxes.

title: The Documentary As Family Memoir: A Surprise Sequel
description: IN THE 18 YEARS SINCE HIS documentary ''Best Boy'' won an Academy Award, Ira Wohl has been asked repeatedly how the subject of the movie, his mentally retarded cousin, Philly, is doing. Today, when ''Best Man'' opens the New York Jewish Film Festival at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, viewers will learn the resoundingly positive answer: Philly, now a septuagenarian, is alive and well.

title: Coffee, Then Pot, Police Say
description: When it opened in late 1994 as a cafe by day and a hipster bar by night, Nation was almost immediately praised by customers as one of those strangely appealing New York hybrids. Nation, at 50 Avenue A, was a place that could serve a frothy cappuccino in the morning and afternoon and offer a chilled martini and a cool disk jockey when the sun went down.

title: Titles vs. Actual Duties
description: If Shakespeare were around today, chances are he wouldn't wax as poetic over job titles as he did over names. While a rose by any other name might smell as sweet, some titles, it seems, give off the scent of egomania or megalomania, and occasionally the distinctive aroma of someone sweating hard to suggest responsibility where none has been bestowed.

title: Body Coddling a la Mode
description: From Griselda's in Park Slope to Trixie Glamourama in East New York and Vinny Venditti's in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn has plenty of beauty salons. It also has plenty of health clubs. But what the borough doesn't have is a spa that is open seven days a week and uses organic products.

title: Elizabeth Kase, Craig Johnson
description: Elizabeth Suzanne Kase, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Kase of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Craig MacLean Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart MacLean Johnson of Port Washington, N.Y. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: Duval Is One Off Lead, And One Behind Hogan
description: What sounded improbable to David Duval just several months ago is now very possible. If he can overtake Phil Mickelson in Sunday's final round of the Mercedes Championships, Duval will become the first man since Ben Hogan in 1953 to win four consecutive starts on the PGA Tour.

title: A School Teaches Students to Accept Those Who Are Different
description: FOR Sheryl, the hardest part of middle school was being in a wheelchair.

title: Jury to Decide Whether Clubs Doubled as Drug Supermarkets
description: He has been known as the prince of New York's nightclub scene, the operator of such Manhattan magnets for young revelers as the Tunnel and Limelight. But Federal drug agents and prosecutors contend that Peter Gatien is also a drug racketeer who turned these megaclubs into virtual drug supermarkets to boost their popularity and profitability.

title: Protecting What's Left of Open Space
description: IN 1970, William H. Whyte, who had written the blueprint for preservation of Connecticut's natural resources in 1962, noted that the state's privately owned land -- the bulk of Connecticut's open space -- still remained highly vulnerable to encroachment. Almost three decades later, the land planner's assessment remains true.

title: A Typeface That Sells
description: To the Editor:

title: The Copy Shop

title: Spreading the Medicare Umbrella Earlier
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S plan to broaden eligibility for Medicare ''sounded great'' to Nick Porto, a 62-year-old chemical plant technician in Donaldson, La., who took early retirement and a pension in October 1996.

title: Where Lingerie Sells to the Orthodox
description: ON Avenue M in Midwood, Brooklyn, the sidewalks bustle with Orthodox Jewish women in wigs and ankle-length skirts, while bearded men in long black coats and broad-brimmed hats walk to synagogue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, ISRAEL S. (I. SAUL)
description: JARCHO-Israel S. (I. Saul). Beloved son of the late Morris and Marsha Jarcho, dear brother of Arthur and Edythe Jarcho, and the late Julia and David Joseph, loving uncle of Robert and Steven Jarcho, Norma Hart and the late Arlene Ingerman, caring greatuncle of the Hart and Ingerman children. The family will receive at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, January 10, 1998, 7-9 P.M. Services at the Chapel, on January 11, at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations in remembrance to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: As Irresistible as Peanuts: Okra Steamed, Stewed or Sauteed
description: PEOPLE either love or hate okra. I happen to love it, and whenever I am lucky enough to come across really fresh, bright green okra in a store I find it hard to pass it by. Often I simply steam the long, slender pods whole and serve them with nothing more than a dash of lemon juice, coarse sea salt and pepper.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Bonds May Win the Catbird Seat
description: A TUMBLE in long-term bond rates in the infant days of 1998 could be the beginning of good news for investors who have been moving holdings into bond funds, seeking a haven from the world's tumultuous equity markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 28 about the investment strategy of Howard F. Ward, manager of the Gabelli Growth fund, referred incorrectly to some of his responsibilities at a previous employer, Scudder, Stevens & Clark. He indeed managed mutual funds -- two of them, as well as large-cap growth investments for institutional accounts.

title: Q. & A.
description: Rules on Renewing A Lease

title: In Praise and Remembrance of a Fallen Leader
description: CHAMBER music. Would that be four or five people, peaceably playing string quartets or wind quintets in a small concert hall? Not at the 10th annual ''Sing in Praise of King'' celebration in Newark. Even its previous tributes to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were chamber music only in the sense that they were presented in nearby churches, and churches are traditionally friendly to chamber music.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Clean Up Calverton T.W.A. Site
description: IT may be one of the most difficult economic development strategies ever implemented anywhere the United States. Riverhead Town officials are seeking to redevelop a former defense factory complex that sits astride, for all intents and purposes, the largest and most expensive aircraft morgue ever assembled in the nation -- the remains of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Lives; The Forbidden Oreo
description: The news came racing across the Internet with apocalyptic urgency. My rabbinical chat group was abuzz. Could it finally be true? No, we don't have a Jewish President yet, but some-thing almost equally astounding has transpired, a sign that Jews have finally made it. After 85 years in the gentile larder, Oreos are going kosher.

title: Film Editing Team Draws World to Ossining
description: WHAT drew the composer and musician Yanni from the Forbidden City in Beijing to Ossining? A studio where he could take his 57 hours of unedited film.

title: In Bronxville, Celebrating Italy's Diversity
description: TASTEFUL, stylish Pane e Vino promises a bit of relief for those longing for Italia. By offering a handful of regional dishes, the special menu celebrates the noble diversity of Italy's fare con brio, attending to one region for a few months and then moving on to another.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Writing in Time A Political Chronicle. By Jonathan Schell. Moyer Bell, $24.95.

title: On Sign Language In Public Schools
description: It is quite often necessary to clarify the facts after an article about the deaf, such as ''Signs for the Hearing, Lessons From the Deaf,'' Dec. 21. The article quotes a University of Connecticut linguist as saying, ''It's a very useful language because students who learn it can then communicate with a segment of the population that is right here in this country: the deaf and the hearing-impaired.''

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Mr. Magoo

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: For 1998, a Rainbow Of New Perennials
description: WHAT'S new in annuals and perennials? Each gardening year begins with enticing offerings of a plethora of seed catalogues.

title: The Man Who Invented Management
description: The World According to Peter Drucker

title: Missing the Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; One-Way Ticket
description: A middle-aged Australian, told he has a terminal illness, indulges a long-held urge to set off alone on a meandering trip, guided only by whim, chance and a need to figure out how to live without a belief in his own future. He travels to Switzerland, northern Italy and finally a hotel in Venice, where each night he retraces his journey in letters to a friend, fretting that his observations on mortality and the search for meaning have ''all been said before in a thousand different ways.'' Perhaps, but rarely with the wit, economy or success of Robert Dessaix's novel NIGHT LETTERS (Wyatt/St. Martin's, $22.95). This pocket-size book, dense with allusions to literary travelers like Dante, Casanova and Sterne, drove the Hollywood-bound ''Horse Whisperer'' from atop the Australian best-seller list. That's a testament to the popularity of its author, a book commentator on television and radio, and to the wry, chatty, surprisingly cheerful voice in which he discourses on heaven and hell, seduction and sex. (The inevitable nod to ''Death in Venice'' is Professor Eschenbaum, a fellow hotel guest drawn to S & M.) Dessaix even provides sniping footnotes to puncture every epiphany that swells too grandly. But his central insight, if hardly original, is hard won and moving: that life may be lived best as a voyage, not to get somewhere or to accumulate experiences but to savor each moment. Patrick Farrell

title: The Cornhuskers Deserved It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INTEREST GROUPS PREPARE TO SPEND ON CAMPAIGN SPIN
description: So many independent interest groups are poised to spend large sums on advertising to influence elections this year that Republicans and Democrats alike fear the candidates may find themselves playing bit parts in their own campaigns.

title: It's a Tree! It's a Cactus!; Phone Companies Try to Soften a Suburban Antenna Invasion
description: Rising over the red barns, duck pond and greenhouses of Twinbrook Nurseries here is an unlikely symbol of a wireless communications revolution sweeping the United States: a 100-foot-tall pine tree.

title: Say No . . . and Win!
description: Can free manicures and the lure of cold cash keep teen-age girls from getting pregnant? Gil Burnett, a retired trial judge from New Hanover County, N.C., thinks it's worth a try. Frustrated by 23 years of punishing crimes whose ''root cause,'' he says, was unwanted pregnancy, Burnett is pushing a plan called Project for Happier Lives, which would entice young women to stay un-pregnant through cash sweepstakes. Under it, any girl age 10 to 19 could enroll in three years of monthly classes in money management, career planning and (the crux) saying no to sexual advances, a subject Burnett has dubbed ''Games Guys Play 101.'' For staying un-pregnant, each girl would get the chance to win monthly drawings of $25 gifts (for hairdos and the like) and a $5,000 grand prize at the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEF, ARTHUR
description: LIEF-Arthur. On January 8, 1998. The kindest man, a true gentleman with the heart of a radical. Conductor, voice teacher, opera translator, and music intellectual. Survived by his beloved wife of forty-five years Ruth Hurok Lief, two stepchildren Peter Hyams and Nessa Hyams Picker, sisters Ruth Leif Miller and Helen Martin, three grandsons Chris, John and Nick Hyams, two great-granddaughters, a niece Laura Miller and nephews Kenneth Miller, Michael Miller and Bill Martin.

title: Philadelphia Tries Everything
description: A PRAYER FOR THE CITY By Buzz Bissinger. Illustrated. 408 pp. New York: Random House. $25.95.

title: Candid Laughter: Recasting a Fond Memory From the 50's
description: IT is December 1996. Two producers walk into the office of Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Entertainment, and show him their six-minute tape of young children giving unintentionally hilarious answers to questions like ''What does your father do for a living?'' The laughter in the room is infectious. Mr. Moonves loves it. As the producers head for the door, Mr. Moonves says, ''It would be great if Bill Cosby could host this.''

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A minor miracle happened when THE OLD MAN AND THE SEA, John Sturges's 1958 film of Hemingway's novel, reached television: it flowered. In movie theaters, the wide-screen projection and Dimitri Tiomkin's swelling, brilliant score all but swallowed this soliloquy of a lone man (Spencer Tracy) battling a huge fish. Now it clicks superbly -- just the right size for intimate viewing. Tracy is wonderfully moving as the old Cuban wrestling with life itself. If the story doesn't hook you, the music will -- 6 P.M. on Sunday and 1:15 A.M. on Sunday/EarlyMonday on AMC.

title: BUSINESS AIR FARES CLIMB, PROMPTING CALLS FOR REMEDY
description: Business travelers are continuing to pay increasingly higher air fares, with the price of a domestic round-trip coach ticket on at least one route surpassing $2,000 for the first time.

title: The Best Quarterback Ever
description: There's nothing to being a football player,'' W.W. (Pudge) Heffelfinger used to say, ''if you're a football player.'' Pudge should have known. He was Walter Camp's first All-America at Yale's 1892 football factory, and the first player to be paid for playing football. Steve Young is a football player, one whom Pudge would probably have let play on his team, even though the passing game that Young excels at was in its Jurassic stage in Pudge's playing days.

title: BOTH SIDES FIGHT TO END SPECTACLE OF UNABOM TRIAL
description: After a week when Theodore J. Kaczynski reduced his trial to chaos, Justice Department officials in Washington considered and ultimately rejected a new offer by him to try to avoid the death penalty by pleading guilty to Unabom crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, EVELYN
description: ROSEN-Evelyn. On January 9, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Moe. Loving mother of Miriam and the late Adele Glick. Adoring grandmother of Richard. Cherished aunt. Services Monday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Russia's Nuclear Temptation
description: The end of the cold war has produced an alarming nuclear irony. Russia is now more dependent on its nuclear weapons than ever and at the same time those weapons are more vulnerable. That increases the chances that in a severe crisis Moscow might consider using them. It is imperative for Washington to help reverse that trend, and President Clinton has the tools to do so, if he is willing to use them.

title: Regrouping, Disney Music Names Chairman
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it was consolidating its music operations and had named Bob Cavallo as chairman of the Walt Disney Music Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, ESTHER
description: FOX-Esther. On January 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin and mother of the late Sylvan. Cherished aunt of Dr. Seymour Romney and Dr. Leonard Romney, Jonas Senter, Ellen Steiner, and the late Arnold, Stanley and Lowell Senter.

title: Farmers Tasting Spring, but Too Soon
description: It was mild yesterday at Donio Farms in Hammonton, N.J. The peach trees continued to turn from muddy brown to lipstick red. The horizon was brimming with bright sunshine. The thermometer read 51 degrees in the shade. This was not good news.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the House & Home section on Thursday with an article about Cubans' upkeep of American cars of the post-World War II era misstated the make of a car. It was a composite of 1948 and 1949 Oldsmobiles with Buick chrome strips on the front fender, not a late 1940's Pontiac.

title: Corrections
description: The Private Eye column in the Arts section on Dec. 22 about a visit to the port of Whitby, England, by a replica of Capt. James Cook's ship, the Endeavour, misidentified the site of Cook's death in the Hawaiian Islands in 1779. It was the island of Hawaii, not Kauai.

title: Barriers to Pedestrians Will Stay, Giuliani Says
description: The pedestrian barricades in midtown Manhattan will stay up after all, until their effectiveness in improving traffic is evaluated, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDEL, MILTON
description: HANDEL-Milton. Beloved husband of the late Judith. Devoted father of Phyllis J. Loved by many cousins and dear friends. Formerly of NY Electronics. Funeral services today, 12:30 PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapels,'' West Broad Street, Mount Vernon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISSELMAN, JEFFREY
description: SISSELMAN-Jeffrey. Loving father of Amanda and Stephen. Dear son of Laura and Frederick Sisselman. Devoted brother of Donna and Derrick Cephas. Service 12 noon, today, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: They Converse but Do Not Speak to Each Other
description: Even though you can't actually see it, it is obvious that the game isn't going well. The hollow clicks of a bouncing Ping-Pong ball, the sounds that open a scene in the Signature Theater Company's revival of Arthur Miller's ''Last Yankee,'' have the fitful, careless cadences of a broken metronome. And when a woman chases a stray ball onto the stage, her expression is not one of spirited competition. ''Why are we doing this?'' she asks irritably.

title: Juggling Themes of Identity and Dance
description: The year isn't even two weeks old, but it is hard to imagine the dance to come quite measuring up to the daring and accomplishment of the program presented by Mark Dendy Dance and Theater on Saturday night, in the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater.

title: Part of 5th Ave. to Reopen After Rupture
description: Ten days after a water main break forced the closing of a stretch of lower Fifth Avenue, the avenue is to be partly reopened to traffic this morning at 6, city officials said yesterday.

title: Boy Who Is Left Alone in Truck Dies When It Rolls Into a Pond
description: A 9-year-old boy sitting in his parents' Ford Bronco died yesterday morning after the truck somehow rolled into a frigid pond with the boy inside, the authorities said.

title: Islanders' Scoring Troubles Continue
description: There was talk of the Islanders' improved corps of forwards, matured defense and better goaltending this season. There was talk of them making the playoffs for the first time in four years. There was talk of Zigmund Palffy scoring 60 goals.

title: A Major Hong Kong Bank Is Forced to Close Its Doors
description: Asia's largest investment bank outside Japan, Peregrine Investments Holdings, was forced to shut down today, the first major casualty of the economic and currency crisis that has swept through the region since summer.

title: Herbert Grossman, 67, Headed Drug Maker
description: Herbert Grossman, a pharmaceutical industry executive who helped introduce some of the world's most widely prescribed drugs, including Valium and the Sabin polio vaccine, died of congestive heart failure in Manhattan on Dec. 29. He was 67.

title: Eldon W. Lyle, 89, a Fighter Of Diseases Affecting Roses
description: Eldon W. Lyle, a noted plant pathologist of Tyler, the East Texas town known as a center of rose research, died on Dec. 28 at a Tyler nursing home. He was 89 and had lived in Tyler most of his life.

title: Dream Study Supports Freud
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Frederic Kavaler, 71, Heart Researcher
description: Dr. Frederic Kavaler, a physiologist whose study of the contraction of heart cells opened the way for research on ways to treat heart disease, died on Jan. 4 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Abroad at Home; Silencing Other Ideas
description: The American Jewish community has for many decades been a force against intolerance. Jews played a leading part in the fight against racial and religious discrimination in this country. And against political hatred, too: Jews were among the prominent opponents of Senator Joe McCarthy.

title: Amid Asian Turmoil, Bullish Forecast for New York City
description: The Asian economic crisis has created uncertainty and heightened volatility in many parts of the world, but not in New York City. Most economists say that 1998 will be much like 1997: steady, with job growth led by Wall Street, and a continued overall surge in tourism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILLINGSWORTH, MAX
description: KILLINGSWORTH-Max. Died at the age of 58, of respiratory and cardiac failure. Max is survived by Thom Hansen, his mother Maude Killingsworth of Dothan, AL, brothers Doug and Jimmy, sisters Mary and Betty, and an extensive extended family here in NYC. He was a longtime resident of Cherry Grove and volunteered as the lighting and sound technician for the Arts Project for over 20 years. He was an active member of the APCG, CGPOA, MCAA Bowling, ICNY and the Twelfth Night Club. He was a longtime friend of Bill W. There will be a viewing at Reddens Funeral Home on 14th Street between 8th and 9th Avenue on Tuesday, January 13, from 2-5 and 7-9. A funeral/memorial celebration will be held on Saturday, January 17 at 10 AM, location to be announced.

title: Kenichi Fukui, 79, Nobel Winner in Chemistry
description: Kenichi Fukui, a Japanese theoretical and physical chemist who was one of two winners of the 1981 Nobel Prize for chemistry, died on Friday in a hospital in Kyoto, Japan. He was 79 and lived in Kyoto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISTAL, DIANA
description: KRISTAL-Diana. On January 9, 1998, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Alexander, loving mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, sister, and aunt. You were our princess. Burial private. Alene, Laura, Julie, Victor, Sam

title: Sports of The Times; The Original Slash Comes to Town and Shows How It's Done
description: Here we go again. Again and again. John Elway has earned his fourth opportunity to do what most players never accomplish in a lifetime. He'll play for a championship.

title: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at the tobacco agreement; U.S. May Fill In for Tobacco Sponsorships
description: Tucked into the hundreds of pages introduced in Congress to implement a settlement with the nation's tobacco companies are several little-noticed provisions, some of which go by names like ''alternative event sponsorship.''

title: Cubans Face Past as Stranded Youths in U.S.
description: Raquelin Mendieta cannot cry. Maria de los Angeles Torres cannot send her daughters alone in a plane anywhere. And Antonio Garcia, married for 31 years, cannot stand to be apart from his wife for even one night.

title: INSIDE
description: Ice-Bound Region Digs Out

title: College Freshmen Aiming For High Marks in Income
description: A survey of college freshmen confirms what professors and administrators said they have been sensing, that students are increasingly disengaged and view higher education less as an opportunity to expand their minds and more as a means to increase their incomes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCANLON, ANTHONY J.
description: SCANLON-Anthony J. Age 46, of High Falls, Ulster County and NYC, on January 10, 1998, of AIDS. Son of the late Clifford J. and Nancy, he is survived by his life partner Mark P. Walter, and his beloved brother and sisters, Clifford J., Nancy and Marina Trentacoste, and brothers-in-law Salvatore Trentacoste and Lewis Spencer, and sister-in-law Joan Scanlon. Also survived by his devoted niece and nephews Stephanie, Peter and Andrew Trentacoste and Clifford J. and Matthew Anthony Scanlon, and dear friends Joseph Ferone and Wilfred and Diana Chabrier and family. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St, NYC, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10:30 AM, The Oratory at St. Boniface Church, 190 Duffield St, Brooklyn, NY.

title: An Ice-Bound Region Struggles to Recover
description: Even the hardiest residents of upstate New York have been astonished at the damage done by the huge ice storm that has paralyzed much of the region and parts of New England and Canada. The brunt of the storm hit last Wednesday night, and it continued until early Friday. It has left several people dead, downed thousands of trees and power lines and left hundreds of thousands without electricity. Crews have had some success clearing main roads and restoring power, but normality is still weeks away. Article, page B6.

title: Essay; Dual Doormat Policy
description: A new U.S. foreign policy toward Iran and Iraq, rooted in a showing of fierce acquiescence, has been quietly adopted by the Clinton Administration. Because the previous policy of ''Dual Containment'' was beginning to demand tough decisions on sanctions and sacrifice, it was replaced by the policy of the Dual Doormat.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Awaking the Poet From Those Sweet Dreams of Truth, Beauty and Loss
description: KEATS

title: 2 Agencies to Focus On Direct Marketing
description: Two agencies are making major changes in their direct marketing operations.

title: A time for sympathy, yes, sympathy for Microsoft in its lonely stand.
description: THERE are times when sympathy for the underdog in the Justice Department's antitrust litigation is unavoidable. There Microsoft stands, the most powerful corporation in the computer business, disdained by rivals, petulant in its responses, heading toward the shoals of limitless litigation. And the attacks come from below as well as above.

title: Korean Banks Said to Be in Technical Default
description: South Korea's banks are technically in default on billions of dollars of loans that have been twice extended by international lenders, according to a leading credit-rating agency.

title: Clinton to Require State Efforts to Cut Drug Use in Prisons
description: Seeking to cleanse prisons of illegal drugs, the Clinton Administration plans to tell the states that they have to determine and report the extent of illicit drug use among their inmates before they can receive more Federal money to spend on prisons.

title: A dozen advertising executives are seeking new agencies and new opportunities to start the year.
description: FRENZIED round of musical chairs involving executives at several agencies has ended with at least a dozen fannies landing in new seats.

title: U.S. Officials Tackle Crisis In Indonesia
description: With Asia's economic crisis threatening to set off political upheaval in Indonesia, a team of President Clinton's top aides arrived here this evening and immediately began searching for ways to stop the free fall of the region's currencies and stock markets.

title: Old Rift Heals in a Modern Crisis; As Population Dwindles, Astoria's Greeks Repair a Schism
description: A religious rivalry from the Old World has smoldered for years on the tranquil streets of Astoria, Queens, inside its Greek diners and schools, and especially in its Orthodox churches.

title: Is Big Brother Watching? Why Would He Bother?; We're All Vulnerable
description: To the Editor:

title: Networks And N.F.L. Near Deals
description: In negotiations that are expected to end this week, the National Football League is seeking eight-year deals with its television partners, according to participants in the talks who insisted they not be identified.

title: David Clark, 73; Furthered Nuclear Research
description: Dr. David D. Clark, a nuclear physicist who developed a nuclear research tool that promises to provide more precise analyses of materials, died on Dec. 22 at his office at Cornell University. He was 73 and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Police Make Arrest In Hit-and-Run Death
