description: The day after a Brooklyn man was killed by a hit-and-run driver, detectives found the car and arrested its owner on charges of vehicular manslaughter and leaving the scene of an accident, the police said.

title: Taking In the Sites; The Easy Way to Discover the Titanic
description: The continuing interest in the story of the Titanic, the unsinkable ship that sank, has obviously been heightened by the current hit movie and Broadway musical. But well before these adaptations came along, the World Wide Web offered a rich resource of Titanic lore and facts.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: In South Korea, A Prudent Bailout; What to Do Next
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferraro Seeks Curbs on 'Personal Attacks'
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, trying to avoid a reprise of her disastrous 1992 campaign, said yesterday that she would not debate either of her opponents for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate unless they signed a pledge promising not to ''engage in personal attacks'' during the primary.

title: Equity Offerings Set
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: An Untimely Retreat by Vietnam
description: Since 1986, Vietnam has attracted tens of billions of dollars in foreign capital and sparked a noticeable rise in urban living standards by moving away from the rigid socialist economics bequeathed by Ho Chi Minh. But in recent years, Vietnam's reforming impulse has stalled.

title: Vote Expected Today On Anti-Fraud Measures
description: A bill that would sharply increase the penalties for fraudulent health insurance claims is in a position to be approved by both the Senate and the Assembly today in the last session of the Legislature before the new legislators are sworn in tomorrow.

title: Sports of The Times; You Can Call It the Cheesehead Offense
description: EVER since Mike Holmgren took command of the Packers in the 1992 season, he has often been described as a disciple of the West Coast offense originally devised by Bill Walsh, the 49ers' coach during their first three Super Bowl victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, CANON JOHN WEBB, E.D., Q.C., B.A., LI.B., D.S.LITT., U.E.
description: GRAHAM-Canon John Webb, E.D., Q.C., B.A., LI.B., D.S.Litt., U.E. Peacefully at home, on Friday, January 9, 1998 in his 86th year. Beloved husband of Natasha. Loving father of Ann Grahman Calderisi and Ted Rogers. Caring fatherin-law of Loretta Rogers. Dear brother of Betty C. Graham. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Edward, Melinda and Martha Rogers and Rafe Calderisi. Great-grandfather of Chloe Rogers. Step-father of Norman Nicholas Campbell and Tanya O'Neil. Predeceased by his wife Velma Rogers Graham. A true gentleman with a distinguished service in the law, business, the military, his church and public service. The family will receive friends at the Humphrey Funeral Home-A.W. Miles Chapel, 1403 Bayview Avenue, Toronto, from 3-5 P.M. and 7-9 PM on Sunday, January 11, 1998. Funeral service Monday, January 12, 1998, 11 o'clock Grace Church On-TheHill, 300 Lonsdale Road (bet. Ave Road and Spadina Road) Toronto. . Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to The John Webb Graham Library, Trinity College, Univ. of Toronto would be appreciated.

title: Let States Keep Their Bankruptcy Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Goldstar develops a VCR that can record and play back digital signals on current tapes.
description: IN the drama surrounding the evolution of digital television, the central character has usually been the smarter, sharper sets that people will have in their homes a few years from now. But how will the new digital signals affect television's sidekick, the videocassette recorder?

title: A Barrier the Niners Just Can't Overcome
description: The classy, stylish and prosperous San Francisco 49ers do not seem the type to be saddled with a nemesis. Winners of five Super Bowls, the most in the league, the 49ers have usually found a way to conquer even their most resolute rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MERSON, ROBERT
description: MERSON-Robert. 4/19/45-1/12/97. We love and miss you more with each passing day. Your joyful spirit lives on in all of us. Miriam and Larry Ann and Ardie All your nieces, nephews, cousins, aunts and uncle

title: Ban Virginity Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: With U.S. Team Set, Thoughts Turn to Nagano and Another Sort of Triple
description: Now that Michelle Kwan, Tara Lipinski and Nicole Bobek have finished 1-2-3 at the Olympic trials, many in the figure-skating community believe that they can also sweep the medals at next month's Olympic Games.

title: A Humorous Strauss Curiosity Becomes a Showcase for Te Kanawa
description: It would have made little budgetary sense for the Metropolitan Opera to mount its own production of Strauss's ''Capriccio'' from scratch. The seldom heard opera, Strauss's last, which received its premiere in Munich in 1942, has never been a crowd pleaser. It's a curiosity, a talky, wryly humorous work with some rapturously lyrical touches in which the story of two friendly rivals, a poet and a composer, vying for the love of a widowed countess, becomes a frame for a sort of Platonic dialogue about whether words or music are more important in opera.

title: Stewart's Magic Runs Out This Time
description: A couple of days before the American Football Conference championship game, Pittsburgh quarterback Kordell Stewart said he was not buying into the sappy, sentimental notion of John Elway, the Denver Broncos' 37-year-old quarterback, making it to the Super Bowl again. Stewart said he wanted to end his first season as a starter with a bang -- a victory today over Elway's Broncos, and another victory in the Super Bowl.

title: Lawmaker Proposes Giving Free Metrocards to More Students
description: A New York State assemblyman from Manhattan and some politically awakening high school students from the South Bronx called on city and state officials yesterday to find money in their budget surpluses to provide free Metrocards to tens of thousands of New York City pupils who have to pay to get to school.

title: The Neediest Cases; New Mattress Eases Life of Bedridden
description: Millie Joyner lives in bed. For the last two decades, her world has been circumscribed by the four walls of her bedroom, the tedium relieved only by television sitcoms, a dog-eared Bible and tapes of the boisterous church services recorded each Sunday by members of her Pentecostal congregation.

title: Scaffolding Shields a School Where Falling Brick Hurt Girl
description: A Brooklyn school where a 16-year-old girl was struck and critically injured by falling bricks last Friday will be open for classes today, encircled by new wooden scaffolding to guard against further mishaps, school officials said yesterday.

title: Bates to Form Travel And Tourism Unit
description: Bates USA Midwest is forming a unit specializing in travel and tourism accounts after landing a large client.

title: State Says Gypsy Moths Are Taking a Beating
description: The state is winning the war against the gypsy moth caterpillars, the foliage-eating pests that have flourished in New Jersey for decades, officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. Budget Surplus: Three Basic Choices
description: As Congress and the White House begin debating what to do with the expected budget surpluses, they face three basic choices.

title: Evoking Sounds of War, Electronically
description: Charles Bornstein and his ST-X Ensemble have done a huge amount for the music of Iannis Xenakis, but not this time. Their big mistake on Friday evening at the Kitchen was to hand over so much of their program to electronic sound projection by DJ Spooky, a k a Paul D. Miller, and then his big mistake was to set the levels so high. ''Mycenes Alpha'' was so loud as to be intolerable. One day it might be interesting to know just what Mr. Miller does in ''taking the original source material of pre-existing electronic compositions by Xenakis and translating them into his own musical spin language,'' but here one could not care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, CATHERINE R. (NEE RYAN)
description: LEAHY-Catherine R. (nee Ryan). Of Astoria and Southampton, NY, unexpectedly died on January 8, 1998. Loving wife of Justice John J. Leahy, retired New York State Supreme Court Justice. Beloved mother of John J., Jr., of Seldon, LI, Patricia Ann of Atlanta, GA, and Thomas L. of Garden City, NY. Loving mother-in-law of Pamela and Diana. Devoted grandmother of Heather, Brian, Christina and Joseph L. Funeral from Thomas M. Quinn and Sons Funeral Home, 35-20 Broadway, LIC, NY 11106, Tuesday, 8:45 AM. Funeral Mass will be celebrated at Most Precious Blood R.C. Church, 9:45 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a new approach to history, called counterfactual analysis, gave an incomplete title for a journal of military history; it is MHQ: The Quarterly Journal of Military History.

title: Machine Tool Orders Down In November
description: Orders for machine tools fell in November, though total purchases so far for 1997 remain above the 1996 level, an industry survey showed today.

title: Voice-Controlled Car CD Player to Be Sold
description: In a move to bring computers to another venue -- the automobile -- the Clarion Company plans to offer a voice-controlled radio/compact disk player with an eight-color liquid crystal display, bringing software from the Microsoft Corporation to the dashboard.

title: Washington Is Losing Millions From Vandalized Parking Meters
description: The District of Columbia, a city criticized for mismanagement and desperate for revenue, is losing millions of dollars a year because vandals have decapitated more than half its parking meters.

title: Kinsman of Sinn Fein Chief Killed at Protestant Club
description: On the eve of resumption of formal peace talks aimed at ending the long history of political violence in this British province, Northern Ireland was shocked today by a particularly bizarre sectarian killing.

title: Order in the Court
description: Many news articles last week compared the request by Theodore Kaczynski to defend himself with the decision by Colin Ferguson, the gunman who killed my husband and five other people on the Long Island Rail Road in 1993, to do the same. Regardless of how the Unabom case eventually plays out, it is important to remember that the Ferguson trial was about more than the defendant's decision to represent himself.

title: Budget-Surplus Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: Universal Experience Resonates In Perky Pop
description: Eggheaded rock critics, music business insiders and radio-playing fans all agreed on one thing in 1997: pop led the way. From Aqua's ode to plastic, ''Barbie Girl,'' to Sean (Puffy) Combs's ode to cash, ''It's All About the Benjamins,'' pop proved that music could be a shiny toy and still stimulate more cultural conversation than the dourest rock poet on the block.

title: Heirs Claim Art Lost To Nazis in Amsterdam; Another Collection Joins the Disputes Over Who Owns War's Cultural Booty
description: Jacques Goudstikker, a leading art dealer in prewar Amsterdam, was one of many wealthy Jewish collectors whose artworks were seized by Nazi Germany in the early 1940's. But unlike, say, the Rothschilds and David-Weills of France, who recovered most of their belongings after the war, Goudstikker's collection was never reconstituted. By the mid-1950's, it was as if he had never existed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARIES, PETER L.
description: ARIES-Peter L. You were an inspiration to me because you never gave up hope. Peter ''A'' was my devoted business partner for over ten years and my cherished friend forever. I will always remember the wonderful experiences we shared working together at Aries Brandenberg Company (ABC) as the Peters ''A'' and ''B'' team. I will never forget you. Rest in peace, my friend. Love, Peter ''B'' Brandenberg

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : 'Caged Bird' Is Silenced In Maryland Classrooms
description: In Maryland, two public school superintendents have removed books by prominent black authors from high school English classes at the urging of some parents who called the works "anti-white."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERENSTEIN, DAVID
description: MERENSTEIN - David. Beloved husband of the late Rita. Devoted mother of Fern Merenstein and Kenneth Rosenberg, and Alan and Carmela Merenstein. Cherished grandfather of Jeremy and Robert. Loving brother of Abraham and Ruth Merenstein and the late Jack Merenstein, and brother in-law of Pearl Merenstein. Services today, 12:30 PM, ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: In South Korea, A Prudent Bailout; Workers Pay the Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EUSTACE, EDWARD PATRICK
description: EUSTACE-Edward Patrick. On Friday, January 9. Age 74. Of Montvale, NJ. Born to the late Patrick and Mary Eustace of New York City. Husband of Catherine Eustace, 39 years. Father of Edward, Stephen, James, Mary Catherine, and John. Father-in-law of Emmy, Maura, Cheryl and Edward Johnson. Grandfather of Ana, Colin and Christopher. Brother of Robert J. Eustace and Mary Eustace Leonard. Combat veteran World War II, serving in the U.S. Army Air Corps as a member of the U.S. 8th Air Force. He was awarded five Air Medals for courageous service in bomber operations over occupied Europe in 1944-45. 1948 graduate of Manhattan College. Served in the Banking Department of the State of New York for 35 years. Retired from the position of Deputy Superintendent of Foreign Banks for the State of New York and was widely recognized for his major contribution to a sound international banking community in the State. Former Grand Knight, Knights of Columbus Council 4486, Park Ridge, NJ. Viewing at Becker Funeral Home, Westwood, NJ, 7-9 PM, Monday, and 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Park Ridge, NJ, 9:30 AM, on Wednesday. Memorial contributions may be made to Tomorrow's Children Fund, 30 Prospect Ave., Hackensack, NJ, or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: Boston Properties to Buy Prudential Center
description: Boston Properties Inc., headed by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, and a real estate fund of Goldman, Sachs & Company have agreed to buy the landmark Prudential Center office complex in Boston for about $700 million from the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Dream Study Supports Freud; Protectors of Sleep
description: To the Editor:

title: Allowed to Use a Cart for Now, Golfer Wins Nike Tour Tourney
description: Casey Martin paused as he tried to get a fix on his new place in golf history. ''What's important to me,'' the 25-year-old said finally, ''is I think I've shown I'm capable of playing out here.''

title: First Steps to Reclaim Streets Are Precise, Joyful, Loud
description: The sound of drums echoed through the streets, signifying the hope and renewal of one north-central Philadelphia neighborhood devastated by lost work, poverty and drugs.

title: Is Big Brother Watching? Why Would He Bother?; Fear of Encryption
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JEAN LOWRY
description: DAVIS-Jean Lowry. On January 9, 1998, of East Hampton, NY, and wife of the late Reverend Samuel Davis. Mother of Timothy J. Davis and Margaret D. Staples, grandmother of three and great-grandmother of two. Visitation Monday, January 12, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, NY, at 24 and 7-9. Services 2 PM, Tuesday, January 13. Interment to follow at Cedar Lawn Cemetery. For information call Williams Funeral Home of East Hampton.

title: W.E. Diemer, Bubble Gum Inventor, Dies at 93
description: Walter E. Diemer, who invented bubble gum and taught salesmen how to market it by blowing gooey pink bubbles, died on Thursday at a hospital near his home in Lancaster, Pa. He was 93.

title: Ishmael Sends a Mind on a Voyage of Comparisons
description: ''Call Me Ishmael,'' the license-plate holder read. It was attached to an old Volvo parked on an Oakland, Calif., shopping street. As the only man to escape the Pequod with a tale to tell, Ishmael could have as well ended up in this place as any other. ''I find myself involuntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every funeral I meet,'' he says as ''Moby-Dick'' begins. Today, presumably, Ishmael or his double goes from the cheese store to the wine shop to the bakery in the same spirit, darkening every door with his morbid sense of humor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILICH, WALLACE M., LT. COL.
description: MILICH-Wallace M., Lt. Col. Military Intelligence AUS Ret, age 75, of Port Washington, Long Island, on January 9, 1998. Beloved husband of Zorka. Loving father of Mark and Andrea. Devoted brother of Rose Tomasevic. Funeral service at the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West 25th Street, NY, on Monday, 11 AM. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Sava Restoration and Development Fund, 15 West 25th St, NYC.

title: Litmus-Test Folly
description: It is hard to imagine a more destructive idea for the Republican Party than a litmus test on late-term abortion. Yet anti-abortion forces will be pushing a resolution at the Republican National Committee meeting this week that would bar the national party from supporting any candidate who opposed a ban on a procedure critics call ''partial birth'' abortion. The resolution, if passed, would essentially banish pro-choice Republicans and destroy any semblance of a ''big tent'' approach to party-building. Jim Nicholson, who is chairman of the R.N.C. and opposes the measure, will have to persuade conservative members that such a test would be folly.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sure, They're Expensive, But the Picture Is Great

title: Hamilton Scores 38 as No. 8 Huskies Rally
description: CONNECTICUT 80, BOSTON COLLEGE 68

title: Mexican Indian Women Protest Army's Search for Weapons
description: Hundreds of Indian women who gathered here today for a protest against the army looked prim in their fuschia dresses with lace collars and pleated skirts, but their words were combative. They demanded that the armed forces halt a campaign of raids to search their villages in southern Chiapas state for weapons.

title: A Big Stylist, In a Pixieish Package
description: Probably no cabaret performer illustrates the concept that less can be more as satisfyingly as Blossom Dearie, the ageless jazz pixie with a blond pageboy who is leading a fine trio at Danny's Skylight Room (346 West 46th Street, Clinton) on Thursdays through Saturdays through the end of February.

title: Is Big Brother Watching? Why Would He Bother?; Screen Your Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * DKB & Partners, Morristown, N.J., was awarded three accounts with combined billings estimated at $16 million: Public Service Electric and Gas Co., Newark, to handle product and service advertising and promotion; MD Foods, Union, N.J., to handle advertising for the dairy company, which had been handled by FDN&P Advertising, Whitehouse Station, N.J., and NYU Downtown Hospital, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising to promote a recent name change and affiliation with NYU Medical Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACLERIO, ALEXANDER C.
description: NACLERIO-Alexander C. On January 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Nicoletta (nee Cristiani). Loving father of Alphonse, Linda and Michael. Devoted grandfather of Michael, Alex, Stephen, Nicholas and Michele. Fond brother of four sisters and three brothers. Reposing at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Our Lady of Sorrows R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 24 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSIN, SYDNEY
description: GOSIN-Sydney. On behalf of our entire organization, we wish to express our profound sorrow to our esteemed partner, Barry Gosin, on the passing of his beloved father, Sydney. We would also like to extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire family, most especially Irene, Sydney's wife. May his memory be a blessing. The Partners of Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc. William Cohen Ira Fishman Ronald Goldberger Aaron Gural Jeffrey Gural James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post Arthur Rosenbloom

title: Metro Matters; Searching For Old Magic Of Tammany
description: OVER the weekend, in the back room of a nightclub in the Bronx, Democratic Party bosses got together to flex a little muscle and try to fix an election or two.

title: Think Globally, Focus Locally; Seeking 'Cruising Speed', Washington Post Editors Prefer Stability to Sizzle
description: It's not Ben Bradlee's Post anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, DAVID
description: BIRNBAUM-David. Of Bronxville, NY, and Boynton Beach, FL, on January 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Selma. Devoted father of Joyce, Ronnie, Beth, Arlene and Steven. Loving grandfather of Adam, Allison, Mark, Jamie, Jay and Jessica. Funeral services today at Free Synagogue of Westchester, Mt. Vernon, at 10 AM. He will live on in our hearts forever.

title: It Isn't Just Big Brother Who Is Watching
description: When Cameron Barrett taught his co-workers to surf the World Wide Web, he never imagined what they would do with their new skills.

title: Several Clients Name New Agencies
description: Several advertisers have made account changes.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Tuesday about Eartha Kitt's cabaret performance on Friday at the Cafe Carlyle misstated a song lyric in the opening paragraph. The line, from ''Champagne Taste,'' should have read, ''With my champagne taste and your beer bottle pocket [not ''budget''], you will have to work on something better than a zircon.''

title: Dream Study Supports Freud; Unanswered Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Northern New York Battles Ice Damage
description: The people who live in this old mill town do not flinch when a foot of snow falls overnight, or when the mercury plunges below zero, or when the bitter winds whip off Lake Ontario. Everyone remembers the blizzard of '77, when the snow drifts touched the roofs of the old frame houses on Rutland Street. This is not a town for soft people.

title: 'On the Town' Postponed on Broadway After Choreographer Leaves
description: The Public Theater's New York Shakespeare Festival revival of ''On the Town,'' the Betty Comden, Adolph Green, Leonard Bernstein and Jerome Robbins musical about sailors on liberty in New York, will not be presented as planned this spring at the St. James Theater, a spokesman for the Public Theater said yesterday.

title: Crisis Grows in Asia As Major Bank Falls
description: The largest investment bank in Asia outside Japan was forced to shut down today, the first major casualty of the economic and currency crisis that has swept through the region since the summer. It is the first major bankruptcy in Hong Kong since the territory reverted to Chinese rule in July.

title: Credit Offerings During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Pepsico Will Test-Market A New Lemon-Lime Drink
description: Tired of watching the lemon-lime soft drink market swallowed up by its competitors, Pepsi-Cola plans to test a new version in at least one city later this year.

title: U.S. to Back Baltic Membership In NATO, but Not Anytime Soon
description: The United States and the three Baltic nations will sign a formal charter on Friday that explicitly supports efforts by Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania to become members of NATO, American officials say.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paul O'Leary, Economist, Is Dead at 96
description: Paul M. O'Leary, an economist who oversaw the rationing program during World War II, died Jan. 1 at the Kendal at Ithaca nursing home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 96.

title: Baena Journal; No Olive Branch in the Embattled Olive Groves
description: Manuel Cubillo had filled his glass, cleared his throat and was ready to test a syrup of an unspeakable vivid yellow-green. Big slurping sounds followed. Mr. Cubillo beamed.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Ellis Island Feud Today
description: In a historic battle for jurisdiction and tax revenue, lawyers for New York and New Jersey are to argue before the United States Supreme Court today over control of Ellis Island.

title: Gunmen Steal $8,467 From Chelsea Piers Safe
description: Two gunmen burst into the new bowling alley at the Chelsea Piers sports complex just before closing time early yesterday and stole $8,467 from the safe, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, MARGARET
description: FOX-Margaret. Beloved mother of Norman Fox and Alan Parker; grandmother of Kim Fox, Steven Fox, Natalie Parker and Adam Parker. She will be sorely missed.

title: Casinos Paying Top Dollar To Coddle Elite Gamblers
description: It was past midnight at the Mirage Casino and Resort, and the actor Bruce Willis was sitting at a blackjack table, an unlit cigar between his teeth, drinking watermelon juice made especially for him and wagering more than $200,000 an hour. With $8,000 riding on one hand, Mr. Willis was dealt an ace and a 10. He slapped the winning cards down on the felt table. ''Look what I got,'' he bragged.

title: Broncos Super Again, but the Champs Will Be Waiting
description: They won with vengeance, with focus and with third-down precision. They won on the run and on the road, before 61,382 hostile fans in Three Rivers Stadium. The Denver Broncos won the American Football Conference title, 24-21, over the Pittsburgh Steelers today in a game full of emotion and momentum and could-have-beens and should-have-beens.

title: Will Iran Now Let a U.S. Congressman Visit? Yes and No
description: Iran's Ministry of Islamic Guidance and Culture had no guidance to offer today. The President's office said the Foreign Ministry would give an answer. But the Foreign Ministry had nothing to say.

title: The Piano at Full Power in Brahms
description: It always takes reminding that Brahms was a small man, verging on roundness as he added girth in his later years. It is tempting to imagine him as he sounds, especially in his piano music: big and burly, with hands like huge maws, able to swallow octavefuls of notes at a gulp.

title: New York Confidential
description: I could see the ''Biography'' sign flashing through the window in front of my treadmill. They had run out of people and were now profiling hurricanes. ''Hazel,'' it repeated, ''tonight at 8 on A&E.;'' Hazel was on Nick at Nite, too, and I wondered what Shirley Booth would think about $600,000 an episode. I climbed off the machine, before the Japanese cartoon syndrome took hold. Two-tenths of a mile? Sweating from embarrassment, I hit the streets.

title: Say This for Knicks: They're Never Boring
description: There were 2.4 seconds left, and the Seattle SuperSonics were inbounding under their own basket with a chance to win the game. Gary Payton wanted to pass to Vin Baker, but Baker could not free himself from his defender. In one of those away-from-the-action snapshots, you could understand why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, SEYMOUR
description: STERNBERG - Seymour. Died peacefully at home January 10, 1998. Husband of Helen (nee Kleban). Father of Diane and Nancy Shear. Father-in-law of Michael Shear. Grandfather of Deborah and Mark Shear. Brother of Leonard. Funeral services in Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, JACK C.
description: HELLER-Jack C. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of the son of its longtime members, Sig and Carol Heller. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus David Werber, President

title: Rangers and the Leafs Know One Another Well
description: The game between the Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight pits teams with many similarities.

title: Mickelson Stands Up to Challenges
description: Phil Mickelson did not have the luxury of playing conservative, risk-free golf today. Not with Tiger Woods raging around La Costa Resort and Spa, making one of his patented, electrifying charges. Not with Mark O'Meara matching Woods stroke for stroke and giving Mickelson another challenger to worry about. Not with David Duval chasing history, trying to become the first player since Ben Hogan in 1953 to win four consecutive PGA Tour starts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The guy is a great player and he deserves all the accolades, but I don't see guys in the N.F.L. who have knee injuries getting mopeds.''

title: Foreign Affairs Magazine Becoming Harder to Predict
description: Soon after taking over as the editor of Foreign Affairs in 1992, James F. Hoge Jr. stood before Washington members of the Council on Foreign Relations and presented them with their worst nightmare for their magazine: a mock front cover with the supermodel Cindy Crawford on the logo (instead of the usual rearing horse and rider) and cover lines like, ''Boris' Babes,'' ''Best Bets in Dictators'' and ''Sexiest Ethnic Rivalries.''

title: Taking a Creative Approach To Introducing New Works
description: Much hand-wringing is done these days about the classical music audience's supposed fear of new music, but too often this concern seems merely an excuse to concentrate on the established classics. At the Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center, which runs Merkin Concert Hall, the problem is being addressed creatively, in a three-year-old series called ''Zoom: Composers Close-Up.''

title: Ga. Tech Is Butler's College Choice
description: Niesha Butler, the subject of one of the country's most intense recruiting wars for a schoolgirl, announced yesterday that she would attend Georgia Tech in the fall. But that does not mean the 5-foot-8-inch guard from Riverdale Country School in the Bronx will stop regarding professional basketball as an option.

title: 2 Hospitals Announce Completion of Merger
description: Nearly 18 months after announcing plans to consolidate, officials of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center held a news conference yesterday to announce the completion of the merger.

title: Canadians Pushed to Drop U.S. Satellite TV
description: After spending $14,000 and more than a decade watching American satellite television with the aid of what, under Canadian law, was considered bootlegged technology, Garry Morcombe has gone legitimate.

title: George Shaw, 64, Backup To Great N.F.L. Quarterbacks
description: George Shaw, a quarterback who played eight professional seasons, mostly as a backup to Johnny Unitas, Charlie Conerly and Fran Tarkenton, died on Jan. 3 at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 64.

title: TCI Seeks Variety in Software And Suppliers for TV Boxes
description: John C. Malone, the chairman of Tele-Communications Inc., believes he can succeed where his predecessors have failed.

title: Two Penalties Sting Steelers
description: To Carnell Lake and Chad Scott, the calls were the equivalent of touch fouls in basketball. But they helped the Denver Broncos to a 24-21 victory over the Steelers in the American Football Conference championship game today, and helped put Denver in the Super Bowl.

title: Brodeur's Bane: Flu and a Full Schedule
description: He has been battling the flu and a demanding schedule of games and travel. And then on Saturday night in Pittsburgh, Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur gave up four goals in one period during a 4-1 loss.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Why Microsoft Is Taking a Hard Line With the Government
description: The Microsoft Corporation's final chance to avoid being dragged into court by the United States Government came on Oct. 16, when the Justice Department summoned Microsoft's legal team to Washington. For 90 minutes the lawyers were interrogated by Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, and his staff.

title: No One Can Stop Cassell, Especially Not the Critics
description: Sam Cassell walked to his car outside the Nets' practice facility at Ramapo College today, moving slowly to ease the pain. As he spoke quietly, he made it clear that the pain in his neck is a physical ailment and has nothing to do with the criticism that has been directed his way recently.

title: Another Shot at the End Fails, And This Time the Knicks Win
description: This was a voice from above, of sorts, a sign for the nonbelievers who had settled back in their seats at Madison Square Garden like skeptics at a faith healers' convention.

title: Ewart Abner Jr., 74, President of Motown Label
description: Ewart G. Abner Jr., a record business executive who was president of the Vee Jay and Motown labels, died on Dec. 27 in Los Angeles. He was 74.

title: Budget in the Black: A Dream Come True Proves to Be Somewhat Hard to Cope With
description: What seemed like a pipe dream only months ago now seems all but assured: the Federal Government will start running budget surpluses soon, perhaps even this year, leaving Congress and the White House with a windfall on their hands.

title: Internet Helps to Keep Silicon Valley in a Boom
description: Silicon Valley's booming economy continued at a near-record growth rate in 1997, adding 53,000 jobs and showing surprising strength in the manufacturing sector, which was once widely believed to be dispersing to low-cost labor regions around the world.

title: City Ballet Picks From a Grab Bag of Diversity
description: A program that ranges from Mozart to John Philip Sousa or Leonard Bernstein might seem something of a stretch. But not at the New York City Ballet, where musical diversity is the norm.

title: From an Opening Heart Lead To a Fatal Diamond Finesse
description: The most recent of many experts to abandon the New York City region is Carol Simon of Summit, N.J., who now lives in Las Vegas, Nev. A decade ago, playing in the Tri-State Women's Pairs, she held the South cards in a four-spade contract. She was helped by an opening heart lead, resulting from a dubious two-heart overcall by East.

title: Crisis in Asia Brings World To New York
description: The Italian, British, Japanese and American investment bankers who met last week around a conference table at Citicorp headquarters in Manhattan had at least two things in common: an abiding interest in the economic crisis in Asia, and the belief that the most logical place to talk about it was New York City.

title: From a Supplier of Gas Comes a Digital Pipeline
description: Pulsing beside a web of underground pipelines snaking out of Tulsa, Okla., one of the more intriguing second acts in the telecommunications industry is about to begin.

title: Two Top Prep Players Square Off
description: The Nike Super Six game yesterday between Hargrave Military Academy of Chatham, Va., and St. Patrick of Elizabeth, N.J., had been billed as a matchup of the nation's top two prep players, and Al Harrington was feeling the tension.

title: Is Big Brother Watching? Why Would He Bother?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISER, MARTIN
description: WEISER-Martin. January 10, 1998. Beloved brother of Sonia Ostrow and uncle of Marion Margolis. We mourn your loss. We love you, too.

title: San Francisco Gets the Weather, But Packers Win
description: If the Green Bay Packers' home-field advantage is the crunchy chill of a Wisconsin winter, then San Francisco's is El Nino. It rained all day today in the Bay area, and 3Com Park was like a muddy sandbox. The 49ers believed that knowing how to run and cut in pudding would be as much of an advantage as being acclimatized to minus-10 degrees. At least that is what they kept telling themselves.

title: Danger Afoot
description: As densely populated world capitals full of tourists, residents and workers on foot, New York and London experienced about the same level of carnage caused by motor vehicles in 1984 -- 300 pedestrian deaths in London, 293 in New York City. Now, more than a decade later, London has dramatically reduced pedestrian deaths -- to 159 in 1994. In the same year, New York's pedestrian death toll was 223. It now hovers between 220 and 260, depending on the data source.

title: They're Big. They're Expensive. They're the First High-Definition TV Sets.
description: The consumer-electronics industry gave the nation its first look at the future of television last week, and for the most part these new digital sets are as expensive as diamond rings -- and about as beguiling to behold.

title: Paris and New York Meet in Spirit and Sometimes Sound
description: The French Institute/Alliance Francaise opened a yearlong series, ''New York/Paris/New York,'' on Friday evening, and the first program drew the connections in every which way but one. A big one, musically speaking: sound.

title: Governor Proposes Surplus Be Used for Construction
description: With New York State's coffers flush with unexpected revenue, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed today paying for a variety of construction projects with $425 million in cash, rather than adding to the state's $30 billion debt by issuing bonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HYMAN R.
description: FRIEDMAN-Hyman R. Age 93. Beloved father of Michael and Carole. Adored grandfather of Debbie and Mark Cooper, Lisa and Tom Steigelman, Jon and Sherri Friedman. Admired great-grandfather of Bradley, Adam and Zachary Cooper. A father's father, a husband's husband, a lawyer's lawyer for almost 70 years, a self made man of deep integrity and wisdom and infinite love who placed his family before himself. He taught by example and we are all the better for having known him. We shall miss him and remember him always. The family requests that visiting with the mourners will take place Monday through Thursday at 7 PM, at 150 Central Park South.

title: In Church, Sharpton Defends Brawley Stance
description: For weeks, the Rev. Al Sharpton has kept a comparatively low profile at his own defamation lawsuit, but today he strode into a small church here and preached about little else.

title: In South Korea, A Prudent Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: New Issue for Journalists: Corporate Writing Duties
description: Mark H. Willes, the chairman of the Times Mirror Corporation, has taken another whack at the wall that separates the news and business operations at his company's newspapers, asking three prominent reporters to write parts of the Times Mirror 1997 annual report.

title: Chorus of Politicians, Executives and Experts Is Unable to Agree on the Key
description: Following are comments from politicians, educators, economists and cultural leaders about the projected budget surpluses and what to do with the money.

title: Raymond-Leopold Bruckberger, Priest and Author, Dies at 90
description: The Rev. Raymond-Leopold Bruckberger, a member of the Roman Catholic Dominican Order who became chaplain general of the French Resistance in World War II and a best-selling author in the United States, died Jan. 4 in a retirement home near Fribourg, Switzerland. He was 90.

title: Zeroing In On Politics In a Range Of Targets
description: About 70 minutes into ''Black Humor,'' his 90-minute one-man Off Broadway show, the comic Lewis Black turns to politics. And at last he seems to have found his proper subject: one that genuinely engages his intellect, truly arouses his characteristic choler and fills him with zest.

title: The CD format is losing its cachet as everyone with a computer starts recording.
description: THERE was a music journalist -- let's call him Neil -- who eight years ago, when he was writing for a weekly newspaper, laid out all of his extra compact disks on a table in the street as part of a moving sale. He sold them for $3 each -- and every single one was bought. People owned so few CD's back then that it was worth a few bucks to add to their collections. After all, if it was on CD, it couldn't be that bad.

title: A New Gandhi Hopes to End The Chaos of India's Politics
description: In a move that her supporters hope will shape Indian politics for years to come, Sonia Gandhi, widow of one assassinated Prime Minister and daughter-in-law of another, today made an emotional entry into public life.

title: With Supplements, Buyer Must Beware
description: A year ago I cautioned that not all supplements purported to contain glucosamine or chondroitin or both deliver what the labels say they do. Dietary supplements are not regulated by the Food and Drug Administration, and quality control and honesty vary widely in the supplement industry. You are likely to get what you pay for, so be suspicious of bargains, especially in products containing chondroitin, which is much more expensive than glucosamine.

title: Responding to Rivals, Sun Plans to Revamp Work Station Business
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. plans to announce today an overhaul of its work station business, including machines priced below $3,000, in response to competition from increasingly powerful personal computers.

title: Societe Generale Buying U.S. Investment Firm
description: Societe Generale, one of France's largest banks, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Barr Devlin Associates, an investment banker and strategic adviser to the utility industry in the United States. Terms were not disclosed. The acquisition is expected to close in February and was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. The deal advances Societe Generale's strategy of expanding its United States and international investment banking and securities businesses.

title: Brooklyn Quintuplet Dies as His Siblings Struggle to Stay Alive
description: The tiniest of the quintuplets born last week to a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, couple died before dawn yesterday, as his brother and three sisters, all weighing less than two pounds, battled for their lives at a hospital.

title: Two Singapore Banks Agree to Combine
description: Keppel Bank Ltd. and Tat Lee Bank Ltd. said yesterday that they would merge, creating a new Singapore bank with assets of more than $18 billion. The move foreshadows possible mergers among other Singapore banks, including a likely link between the new bank, which would be Singapore's fifth largest in terms of assets, and a larger Singapore financial institution, analysts said.

title: Wooten's Friend Is Found Dead
description: The companion of Giants safety Tito Wooten was found dead in the garage of her West Paterson, N.J., town house on Saturday, the Passaic County Prosecutor's Office said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ANDEL & GOLTERMANN G.m.b.H., a German company, said it had offered shareholders $13 a share in its bid to acquire the 38 percent it did not already own of Wandel & Goltermann Technologies, Research Triangle Park, N.C.

title: Skeptical High Court Hears Case Over Pride and Acreage on Ellis I.
description: The battle of Ellis Island was in full rhetorical cry at the Supreme Court today, when a question from the Court's only native New Yorker brought the proceedings down to earth.

title: PHYCOR STOCK SLUMPS 15 PERCENT ON WORD OF WRITE-OFFS
description: Phycor Inc. said yesterday that it would take pretax charges of $120 million, sending shares of the company, a physician-practice management concern, down 15 percent. The charges, mostly to close or consolidate clinics, will also cover last week's collapse of Phycor's plan to buy Medpartners Inc. for $6.8 billion. The shares fell $3.375, to $19, in trading of 12.9 million shares. Phycor, based in Nashville, said it would take an $83 million pretax charge in the fourth quarter, mostly related to two clinics with 70 physicians that it will close or sell. In the first quarter, Phycor plans to take a $22 million charge for consolidating five clinics and a $15 million charge related to the Medpartners deal.

title: CBS Guarantees Billions to Get N.F.L. Back
description: CBS returned to professional football yesterday after a wrenching four-year absence with a bold $500 million-a-year commitment that will assure the National Football League of staggering television fees into the next century.

title: Footlights
description: News

title: Metro Business; DKNY Store Coming To Madison Avenue
description: After years of scouring Manhattan for retail space, Donna Karan International announced yesterday that it would open a DKNY store at 655 Madison Avenue.

title: Gunman Invades Exchange
description: An armed man entered the Tokyo Stock Exchange director's office about 1 p.m. and apparently took a Finance Ministry official hostage, media reports said, citing police.

title: SONOCO SELLING BUSINESS AND EXPECTING LOWER EARNINGS
description: The Sonoco Products Company, a maker of packaging products, said yesterday that it would sell its North American labels operations to CCL Industries, of Willowdale, Ontario, for $100 million and that its fourth-quarter earnings would be reduced by about $175 million. Sonoco said that without the costs -- associated, in part, with the sale -- its earnings for the fourth quarter, ended Dec. 31, would have met Wall Street expectations. Analysts surveyed by First Call had predicted earnings of 49 cents a share. Sonoco also said it expected to record a gain of about $55 million in its first quarter from the $225 million sale of its industrial containers business to the Greif Brothers Corporation. Sonoco, of Hartsville, S.C., had 1996 sales of $2.8 billion.

title: Morality of Corpses
description: To the Editor:

title: One Way To Cope: Play Hard
description: In Pace's first game since the death of Coach Darrell Halloran, the Setters rallied from a 21-point deficit against Stonehill College of North Easton, Mass., last Thursday before losing an emotional game in overtime, 82-77.

title: $1.55 Billion Sale Set By Hong Kong Company
description: The First Pacific Company of Hong Kong said yesterday that it planned to sell its stake in the Dutch trading company Hagemeyer N.V. for about $1.55 billion, shedding its fastest-growing business for a chance to reduce debt and make new investments in Asia. Hagemeyer said it would try to insure a broad placement of the shares among domestic and international investors. First Pacific said it was also negotiating to sell other businesses to try to raise $450 million.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: A Double-Duty Homecoming; A Pioneer Returns to Georgia to Play . . . and Coach
description: When Nicky McCrimmon sailed a lazy one-handed pass through the lane and against the wall, Teresa Edwards stopped practice, put a hand on McCrimmon's head and told her, ''Use this thing.''

title: Trove of Van Gogh Works Is Lent to U.S. by the Dutch
description: The largest collection of van Gogh's paintings to be shown in this country in more than a quarter of a century will go on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington this fall. Seventy works including such iconic images as ''The Potato Eaters'' from 1885, ''The Bedroom'' from 1888 and seven self-portraits are being lent by the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam.

title: Patterns
description: From Saks to Burberrys

title: An Industry That Shrugs Off Errors
description: FIRE up new $800 computer. Click Internet icon. Use Internet Connection Wizard, which calls itself ''the easy way to get connected to the Internet.'' Click Next button. Click Automatic option, which ''sets up your computer to use a modem to connect to the Internet and configures your Internet settings for you.'' Click Next twice more.

title: Poor and Healthy in Albania
description: Albania is a poor country, but its people live as long as those in wealthy countries. In trying to explain that, researchers have come up with another vote of confidence for the Mediterranean diet, which has little saturated fat but lots of fresh fruits and vegetables and includes wine and monounsaturated fats, like olive oil.

title: Japan Questions Its Costly Program to Predict Earthquakes
description: SHORTLY after 1 P.M. one day last year, the silence of a room full of computers at the Japan Meteorological Agency was suddenly broken by a warning. ''An abnormal crustal change has occurred,'' a recorded voice announced.

title: Abortion Foe Will Not Back A G.O.P. Test
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde, one of the strongest opponents of abortion in Congress, came out today against a Republican Party resolution that would deny money to candidates who do not support a ban on a controversial late-term abortion procedure.

title: With West's Help, Bosnian Serb President May Form Cabinet
description: Despite her poor showing in the parliamentary elections, the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, looks set to form a new government -- with the help of her Western backers.

title: A Matter Of Opinion, Or a Crime?
description: IT certainly seemed that way to Mr. O'Grady and his Legal Aid lawyer, and they asked that charges be dismissed. No dice, another Criminal Court judge, Harold Adler, ruled a few weeks ago. And so the case is scheduled for trial tomorrow, though a postponement may be sought because Mr. O'Grady now lives in San Francisco.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: SOUTH KOREA RALLIES. The South Korean currency, the won, rose yesterday as it appeared that investor confidence in the country's economic outlook was growing despite the turmoil that engulfed much of the rest of Asia last week. The Korean stock market has climbed in 9 of the last 10 sessions.

title: The Arthritis Is at Bay, Thank You
description: THE two questions I was asked most often in 1997 were ''Is that dietary supplement still helping your arthritic knees?'' and ''Are there results yet from the studies being done on this side of the Atlantic?''

title: Asian Turmoil Putting Brakes On Arms Race
description: The economic crisis in Asia is beginning to have an unforeseen consequence: slowing a military spending spree that has thrown American, European and Russian arms makers into a heated competition for billions of dollars in weapons sales.

title: Iraq Threatens to Stop Work Of a U.N. Inspection Team
description: Two months after President Saddam Hussein provoked a confrontation with the United Nations and Washington by expelling American arms inspectors from Iraq, the Iraqis threatened again today to block the work of a new team with nine American members.

title: What's at Stake? Why, Just Ellis I.
description: The battle of Ellis Island was in full rhetorical cry at the Supreme Court yesterday when a question from the Court's only native New Yorker brought the proceedings down to earth. ''What, practically, is at stake?'' Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg wanted to know.

title: It's a California Jam Session as Rock Hall of Fame Inducts New Members
description: The Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame celebrated California dreams and New Orleans spirit when it held its 13th annual induction ceremonies last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: No Need to Panic Over Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: VACANT CUBICLES -- A special report.; Software Jobs Go Begging, Threatening Technology Boom
description: Every so often, the co-founder of Carnelian Inc., James Kittock, hears the phones at his Silicon Valley start-up company begin to ring in order, from one cloth-covered cubicle to the next: 0976, 0977, 0978. . . . He knows -- everyone in the Valley knows -- it is the recruiters, calling to steal his programmers away, often at huge salaries.

title: Health Spending Grew Slowly in '96 but Still Hit $1 Trillion
description: Health spending increased in 1996 at the lowest rate in 36 years, but topped $1 trillion for the first time, the Government reported today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan for three reporters from Times Mirror newspapers to write parts of the company's annual report misstated the given name of a reporter for The Los Angeles Times. He is James Flanigan, not Kevin.

title: Barclays Is Shedding Some Asian Operations
description: Barclays P.L.C. has signed an agreement to sell parts of the Asian equities and mergers and acquisition advisory businesses of BZW Asia to Credit Suisse First Boston. The selling price was not disclosed. Barclays said the agreement covered the sale of BZW's Taiwan equities business, its 70 percent interest in a Singapore equities business, one seat each on the Hong Kong and Shanghai stock exchanges, and the mergers and acquisition businesses.

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL PLANS A PRETAX CHARGE OF $62 MILLION
description: The Eastman Chemical Company said yesterday that it would take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $62 million for the partial settlement of pension benefits for early retirees and other workers who left the company last year. The 1,500 jobs that were eliminated represent about 8.6 percent of the company's 17,500 workers, Eastman said, adding that about 2,100 workers either retired or lost their jobs through attrition in 1997 but that the company had also hired about 600 employees. Eastman, which is based in Kingsport, Tenn., and has annual sales of $4.8 billion, said the job cuts were consistent with its plan to lower costs by $500 million by the year 2000. Eastman shares rose 31.25 cents yesterday, to $58.625.

title: Suharto Vows to Step Up Economic Reform, IMF Says
description: SINGAPORE  President Suharto of Indonesia, under mounting international and domestic pressure to put into effect painful austerity measures or resign, agreed Monday to strengthen and accelerate the country's reform program, the International Monetary Fund said.

title: With Higher Fines, Giuliani Hopes to Hobble Jaywalkers
description: Three weeks after drawing fierce criticism for erecting pedestrian barricades in midtown Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he was taking aim at jaywalking, which, like high rents and scarce parking spaces, has long been a fixture of New York life.

title: The Senate Debate Debate
description: New York Democrats will not be voting on a U.S. Senate candidate until September. When Geraldine Ferraro rejected an opponent's call to begin debating in March, six months before the primary, even political junkies must have felt a bit relieved.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Indonesian Leader Vows Support for I.M.F. Plan

title: The Verdict Is In: Put It on Broadway
description: ''We knew we were taking a risk,'' said KENNETH T. WASSERMAN, the entertainment chairman of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, talking about ''Oh, Kaye!'' which is not to be confused with the Gershwin musical ''Oh, Kay!'' Every two years since 1946, the group has staged a musical comedy, lampooning everyone from well-known lawyers to a former Presidential candidate (John W. Davis, who lost to Calvin Coolidge).

title: Wieden Is Asked For Diet Coke Ideas
description: The Coca-Cola Company is again seeking ideas for its Diet Coke soft drink beyond the brand's agency of record, Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, by naming Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., to handle undisclosed creative television assignments.

title: Bronx Woman Held In Child Endangerment
description: A 20-year-old Bronx woman was arrested yesterday on charges of child endangerment after the police broke into her apartment and found three young boys alone in squalid conditions, the police said.

title: Isles Tie, Ending A 10-Game Losing Skid
description: The Islanders faced a crisis tonight.

title: Police to Test Vehicle In Which Boy Drowned
description: Experts will inspect the brakes, transmission, ignition and other mechanical systems of the 1987 Ford Bronco that rolled into a pond here Sunday morning, trapping a 9-year-old boy inside while his parents and a cousin went fishing, the state police said.

title: Market Failure on Health Insurance; Regulate the Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Art Caper (Contd): The Art of the Deal
description: The great Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum heist, that modern-day yarn of all Boston yarns, that real-life clash between the snobbish Bostonians of Henry James and the thuggish friends of Eddie Coyle, squeezes easily into a nutshell:

title: INDONESIAN LEADER YIELDING TO PLEAS TO MEND ECONOMY
description: Under intense pressure from the markets and leaders of other governments, President Suharto of Indonesia told an American delegation this morning that he would commit his country to vigorous enforcement of economic reforms that it has failed to enact, an apparent acknowledgment that he has little choice in the midst of the Asian financial crisis.

title: So Rude, So Complex, So Like Oneself
description: John Wood, playing A. E. Housman at the age of 77, stands on a bank of the River Styx, surveying the Stygian gloom while waiting for Charon (Michael Bryant) to ferry him to Hades. This is the opening scene of Tom Stoppard's spirited new intellectual dazzler at the Royal National Theater, ''The Invention of Love,'' winner of the Evening Standard Award as best new play in London. It is the seventh Stoppard play Mr. Wood has done, a long-running artistic relationship that might put the author and actor in the Guinness Book of World Records alongside Shakespeare and Burbage, or Akira Kurosawa and Toshiro Mifune.

title: INSIDE
description: New Defiance From Iraq

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Men's Wear Addresses the Globe
description: Like women's fashion, men's wear is in the grip of a wrenching transformation into a global enterprise. It was evident in the incessant questions here, as the fall round of men's wear showings got under way on Sunday, about the impact of Asia's economic crisis and, more directly, in the number of American designers now showing collections here.

title: Bond Prices in Spurt, but Stock Rally Later Trims Gains
description: Low inflation, Asian financial turmoil, a plunge in the stock market and investor flight to the perceived safety of the American bond market sent Treasury prices sharply higher early yesterday. But a later rebound in stocks took away some of the gains in bonds by the end of the day.

title: U.S. Seeking More Realism In Auto Safety Commercials
description: The nation's top highway safety regulator said today that the Federal Government planned to help produce television advertisements that would promote safe driving by showing graphic re-enactments of automobile crashes.

title: Burdened by History, France Balks at Wading Into Algerian Strife
description: Four decades after a colonial war that nearly tore France apart and forced a million French settlers from Algeria, France seems frozen into inaction in the face of the horrifying daily slaughter of Algerians by Algerians a few hundred miles across the Mediterranean.

title: Neighbor Testifies That Brawley Pretended She Was Unconscious
description: A witness who stood over Tawana Brawley as she lay mute in a garbage bag testified today that she had opened her eyes and looked at him, then feigned unconsciousness.

title: Renewed Iraqi Belligerence
description: Just as the Clinton Administration was hoping to push Iraq backstage so Washington could concentrate on the State of the Union, Saddam Hussein has bounded back into view. Once again he is trying to dictate conditions to United Nations weapons inspectors. His latest maneuver is no more acceptable than his last, and the White House should be under no illusion that it can pretend it has solved the problem of Iraq's effort to produce deadly biological and chemical weapons.

title: Bozell Takes On Carlsberg Beer
description: Labatt USA in Norwalk, Conn., said yesterday that it had named Bozell Worldwide in New York to handle advertising for its Carlsberg beer brands. Though billings were not disclosed, Brandweek estimated them at $2 million to $3 million. American distribution rights to the brands recently moved to Labatt USA from the Anheuser-Busch Companies.

title: Ex-Chase Official Joins Equitable
description: The Equitable Companies has named Michael Hegarty, a former vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, president of its life insurance subsidiary.

title: Theater Plan Seeks Audiences New and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Search Expands for Man Missing Since Jan. 1
description: The search for a Brewster man who disappeared after spending New Year's Eve in Times Square has expanded into the suburbs.

title: Fond of Whimsy in Word and Deed
description: Kraig Patterson loves odd turns of phrase. Mr. Patterson, who is also a member of Mark Morris's troupe, calls his own company Bopi's Black Sheep. And on Friday night it offered a program bearing the overall title of ''What a Beauty/Head of Lettuce'' at the Pace Downtown Theater. Whimsical steps complemented the whimsical words. Indeed, the choreography was too often self-consciously clever.

title: Novel Assignment, And It Pays Well
description: DOMINICK DUNNE has chronicled the one and only O.J. Simpson trial. He knows ''The Two Mrs. Grenvilles.'' He has spent ''A Season in Purgatory.'' And now, Mr. Dunne has done something that most reporters would never do, not even in their worst nightmares: write advertising copy.

title: Sam Donaldson Returns To Call on the President
description: There he was pressed up against the ropes, first in line by the White House door, ready to belt out a question in his best baritone after the President's chopper alighted on the grounds.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about increases in premiums for health maintenance organizations in the New York region misstated the amount paid by one patient, Linda Gibbs, to Oxford Health Plans. Her premium is $216 monthly, not $311.

title: Sports of The Times; The Incessant Darkness Of Boxing
description: ALREADY without a small piece of an ear, Evander Holyfield is apparently not going to cut off his nose to spite his wallet. He smells the money, and that is why the foul odor of another fight with Mike Tyson is suddenly in the air.

title: Gretzky Justifies His Latest Honor
description: Before last night's game against Toronto at Madison Square Garden, Wayne Gretzky of the Rangers accepted an honor from The Hockey News, which named him the greatest player in the history of the National Hockey League.

title: 'Made in New York' Is Coming Back Into Fashion
description: In her glass-walled corner office overlooking the garment district, Natalie Walker of Tahiti Apparel designs the many styles of summer: sexy leopard-printed bathing suits, sensible navy-and-white-striped maillots and matching sheer cover-ups. And the suits are made not in Sri Lanka or Hong Kong, like so much other apparel, but across the East River at a factory in Long Island City.

title: Nationsbank Posts Profit Rise of 29%
description: Nationsbank said today that its earnings rose 29 percent in the fourth quarter, meeting estimates, as its acquisitions of Boatmen's Bancshares Inc. and Montgomery Securities Inc. brought increases in loans and fees.

title: Spano Pleads Guilty to Fraud in Isles Case
description: John Spano pleaded guilty here today to fraud charges, ending a 14-month saga that began when he convinced banks and the National Hockey League that he had enough money to buy the Islanders when he had shown only about $1.4 million in assets.

title: Erhardt Retires As a Coach With Jets
description: Ron Erhardt called an end to his 25-year pro coaching career yesterday by stepping down as the Jets' quarterbacks coach.

title: Newborn Found Dead in Sewer
description: A 15-year-old girl who complained to school officials yesterday that she was not feeling well later admitted that she had given birth and led officials to her dead infant, which was found in a sewer near her home, the police said.

title: Conde Nast Buys a Magazine; Will Alter Sports for Women
description: Conde Nast Publications Inc., publisher of Vogue and Architectural Digest, said yesterday that it would acquire Women's Sports + Fitness. The terms were not disclosed, but people involved in the deal put the purchase price at about $5 million.

title: Hooked on Tobacco Sponsorships
description: There are plenty of reasons to be concerned about the proposed tobacco settlement that still awaits action by Congress. It would undercut regulatory controls over nicotine and fail to set sufficiently high penalties if the tobacco industry does not curb smoking by youths. Even the $368 billion to be paid by the industry over 25 years to settle class-action lawsuits is probably too low to force up prices enough to deter demand for tobacco products.

title: A Test for Even the Hardiest Souls; Smaller, Isolated Farmers Reeling After Ice Storm
description: For a small dairy farmer like Tom Ellis, every drop of lost milk is equal to lost money. So when a devastating ice storm knocked out power to a broad swath of upstate New York last week, the Ellis family mobilized.

title: Mullen Chalks Up One Victory, One Loss
description: Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., gained one account yesterday while coincidentally losing another.

title: MEDITRUST IN STOCK DEAL FOR GOLF-COURSE OWNER
description: The Meditrust Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cobblestone Holdings Inc., a privately held owner of golf courses, for $241 million in stock. Meditrust, based in Needham, Mass., is a real estate investment trust that has focused on the health care industry. But earlier this month, it said it would pay $2.1 billion for La Quinta Inns Inc., the hotel chain. Cobblestone, of Del Mar, Calif., owns 29 golf courses in six states. Under the deal, Meditrust would also refinance or assume about $154 million of Cobblestone debt and associated costs. Meditrust's stock fell $1.25 a share yesterday, to $33.50.

title: Man Held in Death Of 6-Month-Old Son
description: A Burlington City man was charged yesterday with murder in the death of his 6-month-old son, Issaih, who died Saturday after being scalded in a tub of hot water, the Burlington county Prosecutor's office said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 4 Quixotes Tilt at German Adoption of the Euro
description: In a quixotic challenge to one of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's most cherished visions, a prominent group of lawyers and former bankers petitioned Germany's highest court today to prevent the country from joining Europe's proposed single currency, the euro.

title: Brain of Chimpanzee Sheds Light on Mystery of Language
description: A SURPRISING new study reveals that chimpanzees have a structure in their brains that is similar to a so-called ''language center'' in human brains, challenging cherished notions of how language evolved in humans and why apes cannot talk.

title: Cuts Sought in Wasteful Fish Kills
description: A coalition of conservationists and sportsmen called today for the Government to require deep reductions in the wasteful killing and discarding of fish and other species caught through indiscriminate commercial fishing practices.

title: The Neediest Cases; La Guardia Bomb Victim Recalls New Yorkers' Help
description: It was two days before New Year's Eve in 1975 and La Guardia Airport was choked with holiday travelers. Traffic was backed up on the Grand Central Parkway, takeoffs and landings were delayed and frustrated New Yorkers were cursing the chaos. Then a powerful blast shredded a bank of lockers in the baggage claim area, sending 75 people to the hospital and 11 others to the morgue.

title: Procter & Gamble to Raise Its Paper Prices
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that it would raise the prices of its Charmin, Bounty and Puffs paper products 4 percent to 7 percent as of next Monday, in part to offset an increase in manufacturing costs.

title: A Frozen Disaster
description: Under the weight of ice that will not go away northern New York and New England are frozen in time, without heat, electricity or running water. For some, like Tom Ellis, a dairy farmer in Antwerp, N.Y., the ice meant a threat of economic ruin.

title: Mexico Accuses Policeman Of Helping Arm Mass Killers
description: Federal prosecutors have accused a state police commander of helping to arm a gang of paramilitary gunmen who killed 45 Indian villagers in December. They are the first criminal charges filed against police and state government officials who have been under investigation for the massacre.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION TO ADD CBT OF KENTUCKY
description: The Mercantile Bancorporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the CBT Corporation for about $285 million in stock, allowing Mercantile to expand its banking business into Kentucky. CBT, based in Paducah, Ky., is the holding company for four banks, a Federal savings bank and a consumer finance company, and has $1 billion in assets. Mercantile Bancorp, of St. Louis, has $30 billion in assets and more than 500 branches in Missouri, Iowa, Kansas, Illinois and Arkansas. Under the agreement, CBT shareholders would receive 0.6513 Mercantile share for each CBT share. Shares of CBT fell $1.125 yesterday, to $32.125. Mercantile Bancorp fell 87.5 cents, to $51.875.

title: Tony Lavelli, 71, Musician With a Memorable Hook Shot
description: Tony Lavelli, an all-America basketball player at Yale University in the 1940's and a forward with the Boston Celtics and the Knicks who was equally adept at hook shots and halftime renditions on the accordion, died last Thursday at his home in Laconia, N.H. He was 71.

title: Market Failure on Health Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This isn't normal. It's like the end of the world.''

title: Foreign Affairs; Reciprocity For Reciprocity
description: Next week Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat will visit Washington in the latest last-ditch effort to revive the peace process. Their visits will present President Clinton with the opportunity to make some very clear choices. Let's hope he's up to it.

title: Gay Rights Case Fails in Bid For Supreme Court Hearing
description: A woman who lost a promised job as a lawyer in the Georgia Attorney General's office, after the state Attorney General learned that she was planning a marriage ceremony with her lesbian partner, failed today to persuade the Supreme Court to hear her appeal.

title: By Design; Unbikerly Leather Shirts
description: Even people who used to consider leather clothing as strictly biker wear have changed their minds since high-fashion designers added their stylish touches. The latest idea is the leather shirt, for men and women, to be worn alone or over a T-shirt.

title: Jerusalem Journal; An Unusual Snow Day Brings On a City's Thaw
description: A rare snowstorm struck Jerusalem today, bestowing on the holy city a divine glow and a heavenly respite from the usual storm of crises and conflicts.

title: The Ties That Bind and the Regrets That Strangle
description: CHARMING BILLY

title: Defender of God, South and Unborn
description: Patrick J. Buchanan gazes approvingly from a framed photograph on Charles M. Condon's office wall.

title: Haskins to Coach U.S. Goodwill Team
description: Clem Haskins of the University of Minnesota was named the head coach of the U.S. team that will compete in the Goodwill Games July 18-24 in New York. He said yesterday at Madison Square Garden that he was looking for good shooters and mobile big men to fill his 12-man roster of college stars, which he and a committee will pick from a tryout May 29-31.

title: AIDS GROUP URGES NEW YORK TO START REPORTING OF H.I.V.
description: The Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's leading AIDS service agency, is reversing its position and calling for New York doctors to report H.I.V.-positive people to the State Health Department. The same practice is used for infectious diseases like syphilis and tuberculosis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 17 about a speech by President Nelson Mandela of South Africa misstated the source of a document he mentioned. When he said that in some respects the United States Agency for International Development was making his Government's task harder, he was quoting from a United States Congress staff report, not one from the aid agency.

title: Sex Discrimination on Death Row
description: There has been a good deal of hand-wringing over the case of Karla Faye Tucker, the Texas woman who is scheduled to be executed next month for bludgeoning two people to death with a pickax. But those pleading for mercy are doing so for the wrong reasons. We no longer inhabit a world in which women can be spared the penalties routinely paid by men who commit equivalent crimes. In the end, such efforts are degrading -- both to female criminals and to the cause of justice for all.

title: Who Owns the Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferraro Was 'On the Left,' Now She's On the Spot
description: It has been more than a decade since Geraldine A. Ferraro held elected office, but her three years on ''Crossfire,'' the CNN shout show, have brought her sufficient recognition to reduce her interest in debating with her less visible rivals for the Democratic nomination for United States senator from New York.

title: Fund Buyers Undaunted by Asian Turmoil
description: The continuing slump in Asian markets appears to have had little effect last year on the appetite of investors for American mutual funds, as purchases of equity funds hit a record for the second straight year.

title: Democratic Legislator to Challenge Party Nominee for Flake's Seat
description: Three days after he lost a contest for the Democratic Party's nomination to succeed former Representative Floyd H. Flake, State Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr. said yesterday that he would continue his campaign for the seat in Queens by running on the ballot lines of the Independence and Conservative Parties.

title: Weary of Political Sniping, the Census Bureau Chief Resigns
description: The Director of the Census Bureau resigned today, saying she was weary of the debilitating legal and political fights that have enmeshed her agency as it prepares for the 2000 Census, and acknowledging that she was tired of ''putting out fires.''

title: Gladly Exiled to a World Apart From Politics
description: EVEN in the black-and-white days of 1965, bouncing around the Bronx in his family's beat-up Chevy 210, hustling to become the state's youngest Assemblyman, Robert Abrams was remembered for a certain buoyancy. The young man with the thin tie and the thinning hair may have lacked the features of a Lindsay or the lyricism of a Cuomo, but he left little doubt about his cheery sense of purpose.

title: First Eisie Photo Awards
description: The Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University yesterday announced the winners of a new prize: the Alfred Eisenstaedt Awards for Magazine Photography.

title: Hunt in Sealed Lab Seeks Deadly Secrets of 'Bird Flu'
description: As Thomas Rowe tested samples of the deadly ''bird flu'' strain of influenza virus in a high-security Federal laboratory here this week, a plastic shield protected his face, the air he breathed was filtered as it came through a hose from a battery-powered respirator, a blue gown shielded his body and booties covered his shoes.

title: Bank in an Insurance Deal
description: F&M Bancorp said today that it would acquire Keller-Stonebraker Insurance Inc., an independent insurance agency based in Hagerstown, Md., for an undisclosed amount. Banks throughout the United States want to sell insurance as a way to diversify lending income with more service and sales fees. F&M, based in Frederick, Md., operates 24 Farmers and Mechanics National Bank branches and eight Home Federal Savings Bank branches. It has $1.05 billion in total assets.

title: Wallace J. Campbell, 87, a Founder of CARE
description: Wallace Justin Campbell, a founding director of CARE, the international relief and development organization, who originated the concept of the CARE package, died last Wednesday at the Solheim Lutheran Home in Los Angeles, where he had moved in November from Chevy Chase, Md. He was 87.

title: Thyssen Workers Seek Influence Over Merger
description: Workers at Thyssen A.G. said yesterday that they would try to block the German company's merger with Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp if they did not receive promises that jobs would not be cut and that they would get an equal voice in management. Worker protests helped scuttle an attempted hostile takeover of Thyssen by Krupp last year. Instead the companies merged their steel units and began working toward a full merger.

title: Separate Trials in Attack On a Black Man on L.I.
description: A judge has ordered separate trials for two men charged in what the police have described as a racially motivated beating of a young black man, Shane Daniels, outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub nearly two years ago, officials said.

title: Bricks Had Been Ordered Removed at School
description: Three months before a 16-year-old girl was gravely injured by a brick that fell from a construction site atop a Brooklyn elementary school, school construction officials -- under pressure from parents -- ordered a contractor to stop using bricks to hold down tarpaulins on the edge of the school's roof, school officials said yesterday.

title: FOREST OIL BUYING OIL AND GAS PROPERTIES FROM ANSCHUTZ
description: The Forest Oil Corporation agreed yesterday to buy United States and international oil and gas properties from the Anschutz Corporation for about $80 million in stock as part of an effort to start an international exploration program. Forest Oil said the transaction would involve 6.17 million shares and would leave the closely held Anschutz with a 40 percent stake in Forest. Both companies are based in Denver. The properties being sold include the Anschutz Ranch in Colorado and fields in Utah and Wyoming. Anschutz's chairman, Philip F. Anschutz, is a director of Forest Oil.

title: Metro Business; Telephone Company Sold
description: USN Communications of Chicago has agreed to buy Connecticut Telephone, a cellular telecommunications service reseller in Wallingford, Conn., for about $68 million.

title: His Critics Continue To Deconstruct Childs
description: Chris Childs says he does not read the newspapers, but he cannot help but hear the boos. Less than two years into his Knick career, he has become a scapegoat when things go bad on the floor for his team.

title: Freeze Grips Canada, Already Iced and Powerless
description: First it was ice, then a paralyzing darkness when power lines fell and the lights blinked out. Now weary residents of Eastern Canada, already reeling from the most damaging winter storm in memory, are shivering under a dangerous cold spell.

title: Ellis Rabb, Actor and Director, Is Dead at 67
description: Ellis Rabb, one of the most versatile actors and directors in the American theater who, as the founder and artistic director of the A.P.A. theater company, brought diverse seasons of repertory theater to Broadway in the 1960's, died on Sunday at a hospital in Memphis. He was 67 and lived in Memphis.
