title: W. Harcourt Woods, 85, Davis Cup Official
description: W. Harcourt Woods, an articulate and tireless advocate of tennis's international Davis Cup team competition, who for four decades served the United States Tennis Association in a range of administrative posts, died on Jan. 3 at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 85.

title: Microsoft Pushes to Oust Judge's Adviser
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday intensified its bid to eject a court adviser who was given broad powers by a Federal judge in the software giant's antitrust battle with the United States Justice Department.

title: Knicks Filling Big Shoes With Better Team Effort
description: The same Knicks who once used Patrick Ewing as a cover for their embarrassing moments have been left to wipe the egg off their own faces in his absence.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER STUMBLES. The March silver contract dropped 16.3 cents yesterday, to $5.475 an ounce. In the last three sessions, the price has fallen 9 percent amid rumors of a price manipulation over the last six months. From July 16 to Dec. 24, the price of silver jumped almost 52 percent.

title: Sex Bias Is Reported by U.S. At Border Plants in Mexico
description: Concluding a six-month review of charges of sex discrimination in Mexico, the United States Labor Department reported today that thousands of border assembly plants administer medical tests to weed out pregnant applicants and harass pregnant workers to coerce their resignation.

title: Stocks Rally After Recovering From Overnight Selloff in Asia
description: Stocks staged a muted rally yesterday, recovering from early losses that were set off by sharp overnight selloffs in Asia.

title: After an Ugly Incident, Denver Defused Crisis
description: We all know what happened to the Denver Broncos last season. They won 11 of their first 12 games and finished with a 13-3 record. Then at home in their first playoff game, they were quickly trashed by the Jacksonville Jaguars.

title: An Herb, Yes; a Remedy, No
description: HORMONE replacement therapy is the standard treatment for hot flashes and other symptoms of menopause, but many women turn to herbal remedies in an attempt to get the benefits of estrogen without the side effects, which includes a heightened risk of breast cancer. A new study has found, however, that one herb taken to treat menopausal symptoms, dong quai, is no more effective than a placebo.

title: Peek at Black Holes' Feast Reveals Awful Table Manners
description: ASTRONOMERS observing black holes, those gourmands with a boarding-house reach at the cosmic table, are finding astonishing new evidence of their gustatory excesses, as well as hints of perplexing failures.

title: White House Bailouts for Asia Draw Fire
description: With the financial turmoil in Asia showing few signs of abating, liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans are stepping up criticism of the bailouts engineered by the Clinton Administration, putting the White House under additional pressure as it prepares to ask Congress for more money.

title: First on Fox: Kerrigan and Harding
description: Four years after the Nancy Kerrigan-Tonya Harding melodrama spurred huge ratings, CBS has the Michelle Kwan-Tara Lipinski rivalry to sustain viewer interest in figure skating next month at the Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan. Women's figure skating remains so hot, it seems ratings would soar if Mimi, the secretary-from-heck in ''The Drew Carey Show,'' squared off against Ru Paul.

title: Q&A
description: The Physics of Noodles

title: Dow Rebounds After a Shock : Major Bankruptcy In Hong Kong Hits Asian Markets Hard
description: TAIPEI  Stock markets and currencies around Asia took a dramatic dive to new lows on Monday  pushing down shares across Europe and shaking Wall Street  as one of Asia's largest investment banks, Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., went into liquidation.

title: 3 Morgan Stanley Directors Leave Firm
description: Three managing directors left Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company last week to start their own arbitrage firm.

title: Theater Plan Seeks Audiences New and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Rattling Down Life's Bumpy Road
description: For a memorable rock voice, beauty doesn't count. This column is devoted to albums by songwriters whose voices crack and squeak and bawl and quiver. They're not soothing; they're unvarnished and willful, and in their flaws they reveal their humanity.

title: Can Life Span Be Extended? Biologists Offer Some Hope
description: THOUGH it is often said that only two things in life are certain, maybe only one is truly unalterable: taxes. Biologists who study aging are beginning to talk of death as if it was not entirely immutable.

title: Slaney Enters Mile
description: Mary Decker Slaney vaguely remembers her first victory in the Millrose Games, America's premier indoor track meet.

title: Beware Rotten Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Soar Like a Falcon . . .; . . . Sink Like an Overextended Investment Bank
description: With the collapse of Peregrine Investments Holdings today, Asia's biggest underwriter of stocks has disappeared off the map of Asian investment banking just one decade after it was created by a swashbuckling former British racing driver and his Hong Kong partner.

title: Favre, Irritated and a Bit Insecure, Takes Aim at Critics
description: Brett Favre went searching for his buddy after he dismantled the San Francisco 49ers in the National Football Conference title game on Sunday. That person was 49ers Coach Steve Mariucci.

title: Motorola Has Profits Below Expectations
description: Hit by the economic turmoil in Asia, Motorola Inc. reported yesterday that its profits for the fourth quarter were slightly below the expectations of Wall Street analysts.

title: French Canadian Is a U.N. Chief's First Right-Hand Woman
description: A French Canadian with a flair for finance and a great enthusiasm for New York life was appointed as the first Deputy Secretary General in United Nations history today.

title: No Benefit Found for Fetal Monitors
description: A LARGE study has found that the use of home fetal monitors fails at its intended purpose: to prevent women at high risk of premature labor from giving birth too early.

title: A 'Road Map' for the Future of Ulster Wins Agreement
description: For the first time since formal peace talks began here 19 months ago, the Irish and British Governments today agreed on proposals that they hope will result in a lasting settlement of the sectarian strife that has killed 3,233 people in Northern Ireland since 1969.

title: New York's Title to Ellis Island
description: Few of the cases on this year's Supreme Court docket have evoked as much civic passion as the longstanding dispute between New York and New Jersey over control of Ellis Island that was argued before the Court yesterday. A special master assigned to the case last April awarded the main historic buildings to New York, and the rest -- essentially all the landfilled portion of the island -- to New Jersey. Although the Court rarely second-guesses a master on a question of fact, we urge it in this instance to reverse his decision.

title: Girls' Stressful Tales Draw Newbery and Caldecott Awards
description: Two books about adolescent girls were honored in New Orleans yesterday when Karen Hesse, the author of the free-verse novel ''Out of the Dust'' (Scholastic Press), was awarded the American Library Association's 1998 Newbery Medal for the most distinguished contribution to literature for children, and Paul O. Zelinsky won the Caldecott Medal for the illustrations in his version of ''Rapunzel'' (Dutton).

title: Accounts
description: * Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc., San Diego, to Regan Campbell Ward, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as the first agency to handle advertising for prescription pharmaceutical products for treatment of allergies, asthma and related respiratory conditions. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: Daring and Resolution Help U.S. Finish a Close Second
description: The reason for the fine second-place finish of the United States Team in the World Team Championship was the spirit and determination of the players. On the rating scale of the International Chess Federation, the average of the Americans was 2588, as compared with the Russians' 2652, a difference of 64 units. Nevertheless, the Russians came out just a half-point ahead.

title: Maine Ice Shatters Trees and Reserve
description: It is a lingering, sparkling disaster afflicting Northern New England these days, a Robert Frost nightmare of birches cracked in two by their own glazed weight, of proud Down Easters forced from their heatless homes, of nearly half a million people without power for days, waiting ever more crankily for it to come back on.

title: It's Time to Abandon Bilingual Education
description: The national battle over bilingual education is finally being put to a popular test. If Californians pass an initiative on the June ballot called English for the Children, the state's longstanding bilingual programs will become illegal.

title: A Longtime Adviser Is Selected for WTA Tour's Top Post
description: Left in the lurch last week when Ric Clarson, a PGA Tour executive, reneged on his acceptance of a four-year term as chief executive of the Corel WTA Tour, the board that governs women's professional tennis reacted swiftly. Yesterday it installed Bart McGuire, the WTA Tour's longtime legal and business adviser, to the $250,000-a-year post. At his own request, McGuire, a law professor at Northwestern School of Law of Lewis and Clark College in Portland, Ore., signed a two-year pact. He will begin his duties immediately with a trip to the Australian Open.

title: Dafoe Is Brodeur's Equal For One Night in Boston
description: They play a system in which defense comes first, and they rely on their goalie to bail them out when all else fails. It's the Devils. It's the Bruins. They're almost interchangeable. Who is who? Like Nicolas Cage and John Travolta in the movie ''Face/Off,'' it's hard to tell.

title: Help for the Depressed
description: To the Editor:

title: Under Orders, Mental Tests Of Kaczynski Are Beginning
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski appears to be cooperating with the court-appointed psychiatrist who arrived here today to evaluate his competency to stand trial on charges of being the Unabomber, a spokesman for the Sacramento County Sheriff said.

title: Detroit's Big 3 Say Asia Is Forcing Cost Cuts
description: The Big Three American auto makers might be expected to pop champagne. After all, the stock market has soared, the economic expansion continues, and interest rates have fallen to record lows, all of which would normally lure buyers to showrooms.

title: Babbitt Casino Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Registry Changes Its Name
description: Registry Inc. changed its name today to Renaissance Worldwide Inc. to signify ''rebirth of a combined organization,'' its chairman, G. Drew Conway, said. The concern, a computer-consulting company, purchased Hunter Group on Dec. 1 for about $176 million and in July acquired Renaissance Solutions in a stock swap valued at about $372 million.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about the reopening of a part of lower Fifth Avenue that was closed by a water main break on Jan. 2 misstated the scope of the repairs. Two of the four lanes opened yesterday to all traffic; the sidewalks are open on both sides of the avenue, not just the west side. City officials say they do not know when all four lanes will be reopen, but it will not be by tomorrow.

title: No Need to Panic Over Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about the proliferation of cellular telephone antennas misstated the location of a New Jersey antenna disguised to look like a tree. It was in Ringwood, not Franklin Lakes.

title: Theater Plan Seeks Audiences New and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Gentle Sounds Inside a Cataclysm
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is devoting its programming this month to ''Musical Evolutions,'' a series of concerts and lectures that explore the changes in musical style that occurred between 1887 and 1920. Some of those changes were cataclysmic, of course: Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' and the birth of Schoenberg's 12-tone system, for starters, helped set the course that modern composition has taken since then.

title: Warning Issued on Air Traffic Computers
description: A set of crucial computers in the nation's air traffic control system should not be used beyond December 1999, because they may not operate reliably when the date rolls over to Jan. 1, 2000, and there is no way to predict the effect on air traffic, according to I.B.M., which built the computers.

title: In Kitsch, a Solution
description: THE mathematical models that predict things like climate changes and stock prices have a nearly insatiable appetite for random numbers, but getting numbers that are truly random is not easy. A computer company in California says that to move forward, it is necessary to step back -- to the lava lamp, an icon of the 70's.

title: Tokyo Tries To Calm Fears On Bad Loans
description: The Japanese Government disclosed what it hoped would be reassuring news Monday about the nation's banks: they carry only 76.7 trillion yen in bad or questionable loans, or about $580 billion.

title: Study Favors Monounsaturated Fat
description: MEDICAL research in recent years has offered women some cruel choices. They are told, for instance, that taking estrogen after menopause or having one drink of alcohol a day will reduce the risk of heart disease but increase the risk of breast cancer.

title: 13 Midwood High Students Take Westinghouse Honors
description: For the first time in the 57-year history of the Westinghouse science awards -- a prestigious ticket to college and even to Nobel Prizes for generations of students -- a more or less ordinary Brooklyn magnet school has not only outranked schools in the rest of the country, but also triumphed over New York City's two most elite public schools.

title: Entertainment With a Bit of a Challenge
description: For the most part, the New York City Ballet set out to entertain on Sunday afternoon, and it did so very well. But the program at the New York State Theater also included ''La Stravaganza,'' a ballet that challenges audiences to think as well as look.

title: Beware Rotten Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: Tamer Than the Originals?
description: If it's Christmastime (more or less) in New York, the Ensemble for Early Music must be doing a medieval play somewhere. This time, on Saturday afternoon at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin on West 46th Street, it was ''Herod and the Innocents,'' appropriate for the feast of Epiphany, earlier last week.

title: Saxophones, for Heat and Color
description: Roger Sessions' First Symphony -- brash, uncharacteristic and now more than 70 years old -- is not a piece that needs the attention of the American Composers Orchestra: it was done by the Philharmonic only last season. By starting with it at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, the orchestra got off on the wrong foot, and Dennis Russell Davies and his musicians never quite found the right one. The Sessions performance was unexceptional, and only briefly was the concert's temperature raised, by a burst of energy from Augusta Read Thomas in her new ''Brass Axis.''

title: Rare Brand of Dedication Has Miami on the Rise
description: Leonard Hamilton has preached commitment to his University of Miami basketball players so often and so passionately that two of them have surprised even him.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Douglas Gives Nets Options At Point
description: The Nets, as has been well documented during the course of a history that has often resembled a soap opera, are no strangers to controversy. But the latest budding issue just might be healthy for the team.

title: If You Sell My Book, I'll Sell Yours
description: Among the many conventional devices established during the literary Middle Ages to help authors charm their readers, the excusatio propter infirmitatem, the authors' apology for the weakness of their talents, has, in our time, lost some of its appeal.

title: Helmet Law Extended For Children Under 14
description: Children under 14 would be required to wear helmets while skateboarding and Rollerblading under a bill approved by the State Senate yesterday.

title: Speed Limit to Hit 65 on Major New Jersey Highways
description: The speed limit will rise to 65 miles an hour this spring on lengthy sections of the New Jersey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and a half-dozen other major roadways across the state under an agreement reached tonight between Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and state lawmakers.

title: Rock Musician's Other Role: Tree Farmer
description: On a recent workday on his 1,900-acre tree farm in middle Georgia, Chuck Leavell walked the sandy trails through stands of loblolly and longleaf pine, admiring the exquisite balance of the forest he has designed.

title: Fire Engulfs Church; No One Is Injured
description: Fire raced through a church in this Suffolk County town last night, destroying much of the decades-old building, officials said.

title: When Merchandise Imitates Ad Copy
description: The power of advertising, part 2: Bulgari had to create a real necklace because of a fictional one in an ad.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street's Stumbling Bull Is Relying Heavily on 2 Legs
description: The American stock market has come under severe pressure early in 1998 and has slumped. But it appears that things would be much worse were it not for two disparate groups of buyers: foreigners and individual Americans.

title: Chrysler takes wing on effort to revive identity of its Chrysler division as the home of the upscale.
description: THE Chrysler Corporation is trying to revive its Chrysler division with a new campaign, three new cars and even a new symbol.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Klaus Tennstedt, a Conductor Of Romantic Works, Dies at 71
description: Klaus Tennstedt, a German conductor who was renowned as a Mahler interpreter, died on Sunday at his home in Kiel, Germany. He was 71.

title: Jones Intercable Unit Deal
description: Jones Intercable Inc. said today that one of its affiliates had sold cable television operations serving 17,500 customers in Lake County, Calif., to Mediacom L.L.C. for $21.4 million. Jones Intercable, based in Englewood, owns or manages cable operations serving 1.4 million customers in 17 states. The sale involves its Jones Cable Income Fund l-B/C Venture affiliate. Mediacom, based in Middletown, N.Y., is a unit of Grey Advertising of New York.

title: Two-Party Coalition Seizes Control of the Suffolk Legislature
description: In Suffolk County, with a population of 1.4 million, Republicans hold a commanding 2-to-1 edge in voter registration. The county delivered more than half of Gov. George E. Pataki's winning statewide margin in 1994, and Republicans won 11 of 18 seats in the County Legislature last November. But despite that, Suffolk's Republican Party leaders have now lost control of the Legislature.

title: Great, but Not Super
description: They are among the greatest quarterbacks to play the game, joined not only by their talent but in a sort of collegial picture: the Class of '83. And, oh, yes, there is something else that binds the group that includes John Elway, Dan Marino and Jim Kelly.

title: MACK-CALI REALTY ADDS SEVERAL NEW PROPERTIES
description: The Mack-Cali Realty Corporation said yesterday that it had spent $147 million in six transactions to buy or develop properties in the Northeast and Southwest. With the transactions, which total 1.6 million square feet of office space, Mack-Cali's property portfolio will climb by 7 percent, to 23.2 million square feet. The number of properties will jump to 213 from 187. In the Northeast, the company, which is based in Cranford, N.J., spent $113 million on five transactions for 1.4 million square feet of office, or ''flex,'' space in New Jersey and Connecticut. Mack-Cali also bought Concord Plaza, a 248,700-square-foot office property in suburban San Antonio, for $34 million.

title: Atlantic City's Casinos Show Modest '97 Gains
description: Winnings rose 2.4 percent in 1997 for Atlantic City's 12 casinos, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission reported yesterday. The total of $3.9 billion relieved of gamblers last year, including $2.7 billion at slot machines and $1.2 billion at blackjack, roulette and other tables, provided $310.4 million in tax money for elderly citizens and people with disabilities, said Daniel Henegan, a commission spokesman.

title: The Chef
description: FOR a chef New York is the land of the free. It's not that you can do anything at all, but this city is so ready to embrace innovation that the problem is how to show a certain restraint in the face of liberation, to stay within what you know. My objective as the chef (French- and Swiss-trained) at a Swedish restaurant is to take the ingredients and proclivities of Sweden and marry them to the international ferment of New York.

title: 6 Companies Seek Licenses for Offshore Gambling
description: After months of speculation over whether New York City would become saturated with offshore gambling cruises, six companies paid $100,000 fees and formally applied for licenses to operate the cruises from city piers, Giuliani administration officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MECHANIC, SONNY (SAM)
description: MECHANIC-Sonny (Sam). Darling, today would have been our 62 anniversary. Living without you is getting worse everyday. I love you dearly. Carolyn

title: Intel Earnings Push Stocks Up Sharply
description: Stocks rose sharply yesterday in anticipation of strong fourth-quarter earnings from the Intel Corporation. Investors were hopeful that Intel's results would be a sign that Asian economic turmoil was not battering the nation's high-technology companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPELMAN, MANUEL
description: KOPELMAN-Manuel. A Renaissance man. We shall miss you. Love to your devoted Suzanne. Derek and Caron Enlander

title: Daughter's Injury Brings End To Family's Faith in Future
description: Since 1987, the beige row house at 1249 41st Street in Borough Park, Brooklyn, has been home to four generations of the Zhao family, from the great-grandmother who grew up in the tiny village of Taishan in southern China, now 97, to Yan Zhen Zhao, 16, the studious aspiring doctor who was the family's youngest, brightest light.

title: Cuomo and Abrams Are Spared Brawley Trial
description: A judge ruled yesterday that former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and former State Attorney General Robert Abrams would not have to testify at the Tawana Brawley defamation trial, a possibility that had been raised in early December.

title: Journal; Party Of Lincoln
description: Bring back Ralph Reed!

title: Preacher Takes Thunder to a 'Tiny Chapel'
description: THE Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. made the Episcopalians weep this past weekend in Greenwich, Conn., a place and a culture not known for religious emotionalism. But there he was, the liberal old Anglican warrior, still looking like the chief of staff to God in his miter and cope, once again holding forth from a pulpit about mystery and reason. He recalled the words of Jesus on the cross -- ''My God, my God, why hast Thou forsaken me?'' -- then spoke of a man, stinking of vomit and wine, he encountered at his first parish, in Jersey City. ''Why, father, why?'' the man asked.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about AT&T's agreement to acquire the Teleport Communications Group omitted a law firm among Teleport's advisers. It was Dow, Lohnes & Albertson of Washington.

title: Bowness Still on Alert After Tie
description: The Islanders ended a 10-game losing streak Monday night against the defending champion Detroit Red Wings, but the 1-1 tie may not have been enough to save Coach Rick Bowness's job.

title: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope; Uniqueness Is Assured
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Bars Arms Inspectors Again, Saying American in Charge Is Spy
description: Iraq carried out its threat today to block an arms inspection by an American-dominated team, instantly provoking calls for action in Washington and foreign capitals, and forcing the Security Council to look again for an effective way to condemn Baghdad without threatening force.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLARK, PAUL B. JR.
description: CLARK-Paul B. Jr. Memorial service for Paul B. Clark, Jr. will be held at 11am on Saturday, January 24 at Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Ave, NYC.

title: Duva Inducted Into Hall of Fame
description: Lou Duva, the 75-year-old trainer, has been elected to the International Boxing Hall of Fame in Canastota, N.Y. The induction ceremony will be June 14.

title: A Chemical Mystery That Excites the Taste Buds
description: IF tomatoes and peas are among your favorite vegetables, you love mushrooms and you keep a container of grated Parmesan on hand, chances are you are a big fan of umami.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORDELON, BRUCE V.
description: BORDELON-Bruce V. January 12, 1998. Husband of Kathleen, father of Olympia and Alexander. Memorial service Friday, January 16, at 6:00 PM, Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue (enter on 54th Street). Friends suggest contributions to a fund established for the benefit of the children.

title: $25 and Under; Plenty of Down-Home Food in a Laid-Back Style
description: NORMA JEAN DARDEN's resume is already impressive: author, playwright, actress, caterer and fashion model. Now, it's time to add another entry: restaurateur.

title: ISRAEL ANNOUNCES STRINGENT TERMS FOR WITHDRAWAL
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today that Israel would make no further withdrawal from the West Bank unless the Palestinians satisfied a series of stringent conditions.

title: Richter Ready to Play, But So Is a Hot Rookie
description: The veteran goaltender was pleading his case behind closed doors. The rookie was maintaining a ''just glad to be here'' exterior at his locker. And the head coach was faced with one more tough decision before a needed break.

title: A One-Man Show Backs Up His Words
description: Steve Smith pulled a Reggie last night. An extra dunk or two, a few more jump shots in Allan Houston's face, and perhaps you could call it a Michael. But it was definitely a Reggie.

title: Victory on the Field Doesn't Help Students; Horizon of Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Possible Trial Witness Dies
description: A woman who was considered a potential witness in the upcoming trial of the nightclub owner Peter Gatien was found dead Monday in a Queens apartment, the apparent victim of a drug overdose, the police said. No foul play was suspected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, TERENCE M.
description: NOLAN-Terence M. Of New York City and Southampton, Tuesday, January 13, 1998. Services on Thursday, January 15, 5 PM, at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Lafayette College Maroon Club-in memory of Terry Nolan-307 Markle Hall, Easton, PA 18042.

title: Doctor Is Honored
description: Dr. Savio L-Y Woo of the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center was awarded the International Olympic Committee's top prize for sports medicine last night.

title: A Revamped Student Test Reduces the Gap Between Sexes
description: Despite revisions of the Preliminary S.A.T. intended to improve girls' scores, the gap between the sexes narrowed but did not close among 1.2 million high school students in October, the first time the revamped test has been given.

title: Where the Deer and the Antelope Braise
description: THERE it is, on the plate. It's a profoundly meaty piece of meat, a he-man hunk of beast flesh. Seared on the outside, a shimmering brick red on the inside, it has the power to stun a vegetarian at 50 yards. It is buffalo, served at the Four Seasons just as the Sioux and the Cheyenne would have loved it -- with parsnip puree and truffle sauce.

title: COLE NATIONAL TO CLOSE ALL 430 GIFT BOUTIQUES
description: The Cole National Corporation said yesterday that it would close its 430 department-store gift boutiques, operated mainly in Sears, Roebuck & Company stores, and dismiss 2,000 people to concentrate on its eyewear centers and Things Remembered gift chain. The company, which also sells eyeglasses and contact lenses under the Sears Optical and Pearle Vision name, said it would take a 1997 charge of $12 million to $14 million. Cole, based in Mayfield Heights, Ohio, also said that holiday-season sales from its gift businesses were disappointing and that it expects 1997 profit from continuing operations of about $1.74 to $1.76 a share. The company was expected to earn $1.95, the average estimate of five analysts polled by I.B.E.S. International Inc.

title: N.F.L. Is Must-Have TV; NBC Is a Have-Not
description: The conclusion of the N.F.L. television rights negotiations today for a staggering total of $17.6 billion left three networks gasping with relief at having secured the most reliable programming on television for the next eight years, and one network grasping for some other solution to a sudden switch in fortunes.

title: Inflation Climbed Only 1.7% in 1997, Its Smallest Increase in 11 Years
description: Inflation, once the bane of the economy but these days only a minor irritant, barely budged last month, and for all of 1997 showed its smallest increase in 11 years, the Government reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REUBEN, RICHARD N.
description: REUBEN-Richard N. M.D. Two years have passed and you are sadly missed by all of us who love and care for you so deeply! R, E and M, N & P, M and S A, J, A, K, C, C, J and D

title: Some Minority Admissions Drop in California
description: The number of minority students who enrolled at the law and business schools of the University of California fell dramatically this past fall as a result of new rules barring the consideration of race in admissions, according to systemwide data just made public by the university.

title: Better Rules for Bailouts
description: Top officials of the International Monetary Fund rushed off to Indonesia this week to stanch an economic hemorrhage that the fund now concedes it worsened itself. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers, representing a worried Clinton Administration, followed close behind. Americans are understandably wondering whether the fund can be trusted to put together these kinds of bailouts and whether taxpayer dollars ought to be turned over to the fund so that it can indirectly repay Western banks that made foolish loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETRA, WILLIAM DAVID
description: ETRA-William David. Blanche and Bernie, our sympathy to you and your family upon the loss of ''Pop''. Elise and Ed

title: Lawyers Clash Over Court Order In Clinton Sex Harassment Case
description: Only days from President Clinton's deposition, the lawyers in Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit against Mr. Clinton clashed today over the judge's order barring participants from discussing the case.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.M.F. Acknowledges Misjudgment in Indonesia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEGLINO, NICHOLAS
description: MEGLINO-Nicholas. Founder and past president of ''Jodee Plastic Inc.,'' beloved husband of Josephine (nee Buglione), loving father of Patricia, James and Don. Adored grandfather of Michael and Nicola, dearest brother of Jerry, John and Mary. Reposing at '' Dalton Funeral Home, 412 Willis Avenue, Williston Park, L.I. until Thursday, 9 AM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Aidan R.C. Church at 11 A.M. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10 P.M.

title: Viacom Seems Set to Sell Most Of Publisher
description: Viacom Inc.'s chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, is expected to tell investors and analysts at an industry conference in California today that his company will put most of Simon & Schuster, its $2 billion publishing operation, up for sale, people involved in the sale said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about criticism of construction work at a Brooklyn school where a teen-ager was injured by falling bricks reversed the identities of three students in some editions. Deborah Nitzberg was pictured on the far left, at a vigil; Dena Mizrahi was at her immediate right; Deborah's sister Sara was on the far right.

title: Cable TV Lacks Competition, F.C.C. Notes
description: The Federal Communications Commission confirmed in a report yesterday what most cable television subscribers already knew: that the information revolution has failed to create serious competition to standard cable television and that the public is paying higher cable rates as a result.

title: Metro Business; Help for New Companies
description: The State University of New York at Stony Brook announced yesterday that it would team up with one of the nation's largest software companies to create an on-campus support program for fledgling businesses seeking a foothold in Long Island's high-tech marketplace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANGER, MARTIN A.
description: SCHLANGER-Martin A. The family of Martin A. Schlanger records with great sadness his sudden passing on Monday, January 12, 1998 at Longboat Key, Florida. The chairman of Martin Auto Group, Inc., he was a member of the National Automobile Dealer's Association. He moved to Florida in 1986 from Manhattan and New Rochelle. He was an avid tennis player and lived with such joie de vivre that he was often mistaken for his grandson's father. He attended Temple Sinai in Sarasota and was a former member of Congregation Anshe Shalom in New Rochelle. A devoted husband, brother, father and grandfather, he is survived by his beloved wife of 40 years, Janet (nee Kassoff), his revered brother, Harold (Francine), his dear children Ellen (Dr. Kenneth) Bregg, and Mark E. (Randi) Schlanger, and his cherished grandsons Lee Schlanger and Matthew Bregg. Funeral services are Thursday, January 15, 1998 at 12 noon at Temple Sinai in Sarasota, Florida. Interment will follow at Temple Beth Sholom Cemetery. Memorials to the Martin A. Schlanger Memorial Fund, c/o Temple Sinai, 1802 Kenilworth St., Sarasota, Florida 34231 or CoScep (Coalition to Stop Children's Exposure to Pesticides), PO Box 15853, Sarasota, Florida 34277-1853. For information Tishman Funeral Home, Sarasota, Florida.

title: Victory on the Field Doesn't Help Students; Rutgers Still Misses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, JACK CHARLES
description: HELLER-Jack Charles. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Jack Charles Heller, beloved husband of Janis Heller. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LIBERTY PROPERTY TRUST, Malvern, Pa., a real investment trust, said it had bought, in separate transactions, 22 office and warehouse properties in Florida, Pennsylvania and the Detroit area for $106 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBERSTEIN, SYLVIE B.
description: DUBERSTEIN-Sylvie B., 85. Formerly of Brooklyn, died January 12, 1998 in Kingston, NY. Wife of Louis Emanuel Duberstein, mother of Mrs. Lucy Goldfarb and her husband Dr. Ned M. Goldfarb and the late Seth Franklin Duberstein. Funeral services and burial will be in Kingston, NY on Wednesday. Memorial contributions may be made to AIDS Related Community Services, 2269 Saw Mill River Road, Elmsford, New York 10523.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUCKER, MANUEL
description: BRUCKER-Manuel. The Management and Staff of TotalTel USA Communications, Inc., with great sorrow, mourn the passing of our Founder and former Chairman. He planted the seed from which the company has grown to a successful and respected participant in the exciting world-wide telecommunications industry. He was a true friend, mentor and inspiration to all of us who have had the pleasure of working with him. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entre family, most especially his wife, Carol, who endured the suffering of his last years. May his memory be a blessing. TotalTel USA Communications Inc Warren Feldman, Chairman Sol Feldman

title: Bowles Tells Cheering Staff He Will Stay on Job
description: The White House has eliminated much of the suspense over President Clinton's budget and policy priorities for 1998 with a series of announcements in recent days outlining his agenda, from spending billions of dollars more on child care to expanding Medicare to younger beneficiaries.

title: KOCH INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE PURINA MILLS
description: Koch Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Purina Mills Inc., the largest United States maker of animal feed, for an undisclosed sum. Koch, based in Wichita, Kan., is the second-largest privately held company in the United States, with annual revenue of more than $30 billion from oil, financial services and agriculture. Purina Mills, of St. Louis, which had 1996 sales of more than $1.2 billion, produces about five million tons of animal feed a year, or about 10 percent of the United States total. The company has 59 plants in the Midwest, Great Plains and Southwest.

title: Peregrine Considers Deal With Chinese
description: Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., which collapsed this week after its credit lines were cut, said today that it might sell parts of its profitable equity business to a Chinese company.

title: A Jew Stalin Killed Now Symbolizes Rebirth
description: In the early hours of Jan. 13, 1948, the great Yiddish actor and theater director Solomon Mikhoels was slain by Stalin's secret police, spelling the death of the Jewish theater in the Soviet Union.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about competition for the post of director of the World Health Organization misstated the nationality of a candidate, Fernando Antezana, who has since withdrawn. He is from Bolivia, not Brazil.

title: Sound Bites: 3 Quartets And a Soloist
description: The Association of Performing Arts Presenters invited a soloist and three quartets to perform at the Taipei Theater on Monday. Like all such showcases, it was not an entirely satisfactory occasion: performers and audiences need whole programs in which to get to know each other, and spots of 30 or 40 minutes leave only fragmentary impressions, especially when the musicians -- eager, reasonably enough, to show off their range -- choose single movements from longer works. The Ethos Percussion Group I would gladly hear again. It played from memory, which gave it visual and dramatic as well as musical advantages. It also played with expert togetherness, sensitivity and zest. Cage's ''Third Construction'' was beautifully done, with electric rhythms and fine sounds throughout, whether the instruments were standard (tom-toms), nonstandard (an Aztec log drum) or homemade (sets of tin cans).

title: How'd He Do That? Working Magic Onstage
description: Every life can use a little magic, and happily, Joseph Gabriel is around to provide it.

title: A Way to Poach Eggs to Perfection
description: WHEN I first started to cook, I was terrified of poaching eggs because I had heard so many tales about how things could go wrong. Since I was following standard practices of the day, horrible results were almost inevitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENS, LINCOLN
description: ORENS-Lincoln. On January 12, 1998 of Island Park, NY. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Robert, Stephen, Ralph Silberer, and Jean Kraft. Also survived by seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Visiting and Service at the Towers Funeral Home, Inc., Long Beach and Foxhurst Roads, Oceanside, L.I., on Wednesday between 2-4 PM. Mr. Orens was past President of the Island Park School Board, former Village Attorney and President of BOCES. Donations to NY Burns Center in Mr. Oren's name would be appreciated.

title: THOMSON TO BUY COMPUTER LANGUAGE RESEARCH INC.
description: The Thomson Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Computer Language Research Inc., a tax-return processing company, for $22.50 a share, or $325 million. News of the deal sent shares of Computer Language 58 percent higher in Nasdaq trading; they gained $8.125 each, to $22.125. Computer Language, based in Carrollton, Tex., provides tax, accounting and real estate management software. Thomson, based in Toronto, is involved in publishing and specialized information.

title: Police in West New York Arrested in Bribery Inquiry
description: Saying that a small Hudson County town had been turned into a haven for crime, Federal prosecutors announced the indictment today of the former Police Chief and eight other former or current members of the West New York Police Department. The nine were charged with extorting and accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes in exchange for protecting illegal gambling, prostitution and after-hours liquor sales.

title: Peugeot Says Sales Rose 5.3% Last Year
description: Peugeot Citroen, France's largest car company, said yesterday that it sold 5.3 percent more cars in 1997 than it did the year before, with strong sales elsewhere in Europe making up for a slumping market in France. The company, which makes Citroen and Peugeot cars, said it sold 2.1 million cars last year. Peugeot said unit sales in Europe outside of France were up 13.8 percent, lifting its market share to 8.8 percent, from 8.5 percent in 1996, with strong gains in Britain, Spain and Italy.

title: Ah, the French. But Do They Really Have Anything on Us?
description: In a darkened room one evening this month in Bordeaux, many of the world's most famous chefs and restaurateurs sat with napkins over their heads and faces. . . . Sworn to secrecy, they were chewing the skin, flesh, bones and entrails of one of France's greatest delicacies, the ortolan, a tiny songbird whose declining numbers led the French Government to forbid its sale anywhere in the country. -- The Dining section, Dec. 31, 1997

title: Executive Changes
description: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, promoted Joseph G. Sponholz, now the executive vice president and chief administrative officer, to vice chairman.

title: Thais Report Surplus In Quarterly Trade
description: This country recorded the biggest current-account surplus in 20 years in the fourth quarter. And it said it exceeded requirements imposed as part of an international bailout, as the weakening Thai currency, the baht, reversed years of trade deficits.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: The Chef
description: FOR a chef New York is the land of the free. It's not that you can do anything at all, but this city is so ready to embrace innovation that the problem is how to show a certain restraint in the face of liberation, to stay within what you know. My objective as the chef (French- and Swiss-trained) at a Swedish restaurant is to take the ingredients and proclivities of Sweden and marry them to the international ferment of New York.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We really, unfortunately, aren't able to really talk about race because, again, it's like saying, let's talk about America. We will have to narrow this issue because certainly if we don't, we're going to be criticized, and obviously, it may just kind of wither away.''

title: The Ice Storm
description: Deep cold, undiluted darkness, unsolicited silence -- that is what remains when the power goes down in winter and stays down, as it has this past week after a terrible ice storm along the St. Lawrence River. The temporary loss of power, when it happens in summer, seems almost insubstantial, the ghosting away of something whose presence was almost ghostly to start with. When the power comes on again, it feels as though a tide has come in, lifting everyone and everything in its path.

title: Ah, the French. But Do They Really Have Anything on Us?
description: In a darkened room one evening this month in Bordeaux, many of the world's most famous chefs and restaurateurs sat with napkins over their heads and faces. . . . Sworn to secrecy, they were chewing the skin, flesh, bones and entrails of one of France's greatest delicacies, the ortolan, a tiny songbird whose declining numbers led the French Government to forbid its sale anywhere in the country. -- The Dining section, Dec. 31, 1997

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Center Bank Robbed

title: Robert Townsend, 77, Dies; Wrote 'Up the Organization'
description: Robert C. Townsend, a chairman and president of Avis Rent-a-Car who went on to write the best-selling book ''Up the Organization: How to Stop the Corporation from Stifling People and Strangling Profits,'' died on Monday while vacationing on the island of Anguilla in the West Indies. He was 77 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Bank Regulators Circulating Secret Data
description: Federal regulators are collecting normally confidential information about individual banks' loans to South Korea and are sharing the information with large banks that are leading an effort to extend payments on the loans, according to American commercial bankers.

title: Monday Football Stays on ABC; NBC Out of Game After 33 Years
description: In a dramatic finale to the most expensive sports television negotiations ever, ABC yesterday kept ''Monday Night Football'' for $4.4 billion over eight years, and ESPN secured exclusive National Football League cable rights by paying $4.8 billion for the entire Sunday night package.

title: Despite Crisis, Suharto's Party Plans to Renominate Him
description: As an economic crisis has led a growing number of Indonesians to call publicly for President Suharto to step down, his party affirmed on Tuesday that it would nominate him for a seventh five-year term in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRIN, GERTRUDE
description: PERRIN-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Myles D. Perrin, sister of Bob Daran, mother of the late Robert Perrin and Marjorie Seligman, grandmother of Peter Seligman. Passed at the age of 90, at the Heartland Health Care Center in Boynton Beach, FL., on January 10. Memorial service to be held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY on Thursday January 15 at 10 A.M.

title: Palmer Is Anti-Cart
description: Arnold Palmer said yesterday that he is against the use of golf carts on any professional tour.

title: Slow-Starting Huskies Ride A Quick Second-Half Spurt
description: Coach Jim Calhoun had begun to fret that his University of Connecticut team was becoming something of a one-man scoring band in the person of Richard Hamilton. The sophomore swingman had tallied 127 points in the Huskies' previous four games.

title: A Repentant France Honors Zola
description: France paid solemn tribute today to ''J'accuse,'' the novelist Emile Zola's manifesto against the anti-Semitism of the Dreyfus Affair, on the 100th anniversary of its publication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, MARY JANE (NEE BOHAN)
description: MCDERMOTT-Mary Jane (nee Bohan). On January 12, 1998. Born on Feb. 2, 1907, County Leitrim, Ireland. Beloved wife of Thomas McDermott, deceased. Cherished mother of Dermod Patrick, deceased, Thomas Patrick and Geraldine Mary McDermott Pender. Dear mother-in-law of Shukuko McDermott, Maria McDermott and Sean Pender. Devoted grandmother of Teresa McDermott, Rosemarie DiLorenzo and Clare Abeln. Reposing Dorothy Funeral Home Inc, 14 Emwilton Pl, Ossining, NY, Wednesday, January 14, from 6-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, Jan. 15 at 9:30 A.M. Holy Name of Mary Church, 110 Grand St., Croton-On-Hudson, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please request Masses for her intention.

title: Walking the Walk, Against the Light
description: In presenting his vision of a jaywalker-free New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani noted that pedestrians in many other cities have greater respect for the rights of others.

title: Critic's Notebook; Just Like a Singer Tale: Questions for a Yiddish Sprite
description: Surely among the other qualities that distinguished the career of Isaac Bashevis Singer, who won the Nobel Prize in 1978, was his capacity for seemingly endless productivity. But now, after stories and books like ''Gimpel the Fool,'' ''The Family Moskat,'' ''In My Father's Court,'' and ''Enemies, a Love Story,'' we are most likely at the end of Singer's oeuvre. And a glorious end it has been, marked by the recent publication in English of ''Shadows on the Hudson,'' Singer's darkest and, in many ways, most interesting novel.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ENGLER, GEORGE J.
description: ENGLER-George J. September 12, 1910-January 14, 1992. Dearest Dread Naught. Forever cherished

title: Treasuries Fall as Demand Decreases and Stock Prices Rise
description: Treasury securities fell in choppy trading yesterday as investors warily watched the Asian situation. The flight to quality that had been pushing bond yields lower abated amid rebounding stock prices.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR ENDS LOWER. The dollar dropped against the mark in early trading on rumors of intervention by the Bundesbank to support the German currency. But the dollar later rebounded on talk of a possible German rate cut. It finished down slightly at 1.8200 marks, off from 1.8211 on Monday.

title: BASEBALL: Lessons of a Sibling Rivalry; Alfonzo Learned Game From a Competitor: His Brother
description: There are the rivalries that infect the heart, never to be repeated. If you loved the Brooklyn Dodgers then you hated the Giants. And here, if you cheer for Magallanes, then you despise Caracas.

title: Big Holder Balking At Deal for Nichols
description: A major shareholder wants the J. C. Nichols Company, which has agreed to be acquired by Highwoods Properties Inc., to consider another potential bid.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Forethought Can Prevent Tragedy on the Slopes
description: To the Editor:

title: To Go; Hot and Zesty for a Cold Night
description: KITCHEN/MARKET is exactly that: part takeout kitchen and part market (Mexican), with an impressive selection of produce: chili peppers, hot sauces, beverages, dry goods and trinkets. It describes its takeout offerings as Mexican as well, but the food is more accurately Kitchen's own versions of Cal-Mex and Southwestern dishes.

title: Team One Honored At Auto Awards
description: Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., took top honors, winning the most awards, at the third annual International Automotive Advertising Awards.

title: Elizabeth Standout To Go to Minnesota
description: Asad Abdul-Kaliq, an all-America quarterback from Elizabeth High School in New Jersey, revealed yesterday his intention to attend the University of Minnesota.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HARRY M.
description: COHEN-Harry M. on January 13, 1998. Attorney, husband of the late Betty, father of Edward, Irwin and Leslie. Brother of Pauline Balkin. Grandfather and great grandfather. Services Wednesday 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNERS, ELIZABETH A.
description: MANNERS-Elizabeth A. (nee Crompton) On January 12, 1998. Employee of TWA serving 40 plus years before retiring as Director. She was the first woman Salesperson of the Year and checked in the first TWA international flight. Beloved wife of the late John L. and Seymour G. Pond, loving mother of Seymour G. Pond, dear sister of the late Charles C. Wake Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave, Bklyn. Funeral Thurs. 11 A.M. Interment Green Wood Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELINGER, ALEXANDER MARIO
description: SELINGER-Alexander Mario. Of New York and Palm Beach, Florida. Died January 12, 1998, age 91. Former owner of Eclair Pastry Shops, New York, for 54 years. Survived by wife Marianne, sister Annetta Mandler, step-sons Tom (Ellen) and John (Sue Rosenthal), grandchildren Lucy and Cody. Burial in Palm Beach.

title: New Chicago Office For Ammirati Puris
description: Ammirati Puris Lintas, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has named the creative leadership for an office in Chicago the agency is opening to service its new Ameritech Corporation account.

title: Temptation; Not Your Mom's Meatloaf: Someone Finally Gets It Right
description: THE nicely browned meatloaf at Acme Bar and Grill is what I always wanted my mother's meatloaf to be: filled with other things besides meat, but never enough to overwhelm the satisfying flavor that comes from a nice crust on ground beef.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGERS, RALPH RAY
description: RODGERS-Ralph Ray. January 11, 1998. Loving father of Marc, Kenneth, Rand and Nancy. Adoring grandfather of Jill Karen. Services 12:30 PM Wednesday, Congregation KTI, 575 King St., Port Chester, New York.

title: Mixing Plastic With Play Dough
description: Is American Express changing its slogan to ''Don't leave second grade without it?''

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL WILL BUY ETOWAH BANK
description: The Regions Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Etowah Bank of Canton, Ga., for $117.4 million. Regions will exchange 3.3127 of its common shares for each Etowah Bank common share. Regions' shares fell $1 each, to $38.125, in Nasdaq trading. Etowah Bank operates 18 full-service offices in Georgia. Regions will have 139 offices and $5.5 billion in assets in Georgia when the sale is completed. Based in Birmingham, Ala., Regions Financial is a regional multibank holding company providing banking services from more than 430 offices in five Southeastern states.

title: Nets Find Secrets Of Success On Road
description: The Nets had come into Charlotte Coliseum hoping to steal a game on the road against one of the league's better home teams.

title: Wine Talk; Big Wine Sellers Enlist States in Fighting Tiny Foes
description: CALIFORNIA, the old vaudevillian Fred Allen used to say, was a great place to live -- if you were an orange.

title: Yanks Sign Nelson for 3 Years
description: Questions remain about the Yankees' rotation, but the bullpen may look the same for years to come. Jeff Nelson, the right-handed reliever, signed a three-year contract extension yesterday worth at least $5.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELPERN, IRVING E.
description: HELPERN-Irving E. Age 90, on January 12. Beloved husband of Leona for 60 special years. Loving and proud father of David, Anne Bookstein, and Robert, and of their spouses Joan, Herbert Bookstein, and Jacqueline. Adored grandfather of Lauren; Peter, Scott and his wife Desiree, Jeffrey, and Meredythe Bookstein; and Michael and Joshua. Cherished great-grandfather of Ethan Bookstein. Devoted brother of the late Dr. Gottlieb Helpern. Funeral services today at BoulevardRiverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, at 9:30 A.M. His caring heart finally gave way. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the American Heart Association or UJA-Federation of New York would be appreciated.

title: Albanian Seeking Asylum Is Allowed to Return to U.S.
description: An Albanian asylum seeker deported in July under a new law intended to quickly weed out groundless asylum claims has been allowed to return to the United States to seek refuge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLOCH, ANTHONY EDWARD
description: BALLOCH-Anthony Edward, 81. Of Atlanta died January 13, 1998. Formerly of Wilton, CT. Survived by his wife Mary Chase Balloch; daughters Pat Tuff of Atlanta, Joy Ahrens of Yarmouth, ME; sons Howard Balloch of Beijing, China, Hugh Balloch, Darien, Connecticut; sixteen grandchildren. A memorial service for friends and family will be held in Jamestown, RI in the summer. For information H.M. Patterson & Son Funeral Home.

title: Englewood Mayor Seeks Better Education and Desegregated School
description: Englewood's new Mayor, Paul T. Fader, announced tonight that he wanted to improve local education and press on with a 13-year-old lawsuit to desegregate Dwight Morrow High School.

title: Victory on the Field Doesn't Help Students; Precarious Futures
description: To the Editor:

title: Employment Declined In Germany in 1997
description: The German Statistics Office said yesterday that 34 million workers were employed in Germany in 1997, down 463,000, or 1.3 percent, according to preliminary figures. That is the lowest number of people at work since Germany's reunification, the office said.

title: Richard Graff, California Vintner, 60
description: Richard Graff, an owner of Chalone Vineyards, one of California's most prestigious small wineries, and co-founder and chairman emeritus of the Chalone Wine Group, was killed on Friday when a single-engine Cessna he was flying crashed near Salinas, Calif. He was 60.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, MYRON B.
description: EHRLICH-Myron B. Age 89. Died January 11, 1998; formerly of NYC; survived by nephews John and Robert Herzfeld. He was an active volunteer at the Metropolitan Opera and the Jewish Guild for the Blind. The body was cremated.

title: Forethought Can Prevent Tragedy on the Slopes; Better Terminology
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURGER, JEANNE
description: HAMBURGER - Jeanne, nee Hirsch age 95, on January 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Eugene. Devoted mother of Clifford and mother-in-law of Susan. Loving grandmother of Lee and Russell. A graveside service will be held at 11AM, on January 14, 1998 at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens.

title: Metro Business; Foodtown Says Chief Embezzled Millions
description: The Foodtown supermarket chain in Edison, N.J. filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing its former chief executive of extorting and embezzling more than $12 million from the company between 1993 and 1997.

title: Blocking Money for U.N. Harms U.S. in Iraq Crisis, Albright Says
description: As a new crisis built with Iraq, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright sharply accused Congress today of undermining American foreign policy during a tense situation with Iraq late last year by failing to pay American debts to the United Nations.

title: 3 Gunmen Rob Guards of $1.6 Million at World Trade Center Bank
description: Three armed men got past security yesterday morning in the World Trade Center, disarmed two Brink's guards delivering money to a currency exchange center there and then fled with with $1.6 million, the authorities said.

title: Uncovering Good Music That Few Got to Hear
description: According to several recent surveys, most record buyers find out about new music through commercial radio stations, with music television and the music press trailing behind. What is interesting about this is not that it reveals the obvious importance of these media in making and breaking bands, but that most people let new music come to them. They don't find it themselves. A problem with this is that you can't depend on the music industry -- driven by complex marketing forces -- to tell you what's good. Sometimes you have to find good music on your own.

title: J. Crew Dismisses 10% of Work Force
description: J. Crew Group Inc., the retail and catalogue company recently acquired by the Texas Pacific Group, dismissed about 100 employees yesterday, or about 10 percent of its work force.

title: Westchester Leader Is Confirmed For Seat on State Court of Claims
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, who has been seeking an appointment to a judicial bench since 1991, was unanimously confirmed by the State Senate today to a seat on the Court of Claims.

title: Chance for a Dance With a Star Is Lost
description: Tonight was supposed to have been the second time that DR. DAVID HO, one of the world's pre-eminent AIDS researchers and the person credited with developing the ''cocktail'' drug treatment that has benefited many AIDS patients, came face to face with ELIZABETH TAYLOR, who has raised millions for AIDS research. The last time, she was a patient in a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., where he was an infectious disease specialist. His diagnosis: viral pneumonia.

title: Pataki's Fund Has Taken In $12 Million for Campaigning; His Success Overshadows Democratic Rivals'
description: Ten months before Election Day, Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign has already collected more than $12 million, giving the Governor a huge fund-raising lead over his Democratic rivals and putting him close to the amount that he took in during his entire race four years ago, his aides said last night.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Quiet Site in Shadow of Bustle Looks for Retailer
description: What a difference a block makes.

title: I.M.F. Now Admits Tactics in Indonesia Deepened the Crisis
description: A confidential report by the International Monetary Fund on Indonesia's economic crisis acknowledges that an important element of the I.M.F.'s rescue strategy backfired, causing a bank panic that helped set off financial market declines in much of Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINICH, ARTHUR
description: MINICH-Arthur. Age 91, of Palm Beach, Florida and formerly of Westfield, NJ, died on Sunday, January 11, 1998 at his residence. He had retired in 1969 from Tenneco Chemicals, Inc. as Senior VicePresident after 37 years of service in the chemical industry. Prior to joining Tenneco, Mr. Minich served successively as vice-president, executive vice-president and president of Nuodex Products Company, Inc., of Elizabeth, NJ. Author of many articles and holder of a number of patents in the chemical field, Mr. Minich was a member of numerous chemical, business and management organizations. He received his M.B.S. degree from the Vienna Institute of Technology. He received a Certificate of Merit from the War Production Board and War and Navy Departments for his outstanding contribution to the work of the Office of Scientific Research and Development during World War II. Mr. Minich remained active in the chemical field through consulting activities for many years. He was a member of Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church and the Beach Club in Palm Beach as well as numerous civic organizations. Survivors include his wife, Olga Capp Minich of Palm Beach, FL; two daughters, Karen Minich of Houston, TX and Gail Minich Wragg of Mendham, NJ; sister, Helen Zechmeister of Los Altos Hills, CA. A Memorial Service will be 11:00 A.M., Friday, January 16, 1998 at Bethesda - by - the - Sea Episcopal Church, Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, friends may contribute to a charity of their choice. For more information, contact Quattlebaum - Holleman - Burse Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARIO, RALPH S.
description: VARIO-Ralph S. Of Chappaqua, New York. Visitation from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Thursday at the CassidyFlynn Funeral Home. Services are on Friday 1 P.M., at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mount Kisco, New York. Interment at Fairridge Cemetery, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Rollins College, PO Box 2724, 1000 Holt Ave., Winter Park, FL. 32789-4499, in Ralph Vario's name, designed to help needy students, would be appreciated.

title: A Positive Shift in Forest Policy
description: Michael Dombeck, the chief of the United States Forest Service, will soon announce a moratorium on construction of new logging roads in remote sections of most of the national forests. That will be a courageous change in policy for an agency long regarded as a willing captive of the timber industry it is supposed to regulate.

title: Liberties; Running Like a Girl
description: I've seen Al D'Amato at his worst. Often.

title: Mutual Fund Outflow Reported in Hong Kong
description: Mutual funds registered for sale in Hong Kong had net outflows of $1.65 million in November, the second consecutive month that investors withdrew money. In October, investors pulled a net $82 million from the funds. Fund companies reported $255.12 million in sales in November against $256.77 million in redemptions, the Hong Kong Investment Funds Association said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, STANLEY SAUL
description: HOROWITZ-Stanley Saul. October 18, 1916-January 12, 1998. Survived by his wife of 25 years, Veronica, four children, Miriam, Mark, Susan and Reina; son-in-law Richard Meisler, daughter-in-law Mary; seven grandchildren, Joshua, Daniel, Jason, Sarah, Bennett, Rebecca and Joseph; his brother Larry (Toni) and nephews, nieces and cousins. Preceded in death by his first wife Anna, and by his sisters Henriette (Earl) and Evelyn (Dave). He attended CCNY 1936-39 and the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, and served in the NY Police Department from 1940-1973. He was a volunteer with the Little Neck/Douglaston Ambulance Core for twenty-five years. Stan was deeply devoted to his family, friends and community. His unique perspective and his appreciation of the simple things of life had a profound impact on those who knew him. Memorial Sunday, January 18, at 12:30 P.M., Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows.

title: By the Book; How Women Become Chefs (It Isn't Easy)
description: NEVER before have women achieved the status and recognition as chefs that they have today. How that happened and where the trend may lead is the subject of two books, ''A Woman's Place Is in the Kitchen: The Evolution of Women Chefs'' by Ann Cooper (Van Nostrand Reinhold, $29.95) and ''Women of Taste: Recipes and Profiles of Famous Women Chefs'' by Beverly Russell (John Wiley & Sons, $35).

title: Metro Business; Stagebill Magazine Is Sold
description: Fred B. Tarter, a New York entrepreneur who sells ads to movie theaters, announced on Monday that he had acquired Stagebill magazine of Manhattan from Primedia, which also publishes Seventeen and New York magazines.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about electrical transmission towers that collapsed in an ice storm misstated the location in some editions. The towers were east of Montreal, not south.

title: Classical Tradition, but a Fascination With Pop
description: Young composers -- those who grew up in the 1960's and later -- are often as passionate about popular music as they are about the classical tradition, and many have been determined to find outlets for this fascination.

title: Cells' Life Stretched in Lab
description: In a finding that suggests the thread of life can be extended, at least for human cells, biologists have succeeded for the first time in coaxing cells grown in a test tube to live far beyond the limit at which they usually fail.

title: Whitman Restates Pledge On Taxes and Insurance
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman used her first major speech since her narrow re-election victory last fall to reassure New Jersey voters today that she would address their concerns over paying the country's highest property taxes and auto insurance rates.

title: Ways to Celebrate a Black Truffle Bounty
description: A REVERENCE for black truffles, one of the glories of the winter table, will take a serious turn on Sunday, when a special truffle Mass will be celebrated at the church of Richerenches, a village near Carpentras, in Provence in the southeast of France. On hand to help bless the truffle season will be the New York chefs Jean-Georges Vongerichten, Laurent Manrique, Jean-Louis Dumonet and Geoffrey Zakarian, along with Sylvain Portay of San Francisco.

title: Black Man's Role At Club Is a First
description: CURTIS A. HARRIS has been elected to the venerable New York Athletic Club's board of governors. He is the first black person chosen for the 19-member board in the club's 128-year history.

title: About New York; Dodge City, in More Ways Than One
description: IF you listened closely to the sounds of the city yesterday, you could hear a giddy addition to the streetside symphony of bleating horns, cursing cabbies and rumbling trucks. Laughter -- knee-slapping, get-real guffaws, in fact. The cause of this metro mirth? Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's suggestion to crack down on the legions of curb-jumping Capones who have the criminal nerve to cross the street wherever they can.

title: Holocaust Survivor Presses Insurer for Annuity
description: As soon as he was freed from Buchenwald, Adolph Stern, then 29, made his way back to Prague and the ornate offices of Assicurazioni Generali, Italy's biggest insurance company.

title: U.S. and Microsoft Argue in Court Whether Judge Is Being Defied
description: The Federal Government and the Microsoft Corporation clashed in court today over whether the computer software giant had flouted a judge's order that it stop forcing makers of personal computers to install Microsoft's Internet browser as a condition of accepting its highly popular Windows 95 operating system.

title: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope; Genetic Privacy, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home On Top Of Div. III
description: Middlebury, aiming for a fourth straight Division III national championship, is undefeated in its last seven games and has an overall 7-2-1 record. The losses came in November to Connecticut College and Plattsburgh State. The Panthers, ranked No. 4 in the Division III East poll, meet No. 3 Williams (8-2) in a key ECAC East contest at home in Vermont on Friday. Hamilton (5-5-1) comes in Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, PHYLLIS
description: BLUM-Phyllis. Beloved wife of Harry, devoted mother of Lillian and Marty. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends. Services are today at 10 A.M., at Kirschenbaum's, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUENBERG, EMIL
description: GRUENBERG-Emil. On January 11, 1998; loving father of Claudia Sturtz and Dr. Kenneth Gruenberg; brother of Lee Gruenberg and Charlotte Diamond; grandfather of Aaron, Shana and Nina Sturtz and David and Elisabeth Gruenberg. Interment private.

title: Amnesty Fray Is Heading To the Courts
description: The Truth and Reconciliation Commission said today that it would let a court decide whether it had exceeded its powers by granting a blanket amnesty last month to top officials of South Africa's governing party.

title: For Madeleine Kamman, A Gentler Simmer
description: WITH a fixed gaze, Madeleine Kamman watched the gently rolling chicken broth simmer around the endive on the stove. Her ice-blue eyes trained on a single leaf, she was alert for the faint shiver that would signal its softening.

title: RANGER SELLS SOME OIL AND GAS RIGHTS TO CHESAPEAKE
description: The Chesapeake Energy Corporation has agreed to purchase a 40 percent interest in certain oil and natural-gas properties in British Columbia from Ranger Oil Ltd., a Canadian oil producer, for $71 million (Canadian), or $49.5 million (United States). Under the agreement, operations in the Helmet area of northeastern British Columbia will be conducted on a 60-40 basis between Ranger and Chesapeake, an oil and natural gas concern based in Oklahoma City. In the last month, Ranger, based in Calgary, Alberta, has sold noncore properties in Alberta, for net proceeds of $27 million (Canadian).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSMUNDSEN, LITA S.
description: OSMUNDSEN-Lita S. On January 9th, 1998, beloved wife of John; loving mother of Jonathan and Mirjana; grandmother of Meaghan Kate Dougherty; daughter of Irvin Binns and the late Evadne Parchment; sister of Roger and Heather Habeger and widow of the late Paul Fejos. A beautiful woman, fine mind and powerful influence on the lives of many and on the entire field of anthropology, worldwide, in her forty-one years of service to the Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research, 24 years as President and Director of Research.

title: Celebrating a Drummer's Ongoing Beat
description: One of the happier sights in jazz during the last year has been the re-emergence of the drummer Billy Higgins, who had been ill. Mr. Higgins performed with Ornette Coleman at Lincoln Center last summer and recently he showed up in New York with Jackie McLean. And his playing has been as brilliant as ever.

title: Honors
description: * Ron Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Clevenger Inc., Chicago, received the 1998 Charles S. Downs Chicago Direct Marketer of the Year from the Chicago Association of Direct Marketing.

title: What Staten Island Needs, Mayor Says, Is Baseball
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani intends to eliminate the unfair but common habit of equating Staten Island with a malodorous landfill today when he announces plans to have a baseball stadium built there, one that he hopes might someday serve as the base for a minor-league franchise of his beloved New York Yankees.

title: Iona Escapes Manhattan On Game-Ending 3-Pointer
description: Iona's John McDonald would not let Manhattan graduate from mere annoyance to season-threatening killjoy tonight. His 3-pointer with no time left propelled the Gaels to a 75-72 victory, and he got a ride on the shoulders of his teammates as hundreds of fans spilled out onto Iona's Mulcahy Center court to celebrate.

title: The Neediest Cases; Demons Banished, a Mother Takes Her Children Back
description: The first time she heard the voices, Marie-Francois B. was 20 years old, wandering over a Haitian hillside on a humid afternoon.

title: Jordan Scores 40 To Lead Chicago
description: BULLS 101, SONICS 91

title: Atlantic City Expressway Averts a Toll Increase
description: Tolls on the Atlantic City Expressway will remain level for the 28th straight year, after the state waived $800,000 in payments for state police patrols from South Jersey Transportation Authority, the agency said yesterday.

title: Addressing Racial Issues On Wall St.
description: Wall Street, which is often perceived as still being a white male preserve, has generally been uneasy about openly discussing issues of race and gender.

title: Ameritech Earnings Meet Analysts' Expectations
description: The Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that its profit rose 7 percent in the fourth quarter as demand for new phone lines bolstered revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BISHOP, FRANKLIN G.
description: BISHOP-Franklin G. 12/6/20-1/14/96. Jerry, I miss you. Evelyn

title: Psychiatrist to Receive Transcript in Unabom Case
description: The Federal judge in the Unabom case told lawyers for Theodore J. Kaczynski today to give transcripts of the judge's closed-door meetings with Mr. Kaczynski and his lawyers to a psychiatrist who is evaluating his competence to stand trial.

title: Bush Running Mate Quits Race in Florida
description: The running mate of Jeb Bush, the Republican candidate for governor, withdrew from the ticket today after publicity over spending and ethical lapses that tarnished her reputation as a state Cabinet member and turned her into a political liability.

title: Sports of The Times; Elway Toting A Generation On His Pads
description: SOMEHOW, the realization that John Elway is already 37 years old can make you feel chronologically dated but also spiritually revived. And if Elway can beat Green Bay in the Super Bowl a week from Sunday, millions of graying baby boomers may, at least temporarily, cross an X through the notion that their generation will be in the rocker by the time the Stones roll into town on their next North American tour.

title: Workers Expect Layoffs At Hoechst Drug Unit
description: Hoechst Marion Roussel, the pharmaceutical unit of Hoechst A.G. of Germany, will announce ''several hundred job cuts'' in research and development this week, the head of the Hoechst workers council said yesterday. Employees are planning to demonstrate on Friday to protest the cuts, though they do not plan to strike, said Arnold Weber, the chairman of the workers council. A spokeswoman for Hoechst Marion Roussel, said she could not comment on any planned job cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, CYNTHIA
description: MORSE-Cynthia. On January 12. Age eighty-one. Beloved wife of Joe, mother of Billy and Mike, darling aunt of Mickey and Fran, cherished great-aunt of Leslie, Amy, David and Scott. We will miss your beauty, your wit and alas, even your stubbornness.

title: Food Stuff
description: For a Dessert Chain, Emphasis Is on Mail Order

title: Mexico Army Troops Summoned to Arrest a Police Unit in Chiapas
description: The Governor of Chiapas State has called in army troops to arrest all 29 members of a police unit who opened fire on an anti-Government march on Monday, leaving one Indian protester dead.

title: Seed of Hope In Ulster Soil
description: While encouraged by the new willingness of both sides finally to grapple with details after 19 months of peace talks here, both Catholic and Protestant leaders fear that the effort remains vulnerable to fringe groups determined to wreck an accord.

title: Novartis Plans to Shed 35 of Its 62 Drug Plants
description: The Swiss drug giant Novartis said yesterday that it planned to shut down or sell 35 of its 62 pharmaceutical production sites worldwide by the year 2000. In an interview yesterday with the Swiss newspaper Basler Zeitung, the head of pharmaceutical production, Heinz Scheffler, said the plan was a response to the merger of Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Sandoz A.G., which created Novartis.

title: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope; Evolution Serves Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONKIN, CELINA
description: TONKIN-Celina. On January 11, 1998. Survived by her husband Joseph Tonkin, four daughters, eight grandchildren, one greatgrandchild and many dear friends ... most notably Robert Tompkins. Services Wednesday, January 14, 11 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street. Interment to follow at Mount Neboh Cemetery.

title: A Renewed Sense of Purpose For Clinton's Panel on Race
description: It has been seven months since President Clinton promised to lead the nation for a year in a ''great and unprecedented conversation about race'' -- and most of that time has been spent by his advisers figuring out precisely what the President wants to talk about, and how.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ALLAN ABRAHAM
description: GREENBERG-Allan Abraham. Beloved husband of Ida, devoted father of Nancy Concool, Susan Greenberg, Jack Greenberg, and son-in-law Dr. Barry Concool. Dear brother Esther Bernstein, Lillian Greenman, Gertrude Aberdack and Sara Saretsky. Loving grandfather of Michaela, Shira and Ovi Concool and Joseph and Jacob Greenberg. Services Gutterman - Musicant, Hackensack, New Jersey, Wednesday, January 14, at 2 P.M. (800-322-0533).

title: Korea Steadies Itself on the Road to Recovery
description: What stock market around the world has performed the best so far in 1998?

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT PRICES SURGE. The March contract for wheat jumped 12.25 cents, to $3.34 a bushel, after the Agriculture Department surprised the market yesterday with the announcement that farmers had planted a less-than-expected 46.6 million acres of winter wheat, down from 48.3 million last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSIN, SYDNEY
