description: GOSIN-Sydney. On behalf of our entire organization, we wish to express our profound sorrow to our esteemed partner, Barry Gosin, on the passing of his beloved father, Sydney. We would also like to extend our heartfelt sympathies to the entire family, most especially Irene, Sydney's wife. May his memory be a blessing. The Partners of Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc. William Cohen Ira Fishman Ronald Goldberger Aaron Gural Jeffrey Gural James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post Arthur Rosenbloom

title: Justices Rule One State's Court Cannot Bind Another's Court to a Deal
description: In a case involving an automobile industry whistleblower, the Supreme Court ruled today that one state's court system cannot bind another's to an agreement barring particular testimony or evidence from a trial.

title: U.N. Inspector's Specialty: How Iraq Hides Weapons
description: Among the dozens of United Nations arms inspectors who travel into and out of Iraq in the search for poison gas and other weapons of mass destruction, William Scott Ritter Jr. was bound to be a special thorn in the Iraqis' side.

title: Calendar
description: History Lessons on Food

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUDER, MARGARET ANNE
description: BRUDER-Margaret Anne (nee Harron) ''Peggy Anne'' on January 11, 1998 of Villanova, PA peacefully at her home in Villanova, PA and Longport, NJ. Devoted mother of Margaret Anne Bruder, Jennifer Marie Bruder and James J. Bruder Jr. Loving daughter of Margaret E. (nee Harper) and the late Paul F. Harron, Sr., Newtown Square, PA. Beloved sister of Paul F. Harron Jr., Malvern, PA., and Patricia H. Imbesi, Ocean City, NJ; also survived by 35 nieces and nephews. Family will receive relatives and friends at 9 AM Friday, January 16, 1998, St. Thomas of Villanova Church, (University Campus). Funeral mass 10:30 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery, West Conshohocken. In lieu of flowers remembrances may be sent to the Academy of Notre Dame deNamur, 560 South Sproul Road, Villanova, PA. 19085.

title: Schumer Opens His Ad War In Fight for D'Amato's Seat
description: In a sign that New Yorkers might be in for 10 months of virtually unbroken television advertising in the race for United States Senate, Representative Charles E. Schumer yesterday unveiled two commercials attacking Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. His aides said Mr. Schumer intended to press the advertising campaign indefinitely.

title: Construction Halted at 9 Schools After Inquiry
description: Four days after a brick tumbled off a repair site atop a Brooklyn elementary school and critically injured a 16-year-old girl, city officials said last night that they had temporarily shut down construction at nine other New York City public schools that were found to have inadequate or nonexistent overhead sidewalk protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ALICE A.
description: MILLER-Alice A., on January 12, 1998. Beloved wife of John H. Sister of Helen Sorlingas and Anne Scholl. John J. Fox & Sons Inc. Funeral Director, 718-733-9114.

title: City's Fire Deaths Reach a Historic Low
description: The number of fire-related deaths of civilians in New York City fell last year to its lowest level since 1959, as the city recorded one of the lowest fire-related death rates among large cities, the Fire Department announced yesterday.

title: Starks Is Hot, But Hawks' Smith Is Even Hotter
description: Not even a neon sign could glow brighter than Atlanta's Steve Smith. Not even the halogen-filled John Starks.

title: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope; Insurers' Prerogative
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel: Who Needs Sidewalks?; Many 'Road Warriors' Prefer Airport Hotels to Downtown.
description: Whenever Dirk Van Dongen flies here on business, as he does often, he checks into the O'Hare Hilton and rarely leaves the premises until he checks out to fly back home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, JOHN TAYLOR, MD.
description: ELLIS-John Taylor, MD. January 10th, Rhode Island Hospital, Providence. Born Lufkin, Texas, 1920; graduated from Univ. of Texas Austin and Northwestern Univ. Medical School, Chicago. Captain, Brooke General Hospital, San Antonio. Came to Cornel Univ. Medical College, 1948, in Pathology. Remained there until 1994, except for six years, Chairman 1962-68, Emory Univ. Medical School, Atlanta; serving as consultant, NY Hospital Medical Center, Queens, 1994-97. Devoted husband for 55 years of Marian Caldwell. Father of Evelyn Floy, George Caldwell and John Taylor IV. Loving grandfather of Adrienne and Katherine of NY, Evan, Kelsey and Jesse of Rhode Island. Burial in Dallas, TX.

title: Precision and Fire In Twists and Turns Of Spanish Rhythms
description: Gabriela Granados has an extensive background in Spanish dance and ballet in Spain and her native Peru. That breadth of experience was evident in ''Ole! Ole!,'' an exuberant and stylish program presented by Ms. Granados's American Bolero Dance Company on Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROMBERG, DAVID
description: BROMBERG-David. January 14, 1988, 10 years. On your heart we lay our heads. Family and Friends

title: Off the Menu
description: A Wall Street Oasis

title: Albany Likely To Get Names Of People With H.I.V.
description: Leaders of New York's legislative health committees said yesterday that the state was likely to begin reporting people with H.I.V. to confidential registries of the State Health Department, and that the practice could be in place by the end of the year.

title: Japanese Pitcher Joins The Mets' Starting Staff
description: Last month, the Mets decided that Dwight Gooden was the kind of veteran pitcher they could not really afford. Yesterday, in light of losing Jason Isringhausen for the season after reconstructive elbow surgery, the team acknowledged it could no longer afford to ignore outside help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKINNEY, MARIE, LOUISE (MARIELLE)
description: McKINNEY-Marie-Louise (Marielle). All of us at New York City Opera are deeply saddened by the death of Marielle McKinney, mother of our dear friend and Board member, Edmee de Montmollin Firth. Our sympathies go to Robert McKinney and the entire family. Irwin Schneiderman, Co-Chairman of the Board Mark Newhouse, President of the Board Paul Kellogg, General and Artistic Director New York City Opera

title: The New York Times Promotes 2 Top Editors on Its Magazine
description: Promotions of the two top editors at The New York Times Magazine were announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, executive editor of The Times.

title: Sips; Yo-Ho-Ho and a Bottle . . . Can This Be Rum?
description: RUM, the base of many bad mixed drinks, is on the way to repairing its reputation.

title: Russian Pair Exit With Broken Blade
description: The defending pairs titlists, Marina Yeltsova and Andrei Bushkov, stumbled out of the European championships in Milan, Italy, yesterday when the blade on Bushkov's right skate broke about 30 seconds into their short program.

title: When In Rome
description: New York City doesn't hold a monopoly on jaywalking. Philadelphia had to turn to ''Operation Crosswalk.'' And 151,000-lira fines don't scare Romans.

title: Baghdad's Hall of Mirrors
description: After all the drama of last November, the Clinton Administration finds itself back where it started with Iraq: in another annoying and potentially explosive confrontation with Saddam Hussein over United Nations weapons inspectors.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OLSEN, ROLF W.
description: OLSEN-Rolf W. 12/20/63 to 1/14/96. You're always with me. Love, Dad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROM, JULIUS
description: ROM-Julius. On Monday, January 12, 1998, Julius Rom, formerly of New York, a forensic accountant at the NYS Dept of Law. Loving husband of Rose Rom. Cherished father of Joanna (Steven Goldberg) Rom and Ronnie (Donald Frank) Rom. Dear grandfather of Joshua and Alison Goldberg and Rebecca and Arcadia Rom-Frank. Beloved brother of Esther (Sam) Boorstein. Funeral services will be held today in Rockville, MD. Memorial contributions may be made to Tikvat Israel Congregation or Rockville Nursing Home. For further information call Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, Rockville, Maryland, 1-800-217-9403.

title: Internal Audit Confirms Abusive I.R.S. Practices
description: A new internal audit has revealed that taxpayers' rights have been abused nationwide because the Internal Revenue Service has routinely measured the performance of employees on the basis of how much money they collected, the agency announced today.

title: St. John's Comes Out Strong And the Ending Is a Breeze
description: The empty seats at the top of Alumni Hall provided one measure of the doubts surrounding the Red Storm of St. John's. The uncertainty within has always been more difficult to measure. But last night, before an uncharacteristically happy and supportive crowd, the Red Storm checked its fragility at the door.

title: Federal Jury Indicts Officer In Choking Of Bronx Man
description: Francis X. Livoti, the former New York City police officer acquitted in the 1994 death of Anthony Baez, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges that he violated the civil rights of the Bronx man.

title: Truth Rivals Thrillers, A Fictional Writer Finds
description: KISSING THE BEEHIVE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVALER, FREDERIC
description: KAVALER-Frederic. The SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn mourns the loss of Dr. Frederic Kavaler, Professor of Physiology, and a pioneer in cardiac electrophysiology . We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Rebecca, his sons Matt and Joshua, his brother Arthur and other family and friends. We regret the error in yesterdays expression of sympathy. Office of Institutional Advancement

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALT, JOHANNA GOLDMANN
description: ALT-Johanna Goldmann. A long time resident of Queens, NY. Died January 1 in Fairfax, VA. Born in Lowenberg, Germany. Widow of Felix Alt. Mother of Mia (Miriam) Gardiner and Eva Sherwood. She is also survived by five grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, nephews and a niece and their families. Memorial contributions may be made to The Holocaust Memorial Museum or the UJA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGRAFF, ELSE (NEE HAUSDORFF)
description: DeGRAFF-Else (nee Hausdorff). Beloved wife of the late Martin. Cherished mother of Paula and Bernie Herbst and the late Nico. Dear sister of Gretha Sohlberg. Adoring grandmother of Shuli Nakdimem, Simcha Teren, and Peter. Cherished great-grandmother of 18. Service Wednesday, 12 Noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Car-Dodging With the Mayor
description: Like most New Yorkers, we are sometimes amused, sometimes horrified by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's penchant for control. We also admit that there is a temptation to believe that Mr. Giuliani decided to take on jaywalking out of pique at the widespread ridicule of his pedestrian barriers in midtown.

title: Who Is a Republican?
description: Republicans seem to know how to create trouble for themselves. The Republican National Committee, which meets this week in California, is to vote on a resolution that would bar the national party from supporting any candidate who opposed a ban on ''partial birth'' abortions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, NANCILEE DAVIS
description: KELLY-Nancilee Davis. Artist, Morgan car owner, and colorist for the carpet industry, died on January 9, 1998 at her Lookout Mtn., TN home. She was V.P. of Kelly Group and member of color Mktg. Group, M.C.C.D.C., 3/4 Club, Hunter Museum, Houston Museum of Dec. Arts, and Square 1. She formed an art class at U.T.C. She is survived by a daughter, Kathi Stevens, New London, NH; two grandchildren. Donations may be made to Lookout Mtn. Beautification Fund or TN River Gorge Trust. A memorial service will be held 1 P.M. Thurs at Wann Funeral Home, Chattanooga, TN.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Many Americans, Nothing but Blue Skies
description: Lashed by freezing rain and pummeled by wicked gales roaring off Lake Michigan, Henry Hoornweg trudged doggedly toward the rattling El train in the city's Loop, entitled to feel a bit miserable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMBERMAN, STANLEY
description: IMBERMAN-Stanley. Of Baldwin, L.I. on January 12, 1998. Beloved husband of Natalie. Devoted father of Michael, Barbara and Edward. Loving grandfather of Ian. Dear father-in-law of Randi. Cherished brother of Milton and Carol. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M., at Gutterman's, Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A new trading system may bring a shift in the balance of power on the Nasdaq exchange.
description: IT wasn't so long ago that Wall Street considered many investors to be little more than pigeons to be plucked, particularly investors who bought or sold over-the-counter stocks, so called because they were not listed on an exchange.

title: The Care and Feeding Of a Wild Yeast
description: MY first fling with sourdough bread, some 20 years ago, was moderately successful. I managed the bit of magic that gets it all going: capturing the wild yeast from the air, rather than using the tamed -- that is, commercial -- yeast that comes in a package, and nourishing it with flour to make a starter vigorous enough to cause dough to rise. The bread was fair enough, but it was a lot of work. After a while the starter got pretty nasty and I discarded it.

title: Manfredy Returns To the Ring
description: By his own count, Angel (El Diablo) Manfredy has been involved in 13 auto accidents, and ''the big one'' four years ago left a telephone pole planted in his Buick Skylark and 265 stitches in his forehead.

title: For Some, Human Cloning Might Offer Hope; No Blanket Welcome
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico Holds 2 U.S. Brothers in Gunrunning Case
description: The Mexican authorities said today that they were holding two American brothers for questioning in connection with the transfer of more than 1,000 automatic rifles and other firearms to drug traffickers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPP, JOHN
description: RAPP-John. On Monday, January 12, 1998 of Summit, N.J. Beloved husband of Joy Rapp. Devoted father of the late Marianne Rapp. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey, on January 14th, 1998, at 1 P.M. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ABE
description: KAPLAN-Abe. Beloved husband of Ruth, father of Judy and Stanley Kaplan. Grandfather of Miriam and Zev Kaplan, Deborah and Neal Beylus, Duvy and Benji Kaplan. He was an honest and humble man, who displayed kindness and consideration to all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, DR. LESTER
description: KATZ-Dr. Lester. On his 90th birthday. Dearest husband of Laura. Devoted father of Carolyn and Jason Moss. Cherished grandfather of Peter and Susan. Loving brother of Dr. Sidney. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Ave. (at Prospect Park) Brooklyn, today at 11:30 AM.

title: Brooklyn Academy Bets on the Borough
description: After 15 years of making and (mostly) winning courageous bets on artists at its Next Wave Festival, the always bold Brooklyn Academy of Music is entering an ambitious new phase, a next wave of the institution itself.

title: A Road-Building Scandal Forces a Governor's Hand
description: Seeking to stem damage from a fusillade of disclosures about patronage and political influence in North Carolina's road-building program, Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. dismissed his Transportation Secretary today, acknowledged mistakes and promised change.

title: South Africa Gesture Reopens Old Wound
description: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission said it would let a court decide whether it had exceeded its powers by granting a blanket amnesty last month to top officials of the governing party.

title: Victory on the Field Doesn't Help Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Belichick Interviews
description: Bill Belichick, who served this past season as assistant head coach to Bill Parcells of the Jets, met in Oakland yesterday with the Raiders to discuss their head coaching vacancy.

title: General Partner Named at Ulysses
description: David G. Shulman, formerly the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, has become a general partner in Ulysses Management L.L.C., a midsized hedge fund that was formed last July.

title: Mission of Mercy
description: I left my home here in southwestern Ontario at 9 A.M. Saturday in the company of several pickup trucks carrying generators. They were driven by farmers engaged in unofficial rescue missions to aid their counterparts in eastern Ontario and Quebec, who have been particularly hard hit by Ice Storm '98.

title: No Criminal Charges For Girl Who Hid Baby
description: The 15-year-old Queens girl who gave birth in secret over the weekend and hid the baby's body in a sewer will not face criminal charges, officials said yesterday, because an autopsy determined that the baby was stillborn and more than four months premature.

title: As network fees for N.F.L. games soar, agencies say not-so-fast to potential rise in ad rates.
description: MADISON AVENUE is sending a message to the television networks that will pay astonishingly higher rights fees for National Football League games starting with the 1998-99 season: If they think they're going to recoup those payments by sharply increasing advertising rates, fuhgeddaboudit.

title: A Chemical Mystery That Excites the Taste Buds
description: IF tomatoes and peas are among your favorite vegetables, you love mushrooms and you keep a container of grated Parmesan on hand, chances are you are a big fan of umami.

title: Jean McKelvey, 89, Professor and Labor Arbitration Expert
description: Dr. Jean Trepp McKelvey, who hurdled gender barriers in the field of labor-management mediation and opened the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University, died on Jan. 5 at the Kirkhaven Nursing Home in her hometown of Rochester. She was 89.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the close of the legislative session in New Jersey referred incorrectly in some editions to the fate of a bill to regulate ''rent to own'' businesses, which rent out products while giving customers the option of purchasing them. The bill was pulled from consideration in the Assembly after failing to get enough votes; it did not pass.

title: Forethought Can Prevent Tragedy on the Slopes; Responsible Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich Going on Tour, For Cash and the Future
description: He quoted Churchill. He called for government run in the spirit of the management gurus Peter Drucker and W. Edwards Deming. He imagined what Lewis and Clark felt as they explored the West. And he challenged states to require all school classes to teach the Constitution and Declaration of Independence one day each year.

title: Food Chain
description: Defrosting Meat

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRASHEIM, EDMUND S.
description: GRASHEIM-Edmund S. Beloved husband of the late Marjorie and the late Elinor. Devoted father of Marilyn Richter. Adoring grandfather of Elizabeth Werner, Nina Richter and William Krieger. Donations in his memory may be made to the Museum of Modern Art or Recordings for the Blind.

title: RJR Nabisco Appoints Lawyer to Post
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation has named William Rosoff its general counsel and a senior vice president, replacing Robert Sharpe Jr., who is leaving to accept a similar position with Pepsico Inc.

title: Truck Found With Body Had Keys in Ignition
description: The police said yesterday that the keys were left in the ignition of a 1987 Ford Bronco in which a 9-year-old boy was found dead on Sunday, after the truck was winched from a pond at a state park. Initial information from the Division of State Police on Monday that the keys were not in the ignition was incorrect, said John Hagerty, a state police spokesman.

title: CERTAINTEED TO ACQUIRE BIRD CORPORATION
description: The Bird Corporation, a roofing-products maker, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Certainteed Corporation for $40 million, nearly two years after Certainteed dropped its first bid for the company. Certainteed, based in Valley Forge, Pa., is a unit of Compagnie de Saint-Gobain of Paris. It makes fiberglass products and building materials. Bird, based in Norwood, Mass., manufactures asphalt shingles and roll-roofing goods. In May 1996, Certainteed withdrew an offer for Bird on news that United States antitrust authorities were looking into the practices of asphalt shingle makers. Five months later, the Justice Department ended the investigation without taking action. Bird's shares rose 96.875 cents, or 22 percent, to $5.34375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Whitman's Education Focus: Bid to Carve Out Legacy
description: No longer worried about losing her job, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman offered a series of modest proposals today that may not be politically popular but that could ease the property tax burden and improve public schools.

title: St. Paul d'Abbotsford Journal; Quebec Laments Trees, Cruelly Felled by Nature
description: Proud families that have farmed here for four, five and six generations are struggling without heat, electricity or water. But what they most worry about are the trees.

title: Study Finds a Decline In TV Network Violence
description: A study begun three years ago in response to public anxiety about violence on television has found a steady decline in violent fare on the broadcast networks, one area excepted, according to the third and final annual report, released here today.

title: Hostage Incident Ends in Tokyo
description: Add hostage-taking to the problems afflicting the Japanese stock market.

title: Corrections
description: A music review and a picture caption yesterday about a performance by the Orion String Quartet at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday misidentified the violist who joined the ensemble in Dvorak's String Quintet. She is Ida Kavafian; Ani is her sister.

title: Restaurants; To Marseilles on a Carpet of Lavender
description: FOR the last few years, food pundits have predicted the renaissance of simple French cooking in New York restaurants. The prediction proved wrong until last year, when Balthazar and Payard Patisserie and Bistro came along. The owners are clearly on to something, for the two restaurants are so popular that reservations are almost impossible to get. Perhaps it is time to go back for a look at some older examples of the genre.

title: The Minimalist; Two Starches From Naples
description: WHEN I first encountered pasta with potatoes, it struck me as about the most unlikely dish ever, a stewlike combination of little more than the two main ingredients and canned tomatoes. Starch on starch, like a bread sandwich.

title: U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS TO SPIN OFF 4 OF ITS UNITS
description: The U.S. Office Products Company said yesterday that it would spin off four units to shareholders, buy back up to $1 billion of its stock and sell a $270 million stake to the private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc. The company will spin off its corporate travel services, education, print management and technology solutions divisions into four publicly traded companies. U.S. Office Products' stock jumped $2.8125 a share, to $20.5625, in Nasdaq trading of almost 10.7 million shares. Under the stock program, U.S. Office Products, based in Washington, will buy as many as 37 million shares for $27 each. Clayton, Dubilier's $270 million investment will give it 24.9 percent of the shares outstanding. The fund will also receive warrants that if converted could give it a one-third stake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSON, C.P.
description: PEARSON-C.P. On January 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Camilla. Devoted father of C. Pearson, III, Ellen and Nick. A memorial service will be held at 4PM, January 20, 1998, at St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill, PA. Donations in lieu of flowers to the Chestnut Hill Academy, Philadelphia, PA. 19118.

title: Immigrants Won't Solve the Child Care Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Stability in Technology Stocks Seems to Bolster Markets
description: After months of drifting lower, technology stocks are beginning to show some signs of stability.

title: Pedigreed Haul: Antiques Roundup at Police Barracks
description: The most exclusive antiques venue on the East Coast this week may not be Christie's, Sotheby's or even the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, where the Winter Antiques Show begins tomorrow. No, it is a nondescript state troopers' barracks here, home to the Connecticut Western District Major Crime Squad, where hundreds of stolen antiques recovered by the police have just been put up for public viewing. Burglary victims only, by appointment, please.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, JACK J.
description: HOLLAND-Jack J. Beloved husband of the late Natalie. Loving father of Stephen and Margot, and Richard and Lila. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth and Al, Joshua, Leslie, Adam and Lisa, and great-grandfather of Zoe. Dear brother of Emil and Sylvia, and the late Louis and Sadie. Cherished uncle. Services ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC, 11:15 AM, Friday.

title: Advocates of Abortion Rights Report a Rise in Restrictions
description: Access to abortion is now more restricted than at any time since the procedure was legalized 25 years ago, according to a report issued on Tuesday by advocates of abortion rights.

title: Giuliani Calls For a Merger Of 2 Agencies
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed yesterday that the city's Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services be merged with the Department of Health. And, though the merger requires approval by City Council, he went ahead and named a commissioner of the consolidated agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERBERG, BILLIE
description: MERBERG-Billie. Loving wife of the late Nathan. Adored mother of Elliot and Nancy, and Barbara and Fred. Beloved grandmother and great grandmother. Most loved sister of Anna Klein and Mildred Huberman. Services Thursday 11:30AM, at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 76th Rd, Forest Hills.

title: KIMCO REALTY, SHOPPING CENTER OWNER, TO BUY PRICE REIT
description: The Kimco Realty Corporation, one of the largest United States shopping center owners, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Price Real Estate Investment Trust Inc. Kimco is offering common and preferred stock valued at $45 each, or a total of $535 million. It will also assume about $300 million of debt. Shares of Price REIT rose $1.6875, to $43.875, while Kimco fell 18.75 cents a share, to $34.3125. The purchase will increase Kimco's holdings by about 25 percent, to 367 shopping centers.

title: 'Q' for Quebec Electric Loses Political Glow, Too
description: All through the stormy nights of ice and wind that blacked out much of Montreal and the surrounding region for the last week, the stylized Q that is the symbol of Hydro-Quebec blazed like a beacon atop the company's headquarters on Rene Levesque Boulevard.

title: Georgia's Governor Seeks Musical Start for Babies
description: As it is, newborn children in Georgia often come home from the hospital with a bag of free goodies: baby wipes, diapers, instructions about breast feeding and immunizations. Now Gov. Zell Miller wants to throw in a little something extra: a cassette tape or compact disc of classical music.

title: Bally Total Fitness To McCann-Erickson
description: The Bally Total Fitness Corporation in Chicago said yesterday that it had named McCann-Erickson Los Angeles to handle the creative portion of its television advertising account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $35 million. Those duties had been handled in-house for the last year and a half. McCann Los Angeles, part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising unit of the McCann-Erickson World Group, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, was awarded the assignment without a formal review. The Chicago office of Western International Media, also owned by Interpublic, handles media services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, SAUL ISRAEL, M.D.
description: JARCHO-Saul Israel, M.D. We regret the death notice placed in error (1/13/98). The Mount Sinai Alumni

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIN, JOSEPH
description: AIN - Joseph. The Officers, Trustees and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee express their deep sorrow at the loss of our Distinguished Honorary Board member who cared deeply about the plight of Jews overseas and helped guide JDC's programs of Rescue, Relief and Reconstruction. We will miss his warm and engaging personality, his profound commitment and his wise counsel. Jonathan W. Kolker President Michael Schneider Executive Vice President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, ESTER
description: GREENE-Ester. Loving wife of the late Dave, mother of Richard and Paul, grandmother of Jenny, Sarah, Rebecca, Daniella, Matthew and Jessica and sister of Rose Kesten and Ruth Haken. Devoted friend to her daughters-inlaw, Ruth and Zoey. She dedicated her life to promoting the health and well being of children and all people in need. A memorial for her friends and family will be held in the spring.

title: National News Briefs; Aetna to Charge Extra For In Vitro Fertilization
description: Aetna U.S. Healthcare said yesterday that it would charge extra for coverage for in vitro fertilization and other advanced reproductive treatments in places where Aetna had included the procedure as part of its basic coverage. U.S. Healthcare, a subsidiary of Aetna Inc., is a pioneer in reproductive coverage; it began offering in vitro fertilization in 1995.

title: Upper West Side Doctor Charged in Drug Sales
description: A 76-year-old doctor was arrested yesterday afternoon for selling prescriptions for controlled substances to undercover police officers in front of her luxury Upper West Side office and residence, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINOFF, LILLIAN ROSENTHAL
description: RUBINOFF-Lillian Rosenthal. The administration, faculty, students and boards of the Jewish Theological Seminary record with sorrow the death of Lillian Rosenthal Rubinoff. Billie was a staunch supporter of the Seminary for more than three decades through her devoted service to the Torah Fund Campaign. Her contributions to the Seminary and Jewish education will live on through the establishment of the Billie Rosenthal Rubinoff Memorial Scholarship for Women. May her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

title: Club Operator Created 'Drug Supermarkets,' Prosecutor Says
description: Describing scenes of unbridled and flamboyant drug use, a Federal prosecutor charged yesterday that Peter Gatien, the prominent nightclub operator, was a profit-driven Pied Piper who lured young people to his clubs by turning them into ''massive drug supermarkets.''

title: Indonesia Car Maker To Cut 1998 Output
description: PT Astra International, Indonesia's largest auto maker, said yesterday that it would cut 1998 output by 50 percent because growing inflation and unemployment had hurt sales. Astra is not making a specific profit projection yet because the volatility of the rupiah is making accurate predictions difficult, a company spokesman said. Economists expect Indonesia's economy to contract by as much as 7 percent this year after 27 years of expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IACOBELLIS, DR. WILLIAM
description: IACOBELLIS-Dr. William. A resident of Mount Kisco, died Wednesday, January 14, 1998 at home. He was 85 years old. Dr. Iacobellis was born on March 7, 1912 in New York City to Francis and Archangela Iacobellis. While attending St. Ann's Academy in New York City he won the National Oratorical Contest of the U.S. Constitution awarded by the New York Times in 1930. He then graduated from Villanova University where he was on the Dean's List in premed and played Varsity Football. He also played professional football for the Balitmore Eagles in 1933. He earned his medical degree at Temple University Medical School in 1937 and interned at St. Michael's Hospital in Toronto. Dr. Iacobellis had a medical practice in Manhattan in general medicine for 54 years before retiring. During that period of time he delivered over 5,000 babies. Because of his voluntary care of the clergy, he was made honorary member of the order of Marist Brothers in 1964, a Roman Catholic order dedicated to education. Dr. Iacobellis is survived by his wife, Antoinette of Mt. Kisco, 3 sons, Dr. Francis Iacobellis of Rye, N.Y., William of Richboro, Pennsylvania, and Thomas of New Fairfield, Connecticut and 2 daughters, Delia Gorga of New York City and Jeanne Coon of Chappaqua, N.Y. and 12 grandchildren. The funeral services will be held at Oelker and Cox Funeral Home, 262 Main Street, Mt. Kisco. The funeral mass will be held at St. Francis Roman Catholic Church in Mt. Kisco on Saturday, January 17, at 10 A.M. Interment St. Francis Cemetery, Mt. Kisco, NY. Memorial donations may be sent to the Center for Special Studies at The New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68th Street, NY, NY 10128.

title: Files of Reynolds Tobacco Show Effort on the Young
description: Internal records from one of the nation's largest cigarette makers, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, provide new evidence of the extent to which the company for decades courted young smokers, including some as young as 14, regarding them as the future of its business.

title: Chinese Dissident Refuses to Leave for Exile in the U.S.
description: A veteran democracy campaigner who recently called for free labor unions has defied the powerful Ministry of State Security, publicly refusing its demand that he leave China for the United States.

title: Gates Helped Draft Microsoft's Response to Judge
description: A senior Microsoft officer testified today that the company's chairman, William H. Gates, and other executives came up with a plan to give computer makers a choice between selling their equipment with a nonworking version of Windows 95 or continuing to give consumers the popular operating system with Microsoft's Internet browser already included, despite a judge's prohibition.

title: Duncan Will Play For Japanese Team
description: The veteran infielder Mariano Duncan, who played for the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays last season, has reached agreement on a one-year contract with the Yomiuri Giants of the Japanese Central League. The contract is worth between $1.5 million and $2 million, said Tony Attanasio, Duncan's agent.

title: Chip Plant Plans Job Cuts
description: Mitsubishi Semiconductor America Inc. plans to close its wafer fabrication operations in Durham on March 16 and dismiss about 200 employees because of weak sales. The employees will receive a severance package, along with outplacement and counseling services, the company said. The wafer operations began in 1989.

title: Rio Journal; Death's New Sting in Brazil: Removal of Organs
description: Fernanda Santos de Meneses watched her blood course through a dialysis machine, filtering away the impurities that could kill her. Five years ago, when she started the treatments, she was 95th in line for a kidney transplant. Since then, she has crawled up to 81st place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEATHERSTON, ANTHONY GODFREY, JR.
description: FEATHERSTON-Anthony Godfrey, Jr. January 10th, 1998. Of Newton, Massachusetts, formerly of New York City. Beloved father of Anthony G., IV, Jan-Marc, and Carel Pieter. Grandfather of Riley. Brother of Elizabeth A. Featherston-Quick of Edgartown, Mass. Son of the late Dr. Anthony G. and Mabel (McKissack) Featherston. Also survived by his former wife and life long friend Cornelia J. van Kempen-Featherston.

title: Metro Business; Bank of New York To Acquire Broker
description: The Bank of New York Company agreed yesterday to buy the Mendham Capital Group of Roseland, N.J., a private broker-dealer, for an undisclosed amount, as the bank looks to provide additional capital markets services to its corporate clients.

title: Battle for Leadership Is Brewing at Rutgers
description: Three hours before his team played host to Boston College, Kevin Bannon sat in the Rutgers basketball team's fabulous renovated locker room. Players watched music videos on a large screen in a room that is part lounge, part study, part theater.

title: 'Must See,' 'Must Not': Switching Channels at Midseason
description: Television viewers are the Candides of popular culture, eternal optimists finding hope in the least likely places: lurking in the police precinct of ''Brooklyn South,'' hiding in ''Veronica's Closet.'' Won't we ever learn? Exactly halfway through the television season, the most promising new series have already fizzled. Steven Bochco's police officers have made murder, drug-dealing and gay-bashing seem dull; viewers have become the fashion victims of the uneven Kirstie Alley sitcom about a lingerie-catalogue tycoon.

title: Monday Night Testosterone
description: The numbers are certainly astonishing, but the first word that pops to mind is not ''Wow!'' but ''Why?'' Four networks -- ABC, CBS, Fox and ESPN -- have agreed to pay the National Football League $18 billion over eight years, about double the current price, for the right to televise professional football. That works out to something like $35 million per game, including the playoffs.

title: Metro Business; Greenpoint to Buy Stock
description: The Greenpoint Financial Corporation of New York said on Tuesday that it plans to buy back 2.1 million, or 5 percent of its outstanding shares, over an unspecified period of time.

title: INSIDE
description: Smuggling Ring Uncovered

title: Metro Matters; Next Target: Jaywalkers? Hard to Say
description: YESTERDAY, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered his State of the City address, and doubtless he said a lot of interesting stuff. There was something in there about adding a month or two to the school year, and something else about kicking a lot of students out of city universities.

title: 2 Charged With Insider Trading Of Lotus Stock In '95 Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors have brought the first insider trading charges after an investigation into possible illegal trading that occurred in shares of the Lotus Development Corporation before it was bought by I.B.M. in a $3 billion deal in 1995.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Proud Man Resists Help Even With His Sight Gone
description: Silvian Browne is an amiable man, the kind of neighbor who spends Sunday afternoons scrubbing graffiti off the walls of his apartment building in Queens. ''He's always out there helping people and keeping this place in good order,'' said a neighbor, Dolores Samuelson, who called him ''the friendliest guy you'd ever want to meet.''

title: Graduating at 21? The Mayor Says No
description: For the last decade, New York City school officials have puzzled over and sometimes celebrated the tenacity of students who stick with high school beyond the standard four years, staying for five and even seven.

title: Girl Struck by Falling Construction Debris at a School Dies
description: Yan Zhen Zhao, the 16-year-old girl whose skull was fractured by construction debris that fell from atop a Brooklyn elementary school, died yesterday morning at Kings County Hospital Center, where she had lain unconscious since being injured on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, ELINOR
description: SHAPIRO-Elinor. As your grandsons would say ''I bet she's the brightest star in the sky.'' Forever in my heart.

title: Clean the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Give Bowness Seven Reasons to Smile
description: He didn't need a blindfold. Forget the cigarette. With his job on the line tonight, Rick Bowness smiled in the face of certain coaching death and said everything would be fine.

title: Corruption Charges Irritate a Tiny Town Battling Obscurity
description: This tiny blue-collar town, situated just across the Hudson from Manhattan's Upper West Side, has always had something of an identity crisis.

title: Public Eye
description: ALVAR AALTO, the maestro of Finnish furniture design, is either spinning in his grave or flattered beyond belief. This year marks the 100th anniversary of his birth, and a major exhibition of his work will be mounted at the Museum of Modern Art next month.

title: A Faltering Mideast Peace
description: The Middle East peace effort is dying for lack of trust, imagination and determination. That is clear from a new Israeli proposal that suffers from a shortage of all three ingredients required to revive negotiations with the Palestinians. The Cabinet's idea of an acceptable plan for the next set of Israeli withdrawals from the West Bank is laced with conditions and burdened by a sense that the Government no longer has its heart in making peace with the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, TERENCE MAGIE
description: NOLAN-Terence Magie, 56. Of NYC and Southampton, NY on January 13, 1998. Loving husband of Thea Elliott Nolan, devoted father of Christopher Nolan and Hilary Nolan Penlington; grandfather of Patrick Terence Penlington, born January 14. Beloved son of Marion Hance Nolan Slater and the late Arthur J. Nolan; dear brother of Barry Nolan and of Sheila Nolan Fuller. He was a Managing Director and co-founder of the investment advisory firm of Berkshire Asset Management, Inc. and was President of Nolan Securities Corp. In 1958 he was graduated from Mount Hermon School and in 1962 from Lafayette College. He worked with Wertheim & Co and other Wall Street firms, eventually joining Morgan Stanley & Co. where he served for nine years, becoming a principal. His clubs included The Union club, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Sharon (CT) Golf Club and The Bond Club of New York; he was a past President of the Lafayette College Maroon Club. Funeral services will be held in NYC Thursday, January 15 at 5 P.M. at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Ave. at 64th Street. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his name to the Lafayette College Maroon Club, 307 Markle Hall, Easton, PA. 18042.

title: Queensboro Closed After Ship Accident
description: The Queensboro Bridge was closed last night after the radar unit of a 650-foot cargo ship struck the bridge's underside just before midnight, causing minor structural damage, officials said.

title: An Iranian Says Gesture From U.S. Is Called For
description: As President Mohammad Khatami receives both praise and criticism in Iran for his public overture to the American people last week, one of his advisers and family members said today that the Clinton Administration should respond with a gesture of its own.

title: Export, Asia's Key to Survival, Could Crash Into U.S. Barriers
description: It is one of those embarrassing things that executives are forced to do these days to try to save their companies.

title: Finance Chiefs Will Meet in Spring on Asia
description: The Treasury Department said today that it was planning a meeting for sometime this spring of the finance ministers from the major industrial nations, Asian nations and other countries that have been affected by the financial turmoil in Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONBERG, ANN
description: RONBERG-Ann. Passed away January 11th, 1998. Formerly of Jerusalem and New Haven, Connecticut in her 92nd year. Predeceased by her husband, Heinz and eleven siblings. Survived by her children, Rabbi Yaacov (Nina) Rone and Dr. Baruch Ronberg; grandchildren, Efrem and Rafi Rone, Elana (Dr. Daniel) Finn, Elon (Jennifer) Eitan and Eldad Ronberg; step-grandchildren, Larry, Amy and Daniel Reinharz; and two great-grandchildren. Shiva will be at Rabbi Yaacov Rone's, 315 West 70 Street, #

title: Microsoft Rebuffed in Bid to Exclude Expert in Antitrust Case
description: In a strongly worded rebuke to Microsoft, a Federal judge yesterday denied the company's request to remove an Internet law expert appointed to investigate and recommend a resolution in the software giant's antitrust battle with the Justice Department.

title: Metro Business; MCS Moving to Park Ave.
description: MCS Business Solutions, the retail arm of Canon U.S.A., the American subsidiary of Canon Inc., is moving its headquarters and showroom from 633 Third Avenue to larger quarters at 125 Park Avenue, company officials said yesterday.

title: Environmentalists and Hearst Heirs Locked in Battle at San Simeon
description: It spreads like a rolling green and brown blanket from the mountains to the sea, 77,000 acres of pristine ranch land crowned by the private castle of treasures that William Randolph Hearst called La Cuesta Encantada, his Enchanted Hill.

title: Israel Sets Tight Limits for Any West Bank Pullback
description: The Israeli Government adopted sweeping guidelines today on what it would regard as vital interests in any future negotiations regarding the West Bank.

title: Currents; THE KINDEST CUTS -- If Matisse Had Made Tables
description: The spirit of Matisse -- or at least the look of his famous cutouts -- lives on in the Tut tables by Marissa Brown and Havely Graves, partners in Brown Graves Design in TriBeCa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWARD, MARION W. (VANESSA)
description: COWARD-Marion W. (Vanessa). Of Bedford, New York on January 4, 1998 at 99-1/2. She was the last survivor of the ''White'' sisters, ie. Katharine W. Caulkins and Jane S.W. Canfield. She is survived by one of her two daughters, Jenifer (Gregg) Sims and 3 grandchildren, Peter and Jenifer Sims and James Marquand, the son of the late Sue Marquand. Memorial services on Friday, January 16 at 11 A.M., St. Matthews Church, Bedford, NY. Contributions in her memory can be made to Planned Parenthood of New York City for the Jane Canfield fund for Women's Health Care, 26 Bleecker Street, N.Y.C. 10012 or your favorite charity.

title: Immigrants Won't Solve the Child Care Crisis; Green-Card Lottery
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Hans Burgers, new business development director at Euro RSCG, Amsterdam, a unit of Havas Advertising, was named to the new position of worldwide business development director at Euro RSCG Worldwide, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERNICK, GLORIA
description: VERNICK-Gloria. On January 13. 1998. Of Albertson, L.I. Beloved wife of Irving. Devoted mother of Gail and Peter Burchard, Kevin and Karla Vernick, Melissa and Jeffrey Shangold. Dear sister of Stewart Karp. Cherished grandmother of Amanda, Caroline, Audrey, Dylan and Noah. Services today 11AM at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, LI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROHMAN, TRUDE
description: FROHMAN-Trude. Beloved wife of the late Ludwig, devoted aunt, great-aunt and friend. Private funeral services were held.

title: Bridge; The Year's Strongest Field Is Gathered in The Hague
description: By any measure, the Cap Gemini World Top tournament beginning in the Hague today will be the strongest of the year, the world championships not excepted. The field of 16 invited pairs includes all 3 French pairs that won the world title in Tunisia three months ago and the best partnerships from Italy, Poland, Norway, Britain and the home country.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about changes at The Washington Post referred incorrectly to the paper's interview with President-elect Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, published on Jan. 9. It was not the first by a Western newspaper; an interview with Mr. Kim by Bernard Krisher, publisher of The Cambodia Daily, appeared in The International Herald Tribune on Jan. 5.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts by the Brooklyn Academy of Music to revitalize its neighborhood misspelled the surname of the academy's chairman. He is Bruce Ratner, not Rattner.

title: To Get Landmark, Call Daughter
description: How to get your house designated a landmark? Make sure REBA WIST drives by.

title: Events; Artful and Architectural Portraits
description: Art Through Architecture

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ULLMANN, ERIC
description: ULLMANN-Eric. Six years. Time does not heal all wounds, I miss you more than ever. Lily

title: Immigrants Won't Solve the Child Care Crisis; Broader Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, SAMUEL
description: GOLDBERGER-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Esther and beloved father and father-in-law of Steve and Wanda Gilbert, Ronald and Amy Goldberger, Howard and Lynn Gross and beloved grandfather of Wayne, Adam, Joshua and Jordan Gilbert, Jacob and Edward Goldberger and Jennifer and Jeffrey Gross. Funeral services to be held at 1:45 P.M. on Thursday, January 15 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

title: A consortium of independent grocers is stepping up efforts to compete with supermarket chains.
description: AS large supermarket chains merge to form even bigger regional giants and more retailers push into the grocery business, small supermarket operators are looking for ways to hold their own.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINNEGAN, ANN C. LEARY, R.N.
description: FINNEGAN-Ann C. Leary, R.N. 40th birthday remembrance. Jan. 15, 1958-Oct. 29, 1989. Our beloved daughter, sister and friend to all.

title: Forest Plan Leaves Too Many Trees at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KINGSLEY, CHARLES R.
description: KINGSLEY-Charles R. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Charles R. Kingsley will be held Sunday, February 1, at 1 PM at the Eastview Technology Center, 350 Main Street, White Plains. For more information call Westchester ARC at 914-428-8330 X 338

title: Helen Haje, 74, Dies; Organizer of U.S. Arabs
description: Helen Haje, a Washington public relations woman who championed Arab-American interests with such good-natured fervor that she became gadfly and godmother to the Arab-American movement in the United States, died on Monday at a hospital near her home in Washington. She was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERRENDER, GIRARD F., MD.
description: OBERRENDER-Girard F., MD. Of Ithaca, NY died on January 7, 1998 at the age of 104. Dr. Oberrender was on the staff at Lenox Hill Hospital for sixty years, Director of Otolaryngology from 1945 to 1959 and President of the Medical Board five times. He also held positions with the NYU Medical School, Cornell Medical Center/NY Hospital, Nursing & Child's Hospital, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and Roosevelt Hospital. He was an Honorary Police Surgeon for the NYCPD for many years and a physician to the New York Yankees. He was a member of the Camp Fire Club of America, Century Association, Anglers Club of NY, NY Athletic Club, Charaka Club, NY Academy of Medicine, Medical Strollers of NY, and Phi Delta Theta fraternity. He is survived by his son, Girard F. Oberrender, Jr. and daughter-in-law Martha Worth Oberrender, three grandchildren, Girard F. Oberrender III, Ann Oberrender Noyes, and Robert Worth Oberrender, and nine great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Camp Fire Conservation Fund, 230 Campfire Road, Chappaqua, New York 10514, or the charity of your choice.

title: Essay; 'Look -- I'm Still Here'
description: Sometimes a politician's ad lib is actually off the cuff. Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu -- always falling, never fallen -- rose to meet the astonished world press after surviving yet another challenge to his leadership with ''Look! [in the sense of ''Behold!''] I'm still here.''

title: In Cassell's Absence, Douglas Slips Into the Driver's Seat
description: As far as Sherman Douglas is concerned, there is nothing to get excited about.

title: Starr Questions Hillary Clinton on F.B.I. Files
description: Prosecutors questioned Hillary Rodham Clinton today on an issue that embarrassed her husband's Administration during the 1996 election year: the gathering by White House aides of confidential background files on former Republican appointees.

title: A Death Notice Is Very Premature
description: Like Mark Twain, DR. SAUL JARCHO has been telling people that reports of his death were exaggerated. The Mount Sinai Alumni Association ran a paid death notice in The New York Times on Tuesday. But it was a different Saul Jarcho, a 90-year-old cousin, who had died last week. CYNDI GRUBER, the alumni director at Mount Sinai, called in the death notice after she saw one for a Saul Jarcho in The Times on Saturday. She assumed that it was for Dr. Jarcho, a 91-year-old medical historian and retired internist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ALLAN A.
description: GREENBERG-Allan A. Allan was a colleague, a mentor, a friend, and an integral part of our lives and our business since he joined The Adler Group in 1959. Our sympathy to his wife Ida, and to his entire family. His memory will be with us always. The Adler Group Louise Grunwald Robert Liberman Robert Savitt

title: Cloutier Gets Start, But Doesn't Last Long
description: The choice facing Rangers Coach Colin Campbell tonight was between the red-hot backup goalie, Dan Cloutier, and the struggling but proven veteran, Mike Richter.

title: Gatti Is Trying Not to Tip the Scales
description: As Arturo Gatti prepares for his junior lightweight bout against Angel (El Diablo) Manfredy, a pound of flesh has taken on a double meaning.

title: Whitman Signs Freeze On Taxes for Elderly
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed into law yesterday a measure to freeze property taxes at 1997 levels for about 280,000 low-income elderly and disabled residents.

title: Former Suspect Cleared In 1992 Murder Case
description: Nine days after the police arrested three new suspects on charges that they killed a retired police sergeant during an armed robbery in 1992, a judge dropped criminal charges yesterday against one of the two men who had previously been accused of the murder.

title: In Search of Madness
description: Is Theodore Kaczynski competent? Competent for what? To stand trial? Almost certainly, yes. To be criminally accountable for his alleged crimes? Almost surely, yes. To conduct his own defense? In all likelihood, provided the court is prepared to manage his behavior in a clear and forceful manner.

title: Food Safety Comes First
description: To the Editor:

title: Humanoids Make Scientists Paranoids
description: In the news according to ''Prey,'' there is one small ecological detail that slipped by the global warming conference in Kyoto, Japan, last month. Warming has caused a new species of beings to evolve. They look human, but their brains work faster than the fastest computers. And, quite inconveniently, most are serial killers determined to wipe out humankind and become the dominant species. That is how this surprisingly lively new series came by its droll promotional slogan, ''You've just been bumped down the food chain.''

title: Japan Plans New Financial Terms for Old Privatization
description: The Government disclosed plans today to change financial terms of the decade-old privatization of the Japan National Railways, a revision likely to have a chilling effect on future privatizations and on foreign investment.

title: A $1,500 Chair at the Antiques Show? Dream On
description: I HAVE a bee in my bonnet: I want to buy a pretty antique chair. I think my apartment needs it to look more grown up. Nothing extravagant: I like things simple, elegant. I can't afford -- and wouldn't want -- to collect a period look, but I can see investing in what decorators mysteriously call ''the accent piece.''

title: DuPont Prize for 'Frontline'
description: ''Frontline,'' the public television documentary series produced by WGBH-TV in Boston, won the highest award, the Gold Baton, last night at the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards.

title: PRESSED BY I.M.F., INDONESIA ACCEPTS ECONOMIC REFORMS
description: Under intense international pressure, President Suharto agreed today to a broad program of austerity measures aimed at halting the steep slide of the Indonesian economy.

title: Sea Route Opening for Gamblers From New York City
description: After traveling for years to Atlantic City or Connecticut to play blackjack and yank slot-machine levers, New Yorkers will soon be able to board gambling boats in Manhattan, Staten Island and Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Indicts Bronx Lawyer Accused of Abetting a Drug Gang
description: A Bronx lawyer was indicted yesterday on Federal charges of racketeering and conspiracy to distribute narcotics in connection with his legal representation of suspects in a heroin gang case. In addition, 17 other members of the gang, known as the Maisonet organization, were indicted on various charges. Four were accused of murdering rival dealers.

title: Our Towns; Poor Credit? Rent-to-Moan Is Wooing You
description: THE brown velvetlike sofa in the window of the Rent-A-Center on Bergenline Avenue has puffy Michelin Man arms, wood trim and a matching love seat. The other day, a young couple with two toddlers, two elderly women in dressy church hats and Justina Tomas, a waitress at a local restaurant, were all gazing at this sofa as though it were an exotic creature.

title: McCall Says McCaughey Ross Should Quit State Job if She Challenges Pataki
description: In a sign of discord at the highest ranks of the New York Democratic Party, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said yesterday that Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross should resign if she intends to campaign against her boss and former political ally, Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Iraq Is Warned To Open Sites To U.N. Team
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to rebuke Iraq for blocking weapons inspections and said it must honor its promise to allow inspectors ''full, unconditional and immediate access'' to sites suspected of concealing biological, chemical and nuclear weapons. But the Council stopped short of saying what it would do if the Iraqis did not comply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, LOUIS JOHN
description: COHEN-Louis John, 61. January 13, 1998. ''Home is the fisherman, home to the sea.'' Dear husband of Susan. Devoted father of Judd and Donna, Kenneth and Jacqueline. Adored grandpa of Erica, Brandon and Daniel. He was a graduate of Woodmere High School and Boston University. As an insurance broker, he spent 37 years with Leon Rosenblatt Inc., where his last position was President. He will be sorrowfully missed by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, Louis would request that donations be made to the Send-A-Kid Fishing Program C/O The Long Island Fisherman, 14 Ramsey Road, Shirley, NY 11967. Services to be held Friday, January 16 at 12:30PM, BoulevardRiverside Park West Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Plan for Mayor's School Wins First Round
description: By a 5-to-4 vote, the Jersey City Council gave preliminary approval last night to a plan by Mayor Bret D. Schundler to house a charter school he founded in a building constructed through $9 million in bonds issued by the city.

title: Rolls-Royce Obtains Jet Engine Partner
description: Lucas Varity P.L.C. signed a contract yesterday worth $:2 billion ($3.3 billion) in sales to supply electronic controls and other parts for Rolls-Royce engines used on Boeing and Airbus jetliners set to begin flying after 2000. As part of the accord, Lucas Varity, a British automotive and aerospace parts maker, will give about $:75 million to Rolls-Royce to help it develop three new models of its Trent engines to power the larger, longer-range jetliners. In return, it will take between 3 percent and 5 percent of each engine's revenue.

title: Samaranch Says China Is Losing Votes for 2008
description: In the wake of a second doping scandal at the world swimming championships, China has jeopardized its chances should it decide to bid on the 2008 Summer Games, the president of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday.

title: Conoco Buying Gas Land
description: Conoco Inc. said today that it had agreed to purchase natural gas production and exploration acreage in New Mexico's San Juan Basin from the Amoco Corporation for $56.9 million. Conoco acquired proven reserves estimated at 101 billion cubic feet of natural gas and production of 12.5 million cubic feet of natural gas a day. Conoco, based in Houston, is an oil and gas unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: Henning in Line to Join Parcells As Coach of Jets' Quarterbacks
description: Bill Parcells is expected to name Dan Henning, a longtime friend, as the Jets' quarterback coach.

title: De Montebello Gets Broader Post to Run Met When Luers Retires
description: Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 20 years and known to millions of visitors as the mellifluous voice on the museum's audio guides, has been named to the new position of chief executive officer, putting him fully in charge of all museum operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, CHARLOTTE
description: GORDON-Charlotte. On January 13, 1998. Beloved mother of Paul Theil, dear mother-in-law of Cindy, loving grandmother of Jules, Emily and Michael. Memorial service Friday, January 16th., 10:30 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Louima Says His Attackers Did Not Yell 'Giuliani Time'
description: Abner Louima has retracted a claim that police officers shouted ''It's Giuliani time!'' as they allegedly tortured him in the bathroom of a Brooklyn precinct house last summer, one of his lawyers confirmed yesterday.

title: ALLIANZ A.G. UNIT TO OBTAIN 35% STAKE IN LIFE USA HOLDING
description: A unit of Allianz A.G., Germany's largest insurer, agreed yesterday to buy as much as 35 percent of the rapidly growing Life USA Holding Inc. for an estimated $171 million. Life USA, which specializes in sales of universal life insurance and annuities, will continue to sell Allianz insurance and annuities. As part of the transaction, the Allianz Life Insurance Company of North America will buy $20 million of newly issued Life USA stock in each of the next five years. Shares of Life USA rose $2, to $15.50. As part of the transaction, Life USA will issue Allianz Life 2.43 million common shares at $12.34 each to convert a $30 million debenture Allianz Life bought in 1995. It will buy 239,165 additional shares at $12.36 a share.

title: Thomas J. Stanton, 69, Banker; Restored Jersey City Waterfront
description: Thomas J. Stanton Jr., a Jersey City banker who helped turn his hometown's waterfront from a moldering stretch of rotten piers and rusty rail yards into a sleek corporate district that came to be known as the Gold Coast, died on Jan. 6 at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 69.

title: Photographers at Home; Living Lens: Self-Portraits Of Home
description: AS the photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson observed, there is a decision in every moment. It is as true of designing a home as it is of taking a picture.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When a 'socially responsible' fund has a problem of its own.
description: INVESTORS expect certain things of ''socially responsible'' mutual funds: a disdain for tobacco, liquor and gambling companies, weapons makers and nuclear power producers. A preference for corporations that treat their employees well. And generally above-board behavior, certainly including an adherence to the law.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Currents; DANCING IN THE STREETS -- Do-Si-Do, and Away They Go
description: Here's one cure for a crosswalk crisis: Cued by traffic lights and laws permitting diagonal crossing, pedestrians in the crowded Old Town district of Pasadena, Calif., turn into modern dancers, pasodobling past one another. Four sets of drivers wait patiently as the street becomes a spectacle: bodies converge but somehow rarely collide.

title: Immigrants Won't Solve the Child Care Crisis; Family Role Is Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF: Just How Level A Playing Field?; Casey Martin Says He Needs A Cart to Play; the PGA Says No
description: Is a professional golf organization entitled to make its own rules, or should it be forced to obey broad civil rights disabilities laws that could change the competitive nature of the game?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, FLORENCE
description: WEINSTEIN-Florence, 86. Of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on January 13, 1998. Loving wife of the late Abraham, mother of Ellen and Jerry, sister of Leo and Roz and the late Herbert. She has four grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, Thursday, at 10 A.M.

title: Immigrants Won't Solve the Child Care Crisis; Parent Cooperatives
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PLATINUM AND PALLADIUM JUMP. The April contract for platinum jumped $15.80, to $388 an ounce. Palladium also rose, with the March contract hitting an 18-year high before slipping some to finish at $239.55, up $3.15. Both metals were pushed higher by talk of disruption in Russian deliveries.

title: Outbid on Pro Football, NBC Retains 'E.R.' in Record Pact
description: NBC agreed today to a deal to pay Warner Brothers, the studio that owns the drama ''E.R.,'' about $13 million an episode over the next three years for a total of more than $850 million, making the medical series the most expensive television show ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, KRANE, LESLIE D.
description: O'CONNOR-KRANE-Leslie D., 45. Of Highland Mills, N.Y. on January 12, 1998 in New York City. Beloved wife of Eric J. Loving mother of Bradley J. and Corey K. Devoted daughter of Grace Krane and sister of Joan Gottesfeld. Funeral services today at 10 A.M., at the Quackenbush Funeral Home, 117 Maple Avenue, Monroe, N.Y. Interment will be in Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, KATHLEEN
description: BUTLER-Kathleen. Died January 10, 1998, at The Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Hightstown, NJ. Born January 4, 1914 in New York City and educated in NYC schools. She attended Hunter College High School and Drake Business College. Mrs. Butler resided in Little Silver, NJ and in Silver Spring, MD for many years. She leaves her husband of fiftyseven years Herbert Butler of Hightstown and two sons, David Butler, Audio Engineer of Newton, Mass and Alan Butler, Business Consulting Manager of Pittsfield, Mass. Also one sister Maureen Florio of North Haven, CT. Mrs. Butler was a past president of The Goddard Space Flight Center Wive's Club in Greenbelt, MD. She enjoyed playing the piano, ballroom dancing, reading, letter writing and flower arranging, particularly of the Dahlias grown by her husband. Mrs. Butler has belonged to The Women's Community Club of Eatontown, NJ and The Little Silver Historical Society. A memorial service will be held at Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, at 2 P.M., on Thursday, January 22, 1998. Kathleen donated her body for the advancement of medical science. Please make contributions to The American Parkinson's Disease Association, 1250 Highland Blvd, Staten Island, New York 10305-1946.

title: Mayor Urges Tougher Standards And Longer Terms for Schools
description: In a State of the City address signaling no retreat from the tough-love style of governing that won him a second term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called yesterday for striking changes to New York City's school system, from extending the school calendar by a month to requiring that high school students either graduate in five years or continue their education at night and on weekends.

title: At the Winter X Games, No Limit to Excitement
description: The ESPN Winter X Games and their organizers tend to accentuate the exceptional -- spelled ''Xceptional.'' It is part of what the coordinators of the Winter X Games, a sports competition first developed for television last year, find so tantalizing about extreme athletics.

title: Calendar; Building New York City
description: 100 Years of Architecture

title: Currents; TIP THE TAP -- The Nintendo Faucet
description: Dornbracht, a German company, claims to have brought interactive cyberculture to the bath. Sure enough, its new single-lever faucet, named Tip Tap, looks like a joystick. But, hey, all you get is water!

title: Immigrants Pack Agency, Trying to Beat A Deadline
description: Scores of illegal immigrants around the metropolitan region crowded offices of the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday as a midnight expiration loomed on a Federal law that allowed them to stay in the country while applying for residency.

title: Lucent Forms Venture With Singapore Maker
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that its Microelectronics unit and Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing Ltd. of Singapore had agreed to form a $1 billion joint venture to manufacture integrated circuits. The joint-venture company will be 51 percent owned by Lucent. The company will be in Chartered's semiconductor fabrication campus at the Woodlands Industrial Park in Singapore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MAX
description: KATZ-Max, 89. Of Morristown, N.J. formerly of Greenport and Sag Harbor, N.Y. on January 12, 1998. Beloved husband of Lillian (nee Chrobersky). Survived also by nieces Gertrude Katz of Sag Harbor, Ann Wolman of Wayne, N.J. and Harriet Katz of Clifton Pk. N.Y. and nephews Steve Katz of W. Haven, CT., and Dr. Harry Grossman of North Brunswick, New Jersey, and numerous great nieces and nephews. Services were held on Wednesday, Jan. 14, at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home. Interment Hevre Kodetia Jewish Cemetery, Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEMSKY, SEYMOUR
description: ZEMSKY-Seymour. The Officers, Board of Directors and Members of Engineers Country Club mourn the passing of their beloved member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the Zemsky family.

title: Tracking H.I.V. Infections in New York
description: The case for requiring doctors in New York State to report all cases of H.I.V. infection to public health authorities is becoming irresistible. This week even the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's largest AIDS service organization, reversed its longstanding opposition and urged the state to monitor the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The organization thus joined previous calls for H.I.V. tracking issued by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and by other AIDS organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, DAVID
description: COHN-David. On January 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Ethel. Father of Marcia Goldstein and Joyce Spitzer. Services private.

title: Chinese Economic Leaders Read a Warning in Asian Crisis
description: Over the last few weeks, Chinese leaders have watched with growing alarm as financial crises engulfed other Asian countries, knowing that China's own fragile banking system is deeply vulnerable as well.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Retreat After Bouncing Around
description: The prices of Treasury securities fell slightly yesterday after bouncing around as investor attention shifted among a variety of factors, from the Asian turmoil to the United States stock market to the economy and inflation.

title: South Korean Unions Agree To Negotiate on Job Layoffs
description: Labor unions backed down today from threats of nationwide strikes and agreed for the first time to discuss the possibility of layoffs, which are regarded as necessary for the country to rebuild its economy with international help.

title: Broker Pleads Guilty in Stock Fraud
description: A New York stockbroker who prosecutors say orchestrated an extensive securities fraud -- and made more than $3 million in the process -- pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy to commit securities fraud and money laundering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLPE, CAESER A., M.D.
description: VOLPE-Caeser A., M.D. On Jan 11, 1998, beloved husband of Nancy, dearest father of the late Linda. Former Medical Director of New York State Workmens Compensation Board.

title: GOODRICH AND FREEDOM CHEMICAL IN $375 MILLION DEAL
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company agreed yesterday to acquire the Freedom Chemical Company, a maker of specialty and fine chemicals, for $375 million. Goodrich, based in Richfield, Ohio, is an aircraft systems and specialty-chemicals maker with 1996 revenue of $2.24 billion. Freedom Chemical, based in Radnor, Pa., is majority-owned by Joseph, Littlejohn & Levy, a private investment firm. It had 1997 sales of $300 million, 40 percent of which came from overseas. The acquisition will increase the size of Goodrich's specialty chemicals business by 30 percent, the company said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Microsoft Battle Intensifies at Hearing
description: Microsoft's chief executive, William H. Gates, helped come up with a response to a judge's order to stop forcing the Microsoft Explorer Internet browser on computer makers, a company executive testified. The Government said the testimony showed that Microsoft was deliberately thumbing its nose at the judge.

title: Civic Parties Of Pageantry And Pledges; It's Swearing-In Season For Council Members
description: By the time City Councilman Angel Rodriguez raised his hand to take the oath of office, the 300 people gathered in a Brooklyn grade school auditorium had already sat through the singing of ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' and the Puerto Rican anthem, ''La Borinquena.'' They had witnessed a colorful lion dance performed by the Latin American Chinese Association Cultural Dancers and a presentation of flags by a Boy Scout troop -- followed by an invocation by a Roman Catholic priest, translated from English into Spanish and then Mandarin.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: ASIAN MARKET UPTURNS BOLSTER YEN. A rebound in Asian stock markets and the visits of American and International Monetary Fund officials to Indonesia lifted the yen from five-and-a-half-year lows. Yesterday, the yen rose further, with the dollar slipping to 130.92 yen from 131.72 on Tuesday.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Mountain Flower

title: Retail Sales Increased 0.7% in December
description: Retailers rang up their biggest sales gain in half a year during December, helped by last-minute holiday shoppers as well as strong demand for cars, and analysts and retailers said consumers were likely to continue fueling economic growth early this year.

title: A Diva Returns In a Storm Of Gospel And Glitz
description: The commotion started before the crowd had even settled in for Patti LaBelle's performance at the St. James Theater on Tuesday. People strained to see, then burst into applause as the Rev. Al Sharpton proceeded to his third-row seat. The crowd went wilder still when the songwriters and performers Nick Ashford and Valerie Simpson took their places near Mr. Sharpton.

title: On F.A.A. Tape, Nearby Pilots Describe Explosion of Flight 800
description: There were no signs of emotion, but a tape made public today of the terse transmissions between air traffic controllers and airline pilots in the moments after the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 in July 1996 reveals tension in the voices of pilots who saw the fireball and momentary disbelief by the controller who had just been talking with the T.W.A. pilots.

title: Composer's Child Wants a Memento
description: MARY RODGERS, the daughter of RICHARD RODGERS, knows what she wants from the upcoming revival of ''The Sound of Music'' -- a scale model of the set, under a clear plastic cover, like the one she was given following the Lincoln Center production of ''Carousel'' in 1993.

title: 1-800-Flowers Narrows Review
description: 1-800-Flowers said yesterday that it had narrowed a review on its account to three agencies from nine. Billings on the account, less than $10 million in recent years, are expected to increase to $12 million to $15 million.

title: In America; Mounting A War On Bias
description: Andrew Cuomo likes to tell the story of Antonina Ippolito. Mr. Cuomo is the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Mrs. Ippolito is an Italian immigrant who came to this country 37 years ago, raised a family and, with her husband, acquired some rental property in Buffalo, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; Give Martin A Ticket To Ride
description: IN golf conversations, Tiger Woods has been upstaged by a former Stanford teammate.

title: 3 Aliens Visit Earth: Take Us to Your Culture
description: You've got to love a theater troupe that opens its show with a spaceship made of a skillet lid and aluminum foil that wobbles along a wire toward the stage.

title: More Paintings by Schiele Face Ownership Questions
description: The Austrian collector at the center of a fierce dispute over the ownership of two Egon Schiele paintings plundered by the Nazis says that 16 other works by Schiele in musuems and private collections in the United States share the same provenance as one of the two being questioned.

title: Sales of G3 Computer Lift Apple Back to Profitability
description: Apple Computer Inc. today delivered on the return to profitability promised last week by Steven P. Jobs, the company's co-founder and interim chief executive.

title: Immigrants Won't Solve the Child Care Crisis; Train 'Welfare Mothers'
description: To the Editor:

title: Science vs. the Divine, With Suspense and Passion
description: ENDURING LOVE

title: New York Tries to Clean Up Ash Heap in the Caribbean
description: Two years ago, New York City created a Trade Waste Commission charged with cleaning up the city's corruption-plagued commercial trash hauling industry.

title: Jews Remember Forced Labor Camps in Wartime Swiss Refuge
description: Manfred Alexander was 21 in 1941 when, with his fiancee and her mother, he entered Switzerland from France. There, he says, a new nightmare began.

title: National News Briefs; College Head Apologizes For Using Racial Slur
description: The president of the University of Florida, John Lombardi, said on Tuesday that he was apologizing for a derogatory remark about the man named last week as chancellor of the State University System.

title: CABLETRON TO BUY REMAINING SHARES OF YAGO SYSTEMS
description: Cabletron Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the 76 percent of Yago Systems Inc. it does not own for about $87.8 million in stock to acquire equipment that connects computer networks at high speeds. Cabletron will exchange 6.1 million of its shares for the Yago stake. Provisions for price changes in Cabletron stock could value the closely held Yago at as much as $213 million. Yago will be a separate unit of Cabletron and keep its 50 employees and operations in Sunnyvale, Calif. Cabletron said it would issue as many as 5.5 million additional shares if its stock did not reach $35 a share 18 months after the purchase was completed. Shares of Cabletron rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $14.25.

title: The N.F.L.'s Windfall Can Benefit Owners, Players and Fans
description: It is as if the goal posts at either end of the field had been replaced by giant curvy dollar signs, as if the hash marks were now cent marks, as if the whistle ending each play sounded like a loud, trendy ''ka-ching,'' the newest way to signify cash earned and deposited.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC GILL, ROBERT F.
