description: Mc GILL-Robert F. On January 11, 1998. Family will receive friends on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 P.M., at the Mc Mahon Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, White Plains. 914-949-7777. Memorial service Saturday 10 AM, St. Andrews Episcopal Church, Hartsdale.

title: Leftist Lawyer Reaches Right for Audience
description: THOUGH Ron Kuby enjoys audience participation as much as any radio talk-show host, some of his biggest fans are unable to call in.

title: AMERICAN RESOURCES TO ADD TECO GULF OF MEXICO ASSETS
description: American Resources Offshores Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the offshore Gulf of Mexico assets of Teco Oil and Gas Inc. for $57.5 million. American Resources, based in Versailles, Ky., is a unit of American Resources of Delaware Inc. The unit produces oil and gas and owns pipelines and production sites in the Gulf Coast area and Appalachia. Teco Oil and Gas is a unit of Teco Energy Inc., an energy holding company based in Tampa, Fla.

title: Clinton Agrees to Funds For New York City Police
description: President Clinton has agreed to use Federal anti-crime funds to help Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani pay for the 1,600 new police officers that the Mayor proposed hiring in his inaugural address earlier this month, officials said yesterday.

title: Clinton Race Panel Hears Emotional Tales at Phoenix Forum
description: President's Clinton's advisory board on race made its first foray outside the Washington area today and was subjected to two sides of the national conversation on race: erudition and emotion.

title: MONSANTO SAYS IT MAY SELL OR REVAMP 2 OPTICAL UNITS
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it was considering a sale, revamping or other alternatives for its Orcolite and Diamonex optical and ophthalmic lenses divisions, as it looks to focus on its life-sciences business. The Orcolite division, based in Azusa, Calif., makes eyeglass lenses and other eye products, while Diamonex, based in Allentown, Pa., makes scratch-resistant coatings for sunglasses and glasses, as well as grocery-store checkout scanners. The two divisions employ about 700 people. The St. Louis-based Monsanto said last week that it might also sell or reorganize its Solaris lawn-and-garden unit. The moves are part of Monsanto's effort to focus on agricultural chemicals, seed and biotechnology, and pharmaceuticals.

title: Initiative to Save Theaters May Drive Out Artists; Plays in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts in America; Where Mountains and Theater Make a Nice Mix
description: In a slick double-breasted suit, the legendary gangster Al Capone shuffles across the stage and swings high his jaunty boater as he croons a tune fit for a barbershop quartet. Body bags are flung stage right with macabre frequency as dancers writhe, jolt, jerk, bounce and pant, ''Save us, Eliot!'' A footnote in the life of Untouchable Eliot Ness made musical theater? Yes, a wry black comedy that is refreshingly unexpected.

title: All Those Billions (and It Sounds So Reasonable)
description: Who's nuts now? Four years ago when Fox overturned the sports economy by paying $1.58 billion to get into the National Football League, many snickered at the insolence and imprudence of Rupert Murdoch's broadcast weblet. They wondered if Bart Simpson would diagram plays with a crayon. But the expectations of folly never came true.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Interpublic Opens A Sports Unit
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York said yesterday that it had opened a sports marketing unit named Octagon, to symbolize eight aspects of sports marketing like licensing, merchandising and event marketing. Octagon is composed of Interpublic's sports marketing agency, Advantage International in Washington, and API Associates in London, a sports marketing agency in which Interpublic owns a 60 percent interest.

title: Mets Pleased By Maturity Of Pitcher From Japan
description: Masato Yoshii is a pitcher from Japan and he has signed to play for a team in New York, the Mets. But his similarities with the Yankees' Hideki Irabu end there. In fact, Yoshii is something of an anti-Irabu.

title: Tips on Bank Robbers Lead Police to Brooklyn
description: Police investigators began scouring the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn yesterday after receiving dozens of tips from residents who said they knew the three suspects wanted in Tuesday's $1.6 million bank robbery at the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GRAAFF, ELSE
description: de GRAAFF-Else. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the de Graaff family on the loss of their mother and grandmother, Else de Graaff. She was a righteous woman who personified the qualities of elegance, grace and extraordinary dignity. Mrs. de Graaff was a Golden Founder of the Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem, supported the Jesselson Heart Center and was a member of the Women's Division Board. The people of Jerusalem will be eternally grateful to Else de Graaff. May the family have warm and loving memories of a very special, caring mother and grandmother. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Mrs. Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Menno Ratzker, President Lee Weinbach, President Women's Division Sidney Adler, Treasurer Dr. Stuart Tauber, Exec. Dir.

title: Algeria Rebuffs a Peace Delegation From the European Union
description: Algeria's military-backed Government reversed itself today and said it would reject a mission that the 15-nation European Union wanted to send this weekend to see what could be done to stop the killings of civilians there, which number in the tens of thousands in a six-year civil war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITALE, ROBERT E.
description: VITALE-Robert E. Of Hastingson-Hudson, New York. Husband of Jessie, brother of Emelia Alliegro, Eleanor DiPrima, Evelyn Cordova and Edward Vitale. Mass 10 A.M., Saturday, January 17, 1998 Sacred Heart Church, Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, New York. Memorials to the Alzheimer's Assoc., 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York 10605, appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOIMAN, SYDELLE K.
description: BOIMAN-Sydelle K. at 72. Loving wife of Harold. Devoted mother of Larry and Jane Rubinstein. Sister of Jack Krellman. Adored grandmother of Adam, David and Andee. Gone but not forgotten. Services will be on Friday 10 A.M., at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris. Interment will follow at the Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Residential Resales
description: Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANGER, MARTIN A.
description: SCHLANGER-Martin A. The family of Martin A. Schlanger records with great sadness his sudden passing on Monday, January 12, 1998 at Longboat Key, Florida. The chairman of Martin Auto Group, Inc., he was a member of the National Automobile Dealer's Association. He moved to Florida in 1986 from Manhattan and New Rochelle. He was an avid tennis player and lived with such joie de vivre that he was often mistaken for his grandson's father. He attended Temple Sinai in Sarasota and was a former member of Congregation Anshe Shalom in New Rochelle. A devoted husband, brother, father and grandfather, he is survived by his beloved wife of 40 years, Janet (nee Kassoff), his revered brother, Harold (Francine), his dear children Ellen (Dr. Kenneth) Bregg, and Mark E. (Randi) Schlanger, and his cherished grandsons Lee Schlanger and Matthew Bregg. Funeral services are Thursday, January 15, 1998 at 12 noon at Temple Sinai in Sarasota, Florida. Interment will follow at Temple Beth Sholom Cemetery. Memorials to the Martin A. Schlanger Memorial Fund, c/o Temple Sinai, 1802 Kenilworth St., Sarasota, Florida 34231 or CoScep (Coalition to Stop Children's Exposure to Pesticides), PO Box 15853, Sarasota, Florida 34277-1853. For information Tishman Funeral Home, Sarasota, Florida.

title: Peregrine Dismisses 600 of Its Employees
description: Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., the failed investment bank based in Hong Kong, dismissed about 600 of its 700 employees in Hong Kong after a liquidator was appointed to dispose of the bank, employees said yesterday. The remaining employees include executives and support staff in Peregrine's corporate finance and equity capital markets departments. Peregrine is seeking a buyer for those businesses, which were its most profitable.

title: As Asia's Economic Turmoil Deepens, Pentagon Chief Reassures Indonesia
description: As financial crises continued to rumble across Asia, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen met here today with President Suharto to discuss expanding security ties with the beleaguered Indonesian Government.

title: Times Company Names New Vice President
description: Cynthia H. Augustine has been named senior vice president for human resources of The New York Times Company.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Dining section yesterday with an article about unusual meat dishes referred incorrectly to the buffalo steak shown. It is served at Fifty Seven Fifty Seven in the Four Seasons hotel, not at the Four Seasons restaurant.

title: In Vichy Trial, Papon Stands Not Silent, but Mute
description: BORDEAUX  Marc Robert, the red-robed prosecutor, leans forward just a bit more and with his quiet, nonhectoring voice asks, a reasonable question presuming a reasonable answer, why a Nazi request to arrest Americans in 1942 could be ignored, but not one concerning Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPP, JOHN
description: RAPP-John. The Voluntary Association of Senior Citizens Activities (VASCA) mourns the loss of our friend and Executive Vice President. His generous efforts enhanced the lives of many senior citizens. Our sympathies to his wife, Joy Rapp, and all friends and family members.

title: Giuliani Signs a Ban On Many Tobacco Ads
description: After nearly a month of negotiations with the City Council, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed legislation yesterday that would effectively prohibit outdoor tobacco advertising in most of the city.

title: Personal Shopper; Elegant Tools to Feed Any Appetite
description: NO one was ever born with a stainless steel spoon in his mouth. But you could do worse: stainless steel needs no polishing, can be washed in a dishwasher and needs no special storage. Its combination of chromium, nickel and steel makes it almost indestructible.

title: Strain of Flu From Down Under Brings a Global Misery for Many
description: John Speredakos still has a nasty cough, a voice not as strong as an actor needs and an unusual story about this year's bad-and-getting-worse flu season. He is an understudy in the well-received Broadway revival of ''A View From the Bridge,'' and his big moment came, as it does for understudies, when the lead, Anthony LaPaglia, could not go on. Mr. LaPaglia had the flu.

title: STARWOOD AGREES TO BUY 4 FORMER RITZ-CARLTON HOTELS
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four former Ritz-Carlton hotels for $334 million, as part of its plan to start a new chain of luxury hotels. The purchase consists of a 257-room hotel in Aspen, Colo.; a 232-room hotel in Houston; a 213-room hotel in Washington, and a 214-room hotel in New York. Under the agreement, more than half of the acquisition will be in Starwood stock, and the remainder will be in cash. The seller is the billionaire Saudi businessman, Sheik Abdul Aziz bin Ibrahim al-Ibrahim. In the last year Starwood, a real estate investment trust, has agreed to acquire the Westin hotel chain and the ITT Corporation. The Phoenix-based Starwood plans to rename the New York hotel immediately with the Westin name.

title: Already at the Bottom, Knights Sink Some More
description: The Scarlet Knights of Rutgers know that they will have to scrap for victories where they can find them. Tonight they had a last-place team in their own gym and still came away empty.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTERN WATER CO., San Diego, said it had terminated talks to buy Vidler Water Co. from Global Equity Corp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, ARTHUR
description: DOYLE-Arthur. On Jan. 13, 1998. Beloved son of Ellen Dennehy and Thomas M. Doyle. Dear brother of Mary Ellen, Noreen, Thomas, Patrick, Rev. Martin, SJ, Vincent, Brendan and his wife Vivienne, and Denis. Devoted uncle of Kathryn, Elizabeth and Christian. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 St, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 11:15AM at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 E 14th St.

title: Forest Plan Leaves Too Many Trees at Risk; Preserve Our Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, FRANCIS A., JR.
description: GORMAN-Francis A., Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Francis A. Gorman, Jr. A life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: When Prince Asks, You Return Favor
description: When PRINCE PHILIP is in your wedding party, can you turn down a request for a favor later? ''No, you really can't,'' said BARBARA WAINSCOTT, who met Queen Elizabeth's husband when she was the New York director of the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration in 1976. When she married DAVID BERGER, a lawyer, last year, the prince happily took part. Now she has signed on as deputy chairman for North America of the Duke of Edinburgh's Award World Fellowship, which organizes Outward Bound-type adventures.

title: Belfast Buries Apolitical Victim of Sectarian Strife
description: To lugubrious tunes played by a single bagpiper on a cold, rainy and windy afternoon, the 3,233d person killed in 29 years of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland was buried today on a muddy hillside in West Belfast, another sad statistic.

title: Knicks, on a Win-One-Lose-One Stall, to Welcome Rest
description: For a week, the Knicks have been unable to catch their breath. Their last four games have been filled with emotion and tension, each one coming down to the final shot. Now, with three days off before a pair of games against the lesser lights of the National Basketball Association, Coach Jeff Van Gundy is hoping that his team will not lose the focus that has allowed it to survive.

title: Initiative to Save Theaters May Drive Out Artists; Turning a Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; TOUCHABLE ART -- A Healing Place in the Sun
description: ''Most gardens are about the miracles of life, but this one deviates from the traditional,'' said Topher Delaney, a landscape artist with the San Francisco firm of Delaney Cochran & Castillo. The Leichtag Family Healing Garden was carved from a parking lot at the San Diego Children's Hospital and Health Center; it is a sanctuary for families who have hoped for miracles -- in vain.

title: Hisham Mubarak Dies at 35; Rights Campaigner in Egypt
description: Hisham Mubarak, a political analyst and one of Egypt's leading human-rights advocates, died on Monday night of a heart attack. He was 35. Mr. Mubarak's death stunned Cairo's small but growing human-rights community, many of whose members he had trained and intellectually nourished. Egyptian intellectuals regarded the passionate young lawyer as the best of the country's new generation of civil libertarians and advocates for social justice.

title: Sports of The Times; Ask Not for Whom The Buzzer Sounds
description: THE fingerprints and scratches on the throat of P. J. Carlesimo have faded and healed now, the fingerprints and scratches produced by the choke hold from Latrell Sprewell, his star guard, which were evident on the coach's neck for a week afterward. But in the mind's eye of many, those malicious marks, administered about a month and a half ago, remain vivid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRIN, GERTRUDE
description: PERRIN-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Myles D. Perrin, sister of Bob Daran, mother of the late Robert Perrin and Marjorie Seligman, grandmother of Peter Seligman. Passed at the age of 90, at the Heartland Health Care Center in Boynton Beach, FL., on January 10. Memorial service to be held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY on Thursday January 15 at 10 A.M.

title: Rio Tinto Seeks To Buy Back Stock
description: Rio Tinto P.L.C. of London said yesterday that it would ask its shareholders permission to buy back up to 10 percent of its stock after slowing demand for copper caused its shares to fall 35 percent in seven months. Rio Tinto, the world's biggest mining company, said the move was spurred by a British decision to abolish a tax measure that made buybacks inefficient.

title: 2 Arrested in Beating And Robbery of Nun
description: The Paterson police arrested two men on Tuesday in the Dec. 14 beating and robbery of a nun who spent a week in intensive care and had to undergo facial surgery, the city announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARLTON, REGINA (NEE WYNNE)
description: CHARLTON - Regina (nee Wynne), on January 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Merrill. Loving sister of Sylvia Cook and the late Edwin Wynne. Cherished friend of Dan Berlinghoff. Also survived by her nephew Eric L. Wynne. Memorial service Friday, 3 P.M. at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Widow to Face G.O.P. Maverick in House Runoff
description: In a blow to national Republican leaders, State Assemblyman Tom J. Bordonaro, a conservative maverick, edged the chosen candidate of his party's establishment in a special Congressional primary on Tuesday and will face the widow of Representative Walter Capps in a runoff to fill the seat left vacant by Mr. Capps's death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, WALTER T. JR.
description: HUGHES-Walter T. Jr., 82. Of Longboat Key, FL, died Dec. 16, 1997. Survived by wife Barbara, son Thomas of Birmingham, MI, daughter Marilyn Leddy of Winnetka, IL, three grandchildren. Donations to the Salvation Army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKINNEY, MARIELLE
description: McKINNEY-Marielle. Of Middleburg, Virginia. On January 12, in New York, after a short illness. Beloved wife of Robert M. McKinney, cherished mother of Edmee de Montmollin Firth and Laurent de Montmollin, and stepmother of Robin McKinney Martin, devoted grandmother of Marie-Louise, John and Olivia Slocum, and Laura and Elliott Martin. Funeral on Thursday, January 15, at 4 PM, Church of St. Vincent Ferrer at 66th Street and Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, 43 West 23rd Street, New York 10010.

title: Big Deal; A Rooftop Palazzo With a Split Personality
description: Manhattan

title: Cheaper Oil Propels Import Price Drop
description: Competitive pressure, a drop in oil prices and the financial turmoil in Asia helped knock the prices of imported goods down six-tenths of 1 percent in December and 4.9 percent last year, the largest decline since the Government began collecting such data in 1983.

title: Making Books; Is the Agent Really Needed?
description: If the most powerful person in book publishing is the one who can write the checks, the publisher, then how powerful, and important, is the literary agent? The answer is very, for the agent is the author's pendant.

title: Initiative to Save Theaters May Drive Out Artists
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Turnaround at Apple Surprisingly Strong

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ALVIN, MD.
description: GREENBERG-Alvin, MD. On January 13th, 1998. Loving and adoring husband of Rita, cherished and beloved father of Caren and Linda and devoted father-inlaw of Stephen. Loving grandfather of Jonathan and Daniel. Dear brother of Wallace. Service 1 PM today at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: $2.8 Million for Tiny Site Vital to Tower
description: Only after Reuters American Holdings and the Rudin Organization signed a deal last October to build a 32-story headquarters in Times Square did the two partners realize that the site for the project was not quite big enough.

title: Composer Wins Freedom, but It's Temporary
description: The composer Charles Ives made his living running an insurance firm, and wrote his puckish, iconoclastic music in his spare time. Now the American Academy of Arts and Letters, using the proceeds from a fund started with the royalties from performances of Ives's music, has established the Charles Ives Living, a $225,000 prize to be awarded to a composer in three annual installments of $75,000. The one condition of the award is that for the three- year term of the prize, the recipient must do what Ives could not: give up the day job and concentrate fully on composition.

title: Voice of a Museum, Perhaps of Art
description: Philippe de Montebello was almost at a loss for words yesterday -- almost -- when asked to cite the highlights of his directorship of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a reign now extended with expanded authority.

title: Justices Hear Arguments in Suit Against Election Agency
description: In a case of widespread interest to groups that lobby on behalf of causes, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Federal Election Commission had properly refused to require the American Israel Public Affairs Committee to disclose the sources and uses of money.

title: Telling Stories Of Love, Loss and Racism
description: Racism, AIDS, love and loss. No choreographer has a corner on these themes, of course, but Ronald K. Brown delves into them with originality as well as passion. Few today can match the depth of his ability to marry message and medium.

title: Veneration Gap: Stones and Spice an Odd Mix
description: Lana Donnelly was happy last night. Brenna Senno was not.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an Israeli Government declaration setting conditions for a further withdrawal from Israeli-occupied territory in the West Bank misidentified the diplomatic document cited by Israel as authorization for such conditions. The document, a ''note for the record,'' was prepared a year ago by Dennis Ross, the Clinton Administration's chief mediator for the Middle East, as an attachment to an accord on a partial Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank town of Hebron. It includes general obligations that the Israelis now say will be met if the Palestinian Authority complies with the new, specific demands.

title: U.S. Strikes at Smuggling Ring That Exploited Foreign Nurses
description: More than 500 nurses were smuggled into the United States from the Philippines and South Korea over the last several years by an illegal ring that capitalized on the nationwide nursing shortage plaguing hospitals and nursing homes earlier in the decade, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, JOHN TAYLOR, MD.
description: ELLIS-John Taylor, MD. January 10th, Rhode Island Hospital, Providence. Born Lufkin, Texas, 1920; graduated from Univ. of Texas Austin and Northwestern Univ. Medical School, Chicago. Captain, Brooke General Hospital, San Antonio. Came to Cornel Univ. Medical College, 1948, in Pathology. Remained there until 1994, except for six years, Chairman 1962-68, Emory Univ. Medical School, Atlanta; serving as consultant, NY Hospital Medical Center, Queens, 1994-97. Devoted husband for 55 years of Marian Caldwell. Father of Evelyn Floy, George Caldwell and John Taylor IV. Loving grandfather of Adrienne and Katherine of NY, Evan, Kelsey and Jesse of Rhode Island. Burial in Dallas, TX.

title: Clinton to Give Deposition at Lawyer's Office, Aide Confirms
description: The White House confirmed today that President Clinton would be privately deposed on Saturday at his lawyer's office, thus moving Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit to the brink of the public trial scheduled for May.

title: Justice Dept. Is Investigating Labor Secretary
description: The Justice Department has been considering whether to seek the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate Labor Secretary Alexis Herman's ties to an African businessman who has said he gave her money in exchange for access to the White House, Federal officials said this evening.

title: The Mayor's Curtain-Raiser
description: New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, likes to address his audience as if he were still a prosecutor trying to win over a balky jury. In his State of the City speech yesterday the Mayor wandered from the text so frequently that he threatened to break former Gov. Mario Cuomo's record for sending a teleprompter spinning. But Mr. Giuliani never really veered from the thread of his message. There are still plenty of wrongs to be righted, and he intends to continue being the man in the white hat.

title: Time to Call a Sears Repairman; A Turnaround Is Sidetracked by Its Own Oversell
description: Clearly, 1997 was not Sears, Roebuck & Company's finest hour.

title: Economic Scene; Critics: The I.M.F. is misguided. Skeptics: Too much rot in Asia.
description: WHO lost Asia? No, the vandals aren't at the gates of Bangkok, Seoul or Jakarta. But with Thailand on the brink of depression, South Korea in shock over the rude end to its economic miracle and Indonesia in a succession crisis, finger-pointing seems irresistible.

title: Electric Cable Under L.I. Sound Proposed to Help Lower Rates
description: Long Islanders have long been charged the most expensive electric rates in North America, a problem caused not only by the high cost of producing power here but also by the island's geographic isolation from cheaper power generated elsewhere.

title: Missing Trend, Some Cities See Murders Rise
description: ''See that alley there?''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Currents; MARBLE BATH -- Nothing 'Faux' About It
description: Maybe bathrooms look better as kitchens.

title: Currents; HAVE GENERATOR, WILL TRAVEL -- Theatrical Lighting Goes Architectural
description: Lights can be hot -- especially Irideon AR-500 floodlights.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now don't you feel smarter already? Smart enough to vote for this budget item, I hope.''

title: Treasury Securities End Mixed After New Inflation Warning
description: Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday after bouncing around a bit on weakness in the stock market, an inflation warning from a senior Federal Reserve official, new evidence of an economic slowdown and a glut of corporate bond offerings.

title: Sic Transit Glorious Advertising; In Manhattan, the Vehicle Is Becoming the Message
description: Madison Avenue's credo these days seems to be: if it moves, put an ad on it.

title: Mining One Message in a Blur of World Influences
description: The cosmically minded, dashingly mustached Greek-born composer, Yanni, celebrated multiculturalism at Radio City on Wednesday night by having his Venezuelan flutist play a 3,500-year-old Armenian oboe, the duduk. ''In an ever-shrinking world, diversity must be embraced, not feared,'' Yanni intoned, as Pedro Eustache lifted his lips to the instrument and played a melancholy line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKMAN, AL
description: GLUCKMAN-Al. We are saddened to learn of our dear friend's death. Al, your good deeds and fond memories will always be remembered. To Esther, Natalie and Phyllis, our most heartfelt sympathy. Irwin Bernstein Sidney Bernstein & Son Lingerie

title: Lita S. Osmundsen, 71, an Anthropologist
description: Lita S. Osmundsen, retired president of the Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research, died last Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. She was 71 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Clinton Would End Amtrak Subsidies, Senators Complain
description: The Clinton Administration has tentatively decided to cut off all operating subsidies for Amtrak in the next Federal budget, a move that would threaten the future of the passenger-railroad network, six Senators said today.

title: Indonesia Agrees to I.M.F.'s Tough Medicine
description: The fourth-largest nation in the world began a new and risky chapter in its history today when President Suharto agreed to far-ranging economic reforms that if carried out would overturn the country's entrenched ways of doing business and curb its economic growth.

title: New Law Cracks Down On Health-Fraud Doctors
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday signed into law a bill that sharply increases the penalties for health insurance fraud and allows courts to permanently revoke the licenses of doctors who are involved in insurance fraud cases.

title: Man Arrested as Lookout In Murder of Girl, 13
description: A man who allegedly acted as a lookout during the fatal Jan. 7 stabbing and robbery of a popular 13-year-old girl in Flushing, Queens, was arrested yesterday, the police said. The man, Raymond McFarlane, 32, was a neighbor of the victim.

title: Bowness Can Relax, For Now
description: When the Islanders' losing streak reached eight games, the speculation began on Coach Rick Bowness's job status. When the Islanders suffered their worst defeat of the season, an 8-2 loss to the Montreal Canadiens, for loss No. 9 in a row on Jan. 8, the rumors grew. The following day, Mike Milbury, the Islanders' general manager, went public with a warning to Bowness: his job was in jeopardy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANHORNE, HARRIET
description: VANHORNE-Harriet. On January 15, 1998. Beloved sister of Ida and Helen. Loving aunt of two nephews. Many beloved friends. Interment private.

title: Furniture Of Frontier New England
description: In the 1600's, when America's early colonists said, ''Go west,'' they meant western Massachusetts. Today, it's hard to think of the Connecticut River Valley as a frontier outpost, but that's what it was: 48 were killed in Deerfield, Mass., during a 1704 French and Indian attack. The town rebuilt itself continuously.

title: Celebrating Families and Physiques
description: Jody Oberfelder's imaginative choreography set all sorts of people dancing in ''Physically Inclined,'' a program of new and recent works presented by Jody Oberfelder Dance Projects on Wednesday.

title: Palestinians Dismiss Terms Set by Israelis For a Pullout
description: The Palestinians today rejected the conditions Israel has set for peace talks to continue and called on President Clinton to ''stand next to those who stand for peace.''

title: A Restoration Romp Full of Self-Indulgent Delight
description: Despite the fact that ''The Libertine'' traces the dissolute and violent life of John Wilmot, the second Earl of Rochester, the play, by Stephen Jeffreys, is a romp through theater, poetry and petty politics in England during the reign of Charles II, but at times it stumbles into a sentimentality that rakes like Rochester would scorn.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST DYNASTY MINES LTD., Calgary, Alberta, agreed to sell its Energy Process Services unit to Equatorial Energy Inc. for about $40 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARLTON, REGINA (NEE WYNNE)
description: CHARLTON - Regina (nee Wynne), on January 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Merrill. Loving sister of Sylvia Cook and the late Edwin Wynne. Cherished friend of Dan Berlinghoff. Also survived by her nephew Eric L. Wynne. Memorial service Friday, 3 P.M. at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Arabs Want Israel to Feel U.S. Pressure
description: With the Israeli Government taking a tougher stand on Middle East peace, Arab leaders are making clear their hope that President Clinton will use a meeting in Washington next week to take unparalleled steps to persuade Israel to change course.

title: Weighing Abortion In a High-Tech Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Change on Earnings
description: Beginning today, The New York Times is changing the way it reports company earnings, to reflect new accounting rules.

title: The Look May Be Familiar, But the Trucks Are All New
description: First, Dodge introduced a radically different Ram truck for 1994. Then Ford offered a distinctive, much improved F-150 in 1996. This fall, General Motors will try to regain momentum with new full-size pickups that replace designs dating to 1987. Prototypes of the 1999 Chevrolet Silverado, top right and interior view, and GMC Sierra, lower right, are on display at the Detroit auto show. The new models are larger and roomier, with stronger frames, more powerful V8 engines and standard four-wheel anti-lock brakes. But G.M. seems somewhat defensive about the evolutionary, conservative styling; a preview film features a Chevy owner who implies that stylish competing trucks are ''feminine.'' Last year, Ford's F-Series -- the most popular vehicle in the world -- outsold G.M.'s full-size trucks by 21,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, ARTHUR
description: DOYLE-Arthur. On Jan. 13, 1998. Beloved son of Ellen Dennehy and Thomas M. Doyle. Dear brother of Mary Ellen, Noreen, Thomas, Patrick, Rev. Martin, SJ, Vincent, Brendan and his wife Vivienne, and Denis. Devoted uncle of Kathryn, Elizabeth and Christian. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 St, Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 11:15AM at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 E 14th St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTMAN, LEAH
description: GUTMAN-Leah. On behalf of our ''Kingsbrook Family'', Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center and its constituent institutes express with deep and profound sorrow the untimely loss of Leah Gutman, beloved wife of Milton M. Gutman, CPA, Chief Executive Officer. She was a lovely, loving and righteous person...a woman of valor. We extend heartfelt sympathies and condolences to the Gutman family: Leiby and Chaya, Itzik, Sara, Mordecai, Chaim Zvi, and Hannah. Robert J. Benowitz, Esq., President David Minkin, President Emeritus Stanley Mandel, Chairman, Board of Trustees Herbert Yassky, President, Rutland Nursing Home Charles A. Indelicato, Chief Operating Officer Mohammad Zahir, M.D., Executive Medical Advisor Elliott Gamberg, Chief Financial Officer Linda Brady, M.D., Medical Director/ Director Neurology/Psychiatry Jane O'Rourke, Director, Nursing

title: U.S. Gets Russia's Firm Vow To Halt Missile Aid to Iran
description: The United States Government has received concrete promises of action by the Russian Government to stop Russian companies and scientists from assisting Iran's ballistic missile program, senior American officials say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINSCH, FRANCES
description: HINSCH-Frances. Of Garden City, N.Y. on January 15, 1998. Loving mother of Tom and Ellen. Grandmother of Robert and Matthew and great grandmother of Meghan and Hayden. Most loved sister of Louise Fitzgerald. Donations may be sent to the Garden City Public Library, Garden City, N.Y. 11530.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday referring to a front-page article in some editions about a program of austerity measures accepted by Indonesia misstated the amount of the country's rescue package from the International Monetary Fund. It is $40 billion, not $40 million.

title: Hard to Beat the Devil, a Detective Finds
description: On the eve of his execution, a scarily intense serial killer (Elias Koteas) taunts Detective John Hobbes (Denzel Washington), the officer who caught him, and hints at revenge. The killer also speaks threateningly in a mysterious language, which is presumed (none too plausibly) to be Dutch. And then in the gas chamber, moments before his death, he launches into a nastily meaningful rendition of ''Time Is on My Side,'' the ballad that recurs throughout the occult thriller ''Fallen.'' Only in Hollywood does the Devil have a favorite Rolling Stones song.

title: It's Molinari Vs. Hynes In Sentencing Of Policeman
description: Longstanding animosities between Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island and District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn erupted in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday when Mr. Molinari accused Mr. Hynes of waging a politically motivated prosecution of a police officer who lives on Staten Island.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MEXICAN PESO FALLS. The peso slipped against the dollar yesterday as it continued to struggle to regain the ground lost after the financial turmoil in Asia sent world stock markets lower in October. The value of the peso fell 8.8 percent on Oct. 27 and has only bounced back 2.9 percent since.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZASLOW, ESTHER GOODMAN
description: ZASLOW - Esther Goodman. Riverdale Temple congrational family mourns the passing of Esther Goodman Zaslow, the beloved mother of their devoted Board Member, Marvin Goodman and extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Stephen D. Franklin Sol Blumenstock, President of Congregation Honorable Irving Rosen, President Mens Club

title: Possible Candidate for Top Job Departs From Lehman Brothers
description: Steven J. Berger, a top banker at Lehman Brothers Inc. who had been mentioned as a potential leader of the firm, has left the company.

title: The Neediest Cases; Dentist Goes On the Road For Smiles Of a Child
description: Elvir Dincer has been terrified of going to the dentist ever since that day 30 years ago when a dentist at his Brooklyn public school fumbled the drill and bloodied Elvir's mouth.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Passion For Preachers

title: Profit Off 3.3% At Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that operating earnings in its fiscal second quarter fell 3.3 percent as expenses surged and trading revenue declined.

title: Childs Is Unfazed by Boos and Trade Talk
description: Chris Childs insists that he does not read newspapers or listen to the sports talk shows. But he could not avoid the critique offered up by the Madison Square Garden crowd on Sunday night, when the fans met his introduction with a loud chorus of boos.

title: Love, Guilt, Immolation and Gypsies
description: A production as dramatically inert as the Metropolitan Opera's staging of ''Il Trovatore'' affords an operagoer plenty of time to develop a peculiar theory or two. The one that suggested itself most forcefully when Verdi's tragedy returned to the Met's repertory on Wednesday evening was that if beauty can fade with time, perhaps ugliness can too. This may seem counterintuitive. Yet here was Fabrizio Melano's bleak production, looking not much different from the way it did at its premiere in 1987, except that what seemed grotesque back then now seems merely bland.

title: Arrogance at the School Board
description: The death of 16-year-old Yan Zhen Zhao, who was killed by falling construction debris outside a Brooklyn elementary school, has inflicted enormous pain on her family and schoolmates. Miss Zhao's death is all the more troubling because a construction crew had failed to erect an adequately protective scaffolding over the area where she was struck, as city law requires.

title: McCaughey Ross Receives $2 Million From Husband
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross has received a $2.25 million contribution to her gubernatorial campaign from her multimillionaire husband, giving a boost to her effort to transform herself from spurned sidekick to avenging giant-slayer by ousting Gov. George E. Pataki from office.

title: People
description: * John R. Puglisi, president at Lowe McAdams Health Care, New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was named to the additional position of chief executive, succeeding Irwin C. Gerson, who was named chairman emeritus.

title: Order That Halted Work On Trump Project Is Lifted
description: Work is resuming at Donald J. Trump's luxury apartment tower on the Upper West Side of Manhattan for the first time in nearly three months since city building inspectors discovered that defective concrete slabs in the building might crumble under the weight of the structure.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR PRICE DROPS. The price of raw sugar fell yesterday as the March contract dropped almost four-tenths of a cent, or 3.2 percent, to 11.17 cents a pound. Worry about canceled orders from Asia has been undermining the price since Dec. 29, when sugar hit its recent high of 12.36 cents a pound.

title: Officials, Fearing Falling Masonry, Close Sidewalk
description: The police blocked off the sidewalk in front of a Times Square hotel yesterday after building inspectors determined that masonry on the facade was in danger of falling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, LOUIS JOHN
description: COHEN-Louis John, 61. January 13, 1998. ''Home is the fisherman, home to the sea.'' Dear husband of Susan. Devoted father of Judd and Donna, Kenneth and Jacqueline. Adored grandpa of Erica, Brandon and Daniel. He was a graduate of Woodmere High School and Boston University. As an insurance broker, he spent 37 years with Leon Rosenblatt Inc., where his last position was President. He will be sorrowfully missed by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, Louis would request that donations be made to the Send-A-Kid Fishing Program C/O The Long Island Fisherman, 14 Ramsey Road, Shirley, NY 11967. Services to be held Friday, January 16 at 12:30PM, BoulevardRiverside Park West Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Late-Term Abortion Issue Pulls Republicans in Two Directions
description: Once again, a tug-of-war over abortion is dividing the Republican Party, and two developments in California this week underscore the strains.

title: Chinese Restaurants
description: New Yorkers love Chinese food but often settle for less than the best because it's convenient. At good Chinese restaurants like these, you can both reacquaint yourself with long-forgotten flavors and explore lesser-known regional cuisines. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Earnings Reports Push Major Stock Market Indexes Down
description: Uncertainty about the outlook for corporate earnings pushed investors toward the exits yesterday as major stock market indexes posted their first declines of the week.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Juliao Sarmento

title: Woman Admits Attempt To Have Husband Killed
description: A 38-year-old former advertising executive admitted yesterday in Federal District Court in Trenton that she tried to hire a hit man to kill her estranged husband and his girlfriend in order to recover the husband's life insurance policy, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Pakistan's Lost Millions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODMAN, MORRIS
description: RODMAN-Morris. The Board of Directors and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem mourn the death of Morris Rodman, Founder of the Ruth Youth Wing of the Israel Museum. He was enormously generous to the Israel Museum for more than thirty years. We send heartfelt condolences to his daughter Betsy and the entire family. Teddy Kollek, President, I.M. James Snyder, Anne and Jerome Fisher Dir, I.M. Judy Steinhardt President, A.F.I.M. Nurit Shilo-Cohen, Chief Curator Ruth Youth Wing, I.M.

title: Harnisch Regroups Following Lost Season
description: Some players become free agents at the perfect time, Pete Harnisch was saying last week. Darryl Kile, his former teammate in Houston, had a monster season in 1997 and in the off season signed a three-year contract worth more than $8 million annually.

title: Pataki Backs A School Year Of 12 Months
description: Gov. George E. Pataki intends to propose legislation that would bolster Chancellor Rudy Crew's effort to send some students to school in the summer in order to relieve school overcrowding the rest of the year, his aides said today.

title: Vladimir Prelog, 91, Is Dead; Swiss Chemist Won the Nobel
description: Vladimir Prelog, a Swiss chemist whose pioneering insights into the shape of complex biological molecules were honored with the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1975, died on Jan. 7 in Zurich. He was 91.

title: Debut of DVD Exceeds Rivals'
description: With the compact digital video disk (DVD) past its first holidays, assessments are flowing. Hard figures and interpretations vary, but the CD with a movie on it, touted in some quarters as the eventual successor to the videocassette, appears to have made a respectable sales debut. Still, things could have been better.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLOUGH, PIERRE
description: BULLOUGH-Pierre. Age 44. On January 14, 1998 in Southampton New York, of complications due to AIDS. Beloved son of Henriette and the late Arnold Bullough. Dear brother of Claudine Achter, Eugene, Jeffrey and David Bullough and special nieces and nephews. He is survived by his longtime companion Mel Katzman. He possessed the ability to see the simple as special, thereby bringing pleasure to all who loved and knew him. Funeral services will be held in Salt Lake City, Utah, Saturday, January 17. Donations in his memory may be made to the David Rogers, M.D. Center for HIV/AIDS Care, 335 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, New York 11968.

title: PIONEER STANDARD IN $121 MILLION DEAL FOR DICKENS DATA
description: Pioneer Standard Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Dickens Data Systems for $121 million. Dickens Data Systems, a privately held company based in Roswell, Ga., is a distributor of I.B.M. computer systems, peripherals and services. It had sales of $340 million in 1997. Pioneer, based in Cleveland, is a distributor of industrial electronic components and computer products. For the six months ended Sept. 30, it had $828 million in sales. Pioneer's stock was unchanged yesterday at $13.75 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Finding Life in a 1929 Curiosity
description: The young man, just off the train from Schenectady, is eager, hopeful and as dumb as a post. He is an obvious figure of sport for the weary, worldly Manhattanites among whom he has suddenly found himself. How couldn't he be with his hair sticking up, his chunky wool suit and his rhapsodies about such New York phenomena as the Holland Tunnel and what he insists on calling ''the Goddess of Liberty''?

title: Lusting To Conquer In Bed, Ball And Court
description: Ever wondered what happens behind closed doors in the walnut-paneled offices of $400-an-hour criminal defense lawyers?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EAMES, DAVID TODD
description: EAMES-David Todd. On January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Sarah Frost Eames. Father of Peter and Lee. Son of Phyllis and Edwin. Brother of Mona Steiger and Lori Rusack. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, January 18, at 9:45 A.M. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Why Computer Jobs Go Begging; Hire Foreign Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Monday about ''Keats,'' by Andrew Motion, included an incorrect publication date, from the book, for the revised edition of another Keats biography, Aileen Ward's ''John Keats: The Making of a Poet.'' It appeared in 1986, not 1968.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Rebounded in '97
description: Advertising pages in magazines rose in 1997 after declining in 1996, according to annual totals released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTRONOVO, WILLIAM A.
description: CASTRONOVO-William A., 84. Of Aventura, Florida, passed away January 15, 1998. Former resident of NYC and past President of Staley Elevator Company. Survived by wife Catherine, son Daniel W. Leo (Cindee), grandchildren, Dan, Kevin, Susan, Stephen and Stacie and seven great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Saturday 3 P.M., at Cofer Kolski Combs Funeral Home, Miami, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family suggest contributions to the Alzheimer's Association, 11900 Biscayne Boulevard, Miami, FL. 33181-2753.

title: Jerusalem Journal; Lost Thunder of Ramadan Echoes in the Old City
description: As dusk fell over East Jerusalem this evening and people hurried home to break the daylong fast of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, Rajai Sandouka trudged up the path of a graveyard overlooking the walled Old City.

title: Browsing Through America's Past
description: For 44 years, the Winter Antiques Show has transformed the old drill shed of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 67th Street into a giant collector's cabinet, offering visitors a bit of everything, from antiquities and rare porcelains to medieval art and 20th-century silver. A promotional blurb for this year's event promises that ''a diverse group of internationally known exhibitors make this year's show the best ever.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Joan Nelson

title: Metro Business; Connecticut to Look At Met Life Practices
description: Connecticut is joining three other states in investigating whether the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the nation's second largest insurer, engaged in deceptive sales practices, state officials announced yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Revised I.M.F. Bailout Could Transform Indonesia

title: An Ethnic Morass Is Returned to Croatia
description: There were two ceremonies today in this scared and neglected corner of Croatia.

title: Utrecht, A Radiant Exception
description: Baroque art is a horizon-crowding mountain range of legendary people and places. Its peaks are fabulous: the Rome of Caravaggio, the Amsterdam of Rembrandt. But so are its less visited valleys, fertile esthetic ecosystems half hidden from view but teeming with life.

title: Memphis Grocer Purchase
description: Albertson's Inc. will acquire Seessel Holdings from Bruno's Inc. for $88 million to enter the Memphis grocery market. Seessel, the second-largest grocer in Memphis, has 10 stores there and a 15 percent market share. As a property of Bruno's, it is effectively owned by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the leveraged-buyout firm. Albertson's operates 865 food and drug stores in 20 Western, Midwestern and Southern states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, FREDA
description: DIAMOND-Freda. The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art mourns the loss of Freda Diamond, a distinguished graduate of the college's School of Art. An internationally influential designer and consultant, she produced innovative, popular designs for glassware, dinnerware, furniture, lighting fixtures and furnishings that were found in countless homes throughout the world. We shall miss her great friendship, style and generosity. John Jay Iselin, President The Cooper Union Mark Epstein, President The Cooper Union Alumni Assoc.

title: Stocks Rebound in Hong Kong and Tokyo
description: Stocks rose this morning in Hong Kong, rebounding from a big drop the day before. The gains were fueled by an easing of concern over a big property company, Sino Land, whose shares fell 45 percent on Thursday amid speculation -- denied by executives -- that the company might default on debt.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Weighing Abortion In a High-Tech Era
description: To the Editor:

title: An Old Injury, A New Annoyance
description: A first for BERNIE KOSAR, who retired as a backup quarterback with the Miami Dolphins: he set off an airport metal detector on his way to New York yesterday. The problem was three screws in his right ankle, relics from a bad sack in a ''Monday Night Football'' game several years ago.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Lichtenstein Gets His Wish

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, JACK J.
description: HOLLAND-Jack J. Beloved husband of the late Natalie. Loving father of Stephen and Margot, and Richard and Lila. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth and Al, Joshua, Leslie, Adam and Lisa, and great-grandfather of Zoe. Dear brother of Emil and Sylvia, and the late Louis and Sadie. Cherished uncle. Services ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC, 11:15 AM, Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMARA, THOMAS M.
description: McNAMARA-Thomas M. On Wednesday, January 7, 1998, of primary liver cancer. Beloved brother of Susie McNamara-Peck. Born in Washington, D.C., Tom moved to New York City in 1983. There, he founded Conditioning Fitness Design, Inc., a company that was among the first to offer personalized fitness training for private clients. Tom was a fun-loving, compassionate and generous humanitarian with a special fondness for disadvantaged children. In 1997, he received a U.S. Patent on a jump rope he designed called ''Jump To It.'' In fulfilling Tom's wishes, plans are underway to establish a foundation, the proceeds from which will fund recreational opportunities and sports equipment for underprivileged children in urban communities. A celebration of Tom's life will be held on Friday, January 16, at 7 PM, at St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31st Street in New York City. A reception will follow at Moran's Restaurant, 146 10th Avenue. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to St. Jude's Hospital for Children, the Special Olympics and organizations researching a cure for multiple sclerosis.

title: Korea Opposes Plan by U.S. Banks to Repackage Loans
description: In a blow to American banks, the South Korean Government opposes a debt refinancing plan put forward by the banks, which will meet on Wednesday with Korean officials to discuss how to repackage as much as $28 billion in short-term loans that are smothering the beleaguered nation's economy.

title: A drugstore chain's campaign asserts that its pharmacists 'care about their customers.'
description: THE CVS chain of drugstores is delivering an advertising care package to consumers in the form of a warmly emotional campaign that seeks to develop an image for the retailer as devoted to more than just peddling pills.

title: Nature Stripped to Its Essence in Visionary Images
description: We need shows like the beautiful Arthur Dove retrospective at the Whitney Museum to remind us from time to time of American painting at its most lyric and idiosyncratic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEGEL, GEORGE J.
description: KOEGEL-George J., 71. Of New Canaan, CT., died on Wednesday, January 14th at his home. He was formerly of Garden City, L.I. Retired Divisional Manager of Malden Mills and Sales Manager with J.C. Penney of Texas and New York. Beloved husband of Rita (nee Wulforst). Loving father of Diane Nizlek, Susan Needle, Sandra Heelan and Nancy Koegel. Grandfather to six grandchildren. Graveside services Saturday at 12:30PM in Lakeview Cemetery, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to The New Canaan Volunteer Ambulance Corp, South Avenue, New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: Clinton Will Insist Netanyahu Stick to Palestinian Issues
description: The Clinton Administration, signaling that it will not be diverted from pressing for an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank, has made it clear to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that his meeting with President Clinton on Tuesday morning should focus on the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.

title: Hated Killer In 'Dirty War' In Argentina Is Arrested
description: On the orders of President Carlos Saul Menem, the Argentine Navy today arrested a notorious member of the military death squads of the 1970's who boasted about his killings and threatened journalists and politicians in a published interview.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, GORDON A.
description: WOLFF-Gordon A. Loving husband of the late Carol. Devoted father of Helaine and Susan. Brother of Elyse W. and the late Morrel. Grandfather of Lee, Stephanie and A.J.

title: A U.S. Appeals Court Reinstates The S.& L. Conviction of Keating
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday reinstated the criminal convictions of Charles H. Keating Jr., a leading figure in the savings and loan crisis who had been freed from prison in 1996 after another court overturned those convictions.

title: Manning Hires I.M.G. Agent
description: University of Tennessee quarterback Peyton Manning has hired International Management Group's Tom Condon to be his agent.

title: Venture to Report On Ad Information
description: American Business Press and the Competitive Media Reporting unit of VNU N. V., both based in New York, have teamed up to report on business-to-business advertising information on a monthly basis. The data, which measure ad spending in more than 1,500 publications, will be reported through the Business Information Network. The initial report shows that more than $7 billion a year is being spent in business-to-business advertising, with spending in the first six months of 1997 rising 12 percent from the corresponding period of 1996.

title: F.C.C. Is Criticized By a Commissioner
description: A court case challenging portions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 should serve as a ''stern wake-up call'' to the Federal Communications Commission that it needs to do a better job reviewing regional Bells' applications to provide long-distance service, Michael K. Powell, an F.C.C. commissioner, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOB, ANITA RUTH
description: BOB-Anita Ruth. May 10, 1922January 16, 1991. Aunt Anita, you've always had a special place in my heart. Love Always, Seth

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be legally observed.

title: Borrowing Back The Fine Silver
description: When you let the Metropolitan Museum of Art have something on permanent loan, you can always borrow it back for a weekend. So the First Presbyterian Church, on Fifth Avenue between 11th and 12th Streets in Manhattan, will have its silver collection plates, communion chalices and tankards on hand on Sunday, when the congregation commemorates its first service, 291 years ago.

title: Judge Rejects Libel Suit Over 'Donnie Brasco' Film
description: John Cerasani has had an eventful life: he is a convicted racketeer, Mafia associate, bank robber and drug dealer, court documents say. Most recently, he was indicted on charges that he was a soldier in the Bonanno crime family and accused in a scheme to manipulate the stock market.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Game

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KINGSLEY, CHARLES R.
description: KINGSLEY-Charles R. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Charles R. Kingsley will be held Sunday, February 1, at 1 PM at the Eastview Technology Center, 350 Main Street, White Plains. For more information call Westchester ARC at 914-428-8330 X 338

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, WALTER T. JR.
description: HUGHES-Walter T. Jr., 82. Of Longboat Key, FL, died Dec. 16, 1997. Survived by wife Barbara, son Thomas of Birmingham, MI, daughter Marilyn Leddy of Winnetka, IL, three grandchildren. Donations to the Salvation Army.

title: Giuliani Asks for Apologies In Louima Case Retraction
description: In the days after Abner Louima said he was tortured by police officers inside a Brooklyn station house on Aug. 9, his claim that one officer said, ''It's Giuliani time,'' during the beating added a harsh political spin to the account. It resonated with the critics of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and became a catch-phrase of Ruth W. Messinger's campaign to unseat him.

title: Earnings at Big Banks Meet Expectations
description: A number of big American banks reported earnings yesterday that were generally in line with analysts' expectations.

title: Ill Suited: So Many Fashion Victims
description: The title character (if you could call it a character) of Alex van Warmerdam's absurdist comedy ''The Dress'' is a flashy garment with an unaccountably nasty disposition, since trouble invariably follows whoever has the misfortune to put it on. Don't ask what it means. The Dutch film is too lighthearted and spontaneous to be scrutinized for any deep lurking symbolism. As it follows the short life of a bright blue dress with a leaf design, from cotton field to textile mill to store window to thrift shop to its destruction under the blades of a lawn mower, the story suggests a droll parody of ''La Ronde.''

title: Outlook: Stormy (It's Raining, Too)
description: Deep waters and shallow characters tell the story of ''Hard Rain.''

title: Ireland's Blueprint for Peace
description: The bold and risky effort that Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has put into energizing Northern Ireland peace talks is showing encouraging results. After months of preliminary haggling, Northern Ireland's Protestants and Roman Catholics have before them the outlines of a broad political settlement. With luck and hard work, the proposals submitted by the British and Irish Governments this week could provide a realistic basis for resolving the troubles that have killed more than 3,000 people since 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IACOBELLIS, WILLIAM F., DR.
description: IACOBELLIS-William F., Dr. On January 14th, 1998. Beloved husband of Antoinette, loving father of Dr. Frank W., Thomas J., William F. and the late Stephen Iacobellis, Jeanne Coon and Delia Gorga, also survived by twelve loving grandchildren. Friends may call at the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, 262 Main Street, Mount Kisco, NY, Thursday from 7-9 P.M., and Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10 A.M., at St. Francis of Assisi RC Church. Interment St. Francis Cemetery. Memorial donations may be made to the Center for Special Studies, New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68 Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: Restaurant Leases Signed at Grand Central
description: Grand Central Terminal, which has been undergoing major renovations, will be getting more big-name restaurants to add sparkle to its face lifting. This week, leases were signed for two major restaurant spaces on the balcony level overlooking the main concourse.

title: Mayor's Plan On Admission To CUNY Stirs Opposition
description: If Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's educational vision outlined in his State of the City address this week were to materialize, the community colleges of the City University of New York would become virtually the only community colleges in the country without open admissions.

title: Public Still Backs Abortion, But Wants Limits, Poll Says
description: Twenty-five years and nearly 30 million abortions after the Supreme Court's landmark Roe v. Wade decision, the American public still largely supports legalized abortion but says it should be harder to get and less readily chosen, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Sun Microsytems Earnings Are Stronger Than Expected
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. reported stronger-than-expected earnings for its fiscal second quarter today as the company continued to evade the Asian economic crisis and the Microsoft Corporation's relentless assault on its core market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ZOLA CARL
description: MARCUS-Zola Carl. Artist and educator, died on January 12, in his 83rd year. He is survived by a niece, Julie Feinsilver, now in El Salvador, and two nephews, Alan Feinsilver of Houston and Sherman Marcus of Israel. A service will be held at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 4 P.M., on Monday, January 19. A reception will follow at 605 Park Avenue, Apt. 4G.

title: John Fisher, 68, Retired Insurance Executive
description: John E. Fisher, who served as chief executive of the Nationwide group of insurance companies in the 1980's and directed its national expansion, died on Tuesday at the Indian River Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old and had lived in Vero Beach and Worthington, Ohio, a suburb of Columbus, where Nationwide has its headquarters.

title: Weighing Abortion In a High-Tech Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Computer Jobs Go Begging
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fatal Triangle in the Long Shadow of Apartheid
description: THE HOUSE GUN

title: A Chair, a Fireplace, Binoculars: Sculpture to Be Seen on the Street
description: One of the zaniest, most engaging pieces of public sculpture in Manhattan right now is Donald Lipski's ''Yearling'' (1992), in Doris C. Freedman Plaza at the southeastern edge of Central Park. A child's red chair of steel and fiberglass 20 feet high with a toy spotted pony standing on it, the sculpture appeals in part because of its cockeyed disparities in scale -- the horse, only 10 feet high, is half the size of the chair -- and their unexpected juxtaposition.

title: Nation's Biggest Atomic Utility to Shut 2 Units
description: In the biggest retreat from nuclear power to date, Commonwealth Edison said today it would close 2 of its 12 nuclear generators because they were too expensive to operate now that the industry was being deregulated.

title: 'Milk Tax' Isn't Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, ROY A.
description: BENJAMIN-Roy A. 81. Died at his home in White Plains, N.Y., on January 15, 1998, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Survived by his wife of 50 years, Betty (Heilbrun) Benjamin; his children, Nancy Benjamin, Kate Spector, and Chip Benjamin; his sons-and daughter-in-law Herbert Nolan, Arnold Spector, and Laurie Benjamin and five grandchildren. Also surviving are a brother George Benjamin and a sister, Margaret Rothschild, both of FL. Chairman of the Benjamin Company, a book publishing/marketing organiza tion, he was also an avid golfer and author of two golf books. Memorial services will be held on Monday, January 19 at 11 AM at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, 914-967-4382. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021 or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTOMARENA, ANTHONY, M.D.
description: SANTOMARENA-Anthony, M.D. On January 12, 1998. Survived by many relatives and friends. He will be missed by all. Donations to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY. Ralph Giordano FH, Bronx, New York.

title: TOBACCO CONCERNS SETTLE TEXAS CASE FOR A RECORD SUM
description: In the largest resolution of a lawsuit against the tobacco industry, five leading cigarette companies have tentatively agreed to a settlement with the State of Texas worth about $14.5 billion over 25 years to resolve smoking-related health claims, state officials said.

title: Stravinsky and Schoenberg: A Gulf
description: By a lucky chance, it was possible this week to hear at Lincoln Center two of the first great adventures in modernism: Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps,'' in a program by the New York Philharmonic, and Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire,'' in the Chamber Music Society's series ''Musical Evolutions: 1887-1920,'' at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Of a Shrew Tamed and a Lust Unbridled
description: ''Live Flesh'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 10, 1997. The film -- in Spanish with English subtitles -- opens today in Manhattan.

title: Doctors' Specialty: Undressing
description: Adulterous love affairs on Masterpiece Theater usually come with layers of 19th-century clothes and layers of tortured conscience. But in the utterly contemporary ''Reckless,'' business suits and mobile phones are the trappings for a deliciously tangled story of passion, infidelity and civilized revenge. This tale of a 30-ish surgeon who falls for his boss's wife is an acerbic romance, filled with dry wit and a supremely grown-up attitude.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIN, JOSEPH
description: AIN-Joseph. It is with deep sorrow that the officers, Board of Directors and staff of HIAS note the passing of Joseph Ain, a long time member of our Executive Committee and worldwide advocate on behalf of the organized Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Norman D. Tilles, President Martin A. Wenick, Executive Vice President

title: Metro Business; Firms Seek to Buy the Wiz
description: The Wiz Inc., the struggling discount consumer-electronics chain based in Carteret, N.J., has received ''two very substantial offers'' to buy it, a company official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANRICH, FANNY
description: SANRICH-Fanny. Of Roanoke, Va. Passed away Wednesday, January 14, 1998. She was born on October 25, 1920 in Paris, France. A daughter of Adolph and Alice Blumenthal. She was preceded in death by her husband, Norman Sanrich. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law Sylvia and Paul Shoenfeld, grandchildren, Eric and Brooke, and brother, Pierre Blumenthal. A graveside service will be held at 11 A.M., on Friday, January 16 at the Temple Emanuel Cemetery in Roanoke. The family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the American Cancer Society or the Alzheimer's Assn. Oakey's Funeral Service, Roanoke, Va.

description: Thomas Andersen

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Assault on Unabom Defense Cites Defendant's Wishes
description: Hours before Theodore J. Kaczynski apparently tried to commit suicide last week, he told the judge in his trial on charges of being the Unabomber that he was simply too tired to argue his own case, and would have to continue with his lawyers, despite their efforts to assert that he was mentally ill.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OVENS, DON
description: OVENS-Don. January 16, 1997. We miss your friendship and your love. Ted and Marlin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUILDEN, LOUISE BULOVA
description: GUILDEN-Louise Bulova. Died peacefully at 100 years of age on the morning of January 15, 1998. Sister of Arde Bulova, survived by son Paul, grandchildren Peter, Lynn, Barbara and David, and great grandchildren Adam, Toby, Zack, Elizabeth, Tara, Brenton and Brynn. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Louise and Arde Bulova Fund, 350 Fifth Ave., Suite 1324, New York, New York 10118.

title: Baroque Melodies Inspire a Wide Range of Responses
description: The New York City Ballet's program on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater was doubly fascinating. First, it was devoted to works by three notable choreographers: George Balanchine, Angelin Preljocaj and Jerome Robbins. Second, it showed these choreographers responding to Baroque music in their own distinctive ways.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: ABC and ESPN to Show Women's World Cup
description: For only a few billion dollars less than was paid for the rights to National Football League games, ABC and ESPN yesterday announced a deal to televise all 32 matches of the 1999 Women's World Cup soccer tournament.

title: A Defining Play For Robinson And Elway
description: John Elway and Eugene Robinson have been facing one another for so long they talk about plays they made in the mid-1980's.

title: Editorial Observer; The Long History of Presidential Sex Scandals
description: President Clinton is scheduled to sit down for a deposition this weekend in the sexual-harassment suit filed by the former Arkansas state employee Paula Jones. It will be the first time a sitting President has ever testified as a defendant in a legal proceeding. But as chief executive, Mr. Clinton is already uncommonly familiar with the experience of testifying under oath, having appeared on videotape as a witness in two Whitewater-related trials of his former associates.

title: Observer; Poor Old Mister Money
description: The excesses associated with Sodom and Gomorrah, the last days of Pompeii and the administration of Ulysses S. Grant are now visible in New York.

title: The Peal of Horns Aplenty From a Big-Band Cornucopia
description: Oblivious to economics and cultural trends, the big band plays on.

title: Metro Business; Tax-Free Shopping to Start
description: The third tax-free shopping week in a year begins tomorrow, with the repeal of sales tax on all clothing and shoes costing less than $500. The tax holiday will run through Jan. 23.

title: Lure of Success Out of the Limelight
description: The game might have come easily, but Jackie Stiles was too afraid to stop practicing and find out. At the age of 7, her father let her lie about her age and go to a basketball camp for older youngsters. In seventh grade, she made the all-star team at a camp for the best high school players in the Midwest.

title: Sailor Fighting Discharge Over Policy on Gays Wins a Reprieve
description: A sailor who is challenging his discharge from the Navy for violating the military's policy toward homosexuality received a last-minute reprieve yesterday after filing a lawsuit against the Secretaries of Defense and the Navy.

title: Why Computer Jobs Go Begging; Mid-Career Burnout
description: To the Editor:

title: Wimp to Superwimp: It's His Strong Suit
description: When a seven-foot-tall robot gets a refrigerator stuck on his head, it ought to be funny. When a repulsive horned, lizardlike Broodwarrior from another galaxy breaks down the science teacher's exterior living room wall, it ought to be frightening. But in ''Star Kid,'' the children's sci-fi film in which these scenes occur, no such luck.

title: Stones and Spice. And Bob.
description: There's been a big pop music buzz in New York City this week. Probably it's left your head spinning with a mixture of nostalgia and befuddlement. Don't feel bad; I'm in the business, sort of, and I'm a little befuddled myself.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Japanese Theater in the World'

title: Sailor Now Likes Company
description: For Christophe Auguin, a French sailor who has sailed around the globe alone three times, a 60-day offshore competition in the company of a crew seems like a congenial get-together. At least that's the way the 1998 Gold Race is shaping up.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom misstated the title of their book. It is ''America in Black and White: One Nation, Indivisible'' (Simon & Schuster, 1997), not ''Black and White in America.''

title: Lawrence Treat, 94, Prolific Mystery Writer
description: Lawrence Treat, a prolific author of mystery novels and short stories and a founder of the Mystery Writers of America, died on Jan. 7 at Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 94 and lived on Martha's Vineyard.

title: Chase's Global Pit Boss; Executive Leads Bank Into High-Stakes Markets
description: Donald H. Layton doesn't have a desk job.

title: Mother Sues Her Son for Share of Lottery Winnings
description: For more than a decade, Phyliss Klingebiel says, she and her son, Michael, pooled their money and their hopes, each chipping in $20 a month for lottery tickets. It was a friendly family arrangement that seemed to become a family tradition.

title: 2 1/2 Years for Embezzler Who Loves Clocks
description: A Federal judge today gave a two-and-a-half-year prison sentence to a former Engelhard Corporation executive who stole millions from the company to satisfy his passion for collecting fine antique clocks.

title: Study Offers Surprise on Working of Body's Clock
description: In an experiment from the strange-but-possibly-true category, scientists have shone a bright light on the backs of human knees and, in some mysterious way, reset the master biological clock in the human brain.

title: Madden Agrees to Stay at Fox
description: John Madden ended speculation that he would leave Fox Sports by agreeing yesterday to a new five-year deal to remain the network's premier football analyst. He is expected to continue earning a $7.5 million-a-year salary.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Photography and Video From China'

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''John Glenn's first flight didn't have anything to do with science and this one doesn't either. Flying in space is about the right stuff.''

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Cars Lose in Rail Crossing Races
description: WHEN people die in train collisions, like the 2 engineers and a passenger killed in a commuter train crash in Secaucus, N.J., or the 11 on a Maryland commuter train that hit an Amtrak train in Silver Spring, both in early 1996, there are national headlines and detailed safety investigations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, HENRY
description: STONE-Henry. Poet and lawyer. Henry Stone, a semi-retired lawyer and poet, died in New York City just prior to his 90th birthday. Mr. Stone practiced law in New York for many years, at one time associated with Root, Clark, Buckner & Ballentine, with Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, later with Stone, Malone, Driver & McNeill, and then for a number of years before his death under his own name. Mr. Stone had attended Harvard Law School, transferred to Columbia Law in 1930, and received his L.L.B. in 1932. He ran for the State Assembly in 1932 and thereafter worked for the State Legislative where he drafted the New York Public Housing Act. In addition to practicing law, Mr. Stone wrote poetry and his poems appeared in many leading poetry magazines. He is survived by Mr. and Mrs. James Martin Stone of Boston, by Eugene Robert Stone of New York, and two beloved grandchildren, Curtis Henry Stone and Lauren Kelly Stone. Mr. Stone was a member of the California Bar and probably the oldest volunteer fireman in the Pelham, NY, Volunteer Hose Company #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, SAMUEL
description: GOLDBERGER-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Esther and beloved father and father-in-law of Steve and Wanda Gilbert, Ronald and Amy Goldberger, Howard and Lynn Gross and beloved grandfather of Wayne, Adam, Joshua and Jordan Gilbert, Jacob and Edward Goldberger and Jennifer and Jeffrey Gross.

title: Festival Drops Cobain Documentary
description: The Sundance Film Festival, the nation's premiere showcase for independent filmmakers, began tonight on an unexpectedly discordant and angry note.
