description: Ram Rahman and Sukanya Rahman

title: Tobacco Regulation Pushed
description: Citing disclosures in cigarette industry documents, President Clinton pressed Congress to act. Page A22.

title: Clinton, in a Visit, Offers $120 Million For New Officers
description: Reaching across party lines to fight crime and share political credit for the results, President Clinton appeared yesterday with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to announce a Federal grant of $120 million to help the Mayor make good on his inaugural pledge to hire 1,600 more police officers.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Remember Sparks, the steakhouse that always kept you waiting, no matter how early you arrived for your reservation? Well, it just got bigger.

title: John Glenn to Go Back Into Orbit, at Age 77
description: In a wonder of aeronautics and geriatrics, Senator John Glenn, the first American to orbit Earth, has won his campaign to be rocketed back into space at the age of 77, space officials and experts said today.

title: 2 New Chemical Studies Find Meteorite Samples Show No Traces of Past Life on Mars
description: Two new chemical studies have produced evidence that significant amounts of the organic compounds in a Martian meteorite found in Antarctica are terrestrial contamination, not possible traces of past life on Mars.

title: Two Suspects Are Arrested In Robbery at Trade Center
description: Two of the three men suspected of stealing more than $1 million from security guards making a delivery in the World Trade Center have been arrested, law enforcement officials said yesterday, adding that they were closing in on the third suspect.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Graciela Hasper

title: INSIDE
description: Support for Summer School

title: Labor Secretary's Nemesis Now Finds Himself Impugned
description: The man who has accused Labor Secretary Alexis Herman and his former business partner Vanessa Weaver of influence peddling was in turn accused today of a host of misdeeds, including sexual harassment, looting his business of $100,000 and blackmail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWSNER, DR. NORMAN
description: POWSNER-Dr. Norman. The members of Shelter Rock Tennis Club record with great sorrow the passing of our member, Norman Powsner. He was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to Barbara and the family. Peter Agins, President

title: Landlord Sentenced to Nights in Her Building
description: Although she is a suburban jurist, Judge JoAnn Friia grew up in a working-class quarter of Corona, Queens, and she knows firsthand the gnawing chill of a heatless apartment in winter and the shame of a run-down habitat.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sports of The Times; First Swedes Took Hit For Future
description: ULF NILSSON remembers the curses and the threats and the ethnic slurs, soon to be codified into the term ''Chicken Swede.'' He said he didn't mind the fighting: ''It was the stickwork. One night a guy from the Birmingham Bulls broke a stick over my back -- in the warm-ups.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEUGELOWITZ, DARLENE MARY
description: YEUGELOWITZ-Darlene Mary. On January 14, 1998. Loving daughter of Vincent W. Yeugelowitz and Carol Yeugelowitz (nee Lynch). Loving sister of Vincent and Theodore Yeugelowitz. Devoted fiancee of Thomas Long. Information: the Gary L. Kaufman Funeral Home at Meadowridge Memorial Park in Elkridge, Maryland, (410) 796-8024.

title: On Wall St., Fervent Plea For Minorities
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson exhorted Wall Street and the nation's business managers yesterday to offer decent investment and job opportunities to blacks and other minorities. The call came on the first day of an unusual gathering of business, political and labor leaders at the World Trade Center to discuss issues of race and opportunity in America.

title: MEDIQ AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $526 MILLION
description: Mediq Inc., the medical equipment rental company, agreed yesterday to be acquired by an affiliate of the private investment firm Bruckmann, Rosser, Sherrill & Company for $526 million in cash and stock. Mediq's shares surged 22 percent, gaining $2.4375 each, to $13.4375, on the American Stock Exchange. Bruckmann, Rosser, based in New York, is a private investment firm specializing in growth companies. Mediq, based in Pennsauken, N.J., rents movable critical-care and life-support medical equipment. It tried to merge with Universal Hospital Services last year but dropped the bid when the Federal Trade Commission moved to block the deal. Bruckmann, Rosser will pay $14.50 a share: $13.75 a share in cash and the rest in preferred stock.

title: Accounts
description: * Orthodontic Centers of America, Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., to Lois/EJL New York, a division of Lois/USA, to handle consumer advertising, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Weighing Abortion In a High-Tech Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the formation of a drill team in a Philadelphia neighborhood referred incorrectly to the Pennsylvania Governor who helped link businesses with community development organizations in 1994, and misstated his given name. The official was Robert Casey, not William, and he is not the current Governor; he left office in 1995.

title: Why Computer Jobs Go Begging; Old Switchboard Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Sisters Won't Meet in the Final
description: Serena Williams promised herself last year that she would play in her first Grand Slam tournament by the 1998 Australian Open, and on Monday, her goal will be met. Her world ranking qualifies her as a main draw player.

title: Uncomfortable, But Getting By
description: NORM MacDONALD, the sardonic comedian whom NBC kicked out of the anchor chair on the mock-news Weekend Update segment of ''Saturday Night Live'' last week, sounded yesterday like someone who had just run through a sketch that wasn't funny.

title: Gray to Acquire Midwest Concern
description: Gray Communications Systems Inc. plans to buy the closely held Busse Broadcasting Corporation, gaining entry into three midsize television markets serving the Midwest.

title: THE SUHARTO BILLIONS -- A special report.; For Asian Nation's First Family, Financial Empire Is in Peril
description: Only hours after President Suharto of Indonesia signed an agreement yesterday morning that required his family to give up some of the crown jewels of their multibillion-dollar financial empire, his youngest son stepped from his royal blue Rolls-Royce and into the headquarters of Indonesia's national car project.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERGENFELD, ANITA S.
description: BERGENFELD-Anita S. The puzzles are no longer being done and other things are undone. Miss you. Love, Howard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLIFTON, HENRY, JR.
description: CLIFTON-Henry, Jr. Of New York City on January 10, 1998. Founder and Partner of the Law firm of Clifton, Budd & DeMaria. Survived by his wife Loretta, children Jane E. Dockery and Henry S. Clifton, grandchildren Kristen and Jacqueline Burke. Funeral services were private. In lieu of flowers contributions in memory of Mr. Clifton may be directed to the William Penn Charter School, Phila, PA.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Tessa Traeger and Margaret Courtney-Clarke

title: Iraq Toxin Tests on Prisoners Are Not Proved, U.N. Says
description: Reports of photographic evidence supposedly showing that Iraq tested chemical and biological toxins on prison inmates are inconclusive, United Nations officials familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Better Quality Of Life Found Behind Wheel
description: A HUMBLE question, please, on this quality-of-life business that has received so much renewed attention. Whose life is it, anyway, that we're talking about?

title: Hooked on Young Smokers
description: The latest trove of internal documents from the tobacco industry provides the strongest evidence yet that the industry was not only targeting very young smokers, it was doing so with the approval of high corporate officials. Even in a business renowned for its lack of social conscience, the cynicism is breathtaking. Congress will need to look skeptically at proposals to grant immunity to the industry for its reckless behavior as part of an overall tobacco settlement. The case may be getting stronger for a straightforward crackdown, with or without a negotiated deal.

title: BACOU USA IN $120 MILLION DEAL FOR HOWARD LEIGHT
description: Bacou USA Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Howard Leight Industries for $120 million in cash to add devices like ear plugs to its line of eye-protection and other safety products. Bacou USA, based in Smithfield, R.I., said the purchase of Howard Leight, based in San Diego, was part of its strategy of making acquisitions to broaden its product line. Bacou USA, which is majority owned by the closely held Bacou S.A. of Paris, makes Uvex glasses, Survivair lung-protection devices and Biosystems hand-held gas detectors. Howard Leight expects to report sales of $48 million for 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARCY, THOMAS C.
description: DARCY-Thomas C. Retired Major General 87, of Essex, CT. Husband of Marjorie (Radcliffe) died January 15. Funeral Mass January 19, 10 A.M. Our Lady of Sorrows Church, Prospect Street, Essex, CT. Contributions to Assoc. of Graduates, Bldg 698, Mills Road, West Point, New York 10996.

title: Nets Lose One They Expected To Win
description: For the Nets, tonight's loss was hard to understand, and harder to take.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAULEY, BRENDA J.
description: McCAULEY-Brenda J. On January 13, 1998. Dame of the Holy Sepulchre. Founder, Brenda McCauley Associates. Beloved sister of Miriam and Gerard. Visitation Friday, 2-4 and 6-8 P.M. at St. John The Evangelist RC Church, 55th St and 1st Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday at 10:30 A.M. For further information please call Krtil Funeral Home, Inc., at 212-744-3084.

title: Air Force Panel Wants Search For a Downed Plane Resumed
description: In a belated acknowledgment that the Air Force botched its first investigation, an Air Force advisory panel recommended today that the service resume its search for parts of a Hercules C-130 cargo plane that crashed off California in November 1996 to determine why the plane's engines lost power. Ten of the 11 crew members were killed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINOFF, LILLIAN
description: RUBINOFF - Lillian. Women's League for Conservative Judaism mourns the loss of Lillian (Billie) Rubinoff, a dynamic and devoted member. She was mentor to generations of leaders as a National Vice President, Parliamentarian, member of our Executive Committee, and honorary National Board member. Beloved by the members of Philadelphia Branch and Southern New Jersey Branch, of which she was the founding President, she will be missed by all who benefited from her wise counsel, warm humor and caring ways. Evelyn Seelig National President Bernice Balter Executive Director

title: Showing the Way to the Vanguard at 23
description: With their bold, inventive palette and unfurled gestures, Helen Frankenthaler's color-stain paintings of the 1950's represent a middle-size step for art and an astounding one for a precocious young artist barely out of college. Fourteen of these canvases form a radiant exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum, beginning with ''Mountains and Sea,'' a weightless concoction of translucent pastels that hovers tantalizingly between landscape, still life and pure abstraction. Often seen as the catalyst for Color Field painting, most notably for the mature styles of Kenneth Noland and Morris Louis, it was made in 1952, when the artist was 23.

title: Cisneros Accuser in Plea Deal In Separate Texas Fraud Case
description: Linda Jones, the onetime mistress of former Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros, pleaded guilty to fraud and money laundering today in a plea bargain that her lawyer said was unrelated to the Government's obstruction-of-justice case against Mr. Cisneros.

title: Tighter Tobacco Controls Are Sought by President
description: President Clinton today used the disclosure of new evidence of how a tobacco company had courted teen-age smokers to raise the political pressure on Republicans, many of whom are less enthusiastic than he is about regulating the tobacco industry.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jennifer Monick

title: Yanks' Williams Files For Salary Arbitration
description: Bernie Williams took the first step yesterday in what promises to be an intriguing salary scrap with the Yankees, heading a list of 79 players who filed for salary arbitration. The Mets appeared on the list most often -- seven times.

title: In Art and Academia, More Holocaust Controversy
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Upgrades Team, Reviving Algeria Inquiry
description: An on-again, off-again European Union fact-finding mission on mass killings in Algeria was back on today after the Europeans agreed to send higher-ranking officials there than the ones Algeria had refused a day earlier.

title: In Art and Academia, More Holocaust Controversy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCAROS, IRENE
description: SCAROS-Irene. On Jan. 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Emilios. Devoted mother of Dean and Barbara Scaros, Popy and Anthony Guarente, and Maria and Richard Mercado. Loving grandmother of Gabriel, John, Emily, Erica, Alexander and Alexandra. Dear sister of Ernest and Harriet Thowdis. Visitiing hours Thurs., 7-9 and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main Street, Eastchester, N.Y. Funeral services at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church, 179 St & Wadsworth Ave, NYC, Saturday, 12 N. Donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York preferred.

title: 2 Storms Take Aim at New York Region With Annoying Mix of Precipitation and Mush
description: In the New York metropolitan region it was rain. Upstate it was snow and ice -- again.

title: 300 Years of Surprises, From Life and Legend
description: Whoever she was, the subject of Thomas Gainsborough's frilly, rococo drawing ''Study of a Lady'' is the quintessence of English upper-classdom. Beautiful, well-boned, perfectly poised, with masses of tumbled hair, she stands in a hint of landscape, clad in a billowy dress and huge picture hat, a discreetly sexy fashion plate who makes today's jet set princesses seem more than a little declasse.

title: What Our National Forests Need
description: We can talk money, or we can talk science, but either way, the timber frontier -- that part of it that involves the liquidation of the public lands -- is over, or should be over. I can think of no environmental issue that has outraged conservationists more than the continued Federal taxpayer subsidies for building roads -- temporary or otherwise -- into the last wild cores of our national forests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, HELEN HAYS
description: GORDON-Helen Hays. On Jan. 15, 1998 at 68. Survived by children Cindy (Cos Cob, Conn.), Debbie (Columbus, OH), James Gordon (Berlin, Germany) and Lisa (Joe) Walton (Naperville, IL). Granddaughters Paige and Summer Walton. Predeceased by parents James and Florence Hays, brother Peter Hays and sister Judy Eiseman. Memorial service will be held 2 PM Saturday, January 17 at the Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Avenue, White Plains. Rather than flowers, a gift to the American Heart Association or to Rainbow Center, 2275 Church Rd, Aurora, IL 60504 is suggested.

title: The Painful Joys (Stroke!) of Getting Nowhere Fast (Stroke!)
description: There's a standard joke among female rowers: If you can make it through an erg regatta, giving birth will seem easy. That's erg as in Concept II ergometer, the flywheel rowing machine that is a fixture in health clubs and used by virtually all the roughly 1,000 rowing clubs and college crew teams in the United States. The prefix ergo, from the Greek, means work. And as I discovered two years ago, the name fits.

title: Grant Gets True Test In Bout With Izon
description: Don Turner, who trained Larry Holmes and currently trains the heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield and Michael Grant, believes Grant is the next great heavyweight. Turner, and the rest of the boxing world, will get a better idea whether that is more than just hyperbole after Grant fights David Izon on the undercard of the Arturo Gatti-Angel Manfredy junior-lightweight fight tomorrow night at Bally's Park Place in Atlantic City.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Faith Ebbs on Reader's Digest Stock
description: For much of its illustrious history Reader's Digest has been an eloquent advocate of faith: faith in America and faith in self.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTERO, FATHER NEIL
description: OTERO-Father Neil. Dear brother of John, Catherine, Edward and Barbara, of cancer. Viewing is 3:00-10:00PM, Friday at McGonnell Funeral Home, 175th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Mass Saturday, 10AM at Incarnation Church. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY AGREES TO ACQUIRE OHM CORP.
description: The International Technology Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the OHM Corporation, a provider of environmental services, in a two-step stock and cash deal valued at $365 million. In the first step, International Technology, based in Pittsburgh, will pay OHM shareholders $11.50 a share, consisting of $8 in cash and 0.42 share of International Technology stock to acquire a 50.6 percent stake. In the second step, OHM will merge with a unit of International Technology. Each share of OHM still outstanding will be converted into 1.394 shares of International Technology. The deal also includes debt assumption. Shares of OHM jumped 19 percent, gaining $1.75 each, to $10.875. International Technology gained 6.25 cents, to $8.

title: Two Hurt as Taxi Swerves Onto Manhattan Sidewalk
description: A taxi driver apparently jockeying for space with another cab on a slippery stretch of Lexington Avenue lost control of his car yesterday and jumped a curb at 63d Street, slamming a 51-year-old woman into a metal light pole and crumpling a stroller with a 3-year-old boy inside.

title: Panel Details Management Flaws At Hanford Nuclear Waste Site
description: The Government employees who manage the most dangerous and polluted nuclear weapons site in the country fear for their careers if they raise safety concerns, and the site has no system to analyze safety problems and deal with them before they become serious, an advisory panel told the Energy Department today.

title: AFFILIATED MANAGERS TO BUY 68% OF ESSEX INVESTMENT
description: Affiliated Managers Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a controlling interest in the Essex Investment Management Company, a Boston-based asset manager with about $4.3 billion of assets, for about $120 million. Affiliated Managers, which is also based in Boston, said it would acquire 68 percent of Essex for $69.6 million in cash and 1.75 million shares of newly issued nonvoting convertible Affiliated Managers stock, valued at about $51.6 million. The shares will automatically convert into common stock on a one-for-one basis in a year. Essex executives will retain a 32 percent interest in their company. Affiliated Managers' stock rose 62.5 cents, to $29.50.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Eckard and Paul Forte

title: Veterans and Novices Leap Into New Roles in 'Jewels'
description: Talent will out, especially at the New York City Ballet, where a round of major debuts in George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' made for some spectacular dancing on Wednesday night. Both veterans and novices brought daring and individuality to their roles at the New York State Theater; the ''Rubies'' section set off sparks as Wendy Whelan's streamlined attack lent a new sophistication to the quirkiness of Balanchine's inverted academic steps. It was a sensational debut.

title: Critic's Choice/Television; 'A Day Like All Days,' Says a Voice From the Old Days
description: In the 1950's, before ''docudrama'' meant yesterday's news, CBS television offered ''You Are There,'' a weekly show in which reporters, Walter Cronkite among them, took viewers back in time to visit historical figures. In ''The Death of Socrates,'' Mr. Cronkite sees Aristophanes (E. G. Marshall) and says, ''He has just come from the theater, where his play 'Lysistrata' is in rehearsals.'' Straight out of the time capsule, ''You Are There'' can be a hoot today.

title: Stealing From Gangsters Proves Not a Good Idea
description: The feverish reverberation between Hollywood and Asian cinema, which like competing fashion houses borrow rhythms, moods and styles from one another, has rarely been more flashily displayed than in the Japanese director Takashi Ishii's 1995 neo-noir thriller ''Gonin.'' Opening today at Cinema Village, this cinematic bloodbath dresses up the yakuza gangster genre in ultra-contemporary drag and suggests a gay Japanese ''Reservoir Dogs'' mixed with the gorgeously ominous city-of-night atmosphere of a Michael Mann film.

title: Summoning Moods and Emotions
description: Joy Kellman is a gifted choreographer who specializes in creating sturdy dances with a sense of moody, shifting atmosphere. The four pieces presented by Joy Kellman & Company on Wednesday night as part of the Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater were also filled with moments of acutely observed human behavior. Now Ms. Kellman needs to have the sort of empathy for her audiences that she extends to the characters in her dances.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Kodak Profits Slid 37.7% in 4th Quarter
description: Battered by a strong dollar and lower film prices, the Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest photography company, said yesterday that operating profits plunged by 37.7 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: For These Colonialists, It Really Starts at Home
description: Recent immigration, especially from North Africa, may have engendered a lot of social stress in France, but it has certainly helped enrich that country's films, which increasingly reflect a society no longer smugly rooted in bourgeois custom. Gael Morel's ''Full Speed,'' an enjoyably corny Gallic ''Rebel Without a Cause,'' is set in a French suburb where young Algerian immigrants are menaced by racist skinheads, and middle-class students view the North Africans as the exotically sexy equivalent of American homeboys. The movie has a lot in common with Andre Techine's ''Wild Reeds,'' not only in its use of two of the actors from that 1995 film (in which Mr. Morel played the lead), but in its portrayal of French youth as both sexually precocious and wildly romantic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINITSKY, CHAIM
description: VINITSKY-Chaim. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Chaim Vinitsky, an exceptional Jewish communal leader who was deeply dedicated to helping others. As the former Director General and founder of the United Jewish AppealIsrael Office, he devoted his life to ensuring the welfare and survival of the Jewish people. Even in retirement, he continued to champion Jewish causes through his extraordinary commitment and dynamic personality. UJA-Federation deeply regrets the loss of an outstanding professional who will be sorely missed by his colleagues and friends. Our heartfelt sympathies go to his wife, Pnina, and sons, Yehuda and Danny. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P. Ernest W. Michel, Exec V.P. Emeritus

title: To Burden Of Poverty In France, Add Racism
description: Urban violence, high unemployment and the problem of assimilating millions of alienated North African immigrants have all been gnawing for a long time at France's self-image as a prosperous island of civilized behavior, and the image has frayed badly in the new year.

title: 10,000 Jobs Must Be Cut, Seagate Says
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the world's largest maker of disk drives for personal computers, said yesterday that it would dismiss 10 percent of its employees, or about 10,000 workers, as it struggles to cope with pressure from its competitors and a cooling market for its products.

title: FRONTIER SAYS IT WILL BUY GLOBALCENTER FOR $190 MILLION
description: The Frontier Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Globalcenter Inc., an Internet service provider, for stock valued at $190.3 million based on Wednesday's closing price. It will also assume $11.5 million of Globalcenter's debt. Frontier, based in Rochester, plans to combine its fiber optic network and 1,000-employee sales force with Globalcenter's commercial Internet-service business. Globalcenter, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., had revenue of about $24 million last year. Globalcenter specializes in setting up multiple computer sites to cut response time when consumers seek information from World Wide Web sites operated by Yahoo, USA Today and others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, ROGER D.
description: KAUFMANN-Roger D. On January 14, 1998. Survived by his wife Norma, sister Virginia K. Solis-Cohen, niece Betsy S-C Rizza and nephew David H. Solis-Cohen III. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Friday, 1pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Markle residence, 123 W. 13 St., NYC 10011.

title: EXCITE AGREES TO BUY MATCHLOGIC FOR $120 MILLION
description: Excite Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Matchlogic Inc. for about $120 million in stock. Excite will exchange 3.2 million shares of its common stock for all of Matchlogic's outstanding stock. Excite's shares rose $4 each yesterday, to $37.50, making the deal worth $120 million. Matchlogic is expected to add $22 million in revenue to Excite in 1998. Excite, based in Redwood City, Calif., is the No. 2 Internet directory behind Yahoo. It said it would begin using Matchlogic's Internet advertising services on its site in March to improve targeting of advertisements. The services will also be used on Webcrawler, Excite's other on-line directory.

title: East German Spymaster Takes Secrets to Jail
description: More than eight years after the collapse of the Berlin wall, and two failed attempts to put Markus Wolf behind bars, a court in Frankfurt jailed the former East German spymaster today for refusing to identify an agent he ran in the cold war.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 8 with an obituary of the actress who was the cartoon voice of Betty Boop and Olive Oyl misspelled her surname. She was Mae Questel, as the article said, not Questal.

title: He Fights, Patiently, for Workfare Laborers
description: THE offices of the community organizing group known as Acorn are rather playfully located in a drab downtown Brooklyn building just above a branch of its archnemesis, the city's Human Resources Administration. When the group moved in last November, the security director of the city social services agency walked upstairs suspiciously, figuring it was some kind of demonstration.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: On a Tony List, Few Revivals
description: It may seem odd in a Broadway season crowded with musicals, especially coming after years of complaints about the lack of new American projects, but there is a potential paucity of Tony nominees for best musical revival this year.

title: Second Time Around Is Sweeter for A.B.L.
description: To K. C. Jones, it was astonishing. That afternoon, a crowd of 15,101 had just about packed the Hartford Civic Center for a men's basketball game between the University of Connecticut and Notre Dame. Now, only a few hours later, on a Saturday evening, he looked up to see even more people -- a full house of 15,213, to be exact -- who were watching the New England Blizzard women play their Colorado Xplosion counterparts in an American Basketball League game.

title: Rangers and Devils: A Break in the Game
description: The Devils and the Rangers head into this weekend's All-Star Game break as healthy in the standings as they are in the trainer's room.

title: Gingrich Draws Well in a Democratic Stronghold, Hollywood
description: Hollywood may be Bill Clinton's kind of town. But here was Kurt Russell, action hero and self-described libertarian, poised before a packed conference room in the Beverly Hills Hotel to introduce none other than Newt Gingrich.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article assessing the season's new television shows misstated the name of one. It is ''Veronica's Closet,'' not ''Victoria's Closet.''

title: Betrayal at Every Turn In a Gangster's Paradise
description: ''Illtown'' was shown as part of the 1996 New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 3, 1996. The film opens today at Village East, Second Avenue at 12th Street, East Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, BETTY
description: FISHER-Betty. The world is sadder for the loss of a charming and beautiful woman. Betty Fisher died January 16, 1998, in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. Betty, lovingly known as ''Super Boss'' is survived by her husband of 63 years, the Hon. Harold L. Fisher, former chairman of the MTA and a prominent New York attorney. Theirs was a true love and romance. Betty was the loving mother of Prof. Leonard Fisher and his wife, Yvonne of Danville, California, Hon. Alice Fisher Rubin and her husband Lowell, Stephanie Fisher Cooper and her husband Joseph Harrison of Asheville, North Carolina, Andrew S. Fisher, Esq. and his wife Barbara and Council Member Kenneth Fisher and his wife Kirsten. Adored ''Go-Go'' grandmother because of her energy and travels of Alana, Matthew, Jonathan, Jacob and Penelope Fisher, David and Emily Rubin, and Neil, Edward, Jay and Gary Cooper. Also survived by her sisters Rose Ashin of Little Silver, New Jersey and Sarah Frischling of Tierre Verde, Florida. Great grandmother to 5. Aunt to many, friend to all. Donations may be made to the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation. Shiva at the Rubin home from Monday evening January 19th through 3pm Friday, January 23rd. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMAN, SONIA
description: BAUMAN-Sonia. At the age of 93, on January 15, 1998, after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Marvin J. Bauman. Devoted mother of Beverly Rhodes, Stephen Alan and Gene Bauman. Survived by grandchildren Randall Rhodes, Kim Bauman-Peterson, Sean, Kerry and Colleen Bauman and sister Pat Miller. Services at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Queens, Sunday at 11:15 AM.

title: Marijuana Moments, Many of Them
description: January can be counted on for two things: bad weather and bad movies. The bad weather is usually widely publicized in advance of arrival. Bad movies are another matter.

title: Moe Struggling 4 Years After His Gold
description: If you have not paid heed to ski racing since the last Olympics, you can step off the cog railway car in this venerable Alpine village and think that nothing had changed.

title: T. Wayne Robertson, 47, Leader In Development of Motor Sports
description: T. Wayne Robertson, who became one of the most influential leaders in American motor sports as an executive with R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., died on Wednesday during a hunting trip in Louisiana. He was 47.

title: Junior Wells, Central Player in Chicago Blues, Is Dead at 63
description: Junior Wells, a blues singer and harmonica player who was one of the major players of Chicago's dynamic, funky, electric blues sound in the late 1950's and 60's and an influential figure in the Chicago blues style, died on Thursday at Weiss Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 63 and lived in Chicago.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS HIGHER. Natural gas prices jumped from recent lows as the February contract rose 8.1 cents, to $2.175 a thousand cubic feet. But trading was technically driven, and the rally could fade because winter temperatures around the nation are expected to be milder than normal.

title: Perception vs. Reality: The Life of a Slave
description: Last summer, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill began publishing 100 first-person narratives from Southerners dating from 1860 to 1920. The project was part of a two-year effort to create a database of primary source material documenting the cultural history of the South. The documents, which are available on the Internet (http://www.sunsite.unc.edu), include diaries, autobiographies, travel accounts, slave ownership titles and regional literature from the university's Academic Affairs Library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SELIG
description: GOLDBERG-Selig. 93. Died January 13th, 1998 in Bermuda Dunes, CA, formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Beloved father of Stanley and Melvin. Cherished grandfather of Steve, Sandy, Meryl, Jan and Craig and great-grandfather of ten great - grandchildren. Devoted brother to Rose and Anna. Burial Sunday, 12 noon, Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: A Rossini Rarity, Parts of It Recycled
description: Assaults on the record book, even when successful, are not always pretty. And when Opera Northeast presented what it said was the New York premiere of Rossini's ''Elisabetta, Regina d'Inghilterra'' on Tuesday evening at the Kaye Playhouse, the performance seemed less a labor of love than simply a labor.

title: How One Network's Urgency Spelled Riches for the N.F.L.
description: On Jan. 8, Sean McManus left his office at CBS headquarters, walked east on 52d Street and headed for Park Avenue. The president of CBS Sports carried in his leather briefcase a letter he hoped would change the face of a company that four years ago would not pay enough to keep National Football League games and had spent the intervening time regretting it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTONE, SEABOURN SCHERER (SKID).
description: LIVINGSTONE-Seabourn Scherer (Skid). Beloved husband of Kay Will Livingstone, died suddenly of a heart attack at his home in Hobe Sound, FL at the age of 74, on Wednesday, January 14, 1998. Mr. Livingstone was born in Detroit, MI and graduated from the Berkshire School and Yale University. He was a retired manufacturer. He was an avid golfer and hunter. He is also survived by his stepson and daughter, John Wyckoff Mettler and Susan Salant Wierdsma and numerous grandchildren. A private Memorial Service will be held in the garden of Christ Church on Jupiter Island, FL. For information Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, FL 33458.

title: U.S.-Led Arms Inspectors, Rebuffed by Iraq, Pull Out
description: William Scott Ritter Jr., the American weapons inspector at the center of the latest confrontation between Iraq and the United Nations, left Baghdad today with his inspection team, whose movements have been blocked since Tuesday by the Government of President Saddam Hussein. The team's departure, a day earlier than scheduled, added to uncertainty about what happens next.

title: Microsoft's Troubles Creating Siege Mentality
description: On the campus where food is strictly fuel for another lap around the digital track and a mere eight-hour day is considered slacking off, the Microsoft corporate flag flies as high as ever in a wintry gale. Surrender is not an option.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, JACK
description: HOLLAND-Jack. The Orkin family mourns the loss of our beloved uncle Jack. Cherished brother of Sylvia Holland Orkin and loving uncle of Fred and Susan Orkin and their children Jennifer and Jeffrey and of Stuart and Roslyn Orkin and their daughter Jane. Uncle Jack's strength, generosity and devotion to family will always be remembered.

title: Tough Sanctions Can Halt Trafficking in Humans; Why Russians Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.U. Barely Wins a Neighborhood Battle
description: Two losses in its previous three Northeast Conference games hinted that Long Island University is not the best team in the league after all. Last night, the Blackbirds were barely the best team in their own neighborhood.

title: Religion Journal; Minister Says 'Amistad' Missed an Opportunity
description: Ever since she saw the movie ''Amistad'' last month, the Rev. Davida F. Crabtree has thought that an opportunity was largely missed to explore how religious faith can impel people to work to change society.

title: Bonn to Let Police Tap Residences And Offices
description: Dismantling a cardinal principle of postwar Germany's protection of individual privacy, Parliament took a decisive step today toward allowing the police to bug private homes for the first time since the Nazi era.

title: CORPORATE EXPRESS SETS BUYBACK OF ITS STOCK
description: Corporate Express Inc. will pay up to $150 million to buy back as much as 25 percent of its stock for a premium. The office-products retailer said it would buy back as many as 35 million shares for $10 to $11.50 each. The buyback will proceed only if 15 million shares or more are tendered. The shares of the company, based in Broomfield, Colo., fell 27 percent on Tuesday after it warned that earnings growth will slow the next two years. The stock rose $1.375 a share yesterday, to $9.375, in Nasdaq trading of 14.6 million shares. The shares will be bought through a ''Dutch auction,'' meaning a shareholder will specify a price at which he is willing to sell his shares. Corporate Express will then determine a price at which it will buy all shares tendered at that price or lower.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Hoechst Holds Talks To Sell a Big Unit
description: Hoechst A.G., Germany's largest pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its big Trevira chemical-fibers unit. But Hoechst declined to comment on a report in The Wall Street Journal that said Isaac Saba, a Mexican industrialist, was negotiating to join Koch Industries of Wichita, Kan., in a bid for Trevira that could exceed $3 billion.

title: Distracted and Tired, Martin Misses the Cut
description: Although Casey Martin arrived here Thursday to start play in the Nike Tour's South Florida Classic fresh off his first professional tournament victory, it was obvious something was troubling him.

title: KLM TO SELL STAKE IN NORTHWEST AIRLINES
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that it would sell its interest in its United States partner, the Northwest Airlines Corporation, by May 1. KLM said Northwest had agreed to buy back the 18.2 million shares, which had given KLM a 16.8 percent stake. The sale was originally planned for the year 2000. KLM will receive about $775 million from the sale, which consists of $435 million in cash and $340 million in promissory notes. KLM, 25 percent-owned by the Dutch Government, had 1997 revenues of 10.36 billion guilders, or $5.02 billion. Northwest, the St. Paul-based airline, had 1996 revenues of $9.88 billion.

title: Deal-Brokering Democrat Will Lead a Panel on Medicare
description: Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a moderate Democrat known for his ability to cut political deals, was chosen today to be chairman of a commission that will suggest ways to redesign Medicare to guarantee health insurance for aging baby boomers.

title: Treasury's Ethics Chief Resigns
description: The Treasury Department's chief watchdog, Valerie Lau, resigned today as inspector general after facing accusations that she had committed the kinds of transgressions her office was supposed to be rooting out.

title: 2 Yeltsin Advisers Pushed More Deeply Into Shadows
description: Two of Russia's leading reformers were stripped of some of their official duties today, a move that signaled ongoing power struggles within the Government.

title: Liberia Waits: Which Charles Taylor Won?
description: When Charles G. Taylor, who started this country's devastating civil war in 1989, became West Africa's newest head of state in August, his first inaugural pledge was to ''not be a wicked President.''

title: Sports of The Times; Golfen Goose Just Got Much Fatter
description: YOU'D think that everyone would be dancing in the aisles. Four networks -- Fox, ESPN, ABC and CBS -- have agreed to pay the National Football League a phenomenal $18 billion to televise football games over an eight-year span.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENHECK, SAMUEL
description: ROSENHECK-Samuel. On January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Adele (nee Hahn). Devoted father of Mina Berman and Robert. Loving father-in-law of Steven. Cherished grandfather of Erica and Marshall Berman. Graveside services on Sunday, at 11 AM, at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: In Art Theft Case, Defense Finds Beholder Who Is Not Impressed
description: It began as an international art theft case: three people, from Japan and Azerbaijan, charged in Federal District Court in Manhattan in a conspiracy to traffic in stolen art by the Great Masters.

title: A Grateful Paterno Promises $3.5 Million to Penn State
description: In a dramatic reversal of the economic relationship between universities and high-profile football coaches, Joe Paterno of Penn State, and his wife, Sue, have pledged $3.5 million to the school that has employed him since 1950.

title: Guilty Plea in I.B.M. Insider-Trading Case
description: A Croton Falls, N.Y., man has pleaded guilty to making a profit from inside information about the International Business Machines Corporation's $3.5 billion acquisition of the Lotus Development Corporation in 1995. The plea was entered by Robert M. Cassano.

title: Uphill Climb for a Downhill Car; Inventor Tries to Raise Interest in His Transit System
description: Sam Dordoni is looking for a good place to park a gravity-powered shuttle train.

title: 16-Year-Old Fatally Shot By Gunman On Balcony
description: A 16-year-old Bronx boy described as a hard-working student and an aspiring basketball player was fatally shot yesterday when a gunman fired from an apartment balcony into a crowd of arguing youths, the police said.

title: Intellectual Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Give Pedestrians Their Moment in the Crosswalk; Double-Parked Culprits
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Spanish Radio Station in New York
description: The Federal Trade Commission has given its approval for Heftel Broadcasting, a company that owns mainly Hispanic radio stations, to enter the New York market by buying WNWK (105.9-FM), a multicultural station. Heftel, which is based in Dallas, plans to compete against the two commercial Spanish-language stations operating in New York, WSKQ, or Mega (97.9-FM), and WPAT, or Suave (93.1-FM), both owned by Raul Alarcon and Spanish Broadcasting Systems.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be legally observed.

title: Manslaughter Verdict in Death of a Newborn
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn woman was convicted of manslaughter yesterday in the asphyxiation of her baby minutes after she secretly gave birth in a bathroom at her home.

title: Magee Takes 4-Shot Lead
description: Andrew Magee, playing virtually mistake-free golf, shot a 64 yesterday to open a four-stroke lead in the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic in Bermuda Dunes, Calif.

title: At Last, a Teacher Realizes Her Dream
description: Barbara Morgan's third graders at McCall-Donnelly Elementary School were excited beyond belief this morning when Mrs. Morgan told them she had been selected to be a mission specialist in the next corps of astronauts to be trained by NASA.

title: Navy Case Combines Gay Rights and On-Line Privacy
description: The first that Senior Chief Petty Officer Timothy R. McVeigh knew of his troubles was when the U.S.S. Chicago, a nuclear-powered submarine on which he was a highly decorated crew chief, pulled into her home port in Honolulu last September.

title: Stable and Then Not So
description: Joe Louis Walker has a methodical way with the blues. Mr. Walker, who made his name in the San Francisco Bay Area, demonstrated one capability after another in his first set on Tuesday night at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street in Greenwich Village, where he is appearing through tomorrow night with Ike Turner sitting in.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. 1/17/11-7/26/94 ''Sometimes when one person is missing, the whole world seems depopulated.'' (Lamartine) Forever missed by Janice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MILDRED KALTER.
description: KAUFMAN-Mildred Kalter. On January 15. Beloved wife of Stanley. Devoted mother of Eileen Grotsky, Jonathan Terner and Andrew Terner. Dear sister of Grace and Diane. She passed away at her home in Frenchman's Creek, Florida after a lengthy illness. She was a member of Metropolis Country Club in White Plains, N.Y. Known for her radiant smile, sense of humor and ability to light up a room, her loves included music and dancing, but most of all, people. In her travels and at home she touched old and new friends alike, with her warmth, honesty and indomitable spirit. She is also survived by two loving grandchildren Adam and Jennifer; her adoring extended family Michael and Carol; five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Funeral services will be held 10AM Sunday, January 18 at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers kindly send donations to your favorite charity.

title: Harriet Van Horne, 77, Critic Of Early TV and Radio Shows
description: Harriet Van Horne, a pioneer radio and television critic whose tough-minded crusades for educational programming and against ''women's chatter programs, the vulgar outpourings of the soap opera and the bad taste of commercials'' attracted a wide following in The New York World-Telegram and other Scripps-Howard newspapers for a quarter of a century, died on Thursday at New York Hospital.

title: 'Queer Theory' Is Entering The Literary Mainstream
description: ''It's about trying to understand different kinds of sexual desire and how the culture defines them,'' said Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick, the Newman Ivey White professor of English at Duke University. ''It's about how you can't understand relations between men and women unless you understand the relationship between people of the same gender, including the possibility of a sexual relationship between them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNE, PRENTICE C.
description: HORNE-Prentice C. Age 78. In New London, NH on January 15, 1998 formerly of Plainfield, NJ. Survived by wife of 54 years, Elizabeth (Olsen) Horne of New London, NH; children, Frederick R. Horne, II of New Orleans, LA, James M. Horne of Derry, NH, Sally H. Conklin of Newtown, CT and Carolyn H. Boyd of East Bridgewater, MA; five grandchildren; sister, Marian Dowley of Skaneateles, NY; nieces, nephews and cousins. Memorial services on Monday, Jan. 19, 1998 at 2 P.M. at The First Baptist Church of New London, NH. Memorial contributions to Habitat For Humanity, PO Box 1513, New London, NH 03257. For information Chadwick Funeral Service of New London, NH.

title: U.S. Can't Find Buyer for Jets Thailand Can No Longer Afford
description: Thailand's effort to back out of a contract to buy eight American-made F/A-18 fighter jets has run into a big problem: The United States does not want them back and is not likely to find anyone else to buy them any time soon.

title: Classification of 'Race' Aided Colonialism
description: To the Editor:

title: Squeezing Companies For Profit
description: Hedrick Smith begins ''Surviving the Bottom Line,'' his four-part report on the American economy, with an incisive look at the way a few Wall Streeters go about making enormous profits at the expense of many Main Streeters. ''Running With the Bulls,'' which can be seen at the uninviting hour of noon tomorrow in the New York area, focuses on big players whose single-minded goal is to extract the most money from the companies they take over regardless of what that means for workers, communities and business ethos.

title: Coach Bears Down After Nets Fail to
description: The Nets could look at the highlight films and say that they lost Thursday night's game to the Los Angeles Clippers in the final seconds.

title: Drug Makers at Threshold of a New Therapy; With a Dose of Biotechnology, Big Change Is Ahead in the Treatment of Diabetes
description: Few medical breakthroughs have been as dramatic as the 1921 discovery of insulin, which changed diabetes from a death sentence to a survivable disease.

title: Union City Official Calls For Takeover of Police
description: Three days after a retired Union City police lieutenant was named in a Federal indictment charging several former and current police officers in West New York with corruption, a Union City official announced that he would ask the Hudson County Prosecutor's office to take control of the Union City Police Department.

title: As His Day Darkened, Haydn Kept The Faith
description: Every millennial celebration has its element of hope. Most of us in 1998 eye the year 2000, wistful for a continued bull market and a world in which international violence remains fragmented, not corporate. The disappointments of the last 100 years have taught us not to want too much.

title: Fight Widens Over Keeping Party Funds
description: Escalating the political tug-of-war over money raised from New York's wealthy contributors, the state Democratic Party formally demanded yesterday that the Democratic National Committee automatically turn over 25 percent of all money it raises in New York in 1998.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now the bottom line is everything, Before, companies that had done business with us for a decade would help us out in times of trouble. But no more.''

title: Give Pedestrians Their Moment in the Crosswalk; Undercover Operation
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Reach Deal With Banks
description: The Yankees settled one of their three salary arbitration cases yesterday, but it was not Bernie Williams's and it was not Andy Pettitte's.

title: Win, Lose: Knicks Need Jolt to Get Off Seesaw
description: The Knicks may be tired of treading water win one, lose one -- and may be forced to send up a flare for help.

title: San Simeon Resort Plan Rejected
description: The California Coastal Commission has rejected a plan that would have let the Hearst Corporation build a 650-room resort on land surrounding Hearst Castle State Park at San Simeon, instead approving a scaled-down 375-room project that the company contends would be economically unfeasible.

title: Odysseus Again Plays His Trick
description: The Little Orchestra Society was founded by the conductor Thomas K. Scherman 50 years ago with a twofold goal. First, Mr. Scherman stated, he wanted to ''revive the small, elegant, compact type of ensemble'' for which the orchestral works of the late Baroque to early Romantic periods were written. At the time there was a dearth of chamber orchestras. Since then, of course, the early-instrument movement has brought us quite a few.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Accounting Change Urged to Help Japan's Banks
description: Japan's governing party wants to change an accounting rule so that banks can increase their dwindling capital by trillions of yen.

title: Surge in Asian Stocks Buoys Markets in Europe and U.S.
description: Asia led the way. Then came Europe and the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A picture grouping in the House & Home section on Thursday with an article about the designs that interior design photographers create for themselves at home omitted a credit for scouting and producing. It was by Carlos Mota.

title: Fumes at Private School Send 500 Students Home
description: More than 500 students were evacuated from classes and sent home yesterday morning when fumes spread through the Trinity School on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and sickened five members of the school's staff, the authorities said.

title: Turkey's Politics of Exclusion
description: Turkey's military and political leaders seem under the illusion that the best defense against Islamic fundamentalism is to ban Islamic political parties. The country's highest court did so again yesterday, outlawing the Islamic party that briefly governed Turkey before the military arranged its removal last year. Like previous bans on Islamic parties, this one will only stir greater support for Islamic causes among Turkey's overwhelmingly Muslim population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINES, LEON
description: REINES-Leon. We remember with fondness the father of our friend Sheila and devoted husband, of Esther for 50 years. Fanette Pollack, J.D. Breit

title: Glenn to Slip Bonds of Age in Space
description: He wears glasses now; he is paler and balding. But he still has his freckles and the Midwestern blend of modesty and self-assurance he always displayed as an American hero.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about new restaurants and other businesses planned for Grand Central Terminal carried an erroneous byline. It was by Florence Fabricant, not Geraldine Fabrikant.

title: Chief Iranian Cleric Assails Washington But Backs Overture
description: In a sermon charged with hatred and rage, Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ruled out any dialogue with the United States today, branding it ''the enemy of the Iranian nation'' and the ''Great Satan.'' But the Ayatollah, the most powerful figure in Iran, also praised President Mohammed Khatami and his recent overture to the American people.

title: Republicans Reject Abortion Litmus Test
description: After an unusually passionate debate that amplified tensions in the party, the Republican National Committee today spurned a proposal to withhold money from candidates who do not oppose certain late-term abortions. It was the first big defeat in nearly two decades of the party's most ardent opponents of abortion on a major proposal before the national committee.

title: Taking Leave of the Census
description: The resignation of the Census Bureau's Director, Martha Farnsworth Riche, does not bode well for hopes that the 2000 Census will be more accurate than the flawed effort in 1990. Ms. Riche, a respected professional demographer, says she has accomplished her goal of redesigning the census process, but regrettably she will not see the difficult task to completion. Her departure robs the agency of the leadership needed to resist political efforts to hijack the census.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDERMAN, PAUL ROBERT.
description: RUDERMAN-Paul Robert. Treasured son of Abe and Pearl. Loving brother of David. Loved by all who knew him. His spirit is free. Services Old Montefiore Cemetery, Sunday 11AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, HAROLD I. M.D.
description: KAPLAN-Harold I. M.D. On January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Nancy Barrett Kaplan. Loving father of Phillip, Peter Mark and Jennifer. Dear brother of Vivienne Brickman, Annette Dresdner and Gerald. Devoted grandfather of Alexander D'Addio and Wildon Kaplan. Service Monday, 9:45AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. Contributions in his memory to a charity of your choice.

title: Deutsche Telekom Posts A Drop in Profits
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said yesterday in a preliminary report that its profit fell 6 percent in the second half of 1997 as start-up losses at its Global One venture and money set aside for losses in Asia eroded profit by about 1.5 billion marks ($820 million) in 1997. Shares in the phone company dropped after the preliminary report said that second-half profit fell to 1.5 billion marks from 1.6 billion a year earlier. Full-year net income was 3.3 billion marks, 27 percent less than analysts expected but 84 percent above the 1.8 billion marks earned in 1996.

title: Pulling Strings: The Geppetto Effect
description: Everyone knows about claustrophobia (the fear of confined places), agoraphobia (the fear of public places) and xenophobia (the fear of strangers). But what about pupaphobia, the fear of puppets? Puppets are creepy. Whether they are jerking around on strings or bowing on the tips of fingers, they seem to make people nervous.

title: PURCHASE OF BORDEN DAIRY UNITS ANNOUNCED
description: Nestle S.A., the world's largest food maker, said yesterday that it had bought some dairy products units in Latin America and elsewhere from Borden Inc. to increase its sales in emerging markets. Nestle did not disclose the price. The divisions it bought, which together have sales of more than $400 million, include ice cream, yogurt and other dairy products makers in Puerto Rico, Colombia, Panama, Costa Rica, South Africa and the Middle East. Borden, which is controlled by the acquisition firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, is seeking to focus on pastas and other grain-based foods. Last month it sold its cheese business and grocery brands, including Cremora nondairy creamer and Eagle Brand sweetened condensed milk.

title: Odom Not Eligible to Play at Rhode Island
description: The educational odyssey of Lamar Odom, a former high school basketball all-American who remains without a team, may have taken its final turn yesterday.

title: Give Pedestrians Their Moment in the Crosswalk; Preventable Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HOWARD M.
description: GREENBERG-Howard M. On January 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Annabelle. Devoted father of Carrie and Nancy. Dear brother of Lawrence. Cherished grandfather of Tara, Destiny and Darcy. He lived to teach Social Studies at Long Beach High School and Nassau Commubnity College. He will be greatly missed. Services Sun. 12:45 PM ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Insurance and Infertility
description: To the Editor:

title: Court to Weigh Use of Fifth Amendment in Deportation Cases
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether suspected Nazi war criminals can invoke the Constitution's protection against self-incrimination in deportation proceedings on the ground that their testimony might subject them to prosecution in their native countries.

title: Murdoch's Son Named An Executive at The Post
description: James Murdoch, the younger son of the media and entertainment mogul Rupert Murdoch, was named deputy publisher of The New York Post yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HILDA
description: HARRIS-Hilda. January 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Harris, dear mother of Marceline and Bertram Kalisher. Devoted grandmother of Richard Kalisher and wife Patricia, Nancy Siskind and husband Jeffrey, great-grandmother of Eric, Michael and Laura Kalisher and Andrew, Samuel and Elizabeth Siskind.

title: Journal; The 2 Tim McVeighs
description: Here's a scenario that could be out of Kafka, or at least Alfred Hitchcock -- except that it's really happening and hasn't been sold to Hollywood. Yet. Its protagonist is Timothy McVeigh -- not that Timothy McVeigh, but a 36-year-old sailor who, through bad luck, not genealogy, found himself with the same name as the biggest mass murderer in American history.

title: A Long, Icy Scramble to Reconnect a Region
description: Tom Parmiter peeled off three sets of gloves -- his heavy work pair and two layers underneath for warmth -- and held up a piece of power line. He had just descended in his metal work bucket from a job 40 feet above the rubble-strewn street, erecting a new wooden pole to replace one that had cracked apart in one of the worst ice storms in New York State history.

title: Holocaust Museum Rejects Visit by Arafat
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, had intended to pay an official visit to the Holocaust Memorial Museum in the capital next week but was told by museum officials that he could not, a senior Administration official said tonight.

title: One Dead and One Hurt in Police Shootings
description: In separate shootings yesterday, police officers killed an armed man in the Bronx, and an off-duty officer critically injured an armed man who tried to rob the Brooklyn beauty salon where she was getting her hair cut, the police said.

title: Mother of Injured Disabled Student Asks: How Could This Happen?
description: Ines Crimes, the mother of a 15-year-old who was critically injured when he was accidentally knocked out of his wheelchair at a Brooklyn high school on Wednesday, said she stares at her helpless child, tethered to a ventilator and fighting for his life at Bellevue Hospital Center, and keeps wondering how it could have happened. Didn't he have a full-time aide assigned to watch him?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, MARGARET
description: GALLAGHER - Margaret. For merly of Mastic, LI. Daughter of James and Mary Gallagher, passed on January 14, 1998 at St. Patrick's Home, Bronx. Sadly missed by her son Gerard Gallagher and granddaughter Saoirse Gallagher and her brothers George and James. Predeceased by sister Katherine.

title: PPG to Close Glass Plant
description: PPG Industries will take a $102 million fourth-quarter charge to close a specialty-glass plant in Perry, Ga., and sell its stake in two glass plants in China because the three factories are not meeting performance goals. PPG, a maker of glass, fiberglass, chemicals and paints, said that it would dismiss the 140 workers at the Georgia plant and that it was completing agreements to shed holdings in the Dalian Float Glass Company and the Guangdong Float Glass Company.

title: TURKS' HIGH COURT ORDERS DISBANDING OF ISLAMIC PARTY
description: Turkey's highest court placed an immediate ban on the country's largest political party today, ruling that it harbored a subversive agenda and was working to replace the nation's secular order with one based on Islam.

title: Treasuries Decline as Outlook for Asia Seems to Improve
description: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday as the near-term outlook for Asia seemed to improve, the stock market rallied and there were new signs that the economy was strong as 1997 ended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONETTI, REV. GENNARO M.
description: SIMONETTi-Rev. Gennaro M. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of Our Lady of Miracles Church, 757 E. 86th St., Brooklyn on Jan. 16. Reposing in Guarino Funeral Home, 9222 Flatlands Ave., Brooklyn, Sunday, Jan. 18, 25 and 7-10 P.M. and Monday, Jan. 19, 2-5 P.M. Mass of Transferral Monday, Jan. 19 at 7:30 P.M., Our Lady of Miracles Church. Funeral Mass, Tuesday, Jan. 20, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priest's Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Tom Gentry, 67, Powerboat Racing Record Holder
description: Tom Gentry, a wealthy real estate developer whose fascination with powerboat racing brought him several world records, died at home in Honolulu Thursday, nearly four years after a severe crash at a world championship left him hospitalized and in a coma. He was 67.

title: Backing IMF, Suharto Sends Signal That He'll Stay Put
description: SINGAPORE  By taking charge of the key panel to carry out painful economic reforms and austerity measures in Indonesia, President Suharto has made it clear that he intends to continue his three-decade rule despite increasing calls for his resignation, analysts said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUILDEN, LOUISE
description: GUILDEN-Louise. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the death of Louise Guilden. We extend our sincere sympathy to her son Paul, a true and valued friend of the Home and the entire Guilden family. We hope that your loving memories of Louise will ease your sorrow during this time of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES BUYS RIVERSIDE CEMENT
description: Texas Industries said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Riverside Cement for $120 million, increasing its cement-production capacity 60 percent and expanding its operations in California. The acquisition increases Texas Industries' production to 3.6 million tons a year, and the company expects to increase its capacity further by using its patented processes at the Riverside operations. Riverside, based in Diamond Bar, Calif., has annual revenue of more than $100 million from two cement plants in California, according to Texas Industries, which also produces steel through its majority-owned Chaparral Steel.

title: AIDS Group Opposes Use of Names in H.I.V. Reports
description: After a week of intense criticism from advocacy groups for AIDS patients, the Gay Men's Health Crisis offered a clarification yesterday of its new position that calls on doctors to report H.I.V.-positive people to the State Health Department, saying it will oppose any system that records the names of infected people.

title: Two Tough Guys Meddling In the Prelude to the Alamo
description: Remember the Alamo? The TNT movie ''Two for Texas,'' which has its premiere tomorrow night at 8, tries to be too many things at once -- road film, neo-western, love story -- but it does succeed in being a reminder of a time when a small number of people had a significant effect on the course of American history. And it offers the not-so-frequent chance to watch Kris Kristofferson in gracefully understated action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, SAMUEL
description: GOLDBERGER-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Esther and beloved father and father-in-law of Steve and Wanda Gilbert, Ronald and Amy Goldberger, Howard and Lynn Gross and beloved grandfather of Wayne, Adam, Joshua and Jordan Gilbert, Jacob and Edward Goldberger and Jennifer and Jeffrey Gross.

title: Bills Bring Flutie Back to N.F.L. for Two Years
description: Doug Flutie is headed back to the National Football League after starring in Canada for eight years.

title: Fichaud Agrees to Surgery
description: Eric Fichaud, the Islanders goalie who re-injured his left shoulder while playing for the club's minor league affiliate, the Utah Grizzlies, last Wednesday, agreed yesterday to have season-ending surgery to repair the separated joint.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISS, EMMANUEL A.
description: WEISS-Emmanuel A. January 17, 1995-1998. Dearest Many, I who knew you best, miss you profoundly-daily. We had the happiest days of the past; saddest of the present. My love for you is endless. Vera.

title: Give Pedestrians Their Moment in the Crosswalk
description: To the Editor:

title: New Faces and Old Are Ready for Space
description: Thirty-six years after he circled Earth three times, Senator John Glenn said he was excited to have the chance to make a few more orbits, promising to ''give it my very best try.'' The head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said he had approved the voyage because Mr. Glenn had worked for almost two years to show that space research might benefit the elderly and that he was the one for the job.

title: Fort George Journal; Wherein Is Revealed the Answer to an Old Inquiry About Kilts
description: Asked why he was in this windswept northern outpost, a visitor from Tony Blair's rebranded Cool Britannia said he was looking for a piece of scorned Old Britain.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Said to Seek Deal for Regal Cinemas Chain
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the investment buyout firm, is in talks to buy Regal Cinemas Inc. for more than $1 billion, its second acquisition in the movie theater business in two months, people associated with the talks said.

title: About New York; Night Time Is Right Time At This School
description: WITH relentless enthusiasm, Howard A. Friedman believes that education can redeem even those students who have been left back, dropped out or lost their way. He sees high schools as familylike places where students learn to make the choices that make the difference between presiding over the executive suite or just dropping in to deliver interoffice memos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EAMES, DAVID TODD.
description: EAMES-David Todd. On January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Sarah Frost Eames. Father of Peter and Lee. Son of Phyllis and Edwin. Brother of Mona Steiger and Lori Rusack. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, January 18, at 9:45 A.M. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Optimistic Signs in Japan

title: Error-Prone Williams Loses Final To Veteran
description: Venus Williams fell short in her attempts to win her first title and play a more aggressive game at the net when she lost today to Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, 6-1, 6-3, in the final of the Sydney International tournament.

title: Battle Looms on Move to Change Side-Crash Rule for Cars
description: The auto industry and highway safety groups are bracing for a struggle over how best to protect people in cars hit in the side in traffic accidents.

title: John C. Bradford, 73, Former Art Director
description: John C. Bradford, a former art director in the recording and publishing business, died on Dec. 30 at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 73 and had homes in Manhattan and East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Cathay Pacific Plans Layoffs Next Week
description: Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong's main airline, will start dismissing employees on Monday, a senior company official said yesterday. While it was not clear how many jobs would be lost in a first wave of cuts, the official said the company would begin handing out dismissal notices next week.

title: Peregrine Is Seeking Sale of Profitable Units
description: Executives at Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., the failed investment bank, talked yesterday with potential investors in Europe and Hong Kong, aiming to sell its profitable equities and corporate finance business. In Hong Kong, the co-founder and managing director, Francis Leung, led the efforts to sell Peregrine Capital Ltd. Andrew Jamieson, head of equities, was meeting with investors in Europe. Similar discussions are under way in the United States. A management buyout is also being considered.

title: No New Site for Trial In Death of Newborn
description: The murder trial of a Forked River teen-ager accused of killing her newborn baby at her high school prom will remain in Monmouth County despite extensive coverage in the local press, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Morrison Knudsen Ends Mine Stake Talks
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation had ended talks with its chairman, Dennis Washington, about acquiring his majority stake in a copper mine after a decline in copper prices.

title: Key Figure in Salomon Rescue Is Leaving for Big Hedge Fund
description: John G. Macfarlane, who played a central role in rescuing Salomon after a Treasury-bidding scandal in the early 1990's, is leaving Salomon Smith Barney Inc. to become chief operating officer of the Tudor Investment Corporation, a big hedge fund managed by Paul Tudor Jones 2d.

title: 7-Up Adopts New Formula And New Ads
description: A reformulated 7-Up that is intended to revive the long-slumbering soda brand is being introduced around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBITZ, MAE
description: LUBITZ-Mae, (87 years). Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Devoted mother of Allen, Iris and Bruce. Loving sister of Ralph Ziskin and the late Hy Ziskin. Cherished grandmother of Karen, Steven and Joshua. Memorial contributions can be made to The Association for the Help of Retarded Children, 200 Park Avenue South, NYC 10003. Graveside services Sunday 1PM at the Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: In Unusual Season, N.H.L. Adopts Unusual Format
description: While walking down the hallway of a downtown hotel this afternoon, Detroit Red Wings defenseman Slava Fetisov encountered Brendan Shanahan, a Detroit power forward. Although they are teammates for regular-season games, they will be on opposing sides in Sunday's All-Star Game.

title: Ricky Jay Is Back in Town
description: Ricky Jay stands under the lights at the Second Stage Theater in Manhattan, jacket sleeves pushed up, hands hanging inoffensively at the ends of his pale arms. It is natural to focus on Mr. Jay's hands, even though Mr. Jay himself seems never to look at them. He is one of the greatest card-handlers ever to live, and a historian of his art.

title: Borrowing From Pop
description: Some of the better young jazz musicians have been looking for a way to capture the power of popular music in a small group context: pop's sense for arrangements, its excitement and its connection to the audience. Donald Harrison, a saxophonist who arrived as a Young Turk in jazz nearly 15 years ago, spent a good part of his first set on Tuesday at the Village Vanguard in this pursuit.

title: Debate Distant for Many Having Abortions
description: For K. J., a slight, blond college freshman who has not told her parents that she is 12 weeks pregnant, Roe v. Wade is ancient history, the lone demonstrator outside the Planned Parenthood clinic here in Houston a minor irritant and the blistering debate over ''partial-birth abortion'' not even a blip on the horizon.

title: Congeniality And Unease As Wall St. Addresses Race
description: There was something for everyone at this week's Wall Street conference organized by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and his Rainbow/PUSH coalition.

title: The View From the Cab
description: You are cruising at the legal speed limit and in front of you, in the middle of the street, are two obstacles: a pigeon and a pedestrian. Which will move first to get out of the way of your two tons of metal? The pigeon, every time. Which one is smarter? You figure it out.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing holiday schedules for Martin Luther King Jr. Day referred incorrectly to the New York financial markets. The stock and bond markets will be closed on Monday. A corrected chart appears today on page B4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, EDITH
description: GOLD-Edith. 82. On January 16, 1998 in Philadelphia, PA. Beloved mother of Gerald and Rabbi Aaron. Loving grandmother of five and great-grandmother of 12. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to: Jeane's Hospital, Memorial Fund for Edith Gold, 7600 Central Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19111, Attn: Development Dept.

title: Give Pedestrians Their Moment in the Crosswalk; Take a Walk
description: To the Editor:

title: The Neediest Cases; At Horace Mann, a Fund-Raising Legend and Legacy
description: Tap, tap, tap. For those who attended Horace Mann School between 1911 and 1952, that sound accompanied the annual fund-raising juggernaut run by William J. Nagle, a teacher of Latin and Greek who stood in the hallway tapping a pencil on his clipboard and exhorting passing students to give to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Feverish Dreams of Baseball As Mets Look at Brooklyn
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said last night that the city is considering including a minor league ball park for a New York Mets farm team in its plans for a multimillion-dollar sports complex in the old Steeplechase Park amusement area on Coney Island.

title: Tough Sanctions Can Halt Trafficking in Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis Pushing Asian Capitalism Closer to U.S.-Style Free Market
description: Sitting in his office just off the factory floor, a week's stubble on his face and weariness in his eyes, Kim Jung Ju watches his workers carefully, figuring out whom he might lay off next.

title: A Jazz Mixed With Caribbean Rhythms
description: Steve Turre's Sanctified Shells, a small orchestra of brass musicians who also play modified seashells, is more interesting as a cross-cultural experiment than as the novelty act it's often taken for.

title: China Says Banking System Faces a Sweeping Overhaul
description: At the heart of the financial crisis in Asia is a badly kept secret: many bank loans throughout the region are based on a personal or political relationship between banker and borrower.

title: Cablevision to Sell Some of Its Holdings
description: Federal regulators in Washington told the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, N.Y., yesterday that it could buy several cable television systems from its competitor provided that it sell its holdings in Hillsdale and Paramus, where both companies now operate.

title: As Rail Travel Declines, So Do Amtrak's Options
description: With a new national debate about to begin on the future of Amtrak, the proponents of subsidies for a national, inter-city passenger rail system must wrestle with an undeniable truth: While travel by car and by plane have grown wildly since Congress voted to create Amtrak 28 years ago, the passenger train has become less and less important as a means of inter-city travel.

title: Lie-Detector Results of Brinks Guards Raising Questions
description: The Brinks security guards robbed of more than $1 million Tuesday at the World Trade Center did not perform well on lie detector tests given shortly after the incident, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Nicklaus Says Carts Shouldn't Be Allowed
description: Jack Nicklaus is among those opposed to Casey Martin's use of a golf cart in professional golf tournaments.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCVITY, LEONARD H.
description: McVITY-Leonard H. Died on January 17, 1997. Always remembered, always loved. Frances

title: Rios Takes Title In New Zealand
description: Marcelo Rios of Chile captured a third-set tie breaker today to defeat Richard Fromberg of Australia, 4-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7-3), and win the BellSouth Open tennis tournament in Auckland, New Zealand.

title: Expert Urges Trenton to Spend $350 Million on Poor Schools
description: A nationally prominent expert on school financing has recommended that New Jersey spend an additional $350 million on extra programs for students in poor, urban districts, several people who have seen the report said today.
