title: When a Double's Message Is This: Find a Killing Lead
description: Cover the North, East and South hands in the diagram and put yourself in West's shoes. Your opponents have bid to six diamonds as shown, and your partner has doubled. What do you lead?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KINGSLEY, CHARLES R.
description: KINGSLEY-Charles R. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Charles R. Kingsley will be held Sunday, February 1, at 1 PM at the Eastview Technology Center, 350 Main Street, White Plains. For more information call Westchester ARC at 914-428-8330 X 338

title: Victim of Unabomber Sees Deceit in Kaczynski's Acts
description: As a court-appointed psychiatrist completed her examination of Theodore J. Kaczynski today, one person maimed by a Unabom attack said Mr. Kaczynski was little more than a terrorist who was exploiting the system by stalling his trial, battling his lawyers and provoking questions about his competency.

title: Happy Days Are Here Again (At Least Until After Fall)
description: Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, and two of his top aides braved a sleet storm in Washington on Thursday morning, traveling to Capitol Hill to pay a call on Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, with whom President Clinton has had an often testy relationship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, JOAN WALKER.
description: ABRAMS-Joan Walker. Beloved wife of George. Adored mother of Noel Gahagan Walker and Brooks Walker, and Cherished sister of Ninalee Allen Craig. Died in an automobile accident January 14. Funeral service Sunday, January 18, 3 PM, at Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to your favorite charity would be deeply appreciated by the family. Joan, an expert in Asian art, was known for her generosity, spirit and originality. She never touched anything or anyone without making it or them better. She will be sorely missed.

title: Clinton and 3 Baltic Leaders Sign Charter
description: President Clinton signed a charter of partnership today with the Presidents of the three Baltic countries, once among the ''captive nations'' under Soviet rule, and pledged American support for their aspirations to join NATO.

title: INTERNATIONAL VERIFACT TO BUY CHECKMATE ELECTRONICS
description: International Verifact Inc., based in Toronto, agreed to buy Checkmate Electronics Inc. of the United States for stock valued at $50 million, forming one of North America's largest sellers of systems used to make electronic payments. Shareholders of Checkwell, based in Roswell, Ga., will receive 1.2775 shares of International Verifact for each Checkmate share. International Verifact's stock is traded in Canada, but the offer is worth the equivalent of $8.72 each. The Toronto-based International Verifact makes debit and credit cards, check readers and smart-card readers and other electronic-payment systems.

title: Horse Tracks Need Help In New Jersey, Panel Says
description: After a year's study, a commission on New Jersey's slumping horse-racing industry urged the state government today to pump $25 million to $50 million a year into racetrack purses and to soften betting regulations so residents can place wagers by telephone, via the Internet or in a few new upscale off-track betting parlors.

title: Nostalgia in Orbit
description: Well, why not send John Glenn back into space? If the space agency could provide shuttle rides for two politicians who controlled its budget in the mid-1980's, if it could send a teacher aloft to inspire the nation's schoolchildren on the ill-fated Challenger mission in 1986, then why should it not launch a renowned if ancient astronaut who wants a last big hurrah in space at the age of 77, after he steps down from Congress? At least Mr. Glenn has the experience and competence to perform the job. He has been flying his own plane and exercising like a maniac to keep in shape for his rendezvous with the cosmos. This is one old warrior who refuses to fade away.

title: Ciccarelli Traded to Florida
description: TAMPA BAY

title: INSIDE
description: Russian Reformers Set Back

title: Industrial Production Ends the Year Strong
description: Industrial production increased half a percent in December, the 14th consecutive monthly gain, and 5 percent in the full year, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Justice in Unabom Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MILDRED
description: HOFFMAN-Mildred. ''Auntie'' to a wonderful sister and great aunt. We will always remember you and miss you dearly. You are in our hearts forever. Berkman and Moster Families

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENSCO INTERNATIONAL INC., Dallas, a provider of offshore drilling and marine transportation services, ordered a jack-up drilling rig valued at $130 million from Keppel Fels Ltd., a rig builder based in Singapore.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ZACHER, ISRAEL
description: ZACHER-Israel. On our 50th wedding anniversary. Time does not heal. Sonia

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN STRENGTHENS FURTHER. The Japanese currency extended its rally from five-and-a-half-year lows against the dollar. Since Jan. 6, the yen has risen 3.7 percent against the dollar. Some analysts said that for the rally to progress the yen must break through the 128 level.

title: The Yanni Files
description: Don't misunderstand: we're still very, very proud of the entire Yanni concept, as proud as we were the day 20 years ago we dreamed it up. Do we begrudge the fact that our notion has become the most popular entertainment product on the planet? No -- indeed, we're deeply moved. Do we begrudge the fact that we don't share in the current Yanni revenue stream? No, because money was never the motivation. The process that turned into ''Yanni'' was a bar bet, a lark, a nutty what-if marketing experiment.

title: Rungs Missing In Big Stores' Ladder to Top
description: If Saks Fifth Avenue needed a company president 10 years ago, it would not have had to look far: Saks could have easily poached a top executive from similar retailers like Bonwit Teller, B. Altman or even I. Magnin.

title: Defense Requests Dental Exam and Records of Louima
description: The lawyer for one of the police officers accused of brutalizing Abner Louima requested yesterday that a forensic expert for the defense be allowed to examine Mr. Louima's mouth to help determine whether he had falsified part of his account of being attacked.

title: 'F' on Retest Could Cost Teachers Their Jobs
description: Most days, Naomi Franklin and Lidia Jimenez and Jiao Liang are standing in the front of the classroom teaching, as they have for years. But nights or weekends, they are the ones sitting at the desks, taking remedial classes to prepare for the New York State exams for a teaching license, which they have failed again and again.

title: Give Pedestrians Their Moment in the Crosswalk; New York Imperative
description: To the Editor:

title: Income Up 11% At Abbott Labs
description: Abbott Laboratories said today that net income, lifted by increased sales of drugs and hospital products, rose 11 percent in the fourth quarter, matching expectations.

title: Glenn Kept Talking to NASA, and After 2 Years the Agency Said Yes
description: Saying a persistent John Glenn had finally proved persuasive, NASA formally announced today that the astronaut turned Senator would be allowed to journey again into space and ''show that senior citizens have the right stuff.''

title: Suspect Shot and Killed While in Police Custody
description: A burglary suspect was shot and killed by two detectives at the headquarters of the Cedar Grove Police Department on Thursday after he wrestled a weapon away from a third detective and threatened to kill him, county prosecutors said.

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday with the continuation of an article about Senator John Glenn's plans to return to space as an astronaut misstated the date of a picture of him with a space vehicle in Washington. It was taken in 1987, not this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, WILLIAM M.
description: LANE-William M. Loving father of Peter and Rita. Cherished grandfather of Eric and Adam. Service Sunday 10:30 A.M. at the Sharon Gardens cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Contributions may be made to the United Hebrew Geriatrics Center, 60 Willow Drive, New Rochelle, New York.

title: Indonesian Currency Continues Slide Despite I.M.F. Deal
description: The International Monetary Fund got virtually everything it wanted from President Suharto. Yet today, one day after he reluctantly agreed to a major restructuring of Indonesia's economy, its weakened currency resumed sliding.

title: Gatti Takes the Risk for Piece of Prime Time
description: Arturo Gatti built his reputation working the late shift, becoming one of the most exciting fighters on HBO's ''Boxing After Dark'' series. His second fight against Tracy Harris Patterson on Feb. 22, 1997 is still the highest rated bout broadcast on Boxing After Dark.

title: BID TO ACQUIRE CAJUN ELECTRIC POWER INCREASED
description: The Central and South West Corporation's Southwestern Electric Power Company increased its offer to bail out the bankrupt Cajun Electric Power Cooperative by 19 percent, to $905 million in cash. The bid also includes $25 million in guaranteed debt payments. Southwestern Electric, a utility in Shreveport, La., wants to expand its territory by purchasing Cajun's two power plants and 25-year contracts to sell power to 8 of the 11 members of the cooperative. Cajun has had many suitors since it filed for bankruptcy in December 1994. The main assets are a coal-fired power plant and a natural-gas-fired plant.

title: Foreign Affairs; Haircut Time
description: Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin better hurt somebody fast. Citibank would do. Or maybe his old partners at Goldman Sachs. Or maybe his old competitors at J. P. Morgan. Or better yet, all of them. But he better hurt somebody, fast.

title: INTERWEST BANCORP TO ACQUIRE PACIFIC NORTHWEST
description: InterWest Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Pacific Northwest Bank for $61 million in stock. The combined entity will have assets of more than $2.3 billion and 46 offices serving western and central Washington. InterWest, based in Oak Harbor, Wash., is a bank holding company. Pacific Northwest, based in Seattle, has assets of $197 million. On Thursday, InterWest completed its previously announced acquisition of Puget Sound Bancorp.

title: Esiason In; Gifford Moves
description: Boomer Esiason is headed to ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' replacing Frank Gifford, who will be the co-host of a new pre-game show.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I tell her Mommy was having trouble with, I call them ovums, not eggs. I say that I needed these to have a baby, and there was this wonderful woman and she was willing to give me some, and that was how she helped us. I want to be honest that we got pregnant in a special way.''

title: Using Religion to Reform Criminals
description: Dressed in white cotton shirts and trousers, with a guard stationed in the hallway outside, several inmates at the Texas state prison system's Jester II Unit sat in a stark white classroom, studying a list of steps to ''spiritual recovery'' one recent afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, GEORGE S., SR.
description: LAWRENCE-George S., Sr. On January 17, of Manhasset, NY. Loving husband of Nancy Lawrence (nee Black). Dear father of Diana Pakel, David Lawrence, Molly Coughlin, Johanna Lawrence-Lee and George S. Lawrence, Jr. Sadly missed by 14 grandchildren. Died after a brief illness. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, on Monday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

Grandfather of Yael, Ellen, Daniel and Ronnit and their spouses Chris, Oran, Lee Anne and Michael, great grandfather of Michael, Abigail, Kate, Alexander, Benjamin, Laura, Gabriella and Alana. He will be dearly missed by his family and friends. Donations in his memory may be made to the Friends of Israel Disabled War Veterans, 15 E. 26 St., NY, NY 10010. Funeral services were held on Friday, January 16th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSCHEIN, FLORENCE
description: ROSENSCHEIN - Florence. Be loved wife, devoted mother, cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Passed away in her 100th year. Rest in peace, GiGi. Interment was private.

title: Tyne Daly, Ever in Charge
description: ONCE upon a decade, when illusions sustained and whimsy worked, the search for signs of intelligence was perceived as a not impossible mission. Now that a millennial crisis with its attendant hysteria looms, everyone appears to be searching for signs of something -- anything -- to hold on to.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOTTLIEB, HENRIETTA
description: GOTTLIEB - Henrietta. Dearest Mom, it's been a year. I miss you, and Joanna and I love you very much. Sleep in peace. Love Madeleine and Joanna

title: 'N.Y.P.D. Blue' Station Faces a Real-Life Foe: Trash
description: Ever since ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' had its debut in 1993, the Ninth Precinct station house at 321 East Fifth Street has appeared in the opening credits, its facade beamed nationwide as the home of the television show's fictional crime fighters.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Blood Supply Low

title: The Nation; Rethinking a Myth: 'Who Was That Masked Man?'
description: IT seems hard to believe now, but it wasn't very long ago that the Unabomber seemed like a serious person. To read about him in many newspaper and magazine accounts was to hear of a mysterious philosopher: dangerous yet compelling, brilliant, intriguing. Yes, he was troubled, even evil -- but he was a man of ideas.

title: Feast Is a Power Meal for the Family of Iran's President
description: Just after sundown in this desert city, three dozen women and children sat on the carpeted floor of an upper-class home, kissing and joking as they dined on the huge meal spread out before them on a plastic checkered tablecloth.

title: Art, Hype and Hollywood At Sundance
description: THE buzz of last year's Sundance Film Festival was a weird film called ''The House of Yes,'' in which Parker Posey (the independent film movement's busiest actress) played a crazed young woman obsessed with President Kennedy and his wife, Jacqueline. The ending was predictably bleak.

title: Messenger Chic
description: Another example of street fashion going high fashion: the messenger bag (above left) has been co-opted by designers as this year's replacement for the backpack, with upscale versions abandoning workaday canvas for trendy nylon or leather. The leather-and-nylon bag by Giorgio Armani Le Collezioni (above right) has compartments and is $655 at Barneys New York, which also has Kate Spade's brown nylon bag with black trimming and Velcro closure ($165) and Pen & Alex's black all-leather version ($675). Gucci's black nylon bag is $625 at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: INVESTING IT; Parents, the Ultimate Experts, Critique the Clinton Proposal
description: WHATEVER the merits of its specifics, President Clinton's proposals to spend $21.7 billion over five years to improve child care taps into one of the most vexing daily concerns of many parents at nearly every income level.

title: Afterlife For Stately Amaryllis
description: AMARYLLIS was the gift of choice this year. Many homes were dazzled by these huge trumpet flowers, and their brilliance has lasted well into January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLAN, GERTRUDE
description: KARLAN-Gertrude. On January 9, a woman of rare talent, intellect, capability and strength. An extraordinarily gifted and sensitive pianist/musician, artist, jewelry designer and goldsmith, she affected a legion of friends of all ages. she was mentor to many who loved her. Throughout her 96 years she was true to her inner core. A very early protege of Gurdjieff. Gertrude was the very special dear aunt of Edna Stone, Ellen J. Goldfarb and Marion Ostrovsky Bernstein. A memorial is being planned at a date to be announced.

title: Stay Tuned for the N.F.L. (Gratuitous Violence No Extra Charge)
description: If you, too, are eager to see Nancy Kerrigan sit knee-to-knee with Tonya Harding and watch Evander Holyfield again lend Mike Tyson his ear, then you will share my gratitude to those television visionaries who last week poured fresh billions into the National Football League.

title: New Focus on Attention Deficit Disorder
description: ANDREW GLASS was identified as having attention deficit hyperactivity disorder when he was 7. The years leading up to that pivotal moment were not easy. His mother, Helen Glass of Mattituck, said: ''The teacher would call and say: 'Did you know he is not doing well with reading? I have told him 27 times not to get up and get a drink during class. Did you know he cannot sit still?' ''

title: In 'Ragtime,' a Cast From American History
description: WHEN THE MUSICAL ''RAGTIME'' OPENS TONIGHT, inaugurating the new Ford Center for the Performing Arts, there will be a crowd of familiar names in the character list: Booker T. Washington, Emma Goldman, Houdini, Admiral Peary. These and other figures from early in America's 20th century will flicker in and out of the show, based on E. L. Doctorow's best-selling 1975 novel of the same name.

title: Sports of The Times; How About a Show About Life's Minutiae in Chicago?

title: Not the Friendliest Welcoming Statement
description: TOM STRAUB of Southold makes and sells cannons -- for the home. ''It's a great lawn ornament,'' he said.

title: The Pope Comes to Cuba
description: Pope John Paul II has visited many dictatorships, but few of his trips have carried the expectations of this week's visit to Cuba. Anyone hoping that the visit will make Cuba much freer or shorten Fidel Castro's rule is likely to be disappointed. Only a few previous papal trips have had political reverberations, and those have taken place in circumstances very different from those in Cuba today.

title: Ideas & Trends; Drivers on a Collision Course
description: NOBODY knows for sure why older cars account for a large share of the nation's traffic accidents. They are more often driven by younger drivers and heavy drinkers, who have high accident rates and can seldom afford new cars. The brakes and other safety systems on older models have often deteriorated. And new car owners may simply be more careful because they do not want so much as a scratch on their costly purchases.

title: Tobacco Industry, Conciliatory in U.S., Goes on the Attack in the Third World
description: Last August, dozens of journalists from Latin America arrived in Miami as guests of the British-American Tobacco Company, whose Brown & Williamson unit makes popular cigarettes like Kool, Carlton and Lucky Strike.

title: How to Correct Grouting And Other Tile Problems
description: A GOOD tile surface should last for many years without problems. Eventually, however, the grout in the joints between the tiles may deteriorate or crack. While it is possible that crumbling grout joints can signal a possible problem with the underlying substrate, usually a few cracks here and there are indicative of grout that was improperly mixed.

title: Good Product. Sound Plans. No Sure Thing.
description: AMERICA'S love of innovation runs deep. More than a century ago, Ralph Waldo Emerson earnestly proclaimed that anyone who invented a better mousetrap would find the world beating a path to his door.

title: Novel Noir
description: BAD CHEMISTRY

title: Food; Mrs. Foo's Combination Plate
description: Susanna Foo is not your typical Chinese chef. She doesn't believe that authenticity and improvisation are incompatible, and she doesn't wish to be hemmed in by national or regional boundaries. In her opinion, the finest cooking is a synthesis of time and place. Her own cooking style, which can be sampled at her eponymous restaurant on Walnut Street in Philadelphia, is as Western as it is Chinese, a result of her having lived here for some 30 years.

title: Dead. Blood Everywhere. And on Page 2 . . .
description: FOR these authors to make their living, somebody has to die, at least on the printed page. Five best-selling New York mystery writers will talk next Sunday at the New-York Historical Society about how the city has inspired their art.

title: When Imagination Joins Hands With Improvisation
description: WHEN they describe their wishes, the children at Westhab Family Center in Elmsford talk about houses for everyone, new sneakers and lots of time to play outdoors.

title: 1898 Observances
description: To the Editor: The Q & A column on Dec. 14 (''Remembering the Maine'') outlined events throughout the country to commemorate the Spanish-American War. There will also be a broad range of activities in New York City to mark this important anniversary.

title: Woman, 99, Is Killed In Fire in Chelsea
description: A 99-year-old woman was killed when a fire broke out in her apartment in Chelsea last night, the police said.

title: Event at Library to Recall The Life of Sojourner Truth
description: WHEN she was a young slave girl, the black evangelist and abolitionist Sojourner Truth, lived in Ulster County. For the first years of her life, after her birth in Hurley about 1797, she was owned by a Dutchman. At age 9, she was sold to an English family, but she could understand and speak only Dutch. The new owners beat her because she seemed to be ignoring their orders, when in fact she simply could not comprehend what they said to her.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; Music Once Banned, Now Business as Usual
description: AMERICAN AUDIENCES MAY have been surprised over the last two weeks to hear the Israel Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta, play music by Richard Strauss, who was for a time president of the Reich Music Chamber in Hitler's Germany. The orchestra has included Strauss's ''Till Eulenspiegel'' in many of the programs on its current tour celebrating the 50th anniversary of the nation's founding.

title: Correction
description: The In the Kitchen column on Dec. 28, about cooking for the New Year, referred incorrectly to a chef, Douglas Rodriguez. He is still at Patria restaurant in Manhattan; he did not move to Florida.

title: Teaching Adults to Read
description: ONE night a week, for several weeks now, 13 people have been meeting in the second-floor activities room of the public library here. The group includes a nurse and a retired nurse, a college student and a financial expert, a receptionist for a pharmaceutical company and a manager for the State Department of Labor, a retired clerk and an unemployed paralegal.

title: A Border War Builds Over an Abandoned Road
description: FRUSTRATED in efforts to keep an abandoned road closed to a neighboring city's traffic, Paul J. Feiner, Town Supervisor of Greenburgh, exclaimed recently, ''This is World War III, a life-and-death border war!''

title: Reed and Hudek Are Signed for '98
description: Everything went right for the Mets yesterday. The team's first day of ticket sales for the 1998 season set a record, and two pitchers -- Rick Reed and John Hudek -- agreed to contracts.

title: A Life Out of Print
description: Starting Out

title: Visit to Iran
description: To the Editor: ''For a Few Pioneers, Iran Is Back on the Map'' (July 13) was my inspiration to visit Iran. Like Stephen Kinzer, I found the visa and customs regulations simple, the people warm and welcoming and many of the sights exceptionally rundown, though two major hotels in Teheran are being renovated.

title: Brooklyn Could Have Been A Contender
description: In ''Brooklyn Could Have Been a Contender'' (Dec. 28), John Tierney argues that the 1898 consolidation of Brooklyn and New York was the cause of Brooklyn's current economic woes. Yet he acknowl-edges that Brooklyn ''remained a middle-class bastion through the 1950's.'' If consolidation was the cause of the borough's problems, why did it take more than 50 years to have an effect? Could it be that the postwar trends of deindustrialization and suburban flight were more to blame?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, WILLIAM G., JR.
description: PERRY-William G., Jr. February 13, 1913-January 12, 1998. Professor of Education and founder of Harvard's Bureau of Study Counsel, died of pneumonia on January 12, 1998, in Boston. Mr. Perry began his life-long relationship with Harvard University as an undergraduate, receiving his B.A. in English and Greek in 1935, and his M.A. in English in 1940. Mr. Perry's father, William Graves Perry, Sr., Harvard class of 1905, was the architect who worked on the restoration of Williamsburg, VA, and designed many Harvard buildings, including the Houghton Rare Book Library. Mr. Perry taught English, History, and study skills at the Rivers School in Brookline, MA, from 1935 to 1940. In 1941, at Williams College, he was Assistant to the Dean and Instructor in English. During World War II, as an experienced sailor, he taught celestial navigation to naval pilots, none of whom were subseqently lost due to navigational errors. Mr. Perry founded the Bureau of Study Counsel at Harvard College in 1947, melding several student services into a center for counseling and tutoring. He and his staff counseled approximately 400 students a year. He was noted for his support of student's strengths as they confronted Harvard's curriculum, explaining he did not feel overwhelmed listening to ''problems all day.'' Instead, he said, he ''listened to courage in action.'' His closeness to students, and recognition of common themes in their experience allowed Mr. Perry to develop a map of the cognitive and moral development of undergraduates as they encountered the complexities and challenges of a liberal arts education. His book, ''Forms of Intellectual and Ethical Development in the College Years'' (1970) described nine developmental stages. His framework started with a freshman's simplistic adherence to notions of absolute truth and morality, traced the discovery of multiple frames of reference regarding data, and the upperclassman's subsequent growth and eventual achievement of personal and ethical commitment in a relative world. This developmental framework has had nation-wide impact on the theories of the psychological development of late adolescence. His research validating this developmental scheme led to his appointment as a full Professor of Education in the Harvard Graduate School of Education (1965-1979). His teaching about the counseling process and the role of empathy influenced many graduate students over the course of thirty years. A man of diverse interests, his translation, with Alston Hurd Chase, of Homer's ''Iliad'' was published in 1950. Classical scholar Dudley Fitts in his New York Times book review, described it as the best prose translation of this century. Mr. Perry's other publications include articles on topics ranging from conflicts in the learning process to essays on counseling and psychotherapy. His ironic piece on the role of ''bull'' in undergraduate epistemology, ''Examsmanship and the Liberal Arts,'' has been included in the ''Norton Anthology of American Literature.'' Family and friends remember Mr. Perry as a formidable raconteur, sailor, horseman, boat designer and carpenter, and a man deeply committed to the conservation of the salt marshes of Massachusetts, ''despite the greenhead flies.'' Mr. Perry is described as exhibiting a vigor and love of life, inviting participation in whatever project was at hand, and encouraging others to enjoy learning about themselves. Mr. Perry is survived by: his wife, Mary (Hughes Frank) of Watertown, MA, his daughter, Dr. Lee Perry of Los Altos, CA, his stepson, Kevin Frank of Holderness, NH, and his step-grandson, Brendan Frank of Boston, MA. His first wife, Helen Knowles, his son, Edmund Graves Perry, and his stepson, Colin Frank, predeceased him. The memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Sunday, January 18, at the First Parish Church Unitarian of Cambridge. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Civil Liberties Union or to UNICEF would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, ROSEMARY (NEE KELLY)
description: FAY-Rosemary (nee Kelly) 92. Wife of John J. Mother of Kevin and Rosemarie O'Sullivan and the late sons John and Richard; brothers Monsignor James and John Kelly. Reposing at Wanamaker & Carlough, Suffern, NY, Sunday 7-9 and Monday 2-4, 7-9. Mass Sacred Heart Church, Suffern, NY, Tuesday 10 AM.

description: McVITY-Leonard H. Died on January 17, 1997. Always remembered, always loved. Frances

title: His Nervous Behavior Gave Man Away
description: The attempted escape of a third suspect in last week's World Trade Center bank robbery was foiled on a train trip in New Mexico by drug enforcement agents who thought the fugitive's nervous demeanor and the amount of cash in his possession fit the profile of a drug trafficker.

title: Style; Shirt Wars
description: With a loyalty usually reserved for alma maters and hometown baseball teams, New York men are rallying around their English shirtmakers, two of which have lately set up shop here.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Survivor Still Matches Wits With Bill Collectors
description: If dodging bill collectors were an Olympic sport, Herbert Weiss would have already earned a fistful of gold medals. No matter how many times the telephone rings, no matter how persistent the caller, Mr. Weiss is unmoved, and an impish grin remains fixed on his face. ''They're not going to get me,'' said Mr. Weiss, a 62-year-old Holocaust survivor who owes nearly $100,000 in medical bills. Advancing diabetes has choked circulation and sensation in his limbs, leaving them susceptible to infections and to gangrene. Over the last four years, doctors have removed his right leg and the toes on his left foot, which has in turn removed much of his independence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. A memorial service will be held at The Mount Sinai Medical Center to mark the passing last October of our most cherished friend and esteemed colleague, internationallyrenowned cardiologist, Richard Gorlin, M.D., Senior Vice President of The Mount Sinai Medical Center, The Dr. George Baehr Professor of Clinical Medicine of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and Medical Director of The Mount Sinai Health System. Family, Trustees, faculty, staff, students, and friends are invited to attend at 5 P.M. Tuesday, January 20 in the Stern Auditorium, Annenberg Building, Fifth Avenue at 100th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORONOV, GERTRUDE A.
description: WORONOV-Gertrude A. Widow of Nathan. Prominent retail jewelers died Wed. Jan 14. She leaves 3 children, 5 grandchildren and 8 great grandchildren. Contributions to Hospice.

title: On Trial: Three Officers, and U.S. Policy
description: NEW JERSEY and New York are involved in an intense, breathlessly publicized and utterly irrelevant legal battle over boundary claims to Ellis Island. Last week, when Governor Whitman addressed the State Legislature, she drew thunderous applause by coyly alluding to this dispute over ''the entrance to America -- Ellis Island, New Jersey.''

title: BEST SELLERS: January 18, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Correction
description: The quarterly performance tables in the Mutual Funds Report last Sunday misstated the fourth-quarter, 12-month and annualized five-year returns of the Goldman Sachs Institutional Short Duration Tax-Free fund. The fourth-quarter 1997 return was 1.43 percent, not 1.09 percent; the 12-month return was 5.36 percent, not 4.64 percent, and the annualized five-year return was 4.48 percent, not 4.30 percent.

title: The Nation; In Some Big Cities, Pedestrians See the Light
description: ONE morning in the mid-1980's, Zev Yaroslavsky, then a Los Angeles City Councilman, was rudely interrupted during a jog around his Westside neighborhood.

title: Changing Market In Care of Elderly
description: LAST summer, Wade Costello was happy when her father was admitted to the Decker wing of 3030 Park, a nursing home complex at that address in Bridgeport. Previously only residents of the complex had been admitted to the wing, but with the help of a lawyer who specializes in issues of the elderly, Mrs. Costello's father was admitted on an emergency basis.

title: Jimmie Albright, Fisherman and Guide to Stars, Dies at 82
description: Captain Jimmie Albright, a fly-fishing innovator and pioneer who guided and became friends with some of the most celebrated anglers of his time, died of cancer last Sunday in Islamorada, Fla. He was 82.

title: Betsy Kramer And Lev Dassin
description: Betsy Kramer, a staff lawyer at Lawyers for Children in New York, was married last evening to Lev Dassin, an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Rabbi David Small performed the ceremony at the Chelsea Market in New York.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: DIXIE RISING: How the South Is Shaping

title: Generation X
description: A Lover's Almanac By Maureen Howard. 270 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: 'My Child,' Despite Everything
description: ''You can plan all you want,'' Charlotte Evans says. ''That doesn't mean things will end up the way you think they will.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORDON, CHARLOTTE
description: GORDON-Charlotte. Thanks for Queens College days, for hamburgers on English muffins, for the New York Library and much more. Love, Ruth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, HERB
description: GROSSMAN-Herb. We at Beacon Laboratories deeply grieve and mourn his death and miss him as our friend and colleague. A brilliant professional with great vision who treated all with the utmost warmth and care. We're fortunate to have had the pleasure of working with Herb.

title: Welfare to Work: A Sequel
description: DeParle's article describes perfectly a major flaw in the welfare reform law. The law makes no provision for mental illness or substance abuse that typically make it almost impossible for people to move, in a straightforward ascent, to a productive work life. Perhaps the law, in its stubborn blindness to such realities, is expressing an irrational wish to ''punish'' people into mental health.

title: Word & Image; To Whom It May Concern
description: A ''committee of concerned journalists'' wants my signature on a ''Statement of Concern.'' It says that technology, economics and ''our relationship with the public'' have produced a crisis ''pulling journalism from its traditional moorings.'' Because I, too, feel intimidated by quirky computers, greedy stockholders and fickle readers, I reach for my pen.

title: January 11-17; Bid to Curb Prison Drugs
description: President Clinton signed a directive to get states to do more to purge their prisons of illegal drug use. As a condition of receiving Federal money to build more prisons, the states must report the extent of drug use among inmates and demonstrate progress toward eliminating it. Other legislation will let states tap Federal prison construction funds to test and treat prisoners for drug use. CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

title: Q. & A.
description: Dual Role For Agent Challenged

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Bleak House
description: VISITORS

title: Skip the Traffic, Skim the Waves
description: SOME see Dale Strand as a modern-day Robert Fulton ready to usher in a new age of high-speed ferry boats for commuters on the Long Island Sound. To others, he might as well be the infamous Captain Nemo about to disrupt Norwalk Harbor's boaters and plague quiet East Norwalk streets with cars racing to catch the next boat to New York City.

title: Three Walks On L.A.'s Wild Side
description: THERE is, perhaps, no better way of understanding the history of Los Angeles than by walking its Backbone Trail, which runs through a spectacular sweep of nature preserves extending along the spine of the Santa Monica Mountains, where the land meets the sea. If the new Getty Museum is being touted as the Acropolis of Los Angeles, a harbinger of civilization at its grandest, then the Backbone Trail in the hills to the west of the Getty is a homage to what is truly wild and still easily accessible: stunning waterfalls, wildflowers and hidden canyons that bespeak a time of uncivilized beauty. Not to mention movie stars.

title: The Office's Subconscious
description: ''My God, you sound like some dreary French intellectual who's just set foot in New York for the first time!'' cries George, the hero of Christopher Isherwood's 1964 novel, ''A Single Man.'' George is sputtering to his friend Cynthia, who has just spent a night in one of those ''ghastly new motels'' that are fast replacing old hotels of character. ''That's exactly the way they talk! Unreal! American motels are unreal! My good girl -- you know and I know that our motels are deliberately designed to be unreal, if you must use that idiotic jargon, for the very simple reason that an American motel room isn't a room in an hotel, it's the room, definitively, period. There is only one: The Room.''

title: Educator Joseph Murphy, 64, Former Chancellor of CUNY
description: Joseph S. Murphy, the son of a labor organizer and a champion of the working class who rose to become Chancellor of the City University of New York, died in an automobile accident near Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, yesterday. He was 64.

title: January 11-17; With Aid of a Cart A Golfer Makes History
description: A 25-year-old man last weekend became the first golfer outside the Senior Tour to use a cart in a tournament sanctioned by the Professional Golfers Association Tour.

title: Word for Word / Mayhem on the Tube; Television's Most Violent: It's Payback Time
description: LAST week a university study found that while violence has declined on network TV series, it has proliferated in a raft of new, reality-based ''shockumentaries'' featuring footage of people jumping to their deaths off burning buildings, cop shootouts and wild beasts tearing their jungle brethren to bloody shreds.

title: The View From/New Milford; Enter the Bulldozers, A Face Lift Downtown
description: NEW MILFORD Mayor Arthur J. Peitler has come across some newspaper clippings from the mid-1960's that chronicle ambitious plans for revitalizing the downtown area: Installing pretty patterned sidewalks, burying ugly utility wires, setting wrought-iron benches, gas-lit lamps and flowering fruit trees along the streets.

title: POSTINGS: $50 Million, 400,000-Square-Foot Building in Rockland County; For Mercedes-Benz, a Full-Size HQ
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America can look forward to more leg room when its new headquarters is completed on a 91-acre site in Pearl River, N.Y., in the fall of 1999. The new 400,000-square-foot building will be just four miles from the company's current 37-acre home in Montvale, N.J.

title: Historic House Was Built Of the Rock It Stands On
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A/William Stanley; Small-Town History, From the Heart
description: WILLIAM STANLEY of Norwich is a vice president of the stock brokerage firm Paine Webber, but his avocation is local history.

title: The Early Bird Gets the Seat
description: THOSE who have been aboard lately know that Amtrak has been undergoing steady changes in the last five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, RICHARD THOMAS
description: KENNEDY-Richard Thomas, Honorable. On Monday, January 12, 1998, the Honorable Richard Thomas Kennedy. Husband of Jean Martin Kennedy, brother of Margaret Krizanosky and Mary Parisi. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC, Thursday, January 22, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at Fort Myer Chapel Friday, January 23 at 12:45 P.M. Interment in Arlington National Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to Georgetown University Hospital, 3800 Reservoir Rd NW, Washington, D.C. 20007 or St. Ann's Infant and Maternity Home, 4901 Eastern Avenue, Hyattsville, Maryland 20782-3301.

title: Turning Up The Voltage
description: Chartreuse is spreading out of sportswear into everyday dress, from wool caps to coats to frog backpacks, below. The color came into prominence at last fall's New York Marathon, bottom, second from left. Long a favorite with bicyclists, skiers and the traffic police for reflecting vests, today the color is moving onto Fifth Avenue in a whole range of shadings, from screaming to subtle. Synthetic pile coats sing with the acid color, which was introduced by Elsa Schiaparelli in the late 1930's, when she was shocking the fashion world with a new color palette. Yet, its grating edge gives many in the fashion crowd the vapors.

title: Writers Driven, by the Nose, to Distraction
description: Living in the distraction-rich environment of the Upper West Side for more than a decade, Peter Cohn and Tony Gilroy, screenwriters, have learned how to work successfully through myriad distractions.

title: Brooklyn Could Have Been A Contender
description: Come on. Get it right. The so-called merger with New York City never happened. It has nothing to do with the soul of Brooklyn.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Polluted Tarrytown Riverside Site Draws Developer
description: A COMPANY whose stated mission is to acquire contaminated properties and turn them into viable mixed-used developments has contracted to buy 12 acres of industrial waterfront here and redevelop it into a residential, retail and recreational complex.

title: Out of the Quagmire on a Retirement Plan
description: HUNDREDS, perhaps thousands, of university professors and preparatory school teachers in Connecticut are sitting on seven-figure retirement accounts, but the pension plans and restrictions can be so complicated that even some of the best minds at Yale have cried out for help.

title: Q and A
description: Getting to the Guggenheim

title: Children's Books
description: ROSE DAUGHTER

title: E. Lopato, 77, Psychologist And a Champion of Libraries
description: Esther Wolf Lopato, a child psychologist who was active in civic affairs in Brooklyn and beyond, particularly on behalf of public libraries, died on Jan. 7 at her home in the Midwood neighborhood of Brooklyn. She was 77.

title: Clues, but No Guarantees
description: IT WAS A VERY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLANUEVA, JULIETA R.
description: VILLANUEVA-Julieta R. October 3, 1918 to January 13, 1998. Resided with her family in Queens Village, NY. She is survived by her four children and five grandchildren. Her final resting place will be in her home town and country of Cavite City, Philippines.

title: Singular Difficulty in Stopping Terrorism
description: More than two and a half years after the Oklahoma City bombing stunned the nation as the worst terrorist act on American soil, law-enforcement officials concede that it would be virtually impossible to stop it from happening again.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BENDER, JEREMY JON
description: BENDER-Jeremy Jon. Sept. 1, 1997. Gifted student, teacher of life, inspiration, joyous companion, exquisite friend. Your legacy lives on in everyone you touched. We miss and love you always. Friends are invited to attend the dedication of a Syringa Tree in loving memory at Washington Square Park, New York, New York, Sunday January 25, 1998 at 2:30PM.

title: Editorial Observer; The Nehru Dynasty Rises Once Again in India
description: A paradox of India's democracy is that the long-ruling Congress Party has survived less by keeping faith with its ideals than by keeping alive the dynastic flame lit by the founding Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru. Now once again in a moment of trial the party has called on a Nehru heir, the reclusive Italian-born widow of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, to try to reclaim power.

description: CITYWIDE

title: Master of Shrieks Lowers the Volume
description: THE OTHER DAY, Kevin Williamson's assistant came to him with a question about a screenplay of his that she had just finished reading. ''Kevin,'' she said, ''who is Zeke?'' It was then that Mr. Williamson realized he had unintentionally plucked a character from a science fiction movie he is writing and placed the character in another screenplay in progress, this one a dark comedy titled ''Killing Mrs. Tingle.''

title: The Nation: U.S. v. Microsoft FAQ; Court Is Not Where They'd Like to Go Today
description: MICROSOFT and the Justice Department were at each others' throats again last week. The venue was a United States District Court in Washington, where a Microsoft programming maven and a Government software expert testified on the fine points of Internet browsers and operating system software.

title: Are H.M.O.'s Better at Cutting Costs or Quality?; Ignoring the Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Street Smarts
description: In William Wyler's astute DEAD END (1937), from Sidney Kingsley's stage drama of life in New York City tenements, a ripe variety of Manhattan characters throngs the screen: a returned gangster (Humphrey Bogart), a worn, menial worker (Sylvia Sidney), a smitten young architect (Joel McCrea), several rich tenants and a feisty young street gang (Huntz Hall, Billy Halop, Gabriel Dell, above, and the other Dead End Kids from the Broadway show). The brash youngsters again almost steal the show as the plot becomes tense and gripping. Wyler's keen direction and Gregg Toland's stunningly artful photography of the urban vignettes give the picture a stunning, artistic ambiance -- SATURDAY at 9:30 A.M. on AMERICAN MOVIE CLASSICS. Howard Thompson

title: A Young Composer Leaps Ahead of a Promising Pack
description: AMERICAN COMPOSERS OF ''serious'' music labor invisibly in a country enthralled by popular culture. Only a lucky few achieve fame outside the classical-music ghetto. Philip Glass and Steve Reich did so two decades back, and already 10 years ago the younger generation included many worthy candidates: Michael Torke, Aaron Jay Kernis, David Lang, Tobias Picker and Julia Wolfe.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER MANHATTAN; Mormon Church Grows Apace in Hispanic Neighborhoods
description: People filed into the gymnasium of the Herbert G. Birch school on Fort Washington Avenue last Sunday morning as Francisco Sandoval, the local branch president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, was beginning the service. ''Buenos dias, hermanos'' (''Hello, brothers''), Mr. Sandoval said, greeting 300 Spanish-speaking worshipers.

title: Manfredy Stops a Badly Cut Gatti in Eighth Round
description: Arturo Gatti's penchant for getting into ring wars caught up with him tonight in his lightweight bout against Angel Manfredy at the Atlantic City Convention Center.

title: An Otherwise Typical Boy's Passion for the Violin
description: EVERY Saturday morning, while his friends are sleeping late, Jonathan Zalben takes the train from Port Washington to Manhattan before 7:30 and does not return until 7 P.M.

title: The World; Arafat Trims His Hopes And Pins Them on Clinton
description: WHILE Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his ministers have been working overtime to prepare an arsenal of claims, resolutions, strategies and demands for Mr. Netanyahu's meeting with President Clinton this week, Yasir Arafat has mostly been waiting.
