title: Small Firm's Employees Stung by Lost Retirement Money
description: After a lifetime of New England winters, June Bavin and her husband dreamed of buying a home in Savannah, Ga., where they could spend their retirement years close to their daughter.

title: Fighting Fish
description: To the Editor: While not passionately involved in animal rights causes other than donating to local shelters for stray cats and dogs, I do have a personal love, respect, for animal life. I took exception to a phrase in ''Hopping From Key to Key'' (Nov. 23) discussing bonefish; the small game fish are ''beloved'' for the fight they put up. Popular, maybe, but certainly there is nothing to be loved about any living creature's putting up a fierce fight for its life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MILDRED
description: KAUFMAN-Mildred. Adieu to our dear friend of forty years. Your sparkling smile always lit up our lives. We mourn along with your darling Stanley, children and grandchildren. Bev and Stan Schaffer

title: Ann Whelehan, Michael Smego
description: Ann Marie Whelehan, a daughter of Noreen and Oliver Whelehan of Miller Place, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael John Smego, a son of Margaret and Richard Smego of Oak Brook, Ill. The Rev. Julian von Duerbeck performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Louis de Montford Church in Sound Beach, N.Y.

title: Syria Warns U.S. It Must Act to Rescue Mideast Peace Effort
description: Saying the quest for broader peace in the Middle East has reached ''a very critical moment,'' Syria warned tonight that American credibility could plummet across the region unless President Clinton can use meetings in Washington this week to put the effort ''back on the right track.''

title: Argentines Fight Razing Of a Place Of Horrors
description: From the stately gates, which is as close as most civilians can approach, the colonnaded buildings of the Navy Mechanics School here offer little hint of the atrocities that took place inside during the military dictatorship that ended 15 years ago.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: For Shame

title: Planning an Upper East Side Building for the Elderly
description: AT the age of 80, Rena Hamelfarb describes herself as basically healthy, although the medical bills have begun to pour in, mainly for an ophthalmologist and a dentist. ''I must have spent $15,000 on my teeth in the last five years,'' Ms. Hamelfarb said.

title: COVER STORY; Forget the Alamo; Remember This Victory
description: The Battle of San Jacinto was hardly history's longest military engagement. It lasted all of 18 minutes. Nor was it the biggest. A mere 2,000 men took the field that day. But for all its brevity and lack of scale, the Battle of San Jacinto, fought on April 21, 1836, not far from Houston, was a pivotal event. After a number of setbacks, Texas defeated the Mexican Army and won its freedom, forcing the dictator Santa Anna to withdraw his forces south of the Rio Grande and to recognize Texas as an independent republic. The Texas Revolution had triumphed.

title: Slighting Minorities
description: To the Editor:

title: MY JUNKER, RIGHT OR WRONG
description: After the city government of Saratoga, Wyo. -- pop. 2,500 -- passed an ordinance banning junk cars, disgruntled citizens fought back. Invoking a never-used clause in state law, the pro-clunker contingent forced a referendum last month and soundly rejected the beautification attempt, which was seen as a nefarious first step leading to yuppified socialism. ''We like as little government as possible,'' says Mitch Zeiger, a self-proclaimed redneck whose family runs an auto-repair shop on the edge of town. ''It may be junk, but it has value if the right person comes by.'' Christine Wickstrom, a housewife who helped form the opposition, is fond of her 1951 Ford stock truck, rusting behind the garage. ''We like this town the way it is,'' she says. ''We're mostly working-class people. Who cares if I have a ratty old truck out back?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, FELIX
description: KLEIN-Felix. 1/17/11-7/26/94 ''Sometimes when one person is missing, the whole world seems depopulated.'' (Lamartine) Forever missed by Janice

title: The View From/Bedford Hills; A Celebration of King Becomes a Call to Action
description: JUDITH LEWIS, a member of the Antioch Baptist Church here, is the very picture of a poised, successful woman. At the memorial banquet for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., sponsored by the church and held at the Tarrytown Marriott last weekend, she was wearing exquisitely beaded silver high-heel shoes, a gray silk dress and matching gray pearls.

title: Commercial Property The Rockefeller Group; A Show Biz Curtain, a Development Activity Revival
description: IT'S a long way from owning the Rockettes to tending to the care and feeding of scientists who might rather be in California, but the Rockefeller Group, the company that was left when Rockefeller Center was sold to an investment group led by Tishman-Speyer Properties and Goldman, Sachs, is trying to do just that.

title: Are H.M.O.'s Better at Cutting Costs or Quality?; Less vs. Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Ban of Islamic Party Won't Deter It, Leader Says
description: When Turkey's highest court banned the Islamic-oriented Welfare Party on Friday, it also ruled that the party leader, former Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, could not participate in politics for the next five years.

title: Fast Forward; Genome Dread
description: Astonishing increases in chip capacity and processing speed are yesterday's news in the semiconductor business, but now biomedicine is about to be transformed by similar technological leaps. Ingenious microarrays of genetic probes known as biochips are getting so small that you can almost hide one under a postage stamp. It's less easy, however, to hide from the prophetic reach of the technology.

title: Aftercare for the Stately Holiday Amaryllis
description: AMARYLLIS was the gift of choice this year. Many homes were dazzled by these huge trumpet flowers and their brilliance has lasted well into the month. The flower colors can be anywhere from the bright red Fire Dance, to the delicate white Apple Blossom with its pink stripes, to the newer picotee hybrids with darker edges on the petals.

title: MORE INDIE THAN THOU
description: * The Slamdance Film Festival (Jan. 16 to 23), in its fourth year, bills itself as the alternative to the Sundance Film Festival (Jan. 15 to 25), which some indie-film people now find too Hollywood. * It has at least succeeded in angering Robert Redford, the founder of Sundance. He has referred to the festival as ''parasitical.'' * A typical 1998 Slamdance entry: ''Cannibal: The Musical,'' by Trey Parker, a creator of the Comedy Central TV hit ''South Park.'' It's described as ''a cross between 'Oklahoma!' and 'Friday the 13th, Part II.''' * There's also ''Scrapple,'' which is touted as '''Babe' on acid,'' and ''Junky,'' about a cracker-addicted parrot who's molested by his owner. * Peripheral to both fests, four producers are showing ''The Sound of One Hand Clapping,'' a five-minute film, and calling this mini-mini-festival Undance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, JACK
description: HOLLAND-Jack. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with sorrow the passing of a respected member of our Society of Founders, who with his family, did much to enhance the educational and research programs at our institution. To his children, Stephen and Margot, and Richard and Lila, to his brother, Emil, and to his entire family, we offer our profound sympathy. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Board of Overseers Albert Einstein College of Medicine Dr. Dominick P. Purpura, Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: January 11-17; Lullabies by Brahms and Others
description: Rush Limbaugh questioned whether it was really the proper role of government. Neal Boortz, a radio talk show host in Atlanta, suggested that the state would next want to give each Georgia newborn a compact disk player.

title: Forbidding Fruit
description: IT wasn't the bullet trains, or the Buddhist temples, or the ineffable flavor of blowfish that left the greatest impression upon me during my recent visit to Japan. It was a cantaloupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMPARATO, ARTHUR J.
description: IMPARATO-Arthur J., 75, founder and publisher of the fashion newspaper Fabricnews. Husband of international fashion journalist Marylou Luther Imparato, January 16, of heart failure. In addition to his wife, Mr. Imparato is survived by three sons Arthur J. Imparato, Jr, of Beverly Hills, CA, Walter A. Imparato of Manhattan and Andrew J. Imparato of Baltimore, MD, as well as a daughter Kathleen A. Imparato of Long Beach, CA, and a grandson. A Funeral Mass will be held Tuesday, January 20, at 11 AM, at Church of Our Savior, 38th and Park in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Arthur J. Imparato Memorial Fund, c/o James Tenopir, Ed. D., Superintendent, Cambridge Public Schools, PO Box 100, Cambridge, Nebraska 69022.

title: Correction
description: The Food column on Dec. 28, about cooking for the New Year, referred incorrectly to a chef, Douglas Rodriguez. He is still at Patria restaurant in Manhattan; he did not move to Florida.

title: Audience Picks the Winner as Playwrights Compete
description: It's about as far off Broadway as you can get: the fourth floor of a loft building on Hudson Street, directly opposite the exit from the Holland Tunnel. But for Quincy Rene Dickerson, actress, dancer, aspiring playwright and director from Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the Riant Theater might just as well be in the heart of Times Square.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Foggy Mountain Breakdown

title: That Old-Time Religion
description: STEALING JESUS

title: Rome Cabs
description: To the Editor: Having read the letter about the cabdriver in Rome who pretended to have received a tenth of what he really got (Letters, Nov. 16), I realize that Joseph Collins either had the same cabdriver I had two years ago or this is common practice. When it happened to me, it was a 100,000-lire note I gave the cabbie that he switched with a 10,000-lire note. Later, when I counted my money, I knew I'd been taken, meaning that I'd paid about $50 for a $5 cab ride. I think all tourists to Italy should be aware that when we arrive, usually it's after traveling all night, and we are not used to dealing with such high numbers so we are easily fooled. I wish I'd thought to take his license number, as Mr. Collins did.

title: January 11-17; Public Still Backs Abortion, But With Limits
description: Twenty-five years after the Supreme Court's landmark Roe v. Wade decision, public opinion has shifted away from general acceptance of legal abortion and toward what some people call a position of ''permit but discourage.''

title: Correction
description: The Food column on Dec. 28, about cooking for the New Year, referred incorrectly to a chef, Douglas Rodriguez. He is still at Patria restaurant in Manhattan; he did not move to Florida.

title: Film Traces Life of 18th-Century Midwife
description: ''WHO is the father?'' the woman asked, compassionate yet firm, as she ministered to a birth. The mother, at the height of labor, answered between screams, ''Your son Jonathan Ballard.''

title: Ideas & Trends: Virtual Migrants; Need Programmers? Surf Abroad.
description: THE nation has a shortage of techies, as last week's Government plan to help train more programmers made clear. But corporate America has already hit on a response. It's global telecommuting, through which this nation's technology companies have created a whole new realm of international trade by exporting their work and hiring programmers overseas to do it.

title: How a Documentarian Found Instant Fame and Glamour
description: SOON AFTER JESSICA YU learned that her short film ''Breathing Lessons: The Life and Work of Mark O'Brien'' had been nominated for an Academy Award last year, she realized that her life, at least for the moment, was bound to be anything but ordinary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MILDRED KALTER
description: KAUFMAN-Mildred Kalter. On January 15. Beloved wife of Stanley. Devoted mother of Eileen Grotsky, Jonathan Terner and Andrew Terner. Dear sister of Grace and Diane. She passed away at her home in Frenchman's Creek, Florida after a lengthy illness. She was a member of Metropolis Country Club in White Plains, N.Y. Known for her radiant smile, sense of humor and ability to light up a room, her loves included music and dancing, but most of all, people. In her travels and at home she touched old and new friends alike, with her warmth, honesty and indomitable spirit. She is also survived by two loving grandchildren Adam and Jennifer; her adoring extended family Michael and Carol; five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Funeral services will be held 10AM Sunday, January 18 at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers kindly send donations to your favorite charity.

title: Carolyn Sargent, John Carey
description: Carolyn Nell Sargent, the daughter of Carolyn H. Cook of Santa Fe, N.M., and Henry B. Sargent Jr. of Phoenix, was married yesterday to John Carey, a son of Johanna and John Carey of Clonmel, Ireland. The Rev. Jane Rockman performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in New York.

title: Helmsley, Poised to Sell Empire, Mends Fences Along the Way
description: When Leona Helmsley, wearing a knee-length black dress trimmed in fur, entered the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton on Thursday night, she was mobbed by young deal makers, real estate brokers and some of the top landlords of Manhattan.

title: Rose-Colored Glasses and Gardens Don't Mix
description: IN the interest of sheltering the greenhouse from strong winds, I planted a row of American arborvitae. Never mind that the greenhouse wasn't built yet. I knew where it would go eventually.

title: Police Seek Suspect In Rape at Macy's
description: A 49-year-old woman was raped Friday night in a seventh-floor stockroom of Macy's flagship department store in Herald Square, the police said yesterday.

title: Old Timers Recognize a New Face: Female
description: AS a girl enthralled with sports, Donna Lopiano thought nothing of tucking her long hair under a football helmet and going head to head with boys her age, and sometimes older, in sandlot football games on the West Side of Stamford.

title: A Father of Low-Tech Invention
description: As near as Charles Foley can recall, he was 18 years old when he told his mother that he expected to invent things that would be known and used everywhere.

title: Richard Mack and Christine Jamison
description: Christine Jamison, a daughter of Kerstin V. Jamison of Stockholm and Frank L. Jamison of Baton Rouge, La., was married last evening to Richard Mack, a son of Phyllis and William L. Mack of New York. Rabbi Elana Zaiman performed the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEINGOLD, SALLY R.
description: SHEINGOLD-Sally R. On January 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted sister of the late Marjorie Rothenberg, and dear friend. Graveside service Sunday, 11 AM, at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY.

title: Paying Homage as Only Another Master Can
description: WHEN TITIAN'S ''RAPE OF EUROPA'' arrived in Boston in 1896, Isabella Stewart Gardner, the city's most famous art collector and the painting's new owner, wrote rapturously to the art historian and connoisseur Bernard Berenson, who had procured it for her: ''I am breathless after a two days' orgy, drinking myself drunk with 'Europa,' thinking and dreaming about her.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HERMAN ''HANK''
description: GREENBERG-Herman ''Hank'', 66, of Ft. Lee, NJ and Upper Greenwood Lake, NJ, passed away January 16, 1998 after a long valiant battle with cancer. A 40year member of Temple Gates of Prayer, of Flushing NY, Mr. Greenberg was a past president and a member of the Board of Trustees. He also chaired the reconstruction committee after the temple was destroyed by fire in 1977. He was a past president of the Hebrew Academy of North Queens, Bayside, NY, president of the Lumber Store Inc. of Greenwich Village, and served in the U.S. Army as a medic in the Korean War. He was honored by Israel Bonds, UJA, Federation, the Jewish Theological Seminary, Temple Gates of Prayer, and Hebrew Academy of North Queens. Beloved husband of Connie for 47 years, devoted father of Stewart (Wendy) Greenberg, Karen (Saul) Chapnick, Judi (Gary) Krasna, dear brother of Edythe Schaeffer, adored grandfather of Melissa, Jonathan, Jennifer, Michael, Matthew, Daniel, Amanda, and Michael, caring son-in-law of Helene Schmuger, dear uncle of many nieces and nephews, and a friend to many. Funeral services will be held 1:15 PM Sunday, January 18, 1998 at Temple Gates of Prayer, 38-20 Parsons Avenue, Flushing, NY, with interment to follow at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, NJ. For information call I.J. Morris in Brooklyn, NY (718) 377-8610

title: A Stalwart of Old-Fashioned Deli Fare
description: HOT pastrami and corned beef connoisseurs like to talk about Jewish delicatessens almost as much as they enjoy eating at them. And when they do, legendary deli names like the Carnegie, the Second Avenue, the Stage and perhaps the Pastrami King are sure to come up.

title: Portrait of Young People as Artists
description: Dawoud Bey, the acclaimed portraitist of African-American life, returned home to Queens recently. On the edge of the park where he visited the World's Fair in 1964 -- long before he knew what he could or would become -- he took lush, oversized photos of the young men and women who now inhabit his childhood turf, portraits of artsy teen-agers with fuzzy dreams of their own.

title: Offering School Choice, But Not Very Much
description: It seemed as if Governor Whitman had forgotten all about the concept of school choice. Though it was one of her pet topics during her first gubernatorial campaign, it proved politically unpopular. By the time she was up for re-election, the Governor had stopped talking about the subject altogether.

title: Reckless Behavior
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Good News From Bad for Ski Helmets
description: SHORTLY after Sonny Bono became the second celebrity in a week to die in a skiing accident, the phones at the Bell Sports Corporation began ringing off the hook. Bell, best known as a manufacturer of bicycle helmets, had introduced its first skiing and snowboarding helmets just a few weeks before Michael L. Kennedy, and then Mr. Bono, suffered fatal head injuries on the slopes.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS: GAMBLING WITH THEIR GAMES -- A special report; Images in Conflict: Crack of the Bat, Crash of the Puck and a Roll of the Dice
description: When Major League Baseball officials were in the process of approving the Walt Disney Company as the controlling owner of the Anaheim Angels, they asked for and received a formal statement from Disney that it would not have gambling on its cruise ships, which begin sailing later this year. When the National Hockey League accepted four expansion teams last summer, the league negotiated agreements with the new owners that they would not become involved in casinos.

title: THE GUIDE
description: The Harlem Renaissance

title: American Airlines Expands Latin Tours
description: Using its expanded flight schedule in Latin America, American Airlines has developed an extensive program of excursions to Central and South America.

title: Works That Are Made From Textiles
description: THE show at the Hudson River Museum here is called ''Hanging by a Thread,'' but it is a strong thread and one long enough to have historical significance. The title is linked to a 22-artist survey of fine art made from textiles.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Here People Eat Dreams
description: Myths and legends are usually straightforward parables. But not those in THE MIRROR OF LIDA SAL (Latin American Literary Review, paper, $14.95). Here Miguel Angel Asturias, the 1967 Nobel laureate, retells some of the traditional stories of his native Guatemala in an elliptical, languid prose that is bewildering and enchanting, and never simple. Translated for the first time -- by Gilbert Alter-Gilbert -- more than 20 years after its author's death (and 30 years after its Spanish publication), the book challenges readers with frequent convolutions leading to destinations that are hard to pin down. Hard because Mayan mythology and Guatemalan folk tales are themselves of a convoluted nature, full of the stops and starts of mistake-prone deities and human bumblers. And also hard because Asturias was working toward a new, myth-based fiction and an undercurrent of complexity fitted his purposes. ''The Indians of Guatemala,'' he writes, ''are like fragments of the imagination.'' So are these stories featuring people who eat dreams, a man who ''disappeared for the sake of disappearing'' and a church bell that refuses to ring. ''The Mirror of Lida Sal'' is a surreal journey through a landscape charged with light ironies and weighty implications. James Polk

title: Potential Is Still The Word on China
description: PATIENCE is essential, said State Representative Marilyn Hess of Greenwich, who, along with 15 business leaders from around the state, recently returned from a trip to China.

title: Hoyas Bring a Buzz, But Can't Stop UConn
description: All that matters, even now, is that the visiting uniforms say Georgetown. The brightest memories may be more than a decade old. The roster may be reduced to eight scholarship players because of injuries. Most of the faces may be unrecognizable, if earnest. But the volume in the Hartford Civic Center, and the look in the eyes of the Connecticut Huskies, said that the Hoyas were here.

title: Clinton, in First for a President, Testifies in Sex Harassment Suit
description: After five years of scandalous rumors and heated court fighting, President Clinton journeyed a block from the White House today to face Paula Corbin Jones and defend himself under oath against her allegations of sexual misconduct.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Dineh Mohajer; How Sweet It Is To Turn Blue Into Gold
description: DINEH MOHAJER, 25, the founder of Hard Candy cosmetics, looked as if she were about to rob a bank.

title: With the All-Star Game and the Olympics, the N.H.L. Tries to Extend Its Global Reach
description: When the 19-year-old Wayne Gretzky played in his first National Hockey League All-Star game 18 years ago as a member of the Clarence Campbell Conference team, the opposing Prince of Wales Conference had a 51-year-old right wing named Gordie Howe. Gretzky was a young star in his rookie N.H.L. season. Howe was an old star in his final season. But they had one thing in common: Both were Canadian, as were the overwhelming majority of All-Star participants and N.H.L. players in general.

title: Thousands Across France Stage Marches For the Jobless
description: Thousands of demonstrators and jobless workers poured down the Boulevard du Temple in eastern Paris today, chanting slogans warning the left-wing French Government to do more for France's three million unemployed people or be thrown out of office as its conservative predecessor was.

title: A Feisty Female Rapper Breaks a Hip-Hop Taboo
description: THE LYRICS ALONE DON'T distinguish ''Girlfriend,'' a track on the new album by the rapper Queen Pen, from other rap songs. After all, bragging about luring a woman away from her boyfriend is practically de rigueur on a hip-hop album. ''If that's your girlfriend, she wasn't last night,'' Queen Pen taunts a cuckolded beau.

title: City, Country, City
description: One year ago tomorrow, the writer Elizabeth Hawes wrote a Soapbox essay titled ''Hello Again'' about her impending move back to Manhattan after 18 years in a Connecticut farmhouse. ''I wonder,'' she wrote then, ''if my city persona is still vibrant intact, buried under my country patina like a layer of original paint.'' Here is how the move turned out:

title: Habitats/35 Wyckoff Avenue, Boerum Hill; Digging Up History
description: LAUREN GLANT gazed at the contents of a small plastic container as if they were diamonds.

title: A World Beyond
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Testing Asian Values
description: Philip Tose, the chairman of what was until last week Asia's largest investment bank outside Japan, was one of the biggest fans of what came to be known as ''Asian values.'' In 1992, one of the boom years, Mr. Tose extolled the virtues of ''strong government -- some would call it dictatorship,'' which ''delivered much better economic growth.'' His Hong Kong-based Peregrine Investments Holdings went into bankruptcy on Monday because it had placed too large a bet on one of those strong governments, Indonesia.

title: N.H.L. Ponders Rules to Aid Scoring
description: The National Hockey League has identified the sickness. It is just not sure about the cure.

title: Elana Matthews, W. D. Needelman
description: Elana Chaya Matthews, the daughter of Judith and Steven Matthews of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to William David Needelman, a son of Margaret L. Needelman and Dr. Jerold L. Needelman of Northbrook, Ill. Rabbi Paul Resnick officiated at the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGER, CHARLOTTE M.
description: KRIEGER-Charlotte M. 90, of East Orange, NJ. Died on January 17, 1998. Wife of the late Arthur Krieger, mother of Lewis Krieger, grandmother of Elizabeth Krieger and the late Alexander Krieger. Graduate of Wellesley College, Class of 1927. A member of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Livingston, NJ. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alex Krieger Memorial fund at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: MR. FINE, PORCUPINE. By Fanny Joly. Illustrated by Remi Saillard. Chronicle. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) While the illustrations to Mr. Fine's lament about the prickly problems of being a porcupine are very witty, the text has lost some sparkle in the translation from the French. Of course, true love finds a way.

title: Arts Center to Share Its Former Building
description: THE Northern Westchester Center for the Arts has sold its 52,000-square-foot building here to two partners who plan to lease 30,000 square feet back to the art center for its programs.

title: Graduating to the High Seas
description: Edward Micola and a few of his friends spent a recent Thursday night reminiscing about their past and speculating about their future. All three graduated from college in 1996 and have landed good jobs. One is a social worker at New York University. Another, who majored in sculpture, does graphic design for J. Crew.

title: On Avenue of Americas, No Panama, Paraguay, Peru
description: When Sixth Avenue was officially renamed Avenue of the Americas in 1945, it was lined with colorful medallions bearing the coats of arms of the hemisphere's nations. Now many are missing and those that remain are rusting and neglected on lampposts at either end of the thoroughfare.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Why Builders Want Buyers to Use Their Lenders
description: WHEN Brian Gill and his wife, Karen, signed a contract last February to purchase a 4-bedroom, $425,000 colonial in the Villages at Huntington in Melville, they needed an immediate mortgage commitment even though delivery of the house was more than a year away.

title: Borrowing From Nature
description: JUNE WILSON is driving to her studio through an area where remnants of the old rural life of Monmouth County can still be spotted amid rampant suburbanization. On the way, she has been talking mostly about animals: the herd of cows taking advantage of unseasonable January warmth to sun themselves, the flock of geese near the neighborhood pond, the deer that regularly appear in her yard. ''Usually you just see the fawns,'' she says. ''The mothers are hidden nearby, but the moment something startles them, the does leap and the fawns are gone after them.''

title: January 11-17; Blast From the Past
description: ''I see this as another adventure into the unknown,'' Senator John Glenn ex-plained, referring to the stunning news that, at the age of 77, he will become an astronaut once more. Whether in the interests of pure science or national joy riding, Senator Glenn is to be rocketed up for a 10-day trip in October.

title: Lives; Silent Sundays
description: I don't talk on Sundays. I haven't in more than three years. When my grandfather died, my last memory of him was hearing him yell at my grandmother. He had been ill for years, and his anger with his failing body often overwhelmed him. His death in 1994 focused both my desire to honor him and to get my own life in order.

title: Montana Has Mountains Like Switzerland and Wants Numbered Accounts
description: When people think of Montana, what comes to mind are trophy trout, no daytime speed limit and the occasional mountain hermit. That is all well and good, but state officials would like to project something entirely new: the last best place for rich foreigners to hide their money.

title: Group Behind Paula Jones Gains Critics as Well as Fame
description: The legal and financial energy behind Paula Corbin Jones and her sexual misconduct suit against President Clinton is generated these days from a drab two-story office building alongside a strip mall just north of Charlottesville, Va.

title: $185,000 Tables And Such
description: DRESSED in fur-trimmed couture clothes, dazzling jewels and fabulous boas, an army of ladies who shop descended on the Seventh Regiment Armory on Thursday night, husbands or decorators in tow. It was that annual harbinger of the hibernal social season, the Winter Antiques Show.

title: Unorthodox Weddings Not a Problem for Rabbi
description: PATRICIA CHABRIER GOODMAN, a churchgoing Roman Catholic who lives in Bayside, Queens, remembers the first time she met Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman. It was 1989 and he was presiding over the marriage of two of her friends, one Jewish, one Protestant. When it came time for him to speak, he joked that the wine was a blend of Manischewitz and Christian Brothers. She thought that if her boyfriend, who was Jewish, ever got around to proposing, this would be the rabbi to do the wedding.

title: The Nation; What $13 Million Buys Besides an Hour of TV
description: SO NBC agreed last week to pay $13 million an episode to hold onto television's most popular show, ''E.R.,'' thereby pumping life into the network for at least another year. The deal-makers were congratulating themselves about all the zeroes before the decimal point. The cast was looking forward to one big payday after another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESENFELD, WILLIAM A.
description: RIESENFELD-William A. The Officers, Board members and the entire Beth Abraham Health Services community are profoundly saddened by the death of William Riesenfeld and mourn his passing. Bill approached everything he did with commitment and dedication, whether it was sports fishing (he held several world records) or competing in Squash (he was nationaly ranked) or emersing himself in health care. As a member of the Beth Abraham board since 1972, retiring as Chairman in 1996, he gave generously of himself, his time and knowledge. His guidance was of particular value in the area of real estate. He had a strong sense of humanity and displayed great empathy when visiting our patients. We will miss his wisdom and counsel and always cherish his memory. Edwin H. Stern, III Chairman, Board of Directors BETHCO Michael R. Potack Chairman, Board of Directors Beth Abraham Health Services William H. Frohlich President Beth Abraham Health Services

title: Holocaust Museum Rebuffs Arafat's Plan for a State Visit
description: Encouraged by the State Department, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, made plans to visit the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum here next week, but he canceled his plans when museum officials refused to treat it as a state visit.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be legally observed.

title: Lalique's Dazzling Designs
description: Nothing made a woman more glamorous in turn-of-the-century Paris than wearing jewelry created by Rene Lalique. Sarah Bernhardt often appeared on stage bedecked in his brilliant designs. Although primarily known for his glass objects, Lalique's technical ingenuity and use of a variety of materials in his jewelry -- glass, horn, enamel, precious stones and crystal -- won praise from both art critics and jewelry collectors. He revolutionized design by emphasizing imagination over cost and took jewelry into the realm of Art Nouveau.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WHISKEY'S CHILDREN

title: Our Day-Care Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: At 50, Taking the Stage (and a Risk) Alone
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV was an eye-grabbing blaze of cool fire from his first performances as a Kirov Ballet Wunderkind in the late 1960's. Now, a few days short of turning 50, Mr. Baryshnikov will take the daring step of performing an entire program of solos, his first such venture in the United States. Starting Wednesday at City Center, he will give five performances of the kind of edgy, thought-provoking dances for which he and his company, the White Oak Dance Project, have become known.

title: On Language; The Slow-Walk Issue
description: ' People slow-walk things, you know, especially if you've got a cutoff date,'' said Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, complaining to reporters last summer about the obfuscation he had faced from the White House in his investigation of campaign finance. He repeated the verb more emphatically as his hearings drew to a close: ''We have been slow-walked and deferred and had objections every step of the way.''

title: Developer Has Another Year To Await Trial
description: The criminal trial of Tommy Huang, Flushing's biggest developer, was adjourned until next year by a Queens State Supreme Court judge earlier this month after Mr. Huang's lawyers claimed that he could not get a fair trial in Queens. His lawyers have requested a change of venue.

title: From the Folks at Global Warming, a Tropical Baked Alaska
description: A DESSERT to chase winter doldrums is one that calls on sunny tropical flavors. Coconut, mango, orange and the like not only brighten a dinner party but, when combined to make baked alaska, also give delightful panache to the meal.

title: Are H.M.O.'s Better at Cutting Costs or Quality?; Lack of Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Shaking Out the Dustbin
description: FROM THE OTHER SHORE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KINGSLEY, CHARLES R.
description: KINGSLEY-Charles R. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Charles R. Kingsley will be held Sunday, February 1, at 1 PM at the Eastview Technology Center, 350 Main Street, White Plains. For more information call Westchester ARC at 914-428-8330 X 338

title: Spain's Freest Spirit Gives Maturity a Try
description: AT 46, PEDRO ALMODOVAR IS NO longer the overgrown kid he was back in the early 1980's when he sprang from the thick of Madrid's anything-goes night life, armed with a hand-held camera, to record the intoxication of Spain's post-Franco freedoms.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BENEDICT ARNOlD

title: Stoudamire a Knick? Why Not?
description: Toronto's Damon Stoudamire has scenarios spinning in his head as the National Basketball Association's Feb. 19 trade deadline nears.

title: 'In an Old House In Paris . . . .'
description: ''O.K., O.K., GIRLS!'' the director Daisy von Scherler Mayer shouted to a dozen identically dressed 9-year-olds who had begun to squirm. ''Sing a Spice Girls song in your head with no words, no sound!''

title: A Drawing Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: The Original Mr. Fix-It Gives Way to a Super-Salesman
description: You'd think it would be a day to stay near your boss. At a meeting of I.B.M.'s elite executive committee two weeks ago, Louis V. Gerstner, the company's chief executive, named Samuel J. Palmisano to run its fast-growing services division. But midway through the meeting, Mr. Palmisano excused himself and hopped a plane to Detroit to call on Kmart, a big customer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Eliza and Simon. Brother of Timothy and Ian Clark. Son of Blair Clark and the late Jessie Holladay Philbin James. Memorial service, Tuesday, January 20, 10:30 AM at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73 St., NYC.

title: John Malloy, Courtney Keany
description: Courtney Vanessa Keany, a daughter of Susanne and Sutton Keany of Bronxville, N.Y., was married in Philadelphia yesterday to John Peter Malloy, a son of Gertrude and Peter Malloy of North Haledon, N.J. The Rev. Robert Daley, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Union League of Philadelphia.

title: Sports of The Times; All of Those Billions, The Good and the Bad
description: FOR every National Football League franchise, the good news is all those freshly minted billions from the new television contracts. Jerry Jones, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, who helped negotiate the television deals, expects that each club will collect about $80 million from television this year and that each club's salary cap for 1998 will be $53 million, up from $41 million.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Burning Desires To Enter Hot Business

title: VIEWS; From Foul to Fair, When They Make the Call, People Listen
description: Headline - and history - were made last fall when the National Basketball Association sent women onto the court in black-and-white-striped shirts, the first time female referees have officiated in any of America's four major professional sports leagues.

title: Sleeping on a Cot, Putting Dreams on Paper
description: WHEN THE ART DEALER Bonnie Grossman first discovered the fantastic architectural drawings of Achilles G. Rizzoli seven years ago, she was struck by their formal beauty and meticulous draftsmanship. Her attention was also riveted by qualities that might make a more conventional connoisseur shudder -- the compulsive elaboration, religious mania, creepy sexual overtones and frequently incomprehensible wordplay that indicated that Rizzoli's mental state had veered considerably wide of normal.

title: TriBeCa Fare: Tried and New
description: GIGINO* [rating: one star]

title: Who Will Do Abortions Here?
description: On a cold Minnesota morn- ing, the abortion doctor and I pushed his six-seater plane out of the hangar and onto the runway. We removed the leather nose cozy (handmade by his wife), cranked the prop and minutes later were aloft above the linear plats etched along the Laurentian Divide. We were heading east to Fargo, where the doctor single-handedly keeps North Dakota's last abortion clinic open every Wednesday.

title: Don't Know Much Biology
description: Lifelines

title: The 100,000-Mile Tuneup: Just Make Some Pit Stops Along the Way
description: FOR car owners who have spent too much time in the waiting rooms of dealership service departments, the promise seems too good to be true: 100,000 miles without a tuneup. But this feature, often promoted in auto advertisements today, comes with some significant fine print.

title: Quandary on Donor Eggs: What to Tell the Children
description: In the quiet moments they share with their 5-year-old, when they are brushing her hair or tucking her in for the night, Lynn and Peter G. like to tell their daughter the story of her birth. Children love such tales, and theirs is typical -- loving parents, a wanted pregnancy, an adorable baby.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIKLIN, SCOTT
description: RIKLIN-Scott. Jan. 16, 1952-Aug. 8, 1996 Another sad birthday. Always in our hearts. Mom, Dad, Jeff, Matt

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture last Sunday, with the contents column, was published in error. It showed a house in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., featured in the issue's Habitats column -- not related to the article on living in Plainsboro, N.J.

title: Glen Cove Rallies to Provide Shelter for Homeless
description: ONE by one the men, women and children on line outside the old church in Glen Cove entered through the basement door to the soup kitchen inside. The mood on this damp winter day was almost jovial as the lighted room promised warmth and the smell of hot food wafted to the cold outdoor air.

title: Brooklyn Could Have Been A Contender
description: Tierney's article on Brooklyn's merger with Manhattan fails to describe a single specific public-investment project to help out Brooklyn. Yet, his Big City column ''Piazza Broadway,'' in the same issue, advocates redesigning six city blocks, rerouting traffic and building a pedestrian mall -- to improve what? Manhattan's Times Square.

title: HUSSEIN DELIVERS A NEW ULTIMATUM ON U.N. INSPECTORS
description: President Saddam Hussein threatened today to expel all United Nations arms inspectors from Iraq in six months if his Government is not cleared of suspicions about its weapons programs and if the sanctions that have devastated the country's economy are not lifted.

title: Rules Against Dancing Seem to Make No Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: To Go: A Debate in Camden Over Crime and Takeout Food
description: Jimmy Chang moved to Camden last fall, taking over the family takeout restaurant just as the nighttime gatherings near his corner were winnowing down to what some people here call the ''children of the night.'' And there they remain on freezing January nights -- drug dealers and their customers, girlfriends and hangers-on -- picking up chicken wings and fried rice until the metal grates come down at 1 or 2 A.M.

title: Breaking Thurgood Marshall's Promise
description: Out of 268 first-year students enrolled at the law school of the University of California at Berkeley, only 1 is African-American. Out of 468 at the University of Texas School of Law, only 4 are. Embedded in these cold facts is a personal story, of how 47 years ago I witnessed the birth of racial justice in the Supreme Court and how now, after 45 years as a lawyer, judge and law professor, I sometimes feel as if I am watching justice die.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, JANE GESSLER
description: GRAY-Jane Gessler. On January 16, 1998. Beloved mother of Ralph Peter Gray and beloved friend of Sam Earle. Friends may call Monday, 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, STEWART J.
description: BECKER-Stewart J. On January 16, 1998, of Levittown, LI. Beloved son of the late Sylvia and the late Harold. Dear brother of Barry and Roberta. Loving brother-in-law of Caren. Services Sunday 1:00 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Hair's Vanishing Act
description: Susan Griak of Manhattan recently went to Vanishing Point, which specializes in long-term hair removal by laser, to have her bikini line zapped after many bad waxing episodes. ''The last time I went in for a waxing, I had a woman in a back room who did the job as she ate lunch out of a take-out carton -- not to mention the pain,'' said Ms. Griak, 32, an art director at an advertising agency. ''Everyone knows people get hair removed. This approach makes it easier.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, BETTY
description: FISHER-Betty. The world is sadder for the loss of a charming and beautiful woman. Betty Fisher died January 16, 1998, in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. Betty, lovingly known as ''Super Boss'' is survived by her husband of 63 years, the Hon. Harold L. Fisher, former chairman of the MTA and a prominent New York attorney. Theirs was a true love and romance. Betty was the loving mother of Prof. Leonard Fisher and his wife, Yvonne of Danville, California, Hon. Alice Fisher Rubin and her husband Lowell, Stephanie Fisher Cooper and her husband Joseph Harrison of Asheville, North Carolina, Andrew S. Fisher, Esq. and his wife Barbara and Council Member Kenneth Fisher and his wife Kirsten. Adored ''Go-Go'' grandmother because of her energy and travels of Alana, Matthew, Jonathan, Jacob and Penelope Fisher, David and Emily Rubin, and Neil, Edward, Jay and Gary Cooper. Also survived by her sisters Rose Ashin of Little Silver, New Jersey and Sarah Frischling of Tierre Verde, Florida. Great grandmother to 5. Aunt to many, friend to all. Donations may be made to the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation. Shiva at the Rubin home from Monday evening January 19th through 3pm Friday, January 23rd. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paddling the Everglades Solo
description: THE Everglades Wilderness Waterway winds for nearly a hundred miles through the rivers, creeks and bays of southern Florida's Gulf Coast. It passes through the center of the 2,354-square-mile Everglades National Park, one of the largest expanses of uninhabited territory in the eastern United States, and a place that offers visitors extraordinary birding, as well as a chance to see endangered species like the manatee, the American crocodile and, rarely, the Florida panther. I've wanted to explore this route since 1991, when I saw its serpentine course marked by a dashed line on a map in the National Park Visitor Center in Everglades City.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Nothing but Net For Coach Bird; His Pacers Are Off to Best Start Ever, And Now Comes a Reunion in Boston
description: The team plane was scheduled to leave for Nashville at 4 P.M., but Travis Best and Dale Davis were nowhere to be found. Though it was the preseason, the coach of the Indiana Pacers stood firm.

title: Learning Skills, Finding a Life
description: ''I USED to walk down the street and look over my back to see if that cop was following me, and he usually was.'' By the age of 16, the young man said, he had struck out on his own. Since the death of his mother, his father's drinking had become too unbearable. Now he was shoplifting for food to survive.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: 'Private Purpose' Debt Loses Some Appeal

title: Aggressive Steps in Connecticut
description: As in at least 20 other states, Connecticut's child protection agency is operating under court supervision because of past deficiencies. For several years, it was Kristine D. Ragaglia's job, as an assistant state attorney general, to monitor compliance.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: ON-LINE VACATION PLANNING

title: Education I.R.A.'s Are Already Getting Low Marks
description: IF you think the new education I.R.A. will solve your college financing problems, think again.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Q&A/Joshua Pruzansky; Keeping the Bar a Voice for Freedoms
description: ''THIS ain't my grandfather's bar association.'' So began a recent letter to Joshua Pruzansky, a Smithtown lawyer, a letter of which he is particularly proud because, as president of the New York State Bar Association in Albany, Mr. Pruzansky is seeking unprecedented changes from both the Federal and state governments.

title: Scrambling to Keep a Golf Pro Shop Going
description: AS the head golfing professional at Bethpage State Park for more than 15 years, Chuck Workman ran a pro shop business that few wanted. Now that the U.S. Open is coming, a lot of people are after his job, and Mr. Workman finds himself scrambling to keep it.

title: Mona May Karff Dies at 86; A Dominant Figure in Chess
description: Mona May Karff, who won the United States women's chess championship seven times, died on Jan. 10 at her home on Riverside Drive in Manhattan. She was 86 and had been among the first four Americans to attain the rank of international woman master.

title: Where the Key Lime Is King
description: KEY WEST does a fine job when it comes to memorable sunsets. But what are the chances that the T-shirt capital of the world (or so it is called locally) can provide a memorable meal, to say nothing of several? After a long weekend last month, it was evident that I had an easier time finding good food than my husband, Richard, had searching for some vestige of the city's legendary Hemingway esque raffishness.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BRUISER By Richard House. High Risk/Serpent's Tail/ Consortium Book Sales, paper, $12.99.

title: Mayor and Ministers: Still Much to Overcome
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he had not been invited to a major celebration of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday being held at Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem tomorrow.

title: Uh-Oh: A Bullish Consensus On Bonds
description: Inflation is down, and some sniff deflation on the horizon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, BERTHA B.
description: GOTTLIEB-Bertha B. 1912-1998. Devoted wife and mother. Wife of the late Peter. Loving mother of Samuel and Robert. Sister of Rhoda Hooper. Sister of David Barish. A very special woman.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Rest Is Art History
description: Imagine the bare-breasted woman from Delacroix's painting ''Liberty Leading the People'' storming the barricades of ''The Turkish Bath'' by Ingres and you get a sense of Russell Connor's loopy, anarchic take on art history, MASTERS IN PIECES: The Art of Russell Connor (Journey Editions, $49.95). Connor's collected paintings from 1964 to 1996 work simultaneously as a visual pun, a political statement and a comment on art history (in this case, Delacroix's energetic style really did challenge the more classical style of Ingres's odalisques). Connor, who studied with the color theorist Josef Albers and was the host of the public television series ''Museum Open House'' from the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, paints with an eerie verisimilitude. Some of his images actually do resemble a lost version of an alternative art history: you might have to look twice to figure out what is ''wrong'' with his image of Renoir's sunny lovers from ''Dance at Bougival'' two-stepping on rain-slicked cobblestones in front of the melancholy strollers from Caillebotte's ''Place de l'Europe on a Rainy Day.'' Some of Connor's best effects and most trenchant commentaries derive from the paintings of Manet, whom he calls ''my favorite silent partner in this reckless and rewarding adventure.'' Magically, Connor whisks away the artifice of art history to forge some deeper connections, and makes us smile all the while. Eric P. Nash

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, BARBARA BRUCE
description: FIELD-Barbara Bruce.Of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. on January 14, 1998. Born March 4, 1936 in New York City. Daughter of Barbara and Edward Weld. A great lady and cherished parent who will be missed dearly by those whose lives she touched. Brucie is survived by five sons, four daughters-in-law and ten grandchildren: Bill and Sarah Clark parents of Billy, Amanda, Nico and Perrin; Mike and Pam Clark parents of Avery and Caitlin; Gus and Lisa Field parents of Carley and Maddyn; Jake and Alice Clark parents of Caro and Jack; and Tee. Memorial service to be held at St. Mary's Church, Tuxedo Park, on Monday, January 19th at 11:00am. Spring flowers may be sent to St. Mary's Church.

title: Frivolity Punished Here
description: Like to watch lawyers suffer? Situate yourself outside the Federal courthouse in Denver around 6:15 A.M. on Thursdays. You'll see a couple of dozen sleepy attorneys dragging into ''the Breakfast Club,'' a unique exercise in courtroom management devised by U.S. District Judge Edward W. Nottingham, a stern Bush appointee who deeply resents wasted time. Roughly once a week, Nottingham forces lawyers to show up for dawn hearings, as a lash for raising what he considers frivolous matters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, THOMAS J.
description: STANTON-Thomas J. A man of integrity, compassion, vision. Mentor and friend. The Family of Thomas A. Kelly

title: In Buenos Aires, Cafes for Any Mood
description: AT 8 o'clock on a Tuesday night there is one table left in the Gran Cafe Tortoni, on the Avenida de Mayo, the historic heart of Buenos Aires. The table is near the back of the long, pillared room, past the mirrors on the wood-paneled walls, the ceiling of gold and white paneled stained glass, the Argentine paintings, the busts of artists and tango stars. There is a din of chatter, music, billiard balls banging, of men telling jokes, families shouting, women friends bending over with laughter. A young couple is kissing, an old man is reading. The music is Alberto Ruffino, a tango song of lost love. The air smells of smoke.

title: La Causa: Zapatistas To the Forefront
description: In his young career as a downtown political activist, Moses Nagel says he has supported the squatters, the gardeners and the indigent who call Tompkins Square Park home. Of late he has found a new cause, although it boils thousands of miles from his usual stomping grounds in the East Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, JOAN WALKER
description: ABRAMS-Joan Walker. Beloved wife of George. Adored mother of Noel Gahagan Walker and Brooks Walker, and Cherished sister of Ninalee Allen Craig. Died in an automobile accident January 14. Funeral service Sunday, January 18, 3 PM, at Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to your favorite charity would be deeply appreciated by the family. Joan, an expert in Asian art, was known for her generosity, spirit and originality. She never touched anything or anyone without making it or them better. She will be sorely missed.

title: On Dancer, On Vixen
description: Your sparkling photograph of the Radio City Rockettes should be a role model for all young women who dream of a career in show business (''On Dancer, On Vixen,'' Dec. 21.). There is nary a trace of the bony look found in most models. Well done!

title: Can the Common Cold Cure Cancer?
description: Frank McCormick's cold virus engineered to kill only tumor cells may illuminate a general mechanism that underlies the seemingly miraculous remission of tumors that can occur from time to time (''Can the Common Cold Cure Cancer?'' by Nicholas Wade, Dec. 21). Viruses are error-prone as they multiply, producing an array of defective viruses, most of which are incapable of further propagation. The defective cold virus that will specifically kill tumor cells would also be expected to arise spontaneously, albeit rarely. There are many types of viruses that infect a variety of cell types, from brain to lung cells. Sporadic derivatives of such viruses that are analogous to the engineered cold virus could also arise spontaneously and specifically kill particular types of tumors.

title: Lifeline for Low-Cost Housing
description: Among all the leaks by the Clinton Administration from its forthcoming budget plan, one of the best is a proposed 40 percent hike in the tax credit for investors in housing for low-income families. This tax credit is focused and effective, an exception to the rule that tax credits are often a wasteful way to do the Government's business.

title: Case Dismissed. But Not Resolved.
description: MELVA Max, cop fighter, was squirted out of the criminal-justice system last week. If it wasn't for all the anxiety, expense and the troubling ramifications of her case, it would be another amusing instant urban legend. A 41-year-old mother of two is arrested outside her Chelsea restaurant at midnight after complaining to a passing police sergeant about noisy motorcyclists annoying her customers. According to the official complaint, she hurled herself into the patrol car and grabbed his badge. She was handcuffed in the street and strip-searched at the precinct house. It wasn't until 4 A.M. that her husband, Jean-Francois Fraysse, who is the chef, was able to take her home.

title: Bonds, School Bonds: He Sells Them
description: WHO -- Rafael Perez, 39, of Teaneck, executive director of the New Jersey Educational Facilities Authority for three years.

title: Your Day in Tax Court: It Hardly Resembles TV
description: IN a stark, modern building across from the ornate granite courthouses at Manhattan's Foley Square is a harshly lighted, austere courtroom. Four or five times a year, every seat on the hard wooden benches there is occupied by people on a mission: to prove that the Internal Revenue Service is wrong about how much they owe in taxes.

title: The Bus Stops Here
description: THE Borders Bookstore in Mays Landing, 12 miles west of the Atlantic City Boardwalk, varies little from others in the chain. But to Lisa Johnson, a former casino spokeswoman who is now now a news anchorwoman for WMGM-TV 40 in Linwood, the store is one of the best ways legalized gambling has affected her life.

title: DIARY
description: ASIAN TURMOIL, PART I

title: Preseason Packages For Baseball Fans
description: Baseball fans do not have to wait for opening day to catch their favorite team. In February, major league baseball teams head to spring training camps in Florida and Arizona. Sports Tours, a Massachusetts-based company specializing in travel to sporting events, has packages to help baseball fans attend preseason games.

title: Ideas & Trends: Cells Unlocked; Longevity's New Lease on Life
description: SCIENTISTS have now made human cells in the test tube grow beyond the usual limit at which they curl up and die. If cells can be made to live indefinitely, can people too be made immortal?

title: Frequent-Flying Stars of the Salon; When your colorist has clients on two coasts, you'd better like your roots.
description: FOR some beauty salon clients, making an appointment has been getting a whole lot harder. Beth Rudin DeWoody, the socialite and vice president of a family-owned real estate company in Manhattan, books appointments a month in advance with Robyn Cosio, an eyebrow shaper, who works one week in New York for every three she works in Los Angeles.

title: Double Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: January 11-17; Winding the Biological Clock
description: In a bizarre experiment, scientists shined a bright light onto the backs of human knees and re-set the master biological clock inside the human brain. Volunteers who underwent the light treatment had their body clocks (which determine when one feels awake or sleepy) advanced or delayed by up to three hours depending on when they got the light.

title: Restoration of an Elephant Walk Recalls Yesterday's Menageries
description: AN elephant is buried on the shores of Lake Waccabuc. A rhinoceros once went swimming in a local creek. A monkey pulled a parson's coat to shreds.

title: The 20th Century, Two Viewpoints in Sculpture and Collage
description: AT the end of a century, the impulse is to look back to the beginning, and compare art then and now. The changes in the 20th century have, of course, been enormous, but some things have stayed the same.

title: Q&A; Helping the Police and the Public Speak
description: WHO -- Officer Steve Stryker, 39, an 11-year veteran of the Plainsboro Township police department in Middlesex County.

title: Q&A/Carla D. Glassman; Promoting Civility and Ethics in Court
description: HOPING to confirm the status of law as a noble and honorable profession, the New York State Office of Court Administration recently adopted new rules dealing with the conduct of lawyers. The rules, most of which go into effect in March, are aimed at reducing frivolous lawsuits, insuring courtroom civility and making sure clients understand their rights, Carla D. Glassman, president of the Westchester Women's Bar Association, said.

title: 'Mystery School' at the Long Wharf
description: ONCE upon a decade, when illusions sustained and whimsy worked, the search for signs of intelligence was perceived as a not impossible mission. Now that a millennial crisis with its attendant hysteria looms, everyone appears to be searching for signs of something -- anything -- to hold on to.

title: Students Build Lab Full of Own Computers
description: IN a large, cluttered classroom at Saunders Trades and Technical High School here, electronic hardware and high-tech gadgetry coexist with dusty tools from a bygone era.

title: No 'Side Show': Acting Brothers Get Big Breaks Separately
description: On most evenings, Joey and Kevin Kern come home to their apartment after work, switch on the television and chat about their jobs. Lately, the conversations have been unusual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, WILLIAM
description: LANE-William. Our heartfelt sympathy from our family to yours. His humor and wit lives on. Renee, Marshall, Brian, Debra, Sage, Dean, Corinne and Michael, Sylvia and Cheryl

description: Dr. Kristie Ann Boering and Dr. Ronald Carl Cohen are to be married today in San Francisco. Kimberly A. Thompson, a certified marriage commissioner, is to officiate at the City Club of San Francisco.

title: Cold Outside? Sit in a Warm, Dark Room
description: THE spring season of the New Jersey International Film Festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Co-op and the New Jersey Media Arts Center, opens on Friday and continues through April 25. Unless otherwise noted, all programs begin at 7 P.M. and take place on Sundays at the State Theater, 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick; Wednesdays at Borders Books and Music, Mid-State Mall, Route 18 South, East Brunswick; Thursdays in Room 024, Loree Hall, Nichol Avenue and George Street, New Brunswick, and Fridays and Saturdays in Room 123, Scott Hall, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, New Brunswick. Admission to each program, unless otherwise noted: Wednesdays, free; Thursdays through Saturdays, $5 ($4 for members); Sundays, $8 ($6 for members). Information: (732) 932-8482 or, on the World Wide Web, http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/nigrin.

title: Just Refinanced That Mortgage? Maybe It's Time to Do It Again
description: ALL it the re-refinancing boom.

title: Antiques Clusters, Less Time-Gobbling, Replace Some Shops
description: MULTIDEALER antiques centers are not only springing up but also seeming to beget one another. The Antique and Artisan Center opened on Jefferson Street in Stamford a year and a half ago, and was followed in August of this year by Hiden Galleries, one block west on Canal Street. A third, also on Canal Street is the Stamford Antiques Center, opened Jan. 1 to much fanfare -- brunch, drinks and dancing in the aisles amidst their reason for being, antiques and collectibles from 158 dealers.

title: The World: Indonesia's Economic Crisis; The World Looks at Bali and Sees Krakatoa
description: WHEN Krakatoa blew apart in 1883 in one of the world's most cataclysmic explosions, it took three months before the first evidence of the eruption off Java was visible in America, in the form of brilliant sunsets created by volcanic ash circling the globe.

title: A Victory for New York's Foreign Policy
description: The lexicographers who compile the names of the city's corners and streets are likely to get a newly named corner this week to add to their list: Kudirat Abiola Corner, in front of the Nigerian Consulate on Second Avenue and 44th Street.

title: Two Ways (at Least) of Looking at American Music
description: IN HIS MEMOIRS, THE COMPOSER Aaron Copland recalled the day in 1942 when the choreographer Agnes de Mille telephoned him and requested music for a cowboy ballet. Copland had already had a success with the ballet ''Billy the Kid'' four years earlier. ''Oh, no!'' he told de Mille. ''I've already composed one of those. . . . Can't you write a script about Ellis Island?''

title: Knicks Find Point Guard In Toronto: It's Ward
description: The meticulous Charlie Ward was getting himself together, strapping on a futuristic-looking watch, slipping on his gold cross and singing at the same time. Gospel lyrics, as always.

title: SOAPBOX; Your Nanny Problem
description: ARE you a New Jersey working parent who employs a nanny? Have you recently decided to begin paying the nanny tax because fear, guilt or insanity has finally gotten the best of you? Then I'd like to share with you the secrets of complying with the nanny tax.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Watching Eagles

title: Coming to Terms With a Possible Surplus
description: ECONOMIC and stock-market booms have led both the White House and Congress to project for 1999 the first balanced Federal budget in 30 years. It's a prospect that has already been hailed as the fiscal equivalent of toppling the Berlin Wall.

title: The Art of Marketing Rooms at the Top
description: IT'S an all marble, double-height entry hall with a glass dome at the top,'' said Paula Del Nunzio, a broker for Brown Harris Stevens, guiding a guest on a recent ''walk-through'' of a sumptuous Upper East Side penthouse apartment that is on sale for $4.15 million.

title: A Tantalizing Field, but Not for Unschooled Investors
description: Editor's Note Appended

description: Cousins A Memoir. By Athol Fugard. Theater Communications Group, $19.95.

title: Giving Views A Chance on TV
description: The article ''Film on TV Showing Abortion Criticized'' [Dec. 14] discussed the midnight airing on Channel 55, WLNY-TV, of ''Eclipse of Reason,'' a highly informative, half-hour documentary which includes an actual abortion. The program was criticized by an abortion rights advocate, Michael Gordon of Port Jefferson.

title: Seafood and More With a Peruvian Twist
description: IMAGINE our surprise on entering El Inca, a Peruvian restaurant in Stamford. When we first visited the small storefront space several years ago, it showed all the signs of undercapitalization: a sparse, almost grim room with non-English-speaking personnel, no credit cards, minimal menu.

title: Susan Brophy, Gerald S. McGowan
description: Until she met Gerald S. McGowan, Susan Brophy was a consummate career woman. She rarely left work before 9 P.M., lived alone and was a devoted aunt who sent gifts like red high-top sneakers to her niece. Since 1993, she has worked within yelling distance of the Oval Office as a deputy director of the White House office of legislative affairs.

title: Topless Bar Won't Open: Zone Is Residential (a Cemetery)
description: Jimmy Mitsios had a plan for wall-to-wall skin, and just the idea of this made many men happy.

title: Brooklyn Could Have Been A Contender
description: It is ironic that Tierney chooses to refer to the Left Bank of Paris in bemoaning the ''decay'' of Brooklyn. In fact, Dumbo and other areas of the Brooklyn waterfront have for years been fulfilling the same need that the Rive Gauche did in its legendary heyday, providing a low-cost haven for students, artists and writers. That this part of our city is a gritty place unsuitable for tourists or hordes of Sunday shoppers is just fine with those who have sought it out as an affordable refuge.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Twinkle, Twinkle

title: Aimee Picchi, Peter Dodds
description: Aimee Elizabeth Picchi, a television reporter, was married yesterday to Peter Sheridan Dodds, a graduate student. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Environmental Bond Act Is Little Used
description: A $200 MILLION state program to clean up and reuse idle or abandoned commercial and industrial sites has been virtually ignored on Long Island, where less than $60,000 has been distributed.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Climbing the Mountain
description: Pillar of Fire

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; On Fishing for a Living
description: WHEN a striped base is caught by hook and line, here is what happens: a barbed metal point (often three of them -- the so-called treble hook) pierces its jaw or gills or gullet, sometimes its eye. This causes great pain, but the fish is simultaneously yanked off its course and must began an all-out struggle for its life. It exerts itself to the fullest of its hearts capability, trying to dive, to swerve, to leap free of the force that draws it against its will.

title: Laurel Hollow Weighs Abolishing Its Police
description: LAUREL HOLLOW enjoys a low crime rate.

title: It's Fitted Skaters vs. Baggy Ravers
description: SPEND time at any of the high-energy shops downtown that cater to skateboarders and rave music fans and it quickly becomes clear that these two camps in youth culture embody the old Kipling line: Never the twain shall meet.

title: A Political Kingmaker Takes No Prisoners; Steely State Chairman, a Former Marine, Has the State G.O.P. Squared Away
description: To those who like or despise him, but particularly to the many who fear him, the essential thing about New York's Republican state chairman, William D. Powers, is this: He was a Marine Corps sergeant, and loved it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMSON, GERALD PHILIP
description: SIMSON-Gerald Philip. Rochester, New York, 77 years. On January 12 after a years illness. Beloved husband of Gloria (nee Susnow) for 56 years, loving father of Maxine and David and his life-partner Dan Chesbro. Devoted brother of Gloria Joffe and Carol Rivner, cherished brother-in-law of Cecile and Harvey Olian and Dana and the late Sidney Vittor and dear uncle, grand uncle and friend. He grew up in Brooklyn, attended Ohio State (Alpha Epsilon Pi) and graduated New York University. During W.W. II he served in the Air Force as a bombardier and navigator flying 31 missions and attained the rank of Captain in the Reserves. He was a jeweler and a gifted and energetic cosmetics sales manager (Revlon and Max Factor) that took him and his family from East Rockaway, NY to Pittsburgh, PA. to Rochester, N.Y. where he resided for the past 30 years. The thread throughout his life was his passion for people which manifested itself in a rich and satisfying avocation in the theatre. From early days in shows at the Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Community Center to his co-founding of the Brighton Theatre Guild (Rochester, N.Y.) serving as its first president, he filled our lives and homes and stages with his songs and theatrical magic for over fifty years. In retirement, he inspired another generation with his gifts in our area's classrooms. He was the most sought after substitute teacher in many districts and for ten years supervised the One Act Drama Festival at Brighton High School. His humor and humanity touched many lives. Services and burial to were held on Long Island, N.Y.

title: A Misapplied Vowel Made for a Great Dinner
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Bye-Bye, Fuchsia
description: I know a guy who jokes that Bill Clinton's problems with Paula Jones could have been avoided if he had simply called room service at the Excelsior Hotel in Little Rock and ordered up a bottle of cold duck.

title: An Indian Without Reservations
description: The crowd at the old theater in Seattle is waiting for an American Indian, and they get one when 6-foot-2 Sherman Alexie strolls onstage, playing one of his fictional characters, Lester Falls Apart. Lester is stumblebum drunk, eyelids at half-mast, looking for some railroad tracks to lie down on. A vodka-guzzling native with a self-esteem problem, now there's a role model.

title: Martin Amis
description: Martin Amis's novel ''Night Train'' will be published next month by Harmony Books.

title: INVESTING WITH: G. Kenneth Heebner; CGM Realty Fund
description: IN an investment career that spans more than a quarter-century, G. Kenneth Heebner has compiled one of the mutual fund industry's best records. His CGM Capital Development fund -- which has been closed to new investors for 29 years -- the fourth-longest such period on record -- has a 15-year average annual return of 20 percent. That is nearly three percentage points higher than the Standard and Poor's 500-stock index and more than one-third better than the average growth fund.

title: A Sports Arena in Hoboken?
description: What do you think of a proposal to move the Devils from the Meadowlands to an arena that would be built above the Hoboken train station?

title: Fishy Prozac?
description: Ever tried to make a dog take a pill? Or a cat swallow anything it doesn't want to? Well, now any pet that requires oral medication can have it in liquid form flavored with chicken, beef, cheese, fish or just about anything else that tickles its palate.

title: January 11-17; Asian Arms Race Slows
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen swung through Southeast Asia, hoping to shore up support for expanding the American military presence in the region through joint exercises, port calls and arms sales. Instead, he found his mission overshadowed by the contagion ravaging Asia's economies.

title: No Sir
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; 16 Years Later, Old Stars Still Play, and Replay, the 'Bossy Game'
description: HAROLD Snepsts still wants the puck back, the way Ralph Branca wants the pitch back, the way Scott Norwood wants that field goal attempt back.

title: Grinding It Out
description: HIRED PENS

title: Is the Golden City Taking On Too Many Colors?
description: THE onslaught of tourists has taken its toll on Golden Prague. Visitors may think they are seeing the real thing: narrow cobblestone streets, sandstone statues and a concentration of Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque and Art Nouveau architecture like nowhere else.

title: January 11-17; Big Tobacco Settles For Big Bucks
description: In the battle over smoking's cost to society, two things are certain: tobacco companies will shell out, and lawyers will rake in, huge sums. But how huge should huge be?

title: IN BRIEF; Princeton May Ease Its Financial Aid Formula
description: In a break with standard Ivy League practice, Princeton University proposed Wednesday to scale back, and in some cases, eliminate, consideration of home equity in calculating the size of financial aid awards. Under the proposal, the value of a home would not be included among the assets of most families with incomes under $90,000 and its weight would be reduced for other families, thereby increasing aid awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRASSMAN, SOLOMON E.
description: STRASSMAN-Solomon E. Beloved husband of Natalie, devoted father of Judith and Eric Herbst, Toby and Harold Weinberger, proud and loving grandfather of James and Karen Weinberger, and Elisabeth, Andrea and Seth Herbst, honored brother of Sylvia Lupkin and Hi. The family will gather Sunday, 10AM, at ''Sinai Chapels'' (1-800-446-0406) prior to graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: After-Care for the Stately Holiday Amaryllis
description: AMARYLLIS was the gift of choice this year. Many homes were dazzled by these huge trumpet flowers and their brilliance has lasted well into the month. The flower colors can be anywhere from the bright red Fire Dance, to the delicate white Apple Blossom with its pink stripes, to the newer picotee hybrids with darker edges on the petals.

title: After the Holidays, Quartets and a Trio
description: THE Yale campus in New Haven is again alive with musical activity after the holiday break. On Tuesday evening at 8, the Penderecki String Quartet will present quartets by Bartok, Debussy and Beethoven in Sprague Memorial Hall. On Wednesday evening at 8, Mozart, Franck and Richard Strauss are the composers of choice at Sprague in a faculty recital by the violinist Sidney Harth and the dean of the Yale School of Music, Robert Blocker, a pianist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRKWOOD, MURRAY DELMAR
description: KIRKWOOD-Murray Delmar. 86, at home on January 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Viviane, father of John, Anne, James, Ellen and William, and brother of Kenneth.

title: U.S. IS REVIEWING BAN ON THE SALE OF ARMS TO CHINA
description: On the eve of his trip to Asia this week, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen pressed the Clinton Administration to let an American arms maker sell spare parts to China, despite a ban on sales of military equipment imposed after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989, Administration officials say.

title: More Made Eligible To Let Fingers Do Filing
description: In an effort to encourage more residents to file their state income tax returns by telephone this year, the New Jersey Division of Taxation has raised the income threshold for eligible residents from $75,000 to $150,000 per return (with interest and dividends each $1,000 or less), officials announced on Wednesday.

title: Getting to Work on Tile Problems
description: A GOOD tile surface should last for many years without problems. Eventually, however, the grout in the joints between the tiles may deteriorate or crack. While it is possible that crumbling grout joints can signal a possible problem with the underlying substrate, usually a few cracks here and there are indicative of grout that was improperly mixed.

title: Task of Making Liquidation a Solid Business
description: WHEN the Delta Faucet Company of Indiana discontinued 3,000 sets of almond-color faucets they got in touch with International Purchase Systems, a liquidation concern in Elmsford. And when a major bank could not collect on a $3 million loan made to a toy manufacturer and took possession of the manufacturer's inventory, the bank, too, called on International Purchase Systems.

title: Orthodox Judaism In Great Neck
description: I regret that in responding to the article, ''In Great Neck, New Orthodox Synagogues,'' [Dec. 14] two letters accused the reporter of providing a forum for ''Orthodox bashing'' and attacked Reform Judaism in the process.

title: Silencing Some Noisy Bars
description: Residents of the Upper East Side perennially grouse about noisy bars and complain that no one ever does anything about them. But on Jan. 10, dozens of police officers and officials from the Fire Department and other city agencies cracked down on 13 bars that had drawn neighborhood complaints.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A Korean War romance set in Hong Kong, a memorable look at the Deep South, a low-budget Hollywood knockout and a sci-fi special lend luster to the television movie menu this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, ANDREW P.
description: BARRY-Andrew P. The Michel family is profoundly saddened by the passing of our dear friend Andy. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Our love and support will always be there for Andy's beloved wife Frannie and his loving children Nora and Michael, and Neil and Christopher.

title: With Enough Personality, a Small Stick Will Do
description: HE DIDN'T QUITE TELL every young conductor to get a life. But the great violinist Yehudi Menuhin did say this about the legendary maestro Willem Mengelberg: ''What struck me was the extraordinary power of his musical analysis, precisely of those irregularities, of those deformations which interested me a great deal, excursions away from the metronomic time, the holding-back of certain chords to emphasize the rhythm and other what I call distortions, which are actually the proof of life, of living.''

title: As Mick Sang, the Show in the V.I.P. Seats
description: THE SETTING: The V.I.P. section of the Rolling Stones Concert at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night.
