A spot, 10 feet away from the Stones, on opening night in New York, of the second leg of the ''Bridges to Babylon'' concert tour. There's a feeling of a time warp here. Lots of jockeying by 40-somethings wearing what they remember to be 1960's-70's garb (like suede go-go boots and open polyester shirts showing graying chest hair). Then there were the curious but unapologetic wearing sharp business suits.

title: January 11-17; Exposing Smugglers Who Exploited Nurses
description: Federal agents broke up what they said was the nation's biggest fraudulent-visa conspiracy, in which more than 570 nurses were smuggled into the United States, mainly from the Philippines. Five people pleaded guilty.

title: Hitting a Bump in the Medical Leave Law
description: ''PENNY WORTZ woke up two years ago with such severe back and neck pain that her daughter had to drive her to the orthopedist. She said the doctor told her that the pain was from deteriorating disks and that she needed to take muscle relaxers and painkillers, stay off her feet -- and take a leave of absence from work.

title: Young Loves
description: Set in a small seaside town near Boston, DAWSON'S CREEK is a new dramatic series from Kevin Williamson, the writer of ''Scream'' and ''I Know What You Did Last Summer.'' The focus is on four good-looking, gregarious teen-agers: Dawson, an aspiring filmmaker, and his tomboyish best friend, Joey (James Van Der Beek and Katie Holmes, above), their friend Pacey (Joshua Jackson) and Jennifer (Michele Williams), the new girl in town. Will the friendship between Dawson and Joey survive the maelstrom of adolescence? Why did Jennifer leave New York City? What's going on between Dawson's mother, a local news anchor, and her handsome colleague? We'll find out -- TUESDAYS at 9 P.M. on CHANNEL 11. Rahadyan Sastrowardoyo

title: Appearances; Poetry in Lotion
description: We all read labels. we must read hundreds in the course of our commodity-saturated day, but we use a special part of our brains, a junkyard reserved for background noise, that allows us to imbibe messages, even act on them, without being aware. Anyone who thinks these messages are not having an influence because they are short-circuiting the conscious mind has missed Sigmund Freud and the entire body of psychoanalytic thought in the 20th century.

title: Fine Print In Gains Tax Exclusion
description: LAST year, the Federal Government gave an extraordinary gift to most homeowners by excluding from taxation as much as $500,000 in gain on the sale of a principal residence.

title: Barbara Janowitz, Peter Entin
description: Barbara Ann Janowitz and Peter Entin were married last evening by Rabbi Andrew Bachman at the Americas Society in Manhattan.

title: Food Fantasies: Whip, Roll or Just Throw
description: YOU'VE got to break eggs to make an omelet, or, in rare cases, a television series. When Jacques Torres, pastry chef at Le Cirque 2000, went to Dallas to sell PBS programmers on his series ''Dessert Circus,'' he came up with a splendid idea. Why not give a cooking demonstration and then, just for fun, bombard the audience with eggs? Unbeknownst to the station officials, the eggs were hollow. Unbeknownst to Mr. Torres, an undoctored egg had slipped into the mix.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; New State Code to Ease Rehabilitation-Project Costs
description: EARLIER this month New Jersey put in place a set of rules to govern the rehabilitation of existing buildings. State officials say they could bolster economic development and the production of moderately priced housing, especially in cities.

title: Kauai's Call Is Irresistible
description: ''KAUAI is wild -- it lures you out,'' my wife was saying from the depths of our hotel bed, speaking by phone to a friend, trying to explain what happened the night before on the Kalalau Trail. Seeing me moving about, however gingerly, she covered the mouthpiece. ''Coffee,'' she pleaded. ''Smoothie.''

title: Australian Crucible: Blowflies, Heat and Teen-Agers
description: It isn't so simple to get your Grand Slam game face securely into place for the Australian Open, that below-the-equator gateway to the four-stop 1998 Grand Slam season.

title: Building Confidence In On-Line Shopping
description: To the Editor:

title: Before Dust Jackets, in Book Binding's Gilded Age
description: FROM THE INVENTION OF THE PRINTING press in the 15th century to the beginning of the industrial age, the bound book as we know it did not exist. Instead, books were bought from publishers in folded, printed sheets, wrapped in paper. The buyer -- a reader or a bookseller -- would then order bindings for the texts from a bookbinder. The results, in gold-tooled leather, lined the shelves of gentlemen's libraries.

title: Geoffrey S. Watson, 76; Wrote Statistics Formula
description: Dr. Geoffrey S. Watson, a statistician who helped write a classic formula that has given economists and other researchers more confidence in their predictions, died on Jan. 3 at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. Dr. Watson, who lived in Princeton, N.J., was 76.

title: Hearing Mingus Again, Seeing Him Anew
description: IMITATING ONE OF HIS ABRUPT MUSICAL scene shifts, Charles Mingus starts his 1971 memoir, ''Beneath the Underdog,'' like a shot: ''In other words I am three.'' Mingus then explains, to his psychiatrist, that he has three personalities: a neutral bystander, a self-protective hothead, a softy who lashes out when mistreated.

title: Sharon Musher, Daniel Eisenstadt
description: Sharon Ann Musher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David R. Musher of New York, is to be married today to Daniel Mark Eisenstadt, the son of Dr. Katie Eisenstadt and Zolman S. Eisenstadt of White Plains. Rabbi Gordon Tucker is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELMOWITZ, BERNARD
description: ELMOWITZ-Bernard SOKOLOF-Herbert Happy Birthday Guys.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Bright White

title: MTA CK
description: A little space goes a long way, as bus and subway riders will see next month when an advertisement for the fragrance CK One appears on Metrocards. Starting on Feb. 8, New York City Transit token booths will issue a million such cards, showing Kate Moss and her androgynous pals, photographed by Steven Meisel. And at CK counters at Macy's Herald Square, plastic card holders and special subway maps will be free. The agency expects $500,000 in revenue from this and other such ads this year. ''We tried the concept in Taiwan and Singapore,'' Jan Sharkansky, a spokeswoman for Calvin Klein Cosmetics, said. ''Everyone started to collect them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EATON, BERNICE
description: EATON-Bernice. Age 95, January 8, 1998. The light of God surrounds her. The love of God enfolds her. The power of God protects her. The presence of God watches over her. Wherever she is, God is. Thanks mom for all your love.

title: Viewers' Market for Videos
description: Northside in Williamsburg is a neighborhood that ranges from the warehouses and gutted buildings on the waterfront to weedy McCarren Park in the north and the oil-drum wasteland under the elevated Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in the east. In the middle, narrow streets are lined with meat-packing plants, textile factories and metal-parts plants. Foot traffic is sparse. The main drag, Bedford Avenue, is a good example: except for 8:30 A.M. and 5:30 P.M. on weekdays, the heaviest sidewalk traffic consists of a few elderly women inching along on canes and occasional bleary-eyed artists going out for coffee.

title: Telecom Bill Created A Phone Market Muddle
description: To the Editor:

title: A Class in Miracles
description: This week, barring a last-minute ruling from a judge, seven public high schools in Lee County, Fla., will start teaching Bible classes as an elective. The twist is that these aren't religion classes but history classes that use the Bible as a ''textbook.'' Citing the usual First Amendment concerns, various groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, have filed suit, but the real story here isn't courtroom drama. It's the unintended light comedy of the curriculum.

title: Now, Big Blue Is at Your Service
description: IT was the way the new, improved I.B.M. was supposed to work. In September 1996, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the company's chairman, lured a handful of corporate chief executives to a daylong strategy seminar. During a discussion of research collaboration among companies in different fields, Robert B. Shapiro, the chairman of Monsanto, wondered aloud whether his pharmaceutical and agricultural-products company could use any I.B.M. technology in its genetics research.

title: Revenge of the Krath
description: For months, investigators in Pearl, Miss., have insisted that the teenagers linked to the shootings at Pearl High School belonged to a devil-worshiping group called the Kroth. Grant Boyette, the group's 18-year-old leader, supposedly persuaded his friend Luke Woodham to go on the Oct. 1 shooting spree, inspired by Boyette's devotion to Satan. But in a recent development, Jason Pollan, a class of '97 Pearl High graduate, has come forward to argue that Boyette was inspired as much by ''Star Wars'' as by Satan. Pollan was involved in a 1996 role-playing game with Boyette that featured the Krath, characters from ''Star Wars'' comic books. Did investigators, who haven't said where they heard about the Kroth, hear it wrong? They aren't talking, but Pollan says Boyette's playing style did reveal a dark side. Here's a look.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A Dry Spell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON WURTZLER, ARISTID
description: von WURTZLER-Aristid. Suddenly during a concert tour of Hungary, November 30, 1997. Noted harpist, conductor, composer and pedagogue. Survived by his wife Barbara and brother Bela. Cremated and interred in Budapest.

title: One Man Is Not Enough For the Struggling Irish
description: SETON HALL 64, NOTRE DAME 58

title: G.O.P. Chief's Recent Success Is Seen as Turning Point
description: After the Republican Party rejected a divisive anti-abortion resolution on Friday night, several rank-and-file party members marched up to their chairman, Jim Nicholson, and offered him something he has heard infrequently in his one-year tenure: praise.

title: In America; Duck and Cover
description: Joe Louis famously said of Billy Conn: ''He can run, but he can't hide.''

title: Exploring Imagery In Patchwork Forms
description: Patchworks: Contemporary Interpretations of the Quilt Form

title: Sloane Schweber, Joshua Zamat
description: Sloane Tracey Schweber, a daughter of Ellen and Dennis Schweber of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married last evening to Joshua Daniel Zamat, a son of Barbara and Dr. Mark Zamat of Fairfield, Conn. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Correction
description: The Food column on Dec. 28, about cooking for the New Year, referred incorrectly to a chef, Douglas Rodriguez. He is still at Patria restaurant in Manhattan; he did not move to Florida.

title: Streetscapes/202-220 West 122d Street; 1880's Harlem Rowhouses With an Uncertain Future
description: WHILE 122d Street next to Mount Morris Park is burnished and prospering, the same street a block to the west, between Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, includes vacant lots, empty buildings and burned-out shells. Amid the desolation, however, owners of rowhouses on the south side, between 202 and 220 West 122d -- one of the most unusual rowhouse groups in Harlem -- are pondering the block's future in the light of city plans to construct two- and three-family homes across the street.

title: The Last Best Friends Money Can Buy
description: Ted Conover's article ''The Last Best Friends Money Can Buy'' (Nov. 30) was touching and incisive. But it left out the perspective of the child-caregiver. While the family member in the article had the finances and the emotional distance to delegate elder care to an agency, I suspect that most children (perhaps daughters, in particular) would not or could not make that choice. Instead, we manage the households of our elderly parents, often while juggling full-time jobs and our own homes and families.

title: The Original Taxi Voice Didn't Repeat Same Jokes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art Crowd
description: Connoisseurs of the hottest shirt, they wear their art on their sleeves.

title: Loving Farewells For a Lover of Dance
description: HOWARD GILMAN, A GENTLE MAN and a gentleman, was a special friend of the dance, generous with both moral and financial support. His death at 73 on Jan. 3 leaves a void in a world where corporate boards and foundations often respond with cold formality to desperate needs in the arts. Mr. Gilman was a patron with a humane personal touch.

title: Beading the Stars
description: This fashion moment is about decoration and artisanal handwork. And that is just what defines Andra Gabrielle's work. She designs luxurious silk blouses, lingerie and evening wear adorned with embroidery and hand-dyed silk ribbon, along with bead work so fine it requires special needles. Unlike those designers who campaign to have their clothes worn in movies, she is always surprised to see one of her silk blouses or nighties on the big screen. So far, she's spotted her designs on Susan Sarandon, in ''The Client''; Michelle Pfeiffer, in ''One Fine Day''; Annette Bening, in ''Regarding Henry,'' and Glenn Close in ''Reversal of Fortune.'' More recently, one of Ms. Gabrielle's blouses went to court in ABC's ''The Practice.''

title: BENEFITS
description: Song Aid

title: Lopez and Red Storm Assert Themselves in Second Half
description: Well into his senior season, Felipe Lopez today was everything that had been heralded three years ago when he was a St. John's freshman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, JANICE GLANTZ
description: GREENSTEIN-Janice Glantz. Beloved wife of S. Robert. Dearly loved and loving mother of Susan (Mark) Fox, Ivy (Chris Doolittle) and Tod (Gayle Kaplan). Devoted grandmother of Matthew, Peter, Colin, Jillian Rachel, Jillian Hannah, Thea and Sophie. Loving sister of Gerry Bergman and Lois Rosenfeld. She loved life, she loved to laugh, she loved her many friends and most of all she loved her family. Services 3 PM, Tuesday, January 20, at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ.

title: Quick Bite/Palisades Park; Far From Soybean Country, an Exotic Meal
description: In the farm country where I grew up, there were plenty of soybeans. But Grandma McCombs never thought about making a meal of them, certainly not at 6 A.M. However, that's when the doors open at a Palisades Park restaurant that features soybeans, in the form of tofu, 21 hours a day, 7 days a week.

title: A Pianist's Final Piece: DeWitt's Descent
description: HE had marvelous hands, magical hands. DeWitt White grew up poor in a Bronx neighborhood where piano lessons, not to mention pianos, were in short supply. But at 12, he discovered classical music and a prodigious talent for playing it.

title: The State 'Farms' Deer for Hunters
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope and Castro Set a Visit to Befit Gambling Men
description: Most papal trips -- and Pope John Paul II so far has made 80 outside Italy -- are choreographed, scripted and ultimately predictable. But there are others that for both the Pope and his hosts, are a historical roll of the dice, with consequences no one can foresee.

title: Lisbon Culture Festival To Precede World's Fair
description: To introduce itself as host of the 1998 World's Fair (May 22 to Sept. 30), Lisbon is holding the Festival of 100 Days, Feb. 12 to May 21. It offers art exhibits, opera, films, dramatic and musical theater, ballet and concerts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ZOLA CARL
description: MARCUS-Zola Carl. Artist and educator, died on January 12, in his 83rd year. He is survived by a niece, Julie Feinsilver, now in El Salvador, and two nephews, Alan Feinsilver of Houston and Sherman Marcus of Israel. A service will be held at The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 4 P.M., on Monday, January 19. A reception will follow at 605 Park Avenue, Apt. 4G.

title: For a Change of Pace, Faulkner in Nagano
description: American-literature buffs who travel to Nagano, Japan, for the Olympic Winter Games next month can find a dose of Faulkner far from home.

title: Can You Crush The Millennium Bug?
description: IF the Asian financial crisis and roller-coaster markets haven't given you enough post-holiday worries, you can always turn your attention to the year 2000 computer crisis.

title: The Tracks Are Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebecca Did It
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: 3-Building Complex for S.I. Corporate Center; Offices and Hotel, Next to Wetlands
description: Ground will be broken next month for a 65,000-square-foot, three-story office building in the Bloomfield section of Staten Island. It will be the first component in a $19 million, five-building complex in Staten Island Corporate Park.

title: January 11-17; Dog Day at the Trade Center
description: They began the day on a road to fame and riches, slipping into one of New York City's most secure buildings last Tuesday, then walking out with $1.17 million in stolen money. People on the street wondered about their brilliant criminal minds while security experts called it a ''brazen well-planned heist.''

title: ON THE CASE -- A special report.; Child Welfare Foot Soldier Treads Fine Line
description: Making her way down the pitch-dark staircase, an obstacle course of debris, Ana Diaz-DeJesus, a child protection caseworker, shudders.

title: Annual Event for King to Benefit Agencies
description: FOR the last five years, the Westchester Philharmonic has given a benefit concert in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The sixth gala takes place next Saturday at 8 P.M. at Purchase College.

title: INSIDE
description: An Encounter in Cuba

title: The Shopping Mall And the Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Jim Feeney, 61, Producer of Sports on TV
description: Jim Feeney, an ABC-TV sports producer whose three decades of work included ''Wide World of Sports'' and coverage of the Olympics, died last Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 61.

title: STYLE OVER SUBSTANCE; So Long, Chrome Domes
description: SOMETHING was very wrong with the supermodel Tyson Beckford on a recent installment of ''The Keenen Ivory Wayans Show'': he had hair. His signature Schick-smooth scalp -- that pinnacle of masculine minimalism -- had been replaced, for his late-night couch time, with a freshly grown, very lush thatch, all his own. That night, Mr. Wayans was the only chrome-domed homey in the house.

title: Making Light of Things
description: IMPRESSIONISM

title: P.R. Bauble of The Week
description: Toot, toot. Get on the bus with Sporty, Ginger, Baby et al. for the big Spice Girls movie, ''Spiceworld.'' Will it be the British girl group's ''Hard Day's Night,'' or the last ride before the tank runs dry?

title: Piazza Broadway
description: Cheers to John Tierney for his funny and fascinating column ''Piazza Broadway'' (The Big City, Dec. 28). The concept of closing Times Square from 45th to 47th Streets is brilliant. Since the entire area is cleaning up its act, this move is a natural. And by all means, erect that statue of the sailor kissing the mystery woman.

title: Almost Nothing to Lean on but Onstage Chemistry
description: RECOUNTING THE PRODUCTION history of his play ''A View From the Bridge,'' Arthur Miller described the challenge facing the company that first brought it to the stage in 1955. ''We were all aware that a strange style was called for,'' he wrote in the introduction to the text, ''which we were unsure how to provide.''

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mitsubishi Mirage; Out of the Shadows, an Eye-Opener
description: MITSUBISHI is known in America for the Montero, its tough, midsized sport utility. The company ubiquitously advertises the Diamante as an alternative to entry-level luxury sedans like the Lexus ES 300. Its Galant has a solid if not broad following in the market for midsize sedans. And while they are beginning to show their age, Mitsubishi's affordable Eclipse and more-macho-than-thou 3000GT sports car still appeal to real road warriors.

title: At the Changing of the Guard, Not Many Changes
Billion Dollar Box
description: In a stunning megadeal that may permanently alter the playing field of the network television business, NBC has agreed to a $20 billion, nine-year deal for the exclusive rights to the ''Please Stand By'' sign.

title: Let The Music Begin
description: Coming out to celebrate Ellington, the Russian New Year and charity.

title: Corrections
description: The table of contents on Jan. 4 carried an erroneous credit for the photographs of the artists Willem de Kooning and Roy Lichtenstein on the cover of that issue. The pictures, by Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, were not taken for The New York Times.

title: Welfare to Work: A Sequel
description: In ''Welfare to Work: A Sequel'' (Dec. 28), Jason DeParle suggests that welfare reform fails to deal well with troubled mothers like Mary Ann Moore. Her case shows that a work program, to succeed, has to do more than offer jobs and child care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, SAMUEL
description: GOLDBERGER-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Esther and beloved father and father-in-law of Steve and Wanda Gilbert, Ronald and Amy Goldberger, Howard and Lynn Gross and beloved grandfather of Wayne, Adam, Joshua and Jordan Gilbert, Jacob and Edward Goldberger and Jennifer and Jeffrey Gross.

title: To Cook Is to Delve Into a Culture
description: JACQUES PEPIN was just a little ahead of his time. When the superstar of public television's cooking lineup was a young imigrant chef in New York in the 1960's, he enrolled at Columbia University, eventually going to the master's degree level. But when he proposed a doctoral dissertation on the history of French food, his advisors turned him down.

title: Following One's Appetite in Rye Brook
description: BACK in the bad old days, when conference center restaurants defined their mission as one to provide steaks and chops, Provare had the foresight to paint over the dark green walls with a Tuscan ocher and offer roasted vegetables to business executives. Although the concept is no longer surprising, the cuisine still appeals, and Provare has managed to keep dishes fresh and current.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, DR. LOUIS
description: RUBIN-Dr. Louis. On January 14, 1998, in Laguna Hills, CA. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of David (Katherine) and Harriet. Cherished grandfather of Aaron, dear brother of Seymour (Enid). US Army lieutenant, WW II, Pacific Theater. Retired reserach scientist involved in aerospace.

title: Seven Unsung Novels Crying to Be Filmed
description: HAD I THE WINGS OF A dove, I would certainly consider flying away from the decorous sameness of the classics now being made into movies and television specials.

title: Tax Credit for Natural-Gas Fuel Could Mean Cleaner Air for South Bronx
description: More than 10,000 trucks make deliveries every day in the industrial South Bronx, their exhaust fumes contributing to some of the most polluted air in the city. It is a neighborhood where rates of asthma and other respiratory illnesses are the worst in the city, but residents' complaints have long taken a back seat to the area's economic desperation. Any solution that might drive away the trucks, and precious jobs, was no solution at all.

title: Jessica Michelson, David Shklar
description: Jessica Rachel Michelson, a daughter of Dr. Kadimah Michelson and Mark A. Michelson of Brookline, Mass., is to be married there today to David Lewis Raphael Shklar, a son of Dr. Gerald Shklar of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Prof. Judith Nisse Shklar. Rabbi Hillel Norry is to perform the ceremony with Rabbi Avraham H. Freedman, who is the bride's maternal grandfather, at Young Israel of Brookline.

title: Forced Fun?
description: The office party: you love it or you loathe it. Be it a going-away party, a baby shower for a co-worker or a holiday celebration, it can be a genuine good time or an occasion for intense embarassment. What are the unusual styles of celebration in your office -- and the results? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Seeking More Money For Local Schools
description: EVEN as districts begin the midwinter ritual of preparing school budgets for discussion before the public votes in the spring, a potentially new wrinkle has entered the process.

title: How George Eliot Found Happiness
WHAT'S DOING IN; Phoenix
description: Phoenix, the nation's sixth largest city, can't gloat about efficient public transportation or smog-free air. But it can brag about warm winter days that beckon visitors onto lush golf courses, along downtown hiking trails or into a four-wheel-drive vehicle for a hang-onto-your-hat tour of the desert.

title: Felice Roggen And Peter Bass
description: Felice Elaine Roggen, an associate in Washington at the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, was married last evening to Peter Evan Bass, the chief of staff to Under Secretary of State Stuart Eizenstat. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: January 11-17; It's Cold Up There
description: Canadians know cold. Canadians know ice. But even the heartiest were humbled by the ferocious ice storm that blacked out a huge swath of the north from eastern Ontario to Maine.

title: January 11-17; Good Marks for Congress
description: For the first time in seven years, more people say they approve of the way Congress is handling its job than say they disapprove.

title: After Holiday Joy, A Somber Story
description: MURDERING children for personal gain is an enduring theme in theater as well as history. ''Herod and the Innocents,'' a medieval treatment of that theme, has been compiled by the Ensemble for Early Music from religious manuscripts and presentations of 13th-century French Benedictine monks. Its look is foreign, but its sad truths glimmer, unchanged by time.

title: A Sacrament of Praise
description: To the Editor:

title: Hankies, Not Hands!
description: To the Editor:

title: Sundance on Cable: Anomie, Freshly Served
description: FOR THE LAST FEW MONTHS, I've been cocooning with the avant-garde.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, MARILYN. (NEE DUBERSTEIN)
description: ALEXANDER - Marilyn. (nee Duberstein). On January 13, 1998. Wife of the late James and beloved mother of James, Mary Beth, Andrew and Kevin. Former Director of Faculty Services at Fordham University Law School. A memorial service will be held January 23rd, 2PM at Fordham Law School. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Marilyn Alexander Scholarship Fund, Fordham Law School, 140 W. 62 St, NY, NY 10023, or the HHT (Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia) Foundation International, P.O. Box 8087, New Haven, CT 06530.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: For What It's Worth
description: What's a dream worth? If the dream is in the form of an old chair, a painting or a vase from your attic that just might be worth a fortune, the value is unlimited -- until an expert casts an eye on it. If you weren't among the 6,000 who lugged their heirlooms to the Meadowlands Exposition Center in September for a session of ''Chubb's Antiques Roadshow: Discovering America's Hidden Treasures'' for a free expert appraisal, you have a chance to watch others learn the real value of their dreams. The event, taped as part of a public broadcasting series underwritten by the Chubb Group of Insurance Companies, will be shown in two parts on PBS, tomorrow and Jan. 26. (Check local listings.)

title: Face That Launched a Thousand Greeting Cards
description: MEET Kat Caverly, star of greeting cards. For the last nine years, Ms. Caverly has played Elvis, Marilyn Monroe, Ivana Trump, Count Dracula and Carmen Miranda in her job for Recycled Paper Greetings, a small card company in Chicago. Besides wearing bananas and fake Groucho Marx mustaches in pictures on the cards, she also creates messages that go on and in them, like ''Birthdays are special. Go bananas!'' and ''Thanks a bunch!''

title: IN BRIEF; Blood Supplies in State Are Critically Low
description: Blood supplies are at a critically low level in the northern and central parts of the state, prompting appeals for blood donors.

title: Preparing to Race in Key West, and Beyond
description: Russell Coutts was driving to a boatyard in Auckland, New Zealand, last Wednesday to spend the day testing sails on the water. En route, he decided to return a phone call from the United States.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Old Religion By David Mamet. Free Press, $24.

title: Joyner-Kersee Takes On Another Hurdle, This Time as N.F.L. Agent
description: Could it be only a matter of time before a former Olympic track star becomes a force in professional football?

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Victims Sue Bank Over Employee's Fraud
description: Some of the people whom a former Marine Midland Bank employee bilked out of millions of dollars have filed suit against the bank, charging that it learned of the decade-long fraud five years before the scheme collapsed but did nothing to halt it or warn the victims.

title: Above-It-All, Partying at the Club
description: HERE are Pooker, Froggy, Bri, Zip and Hutch. And Soos, whose siblings Chipper and Cuffy do not appear in ''The Country Club,'' Douglas Carter Beane's pseudo-satirical and intensely problematical new play at the Long Wharf Theater.

title: The Nation: Out of Bounds; Beyond the Bottom Line: The New Math of TV Sports
description: AS weeks go, the television industry just provided a pretty entertaining one, and the best action was away from the screen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERZWEIG, STAN
description: SILVERZWEIG-Stan. Age 61, of Park City, Utah, formerly of New City, NY, on January 11. Survived by his wife, Mary Zenorini Silverzweig and their three children Zachary, Joseph and Rebecca, as well as three daughters from his first marriage Jennifer, Leslie and Amy. He is also survived by his sister, Rene Marciari. A Memorial Service will be held Monday, January 19 at 3:00 P.M. at the Church Centre for the United Nations, 777 United Nations Plaza, (44th St. on First Avenue), New York, NY (212) 661-1762. The family has requested that memorial donations be sent to The Stan Silverzweig Memorial Scholarship Fund. Please contact Christine M. Parker or Teresa Petkavich at Payback Training Systems (973) 993-9586 for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMOYE, EMIKO
description: AMOYE-Emiko. On January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Grace. Cherished father of Gbubemi, Shola, Alero, Scott and Eyituoyo. Loving grandfather of Temisan, Tuoyo and Christian. Services Monday, 1 PM, First Baptist Church, 79th and Broadway, New York City. We mourn the death and celebrate the life of Emiko Amoye who inspired and taught many.

title: Why Cubs Got Beck For a Bargain Price
description: In a world of ever-escalating salaries, Rod Beck may as well apply for welfare. Beck will pitch for the Chicago Cubs next season for $3.5 million, only $250,000 more than his 1997 wages.

title: The Region Seen Through a Lens, Brightly
description: IN the hands of a photographer with vision, a camera can transform an everyday scene into an evocative and memorable image. Such transformations are at the heart of ''Connection/ Reflection,'' an exhibition of works by Robert Cornelius and Cathleen Schiman at the Wilson Gallery of Rowan University. Mr. Cornelius, a professor of photography at the Art Institute of Philadelphia, has shown his work around the world but for this show has focused on the New Jersey landscape, natural and otherwise. Ms. Schiman specializes in selenium-toned black-and-white photos of puddles -- an integral part of life anywhere in the region this time of year. Both artists force their viewers to a fresh look at the familiar. And isn't that the point of art?

title: An Expansion in Size and Offerings
description: LE PETIT BIJOU is no longer petite. Five years ago, the Lynbrook restaurant was a pocket-size, one-room charmer. That room is now the bar, a pretty place for a drink with its faux fireplace flanked by two overstuffed chairs and tiny tables covered in floral cloths.

title: Pataki Proposes $454 Million Increase in Education Spending
description: Taking advantage of a robust budget surplus in an election year, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed a major increase in state spending for schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, HAROLD I., M.D.
description: KAPLAN-Harold I., M.D. On January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Nancy Barrett Kaplan. Loving father of Phillip, Peter Mark and Jennifer. Dear brother of Vivienne Brickman, Annette Dresdner and Gerald. Devoted grandfather of Alexander D'Addio and Wildon Kaplan. Family will receive friends Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Service Monday, 9:45AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions in his memory to a charity of your choice.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about police officers' feelings toward their guns misstated the Minneapolis affiliation of Anthony Bouza, a retired New York police commander who described a dream many officers have of guns malfunctioning. He is a former police chief of Minneapolis, not the current one.

title: Buncha Girls Talking Movies
description: When Lise Carrigg was a graduate student at New York University's film school in 1995, one of her assignments was to set up a Web site. The project soon took on a Web life of its own with help from three fellow film buffs, friends of Ms. Carigg's from Vassar College. Along with Ms. Carigg, Andrea Pyros, a television production assistant in New York; Sibyl Goldman, who worked in the St. Louis public school system, and Clare Bundy, who did public relations in Dallas, contributed movie reviews and film commentary.

title: Effort to End Taxi Ambushes by New York City
description: WHAT happened to him about 16 months ago, Patrick J. O'Kane said, is typical of what has happened to many limousine drivers from Westchester: he sent a car to La Guardia Airport to pick up a regular customer. When the driver returned with the customer and headed out of the airport, he was stopped by agents of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission and his car was impounded.

title: Are H.M.O.'s Better at Cutting Costs or Quality?; An Inefficient Model
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nets Triumph After a Night of Finger-Wagging
description: Three times in the first four minutes of tonight's game, Atlanta center Dikembe Mutombo wagged his finger at the Nets.

title: Our Towns; A Good Time To Test Living In a Log Cabin
description: TEN days later, the ice storm that conquered the North Country was still playing dictator, thwarting the work that would bring back the light and the phone, finishing off hundreds more trees and reminding everyone -- as if anyone needed it -- that winter is always lord and master.

title: A Mobile Operation to Remove Graffiti Hits Newark's Streets
description: On a recent morning in Newark's North Ward, artless, seemingly hastily scrawled graffiti seemed to undermine the security of the iron gates in front of the Foto Amor Studio, Galeria D'Hair Salon de Belleza and Metropolitan Pharmacy. Then a Department of Neighborhood Services truck pulled up with the city's new graffiti removal trailer in tow, and within minutes the squiggly black marks were gone, spray-painted over with a near perfect match of the gates' flat gray. ''It makes the business look bad,'' Anthony Ochuba, Metropolitan's owner, said of the graffiti. ''But once they clean it, people like to come and shop.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIMOWITZ, MILDRED
description: HAIMOWITZ-Mildred. On January 14, 1998. Loving sister of Mary Rachlin, Irving Haimowitz and the late Pauline Shulman. Aunt of Gerald, Mitchell, Randy, Sherry, Elsa, Larry, Sharon, Alvin, Susan, Brenda and families.

title: Room and Board
description: THE grandparents have come through again, and we are off on another childless jaunt, a rare event since our marriage. This time, we head for the Bernards Inn, one of six hotels and lodges in the state that received four stars (out of a possible five) in the most recent Mobil Travel Guide.

title: Airlines Improve Coffee; No Word on Food
description: Airlines, where food is getting scarcer, are going for fancy coffee. On Jan. 1, American Airlines seized the hand of Juan Valdez and began serving Colombian coffee on its flights. That will add up to 131 million cups in 1998, the airline predicted on Jan. 6. Then on Jan. 7, Delta pledged its troth to Caribou Coffee, which operates 20 coffeehouses in Delta's home city, Atlanta. Caribou goes up the aisle in July. As for the reorganized Pan Am, its breakfast menu -- a Snackwell's cereal bar -- is augmented by the venerable A.& P. brand, Eight O'Clock, served in labeled six-ounce cups.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUCHMANN, HILDEGARD
description: TUCHMANN-Hildegard. Memorial service Sunday, January 25, 1PM, at Margaret Tietz Center for Nursing Care, 164-11 Chapin Parkway, Jamaica (718) 523-6400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTURA, WILBUR J.
description: MATTURA-Wilbur J. Died January 2, 1998 in Reno, NV at the age of 65. A memorial service will be held 10 AM, Wednesday at St. Francis Xavier Church, 46 W. 16 St., NYC. Inurnment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 10 W. Stephens Avenue, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Sudden Weakness Aside, Suharto Looks to Outlast Economic Crisis
description: For 32 years, Asia's longest-serving leader, President Suharto of Indonesia, has bent this sprawling, fractious and astoundingly diverse nation to his will.

title: An Art Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: A Smart Cart for the PGA
description: Casey Martin, a 25-year-old professional golfer afflicted with a circulatory disorder that hinders his ability to walk, has sued the PGA Tour to force it to exempt him from one of professional golf's basic rules. The rule says that, except for golfers over 50 on the Senior Tour, players must walk the course. Martin says he cannot earn a livelihood in his chosen profession unless he can ride in a cart. Martin is a first-class golfer with bright prospects. He was Tiger Woods's teammate at Stanford, and when a judge's preliminary injunction allowed him to play (and ride) in a PGA satellite event last week, he went out and won the tournament with a 19-under-par score of 269.

title: We Can't Just Ignore the Devastation of Drugs; Needless Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title: January 11-17; Court Ruling Ahead On South African Amnesty
description: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission laid the groundwork for backtracking on one of its most contested decisions: the granting of a broad amnesty to 37 top officials of the country's ruling party.

title: GE 73 3/8 GI 18 5/8 GM 57 1/2: The Ticker Explained
description: AT the New York Stock Exchange in the early 1920's, a swarm of men jostling around a small dome-topped stock ticker caught the attention of a mustachioed British immigrant, Percival N. Furber. He saw that the broker who did the most elbowing got the first look at the ticker tape, to his considerable advantage.

title: Fourth Stab at Glory for Broncos' Owner
description: Pat Bowlen is an athlete, a former triathlete, a distance runner and a front-runner who, interestingly, loves sprinting through the back door. His Denver Broncos are in their fourth Super Bowl during his 14-year reign as the team's owner. Super Bowl XXXII against the Green Bay Packers next Sunday in San Diego provides Bowlen with a chance to finish pro football's biggest race with its biggest prize -- the Lombardi Trophy.

title: Edmund Morris, 85, Actor and Writer
description: Edmund Morris, an actor, playwright and screenwriter whose drama ''The Wooden Dish'' was performed on Broadway and elsewhere, died on Jan. 6 in Providence Hospital near his home in Seattle. He was 85.

title: Youth Is Charged in a Deadly Random Shooting From a Balcony
description: A 17-year-old Bronx boy with a sealed juvenile police record was charged yesterday with killing a teen-ager he did not know by firing a gun from his balcony into a noisy, after-school crowd that had gathered on the street below to watch two girls fight.

title: We Can't Just Ignore the Devastation of Drugs; A Racial Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Dejected Belgrade Embraces Hedonism, but Still, Life Is No Cabaret
description: Pulsating music thumped through the blue haze of cigarette smoke and strobe lights of the Lotus Club. Scantily clad strippers spun around poles and leapt into two huge floodlit cages with men and women from the dance floor. The young couples began to peel off their shirts and simulate sex with the dancers.

title: N.J. Deserves a Share of Ellis Island
description: To the Editor:

title: A Classified Advertising Free-for-All
description: For more than two decades, consumers around the world in search of widgets, wombats or wives have turned to their local free-ads papers -- and have often got what they wished.

title: 5 From Md. College Sexually Assaulted On Guatemala Trip
description: Five American students from a Maryland college on an educational tour of Guatemala were raped on Friday after their bus was ambushed by four gunmen, the United States Embassy there said last night.

title: Proud to Be the Towns That Taste Forgot; Wildwoods Stop Lamenting Cheap, Tacky Motels and Start Promoting Them
description: The last campaign to try to lure the tourists back here promoted the size of the island's beaches, which are so wide that patrols regularly rescue bathers overcome by heat exhaustion as they trudge to and from the water's edge.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Indonesia a Bargain Now, Except for Most Indonesians
description: If you hop into a sleek, well-air-conditioned taxi in Jakarta these days, go from meeting to meeting in the glass office towers that are now up for sale, take in a little shopping, then make your way back to the hotel three hours later, the meter will read about 30,000 rupiah -- or just $3.50 at Friday's exchange rates.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KAHANE, ARTHUR S.
description: KAHANE-Arthur S. 8/7/14 1/19/88 A decade ago you left. Memories of your wit, generosity, optimism live on in my heart. Love, Jane

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Rock Titans in Their 50's: Too Cranky to Fade Away
description: In rock-and-roll, only the cranks survive. Or so it seemed last week, when rock icons of the 1960's descended on New York City. Baby boomers dug deep into their pockets to sell out both parts of Madison Square Garden for three shows by the Rolling Stones in the arena and, in the smaller Theater, five shows (continuing through Wednesday) that pair Bob Dylan and Van Morrison. Although they were in the same building -- with the potential for a historic collaboration, or at least a memorably sloppy mutual-admiration session -- the titans didn't play together. But the Rolling Stones couldn't resist playing Mr. Dylan's ''Like a Rolling Stone.''

title: In 'Cenerentola,' What One Coloratura Does, Another Does Differently
description: When the Metropolitan Opera offered its first production of Rossini's comic opera ''La Cenerentola'' in October, much was made of the fact that it was doing so specifically in behalf of the mezzo-soprano of the moment, Cecilia Bartoli. Ms. Bartoli, an old hand at the role, professes a certain attachment to the story (''Cinderella'' to you) and brings to it a personality and vocal qualities seemingly tailor-made for the purpose.

title: Patents; When it comes to number of patents, the petroleum industry is a veritable gusher.
description: THE petroleum industry, if one considers Patent Office statistics, must be a hotbed of innovative research. The oil and gas sector is annually one of the most patently prolific industries in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, STEWART JOSEPH, DR.
description: COHN-Stewart Joseph, Dr. On January 14, 1998 in Arizona. Rest in peace. Private services were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTA, D. FRED
description: SLOTA-D. Fred. January 16. Age 83, of Allentown, PA, formerly of Long Island City, NY. Survived by his wife Helen A. Autenrieth Slota, of Allentown, PA; brother Michael of Rockville Centre, NY; two daughters Eileen Harkless of Edison, NJ, and Karen Legg of Allentown; and four grandchildren. Visitation Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 10-11 AM, Keller Funeral Home, 1018 Church St., Fogelsville, PA, with service at 11. Donations to Heart Assoc., 212 E. Broad St., Bethlehem, PA 18018.

title: Crime in New York City in 1997
description: The crime rate in New York City fell 9.1 percent last year, with murders dropping to their lowest level since 1967. Here is a neighborhood-by-neighborhood breakdown of where the major crimes were committed in 1997. East New York, for example had the most murders and rapes, while south Staten Island had the least in both categories. Figures, which are preliminary, were compiled from New York City Police Department data.

title: N.Y.'s Budget Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTH, SAMUEL
description: WORTH-Samuel. On January 17, died at his home in Palm Aire, Pompano, FL. Cherished husband of Goldie for 61 years. Devoted father to Harvey and to Theona Deutsch, loving grandfather to Danny, Michael, Douglas, Beth and Jacquelyn. Founding member and former president of Hollis Hills Jewish Center. Funeral services at Sinai Chapels, 162 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, Queens, Monday at 9 AM.

title: Big British Liquor Distributor Is Said to Be in Merger Talks
description: Seeking safety in size, Allied Domecq P.L.C., the distributor of liquor brands like Kahlua, Beefeater gin and Maker's Mark bourbon, has been discussing a possible merger with some of its competitors, including the Seagram Company, a beverage industry official said yesterday.

title: Tenor Who Fits the Part Of Hugh, the Big Drover
description: There are relatively few tenors you would want to see in the title role of Ralph Vaughan Williams's opera ''Hugh the Drover.'' Not that the music is particularly difficult in this studied folkish creation from 1914, set in the Cotswolds of England some 102 years before.

title: Willis Green Jr., 50, Advocate Who Expanded AIDS Services
description: Willis Green Jr., a nationally known advocate for people with AIDS, a professional social worker and, most recently, the executive director of the Harlem United Community AIDS Center, died on Dec. 19 at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 50 and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: So Slinky and Understated On a Loose Stream of Sound
description: Leaving no footprints behind them after a short set, Gary Peacock, Paul Bley and Paul Motian snaked their way through a quiet, understated, guileless, nearly anti-show-business performance late Friday night at Birdland.

title: Nets' Van Horn Out to Prove He's Not a Notch Below the Spurs' Duncan
description: Keith Van Horn leaned heavily on the door to the Nets' training room in the catacombs of Continental Arena today, looking as though Saturday night's game had just ended. With a high-profile matchup looming a day ahead of him, Van Horn appeared more interested in sleep than in the arrival of Tim Duncan.

title: John Paul Creates 22 More Cardinals, Including 2 American Archbishops
description: Using his latest and perhaps one of his last -- chances to leave his mark on the highest ranks of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope John Paul II today appointed 22 new cardinals, including 2 from the United States and another 2 whose names he will keep secret for now.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Harbinger of New Nocturnal Habits
description: I was glad to read the other day that the National Football League has finally done something to accommodate my bedtime. In renewing its contract for Monday-night games with ABC, the N.F.L. agreed to move the kickoff to 8 o'clock on the East Coast. After years of snoozing through the second half, if I got that far, I may once again be able to see a last-second field goal or two.

title: A Movement Quartet, With Ideas Peeping Out
description: Wally Cardona's dances shift, without warning yet never abruptly, between soft loops of luscious movement and brisk athletic thrusts into space. The first minutes of his ''Monster Suite,'' the opening dance in Mr. Cardona's ''Altogether Different'' program on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater, build inexorably toward a purely physical climax. Although there are strong suggestions of an approaching cataclysm in the sound score, created by Walter Quintus and Joachim Kuhn, there is no hint of narrative in the dance itself. That purity is exciting.

title: An 18th-Century Midwife, Helping in Harsh Times
description: The experiences of three American women are joined in the first program of a new season of ''The American Experience.'' Martha Ballard was an 18th-century Maine midwife who kept a 27-year diary that included a record of helping deliver more than 800 babies. From those notes, a historian, Laurel Thatcher Ulrich, composed a book of her own, ''A Midwife's Tale: The Life of Martha Ballard, Based on Her Diary, 1785-1812,'' which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1991. And that inspired a television producer, Laurie Kahn-Leavitt, to make this 90-minute dramatization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. January 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Eliza and Simon. Brother of Timothy and Ian Clark. Son of Blair Clark and the late Jessie Holladay Philbin James. Memorial service, Tuesday, January 20, 10:30 AM at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73 St., NYC.

title: Taking In the Sites; Internet Can Help Sort Out Economic Turmoil in Asia
description: The economic crisis in Asia has generated a great deal of interest in news about the region, and many people are increasingly turning to the World Wide Web for timely information.

title: Koons Qualifies For U.S. Team
description: Scott Koons has not moved to the Adirondack Mountains. It only seemed that way yesterday in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Social Security Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Skill Game Breaks Out In a Hockey Arena
description: THE hockey All-Star Game is supposed to be a sedate, sanitized affair among colleagues, but when the Europeans took a very early two-goal lead yesterday, one of the North American players used his stick and his body to impede Igor Kravchuk of Russia from doing much of anything.

title: ALBANY IS FAULTED FOR NOT PREPARING TO MEET RECESSION
description: For some time, it has seemed that all the fiscal news from here was good. The state is running a big budget surplus for the third year in a row. Gov. George E. Pataki boasts that he has slowed the upward spiral of spending and that the state's emergency reserve fund is larger than ever.

title: Charles E. Claggett, 89, Headed Gardner Advertising of St. Louis
description: Charles E. Claggett, the former president and chairman of the Gardner Advertising Company, died on Jan. 8 at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 89.

title: Israel to Set No Pullback Goal Before Talks With Clinton
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today not to set a figure for the percentage of land to be included in the next Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank in advance of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's meeting with President Clinton, saying it would later consider a pullback up to an unspecified ''ceiling.''

title: Cuba and the Church Continue To Maneuver Over Pope's Visit
description: With Pope John Paul II scheduled to begin his long-awaited visit to Cuba in just three days, the Cuban Government and the Roman Catholic Church here are locked in behind-the-scenes maneuvering that ultimately will determine to what degree the political impact of the trip is muted or enhanced.

title: A Small Spark Reignites Debate on Cloning Humans
description: For nearly a year, Representative Vernon J. Ehlers has watched, frustrated, as his legislation to ban the cloning of humans remained stuck in Congress. With such pressing matters to tend to as balancing the budget and cutting taxes, his two cloning bills, he says, got ''lost in the dust.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAEUBER, DOROTHY B. (HOLLAND) HOSEA HARRIS
description: TAEUBER-Dorothy B. (Holland) Hosea Harris, of Nashua, NH, died in Nashua on January 15, 1998. Wife of Conrad F. Taeuber. Mother of Carolyn Wiljanen of Chelmsford, MA. Stepmother of Richard Taeuber of Salisbury, MD, and Karl Taeuber of Madison, WI. Memorial contributions: Chelmsford High School Fine Arts Department, North Chelmsford, MA 01863 or Women's Center for Wellness, 291 Main St., Milford, MA 01757. For information call the Davis Funeral Home, 603-883-3401.

title: Federal Grant Used to Raze Drug House For Church
description: For three years, a two-story brick house flanked by two shuttered churches had trouble written all over it. The graffiti on the side identified the house as a place run by gang members, and the address under a broken porch light was familiar to narcotics officers who raided the house twice last summer, seizing crack cocaine, five handguns and a shotgun, and arresting seven people.

title: U.S. Leaked British Intelligence to I.R.A., Ex-Envoy Says
description: A former American Ambassador to Britain has accused the Clinton Administration of having leaked British intelligence on Northern Ireland to the Irish Republican Army.

title: The Clinton Administration is taking a tough stance on cyberspace copyrights.
description: AS Congress prepares to reconvene later this month, cyberspace law experts are bracing for yet another battle with the Clinton Administration over its dogged pursuit of restrictive copyright legislation for the digital age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, JANE GESSLER
description: GRAY-Jane Gessler. On January 16, 1998. Beloved mother of Ralph Peter Gray and beloved friend of Sam Earle. Friends may call Monday, 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: San Diego Reminded Of One That Got Away
description: Well, you can go home again, and you can find yourself surrounded by all of the things you once loved, and you can move forward and all of a sudden find yourself stuck in the past.

title: Martin Luther King Jr. Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Antalaha Journal; Vanilla Farming? Not as Bland as You Might Think
description: Barefoot in the steamy rain forest that surrounds his wooden hut here, Solomon Rasolomonina pushed his way through the branches, hunting for his vanilla plants. When he found one, he snapped a twig the size of a matchstick from a nearby tree and, gently reaching into the plants' blooming orchids, pollinated them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, ANNA (NEE CAMERON)
description: CASEY-Anna (nee Cameron). Beloved wife of the late Martin. Devoted mother of the late Mary Weeden, Ann Wight, Helen Flynn, James, Martin, Sister Patricia C.S.J., Theresa, Brendan, Dorothy Clark, Thomas and Jane Carreo. Also survived by 41 grandchildren and 31 great-grandchildren. Repsong at Dahill Funeral Home, 2525 65th St., Brooklyn, until Tuesday, 8:30 AM. Mass of the Resurrection, St. Brendan's R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. Visitng hours Monday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Girl, 9, Struck by Driver Without a License, Dies
description: A 9-year-old girl who was severely injured when she was struck on a Harlem sidewalk Saturday night by an unlicensed teen-age driver died yesterday at Harlem Hospital Center, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HEREN, DANA JOY (NEE BECKER)
description: O'HEREN-Dana Joy (nee Becker). Cherished daughter of Jerome M. Becker and Nancy W. Drake (nee Wohl). Beloved wife of Gary Dodd O'Heren. Step-daughter of Kris Becker. Loving sister of Douglas and Sharon Becker and stepsister of Melanie Drake. Adored granddaughter of Ronne and Samuel Wulwick and Margaret and Benjamin Becker and the late Joseph S. Wohl. Aunt of Jake and J.T. Niece of Elianor Cohen, Vicky and Michael Greenberg, Larry and Denise Wohl, Andrew and Maxine Becker. Cousin of Ricky, Elizabeth, Alissa, Tony, Joselyn, Arden, Kimberly, Allison, Robby, Kelly, Jordan, Riley, Tanner, and the late Roddy. Funeral Monday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, DANA JOY O'HEREN
description: BECKER-Dana Joy O'Heren. We mourn the loss of our beloved doughter who has found peace. Rest sweet darling, rest. Kris and Daddy

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall St. Appeals For Millennium Break

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, JAMES I.
description: JOHNSTON-James I. The family of James I. Johnston bade farewell to a loving husband and father who passed away January 17, 1998. Jim, a 1953 graduate of the University of Pittsburgh, began his career as a Certified Public Accountant at Touche Ross and Co. After becoming a partner, he was a key contributor to building Touche Ross' international presence. After 25 years at Touche Ross, Jim continued his career at Main Hurdman and KMG, both in the U.S. and in the Netherlands. Jim retired from KPMG in 1988, at which point he married Jean, his soulmate, and started his ''second'' career as retailer and restaurateur. Jim is survived by his loving wife, Jean and their combined families. In lieu of flowers, the Johnston Scholarship Fund has been created for the Cadets of Bergen County Drum Corps. Contributions can be made to ''The Cadets,'' PO Box 506, Bergenfield, NJ 07621.

title: N.J. Deserves a Share of Ellis Island; Judgment Was Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis Are Told to Prepare for 'Holy War' on U.N. Sanctions
description: The Government of President Saddam Hussein called on Iraqis today to report for military training and said it was ready for a ''holy war'' against United Nations sanctions that have crippled its economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, BERNARD
description: HOROWITZ - Bernard. Devoted husband of the late Frances, loving father of Irving and Marvin. Dear brother of Norman. Adored grandfather of Seth, Bret, Beth and Francie. Services 10 AM, January 20, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

title: A.B.L. Has Its Turn and Shows Its Stuff
description: Sylvia Crawley walked to the basket tonight, spun around and marched off 10 steps -- 7 long ones, 3 short. Then the Colorado Xplosion center slipped on a blindfold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ANNE RIVA
description: WHITE-Anne Riva. Loving mother of Erwin and Sidney and sister of Celia and the late Albert. Grandmother of Paul, Julie, Tina, Danny and Ken. Great-grandmother of Molly and Willi. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at the ''Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBMAN, ALEX A.K.A. ALLAN SMALL
description: SCHREIBMAN-Alex a.k.a. Allan Small. 87, died Saturday in his home at Boca Raton, FL. He was a noted pianist, composer, arranger and music teacher. He is survived by his wife, Lucille and three children. Graveside service will be held Tuesday, January 20, at New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to a charity of your choice. For information call I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Inc., 1-800624-8282.

title: All About the Art, and Heart, of Ballet
description: The ABT Studio Company, American Ballet Theater's junior troupe, seeks to present new works, to give performing experience to dancers embarking upon professional careers, and to bring the excitement of dance to audiences young and old. It offered a lively program on Friday night at the New Victory Theater as part of a series called ''Step One: Dance at the New Victory.''

title: Esiason Felt Pushed Toward TV Booth
description: Boomer Esiason's decision to join ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' broadcast team was accelerated by a feeling that the Cincinnati Bengals no longer wanted him -- even after he led them to four victories in the final five weeks of this season.

title: Accounts
description: * Aurora Foods Inc., Columbus, Ohio, a unit of MBW Investors L.L.C., to N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, part of MacManus Group, to handle its Duncan Hines line of baking products, which Aurora recently acquired from the Procter & Gamble Co. Ayer had handled Duncan Hines for 13 years under P.& G.'s ownership. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: 'The Best Player in the Country'
description: The small, dark-haired girl was 6 years old when she discovered what for her was heaven. It was a basketball court on a scruffy little playground in Figueira da Foz, a northwestern beach town in Portugal where she grew up. She remembers that she would play ''quando a lua substituia o sol'' -- or, until the moon replaces the sun. Or until her mother dragged her home for dinner.

title: 'Paris' to 'Seville,' by a Curious Route
description: Thursday night's New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall, conducted by Leonard Slatkin, was a strange sequence of bits and pieces. There were some symmetries in it: each half had, in the middle, a group of three Mozart arias, and the first half began and ended with 20th-century American works. But what those works had to do with the songs, how Mozart's ''Paris'' Symphony got in there, and why the program finished with an overture -- Rossini's ''Barber of Seville'' -- were all questions left in the air at the end.

title: Bridge; Trans-Atlantic Partners Take A World Pairs Championship
description: A trans-Atlantic partnership captured the prestigious Cap Gemini World Top Pairs in The Hague yesterday. Zia Mahmood, the Pakistani star who lives in Manhattan but is usually somewhere else, was playing with the top-ranked British player, Tony Forrester. They held a big lead at the start of the final session but were challenged by two Italians, Andrea Buratti and Massimo Lanzarotti. The margin was 13 victory points with one match remaining to be played, but Zia and Forrester held on to win by 21.

title: Clinton Plan On Medicare Is Opposed
description: Entering into the election year debate over Medicare, the majority leader of the Senate today said he opposed President Clinton's proposal to allow hundreds of thousands of early retirees, laid off workers and uninsured people who are nearing retirement age to buy into the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HERMAN
description: GREENBERG-Herman. The officers, trustees, and members of Temple Gates of Prayer record with profound sorrow the passing of our past President, Herman Greenberg. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Connie, to his children Stewart, Karen and Judy, their spouses and children, to his sister Edith, and his mother-in-law Helene Schmuger. He served a distinguished term of office as President of our congregation from 1987 to 1990. When our Temple was destroyed by fire in 1977, he was a vital force in its reconstruction and again directed its refurbishing in 1991. As an officer and trustee, he strove both for continuity and renewal. His devotion to the Temple was limitless. We mourn our great loss. Morris A. Urieff, President Albert Thaler, Rabbi

title: Packers Plan to Rely on Favre Again
description: The Green Bay Packers arrived here today for Super Bowl XXXII a year older, a year wiser and a year more experienced. They know the Super Bowl routine. They know that winning the game is the thing.

title: ESPN Rivals Set for Fight As Magazine Debut Nears
description: Boys will be boys.

title: Hold On to Open Admissions
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was right when he urged the City University of New York to strive for higher standards and do a better job at remedial education in its six community colleges. His call for more hours of instruction and fundamental reform in kindergarten through 12th grade was equally on target. But the Mayor's proposal for killing off CUNY's open admissions program is disastrously wrongheaded. Such a policy would foreclose a principal avenue by which new immigrants and disadvantaged students better themselves and gain entry to the work force. Driving these students away from college dims their prospects and the city's long-term future.

title: Following Up on Glowing Hockey Pucks
description: The glowing hockey puck was simply not enough.

title: Pataki Seeks Aid For Drivers
description: The budget proposal that Gov. George E. Pataki plans to present on Tuesday will contain a few election-year treats for New York State's drivers.

title: This Term, a New Dynamic for Whitman and Legislature
description: When Christine Todd Whitman was sworn into office as Governor four years ago, she demanded immediate legislative action on her bold campaign pledge to cut state income taxes. Most lawmakers, cowed by her defeat of an incumbent governor, overcame their skepticism and went along with her plan.

title: Israeli Isn't a Peacemaker
description: To the Editor:

title: An Extra Day to Fine-Tune 1,000 Years
description: Wall Street has been planning to update its vast networks of computers since at least 1995 to insure that they can handle dates in the year 2000 and beyond. Now, with less than two years to go, it is about to ask for extra time --one day's worth.

title: Anything Can Still Happen At Sundance Film Festival
description: Gabriel Byrne is shivering in icy rain, waiting for a shuttle bus. Frances McDormand is trudging through the snow. So are Gwyneth Paltrow and Lena Olin. Kyra Sedgwick is wandering up Main Street looking for gifts for her two children. ''There's something schizophrenic about Sundance,'' said Ms. Sedgwick, who plays a Mafia gun moll in ''Montana,'' a film by a first-time director that had its premiere the other night at the Sundance Film Festival here. ''On the one hand, it's great to see these young, hungry filmmakers meeting on common ground. You can feel the ambition in the air.''

title: Sound Familiar? It's Boston, the Crowd Cheers, Bird Wins
description: He saw the big shot Reggie Miller made and the padlock defense the Indiana Pacers played. Still, Larry Bird's impassive expression did not change. Spare with his words, he calmly walked along the sideline and watched his team hold on at the end.

title: Budget Heroes Include Bush and Gorbachev
description: Who should get credit for the fact that the Federal budget is now virtually balanced?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUBY, DR. ROBERT
description: TUBY-Dr. Robert. Happy Birthday, Daddy! Our hearts have not stopped crying for you. We miss and are lost without you. Evelyn, Joan and Family

title: Suggestions of Balanchine In an Elegy From Robbins
description: Jerome Robbins's moody and mysterious ''In Memory of . . .'' has prompted questions about the true meaning of the ballet, presented by the New York City Ballet in a revival on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. Created in 1985, two years after George Balanchine's death, ''In Memory of . . .'' is certainly an elegy, though program notes suggest it was inspired by the circumstances surrounding the ballet's score by Alban Berg.

title: Hot and Dirty Jobs End; So Does a Way of Life
description: Looking into the glowing mouth of the coke ovens, a man could almost imagine what hell is like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARGILL, WILLIAM BURNELL
description: CARGILL-William Burnell, 42, of Southport, CT, died on January 15 in a yachting accident off the Florida coast near Key Largo. He is survived by his beloved wife Virginia and sons Stephen and William, his sisters Sissy Biggers, Molly Spruance, Sarah Brundage, and half-sister Alexandra Cargill, his brother Samuel W. Cargill, his mother Mrs. Harris E. Russell, and two nieces. Survivors also include his stepsister Alison M. Russell, stepbrothers H. Edward, Peter S., Timothy G., and George F. Russell, and his stepfather Harris E. Russell. He attended Aiglon College, Villars, Switzerland, and was a graduate of Pomfret School and Georgetown University. He started his business career at Richardson-Vicks, Inc., and subsequently worked at Nielsen Marketing Research, Inc.-Majers Division. For the last nine years, he was with Actmedia, Inc. of Norwalk, CT, the worldwide marketing services company, where at his death he was President and CEO, Actmedia International. An avid and experienced sailor, he was a Governor of the Pequot Yacht Club, Southport, as well as an active member of the New York Yacht Club. He was also a member of the Country Club of Fairfield, and a trustee of the Pomfret School and Aiglon College. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church, Southport on Tuesday, January 20, at 11 AM, followed by a farewell tribute at Southport Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Pequot Yacht Club Junior Sailing Program.

title: Pushing for Court Reform
description: The cause of sensible court reform received an important boost earlier this month when Gov. George Pataki endorsed Chief Judge Judith Kaye's plan to reorganize the state's convoluted court system. Quick action on the measure would insure that court streamlining does not get lost in the annual wrangling over the state budget.

title: 'Ragtime': A Diorama With Nostalgia Rampant
description: Blessed with beauty, ambition, a smashing wardrobe and a social conscience, ''Ragtime'' would seem to be the kind of musical that brings Broadway audiences to their knees in adoration. Then why does this $10 million show, which opened last night at the new Ford Center for the Performing Arts, feel so utterly resistible?

title: Ex-Denver Archbishop Was Host To 'Catholic Woodstock' in 1993
description: Archbishop James Francis Stafford, president of the Pontifical Council for the Laity in Rome, may be best known among American Catholics as the Denver prelate who served successfully as host to Pope John Paul II and about 400,000 other Catholics at World Youth Day in August 1993.

title: Marilyn Costello, 72, Harpist For the Philadelphia Orchestra
description: Marilyn Costello, the principal harpist of the Philadelphia Orchestra for 46 years and a respected teacher at the Curtis Institute of Music, died on Jan. 5 at her home in Philadelphia. She was 72.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Inmate Is Found Dead In an Apparent Hanging
description: An inmate at the Monmouth County Jail apparently hanged himself inside his cell yesterday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: Stocks Higher Across Asia
description: In trading this morning, markets across Asia were mostly higher. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues, based in Tokyo, was up 2.54 percent at the midday break. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong was up more than 5 percent in morning trading, and the Indonesian composite index was up more than 6 percent. South Korea's composite index was also doing well, with the shares pushing beyond 4 percent. Singapore, Malaysia and the Philippines were also higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOPER, SAMUEL
description: KOOPER-Samuel. Attorney in New York City for over 50 years. Beloved husband of Natalie. Adored father of Al. Cherished grandfather of Brian. Dear brother of Ceil Rachlin.

description: GOLDBERGER-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Esther and beloved father and father-in-law of Steve and Wanda Gilbert, Ronald and Amy Goldberger, Howard and Lynn Gross and beloved grandfather of Wayne, Adam, Joshua and Jordan Gilbert, Jacob and Edward Goldberger and Jennifer and Jeffrey Gross.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. A memorial service will be held at The Mount Sinai Medical Center to mark the passing last October of our most cherished friend and esteemed colleague, internationallyrenowned cardiologist, Richard Gorlin, M.D., Senior Vice President of The Mount Sinai Medical Center, The Dr. George Baehr Professor of Clinical Medicine of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and Medical Director of The Mount Sinai Health System. Family, Trustees, faculty, staff, students, and friends are invited to attend at 5 P.M. Tuesday, January 20 in the Stern Auditorium, Annenberg Building, Fifth Avenue at 100th Street.

title: Louima Hears Sharpton Say Exaggeration Isn't Needed
description: Striking a reserved note in an otherwise spirited defense of Abner Louima, the Rev. Al Sharpton told more than 200 worshipers -- including Mr. Louima -- at a Brooklyn church yesterday that distortions of the facts in the case were ''inexcusable and intolerable.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, EDWARD
description: JENNINGS-Edward. On January 17, 1998, of Long Boat Key, FL, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY. Beloved husband of the late Molly Jennings. Loving brother of John, Thomas, Patrick, Mary, Bridget, Angela, and the late Tobias. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends Monday, 2-4, 7-9 PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY. Interment to follow at Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Lung Cancer Service, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY.

title: Video World Is Smitten by a Gun-Toting, Tomb-Raiding Sex Symbol
description: Her name is Lara Croft, and she seems to be everywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, MILDRED WEDEKIND
description: POTTER-Mildred Wedekind. Former cosmetics executive, 95, died January 16, 1998, Somers, NY. Survived by her daughter Joan Arnold and three grandchildren. Contributions to UNICEF, 333 East 38th Street, NY, NY 10016, Attn: Tribute Card Program.

title: Pope Names 22 Cardinals
description: Pope John Paul II yesterday named 22 new cardinals, including 2 Americans and 2 whose names were kept secret for now. Page A8.

title: At Bronx School, 'Ultra-Seniors' Ponder Graduation
description: It never really dawned on Julio C. Santos that he was getting on in years until, like a veteran office worker sizing up the interns, he noticed that the other students at Theodore Roosevelt High School on East Fordham Road in the Bronx seemed to be getting younger and younger.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Jones's Lawyers Seek to Find Pattern of Clinton Misconduct
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones said today that the sexual misconduct case against President Clinton would seek to establish a pattern of licentious behavior toward other women by Mr. Clinton, in order to bolster Ms. Jones's allegations.

title: An N.H.L. Pioneer Gets His Due, 40 Years Later
description: Willie O'Ree didn't stop to consider his place in history when he became the National Hockey League's first black player.

title: Last week's deals proved that the networks can't live without high-rated programs.
description: AT the end of the week of spending extravagantly, the networks rested -- and wondered what they had wrought.

description: IF you wanted to convince young, urban media planners that the Good Housekeeping Seal helps make Good Housekeeping, the venerable women's service magazine, a vibrant, contemporary vehicle for marketers, you would introduce a trade advertising campaign with which of the following strategies:

description: KARLITZ-Vivian Zweig. On January 18, peacefully with her family. Beloved wife of Irwin. Devoted mother of Herb. Cherished grandmother of Joelle and Jenna. Services 1:15 PM, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Women's Cancer Research Alliance, 818-760-7722.

description: TRAVERS-Fay. January 17, 1998. Beloved sister of Dorothy Jacobs. Cherished aunt of Ruth and Darwin Green. She will be missed. Interment private.
