title: 'Defying Gravity,' Inmate Population Climbs
description: Despite a decline in the crime rate over the past five years, the number of inmates in the nation's jails and prisons rose again in 1997, led by a sharp increase of more than 9 percent in the number of people confined in city and county jails, according to a study released today by the Justice Department.

title: New Hope for Finding a Murderer
description: It has been 22 years since the body of 15-year-old Martha Moxley was found near her family's home in an exclusive section of this exclusive town. She had been beaten to death with a golf club under a weeping willow in what has become an enduring mystery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUYLER, PEARL
description: SCHUYLER-Pearl. Suddenly on January 17, 1998. Beloved wife of Irving. Loving mother of Sandra Schuyler Jaffee and Harvey Schuyler. Dear mother-in-law of Carl Jaffee and cherished grandmother of Evan Jaffee. Private private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, MARCELLA BUTLER
description: O'MALLEY-Marcella Butler. On January 18, after a courageous struggle with multiple myeloma. Beloved wife of James for 55 years, daughter of the late Thomas and Margaret, mother of Malcolm and Anne, sister of the late Reynolds Butler and Catherine Butler. Born in Montreal in 1915. Her strength, graciousness, beauty and determination were admired by many. She cared deeply about her community and creative efforts, to which she contributed her paintings. Her inimitable presence and loving spirit will be missed enormously. Friends will be received at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 St., on January 20, from 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Ave. at 66th St., on January 21, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ADA
description: RUBIN-Ada. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Dorothy Hertling and Arlene Zelesnick. Mother-in-law of Julius Hertling and Jay Zelesnick. Dear grandmother of Richard and Jim Hertling, and Robin and Brooke Zelesnick. Delighted great-grandmother of Lily. Dear sister of Ruth Grossman. Longtime member of Riverdale ORT. Services 12 noon, Monday, January 19, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. She will be missed.

title: Technology to Let Engineers Filter the Web and Judge Content
description: In a private vote by E-mail a few days before Christmas, a group of about 200 computer scientists and engineers endorsed a set of rules that could govern some of the most fundamental ways people around the globe will get electronic information -- and will be prevented from getting it -- in years to come.

title: Australians Drop Two Openers
description: The clouds parted for the teen-agers on opening day at the Australian Open, where 16-year-old Lleyton Hewitt caused the host nation's first case of heartbreak and 15-year-old Mirjana Lucic of Croatia dealt Australia a second blow by overpowering Rennae Stubbs, 7-5, 6-1.

title: People
description: * Chris Grindem, new business director at J. Walter Thompson Detroit, a unit of WPP Group, was also named to the position of director for the agency's new retail unit, J. Walter Thompson Retail Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, PAUL
description: WEINER-Paul. On January 17. Devoted father and father-in-law. Cherished grandfather of Michael, David, Danielle and Julian. Adored uncle. Services 11 AM today, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Knicks' Guards May Be Flummoxed
description: The Boston Celtics surround their targets as they would surround a bonfire, circling tight with their hands out and constantly feeling for the ball.

title: Treasury Bill Sale Set for Tomorrow
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills. Because of the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, there is no trading today in United States Treasury securities and no trading of futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURETZ, SHIRLEY
description: PURETZ-Shirley. Loving wife of Murray, devoted mother of Arleen Cook (Ed) and Julian Puretz (Judy). Cherished and adored grandmother of Tara, Peri and Jeni Cook. Loving sister of Bertha, Beatie, Harry, Gertie and the late Frances. Funeral services Monday, 12:30 PM, I. J. Morris Inc., 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BICKERMAN, MILTON
description: BICKERMAN-Milton. Age 83, on January 17, 1998. A sweet, gentle and generous man. We will miss your warmth, your good counsel and your laughter. Cherished husband of Leonore for more than 50 years. Loving father of Barbara, John and his wife Debra, and Michael. Proud grandfather of Gregory and Melissa. Devoted to his family and The New York Times. Past President of The Times Thirty Year Club. Funeral services today at noon, at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI. Memorial contributions may be made to the Mike Bickerman Scholarship Fund, Lawrence High School, Cedarhurst, NY.

title: A City Strives to Balance Its Role in King Legacy
description: In the decades since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was slain here, this city has struggled to live down the impact of that moment on its national image and in the hearts of its residents.

title: The Neediest Cases; Foster Care Tames the Wild Side of a Troubled Youth
description: Wilfred Jean-Phillippe does not remember much about his early years in Haiti. He has little recollection of the mother who sent him to New York at age 7 to live with the father he had never met. ''All I remember is that we slept in a hut and there was not much to eat,'' said Wilfred, now 15.

title: Renegade Irish Militants Plan Mayhem, Officials Say
description: Several renegade groups, including one that took responsibility today for the killing of a Catholic man in Northern Ireland, have the capacity, and apparently the intention, to wreak mayhem in the coming weeks with shootings and bombings, according to British security and intelligence officials.

title: By Knocking Spirlea Out, Serena Williams May Get to Face Her Sister Next
description: They are the hottest novelty act in this tennis-crazed city, and the act heated up on schedule today at the Australian Open.

title: Nixon, on the Ascendant, Vs. Douglas, Eclipsed
description: TRICKY DICK AND THE PINK LADY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, BETTY
description: FISHER-Betty. The world is sadder for the loss of a charming and beautiful woman. Betty Fisher died January 16, 1998, in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. Betty, lovingly known as ''Super Boss'' is survived by her husband of 63 years, the Hon. Harold L. Fisher, former chairman of the MTA and a prominent New York attorney. Theirs was a true love and romance. Betty was the loving mother of Prof. Leonard Fisher and his wife, Yvonne of Danville, California, Hon. Alice Fisher Rubin and her husband Lowell, Stephanie Fisher Cooper and her husband Joseph Harrison of Asheville, North Carolina, Andrew S. Fisher, Esq. and his wife Barbara and Council Member Kenneth Fisher and his wife Kirsten. Adored ''Go-Go'' grandmother because of her energy and travels of Alana, Matthew, Jonathan, Jacob and Penelope Fisher, David and Emily Rubin, and Neil, Edward, Jay and Gary Cooper. Also survived by her sisters Rose Ashin of Little Silver, New Jersey and Sarah Frischling of Tierre Verde, Florida. Great grandmother to 5. Aunt to many, friend to all. Donations may be made to the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation. Shiva at the Rubin home from Monday evening January 19th through 3pm Friday, January 23rd. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Critics Say Rockefeller Drug Laws Pack the Prisons, Force Plea Deals and Hit Small-Timers the Hardest
description: In the 25 years since New York enacted some of the toughest drug laws in the country, drug dealers, prosecutors and defense lawyers have increasingly found ways of working around the laws or using them in a manner never intended, softening the goal of putting away hardened drug traffickers, say many people involved in drug cases.

title: Metro Matters; Housing Hope Of Mentally Ill Is Fading Away
description: NUBY BATCHELOR is more than willing to talk about his past and its long bleak stretches. But he cannot quite join the pieces together. At one point, he says, he was an Army combat instructor. Sometime later, he became a violent alcholic.

title: Op-Art
Abroad at Home; But There Is No Peace
description: Cut through Benjamin Netanyahu's talk, and the reality is plain. The present Government of Israel is not interested in making peace with the Palestinians.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: A Done Deal Redone Anyway
description: ''Talk is cheap,'' says John Tu, the chief executive and co-founder of the Kingston Technology Corporation, who showed in December 1996 that he is not stingy by handing out $100 million in bonuses to 500 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOSE, HELEN WILLENS
description: MOOSE-Helen Willens. On January 17, 1998. Beloved mother of the late Charles Seth Moose. Devoted sister of Iva Schlesinger. Dear aunt of Jonathan Schlesinger and Jennifer Curling. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: 'Year of Woman' Senators In Tough Re-election Races
description: The opulent banquet room in the Chicago Hilton and Towers was brimming with Democrats, their $500 gate fees entitling them to an open bar, a roster of spunky speeches and the chance to fatten the re-election campaign coffers of Senator Carol Moseley-Braun.

title: N.J. Deserves a Share of Ellis Island; Tradition Preserved
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Murphy, 64, Professor And Ex-Chancellor of CUNY
description: Joseph S. Murphy, the son of a labor organizer and a champion of the working class who became Chancellor of the City University of New York, died in an automobile accident near Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Saturday. He was 64.

title: North America All-Stars Conquer World
description: After the dancing guys in goalie suits, the tumblers in the mascot costumes and the indoor fireworks explosions were all finished, the Canadian rock singer Bryan Adams stood on the ice at General Motors Place today surrounded by four members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in their bright red uniforms.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: California Stumbles On Bilingual Classes; Language by Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Titanic' Wins Top Golden Globe Award
description: In an evening that was expected to pit the big guns of expensive Hollywood dramas against the depth of small, independently produced works, an array of big and small films took Golden Globe awards here tonight, with ''Titanic,'' a $200 million costume drama, winning as top film drama but several smaller movies taking most other awards.

title: Free Speech About Food
description: The lawsuit brought by Texas cattle ranchers against Oprah Winfrey will provide the first legal test of any of the ''food disparagement'' laws now in place in 13 states. These harmful and probably unconstitutional statutes are intended to protect farmers and ranchers from malicious or reckless statements suggesting that a food product is not safe for consumption. But if upheld, these laws could chill needed public debate about food safety and food processing methods.

title: Essay; Gravy Trains Don't Run on Time
description: The great lesson of the financial meltdown of Asian autocracies is this: Freedom is indivisible. Economic freedom cannot exist without political freedom.

title: Advertisers Part With 2 Agencies
description: Relationships between two advertisers and their agencies have ended abruptly.

title: Science Triumphant? Not So Fast
description: These are giddy days for scientists. In his new book, ''Remaking Eden,'' Lee M. Silver, a biologist at Princeton, foresees an era in which humans attain virtually infinite power to manipulate their bodies and minds. Our descendants will be smarter than Einstein and more athletic than Michael Jordan, he predicts, and they will live for hundreds of years, if not forever.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Sam Dordoni, an inventor who is promoting a fuel-free transit system in Manhattan, gave an incorrect E-mail address for Mr. Dordoni. His address is: gravtran@nac.net.

title: Success in Failures
description: Dan Couvrette's 10-year marriage dissolved in 1994, which seemed like another good reason for him to leave Wedding Bells, Canada's largest bridal magazine. Two years later, he founded another magazine, Divorce.

title: Gatti and Manfredy Nurse Wounds
description: On Saturday night, Arturo Gatti looked as if he had stepped out of one of those grainy, black and white 1950's B movies on boxing. A gaping gash above his left eye was streaming blood, his other eye was a slit visible through a puffy pillow, and Gatti was still slinging punches at Angel Manfredy. Finally, the referee, Wayne Hedgepeth, and the ring physician, Dr. Domenic Coletta, had seen enough by the eighth round and stopped the lightweight fight.

title: Voice Technology Appears Ready to Recognize Bottom Line
description: When Charles Schwab, the brokerage company, decided late last year to switch to an automated phone system for taking customer calls, it put its trust in speech-recognition technology, which it would have spurned a few years earlier.

title: In Poetry, Ted Hughes Breaks His Silence on Sylvia Plath
description: It has been nearly 35 years since the poet Sylvia Plath put her head in a gas oven, killing herself at age 30 soon after her husband left her for another woman. And for all that time, her widower, the poet Ted Hughes, has maintained an implacable silence about their life together, emerging from his self-protective cocoon only occasionally, mostly to correct errors or to write prefaces to Plath's work.

title: Police Chief's Suspension Is Overturned in Court
description: A state judge has overturned a three-day suspension of Paterson's Police Chief on insubordination charges, ruling that the municipal police come under the jurisdiction of the County Prosecutor, not local elected officials, in criminal matters.

title: Internet Ad Monitors In Strategic Alliance
description: Two companies are combining units that track advertising spending on the Internet as they agree to a strategic alliance.

title: Marilyn Horne and Friends in Party Mood at Carnegie
description: There was much to celebrate on Friday night when the Marilyn Horne Foundation observed its fifth anniversary with a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall. The renowned American mezzo-soprano began her foundation to support young singers who wished to devote part of their future careers to the song recital. To date, among its many activities, the foundation has presented 23 young vocalists in 39 recitals across the country.

title: Sports of The Times; In Lombardi's Office, A Man With a View
description: AS the Packers' general manager, Ron Wolf works in the same office that Vince Lombardi once did as their general manager and coach. And on Sunday, the Packer team that Wolf built will try to win a second consecutive Super Bowl, as Lombardi's teams did by winning the first two Super Bowls. But Wolf was around Lombardi only once.

title: One Step Back; Just a Song, Luring the Listener to a Road Not Taken
description: In 1997, Jakob Dylan's band, the Wallflowers, sold four million copies of its second album, ''Bringing Down the Horse.'' Led by the hit single ''One Headlight,'' it stayed in the Top 10 for most of the year and, sustained by the single ''Three Marlenas,'' the album is still on the radio.

title: WAVE OF MERGERS IS RECASTING FACE OF BUSINESS IN U.S.
description: Not since a wave of industrial takeovers created the great oil, steel and auto companies at the beginning of the century has corporate America been reshaped by a sweep of merger activity as broad as the one taking place today.

title: Over 100 Bald Eagles For the 3d Straight Year
description: For the third year in a row, more than 100 bald eagles are living in New Jersey, state environmental officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph in some copies yesterday with an obituary of Edmund Morris, an actor and playwright who died on Jan. 6, was published in error. The picture showed the historian Edmund Morris, who wrote ''The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt'' and has been working on a biography of Ronald Reagan.

title: Internet Sales Climb for Barnes & Noble
description: Barnes & Noble Inc. is expecting sales at its Internet book-selling site to reach $8 million in the current quarter, helped by the holidays.

title: Tax-Free Shopping Week in New York Thins the Mall Crowds Across the Hudson
description: Yes, Carlos Sosa did some shopping in his home state of New Jersey today. But only on his way to New York City, where he planned to take full advantage of the tax-free shopping week that started on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBENTHAL, JON
description: LIEBENTHAL-Jon. Age 37. Beloved son of Phyllis and Lester. Adored brother of Roy. Untimely passing. Services today, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: No Smithsonian Retreat On Israel Lectures; What 'McCarthyism'?
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: At Princeton, A Sense Of Where They Are; The Tigers Thrive In a Special System
description: The players on perhaps the most precise and definitely the most unusual college basketball team in the nation are sitting at school desks inside a musty room waiting to oppose Yale on a January night. A curtain surrounds the Princeton Tigers to supposedly muffle the sounds of students on rowing machines as Coach Bill Carmody lectures his squad.

title: Off-Duty Officer Fires at 2 Attackers
description: An off-duty police officer opened fire on two men who were attacking him in a residential neighborhood in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, shooting one man in the leg, the police said.

title: Strong Job Gains Made In December and in 1997
description: More than 13,400 new jobs were created in New Jersey last month, making 1997 the best year for new employment since 1988, according to a report released on Friday by state officials.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Instead of a meeting between an angel and the devil, wouldn't it be better to think of a meeting between two angels who are friends of the poor?''

title: No Smithsonian Retreat On Israel Lectures
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Ira Progoff, 76, a Psychotherapist and Author
description: Dr. Ira Progoff, a New York psychotherapist and author known for an intensive journal-writing method he developed as a way to encourage personal growth, died on Jan. 1 at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 76 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Chicago Archbishop Represents A Vital Center of U.S. Catholicism
description: In elevating Archbishop Francis Eugene George of Chicago to the status of cardinal, Pope John Paul II continued a long tradition of Vatican recognition that Chicago's spiritual head speaks for a vital center in American Catholicism.

title: A. M. Selinger Dies at 91; Ran Famed Bakery
description: Alexander M. Selinger, an Italian-born, Czech-reared businessman who brought the sweet taste of Austria and Hungary to a generation of Middle European refugees on the Upper West Side, died on Jan. 12 at a nursing home near his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 91 and had operated the Eclair Bakery at 141 West 72d Street for more than 50 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, ARCHIE
description: LEVITT-Archie. January 15, in Boca Raton FL. Beloved husband of Evelyn, father of Ellen Rappaport and husband Joel, Howard Levitt and wife Terry. Grandfather of Eric Rappaport and wife Michelle Stefanie Janoff and husband Jason, and Danielle Levitt.

title: Metro Business; Bagel Chain Acquires Deli
description: Big City Bagels of Hicksville, N.Y., which has stores in several Western states, has announced that it has entered the New York market by acquiring a deli and catering store in the garment district.

title: Mets' Wilpon Helps Post Medical Victory
description: Healing. The word is integral to the Mets' story this winter, as Todd Hundley, Jason Isringhausen, Bill Pulsipher, Carlos Baerga and Jay Payton travel from various injuries and illnesses back to playing condition.

title: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.
description: At least five members of Congress and dozens of Congressional aides have traveled a grueling 9,000 miles, crossed nine time zones and endured serious jet lag, all in the name of diligent fact finding.

title: Sports of The Times; The Time Of Reckoning For Rookies
description: IF this was a rookie of the year statement game, then Tim Duncan tooted his horn just a bit louder than Keith Van Horn. No. 1 in the draft outscored number No. 2 by 24-21, outrebounded him by 17-10, and was such the long-armed defensive presence that Van Horn missed more shots (23) than Duncan took (17).

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Science Times on Jan. 13 about the virus that causes ''bird flu'' credited a photo of the virus incorrectly. It was provided by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Let's Have a Family Discount
description: Not since college have I been so interested in getting a fake I.D. This time, I'd like to be mistaken for an older woman -- about the age of 65.

title: Japan's 3 Big Brokerage Firms Post Losses
description: Japan's three largest brokerage firms reported losses today for the final quarter of 1997, reflecting the damage done by a payoffs scandal.

title: Americans and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Oct. 7 with a movie review of ''Fallen Angels,'' at the New York Film Festival, included an erroneous reference from the festival press office about the dialect of Chinese spoken in the film. ''Fallen Angels,'' which opens at the Film Forum tomorrow, is in Cantonese with English subtitles, not in Mandarin. The error came to light with the arrival of a press release from the Film Forum.

title: On Day to Honor Dr. King, Some Pause as Others Shop
description: Yesterday was a time to reflect on the fight for racial justice, and many in New York and elsewhere did just that, recalling what was accomplished with marches along dusty Southern roads and sit-ins at the lunch counters of segregated five-and-dimes.

title: Yankees and Williams Set Arbitration Records
description: Earlier this off season, the Yankees said that management experts on salary arbitration had told them the best salary Bernie Williams could gain in arbitration was about $7.5 million. That was the average salary they offered him for a five-year contract, and yesterday that was the number they submitted for arbitration for 1998.

title: Making a Pitch For the Dahesh
description: JULIET HARTFORD, the 27-year-old daughter of the supermarket heir Huntington Hartford, is spearheading a letter-writing campaign in support of selling the mostly windowless structure he built at 2 Columbus Circle. She wants the city-owned building to go to the Dahesh Museum, which specializes in 19th century European art. It has been bruited about that one of the rival bidders for the city-owned building is DONALD J. TRUMP, who has a hotel across Columbus Circle.

title: Jewish Conservatives Attack Holocaust Film
description: A small group of politically conservative Jews, aligned with evangelical Christian groups on the issue of anti-Christian discrimination around the world, have lodged a complaint against a seemingly improbable target: a 14-minute film shown at the United States Holocaust Museum.

title: Gerry Adams, Meeting Blair, Objects to New Ulster Blueprint
description: Gerry Adams and a delegation from his Sinn Fein party voiced their strong objections today to a new British-Irish negotiating blueprint in a ''frank'' meeting with Prime Minister Tony Blair. But they said they remained committed to participation in the current peace talks in Belfast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, EDNA BRAND
description: MANN-Edna Brand. Wife of the late Harvey T. Mann, mother of the late Peggy Mann Houlton, died peacefully January 17, at 100 years of age. She is survived by a son, John H. Mann, of Cottonwood, Arizona, six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, JOAN WALKER
description: ABRAMS-Joan Walker. Beloved wife of George. Adored mother of Noel Gahagan Walker and Brooks Walker, and Cherished sister of Ninalee Allen Craig. Died in an automobile accident January 14. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to your favorite charity would be deeply appreciated by the family. Joan, an expert in Asian art, was known for her generosity, spirit and originality. She never touched anything or anyone without making it or them better. She will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, AARON D.
description: MILLER-Aaron D. Friday, Jan. 16, 1998, of East Orange, formerly of Jersey City, Glen Ridge and Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved husband of the late Edith Miller, devoted father of Lenore Urdang and Roslyn Romanow, loving grandfather of Scott, Meryl, Seth and Aimee, great grandfather of Jennifer, Melissa, Sara, Liza and Alexandra. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J. on Tuesday, January 20, 1998 at 9:00 A.M. Interment Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to City of Hope Hospital, Gift of Life Chapter, Duarte, CA.

title: Union's Game Tickets Hostage to Dispute
description: Having a problem getting Super Bowl tickets? The National Football League Players Association feels your pain.

title: In Quebec, Ice Storm Isn't Time for Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lifetime of Living and Dying in Song; With an Eye on the Unseen, Ned Rorem Sums Up in a New Work
description: By most accounts, Ned Rorem, who will turn 75 in October, should be deeply satisfied with what he has achieved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LEARY, REV. WILLIAM A.
description: O'LEARY-Rev. William A. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Benedict Joseph Labre Church, 94-40 188th St, Richmond Hill, January 17. Reposing LeahyMcDonald Funeral Home, 111-02 Atlantic Avenue, Richmond Hill, Tuesday, January 20, from 2 to 4:30 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass in St. Benedict Joseph Labre Church, Wednesday, Jan. 21, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Review/Fashion; Suits for Devils, Boys And Men of Mystery
description: The latest sequel in the saga of the Gucci man is a melodrama: he's in love with himself by day -- and by night, well, he's in love with himself then, too.

title: Crazy Eddie's Returning, Minus 2 Jailed Founders
description: Call it insane, but Crazy Eddie is coming back.

title: A Straussian Rarity About a Foolish Hero And a Faithless Wife
description: Richard Strauss gave ''Die Agyptische Helena'' so many reasons to fail that its best qualities are neutralized, held hostage by its worst instincts. Blessed with gloriously melodramatic stage music and a soaring soprano part as only Strauss could write one, there exists so much in the opera's favor, yet so much that almost guarantees its doom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNENFELD, HYMAN, M.D.
description: DONNENFELD-Hyman, M.D. on January 19, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Lyse. Loving father of Caroline (David) Diamond, Shari Donnenfeld and David Donnenfeld. Dear brother of Claire Martow and Ethel Strigler. Services 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HISCOX, ELIZABETH ANN WILSON, PH.D.
description: HISCOX-Elizabeth Ann Wilson, Ph.D., a clinical psychologist, died of heart failure on October 23 in her Manhattan home. She was 81. Dr. Hiscox, born in Ada, Okla., was a former director of counseling services at New York University and Baruch College and also had a private practice. Her family, friends, colleagues and clients mourned her loss. Her luminous spirit, wisdom and compassion were a bright beacon to those she guided. She lives on, cherished, in our hearts. In keeping with her wishes, no memorial service was held. Donations may be made to a battered-women's shelter or to Planned Parenthood. Jeanne Broadbent, Joseph De Cola Susan Rubinowitz

title: Japan and U.S. Draw Closer to Agreement to Liberalize Air Travel
description: United States and Japanese negotiators have agreed on the broad outlines of a deal that would greatly increase the number of flights between the two countries and liberalize travel across the Pacific, airline executives and officials in the Clinton Administration said yesterday.

title: U.N. Envoy, In Baghdad, Hints Teams Could Alter
description: The United Nations chief arms inspector for Iraq, Richard Butler, said here today that he might at some point be willing to take a second look at the composition of inspection teams, some of which the Iraqis have complained have too many Americans.

title: Manners From Other Times and Other Worlds
description: ''Slavonic Dances'' and ''A Schubertiad,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater, take a look at other times and cultures. Neither was helped by sharing the same program. But the pairing of the ballets, choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon and Peter Martins, respectively, did suggest the value of experience.

title: Review/Fashion; For Couture, New Ways to Seduce
description: In the cloistered world of couture, the newcomers, the British lads who stormed the gates of this hallowed French tradition in the last three years, are settling in. And the clients, whose low profile once caused much hand wringing in France and the fashion world, are newly prominent.

title: People
description: * Stephen McDonald was named client service director at Jeff St. Onge & Friends, New York, succeeding Eileen Schneidman, who will serve as a consultant to the agency. Mr. McDonald had been vice president and account service director at YAR Communications, New York, owned by Leap Group.

title: Franks Is Planning Race to Oppose Dodd for His Senate Seat
description: Gary A. Franks, a Connecticut Republican who lost his seat in the House of Representatives two years ago, is beginning a race for the Senate seat of Christopher J. Dodd, the three-term Democratic incumbent and former general chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: ASTEC REBUFFS EMERSON'S OFFER FOR REMAINING SHARES
description: An attempt by the Emerson Electric Company to acquire the shares of Astec (BSR) P.L.C. that it does not already own for $:170 million ($278 million) was dismissed yesterday by Astec as ''wholly inadequate.'' Emerson said it would continue its bid. The company, the St. Louis-based maker of electronic and electrical products, had offered 111 pence a share for the remaining 48.9 percent of Astec, which makes power supply and power conversion products. Emerson said that it had approached Astec on Friday with its offer and that Astec faced ''a number of significant commercial challenges'' because of changes in its markets and financial chaos in Asia.

title: Hoping to Continue Education as Union Head
description: IT is not, Randi Weingarten cautions, a foregone conclusion that she will be elected president of the United Federation of Teachers. ''Kayn aynhoreh,'' she says, or ''don't jinx it,'' as her grandmother used to say -- the grandmother, by the way, who brought Randi Weingarten's schoolteacher mother rugelach when she was on the picket line. But the flowers are on Ms. Weingarten's desk, the calls from well-wishers are coming in, so let's cut to the chase:

title: Personal Health; For Glaucoma Risk Group, Ignorance Is Blindness
description: IGNORANCE and misinformation about glaucoma and its treatment is threatening the eyesight of millions of Americans. A newly released national survey conducted for the Glaucoma Research Foundation has revealed widespread ignorance of the risk factors for this leading cause of blindness.

title: Nebraska Names Field for Osborne
description: The University of Nebraska has named Memorial Stadium's playing field Tom Osborne Field in honor of their retiring football coach, the school said.

title: Mexico City Journal; News (and State) Anchor Weighs His
description: After the Virgin of Guadalupe, Mexico's revered patroness, probably the most familiar image in this country is the impassive, bespectacled face of the television newscaster Jacobo Zabludovsky.

title: Now, Liquid Gold Comes in Bottles; Marketers Find a No-Frills Rival to Soda
description: A bottle of water instead of a Coke? It sounds downright un-American.

title: A Detector's Rare Metal Faces Seizure in Russia
description: HARD on the heels of a series of attempted robberies, one of the world's major neutrino detectors now faces seizure by the Russian Government of some of its precious gallium.

title: Some Roads Will Have 65 M.P.H. Speed Limit
description: The speed limit on sections of New Jersey's highways will be raised this spring to 65 miles per hour from 55 m.p.h. under a bill signed into law yesterday by Governor Whitman.

title: PC Financial Software: Bank on It?
description: IF you are willing to let a computer program try to help set your financial house in order, the arrival of your January bank statement heralds the best time to do it. For reasons involving the Internal Revenue Service, getting your records organized for the entire year may help reduce the pain on April 15, 1999.

title: VENTURE PROMISES FAR FASTER SPEEDS FOR INTERNET DATA
description: Three titans of the personal computer industry have joined with most of the nation's largest local telephone companies to enable consumers to receive Internet data over regular telephone lines at speeds much higher than are currently possible, according to executives involved with the alliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OZKAYA, ALI NIHAT
description: OZKAYA-Ali Nihat. Died Sunday. Husband of Dawn Leger. Donations to Gottlieb Melanoma Research Fund of NYU, 530 First Ave., Suite 9R, New York, NY. 10016. For information contact Funk Funeral Home, 860-583-4107

title: Unabom Team Straddles A Bluff and a Hard Place
description: Smack in the middle of the tangle Theodore J. Kaczynski has made of his trial are two defense lawyers known for an understated advocacy that is usually far from the legal carnival the Unabom trial has become.

title: Netanyahu, in U.S., Woos Conservatives
description: The Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, arrived here today and went directly to a Christian-Jewish rally of conservative supporters, who include some of President Clinton's harshest political opponents.

title: OMNIAMERICA ACQUIRES 30 MEDIA TOWERS IN FLORIDA
description: OmniAmerica Inc., a venture involving Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., acquired 30 wireless-communications towers in Florida yesterday for $20 million. The company, based in West Palm Beach, bought 3 towers in Palm Beach County and 2 towers in Fort Pierce from the Ardman Broadcasting Corporation and 25 towers serving the Tampa-St. Petersburg area and western Florida from HSW Associates Inc. OmniAmerica was formed in September by Hicks, Muse, the Dallas-based leveraged buyout firm; Carl Hirsch, OmniAmerica's chief executive, and Anthony Ocepek, its senior vice president and chief operating officer. OmniAmerica buys media towers for the radio and television broadcasting and wireless communications markets.

title: With No Time to Waste, Rangers Get Back to Work
description: On Sunday, the Rangers could allow themselves to fantasize for a day about how things might have been, watching Wayne Gretzky slip a beautiful pass to Mark Messier for a game-winning goal in the All-Star Game. But when the team reported to practice today, reality quickly set in.

title: H.I.V. Reporting May Deter Some From Testing; Try Coded Systems
description: To the Editor:

title: Azure Waters
description: Q. Gazing upon the clear, aqua-colored water ringing Bermuda, I wondered why southern waters look that way while shallow waters off New Jersey, for example, are murky. What accounts for the difference?

title: For Perlman, A Matter of Taste
description: The talk at a cocktail party before the Israel Philharmonic's concert at Carnegie Hall last night was whether the violinist ITZHAK PERLMAN had lost his sense of taste, a potential liability for a wine connoisseur like Mr. Perlman. ''It was evidently the antibiotics'' that Mr. Perlman had taken to fight a recent case of flu, said HERMAN S. SANDLER, an investment banker who was the host of the party.

title: New Baldness Drug Is Older Product at a Premium Price
description: Kenneth Scovotti, a balding 55-year-old manager of a New York City gasoline station, has spent $15,000 for five hair transplants the last four years. So he was elated to learn about Propecia, Merck & Company's new hair-growth drug.

title: Doctors Could Help Break the Drug Oligopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: Maguire, a Voice (Not a Face) for Hire
description: After he calls the Super Bowl on Sunday, NBC's Paul Maguire will be out of work. His network refused to pay megabucks to keep American Football Conference rights (but CBS did), so pro football is off NBC for at least the next five seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRIE, WILLIAM F.
description: BARRIE-William F. Age 84. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn. A rare and unique Christian gentleman. Reposing Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 Street, New York City, on Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service Thursday at noon.

title: Panel Backs Mexico Judge Who Freed 5 In Death Case
description: An appeals tribunal today admonished a judge who described a murder defendant as a ''modern Robin Hood'' to express herself more carefully, but upheld her decision to free the man and four fellow suspects, who prosecutors say admitted killing an American executive.

title: The Insane Millionaire And His Devoted Wife
description: RIVEN ROCK

title: First Stop a Tough One For Panel on Gambling
description: The Atlantic City Rescue Mission, a huge, modern building that sits amid run-down houses just a few blocks from the Boardwalk, offers a look at the good and bad of the gambling boom that has swept the country over the past 20 years.

title: Arts in America; How Houston's Adopted Daughter Said Thank You
description: Dominique de Menil died here on the last day of the year, at the age of 89, and in the days since there has been a steady outpouring of tributes and fond remembrances for this remarkable art collector and philanthropist, a frail woman with the strongest of wills whom Peter Marzio, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts here, describes simply as ''the single greatest cultural force in the history of Houston.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMAN, HELEN M.
description: HARMAN-Helen M. On January 18, 1998. Former President of Joseph S. Reilly Travel Bureau and Past President of the Leitrim Society of New York. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Donald D. Harman. Loving mother of Donald J. Harman and the late Dr. Maureen Pacifico and Helen Ryan. Adored grandmother of Maureen McCann, Dr. Kevin Ryan, Christine Corcoran, John C. Ryan, Helen Sommer, Dr. Albert Pacifico and Christine Harman Gladbach. Dear sister of Delia and Rosaline. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday 2 to 5 P.M., 7 to 9 P.M. Funeral Mass at Holy Name Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 96th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LOUIS
description: SMITH - Louis. Of Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved, caring and devoted husband to Minerva. Father to Richard and Jerome. Father-in-law to Julia and Natalie. Grandfather to Jessica, Matthew, Alexander and Douglas. Passed gently into the night on January 17, 1998, with his family at his side. We will miss him terribly and remember him always.

title: Tribute to King Was All Inclusive
description: BOB GRANT, the caustic talk-radio personality who once used a crude sexual epithet in referring to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., walked into the ballroom last night and shook hands with ROY INNIS, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality. ''We try to love our enemies,'' Mr. Innis said before the speeches at the group's Martin Luther King Day dinner at the Sheraton New York Hotel, at Seventh Avenue and 53d Street, ''and, at least for one day, bury our differences.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEVUSH, DAVID
description: SEVUSH-David. With his passing on January 19th, 1998, the world became a poorer place. Born on June 29, 1922, he fought for his country in World War II and returned from the Pacific to marry and raise a family. Though he had to leave school during the Depression, he was a lover of learning and returned to school in his later years, receiving a college degree from Kingsborough Community College at the age of 65. Throughout his life, he was an active and integral part of his beloved Brooklyn through his involvement with the Boy Scouts, Youth Baseball, Coney Island Community Council, and the Sea Gate Community Council and Board of Directors. He was a passionate and tireless advocate for the truth. He is survived by his bride of fifty years, Norma; their three sons, Steve, Herb and Ralph; their daughters-in-law Elaine, Aline and Tobe; their four grandchildren Jeremy, Jennifer, David and Jamie; his two younger brothers, Leo and Jack, and relatives, friends, neighbors and coworkers who mourn their loss. Services will be held at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Flatbush Avenue and Avenue V in Brooklyn on Wednesday, January 21 at 11:30 AM. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to the charity of their choice.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My great-aunt, who is 87 and has seen it all in this country, and I mean everything, says that after the Pope comes, she can die in peace, because then she really would have seen it all. The Pope in Cuba, imagine that.''

title: No Way to Silence Whistle-Blowers
description: A unanimous Supreme Court last week defeated a corporate strategy to buy the silence of whistle-blowers in product liability suits. The thoughtful decision by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg appropriately protects consumers and the ability of trial courts to secure testimony needed to get at the truth without weakening the obligation of states to honor one another's legal judgments, as the Constitution's ''full faith and credit'' clause commands.

title: Faith in a Moral Motive for Work; The Man Who Redesigned Welfare in Wisconsin Is Coming
description: Some teen-agers doodle away the hours drawing race cars or basketball plays. As a high school student in the late 1960's, Jason A. Turner used to draft plans for factories that would put welfare recipients to work.

title: Sober Jury Learns of the Lurid Life at Club Owner's Drug Trial
description: The 12 jurors in the drug racketeering trial of Peter Gatien do not seem like the sort who would be attracted to the downtown Manhattan nightclub scene, the kind who would set foot in such throbbing, clamorous outposts, packed with young people and pounded by music, as the Tunnel and Limelight.

title: ITEQ AND MATRIX SERVICE CALL OFF AGREEMENT TO COMBINE
description: Iteq Inc. and the Matrix Service Company have agreed to end their merger agreement, citing ''unanticipated difficulties'' in integrating their ''divergent corporate cultures.'' Iteq agreed to buy Matrix in December for cash and stock. The deal called for Iteq to pay either $10 cash or 0.83 common share for each Matrix share, with cash accounting for 30 percent to 50 percent of the purchase price. Matrix, of Tulsa, Okla., supplies storage tanks, tank products and specialized maintenance services. Iteq, of Houston, provides equipment, systems and services to process, treat, store and move gases and liquids.

title: In Quebec, Ice Storm Isn't Time for Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Race for President Heats Up
description: There were heightened indications yesterday that Sepp Blatter of Switzerland, the general secretary of FIFA, the sport's world governing body, intends to be a candidate to succeed the 82-year-old Joao Havelange of Brazil as president.

title: Ivanisevic And Muster Are Ousted In Openers
description: Martina Hingis, who made history last year when she became the youngest Australian Open champion at the age of 16, pranced through her opening match in the cloud-shrouded stadium today in straight sets.

title: Expansion Considered For Newark Airport
description: In an effort to accommodate growth at Newark International Airport -- and to reduce overcrowding and delays -- Continental Airlines and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are considering spending as much as $1 billion over the next few years to create additional gates and parking and expand the airport's crowded network of runways and taxiways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERGES, FLORENCE JUNE
description: GERGES-Florence June. Devoted wife of Abraham G. Gerges, Justice of New York State Supreme Court. Beloved mother of Nina Kurtz and mother-in-law of Donnie Scott Kurtz. Loving grandmother of Sarah and Jamie. Cherished sister of Murray Benenson. Former Assistant to the New York State Deputy Housing Commissioner. She spent her life volunteering for good causes. The Mayor's Volunteer Action Committee, school volunteer, Girl Scouts. She was a beautiful woman inside and out. She was happiest helping others and will long be remembered. She was our best friend. Funeral will take place Tuesday, January 20, 1 P.M., at Congregation Mt. Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn. All donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Butler Thinking Dynasty
description: Green Bay safety LeRoy Butler is not afraid to put big goals in front of the Packers. Butler, who said earlier this season that the Packers should have a 19-0 record this season, said tonight that the team could be a dynasty.

title: Asian Financial Crisis Begins to Affect European Economy
description: Asia's financial crisis is starting to affect Europe, slowing down exports of everything from heavy machinery to telephones and worsening what were already gloomy prospects for reducing joblessness this year.

title: Pataki Urges $3 Billion Plan For Campuses, Doubling Total
description: As he prepared to release his election-year budget on Tuesday, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed doubling state spending on campus improvements in the state and city university systems, with a $3 billion, five-year capital program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, SAMUEL
description: GOLDBERGER-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Esther and beloved father and father-in-law of Steve and Wanda Gilbert, Ronald and Amy Goldberger, Howard and Lynn Gross and beloved grandfather of Wayne, Adam, Joshua and Jordan Gilbert, Jacob and Edward Goldberger and Jennifer and Jeffrey Gross.

title: Ford Urges G.O.P. to Drop Abortion Issue and Shift Center
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford condemned today what he viewed as Republicans' preoccupation with abortion and warned that an ''ultra-conservative'' faction could threaten the party's drive to regain the White House in 2000.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Dr. Geoffrey S. Watson, who helped develop a classic statistical method, omitted one of his survivors. They include a son, Michael, of Yokohama, Japan.

title: The Neediest Cases; Parents Buckle Under Crushing Grief
description: The voice coming over the dispatcher's radio was confused and panicky. ''I've just been punched in the back,'' Konstantine Kondratenko gasped. Then there was silence.

title: Hong Kong Developer May Sell Some Hotels
description: The Lai Sun Development Company, the Hong Kong owner of the Four Seasons Hotel in New York and the Regent Beverly Wilshire in Los Angeles, plans to sell some of its hotels after a surge in its borrowing costs cast doubt over its ability to repay its debt. The property developer plans to sell hotels outside Hong Kong and would not rule out selling trophies like the Four Seasons, it said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRAFTON, SAMUEL
description: GRAFTON-Samuel. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Samuel Grafton will be held at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 81st and Madison, on Friday, January 23, at 2:30 P.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Authors League Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUTER, EVA
description: REUTER-Eva. The family of Eva Reuter, devoted wife of Max Reuter, loving mother of Fay and Dov Stern and Diane and Harry Ramras. Adored grandmother of Adina, Uri, Daniel, and Ahuva Stern. Shimmy, Jaclyn and Benjamin Ramras. Shiva will be observed at 570 Fort Washington Avenue, NY til Friday afternoon, January 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICHTER, PAULINA (NEE RUVINSKA)
description: DICHTER-Paulina (nee Ruvinska). On January 17, 1998. Immeasurably loved and admired by her family and friends who cherished her countless gifts of brightness and life. In lieu of flowers, donations to your favorite cause. Services at 9:45 A.M., on Tuesday at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Joblessness: A Perilous Curve On China's Capitalist Road
description: The chant of the bean-curd peddler swirled through the alleys of the derelict Daowai district of Harbin, but on this 5-below-zero morning there were no takers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, MARCELLA BUTLER
description: O'MALLEY-Marcella Butler. On January 18, after a courageous struggle with multiple myeloma. Beloved wife of James for 55 years, daughter of the late Thomas and Margaret, mother of Malcolm and Anne, sister of the late Reynolds Butler and Catherine Butler. Born in Montreal in 1915. Her strength, graciousness, beauty and determination were admired by many. She cared deeply about her community and creative efforts, to which she contributed her paintings. Her inimitable presence and loving spirit will be missed enormously. Friends will be received at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81 Street, on January 20, from 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Ave. at 66th St., on January 21, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MARION L.
description: MILLER-Marion L. On January 19, 1998. Beloved wife of James F. title: Whitman to Offer Plan Freezing Tuition Rates
description: Leaders of the state's 19 community colleges have agreed to freeze fall tuition rates at 1997 levels under a plan Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to outline today, state and college officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Alliance Aims to Provide Fast Net Access by Phone

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOSEPH
description: MURPHY-Joseph. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of Joseph Murphy, former Chancellor of the City University of New York. A respected educator and humanitarian, Professor Murphy was an earnest supporter of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and its mission of expanding and disseminating medical knowledge, both during his tenure as Chancellor and in the years that followed. We extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, children, grandchildren, mother and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, M.D., President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice-President Wendy Z. Goldstein, Director

title: Patterns
description: Back to the Tents

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Even if Used as Weapon, TV Is True to Its Nature
description: Now and then television news turns out to be inadvertently revealing about the nature of television itself. Consider the ''60 Minutes'' report last month that began as a look at human rights abuses by and corruption in the Palestine National Authority, forerunner presumptive to a Palestinian state, and wound up exposing differences among officials over television freedom.

title: Baroque And Folk In Festive Mixture
description: The New York City Ballet demonstrated how ballet can absorb many influences in weekend performances at the New York State Theater that paid tribute to barn dances, Renaissance ballrooms and Elizabethan tragedy. On Sunday afternoon, when Hugo Fiorato conducted, the program included the previously reviewed ''Schubertiad'' and ''Brandenburg,'' as well as George Balanchine's ''Square Dance'' with a new pair of leading dancers.

title: Review/Fashion; Armani Stands Fast As Others Take Aim
description: There is nothing quite so menacing as a man with nothing left to prove. One is never sure which way he may turn. On the one hand, he may choose to stride purposefully into the unknown and try to open some new territory. Then again, his position as conqueror may keep him on the path to victory. Giorgio Armani's studied adherence to the look he used to revolutionize men's wear almost two decades ago reveals a designer who has clearly decided that being on top is preferable to being in the vanguard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, JACK G.
description: BROWN-Jack G. Of Bronxville, NY. On January 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary Ann Schmidlein Brown. Son of the late Ross E. and Augusta Brown. Brother of the late Ross M. Brown. Brother-inlaw of Marilyn. Uncle of Kathryn, Jenny, Ross Mitchell and wife Lisa. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Paul the Apostle Church, Yonkers on Wednesday, January 21 at 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ALTON, CLARENCE J., M.D.
description: D'ALTON-Clarence J., M.D. On January 15, 1998, of Southbury, CT, formerly of Warren, CT., and New York, New York. Born Petersburg, VA, April 25, 1918. Graduated from Canterbury School June 8, 1935, B.A. Yale 1939, MD Columbia 1943, Member Alpha Omega Alpha, recipient of Harold Lee Meierhof Award for proficiency in Pathology, Captain M.C.A.U.S. 236 GH France (1944-46), W.W.II. On the staff of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, Faculty of College of Physicians & Surgeons, Medical Director U.S. ITT Corp. (a subsidiary of ITT) and practiced internal medicine in New York City until his retirement in 1983. Survived by five daughters, Julia F. Houston, Katherine E. Desmond, Martina Shroyer, Susanna Alde, Anne M. Morse, five grandchildren and two brothers, Robert F. and William B. Private burial in spring in St. Francis Cemetery, New Milford, CT. Donations may be made in the name of Dr. D'Alton to Presbyterian Hospital, Development Office, 180 Fort Washington Avenue, Harkness Pavillion 7th Floor, New York, New York 10032.

title: Metro Business; Insurer to Cut Auto Rates
description: The Hartford Financial Services Group has said it will cut premiums on its automobile insurance policies in New York and Connecticut because claims and other costs have declined.

title: New Picture Emerges On How Dinosaurs Of Gobi Were Killed
description: IN trying to figure out why the Gobi Desert of Mongolia holds so many well-preserved dinosaur fossils, paleontologists usually relied on their own experience. They had often weathered fierce Gobi winds suddenly whipping up blinding storms of sand and dust. So it stood to reason that such storms in the past overwhelmed dinosaurs, burying their bodies before they could be scavenged or destroyed by the elements.

title: High-Stakes Face-Off Begins for Columbia/HCA
description: The decision by the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation to try to settle possible Federal charges signals what could be the start of a high-stakes face-off in the sprawling fraud investigation of the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBRIN, TEDDY (THEODORE)
description: KOBRIN-Teddy (Theodore), 79. On January 18, after a valiant battle with heart disease. Beloved husband of Sally (Sarah), brother of David and the late Frank and Bernard, loving father of Trudi (Frank Gunsberg) and Gloria (Ron Froug), dearest grandfather of Alan, Meredith (Jay Bluestine), Shari, Rachel and our dearly missed Risa, loving uncle and dear friend to many. World War II veteran. You will be truly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARASZTI, ALEXANDER S., DR.
description: HARASZTI-Alexander S., Dr. His family and numerous friends will greatly miss Dr. Alexander S. Haraszti, who died on Jan. 16, 1998 in Atlanta. Dr. Haraszti was an ordained Baptist minister, a linguist who spoke eight languages, and a physician who practiced first as an obstetrician-gynecologist in his native Hungary, and then in Atlanta for over three decades as a general surgeon. Dr. Haraszti was born in 1920 in Soltvadkert, Hungary. He received a doctoral degree in linguistics from the Royal Hungarian Pazmany Pater Univ in Budapest in 1944, and was ordained as a Baptist Minister in Hungary in 1944 and for many years was a Professor at the Baptist Theological Seminary in Budapest, Hungary. Over the next twelve years he preached the Gospel extensively as a minister in Hungary, in the process supporting both his own medical studies as well as the medical studes of his wife, Rosalie B. Haraszti. He received his medical degree from Semmelweis University School of Medicine in Budapest in 1951. During the Hungarian uprising against Soviet domination in 1956, Dr. Alexander Haraszti left Hungary with his wife and five children, intent on pursuing his goal of serving God as a medical missionary. After a short stay in Vienna, Dr. Haraszti brought his family to the United States where he furthered his medical training, interning in St. Louis, then serving as a surgical resident at Emory University, the VA Hospital and Grady Memorial Hospital from 1960-1964. In the years that followed Dr. Haraszti realized his dream of becoming a medical missionary, practicing in Ghana, Tanzania and the Gaza Strip. In addition to this mission work, Dr. Haraszti practiced medicine in College Park, Jonesboro and Henry County. In addition to his devotion to his family and patients, Dr. Haraszti committed over two decades of his life to fledgling evangelical movements in Hungary, Romania, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Poland and the Soviet Union. Dr. Haraszti served for many years as the personal emissary of Billy Graham in Eastern Europe, ensuring that Dr. Graham would accomplish his historically important goal of bringing the Gospel behind the Iron Curtain. Using his vast energy, intellect, considerably diplomatic finesse and historical and religious insight to great advantage, Dr. Haraszti was instrumental in securing an invitation for Dr. Graham to preach first in Hungary in 1977, where he also served as Dr. Graham's translator. Using this first evangelical opening to great effect, Dr. Haraszti secured invitations for Billy Graham to preach in Poland in 1978, East Germany and Czechoslovakia in 1982, and then the Soviet Union in 1982, 1984 and 1988. During that same time, Dr. Haraszti helped to secure the return of the Crown of St. Stephen to Hungary from the United States Government, which had obtained it during World War II. The crowning achievement of these efforts in Eastern Europe was the Crusade in Hungary in 1989, during which over 110,000 people gathered at the People's Stadium in Budapest with Billy Graham preaching and Dr. Haraszti translating. Dr. Haraszti was of the firm belief that the spread of the Gospel in Eastern Europe would help to create fissures in the control the communist regimes held in these nations. Determined to spread his faith in an ecumenical fashion, Dr. Haraszti labored to assist Christians of all faiths to come together. He was instrumental in facilitating and arranging the historical first meeting between Pope John Paul II and Billy Graham on January 12, 1981. Since retiring from his medical practice in 1994, Dr. Haraszti worked extensively on his memoirs, chronicling his contributitions to the Hungarian Baptist movement, and the important work that he performed with Billy Graham. He also continued to promote an ecumenical spirit here in the United States as well as his native Hungary. Dr. Haraszti remained active until his death in the American Hungarian Baptist Union, for which he served as president for many years, and for which he had been made honorary president at the time of his death. Dr. Haraszti gained the most delight from the frequent family gatherings he organized at his home in Atlanta, and from the larger family reunions he spearheaded in his birthplace of Soltvadkert. Dr. Haraszti is survived by his wife Dr. Rosalie Haraszti, his sons Dr. Joseph Haraszti and Dr. Leland Haraszti, his daughters Dr. Rose Badaruddin and her husband Syed Badaruddin, Stella Beerman and her husband, noted contemporary American composer Professor Burton Beerman, his daughter Dr. Pamela Guoth and her husband Dr. Janos Guoth, his granddaughter Dr. Anisa Threlkeld and her husband Robert Threlkeld, his granddaughter Samantha Haraszti, his grandsons Chris Haraszti, Brent Beerman and his wife Sandy, Johnny Guoth, Kareem Badaruddin and his wife Denise, Shandor Badaruddin and his wife Michelle, and his great grandchildren Justin and Jessica Beerman, Bryce Saber Badaruddin and Anisa Rose Threlkeld, as well as four surviving sisters of Dr. Haraszti and numerous nephews and nieces. Dr. Haraszti will be buried alongside his son Benedict Haraszti, who died in 1981. Funeral services will be held at 1 P.M. on January 21, 1998 at Pope Dickson & Son Funeral Home, 1210 Morrow Road, Morrow, Georgia. He will be buried at Sherwood Memorial Park. Pope Dickson & Son Morrow Chapel 770-961-2700.

title: Doctor's Body Is Found Under George Washington Bridge
description: A badly decomposed body was found on rocks under the Manhattan side of the George Washington Bridge yesterday, and the police tentatively identified it as that of Geoffrey D. Chazen, a prominent Manhattan doctor who disappeared two weeks ago and left a note telling of despondency and financial problems.

title: Pentagon May Know Identity Of One in Tomb of Unknowns
description: Pentagon officials said tonight that they were dealing with the possibility that an American killed in Vietnam and interred at the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery might not be unknown at all.

title: Pentagon Chief Gets Tour Of Key China Command Site
description: Inside a drab, innocuous cluster of buildings, the very existence of which the Communist Government here refused to acknowledge only a short time ago, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen on Monday took what American officials hope will be a significant step toward better relations with China.

title: More Rounds Fired In Feud at Andersen
description: The civil war raging within Andersen Worldwide shows no signs of abating. In response to claims made by Andersen Consulting partners, the accounting partners at Arthur Andersen are now raising questions about exactly how the disagreement should be handled and continue to insist that they deserve ample compensation if the consultants leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARMODY, SISTER MARIE LOUISE, RSCJ
description: CARMODY-Sister Marie Louise, RSCJ, age 84, died at the Kenwood Convent of the Sacret Heart on January 18. Born and raised in Watertown, she attended Noroton, Convent of the Sacred Heart in Darien, CT. After graduating from Wheaton College and working several years, she entered the Society on Oct 19, 1944 at Kenwood. Her final profession was in 1953 at the Motherhouse, Rome, Italy. Thereafter, she began a life of intense activity as a teacher, administrator and college guidance counselor. During those years many young women came to know her educational and personal gifts. In 1980 she moved to Kenwood, where she began and carried out with great skill the work of development officer for the Kenwood infirmary and retirement home. Retiring from this work in 1994, she joined the retirement community she had served so well. Her religious sisters, her family and her many friends will miss her greatly. Sr. Carmody is survived by several nephews and nieces. A Vigil Service will be held on Tuesday, January 20, 1998 at 4:15 P.M. in the Convent Chapel. The Mass of Christian Burial will be Wednesday at 9:00 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUBBIONDO, CHARLES
description: SUBBIONDO-Charles. On January 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Ann, loving father of Charles and Ralph, cherished brother of Andrew, Joseph and Mary, adored grandfather of Susan, Douglas, Christopher and Charlie III, devoted great grandfather of Alexa and Charlie IV. Reposing at Ridge Chapels, 405 91 St, between 4th and 5th Aves, Brooklyn. Viewing Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Wednesday service at chapel 10AM-noon. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Leukemia Society, 600 3rd Ave., New York, New York 10003.

title: College Knew of Warnings Before Rapes, Professor Says
description: A professor who helped organize a two-week tour of Guatemala that ended after five students were raped last Friday during an armed robbery said today that college officials were aware of State Department warnings that rapes and robberies had occurred in the same area.

title: For Bookstore Browsers, Blurbs Can Be a Help
description: To the Editor:

Dear brother of Bernard Kamens. Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Nathan, Abigail, Benjamin and Melissa. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ on Wednesday, January 21, 1998 at 10:00 AM. Interment in the Beth David Memorial Park, Kenilworth, New Jersey.

title: 3 Years After War, Ecuador and Peru Agree to Peace Talks
description: Ecuador and Peru, which went to war three years ago over a border dispute, signed an agreement here today creating a timetable that they said would lead to a peace treaty.

title: Three Senate Reputations
description: The new Congressional session does not begin for another week. But it is not too early to expose the plotting by the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, to keep strong campaign finance legislation from emerging. Nor is it too soon to put the spotlight on three moderate New England Republicans -- Olympia Snowe of Maine, Jim Jeffords of Vermont and John Chafee of Rhode Island. Each enjoys a reputation as a good-government supporter. But they must stand up to Mr. Lott and the anti-reform majority in their own caucus if they want to keep those reputations.

title: Chopper Alert
description: The first security breach of Super Bowl week occurred today at the Denver Broncos' practice. No one's safety was threatened, but as far as the Broncos' coaches were concerned this was as nearly as serious: a television station's helicopter flew over practice at the Chargers' training facility for 20 minutes. The National Football League and the Broncos have hired extra security personnel because the area is so accessible.

title: Cell Rejuvenation May Yield Rush of Medical Advances
description: THE report last week that human cells can be rejuvenated, at least in test tubes, suggests new remedies for many major diseases of aging.

title: By Design; Thinking Gray
description: Women used to build their spring wardrobes around navy blue. This year the fashionable set is thinking gray, which is chic when worn monotone or mixed with white.

title: Real-Life Programmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Korea Pays for Its Life Raft
description: South Korea has been saved from default by the International Monetary Fund's $57 billion bailout and by international lenders who agreed to roll over its short-term debt for 90 days. With this breathing room, Korea, the United States and international banks are negotiating how to set Korea off on the long road to financial recovery.

title: Nexstar Makes Deal On DNA Technology
description: Nexstar Pharmaceuticals Inc. has agreed to buy DNA synthesis patent rights from Perseptive Biosystems Inc., a move that will allow Perseptive's $360 million merger with the Perkin-Elmer Corporation to take place.

title: Indonesia Begins the Rescue and Consolidation of Banks
description: Moving quickly to fire up the country's stalled economic engine, Indonesia announced the first of an expected series of bank mergers today, aimed at making the financial system more efficient and accountable.

title: A Tough Race Is Expected for 5 Seeking Schumer's Seat
description: As the campaign for United States Senate is starting with a torrent, the race to succeed one of the candidates in that race, Representative Charles E. Schumer, is moving at an equally rapid pace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOW, LILLIAN
description: SOKOLOW-Lillian on January 19, 1998. Beloved wife of William. Dear mother of Jim, Marjorie and Alan. Grandmother of Johnny, Jennifer, Joe, Josh, Liz, Morgan, Schuyler, Caldor and Wendy. Great grandmother of 9. Sister of Dorothy Heyman. Services Wednesday, 2PM at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, L.I.

title: CAMBIOR TO BUY OUT BARRICK IN JOINT GOLD VENTURE
description: The Canadian mining concern Cambior Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the other half of the Doyon gold mine in northwestern Quebec for $95 million (United States) from its joint venture partner, the Barrick Gold Corporation. Under the agreement, Cambior, based in Montreal, would also transfer to Barrick its 50 percent interest in the El Coco (Dormenan) exploration property, in northwestern Quebec, and Barrick, of Toronto, would transfer to Cambior certain interests in exploration properties adjacent to the Doyon Mine.

title: Red Storm Rattles Ranked Huskies
description: If tournament-ready teams are supposed to be tested by fire at some point during the regular season, then this could be the beginning of something special for St. John's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADOM, PEARL W.
description: RADOM-Pearl W. Suddenly, in her 87th year on January 18. Beloved wife of the late Ial. Devoted mother of the late Carl. Loving mother of Gayle and Simon. Cherished grandmother of Alan, Todd, Sue and great-grandmother of Cara . She will be missed by all whose lives she touched. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Studies of Schizophrenia Vindicate Psychotherapy
description: WHEN a man with schizophrenia requested psychotherapy recently in addition to his antipsychotic medication, he was told that his health maintenance organization would allow only six sessions. ''The insurer said there was no evidence that psychotherapy helps people with schizophrenia,'' said Gerard Hogarty, a researcher and professor of psychiatry at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine.

title: 2 South Korean Companies Respond to Economic Crisis
description: Two of South Korea's four largest chaebols, the octopus-like conglomerates that dominate this country's corporate landscape, provided details today of sweeping revamping plans that raised almost as many questions as they answered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, JEROME
description: RUBENSTEIN-Jerome. On January 18, 1998. Devoted husband of Evelyn, beloved father of Robert and Fran Alyssa, fond brother of Yvette and loving uncle. Retired from the NYPD and Board of Education. Funeral service 10 A.M., Tuesday from the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment Montefiore Cemetery.

title: 17 Injured as Wall Collapses When Demolition Goes Awry
description: The razing of a dilapidated theater in Jersey City went awry yesterday when a large piece of a brick wall crashed through the roof of an adjacent structure, opening a hole through to the basement of the two-story building and injuring at least 17 people, 2 of them critically, officials said.

title: Let's Hear It for Romance And Punk Solidarity
description: To many who never explored its ethic, punk rock meant destruction. But for those who actually found their voices through this furious music, punk had a different message. It tore things apart so that its faithful, outsiders all, could make them anew.

title: CHIEF RESIGNS AND LOSS PREDICTED AT APRIA HEALTHCARE
description: Apria Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Jeremy M. Jones, had resigned in a sweeping reorganization of the company's top management, sales organization and board structure. The company, a home health care concern based in Costa Mesa, Calif., also said it expected its fourth-quarter results to be below analysts' expectations and predicted a net loss of $2.20 to $2.40 a share for the year, before a possible write-down for good will. Apria also said it expected 1998 earnings to be ''significantly below'' most analysts' estimates. Its president and chief operating officer, Lawrence M. Higby, 52, will add the job of chief executive. George L. Argyros, 60, a real estate developer, will take over as chairman.

title: Messier and Larionov Long for Olympic Call
description: Mark Messier of the Vancouver Canucks is not the only 37-year-old center pining for a second chance to join his Olympic team. Another is Igor Larionov of the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, SALLY
description: KOHN-Sally. On January 17, 1998, in Washington, D.C. With singular success, this brilliant and charming woman devoted her life to making other peoples' lives healthier and happier. The glow of her warmth and laughter lit her world and ours. Former Director of the New York AIDS consortium and a leading figure, in her quiet way, in the fight against AIDS and for child health, since 1990 Ms. Kohn was an assistant clinical professor at Albert Einstein College and was the recipient in 1990 of the U.S. Public Health Service Award for Outstanding Contributions to the HRSA AIDS Service Demonstration Program. At the time of her death, Ms. Kohn was the Deputy Director of Opening Doors and a consultant to the New York Community Trust and the Public Health Service. Ms. Kohn is survived by her husband, Sam Eskenazi, a daughter, Becca Zerkin of Washington, DC, parents, Ruth Kohn and Max Kohn, of Elkins Park, PA. She has two sisters, Susan Gleeksman of Cranbury, NJ and Jean Gray of Hilltown, PA, a brother Andrew Kohn of Cleveland, OH, and eight nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Jewish Fund for Justice, 260 Fifth Avenue, Suite 701, New York, N.Y. 10001. Family will be observing Shiva today through Thursday evening and Sunday at the residence.

title: McCaffrey Is Rising Above The Doubts
description: They call Denver Broncos wide receiver Ed McCaffrey a role player. And McCaffrey knows the role.

title: Metro Business; Duane Reade Plans Public Stock Offer
description: Duane Reade, the New York drugstore chain, plans to sell 6.7 million shares in an initial public offering, hoping to raise about $92.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOSE, HELEN WILLENS
description: MOOSE-Helen Willens. On January 17, 1998. Beloved mother of the late Charles Seth Moose. Devoted sister of Iva Schlesinger. Dear aunt of Jonathan Schlesinger and Jennifer Curling. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBER, ALAN E.
description: COBER-Alan E. Loving husband of Ellen. Loving father of Leslie and Peter. Loving grandfather of Alexander and Paige. Funeral Tuesday, 12PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mt Vernon, N.Y. 914-664-6800.

title: Intel Offers Software to Cut Web Delays
description: The Intel Corporation introduced software yesterday to help Internet service providers eliminate some of the delays that plague users of the worldwide computer network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, PHILIP ELI
description: POLLACK-Philip Eli. Beloved and devoted husband of Edith Hirsh. Beloved father of Alan (Iris) and Gary (Robin). Devoted grandfather of Hal, Jonah, Ben and Lea. Brother of Florence Hirshfield.

title: British Investment Bank Bids for Bluebird Toys
description: Guinness Peat Group P.L.C., a British investment company, has offered to acquire Bluebird Toys P.L.C. for $:42 million ($68.7 million). Guinness Peat's offer of 101 pence a share in cash is a 19 percent premium over Bluebird's closing price on Friday of 85 pence. But Bluebird said the offer ''significantly undervalues'' the company, and the shares rose 27.5 pence yesterday, to 112.5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, MILTON
description: ALEXANDER-Milton. On January 19. Loving husband of Edith. Devoted father of Robert (Merly), Marcie and Charlotte. Beloved grandfather of Dina, Annie, Max and Sam. Funeral services will be private. The family will be sitting Shiva at their residence. For information, call Garlick/Hellman Funeral Home (914-237-3500).

title: Steelers Keep an Executive
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers did not make it to the Super Bowl, but they were celebrating yesterday in the front office. Tom Donahoe, the man credited with keeping the team competitive despite heavy losses to free agency, decided to stay with the team. Donahoe, the team's director of football operations, had been courted by the Seattle Seahawks, who were said to be floating a $1 million offer. TOM JOLLY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWOH, EMILY T.Y.
description: KWOH-Emily T.Y. A woman of remarkable strength and imagination died on January 18, 1998. Her life was an array of triumphs and vicissitudes, the joining of east and west. Born and raised in China she came to the U.S. after the war in 1947. She received a graduate degree from Harvard in Psychology and went on to Columbia to prepare for a career in Early Childhood Education. Oddly, her career took a different path and Emily found herself as a pioneer in bringing the broad range of the Chinese cuisine to the U.S. with the great shanghai, Mandarin House and Mandarin East in the 50's and 60's. Her life was her family, friends, and dreams. She is survived by her children Bonny, Jesse and his wife Deborah, her grandchildren Carl and Catherine, her husband Ted, her brother Marcian and her sister Lydia. Remember and honor her. A memorial service is being planned.

title: At Khomeini's Tomb, Iran's President Switches Tune on U.S.
description: In surprisingly harsh tones, President Mohammad Khatami of Iran criticized the United States tonight for oppressing the people of Iran and vowed that they would never be enslaved again.

title: Accounts
description: * Land O'Lakes Inc., Arden Hills, Minn., to Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis, owned by top management and the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its consumer promotion account, which had been handled by Rapp Collins Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $15 million. Campbell Mithun also handles consumer, trade and interactive advertising for Land O'Lakes as well as direct marketing.

title: FIRST DATA BUYS A UNIT FROM, AND SELLS ONE TO, CERIDIAN
description: The First Data Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the gambling division of the Ceridian Corporation and that Ceridian had bought First Data's NTS transportation-services unit.
