Terms were not disclosed. Ceridian's gambling services unit provides credit card, debit card and money transfer help for 800 casinos and their customers. It will be integrated with Telecheck Services Inc., a check-acceptance company owned by First Data, which is based in Hackensack, N.J. Ceridian, of Minneapolis, will combine First Data's NTS transportation services business with its Comdata unit. NTS provides transaction services related to fund transfers, fuel purchases and permits to the trucking industry.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Sadat Standard
description: An important anniversary quietly slipped by a few weeks ago. It was the 20th anniversary of Anwar el-Sadat's visit to Jerusalem. It's worth recalling Sadat these days -- both his wisdom and courage to just get on a plane, fly to Israel, extend his hand to the Israeli people and thus pave the way for the first Arab-Israeli peace. Twenty years later, the lesson of Sadatism seems to have been forgotten by both Israeli and Arab leaders. We are back in a pre-Sadat era.

title: For Bookstore Browsers, Blurbs Can Be a Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEITLER, BEATRICE O.
description: TEITLER-Beatrice O. At age 88. Died January 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel L. Teitler. Devoted mother of Michael, Bob and Ann Teitler Ozer. Loving mother-in-law of Judith Katz. Proud grandmother of William, Joseph, Sarah, John, David and Kenneth Teitler and Katherine, Elizabeth, Mark, Emily and Nicole Ozer. Loving great-grandmother of Lucy, Isabel and Anna May Teitler and Sam and Max OzerStaton. Services on Wednesday, January 21 at 11:30AM at Schwartz Brothers, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, followed by burial at New Montefiore cemetery in Pinelawn, New York.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Chess; Intercollegiate Title Won By Team From Manhattan
description: The 52d annual Pan-American Intercollegiate Team Championship was won by the Borough of Manhattan Community College with a perfect match score of 6-0. The 26-team, Swiss-system event was held at Western Kentucky University in Bowling Green, Dec. 26 to 29. Borough of Manhattan also triumphed in 1993 and 1994.

title: Raising The Curtain On a Golden Broadway
description: Do you like overtures? Then you should get a big kick out of the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, the glittering show palace that officially opened on Sunday night with the debut of the musical, ''Ragtime.'' Architecturally speaking, the Ford Center is a sparkling medley, smoothly pieced together from the ornamental tunes of Broadway's great old houses: marbles, mosaics, red-velvet seats, gold-leaf domes, rosettes, lyres, masks of comedy, murals of frolicking maidens, cupids and low-wattage filament light bulbs.

title: Science Watch; Why Shoes+Carpet=Sparks
description: USING an apparatus similar to French mercury barometers of the 1670's, physicists have set out to explore a longstanding mystery: why do shoes sliding over a carpet generate sparks?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUYLER, PEARL
description: SCHUYLER-Pearl. Suddenly on January 17, 1998. Beloved wife of Irving. Loving mother of Sandra Schuyler Jaffee and Harvey Schuyler. Dear mother-in-law of Carl Jaffee and cherished grandmother of Evan Jaffee. Funeral private.

title: Celtics' Long Day Of Pressing Is Wasted
description: A fresh-faced Chris Mills trotted over to the Boston bench and embraced each Celtic player, each worn and lifeless one of them. Like hugging crash-test dummies.

title: Cuban Catholics Feverishly Prepare for Pope
description: For two straight hours, Maria de los Angeles Romero has been gluing paper Cuban flags to rough wooden sticks. The glue, a homemade lumpy mixture of water and flour, sticks to Ms. Romero's bony fingers, and from there to her limp hair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. Jan. 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Eliza and Simon. Brother of Timothy and Ian Clark. Son of Blair Clark and the late Jessie Holladay Philbin James. Memorial service, Tuesday, January 20, 10:30 AM, at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73rd Street, NYC.

title: Undercover Officer Is Slain in the Bronx In a Drug Operation
description: An undercover New York City police officer was killed in a shootout in the Bronx last night after a ''buy and bust'' drug operation erupted in gunfire, officials said.

title: On Gulf Veterans, Head vs. the Heart
description: ''Last Battle of the Gulf War'' took place, or is taking place, at home. American veterans of the fighting in Iraq who complained of an array of symptoms that came to be called gulf war syndrome have found themselves allied with mainstream media, members of Congress and a few doctors against the Pentagon and the nation's scientific establishment. The issue remains whether something happened in the gulf that made the veterans sick and entitles them to Government aid.

title: H.I.V. Reporting May Deter Some From Testing; Enforce Confidentiality
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the departure of a United Nations weapons inspection team from Iraq misstated the number of team members. It is 16, not 14.

title: New Toys Try to Make Computer Programming Child's Play
description: TWO toy dinosaurs whirr across the tabletop, lock infrared eyes and glide through a dos-a-dos. Along the way, they may also plant the seeds of scientific curiosity in their young masters.

title: H.I.V. Reporting May Deter Some From Testing; Protect Schoolchildren
description: To the Editor:

title: My Life In the Swiss Camps
description: A recent report by the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles paints a dark portrait of life in Switzerland during World War II for the more than 22,000 mostly Jewish refugees who managed to cross its border illegally. According to some first-hand accounts, refugees were forced into draconian camps where they were miserably treated and forced to do backbreaking labor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HEREN, DANA
description: O'HEREN-Dana. Dearest Doug, Sharon and family our love, thoughts and prayers are with you. Love Mark, Diane, Alex and Emily

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, MILTON L.
description: WEISSMAN-Milton L., 89. January 18, 1998. Formerly of New York City and currently San Diego, CA. Most devoted and loving husband of Helen H. Weissman for 65 years. Magnificent and loving father of Stephen Bruce Weissman. Deeply caring and loving grandfather of Stephanie Bryn Weissman Clement (and husband Gregory) and Serena Blake Weissman Sandino (and husband James) and for far too brief a time smiling and loving great grandfather of Samantha Gwyn Clement. Milton L. Weissman was a giant and legend in the insurance brokerage business. He was president of Weissman and Weissman Inc. for 50 years and continued on with Frenkel & Co. for 10 years after the firm was acquired. He taught all of us what true love, courage and dedication means. Formerly a member of Glen Oaks Club and a major supporter of all Jewish causes. Services private.

title: Merger by 2 Russian Tycoons Creates an Oil Colossus
description: Two of Russia's most powerful tycoons merged their oil companies today, creating a politically potent enterprise with control over one of the world's largest oil reserves.

title: Van Horn Struggles, but Nets Don't
description: On any other night, it would have been a shooter's worst nightmare. At least that was the way it felt to Keith Van Horn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, NOEL
description: BLOCK-Noel. On January 17, 1998. Father of Rachel of Baltimore, Md and brother of Adrian of Annapolis, Md. Services were private.

title: Asia Troubles Affecting Boeing Orders
description: The Boeing Company may have to delay deliveries of jetliners to Malaysian Airline System Bhd. and Philippine Airlines Inc., as Asian airlines struggle to pay for orders made before the region's financial crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OROL, LILLIAN S.
description: OROL-Lillian S. Died Jan. 18, 1998 in Sunnyvale, CA. Previously from Lauderhill, FL., and Kew Gardens, NY. Born Jan. 7, 1913 to Pauline Levitt and Benjamin Spatz. Predeceased by her beloved Harry Orol, DDS and brother Leon D. Spatz, DDS. Survived by son Edward (Harriet); daughter Marcia Orol Kaplan, J.D. (Dr. Henry), sisters Belle Gold and Beatrice Weidman; grandchildren Kerith and Jessica Orol; Joshua (Stefanie), Seth, Daniel and Jonathan Kaplan; greatgrandchildren Kayla Hilary and Benjamin Levi Kaplan; many friends and relatives. Fiercely independent to the end. Life member of Hadassah. Services Wed., Jan. 21, 1998, 11:00AM, Montefiore Cemetery (718-528-1700).

title: Editorial Observer; The Trade Secrets of Chile's Dextrous General
description: A quarter-century after the coup that overthrew Salvador Allende, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is still poisoning Chile's public life. He must retire as commander of Chile's armed forces by March, but his plan to take a lifetime seat in the Senate and his attempts to delay his departure till the last moment have sparked protests, the resignation of Chile's Defense Minister and a renewed debate about the role of the military.

title: 2 Commissioners Shop Uniformly
description: No, they don't wear uniforms, and yes, they love tax breaks.

title: Saatchi Appoints Top Creative Official
description: Stan Becker, who has served as the top creative executive at the New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi, will step down, the agency said yesterday, and will be replaced by Tod Seisser, a former top creative executive of J. Walter Thompson New York.

title: INSIDE
description: New Pill for Baldness: Old Drug at Higher Price

title: New Window on Cosmos Opening a Mile Down
description: AS the world's first heavy-water neutrino detector nears completion, scientists eagerly await results expected to open a new window on the universe and settle one of the thorniest questions in physics: whether or not the elusive neutrino particle has mass.

title: A 'Dead Zone' Grows in the Gulf of Mexico
description: IT can stretch for 7,000 square miles off the coast of Louisiana, a vast expanse of ocean devoid of the region's usual rich bounty of fish and shrimp, its bottom littered with the remains of crabs and worms unable to flee its suffocating grasp. This is the Gulf of Mexico's ''dead zone,'' which last summer reached the size of the state of New Jersey.

title: A Defining Moment For UConn Women
description: Suddenly, somehow, the taut game was no longer a struggle. An afternoon that seemed headed for the inevitable last shot -- make or miss, win or lose -- had turned into a loud party. Another generation of Connecticut Huskies raced back to the hugs that waited at their bench.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The battle between two famous indexes in stock market futures appears to be close.
description: THREE months into the pitched Chicago battle for the hearts and minds of retail speculators in stock market futures, the battle between the famous upstart, the Dow Jones industrial average, and the entrenched old-timer, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, appears to be close.

title: Hillary Clinton Plays Down Publicity Over Paula Jones
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she and President Clinton had ''not really'' been affected by publicity surrounding Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct accusations, and she suggested that the case was driven by politics.

title: Samaritan Fears Chance of Reprisal
description: For Raheem Dawkins, life should be returning to normal. On Jan. 1, he was shot by the off-duty police officer he was trying to rescue from an attacker. At first, Mr. Dawkins was called a possible suspect in the attack, but the teen-ager was eventually lauded as a hero by the Mayor and the Police Commissioner.

title: Starwood Says It Has Arranged Financing for ITT Acquisition
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Trust has obtained more than $7 billion in financing that will allow it to complete its $10.2 billion acquisition of the ITT Corporation, a hotel and casino company, Starwood's chairman and chief executive, Barry S. Sternlicht, said yesterday.

title: H.I.V. Reporting May Deter Some From Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARREN, ROSE (COHEN)
description: HARREN-Rose (Cohen). In her 83rd year on January 18, 1998. Wife of the late George J. Harren. Loving mother of Carol and Jill (Jack Shaifer). Beloved sister of Helen Barkin and Felix Carlson (Audre). Adoring grandmother of Seth. Cherished aunt of Amy (James Reiter) and Michael Carlson. Dear great aunt of Scott, Adam, Eric and Abigail. Services Wednesday, January 21, 10:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Campaigns are making mistakes on purpose in the quest to stand out from the crowd.
description: PRINT advertisements have become replete with inadvertent mistakes, from a reference to a student making the ''honor role'' by the Partnership for a Drug-Free America to a description of Pepperidge Farm garlic bread as ''the ultimate compliment to pasta'' to a sale on ''classic music'' at the Nobody Beats the Wiz retail chain. Now, though, some print ads feature mistakes that are anything but accidents.

title: A Giggle of Girls, Dreaming and Steaming
description: The very precocious schoolgirls in ''Benita Canova,'' the 1998 offering from Richard Foreman's Ontological-Hysteric Theater, are a steamy lot. Crafty, feline and sexually charged, they variously bring to mind the dreamy pubescent figures in Balthus paintings, the turn-of-the-century New Orleans prostitutes of E. J. Bellocq's photographs and the decadent Weimar chorines from the Kit Kat Club in ''Cabaret.''

title: Leftists Steal Enemy Tactic: The Merger
description: IT said in the newspaper that New York's real estate powers gathered at a midtown hotel last Thursday night and that the star was Leona Helmsley, the famous tax cheat and felon. Naturally, everyone flocked around her. Never let it be said that the politically connected are unforgiving, especially when they spy $5 billion on two legs.

title: WESTMIN RESOURCES FAILS TO GET BIGGER TAKEOVER BIDS
description: Westmin Resources Ltd., a Canadian mining company, said yesterday that it had not been able to attract takeover offers topping Boliden Ltd.'s hostile bid of $809 million (Canadian), or $562 million (United States), in stock and debt, and its financial adviser warned that its shares would probably fall if it was not bought. Westmin has searched for a rival bidder since last year when Boliden, based in Toronto, offered to pay $5.40 (Canadian) a share and assume $228 million in debt. Yesterday, Westmin said its board would not make a recommendation on the offer, which expires Wednesday. Its shares closed at $5.30. Westmin, a target because of its low-cost Lomas Bayas copper deposit, said Boliden's bid did not fairly value the company.

title: Clinton Seeks Additional Money To Enforce Civil Rights Laws
description: Seeking increased Federal action to back up the President's calls for racial reconciliation, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would request a 16 percent increase in spending next year to enforce civil rights laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESENFELD, WILLIAM A.
description: RIESENFELD-William A. The Officers, Board members and the entire Beth Abraham Health Services community are profoundly saddened by the death of William Riesenfeld and mourn his passing. Bill approached everything he did with commitment and dedication, whether it was sports fishing (he held several world records) or competing in Squash (he was nationaly ranked) or emersing himself in health care. As a member of the Beth Abraham board since 1972, retiring as Chairman in 1996, he gave generously of himself, his time and knowledge. His guidance was of particular value in the area of real estate. He had a strong sense of humanity and displayed great empathy when visiting our patients. We will miss his wisdom and counsel and always cherish his memory. Edwin H. Stern, III Chairman, Board of Directors BETHCO Michael R. Potack Chairman, Board of Directors Beth Abraham Health Services William H. Frohlich President Beth Abraham Health Services

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NATMAN, LEONARD
description: NATMAN-Leonard. Aug. 29, 1952Jan. 20, 1987. Remembered with love every day. Mr. D.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: EVENTS

title: Survey Shows Dominance of Managed Care Plans in 1997
description: Managed health care does not seem to be winning any popularity contests, if you listen to audiences applauding as the actress Helen Hunt castigates H.M.O.'s in the new movie with Jack Nicholson, ''As Good as It Gets,'' or if you count the new laws that regulate health maintenance organizations. But in the workaday world, managed care achieved a near-monopoly of employer health plans last year.

title: St. Paul to Pay $2.8 Billion For USF&G
description: The St. Paul Companies, one of the nation's largest insurers of corporations, said yesterday that it was acquiring a large competitor, USF& G, for about $2.8 billion in stock, in one of the largest insurance mergers in recent years.

title: Women's Pole Vault At Millrose Games
description: Stacy Dragila, America's best female pole-vaulter, predicted yesterday that she would clear 16 feet by the year 2000. But first she plans to break the indoor record of 14 feet 5i inches she shares with Emma George of Australia in the inaugural women's pole vault at the Chase Millrose Games on Feb. 13.

title: Clinton Plan to Widen Medicare Can't Pay for Itself, Experts Say
description: Insurance experts say they doubt that President Clinton's proposal to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old would pay for itself, because, they say, sicker and costlier patients would be the ones most likely to sign up for the new coverage.

title: Golden Globe Winners
description: Here are the 1998 Golden Globe awards presented by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association on Sunday night during a ceremony in Beverly Hills, Calif.:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOERGER, HARRY C.
description: JOERGER-Harry C. Of South River, New Jersey, on Friday, January 16, 1998. Husband of the late Catherine (nee Ryan); father of Very Reverend Robert Joerger C.P., Provincial of the Passionist Fathers; brother of Raymond and Anna Daly; uncle of many nieces and nephews. Funeral service on Thursday, January 22 at 11 AM from the McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th St., Brooklyn, New York, thence to St. Anselm Church, Brooklyn where at 12 PM a funeral mass will be offered. Interment Cemetery of Resurrection, Staten Island. Visitation Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. For those desiring, donations may be sent to St. Gabriels Youth Retreat House, Shelter Island, New York 11965.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MANITOBA TELECOM SERVICES INC., Winnipeg, Manitoba, a wireless and wireless phone service operator, said it would offer buyouts to some employees in an attempt to cut about 350 positions.

title: Williams Sisters Will Meet in 2d Round
description: Pete Sampras, the grand old man at this Grand Slam event, is chasing history. Venus and Serena Williams, the beaded beanpoles who have made the grandest debut Melbourne Park has ever witnessed, are chasing each other.

title: Young, Handsome and Clueless in Peyton Place
description: Kevin Williamson, who rejuvenated the teen-age horror movie with his witty, self-conscious scripts for the ''Scream'' movies, has now done the same for another pulpy genre: the prime-time soap opera. Never mind that Mr. Williamson and the WB network are positioning his autobiographical ''Dawson's Creek'' as a glimpse of reality. This series about 15-year-olds in a New England seaside town is pure soap, redeemed by intelligence and sharp writing. Less earnest than the series it superficially resembles, like ''Party of Five'' and ''My So-Called Life,'' ''Dawson's Creek'' is also far more entertaining as it takes the characters' submerged fears and fantasies and turns them into action.

title: Americans and Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu, in Washington, Courts Conservatives
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arrived in Washington for talks about Middle East peace and went directly to a Christian-Jewish rally of conservative supporters, who include some of President Clinton's harshest political opponents.

title: Black Coaches Are Angry With N.F.L. Over Hiring
description: As Super Bowl XXXII descends on this city, Sherman Lewis, the scholarly offensive coordinator of the Green Bay Packers, is trying to keep a low profile. But that's impossible.

title: Senseless Killing in the Seas
description: America's fisheries are not in good shape. By some accounts, more than two-thirds of all commercially important fish populations are now classified as ''fully fished'' or ''overexploited,'' which means they are in decline or heading there.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLAUSTEIN, SOL LARRY
description: BLAUSTEIN-Sol Larry. 1/20/09-7/12/69. Dearest dad, we love and miss you very much. Adrienne, Hank and Frank. Miriam, Simcha and Anna would have loved you too.

title: Japan's Cabinet Clears Huge Bank Bailout
description: Japan's Cabinet gave its approval yesterday to one of the largest bank bailouts in history -- a 30 trillion yen ($232 billion) package to protect depositors and increase banks' capital -- and sent the measures to Parliament. The Cabinet also approved a 77.7 trillion yen budget for the year starting April 1. In contrast with the bank bailout, the budget calls for spending cuts across the board.

title: HILLENBRAND PLANS TO REPURCHASE UP TO 7.4% OF STOCK
description: Hillenbrand Industries, based in Batesville, Ind., said yesterday that it would buy back as many as five million shares, or 7.4 percent of its shares outstanding. Hillenbrand, a maker of hospital beds, funeral products and security equipment, said it would hold the repurchased shares as treasury stock for use in stock option plans and other purposes. Based on Friday's closing price of $52.4375 a share, the buyback could represent more than $260 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, WALTER
description: PRINCE-Walter. Of New Rochelle, NY. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Father of Judith (Edward Shapiro), Donna (Richard Ullman). Grandfather of Douglas, Larry, Pamela and the late Andrew Shapiro. Services on Tuesday 1 PM, Bethel Synagogue, New Rochelle. We'll love you always.

title: Carl Perkins Dies at 65; Rockabilly Pioneer Wrote 'Blue Suede Shoes'
description: Carl Perkins, the pioneering rockabilly singer, songwriter and guitarist who wrote ''Blue Suede Shoes,'' died yesterday in Jackson, Tenn., where he lived. He was 65.

title: A Budget to Run On
description: Taking advantage of the continuing boom on Wall Street, Gov. George Pataki has unveiled an election-year budget for New York State with enough programs to please nearly everyone. The only hitch is that it ignores fiscal prudence.

title: ALPINE GROUP BUYING AMERICAN PREMIER REFRACTORY UNIT
description: Alpine Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the refractory operations of the closely held American Premier Holdings Inc. for $133 million in cash and stock. Alpine Group, based in New York, operates Superior Telecom, which makes copper wire and cable for the telecommunications industry, and Refraco, which makes heat-resistant products used in the steel, aluminum, cement, glass and other industries. American Premier, based in King of Prussia, Pa., had about $180 million in revenue from its refractory operations in 1997. Prior to the transaction, American Premier will transfer its American Minerals division to Minerals Trading Inc., a subsidiary of CE Minerals Inc., which is owned by Imetal S.A. of France.

title: OIL EQUIPMENT COMPANIES IN $418 MILLION DEAL
description: Smith International Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Wilson Industries, a closely held distributor of oil-drilling products and services, for almost $418 million in stock, based on Friday's closing price. Smith, a drilling equipment maker in Houston, will issue 7.9 million shares for Wilson and assume $65 million of debt. The purchase gives Smith a horizontal well-drilling technology and equipment company. Use of this technology is expanding quickly as oil and gas producers drill farther away from well platforms. Smith will also get a distribution network that it can use to sell oil and natural gas drilling equipment. Smith Industries jumped $4.5625 yesterday, to $57.4375.

title: Razorfish Teams Up With Avalanche
description: Two New York agencies that specialize in interactive advertising, Avalanche Systems and Razorfish, said yesterday that they would form a strategic partnership, as Razorfish is acquiring a majority stake in Avalanche. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Overseas Crisis Takes a Toll On Earnings Of 3 Big Banks
description: The crisis in overseas financial markets was again felt in the United States yesterday, as three of the nation's largest banks said fourth-quarter earnings were hurt by sharp economic downturns in Asia and Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNENFELD, HYMAN, MD.
description: DONNENFELD-Hyman, MD. The Medical Staff of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center of New York expresses its deep sorrow at the loss of one of its most honored and respected members, Dr. Hyman Donnenfeld. Dr. Donnenfeld enjoyed a thiry-year career with Saint Vincents as a Neurologist and Neuropathologist, for many years serving as the Chief of Neurosciences and Neuropathology. Born in Quebec, he trained at Ottawa University, followed by a Fellowship at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center from 1964-67, before starting his association with Saint Vincents. Dr. Donnenfeld will be remembered as an accomplished and caring physician as well as superb teacher and compassionate human being. His gifts, skills, friendship and humor will be dearly missed, and his absence sorely felt by the caregivers, administrative staff and patients of Saint Vincents. We express our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Donnenfeld's family, his daughters Caroline and Sherry, and his son, David. Eduardo M. Gonzalez, MD, Pres. for the Medical Staff of Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center

title: Zevulun Hammer, 61, Dies; Israel's Education Minister
description: Zevulun Hammer, Israel's Education Minister, leader of the National Religious Party and a founder of the movement to build Jewish settlements in occupied Arab territories, died today after a long bout with cancer. He was 61.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, HAROLD I., M.D.
description: KAPLAN-Harold I., M.D.. The faculty and staff of the Department of Psychiatry of New York University Medical Center and the entire community of New York University School of Medicine wish to express our profound sorrow on the passing of our esteemed colleague, Harold I. Kaplan, on January 15, 1998. Dr. Kaplan, a member of the Department for 17 years, was Professor of Psychiatry at NYU School of Medicine and an Attending Psychiatrist at Bellevue, Tisch and Lenox Hill Hospitals. He was founding editor of the ''Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry'', a major work translated into 11 languages and used by psychiatrists around the world. A brilliant and humane educator, Dr. Kaplan was Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, the American College of Physicians, and the New York Academy of Medicine, and the recipient of numerous awards that recognized extraordinary talents and capabilities. To his wife, Nancy, to his children, Philip, Peter and Jennifer, and to his many patients, we extend our deepest sympathies. Robert Cancro, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Psychiatry NYU School of Medicine

title: Flavored Vodka: A Revolution The Romanovs Missed
description: WHILE the world was preoccupied with Dolly the sheep, a team of scientists quietly introduced banana flavor into vodka. Banana vodka is fact, not theory. It is legal in all 50 states. And it poses the same moral question as human cloning: just because scientists can do it, must they?

title: Business Travel; With corporate hotel rates on the rise, the search is on for good rooms that don't break budgets.
description: WITH American Express estimating that corporate hotel rates will escalate around 15 percent this year, business travelers are trolling for good budget hotel rooms -- and finding them aplenty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUBBIONDO, CHARLES
description: SUBBIONDO-Charles. On January 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Ann, loving father of Charles and Ralph, cherished brother of Andrew, Joseph and Mary, adored grandfather of Susan, Douglas, Christopher and Charlie III, devoted great grandfather of Alexa and Charlie IV. Reposing at Ridge Chapels, 405 91 St, between 4th and 5th Aves, Brooklyn. Viewing Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Wednesday service at chapel 10AM-noon. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Leukemia Society, 600 3rd Ave., New York, New York 10003.

title: Metro Business; Funds for Women's Group
description: The United States Small Business Administration has committed $750,000 over five years to establish the Women's Business Center in New York, an organization that will help women start their own businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRIE, WILLIAM F.
description: BARRIE-William F. Age 84. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn. A rare and unique Christian gentleman. Reposing Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 Street, New York City, on Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service Thursday at noon.

title: Sports of The Times; The Packer Who Packs The Middle
description: HIS size 24 neck is wider than his head. He wears a size 64 jacket. His ''Big Dog'' tattoo on his right biceps is almost as big as some dogs. Gilbert Brown is listed at 345 pounds, but whenever the Packers' 6-foot-2-inch nose tackle was asked yesterday what he really weighed, he had the same answer with the same feigned smirk.

title: Museum Invites Arafat, Reversing Itself Twice
description: First, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum agreed, at the State Department's suggestion, to invite the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to tour the museum during his visit to Washington this week. Then the museum decided not to invite him.

title: Can Prenatal Music Create Little Leonardos?; Investment in the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACKERMAN, JOHANNA
description: ACKERMAN-Johanna. A year has gone by and we miss you. You are always in our hearts. Love, Edie, Peppy, Mark, Alan and Michael

title: Pierre Boulat, Photographer, 73
description: Pierre Boulat, a photographer who worked for Life magazine in the 1950's and 60's, died on Jan. 11 in Nemours, France. He was 73.

title: Alan E. Cober, 62, News and Book Illustrator
description: Alan E. Cober, an innovative magazine, newspaper and book illustrator and a graphic commentator known for his visual essays on the death chamber at Sing Sing prison and on mental patients at the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island, died on Saturday while swimming in Sarasota, Fla. He was 62 and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Food Stuff
description: French Fries The Belgian Way

title: Cave-In to Japan
description: The broad outline of the airline deal shaping up between the United States and Japan appears deficient. According to reports, the preliminary agreement would increase the number of flights into Japan by American carriers by only a modest number. Worse yet, it would preserve the Japanese Government's right to veto fare cuts -- Japan's tactic for protecting its inefficient carriers from competition by low-cost American carriers.

title: On the Korea Tightrope, 1980
description: The interesting account by Richard Holbrooke and Michael Armacost (''A Future Leader's Moment of Truth,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 24) of the 1980 rescue of Kim Dae Jung suggests that it is time to tell the full story of a distant drama that could have become a catastrophe.

title: By the Book; Inside California Home Kitchens
description: COOKBOOK authors have tried all the angles. There are books dedicated to barbecue sauces, to Christmas in the Heartland, and even one on cooking ''unplugged,'' without the aid of electric appliances. Now, Michele Anna Jordan, who wrote an entire book on polenta (once a simple peasant dish made of cornmeal, water, salt, butter and cheese), has produced ''California Home Cooking'' (Harvard Common Press, $16.95).

title: TV Notes; Globe Power for Fox
description: Sunday night's NBC broadcast of the Golden Globe Awards drew the largest audience yet for that increasingly prominent presentation of movie and television prizes, with more than 24 million viewers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEITLER, BEATRICE O.
description: TEITLER-Beatrice O. At age 88. Died January 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel L. Teitler. Devoted mother of Michael, Bob and Ann Teitler Ozer. Loving mother-in-law of Judith Katz. Proud grandmother of William, Joseph, Sarah, John, David and Kenneth Teitler and Katherine, Elizabeth, Mark, Emily and Nicole Ozer. Loving great-grandmother of Lucy, Isabel and Anna May Teitler and Sam and Max OzerStaton. Services on Wednesday, January 21 at 11:30AM at Schwartz Brothers, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, followed by burial at New Montefiore cemetery in Pinelawn, New York.

title: Gatling Goes the Extra Mile To Hasten His Recovery
description: Chris Gatling was dripping with sweat, dropping in layup after layup as Nets coaches watched carefully. When he was done, he went straight from the court to the weight room.

title: Profits Are Up at Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that its earnings grew more than 13 percent in the fourth quarter as rising drug sales made up for a decline in sales of a key medical device.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADOM, PEARL W.
description: RADOM-Pearl W. Suddenly, in her 87th year on January 18. Beloved wife of the late Ial. Devoted mother of the late Carl. Loving mother of Gayle and Simon. Cherished grandmother of Alan, Todd, Sue and great-grandmother of Cara . She will be missed by all whose lives she touched. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Saving Swordfish
description: Swordfish is a popular dish among seafood lovers everywhere. For that and other reasons, its numbers are dwindling at an alarming rate, especially in the North Atlantic. So it is heartening that leading chefs at more than two dozen leading restaurants across the country -- including Le Bernardin and Felidia in New York City, and Nora in Washington D.C. -- have joined a cooperative effort to help the species. Although the decline in swordfish populations has been common knowledge among environmentalists and commercial fishermen for 20 years, this is the first time that the consumer end of the food chain has paid attention.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about Paul Maguire, a football broadcaster for NBC television, referred incorrectly to Ted Nathanson, who had commented on Mr. Maguire's work. Mr. Nathanson should have been described as a former producer, not a current one; he died in June.

title: Calendar
description: Champagne Toasts

title: Evangelicals for Israel
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said he and Southern Baptist leaders would urge evangelical churches to oppose the transfer of land to Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, NATHAN
description: FELDMAN-Nathan. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Devoted father of Arnold and Sandra Feldman. Dear brother of Sue Feigenbaum, Betty Bloomberg, Diana Gluckstern, David Feldman and Faith Cohen. Services Wednesday, 1PM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76 Road, Forest Hills.

title: Big Indonesian Bank Holding Merger Talks
description: Shares of Bank Danamon, Indonesia's fourth-largest publicly traded bank, soared yesterday after the company said it was in talks with a group of private banks on a possible merger. The Indonesian newspaper Harian Ekonomi Neraca reported that Danamon would merge with 10 smaller Indonesian banks. A Danamon spokesman said he would not deny the report, though he said he could not specify the total number of banks involved, or identify them.

title: Test Kitchen; Fuzzy Logic Makes Perfect Rice
description: IN Asia, where the average person eats more than 200 pounds of rice a year, a rice cooker is standard equipment. But does the average American -- who eats only 25 pounds of rice a year -- really need such a specialized appliance? And if so, which one? Dozens of models, from $20 to more than $200, are sold in stores and catalogues.

title: Georgetown Squeaks By Seton Hall
description: The Seton Hall Pirates came calling on Georgetown with a host of goals. But their shot at double digits in victories, their bid to break an eight-game losing streak against the Hoyas and a quest to climb to .500 in Big East play proved too big a burden. The last of nine turnovers, with only 1 second remaining, condemned Seton Hall to a 68-66 defeat tonight.

title: Unpredictable Night for 'Elisir'
description: In recent seasons at the Metropolitan Opera, Luciano Pavarotti's work has been sadly mixed. Though 62, his voice has remained remarkably intact. But he suffers from chronic leg problems, and it has been painful to watch him hobble through performances. Last fall, as Calaf in Puccini's ''Turandot,'' he was virtually escorted through the role by two men, one on each arm, portraying palace guards in ancient Beijing.

title: Peter Kiewit Sons to Build National Fiber Optic Network
description: Adding to the growing list of companies that are building new national communications networks, Peter Kiewit Sons Inc. has said that it intends to spend up to $3 billion over the next three years to build a 20,000-mile web of fiber optic cable.

title: Contractor Is Scrutinized After Collapse
description: The demolition company that had been tearing down the old State Theater in Journal Square said today that the building's collapse on Monday, which injured 17 people, might have been caused by a weakness in the flat roof of the adjacent building where workmen had mounted scaffolding.

title: Mayor Visits Police Task Force And Receives Mixed Reviews
description: On the day after a New York police officer was shot to death in the Bronx, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani walked into a meeting of his task force on police-community relations to announce that he would give the group 60 days to come up with final recommendations.

title: Hitachi Sets Cutbacks In Chip Production
description: Hitachi Ltd., Japan's largest electronics maker, will temporarily stop production of computer memory chips at eight factories in Japan to reduce inventories. Production of dynamic random access memory and other memory chips will halt for four to seven days in February and again in March, a spokesman, Masahiro Takahashi, said yesterday.

title: Possible Merger of Drug Makers Causes Late Stock Rally
description: For Wall Street, bigger seems to be better.

title: OBITUARY : Peter Diamand, 84, Music Administrator
description: PARIS  Peter Diamand, 84, former director of the Holland and Edinburgh music festivals and artistic adviser to the Orchestre de Paris since 1976, died Friday in Doetinchem, the Netherlands.

title: I.B.M. Offers Profit Warning for Quarter
description: I.B.M. warned yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter would be dragged down by the rising dollar, a sales decline in Asia and several one-time factors, even as it reported earnings in the fourth quarter of 1997 that were slightly above expectations.

title: Bonds Fail to Hold Gains on More Signs of Asian Stability
description: Treasury prices surrendered early gains to finish lower yesterday.

title: Restaurants; A Neapolitan Jewel Outshines Its Setting
description: IN this time of high-intensity design, when restaurateurs often spend more time selecting the architect than the chef, Pierino is a challenge. Are good food and a passionate presentation enough to overcome an ugly room?

title: The Minimalist; Crisp Duck Without Fat Cooked in a Skillet. Really.
description: WHAT keeps most people from cooking duck more frequently isn't, I'm sure, that they don't like it, but that the roasting methods that efficiently rid duck of its thick layer of fat take so much time and a fair amount of attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIN, LEO
description: SCHEIN-Leo. On January 20, 1998. Retired January 8, 1959 after 25 years as Assistant Civil Engineer for NYC. Served in U.S. Army in the same capacity from 1941-1943. Along with his younger brother, George Schein, they helped organize and they founded the U.S. Table Tennis Association in the early 1930's. Surviving are his sister-in-law, Hilja Schein an her son Henry Lucenius. Graveside service and interment at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY at 11 AM on Thursday, January 22, 1998.

title: With Pope Due, the Cubans Wrest Dollars From Heaven
description: At the Hotel Habana Libre, Dan Rather and his CBS News team are already ensconced on the 16th floor, while Ted Koppel and the ''Nightline'' staff are down on the 12th. Peter Jennings flew in Monday night, Tom Brokaw is expected today, and even Martha Stewart is coming in her role as a regular contributor to ''CBS This Morning.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Woody Allen, In Court Again
description: WOODY ALLEN is making a second appearance in State Supreme Court, where he battled MIA FARROW in a widely publicized child-custody case in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, GEORGE
description: SCHAEFER-George. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the death of their Life Fellow, Dr. George Schaefer, on September 27, 1997. David Rosenfeld, MD, President Richard L. Berkowitz, MD, Secretary

title: Vehicles for Market Share; Wheelchair Makers Are Trying to Expand Their Turf
description: Late this year, Dan Sullivan will buy a new wheelchair. Unable to walk since birth, Mr. Sullivan, a 54-year-old executive director of a Philadelphia employment agency, trades up every two years for one of the industry's new models. His next purchase promises to be the best yet.

title: Shurmur Likes Being Old and in the Way
description: The hardened face, the white, wispy hair and the raspy voice are all part of Fritz Shurmur, Green Bay's defensive coordinator. He is 65 years old and has spent 23 years in the National Football League. Listen to people who say he's too old, and you're bound to lose.

title: F.D.A. Stand on Cloning Raises Even More Questions
description: In announcing that it has the power to block scientists who try to clone people, the Food and Drug Administration may have thrown a kink into efforts to ban the practice, pitting the White House and Congress against leaders in science and industry who say legislation is now unnecessary.

title: The Chef
description: I HAVE no memories of Ethiopia, where I was born. The marvelous Swedish family that adopted me when I was 3 is the only one I know. But once I found myself working as a chef in New York, I gravitated toward Ethiopians here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, SARAH
description: SCHNEIDER-Sarah. The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany records with sorrow the passing of Sarah Schneider, the mother of Michael Schneider, a member of our Board of Directors and Committee Chairman. We extend our sincerest sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Israel Miller, President Saul Kagan, Executive V.P.

title: Mirage Resorts Is Accused of Breaking Joint Agreement to Build Project in Atlantic City
description: A long-planned cooperative venture to build a complex of three gambling resorts in a sparsely developed section of Atlantic City may have fallen apart -- at least judging from the announcements yesterday by the casino developers.

title: Richter Has 45 Answers for Questions the Rangers Face
description: Most of the questions could be answered by the time the National Hockey League interrupts its season. Between now and the break for the Winter Olympics, the Rangers, and their opinionated following at Madison Square Garden, should have a strong sense of whether this is just another borderline playoff team headed for a certain first-round exit, or something more substantial.

title: Wrap Dress Reviver Who's a Jet Set Star
description: ALEXANDRA VON FURSTENBERG is the American billionaire's daughter who married nobly, expensively and well, then went to work helping her mother-in-law, Diane Von Furstenberg, revive the 1970's wrap dress. Her riches-to-the-rag trade story is of course not unknown, at least by people who pay attention to money and clothes. The same people compare Ms. Von Furstenberg to the heroines of Edith Wharton and Henry James.

title: Court Clerk Is Charged In Theft of Bail Money
description: A clerk for the Hudson County Superior Court was charged yesterday with stealing nearly $400,000 in bail money and filing fees, state investigators said.

title: Off the Menu
description: One More Bellini

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HEREN, DANA
description: O'HEREN-Dana. We wish to express our sincerest condolences and heartfelt sympathies to Dana's entire family for their tragic and untimely loss. Our hearts ache for you. May her memory be a blessing. Gail, Billy, Sarah and J.D.

title: Twice a Year, It's a Gumbo Gig
description: BY night, six months out of the year, Tony Garnier is on stage somewhere in the world, playing bass behind Bob Dylan. By day, once and maybe twice a year, Mr. Garnier stands behind a stove, feverishly stirring the roux of what will in a few hours become a remarkable gumbo.

title: Devils' Breakthrough In 3d Period Is Decisive
description: In a game that had all the ingredients of a playoff encounter between two of the National Hockey League's elite teams, the Devils stifled the Red Wings' attack, patiently put pressure on Detroit goaltender Chris Osgood, then scored three goals in the third period for a 3-1 victory last night at Continental Arena.

title: Of Phones and Software
description: To the Editor:

title: Feinstein to Stay Out of Race for Governor
description: Ending months of speculation, Senator Dianne Feinstein announced today that she would not run for governor of California this year, despite public opinion polls that showed her as the consistent front-runner and despite encouragement by Democrats from President Clinton down that she could help their party retake the leadership of the nation's most populous state.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 2d Suspect Held in Killing Of Detective in Drug Sting
description: A second suspect in the killing of an undercover police detective was charged last night with second-degree murder. The detective was shot dead on Monday night during a ''buy and bust'' drug operation in the Bronx that was part of the investigation of a previous killing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTH, SAMUEL
description: WORTH-Samuel. The Hollis Hills Jewish Center expresses our profound sorrow upon the passing of our esteemed past-president, Samuel Worth. We offer our deepest prayers for comfort to his beloved wife, Goldie, and family.

title: To Boldly Go Where Fish Haven't; Testing Feasibility of Piscine Farms for Space Voyages
description: In a Brooklyn College laboratory where thousands of fish swim endlessly in hundreds of tanks, a poster shows a rocket blasting off. ''Going to Work in Space,'' it says.

title: Number on Welfare Rolls Dips Below 10 Million
description: The number of people on Federal welfare rolls has dropped below 10 million for the first time in more than 25 years, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Why Students Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: A Novelist's Son Pleads In Stolen Property Case
description: The son of a popular New York novelist pleaded guilty yesterday to possession of stolen property in connection with the 1996 slaying of Angel Melendez, a one-time fixture of the city nightclub scene.

title: Still in the 60's and Groovy, Baby
description: Question Mark and the Mysterians performed at Coney Island High on Saturday night as if they had popped out of a 1960's time capsule. Question Mark, whose original name was Rudy Martinez, had shoulder-length hair, sunglasses and a frilly cuffed orange shirt; in motor-mouthed raps between songs he declared everything ''groovy'' and called the audience ''baby.'' The band members have been with Question Mark since the 1960's, and his songs were full of the mixture of cockiness, lust, frustration, nasal vocals and insistent, organ-driven two-chord vamps that made them punk progenitors.

title: Indonesian Currency Continues to Plunge
description: The Indonesian rupiah plunged for a fifth day today as foreign and local investors sold the currency, rejecting President Suharto's plans to serve a seventh term in office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCH, FREDA DIAMOND
description: BARUCH-Freda Diamond. The Board, staff and entire League Treatment Center family extend our deepest sympathy to the family of Freda Diamond Baruch, who was a member of our board of Trustees for many years. Freda was an outstanding designer. Her elegance was matched by her devotion to our handicapped children. Bernice Sherman, Board of Trustees Hannah Achtenberg Kinn, Executive Director

title: Zany Vignettes and Heartbreak on Hong Kong's Neon Streets
description: ''Fallen Angels'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 7. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, JEROME S.
description: EISENBERG-Jerome S., 76, died Jan. 18th, 1998. A kind, loving and generous man. We will miss your warmth and laughter. Cherished husband of Rosalind for fifty years. Loving father of Shelley and Neil. Devoted grandfather of Michael and Jennifer. Also survived by brothers Robert and Alan

title: Sugihara's List: A Drama Of 6,000 Jews Rescued
description: In August 1940, with the city of Kaunas, Lithuania, in turmoil, Jewish refugees from Poland frantically crowded the courtyard of the Japanese consulate hoping to obtain visas to escape from the Nazis. The Japanese consul, Chiune Sugihara, took what turned out to be a noble and historic step. Acting against the orders of his Government, which was still neutral, he began issuing transit visas.

title: Pataki Budget Seeks 7.6% Spending Rise
description: Reversing course from the austerity program he brought to office three years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York yesterday proposed a 7.6 percent rise in state spending for this coming election year.

title: Suharto Picks A Likely Heir As President Of Indonesia
description: President Suharto gave a strong hint today that his choice as his next Vice President and potential successor was a longtime aide who holds the post of Minister of Research and Technology.

title: Good-News Budget
description: In his first three years in office, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed some of the most contentious state budgets of the last 50 years: ideological cauldrons bubbling with demands for huge cuts in health care, welfare and education, along with tuition hikes at public universities and massive tax cuts.

title: In New York City Drug War, Risky Tactics and Casualties
description: Its war on crime increasingly focused on ridding neighborhoods of drugs, the New York City Police Department finds itself forced to confront drug dealers at their last sanctuary: inside apartment buildings, where suspicious sellers now commonly pat down their customers and subject them to intense scrutiny.

title: Despite Asian Crisis, 3 Securities Firms Post Strong Earnings
description: Despite the chaos that roiled Asian financial markets late last year, American securities firms continued to report strong earnings for the fourth quarter of 1997, as three big brokerage houses announced their results yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, THEODORE
description: PRATT-Theodore. On January 15, 1998, of San Diego, CA, formerly of Lindamoor Estate, Annapolis, MD. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor Wilcoxs Pratt of San Diego, CA; brother, Merrick Pratt and wife Lillian Veret Pratt of Highlands, NJ; sister, Mary Pratt Boyd and her husband Edwin Boyd of Vero Beach, FL and Richmond, VA; children, Theodore Pratt III and wife Elina Hum Pratt of Manassas, VA, Katherine Pratt and her daughter Kirsten Todd Pratt of Harwood, MD, Stephen Pratt and wife Cynthia Bailey Pratt and their daughter Elizabeth Pratt of Salisbury, MD, Laurian Pratt and her husband Frank Fasano and their son David Fasano of Bethesda, MD. A Memorial service will be held Friday, January 23, 1998, 10 A.M., First Presbyterian Church, Conduit and Duke of Gloucester St., Annapolis, MD. Minister Winslow Shaw, officiating. A graveside memorial in Glen Cove, Long Island, NY, will be held in the Spring. In lieu of flowers, it would be appreciated if donations could be made to the National Sjogren's Syndrome Association. (1-800395-6772).

title: BUTTREY AGREES TO $134 MILLION DEAL WITH ALBERTSON'S
description: The Buttrey Food and Drug Stores Company said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Albertson's Inc. for $15.50 a share, or $134 million. Buttrey, based in Great Falls, Mont., operates a chain of 43 stores in Montana, North Dakota and Wyoming. It had $292 million in revenue in the nine months ended Nov. 1. Its shares shot up almost 42 percent, rising $4.50, to $15.25, on the Nasdaq stock market. Albertson's, based in Boise, Idaho, is a food and drug retailer with 860 stores. For the nine months ended Oct. 30, it reported $10.9 billion in revenue. Buttrey said that its largest shareholder, an affiliate of the private investment firm Freeman Spogli & Company, had agreed to tender its 4.4 million shares, or 50.8 percent, of Buttrey's stock.

title: Stocks Up in Japan, Helped by Wall Street's Gain
description: Japanese stocks rose today for a sixth day, helped by Wall Street's gains and the possibility of additional measures to invigorate the domestic economy.

title: Labor Secretary's Private Labors
description: ALEXIS M. HERMAN, the Secretary of Labor, began by saying that she had intended to tell her lunchtime audience at Good Housekeeping magazine what was on her mind. Then she said that she had thought better of doing that.

title: Reality Check for the Mythic Mahler
description: MAHLER

title: Benes Is Considering An Offer From Mets
description: The Mets have always said that their interest in Andy Benes was conditional. They would like the right-handed pitcher, but only at the right price. Now it is up to the free agent to decide whether the Mets' offer is good enough.

title: Falwell to Mobilize Support for Israel
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said yesterday that he and several leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention had told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that they would mobilize evangelical churches to oppose the giving up of any more territory to the Palestinians.

title: Journal; Back To the Future
description: Before she found her current 15 minutes of fame as Paula Jones's camera-hogging front woman, Susan Carpenter-McMillan did the same for the anti-abortion crusade. As media rep for the Right to Life League of Southern California, she was a fixture on TV and radio, describing abortion as America's Holocaust. Her position was absolute: She opposed abortion as a legal choice, even for victims of rape and incest.

title: Simply Look Homeward, Terrell
description: The world came to old Lincoln High School here today reporters and television cameras from Japan and Washington and San Francisco and so many other places -- to see Terrell Davis and his old jersey, No. 7, retired. Davis, the Denver Broncos' super running back who now wears No. 30, took a break from preparing for Super Bowl XXXII to take a bow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMERSTEIN, ANNA
description: SOMMERSTEIN-Anna. On January 19, 1998. Loving and beloved wife of the late Heinrich. Very devoted mother of Helen and son-inlaw George Sadow. Loving and supportive grandmother of Jackie and Sharon and grandmother-inlaw of David Akselrad and Andy Alper, great grandmother of Karen, Brian, Jennifer and Melissa, who brought naches to her in her later years. Her loving and loved brother Sasha Kern and his family. Always welcomed in their hearts and homes by the entire Shapiro family. Remembering and remembered by all her kaffeklatch friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINITSKY, CHAIM
description: VINITSKY-Chaim. The Officers, Trustees and Staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee express their deep sorrow at the loss of Chaim Vinitsky, known as ''Mr. Israel'' by so many JDC, UJA, and top Federation leaders. A man of warmth, decency and caring, he labored valiantly for the unity of the Jewish people. His love of Israel was contagious. He will be missed. Condolences to his widow, Pnina, and family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Exec VP Ambassador Milton A. Wolf Chairman of the Board

title: For a Bronco, History Can Be a Losing Battle
description: If the Denver Broncos lose Super Bowl XXXII, offensive guard Mike Lodish would make history. He would become what is believed to be the second player to lose all five Super Bowl games he has appeared in.

title: 2 Buyout Firms Make Deal To Acquire Regal Cinemas
description: The movie theater business has captivated two of the nation's largest and savviest leveraged buyout firms, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, which will join forces to form the world's largest chain of movie theaters. But their agreement, announced yesterday, raises the prices for theaters to a level that many in the business called hard to justify at a time when a multiplex building binge has already given the nation too many screens.

title: TV Notes; 'Sanders' Going But Not Quietly
description: Jeff Bewkes, the chairman of HBO, stood in front of a roomful of television writers late Monday and announced that this season would be the last for ''The Larry Sanders Show,'' HBO's signature comedy starring the neurotic comedian Garry Shandling as the neurotic late-night talk show host Larry Sanders.

title: Don't Let Unabom Suspect Take Over Defense; Limited Examples
description: To the Editor:

title: After 2 Decades, a New Transit System Map
description: The straphanger's universe just got a little busier, a little more colorful and a lot bigger, at least on paper. This week, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is rolling out what it calls, somewhat unhumbly, The Map, the first major redesign of the familiar subway map in nearly 20 years.

title: Lawyers for Kaczynski Agree He Is Competent to Stand Trial
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski is competent to stand trial on charges that he is the Unabomber, defense lawyers conceded today. Then, with that issue resolved, the Federal judge in the case suggested that he would keep the current defense team in place and hold Mr. Kaczynski to an agreement to use a mental-illness defense at least in the penalty phase of his trial, which is to begin on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEDDINI, LINDA
description: BEDDINI-Linda. July 31, 1947-January 21, 1991. Dear Lindy, We miss you more and more. Love, Mom and Laura

title: Small Progress in U.N.'s Chasm With Iraq
description: The Iraqis and the chief United Nations weapons inspector made some progress in talks today, but Iraq is clinging to what the inspections chief, Richard Butler, called ''disarmament by declaration,'' refusing to provide further documentation to back its assertions that certain weapons have been eliminated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, HYMAN
description: TAUB-Hyman. Of the Bronx on January 19. Loving husband of Sally. Devoted father of Joel and Richard Taub, Beth and Mark Grossman. Brother of Sylvia Lupo. He is also survived by four grandchildren. Services will be held at the Garlick Riverside Chapel, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx on Wednesday at 11:30 A.M. Interment will be in Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODOLITZ, ABRAHAM
description: RODOLITZ-Abraham. Beloved husband of almost 57 years to Anna. Father of Eileen, Gary, Jerry, Bruce and Scott. Fatherin-law to their respective spouses, and loving grandfather to ten grandchildren. Died suddenly on January 20. Immeasureably loved and admired by family and friends. He will be sorely missed. Funeral services conducted from ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. on Friday, January 23 rd. at 9:30 A.M. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. Family will observe shiva at the residence from Friday, January 23rd until Thursday evening January 29th.

title: New Partner at Parkside
description: Gilbert F. Amelio, who resigned as chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc. last summer, has joined the Parkside Group of San Francisco, a private equity investment firm. Mr. Amelio will serve as a partner and a member of its board. The Parkside Group was founded by Barry L. Schneider in April 1997 after the sale of his company, MSA Industries, a commercial floor covering company, to E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. Parkside is planning to make acquisitions in a variety of industries.

title: Republicans Present Schools Bill Calling for Teacher Testing
description: Congressional Republicans, most of them die-hard opponents of national tests for students, today called for regular testing of teachers. But they said even those exams, while needed to reassure parents, should not be mandatory.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 14-Year-Old Is Wounded As He Plays With an Uzi
description: A 14-year-old boy was critically injured yesterday afternoon when the Uzi machine gun he and two teen-age friends were playing with in Harlem accidentally fired and struck him in the abdomen, the police said.

title: Earnings Climb 12% at Lockheed Martin
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said today that earnings before gains and charges rose 12 percent in the fourth quarter, lifted by more than $800 million in payments received for three important military contracts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. We mourn the death of Cameron, the beloved son of our friend and board member, Blair Clark. We extend our sympathies to Blair and to all of Cameron's family. The Board of Overseers and Staff Brookdale Center On Aging of Hunter College

title: Rutgers Drops 4th in Row, but Not Quietly
description: After watching a more talented West Virginia team hand Rutgers its fourth straight Big East loss tonight, Scarlet Knights Coach Kevin Bannon said he was proud that his team did not quit. Then he issued a warning to the 12 teams that sit above Rutgers in the conference.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Trusts Are Making Strides as Investors in New York Buildings
description: During the early part of this decade, Lawrence H. Feldman, chairman of what was then called Feldman Equities, was anguishing over missed opportunities. He could see that there were Manhattan buildings that could benefit from his upgrading formula available at attractive prices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLAUSTEIN, SOL LARRY
description: BLAUSTEIN-Sol Larry. 1/20/09-7/12/69. Dearest Dad, we love and miss you very much. Adrienne, Hank and Frank. Miriam, Simcha and Anna would have loved you too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CHARLES
description: SMITH-Charles. The administration and staff of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center (SLRHC) and Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) join with the leadership of their parent, Greater Metropolitan Health Systems (GMHS), in extending sympathy to our colleague and friend, Shelley Mayer, vice president of government and community relations, on the death of her beloved father-in-law, Charles Smith. To Shelley, her husband, Lee, their children, and loved ones, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Robert G. Newman, M.D., President, GMHS Ronald C. Ablow, M.D., President, SLRHC Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President, BIMC Kathleen McGovern, Vice President of Public Affairs and Marketing, SLRHC and BIMC

title: New Arena Opens for An Old Foe
description: The Tigers play their first game Friday night in the $55.3 million World Arena, which will seat 7,343 for hockey. During the four years that the new arena was being planned and built, the Tigers' home ice was the nearby Air Force Academy rink, and they did well there with an .803 winning percentage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBETT, JOHN T.
description: CORBETT-John T. (Retired Printer NYC). On January 20, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Florence, dear uncle of Delphine and Julian Covell. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Ave at 97 St, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial, Friday, 10:15 AM, St. Patrick's Church.

title: TRIZECHAHN TO OFFER STAKE IN BARRICK GOLD TO PUBLIC
description: The TrizecHahn Corporation, a Canadian real estate concern, said yesterday that it would sell its interest in the Barrick Gold Corporation in a public offering valued at $516.9 million. About 28.1 million Barrick shares, equal to a 7.5 percent stake, will be sold for $26.40 (Canadian) each, the equivalent of $18.48 (United States), TrizecHahn said. The sale is part of TrizecHahn's plan to convert assets other than real estate into cash to be invested in its core business. About $15.80 (Canadian) of the share price will be paid on closing, TrizecHahn said. The balance will be payable in one year. Both companies are based in Toronto.

title: Students' Risky Foreign Trips
description: The rape of five college students on a winter break study trip in Guatemala is a nightmare and a tragedy. It is also a warning that foreign trips must be carefully planned to eliminate unnecessary risks, and it is not yet clear whether the sponsoring college did so. But the assault is not a reason to cut back on schools' foreign study programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, MILTON L.
description: WEISSMAN-Milton L. To my most dearest father and friend. One final goodbye. I love you forever. Your son, Steve

title: Cowbells, big TV, chocolate kisses, live bulls, cancan: After money, Wall Street loves publicity.
description: A FEW months ago, the streets around the New York Stock Exchange were cordoned off so that Gap Inc. could set up a huge Sony Jumbotron television to show commercials from its new marketing campaign.

title: Diamondbacks and Springer Make a Deal
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks have not played a game, but they got their initiation into the January phase of the economic part of baseball yesterday. The Diamondbacks reached an agreement with Russ Springer, one of three players they exchanged salary arbitration figures with the day before.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: POUND WEAKENS. The dollar rose against the pound after the governor of Britain's central bank said the strength of the pound was complicating the bank's work. A stronger pound helps cut inflation but also makes British exports less competitive and curbs economic growth.

title: Sports of The Times; When Old Ballplayers Are in Need of Help
description: ''GENTLEMEN,'' or ''Dear Sir,'' the letters begin, and then the stories of needy people pour out: one must have a prostate operation but can't afford it, another has a wife who needs a double mastectomy and hip replacement, another is on the verge of suicide. And there are phone calls: ''Joe, this is embarrassing because I don't like to ask for help, but -- '' and then one after the other tell their improbable stories, improbable because most of them were major league ballplayers, American heroes or icons, basking in glory for a game, for a season, for a decade.

title: Mehta's Way to Carnegie: Patience, Patience, Patience
description: Zubin Mehta, the Yiddish-speaking, Bombay-born conductor from Los Angeles who says he is really Viennese at heart (but is taking over the Munich opera later this year), is back in New York this week with his Israel Philharmonic Orchestra filled with Russians.

title: For an Astronaut-to-Be, Teaching Remains No. 1
description: Although Barbara Morgan will be trained as an astronaut to venture into space, she made it clear today that she is first, and foremost, a schoolteacher.

title: Comcast to Buy Globalcom
description: The Comcast Corporation, a cable operator, agreed today to buy Globalcom Telecommunications Inc., a long-distance provider operating mainly in the Northeastern United States. Financial terms were not disclosed. Globalcom, based in Philadelphia, will operate as Comcast Telecommunications and will manage all Comcast's telecommunications products and services. They include long-distance service, business phone equipment, digital and analog cellular, paging and wireless data.

title: Can Prenatal Music Create Little Leonardos?; Prize for Starving Artists
description: To the Editor:

title: The Map To End All
description: Need to go from the Bronx to the New Jersey shore? Staten Island to Westchester? With the first major redesign of New York City's subway map in nearly 20 years, riders should be able to do just that. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will begin distributing The Map this week. It includes the entire M.T.A. system, including the bus connections that are available at all the major subway stations. Page B4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBER, ALAN E.
description: COBER-Alan E. We are profoundly saddened by the untimely death of our colleague and friend. His spirit, energy and humor, as well as devotion to his family will always be remembered. A world renowned illustrator and visual journalist, he was best known for his work in many national magazines and newspapers. He faced adversity squarely and lived life to the fullest. Alan, you will be greatly missed. Members of the Clay Art Center Port Chester, New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, HUBERT JAMES
description: BURKE-Hubert James. On January 19, 1998. Loving husband of the late Catherine. Devoted father of Kathleen and Edward. Proud grandfather of Olivia Catherine and Dylan. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20 St), NYC Wednesday, 25 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10AM at the Immaculate Conception Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Saint Francis' Bread Line, Saint Francis of Assisi Church, 135 West 35 St, NY, NY 10001 will be appreciated.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This isn't like George Bush saying, 'I don't like broccoli.' ''

title: Eating Well; Serving No Swordfish
description: FOR several years, Americans have been warned not to eat swordfish more than once a week because of the potential for mercury poisoning. Now, they may have a reason not to eat swordfish at all: population levels are in serious decline, and unless measures are taken, there may not be a commercial swordfish industry in 10 years.

title: Music Shaped by a Flurry of Changes
description: Evolution in nature does not occur in a straight line. The same is true of evolution in music, which is the point the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has been trying to make in a concert series called Musical Evolutions: 1887-1920. These were years of turbulent change in music. But the changes were coming from every which way, as the concert on Sunday afternoon, presenting the Orion String Quartet and the pianist Peter Serkin, suggested.

title: Teacher Loses Case Claiming Bias Based On Marriage
description: A biology professor who has been fighting her denial of tenure by Vassar College for the last 13 years lost a final appeal today when the Supreme Court refused to review her claim that she was the victim of discrimination against married women in the sciences.

title: Pataki's 1994 Fund-Raising Is Under Investigation
description: Federal prosecutors have begun an inquiry into fund-raising for Gov. George E. Pataki's 1994 election campaign, investigating whether potential donors were promised favors from the state government in return for campaign contributions, officials involved in the case said tonight.

title: A New Cuisine From a Land Called Oz
description: ON my first trip to Australia, in 1968, I got stuck overnight in an outback mining town called Mount Isa. The motel manager sent me for dinner to the Finnish Cafe, which may have been the only restaurant in town; I don't remember. But I remember the menu: ''Steak, steak with onions, steak with one egg, steak with two eggs.''

title: Cuban Church: It's Weak but Unified
description: When Pope John Paul II arrives in Cuba today, he will encounter a Roman Catholic Church vastly weakened under Fidel Castro's rule, shoved by the Government to the margins of Cuban society since before the Second Vatican Council, which introduced sweeping reforms into Catholicism worldwide.

title: Overseers Are Asked To Let Ex-President Remain in Teamsters
description: Having been barred from running for re-election, Ron Carey, the teamsters' president, began a last-ditch effort today to salvage his reputation and save himself from being expelled from the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Monsanto Says Herbicide Sales Lifted Fourth-Quarter Earnings
description: The Monsanto Company said today that earnings before extraordinary items more than doubled during the fourth quarter, in line with expectations, lifted by increased sales of its Roundup herbicide and pharmaceutical products. On a net basis, the company swung to a profit from a loss a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPTEKMAN, HAROLD
description: OPTEKMAN - Harold. Admired and respected pharmacist, devoted husband of Annette, beloved father of Arline and Richard Golby, Stephanie and Stuart Saft, and Bonnie Optekman, dear brother of Miriam Wilens and Isabel Schneider, adored grandfather of Stacy Schneid, Barbara Golby, Brad and Gordon Saft, cherished great grandfather of Craig and Sarah Schneid. Services on Wednesday at 12 noon at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Just a Nonartist in the Art World, but Endlessly Seen and Cited
description: In the tradition of the painter's painter or the poet's poet, M. C. Escher is the nonartist's nonartist. The space-twisting, mind-bending images of this Dutch printmaker rank among the 20th century's most popular.

title: Foreign Writers Join Critics Circle List
description: For the first time, foreign authors, including Mario Vargas Llosa, Doris Lessing and J. M. Coetzee, are among the finalists for the National Book Critics Circle Awards.

title: Coca-Cola Flexes Muscle for a Blitz
description: The Coca-Cola Company is beginning a monthlong marketing blitz that includes advertising during high-profile events like Super Bowl XXXII and the Winter Olympics.

title: TV Notes; Snoopy Season
description: Nickelodeon says that it has acquired 63 ''Peanuts'' cartoon specials, including a series originally televised in the 1970's called ''Snoopy and Charlie Brown.'' Missing from the acquisition, said Herb Scannell, president of the cable network, were two of the best-known Peanuts specials, for Halloween (''The Great Pumpkin'') and Christmastime. ''CBS still has them,'' he said, ''But I can tell you, we have our eyes on them. We want them.''

title: Political Memo; Jones's Suit to Test Clinton's Resilience
description: As President Clinton turned back to official responsibilities today, the Middle East crisis may have had an inviting ring after the harrowing weekend for the Administration in which the President finally had to face Paula Corbin Jones and her sexual misconduct lawsuit.

title: In Williams vs. Williams, Big Sister Moves Ahead
description: Their beads fell from their Technicolor cornrows and littered the stadium floor. It was proof that meeting your sister in the second round of your first visit to the Australian Open is an unraveling experience, even for the poised and powerful Williams sisters, who have joint designs on the No. 1 ranking now owned by yet another overachieving teen-ager, Martina Hingis.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on the Public Lives page yesterday about the treasurer of the United Federation of Teachers, who is running for the union presidency, misstated her family name at some points. As noted elsewhere in the article, she is Randi Weingarten, not Weinstein.

title: Whitman Vetoes a Bill On Hospital Conversions
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman failed to sign a bill yesterday that would have regulated hospitals seeking to convert from charitable to for-profit status.

title: 1987 Grand Jury Report Is Read at Brawley Trial
description: Doctors, the police and friends of Tawana Brawley were among the sources quoted in an exhaustive 170-page grand jury report read aloud in court yesterday that found Ms. Brawley's 1987 claims of abduction and rape to be a hoax.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOSEPH S.
description: MURPHY-Joseph S. Charismatic and wonderfully accessible to students and staff, Joseph S. Murphy was the outgoing and dynamic 5th President of Queens College. It was a terrible blow to all of us to learn of the accidental death of so vital and accomplished a friend and colleague. The College has suffered an irreparable loss. We mourn him deeply. He brought to our campus his compassionate concerns evident during his service in the Peace Corps and posts in Federal Service. He was a man of ideas and a man of action; a political scientist as a well as a philospher. He was deeply committed to the well-being of working people, particularly those struggling to win an education while earning a living. His Queens College Presidency was marked by stirring challenges from students and the community, and by fiscal emergencies. He was determined, he said, to invest ''a good piece of my life in Queens College to let the City learn how good the school is.'' A strong and determined man of the world and of our times, he left Queens College a legacy of caring and commitment. Allen Lee Sessoms, President The Entire Queens College Community

title: Spending Rise Of 7% Sought In Pataki Plan
description: Reversing course from the austere program he brought to office three years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed an election-year budget today that is 7.6 percent larger than the last, swelled by a major rise in school spending that was agreed to last year and new increases for education and health care.

title: Merry Land Acquisition
description: The Merry Land and Investment Company said today that it had agreed to acquire as many as 13 Florida apartment communities from the Trammell Crow Company's residential unit and its affiliates for $248 million. The properties include 4,000 units primarily in Tampa, Orlando and Jacksonville. Merry Land, based in Augusta, is a real estate investment trust. Trammell Crow is a real estate services company based in Dallas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOPER, SAMUEL, ESQ.
