description: KOOPER-Samuel, Esq. The Hollis Hills Jewish Center expresses profound sorrow on the passing of our esteemed past-president, Samuel Kooper, Esq. We offer our deepest prayers for comfort to his beloved wife and past-president of Sisterhood, Natalie, and family.

title: Moya and Philippoussis Make Disappointing Exits
description: Last year Carlos Moya took his Cinderella run in the Australian Open all the way to the final round. It was the best result ever for Moya, a Spanish heartthrob who was a virtual nobody until he knocked off the defending champion Boris Becker in the opening round, but it was one he has failed to replicate at ensuing Grand Slam events -- this year's Australian Open included.

title: Rockers Lead New Wave of Anti-Abortion Fight
description: Teen-age boys in spiked hair and girls in nose rings stepped into the church basement carrying their admission fee of $4 and a jar of baby food. When the concert started, the punk and hard-core bands unleashed deafening waves of sound. But in breaks, the rockers preached against abortion and welcomed to the stage a young organizer, the second generation in her family to help lead the fight against abortion.

title: Metro Business; Cablevision Official Quits
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, N.Y., said yesterday that its chief operating officer, Robert May, had resigned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUGO, ALFREDO
description: LUGO-Alfredo. On January 28, 1998. Beloved father of Christine. Loving son of Herminia Lugo (nee Sule). Fond brother of Raul, Johnny, Robert, Tyrone, Myrna, Minnerva, Evelyn and Marina. Cherished grandfather of Christopher. Funeral from Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, NY, Friday 10AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. James E. McQuade, Director.

title: After the Creation, the Details
description: Having recreated the universe with the help of Haydn's oratorio ''The Creation'' last week, Robert Shaw and his choral workshop put the new gizmo through its annual paces on Sunday afternoon, performing Haydn's other great oratorio, ''The Seasons,'' at Carnegie Hall. This is the first time Mr. Shaw's New York workshop has generated two public concerts, and there might have been a slight sense of anti climax in the performance, as there has always been in ''The Seasons'' itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSL, ROBERT A.
description: KASSL-Robert A. We note with profound sorrow the death of Robert A. Kassl, President of Karey-Kassl Corporation. Devoted husband of Joan-Marie. Loving father of Robert N. and Marliese. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Adam, Katherine, Thomas, and Bradley. He was deeply admired and respected by all whose lives he touched. A loving, compassionate, fair-minded human being who will be sorely missed by his family, relatives and many friends. Our loss is Heaven's gain.

title: Pope vs. Embargo: Still a Sharp Divide in U.S.
description: Pope John Paul II will soon add his voice to a growing chorus calling for an end to the United States' economic embargo against Cuba. But the debate that he will be joining is an old one, and opinions in the White House and Congress are deeply entrenched.

title: The Hottest Lunch In New York: The Sandwich
description: LIKE soup kiosks in the afterglow of their ''Seinfeld'' embrace, the sandwich field is booming, catering to an accelerating appetite for anything that can be amicably placed between two slices of bread.

title: SmithKline and American Home Are Talking of Huge Drug Merger
description: Ending a week of market speculation, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. and the American Home Products Corporation confirmed yesterday that they were considering the largest corporate merger ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, EDWARD
description: GOTTLIEB-Edward. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of The Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute are saddened by the passing of Edward Gottlieb, distinguished Trustee, committed friend and loyal benefactor of the hospital. His lifetime of dedicated work, encouragement and philanthropic support of our major initiatives will always be remembered. His friends and colleagues at HJD grieve his passing as they celebrate his exemplary life. We extend our condolences to his wife, Janet, his children, Elizabeth and Richard, and to the entire Gottlieb family. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman of the Board Victor H. Frankel, M.D., President John N. Kastanis, FACHE Chief Executive Officer Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARREN, ROSE
description: HARREN - Rose. Riverdale Temple congregational family mourns the passing of Rose Harren, beloved mother of their devoted Board Member, Jill Shaifer, and extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Stephen D. Franklin Sol Blumenstock, President

title: Scientists Announce Births of Cows Cloned in New Way
description: First Dolly the sheep, now Charlie and George the calves. Two long-lashed, week-old, genetically engineered Holsteins became the latest cloning sensations today when scientists announced that the animals had been given life using an efficient new method that offers the hope of broad and lucrative medical benefits.

title: St. John's Is Confidently Looking Ahead
description: After his team lost to Louisville earlier this month, St. John's Coach Fran Fraschilla deviated from his usual practice of looking at the next game only, and told his players to look ahead on the schedule and ponder the possibilities. At the time the Red Storm was mired in a two-game slump, was off to a 1-3 start in the Big East Conference and looked dead in the water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCIANI, ROSE L.
description: LUCIANI-Rose L. On January 19, 1998 of Bayside, New York. Loving wife of the late Thomas; dear mother Lorraine Ralph. Also survived by four granddaughters and great grandmother to Kade and Kelly. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Friday, 9:45 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUYLER, PEARL
description: SCHUYLER-Pearl. We grieve the loss of a remarkable woman whose love and loyalty to family and friends will always be remembered. Adolfo and Allan

title: Don't Let Unabom Suspect Take Over Defense; Grasping the Charges
description: To the Editor:

title: David (Junior) Kimbrough, 67, a Blues Musician
description: David (Junior) Kimbrough, a Mississippi bluesman who ran his own juke joints for more than 30 years, died on Saturday in Holly Springs, Miss., where he lived. He was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFANI, EDWARD EZATOLLAH
description: SAFANI-Edward Ezatollah. Beloved husband of Fakhri. Devoted father of Lily and Alan. Loving grandfather of Maia and Darius. Passed away January 18, 1998. Funeral service will be held 11:30AM, Wednesday, January 21, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, NYC.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.B.M.'s Quarterly Results Tempered by Asia Warning

title: Public Advocate Says Hospital Accreditation System Is Faulty
description: Public Advocate Mark J. Green charged yesterday that shortcomings in the city's hospitals -- like poor patient care, overburdened residents and sloppy record-keeping -- are often overlooked because the national body that accredits health care institutions is far too accommodating to hospital administrators.

title: Lucent Profits Top Estimates
description: Regaining the vigor that marked its early days but had seemed absent recently, Lucent Technologies Inc. announced quarterly financial results yesterday that soundly beat the expectations of Wall Street analysts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOBODIEN, RICHARD P.
description: SLOBODIEN-Richard P., 63, of Livingston, NJ on Tuesday, January 20, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Sara (nee Kassover). Beloved father of Cindy Gordon and Keith Slobodien. Brother of Rhoda Wilentz; grandfather of Sean and Taylor Gordon, and Sayde, Rachel, Harrison Slobodien. Funeral from Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey, Wednesday 2:00 PM, January 21. Interment Beth Israel, Woodbridge. Donations may be made to the Daughter of Israel Geriatric Center, West Orange, New Jersey.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; G.M. is poking around Asia looking for good deals or alliances with beaten-down auto makers.
description: GENERAL MOTORS is kicking the tires of auto companies in Asia.

title: White House Will Reject Advice to Abolish Immigration Service, Officials Say
description: The White House is preparing to reject a Federal advisory commission's recommendation to abolish the troubled Immigration and Naturalization Service and assign its duties to other Government agencies, officials said today.

title: Newark Is Practical (and Symbolic) Answer to Logistical Puzzle
description: Why was Gov. Christine Todd Whitman inaugurated in Newark today? Mainly because the War Memorial in Trenton, where every inauguration has been held since 1932, was closed for renovations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPPINGER, JOSH
description: EPPINGER-Josh, on January 20, 1998. Husband of Mary, father of Nell, brother of Fred and Wendy, stepson of Consuelo Lilienthal of San Francisco and stepbrother of five. Interment private. Memorial service to be held in San Francisco this Spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNULTY, RAYMOND PATRICK
description: McNULTY-Raymond Patrick. On January 19, 1998, of New York City. Beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father and father-inlaw of Kevin and Mary, Diane and Jim Wolfe, Patricia and Gerald Langlade, and Maureen and Frank Pichl. Devoted grandfather to Jennifer and Juliette, Tommy Finn, Laura and Tracey, and Charlie, Tommy and Emma. Beloved brother-in-law of Frank and Jack Short. His rapier sharp wit and love of a good duel earned him the nickname ''The Swordsman''. He did it his way. Friends will be received at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, on January 21 and 22 from 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass January 23, 10 AM, Epiphany Church, 22 St. & 2 Ave.

title: Princeton Will Liberalize Its Financial-Aid Formulas
description: In a step indicative of the competition among top universities for middle- and lower-income students, Princeton University is liberalizing its financial aid policies, changing many loans to outright grants and altering its formula for calculating a family's ability to pay college bills.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE HIGHER. The price of the March coffee contract on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange jumped 11 cents, to $1.7805 a pound. Traders said the buying reflected expectations of shortages in the near term. But the price is expected to remain well below its recent high of $3 a pound.

title: KPMG Settling Suit by Teachers In California
description: KPMG Peat Marwick agreed yesterday to settle a class-action lawsuit filed on behalf of some 20,000 California teachers who contended that the accounting firm was not independent when it audited the financial books of real estate partnerships that the teachers had invested in.

title: Temptation; What They Decant For Breakfast In Napa Wine Country
description: CALISTOGA ROASTERY is on the main street of Calistoga, Calif., a Napa Valley town best known for its geyser, mud baths and proximity to world-class wineries. But some people think this little coffee house is really Calistoga's main claim to fame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLMAN, MARCELLE R.
description: COLMAN-Marcelle R. In North Branford, CT. Jan. 19, 1998 of 88 Notch Hill Rd., Evergreen Woods, North Branford, CT., formerly ofNew Rochelle, NY. Wife of the late Louis R. Colman. Survived by two daughters Nancy Colman and sonin-law Alex Reisman of Brisbane, CA. and Linda Colman and son-inlaw Sal Macri of New Haven, CT., a brother Albert Reichenberg of Troy, NY, and 3 grandchildren Jonah, Eli and Arielle Reisman of Brisbane, CA. For information Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church Street, Guilford, CT.

title: Bronco Linemen Open Up
description: The National Football League threatened to fine the Denver Broncos' offensive linemen if they didn't break their seasonlong vow of silence to the news media during Super Bowl week. But the league did not say the players had to be interesting.

title: Tomsk Journal; Siberia's Underground Man Emerges as a Gadfly
description: Defiance rolls like the Arctic wind across Siberia. It always has. People who live here -- and survive -- are tough and independent. Once the world's most brutal and expansive penal colony, it has become an unlikely haven for free thought.

title: NISSAN SUES TO BLOCK REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES' ACQUISITIONS
description: The Nissan Motor Company said yesterday that it had sued Republic Industries in an attempt to stop Republic's acquisition of two Florida Nissan dealerships. Nissan approved several earlier acquisitions of Nissan and Infiniti dealerships by Republic. Nissan said the Florida lawsuit came after a year of negotiations with Republic had broken off. The Honda Motor Company has a Federal suit against Republic pending, while the Toyota Motor Corporation recently settled several suits against it. Republic, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has become the world's largest car and truck seller in the last 13 months as it has agreed to acquire 269 dealerships for its Autonation USA retail chain.

title: A European Inquiry on Accounting Mergers
description: Giant mergers proposed by four of the Big Six accounting firms encountered a potentially serious roadblock today, when the European Commission's top antitrust official announced that he would conduct investigations of both deals.

title: Coke Unit Offers Buyback
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the Atlanta-based soft drink bottler and distributor, said today that it would reinstate its 30-million-share stock buyback program. Based on the company's stock price today of $35.875, the program represents more than $1.05 billion in stock. The company will begin by repurchasing 1.3 million shares over a 10-day period starting on Friday. Coca-Cola Enterprises said its board authorized the repurchase program in April 1996; however, because of acquisition activity at the time, the company did not repurchase any of its shares.

title: Game Plan for El Nino
description: With the game said to be worth more than $200 million to the local economy and San Diego fighting for the right to host Super Bowl XXXVI in 2002, weather understandably is a preoccupation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, LEONARD
description: FINKELSTEIN-Leonard. On Tuesday, January 20, 1998, of Old Bridge, NJ. Beloved long-time companion of Helen Klein, devoted father of Robin Finkelstein, Lauren Bar, and Robert Finkelstein, dear father-in-law of Ayel Bar, adored brother of Estelle Edelson. Funeral services conducted from The Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey, 11:30 A.M., on Wednesday, January 21, 1998. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey.

title: $25 and Under; His Own Dishes, at Last, in His Own Restaurant
description: IN the last few years, Alan Harding has run more than a few restaurant kitchens. He established his reputation as a creative cook in a stint at Nosmo King, the high-end health food restaurant that closed in 1995, and has since had brief turns at 9 Jones Street, La Petite Crevette and 131 Duane Street, none of which were completely happy experiences. Like most chefs employed by somebody else, he chafed at the demands of the owners.

title: Worn but Not Torn, Oakley Grinds It Out
description: The man with the body built like a Tonka truck continues to crash, roll and bang without so much as denting a fender, but habits and Charles Oakley are hard to break.

title: Political Litmus Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: So Much for the Respite; Isles Back in Trouble
description: BLACKHAWKS 5, ISLANDERS 2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTERSDORF, GUSTAV
description: MATTERSDORF-Gustav. Age 93 of Lakehurst, NJ, January 19, at home. Beloved husband of Doris Koedding Mattersdorf for 22 years. Mr. Mattersdorf was a CPA for the State of New York, Dept. of Labor, NYC, at the time of his retirement. He was Area Director Field Tax Service Man-Bronx Area (35 years retiring). Survived by stepson John F. Newman of Middletown, NJ; stepdaughter Carolyn R. Thomas of Roswell, GA; brother of the late Leo (1984); niece Stephanie of Jupiter, FL; 2 grandnephews and 1 grandniece. Service and burial private.

title: New Finding on Mixing Sexes in Military
description: Only a month after one advisory committee urged the Defense Department to separate men and women during much of their military training, another Pentagon panel has found that most members of the armed services actually want more integration of the sexes during their early months in uniform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTY, LINDA KITE PAKH
description: CANTY-Linda Kite Pakh. February 8, 1950-January 20, 1998. Beloved wife of David Canty, dearly loved by the Waldron, Gehlbach and Pakh families. Died at her home after a 10 year battle with cancer. Graduated from Northfield School, Middlebury College (1972) and New York University (MBA, Summa Cum Laude); received the Middlebury Alumni Achievement Award (1993). Vice President of The Bank of New York in the Multinational Group of the International Division, 1979-1989. Member ''Fang & Claw'' of New York. Linda bravely fought her disease, dancing, back packing, travelling, writing and volunteering to visit cancer patients. She and her husband were Amateur Over-35 North American Ballroom Champions, 1990-1992. She is survived by her husband David Canty of Manhattan, sisters Anne Waldron of West Chester, PA., and Carolyn Gehlbach of Commack, NY. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, Madison and 81 Street, Friday, January 23, 1-4PM. Memorial service following.

title: Wine Talk; A Writer Many French Chateau Owners Rely Upon
description: A TYPICAL wine writer was once described as someone with a typewriter who was looking for his name in print, a free lunch and a way to write off his wine cellar. It's a dated view. Wine writers now use computers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLARK, PAUL B. JR.
description: CLARK-Paul B. Jr. Memorial service for Paul B. Clark, Jr. will be held at 11am on Saturday, January 24 at Christ Church United Methodist, 520 Park Ave, NYC.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES A WEST BANK PLAN TO ISRAELI LEADER
description: President Clinton presented the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, with a detailed plan on Tuesday for the phased withdrawal of Israel from the West Bank. And at each step, Mr. Netanyahu made clear that Israeli redeployment depended on Palestinian compliance with Israeli demands, including protecting the rights of settlers and cracking down on terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAZEN, GEOFFREY DAVID
description: CHAZEN-Geoffrey David. Beloved husband of Jamie Rachel, father of Zoe Alexandra and Charlotte Annabel, died at age 39. According to his wishes, the family has donated his body to the Microbiology Dept. at NYU Medical Center. Shiva will be observed at 101 Central Park West. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan on Thursday afternoon; time and place to be announced.

title: About New York; Architecture Doesn't Stop At 96th Street
description: THE chorus girls on Broadway stood still as statues, but they made Michael Adams's eyes dance. He craned his neck to behold the slender, bare-chested figures that flanked the windows on the old Hamilton Theater on West 146th Street.

title: State Farm Lawsuit Says Ford Hid Risk Of Fire in Vehicles
description: State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, sued the Ford Motor Company yesterday, charging that the auto maker installed defective ignition switches in 26 million cars and then for years has continued to withhold information about the potential fire hazard from Federal officials and customers.

title: Don't Let Unabom Suspect Take Over Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korean Unions to Accept Some Layoffs
description: Labor leaders agreed for the first time late Tuesday that layoffs will be required to rescue South Korea's economy and to satisfy the International Monetary Fund's stringent conditions for a $57 billion bailout.

title: Talk of the Town: Burgers v. Oprah
description: This Texas Panhandle city proudly calls itself the cattle-feed-producing center of the world. A slaughterhouse is the largest private employer in town. Huge highway billboards for the Big Texan Steak Ranch offer a 72-ounce steak dinner free (to anyone who can consume it within an hour).

title: Don't Let Unabom Suspect Take Over Defense; Madmen Retain Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Crew Urges Summer Camp For 10,000
description: In an effort to extend schooling into the summer but shift it to a more bucolic setting, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he would like to send as many as 10,000 New York City public-school children to sleepaway camps in the Catskills and elsewhere each year, beginning this summer.

title: Executive Changes
description: CINCINNATI STOCK EXCHANGE, an electronic stock exchange with headquarters in Chicago, named David Colker, its chief operating officer, to the additional position of president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEISLER, FRANCES L.
description: GEISLER-Frances L. Beloved wife of Marvin. Devoted mother of Bruce Geisler and Laurie Donovan. Dear sister of Roseline Lissak. Cherished grandmother of Sarah. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. Graveside services today. Family will gather at ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Riverside Building), Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, NYC, at 12:30. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Corel, a Rival Of Microsoft, Had a Bad Year
description: The Corel Corporation, an Ottawa-based software company locked in a bruising battle with Microsoft for a share of the word-processing market, reported today that it lost $231.8 million in 1997, by far the worst performance since Corel was founded in 1985.

title: Sister of Dead Long Island Teen-Ager Offers Account of Killing in Exorcism
description: The Suffolk County District Attorney's office released a chilling first-person account today of the efforts of a Long Island woman to ''drive the demon'' from her 17-year-old daughter over a seven-hour period on Sunday that ended in the girl's death.

title: Metro Business; Sbarro Food Chain Gets a Buyout Offer
description: Sbarro Inc., the Commack, N.Y., restaurant chain, said yesterday that it had received a buyout offer from the founding Sbarro family for $380 million.

title: Queens Man Is Charged With Rape of 5-Year-Old
description: A 25-year-old man was arrested Monday in Corona, Queens, and charged with repeatedly raping and sodomizing a 5-year-old girl three times last October, the police said. The man, Victor Valle, was charged with three counts of rape, sodomy, sexual abuse, and endangering the welfare of a child.

title: COINMACH ACQUIRING MACKE LAUNDRY FOR $214 MILLION
description: The Coinmach Laundry Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Macke Laundry Service L.P. for about $214 million as part of its expansion into the Midwest. Coinmach, which provides laundry machines for apartment buildings, said the Chicago-based Macke would add about 236,000 machines, bringing its total to about 672,000. Coinmach, which is based in Roslyn, N.Y., said Macke, its seventh large acquisition in two years, had revenue of $122 million and $39 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for the year ended June 30. Shares of Coinmach rose $4.125, or 16 percent, to $28.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Seagate Posts a Lower-Than-Expected Loss
description: Seagate Technology Inc. reported a second-quarter loss yesterday that was less than analysts expected, though the maker of computer disk drives continues to be hurt by falling prices and weak demand for its products.

title: Looking Good, Eight Times Over
description: It is every well-dressed woman's nightmare: what to do when someone across the room is wearing the same dress you are wearing.

title: Sports of The Times; A Temporary Truce Fits Broncos' Plans
description: AT the end of a long news media session yesterday, the Denver Broncos, in bright blue-and-red jerseys, huddled for their Super Bowl photo. There was conviviality and laughter. Coach Mike Shanahan shared good-natured fun with his players and staff. Granted, laughter comes easy when you reach this level. But this seemed to be more than the surface camaraderie that accompanies winning. Denver seemed to be a team whose players enjoyed one another. Except for being all male, they were an ideal American mosaic: black, white and brown faces. A team. A family.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Abortion Debate Ignores the Alternatives; A Tactical Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Urges Funds for Cities And Open Land
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman pledged today in her second inaugural address to devote her next term to rebuilding neighborhoods in New Jersey's cities and protecting farmland and other open space from development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMER, HON. ZEVULUN
description: HAMMER-Hon. Zevulun. The Orthodox Union mourns the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague, Israel's Minister of Education and Culture, Deputy Prime Minister, head of the National Religious Party, a creative force for Torah education and the strengthening of Israel and its Torah community. May his family and all Israel be consoled among the mourners for Zion and Jerusalem. Mandell I. Ganchrow, M.D., Pres. Marcel Weber, Chairman Board of Directors Dr. Marcos Katz, Chairman Board of Governors Rabbi Raphael Butler, Executive Vice President Rabbi Pinchas Stolper, National Director, NCSY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MARION L.
description: MILLER-Marion L. On January 19, 1998. Beloved wife of James F. Miller, mother of Jacqueline Rice of Guilford, CT, grandmother of Shauna Rice of San Francisco, CA and Hilary Scott of Manhattan, MT. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the South Hampton Fresh Air Fund.

title: The Neediest Cases; Single Mother Struggles to Keep Her Children's Feet on the Ground
description: She was slight and shy, a 26-year-old mother of twin boys who worked in a shoe factory. He was a dapper, deferential limousine driver, the kind of man who gazed at his shoes in the presence of young women.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a Federal judge's dismissal of a libel suit over the film ''Donnie Brasco'' misstated the role of Barry Levinson. He was a producer of the movie, not its director.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL BUYS FRIGOSCANDIA FOR $395 MILLION
description: Security Capital Industrial Trust said yesterday that it had acquired Frigoscandia A.B. of Sweden, which owns 90 refrigerated warehouses in eight European countries, for $395 million. Security Capital, based in Aurora, Colo., owns industrial and warehouse properties in the United States and 21 other countries. The company said Frigoscandia's 15 percent market share in Europe is more than twice that of its largest competitor. The acquisition of Frigoscandia's 160.5 million cubic feet of distribution space increases the size of Security Capital's facilities to 263 million cubic feet in the United States and Europe. The stock of Security Capital rose 75 cents, to $25.625.

title: Can Prenatal Music Create Little Leonardos?
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Officer Is Charged In Assault on a Woman
description: An Elizabeth police officer, suspended last month after allegations that he broke into the home of a 66-year-old woman and attacked her for no reason, was charged yesterday with aggravated assault and trespassing.

title: For a Secular Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: A House Chief Limits Uses of Any Surplus
description: The chief tax writer in the House laid out a plan today to apportion any Federal budget surpluses equally between reducing the national debt and cutting taxes, saying he wanted to shrink the Government and keep any fiscal windfall out of the hands of those politicians who would spend it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELB, LEAH
description: GELB-Leah. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Max Gelb. Loving mother of Bernard and David. Cherished mother-in-law of Mimi and Carol. Devoted grandmother of Michael, Lauren and Alex. Dear sister of Dr. Ruth Lefkowitz. She was a founder and the first principal of the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester. She was also a past president of both the Alumni Association of the Seminary College of Jewish Studies and the Sisterhood of Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle. Services Thursday, 10AM, Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Virtuoso Who Riffs Over Borders and Embargoes
description: In his biography of Art Tatum, ''Too Marvelous for Words,'' James Lester struggles with a paucity of facts in trying to explain not how Tatum did what he did, but why. The best the biographer can do is to position Tatum as a unique creature: a displaced person, a kind of outsider keeping alive an old tradition (piano virtuosity) in an alien country (jazz).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EQUITY INNS INC., Memphis, , a hotel real estate investment trust, agreed to acquire at least 36 Hawthorne Suites hotels from U. S. Franchise Systems Inc., Atlanta, for undisclosed terms.

title: Liberties; Revenge on the Nerds
description: I figured things were way out of perspective in the Other Washington when I heard that Bill Gates had put an inscription from ''The Great Gatsby'' around the domed ceiling of the library in his new $100 million pad: ''He had come a long way to this blue lawn and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it.''

title: INSIDE
description: Support for Mixed Training

title: Cowen Is Rumored to Be on the Block
description: Cowen & Company, the New York investment bank, is considering putting itself up for sale, according to bankers involved in the matter.

title: Abortion Debate Ignores the Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes; Comedies to Go
description: With the start of television's midseason networks have begun cleaning house, sweeping some underachievers off their program schedules.

title: SUPER BOWL XXXII: One More Time, With Feeling; Elway's Brilliant Career With the Broncos Is Missing Only the Ultimate Triumph
description: The question to Denver quarterback John Elway was simple but hardly innocent.

title: Hitler's Genocide Order: 5 Days After Pearl Harbor?
description: For decades, it has been the ultimate enigma among historians of what the Nazis called the final solution: how can it be proved empirically that Hitler ordered the annihilation of Europe's Jews, and when did he do so?

title: Slain Detective Is Recalled as a Quiet Realist by Fellow Officers
description: Sean Carrington, the first New York City policeman killed in the line of duty this year, was remembered yesterday as a quiet man, not the edgy, confrontational sort common in undercover work.

title: On-Line Service Accuses Navy of Deception in Inquiry About Sailor
description: America Online today accused the Navy of deception after an internal investigation showed that the computer service company had violated its own rules and disclosed confidential information to the Navy that identified a 36-year-old sailor as homosexual.

title: A Movie Becomes Music to His Ears
description: Elmer Bernstein stood at the podium, staring a hole through the control booth window, jiggling his baton impatiently and listening for a signal from the earphones clamped to his skull. About five dozen musicians sat at their places in a semicircle around him, poised to play. ''Tape, please,'' he called out. ''Can anyone hear me? We're waiting for a tape signal.''

title: Arnott Breaks The Ice
description: Jason Arnott's ability to hold his ground in front of the opposing goal was one attribute that led the Devils to trade Bill Guerin and Valery Zelepukin to Edmonton on Jan. 4. He gave a good demonstration of that skill Tuesday night, when he scored the winning goal for the Devils against the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Knicks Team Up To Handle Pacers
description: It has not taken super glue, paper clips or a trade for a superstar to help the Knicks hold it together in Patrick Ewing's absence. The self-adhesive Knicks are doing it on their own.

title: Broker Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Case
description: A Manhattan real estate broker pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of insider trading stemming from the state prosecution of a former compliance worker at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Smith Barney Inc.

title: Iraq Orders Freeze on Arms Inspections
description: President Saddam Hussein has called for a freeze on all weapons inspections and even discussion of sites considered to be sensitive, Iraqi and United Nations officials said today.

title: Essay; Presume Innocence
description: Knowing full well that a firestorm was about to break out all around him, the President of the United States spent three and a half hours in two meetings with the Prime Minister of Israel sifting specific ways to renew negotiations.

title: Deal Called Off For Stoudamire
description: Damon Stoudamire, one of the National Basketball Association's smallest players, created a large stir around the league yesterday.

title: Currents; IN THE GARDEN -- Every Yard a Versailles?
description: Smith & Hawken, known for English garden tools that seem too pretty to soil, is branching out in its new catalogue with a few offers that might raise eyebrows, not plant beds. ''Create a Versailles in 10 square feet'' (right) is one tall order: it's really a formal garden-edging kit with steel corners (4 1/2 inches tall, $39 each), or a circle ($39) or 25-inch rosettes ($49). Plants not included. Like Louis XIV, why stop there? There is Gothic cast-iron edging (top, $49 for about six feet), prerusted ''to get a head start on nature.'' Mac Griswold, a garden writer, confided, ''It's a color all gardeners love, a sort of off-dirt hue.''

title: Victim Alive After Suspect Is Charged With Murder
description: Sixteen hours after the police charged a 28-year-old Queens man with murdering a missing 13-year-old girl, the girl abruptly returned to her grief-stricken family's home last night, the police said.

title: Lawyers Say Kaczynski Can Represent Himself at Trial
description: A day after the judge in the Unabom trial suggested that he might bar Theodore J. Kaczynski from representing himself, prosecutors and defense lawyers said today that Mr. Kaczynski appeared to have a constitutional right to handle his own case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZ, WILLIAM J.
description: HOLTZ-William J. Loving husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Alan, Elliot and Jodi. Beloved son of Beatrice and the late Jack. Dear brother of Martin and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Barrie, Rachel, Adam and Courtney. Contributions may be made to the Coop Care Unit of NYU Medical Center of The American Cancer Society, Long Island Division. Services will held today at 12:30 P.M., at Temple Beth Sholom of Smithtown. Interment to follow at the Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIORE, JAMES M. JR.
description: FIORE-James M. Jr. 1947-1984. You are sadly missed along life's way; quietly remembered everyday. No longer in our lives to share, but in our hearts you're always there. Beloved son, rest in peace Mom and Dad.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: A Crisis From Petty Sources
description: There is a general reluctance to have the private life of any President become a matter of public inquiry. In some quarters there is a willingness to believe that Kenneth Starr, the Whitewater Independent Counsel, has a vendetta against this President and that the far right's backing of Paula Jones is designed to destroy his Presidency. Yet the political good will that normally flows toward the White House is constantly being blocked in Mr. Clinton's case by reports -- unproven, but disturbingly persistent -- of unrestrained personal behavior and of fund-raising that flouted the law. More seriously, this Administration repeatedly forces its supporters to choose between loyalty and respect for the law.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column of the Westchester section on Sunday about an exhibition of photographs by James Van Der Zee at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers misstated the date of a lecture on the subject by Dr. Regenia A. Perry. It will be at 3 P.M. on Feb. 1, not this Sunday.

title: Life Magazine, Struggling for Niche, Dismisses a Third of Staff
description: Life magazine has dismissed 15 editorial employees, or about 33 percent of the staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, ED
description: GOTTLIEB-Ed. On January 20, 1998. Great husband, father and a brilliant public relations consultant. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions in his memory to the Hospital for Joint Diseases/Orthopedic Institute. Janet, Liz and Richard

title: Explorers on a Mystical Quest
description: Moment by moment, Nai-Ni Chen's choreography was often pictorially attractive. But the lovely moments seldom formed coherent wholes in the program the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company offered on Tuesday night as part of the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater.

title: McCann-Erickson Shuffles Top Deck
description: Top management changes have been announced at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising and its parent, the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, effective April 1.

title: From M.V.P. to Federal Prisoner
description: The former pitching star Denny McLain, accused yesterday of involvement in a calling-card scheme, has seen his fortunes plummet since he won 31 games for the World Series-champion Detroit Tigers in 1968.

title: Tobacco and Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanders Gets Miller Award
description: Barry Sanders had to share the National Football League's most valuable player award with Brett Favre, but he stood alone today as the winner of the Miller Lite N.F.L. player of the year award.

title: Earnings Results at Exxon Lift Oil Industry Outlook
description: In a signal of healthy profits for the entire oil industry, the Exxon Corporation reported a slight improvement in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday helped by strong gains in refining that more than offset a big drop in crude petroleum prices.

title: Wells BDDP loses another account, and notice of its dismissal has some very unminced words.
description: THE Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had dismissed Wells BDDP Inc., removing all its accounts, with billings estimated at $125 million, and delivering a damaging blow to an agency already in turmoil.

title: SUBPOENAS SENT AS CLINTON DENIES REPORTS OF AN AFFAIR WITH AIDE AT WHITE HOUSE
description: As an independent counsel issued a fresh wave of White House subpoenas, President Clinton today denied accusations of having had a sexual affair with a 21-year-old White House intern and promised to cooperate with prosecutors investigating whether the President obstructed justice and sought to have the reported liaison covered up.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on the Public Lives page on Tuesday about Randi Weingarten, who is seeking the presidency of the United Federation of Teachers, misspelled the name of the law school from which she graduated. It is the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, not Cardoza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, DEIRDRA ''DEE DEE''
description: YOUNG-Deirdra ''Dee Dee'', 25. Passed away in Santa Fe, New Mexico, on January 8, 1998. She was a graduate of The Masters School, Dobbs Ferry, NY (1990) and Barnard College at Columbia University (1994). Deirdra was employed in Santa Fe by Sommer & Fox Law Firm and volunteered with the Santa Fe Playhouse. She was an avid skier and an accomplished violinist. Deirdra is survived by her parents, Robert and Grace Young of Hartsdale, NY; and her brothers, Geoffrey of New Fairfield, CT and Oliver of Ridgefield, CT. A memorial service for Deirdra will be held at 1 P.M. on January 24, 1998 at The Ardsley United Methodist Church, 525 Ashford Ave, Ardsley, N.Y. The family requests that no flowers be sent. Donations may be made to ''Deirdra Young Memorial Fund'', The Santa Fe Playhouse, 142 East DeVargas St., Santa Fe, NM 87501.

title: Web Sites Show You The Snow
description: Looking out the kitchen window at bare trees, brown grass and gray squirrels in northern New Jersey makes a snow-starved cross-country skier long for the mountains of snow deposited in the winter of 1996. Cross-country skiers in the East have been relegated to watching the sky and watching the Weather Channel (not necessarily in that order). Now, we can watch our computers.

title: Currents; SPACE SAVERS -- Furniture To Grace Small Quarters
description: Freiraum is among the exhibitors at the Cologne International Furniture Fair in Germany, which closes Sunday. Freiraum specializes in furniture for small spaces.

description: A lot of people think the Texas cattlemen have no legitimate complaint against Oprah Winfrey. If free speech means anything, many people argue, surely it means that the host of a television show can hold a discussion on the possible health hazards of beef -- without facing a lawsuit.

title: Clinton's Warning to Iraqis: Time for Diplomacy May End
description: President Clinton said today that the time for diplomacy may be dwindling in the standoff with President Saddam Hussein over Iraq's refusal to open its suspected biological and chemical weapon sites to United Nations inspectors.

title: Panel Suggests Ways to Trim Cost of College
description: After weathering a battle with its Congressional sponsors and repeatedly postponing the issuance of a report because of internal strife, a Federal commission to study the cost of higher education today all but unanimously adopted 42 recommendations intended to make college less expensive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIE, MILDRED MAIDMAN
description: BRODIE - Mildred Maidman. 1904-1998. Beloved mother of Dr. Sheldon and Charlotte Brodie and Barbara and Isidore Klebanowcherished Nana of Bonnie and Jay Shevins, Martha and Harvey Sepler, Barnett Brodie, Dr. Edward Klebanow, Elan and Karen Klebanow, Steven and Robyn Klebanow, loving great-grandmother of Russell, Scott, Jessica, Elizabeth, Craig, Aubree, Daniel, Jamie and Leigh. ''She was our matriarch and treasure.'' Funeral services to be held Friday, January 23, 1:30PM at Gutterman's, Syosset, NY.

title: Patriots Said to Have An Interest in Lewis
description: New England wants to interview Green Bay's offensive coordinator, Sherman Lewis, for that same job with the Patriots, according to several National Football League executives.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROKEACH, MARJORIE
description: ROKEACH-Marjorie. 7/22/21 to 1/22/93. Mother, we miss you, and love you now as always. Linda, Mickey and Stevie

title: Abortion's Children
description: On the 25th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, we know certain facts. We know that at this point about 1.5 million abortions are performed each year in the United States. And we know that the fight over whether legalized abortion should continue has not waned with time, as many thought it would, but grown.

title: In Fair Weather and Foul, a Friend to Clinton
description: At virtually every whiff of scandal, every sensitive moment throughout his Presidency, Bill Clinton has turned to Vernon E. Jordan Jr. for comfort, for advice or, often, for rescue.
