description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Himself
description: The White House has often relied on aides to defend President Clinton from scandal. But yesterday, the President himself tried to assure the public that he had not had an affair with a White House intern and then urged her to lie about it.

title: Microsoft Will Revise European Contracts Amid an Investigation
description: The Microsoft Corporation appears to have derailed at least one antitrust inquiry by the European Commission by announcing Tuesday that it would revise contracts with at least two dozen European Internet service providers to drop a requirement that they offer their customers Microsoft's World Wide Web browser in return for being listed in the Windows 95 operating system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, GEORGE
description: COHEN-George. Beloved husband of Roslyn (Roz). Devoted father of Jeffrey and Mitchell Cohen. Loving brother of Carol Wolfson and brother-in-law Irwin Berger. Adored grandfather of Jennifer and Michael. Dear nephew of Sylvia Sherman. Services Friday, January 23 at 11 AM at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Ave. at 10th Street, New York City.

title: Japanese Stocks Climb on Hints of Slower Austerity Program
description: The stock market soared today for the sixth consecutive day, the longest rally in two years, and the yen rose on hopes that Japan might take bolder steps to turn around its ailing economy.

title: Sure-Footed in the Slippery World of Rock
description: FOR most musicians who make it into the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame, the induction ceremony is a deep breath of satisfaction after a career's uphill climb. Here is what happened to Lloyd Price at last week's ceremony:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASENFELD, HENRY
description: HASENFELD-Henry. Congregation Ezrath Israel, The Actors Temple, mourns the passing of our esteemed Trustee, dear friend and long time member. We express our sympathy to his family. We will miss him. Robert Goldman, President Naoch Valley, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GONNEAU, GEORGE
description: GONNEAU-George. Jan. 22, 1997. In our thoughts and in our hearts. Mary, Matthew and Daniel

title: NOW Tries to Seize Abortion Foes' Airline Miles
description: The NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund asked 13 major airlines yesterday to freeze any frequent-flier miles earned by or credited to Randall Terry, an anti-abortion leader, and said it would try to have the mileage transferred to the National Organization for Women.

title: I.R.A., in Veiled Threat, Says Proposals Throw Talks Into a Crisis
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that there is a crisis in the peace effort in the Protestant-dominated British province of Northern Ireland.

title: Struggling to Break Free Of an Oppressive Past
description: There is a kind of wine made from grapes left long on the vine, intense with acrid sweetness. Indeed, late growth in music as in wine can both tantalize and seduce with its hint of corruption.

title: Samsung Will Sell Property And End a Skyscraper Plan
description: The Samsung Group will sell a $300 million portfolio of global properties, get an $80 million cash infusion from its chairman and scrap plans for a Seoul skyscraper under a restructuring that the Korean conglomerate said was aimed at improving competitiveness.

title: Wunderman, at 77, Is Calling It a Day
description: Lester Wunderman, a pioneer of direct marketing, is retiring as chairman of Wunderman Cato Johnson in New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: Feeding Egos, Not Book Sales
description: After a seasonal lull, Manhattan is once again a frieze of book parties stretching from the Upper East and West Sides to SoHo and TriBeCa. Publishers hate them. Writers demand them. For authors, the parties are celebratory, and a conjuring of the deities in behalf of reviews and sales. They are essentially about buzz, and ego.

title: At 74, a New Life as a Spellbinder Haunted by War
description: Fred Rochlin has a fitful memory; he has trouble recalling specific dates, matching names with faces, even something so significant as what it was that made him want to stand up in public and reveal the most dramatic and painful moments of his life.

title: Drug Makers See Decrease In Share Price
description: The shares of the American Home Products Corporation and of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. retreated yesterday as the euphoria over a possible merger of the companies began to cool.

title: School in Brooklyn Is Closed After Section of Facade Falls
description: A Brooklyn vocational high school was ordered closed after a swatch of ornamental brick facade measuring about 600 square feet broke free from the side of the building last night and crashed through protective wooden scaffolding to the sidewalk below, city and school officials said.

title: A Landlord's Sentence Won't Help Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: Collinsworth Going to Fox
description: Cris Collinsworth, the top analyst on NBC's National Football League pre-game show since 1996, is moving to Fox, television industry officials said yesterday. He will make about $1 million annually for five years.

title: U.S. Studying Pataki Donations by Inmates' Parents
description: In 1992, a 17-year-old Korean immigrant was arrested in Queens after he took part in a string of gang-related robberies that culminated with a botched holdup at a doctor's office. After the teen-ager went to prison, his father, John S. Jhang, gave a total of $12,000 in contributions in 1994 and 1995 to the gubernatorial campaign of George E. Pataki.

title: Berard Shaky, but Gets Nod
description: Despite having given the puck away on the power play twice in Chicago on Tuesday night, leading to a pair of shorthanded goals for the Blackhawks, and despite having the worst plus-minus ratio on the Islanders, Bryan Berard will not be benched for Thursday night's game against the St. Louis Blues.

title: Currents; LIGHTING WITH NEW MATERIAL -- Diffusion a la Alabaster
description: Kevin Walz, who won a Rome Prize in 1994 to study design, has created a collection of lighting fixtures for Baldinger that includes pendants, wall sconces, and table and floor lamps. The lamps' diffusers are a new grade of Du Pont Corian just three millimeters thick. The material, which resembles alabaster, went into production in Tokyo last week. For the diffusers, Mr. Walz said he asked a ''genius chemist'' at the Du Pont Company to replicate a sample of Italian army bed linen that he had soaked in shellac. Another variation, embedded with mica, is closer to true white. The pendant lamps above, called One Bay Arc, cost $480 each and will arrive in showrooms in May. Information: (718) 204-5700.

title: Moving the Furniture Just Isn't the Answer
description: Not too long ago, people following the Knicks became disenchanted with the point guard running the team. By his third and fourth seasons at Madison Square Garden, Mark Jackson was blamed for everything from bad passes to unpopped kernels at the bottom of the paper box.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Currents; IN PLACE OF CHENILLE -- For Upholstery With Texture
description: Boucle, the new chenille? Like chenille, boucle is dimensional; the new boucles, with their stiff textures, have a vintage feel. Suzanne Tick, the creative director for Knoll Textiles, noted that upholstery looms used to be ''overfed'' to create a thick pile.

title: Societe Generale to Take $164 Million Provision
description: Societe Generale S.A. said yesterday that it would take 1 billion francs ($164 million) in provisions against 1997 earnings for loans made to Southeast Asia, a move the company said would not stop its profit from rising. The largest retail bank in France said its total loans to the region, which includes Indonesia, Malaysia, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines, totaled $6.8 billion at the end of December.

title: RCN TO BUY ULTRANET AND EROL'S INTERNET
description: The RCN Corporation said it would buy Ultranet Communications Inc. and Erol's Internet Inc. for $110.5 million in cash and stock, as it seeks more Internet customers in the lucrative Northeastern United States with the goal of selling them phone and cable service. Erol's and Ultranet are both closely held providers of Internet-access service. RCN, a cable, local and long-distance phone and Internet company, said it would pay $35 million in cash and $48.5 million in stock for Erol's, and $7.8 million in cash and $19.2 million in stock for Ultranet. RCN will add about 325,000 Internet customers with the addition of Erol's, based in Boston, and Ultranet, based in Springfield, Va. Shares of RCN, based in Princeton, N.J., rose $3.50 yesterday, to $39.75.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the fatal shooting of an undercover narcotics officer in the Bronx misspelled the surname of the officer in some editions. He was Sean Carrington, not Harrington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORWOOD, DOROTHY MARIE
description: NORWOOD-Dorothy Marie. On January 21, 1998 of Stewart Manor, NY. Beloved wife of the late James C. Norwood, Sr. Loving mother of James C. Jr., Janice E. Becker, Jane M. Kusiak, the late Joan C. Beck and the late Dorothy Jean Norwood. Fond sister of Joan Kelser and George Knorr. Cherished grandmother of nine. Friends may call on Friday, 2-5 and 7-9, at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue (at Railroad Plaza), Floral Park. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:15 A.M., St. Anne's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAZEN, GEOFFREY DAVID
description: CHAZEN-Geoffrey David. Beloved husband of Jamie Rachel, father of Zoe Alexandra and Charlotte Annabel, son of Eric and Barbara Chazen of Nashville, TN, sister of Lisa Levine of Washington, DC, grandson of Juliett Grobstein of New Rochelle, NY, son-in-law of Phyllis Zimmerman of NYC, died at age 39. According to his wishes, the family has donated his body to the Microbiology Dept. at NYU Medical Center. Donations in his memory can be made to the Geoffrey David Chazen, M.D. Memorial Fund for AIDS Research at NYU Medical Center, Office of Development, 550 1st Ave, NY NY 10016 or the Geoffrey David Chazen Memorial Fund at Vanderbilt University, School of Medicine, 201 Alumni Hall, Nashville TN 37240. A memorial service will be held today, Thursday, January 22, at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street (between 2nd & 3rd) at 4:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARITY, EDWARD J.
description: GARITY-Edward J. January 22, 1996. Your abrupt departure still haunts me. I miss you so. Love, Susie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGE, SYLVIA
description: INGE-Sylvia. At age ninety, mother of Susan Gould, grandmother of Stephen and Andrew Gould, devoted friend of Betty Geffen. Contributions to The Israel Cancer Research Fund, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10104. Services today 10:30 A.M., at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Pataki Budget Plan Sets Off Jockeying for Share of Albany Surplus
description: As legislators filed into an auditorium where Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled his budget proposal on Tuesday, they were handed fliers from a group demanding that the state spend a part of this year's huge budget surplus on helping people with AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANOWSKI, REV. FRANCIS C.
description: ROMANOWSKI-Rev. Francis C. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Stanislaus Bishop & Martyr Church, 88-10 102nd Avenue, Ozone Park, on Jan. 20. Reposing in James & Stephen Romanelli Funeral Home, 89-01 Rockaway Blvd., Ozone Park, Thursday, Jan. 22, 2-10 P.M. and Friday, Jan. 23, 25 P.M. Mass of Transferral Friday, Jan. 23 at 7:30 P.M., St. Stanislaus Bishop & Martyr Church. Funeral Mass Saturday, Jan. 24, at 10 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Metro Business; Temp Company Acquired
description: Strategic Legal Resources, a two-year-old Manhattan company that supplies temporary lawyers and paralegals to law firms and investment banks, said this week that it is being acquired by Staffmark, a national staffing services company in Fayetteville, Ark.

title: Calendar; On Display, New York And Artwork
description: Wood and Paper Artworks

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: CANADIAN DOLLAR FALLS. The Canadian currency hit a 12-year low against the United States dollar on concerns that recent ice storms and Asian turmoil will slow growth. The Canadian dollar finished at 1.449 to the United States dollar, or 69.21 cents, just above the record low reached in February 1986.

title: Glenn's Space Junket
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Some Hope And Advice For Lopez
description: THE happy, ending-altered script for Felipe Lopez was playing out last night in the Houston Rockets' locker room, where Rodrick Rhodes was on a mission to round up every ticket he could, more than 30 at last count. Rhodes, who was Lopez before Lopez clanked his first jump shot for St. John's, had come home to New Jersey a pro, against big odds, if not all hope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARISI, MARIE J. (NEE DATTOMA)
description: PARISI-Marie J. (nee Dattoma). Loving wife of Joseph, devoted mother of Camille, Michael and Joseph. Reposing at Papavero Funeral Home, 72-27 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Funeral Mass Transfiguration R.C. Church, on Saturday at 10 A.M. Entombment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Hours 2-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: New York Rule on Nonresidents' Alimony Cost Is Voided
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that New York State unconstitutionally discriminates against nonresident taxpayers by denying them the right to deduct alimony payments from their New York income tax.

title: Her Ex-Teacher Is Her Patient
description: GEORGE TOKIEDA had a heart transplant last month at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Memo Suggests U.S. Position In Rejecting Casino Is Weak
description: A House committee resuming hearings into campaign finance abuses created a small furor today by releasing an internal Interior Department memorandum suggesting that the Government would have a tough time defending its actions in a lawsuit filed by an Indian group that lost its bid for a casino license.

title: For the Exiles, Come Home, It's 'Miracle Time' in Havana
description: For almost 40 years, Mildred Allen hid from the ghosts of her homeland behind a black, whirring sewing machine in the factories of New York City. Fingers flying, toes tapping, she stitched a brand new life. She paid union dues. She found an American husband and hung his flag in her tiny apartment in the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOROBKIN, LEE
description: KOROBKIN-Lee. Died on January 21st, 1998, at her home in Port Washington, New York. Beloved wife of Edward Lawrence. Loving mother of Barry, David, Nancy and the late Richard. Devoted grandmother of Rachel, Rob, Lexi, Jake, Katie, Ben, Russell and Sara. Funeral services Friday, January 23rd, at 10 A.M., at Community Synagogue, Sands Point, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, MARGARET (NEE FORDE)
description: O'BRIEN-Margaret (nee Forde). Of Parkchester, NY, native of Co. Mayo, Ireland on January 20, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Matthew O'Brien. Dearest sister of the late Della Curley, the late James, Andrew, and John Forde. Loving aunt of Joan Treco, Andrew Forde, Noreen McDonald, Eileen Murphy and Geraldine Riedell. Cherished grand aunt of Janet Curley and 14 grandnieces and 9 grandnephews. Friends may call Friday 8-9AM at the Hunt Stellato Funeral Home, 1601 Palisade Ave., Ft. Lee, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial 10:15AM, Friday at the Church of St. Helena's Bronx, New York. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, Long Island.

title: Turf; The Perfect Doorman Is Made, Not Born
description: IT'S not easy being a doorman.

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL BUYS BRAZILIAN ASSETS
description: The Champion International Corporation bought the timberlands and paper plant of the former Bamerindus banking group yesterday for 84 million reals ($75 million). Champion bought Bamerindus Agro-Florestal and Industria de Papel Aropoti S.A. for the minimum price required by the Brazilian central bank, which took over and managed the debt-ridden companies when Bamerindus was sold to HSBC Holdings P.L.C. last year. Champion gains BAF's timberlands of eucalyptus and pine trees in the southern state of Parana, adding to its forests in the states of Sao Paulo, Amapa and Mato Grosso do Sul. Inpacel and BAF have 1,000 employees. Inpacel, a paper factory, produces 150,000 tons of paper a year, mainly for the publishing industry. Champion is already a strong producer of copying machine paper there.

title: Larry Gilbert, 55, Well-Known Member of Golf's Senior Tour
description: Larry Gilbert, a prominent golfer on the Senior PGA Tour, died of lung cancer yesterday at Samaritan Hospital in Lexington, Ky. He was 55.

title: Topless Club Is Province of Celebrities
description: When it comes to topless nightclubs, those in the know say that Scores, on Manhattan's Upper East Side, ranks as the creme de la creme, the kind of establishment in which celebrities, sports figures and newsmakers can be spotted regularly.

title: Dream Pond: Just Add Water. Then Add More.
description: NOT long ago, I found myself in a crowded lecture hall surrounded by grim men and women sitting before specimen jars brimming with an alarming assortment of scums and growths in brodo. We had come to this annual Pond Management workshop at the Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, N.Y., because we all had ponds that were sick in one way or another -- choked with weeds, clouded with algae or, in my own case, lacking in the defining characteristic of a pond: water.

title: Harry S. Ashmore, 81, Whose Editorials Supported Integration in Arkansas, Dies
description: Harry S. Ashmore, who was executive editor of The Arkansas Gazette when he won a Pulitzer Prize for antisegregation editorials he wrote during the crisis and confrontation over admission of black students to a Little Rock high school in 1957, died on Tuesday night in the infirmary of the Valle Verde retirement home in Santa Barbara, Calif., where he and his wife moved several years ago. He was 81.

title: Chip Maker's Operating Net Is Up Sharply
description: Texas Instruments reported a healthy jump in operating earnings today despite fading orders at the end of the year resulting from Asia's economic turmoil. And despite predicting a slow first quarter, the company issued a bright outlook for the year.

title: Two Newspapers Publish Name of a Sex Offender
description: A central New Jersey newspaper yesterday published the name and pictures of a convicted sex offender after obtaining a flier intended for the private notification of his neighbors under Megan's Law.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. A mild winter, a decline in demand in Asia and squabbling among OPEC members has helped keep crude oil prices near four-year lows. The March contract fell 20 cents yesterday, to $16.36 a barrel. Heating oil also declined, and gasoline prices dipped briefly below 50 cents a gallon.

title: Metro Matters; Take Seriously Rich Populists Named Ross
description: EVERY race has to begin somewhere. And on Monday, while the rest of New York was out shopping, the Democratic hopefuls for governor -- all five of them -- and the three for United States Senate appeared at the first public forum of this year's campaign. Speaking one after another in an auditorium in Harlem, they took their turn, one after another, to call for greater job growth and better schools, and to decry, one after another, the decline of manufacturing in the inner city.

title: Revenue for Euro Disney Up by 17% in Quarter
description: Euro Disney S.C.A., Europe's biggest theme-park operator, said yesterday that first-quarter revenue rose 17 percent, driven by higher attendance and ticket prices. Euro Disney, which is based in Seine-et-Marne, France and is the holding company for Disneyland Paris, is 39.2 percent-owned by the Walt Disney Company and 24 percent-owned by Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabi. The company said revenue rose to 1.3 billion francs ($213 million) in the three months ended Dec. 31, from 1.12 billion francs in the period a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOSEPH S.
description: MURPHY-Joseph S. The Board of Trustees, President, faculty and staff of Bennington College mourn the tragic and untimely death of our esteemed former President, Joseph S. Murphy. His leadership of Bennington at a critical time will be remembered with gratitude. We extend our deepest sympathy to Susan, Lisa, Suzanne, Peter, Joe's mother and his entire family. We share your great loss. John W. Barr, Chairman Board of Trustees Barbara U. Deane, Vice Chairman Board of Trustees Rebecca B. Stickney, Secretary Board of Trustees Elizabeth Coleman, President Bennington College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLANICK, WILLIAM (BILL)
description: PLANICK-William (Bill). Passed away January 20, 1998 in Plano, TX. Survivors daughter Cynthia, son Neil, daughter-in-law Susan, granddaughter Rachel, sister Janice Stone. Also former spouse and lifelong friend Phoebe. Bill was loved by everyone who knew him. Graveside services at 2 P.M. Friday, Hillcrest Memorial Park, Rabbi Jeffrey Leynor, officiating. Memorial contributions in Bill's name may be made to any Animal Charity.

title: Suspect Denies Knowing Men Were Police
description: The man charged in a shootout that left an undercover detective dead in the Bronx on Monday night has admitted to firing his .25-caliber handgun at the detective and his partner, but he has asserted that he did not know they were police officers, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUATTROCCHI, MARIE STEPHENSON
description: QUATTROCCHI-Marie Stephenson, of Chatham, NJ, peacefully at age 95 on January 16, 1998 at King James Care Center, Chatham, NJ. Beloved wife of the late William R. Quattrocchi, devoted mother of Marcia Conze of Boynton Beach, FL., and William R. Quatrocchi Jr. of Summit, NJ. Also survived by four grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Interment and private memorial service to be held in the springtime at Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich, CT.

title: Castro's Spin: Pope Is on Our Side
description: To the rest of the world, the arrival of Pope John Paul II here today seems a direct challenge to Fidel Castro and everything he stands for. Inside Cuba, however, Mr. Castro is using every means at his disposal to convince his 11 million people that he and the beleaguered Cuban revolution he has led for nearly 40 years will be the ultimate beneficiaries of the visit.

title: S.E.C. Initially Backs Fidelity Plan to Insure Money Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has given preliminary approval to a plan allowing Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund company, to establish a mutual insurance company to guarantee its money market funds against some losses.

title: New York Seeks Fines Over a Retailer's Restocking Fee
description: A month after accusing Circuit City, the nation's largest consumer electronics chain, of improperly charging a 15 percent ''restocking fee'' on merchandise returns, New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday that it would seek more than $30,000 in fines from the chain.

title: Detente in Iran-U.S. Relations Will Be a Little Late This Year
description: For the moment at least, the initiative by President Mohammad Khatami to break down what he called the ''wall of mistrust'' between Iran and the United States seems to be dead.

title: UNION REJECTS NCO IN FAVOR OF OUTSOURCING SOLUTIONS
description: The Union Corporation, a provider of billing, collection, and credit-authorization services, said yesterday that it had rejected an offer to be acquired by NCO Group Inc. for $232 million in favor of a $190 million bid from Outsourcing Solutions Inc. NCO, a provider of accounts-receivable management services, offered $39 for each of Union's 5.8 million shares outstanding, topping a $31.50-a-share cash offer from Outsourcing Solutions. Outsourcing said its offer, which expires at midnight tomorrow, would create a company with 1997 revenue of $450 million. It would be Outsourcing's seventh acquisition since its formation in September 1995. Union, based in Greenwich, Conn., had $121.7 million in revenue for the 1997 fiscal year. NCO, based in Blue Bell, Pa., had nine-month revenue of $63.8 million as of Sept. 30. Outsourcing, a privately held provider of receivables-management services in Chesterfield, Mo., had six-month revenue of $130.1 million last year.

title: After Parade Mishap, A Long Battle Back; Victim's Survival Was 'a Miracle,' But When Will the Recovery End?
description: It was Kathy Caronna's idea, going to the Thanksgiving Day parade. ''Not one of us has been there and we just have to see it,'' she kept insisting, until finally, her husband, Massimo, developed parade fever. They would make a video: ''Our First Thanksgiving With the Baby.'' True, he might not remember much of it, but the memory would be there forever, on tape.

title: U.S. Charges John Gotti Jr. With Extortion
description: Five years after John Gotti was sent away to spend the rest of his life in solitary confinement, Federal officials said today they had arrested his son and anointed successor, John Gotti Jr., in another attempt to destroy the Gambino crime family by beheading it.

title: Accounts
description: * Accutrade, Omaha, a division of Ameritrade Holding Corp., to Dormeus Advertising, New York, part of Omnicom Group, as its first agency. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: 44 Officers Are Charged After Ohio Sting Operation
description: In what may be the largest and widest ranging police corruption investigation in the country in recent years, 44 officers from five law-enforcement agencies were charged today with taking money to protect cocaine trafficking operations in Cleveland and northern Ohio, Federal authorities said.

title: Lehman Hopes to Gain From His Weight Loss
description: There is less of Tom Lehman this year, which Lehman hopes will lead to more victories.

title: Elderly Have Not Gained at Expense of Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Sundance as Documentary Support Group
description: Big sales and celebrity sightings make the news here, but there is an aspect of the Sundance Film Festival that too often goes unmentioned: This is documentary heaven.

title: Cassell Haunts Old Team
description: The Houston Rockets had spent the day in limbo, growing angry and frustrated as game time approached and they wondered just who would be on their roster when the ball was thrown up. Rumors swirled that the Rockets were close to pulling the trigger on a six-player trade, attempting to acquire the point guard the team feels is the missing ingredient.

title: Indonesia's Currency Deepens Its Plunge
description: The Indonesian currency accelerated its decline in early trading today, demonstrating a growing lack of faith in the country by investors and suggesting that an eventual recovery of the economy will be even more difficult than foreseen.

title: Castro and Cheering Crowds Greet Pope
description: Greeted by a respectful Fidel Castro as he stepped off the plane into steamy tropical sunshine, Pope John Paul II today began his five-day mission into one of the world's last Communist bastions with an appeal for Cuba to open up to the world, and the world to open up to Cuba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, RUTH
description: KLEIN-Ruth. On January 19, 1998, in Tucson, Arizona. Beloved wife of Edward. Loving mother of Barbara and Marjorie. Devoted sister of Beverly Bluver.

title: Viva la Genre! Elmore Leonard Visits Old Havana
description: CUBA LIBRE

title: INSIDE
description: Gotti's Son Is Arrested

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, MILTON
description: LEWIN - Milton. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its Honorary Trustee and former Segan, and extends its deepest sympathy to his family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Microsoft Profit Gained Sharply During Quarter
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday reported strong growth in earnings in its most recent quarter, slightly exceeding Wall Street expectations. But the company, the leading maker of personal-computer software, warned that the weakness in Asian economies was likely to slow its growth this year.

title: Rumbling of Weaker Earnings Dims Outlook for Market in '98
description: The profit numbers are coming in, and investors are beginning to see the potentially sour makings of 1998.

title: Profits Fall 11% At Semiconductor Maker
description: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V. said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 11 percent as semiconductor prices dropped amid worldwide overcapacity, a situation it said could be prolonged because of an Asian economic slowdown. The French-Italian company is Europe's No. 2 semiconductor maker after Philips Electronics N.V. of the Netherlands.

title: Broncos' Mobley Rises to Unlikely Stardom
description: Linebacker John Mobley of the Denver Broncos has not taken the traditional route to the Super Bowl.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''May Cuba, with all its magnificent potential, open itself up to the world, and may the world open itself up to Cuba so that this people, which is working to make progress and which longs for concord and peace, may look to the future with hope.''

title: Carey Denies Any Knowledge Of Teamsters Fund Diversion
description: Ron Carey, the teamsters' president, told a court-appointed review board today that he neither knew about nor participated in a scheme in which several aides diverted union money into his campaign coffers.

title: French Premier Pleads for Time to Whittle the 12.4% Jobless Rate
description: Rejecting demands by jobless workers' groups for large increases in benefits, the leader of France's left-wing Government pleaded on national television tonight for enough time for his policies to start cutting the 12.4 percent unemployment rate.

title: Study Challenges Idea of PMS as Emotional Disorder
description: A new study calls into question the view that premenstrual syndrome is an emotional disorder, suggesting instead that its cause is biological.

title: Currents; ADVICE FOR GIFT GIVERS -- Getting the Approval of the Stars
description: At lunch in the tea room at Felissimo, a crafts store with the motto ''Blending the material and spiritual,'' the astrologer Constance Stellas awaits. Aided by a computer, she helps select the perfect gift. Her advice ($15 for 15 minutes) is based on the date, time and place of birth of the recipient.

title: Today's Japanese Melodies As Heard In Japan
description: Music From Japan, which was founded in 1975, is devoted to bringing the works of Japanese composers to the American concert stage and into the consciousness of American musicians and listeners. It has sponsored tours and performances, commissioned new works, established a library of scores and recordings at its Manhattan headquarters (7 East 20th Street) and opened an Internet Web site (http://users.aol.com/ mfjrc/mfjhome.html) with a composer index. The centerpiece of its programming, though, is an annual festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELB, LEAH
description: GELB-Leah. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Max Gelb. Loving mother of Bernard and David. Cherished mother-in-law of Mimi and Carol. Devoted grandmother of Michael, Lauren and Alex. Dear sister of Dr. Ruth Lefkowitz. She was a founder and the first principal of the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester. She was also a past president of both the Alumni Association of the Seminary College of Jewish Studies and the Sisterhood of Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle. Services Thursday, 10AM, Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains.

title: Morgenthau Said to Be in Plea Talks With Top Construction Executives on Bid Rigging
description: Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau is conducting plea negotiations with top executives from several construction and interior design companies in connection with a long-running investigation of bid-rigging and payoffs in the contracting business, according to real estate executives and lawyers involved in the talks.

title: Chief Chosen for French Military Supplier
description: Denis Ranque has been named chief executive of the state-controlled Thomson-CSF, Europe's largest military electronics company.

title: Personal Shopper; Dressing Up a Desk In Its Leather-Best
description: AFTER years of wire boxes and stainless steel pencil cups, luxurious leather desk accessories are back in the home office. The staying-power of fine leather's allure was evident in the number of vintage desk sets for sale at the Modernism/Photography show at the Seventh Regiment Armory in November. Who would have thought there would be a futures market for old Hermes accessories?

title: Rubin Defends Asian Bailout and Asks Funds for I.M.F.
description: Saying that the United States ''cannot afford to stand back and gamble that the crisis will resolve itself,'' Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin defended the Clinton Administration's efforts today to calm Asia's financial turmoil and called on Congress to help by providing more money to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESTEFANIS, LOUIS A.
description: DeSTEFANIS-Louis A. Who retired as an executive in the moving and storage industry in 1970, died Jan. 20 at the home of his son, John. He was 92 years old and lived in Southampton, New York. The cause of death was heart failure. Mr. DeStefanis established his own business, Acme Van Company, in Manhattan in 1925 and was a leader in the industry for the next 45 years. He was president of the City Movers Association in New York for many years and served from 1963 until his retirement on the Board of Directors of United Van Lines of Fenton, Missouri, for whom he was an agent for over twenty years. He was chairman of the New York Movers' Tariff Bureau and a director of the New York Furniture Warehousemen's Association. Mr. DeStefanis' wife, the former Ethel Engelman, died in 1975. He is survived by six children; three daughters, Pauline Julig of Kennesaw, GA, Rena Hines of Falmouth, MA and Linda Kofmehl of Greenwich, CT.; three sons, Thomas of Fernandina Beach, FL, John of Sagaponack, NY and Robert of Sag Harbor, NY; twelve grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A brother, Ralph, of Amityville, NY also survives. Mass Thursday, January 23, 10:30A.M. St. Andrews RC Church, Sag Harbor. Interment Southampton Cemetery.

title: Abortion Rights, 25 Years Later
description: A quarter-century after the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade, the right of women to control their reproductive lives remains central to their ability to participate fully in America's economic, social and cultural life. Yet a woman's right to choose abortion before a fetus becomes viable remains as embattled as ever. The current campaign in Congress and within the Republican Party against so-called partial birth abortions, most of which occur before viability, is only the latest blow against abortion rights. The past 25 years of litigation, clinic bombings and political struggle have taken a grievous toll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMER, HON
description: HAMMER-Hon. Zevulun. AMIT is profoundly saddened by the very untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague, Israel's Minister of Education and Culture and Deputy Prime Minister. A true Ben Torah and champion of religious Zionism, Zevulun Hammer fostered the growth of religious education in Israel. Through his inspiration, AMIT was proclaimed Israel's official network for religious technological secondary education. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife and children. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN TO BUY THERMADYNE HOLDINGS
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.'s Merchant Banking Partners II said yesterday that it would buy 82 percent of the Thermadyne Holdings Corporation for $790 million in stock and debt. The fund will pay shareholders of Thermadyne, among the world's top five makers of welding and cutting equipment, $34.50 each, or 19 percent more than the company's closing share price on Tuesday. Stock of Thermadyne, based in St. Louis, rose $4.625, to $33.50. DLJ Merchant Banking will spend $140 million of its own cash and the rest will be raised through bank loans and the sale of high-yield debt. It will assume $409 million of Thermadyne's debt.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLAGSBRUN, DANIEL
description: KLAGSBRUN-Daniel. Dan, today on your birthday and every day with the rising and setting of the sun, you are held deeply within our hearts with love. Your Loving Family

title: Sybase Loss to Grow as Sales Are Disputed
description: Sybase Inc. said today that it had discovered inappropriate accounting for sales by its Japanese subsidiary, forcing the company to postpone release of its fourth-quarter financial results for one week, and to revise results for the quarter and year.

title: Denver's Little Big Men Don't Fear the Packers
description: Guard Mark Schlereth of the Denver Broncos pauses, counts on his fingers and tries to add up how many times he has had surgery. Not enough fingers.

title: Jury Awards $60,000 In Discrimination Suit
description: A Federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday awarded $60,000 in damages to a female supervisor in New York City's transit agency after finding the agency had violated her rights ''by its deliberate indifference to widespread discriminatory practices and sexual misconduct'' against other women.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Trial Focuses On the Sanity Of Man Held In Attacks
description: John Royster slouched at the defense table yesterday afternoon, his chin resting on his hand as a prosecutor, Lisa Friel, turned from the jury box and pointed across the courtroom.

title: House Proud; Where Outsider Art Has a Standing Invitation
description: ''I THINK of everything as flesh and blood,'' Frank Maresca said. ''The things I like best have an element of design and an element of emotion.''

title: U.S.A. FLORAL TO ACQUIRE 6 FLORAL PRODUCTS COMPANIES
description: U.S.A. Floral Products Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire six floral products companies and two of their affiliates for $50.3 million in stock and $51.8 million in cash. U.S.A. Floral, based in Washington, is a wholesale flower distributor with annual revenue of more than $350 million. The companies to be acquired are H & H Flowers, doing business as La Fleurette; Ultraflora Inc.; Everflora Inc. and its affiliate, Everflora of Miami Inc.; Koehler & Dramm Inc.; XL Group Inc., and Continental Farms Ltd. and its affiliate, the Atlantic Bouquet Company. The companies have combined annual revenue of $175 million, U.S.A. Floral said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. Partner in the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Eliza and Simon. Brother of Timothy and Ian Clark. Son of Blair Clark and the late Jessie Holladay Philbin James. His death occurred suddenly on January 15, 1998 in NYC.

title: First Aid for a Wounded Mideast Peace
description: Disputes over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Washington schedule and the White House's no-frills welcome briefly threatened to eclipse the larger purposes of the Israeli leader's visit to the United States. But President Clinton used two working sessions with Mr. Netanyahu on Tuesday to turn attention back where it belongs with a new American bid to rescue the faltering Middle East peace effort.

title: Currents; HOUSEWARES -- The Fine and Applied Art of Recycling
description: Maria Capotorto, an industrial designer who graduated from Pratt in 1995, finds beauty in trash. After apprenticing with Ayse Birsel and Bruce Hannah, she turned to inexpensive, practical objects. For wastepaper baskets, she uses a zigzag stitch on newsprint and tissue paper, which she laminates with acrylic (14 inches tall, $32). And then there's her white Chinese food container, with a 40-watt socket and plaster of Paris weighting the inside ($35). Through Your Sister's Moustache, (718) 399-8282.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGSHORE, ESTELLE MORGAN
description: LONGSHORE-Estelle Morgan, 86. Jan. 17, 1998. In loving memory of our mother and grandmother from her children Jo-Ann and Pete, daughter-in-law Shirley, sonin-law Michael, grandchildren Patricia, James, Irene and Kathryn. Memorial service Saturday, January 24, 3 P.M., St. Mark's Church, Jackson Heights. Contributions in lieu of flowers appreciated: Estelle M. Longshore Memorial Fund, St. Mark's Church, 33-50 82 Street, Jackson Heights, New York 11372.

title: Business Coalition to Fight Legislation Protecting Patients' Rights
description: Lobbyists for big business, small business and health insurance companies today unveiled a $1 million campaign to block bipartisan legislation intended to protect the rights of patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREMIN, JOANNE L.
description: CREMIN-Joanne L. The staff of the Development Office of The Metropolitan Museum of Art is deeply saddened by the untimely death of our friend and colleague, Joanne L. Cremin. Jody's brilliant mind, quick wit, and enormous dedication have been an inspiration to all of us. She will be sorely missed.

title: Chang's Grand Slam Jinx Continues With a Loss in Australia
description: Michael Chang, the little player who could, seems to have turned a career corner and is coping now with the unwanted reality of being the little player who doesn't have it anymore.

title: Paris Journal; Remnants of the Old Regime Mourn a Lost Head
description: Prince Sixte-Henri de Bourbon-Parme, a distant relative of King Louis XVI of France, stood about where the guillotine chopped the royal head off 205 years ago today and looked on the bright side.

title: U.S. and Israel Talk Mainly Of More Talks
description: For the first time, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is insisting that an agreement to open intensive talks on a final settlement between Israelis and Palestinians must be an integral part of any deal on the promised Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank, senior Israeli and Palestinian officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SASS, LOUIS DEWALD
description: SASS-Louis DeWald. September 4, 1912-January 22, 1997. Beloved father of Ann and Louis. Father-inlaw of Shira, grandfather of Louisa, William and Juliana. A year has passed, and he is profoundly missed.

title: Economic Scene; Salmon eaters salute a victory against the protectionists.
description: THANKS to hard-charging Chilean exporters, fresh salmon -- in particular, the bone-free fillets ready for the broiler -- has become a major bargain. Check that: much of the thanks must go to lobbies for wholesale fish distributors and restaurants here in America.

title: Letting Side Business in the Side Door; Companies Tap the Earnings Potential of Selling In-House Services to Outsiders
description: The Shell Oil Company has a new revenue geyser on its hands, and there is not a drilling rig in sight.

title: He Talks With Personality
Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKS, BEACH, JEANNE M.
description: HICKS-BEACH-Jeanne M. On January 20, 1998 of Bedford Hills, New York. Wife of the late John H. Hicks-Beach, a former Westchester County Legislator. Mother of Lucinda Quinn, Priscilla Hopkins and John Hicks-Beach, Jr. Grandmother of Tressan and Holly Quinn. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York, Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM. With services at the Funeral Home, Saturday at 11 A.M. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hospice of Northern Westchester and Putnam, 43 Kensico Drive, Mount Kisco, New York 10549.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The continued rise of the market rests in the hands of the Super Bowl team from Green Bay.
description: IN years gone by, when people thought that stocks went both up and down and that market timing was therefore important, market seers searched for indicators that would point the way to determining whether a certain time was a good one to be in the market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEN, LAWRENCE C.
description: SCHOEN-Lawrence C. My dearest friend for over fifty years, I will miss you terribly. Your warmth and energy can never be duplicated. No more backgammon games for awhile. Jerry White

title: Excerpts From Statements by White House and President on Accusations
description: Following are excerpts from a statement today by Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, and interviews with President Clinton by Jim Lehrer of PBS for broadcast on ''The News Hour with Jim Lehrer'' and by with Robert Siegel and Mara Liasson of the National Public Radio program ''All Things Considered'' about accusations that Mr. Clinton had had an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, a White House intern, and then sought to have her lie about it. Mr. McCurry's statement was recorded by The Associated Press. The interviews were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.

title: Study Shows That Some Do Better in Group Homes
description: Former residents of an institution for the developmentally disabled that was closed in 1992 have fared better in group homes or supervised apartments than residents sent to other hospitals, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, JOSEPH RABBI DR.
description: LICHTENSTEIN-Joseph Rabbi Dr. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing in Israel of Rabbi Dr. Joseph Lichtenstein, beloved father of Pnina Rand, devoted wife of of our distinguished Cantor Israel Rand. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier, Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: The Neediest Cases; Spreading Good Fortune By Helping Others in Need
description: For a struggling SoHo artist, it was the sale of eight watercolors after three dry decades. For a Long Island lawyer, it was his wife's pregnancy with twins after five barren years. And for a single mother in Queens, it was the simple realization that things could always be worse.

title: Currents; DECOR -- A Capitalist Indignity, Comrade
description: Jeffrey Chodorow brought Havana to New York with Asia de Cuba, so why not Moscow to Miami? The latest outpost of his restaurant empire is Red Square in South Beach, where caviar flows. The top of the vodka bar is made of ice. ''We built it like a hockey rink,'' Mr. Chodorow said. Light fixtures from foreign flea markets suggest the onion domes of Red Square. A statue of Lenin presides. But this is a capitalist place. Private freezers to store bottles of vodka from the bar can cost as much as $5,000 a year. At 411 Washington Avenue; (305) 672-0200.

title: Computer Chairs Suitable for Liftoff
description: THE world of design has something for everyone, but is there a need for a chair a person can't get out of? An eye-catching new computer stand and reclining-desk-chair combination called the Netsurfer, by Valvomo-Design of Helsinki, Finland, sits in the up-to-the-minute window of Moss, 146 Greene Street, in SoHo. The chair promises a relaxing, back-friendly seat for people who work (and play) at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JACOB
description: COHEN-Jacob. The HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies notes with sadness the death of Jacob Cohen, Ph.D. For the past 10 years, Jack enriched our lives and work with his knowledge, warmth, and wit; we will miss him greatly. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Patricia; their children, and the rest of the family. Anke A. Ehrhardt, Ph.D., Director HIV Center for Clinical and Behavioral Studies New York State Psychiatric Institute and Columbia University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, MARION
description: GERSON-Marion. On January 21, 1998. Beloved sister of the late Bertha, Sarah and Esther. Services on Friday at 11:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 2 Agency Companies In Media-Firm Deals
description: Two large agency companies said yesterday that they had agreed to deals with leading media and research firms.

title: Coaxed Out Of Her Nest, A Diva Takes Wing Again
description: During a career of more than 40 years, Dame Joan Sutherland traveled constantly. It took a toll on her peace of mind, on her family life, even on her troublesome knees, weakened by the countless times that, as mad Lucia, sleepwalking Amina and the other distraught heroines, she had to collapse onstage and die.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IMAGYN MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIES INC., Newport Beach, Calif., said it would close its plant in Laguna Niguel, Calif., and cut about 120 jobs, as part of a plan to consolidate facilities and save $18 million a year.

title: Officials to Attend McDowell's Workout
description: Jack McDowell, recovering from arm trouble, will work out at Stanford University next Tuesday, and the Yankees will have a club official there to watch him, according to General Manager Bob Watson.

title: Sisters Still the Talk of Open
description: Although the Williams sisters kicked off a difficult day by sharing an omelet and a practice session, mercy was nowhere in evidence on the second-round menu once the matches got under way at sold-out Melbourne Park today. And if this Grand Slam tournament's most conspicuous debutantes could turn Melbourne into a town without pity as they tried to whack each other out of the Australian Open, what chance did anybody else have?

title: Finally, Two Get Shot At Winning One Ring
description: SOME pro football players get to the Super Bowl early in their careers, occasionally as a rookie. Others never do. And for a decade, it seemed that two of the best, Neil Smith and Seth Joyner, never would.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARVIS, SERGE
description: JARVIS-Serge. On January 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Lucy Jarvis, dearly beloved father of Barbara, Peter and Junko, loving ''Poppi'' of Serena and brother of Adele Lane. Mr. Jarvis, a founder and Vice President of the European Division of the American ORT Federation, was a practicing international attorney in N.Y.C. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street. The family will receive there on Thursday, January 22nd. at 6 P.M. with services at 7 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANOFF, IRVING
description: YANOFF-Irving. On January 20, 1998. Dear husband of the late Mollie. Beloved father of Judith and son-in-law Russell Rodewald, and Arlene and son-in-law Rick Heckendorn. Loving grandfather of Aimee. We will miss him and remember him always.

title: Proposal to Revamp South Korean Debt
description: The South Korean Government and international banks are considering repackaging slightly less than $30 billion in short-term loans due the end of the year as new, longer-term debt.

title: What Fabric Goes With the Bulls?
description: PENNY GLAZIER was inspecting the empty space where her next restaurant is to take shape, on the balcony below the starry ceiling in Grand Central Terminal (and just above the main concourse). There, in a quintessentially New York setting, will be a 150-seat steak house named for a basketball star from out of town: Michael Jordan.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator Dianne Feinstein's decision against running for governor of California misstated the situation of State Senator John Vasconcellos. Mr. Vasconcellos, a Democrat, is exploring the possibility of running; he has not declared his candidacy.

title: Court Rejects an Immunity For Some Federal Workers
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Federal employees who are under investigation for misconduct can be punished for falsely denying the allegations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDRIDGE, WILLIAM T.
description: ELDRIDGE-William T. Of Darien, CT. on Jan. 18, 1998, at age 72, of cancer. Package goods marketing and advertising executive and entrepreneur. Survived by wife Marlene (Pete) Eldridge, daughters Linda Tarbox, Donna Eldridge, Sandra Kohler, Elizabeth Morton, and 4 grandchildren. Memorial service Sat., Jan. 31, 1998 at 2 P.M. at Noroton Presbyterian Church, 2011 Post Road, Darien, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, PEARL
description: ROGERS-Pearl. We will miss your smile, spirit and sense of humor, and thank you for some of our most cherished memories. Most of all, we will miss you as a warm and loving friend and mother, and you shall remain in our hearts forever. Respects at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, NYC on Friday, January 23, from 10 AM to noon. In lieu of flowers please make donations in her memory to the American Cancer Society. With Love, Beth, Debbie, Bruce and Les

title: Treasury Prices Gain, With 30-Year Bond Set to Yield 5.81
description: Treasury prices gained yesterday after a slumping stock market helped erase early losses.

title: The Housewares Show Awards, of a Sort
description: THERE is no mistaking what draws more than 2,000 exhibitors and tens of thousands of retailers to the annual International Housewares Show here. The Rival Company promised those attending this year's version, which ran from Jan. 11 to Jan. 14, that its array of appliances would make cash registers go ''cha-ching!''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROGOVIN, SAUL
description: ROGOVIN-Saul. 3/24/22-1/22/95 In loving memory of my beloved husband. Missing you every day. Evie

title: In Interviews, President Denies Affair With Intern
description: In the past, the White House has often relied on aides and even former aides to defend President Clinton from scandal, his frequent if not constant companion.

title: Viacom May Form Joint Venture For Simon & Schuster Trade Unit
description: Viacom Inc., which has put its Simon & Schuster publishing business up for sale, is exploring the formation of a joint venture of Simon & Schuster's trade publishing division with other trade publishers, according to an executive close to the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEL, DR. HARRY
description: SEIDEL-Dr. Harry, 89. On Jan. 20, 1998, in Williamsburg, VA. A native of New York, Dr. Seidel had a private podiatry practice in Manhattan for 47 years. He was dedicated to his profession and a devoted family man. He is survived by and will be remembered as the beloved husband of Regina for 65 years, loving father of Suzanne Schoenbaum, cherished grandfather of Carol Wolf and Robert Schoenbaum, adored great-grandfather of Michelle Wolf, dear brother of Shirley Krauss.

title: From Beethoven to Rouse: The Philharmonic's Next Season
description: A Beethoven symphony cycle, celebrations of George Gershwin's and Duke Ellington's centenaries and the world premieres of works by Sofia Gubaidulina, Christopher Rouse and Tan Dun are among the New York Philharmonic's offerings for its 1998-99 season, Kurt Masur's eighth as music director.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Narrowed In November in Surprise Drop
description: The United States trade deficit unexpectedly narrowed in November, though analysts said it was likely to be only a brief respite before the Asian economic crisis leads to larger deficits this year.

title: A Night in Havana
description: Anchors for the network television news shows had to report on the latest accusations against President Clinton from Havana, where they had gone to report on the visit of Pope John Paul II.

title: Memorabilia Sale Helps Victims of Store Swindle
description: Nearly four years ago, the owner of a well-known sports memorabilia store in Levittown was charged with selling photographs and other items with forged autographs of some of the biggest names in baseball, including Joe DiMaggio, Ted Williams and Mickey Mantle.

title: Eastern Europeans Keep Ex-U.S. Spies in the Cold
description: Mihaly Bencsik had been on the inside of the Soviet Union's Communist Party apparatus, and by the time he walked into an apartment building near an American military base in Munich in 1981, he was ready to tell what he knew.

title: Brooklyn Man Kills Niece And Then Shoots Himself
description: A Brooklyn man shot his 11-year-old niece to death and then committed suicide on the roof of his Crown Heights apartment building, the police said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the fourth-quarter results of three big banking companies referred incorrectly to an internal memo at Citicorp about its earnings. The memo was written by a company executive, not by John S. Reed, the chief executive, and it was not circulated among employees.

title: Havel Still Czechs' No. 1 Despite Narrow Victory
description: PRAGUE  It was a slap in the face, but Vaclav Havel hardly seemed to mind.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Might as Well Be Spring

title: Host Marriott to Acquire 4 Complexes
description: The Host Marriott Corporation is planning to buy four retirement communities for $96.2 million, as the company expands its roster of housing for the elderly.

title: Our Towns; A Neighbor Just Says No To Casinos
description: THE beginning of the very long day she had been waiting for started out quite productively for Lillian Bryant.

title: Public Eye
description: ''I FOUND Rome in brick,'' Emperor Augustus boasted late in his life, ''and I leave it to you in marble.'' From about 50 B.C. to A.D. 15, Augustus rebuilt the city, not in a day, to be sure, but pretty quickly: he slapped up new temples at the rate of 80 in one year.

title: Hamed's Next Bout May Be at the Garden
description: Is Madison Square Garden ready for another party by the Prince? The negotiations for Prince Naseem Hamed's next fight, which will be against Kennedy McKinney, are almost complete. And all those involved would love to have the bout at Madison Square Garden, which was the site of Hamed's first American bout on Dec. 19.

title: Bridge; Four Books on Defense, The Hard Part for Many
description: It is often said that defense is the most difficult part of the game, an arguable proposition. It is probably not true for experts, who win and lose their points mainly in the area of bidding, but it is true for everyone else. Four recent books from England are worthy contributions to this important field. In ascending order of difficulty they are:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOFEL, HARRY J.
description: TOFEL-Harry J. On January 21, 1998. Loving husband for 67 years of Lee. Devoted father of Joseph and Robert. Proud grandfather of Steven, Beth, Richard, Lawrence and Brett, and great-grandfather of Peter, Matthew, Colby, David, Andrew, Rachel, Colin, Carly and Alex. Services Friday at Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Avenue at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: Swiss Didn't Mistreat Labor-Camp Internees; Jewish Children's Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLINAN, RICHARD
description: HALLINAN-Richard. The Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of the national office of the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation mourn the passing of our esteemed former chairman, Richard J. Hallinan, Esq. Mr. Hallinan served as a member of the Board of Trustees from 1965 to 1992 and held the position of vice chairman. He was named chairman of the Board in 1984 and served in that office until 1988. Mr. Hallinan was a true humanitarian who cared deeply about our work to improve infant health, and his vision and leadership were especially valuable to our research program to fund lifesaving medical breakthroughs for babies. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President Richard J. Freeman, Chairman

title: Despite Balancing Act, Richter Maintains Focus
description: As if he needed any reminders, Mike Richter is discovering day by day that his two hockey lives have begun to merge.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports of The Times; 2 Coaches Pretending To Be a Good Subplot
description: THERE is nothing complex about this Super Bowl story line. The questions are as clear as they have ever been: Can Denver end a miserable skein of embarrassments? Can the American Football Conference snap a 13-year losing streak? Will John Elway outduel Brett Favre and win a championship in his fourth try?

title: RUBBERMAID PLANS $200 MILLION COST-CUTTING
description: Rubbermaid Inc. said yesterday it would take a pretax charge of up to $200 million in the next two years to cut costs. The maker of plastic and rubber products said its earnings would fall short of analysts' estimates for the third consecutive quarter in the fourth quarter. The company, based in Wooster, Ohio, said it would report fourth-quarter net income of about $32 million, or 21 cents a share, up from $19.9 million, or 13 cents, in the quarter one year ago. Rubbermaid was expected by analysts to earn 25 cents a share. Rubbermaid said increasing costs and falling prices had prompted it to undertake the moves. The company said it would consolidate its worldwide procurement operations and reorganize its manufacturing and distribution.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Trade Deficit Drops, But Asia Impact Widens

title: Metro Business; Decision on Wiz Fate Is Expected Monday
description: Lawyers for the the Wiz, the Carteret N.J., electronics retailer that filed for bankruptcy last month, said yesterday that they would announce on Monday whether the company will be liquidated or whether a deal is in the works to sell the 52-store chain.

title: A Big Board Vice Chairman Will Step Down
description: James Jacobson, a vice chairman of the New York Stock Exchange since 1996, will step down in June and not seek reappointment, a Big Board spokesman said yesterday.

title: Book Award Nominees
description: These are this year's nominees for the National Book Critics Circle Awards, which will be awarded on March 24 in a ceremony at New York University Law School:

title: Friendship of 2 Women Slowly Led to the Crisis
description: Monica Lewinsky, 24, formed a fateful friendship with an older woman, Linda Tripp, 48, at a time in her life when she was distraught and looking for a sympathetic ear, according to Government investigators and people who have worked with the two women.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about competition among wheelchair manufacturers misidentified the purchaser of a medical supply company, Medipex. It was Graham-Field Health Products Inc., not the Invacare Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBETT, JOHN T.
description: CORBETT-John T. (Retired Printer NYC). On January 20, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Florence, dear uncle of Delphine and Julian Covell. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Ave at 97 St, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial, Friday, 10:15 AM, St. Patrick's Church.

title: $1.4 Billion Boeing Charge to Force First Yearly Loss Since '47
description: The Boeing Company, compounding one of its worst annual financial performances in 50 years, said yesterday that it would take a $1.4 billion pretax charge against its earnings for the fourth quarter of 1997 related to its merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, RAE
description: WEISS-Rae. Beloved wife of the late Harry J. Weiss. Loving mother of Cynthia Lefcort (Mac). Grandmother of Robert Lefcort (Marilyn) and Wayne Lefcort. Great-grandmother of Melissa Hope and Stephen Ira. Services were held.

title: Letterman Acting In Student Films
description: DAVID LETTERMAN wants to be in pictures again. (Remember his big scene in the 1994 flop ''Cabin Boy,'' in which he bellowed, ''Do ya wanna buy a monkey?'')

title: For Freeman, Waddle Comes Before Swagger
description: Quack, quack, quack!

title: Workers Remove the Rest Of Wall That Collapsed
description: Demolition crews working before the morning rush hour yesterday carefully took down much of the remainder of the crack-ridden western wall of the State Theater, which collapsed onto the roof of an adjacent building on Monday, officials said.

title: End Video Poker Gambling, South Carolina Chief Urges
description: To hear the Governor tell it, the very soul of South Carolina is at risk in a high-stakes game of video poker, which has resulted in everything from rampant gambling addiction to the death of a child.

title: Whitman Backs Charter School Expansion
description: In the first public appearance of her second term, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman visited one of the state's most successful charter schools today to announce that she would allow 23 more of the independent public schools to open in New Jersey by 1999.

title: Bonding in a Rapture of Rhythm
description: When a good salsa band blows through New York, the way Roberto Roena y Su Apollo Sounds did last week, the shows attract the farandula, the street scene. The best dancers showed up at Mr. Roena's show at the Copacabana on Tuesday night. The best nondancers showed up as well, the cognoscenti and fans, the music business people. And musicians showed up, including a group of Cubans in town for a concert at Lincoln Center. The house was packed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOLFETAS, DIMITRI
description: MOLFETAS-Dimitri. The loveliest of men. Friendship through eternity. Babis and Helene

title: Trade Secrets; The Private Life of Club Chairs
description: THINK of what Freud could have done with a leather club chair instead of a couch. People might have discovered they liked themselves. Had a drink or read a book instead of regressing. Sunk into something other than despair.

title: In America; The Spirit of Randall Robinson
description: While we're traveling the country having these Oprah-like feelgood conversations about race, somebody ought to take notice of Randall Robinson's anger.

title: The Pop Life; Transformation Of a 'Sunday'
description: ''No Tengo Dinero'' by Los Umbrellos may be one of the strangest songs climbing the pop charts. It's based on a 1960's movie melody ''Never on a Sunday,'' by the Greek composer Manos Hadjidakis, produced like a reggae song and topped with Spanish lyrics sung by a pair of Danish models and an English rap delivered by an exiled African prince. Originally intended to bring the world together in a pop song and sweep through vacation resorts like a new ''Macarena,'' ''No Tengo Dinero'' ended up as a hit in America before Europe and Club Med even accepted it.

title: Independent Counsel Cites Deceit Pattern
description: The Whitewater independent counsel decided to ask the Justice Department to expand his investigation because new evidence suggested a possible pattern of obstruction of justice involving President Clinton and his close friend Vernon E. Jordan Jr., law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, HENRY
description: LEWIN-Henry. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Dr. Jonathan Lewin on the loss of his beloved father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Microsoft Gives In To a Federal Order On Internet Browser
description: After insisting for weeks that its World Wide Web browser software could not be separated from its Windows 95 operating system, the Microsoft Corporation agreed today to do just that to avoid being found in contempt of court.

description: 'Drawers'

description: Theodore J. Kaczynski pleaded guilty today to all the Federal charges against him, acknowledging that he was the Unabomber who killed and maimed people with package bombs in a solitary 18-year campaign aimed at bringing down the technological system.

title: INSIDE
description: Abortion Case Remembered

title: Switched-On Spin, Without Turntable
description: Hip-hop modernists populated Tramps on Tuesday night, throwing beats and rhymes that might have made T. S. Eliot run for his notebook. If high-art avant-gardists like Eliot sought the essence of art in its sources and structures, their approach scarcely differs from that of Rhazel, the X-Ecutioners and Common. Each act explored hip-hop's origins in order to forge new paths.

title: Sadness Now Mixes With Relief And Regret
description: For those maimed or deprived of loved ones by packages meticulously assembled by the unabomber, the guilty plea yesterday by Theodore J. Kaczynski elicited a mixture of bitterness, relief, gratitude and sadness.

title: First Dutchman In Super Bowl
description: Broncos defensive end Harald Hasselbach is the first Dutchman to reach the Super Bowl, but that bit of history hasn't electrified the Netherlands. The country's lone news media representative here is Hasselbach's 31-year-old brother Ernst-Paul, who is trying to capture the essence of the event for the Netherlands' commercial television station, SBS6, and is also writing for Het Parool, an Amsterdam- based newspaper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVITO, ROCCO
description: DeVITO-Rocco. On January 21, 1998. Loving husband of the late Margaret (nee Binetti). Beloved father of Dominick, Julius and Nicholas. Father-in-law of Marie and Mary. Dear brother of Gaetano. Loving grandfather of Rocco, Joey and Margaret Ann, Nicholas, Jr., Margaret and Dawn and seven great grandchildren. Funeral from Thomas M. Quinn and Sons, Inc. 35-20 Broadway, LIC, NY on Saturday 8:30 AM, Funeral Mass 9:30 AM at Mt. Carmel RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Time Warner Exercises Canal Plus Option
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had exercised an option to buy 10 percent of the Canal Plus S.A. satellite pay-television company CanalSatellite, giving it a foothold in Europe's emerging digital television market. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

description: LUGO-Alfredo. On January 20, 1998. Beloved father of Christine. Loving son of Herminia Lugo (nee Sule). Fond brother of Raul, Johnny, Robert, Tyrone, Myrna, Minnerva, Evelyn and Marina. Cherished grandfather of Christopher. Funeral from Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, NY, Friday 10AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. James E. McQuade, Director.

description: VOGEL-Alfred T. 8/04/06 01/23/92 Dear Dad, six years and two new great grandchildren later... we still love and miss you. Jane, Lynn, Anne and Family

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: I loved the hearty food conceived by Tom Valenti at Wall Street Kitchen and Bar. I liked the huge beer list as well. But every time I tried to eat at the crowded restaurant, the noise drove me out. After a while, even the promise of a great short-rib sandwich couldn't make me enter that cacophonous space.

title: Outsiders Come In For Attention
description: You could call it pure coincidence, careful planning or a highly symbolic harmonic convergence. Or even a cocktail of all three. But this weekend, the increasingly popular, amorphous realm of outsider art -- or folk, self-taught, naive or visionary art -- is casting a long, friendly shadow over the Manhattan art world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERNAN, RICHARD ROWEN
description: KIERNAN-Richard Rowen. On January 22, 1998. Husband of Greta and friend and companion of Judy Frisch. Father of Ann, Mark, Paul, John, James Kiernan and Clare Lafferty. Grandfather of ten. Brother of David and Jerry. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Saturday and Sunday 2-5 P.M. Funeral mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, on Monday at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Renal Dialysis Unit of Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: MARC to Acquire Agency in Dallas
description: MARC Advertising in Pittsburgh said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Larkin, Meeder & Schweidel, an agency in Dallas. Terms were not disclosed.

title: What Light? It Is the East, and Juliet Is a Son
description: Olivia Hussey he isn't. But when Daniel J. Shore takes the stage in ''Shakespeare's R & J,'' a vibrant, hot-blooded new adaptation of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' you just might forget for a spell all the more Botticelli-esque fawns you've seen in the role of Juliet.

description: SORKIN-Charles. All of us at the East Midwood Jewish Center profoundly mourn the passing of Charles Sorkin, Honorary Trustee, long-time member, and devoted leader of our synagogue. His sincerity, decency and hard work made him a invaluable resource. We pray that God will send His blessings of comfort to his dear wife Marcia and to the entire family. Marsha Shlefstein, President Alvin Kass, Rabbi

title: Ford Is Moving Lincoln-Mercury Headquarters to California
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that the headquarters of its Lincoln-Mercury division would move to Southern California, marking the first time that a division of one of the Big Three domestic auto makers has moved out of the Detroit area.

title: On My Mind; Heart of the Matter
description: Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat came here with the heart of the matter on both their minds -- the survival of Israel and how peace would affect it.

Billings were not disclosed. The agency creates campaigns for the ESPN network and the ESPN program ''Sports Center.''
