title: Aikman Honored by N.F.L.
description: Troy Aikman didn't make it to the Super Bowl this season, but today he was named the True Value/N.F.L. man of the year for his work on behalf of hospitalized children in the Dallas area.

title: Some stock analysts may end up working for the companies they cover. Does that color views?
description: STOCK analysts on Wall Street are charged with helping investors determine which companies are on the rise and which companies are on the decline. But what happens when they begin talking with a company not only about its future but about their place in it?

title: Metro Business; Software Industry Growth
description: The software industry in the New York metropolitan region expects to post strong revenues during the next few years, according to a study released this week by KPMG Peat Marwick, an accounting firm.

title: Teamster President Struggles to Rebut Charges and Keep His Post
description: In a bid to avoid being expelled from the teamsters' union, Ron Carey, the union's president, struggled during cross-examination today to rebut charges that he knew about an improper fund-raising scheme for his campaign and had failed to oversee the union properly.

title: When NBC's Millions Counted for Something
description: NBC's decision to sever a 33-season relationship with pro football after Sunday's Super Bowl is reason to look back at what NBC thought when it first got in, with a five-year deal to televise American Football League games beginning in 1965.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENGARINI, ARIEL
description: MENGARINI-Ariel. On January 9, 1998, Ariel Mengarini, M.D. board certified psychiatrist, born October 19, 1919 in Rome to what the Dictionary of American Biography calls ''a distinguished Roman family.'' Ariel, with his mother, the sculptress Fausta Vittoria Mengarini, came to the United States when he was still a young boy. He finished his education in Washington, D.C. and in New York. When he was 23, he became United States Amateur Chess Champion. Chess was a lifelong obsession for him. He became a United States citizen in 1942. He honorably served in World War II. He was a Captain in the United States Army Medical Corps-Neuropsychiatrist. In Germany, he made part of a team to take over the administration of a large prison-of-war hospital. He received three campaign medals and the World War II Victory Medal. Honorably discharged in October 1946. He worked for the United States Government as a psychiatrist. He was devoted to his patients and said that he was ''proud to have helped a great many of them.'' Upon retiring, he continued his intense interest in the game of chess, playing in tournaments throughout the rest of his life. He wrote a book on chess: ''Predicament in 2-Dimensions: The Thinking of a Chess Player'', which had three printings. He wrote chess articles and articles on his medical specialty. He was an avid reader with a wide interest which included history, philosophy, poetry, fiction and the study of the human brain. He is survived by his loving wife Aristea Drivas Mengarini, his daughter Athena, his son Will, and by nephews and nieces in Maryland, along with their children and grandchildren and by first cousins in Italy, Germany and Sweden. He died of brain cancer after an illness lasting eight months. ''Comforter, where, where is your comforting?''

title: Stricker Finds Range Again After Quitting Tour in '97
description: Golf became so frustrating for Steve Stricker last year that he simply stopped playing.

title: Judge Offers Specific Plans For Schools
description: A judge appointed by the New Jersey Supreme Court to address inequities between the state's poor and wealthy school districts has recommended that the state spend $312 million more a year on its urban schools for programs ranging from all-day preschool for 3-year-olds to psychological counseling for high school students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERR, MAX
description: SCHERR-Max. Temple Israel, Lawrence, New York, mourns the death of Max Scherr, father of Jeffrey Scherr and extends deepest sympathy to the family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: CLINTON AND VERNON JORDAN TIGHTEN DENIALS ON AFFAIR AND ON SEEKING A COVER-UP
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., an influential Washington lawyer and a close friend of President Clinton, today stated ''absolutely and unequivocally'' that the young White House aide with whom the President is accused of having a sexual affair had told him that it never occurred.

title: Sears's Net In 4th Quarter Down and It Warns on '98
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that its earnings dropped in the fourth quarter, and it warned that first-quarter profit would decline substantially, because more customers are falling behind on credit card payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVIAR, IRIS
description: KAVIAR-Iris. On January 20, 1998. Loving wife of George. Devoted mother of Glen, Eric, Craig, Brent. Proud grandmother of six. Memorial service at 2 P.M., Friday, January 23 at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Robbins Program At City Ballet
description: A master of American musical theater, the choreographer and director Jerome Robbins helped popularize the genre with epochal shows like ''On the Town,'' ''West Side Story'' and ''Fiddler on the Roof'' that brought the common man onto the Broadway stage and made a scruffy hero of him. Mr. Robbins also brought the everyday world to both American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet, putting three wartime sailors onstage in ''Fancy Free'' and pouring out an entire village of abstracted dreamers, lovers and friends in ''Dances at a Gathering.'' And though among dancers he has a reputation as an unrelentingly stern taskmaster, Mr. Robbins is also known for making it plain to performers that the art of dance is as much about the outside world as it is about the hermetic life of the studio.

title: Sports of The Times; It Could Be Very Last Super Bowl
description: STOCK up on your munchies and your drinks and gape at the Super Bowl on Sunday. We're going to miss it when it's gone.

title: Comptroller Forecasts 2d Big Surplus
description: For the second year in a row, city auditors are projecting that the city will end its fiscal year with more than a $1 billion surplus, a larger-than-expected windfall being generated by factors ranging from rising tax collections to a drop in the number of people on welfare.

title: Modern Tries to Quash Order to Keep 2 Schieles
description: The Museum of Modern Art moved yesterday to quash a grand jury subpoena requiring it to retain two paintings with disputed ownership that were lent to the museum for its ''Egon Schiele: The Leopold Collection'' exhibition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS PLANS TO BUY A UNIT OF DIALOGIC
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Spectron Microsystems, a unit of the Dialogic Corporation, for more than $20 million in cash. Texas Instruments is Spectron's largest customer. Spectron, which has 60 employees, accounts for less than 3 percent of Dialogic's revenue. Dialogic, which makes software operating systems for digital signal processors, reported $68.8 million in sales in the third quarter. Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, has been selling defense and other businesses as it shifts from memory chips and focuses on more profitable digital signal processors, chips that translate inputs such as sound and light into the ones and zeros of digital signals in products like cellular phones, automobiles and camcorders.

title: Children Freeing a Sea Lion? If It Worked for Willy. . . .
description: In the long historical march of motion pictures, studded with images and effects that dazzle the eye, assault the ear and boggle the mind, now comes film with footnotes.

title: Journal to Start Technology Page
description: Continuing its program to expand its coverage, The Wall Street Journal announced yesterday that it will add a new Thursday page, Technology Journal, which will be devoted to technology business news and is set to begin on Feb. 12.

title: The Neediest Cases; Clicking Off the Television And Turning On to Reality
description: After Leonard Kissner's parents died back in the 1980's, he got involved with some characters who would lie, cheat, steal and commit adultery in the course of a single afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARHAFTIG, SARA
description: WARHAFTIG-Sara. Loving mother of Solomon and Raya. Grandmother of Jeremy and Daniel. Service at Shearith Israel Cemetery at 11 A.M. today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, MILTON
description: LEWIN-Milton. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our uncle who we loved very much. We will always cherish our fond memories of him. Jonathan Lowe Louise and George Miller

description: To the Editor:

title: Agassi Surging, Chang Stumbling
description: One player, the baldish and flighty one, has just returned from a self-styled trip to oblivion that taught him to treat his tennis talent like a brand-new car and demonstrate some pride of ownership. The other player, the gritty workaholic whose tennis talent has suddenly gone bankrupt, seems headed toward oblivion.

title: On H.I.V., Don't Name Names; 'Don't Ask' Is a Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Slaying Charge Called Justified by Confession
description: A day after a presumed murder victim returned home safely to Queens, law enforcement officials stood by their earlier decision to charge a man with murder in the case, saying the man repeatedly confessed to killing the 13-year-old girl, who had been missing for five days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. Partner in the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Eliza and Simon. Brother of Timothy and Ian Clark. Son of Blair Clark and the late Jessie Holladay Philbin James. His death occurred suddenly on January 15, 1998 in NYC.

title: From Festivals Or Short Runs
description: This week the independently produced movie is enjoying its annual due at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah. By this time next week, though, home video will have an unusually active independent scene of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONCHIN, ALEXANDER
description: DONCHIN-Alexander. With sorrow, the loss of a long time special friend and man of unusual interests who will be missed. Pearl Newman

title: Widowed by a Crocodile and More
description: Cultural satire is not a prized commodity on television. Though a few shows like ''Politically Incorrect'' announce their daring, then struggle to live up to it, most satire sneaks in quietly, in late-night monologues (protected by standard talk-show babble), and in the occasional sitcom plot (surrounded by safe, cozy characters). Two of television's best and truest satires appear this weekend: ''Tracey Takes On . . .'' on HBO, and a special post-Super Bowl episode of NBC's ''Third Rock From the Sun.'' Neither boasts about its social commentary, but that is what gives the comedy its appealing bite.

title: Patients, Not Customers
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Don Celander

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Peter Campus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLDUC, EDGAR, JR.
description: BOLDUC-Edgar, Jr. You were my dearest client. You honored me with your friendship for thirty-five years. I loved you like a brother. My condolences to all the family. Jerry Abrams

title: Tell the Full Story, Mr. President
description: The term ''carefully worded'' has appeared in almost every description of President Clinton's denials of sexual involvement with Monica Lewinsky. Other words that could as easily be applied are cryptic, partial and insufficient. Those terms also apply to Vernon Jordan's compact statement that had, in addition, the unwholesome feel of an attempt to portray the President's secretary, Betty Currie, as a central player in the attempt to find a job and a lawyer for Ms. Lewinsky.

title: DANCE REVIEW: A Flurry Of Dance; Baryshnikov At City Center
description: At the end of the fourth and last solo on the program he is performing this week with a chamber music group, Mikhail Baryshnikov stands alone on the darkening stage at City Center. It isn't a case of me and my shadow but of me and my heartbeat. Suddenly, a conceptual work about a dancer generating sound in front of a sensor that amplifies electrical impulses from the brain to the heart becomes a touching study in vulnerability.

title: MALLINCKRODT CONSIDERS SELLING TWO OF ITS BUSINESSES
description: Mallinckrodt Inc. said yesterday that it was exploring the sale of its industrial specialty chemical and aerospace businesses to focus on the health care industry. The specialty chemicals are used as additives for paints and plastic coatings, catalysts, laboratory chemicals and chemicals used in microelectronics. The unit, which has 1,400 employees, had sales of $335 million last year. The aerospace business makes oxygen equipment, video systems and passenger-service products. Mallinckrodt, based in St. Louis, also makes products for diagnosing and treating respiratory problems, and medical imaging devices and drugs. Shares of Mallinckrodt rose 25 cents, to $35.1875.

title: Greening a South Bronx Brownfield
description: The Getty Center is finished, the Guggenheim Bilbao branch is done, the competition to design the Museum of Modern Art's expansion has ended with the choice of a graceful plan. After this cluster of high-profile projects, architecture deserves a breather. Here's a breath of fresh air: Maya Lin's design for the Bronx Community Paper Company. A scale model and drawing for this thoughtful, idealistic design are now on view at the Urban Center in a crisply installed show presented by the Municipal Art Society.

title: A Disciple, Precisely, of Nat (King) Cole
description: If you're a performing musician, there are essentially two ways of approaching vintage jazz styles. One is scholarly and analytical, and sees history as a series of blips on a continuum. The other, represented by performers like the jazz guitarist and singer John Pizzarelli, is so emotionally committed to tradition that cool academic scrutiny has little to do with it.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROGOFF, IRA
description: PROGOFF-Ira. With love to a devoted and wise parent. Sue, Jon, Richard, Daniel and Matthew

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIERSTEIN, PHILIP
description: FIERSTEIN-Philip. For further information please call Apter's Funeral Home, Maplewood, New Jersey 973-763-3505.

title: An Unsettling Sifting of Truth and Trust
description: What if what we call our past is just a dream, and life is really a process of waking up to a different and harsher reality than anything we've been prepared to experience? The fear that life may only be a collection of memories and symbols that we willfully organize into a coherent narrative, the anxiety that what we call ''home'' may only be an illusion, permeates Attila Janisch's 1997 film, ''The Long Twilight.'' The film, which will be shown this evening at 8 at the Walter Reade Theater, is one of the opening films in the series ''Somewhere in Europe,'' a sweeping, thoughtfully chosen historical survey of Hungarian cinema, one of the richest in Eastern Europe.

title: Pinault-Printemps Makes $1.5 Billion Offer
description: The French retailer Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire the stationery and office-supply group Societe Guilbert S.A. for about 9.1 billion francs, or $1.5 billion, in cash and stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERMANO, ANTON
description: GERMANO-Anton, 58. Of New York City died October 29, 1997. Donations may be made to Kaleidoscope Dance Theatre, P.O. Box 1101, Auburn, New York 13021.

title: Court Orders F.C.C. To Obey Its Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court ordered the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to stop circumventing a ruling by the court that leaves pricing decisions on local phone service to the states.

title: Special School District's Backers Gird for 3d Suit and More
description: Two times state lawmakers have created a school district for a Hasidic Jewish enclave in Orange County, only to see the courts rule it unconstitutional. Undaunted, they did it a third time last year, only to have it again challenged in court.

title: Palm Beach High Rollers Get a Fair
description: Park Avenue real estate may be hot and Aspen may be heaven, but no place can touch Palm Beach, Fla. In 1996, more than half of the 22 houses in the United States that sold for more than $10 million were in Palm Beach, The Palm Beach Post reported. Last October, the newspaper said that 19 mega-mansions ranging from 23,000 to 64,000 square feet were being built or had recently been completed between Jupiter Island, 20 miles to the north, and Boca Raton, 25 miles to the south. (By comparison, Bill Gates's house in Medina, Wash., has 45,000 square feet.)

title: Reaching Across the N.F.L.'s Color Line
description: With the regular season over and the Super Bowl looming, a group of African-American assistant coaches has publicly discussed filing a class-action discrimination suit against the National Football League. The coaches point to the case of Sherman Lewis, the outstanding offensive coordinator of the Green Bay Packers, who was not considered for any of the 11 head coaching positions that were vacant after the 1996 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANG, ZIANG TSIEN, M.D.
description: TANG-Ziang Tsien, M.D. On Jan. 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Lynn, father of Henry, Frank and Lillian and grandfather of David and Penelope. Services today, Friday, 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Waking From the Nightmare of Life With Mother
description: MY SISTER LIFE

title: ROCHESTER GAS AND ELECTRIC TO SHUT 106-YEAR-OLD PLANT
description: The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would close its coal-burning Beebee Station power plant next year. The plant, which has been open since 1892, generates about 80 megawatts of electricity. It is the company's smallest coal-burning plant. The closing will affect about 35 employees, who will be eligible for either an early retirement package, reassignment or retraining for jobs outside the company, Rochester Gas and Electric said. The utility, based in Rochester, said that the cost of meeting the requirements of the Federal Clean Air Act was a factor in the plant's closing, as was its fit with nearby development in Rochester.

title: Homebuyers Who Need Help
description: The Clinton Administration wants to raise the limit on home mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration from roughly $170,000 to $220,000. By insuring mortgages made by private lenders, the F.H.A. makes the loans risk-free, a bountiful gift to mortgage lenders and real estate agents throughout the country. But many community groups oppose the idea, and for good reason. It would deflect the F.H.A. from the important task of helping people with modest incomes buy, and keep, their first homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, ED
description: GOTTLIEB-Ed. On January 20, 1998. Great husband, father and a brilliant public relations consultant. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions in his memory to the Hospital for Joint Diseases/Orthopedic Institute. Janet, Liz and Richard

title: Metro Business; Realty Company Expands
description: NRT Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., the largest franchise holder in the Coldwell Banker chain of residential real estate brokerages, said yesterday that it had acquired Joseph J. Murphy Realty Inc., a Saddle River company with 25 offices in northern New Jersey.

title: Officer Pleads Not Guilty To Fatal Choke Hold
description: A former police officer, Francis X. Livoti, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a Federal charge that he violated the civil rights of Anthony Baez, a Bronx man who died after he was choked during an arrest in 1994.

title: NOVA AND TRANSCANADA PIPELINES CONSIDER A MERGER
description: The Nova Corporation said yesterday that it and TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. were in merger talks that would create a $9.66 billion pipeline company. Nova, based in Calgary, Alberta, is a petrochemicals and natural gas services company. It owns about 25 percent of the Methanex Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia. TransCanada PipeLines, also of Calgary, is a gas transportation company with nine-month net income of $343.7 million (Canadian) on revenue of $10.36 billion (Canadian). Analysts said it was important for the companies to combine before Nova completed its planned split into natural gas transport and chemicals companies, which could generate accounting charges that would hurt earnings for years.

title: Gustavo Lobo, 92, Commodities Executive
description: Gustavo F. Lobo Jr., a leading commodities executive for 57 years, died on Dec. 28 at the Andrus Retirement Community in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Mr. Lobo, a resident of Bay Hill, Fla., was 92.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of nominees for the National Book Critics Circle Awards yesterday misidentified the publisher of ''The Blue Flower,'' a novel by Penelope Fitzgerald, who was nominated in the fiction category. It is Mariner Books/Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: Ad Bowl Serves Up Chips, Both Snack and Computer
description: Brace yourself, America. Madison Avenue is about to unleash its annual all-out assault on your senses, otherwise known as Super Bowl advertising.

title: Observer; Is This the End of Rico?
description: The latest tale about President Clinton's extramarital sex life is so bizarre that it's tempting to say, ''Nobody can be that dumb.''

title: Queens College Forging Ahead With AIDS Center Plan
description: Energized by a commitment of nearly $20 million from the state and the city of New York, Queens College forged ahead yesterday with plans to create a world-class center for AIDS research and introduced the head of the center, a discoverer of the AIDS virus.

title: Housing Tax Credits
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSLER, DOROTHY
description: TESSLER-Dorothy. On January 20, 1998, devoted wife of the late David, beloved mother of the late Jack, loving grandmother of Gabrielle and Michelle. Family will receive Friday 3PM-7PM, Saturday and Sunday 12PM-5PM.

title: The 23 Percent Solution?
description: Suppose a bunch of rich people want to promote a national sales tax to replace the Federal income tax. How do they try to persuade the public to support such a plan? Simple: play with the arithmetic.

title: Nets Talk Quietly About Beating the Bulls
description: The last time the Nets faced Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls, Jayson Williams tried hard not to make any of the little mistakes that could set Jordan off. The normally loquacious Williams kept his mouth shut, trying not to be noticed, trying not even to acknowledge Jordan's presence. But late in the game, Jordan got him.

title: Fund Managers Get New Rules On Advertising Past Performance
description: Mutual fund managers who leave a fund company to set up their own shop will not be allowed to advertise the performance of the fund they managed at their previous employer, even though that information might be allowed in the prospectus of the new fund, according to guidelines announced yesterday by the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Amy Hauft

title: Official Says Indian Casino Was Rejected On Its Merits
description: The House's chief inquisitor into campaign finance abuses tried to show today that career Interior Department officials were pressured by their politically appointed bosses to recommended killing an Indian casino project in Wisconsin.

title: Metro Business; Nine West Trimmed Corporate Jobs 6%
description: The Nine West Group of White Plains, the largest women's shoe maker in the nation, said yesterday that since October, it had dismissed 85 employees, or 6 percent of its corporate work force, in an effort to cut costs.

title: . . . and in TriBeCa
description: ''We were saying how much fiction and real life are coinciding,'' said DREW NIEPORENT, a partner with ROBERT DE NIRO (who co-starred in ''Wag the Dog'') in Nobu, the fashionable and well-reviewed restaurant in TriBeCa.

title: Groaners and Grinners: Images Ever Adolescent
description: Though photomontage has traveled the world, it has never shaken its adolescent roots. Whether in Germany, where it began with the Dada movement, or in Russia, where it found a political cause, or in France, where it linked up with Surrealism, it has remained resolutely immature, a rebellious art exulting in clever visual puns, overly significant juxtapositions and crazy assemblages of ill-fitting body parts. At its best, it is deft satire and at its worst, heavy-handed commentary.

title: Girls' Coach Admits Molesting 7 Players
description: A Medford man who coached girls' youth soccer and softball admitted yesterday that he molested seven of his players from 1991 to 1996, the Burlington County Prosecutor's office said.

title: For Malamud, New York as a Mood
description: ''In New York, who needs an atom bomb?'' the gloomy writer Lesser thinks in Bernard Malamud's novel ''The Tenants.'' ''If you walked away from a place they tore it down.'' Fortunately, Malamud's fiction has proved more durable than the tenements and struggling grocery stores his characters inhabit. His stories were given new life in a complete collection recently published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux, and three of them will be read on Wednesday at Symphony Space by the actresses Linda Lavin and Marian Seldes in a tribute to this most New York of authors.

title: Cairo Journal; Fasting for Faith, This Winter, Is a Long Banquet
description: Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of daytime abstinence, is a moveable fast. It can arrive at any season, whether it be the long hot days of summer or the cool short days of a Middle East winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARISI, MARIE J. (NEE DATTOMA)
description: PARISI-Marie J. (nee Dattoma). Loving wife of Joseph, devoted mother of Camille, Michael and Joseph. Reposing at Papavero Funeral Home, 72-27 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Funeral Mass Transfiguration R.C. Church, on Saturday at 10 A.M. Entombment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Hours 2-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Kimbell Director Is Resigning

title: Kerr to Acquire Bayer Unit
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, the energy and chemical company, said today that it had agreed to buy the European titanium dioxide pigment business of Germany's Bayer A.G. The purchase price was not disclosed. Kerr-McGee will initially receive an 80 percent stake in Bayer's titanium dioxide marketing, research and development and manufacturing activities.

title: Reports of Sexual Scandal Have Everybody Talking
description: Television networks rushed their anchor men home from the Pope's Havana visit and interrupted their daytime soap operas with live White House briefings. Internet sites specializing in political scandal became unreachable through overuse. Radio talk show hosts, handed a topic with an enviable mix of sex and power, found their switchboards jammed.

title: On H.I.V., Don't Name Names; A Secret Till Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Remarks on Case by Kaczynski's Brother
description: Following is the statement of David Kaczynski, who had suggested to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that his brother, Theodore, could be the Unabomber, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Back to a Rustic Playground of the Gilded Age
description: Ideally, the exhibition titled ''A Central Park for the World: New York's Adirondack Park'' should be seen by the light of the silvery moon. Or maybe as a prelude to paddlin' Madelin' home on a sun-flecked summertime lake in upstate New York.

title: Once Again, Devils Lack Power to Prevail
description: The Devils boast one of the most efficient teams in the National Hockey League, but their power play has not been anything to brag about lately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIGEL, SAMUEL E.
description: SEIGEL-Samuel E. Attorney and Counselor at Law, on January 21, 1998; only twelve days after the passing of his beloved wife and best friend, Pauline M. Seigel. Born March 29, 1912. He was a community leader, innovative President of the Kiwanis Club of Elmont, NY and founding chairman of the Aircraft Noise Control Council of Nassau County, Inc., credited with creating the impetus to compel the aircraft industry to add noise suppressors to jet planes. Father of Florence (Ralph) Belkind and Elaine (Martin) Schwartz. Grandfather of Dennis, Deborah and Alison Schwartz. Service at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York, Sunday, January 25, 1998 at 11:30 AM. Interment at the J&B Moroch Family Circle plot at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAZEN, BURCHARD M.
description: HAZEN-Burchard M. On January 22, of Vero Beach, FL. Husband of Emily French Hazen. Also survived by daughter, Barbara Glidden of Dedham, MA., son, Burchard M. Hazen, Jr. of Sebastian, FL and two grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of Vero Beach, FL.

title: Quiet on the Williams Talks
description: The agent for Bernie Williams says that the Yankees center fielder is headed for free agency next fall, but George Steinbrenner is playing down the issue. The Yankees owner said yesterday that he would not let Williams overshadow other matters, cutting short any public discussion of the contract negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, BARBARA
description: ALTMAN-Barbara. At age sixtysix, on January 22, 1998. Loving wife of Daniel. Mother of Michael (Marita). Devoted grandmother of Samantha and Theodore. Services Sunday, January 25, 11:30 A.M. at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Crowd Quiet And Staid: 'Pope Leaves, But We Stay'
description: Before Pope John Paul II had left this provincial capital today to meet with President Fidel Castro in Havana, most of the yellow and white signs put up to welcome him had been taken down.

title: Bill Would Restrict Corporate Gifts to Candidates
description: New York City edged closer yesterday to prohibiting candidates in city elections from accepting corporate donations, which were an important source of financing during last year's mayoral campaign.

title: For Greeks in Turkey, Distrust Turns to Fear
description: An arson attack and a killing at a holy Eastern Orthodox site in Istanbul, the second violent assault here in two months, have led senior Orthodox figures to question Turkey's commitment to protect their church.

title: Sharpton Lawyer Berates Judge in Brawley Defamation Case
description: In one of the nastiest outbursts to rattle the Tawana Brawley defamation trial in several weeks, the lawyer representing the Rev. Al Sharpton launched a prolonged, detailed personal attack today against the judge that culminated with a request that the judge recuse himself and declare a mistrial.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Fall
description: On the smaller American Stock Exchange, the decline was much sharper, with open short positions falling 10.6 percent from 189,131,890 to 171,012,058. Short positions on the American exchange also declined a month ago, down 1.8 percent.

title: Residential Real Estate; Town House Project Is Rising on Hudson Shore
description: The first town house project to be built along the resurgent Hudson River in a decade is rising at the water's edge in West New York, N.J.

title: POPE & TALBOT SAYS IT WILL SELL TISSUE BUSINESS
description: Pope & Talbot Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its private label tissue business to an investor group led by Plainwell Inc. for $121 million in cash and $26 million in debt, refocusing the company's attention on its pulp and lumber business. Pope & Talbot, a producer of wood-fiber products in Portland, Ore., said the unit generated $136 million, or 29 percent of Pope & Talbot's total revenue, in 1997. The plants to be sold are in Ransom and Pittston, Pa., and in Eau Claire, Wis. Plainwell is based in Plainwell, Mich. Shares of Pope & Talbot fell 25 cents, to $14.3125.

title: Jones Giddy Over Three-Year Pact
description: Bobby Jones could have been Calvin Coolidge in a previous life, given his reserved manner. But the Mets pitcher was overflowing with enthusiasm yesterday after agreeing to a three-year, $13.35 million contract that binds him to the team through the 2000 season.

title: Judge Denounces U.S. Visa Policies Based on Race or Looks
description: Jose Bayeux, a 24-year-old technician in Brazil, said he wanted to travel to Miami and Disney World for a vacation in 1994. He applied for a tourist visa at the United States Consulate in Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city.

title: H.M.O. Investigated Over Fee Practices
description: The state is investigating claims that a Neptune-based health maintenance organization canceled surgeries at hospitals where anesthesiologists refused to accept a 20 percent fee cut and redirected them to hospitals whose doctors agreed to the reduced fees, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, IVAN, SR.
description: BENJAMIN-Ivan, Sr. 80. January 20, 1998 (formerly of Guyana). He is survived by his beloved wife Edna of 50 years; his children Edris, Ivor, Ivan Jr., Lolita, Jim and Mortimer; nine grandchildren; and his sisters Christina Burton, 93 years old, and Beatrice James, 85 years old. Viewing Friday 7-9 PM, Dowd Funeral Home, 165-20 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, New York. Service on Saturday, 9 AM at St. David's Episcopal Church, 117-35 235th St., Cambria Heights, New York. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery, 83-12 Kew Gardens Road, Kew Gardens, New York.

title: Flyers Maintain Their Advantages Over the Rangers
description: When Philadelphia eliminated the Rangers in the third round of the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring, the Flyers seemed a little bigger, a little stronger, a little faster, a little younger and a little more talented. Since then, the Flyers have got a little better and the Rangers have got a little worse.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Fraying Alliance: Iraq Sees Sanction Backers Divided
description: In an orchestrated series of steps during the last week, President Saddam Hussein has sent the world an unmistakable message: Seven years after the Persian Gulf war, Iraq is going to extricate itself from economic sanctions, with or without permission from the United Nations Security Council.

title: Indonesia Currency Falls Hard, Clouding Recovery
description: A week after Indonesia agreed to stringent new austerity measures that increased hope somewhat for Asian economic stability, this country's currency plummeted Thursday and again this morning, to new lows that roiled other Asian markets and threw into question the prospects for Indonesian recovery.

title: PSINET REJECTS OFFER FROM USINTERNETWORKING
description: Psinet Inc. said its board rejected an offer from USinternetworking Inc. to buy at least a 51 percent stake in the company for $10 a share in cash. The offer price was 19 percent, or $1.5625, higher than Psinet's closing price of $8.4375 on Wednesday. Psinet, an Internet service provider, said the proposed offer was ''inconsistent'' with its business plan, including its alliance with IXC Internet Services Inc. USinternetworking, based in Washington, is a company whose stated purpose is to acquire Internet-related companies. It is run by Christopher S. McCleary, the former chief executive of Digex Inc., an Internet service provider that was bought by Intermedia Communications Inc. last year. Shares of Psinet rose 56.25 cents, to $9.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VALVOLINE CO., Lexington, Ky., agreed to acquire privately held Eagle One Industries, of Carlsbad, Calif., a maker of premium car-care products, for undisclosed terms.

title: 10 Youths Indicted In Hate Crimes
description: Ten Burlington County youths were indicted yesterday on charges they terrorized local black and Asian families from 1994 to 1996, Peter G. Verniero, the State Attorney General, announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOFEL, HARRY J.
description: TOFEL-Harry J. On January 21, 1998. Loving husband for 67 years of Lee. Devoted father of Joseph and Robert. Proud grandfather of Steven, Beth, Richard, Lawrence and Brett, and great-grandfather of Peter, Matthew, Colby, David, Andrew, Rachel, Colin, Carly and Alex. Services Friday at Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Avenue at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: New Vigor for a Prosecution Once Seen as Flagging
description: In his three and a half years as the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, Kenneth W. Starr has spent more than $25 million, won three convictions in Federal court and obtained 10 guilty pleas.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 9 about the financial dealings of the family of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan referred incorrectly to the holder of a 1990 contract to provide preshipment verification of major imports for the Pakistani Government. The contract signed by Ms. Bhutto's Government was with Cotecna, a Swiss concern, which later became an affiliate of Societe Generale de Surveillance, another Swiss company; S.G.S. was not the holder of the 1990 contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRYSTAL, SOPHIE GERSCHEWITZ
description: CRYSTAL-Sophie Gerschewitz. On January 22, 1998. Wife of Aaron (deceased). Mother of Joel and Tamar. Mother-in-law of Marilyn. Grandmother of Wendy. Long time teacher at S.J. Tilden High School, Brooklyn, New York. Known as Sunny, the Head Counselor to generations of campers. Services on Friday, 12:30 P.M., at Zion Chapel, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck.

title: The Wrong Place for Queen Catherine
description: There is no comprehensive Who's Who of those involved in the trans-Atlantic slave trade. But even if one existed, it is highly unlikely that Queen Catherine of Braganza, a Portuguese noblewoman who became the wife of England's Charles II, would merit a separate entry. As far as historians can tell, she played no active role but was a member of two royal families that chartered and sought to profit from companies involved in the slave trade.

title: Shuttle Blasts Off With Last American to Live on the Mir Station
description: The space shuttle Endeavour, its crew including the last American astronaut scheduled to live aboard the Mir space station, blasted off tonight for a rendezvous with the Russian outpost in space.

title: On the Spice Rack: Hits and Hairdos
description: A fantasy sequence in ''Spice World,'' the sunny feature-length music video in which the Spice Girls make their movie debut, finds the stars looking blowsy and boozy sometime in the not-so-distant future. Motherhood has not been kind (''Thank God for boarding school!'' one exclaims), and the ex-celebrities have grown so over-the-hill that they no longer even like pop music. Disarmingly, the film thus acknowledges the Spice Girls' flash-in-the-pan status and lets them kid around about their frankly synthetic career. It even incorporates a dead-on assessment of their recording style: ''That was absolutely perfect without actually being any good.''

title: Formerly of Bouley
description: In the early 1990's, it seemed that not a week went by without another Manhattan restaurant opening with a chef ''formerly of Bouley.'' When David Bouley closed his Manhattan restaurant in 1996, former Bouley employees flooded the market. Now some have left town or are between jobs, but these 12 restaurants still have Bouley alumni in important positions.

title: Reliving an Unremembered Life
description: O'Neill fashioned a masterpiece around a case of tuberculosis. Ibsen saw cataclysmic family tragedy in a diagnosis of syphilis. Now, as evidence that even the most obscure entry in a medical encyclopedia can serve the prescriptions of the stage, the playwright Paul Mullin has brought forth a drama that takes on . . . Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

title: Fiat Chief Wants G.E. Officer as Successor
description: The chairman of Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest corporation, said today that he would step down in June and would recommend that Paolo Fresco, a vice chairman of the General Electric Company, take his place.

title: On H.I.V., Don't Name Names
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Name? Public Health? Public Ruin?
description: YOU wade through murky waters when you delve into the business of naming names. From Elia Kazan's informing on old Hollywood Communists to John Dean's blabbing about Richard M. Nixon's Watergate sins, emotional arguments have swirled, even to this day. Are we talking about heroes who did what had to be done, or the lowest of the low: snitches and finks?

title: A Waggish Tale In Washington . . .
description: LARRY BEINHART sounded as if he was having an I-told-you-so kind of day. As the author of the novel on which the film ''Wag the Dog'' was based, he was chuckling about what many moviegoers consider parallels between the developments in Washington and his sardonic story of entertainment bigwigs advising yuppie careerists whose only loyalty is to the power of public opinion polls.

title: People
description: -- Andrea MacDonald, former senior partner and director for nontraditional media at Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of WPP Group, left to open MacDonald Media, New York, where she is president and chief executive.

title: Administration Proposes Moratorium on New Logging Roads
description: The Clinton Administration proposed a moratorium today on building new logging roads into millions of acres of national forest for the next year and a half, but it exempted large areas of Alaska and the Pacific Northwest from the moratorium.

title: Looking Back At 2 Classics
description: By the time he was 30, Paul Schrader (left) had written the screenplay for ''Taxi Driver,'' which was directed by Martin Scorsese and starred Robert De Niro. Four years later, the three men teamed up again for ''Raging Bull,'' the 1979 classic that, like ''Taxi Driver,'' was arguably one of the most significant films made since World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLLIN, RABBI NATHAN J.
description: KOLLIN-Rabbi Nathan J. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, age 92. After ordination in 1929, he served congregations in Ottawa, Youngstown, Ohio, Richmond, VA., and Buffalo, NY. In 1953, he assumed the pulpit of Rodef Sholom in Johnstown, PA. from which he retired in 1970. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, Joel and Joanne and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Joan Sutherland's visit to New York City misstated the day when she would sign copies of her new book, ''The Autobiography of Joan Sutherland: A Prima Donna's Progress,'' at the Metropolitan Opera Shop. The event took place yesterday; she will not appear there today.

title: More Questions and Concerns
description: INQUIRY GETS A BOOST -- The latest accusations against President Clinton have put Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, back in the spotlight. There has been no public indication that Mr. Starr is close to proving wrongdoing by the President, the First Lady or any top Administration officials. Page A16.

title: Late to School, Without a Note
description: At least the Manhattan Borough President, C. VIRGINIA FIELDS, didn't say the dog ate her limousine.

title: Trade Now Would Shock Van Gundy
description: His players consumed with speculation and innuendo, Jeff Van Gundy decided to deal with the facts. The Knicks he coached yesterday are the Knicks he is coaching today. And if he has further say in the matter, Van Gundy would like to keep it that way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANCIGER, HERBERT N.
description: DANCIGER-Herbert N. January 19, 1998, outstanding family man. Beloved husband of Beulah Klein; devoted father of Roanne and Hank Gotthelf; Leslie Wander and Harvey and Sandi Danciger. Adored grandfather of Kenneth and Wende Gotthelf; Sean and Jeffrey Wander; and Aimee and Jill Danciger; loving great grandfather of Justin. Cherished brother or Ruth Danciger. Service 12PM Sunday at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Arson Destroys Luxury Home In Weston, Baffling the Police
description: A $2 million home in the affluent town of Weston, Conn., was virtually destroyed in an arson believed to have occurred on Jan. 10, about a month before a family was to move in, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, LOUIS A.
description: SOLOMON-Louis A. (Buddy). Suddenly on January 21, 1998. Beloved husband of Bernice (nee Fiering). Devoted father of Sally Cohen and Richard Solomon. Caring fatherin-law of Arnold Cohen and Carol Solomon. Dear brother of Frances Litman. Cherished grandfather of Joseph Resignato, William Solomon and Aaron Cohen. Services today, 10AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Hoisting a Pint to a Heritage; New Breed of Irish Bars Caters to the Culturally Curious
description: The evening was a cold, dank weep, the kind of weather that can bring on thoughts of doom. Thus it was an ideal time to settle into the snug dimness at Rocky Sullivan's, one elbow propped up on the bar and one hand cradling a pint of Guinness. Up and down the bar, activity was at full boil.

title: Sharp Rise Is Seen in Deaths Of Those on Foot and Bikes
description: After declining steadily since the start of the decade, the number of pedestrians and bicyclists killed by motor vehicles in New York City jumped sharply last year, to 302 from 245, according to preliminary police figures.

title: TRIGEN ENERGY ACQUIRES NORTH CAROLINA COMPANY
description: The Trigen Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Power Sources Inc., an energy producer based in Charlotte, N.C., for $63 million. Power Sources, with annual revenues of about $17.9 million, is expected to add about 9 cents a share to Trigen's annual earnings. Trigen Energy, a power generation company based in White Plains, had 1996 revenues of $243.6 million.

title: Novartis Sales Rise 13.6% in Quarter
description: Novartis A.G. posted an implied fourth-quarter sales increase of 13.6 percent, lifted by new drugs and growth in sales of crop-protection products. Sales rose to 7.33 billion Swiss francs

title: Jack Lord, 77, Helped Direct And Starred In 'Hawaii Five-O'
description: Jack Lord, the deadpan star of ''Hawaii Five-O'' who made ''Book him, Danno'' a fixture of American slang, died Wednesday at his home in Honolulu.

title: Slaying Puts Prosecutor on Spot Again Over Death Penalty
description: The killing of an undercover detective in the Bronx on Monday night has once again placed the Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, under heavy political pressure to seek first-degree murder charges against a man accused of killing a police officer and to consider seeking the death penalty.

title: Hormone Seen As Risk Factor For Cancer Of the Prostate
description: Researchers have identified a new risk factor for prostate cancer that may be present in as many as 25 percent of men. Those men, with high blood levels of a certain hormone, have four times the risk of prostate cancer as men with lower levels, though the high readings do not mean that men are certain to develop the disease.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Virtues of Adopting an Orphan Car
description: MY dad always drove Hudsons; he loved Hudsons.

title: Isles Can't Hold Lead On the Road
description: ISLANDERS 3, BLUES 3

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Both Sides Rally to Mark Abortion Ruling
description: Twenty-five years after the Supreme Court recognized a constitutional right to abortion, tens of thousands of abortion opponents marched to the Court today in somber protest, while abortion rights advocates pledged to fight any rollback.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Atlanta Committee Wraps Up '96 Games
description: Acknowledging problems with technology and transportation, but exulting in the successes of the sports competitions, the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games published its final report yesterday on the centennial Olympics of 1996.

title: Family History Translated Into Stories in Movement
description: Keely Garfield is one of the wittiest of today's experimentalist choreographers. The new and recent dances Ms. Garfield presented in ''My Mother Was a Four-Alarm Fire and Other Mostly True Dances'' on Tuesday night at Dance Theater Workshop were filled with deadpan, mostly physical incongruities. But there was also a surprising depth to most of the pieces. Ms. Garfield has talked about her nutty family and about how personal histories eventually settle into the muscles and the bones. The best of the dances here bore out her ideas.

title: Posing as Electricians, Five Men Steal $80,000
description: Five men dressed as electricians stole $80,000 in cash from a 76-year-old man's East Village apartment yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, LOUIS
description: ROBBINS-Louis, 86. Of Fort Lee, NJ on January 22, 1998. Retired principal musical librarian of New York Philharmonic Orchestra. Husband of the late Ann and Eve. Devoted father of Walter (Toby) and Steven (Frances) Robbins, four grandchildren. Services on Monday 10 A.M. at Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 1534 Pennington Road, Trenton, N.J. Burial at Pinelawn Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Steve McQueen

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Francisco Leiro

title: New Video Releases
description: Broken English

title: Prices Are Mixed; 30-Year Off Sharply
description: Treasury prices were mixed yesterday, with longer-term securities down sharply on strong housing and labor reports, while shorter maturities gained as investors sought refuge from the Asian financial turmoil.

title: Four A's Council Nominates Officers
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York said yesterday that its advisory council had nominated executives to serve as top officers for the 1998-99 year.

title: Accusations Presenting Many Issues on the Law
description: In addition to the political problems, the accusations that President Clinton had a relationship with a former White House intern raise numerous legal questions.

title: Golf Cart Gives Disabled Athlete No Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about President Clinton's lawyer misstated his given name. He is Robert Bennett; William Bennett, the former Education Secretary, is his brother.

title: Majoli's Many Blunders Lead to 3d-Round Exit
description: With a swing and a miss, the French Open champion Iva Majoli, the unpredictable Croatian who last year became the first player from that nation to capture a Grand Slam title, pumped out the last of her 33 unforced errors and blundered her way out of contention today in the third round of the Australian Open.

title: Statement by the President
description: Following is a statement by President Clinton today regarding accusations that he had an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky and, with the cooperation of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., had sought to have her lie about it. Mr. Clinton's statement, made at a White House photo session with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company.

title: CUNY Open Admissions Is Ripe for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: 13-Year-Old Tells Police Of Rapes at School
description: A 13-year-old girl told the police yesterday that she was raped twice in the stairwell of a Manhattan intermediate school last year by a 17-year-old boy. The girl, whose name was withheld because of her age and the nature of the crime, said the rapes occurred in November and December.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURDEN, CARTER
description: BURDEN-Carter. Another year gone by. We think of you everyday. M & D

title: Mary Bunting-Smith, Ex-President of Radcliffe, Dies at 87
description: Mary Ingraham Bunting-Smith, the Radcliffe president who sought ways to help educated women carve out careers in a society not yet transformed by the feminist movement and became a mentor to several female writers, performers and scholars, died on Wednesday at Kendal at Hanover, a continuing care community in New Hampshire. She was 87.

title: Sprewell Gets Ready for New Arena: The Hearing Room
description: Bound together, the document is about an inch thick. A copy rests in the conference room of the National Basketball Players Association office in midtown Manhattan. It is laced with depositions and protocol and is unlike any playbook Latrell Sprewell has had to read before.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Letting Art Out of the Bag

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREMIN, JOANNE LAURA
description: CREMIN-Joanne Laura. On January 21, 1998. Devoted daughter of Charlotte and the late Lawrence. Dear sister of David and sister-inlaw of Dana-Joy. Beloved companion of Daniel Schlenoff. Cherished aunt of Stephanie, Eliot, Natasha and Phillip. Services Sunday, 10:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. For information regarding the memorial gathering and location on Friday, 4-6PM, call 212-570-3956

title: Where's the Joy of Life? The Dirt Poor in Cuba Wonder
description: Eight-year-old Yanela Nemer, who wants to be a ballerina, left her home before dawn today wearing her only pair of dressy shoes. The shoes, black patent with a bow, are reserved for special occasions like the trip to Santa Clara to see John Paul II today.

title: Door Is Still Open For a State Trial
description: The Government's plea agreement with Theodore J. Kaczynski resolves all Federal cases against him, but states could still bring murder charges that carry the death penalty or attempted murder charges against him, said Robert J. Cleary, the chief Federal prosecutor handling the case.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts and Leisure section on Sunday for the New York Philharmonic's concert tonight at Avery Fisher Hall misstated the nature of the concert, the performance time and part of the program. It is a regular evening concert, not a ''rush-hour concert''; it starts at 8, not 6:45. The program consists of William Schuman's ''New England Triptych,'' Joseph Schwantner's Percussion Concerto, John Zorn's Orchestra Variations and Aaron Copland's ''Billy the Kid.''

title: Death Row and Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: A Monster Hungry for Attention
description: How on earth did actors of the stature of Peter O'Toole and Ben Affleck (whom ''Chasing Amy'' and ''Good Will Hunting'' has put on the fast track to major movie stardom) get bamboozled into lending their talents to a junky little horror film like ''Phantoms''? Adapted by Dean Koontz from his own novel, the movie finds a cadaverous, glassy-eyed Mr. O'Toole squirming uncomfortably in the role of a loony scholar-turned-tabloid writer named Timothy Flyte who is an expert on ancient epidemics.

title: Percussionists Step Into the Spotlight as Soloists
description: Percussionists are team players. Most work obscurely as part of an orchestra, usually at the back.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Man in the News: Lewis Dennis Schiliro; A Career Crime Fighter
description: Now that Lewis Dennis Schiliro, the new head of the F.B.I.'s New York office, works in a tastefully appointed office with an expansive view of the midtown Manhattan skyline, it might be easy to overlook the fact that his career began, quite literally, in the dumps.

title: Red Storm Triumphs In Double Overtime
description: They had to fight through their own sluggishness in the first half, overcome a tenacious Pittsburgh team in the second half and battle through two overtime periods, but St. John's basketball players managed to push their winning streak to five games with a 90-83 victory over the Panthers tonight at Fitzgerald Field House.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Compromises, Avoiding Punishment

title: RUTHERFORD-MORAN IS CONSIDERING MERGER OR SALE
description: The Rutherford-Moran Oil Corporation said yesterday that it might seek a merger or sale to help pay for oil exploration in the Gulf of Thailand. Ruthorford-Moran, an oil and natural gas exploration company based in Houston, said it had hired Morgan Stanley & Company and Chase Securities to ''explore various strategic alternatives,'' including a sale. Rutherford-Moran, through its Thai Romo unit, has concentrated on a concession from the Government of Thailand to explore about 750,000 acres in the Gulf of Thailand. The company has reported mounting losses and plans to spend about $110 million this year, according to financial filings. Its shares rose $1.5625, to $18.50.

title: Lift Fiscal Burden From Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Labor Leader Seeks Union Support in Mexico
description: John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., began a two-day trip to Mexico today that he said was aimed at encouraging Mexican and American unions to help each other in cross-border organizing drives and to find other ''practical ways to work together.''

title: Mehta and Masur Match Up In a Contrast of Conductors
description: For New Yorkers, two concerts this week by the Israel Philharmonic offered an interesting juxtaposition: Zubin Mehta, the orchestra's music director for the last 30 years and the conductor of the Monday evening concert, also spent 13 years on the podium of the New York Philharmonic. Kurt Masur, Mr. Mehta's successor in New York, led the Israeli orchestra on Wednesday.

title: Washington Mayor's Actions Say Campaign
description: In what appears as the strongest sign yet that he intends to run for re-election in November, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. spent more than 12 hours today tapping the pulse of constituents in the Anacostia section of town, his political base in all six of his previous campaigns.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Rita Ackermann

title: Brooklyn School Was Inspected Before Bricks Fell
description: City construction officials inspected a Brooklyn vocational high school and found it safe just five days before a wide swath of brick facade broke free from the building's rear wall and crashed through a protective shed to the sidewalk Wednesday night, city and school officials said yesterday.

title: Lady-Killer Meets the Wrong Lady
description: With unexpected success, Robert Altman plays a John Grisham mystery in a seductive new key with ''The Gingerbread Man.'' It's a film that illustrates not only the delicacy of Mr. Altman's brooding, richly atmospheric style, but also an important maxim: never trust buzz. Murderous advance word branded this film as all but unreleasable, but it turns out to be Mr. Altman's best genre piece since ''The Long Goodbye.'' And like that film, it turns its setting into a significant character in a tempestuous detective story. The intriguing Savannah that eluded Clint Eastwood's ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil'' is very much alive here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIKMAN, DAVID P.
description: DIKMAN-David P. Of Tamarac, Florida. Formerly of Queens, NY. Husband of Beverly, father of Steven, Bernard (Buddy), fatherin-law of Carol and Chuck Davis, grandfather of Andrew. Insurance executive in Ridgewood Queens, President of Kiwanis and Knights of Pythias, member of Bellerose Jewish Center. Contributions to American Cancer Society, 8383 McNab Road, Tamarac, FL. 33321.

title: Pataki Asserts Confidence In Fund-Raising Practices
description: In his first public comment on a Federal inquiry into his campaign finances, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he was ''absolutely confident'' that no wrongdoing had occurred, suggesting that he was so unconcerned that he had not even spoken about it to campaign officials.

title: Currency Hits Record Low Vs. Dollar In Canada
description: A record number of American tourists are making overnight trips to Canada, and for good reason. The Canadian dollar has plunged 5 percent against the dollar since October and dropped to its lowest value ever yesterday, making trips north of the border much more affordable.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our reaction to today's plea agreement is one of deep relief. We feel it is the appropriate, just and civilized resolution to this tragedy in light of Ted's diagnosed mental illness.''

title: Ukrainian Patient: A Romance In the Rain
description: What cinematic dessert could be tastier than an epic, star-crossed romance that transports you to the land of forever, where the words of every sappy love song you've never paid attention to suddenly ring loud and clear and true? ''Swept From the Sea,'' Beeban Kidron's adaptation of Joseph Conrad's story ''Amy Foster,'' wants desperately to be that kind of movie, but falls sadly short.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNRO, VIOLET (POWELL)
description: MUNRO-Violet (Powell). Of Newton Center, MA, Jan. 21, 1998. Wife of the late James S. Munro. Mother of Patricia LaBranche of Marblehead, MA and Amagansett, NY, Carol Barker of Bryn Mawr, PA, Jane Barrett of Concord, MA, James S., Jr., of Nahant, MA and Donald Munro of Hot Springs, AK. Also survived by 24 grandchildren and 44 great grandchildren. Memorial services in Newton Highlands Congregational Church, 54 Lincoln St., Tues., Jan. 27 at 11A.M. Gifts in her memory may be sent to the Mass. Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society ''Bafalin Fund'', 101 First Ave., Waltham, MA 02154 or Immanuel United Church, P.O. Box 149, Ocho Rios, St. Ann, Jamaica, W.I.

title: Arafat Tells Clinton Israel's 10% Pullback Offer Is Short
description: In talks here this week with President Clinton, Israel offered a withdrawal from less than 10 percent of the West Bank, in three phases over several months, officials on all sides said today. But the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat told Mr. Clinton in his own talks today that the offer was insufficient, the officials said.

title: New Concern, Few Answers On Ford Fires
description: A LAWSUIT filed this week by the nation's largest auto insurer raises new concerns for millions of owners of Fords, Mercurys and Lincolns about the possibility that defective ignition switches may cause fires. And while the case raises a number of questions, the owners may find that there are, as yet, few clear answers.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Hanne Darboven

title: Societe Generale Unit To Buy Yamaichi Stake
description: Societe Generale Asset Management of France said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an 85 percent interest in Yamaichi International Capital Management, a unit of the failed Japanese brokerage house Yamaichi Securities. Financial terms were not disclosed. Societe Generale Asset Management is a unit of Societe Generale, the French bank.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEATING, MICHAEL B.
description: KEATING-Michael B. On January 23, 1997. Devoted husband of Diane. Beloved father of Michael, Catherine and Cynthia. Loving grandfather of Brett and Lindsey.

title: A Mood of Dismay and Concern in a Democratic Stronghold
description: Bettina Tahsin considers herself ''a pretty strong Democrat'' who twice voted for Bill Clinton for President, and when she first heard about the accusations that Mr. Clinton had had an affair with a White House intern, Ms. Tahsin said she was unperturbed.

title: Killer Casts Shadow on Brother Who Seeks to Be a Federal Prosecutor
description: In his bid to become the top Federal prosecutor in the Southern District of Texas, Roland Garcia Jr. presents some impressive credentials. He is a partner in a prestigious law firm here, a director of the Houston Bar Association and a past president of the Hispanic Bar Association. The Democratic members of Congress in the Southern District have officially recommended him for the post.

title: On H.I.V., Don't Name Names; Universal Precautions
description: To the Editor:

title: Man With Clinton Scoop Is Scooped Again
description: IT was an investigative reporter's biggest nightmare, and worse, it was recurring. On Saturday, Michael Isikoff of Newsweek, likened by his friends to a cruise missile in pursuit of a story, had in his computer one of the most explosive scandals in American political history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, ADELINA P.
description: LEHMAN-Adelina P. Thursday, January 22, at noon at her home. Loving wife of the late Alcuin W. Lehman. Beloved sister of Mary Berol, Bedford Hills, N.Y., Vera F. Bissell, Cambridge, MA., and Grace Pope of NYC. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday 2-5 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66 St., Monday 10:30 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Lee Lehman to Cancer Research Foundation would be very much appreciated by her family.

title: Green Says He'll Quit Without a New Deal
description: Minnesota Vikings Coach Dennis Green said today that he would resign unless he received a contract extension by early next week.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Browser War: A Concession And a Push
description: Microsoft blinked yesterday in a pragmatic, if belated, gesture that concedes one tactical skirmish to the Government in its high-stakes antitrust battle with the software giant.

title: Golf Cart Gives Disabled Athlete No Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Removal of Ads Ruled Free Speech Violation
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority violated New York magazine's free-speech rights when it removed a satirical advertising campaign from city buses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, PEARL
description: ROGERS-Pearl. We will miss your smile, spirit and sense of humor, and thank you for some of our most cherished memories. Most of all, we will miss you as a warm and loving friend and mother, and you shall remain in our hearts forever. Respects at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, NYC on Friday, January 23, from 10 AM to noon. In lieu of flowers please make donations in her memory to the American Cancer Society. With Love, Beth, Debbie, Bruce and Les

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: John Baldessari

title: Clinton Contributor Recommended White House Aide
description: A retired New York City insurance executive who was one of President Clinton's top contributors recommended Monica S. Lewinsky for her job as a White House intern, a former Clinton campaign official and Government investigators said.

title: Bankers Trust Profit Up 12.5% in Quarter
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, defying expectations that Asian economic turmoil might have taken a heavier toll, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 12.5 percent.

title: POPE CHALLENGES CUBA ON ABORTION AND ON EDUCATION
description: Pope John Paul II met this evening with President Fidel Castro for 50 minutes behind closed doors in the Palace of the Revolution here, hours after he opened his evangelical mission to this Communist country with a Mass attended by 60,000 to 80,000 people, the largest crowd of Catholics to gather here in four decades.

title: Whitman Nominates New Prisons Head
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman nominated Bergen County Sheriff John S. Terhune yesterday to replace former Corrections Commissioner William H. Fauver, who resigned in November amid criticism of excessive overtime at the department.

title: Dow Continues Its Retreat as Profit Hopes Grow Dimmer
description: Another round of corporate earnings disappointments took its toll on stocks yesterday, dragging major indexes lower for a second consecutive day.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Skiing Made Simple But Still Such Fun
description: It's the day after New Year's, and I still haven't been skiing. Or snowboarding. Or even sledding. I can't remember the last time I went this late in the season without sliding on snow, and I don't like it.

title: AT&T Chief Said to Plan Big Job Cuts
description: Union leaders and senior executives at the AT&T Corporation, the nation's largest telecommunications carrier, said yesterday that they expected the company to announce on Monday that it intended to cut its work force by about 15,000 employees, or roughly 12 percent.

title: Packers and Broncos Wield Crossing Receivers to Break Down the Defenses
description: The defenses for the Green Bay Packers and the Denver Broncos do not want to be crossed on Sunday in Super Bowl XXXII. But it will very likely happen, frequently, with pass patterns by receivers from both offenses that create confusion.

title: Justice in the Unabomber Case
description: The Justice Department's decision yesterday to allow Theodore Kaczynski to plead guilty and avoid the death penalty was belated common sense. Mr. Kaczynski's mental illness threatened to disrupt the progress of any trial and made him a dubious target for execution. The department had unwisely rejected Mr. Kaczynski's offer last month to plead guilty in exchange for a life sentence without possibility of release. But a recent evaluation by a court-appointed psychiatrist indicating that Mr. Kaczynski is a paranoid schizophrenic appears to have altered the prosecutors' thinking.

title: G.I.'s in Bosnia Make Their First Arrest of a War-Crimes Suspect
description: American soldiers made their first arrest of a war-crimes suspect in Bosnia today. The soldiers leapt out of two unmarked vans and grabbed Goran Jelisic, a former detention camp commander who called himself the Serbian Adolf, as he left home. They put him in one of the vans and drove away without incident, according to witnesses.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the policy of the Iranian President, Mohammad Khatami, characterized the status of his overture to the American people incorrectly. The effort has been put aside for now; it is not dead.

title: Jervey Does Things His Way
description: It is often said that it takes a special breed to play special teams, and Travis Jervey of the Packers certainly fits that description.

title: INTERTAN SAYS IT WILL CLOSE 69 TANDY STORES IN BRITAIN
description: Intertan Inc. said yesterday that it would close 69 poorly performing Tandy electronics stores in Britain and dismiss the 230 employees who work there as part of a revamping of its British operations. The revamping will result in a charge of $13 million to $16 million, the company said. Intertan, based in Fort Worth, was spun off from the Tandy Corporation in 1986. It operates 1,600 stores in Canada, Britain and Australia under the names Tandy, Tandy Electronics and Radio Shack. Intertan reported that net income for its second quarter, ended Dec. 31, rose 19 percent, to $11.3 million, or 55 cents a diluted share, from $9.48 million, or 50 cents, in the quarter a year ago.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL PRICE LOWER AGAIN. Crude oil futures continued to fall, to the lowest price in more than three years, amid an increase in United States inventories and declining consumption in Asia. Oil for March delivery fell 32 cents, or 2 percent, to $16.04 a barrel. Heating oil and gasoline prices also fell.

title: Contract Extension Talks Stalled
description: The National Football League Players Association and the league's owners have reached an impasse on an extension of the collective bargaining agreement, and both sides feel a pact won't be reached soon.

title: State Casino Officials Fight Trump Land Deal
description: State casino officials are trying to back out of a plan to condemn a small restaurant in Atlantic City so that Donald Trump can develop the property, according to court documents unsealed yesterday.

title: Scientists Find No Evidence Of Bird Flu in Southern China
description: After a week in southern China, a team of international infectious disease experts announced today that they have not detected any evidence of the deadly bird flu virus that recently killed six people in Hong Kong and left almost a dozen others critically ill.

title: BENCHMARK ELECTRONICS TO BUY UNIT OF LOCKHEED
description: Benchmark Electronics Inc. has signed an agreement to buy the Lockheed Martin Corporation's Lockheed Martin Commercial Electronics unit for $70 million cash. Lockheed said yesterday that the Commercial Electronics unit, based in Hudson, N.H., provides printed circuit board assembly and testing, prototyping, depot repair, materials procurement and engineering support and employs about 680 workers. Roger M. Damphousse, president of Lockheed Martin Commercial, will be named president of Benchmark's Hudson unit. Benchmark Electronics is based in Angleton, Tex.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dollar Drop Roils Bonds, Sending Yields Up

title: Starr Inquiry Has Crossed the Line of Decency; Lesson of a Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Killer of Two At C.I.A. Draws Death Sentence
description: Mir Aimal Kansi, who murdered two employees of the Central Intelligence Agency outside the agency's headquarters five years ago, was sentenced today to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BEN
description: LEVY-Ben, of Garden City on January 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Hazel (nee Orpheus). Loving father of Rickie Hochman and Claudia Sukman. Proud grandfather of Hilary, Tom, Chris, Matthew and Dan. Funeral private. For information McCourt & Trudden Funeral Home Inc., Farmingdale.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I looked at him in court and I came to the decision, this is a profoundly evil person.''

title: Venerable Brands Go Modern With Help From U.S. : Dusting Off the British Classics
description: LONDON  They never show on the runways. The fashion revolution of the 1980s passed them by. Their sales, led by classic English men's tailoring and coats, have ticked over pleasantly but unspectacularly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARCHIBALD, BRIG. GEN. WILLIAM T.
description: ARCHIBALD-Brig. Gen. William T. on January 22, 1998. Loving brother of John Lauren Archibald and Robert Voorhees Archibald. Devoted uncle of four. Services will be Monday 11 A.M. at the Middlebush Reformed Church, Middlebush N.J. Interment will follow in Cedar Grove Cemetery, Middlebush. Relatives and friends may call Sunday from 1-4 P.M. at the Gleason Funeral Home, 1360 Hamilton St, Somerset. Memorial contributions may be made to the Middlebush Reformed Church, 1 South Middlebush Road, Middlebush, NJ 08873 or the Circumnavigators Club Foundation, 24 East 39th St., New York, NY 10016.

title: Artistic Equation: Old Music, New Ideas
description: Those who wonder what can still be done with the New York City Ballet's formula of presenting plotless neo-classical ballets with music as a prime springboard are in for a refreshing surprise.

title: We Need to Be America's Team
description: Unlike 99 percent of my fellow Wisconsinites, I don't give a hoot about football. In fact, the first time I watched a game was last year's Super Bowl. I'm pretty sure the Packers won, though it was hard to tell through the veil of boredom.

title: BID TO TAKE BET PRIVATE IS SEEN AS TOO LOW
description: BET Holdings Inc. said yesterday that a special committee of one board member determined that an offer by Robert Johnson, company chairman, and the Liberty Media Corporation to take the cable TV programmer private for $200 million, or $48 a share, was too low. The company, whose prime asset is the Black Entertainment Television cable channel, said it would hold more meetings with Mr. Johnson and his advisers on increasing the offer. Mr. Johnson and Liberty, the programming arm of Tele-Communications Inc., own all but six million shares and control 90 percent of the voting power. His offer has come under fire from other investors who contended he was trying to gain control of the company he founded for too low a price.

title: Pataki Says Root of Crime Is Criminals, Not Society
description: With a toughly worded speech designed to frame both the legislative session and his re-election campaign, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday ridiculed the notion that societal factors were to blame for violent crime and pledged to push for bills this year that would make it easier to imprison and, in some cases, execute criminals.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD RALLIES. Gold surpassed $300 an ounce for the first time in two months as the dollar weakened, making it cheaper for Asians and Europeans to buy the metal. Gold for February delivery rose $9, to $300.30 an ounce, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, MILTON
description: LEWIN-Milton. The community of the Abraham Joshua Heschel School expresses heartfelt condolences to our devoted trustee, John Lewin on the death of his beloved father. May all the members of the Becker-Lewin family be comforted by his noble memory. Terry Krulwich, President Roanna Shorofsky, Director

title: Editorial Observer; Revisiting the California Gold Rush Landscape
description: 150 years ago today, James Marshall reduced the flow of water through a tailrace at Sutter's Mill and found in the shallow stream a lump of gold. It was, he later wrote, ''about half the size and of the shape of a pea.'' The mill had been built on the bank of the American River for the purpose of sawing timber, but like nearly every other modest purpose in the territory of California, and indeed in much of the United States, milling lumber at Sutter's Mill was soon set aside in the frenzied search for gold.
