title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKOFF, HOWARD M.
description: WILKOFF-Howard M. With profound sorrow, the leadership of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations notes the death of our Honorary Life Treasurer. He served our cause with great devotion for many years and chaired numerous critical committees. A man of wit and wisdom, Howard was a source of strength to Reform Judaism giving of his time and talents as well as his means with generosity of spirit. We convey heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife Ida and all his dear ones. Jerome H. Somers, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, President Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, President Emeritus

title: Mondesi Agrees To $36 Million Deal
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers dealt a serious blow to the Yankees' salary arbitration case with Bernie Williams, reaching agreement with outfielder Raul Mondesi last night on a four-year, $36 million contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, REVA
description: COHEN-Reva. On January 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Marvin and Sandra Sunderland. Services Sunday 12 noon, Temple Kol Ami (JCC), White Plains. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Taking the First Steps of Freedom As an Inflexible Law Is Waived
description: Angela Thompson's son, Shamel, was born nearly eight years ago in a prison nursery here, behind the cinder block walls and razor wire fences of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, and raised by his aunts.

title: Evil, or Sick, to His Core: Two Views of Unabomber
description: For those whose lives he changed, this was a day for trying to make sense of the Unabomber, Theodore J. Kaczynski, who acknowledged on Thursday that he had spent years trying to kill people and who has shown no remorse.

title: Postal Worker Admits Stealing Stamp Money
description: A former window clerk at the main post office in West New York pleaded guilty yesterday to embezzling more than $117,000 from the post office, including money he collected from selling stamps, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Juror Subject Of Complaint On Behavior
description: The judge and lawyers in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial held a private meeting with the jury today to deal with the foreman's complaint that another juror was making inappropriate, opinionated remarks in the courtroom.

title: A Former Judge Admits Propositioning Women
description: A former Jersey City Municipal Court judge pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to propositioning dozens of women in exchange for fixing their traffic tickets, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Chrysler Net Up But Higher Costs Raise Concerns
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that were better than expected, but the numbers, particularly a sharp increase in rebates and other incentives, set Wall Street to worrying about the auto industry's prospects for this year.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Crippled Policy
description: When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Clinton sat down in the Oval Office on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton began by clearing the air. The President, according to U.S. and Israeli officials, basically said to Mr. Netanyahu: ''I know you're upset about reports that we're stiffing you, and that we're not doing a lunch for you, and that you're not staying at Blair House. But before you came in here today you met with my sworn political enemies [the Christian far right] who have put out tapes accusing me of having people murdered. So, Prime Minister, we're even.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUMMERE, WILLIAM JR.
description: GUMMERE-William Jr., died Wednesday January 21, at a Portland Nursing Home. Widower of Margaret (Peplow) Gummere. Survivors include 2 daughters, Mary Hall of Cumberland Foreside, ME, Agnes La Storia of Portland, ME, 4 sons, William, III of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Richard M. of LaPlanta, MD, Peter J. of St. Johnsbury, VT, John D. of Philadelphia, PA, 17 grandchildren and 1 great grandchild. A Mass of Christian burial will be 10 a.m. Monday Jan. 26th at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, Portland, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mercy Hospital, 144 State St., Portland, ME 04101 or St. Joseph's Manor, 1133 Washington Ave., Portland, ME 04013. For information Conroy-Tully Funeral Home, 172 State St., Portland, Maine.

title: Spreading Ripples of Crisis and Concern
description: THE WORLD WATCHES -- The sex scandal engulfing President Clinton is being greeted with dismay and bewilderment as it is avidly reported by television and newspapers around the world. Page A9.

title: Op-Art; Manhattan by the Foot
Arafat Departs, Calling Israeli Offer 'Peanuts'
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, left Washington today considering new American compromises but rejecting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's offer of a limited Israeli redeployment from less than 10 percent of the West Bank.

title: Pope's Call for Clemency Lifts Dissidents' Hopes
description: The dissident movement in Cuba is small, fragmented, isolated and constantly hounded. But by requesting clemency for imprisoned members of human rights and political groups, Pope John Paul II has given human rights advocates here and abroad hope that some respite, however brief and temporary, may soon be in the offing.

title: When No Good Bid Goes Unpunished: A Song of Woe
description: Sad bridge stories are often extremely funny, unless you are the sufferer. One of the saddest, and funniest, of the decade was reported by Zia Mahmood in his bridge column in The Guardian in Britain. The sufferer in the East seat on the diagramed deal was a touring professional named Eddie.

title: Bud Shuster's Heresy
description: Congress will spend most of this election year debating what to do with something it has not seen in 30 years -- a budget surplus. True, the surplus will be, at best, small for the next few years and will be replaced by deficits once the baby boomers begin to retire. But the mere possibility of a surplus will transform Congress from a purveyor of pain, like the deficit-reduction packages of 1990 and 1993, to purveyors of pleasurable surprises like tax cuts.

title: U.S.G.A. Backs PGA On Use of Carts
description: The U.S.G.A. has thrown its considerable prestige and influence behind the PGA Tour's decision to bar motorized carts in competitive golf tournaments. The PGA has generally adopted the U.S.G.A.'s rules for tournament play.

title: Inferno at White House Burst From Modest Kindling
description: If President Clinton had been accused of nothing more than having had an affair with a White House intern, it would have been embarrassing, maybe even shocking, but given the President's reputation for indiscretion, it probably would not have threatened his Presidency.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq Frustrates Inspector

title: Pope Urges Cubans to Find Their Christian Roots Again
description: Traveling halfway across Cuba to the most enthusiastic reception of his trip so far, Pope John Paul II urged Cubans today to find their Christian roots and warned them to stop a slide toward a life of ''emptiness,'' without faith, morals or ideals.

title: J. Austin Lyons Jr., 75, Ex-Met Life Counsel
description: J. Austin Lyons Jr., a former general counsel at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died on Jan. 8 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 75.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section on Thursday about Ben Kingsley's appointment as chairman of the jury at the Berlin International Film Festival next month misstated the number of Academy Awards he has received. He won an Academy Award for ''Gandhi'' (1982); he did not win one for ''Bugsy'' (1991).

title: Edward Safani, 85, Founder Of Gallery Selling Ancient Art
description: Edward Safani, founder of one of the oldest galleries of ancient art in the United States, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hingis Defeats Kournikova, With Little Love Lost
description: Mr. Congeniality, Andre Agassi, had no qualms about giving the opponent he had just thrashed a sympathetic tap on the back, but the players next up on the stadium court for today's feverishly anticipated showdown between the teen-ager who rules women's tennis and the teen-ager who rules its pinup sales made it obvious that theirs was no love match.

title: Where Writers Leave Their Imprint on Events
description: Emile Zola was not the first French writer to speak out on the political issues of his day. But more than anything done by, say, Voltaire or Victor Hugo before him, it was Zola's dramatic ''J'accuse,'' proclaimed 100 years ago this month in the infamous Dreyfus Affair, that inspired this country's writers to start using their prestige as artists as a way of influencing public opinion.

title: American Puritanism or Zionist Plot? Opinions Vary
description: From Tokyo, where it was headlined as the President's ''bottom-half problem,'' to Moscow, where a newspaper blamed ''the righteous wrath of diehard feminists,'' the world reacted with dismay and bewilderment to the sex accusations endangering Bill Clinton's Presidency.

title: West Seeing Payoff From Its Support for Flexible Leaders in Bosnia
description: Milovan Stankovic, a Bosnian Serb war hero and the new head of the Bosnian Serb police, quickly strode into a meeting here this afternoon and agreed to what most Bosnians and almost all foreign diplomats have wanted for months -- uniform license plates throughout the country.

title: Consumers Play Role In Depleted Fish Stocks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURASCH, MARTIN
description: KURASCH-Martin. 84. On January 23, 1998 in Stamford, CT. Loving husband of the late Lillian. Brilliant U.S. government career, serving as lawyer for War Labor Board, NLRB, General Counsel for Wage Stabilization Board and Rural Electrification Union. In 1951, he was First General Counsel and helped create Development Corporation for Israel until retirement in 1984. But most importantly, he had the gentlest soul, the sharpest mind, warmest laugh. Survived by daughters Toni Elizabeth, Polly (Terry) Blank; grandchildren Marni, Willa; sister Gladys (Stanley) Segal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIDERMAN, ANNA
description: BIDERMAN-Anna. On January 22, 1998. Loving wife of the late Leon, beloved mother of Mitchell and Ira. Mother-in-law of Mary Alice and Meryl. Devoted grandmother of Rachel and Jonathan. Services Sunday January 25, 10:30am at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, NY

title: Tagliabue To Confer On Black Coaches
description: National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said today that he would meet with black coaches and league executives in early February to deal again with the lack of black head coaches in professional football.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about discrimination in the issuing of visas to enter the United States was scrambled in some copies. The affected passage should have read: ''The visa policies 'instruct visa officials to rely heavily upon factors such as physical appearance and national origin when adjudicating the applications,' Judge Sporkin wrote. 'The principle that government must not discriminate against particular individuals because of the color of their skin or the place of their birth means that the use of generalizations based on these factors is unfair and unjustified.' ''

title: Argentine Officer Who Hailed '70's Is Cashiered
description: President Carlos Saul Menem today expelled from the Argentine Navy a retired captain who caused an international outcry last week when he defended torture and killing under the military dictatorship of 1976 to 1983.

title: Starr Inquiry Has Crossed the Line of Decency
description: To the Editor:

title: Von Stade Sings in a Work About Her Father at War
description: Getting to Carnegie Hall, as the old joke has it, is one thing; getting in is another. It takes a ticket, even for some performers.

title: Another Day, Another Indonesian Plunge
description: The International Monetary Fund and the Clinton Administration worked today to complete a plan to prop up the rapidly deteriorating Indonesian banking system, diplomats and Government officials said.

title: Computer Log of White House Visitors Becomes a Focus of Investigators
description: Monica S. Lewinsky's visits to the White House after her employment there ended are central to the allegations against President Clinton. The exact dates and times of those visits are in Secret Service records that Federal officials say are easily retrieved, even though Mr. Clinton and his lawyers have so far refused to divulge them.

title: School Has Success Down to a Science
description: How many grains of sand are on the beach at Coney Island? Is there a correlation between how many books students read independently and their English grades? And -- Woody Allen aside -- how close in age are most husbands and wives?

title: Man Pleads Guilty To Hacking Into a Bank
description: A 30-year-old computer programmer pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to breaking into a Citibank computer system and stealing $3.7 million in 1994. The man, Vladimir L. Levin, carried out the crime while he was living in St. Petersburg, Russia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, SAMUEL D.
description: MAY-Samuel D. 87. On January 22, 1998. Loving husband of Isabel. Beloved father of Linda and Stephen Sklar, and Leni and Peter May. Adored grandfather of Marci and Stu, Caryn, Kenny and Vivian, and Jon and Juliana, and Leslie and Andrew. Great-grandfather of Alison, Carlee and Jake. Brother of Richard. Services Sunday, 11:00AM, at Temple Israel, 140 Central Avenue, Lawrence, LI.

title: U.S.-Sweden a Testing Ground
description: When the United States men's national soccer team makes its 1998 debut today with a friendly match against Sweden at the Florida Citrus Bowl in Orlando, Fla., Coach Steve Sampson will be scrutinizing his players' fitness and how well certain individuals play together.

title: Clinton's Rapid-Response Squad Now Moves in Slow Motion
description: When Bill Clinton was running for President in 1992 and faced accusations of a 12-year extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers, his aides corralled reporters to declare that Ms. Flowers was lying and had been paid by trashy tabloids.

title: Streaking Storm Has First Place in Sight
description: St. John's Coach Fran Fraschilla is not deluding himself. Yes, his team whipped Pittsburgh in double overtime Thursday night to extend its winning streak to five games, all in the Big East. And, sure, the team is playing its best basketball since he took over last season.

title: Those Closest to Clinton Are Left in the Dark
description: As he faces the deepest political crisis of his career, President Clinton is portrayed by staff members and friends as increasingly a picture of isolation.

title: 'Salome,' Insulting But Still Winning
description: The Herod in Richard Strauss's ''Salome'' speaks for everyone in the audience. He loves the show. He is also willing to pay for it, even if the price seems a bit steep. Troubling him more are other irritations. He is bothered that there is a lot going on he does not understand. He keeps hearing these strange sounds. And he can never get away from his significant other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, DOROTHY
description: HIRSCH-Dorothy. On Thursday, January 22, 1998. Beloved sister of David, Murray and the late Arthur Hirsch. Devoted sister-in-law of Carol, Janice and Leni. Loving aunt of Debra Kornreich and Dr. Lawrence Hirsch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAMY, NANCY (NEE BELLIS)
description: SALAMY-Nancy (nee Bellis), beloved wife of Samuel. Adoring mother of Chelsey Taryn. Devoted daughter of Abe and Ruth Bellis. Close sister of Marjorie Miller and Zachary and Zoe's. Dear aunt Nunny. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Sunday, 12:30 PM.

title: Furrier Charged With Threatening Advocate for Animals
description: Stephen Cowit, a furrier whose family is a major leader in the New York fur trade, was arrested Thursday at a Long Island train station on charges that he repeatedly made anonymous phone calls to an animal rights advocate, threatening to harm him and his cat, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. Partner in the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Eliza and Simon. Brother of Timothy and Ian Clark. Son of Blair Clark and the late Jessie Holladay Philbin James. His death occurred suddenly on January 15, 1998 in NYC.

title: Missing Baby Reappears 7 Years Later but Faces Uncertain Future
description: In the annals of child disappearances, the case of 8-year-old Crystal Leann Anzaldi was regarded as something just short of a miracle. Missing since 1990 when her parents reported that the toddler had vanished from her home in San Diego, she reappeared seven years later in Puerto Rico, alive and healthy.

title: Did Amateur Gold Diggers Find Mount Sinai? The Pros Doubt It
description: Larry Williams, a millionaire commodities trader and two-time Republican candidate for the Senate from Montana, and Bob Cornuke, a former police SWAT team member from California, sneaked into an obscure corner of Saudi Arabia in 1988 looking for Mount Sinai. Though neither man spoke Arabic nor had any training in archeology, they had, by their own account, a remarkably successful trip.

title: Tobacco's Judgment Day
description: Big tobacco companies may have given themselves a way of wriggling out of paying the hundreds of billions of dollars they have been offering for peace in the courts.

title: Hard-Working Gibson Shoots for Time Off
description: If there is a PGA Tour event taking place, Kelly Gibson is usually there.

title: Bill Clinton: Accusations and Explanations
description: President Clinton has defended himself against several accusations involving sexual liaisons over the years, and the precision of his language has undergone endless scrutiny since his days on the campaign trail in 1992. Critics say his defenses are ever-shifting; supporters counter that he has been forced to deal with a relentless attack on his personal life.

title: PATTERSON ENERGY TO BUY ROBERTSON ONSHORE DRILLING
description: Patterson Energy Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Robertson Onshore Drilling Company for $40 million to bolster its fleet of land-drilling rigs to the third largest in the United States. Patterson, which provides drilling services to oil and gas companies, said the acquisition would increase its rig fleet to 114. Robertson owns 15 operable drilling rigs, 10 in East Texas and five in Mississippi and Louisiana, with depth capacities of 6,000 to 16,000 feet. Robertson also owns a rig-fabrication yard in Liberty City, Tex. Patterson is based in Snyder, Tex.

title: New Air Chief In Russia Has No Regret On Korean Jet
description: The new chief of the Russian Air Force acknowledged this week that he gave the order to shoot down a South Korean jetliner in 1983.

title: Mexico Wins Extradition of Two Defendants From U.S. for Drug-Killing Trial
description: Reversing a string of embarrassing failures in prominent extradition cases, Mexican prosecutors have persuaded the California courts to send two men accused of murder and criminal conspiracy back to Mexico to face trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREIER, BETTY
description: DREIER-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Len and Don (Feiman) and Sandy (Kozinn). She was adored by her grandchildren Debra, Amy, Gary, Sharon and David and cherished by her 13 great-grandchildren.

title: MATCHUP: SUPER BOWL XXXII -- PART II
description: Packers 15-3 (351 Yards gained per game (second best in the N.F.C.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNS, MOLLY
description: BERNS-Molly. No one could match your wit or your beauty. We think of you often. Susan and John, Abby and Steve and their families.

title: State Prison's Doubling Up of Inmates Is Legal, Federal Judge Says
description: New York State's practice of doubling up inmates in cells designed for one person in a prison near the Catskills does not violate the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: SUIZA FOODS AGREES TO BUY LOUIS TRAUTH DAIRY
description: The Suiza Foods Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Louis Trauth Dairy Inc. for an undisclosed amount, part of the dairy and packaging company's effort to build a regional dairy network. Suiza said Louis Trauth, based in Newport, Ky., sold $67 million of milk, ice cream and other dairy products in the year ended Sept. 30, 1997. Trauth supplies milk to about 2,000 stores in in southeastern Indiana, Lexington and Louisville, Ky., and Columbus, Dayton and Chillicothe, Ohio. Suiza is based in Dallas.

title: Sports of The Times; A Life Of Pain Management
description: SONNY JURGENSEN, the old Washington Redskins quarterback, sat at a news media table listening intently as Mark Schlereth went on about the bumps and bruises of his life.

title: NU SKIN ASIA TO ACQUIRE ALL OF AFFILIATE
description: Nu Skin Asia Pacific Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the core assets of its privately held affiliate, Nu Skin International Inc., for $70 million in preferred stock and assume debt of $180 million. Nu Skin Asia Pacific, based in Provo, Utah, sells health and beauty products through direct-sales networks. Upon completion of the deal, the combined entity, which will be renamed Nu Skin Enterprises Inc., will distribute products in 17 markets worldwide. Nu Skin International has operations in Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany, Austria, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland, as well as Australia and New Zealand. Shares of Nu Skin Asia rose $4.25, to $20.50.

title: Chinatown Leaders Negotiate To Use New Year Firecrackers
description: With less than a week to go before Chinatown holds its New Year's celebration, a group of neighborhood leaders and businessmen are working to persuade the city to ease a ban on firecrackers imposed last year by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: No Constitutional Right to Lie
description: The Supreme Court took an appropriately dim view this week of the notion that government employees being investigated by their agencies for on-the-job misconduct have a broad, constitutionally protected right to lie. In a unanimous ruling, the Court overturned a Federal appeals court decision that barred Federal agencies from punishing employees for making false statements while denying an administrative charge of wrongdoing. The lower court cited concern about employees' due-process rights. But it was never clear how constitutional protection for untruthful responses would advance the due-process goal of avoiding unfair or inaccurate decisions by government.

title: That Indefinable Air Of French Male Chic
description: PARIS  Haughty and notoriously self-critical, Frenchmen have a love-hate relationship with clothes and they are proud of it. While the English celebrate eccentricity, Italians radiate proud sensuality, and Americans are a clean-cut team, the French manage to be both in and beyond fashion.

title: U.N. Official Doubts Team Can Verify Iran Arms
description: The United Nations chief weapons inspector warned the Security Council today that Iraq is determined to stop his investigations and that he harbors grave doubts that he can ever verify whether Saddam Hussein has fulfilled his obligations to destroy his weapons of mass destruction.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITE, NATHANIEL (NAT).
description: WHITE-Nathaniel (Nat). 1/24/93. No matter the years that pass, you are the wind beneath my wings. Elinor

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CADENA, EDUARDO
description: CADENA-Eduardo. 1/24/95. Beloved Daddy, in deeply cherished memory; ever remembered, ever missed, ever loved. Judy

title: Corrections
description: A table yesterday with an article about the new wave of Irish bars in New York City reversed the typical numbers of television sets in old and new Irish bars. As the article noted, Rocky Sullivan's, the new bar, has two sets; O'Hanlon's, the old one, has eight.

title: Bernadette Szymczak, 76, Dies; Fed the Poor
description: Sister Bernadette Szymczak, who fought hunger and despair with such loving zeal that she turned a tiny Brooklyn food program into a mighty engine of sustenance and hope, died Monday at Long Island College Hospital. She was 76 and, until six months ago, had been getting up at 5 A.M. to stir the soup and poor people's spirits as the hands-on founding director of St. John's Bread and Life Soup Kitchen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASANELLA, CHARLES R.
description: FASANELLA-Charles R. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles Fasanella, associated with The Times from May 1, 1966, until retiring on Dec. 1, 1973.

title: It's Crazy, Lavish and Excessive, but Not Spontaneous
description: There was a two-page news release to announce the color, shape and design of the approximately two million pieces of confetti that will be shot from cannons at the end of Sunday's football game between the Green Bay Packers and the Denver Broncos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATUSEWITCH, SERGEI
description: MATUSEWITCH-Sergei. Suddenly on January 22. Beloved husband of Jean, loving father of Gerri and Sondra. Loving grandfather of Mia and David. Brother of the late Boris. Uncle of Marc, Eric and Peter. Funeral private. Contributions to Manhattan Plaza AIDS Project, 400 West 43rd St., NYC 10036 in honor of Jean, longtime volunteer.

title: Atmosphere of Uncertainty Leads to Continued Losses
description: After three years of spectacular returns, the stock market seems to have entered a period of uncertainty.

title: As Rangers Falter, LaFontaine Surges Toward a Trophy
description: With 33 games remaining in their 82-game schedule, the struggling Rangers lack viable candidates for most post-season awards. Brian Leetch, the winner last year of the Norris trophy as the National Hockey League's best defenseman, will probably not repeat. Although his play has improved recently, his plus/minus ratio of minus-23 suggests a substandard season.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Dominican Pitcher Is Invited to Camp
description: The Mets have signed Efrain Valdez, a left-handed free-agent pitcher from the Dominican Republic, and invited him to their major-league camp in spring training. Valdez, 31, was named the most valuable pitcher in the Dominican winter league this year.

title: Two of Canada's Biggest Banks in a Surprise Merger Plan
description: Taking a cue from the recent wave of bank mergers in the United States and Europe, two of Canada's biggest banks surprised financial markets today by announcing plans to combine and form a bank that would automatically become the third largest in North America.

title: About New York; Help the Poor And Afflicted: Faith in Action
description: CHILD-SIZED wheelchairs sat empty in the corridor, an odd sight alongside the playful murals of elephants peeking through the jungle bush. Colorful, too, were the red and yellow syrups and pills by the nurses's station with notations for AZT or Dilantin. In a crib tucked into one corner, a 3-year-old rested, his chest rising and falling with every rasp of breath.

title: No. 2 at Hewlett-Packard To Head Silicon Graphics
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. has recruited the No. 2 man at the Hewlett-Packard Company, Richard E. Belluzzo, to be chairman and chief executive of the troubled computer company. News of the appointment today sent Silicon Graphics shares up 22 percent.

title: Bulls Stun Nets in Bizarre Final Second of Overtime
description: Beneath the blanket of fan noise, there were shouts of ''four . . . four . . . four'' coming from the hardwood floor. This was not a signal to duck, but for Nets Coach John Calipari to look up.

title: New Killing in Belfast Adds to Doubts on Ulster Peace Talks
description: A Roman Catholic man was shot and killed today in Belfast, apparently the ninth victim of sectarian attacks by Protestant and Catholic paramilitaries in Northern Ireland in the last four weeks.

title: The Neediest Cases; Family Regains a Home After Living Lost in La Guardia's Bustle
description: Geraldine P. puts in her eight hours each workday as a secretary for a Manhattan office-supply company. But until recently, when her co-workers headed home at 5 P.M., she boarded a bus for La Guardia Airport. ''And it wasn't because I was jet-setting to the Caribbean,'' she said.

title: Lani Guinier Joins Faculty Of Law School At Harvard
description: Lani Guinier, one of the nation's most eminent and outspoken legal scholars on issues of race and sex, and whose nomination as Assistant Attorney General for civil rights was withdrawn by President Clinton in a political storm in 1993, has been named a professor with tenure at Harvard Law School, the first black woman to hold such a position there.

title: Supreme Court Will Revisit Issue of Sexual Harassment
description: Expanding its already wide-ranging review of the law on sexual harassment, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether an employee can sue if she has been the target of a supervisor's sexual advances but has neither submitted nor suffered adverse consequences on the job for refusing.

title: Who Will Replace Teachers Who Fail the Test?
description: To the Editor:

title: S. C. JOHNSON & SON WINS APPROVAL FOR DOW PURCHASE
description: S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. won United States antitrust approval yesterday for its $1.125 billion purchase of the Dow Chemical Company's consumer-products business as long as it completed its planned sale of Spray 'n Wash and two other popular household products to Reckitt & Colman P.L.C. In an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission, S. C. Johnson agreed to sell assets related to Spray 'n Wash, Spray 'n Starch, and Glass Plus products to the United States subsidiary of the London-based Reckitt & Colman for $160 million. Reckitt and S. C. Johnson announced this agreement in December. Without the settlement, Johnson, based in Racine, Wis., which makes a number of household products including Johnson Wax, Raid and Windex, would have eliminated competition in the markets for glass cleaners and soil and stain remover products, the F.T.C. said.

title: Beliefs
description: Twenty-five years after Roe v. Wade, the United States continues to have a bad conscience about abortion. That is one of the few conclusions that can be drawn from the surveys of public opinion accompanying the anniversary of the Supreme Court's 1973 decision striking down almost all existing legal restrictions on abortion.

title: Sailing the High-End Seas; Luxury Craft Are Back and Prices Are Bigger Than Ever
description: Susan Puleo, an interior architect, mixes glass spiral staircases, leather floors, fiber optics and African rosewood to set off antiques in clients' salons. The stairs, entwining cockatoo cages, lead to master bedrooms with fireplaces and waterfront views, dance floors with smoke machines, hot tubs with wet bars, even to basketball courts that fold away when not in use.

title: Mayor's Shopping Mission: Tax Free or Bust; Trumpeting Cause to Lift Levy (and Picking Up Socks Along the Way)
description: A few days ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani found himself in a setting of Felliniesque design: surrounded by four sets of identically dressed identical twins, while a Giuliani impersonator belted out the lyrics to ''New York, New York.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: State to Fine an H.M.O. For Canceling Surgeries
description: A Neptune-based health maintenance organization that canceled at least two surgeries at hospitals where anesthesiologists refused a pay cut and redirected patients to hospitals whose doctors had agreed to lower fees will be fined as much as $500,000, state health officials announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, ARTHUR G. JR.
description: FOX-Arthur G. Jr. On January 21, 1998. Vice President for Systems and Programming, Chase Bank. Beloved husband of Denise. Loving father of Ryan and Eric. Devoted son of Arthur G. Sr. and Ruth Fox. Dear brother of Carol Anne Davila and Janet Fox. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Inc,, 9105 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Funeral mass at St. Genevieve Church on Monday at 9:45 AM. Interment, Long Island National Cemetery at Pinelawn. Visiting 2-5 and 7-10 PM Saturday and Sunday.

title: Knicks Focused on Their First Road Stop
description: In another time, when Patrick Ewing was sweating with his teammates on the court, not on an exercise bicycle, the Knicks might be guilty of looking ahead. Although a tough three-game road trip awaits, it would be easy for the Knicks to focus on the Miami Heat, which lurks in the trip's final game, which will be the first meeting with Pat Riley since last year's second-round playoff defeat.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COOKSON GROUP P.L.C.,

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Thursday, about relationships between the Super Bowl and the stock market, misstated the level of the Dow Jones industrial average at the end of November. It was 7,823.13, not 7,691.77.

title: Who Will Replace Teachers Who Fail the Test?
description: To the Editor:

title: Civics at an Impressionable Age
description: The way they saw it was, what a mess! And the feeling they had was, it was ''pretty yucky'' or ''he must be so embarrassed'' or ''this is like so weird.''

title: Clinton Proposal Would Help Workers Save for Retirement
description: The Clinton Administration unveiled proposals today to help workers save for retirement, part of an effort by the White House to keep some momentum behind a series of policy initiatives it has set out in recent weeks.

title: Alma Hawkins, An Educator In Dance, Is Dead at 94
description: Dr. Alma Hawkins, a pioneering modern-dance educator who founded the dance department at the University of California at Los Angeles, died on Jan. 8 at her home in Santa Monica. She was 94.

title: Report on Attack in Mexico Castigates Police for Abetting Massacre
description: In his first extensive report on the investigation into the killings of 45 Indian villagers in a southern mountain hamlet, the Attorney General has accused police officers in Chiapas state of abetting the massacre and lying under oath, and he blamed top state officials for letting the killers think the crime would go unpunished.

title: Illusions of a War Against Cocaine
description: Panama is debating whether to let Washington keep American troops there to combat drug trafficking after the 1999 pullout date set by the canal treaties. The proposal, called the Multinational Counternarcotics Center, is one of several efforts to broaden the role of Latin American militaries in fighting drugs. It is dismaying to see Congress and the Clinton Administration return to a strategy that has failed and could harm Latin democracies.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Richard Kennedy, 78, Diplomat Involved in Nuclear Arms Issues
description: Richard T. Kennedy, a former Army colonel and statesman who was responsible for the Government's nuclear nonproliferation policy during the final years of the cold war, died on Jan. 12 at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Washington.

title: The Budget's Best Friend
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing? Angry? Ah, It's Rodman
description: Upon hearing that Dennis Rodman had suddenly left the Bulls last night before the Nets game and returned to Chicago, the first thought, naturally, was that he had an emergency appointment with Heidi, his hair stylist. Perhaps to add dye to his latest design, which looked like a cat had stepped in ink and then walked around on his head, leaving black pawprints on a bright blond head.

title: Tailoring and Sportswear Merge to Make the Classic Cool
description: PARIS  When Yohji Yamamoto sent out his entire fall menswear collection worn by women friends  albeit mostly androgynous types like the beanpole former model Ines de la Fressange and the skinny actress Charlotte Rampling  it marked a fashion moment.

title: Steep Fall in Dollar Pulls Down Treasury Security Prices
description: A plunging dollar pulled bond prices sharply lower yesterday, sending the yield on the 30-year bond back near 6 percent. The dollar fell 1.5 percent against the German mark and 1.3 percent against the Japanese yen.

title: Eccentric's Hubris Set Off Global Frenzy Over Cloning
description: As scientists and academics batted around some esoteric notions at a recent conference on genetics, a 69-year-old bearded man stood up, made some vague and rambling statements, then issued a grandiose claim:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a survey of employers' health care costs misstated the title of Paul Fronstin of the Employee Benefit Research Institute. He is a research associate specializing in health benefits, not the research director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, PAULINE
description: WEISSMAN - Pauline. Beloved wife of the late Max S. Devoted mother of Rosalie and Sandy Forster, Iris and Burt Schwartz. Adored grandmother of Arlene, Scott and Pam, Steven and Sally, Robert, Alan and Eileen. Adored great-grandmother of Daniel, Corey and the Schwartz grandchild. Services were held on Friday.

title: LUCAS VARITY OF BRITAIN IN PRESTOLITE DEAL
description: The British engineering group Lucas Varity P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell some of its starter and alternator-making businesses to Prestolite Electric Inc. for $:25.4 million, or about $42 million. Lucas Varity, based in London, is an automotive and aerospace parts maker formed by the 1996 merger of Lucas Industries P.L.C. and the Varity Corporation of the United States. Prestolite Electric, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., manufactures alternators, starter motors, direct current motors, and battery chargers. The sale includes heavy-duty starter and alternator manufacturing in London and light-duty starter and alternator businesses in South Africa and Argentina.

title: A Good Listener and a Keeper of Confidences
description: The President's personal secretary, who has been subpoenaed in the investigation of President Clinton's possible relationship with the former intern Monica Lewinsky, is not only a gatekeeper to the Oval Office, but the keeper of lots of White House secrets by virtue of her status as everybody's favorite confidante, colleagues said today.

title: My Life as a Washington Aide
description: The investigation into whether President Clinton had an affair with a White House intern should be left to the legal system. What we don't need is any sanctimonious harumphing from other political quarters. It's no secret that young female interns and aides can have a tough time in Washington. A lot of women and I can tell hair-raising stories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STELLA, MARIA
description: STELLA-Maria. Wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Concetta, Marie, Frederick and Roseanne, Rochelle, and Jo-Ann and Dan Baldwin. Cherished sister of Philomena Principe, Vita and Dewey Gallese, Nancy and James McMahon. Also survived by five grandchildren. Reposing at Cusimano & Russo Funeral Home, 2005 W. 6 St. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 10:30am, Saints Simon and Jude RC Church.

title: Journal; All Monica All the Time
description: So much for the Pope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, ADELINA P.
description: LEHMAN-Adelina P. Thursday, January 22, at noon at her home. Loving wife of the late Alcuin W. Lehman. Beloved sister of Mary Berol, Bedford Hills, N.Y., Vera F. Bissell, Cambridge, MA., and Grace Pope of NYC. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday 2-5 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66 St., Monday 10:30 A.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Lee Lehman to Cancer Research Foundation would be very much appreciated by her family.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing in Business Day on Tuesday about Stan Becker's stepping down as chief creative officer of the New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi misattributed the slogan ''Sometimes you feel like a nut, sometimes you don't'' for Almond Joy and Mounds candies. It was written by Fred Massin, not by Mr. Becker.

title: Punish Sport Utilities With a Weight Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Defiant on Apartheid, Botha Gets His Day in Court
description: Former President P. W. Botha stood today before a black judge his Government would never have allowed on the bench, facing charges of contempt of court for refusing to testify about atrocities committed under his apartheid-era rule.

title: Somber Colleagues, and Fiancee, Remember a Slain Officer
description: Outside the Garden of Prayer Cathedral, driving sleet and rain dampened an already somber mood as thousands of officers in soaking dress blues massed along Washington Avenue in the South Bronx yesterday for the funeral of one of their own.

title: Regent Urges That Agency Aid in Upkeep Of Schools
description: Harold O. Levy, the Wall Street executive who documented the severe deterioration of hundreds of city school buildings in a report released two years ago, said yesterday that he would soon convene inquiries at the city and state levels into how well the Board of Education and the School Construction Authority were coping with such problems.

title: Hard-Working Gibson Shoots for Time Off
description: If there is a PGA Tour event taking place, Kelly Gibson is usually there.

title: Majoli Blunders Her Way to an Early Exit
description: While there is no unwritten law that says champions of Grand Slam events have to be invincible, they are not supposed to be pushovers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANCIGER, HERBERT N.
description: DANCIGER-Herbert N. January 19, 1998. Outstanding family man. Beloved husband of Beulah Klein; devoted father of Roanne and Hank Gotthelf; Leslie Wander and Harvey and Sandi Danciger. Adored grandfather of Kenneth and Wende Gotthelf; Sean and Jeffrey Wander; and Aimee and Jill Danciger; loving great grandfather of Justin. Cherished brother of Ruth Danciger. Service 12PM Sunday at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: British Music Company Hurt by Asian Turmoil
description: EMI Group P.L.C. stock fell as much as 12 percent after the British music company said annual operating profit would miss its own target because of setbacks in the troubled economies of the Asia-Pacific region. EMI, whose artists include the Spice Girls, Janet Jackson and Garth Brooks, said operating profit would be $:25 million ($41 million) lower than expected, prompting its shares to drop as much as 61.25 pence, to 417.5 pence.

title: 'Side Show' Rescue Is Abandoned
description: Plans to reopen the musical ''Side Show'' in April at the Richard Rodgers Theater, where it closed on Jan. 3, were abandoned yesterday after the show's director, Robert Longbottom, decided to drop out of the project, the producer Emanuel Azenberg said.

title: What Liberia Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Starr Inquiry Has Crossed the Line of Decency; Was Wiretap Legal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKER, WILLIAM
description: HACKER-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Hacker, associated with The Times from Aug. 1, 1966 until retiring on June 1, 1975.

title: Literary Agent Says Recordings Were Her Idea
description: A New York literary agent says that she instigated the tape recordings that are crucial to the sex scandal swirling around President Clinton and that she did so to protect a friend.

title: Ex-Intern Offered to Tell of Clinton Affair In Exchange for Immunity, Lawyers Report
description: The lawyer for Monica S. Lewinsky told prosecutors last Sunday that in exchange for immunity from prosecution, his client would testify that she had a sexual relationship with President Clinton, lawyers familiar with the case said today. But, the lawyers said, she was unwilling to repeat all of her allegations, taped by a co-worker, that Mr. Clinton or his close friend Vernon E. Jordan Jr. asked her to lie about it.

title: MCI Is Ending Plans to Resell Local Service
description: The MCI Communications Corporation cannot make money reselling local residential phone service and will focus on providing businesses local service through its own networks, its president, Timothy F. Price, said on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODMAN, MORRIS
description: RODMAN-Morris. The officers, trustees and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee express their deep sorrow at the loss of Morris Rodman, a longtime member of the JDC Board and a prominent leader nationally and in world Jewry. In addition to his JDC activities, he played a significant role in his Washington community and in Israel, where he and his late wife, Gertrude, established the Ruth Youth Wing of the Israel Museum in memory of their daughter. Morris and his family were pioneers in establishing high schools in Israel and were benefactors of the Community College in Tel Chai. Condolences to his family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Exec. VP Ambassador Milton A. Wolf Chairman of the Board

title: Budapest Journal; Hungary's Favorite Clan: No, It's Not the Gabors
description: In 1959, before television came to Hungary and as the Communist Government was reasserting itself after a failed popular uprising, a warm but rather realistic weekly radio drama went on the air.

title: Consumers Play Role In Depleted Fish Stocks
description: To the Editor:

title: Strother MacMinn, Design Instructor, 79
description: Strother MacMinn, who taught automotive design for 50 years at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., and whose students went on to become leading automotive designers in the United States, Europe and Japan, was found dead on Monday at his home in Pasadena. He was 79.

title: Teen-Agers' Vandalism Leads to Mercury Crisis
description: Christy Wise looked out her living room window at a mercury decontamination tent and the temporary command post for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency this week and wondered aloud how much of the toxic substance was still in the hands of the town's young people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINGHOFF, ROSLYN B.
description: BERLINGHOFF-Roslyn B. Died January 19, 1998. Mother of Florence Sudakow and John Berlinghoff. Grandmother of Sarah and James. Services held at Temple Beth David, Westminister, California.

title: Consumers Play Role In Depleted Fish Stocks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAZO, JACOB
description: HAZO-Jacob. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Jacob Hazo, associated with The Times from January 26, 1948 until retiring on January 1, 1969.

title: Kwan May Stay Home For Opening Ceremony
description: Although her injured foot continues to improve, Michelle Kwan has kept to a reduced training schedule since the national figure skating championships. And though she wants to attend the opening ceremony at the Winter Olympics on Feb. 7 in Nagano, Japan, she said she may remain in California to continue physical therapy on the stress fracture in the second toe of her left foot.

title: Porsche Says Profit Was Up Only 69%
description: Porsche A.G. said yesterday that profit in the first six months of the 1998 fiscal year rose a less-than-expected 69 percent as production of the 911 sports car slowed for the introduction of an updated model and the less expensive Boxster dominated sales.

title: Accord on Conversion May Elude Netanyahu
description: Having survived another political tussle with the Palestinian issue, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu must now confront another one of the conflicts that have bedeviled him since he came to office 19 months ago: conversion.

title: Knicks Focused on Their First Road Stop
description: In another time, when Patrick Ewing was sweating with his teammates on the court, not on an exercise bicycle, the Knicks might be guilty of looking ahead. Although a tough three-game road trip awaits, it would be easy for the Knicks to focus on the Miami Heat, which lurks in the trip's final game, which will be the first meeting with Pat Riley since last year's second-round playoff defeat.

title: HANDY & HARMAN STUDIES SALE OF COMPANY
description: Handy & Harman said yesterday that it was ''considering all strategic alternatives'' to increase shareholder value, including a possible sale of all or parts of the precious metals and auto-parts company. The news sent shares of Handy & Harman up $2.5625, to $35. The company, which spurned a takeover bid earlier this week by the WHX Corporation, said it had received several unsolicited inquiries from unnamed companies since Dec. 15, when WHX offered to pay $543 million in cash and assumed debt, or $30 a share. WHX, the parent of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company, acquired just 425,152 shares in its failed tender offer, raising its stake in Handy & Harman to 8.4 percent from 4.9 percent. The New York-based Handy & Harman, whose products include auto electronics, processed precious metals and specialty wire and tubing, said there was no assurance any transaction would take place. Goldman, Sachs is its financial adviser.

title: At Sundance, Talk Of Life Imitating Art
description: ''My secret psychotic fantasy is that someone in the White House is saying, 'What we should do is go to war, but we can't even do it because of that movie,' '' David Mamet said over lunch at the hotel coffee shop that is one of the Sundance Film Festival's nerve centers. Mr. Mamet was well aware that his script written with Hillary Henkin for ''Wag the Dog,'' about spin control of a White House scandal, is being newly appreciated for its scary prescience. Actually, he was making his first visit to the festival for a movie he wrote and directed, ''The Spanish Prisoner,'' the most unequivocal hit in town.

title: Questioning of Ex-Intern Provoked Angry Words
description: Monica S. Lewinsky, the fresh-faced former White House intern, was having lunch with her friend, Linda Tripp, at the Ritz Carlton in the Pentagon City mall. It was supposed to be a casual Friday tete-a-tete between two Pentagon colleagues.

title: Streaking Storm Has First Place in Sight
description: St. John's Coach Fran Fraschilla is not deluding himself. Yes, his team whipped Pittsburgh in double overtime Thursday night to extend its winning streak to five games, all in the Big East. And, sure, the team is playing its best basketball since he took over last season.

title: Injury Sidelines Beebe
description: Green Bay wide receiver Don Beebe, who has played in four Super Bowls, will miss this one because of injury. The Packers put Beebe on injured reserve today because of a lingering hamstring problem and activated receiver Ronnie Anderson from their practice squad.

title: Union Hopes to Organize Workers at Tribe's Casino
description: In the last few days, billboards have sprung up here and in nearby towns warning of the ''Foxwoods flu,'' a malady that has more to do with labor unrest than any virus.

title: Kovalev Sits With Bad Knee
description: Because of swelling and soreness in his right knee, Rangers right wing Aleksei Kovalev will miss this afternoon's game with the Devils at Madison Square Garden. Kovalev has been feeling discomfort in the knee since last week's game against the Devils at the Meadowlands.

title: Science Confronts The Unknowable; Less Is Known Than People Think
description: Many scientists are not fond of the idea that there are things in the universe beyond their grasp. They do not even like the word unknowable and prefer to use the term intractable instead. They consider the idea of unknowability an admission of defeat or an invitation for an attack on science.

title: Raytheon Plans Deep Job Cuts And Closing Of 20 Plants
description: The Raytheon Company said today that it would cut 10 percent of its military-related work force, or about 8,700 people, in an effort to consolidate its operations after the recent acquisitions of Hughes Aircraft and the military businesses of Texas Instruments.

title: Bulls Stun Nets in Bizarre Final Second of Overtime
description: Beneath the blanket of fan noise, there were shouts of ''four . . . four . . . four'' coming from the hardwood floor. This was not a signal to duck, but for Nets Coach John Calipari to look up.

title: Street Makes Way Back
description: She has hugged Katja, whooped it up with Florence, cheered loudly for her less-visible and less-audible teammates, and, most important, skied very fast.

title: Chrysler Posts Rise in Profit; Costs Also Up
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that were better than expected, but the numbers, particularly a sharp increase in rebates and other incentives, set Wall Street to worrying about the auto industry's prospects for this year.

title: In Clinton Crisis, Fine Line Between News and Gossip
description: It was a moment you might expect on, say, ''Geraldo,'' but on ''Nightline''? Ted Koppel's estimable ABC late-night news program opened Thursday with the promise that viewers would learn that the ''Crisis in the White House'' might ultimately ''come down to the question of whether oral sex does or does not constitute adultery.''

title: Downpour Can't Deter Williams and Korda
description: Thunderstorms turned up as promised here today, dumping nearly two inches of rain on the Australian Open. All of the day's doubles matches and two women's singles matches were postponed, but it did not rain on Venus Williams, who needed just 54 minutes to reach her second consecutive Grand Slam quarterfinal.

title: DON'T BE P.C. WITHOUT IT
description: Sometime this year, Greenpeace is joining forces with Household Bank to introduce a biodegradable credit card made from a polymer vegetable-base plastic rather than PVC. Why? To raise money, in part -- each charged purchase will generate a small percentage to be donated to the group -- but also to appeal to consumers who worry about pollution produced by the manufacture of ordinary plastic cards. Another benefit touted by Greenpeace: if baby gets hold of the card and teethes on it, it's nontoxic. ''But it's mainly a symbolic usage,'' admits Rick Hind, a Greenpeace spokesman who suggests more heroic possibilities. ''As we see it, Greenpeace activists can use the card to buy handcuffs to lock themselves to the front gates of timber companies.''

title: A West African Border With Back-to-Back Wars
description: Just visible at the far side of the bridge that links this Liberian town with Sierra Leone, the region's newest militia can be seen patrolling recently conquered territory.

title: Streetscapes/421 East 61st Street; From House Museum to Historic 19th-Century Hotel
description: IT wasn't built as a house, so why call it a house museum? That's what the Colonial Dames of America decided 10 years ago when they began to reposition the 1799 Abigail Adams Smith Museum, at 421 East 61st Street, as a historic hotel. Now they are near the end of a $1.5 million capital campaign, and the results offer an interesting twist on the usual formula.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZYMCZAK, SR. BERNADETTE
description: SZYMCZAK-Sr. Bernadette . The employees of Philip Morris Companies Inc., express their deep sorrow at the loss of Sr. Bernadette Szymczak. Her tireless dedication to helping feed the poor and homeless has served as a true inspiration in our commitment to combat hunger nationwide. Stephanie French, V.P. Karen Brosius, Director And the Corporate Contributions Staff

title: Appearances; Beam Me Up, Scotty
description: At the spring fashion shows, models' faces were not matte but shiny. Some had a subtle glow; others had so much glitter around the eyes that it looked like tears. The gleam seemed right with all the sheer, shiny fabrics, sequins and beading.

title: The Neediest Cases; Fire Consigns a Holocaust Survivor to a Shelter
description: It was just before dawn when Ruth Walker awoke to shouts and thumping in the hallway of her Washington Heights apartment building. ''The only problem is that everyone was yelling in Spanish, which I don't understand,'' she said.

title: What's the Complaint On Religious Freedom Act?
description: To the Editor:

title: Standouts in Exhibits Covering a Broad Range of Techniques and Interests
description: Two Spaces/Expanded Concept

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, EVELYN
description: GLICK-Evelyn. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted mother of Susan Glick-Stumer (Frank), Wendy Muchnick (Warren) and Ellen Kapito (Hy). Loving sister of Dr. Fred J. Goldstein of Los Angeles and Sally Levy and the late Fay Apfelberg and Eli Goldstein. Adored grandmother of David and Jennifer Baltaxe, Daniel, Keith and Brian Muchnick, and Brandi and Peter Uschin, Steven, Sam, Scott Stumer. Services 2:15 Sunday at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: A Dream Is Up and It's Good
description: Ryan Longwell was not supposed to be the Green Bay place-kicker. Not here, not this season.

title: West Side Story
description: SHADOWS ON

title: Brash American Intruders Amid l'Elegance
description: ON A RARE DAY WHEN THE AMERICAN Ambassador's residence in Paris is empty of foreign dignitaries and visiting heads of state, it is so still that the normally inaudible sounds of white-gloved servants scurrying across the marble floors can be heard. Filtering through tall arched windows overlooking formal gardens, sunlight illuminates the stately rooms of this vast 19th-century mansion, glinting off gilded wall paneling, ornamented mirrors, Baccarat chandeliers and 17th- and 18th-century furnishings.

title: NYC*100: THE FOURTH DECADE
Mayoral Follies, The 1969 Edition
description: WHEN Bismarck pronounced that politics is not an exact science, he presumably had uppermost in his mind politics in 19th-century Europe. But there are New Yorkers who can conjure up more recent events in their own city that are memorable for their political inexactitude or for the politics of miscalculation. There was, for example, the 1969 mayoral campaign in which John V. Lindsay ran for re-election.

title: Shape Up, Date!
description: Debs from around the world assembled last month for the International Debutante Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria. The debs got two kinds of escort: civilian dates -- college-age boyfriends, many of them deb-circuit regulars -- and military dates. The cadets pitched in with dancing and fetched drinks, but their main responsibility was less romantic -- carrying state and national flags during the pageantry. Which raises a question: Would this party really be fun for the cadets? Here's a look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORPE, FRANCES (NEE WILLS)
description: THORPE-Frances (nee Wills). On January 18, 1998. The Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden mourns the passing of our most devoted and endearing past president, who was the consummate volunteer, assisting the Garden in its many events and activities. She will long be remembered personally as a dear friend, and as a loyal supporter of the Garden. We offer our sincerest condolences to her husband Charles.

title: Washington Heights Center Rededicated
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was among several dignitaries on hand yesterday for the rededication of the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan. The facility will now be known as the Youth Center and will be expanded to programs beyond track and field, such as computer science, martial arts, vocational training, college preparation courses and drug prevention support groups.

title: Torquay Authors
description: To the Editor: Another author with Torquay associations (''Tracing Agatha Christie in Torquay,'' Nov. 9) is Beatrix Potter. Her highly amusing journal entry for March 14, 1893, recounts her adventures there, especially her exploration of Kents Hole (Cavern) with her Papa. She mistook candle drippings in the cave for a geological feature. Her defining statement was ''There are only three almond trees in Torquay; I have seen them all and they are small ones.''

title: Man Killed Was Mobster, Police Say
description: A 67-year-old reputed associate of the Gambino crime family who gained notoriety two decades ago when he and a fellow mobster accidentally shot each other was gunned down Friday evening in Brooklyn, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Buddy's Buddies
description: The Rowan University Jazz Program waited 25 years to produce its first recording. And then students and faculty members went for broke, producing a concert tribute to the drummer Buddy Rich. It was recorded live -- no overdubbing, no second chances. According to liner notes written by Denis DiBlasio, director of jazz studies, ''the only thing left out is my time-consuming babble.'' The concert tribute makes up one disk of a two-CD set that also includes a sampler of faculty performances.

title: Charms of Lech
description: FOR a family growing up in the Netherlands, where the only hills are dunes and the national summit is 1,000 feet above sea level, our annual winter vacation in the mountains inevitably took on a special significance. During the February break, we would drive the 600 miles to the Alps, usually to Saas Fee in Switzerland, or to Lech, in the Austrian Arlberg, which we knew because it was where the Dutch queen went with her family.

title: Mussolini Medallions Turn Up at Ranch
description: A collection of large copper medallions created for one of Mussolini's principal Fascist shrines in Rome and missing since American troops occupied the Italian capital in World War II has come to light at a cattle ranch here in southwestern Missouri.

title: Tough Times for a City of Tenants
description: MANY years before I understood that the personal was political, I had begun to take the political very personally. It was the defeat of Al Smith in 1928 that hurt my feelings. For some reason up and down my Bronx street, large photographs of Smith had appeared in the butcher's window, the grocer's and the candy store. I was certain he would be our President. I was about 5 1/2, at the time patriotic, the owner of several American flags; I believed in voting and martyrdom. Anyway, how could a man absolutely unknown to the neighborhood become President of the whole country?

title: Of Shanties and Skylines
description: IF NEW YORK seems like a work in progress today, imagine how it seemed a century ago. The city wouldn't stand still long enough to be captured faithfully in a single frame by the map makers at August R. Ohman, the company that produced this view of the new metropolis about 1902 (the map's copyright date). But an artist's rendering offered them license to imagine the motion.

title: January 18-24; Presidential Advice
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford injected himself into a political maelstrom by warning that the Republican Party was preoccupied with abortion. An ''ultra conservative'' faction, he said, could threaten the party's effort to win back the White House in 2000.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Building Falls

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIS DAVID
description: COHEN-Harris David. January 25, 1967-August 13, 1985. Oh what a year we've had. So sad that you are not here to share it with us. Our memories are beautiful; our hearts are broken. Much love, Mom, Dad and Jonathan.

title: Loss for Ages May Show Nets Are Coming of Age
description: Keith Van Horn sat in front of his locker nearly 24 hours after the fact and tried to come to grips with just how the Nets had allowed Friday night's game against the Chicago Bulls to slip out of their grasp, or at least out of the grasp of the four players who were on the floor at the end of the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTERDAM, JACK
description: AMSTERDAM-Jack. On January 23, 1998. Chairman of the Board of Leviton Manufacturing Co. Beloved husband of the late Mimi Leviton Amsterdam. Devoted father of Dasha Epstein. Caring and loving grandfather of Robert and Danielle Epstein. Dear brother of Jean Ross. Loyal and best friend of Mimi Goodman. Service Tuesday 11 AM Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave. at 55th St.

title: Mighty Tomatoes From Little Seeds Do Grow
description: THOUGH most gardeners are still busy studying seed catalogues now, it is not too soon to talk about seed starting. Experienced gardeners have learned that the best way of being assured of growing a particular flower or vegetable is to raise the plant yourself.

title: After Earlier Failure, N.Y.U. and Mount Sinai Medical Centers to Merge
description: A year after officials at Mount Sinai Medical Center and New York University Medical Center said they could find no way to complete a much anticipated merger, the boards of trustees of both institutions are about to approve plans to do exactly that.

title: All the Marbles
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Suspension of Belief
description: Let's see. Monica Lewinsky wasn't a particularly talented intern. And she was perceived as a nuisance at the White House, lurking in this room and that, hanging out, always hoping to spend a moment or two in the presence of the President. She was a kid, and not a particularly bright one.

title: He Did It His Way, Or Else
description: MOSES is immortalized all over New York City -- but it's the guy who parted the Red Sea, not his namesake. He was the Moses who parted East Tremont by gouging out the Cross-Bronx Expressway and linking the suburbs with the city via bridges, expressways and parkways to deliver commuters to their promised land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONFELD, MOSES
description: SCHONFELD-Moses. On January 23, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Ruth; loving father of Deborah, Joann and Victor. Dear brother of Jacob and Asenath Petrie; adoring grandfather of Nathan Harrison and Oscar Schonfeld. Service Sunday, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Chic Heroine, but Not a Pretty Story
description: When Gia Carangi came to New York City in the late 1970's to find work as a fashion model, the most successful women in her field were blond, cheerful, healthy-looking cover girls like Christie Brinkley, Kim Alexis and Cheryl Tiegs. But Gia, as she was known in the business, was strikingly different: dark-haired, Italian, with stormy eyes and a personality to match.

title: Looking Back (Again) on '97; Foes of Brooklyn Junction Are Repeating Earlier Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Big and Beautiful, 'Ragtime' Never Quite Sings
description: TAKING ''RAGTIME,'' E. L. Doctorow's brisk, corrosively satiric 1975 novel about America at the beginning of this century, some gifted theater people have made a long, elaborate, sobersided musical pageant, also called ''Ragtime.'' It is the inaugural attraction at the new Ford Center for the Performing Arts on 42d Street.

title: Refund Snarl After Luxor
description: THE Nov. 17 terrorist attack at Luxor, Egypt, in which 58 foreign tourists were killed, has had a wide impact on travel, but has not halted all trips to Egypt. The State Department quickly issued two Public Announcements, but no Travel Warning, which is issued only in situations where the Government believes it cannot protect its citizens. A number of major tour companies canceled scheduled trips; others postponed departures. Some are still operating cruises and tours into the Luxor area.

title: Breaking the H.I.V. Chain; Counselors Battle Spread of Infection -- and Despair
description: Yasmin Ramos delivers the knock on the door that no one wants to answer. She is a senior public health adviser for New York City, a petite woman six months' pregnant whose job includes untangling the web of sexual partners that begins with a single case of H.I.V.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Charles Kuralt certainly merited more than your footnote of exclusion. I think readers would be more interested in reading about him than about Joanie Weston, a star of the sexploitationist sport of roller derby.

title: Parents Turn to Schools To Curb Unruly Youths
description: FOR parents of uncooperative teen-agers or disobedient ones, reining in unruly behavior can be daunting. Parents look to the schools to help impose order, especially to discourage drinking, smoking and drug use.

title: New Standards Finding Way Into Schools
description: At Public School 158 on the Upper East Side this school year, the first 90 minutes of each teacher's schedule is synchronized with to-the-minute precision. If it is 9:50 A.M., you can walk into any room and observe a class ending its time for reading aloud and beginning its vocabulary lesson.

title: Italy's New Fiscal Rigor Fails to Reassure Europe
description: For two years now, Italy has been swept up in an anxious romance with Europe's impending single currency, the euro, doing its best to reassure its northern neighbors that it is fiscally worthy to join their monetary union when the currency is introduced in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, STEPHEN H.
description: GLUCK-Stephen H. Passed away on Wednesday, Jan. 14, 1998, after a short illness at age 63. Steve was an award-winning TV commercial director-cameraman and filmmaker. For a career retrospective, see the 1/30 issue of Shoot. Steve is survived by wife Valerie, sons Peter and Evan and their mother, Natalie. Memorial service at 1 P.M. 1/28, at National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park S.; 212-475-3424. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to a worthy cause benefitting the blind or partially sighted.

title: Studying Architecture And Art of Mexico
description: Two excursions to Mexico are offering travelers a chance to immerse themselves in architecture, design and art.

title: 50-Year Concert, 50-Year Toast
description: Music for Israel, and a smile from a partygoer's partygoer, age 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, DANIEL
description: PECK-Daniel. Loving husband of Karin. Father of Robyn and Robert. Grandfather of Jaime and Michael, was taken from us on January 21, 1998. We will miss you. In lieu of flowers please make donations to The American Leukemia Society.

title: After House Fire, Mutual Aid Setup Stirs Controversy
description: THE call for the house fire came in at 2:47 P.M. Four hours later, an expensive Rye Brook home was gutted and its occupants left out in the cold. No one was in the dwelling when the blaze began, and no lives were lost. But what occurred between midafternoon and nightfall that December day laid bare the weaknesses of the county's fragile mutual aid system, a fire safety arrangement affecting hundreds of thousands of lives.

title: Disabled, He Helps Others Beat Handicaps
description: THE real issue for people with disabilities is their abilities. In an ideal world, people with disabilities will live simply as people, with the same opportunities as everyone else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, SAMUEL D.
description: MAY-Samuel D. 87. On January 22, 1998. Loving husband of Isabel. Beloved father of Linda and Stephen Sklar, and Leni and Peter May. Adored grandfather of Marci and Stu, Caryn, Kenny and Vivian, and Jon and Juliana, and Leslie and Andrew. Great-grandfather of Alison, Carlee and Jake. Brother of Richard. Services Sunday, 11:00AM, at Temple Israel, 140 Central Avenue, Lawrence, LI.

title: Trading in Wicked Wit
description: HEARD the one about the President and Monica Lewinsky?

title: Whatever Happened to Politics?; United Shareholders Of America
description: A political milestone passed without comment last fall when President Clinton was trying unsuccessfully to persuade Congress to renew his fast-track trade-negotiating authority. ''If it passes,'' the President told reporters, ''I think it will have a very positive impact on the stock market here and around the world.''

title: Opera Without Frills Like Sets or Costumes
description: AS guest conductor, Eve Queler has led operas as famous as ''Carmen'' and ''Rigoletto.'' But in the 27 years since she founded the Opera Orchestra of New York, she has built a reputation by introducing concert versions of little-known operas and singers, taking suggestions from loyal subscribers who ferret out tapes. Now, she holds an unusual but respected niche in conducting, a field that hardly welcomes women.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business Diary column on Jan. 4 about the data storage capacity of new I.B.M. disk drives referred incorrectly to the size of a gigabyte. It is equivalent to about 512,000 double-spaced, typewritten pages of text, not 62,500. (A gigabyte is 1.024 billion bytes; the computation is based on 2,000 characters to a typewritten page.)

title: Woman, 41, Is Strangled And Left In Minivan
description: A 41-year-old Long Island mother who worked part time caring for the elderly was found strangled late Thursday in her minivan in a supermarket parking lot, possibly the victim of a carjacking or random robbery, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: Ideas & Trends: Show and Tell; How Did You Get That Art in the War, Daddy?
description: ONE, a portrait, is little bigger than a coffee table book; the other, a landscape, is smaller. But these two paintings by Egon Schiele are causing jitters of monumental dimensions in the museum world.

title: Music in Color
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGLER, BARBARA
description: ZIEGLER-Barbara. On January 23, 1998 in New York. Daughter of the late Gladys Watson and William Ziegler. Survived by her brother William Ziegler III, her sister Helen Steinkraus and her niece Melinda Page. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: Don't Blame School For a Smoking Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: United Ways Report Rise In Donations
description: Donations to many United Ways rose significantly last year, reversing a trend in which donations fell from 1991 to 1996, preliminary figures obtained from large United Ways show.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My theory is that birth and death occurring on the same day, the confluence of life's greatest mysteries, was just too much for people to handle. But today, men and women, grieving mothers and fathers, are demanding that people accept their right to mourn, their need to mourn.''

title: Homage To a Queen Of Writers
description: THE best table at Balthazar on Tuesday night was the one occupied by Toni Morrison, who sat all by herself. Not that Ms. Morrison was alone; the bistro was filled with people celebrating the publication of her most recent book, ''Paradise.''

title: High-Stepping to an Uptown Beat
description: IT was during the 10-year period beginning in November 1918 that New York City consolidated its status as undisputed culture capital of the United States, indeed of the Western Hemisphere. This was the postwar decade of the Roaring 20's, with its deluxe sedans and sporty roadsters and increasingly available flivvers and jitneys. The newly ratified 18th Amendment brought in Prohibition, bootleg liquor and gangster-affiliated speak-easies.

title: The Small Print Becomes Large in the New Car and Truck Leases
description: THIS month, consumers who lease cars and trucks began to benefit from a new, more illuminating financial disclosure form mandated by the Federal Government.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Shorter Than Sweet
description: THE NOVELLAS OF HORTENSE CALISHER (Modern Library, $20) -- a collection of work published from 1963 to 1987, along with one previously unpublished novella -- highlights Hortense Calisher's talents as a creator of distinctive characters. Most are slightly marginal people (like the eccentric Indian doctor of ''Tale for the Mirror'' or the reformed prostitute of ''Women Men Don't Talk About'') whose lives are damaged by mental illness, alcoholism, spousal abuse, injury or money troubles. Still, they revel in the signs and symbols of regeneration found in the world around them, and frequently celebrate mere existence through dedicated living. ''Saratoga, Hot'' tells of a woman and her husband who spend their days on the well-heeled edges of the town's famous race track, soaking up the reflected glory, while ''Extreme Magic'' follows an antique dealer as he rescues a battered wife from her alcoholic husband through a miraculous -- and epiphanic -- intervention. In ''The Railway Police,'' Calisher charts an heiress's descent into a kind of vagabondism, and in ''The Man Who Spat Silver,'' the most experimental of these tales, she makes language itself the key to unlocking a shifting, hypnotic narrative of love and obsession. Challenging and potent, Calisher's novellas are enmeshed in history and intensely personal details. In her introduction, she writes that a novella ''is not merely a shorter novel'' but ''a small one, tenaciously complete.'' The seven collected here reveal just how tenacious and complete a novella can be. Erik Burns

title: Changes in Welfare Push Demand for Child Care
description: AT 6:15 A.M. Catherine Donahue is still sleepy as she begins her workday. She opens the door of her ranch-style house in New Haven and greets Ryan Ferraiolo, 7, and Page Ferraiolo, 5 years old. She feeds them breakfast and puts them on their school bus. Mrs. Donahue, a day care provider, agreed to wake up early for the the two youngsters whose mother, Patricia Ferraiolo, must be at her hospital job by 6:30 A.M. But when other mothers asked Mrs. Donahue to work later to accommodate their night jobs, she refused. ''I have to take care of my own kids,'' said the mother of four.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Club Owner's Lawyer Is Quick to Draw Calculator
description: It is not often that a lawyer uses a calculator while questioning a witness at a criminal trial, but that is just what a defense lawyer did last week at the trial of Peter Gatien, the prominent New York nightclub owner accused of turning two of his popular clubs into drug bazaars.

title: A Radio Giant's Antitrust Question
description: A more comprehensive analysis of what Chancellor Media's purchase of WBAB and WBLI will actually mean to Long Islanders would have served your readership better than a simple recitation of the abstract allegations made by Washington-based Justice Department lawyers who frequently presume to know what's best for local communities.

title: Soft, Softest
description: If cashmere is fancy, pashmina -- cashmere hand-woven with silk to give it strength -- is fancier still.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Demand Spurs Adult-Only Community Construction
description: WITH demand ahead of supply in the market for active adult communities, developers are starting new projects or expanding existing ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIGLIUCCI, MARIO
description: MIGLIUCCI-Mario. Restauranteur of Mario's Restaurant, Bronx, NY. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Bochino). Devoted father of Joseph and Diane Lentini. Also survived by six loving grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. Reposing Lucia Bros., 569 E. 184th St., Bronx. Mass Tuesday, 9:30 AM, Mt. Carmel Church.
