Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-5, 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS; When Going Against the Grain Works Against a Fund
description: WHEN you run against the herd, you risk getting trampled. Such is the case for Paul H. Stephens, whose offbeat and once-popular Robertson Stephens Contrarian fund finished 1997 down a nasty 30 percent. In a year when the Standard & Poor's 500 index climbed 33 percent, that fall was enough to send shareholders fleeing: they yanked $400 million from the fund between last March and December.

title: Third Base or Quarterback? Marlins' Josh Booty Could Be a Bit of Both
description: Josh Booty is a John Elway wannabe who still may be. Or he may yet be the next Mike Schmidt.

title: JEEVES 2000
description: Tomorrow morning, Lady Apsley's School for Butlers opens in Cirencester, England. After eight weeks (and $5,000), 15 students will emerge as thoroughly modern butlers, able to polish silver one minute and surf the Internet the next. ''We'll teach butlers the old-fashioned standards, but with modern ideals,'' says Lady Apsley, a former beauty queen who is running the school on her and her husband's estate, Cirencester Park. In addition to studying how to mix perfect drinks and mind drunken house guests, students will learn cyber-servility -- keeping a watchful eye over E-mail, booking travel on line. ''Every career has to evolve,'' says Michael Shaw, a former Buckingham Palace butler who will teach the classes. ''The days of 'Remains of the Day' are well and truly gone.''

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: A Man, a Plan, a Hot Dog: Birth of a Nathan's
description: IT'S one of life's little ironies that in New York, a gastronomic paradise, the classic of classics is the lowly hot dog, served from a street cart. Nestled in a bun, topped with mustard, onions and sauerkraut, the $1.50 dog exudes the city's essence as no other food can.

title: Tobacco Tax, Part 2
description: Will the newly doubled state tax on cigarettes, with revenues to go to schools and hospital care for the uninsured, discourage smoking?

title: The Nation: Ambivalence? Incompetence? Fairness?; Behind the Death Row Bottleneck
description: TEXAS plans to execute Karla Faye Tucker on Feb. 3, the first woman since the Civil War to join that state's increasingly efficient march to the executioner. Her case has focused attention on a state where executions now verge on routine. Last year, Texas executed 37 men, more than any other state in any year since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment two decades ago.

title: Sliding Isles Are Unable To Hold On
description: In one breath, Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury says Rick Bowness's job security is not an issue. In the next he says his head coach is ''on alert -- we're all on alert.''

title: Tariff-Free in Saipan
description: To the Editor:

title: Beg to Differ
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Richard Goode Heads to Emelin Theater
description: ON Thursday at 8 P.M., the pianist Richard Goode will give a benefit recital at and for the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck. ''It will be an occasion no lover of the piano repertory will want to miss,'' David Watson, executive director of the Emelin, said. ''This is truly a wonderful event, an opportunity to hear one of the consummate piano artists performing today'' in an intimate setting.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An opinion article on the Voices page on Jan. 11, examining the financial needs of public television, advocated the use of some form of commercial messages. The article mentioned a decision by the Federal Communications Commission that certain underwriting announcements were too commercial for use on public television.

title: Spheres of Influence
description: SUMNER WELLES

title: NYC*100: THE EIGHTH DECADE
Hamlets
description: BODY PARTS Stories. By Jere Hoar. 286 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. $26.

title: NYC*100: THE TENTH DECADE
Her Body, Their Selves
description: CELEBRATION

title: A Jazz Pianist Stands Tall In the Rock Underground
description: IN THE EARLY 1990's, Matthew Shipp began to achieve recognition as the most significant pianist in avant-garde jazz since Cecil Taylor -- but not in the quarters one might have expected. Long before Downbeat discovered Mr. Shipp, he was receiving acclaim in experimental rock magazines like Sonic Death and Forced Exposure. Some jazz musicians might have recoiled from the rock underground's embrace. Not Mr. Shipp. He had courted this audience for some time.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Lives; What Barbie Really Taught Me
description: Now that my son is 6 and inextricably linked to the grade-school social circuit, he gets invited to birthday parties. Whenever I telephone to say he is coming, I ask about gifts. And whenever the child is a girl, I secretly hope the answer will be the dirty little word I am longing to hear. The word is Barbie.

title: Taking a Step Up On Swiss Trails
description: WHEN we landed in Zurich on the way to six days of cross-country skiing in the Engadine Valley last March, my husband, Bob, and I saw ourselves as seasoned veterans. We'd skied in Klosters, north of the valley the previous year, and this time we'd chosen a more challenging section of the Swiss Alps.

title: CLINTON'S LAWYERS SCRAMBLE TO LEARN DETAILS OF INQUIRY
description: President Clinton labored today to project a White House busy with the people's business as his lawyers scrambled to learn the crucial details of the sex scandal case that prosecutors were trying to build against Mr. Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ANN DURKIN
description: COHEN-Ann Durkin. 90. On January 22nd, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Henry (Chick) Cohen, mother of Michael and Lynn, mother-in-law of Eileen Cohen and Robert Thomforde. Grandmother of Cari and Max Lang, Scot and Julie Cohen, and Jamie Cohen. Great-grandmother of Zack, Ruby and Ben Lang, and Hank Cohen. Visiting Monday, January 26th, 5-9 PM, at Walter B. Cooke, 117 W. 72nd St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to the memory of Ann Durkin Cohen to Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, 100 W. Kingsbridge Rd., Bronx, NY 10468.

title: Republicans Draft Child-Care Legislation That Would Also Help Stay-at-Home Parents
description: As an alternative to President Clinton's child-care initiative, Republican members of Congress are developing proposals of their own that would help not only parents who work outside the home, but also those who stay home to care for their children.

title: Saving Salmon In the Atlantic Makes Sense
description: A few days ago, I thawed out a small Atlantic salmon that I caught in Caribou Pool on the Upsalquitch River in Canada last summer, and poached it for supper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, SIMON
description: DIAMOND-Simon. On January 23. A resident of Lake Worth, FL. Beloved husband of Kate. Loving brother of Florence Podell. Devoted uncle of Martin, George, Barbara Custen, Rhoda and Judy Glassman and Linda Podell Goodman. Services Monday noon at Menorah Gardens and Funeral Chapels, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: A Slice of Life: Cheeseheads Are More Than Cute
description: It is a piece of foam weighing three quarters of a pound, but don't think for a Super Bowl second that the Cheesehead is just something silly to wear.

title: Tariff-Free in Saipan; Workers' Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LAURA
description: STONE-Laura. On January 22, 1998. Beloved wife of Scott. Dear mother of David. Cherished daughter of Thomas and the late Ruth Fox. Adored sister of Gregory and Janet Fox. A memorial service will be held Monday 11 A.M. at the St. Margaret's Episcopal Church, Plainview, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Cure Autism Now (CAN), 5225 Wilshire Blvd., Suite 1503, L.A., CA 90036.

title: Style; Brace Yourself
description: A stylish friend of mine tore some ligaments in her leg last year and was fitted with a soft black cast designed exclusively for day wear. It was attached by Velcro straps -- very Helmut Lang, she told me. Eventually, she graduated to a cane, choosing basic aluminum. ''I expected something a bit more chic,'' a colleague at work remarked upon seeing it, ''or at least carved with the head of a duck.'' My friend explained that she didn't want a smarter cane for fear she'd become dependent on it as a fashion accessory. Her colleague gave her a knowing look. ''You mean you don't want it to become a crutch.''

title: A South Korean's Rise to Free Market Evangelist
description: It was a long journey for You Jong Keun from the dirt-floor hut where he grew up in a Korean mountain village to his office as an economics professor at Rutgers University.

title: A City Shaped By Movement
description: ''ALL your cars are painted yellow,'' my friend Maggie exclaimed with an astonished laugh. She had just arrived from California -- her 50th Vassar reunion brought her to town -- and was calling from a room overlooking Park Avenue.

title: A Survivor Seeks to Stand Tall in Sandals
description: FIRST there was the flip-flop, then there was the flip-flop revolution.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HIGHWAYS AND DANCEHALLS

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday on an article about a report by the United Nations' chief weapons inspector to the Security Council misidentified the country subject to inspections. It is Iraq, not Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ERTAG, HENRI
description: ERTAG-Henri. January 27, 1964. Beloved brother. Rose Ertag Schreiber

title: Food; The Bitter Truth
description: Broccoli, cauliflower and broccoli rabe are the mainstays of the Italian winter kitchen. Members of the mustard family, these crucifers range in bitterness from hardly any, in the case of broccoli and cauliflower, to considerable for broccoli rabe.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Spice World

title: Crime
description: The words ''worried,'' ''indecisive'' and ''panicked'' do not normally apply to Kate Fansler, the strong-minded, outspoken heroine of Amanda Cross's spirited academic mysteries. But Kate has good reason to be distraught in THE PUZZLED HEART (Ballantine, $21); her husband has been kidnapped, and to ransom him Kate must renounce her feminist political activities and join the Christian right wing ''in its efforts to restore true family values.''

title: Genocide, Recorded by Victims
description: A secretly maintained archive of diaries, photographs and drawings that document the suffering of thousands of Jews herded into a Lithuanian ghetto during World War II has been put on display at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.

title: The View From/Baldwin Place; Astronomy Photographer's Passion For Recording the Things in the Sky
description: WHEN Rick Dilsizian was 13, he was obsessed with two things: astronomy and dinosaurs. He is 51 now, and one of those passions is still burning strong. Every chance he gets -- virtually every night that is not marred by clouds or rain -- he goes out in his backyard here, sets up telescope and camera, and takes pictures of planets, stars and comets. Additionally, he has traveled to all ends of the earth -- Australia, South America, Africa -- to chase eclipses and the better views of things in the sky.

title: In the Region/Long Island; 8 New Start-Up Incubators for Business Proposed
description: SINCE its purchase in 1996 of a 240,000-square-foot office building in Bethpage from Northrop Grumman, Briarcliffe College has refurbished half the structure for its academic needs and leased out 104,000 square feet to others.

title: Suit on S.A.T. Security Settled
description: The Educational Testing Service, which administers the Scholastic Assessment Test and other standardized tests, and Kaplan Educational Centers, a test-preparation service, have agreed to settle a lawsuit arising from Kaplan's covert attempt to demonstrate a potential security problem with the computerized Graduate Record Examination in 1994.

title: January 18-24; Life Without Parole For the Unabomer
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski closed one of the most unusual chapters in law-enforcement history by pleading guilty to Federal charges against him, acknowledging that he was the Unabomber, the elusive figure who killed 3 people and injured 28 others in an 18-year campaign aimed at disrupting technological society.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Helen of Troy in 2 Acts

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Long Island City Mall Gets Big, New Supermarket

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Builder Plans Assisted-Living Complexes in 6 Towns
description: BRIDGES COMMUNITIES of New London has embarked on a $72 million plan to develop assisted-living complexes in six Connecticut towns. The initiative is one of the most ambitious by a state-based developer since such projects were authorized by law in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANCIGER, HERBERT N.
description: DANCIGER-Herbert N. January 19, 1998. Outstanding family man. Beloved husband of Beulah Klein; devoted father of Roanne and Hank Gotthelf; Leslie Wander and Harvey and Sandi Danciger. Adored grandfather of Kenneth and Wende Gotthelf; Sean and Jeffrey Wander; and Aimee and Jill Danciger; loving great grandfather of Justin. Cherished brother of Ruth Danciger. Service 12PM Sunday at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: Retirees, Refusing to Stand Pat, Infuse Communities
description: WHOEVER said there's no future in retirement should meet Marvin Levine. Since resigning from the Psychology Department of the State University at Stony Brook six years ago, he has been writing and publishing poetry, playing in an orchestra and giving lectures on the psychology of Buddhism.

title: With Second Chance, Dog Track Hopes for Second Wind
description: When the Shoreline Star greyhound race track opened here in November 1995, it was hailed as the best new dog track in the country, had 600 employees and attracted 20 of the world's best kennels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LOUIS L.
description: ROSENBERG-Louis L. On January 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Sherry. Loving father of Michael and Karen. Adoring grandfather of David, Jenna, Joshua and Marissa. Devoted brother of Pearl Lamberg, Ruth Russ and Emanuel. Visiting Sunday 7-9 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Service Monday, 1 PM at Union Temple, 17 Eastern Pkwy., Brooklyn, NY.

title: New Ruling On Eviction Procedures
description: JENNIFER LYNN ROMEA recalls spending the 1996 New Year's Eve alone in her Manhattan apartment, out of work, four months behind in her rent and wondering how things could possibly get any worse. Then a process server slipped a notice under her door saying she must pay the rent in three days or vacate the premises.

title: NYC*100: THE FIFTH DECADE
Now Showing: A Cast of Millions
description: ON Dec. 24, 1908, Mayor George B. McClellan Jr. of New York issued a police order to revoke the license of every motion-picture theater in the city -- some 550 of them. The Mayor's action followed one of the longest and angriest public hearings in the city's history, with ministers from almost every denomination testifying to the pernicious effects of movies and arguing that movie theaters should be shuttered.

title: Excerpts of Taped Phone Conversations
description: Following are excerpts from what Newsweek magazine described as tapes of conversations between Monica S. Lewinsky and Linda R. Tripp. The recordings were made by Ms. Tripp without Ms. Lewinsky's knowledge. The transcripts were released by Newsweek last night.

title: Tense Home Life Before Moving to Capitol
description: Monica Lewinsky grew up in a home worth $1.6 million in Beverly Hills, Calif. She went to pricey prep schools there and in Bel Air, another exclusive Los Angeles area. Her family spent $20,000 a year on vacations, and $500 a month on clothes and shoes for her and her younger brother, Michael.

title: Life in the Other Four
description: AS is well known, it is easier to get to Manhattan from Queens than it is to get to Queens from Manhattan. Or to the Bronx, Brooklyn and -- where is it? -- Staten Island. If the vote of 1898 united all these in one megacity, the parts have not only been visibly separate but, more invisibly, unequal. There were, to be sure, gains for the four joined to Manhattan that, with part of the earlier annexed Bronx, constituted New York City.

title: A Korean Giant Spins Out of Control
description: HE'S known as Budo Ong, the old man who can't be toppled. Despite being 77 years old and dependent on a wheelchair because of a stroke, Chung In Yung has been traveling overseas 200 days a year, seeking customers, strategic partners and factory sites for the company he founded, Halla Group.

title: Touring the Collections At 26 Sites, From A to Z
description: The city's hundreds of museums contain enough sights to fill any sightseer's itinerary, literally everything from A to Z. The 26 cited here are only a representative sampling. All the items cited here are in the museum's permanent collections and should be there for the seeing when the museums are open. Hours are subject to change and can be found by calling the phone numbers listed.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Too bad you didn't include a blurb on America's greatest jockey, Eddie Arcaro. I remember once, at the old Aqueduct Racetrack, he was lounging on the low-slanted roof of the jockey's quarters, awaiting the call to the paddock. A horseplayer called out to him, ''Eddie, who do you like in the next race?'' Arcaro yelled back, ''Me.''

title: For Marshals With Dirty Jobs, Hints From the City
description: City marshals will never tell you to have a nice day. At least, not while they're working. What better way to make the people they're evicting even madder?

title: The State of the Presidency
description: This normally festive and frivolous Super Bowl Sunday is a somber time for America. This newspaper reported yesterday that Monica Lewinsky has offered in immunity bargaining to testify that she had sex with the President. By other accounts, physical evidence of intimate contact may exist. When the Cabinet and top White House aides try to defend Mr. Clinton, they speak of what they hope and believe, not what they know. Those hopes have been strengthened by lawyers' assertions that Ms. Lewinsky is so far refusing to testify that Mr. Clinton and his friend Vernon Jordan urged her to lie. The White House has also hinted that Mr. Clinton may eventually produce a mitigating explanation for any contact he may have had with Ms. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, DR. LUCILLE H. BLUM
description: SACHS-Dr. Lucille H. Blum. Beloved mother of Stuart Blum and Abby Nusbaum. Loving grandmother of Jenny and Rachael Nusbaum and mother-in-law of Barbara Blum. Private services and interment were held.

title: Turkish Offerings at Easy-to-Take Prices
description: AT the 109 Shish Kebob House in North Lindenhurst (226-9229), diners can order burgers, pasta, pizza, Cajun chicken, chicken fingers, french fries and, oh yes, Turkish food. Go with the last. Those are Turks, not Italians, in the dining room and kitchen. Anyway, there are so many Italian restaurants on the Island and so few Turkish ones, why go to a Turkish spot (which this is) and order Italian food?

title: Anne Bevis, William Detwiler
description: Anne Bevis and William Franklin Detwiler were married last evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. James Burns, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Masks and More: Art Objects of Oceania
description: VIEWERS may be transported to the other side of the world, to the Sepik River region of New Guinea, considered the most important art center in the region known as Oceania. In ''Spirit Images: The Lidz Collection of Southwest Pacific Art,'' an exhibition at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven through Sept. 27, themes include the separation of sexes and relationship of the dead to the living.

title: Waiting for Courtyard Lock
description: There is no lock on the gate leading to the courtyard for the apartments at 253 East 77th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, a fact that tenants there feel anxious in mentioning because it may be an open invitation to criminals.

title: Shanghai, for Less
description: Fashion's fascination with all things Asian, from mandarin collars to gleaming brocades, has created a look that is popular on runways and in high-end stores. But it is not just for women, and it doesn't have to be expensive to achieve. At Pearl River Mart, an emporium in Chinatown that sells everything from bamboo shoots to linens, there are clothes for the entire family. A man can lounge about in a full-length blue silk robe that fastens at the side ($79.50). A child can keep warm in a quilted rayon brocade jacket in red, gold, peach or ivory ($49.50). And of course, a woman can slither about in a cut-velvet rayon sleeveless dress that has a skirt slit to the thighs, in black, rose or brown ($65).

title: For the Disabled: State Will Refund Plates Fees
description: The state has agreed to give refunds to drivers with disabilities on fees for the license plates and dashboard placards that allow them to use special parking spaces.

title: Love or Money: A Publisher Entwines Both
description: IF there's anything Walter Zacharius finds hard to resist, it's a good romance tale. Like this one.

title: The Man Who Wrote, Haltingly, The Book on Special Effects
description: A DINOSAUR COMES BACK TO LIFE after an atomic-bomb blast and terrorizes New York, scooping up an on-duty police officer from a busy avenue and eating him. A fleet of flying saucers attacks Washington, slicing the Washington Monument in two. A tiny reptilian monster from Venus grows into a Godzilla look-alike at an amazing rate and fights his final battle atop the Colosseum.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Mexico Frees 300 Prisoners To Seek Talks With Rebels
description: The Government of Chiapas state freed 300 prisoners from its jails today in what officials called a ''show of political will'' to help re-open peace talks with the Zapatista rebels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERNAN, RICHARD ROWEN
description: KIERNAN-Richard Rowen. On January 22, 1998. Husband of Greta and friend and companion of Judy Frisch. Father of Ann, Mark, Paul, John, James Kiernan and Clare Lafferty. Grandfather of ten. Brother of David and Jerry. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Saturday and Sunday 2-5 P.M. Funeral mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, on Monday at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Renal Dialysis Unit of Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Younger Hevesi's Senate Bid Unites Comptroller and Rival
description: It was a feud that cast a long shadow over Queens politics for the last four years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, HAROLD I.
description: FRIEDMAN-Harold I. January 22, 1980. A special husband and dad. Lovingly remembered by Selma, Iris, Paul, Amy, James and Meryl.

title: Hackley Second Best In Picking Stocks
description: THE first run of a nationwide student stock market tournament ended as the old year faded, and the Hackley Hornets from the Hackley School here placed second among 2,300 teams.

title: New York Note
description: Caught on a side street

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 28 about an anthology of Yiddish songs misstated the given name of the translator. He is Barnett Zumoff, not Boris.

title: Coming to America
description: DEGAS IN NEW ORLEANS

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE VILLA MARINI By Gloria Montero. Ecco, $23.

title: A 'Star Trek' Voyage Lands in Las Vegas
description: After ''Star Trek,'' there came a universe of sequels and movies. So it was only a matter of time until that science fiction series found its way to the interplanetary outpost called Las Vegas. Star Trek: The Experience opened Jan. 4 at the Las Vegas Hilton, and for $9.95 each, fans can visit the bridge of the Enterprise (no sitting in the captain's chair, though) and the transporter room. Prowling around with them will be actors dressed as those intergalactic high rollers, Ferengi and Klingons.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Willem de Kooning on Dec. 28, with a year-end feature about influences in the art world in 1997, carried an incomplete credit. It should have read ''Copyright by Arnold Newman.''

title: But Will It Fly?
description: TAKING WING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEN, LAWRENCE C., ESQ.
description: SCHOEN-Lawrence C., Esq. Beloved and devoted husband of Marlene. Beloved father of Matthew, Kathy and Amy. Grandfather of Kasey and Sarah. Son of Flora and the late Arthur Schoen. Brother of Dr. Jocelyn Malkin. All of us who loved him mourn his passing. Memorial services were held in Woodmere on Sunday, January 18, 1998.

title: Surviving Fiscal Ruin (and Disco)
description: IN THE 70's, New York hit bottom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOD, MARY CARR
description: HOOD-Mary Carr. On January 23, 1998. Wife of William Hood. Mother of David and Isabel Carmichael. Grandmother of James and Emily Carmichael and Felicity Carmichael Sundlun. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Scott Baio
description: Scott Baio, who played Chachi on ''Happy Days,'' is currently directing episodes of ''Nick Freno'' on the WB Network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, CAMERON
description: CLARK-Cameron. Partner in the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Eliza and Simon. Brother of Timothy and Ian Clark. Son of Blair Clark and the late Jessie Holladay Philbin James. His death occurred suddenly on January 15, 1998 in NYC.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Farewell to Arms, Hello to Doubts
description: ON Mark Hoye's desk in the brand-new suburban offices of the mortgage company where he works are a few reminders of his former life as a Navy aviator -- a model of the P3 Orion submarine tracker he navigated in the Persian Gulf and the plaque they gave him after he came home.

title: Help for the Neediest Newcomers
description: New York City is enriched by people from every part of the globe who come bringing their energies, entrepreneurship and optimism. Half of the residents of this city are foreign born or have a foreign-born parent. But some immigrants are also among the poorest and most vulnerable in the city. The social isolation is especially hard on families escaping war or persecution in their native lands. Any crisis, like the loss of a job or a child falling ill, can be devastating for people without English language skills or community contacts.

title: Elway Throws, Davis Runs and Denver Hopes
description: KEYS TO THE BRONCO OFFENSE

title: Grand Delusion
description: ENDURING LOVE

title: Theme of Light Dominates Temple Frieze in Scarsdale
description: THE frieze wrapping around the walls of the new Center for Jewish Life of the Westchester Reform Temple here concentrates religious, historical and decorative ideas into a shimmering band of color and light.

title: Crib Notes
description: One day, it might not be unusual to receive a thank-you note headed ''From the crib of,'' judging from the growing number of toddlers and young children who have their own personalized stationery and calling cards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPPINGER, JOSH
description: EPPINGER-Josh, on January 20, 1998. Husband of Mary, father of Nell, brother of Fred and Wendy, stepson of Consuelo Lilienthal of San Francisco and stepbrother of five. Interment private. Memorial service to be held in San Francisco this Spring.

title: The Singing Cowboy as Everlasting Everyman
description: SEATED BEHIND AN OAK DESK in his roomy, memorabilia-filled office, Gene Autry is thumbing through ''Western Classics,'' a 1947 bound volume of his 78-rpm recordings, most of them featured in his B-westerns of the 1930's and 40's. He is dressed as usual in a tailored western suit and ornate cowboy boots. His white, 10-gallon Stetson hangs on a nearby hatrack. ''I'll be doggoned,'' Mr. Autry says in a warm voice as he inspects the album set. '' 'Red River Valley,' 'Mexicali Rose,' 'South of the Border,' what a great song! That was a dandy.''

title: Looking Back (Again) on '97; Arab Woman's Story Helped Humanize a Group
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher and Students Fire Back at Vocal Foe of Diversity
description: A self-proclaimed right winger, Frank Borzellieri, has long taken archconservative positions in his capacity as a member of Queens Community School Board 24, such as opposing multiculturalism and demanding that students be taught that American culture is the best in the world.

title: Fairfield Team, After a Banner
description: MOMENTS before his team's opening practice in late November, Dave Danko, the coach of Fairfield High School's girls' basketball team, pointed toward the far wall of the gymnasium, at a gleaming red banner. It symbolized the team's first-ever Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference championship, accomplished last winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODFIN, KATHRYN JANE
description: WOODFIN-Kathryn Jane. Born on February 22, 1946, died on January 22, 1998 in London after a short illness. She was on a holiday trip for Christmas when she became ill. Her mother, Jane Gentry Woodfin, predeceased her. Kay is survived by her father, Gene M. Woodfin and his wife Jerry Ann of Houston, brother Dr. William S. Woodfin and his wife Fran of Dallas, nephews William Keith Woodfin of Connecticut and Gene Sam Woodfin of Dallas, stepbrothers Robert Eldon Young III of Austin and Jerry McFaddin Young of Houston, her beloved aunt Susan Woodfin of Paris, Texas and cousins Hester Sue Parker of Corsicana, Texas, Mack Woodfin and Georgia Leddy of Paris, Texas, and many other cousins. Kay attended The Kinkaid School in Houston and graduated from The Spence School in New York City. She received her Bachelor of Arts degree from Fordham University and Master of Business degree from New York University. Kay had lived in New York since 1962. She was a lovely girl and will be missed by her family and many friends. After a private memorial service for the family, her remains will be interred in the family cemetery on the Woodfin Brothers Ranch in Lamar County, Texas.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: PARK

title: NYC*100: THE FIRST DECADE
Williams Is in Control of His Game, and His Life
description: For Tyrone Williams, the game is all about control. His checklist begins when the Green Bay Packers' defense breaks its huddle and he moves toward his position at left cornerback.

title: Look Who's Leaping From That Hollow Tree
description: KEEBLER FOODS is hoping to work some of its elfin magic on investors.

title: Real Life Story: Tale of a Shipwreck and the Actor Who Lived to Tell About It
description: Peter Kapetan has a story he can dine out on. Well, he gets cocktails with it anyway. ''Oh, Peter, tell your lifeboat story'' he's begged pretty regularly. ''I can't half tell it,'' he said, ''I'm either up for it or I'm not.''

title: John Long and Paulette Owens
description: FOR as long as he can remember, John Charles Long has loved everything about newspapers. He still sometimes buys the paper just to hold it in his hand like a meditation stone.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: HITLER'S BANKER

title: How to Install a Suspended Ceiling
description: AN easy way to finish off a ceiling is by installing a suspended one. The skills required for this project are minimal, and only a few basic tools are needed.

title: Bustle and Formality in Chappaqua
description: ON a weekend evening, this seems the place to be. Valets zoom away in cars, greeters take coats, staff bustles and hustles, conversations become animated, deafening -- everyone is glad to be here.

title: Surreys With Less Fringe: A Decline in Executive Perks
description: DOUG GEOGA, the president of the Hyatt Hotels Corporation in Chicago, drives a company-leased 1989 Oldsmobile Cutlass and gets a company-paid membership in a no-frills gym. But he receives little else in perquisites. When he stays at a Hyatt, he waits in line to check into his basic guest room -- no Champagne cocktail, no luxurious presidential suite.

title: How's the Mayor? Ask Him, if You Dare
description: AS a rule of thumb, it is folly to challenge any man who habitually refers to himself in the third person. So Sharpe James merely assumed a pose like a batter when he was warned that a verbal curveball was headed his way.

title: Land of Giants, Bums and Bombers
description: IN the small town where I grew up in the heart of a middle-American county during a decade that promoted atomic terror, family togetherness and a gray-flannel future, my generation was given a unique opportunity. By pledging allegiance to one of the three major-league baseball teams then playing in New York, each of which represented an aspect of the city's personality, we could declare our aspirations, invent ourselves -- at the least disguise our fears.

title: Seventh Avenue, Street of Dreams
description: SAM COPELAND, a struggling Brooklyn blouse jobber and father of nine, was devout, shrewd and practical in equal measure. He was a man who appreciated art if it could be turned to honest profit. That was what he knew. The garment trade in which he labored was just emerging, in the shadow of the Great War, into a respectable American business. Real-estate fortunes would soon be amassed by farsighted men who moved the scattered, infamous sweatshops of the Lower East Side into Seventh Avenue skyscrapers.

title: All Over but the Legislating
description: WRATH OF ANGELS

title: Looking Back (Again) on '97; Foes of Brooklyn Junction Are Repeating Earlier Error
description: To the Editor:

title: A Production Brings Old Friends Full Circle
description: THE top of the program's title page reads, ''McCarter Theater presents 'Cymbeline' by William Shakespeare, directed by Mark Lamos.'' Near the bottom appears the credit ''Emily Mann, artistic director,'' as it has five times a season since 1991.

title: Whatever Happened to Politics?; When Naptime Is Over
description: There's no longer any political news, a reporter friend confided recently, explaining why ''human interest'' stories were oozing like syrup across his newspaper's front pages. We're in the Bland Decade now, a time when citizens march on Washington not to affect politics but to vow they'll be better people and when politicians speak out mainly to urge niceness: volunteer your time, enter into dialogues on race, hire someone off welfare, please. Apparently we need little more than charity, moral uplift and perhaps a modest program or two. Politics is dead, or so it seems.

title: When Fish Came to the Rescue
description: I enjoyed reading ''Giving a Fluke a Chance'' [Dec. 14]. Rose N. Freidman, the writer, however, did find a fish ''at her doorstep'' once before. . . .in Alaska. Her husband was a United States. chaplain stationed there during the Korean War.

title: BENEFITS
description: 'Capeman' and Its Composer

title: Barefoot Road To Glory
description: MAKE no mistake: rock and country singers have known how to kick up their heels for years. But these days, more of them are doing it in a decidedly free-spirited way -- barefoot.

title: TELEVISION; Cinemax Bites Reality and Tastes Respect
description: ''REEL LIFE,'' THE QUIRKY DOCUMENTARY series on Cinemax, is governed by one rule: forget rules. Everything from style to time slot is up for grabs. Since its beginning in 1995, ''Reel Life'' appears on one Wednesday each month, maybe at 8 P.M., maybe at 11 P.M., depending on a film's content, which can vary wildly. There's ''Roe vs. Roe: Baptism by Fire'' following Jane Roe's odyssey from abortion-rights icon to handmaiden for the anti-abortion movement, and ''The Burger and the King,'' a chronicle of Elvis Presley's fatal eating habits. ''Calling the Ghosts'' investigates gang rape in Bosnia, while ''All Dressed Up'' celebrates heterosexual men who don women's clothes. The only common element among these documentaries -- tragic or darkly funny, shot on film or home video, 90 minutes or half an hour -- is that they needed a venue.

title: Open Land, Park or Both in Naugatuck?
description: IN the summer of 1995, when Leonard and Christine Yannielli spotted a pair of scarlet tanagers on a parcel of undeveloped land recently purchased by the town of Naugatuck, they resolved to work to preserve the land in its natural state.

title: Sports of The Times; Running Backs' Attitude: 'Built Like a Rock'
description: IT'S pro football's toughest job. Running backs take a handoff or a pitchout and then take the punishment from the 300-pound linemen and 250-pound linebackers swarming toward them. If you're down on the field to hear the crash and clack of all those helmets and pads, the collisions sound almost like auto accidents.

title: One Park, Many Squabbles
description: The vision is clear: a lush green park along the Brooklyn waterfront. The challenge, as recent developments indicate, is to prevent that goal from drowning in process.

title: Compelled by an Early Crime of the Century
description: AFTER MANY RETELLINGS OF the 1920's Leopold and Loeb murder case, why has the fascination lasted from the Capone-era to the Cunanan-era?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, SAM C.
description: HERMAN-Sam C. Died in Nashua, NH January 21, 1998. Former Advertising Director of The Long Island Press, Jamaica, Long Island, NY, retiring in 1975 after 30 years. Husband of the late Emma (Brody) Herman. Father of Marilyn H. Solomon of Nashua, NH. Grandfather of Laurie Berna of Hollis, NH, David H. Solomon of Dracut, MA, and Dr. Michael E. Solomon of San Diego, CA. Great-grandfather of James McMurchy of Hollis, NH and Matthew Solomon of Dracut, MA. Funeral services: Temple Beth Abraham, Nashua, NH, Sunday (today). Interment: Beth Abraham Cemetery, Nashua, NH. Memorial week will be observed privately. Contributions: American Cancer Society, c/o Pat Trainovich, 2 Wren Court #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, BARBARA
description: ALTMAN-Barbara. At age sixtysix, on January 22, 1998. Loving wife of Daniel. Mother of Michael (Marita). Devoted grandmother of Samantha and Theodore. Services Sunday, January 25, 11:30 A.M. at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Washington Ellipse: Words of Denial, Carefully Chosen
description: Among the avenues of scrutiny in President Clinton's denials of sexual affairs is the precision of his language in insisting on his innocence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, ANN
description: STONE-Ann. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved sister of Murray Gallahou and extend heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Fred Distenfeld

title: Collapse on Lower East Side Leaves Families Homeless
description: A century-old, five-story brick apartment building on the Lower East Side partially collapsed yesterday morning, leaving at least 10 families homeless. The building was later demolished, angering the tenants who said they had been given no chance to rescue pets or belongings.

title: The Perfect Teaming of Cauliflower and Anchovies
description: CAULIFLOWER and anchovies are one of the more curious and successful marriages in the kitchen. When anchovies are cooked they develop a subtle, almost nutty taste and they act as a perfect foil for the mild sweetness of cauliflower, a vegetable that can be rather bland when eaten on its own.

title: A Museum for Digital Art
description: Even before it had a Web site, the Museum of Modern Art was on the Web. As long ago as 1995, decades away in Internet time, MOMA curators would put on other institutions' Web sites such exhibitions as ''Mutant Materials in Contemporary Design,'' a look at artists working in materials like carbon-fiber-reinforced plastic. That May 1995 exhibit, with Paola Antonelli as curator, was on the Web site of the School of Visual Arts, another Manhattan art institution.

title: Seton Hall Falls Just Short at Buzzer
description: After a close game, many coaches in the Big East act as if they have just finished a triathlon. Seton Hall Coach Tommy Amaker usually acts as if he has just taught a physics class.

title: A 300-Year Dress Rehearsal
description: GEOLOGY created conditions for a wonderful port at the mouth of the Hudson River. It took an explosion of commerce to make it a great city and a strong political will to make Greater New York in 1898.

title: Singletary and Munoz Lead Rush to the Hall
description: When Mike Singletary played college football at Baylor, he hit people so hard that he cracked nine of his own helmets. When he went to the Chicago Bears, he broke at least five more during a brilliant 12-year career as a linebacker.

title: Pep Talks for Jews in Nebraska and Alaska
description: CHAYA TELDON of Commack has taken to the road once again. With a song in her heart and the Torah on her mind, Mrs. Teldon, a mother of five, was home only two days last week. ''Enough time to do the laundry,'' she said.

title: How a Single Telephone Call Was the Catalyst for a Crisis
description: Shortly after 9 o'clock on the evening of Jan. 12, the Whitewater independent counsel's office received a call that would transform the 41-month investigation led by Kenneth W. Starr and profoundly shake the Presidency of Bill Clinton.

title: Ideas & Trends; 30 Years After Tet, the War as Hanoi Showed It
description: TET, the springtime festival of flowers, gifts and family reunions, is traditionally the happiest day of Vietnam's lunar calendar, a time to observe the joyful rites that signify rebirth and bountiful harvests. But 30 years ago this month, Tet assumed quite a different character when it became a bloody symbol of Hanoi's all-out drive to undermine American confidence and resolve.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: It is inevitable that in an issue with the scope of your biographies of the great who died in 1997, there would be some significant omissions (''The Lives They Lived,'' Jan. 4). I believe one was Jean Hoerni, who invented the planar structure for transistors. Without that structure, today's integrated circuits (chips) would not exist. Integrated circuits, especially microprocessors, are at the heart of just about everything electronic that touches our lives. Hoerni was one of the scientists who left Shockley Semiconductor in 1957 to found Fairchild Semiconductor, the granddaddy of what we now call Silicon Valley.

title: The View From the Paying Passenger's Seat
description: LINCOLN can talk all it wants about the extensive makeover that has given the Town Car a revamped suspension, brakes, transmission and body. For a lot of people who use the car, all that really matters is the rear seat and the trunk.

title: Iran Keeps Its Distance On U.S. Crisis With Iraq
description: If Washington is curious about Iran's reaction to the current crisis between Iraq and the United States, it has only to look at the reception given here to Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Kent, N.Y.; Rustic, Rugged Yet A Workable Commute
description: WHEN Anne Ladau talks about the Town of Kent in northern Putnam County, she often jokingly refers to it as ''L. L. Bean country.''

title: The World; Hearing the Pope With Ears of Marx
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II stood above the sea of worshipers and urged the Cuban people to respect the permanence of marriage and the sanctity of the unborn. But as his words echoed through the town of Santa Clara last week, young women here were filing into abortion clinics and disgruntled husbands and wives were paying $4.50 in this city's Collective Law Offices to end their failed unions.

title: NYC*100: THE SIXTH DECADE
City Reaches Tentative Contract With Guards
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that his administration had reached a tentative agreement with the 11,000-member union representing correction officers, leaving only one major municipal union still at the bargaining table.

title: Most Promising (and Grating) Playwright
description: The Green Man and French Horn pub, wrapped in dark wood and saturated with yeasty vapors, is just down St. Martin's Lane and across the street from the Royal Court Theater's temporary home in the heart of the West End. A crush of passageways and marquees in the few surrounding blocks marks the center of London's theater world. Martin McDonagh, sitting at a side counter in the Victorian gloom with the sheen on his two-tone leather shoes catching what little light bounces off the leaded glass, calls out, ''Bitter and twisted.''

title: Alter Riverside Church? Like Redoing Chartres, Foes Say
description: Occupying two solid blocks from 120th to 122d Street, between Riverside Drive and Claremont Avenue, Riverside Church is a landmark, if not technically so then in the hearts and minds of many in the community it serves.

title: Where London Shops and Sups
description: SHOPPING is hard work that requires sustenance. To insure that customers don't drop while they shop, more and more retailers worldwide have installed restaurants on their premises. In London the best of these are very good indeed, rewarding even those without an appetite for recreational shopping.

title: Lisa Pulitzer, Douglas Love
description: Lisa Beth Pulitzer, a writer, was married yesterday to Douglas Paul Love, the senior correspondent for The Southampton Press. The Rev. Susan Marlan of the Interfaith Church performed the ceremony at the Maidstone Arms in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: A Caseworker's Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: John Paul Monahan 3d, 42, Dies; A Legal Analyst for NBC News
description: John Paul Monahan 3d, a lawyer and NBC News legal analyst, died yesterday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. The husband of Katie Couric, the NBC ''Today'' host, Mr. Monahan was 42 and lived in Manhattan.

title: On Wisconsin: Green Bay Can Pile Up the Points
description: KEYS TO THE PACKER OFFENSE

title: On Staten Island, a Buried Treasure
description: THE school page of The New York World-Telegram and Sun carried lists of jobs available for teachers around the city. In March 1958, there was a vacancy for an English teacher at McKee Vocational and Technical High School, St. Mark's Place and Wall Street. There was a phone number and when I called, a lady said, ''Come right over.'' I lived, then, near Borough Hall in Brooklyn, and I was pleased at how convenient it would be to travel such a short distance to my first teaching job.

title: Seasonal Greenery
description: On a minor note, in this dreary season of warehouse vegetables, sauteed bok choy with garlic is starting to appear on the menus of Chinese restaurants in New Jersey. If you've never tried it, now is the time. It's the Chinese counterpart to the sauteed escarole served in most Italian restaurants. Even when it's bad, it's good, and when it's good, it's sensational. Eat it plain or with shrimp or chicken.

title: A Chesnutt on Film
description: To the Editor:

title: What's the Advantage Of H.O.V. Lanes?
description: The H.O.V. lane as interpreted on the L.I.E. is ill conceived, as are most traffic plans for Long Island. Trapping cars by an invisible wall created by a painted divider, whether the lane restrictions are in effect or not, can do nothing but add to the road rage.

title: Shy, Bullied, but He's Got a Tailor-Made Solution
description: Star Kid

title: A First Play With an Unprintable Title: Call It a Hit
description: FOR A FIRST-TIME DRAMATIST, Mark Ravenhill is making an unusual stir, since he has chosen a title for his play that many publications, including this one, cannot print.

title: The Winds Were Warm, Then Bitter
description: ALL ERAS have their colors, by which I mean their tonalities. The Victorian age is dove gray, the Renaissance is sunny gold, the 18th century a creamy white. Eras also have their time of day; the Middle Ages is early morning; fourth-century Athens is brilliant noon. New York in the 60's was always summer, and the sun fell on the sidewalk through a net of light green leaves.

title: Paulina Ruvinska, 85, Pianist of Vast Range
description: Paulina Ruvinska, a pianist known for her vigorous technique and the breadth of her repertory, died on Jan. 17 at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Jordan Trades Stories With Clinton, and Offers Counsel
description: He is the successor to a long line of famous back-room cronies of Presidents, holding no government position, who have had as much entree to the White House as the highest-ranking officials.

title: TV Images Give Exiles In U.S. Some Hope
description: At a shrine to Cuba's patron saint, Our Lady of Charity, there have been daily Masses since Pope John Paul II arrived in Cuba and around-the-clock praying for Cuba and for his success as, in the words of a Miami Bishop, ''a solidifier of liberty.''

title: Skeptics Ignore a Century of Scientific Triumph; Thorough Investigations
description: To the Editor:

title: Not for Gold Medalists Only
description: THE ride from Paris on the T.G.V. seemed like a good way to start a ski vacation, because the destination was Val d'Isere, where the racers on television often seem to imitate high-speed trains as they hurtle down the mountainside.

title: Greater New York? Not Without Bridges
description: THERE are 2,027 bridges in this city, by the Museum of the City of New York's count. And the museum will show some of the most striking ones in its exhibition ''Bridging New York,'' which opens on Saturday.

title: Knick Player Reaches for More Time on Court
description: WHEN Chris Dudley, the New York Knick center and Rye resident, turned down a four-year, $13 million deal with the Detroit Pistons to play for the Knicks for $272,000, the league minimum, he expected to receive regular playing time on a championship-caliber team. Instead, Patrick Ewing's season-ending wrist injury actually decreased Dudley's playing time, and although the Knicks have played well during Ewing's absence, making the playoffs and possibly winning one round is a more realistic Knick goal than a championship.

title: NYC*100: THE SEVENTH DECADE
Hand Sees All
description: It's cute. It's sleek. It's the Elph, the tiny stainless steel camera that fits in the hand, tucks into a shirt pocket -- and takes pictures in three different formats: regular, panoramic or close-up, using the same cartridge of 24-millimeter film.

title: The Don Flows Again
description: It is common wisdom that important works of literature should be retranslated at least once in every generation. The greater the original, the more translations it can bear -- witness the continuing flood of new versions of Homer, Dante and books of the Bible. The point is that few translators can match their chosen authors for genius. Another reason is that a translation is only one of a myriad possible readings, a critique of the original, a provisional version limited and defined by the translator's talents and the intellectual currents of his time. In rare instances -- Dryden's Virgil, Pope's Homer, Urquhart's Rabelais -- translations attain classic status, but they cannot compete with their originals for authority and influence, unless, like Edward Fitzgerald's ''Rubaiyat,'' they surpass them.

title: Their Devil's Advocates
description: On the day he was to have what he would later call his ''meeting with the devil,'' Randy Warren woke up early. It was the last day of April 1997, and Warren had spent a restless night in a hotel at the Toronto airport, two hours from his home, awaiting the morning arrival of two strangers, businessmen from New Jersey.

title: On Location In the Jungle
description: OUR first tip-off was Patsy Cline. Having plowed 88 miles for three hours along unforgiving jungle roads into the bumpy backbone of western Belize, past desperately remote villages with names like Black Man Eddy and Double Head Cabbage, we were hardly expecting to find indoor plumbing at Blancaneaux Lodge, let alone country music drifting sweetly through the pine-mountain air.

title: The Big City; The Upside of Gossip
description: For cultural anthropologists who monitor New York's tabloids, this social season is already a textbook classic, not to mention a watershed in male-female relations. It began, of course, with the troubles of Marv Alpert and headlines like ''The Kink and I,'' followed by the travails of the art dealer Alec Wildenstein, who was arrested after his wife, Jocelyne, returned from their ranch in Kenya and surprised him in their East Side town house. Jocelyne, dubbed ''The Bride of Wildenstein'' because of her extensive plastic surgery, said her husband pulled a gun on her when she discovered him, wearing only a towel, with a beautiful young woman.

title: Different Roads To the Super Bowl
description: ONE is from a predominantly black high school in Hartford, and the other from a practically all-white Hartford suburb. One is a lithe, soft-spoken 190-pound free safety; the other is a powerfully built 245-pound and somewhat raucous linebacker. What they have in common is that they will be the only players from Connecticut in today's Super Bowl football game in San Diego.

title: Word for Word / The Wendt Divorce; What's a Corporate Wife Worth In Court? Go Figure.
description: DURING the trial, you could hear the rumbling organ tones: this was a landmark test of women's rights. Lorna J. Wendt, after all, was the ultimate corporate wife. Even after learning that her husband, Gary C. Wendt, chief executive of the GE Capital Corporation, secretly planned to divorce her after 31 years, she played the dutiful hostess at the corporate Christmas party.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Former Virgin By Cris Mazza. FC2, paper, $11.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STELLA, MARIA
description: STELLA-Maria. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians, nurses and staff of our Institute for Neurology and Neurosurgery (INN) in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Maria Stella, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague JoAnn Baldwin, Administrator for The INN. To JoAnn and family, we offer our heartfelt condolences during this difficult time. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President, BIMC Fred J. Epstein, M.D., Chairman, Department of Neurosurgery and Director, The INN Alejandro Berenstein, M.D., Director, Center for Endovascular Surgery and Co-Director, The INN Ruth E. Hennessey, Vice President for Administration Beth Israel-North Division

title: IN BRIEF; New Jersey Was No. 2 In Hate Crimes in 1996
description: New Jersey ranked second in the nation in the number of hate crimes in 1996, moving up from the third-place position in 1995, according to an F.B.I. report released earlier this month.

title: The Ebb and Gush of Oil Services
description: AS roller-coaster rides go in the stock market, few have offered the thrills and chills of oil-service stocks. The stocks soared last year, gaining an average of 40 percent in October alone, only to plunge since December on falling oil prices and turmoil in Asia.

title: A Mortgage Broker Fee on the Ropes
description: THE battle between home buyers and the mortgage industry intensified recently when a Federal appeals court ruled that certain fees banks pay to mortgage brokers were little more than kickbacks.

title: Virtue Over Vice, But Barely
description: ITS SUPPORTERS hailed the creation of Greater New York as an event of historic significance on a par with the founding of Rome. Yet in the early light of Jan. 1, 1898, things didn't appear too different from before. No one among the five boroughs' 3.5 million residents proposed starting a new calendar, as the Romans had, ab urbe condita, ''from the founding of the city.''

title: THE BOATING REPORT; Adversity Gives Grit a Lift
description: The nine-boat fleet in the Whitbread Round the World Race is in the midst of a three-week layover in New Zealand. The 31,600-nautical-mile odyssey restarts on Feb. 1 for the fifth and longest of nine legs, 6,670 nautical miles from Auckland to Brazil and around Cape Horn. Currently, EF Language is first over all, with Merit Cup, the winner of Leg 4, in second place. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women's crew of EF Education of Sweden, which stands eighth over all, will continue to file periodic updates of life at sea until the race's scheduled return to Southampton, England, in May. This is her 13th report.

title: Sports of The Times; The Old Commissioner Is Cheering for Denver
description: THE commissioner will arrive in San Diego this morning. He'll arrive by bus, sit in some undesignated section and cheer like crazy for ''my Denver Broncos.''

title: Carrying On About Carry-Ons
description: SOON air travelers will no longer be allowed to cram overhead bins with an assortment of stuff they don't need on the trip -- mandolins, toaster ovens, ski boots, duty-free single malt whiskey, what have you. Many airlines are apparently cracking down on this practice and will require passengers to check all but one carry-on (''plus either a briefcase, a laptop computer or purse'') when they present their tickets to the agent behind the counter.

title: New Orleans
description: Contrary to hearsay, New Orleans is not entirely hedonistic. How could it be? No place without a work ethic could invent so many excuses for a holiday. The high holiday season is at hand.

title: After the War, a Whirlwind Ride
description: THE DECADE caught the city like a gigantic mood swing, flinging its fortunes into unexplored space. Economic hardship blanketed New York throughout the 30's, particularly in Harlem, where 40 percent of the families were on relief. Yet when Albert Camus arrived from France for a visit in March 1946, he was stunned by the city's visible economic power, its magnificent food markets and monstrous billboard advertisements, all designed to arouse envy among war-ravaged Europeans.

title: Q. & A.
description: Renovated House Next Door

title: Tuscan Holidays
description: To the Editor: Your article about Thanksgiving in Tuscany was correct about what a splendid time of year it is to visit that region, for reasons quite aside from the culinary. Last year, I spent four days in November visiting friends on sabbatical in Florence. No crowds lined up for the museums, and no tour buses jammed the squares. I was able to view the art and architecture of Florence and the surrounding countryside in an unhurried way.

title: . . . And Burlington County Will Evaluate Home Security
description: Programs have been established in New Jersey in recent years to help senior citizens improve security in their homes in an effort to thwart criminals who prey on the most vulnerable. The Burlington County sheriff's office has extended the service to the 35,000 people with disabilities who live in the county. It is believed to be the only county in the state to do so.

title: Millinery District
description: The clouds, piled in rows like merchandise,

title: BEST SELLERS: January 25, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Theater Air Rights Plan Awaits Reviews
description: LIKE the characters in ''The Sunshine Boys,'' whose set they used for the announcement, city officials and leaders of the theater industry have reached entente after years of estrangement.

title: Determined or Not, Rangers Still Can't Beat Devils
description: Playing one of their best games of the season yesterday, the struggling Rangers managed only a 3-3 tie with the Devils at Madison Square Garden. It was a lengthy, grueling affair, spiced with fights and blood and filled with tedious breaks for television commercials. It took 3 hours 18 minutes to play the 65 minutes.

title: St. Francis Xavier
description: To the Editor: I would add a fact to Martha Stevenson Olson's very fine article about Goa and its Catholic history (''Beaches for Saints and Sinners,'' Nov. 30). While most of St. Francis Xavier's body is indeed on view in Goa, his right arm, used to bless and baptize countless thousands, was removed and sent to Rome. St. Francis's arm can be seen in a silver reliquary above a side altar in the Church of the Gesu on the Via del Plebiscito.

title: A Saddler Who Dreamt Of Flying Machines
description: AT 78, AFTER WORKING FOR A HALF century as a butcher and a saddler in Prussia and Texas, Charles A. A. Dellschau began to paint. Almost until his death at 92 in 1923, he produced a watercolor or a collage a day in the attic of his home in Houston, depicting his fantasies: flying machines.

title: Emil Sitka, Favorite Foil Of 3 Stooges, Dies at 83
description: Emil Sitka, a character actor who portrayed butlers and others with such exquisite dignity and in such rarefied company it was inevitable that if he didn't get poked in the eye or bopped on the head he was sure to catch a cream pie in the kisser, died on Jan. 16 at a hospital near his home in Camarillo, Calif. He was 83 and had been a favorite foil of the Three Stooges.

title: Q and A
description: New Zealand Arts Festival

title: Q&A/Frank Panzarella; Workplace Safety, at the State Level
description: FRANK PANZARELLA is the director of the Connecticut Council on Occupational Safety and Health, a nonprofit, statewide organization based in Hartford. Its members includes local unions, labor councils, health and safety activists and health professionals and its goals are to to solve workplace health and safety problems, support new legislation and better enforcement of existing laws as well as provide training to workers and employers.

title: The Day Lady Died
description: It is 12:20 in New York a Friday

title: Tariff-Free in Saipan; Siphoning U.S. Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENGARINI, ARIEL
description: MENGARINI-Ariel. On January 9, 1998, Ariel Mengarini, M.D. board certified psychiatrist, born October 19, 1919 in Rome to what the Dictionary of American Biography calls ''a distinguished Roman family.'' Ariel, with his mother, the sculptress Fausta Vittoria Mengarini, came to the United States when he was still a young boy. He finished his education in Washington, D.C. and in New York. When he was 23, he became United States Amateur Chess Champion. Chess was a lifelong obsession for him. He became a United States citizen in 1942. He honorably served in World War II. He was a Captain in the United States Army Medical Corps-Neuropsychiatrist. In Germany, he made part of a team to take over the administration of a large prison-of-war hospital. He received three campaign medals and the World War II Victory Medal. Honorably discharged in October 1946. He worked for the United States Government as a psychiatrist. He was devoted to his patients and said that he was ''proud to have helped a great many of them.'' Upon retiring, he continued his intense interest in the game of chess, playing in tournaments throughout the rest of his life. He wrote a book on chess: ''Predicament in 2-Dimensions: The Thinking of a Chess Player'', which had three printings. He wrote chess articles and articles on his medical specialty. He was an avid reader with a wide interest which included history, philosophy, poetry, fiction and the study of the human brain. He is survived by his loving wife Aristea Drivas Mengarini, his daughter Athena, his son Will, and by nephews and nieces in Maryland, along with their children and grandchildren and by first cousins in Italy, Germany and Sweden. He died of brain cancer after an illness lasting eight months. ''Comforter, where, where is your comforting?''

title: Love Changes All
description: There is no mistaking the origin of YOUNG AT HEART. A 1954 musical remake of Fannie Hurst's romance ''Four Daughters,'' it is still the frankly sentimental tale of small-town sisters (only three this time) whose peaceful home is invaded by, among others, a bitter misfit with considerable musical talent. Frank Sinatra is the rude and prickly Barney Sloan, destined to be radically reconstructed by a bouncy Doris Day in the role of Laurie Tuttle. Several memorable songs -- ''Just One of Those Things,'' ''There's a Rising Moon'' -- and a supporting cast that includes Gig Young, Dorothy Malone and Ethel Barrymore help sustain the warmth and feeling of this elaborately optimistic film -- SATURDAY at MIDNIGHT on CHANNEL 21.

title: Scandals Can Hurt Bulls and Presidents
description: Scandal engulfed Washington. A recession arrived. Stock prices plunged. The Vice President replaced the President.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Antiques in Westport

title: Older and Younger Performers at Work
description: ON Saturday afternoon at 5, when the Musical Masterworks Series resumes at First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, the generation gap becomes one of the attractions: the veteran pianist (and series director) Charles Wadsworth offers on-stage commentary, listens while the violinist Juliette Kang and the cellist Andres Diaz play the Kodaly Duo, accompanies the clarinetist Todd Palmer in the Debussy Rhapsody, and is partner to Ms. Kang and Mr. Palmer in a Suite from Stravinsky's ''L'Histoire du Soldat.'' Ticket information is available by calling (203) 434-0131.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNEIL, CHARLES
description: McNEIL-Charles. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles McNeil, associated with The Times from 1982.

description: Celibates & Other Lovers
