description: SELLING 'EM BY THE SACK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTRO, OGDEN WINNE
description: SUTRO-Ogden Winne. Of Long Hill Farm in Guilford, CT died Wednesday evening January 14, 1998, at the age of 84. Mr. Sutro was a Connecticut businessman who devoted much of his time and interest to the Boy Scouts, Education and the development of industry in Southern Connecticut which included founding an electronics company, a bank and a consulting firm. In particular, he devoted his time and energy to The Foote School and Yale University, where he was Managing Director of the Yale Alumni Fund for several years, and to his class of 1936, ''Yale's greatest class'' of which he was class secretary until his health declined. He was a direct descendent of Christiaan Winne, one of the Dutch founders of New York City. He was a member of the St. Nicholas Society, the New Haven Lawn Club, and the Hartwood Club. He was born in New York City and graduated from the Pingry School prior to attending Yale University where he graduated in 1936 from the Sheffield School of Engineering. He played football and lacrosse for Yale. He was a Naval Officer in World War II in the South Pacific. He lived and worked in Connecticut. His first wife, Priscilla Alden Egleston, died in 1984. He is survived by his wife Susanna Small Sutro of Guilford, CT; three children, by his first wife, Ogden Hillyer Sutro of Stonington, CT, Virginia Sutro Morse of Winchester, MA, and Curtis DeWitt Sutro of Stratford, CT; two grandchildren, Andrew Hillyer Sutro and Alden David Morse; his brothers, Louis Lefevre Sutro and Fred C. Sutro. There will be a private interment followed by a memorial service on Saturday, February 7, 1998 at 12:00 noon at Trinity Church on The Green located at the corner of Chapel and Temple Street, New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Yale Class of 1936 Alumni Fund Endowment, PO Box 1890, New Haven, CT 06508, Attn John Sargent. Services under direction of Oak Grove Cremation Service, 662 Savin Avenue, West Haven, Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVEY, JOHN G.
description: LEAVEY-John G., a retired IBM executive, died on January 21. Mr. Leavey was 74 and died of pneumonia He joined IBM in 1957 and spent over 34 years as a special activities executive. He is survived by his wife Lorraine, his sons James, John and William, and his five grandchildren, Christopher, Michael, Patrick, Noel and Owen. For information contact Waterbury & Kelly, 914-941-0838.

title: On Language; Misrule of Thumb
description: 'We had to go by rule of thumb,'' said Louis Katz, vice president of the George Washington University, explaining some funding problems to The gw Hatchet, an independent student newspaper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVINE, RITA K.
description: DEVINE-Rita K. Died December 29, 1997, at the age of 72, in San Diego, CA. She was a resident of Stamford, CT, for six years, and previously of Rye, NY. Predeceased by husband John F. Devine. Survivors include Patrick F. Devine II and his wife Debra, of Newport Ritchy, FL, Mary Ann Routson and her husband Geoffrey, of Maybrook, NY, grandchildren Ashley and Rebecca Routson. Memorial service at Doral Farm Community Center, Doral Farm Rd, Stamford, CT, Saturday, January 31, 1998, at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence, 135 Broad St, Hartford, CT 06105.

title: January 18-24; Deconstructing PMS
description: Researchers are zeroing in on the biological causes of premenstrual syndrome, with the promise that treatments can be developed to counter its hormonal underpinnings. The latest study, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, revealed that the brains of women with severe PMS respond aberrantly to changes in blood levels of estrogen and progesterone.

title: The World: The Curse of Riches; In Africa, Wealth Often Buys Only Trouble
description: SENSING a killing to be made, Jean-Raymond Boulle, the founder of an aggressive mining upstart called American Mineral Fields, picked sides early in the civil war that swept Zaire last year.

title: POSTINGS: A Site That Crunches Numbers; Refinancing On the Web
description: With mortgage rates low, many homeowners are wondering whether they should refinance. To help provide answers, Intuit Inc., the Mountain View, Calif., company that markets Quicken financial software, opened an electronic Refinance Center last week on its Quicken Mortgage Web site -- a cybershopping center for mortgages that the company started last November.

title: Who Says She Can't?
description: SO far, Celestine Tate has missed only one day of work since she was hired in December by the McDonald's restaurant at Ocean One Mall. Unusually high blood pressure forced her to see a doctor, she said.

title: Looking Back (Again) on '97; Article on Monastery Missed Spiritual Dimension
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: TOMORROW IN THE BATTLE THINK ON ME By Javier Marias. Harcourt Brace, $24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, DOROTHY
description: HIRSCH-Dorothy. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the Chairlady of its Women's Club. Her exemplary dedication to our Synagogue, enthusiasm for its programs and selfless concern for all its members will be remembered among us with gratitude and affection. Heartfelt sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Sanford Meisner
description: I was appalled reading the description of the late Sanford Meisner's teaching methods. Gregory Peck nearly throttles his acting partner. Meisner ''liked that one.'' Joanne Woodward runs out of the room in tears. Meisner said to her, ''That's the best thing you've done in six months.'' Diane Keaton never acts on stage because of a remark by Meisner. The theater seems to be the last area of society where the fascistic personality is not only acceptable, but actually admired.

title: Jackie Gingrich, J. E. Cushman Jr.
description: Jackie Sue Gingrich, a daughter of Jackie Gingrich of Carrollton, Ga., and Representative Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, was married in Atlanta yesterday to James Edward Cushman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cushman of Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. Spencer D. Simrill performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: So Once There Was This Guy Named Gotti . . .
description: THE SETTING: 101st Avenue in Ozone Park, Queens, a strip anchored by the Bergin Hunt and Fish Social Club, the erstwhile hangout of one John Gotti -- the former boss of the Gambino crime family and current resident of a 7-by-8-foot prison cell over there in Marion, Ill.

title: Week of the Locust
description: ACCORDING to local history, a black cloud of crickets descended upon the Mormon people's first wheat harvest here, more than 150 years ago. Fortunately, a white cloud of sea gulls, it is said, swooped in to eat the crickets, saving the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTSCHALK, HERTHA (NEE KAUFMANN)
description: GOTTSCHALK-Hertha (nee Kaufmann). On January 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Fred. Devoted mother of Susan and Elaine. Loving sister of the late Walter Kaufmann. Cherished grandmother of Marc, David, Adam and Lisa, and a good friend to many. Services at Riverdale Temple, 246th St and Independence Ave, Riverdale, NY, 12:30 PM, Sunday, January 25, 1998. Her loving generosity, dignity and impeccable demeanor will be remembered by all who knew her. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or Race for the Cure.

title: DIARY
description: BIG GAME, PART 1

title: Playing 5 on 5 Isn't Enough To Save the Dragging Nets
description: When the Nets and the Washington Wizards lined up for the opening tap tonight, the Nets had five players on the floor. So far, so good. But apparently there is more to winning than just putting five players on the floor.

title: Sheryl Kahn And Peter Berk
description: Sheryl Beth Kahn, the entertainment editor at McCall's magazine in Manhattan, was married last evening to Peter Marshall Berk, a vice president of Sonnenblick-Goldman, a real estate investment banking company in Manhattan. Rabbi Malcolm Thomson performed the ceremony at the Mark Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Making New Christians
description: CHURCH was the last thing on Neil Gamblin's mind when he came to New York from his native Texas in 1993. He was 24, looking to make money and have fun in what he calls ''the greatest city in the world.''

title: Allen Ginsberg
description: Aaron Latham's ''Birth of a Beatnik'' seems an odd tribute to one of America's greatest poets. Latham chose to highlight Allen Ginsberg's youthful misdemeanors while ignoring his major contributions to American poetry and culture. Your introduction states that the aim of the issue is ''to give notice to people who ... made a difference.'' Why not focus, then, on Ginsberg's accomplishments? His quest for peace, freedom and compassion in all areas of life continues to inspire those who read his poetry.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: CLOUD CHAMBER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, GERTRUDE
description: REICH-Gertrude, 82, died on January 21, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Eugene Reich, loving mother of Rachel and Alan, proud granmother of Gene, friend and mother-in-law to Ira and Ginny. A long time participant in the movement for peace and justice in the world. We will miss her.

title: Oakley's All-Round Game Well Suited to Helping Knicks Win 4th Straight
description: Charles Oakley brushed his graying hair, stepped into his black alligator shoes and tightened a black tie, an easy match for his black pants and coat.

title: What's the Advantage Of H.O.V. Lanes?
description: Here we go again. Every year or so the New York State Department of Transportation mounts a campaign to justify H.O.V. lanes on the L.I.E. [''Are H.O.V. Lanes Speeding Rush-Hour Traffic?'' Jan. 4]

title: Reading Is Up, Principal Is Down
description: When Jeanette Headley became principal of P.S. 64 in 1995, the school was ranked one of the state's worst. Only one in 10 third graders could read at their grade level, and basic math skills escaped many students. So when last year's tests showed 87 to 90 percent of third- and sixth-grade students performing at grade level in math, and third-grade reading scores up nearly 300 percent, many parents gave her full credit.

title: Breakfast, Lunch or Whatever: Pancakes, Panini and Other Casual Dining
description: The Original Pancake House

title: A Suite in Red, With Texture and Sheen
description: AT first, the installation of Archie Rand's exhibition ''The Red Paintings 1992'' at Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art here looks like the kind of overhanging no artist's work could survive: 50 paintings, each 28 by 40 inches, packed into two horizontal rows around four walls, with just a few inches of breathing room between one and the next. But then, Mr. Rand is not your typical painter, and he doesn't seem to think in terms of individual self-contained paintings, as if they could never satisfy his overweening ambition.

title: Couple Trade Their Suits for Baker's Aprons
description: BY 8 A.M the smell of baking bread, coming from the huge oven of the Great Harvest Bread Company here wafts out onto Chatsworth Avenue, causing passers-by to sniff the air appreciatively.

title: Roland Topor
description: I first met Roland Topor at La Coupole in Paris in 1967. I was smoking a Marlboro. A few tables over sat a short, stocky man with huge eyes who looked like Peter Lorre. He started making funny faces at me, so I made them right back. Soon, a waiter arrived at my table with a silver serving dish, lifted the cover and presented me with a bowl of green pea soup, in the middle of which floated a pack of Marlboro Reds. I asked who had sent it, and he pointed to the funny man with the big eyes. The man was Roland Topor, who became my buddy and friend. I have three of his cherished designs, including one of dice with breasts sticking out, in place of dots, which is signed, ''For Margie: this badly drawn little design will make you blush with shame. That will teach you to be nicer to your old friends.'' I miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, GLADYS ROACH OTTO
description: PECK-Gladys Roach Otto. On January 19, 1998, at age 96. Wife of the late David W. Peck, a past Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court, and partner in the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. Survived by twin daughters, Mary Ann Otto Ormes and Nancy Otto Heller, her stepsons, David W. Peck, Jr. and M. Scott Peck, 12 grandchildren and 8 great-grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held in New York, and a burial service at a later date in Crawfordsville, Indiana.

title: January 18-24; Welfare Rolls Down
description: The number of people on welfare has dropped below 10 million for the first time since 1971, the Government reported. There were 9,995,000 people on the Federal rolls in August, and the number has probably declined since then. In January 1993, when President Clinton took office, 14.1 million people were on welfare. The decline results from a strong economy, the 1996 welfare law and changes initiated by various state officials. ROBERT PEAR

title: Spice Islands
description: To the Editor: In regard to the article by Marian Burros on the Spice Island Cruise (''To the Dragon's Lair,'' Oct. 5), we recently returned from a trip to Indonesia that included the three-day Spice Island cruise on the newer sister ship, Oceanic Odyssey, built in 1989.

title: Looking Back (Again) on '97; In Corner of a Window Another Titanic Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Not Suitable for Children
description: There have been so many people rushing to TV studios in this giddy and cataclysmic week to talk about sex that networks are bringing makeup artists out of retirement.

title: The Star and the Friend Who (Really) Knows Her
description: They're ''best friends,'' they say, friends who hang out with their kids, go out to eat and goof around the apartment. Friends who go shopping together, too, and gab on the phone, sometimes as often as three times a day. Best friends and regular folks, just like you and me.

title: Priorities on Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: $90 Million New York Sofitel Hotel to Open in 2000; On W. 44th St., a Touch of France
description: The architects who designed the French-owned Sofitel that is to be built on West 44th Street were, in a way, trying to make a bilingual statement.

title: Looking Back (Again) on '97; Foes of Brooklyn Junction Are Repeating Earlier Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Being Irish And Being Married
description: WHEN the actor Matthew Cowles takes the leap into playwrighting with ''Our Daly Bread,'' which deals with a working class Irish family, it could be reasonably assumed that the subject is autobiographical, but that would be wrong.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of state tax provisions with the Minding Your Business column on Dec. 14, about investing in municipal bonds, referred incompletely to six states' treatment of those investments. Those states -- Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma and Wisconsin -- levy taxes on only some of the bonds they have issued, and in some of the states, the exempt bonds are numerous. A reader's letter dated Jan. 9, pointing out the error, was delayed in routing at The Times.

title: Daly's 66 Places Him in Contention
description: The huge, festive gallery that descended upon the TPC of Scottsdale today had plenty to shout about.

title: Sprawling Albuquerque Hopes to Cut Through Monument
description: Cars rocket along the divided highway Paseo del Norte, speeding commuters to freshly minted suburbs. Then, on the west side of the Rio Grande, the highway abruptly stops.

title: Spinning: 'The Flavor of the Year' for Cardiovascular Fitness
description: IN a darkened sweat box of a room, 15 men and women sit in a circle, each on a stationary bike. Perched on seats roughly the size of a slice of pie, they are pedaling as if pursued by the 2,400 calories of a celebratory dinner. They execute quick movements on and off the seat, sometimes standing up and riding out of the saddle.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: Telling Adoptees of Their Past Is No Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Holding Hands Without Making Waves
description: WHAT could be more innocent than a couple strolling down the street and holding hands? But replace John and Mary with Bob and Larry and the picture changes entirely.

title: Teachers' Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: January 18-24; Police Caught in Sting
description: In Cleveland, 44 law-enforcement officers were charged with taking money to provide security for people they thought were major cocaine traffickers. They were really F.B.I. agents who had uncovered the network of corrupt officers during an unrelated investigation of organized crime. The operation, one of the largest roundups in a police corruption case, netted two sons of former police chiefs. PAM BELLUCK

title: Religious Leaders Take Wait-and-See View
description: Religious leaders, invoking an ethical imperative to suspend judgment until the facts are known, say they do not plan to deliver sermons this weekend about the personal and legal crisis enveloping President Clinton.

title: Skeptics Ignore a Century of Scientific Triumph; Too Much Pessimism
description: To the Editor:

title: Moving the Helmsley Properties to New Ownership
description: THE late Harry B. Helmsley had no children, but he used to say that his buildings were his children. He left them to his wife, Leona, and now an international quest is under way for new parents for most of them.

title: ON THE MAP; Restoring an Estate, and the Lives of the Girls Treated There
description: Where weeds grew shoulder-high six years ago, fields of iris, foxglove and red poppy will splay out this spring along the brick paths and rock walls of Devereux Deerhaven, a residential treatment center for 70 troubled girls in Chester Township, Morris County. As they have for the last five years, the gardens will flower thanks to the labors of 15 of the center's residents.

title: Books Children Love, Lovingly Collected
description: AS Billie Levy tells it, when she was growing up as Billie McGuffee before World War II in the little town of Utica, Miss. -- ''about a thousand people but no library'' -- she loved to read, and to collect books.

title: Author Revisits Gloria Steinem Milestones
description: WRITING biographies of the living can be risky business, especially when the subject is as full of contradictions as Gloria Steinem, the founder of Ms. magazine and perhaps America's most well-known feminist.

title: Race Is an Issue in Mt. Vernon School Job
description: BY all accounts, Carl Albano is a bright, concerned, sensitive young teacher with a winning personality and an intense commitment to education. The 29-year-old Mr. Albano, a slim, dark-haired fifth-grade teacher at Pennington-Grimes Elementary School here, has seven years of teaching experience and was acting building administrator last year when the Pennington-Grimes principal, Thomas A. Pesce, attended frequent district restructuring meetings.

title: Bronze Have More Fun
description: They are not your grandmother's bronzes; nor are they your garden-variety ''decorative accessories'' -- although each serves a useful purpose. The items shown on these pages represent the first collection of United Labor, a collaboration between Randy Franks, a Los Angeles designer who prefers his furniture with an element of surprise, and Simon Toparovsky, an artist who makes bronze sculptures from objects found in nature. The two met last year when Franks sought Toparovsky's advice on casting some furniture designs. They were soon brainstorming about a joint venture. With their idiosyncratic spin on an ancient art, these objects might just signal the dawn of a new bronze age.

title: Edmund Stephan, 86, Lawyer Who Reorganized Notre Dame
description: Edmund Anton Stephan, a prominent Chicago lawyer who three decades ago shepherded a precedent-setting conversion in the governing of the University of Notre Dame, died on Jan. 16 at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 86 and lived in the nearby town of Wilmette.

title: Ben Hogan
description: Charles McGrath's brief review of the life and career of Ben Hogan may be true as far as it goes, but it does seem to describe a man less gracious than the great athlete I recall from my youth.

title: Umbrella Man Under Siege
description: KHAIRY GURGIS was 30 years old and broke. Two years earlier, he had been driven out of Egypt, where he had been a manager for Panasonic, by anti-Christian persecution. In New York, his business degree meant nothing to American companies, and his marriage was falling apart. And on this day in March 1983, it was raining.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, JEFFREY
description: RICHMAN-Jeffrey. On January 23, 1998. Adored husband of Gail (nee Freeman). Cherished and loving father of Adam. Special brother to David. An incredibly considerate friend who will be missed by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held today, 10 AM at Kirschenbaum Bros. Funeral Chapel, 1700 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to The American Diabetes Foundation.

title: MORE ON THE PRESIDENTIAL CRISIS
description: CLINTON'S NO. 1 DEFENDER -- Hillary Clinton has again rushed to her husband's defense -- ''in battle mode,'' as an associate put it. Page 18.

title: Lines and High Wires
description: To the Editor:

title: January 18-24; Power Surge
description: Internet users tired of waiting to download information from cyberspace could get a big boost in the foreseeable future. Compaq, Intel and Microsoft have joined forces with most of America's big local telephone companies. The result should enable users to receive information up to 30 times faster than before. The new technology may be available by Christmas or mid-1999. SETH SCHIESEL

title: From Welfare to Work, Through a Playground Gate
description: When assigned to workfare three years ago, Deborah McDowell, 47, a Bronx resident, did not see it as pointless grunt work for near-starvation wages. Instead, she saw a rare chance to push back into the world of self-supporting adults, of people who can pay their way without depending on a grouchy, grudging governmental Dad.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Sunday Styles today about the Henry Clay Frick Fellows dinner misspells the given name of a guest. She is Lizabeth Newman, not Elizabeth.

title: BIG TALK
description: * If you watch President Clinton's State of the Union address Tuesday night, you might pause to reflect that the custom almost vanished -- Jefferson dropped the speech in 1801, saying it was too monarchical. * Woodrow Wilson brought it back in 1913. * The floor of the House chamber, where the speech takes place, contains 449 permanent seats. Some Congressmen arrive up to 90 minutes early to stake out a high-visibility center-aisle spot. * The 167-member diplomatic corps files in according to ambassadorial seniority. First up: Prince Bandar bin Sultan of Saudi Arabia. * Last: Michael Arneaud of Trinidad and Tobago. * There's no formal rehearsal, though the sergeant-at-arms has to memorize the location of a hidden microphone. That way he'll be heard when he brays, ''Mr. Speaker, the President of the United States!''

title: SOAPBOX; The $22 Million Victory
description: ON Dec. 18, three days before the Sunday New Jersey section published ''The $25 Million Defeat'' about the failure to pass a school bond referendum in Ridgewood, Metuchen passed its school bond issue of $22.3 million -- on the first ballot, with a school board divided on whether it was needed. Metuchen's population is half that of Ridgewood's. Metuchen's tax increase per home will be higher than Ridgewood's would have been, even though our average home values are lower, and the repayment term for Metuchen's citizens will be 10 years longer. As in Ridgewood, there was organized resistance in Metuchen. Metuchen's citizens don't like tax increases any more than Ridgewood's citizens do.

title: Never a Loss For Words
description: NEW YORK'S greatest writers, Whitman and Melville, were nearly forgotten when they died in the 1890's. In the 1920's, the resurrection of these world-towering figures became central to New York's self-celebration. New York then gave its special vitality to every new movement in art and literature. Only New York had virtually every leading publishing house, most of the national magazines (three of the best known have ''New York'' in their titles) and neighborhoods, like Greenwich Village, famous for the literary and artistic rebellions they inspired. New York has been the magnet beyond all other American places for writers from North America and much of Europe.

title: Correction
description: A listing on Jan. 4 with an article about day trips from Nagano, Japan, misspelled the name of an inn in Jigokudani. It is Sekiya, not Seyika.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOUNT, OLIVER
description: BLOUNT-Oliver. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Oliver Blount, associated with The Times from 1977.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAMY, NANCY (NEE BELLIS)
description: SALAMY-Nancy (nee Bellis), beloved wife of Samuel. Adoring mother of Chelsey Taryn. Devoted daughter of Abe and Ruth Bellis. Close sister of Marjorie Miller and Zachary and Zoe's. Dear aunt Nunny. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. Sunday, 12:30 PM.

title: Christina Norsig, Eric Anton
description: Christina Norsig, the daughter of Marcia Norsig of Deal, N.J., and George Norsig of Dallas, was married last evening to Eric Michael Anton, the son of Gloria and Saul Anton of Paramus, N.J. Rabbi William Kloner officiated at Oheka, the Otto Kahn country house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y.

title: The Party Always Ran Late at Sherman's Place
description: THE Duke and Duchess of Windsor did it. Ethel Merman did it. J. Edgar Hoover did it. Frank Costello did it. John F. Kennedy did it. When the lights went down on Broadway, they migrated, at one time or another, across town to the velvet-and-silver world of the Stork Club. Founded as a speak-easy in the Roaring Twenties, Sherman Billingsley's oasis at 3 East 53d Street (now Paley Park) reached its apotheosis in the 40's, drawing movie stars and political bosses, gangsters, aristocrats and generals on wartime leave.

title: Westphal, Coach Out of Style
description: When Paul Westphal was interviewed for the Dallas Mavericks' head coaching job two seasons ago, he made sure he told the new owner, Ross Perot Jr., about a skeleton in his closet. He said he was friends with Rush Limbaugh, the political commentator who goes harder to his right than Michael Jordan and often had fun at Ross Perot Sr.'s expense.

title: A High Tab, but Some Interesting Dishes
description: THE Palm Court at Carltun on the Park in Eisenhower Park is the most expensive restaurant on the Island but it is not the best. Most of the food is quite good, but many other local restaurants have better for less money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, NATHAN
description: GOLDBERG-Nathan. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nathan Goldberg, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1970.

title: Book Agent Advised Taping Accusations
description: A New York literary agent said yesterday that she had advised Linda R. Tripp, a Pentagon aide, to tape-record her conversations with Monica S. Lewinsky, the woman at the center of accusations that President Clinton had an affair, because Ms. Tripp ''felt very, very threatened'' and thought she might lose her job.

title: Ewe and Cry
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Rule a 25-Year-Old Can Sue for Age Discrimination
description: A state appellate panel ruled last week that a 25-year-old former bank vice president can sue for age discrimination regarding his dismissal by a Paramus bank in January 1994. Judge Isabel B. Stark had dismissed the suit by Michael Sissler in Superior Court in Bergen County in August 1996 after lawyers for Bergen Commercial Bank argued that he had been fired for incompetence and that under Federal law, a person must be 40 to sue for age discrimination.

title: The Lady Is a Stamp?
description: Mae West may have been America's premier bad girl and sassiest sinner, but for some people, the lady was not a tramp -- she was a saint. One of her greatest champions is Bishop Andre Penachio, the pastor of the St. Thomas Liberal Catholic Church on West 144th Street.

title: Habitats/Franklin Lakes, N.J.; A 16-Sided House for Two People and Six Birds
description: JOHN RHODES and Marianne O'Donnell were about ready to give up their house search. With a budget of $300,000 they had found little to excite them in northern New Jersey, particularly along the Hudson River.

title: Home-Grown Musical Master
description: It's priest.

title: Tuscan Holidays
description: To the Editor: About five years ago, during a sweltering summer, we too were guests of Roberto and Sylvie at the Podere Terreno in Chianti, discussed in ''Reinventing Thanksgiving in Tuscany'' (Nov. 23). We recall a pleasant stay with exuberant hosts and delicious food. We all stayed up late one night sitting on the terrace and watching, on a very small TV screen, an important soccer game. Sleep was impossible because of the group's vocal involvement with the game. It was a lovely visit. One outstanding memory is of requesting coffee after dinner and being told to buy it at the lobby machine.

title: Bringing It Home, Where the Beat Began
description: JEFFREY Gaspin, chief of programming and production for VH1, has a simple explanation for the success of ''Behind the Music,'' the channel's weekly music biography series. ''It hits our target audience like a bulls-eye,'' he says.

title: Federal Travel Stipend Rises, Pleasing Hotels in Manhattan
description: For years, Federal employees have echoed a grievance common to penny-pinching tourists in New York City: that tight budgets have forced them to find inexpensive hotel rooms far from where they wanted to stay, Manhattan.

title: A Nation's High Hopes Too Heavy For Rafter
description: Patrick Rafter, the United States Open champion, probably does not know who Atlas was, but he definitely knows how he felt -- world weary.

title: When Great Ships Came In
description: YEARS AGO, John Cheever wrote about a New York ''filled with a river light.'' He meant, of course, the shimmer of the Hudson and East Rivers, which then dappled the island, filtering between the iron mesh of the old El and shining innocently, now and then, along the skyscraper canyons.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Alfred C. Cerullo 3d; An Eye for a (Tax-Free) Deal
description: ''I used to be the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs; I know how to keep in control,'' said Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, as he rifled the clothing racks of Bloomingdale's.

title: Kidnappers Rob Then Release a Prosecutor
description: The kidnapping of a Federal prosecutor outside a Greenwich Village restaurant on Wednesday night apparently was a robbery and not retaliation for his work in law enforcement, officials said yesterday.

title: Telling Adoptees of Their Past Is No Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Need a Lawn Frog? An R.V.? Expos (Lots of Them) Await
description: The Greaseless Cookware People were back.

title: An Istanbul Reprise For the Orient Express
description: The Venice Simplon-Orient Express will make the journey from Paris to Istanbul and back to Venice only once this year, leaving Aug. 28, and starting its return Sept. 2. This luxury train, a restored version of the Orient Express of 115 years ago, which made the journey to the Golden Horn regularly, now usually travels between London and Venice.

title: January 18-24; Talks Poorly. No Visa.
description: Foreigners' fears in applying for an American tourist visa may be well founded, at least in Brazil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, ALAN G.
description: MILLSTEIN-Alan G. On Friday, January 23, 1998. Dear friend, former husband. A man of piercing intelligence, uncommon wit, unique perspective, with wide interests in art, theater, the cinema, and a love of New York City. I am eternally grateful to him for always making me laugh and for introducing me to a world of beauty and fashion and glamour, which changed my life only for the better. ''At the round earth's imagin'd corners, blow Your trumpets, Angells, and arise, arise from death ...and you whose eyes, Shall behold God, and never taste deaths woe.'' Anne Taylor Davis Millstein

title: March of Retail
description: BROOKS BROTHERS had been outfitting men -- Abraham Lincoln and the Union Army officers and troops, among many others -- for 80 years by the time New York consolidated in 1898. The store introduced its trademark button-down shirt two years later. Tiffany & Company was selling fine jewelry and silverware on Union Square. The huge ''cast-iron palace,'' as it was called, that housed A. T. Stewart's at Ninth Street and Broadway -- eight floors, each a sprawling 2.5 acres -- was one of the largest retail stores in the world.

title: Chelsea Mornings, And Evenings Too
description: Starting today, each listing in the Good Eating column will include information supplied by the restaurant about its policy on smoking.

title: A Summer Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Cars Can't Anchor Here

title: Power Play Yields No Advantage For Devils
description: After rallying to tie yesterday's game with the Rangers at 3-3 on a power-play goal, the Devils had a chance for victory in overtime when New York's Mike Keane was penalized for cross-checking with under a minute left.

title: Orthodox Jewry And Discrimination
description: The views expressed by Dr. Alan A. Mazurek and Dr. Mark Weinblatt in the Long Island section [Letters to the Editor, Jan. 4] show the extremes to which Orthodox Jews have gone. The criticism of gay and lesbian rabbis as being opposed to Orthodox Jewry for over 3,000 years only shows that the Orthodox Jewry are 3,000 years behind the times.

title: Running Risks Without Forgetting Tradition
description: IF Shakespearean cycles abound, why not a Tennessee Williams marathon?

title: When Reckless Laws Team Up
description: So it comes to this. America finds itself in the extraordinary position of contemplating impeachment hearings, as an independent counsel investigates allegations that the President of the United States encouraged a 24-year-old woman to lie under oath about an adulterous affair.

title: Choosing Between Phone and Cable for Internet Access
description: WHEN Wall Street learned last week that most of the Baby Bells were joining with three computer giants to offer consumers superfast access to the Internet, there were some short-term stock gyrations and some long-term speculation about the meaning of it all. The biggest question: Will the telephone companies or the cable companies win the battle to offer this service?

title: Young's Impact
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATUSEWITCH, SERGEI
description: MATUSEWITCH-Sergei. Suddenly on January 22. Beloved husband of Jean, loving father of Gerri and Sondra. Loving grandfather of Mia and David. Brother of the late Boris. Uncle of Marc, Eric and Peter. Funeral private. Contributions to Manhattan Plaza AIDS Project, 400 West 43rd St., NYC 10036 in honor of Jean, longtime volunteer.

title: Q&A: David Lerner; Advocating a 'Safe' Route in Investment
description: ''THE tree doesn't grow to the sky,'' said David Lerner, referring to recent record highs set by the stock market. As chief executive officer of the Syosset-based David Lerner Associates, one of the nation's largest regional dealers of municipal bonds, Mr. Lerner recommends that investors put just a small portion of their investable assets into the stock market, with the remainder in ''safe'' investments like tax-free and zero coupon bonds.

title: A Blooming High Soprano With Admirers in High Places
description: HEIDI GRANT MURPHY'S career, over the last decade, has been as quiet as it has been successful. Ms. Murphy, a 32-year-old soprano, has been on the roster of the Metropolitan Opera for nine years and has appeared with such notable institutions as the New York Philharmonic, the Boston Symphony and the Salzburg Festival. Yet she remains a well-kept secret among connoisseurs, an artist some consider the heir apparent to Kathleen Battle in the soprano repertory for light voice.

title: NYC*100: THE SECOND DECADE
Looking Back (Again) on '97; Directional Signs Make You Wonder Who's in Charge
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gang's All Here!
description: The office party: you love it or you loathe it. Be it a going-away party, a baby shower for a co-worker or a holiday celebration, it can be a genuine good time or an occasion for intense embarassment. What are the unusual styles of celebration in your office -- and the results? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUYLER, PEARL
description: SCHUYLER-Pearl. The Board of Directors of 812 Fifth Avenue are profoundly saddened by the sudden and untimely passing, on January 17, 1998, of Pearl Schuyler, the beloved wife of our esteemed Board President, Irving Schuyler. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Irving and to the family.

title: 13 and Counting for N.F.C., And A.F.C. Is Desperate
description: Who broke a mirror over the head of the American Football Conference? Did somebody stick pins in an A.F.C. voodoo doll? Is this conference stuck in its own Bermuda Triangle? What about this hex, this hapless showing by the A.F.C. in the Super Bowl? The National Football Conference team has won 13 -- count 'em, 13 -- consecutive Super Bowls. Most of them have been blowouts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVITZ, JERRY
description: KRAVITZ-Jerry. On January 23, 1998. Beloved father, grandfather, brother, uncle. Services I. J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY, 12:15 PM Sunday.

title: Chronicle of an Upheaval the World Couldn't See
description: THE 20TH-CENTURY HISTORY of this ancient Central Asian land has unfolded largely behind a curtain of silence drawn by rulers of the Soviet Union. Their radical transformation of a highly traditional feudal society into a modern Soviet republic is a stirring but almost unknown story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROGOFF, IRA
description: PROGOFF-Ira. With love to a devoted and wise parent. Sue, Jon, Richard, Daniel and Matthew

title: Looking Back (Again) on '97; In Corner of a Window Another Titanic Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Shinnecock Powwow Explored in Film
description: GROWING up in Huntington, Ziggy Attias never realized that the frontier was not far from his own backyard. Like many Long Islanders, Mr. Attias assumed that Indians were either out West or long gone vestiges of his favorite cowboy movies.

title: Rebecca Knapp, Christopher Adams
description: Rebecca Kearney Knapp, a magazine editor, and Christopher John Adams, an English teacher, were married last evening in Wilmington, Del., at Brantwyn, the former home of Pierre S. duPont 3d. The Rev. Dr. Joseph McOscar, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Sports of The Times; In the N.B.A., Punishment Usually Fits the Perpetrator
description: WHEN John Feerick hears the arguments for Latrell Sprewell next week, he should pay less attention to the union lawyers' cries for due process and more to the case of Eugene Amos. The difference in how David Stern handled two disturbing, image-fracturing events will explain why his one-year suspension of Sprewell was as much a slick public relations coup as it was an example of a commissioner acting in the so-called best interests of his sport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIGEL, SAMUEL E.
description: SEIGEL-Samuel E. Attorney and Counselor at Law, on January 21, 1998; only twelve days after the passing of his beloved wife and best friend, Pauline M. Seigel. Born March 29, 1912. He was a community leader, innovative President of the Kiwanis Club of Elmont, NY and founding chairman of the Aircraft Noise Control Council of Nassau County, Inc., credited with creating the impetus to compel the aircraft industry to add noise suppressors to jet planes. Father of Florence (Ralph) Belkind and Elaine (Martin) Schwartz. Grandfather of Dennis, Deborah and Alison Schwartz. Service at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York, Sunday, January 25, 1998 at 11:30 AM. Interment at the J&B Moroch Family Circle plot at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

title: Frugal Hotels
description: To the Editor: Sarah Ferrell (''Plotting a Strategy for San Francisco,'' Dec. 7) was lucky that San Francisco was having a warm spell when she stayed at the Grant Plaza Hotel in November. While it is a good buy, when I stayed there during a chilly, rainy winter, the management shut the heat off during the day.

title: Risk-Reducing Strategy Has Its Own Risks
description: SURE, the conventional wisdom is that only risk takers can hope to win big in the investing game. But that doesn't stop market strategists from trying to rake in competitive returns with low risk.

title: Shrinking Universe for Vendors?
description: Magdy Eltant, a 38-year-old Egyptian immigrant, once had his shish kebab cart stationed at a prime spot, near Radio City Music Hall. But in 1995, Mayor Giuliani cracked down on vendors in midtown, and Mr. Eltant and other vendors were displaced.

title: 14 Presidents Have Been The Talk of the Pillow
description: When President Clinton asserted the other day that the latest accusations of sexual misconduct leveled at him not only were false but, worse, were making it difficult for him to govern the country, he was voicing an old Presidential complaint.

title: Commercial Property/111 Eighth Avenue; From Back Office to Front Office and High Tech
description: THEY incorporated on Sept. 1. Now they control 3.3 million square feet of office space, including the mammoth, 2.3 million-square-foot former Port Authority building at Eighth Avenue and 16th Street.

title: VIEWPOINT; U.S. v. Microsoft: The Bigger Question
description: THE resolution of the immediate crisis between Microsoft and the Justice Department opens the way for considering the potential damage that Government action can have on the growth and vitality of the information industry. Lost in the sparring of the two protagonists is an appreciation of the enormous potential harm that misguided Government interference can wreak on the largest, fastest-growing and arguably most important part of the United States economy.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Father of the 'Family'
description: Photography is the essential art of the 20th century, and Edward Steichen did more to advance its artistic, technical and commercial limits than almost anyone. Based on exhaustive research in the personal papers of Steichen's family and friends, Penelope Nivens's STEICHEN: A Biography (Clarkson Potter, $45) follows every groundbreaking step of the photographer's life. Combining his skills as a painter, designer and photographer, Steichen (1879-1973) battled for the acceptance of photography as art and pioneered the photographic conquest of the mass media. He revolutionized the science of aerial reconnaissance and produced some of the first fine color photos. As curator of the ''Family of Man'' exhibition in 1957 at the Museum of Modern Art, Steichen brought socially conscious documentary photography into museums and before the eyes of a vast audience. Nivens, the author of a biography of Carl Sandburg, complements her own clear, lyrical voice with the eloquent words of Steichen's contemporaries. She describes the ''liquid motion'' and ''forms dancing in the light'' of Steichen's photographs, and quotes one critic who wrote of Steichen, ''Like a highwayman he lies in wait for beauty.'' Nivens sometimes seems more concerned with her research than with her readers; she repeats nearly identical quotations and uses oddly stilted language to explain gaps in the story. But for the most part she succeeds in weaving the many threads of Steichen's life into a seamless narrative. Jake Miller

title: Pope Carries His Message to the 'Rome' of an Afro-Cuban Faith
description: In a cramped back room of her tiny house in a run-down working-class neighborhood here, Noemi Rafaela Constantin Garcia has for decades carefully tended an altar honoring Nuestra Senora de la Caridad del Cobre, Cuba's patroness, and various other Catholic saints. Naturally, she was elated that Pope John Paul II would honor the patron saint at an outdoor Mass here today.

title: Backtalk; On Such a Macho Day, Reality Is a Blur

title: U.S. LISTS OPTIONS ON USE OF FORCE IN IRAQ STANDOFF
description: President Clinton's top foreign policy advisers met today to weigh military and political strategies against Iraq, among them a sustained attack on suspected biological and chemical weapons sites that Saddam Hussein has hidden from United Nations inspectors, White House officials said.

title: New Life, Far From the Bright Lights
description: EVERY DAY, Astin Jacobo ambles past the shops and houses of Crotona, surveying his Bronx neighborhood like a one-man block watch. He misses nothing, stopping to watch teen-agers kicking up dust in a brisk game of football or to chat with their parents on the sidelines. He turns down one street, where new brick row houses share the block with a community garden.

description: No one had ever gone through what Hillary Rodham Clinton went through this week -- no one, of course, except Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Pope, Openly Challenging Castro, Is Pressing for Release of Prisoners
description: In an open challenge to President Fidel Castro, Pope John Paul II called publicly tonight for the release of Cuba's political prisoners as a gesture of national reconciliation.

description: After months of complaining that he was being railroaded out of office, Ron Carey, the teamsters' president, had his day in court this week and presented an impassioned, point-by-point defense against accusations that he had approved an illegal campaign finance scheme.

title: For Lost Pregnancies, New Rites of Mourning
description: The plaintive notes of a clarinet hung in the air as several dozen people filed into a small meeting room at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. Some sat solemnly, clutching tissues, their heads bowed in silent prayer. Others tearfully embraced old friends.

description: The top two teams in the Big East were both coming off disappointing losses in today's nationally televised showdown at the Carrier Dome. Unfortunately for Syracuse, it was No.8 Connecticut that bounced back, defeating the 15th-ranked Orangemen, 63-54, before a noisy crowd of 25,788.

description: AS Asia's leaders survey the wreckage from the region's financial typhoon, they must also address the task of building a more stable monetary framework.

description: Meat's Home Companion

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE -- In Rental Discords, Landlords Call the Tune; Housewares Mecca To Close in March
description: The big, illuminated yellow sign for Broadway Bazaar has long been a fixture of Broadway. Before Lechter's, before Pottery Barn and way before Bed Bath and Beyond, shoppers could get all manner of housewares -- kitchen stools, clocks, frames, you name it -- on the two cluttered floors of Broadway Bazaar.

title: Windowsills in Winter Yield Fragrant Bouquets
description: GARDENERS can be lumped into three convenient categories. The visual people are prone to big, showy dahlias and other head-turning bloomers. The touch folks gravitate toward lamb's ears and chenille plants with plenty of pettable leaves and floral parts for fondling. And finally there are those who follow their noses and favor any plant that is fragrant.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: The freshest film fare on television this week is a varied batch marked by originality, starting with a tasty monster-thriller, Lewis Teague's ALLIGATOR (1980). When did you last see a neat, witty jolter? Well, gangway. The big cruncher here chomps on culprits in suburban Chicago. Robert Forster and Robin Riker do nicely as a smart young pair who manage to stay several jumps ahead. And don't miss the lawn party. It's a hoot -- Sunday at 3 P.M. on the Sci-Fi channel.

title: Organized Medicine
description: IN October, Dr. Anthony Tonzola received payment from the United Healthcare health maintenance organization in the amount of nine cents. He knew better than to cash it. It's much better saved as a tangible proof of the decline of doctors under managed care.

title: When the Credit Bubble Bursts
description: FOR eight Federal court judges, 150 staff members and 700 bankruptcy lawyers, February used to be the calm before the storm of New Jersey bankruptcy filings.

title: NYC*100: THE NINTH DECADE
Set the Table and Fire Up the Microwave
description: IN the busy 1990's people are eating out in record numbers, as the tidal wave of new restaurant openings attests. But people are also eating in: take-out food they have ordered and picked up.

description: Special Today: New York Then & Now/Section 15

title: Elway vs. Favre: Two Great Arms Reach for Trophy
description: As it has many times before, Sunday's Super Bowl will come down to big arms. The combined artillery that the starting quarterbacks, Denver's John Elway and Green Bay's Brett Favre provide may be the most explosive in football history. Light a match and stand back.

description: With South Korea's economy in crisis, the family-controlled companies that have been its rulers are facing the end of an era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, HERMAN J.
description: JAFFE-Herman J. On January 23, 1998. Faculty member of the Department of Anthropology, Brooklyn College-CUNY for 30 years. Dear husband of Trude Michel. Brother of Lillian Kent and Daniel. Loving uncle of David, Edward, Susan, and Brian. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Karen Rosenbach, Thomas Daniel
description: Karen Lynne Rosenbach, the senior vice president for human resources and administration at Polo Ralph Lauren in New York, was married last evening to Thomas Craig Daniel, a commercial broker at the Towle Real Estate Company in Minneapolis. Dr. Richard Chapin, a rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: A Radio Giant's Antitrust Question
description: Missing from your recent story on the antitrust lawsuit brought against a corporate radio giant for allegedly securing a monopoly on Long Island ''A Radio Giant's Purchases on L. I. Raise Antitrust Questions' (Dec.28) is mention of the man who brought the issue to the Justice Department in the first place. The late Danny Lehner had served as President of the Nassau County Council of Chambers of Commerce and believed that the virtual monopoly of local radio stations put his members at enormous economic disadvantage. On a related issue, he also cautioned the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) that consolidating corporate ownership would cripple public affairs coverage, locally originated news and public service announcements.

title: Wild Kingdom
description: Two of nature's most distinctive patterns, leopard spots and tiger stripes, continue to leave their imprint on the fashion world. The markings are endlessly imitated on fabric for day and evening wear, and for accessories from handbags to muffs. Some clothing patterns are drawn by designers. Others are reproduced photographically from the fur of various members of the cat family, including Somali leopards (solid spots), the jaguar (large open doughnut-shaped spots) or the ocelot (tiny spots). One woman, bottom far right, doesn't play favorites. She wears a patchwork coat of different patterns stenciled on calfskin, each frame separated by mink. Other coats are worn ankle-length: far left, a leopard pattern framed by a fox collar, and second from left, a tiger pattern on pile. Louis Vuitton offers one of its signature handbags, right, in a leopard print. Children, too, have made the leopard print a fashion favorite.

title: Ever Wonder Just What a Principal Does All Day Long?
description: One day she was Mrs. Foster, the principal of Public School 34 in Jersey City. The next day she was a star.

title: A Matter of Degree
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: There Is No Recreating 'The Creation'
description: HAYDN'S ORATORIO ''THE CREATION'' returned to Carnegie Hall 10 days ago as old friend and visiting dignitary. A full house simmered in the warmth of reacquaintance, dividing its respects between the evening's conductor, Robert Shaw, and the work itself.

title: Murray Kempton
description: For several years I had the privilege and pleasure of editing Murray Kempton's columns for Newsday. Time after time, he saw the good in the bad and the bad in the good. When awed yet again by his ability to see people in the whole, I thought of what Mrs. Thrale said when she was asked what her friend Dr. Johnson was like. ''His soul was no different from any other man's,'' she said, ''only greater.''

title: The Ultimate Takeover
description: SHORTLY after noon on Oct. 19, 1987, as the giant plunge on Wall Street gathered force, I boarded the downtown Seventh Avenue IRT in search of high drama. Newly embarked on ''The House of Morgan,'' I wanted to stand at the corner of Broad and Wall Streets and savor the full thrill of financial disaster. My mind teemed with grainy black-and-white images of ashen-faced investors thronging the sidewalks during the 1907 panic and the 1929 crash. Yet when I emerged from the subway that day, I found, to my great dismay, no ranks of grim, ruined speculators, no stockbrokers sailing from upper-story windows. The famous corner, if not quite as calm as a country crossroads, gave no hint that $500 billion of shareholder value was being erased behind the Corinthian columns of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Jolie Gabor
description: In the 1940's and early 50's, my father had a jewelry store on Madison Avenue, not far from Jolie Gabor's boutique. Jolie and my father had known one another in Budapest, and we frequently had the pleasure of a visit from ''the girls'' and Mama. Their fur coats, lap dogs, perfumes and animated chatter made an indelible impression on me as a teen-ager. I was often sent on errands to Jolie's place. One time we needed a string of pearls from Jolie. Wrapped in mink (or was it sable?), she said to me, with a grand gesture: ''Dahling, I cannot talk to you now. I have a luncheon date with the Prince of Arabia. Please come back at 4.''

title: Through the Windshield, A Vision for the State
description: When Governor Whitman announced four years ago that she would not use the state helicopter to get to most of her official events, she saved the state $7 million -- and earned some political points.

description: The family that owns Hong Kong's largest-selling Chinese-language newspaper says that it paid Britain's Conservative Party $1.7 million for ''certain commitments,'' but now wants its money back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, WILLIAM EITEL
description: SCHNEIDER-William Eitel. 88 Died Friday, January 23, 1998. A native of Bronx, NY, he had resided in Westport, CT for more than 40 years prior to moving to Virginia. Mr. Schneider retired in 1984 as Vice President of Business Affairs for the television and radio departments at Benton & Bowles Advertising Agency in New York, NY. He volunteered at the Carver Center for 10 years as a tutor and mentor. He was preceded in death by his wife, Charlotte M. Schneider. Survivors include two daughters, Erica Porter of Newport News and Debby Schneider of Chicago, Ill; his son Christopher Schneider of Englewood, CO; his sister, August Severin of Bronxville, N.Y.; two grandchildren, Melissa Porter and Jason Rafferty; and numerous nieces and nephews. A private memorial service will be held at a later date in Westport, CT. For information Peninsula Funeral Home, Newport News.

title: Where the Gettys Hold Court a la Falstaff
description: The PlumpJack Balboa Cafe may seat 75, but what it really feels like most nights is an oversize dinner party. Regulars have taken to calling it Mortimer's West, after the ultraclubby Manhattan restaurant that is home to socialites and the occasional power broker.

title: Some Applause, Please, For the Slide Show
description: To the Editor:

title: My Dinner With Donald, And Other Happenings
description: NINETEEN SEVENTY-EIGHT. The year of the Camp David treaty between Israel and Egypt; Jonestown; the year of two Popes; the first human test-tube baby is born in England. I am 40. Jung says that if you're not on a spiritual path by the second half of your life, the first half has been wasted, but I can't remember where he said it.

title: Whatever Happened to Politics?; Washington Is Not Where It's At
description: Is Bill Clinton our first post-political President? It is hard to find, anywhere on the current scene, a politics of the sort once recognized as serious. There are no great debates on great issues. Party loyalty is down, voter apathy up. The vacuum in political interest is filled more and more by obsession with headline trials -- William Kennedy Smith, the Tonya Harding affair, the Menendez brothers, O. J. Simpson, Marv Albert, Louise Woodward, the Unabomber case. What still passes for politics will be absorbed into the vortex of trials when Paula Jones's suit against the President is brought into the courtroom.

title: Car Rental Companies Cut Back on Flier Awards
description: FREQUENT-FLIER miles are more available than ever, but the major rental car companies are applying the brakes to their involvement in frequent-flier programs.

title: A Dark Time Recalled in Shades of Gray
description: ''FOUR DAYS IN SEPTEMBER,'' a Brazilian thriller about Marxist insurgents who kidnapped the American ambassador here in 1969, has been waiting almost two decades for history to catch up with its sense of ambiguity.

title: January 18-24; Whoops! Sorry.
description: Promises in cyberspace are made to be broken. Or so Senior Chief Petty Officer Timothy R. McVeigh learned after he joined America Online, the nation's largest on-line service. The decorated submariner said that when he created a customer profile that identified him as ''Tim'' and his sexual orientation as ''gay,'' he believed AOL's promise to protect the anonymity of its members.

title: Oldies Endure, Even in the Era of MTV
description: THE first song is still playing a few minutes past 6 P.M. on a recent Sunday night in Dick Bartley's Westport broadcasting studio, but 10 telephone lines are already blinking.

description: Dear Writer, Dear Actress

title: All the President's Pizzas
description: Last year on Super Bowl Sunday, Domino's Pizza delivered 829,765 pizzas nationwide, and the company knows where they all went, because it keeps track on computers at Domino's outlets worldwide. It's also known that the President held a Super Bowl party at the White House and that guests ate Domino's pizza.

description: DREIER-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Len and Don (Feiman) and Sandy (Kozinn). She was adored by her grandchildren Debra, Amy, Gary, Sharon and David and cherished by her 13 great-grandchildren.
