description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Boulevard Is Getting Its Stars Back
description: Absent for nearly four years, 222 of the nation's most recognized names in film and television are returning home to the sidewalk along Hollywood Boulevard. Some of the brass-and-terrazzo stars of the Hollywood Walk of Fame are being reinstalled this month and next after having been put into storage during construction of an underground line of the Metro Rail system.

title: U.S. Taking Nuclear Work To Academia, Report Says
description: The United States Energy Department is setting a dangerous precedent for academic independence by involving some of the nation's leading universities in nuclear-weapons-related computer research and by pushing classified weapons research programs into the academic arena, according to a report by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: A Few Good Men? Don't Look in the Movies
description: WHY ARE IMAGES OF MEN IN movies these days so desolate when it comes to real love, real sex, real families, real children and real work? Why has the art form become so detached from what is true and good? Why has our collective imagination concerning the male sex become so perverse and hallucinogenic? In short, why has the film industry declared an open hunting season on men?

title: Those Caution Signals Are Blinking for Junk Bonds
description: INVESTORS who have been pouring money into junk bond funds in recent months should hope that the managers entrusted with their cash have good defensive strategies for 1998.

title: Web Surfing Amid the Suds
description: Monica Serrano could have been watching cartoons or playing with friends on a recent Saturday morning. But she insisted on going to a new Laundromat in her neighborhood. The fourth grader, whose favorite subjects are science and math, was not interested in sorting and folding clothes. She wanted to surf the World Wide Web.

title: A Before-Hours Joint
description: With its curved blue velvet walls, swanky banquettes, chartreuse and blue spiral-motif ceiling, and all-white vinyl side room, Drinkland, in the far reaches of the East Village, seems the kind of bar that Austin Powers and his sidekick, Vanessa Kensington, would love. Instead, real-life photographers and men and women of mystery -- in the form of musicians and models -- have been frequenting the place.

title: Skeptics Ignore a Century of Scientific Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Ignoring Barriers, a Ballerina Returns
description: ALICIA ALONSO, the legendary ballerina, knows the value of perseverance. For 19 years, political tensions between the United States and Cuba prevented her company, the National Ballet of Cuba, from returning to this country. But Ms. Alonso, who did not even let near-blindness keep her from conquering the dance world decades ago, would not give up. Finally last summer, the doors opened. ''I'm not exactly sure why the barriers fell,'' said Ms. Alonso, still boldly glamorous at 76. ''All I did know was we needed to dance in New York and that New York would appreciate us.''

title: Correction
description: The Residential Sales listing last Sunday included an erroneous entry based on information from the brokerage firm of Sterling Properties. The house at 35 Hickman Street, in Syosset, L.I., is still on the market. The asking price is $550,000, not $569,000; the property taxes are $10,300 a year, not $10,200.

title: At the Beach, Sowing Old Trees to Reap New Sand
description: A SMALL forest of discarded Christmas trees took shape on the beach of Margate City last week, put in place by fourth graders, with some adult help. The students, from Tony Pontari's science class at the Union Avenue School, hope the trees will trap and hold grains of sand as well as they once held strands of tinsel.

title: Warm, Wet Winter Fits Extreme Weather Pattern
description: This is not the wettest or warmest winter in New York history, meteorologists say, but daily temperatures through December and January have been running an average of 5.4 degrees above normal, and rainfall has been relatively heavy, leaving a warm, soggy impression and snow boots stashed in closets..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXTER, THE HON. KAY, O.D.
description: BAXTER-The Hon. Kay, O.D. Consul General of Jamaica. The officers, directors and friends of American Friends of Jamaica offer sincere condolences to family and government of Jamaica in the untimely passing of Kay Baxter, who gave creativity and excellence to her diplomatic life. She will be missed by all who knew her. Hon. Glen A. Holden, Chairman Anne F. Sabo, Secretary A.F.J.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Run on Abortion Pill

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE -- In Rental Discords, Landlords Call the Tune; Music Teacher Loses An Ansonia Battle
description: Fausto Bozza, a ponytailed guitar player who leads the electric swing band Groovalaya, said he was only continuing a long tradition at the Ansonia, the landmark Beaux Arts apartment building at Broadway and 73d Street. His large, rent-regulated apartment doubled as Guild Rehearsal Studios, where Mr. Bozza's fellow musicians could rent a room with a piano by the hour to practice.

title: Most Believe Affair Happened But Question Claim of Perjury
description: President Clinton continues to get very high marks from the public for the way he is doing his job as President, recent polls show, even though much of the public also says that Mr. Clinton probably did have an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARAUDA, JOSEPH R.
description: PARAUDA-Joseph R. The Putney Twombly Family mourns the loss of our dear friend and respected Managing Partner who died on January 23, 1998. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Martina, their children and family. We share your loss. The Partners, Associates and Staff Putney Twombly Hall Hirson

title: Modernists in the California Sun
description: ONE OF THE ENDURING myths about 20th-century music claims that the masters of European modernism who fled Hitler's Europe for the United States were done in by American callousness and commercialism.

title: Our Towns; Wedded To Casinos, For Richer . . .
description: THE rain was coming down in pellets, but Shirley and David Gold kept their weekly date at the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. That's two and a half hours on the road from the Port Authority, and the bus was packed.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lincoln Town Car; An Old Square Gets a Hip Transplant
description: THE old Lincoln Town Car had become a kind of executive-level Checker Cab: a roomy, ubiquitous vehicle for hire. If the styling was noteworthy for anything, it was for the glorification of the 90-degree angle, and for front and rear overhangs worthy of a B-52. It's the kind of car most people under age 60 didn't mind being driven in, but couldn't imagine ever driving. So for the new, redesigned Town Car to succeed, it must inspire some occupants to move from the back seat to the front.

title: Skeptics Ignore a Century of Scientific Triumph; Politicians Must Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHACON, SARAH M.
description: CHACON-Sarah M. Born in Guayaquil, Ecuador June 17, 1914, died January 22, 1998 in Reston, Va. Loving mother of Sarah Burgos of Guayaquil, Ecuador, Carlos A. Freile, Queens, N.Y., Linda Hofmann, Reston, Va. Cherished grandmother ''Mamacita'' to seven. Adoring great grandmother to 15. She was the first Miss Ecuador in 1930, second in the Miss World Pageant also in 1930. She practiced cosmetology in New York and Ecuador, taught English and Spanish, worldwide traveller and Ambassador, residing in South America, Japan, Singapore, France. Longtime resident of Queens, N.Y., known for her radiant, dignified beauty. She loved parties, cooking, wine, French champagne, shopping, laughing, praying and most of all her family. We will miss you ''Mamacita'', a beauty queen to the end. Reposing Sun. January 25th. at Green Funeral Home, 721 Elden St., Herndon, Virginia. Funeral Monday at St. Thomas of Beckett in Reston, Virginia.

title: Animals That Have Some Stories to Tell
description: REAL stories with characters and plots are what readers of fiction seem to want now. After an age of experiment it seems that only meat and potatoes will do.

title: Barnyard Romance
description: ANIMAL HUSBANDRY

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Don't Look Back

title: Big City, Big Labor: A Blue-Collar Past
description: IN the years just after World War II, Hollywood was glamorizing Manhattan as a place of luxurious high-rises, nightclubs and financiers. But demographers knew another New York -- a manufacturing town boasting the nation's largest concentration of unionized workers. Of the city's 1.2 million jobs, 300,000 were in services, mostly in finance, publishing and advertising. The vast majority, however, were blue collar, coming from the 40,000 companies making ladies' garments, books and small metal, wood and chemical products and processed foods. Fifty years after the city's consolidation, organized labor was at its height, and New York was its capital.

title: The Nation; A Primer: Prosecuting a President
description: THE question of whether a sitting President can be indicted and criminally prosecuted has been, for most of the nation's history, an obscure matter for debate among constitutional scholars and legal historians. That changed last week, as it periodically does when allegations of impropriety and possible illegality start swirling around a President.

title: A Victory, but Wynalda Isn't Too Thrilled
description: The top American goal scorer in international play was a perplexed man today, even as the United States made a successful 1998 debut.

title: Saints: The Next Generation
description: ''Other ancient preachers decried popular dancing as dangerously libidinous, but St. Gregory extolled its use in worship,'' says the Rev. Richard Fabian, co-founder of a free-spirited Episcopal church in San Francisco that bears Gregory's name. Currently in progress at St. Gregory's is ''The Dancing Saints Icon Project,'' a 2,300-square-foot iconographic mural by Mark Dukes, a painter. Scheduled for completion in 2001, the mural will feature 74 spiritual and cultural ''saints'' -- all selected based on what Fabian calls ''a broad sense of sainthood, in place of the commonplace rarefied moral purity.'' Included with all-stars like St. Francis will be wild cards like Lady Godiva and Thurgood Marshall. Here is a look at the first panel, which was just installed.

title: Winning a Battle but Losing The War Over the Blacklist
description: WHEN BATTLES AND bruised feelings over controversial movie ratings emerge, it's useful to remember that what's being graded is merely a strip of celluloid, never the life and reputation of a film director. Yet there was a time when directors themselves were graded politically, and if they received a ''restricted'' rating they faced, quite possibly, the end of their careers in Hollywood.

title: Cure-All Patches Are Today's Beauty Spots
description: I'M sticky, sticky, sticky with patches. There's a bright blue one on my wrist, ''impregnated with the oil of a tropical orchid,'' in the words of its inventor, a chef in Ilkley, England. If I take little sniffs of it, the maker promises, I won't want to eat anything sweet.

title: Why Did Mrs. Whitman Switch on Speed Limits?
description: To the Editor:

title: Recalling a Friendship Across the Jordan
description: AT a time when the Middle East peace process limps along a course of seemingly unending obstacles, a recent book tells the story of a friendship between two unlikely partners: King Abdullah of Jordan, born in Mecca to a distinguished Muslim family, and his Jewish carpenter, the Jerusalem-born Mendel Cohen.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WAITING FOR THE BARBARIANS

title: The Nation: Scandale; Public Tolerance in the Clinton Era, and Its Limits
description: AFTER a harrowing week in which President Clinton was sworn in as a defendant in one sex scandal, then dragged by the headlines into another, the American public, parsing his language as much as his rectitude, had to wonder about the truth, or at least the passing comfort of the half-truth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRASSMANN, WALTER J.
description: GRASSMANN-Walter J. January 22, 1998, of Pound Ridge, NY. Uncle of Donald P. Grassmann. Service and interment private. For information contact Clark Associates, Katonah, NY.

title: Emily King and William Michie
description: Emily King and William Drew Michie were married on Friday at the Players in New York. Judge Richard Owen of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Q&A/Cheryl Dews-Brewton; When Troubles Mount, Seek Outside Help
description: THE message of Cheryl Dews-Brewton is simple but not always easy to act on: when life throws you an extraordinary number of lemons, get professional help.

title: Packers Will Run, But Broncos Won't Hide
description: Keith Traylor has a vision. Traylor, the Broncos' 304-pound defensive tackle, sees a career-best game coming Sunday in the Super Bowl:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBIN, BERNARD
description: ALBIN-Bernard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard Albin, associated with The Times from 1976, until retiring in 1987.

title: The View From/Stamford; Fast Feet At the Ceili, Sets Given Too
description: THE floor was shaking and tables were moving, but it wasn't exactly an East Coast earthquake. It was the joyous, pounding feet of Irish ceili dancers that were shaking the hall in Stamford. ''This is one of the biggest ceilis in the area, held mainly to keep Irish culture alive,'' said Catherine Duggan, who organized the group. ''Up to 120 people come.''

title: Last Hurrah for NBC, And Enberg Is Ready
description: Dick Enberg prizes the time he takes to prepare for a game. With two weeks to prepare for tonight's Super Bowl, the NBC announcer has simply prepared more. He will settle into the Qualcomm Stadium booth in San Diego and place four 12x19-inch sheets of cardboard before him. He divides the sheets into boxes with key information (draft position, high school and college, nicknames, height, weight), statistics (the most recent ones in pencil) and enough personal tales about players, coaches and referees for a 20-hour miniseries.

title: We Do Not Have Liftoff: the Outta Space Crew
description: AMONG the many politicians who sought a seat on the space shuttle, John Glenn was the obvious, perfect choice. He was the only politician with experience, unless you count Jerry Brown. At 76, Senator Glenn may be old, but he's fit, and he won't be driving. While scientists applaud his homework assignment -- studying the impact of weightlessness on aging -- skeptics wonder if the future will really find Century Village retirees playing shuffleboard on the Mir space station.

title: A Conductor's Homecoming
description: He's back. In the spirit of reunion, Hugh Wolff, whose pivotal tenure as music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra from 1985 to 1992 won it national attention, is to bring in his current group, the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, and lead his old one. It's a little like going home to the grandparents to show off the new baby.

title: For Beansie, the Short Goodbye
description: IT IS 1:47 on the morning of July 16, 1912. Even now, not a breeze is stirring. It has been one of the hottest summers on record, and it is about to get hotter. A 1909 Packard touring car pulls to the curb outside the Metropole Cafe at 43d Street and Broadway. At this hour, the place is a hangout for actors, promoters and ''East Side types,'' a euphemism for the young immigrant owners of two-bit gambling houses below 14th Street.

title: Syria, Stagnant Now, Faces the Day When the Oil Runs Out
description: Still mired in a formal state of war with Israel, Syria is also stuck in an economic bog with the most important trends heading in uncomfortable directions.

title: Turmoil Is Wracking Suffolk Legislature
description: A TWO-PARTY coalition that briefly held control of the Suffolk County Legislature appears to have collapsed after only days of existence.

title: January 18-24; Suing Like a Good Neighbor
description: In a battle of corporate titans, the largest auto insurer, State Farm, took the Ford Motor Company to court, seeking millions of dollars in compensation for thousands of fires the insurer said were caused by defective ignition switches in Fords, Lincolns and Mercuries made between 1983 and 1992.

title: A Show That Follows Al Hirschfeld Line by Line
description: THE caricatures of Al Hirschfeld are the most easily recognizable American ones since Thomas Nast's. His polished and poised drawings take center stage at the Katonah Museum of Art here in an immensely satisfying survey titled ''In Line With Al Hirschfeld.'' It is illuminating on two fronts: it relates the history of his development and also demonstrates how his drawings proceed from idea to finished work.

title: Governor Whitman's Broader Vision
description: In her first years in office, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was known primarily for cutting taxes and for her moderate record on social and environmental issues. Last week, Mrs. Whitman was inaugurated for a second term and came bearing a broader agenda, with particular emphasis on blocking suburban sprawl, preserving open spaces and renewing blighted urban neighborhoods. Declaring a renewed commitment to improving the quality of life for the state's rich and poor residents, Mrs. Whitman has outlined the legacy she hopes to leave after the next four years, provided she gets cooperation from a potentially balky Legislature. The only worry -- a potentially huge worry -- is how she will pay for it all.

title: January 18-24; Touring Guatemala
description: After gunmen raped five American college students in Guatemala last weekend, some people questioned whether the students should have been there at all. The State Department had warned that the country was dangerous for tourists.

title: The Nation; Giving Credit Where Blame Might Be Due
description: HOW can the world be saved from financial disaster without helping the very people who caused that disaster? The world's financial doctors think it can't be done.

title: January 18-24; Breaking the Silence With Poetry
description: Sylvia Plath, who died in 1963, a suicide at the age of 30, left behind a treasure trove of biographical writing. There were letters, journals and a succession of searing poems that chronicled, in angry, dramatic detail, her increasingly tempestuous relationship with her husband, the British poet Ted Hughes. For all these years, Mr. Hughes, who is now 67 and has been Britain's poet laureate since 1984, has kept up a bristling silence about his life with Plath, saying he wanted to be left in peace.

title: A Shooting, Then an Obsession and Finally, 25 Years Later, a Book
description: In Bernardsville, the death of Rabbit Wells remains vivid to a lot of people, Bernardsville being the placid place that it is, and Rabbit Wells having been the kind of person -- a young black man -- who to this day would be noticeable in that corner of Somerset County. But to a writer in Maryland, Mr. Wells's killing by a town patrolman 25 years ago cannot be too vividly remembered.

title: Intern's Counsel Coached Peers on Art of Deposition
description: William H. Ginsburg's specialty is medical malpractice, not criminal defense, and he became Monica S. Lewinsky's lawyer because of old family friendship, not professional expertise. But he is no stranger to high-profile cases, tense depositions and the meticulous arts of his trade.

title: Erosion Control And Fire Island
description: David Edelstein [Letters, Nov. 23] says that coastal scientists dispute the claim that government erosion control structures have accelerated erosion on Fire Island. But no responsible coastal scientist denies that the Westhampton groinfield and Moriches Inlet deltas have trapped some 10 million cubic yards of sand.

title: Pataki's Plan to End Parole Is Tougher Than Other States' Moves
description: Rarely do Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani let a few days pass lately without calling for an end to parole for violent felons. And all too often, newspaper headlines supply fresh mayhem to help them make their case: a police officer wounded in a drug bust, another officer killed, a girl stabbed to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODFIN, KATHRYN JANE
description: WOODFIN-Kathryn Jane. Born on February 22, 1946, died on January 22, 1998 in London after a short illness. She was on a holiday trip for Christmas when she became ill. Her mother, Jane Gentry Woodfin, predeceased her. Kay is survived by her father, Gene M. Woodfin and his wife Jerry Ann of Houston, brother Dr. William S. Woodfin and his wife Fran of Dallas, nephews William Keith Woodfin of Connecticut and Gene Sam Woodfin of Dallas, stepbrothers Robert Eldon Young III of Austin and Jerry McFaddin Young of Houston, her beloved aunt Susan Woodfin of Paris, Texas and cousins Hester Sue Parker of Corsicana, Texas, Mack Woodfin and Georgia Leddy of Paris, Texas, and many other cousins. Kay attended The Kinkaid School in Houston and graduated from The Spence School in New York City. She received her Bachelor of Arts degree from Fordham University and Master of Business degree from New York University. Kay had lived in New York since 1962. She was a lovely girl and will be missed by her family and many friends. After a private memorial service for the family, her remains will be interred in the family cemetery on the Woodfin Brothers Ranch in Lamar County, Texas.

title: Broncos Victors As Super Bowl Earns Its Name
description: In one of the most competitive games in Super Bowl history, John Elway and Terrell Davis led the Denver Broncos to a 31-24 upset of the Green Bay Packers last night in San Diego. The Broncos' first National Football League championship ended the American Conference's 13-year losing streak in the Super Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYBLUM, BURTON LEWIS
description: MAYBLUM-Burton Lewis. In Boston, of cancer, on January 24, 1998, at the age of 61. Loving son of Rae. Brother of Marilyn. Uncle of Jaymie Rosen and Scott and Leah Martin. We will miss you.

title: Lawyer's Suit Challenges Women-Only Gyms
description: Caution: This issue has ignited spats between many a Boston husband and wife. Be advised that in debates, it is best to avoid phrases like, ''You men just want payback for the privilege you've lost,'' and ''You women can't have it both ways.''

title: Rorem's Songs Offer a Guided Tour Through Life
description: Among the tales of Isak Dinesen is a story about stories. Celebrated is not the choice of characters, the subtlety of situation or any breadth of significance, but the act of telling. For those possessed, and sometimes burdened, by the gift of language, the telling of stories is not only a fundamental impulse but the highest form of art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWALD, DOROTHY B.
description: ROSENWALD-Dorothy B. Died January 24, 1998, after a long illness in her Kings Bay, Tobago, home at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late James B. Rosenwald, she is survived by her daughter Patricia R. Heller and her husband Ben of New York City and Sharon, CT, her son James B. Rosenwald, Jr., and his wife Mimi of Ossining, NY, her sister Eleanor B. Handwerger and niece Blair Walker of Longmeadow, MA. She was a caring, loving grandmother of ten and great-grandmother of ten. A service in her memory is to be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions can be made to the Ackerman Institute for the Family or the Irvington Institute for Immunological Research, both of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOGGETT, PATRICIA (NEE MANNING)
description: DOGGETT-Patricia (nee Manning). Age 67, of Oldwick, NJ, on Wednesday, January 21, 1998. Wife of Albert K. Mother of Cynthia D. Ehrenclou of Bernardsville, NJ, Shelby D. Mellick of Oldwick, NJ, and J. Scott Doggett of Providence, RI. Also survived by nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, January 30, at 11 AM, at the Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lamington Rd., Bedminster, NJ. Memorial gifts may be made to Hunterdon Hospice, 2100 Wescott Dr., Flemington, NJ 08822.

title: 4 Men and 3 Teen-Age Girls Arrested in Kidnapping of Prosecutor
description: Four young men and three 16-year-old girls were arrested yesterday on charges that they kidnapped a Federal prosecutor Wednesday night and held him captive for more than 24 hours while using his bank card to withdraw cash from his account, the police said.

title: Enter Geekdom's Diaper Dandy. Can You Explain This, Sigmund?
description: He's no bigger than a computer screen, and no more than two years old, judging by appearances. His features are minimal, his hair even more so, and it is not even completely clear that he's a he.

title: In Gary Hart's Hometown, Residents View Sex Scandal With Disgust
description: As the hometown of Gary Hart, this Rocky Mountain community has experience in pondering the sexual dalliances of politicians. So when allegations about President Clinton and a female intern started cascading out of Washington last week, people were quick to sharpen their opinions.

title: Two Debuts at Met: Conductor and Baritone
description: The Metropolitan Opera has taken some criticism for the difficulty it has had in attracting internationally renowned conductors to its guest roster. The company has been working to correct this, however, and on Saturday night, Edo de Waart, the distinguished Dutch conductor, made an overdue Met debut in Mozart's ''Zauberflote,'' in the first of nine scheduled performances this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORMAN, JACK
description: KORMAN-Jack. Beloved husband of Rose; devoted father of Judy Korman and Richard Korman. Adored grandfather of Meredith and Jared. Dear brother of Teddi Kotlus. Services today, 10 AM, at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY (near Avenue V).

title: MacManus and Ayer Appoint Executives
description: MacManus Group in New York and one of its agencies, N. W. Ayer & Partners, have made appointments to top-level media and planning positions.

title: WHITE HOUSE ACTS TO CONTAIN FUROR AS CONCERN GROWS
description: As the White House mounted its first orchestrated campaign to contain a sex scandal, Cabinet members and panicked Congressional Democrats privately expressed worries today that President Clinton might be unable to recover.

title: Countdown on Iraq: U.S. Weighs February Attack
description: The United States and Britain are laying plans for a three- or four-day bombing campaign of Iraqi targets as early as mid-February if President Saddam Hussein continues to block the work of United Nations weapons inspectors, according to senior American officials and Western diplomats.

title: Swinging From Style To Style
description: When the saxophonist Jay Collins improvises, styles flicker across his canvas. Sometimes he plays with the rhythmically aggressive force of Sonny Rollins around 1958. Or he bursts through chords in mathematical sequences that angle their way across the movement of the band; it's modern. Mr. Collins can dip into the big swing tenor sound or jump around registers or snake his way through harmonies with the swing and smoothness of a Johnny Griffin.

title: Abroad at Home; Lord High Executioner
description: No one can be sure now how the Clinton story will end. But I am sure of one thing. The Constitution was not meant to give us -- and we should not want -- a system of government in which a roving inspector general with unaccountable power oversees the President of the United States.

title: Booming Stock Market Changes Rankings in Philanthropy
description: A booming stock market is changing the face of American philanthropy, knocking the Ford Foundation out of the position it has held for more than 30 years as the nation's largest private foundation.

title: People
description: * Patricia Doyle was named to the new position of executive vice president for worldwide accounts and strategic services on the Compaq Computer Corp. account at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. She had been senior vice president and executive group director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, SAMUEL D.
description: MAY-Samuel D. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Samuel D. May, beloved father of Peter May, an outstanding leader of UJA-Federation and very generous philanthropist who was instrumental in rescuing hundreds of thousands of Jews from the former Soviet Union as Chair of our Passage to Freedom and Operation Exodus Campaigns. Peter and his wife, Leni, have earned admiration and respect for their dedicated leadership and tireless efforts on behalf of the Jewish community. Our deepest sympathies go to Samuel's wife, Isabel; his son and daughter-in-law, Peter and Leni; his daughter and son-inlaw, Linda and Stephen Sklar; his grandchildren, Jonathan, Leslie, Caryn, Marci, and Kenneth; and great-grandchildren, Jacob, Alison, and Carlee. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Owners of Fallen Building Called Negligent
description: As residents of a demolished Lower East Side apartment building sifted through a meager pile of their salvaged possessions yesterday -- smashed furniture, a tattered photo album, a broken guitar -- they and neighbors of the building said that its owners had ignored an array of recent complaints that the building was in danger of collapse.

title: Hasidic Family Hurt in Unrest Settles Lawsuit
description: A Hasidic man and his son who said that the New York City Police Department did nothing to protect them while an angry crowd beat them during the 1991 racial unrest in Crown Heights have received $200,000 in a settlement with the city, officials confirmed last night.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about research on elusive particles called neutrinos misidentified the type of nuclear power reactor in Canada that relies on heavy water, the substance also being used in a neutrino detector in Ontario. The reactors are Candu, not Cando.

title: Cyberspace Is on Alert For More Scandal News
description: No self-respecting scandal gets by these days without a frenzied following in cyberspace, and the Monica S. Lewinsky episode has not disappointed.

title: Broncos' Stellar Running Unravels the Packers' Blitz Plans
description: The Packers won this season by using a variety of blitzes. The problem against Denver was that the Broncos ran the ball so well, Green Bay couldn't do what it wanted.

title: New Wave of Screen Phones Is Ready to Hit the Market
description: By some estimates, nearly half the households in the United States have a personal computer capable of connecting to the Internet. Now a handful of telephone makers would like to sell a phone to the other half.

title: Indonesian Stocks Rise as Rupiah Falls
description: Indonesian stocks rose, led by Government-controlled phone companies PT Telkom and PT Indosat, as investors took advantage of the difference between the value of their shares in Jakarta and New York as the rupiah plunged to a record low.

title: Gen. Ralph C. Smith, Honored For War Bravery, Dies at 104
description: Maj. Gen. Ralph Corbett Smith, a rugged Nebraskan who was decorated for bravery in World War I, commanded an infantry division in combat in the Pacific in World War II and became the oldest surviving general officer of the United States Army, died on Wednesday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 104.

title: Three Giants Of PC World Turn Focus To Speed
description: On the first Monday of last month, Compaq, Intel and Microsoft summoned representatives of the nation's largest local telephone companies to a hotel in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISELS, ZELDA
description: MEISELS-Zelda. On January 25, 1998. Beloved wife of Raphael, mother of Deborah, Naomi and Anna. Cherished grandmother and great - grandmother. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Monday 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospital for Special Surgery.

title: More Protection Needed For Police, Group Says
description: Saying that the slaying of a plainclothes police detective during a drug sting last week had raised new concerns about the perils of undercover narcotics work, an advocacy group representing black police officers said yesterday that it was calling on the Police Department to take more steps to protect its officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYDGATE, WILLIAM A.
description: LYDGATE-William A. The entire family of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of former Trustee William A. Lydgate. A former Chairman of the Earl Newsom & Co. public relations concern, he was named Trustee of the Year by the NYS Hospital Trustees Association in 1986. The ''quintessential trustee,'' he was a revered and distinguished leader of our institution and will be sorely missed. To his wife Cynthia and his family, we offer our profound condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Ronald C. Ablow, MD President Richard P. Fried, MD President of the Medical Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARAUDA, JOSEPH R., SR.
description: PARAUDA-Joseph R., Sr. Of Edison, on Friday, January 23, 1998. Services on Tuesday, 8:45 AM, at the Gosselin Funeral Home, 660 New Dover Road, Edison, followed by a 9:30 AM Mass at St. Helena's R.C. Church, Edison. Interment will be held in St. Gertrude's Cemetery in Colonia. Visitation will be held on Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers donations be made to Bishop Ahr High School Capital Campaign, 1 Tingley Lane, Edison, NJ 08820, or Fordham University, Bronx, NY 10458.

title: U.S. Proposes Tighter Limits On Rafting on Salmon River
description: The United States Forest Service has proposed sharply curtailing white-water trips on the Salmon River gorge in central Idaho, angering professional outfitters and boaters.

title: Red Cross Is Criticized on Deal With Manufacturer
description: Few symbols in the world are as widely recognized, or as stringently guarded, as the red cross on a white background. Adopted by the International Red Cross in 1863, it is protected by the Geneva Convention, and improper use of it in the United States is a Federal crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, JAMES J., SR.
description: O'BRIEN-James J., Sr. Of Madison, NJ, former Senior Vice President and Chairman of Trust Investment Committee of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and former General Partner of Solomon Brothers and Hutzler. On Friday, January 23, 1998. Husband of Kathleen (nee McFadden) O'Brien. Father of Virginia O'B. Stacey of Baltimore, MD; Mary Patricia Roth of Washington, D.C. and the late James J. O'Brien of Boca Raton, FL. Grandfather of Mary Virginia Murphy of Baltimore, MD; Siobhan and Soren Roth and James J. O'Brien III, all of Washington, D.C.; and Kerry O'Brien of Boston, MA. Funeral service from the Burroughs, Kohr and Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main Street, Madison, NJ, on Tuesday, January 27, at 10 AM. Then to Saint Vincent, Martyr Church, Madison, for the Funeral Mass at 11 AM. Interment at the Mount Olivet Cemetery, Newark, NJ. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may be made in Mr. O'Brien's name to the James J. O'Brien, Sr. Scholarship Fund for Respiratory Therapists, in care of Royston, Muller, McLean and Reid, Attorneys at Law, Attention, Harrison Stone, Esq., 102 Pennsylvania Ave., Suite 600, Towson, MD 21204, or to a charity of your choice. Visiting hours Monday, 2-4 and 7-9.

title: The Pious and the Curious Share a Historic Moment
description: Their hearts racing, their throats aching, the two women waved their Cuban and Vatican flags with abandon today, clapping and shouting, ''I believe! I believe!'' as Pope John Paul II outlined the tenets of the Catholic faith. Then they looked at each other.

title: When the Truth Hurts
description: When my love swears that she is made of truth, I do believe her, though I know she lies . . .'' In these lines and the 12 that follow -- written 400 years ago -- Shakespeare succinctly captures much about the complexity of truth-telling. The sonnet expresses his gratitude that his beloved allows him to avoid much truth. Her lies -- claiming that he is still young though he knows he is not -- make growing old bearable.

title: For book clubs, the big increase in sales is coming in smaller niches.
description: TWEEDY judges may no longer sip sherry and debate literary merit for the monthly selections at venerable book clubs, but in today's flourishing market for club sales, executives remain willing and eager to reach for higher inspiration to guide an expanding membership.

title: Perfecting His Word; Corel's Feisty Founder Promises the Company Will Rebound
description: Michael C. J. Cowpland beams, tanned and confident, despite the nasty things people are saying about him.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Normally Stoic Shanahan Has a Reason to Grin
description: Denver Broncos Coach Mike Shanahan was smiling a big, broad, toothy smile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINER, JACK
description: KLEINER-Jack. Devoted father of Robert, Michael and Richard. Proud grandfather of Melissa, Mark, Yvette, Nicholas and Dolly. He cherished the memory of his late wife Barbara. A lifetime member of the Million Dollar Roundtable, he served his clients well. He played basketball for Tilden and NYU, and always made his foul shots. Funeral private.

title: Editorial Observer; Finding Qualified Teachers for the Dead Zone
description: Anxiety about public schools has pushed education to the top of the domestic agenda, with Democrats and Republicans scrambling to own the issue and milk it for votes. The Democrats style themselves as reformers but will go no further than their masters, the teachers' unions, permit. The Republicans are posing as advocates of school choice for the urban poor, who are largely confined to the nation's worst schools.

title: Mixing Legal Ferocity and Courtroom Ballet; In Defamation Case, Sharpton's Lawyer Is the Most Unpredictable Player
description: There are times when Michael A. Hardy plays the court jester, defusing tensions at the Tawana Brawley defamation trial with cunning quips and loopy asides.

title: Norwegians Take Pairs Title By an Overwhelming Margin
description: The second of two big European Pairs contests, the Macallan Invitational, ended in London on Friday, and there were two remarkable features.

title: Health Gap Grows, With Black Americans Trailing Whites, Studies Say
description: A robust economy and years of Government pressure have helped move minority groups closer to the mainstream. But when it comes to health, studies show a stubborn, daunting and in some respects growing disparity between black and white Americans.

title: Rap Empire Unraveling As Stars Flee
description: The six-year reign of Death Row Records, one of the music industry's most profitable and controversial labels, may be coming to an end.

title: Another Day at The Office
description: DEVILS 3, CANADIENS 1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIGERMAN, HYMAN
description: EIGERMAN-Hyman. On Saturday, January 24, 1998, in Cambridge, MA, a lifelong New Yorker. For 65 years, the beloved and loving husband of Leah. Always caring father of Daniel, Joel and Sarah. Loving, proud and supportive grandfather of Hannah, Nathan, Edward and Jared. Teacher, Scholar, Educator, Raconteur, Chessmaster, Punster and Dogged Controversialist. Author of ''The Poetry of Dorothy Wordsworth,'' 1940. He leaves his work and the family he created. A memorial service will be held at a later date. For more information call Levine Chapel in Brookline, MA.

title: Video Network Hopes to Copy Success of Spanish-Language Radio
description: Eduardo Caballero, an early promoter of Spanish-language radio, is again breaking new ground with a start-up Spanish music-video television network built from a string of low-power stations in the San Joaquin Valley and along the central coast of California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARLEY, AGNES E.
description: FARLEY-Agnes E. Of New York City and Sea Girt, NJ, on January 23, 1998. Beloved sister of Elizabeth Coleman and Gerald, Joseph and Vincent Farley, all of whom predeceased her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Monday, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Ave. at 66th St., on Tuesday at 11 AM.

title: Holmgren's Replay Campaign
description: Packers Coach Mike Holmgren is still hoping that the league will reinstate instant replay, which he championed in each of the past two off seasons. But Holmgren, a member of the league's competition committee, said he did not expect to devote as much energy to it as last season, when he believed it would be approved and was greatly disappointed when it was defeated in the league meetings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMOFF, WOODY
description: ROMOFF-Woody. January 20,1998. Loyal, devoted nephew of my late husband, Sam Freed. With love, Aunt Laura, cousins Dan, Joey, and Jessica Weiss

title: Meat Wholesaler Shot and Stabbed to Death in His Company Office
description: The owner of a wholesale meat company was shot and stabbed to death in the company's offices in Keansburg, N.J., on Friday, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Gallons and Dollars Match, So Gas Sells Fast
description: Watching the digits on a gas pump race, any driver will admit, can be vaguely hypnotic, if rather unsatisfying: total gallons are usually no match for total dollars.

title: The Rangers Approach a Crucial Stretch
description: Aleksei Kovalev of the Rangers will skate this morning to test his tender right knee. If he feels no soreness or swelling, he will probably play tonight against the Washington Capitals at Madison Square Garden in the final match of a four-game homestand. If the knee still hurts, he might have arthroscopic surgery to remove loose cartilage, a procedure that could idle him for 10 days to two weeks.

title: Taking In the Sites; A Virtual Trip to World Fairs Past
description: It has been more than a quarter-century since the last New York World's Fair closed up shop on a former ash heap in Queens. Precious little of it remains in Flushing Meadows -- just the Unisphere and a few other structures in varying states of decay.

title: Now Hiring! If You're Young
description: Readers of recent reports about a shortage of computer programmers would be baffled if they also knew that Microsoft hires only 2 percent of its applicants for software positions. Even among those applicants whom Microsoft invites to its headquarters for interviews, according to David Pritchard, the director of recruiting, the company makes offers to only one in four.

title: Lead-In Show Drags Down A Good Game
description: Last dance, last chance for NBC to broadcast a National Football League game for as many as eight years. Was last night's seven hours of Super Bowl programming an impressive, stupendous goodbye effort? Did it make us want to lip sync better than Jewel did during the national anthem, and sob, knowing Ahmad Rashad won't do his usual nothing in an N.F.L. studio for a long time?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, ETHEL
description: FENTON-Ethel. Beloved wife of the late Lee. Mother of Dr. Herb Fenton and Jain. Grandmother of Lee. Sister of Gerald Franklin. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Riverside Building), 331 Amsterdam Ave, (corner of 76th St), NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLEET, GERALD A.
description: FLEET-Gerald A. 1916-1978. Dearly missed. Remembered with admiration and love. Your family.

Graveside services Monday, 2:30 PM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. The family will return to the home of Rita and Dan Hurley.

description: AMSTERDAM-Jack. On January 23, 1998. Chairman of the Board of Leviton Manufacturing Co. Beloved husband of the late Mimi Leviton Amsterdam. Devoted father of Dasha Epstein. Caring and loving grandfather of Robert and Danielle Epstein. Dear brother of Jean Ross. Loyal and best friend of Mimi Goodman. Service Tuesday 11 AM Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave. at 55th St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARCHIBALD, WILLIAM T.
description: ARCHIBALD-William T. The Officers and Board of Governors, along with the entire membership of the Circumnavigators Club, mourn the passing of their revered Bill, who served as President in 1981-1982, and Foundation President in 1986-1988. He will be long remembered.

title: Damone, in Sinatra Hits, Does It His Own Way
description: On Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, Vic Damone reminisced about Frank Sinatra's introducing him at another concert, more than 40 years ago. ''He called me 'a kid that's got stardust on his shoulders,' '' Mr. Damone said.

title: Iomega is spending heavily to loft its brand into the name-recognition stratosphere.
description: EVEN as computer technology becomes more imbedded in mainstream culture, it remains uncommon for a branded product to command the loyalty of the garden variety customer. Those achieving that status are, of course, some of the world's most powerful brands: Apple's Macintosh; Microsoft's Windows; Intel's Pentium chips.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: A Subway Map for All

title: Defense Says Blood Feud, Not Murder, Was Involved
description: The defense lawyers say that Rigaletta Nikc fell in love with Joseph Rukaj even before he won $17.5 million in the lottery and started wearing Versace suits, driving a Range Rover and spending money as if he were born to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, ALAN G.
description: MILLSTEIN-Alan G. On Friday, January 23, 1998. Dear friend, former husband. A man of piercing intelligence, uncommon wit, unique perspective, with wide interests in art, theater, the cinema, and a love of New York City. I am eternally grateful to him for always making me laugh and for introducing me to a world of beauty and fashion and glamour, which changed my life only for the better. ''At the round earth's imagin'd corners, blow Your trumpets, Angells, and arise, arise from death ...and you whose eyes, Shall behold God, and never taste deaths woe.'' Anne Taylor Davis Millstein

title: Sports of The Times; Instead of a Dynasty, the Beginning of the End in Green Bay?
description: THIS was a game of roaring. It was one of the few times in Super Bowl history that the week-long hype, the round-the-clock parties, the thick crowds, the excesses at every level failed to overwhelm the championship game.

title: Turkish Inquiry Links Government Agents to Assassinations
description: An official investigating Turkey's biggest modern political scandal has concluded that agents of previous Governments committed clandestine murders, worked with drug dealers and laundered their profits through casinos.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEITELBAUM, JEROME
description: TEITELBAUM-Jerome. 11 years ago today. Sorely missed. Lovingly remembered. Marian

title: Too Much Confidence Second Time Around
description: For Green Bay quarterback Brett Favre, the day began with a nice welcome from the Denver Broncos: a blitz up the middle on a second-and-9 pass play. It foreshadowed a tough afternoon for Favre and the Packers in Super Bowl XXXII.

title: Recovery Is Built to Last
description: To the Editor:

title: Various Guises of Misery in Sundance Winners
description: At the Sundance Film Festival, where young white audiences predominate and much of this year's emphasis was on antic white characters having trouble with their love lives, two big winners were films about black men in prison. Top dramatic honors went to Marc Levin's ''Slam,'' made in a muscular documentary style and featuring a strong performance from Saul Williams, who plays a young man from the ghetto who is jailed on a marijuana charge. Punctuated by tough, galvanizing outbursts of rap poetry, ''Slam'' tells a not entirely unpredictable story in newly energetic fashion.

title: INSIDE
description: Blacks Lag in Health Care

title: London Journal; Scare or No, the Britons Are Still Mad About Beef
description: Since the British Government outlawed the sale of beef on the bone, saying mad cow disease might be lurking inside beef bones and marrow, Mary Killen has been served roast rib of beef no fewer than six times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZMAN, FLORENCE
description: WEITZMAN-Florence. Of Boca Raton, formerly of Hewlett, died Thursday, January 22, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Saul; loving mother of Rissa and Jody. Dear sister, aunt, great-aunt and adored friend. Graveside services 11 AM, Tuesday, January 27, Old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Blvd, St. Albans, Queens.

title: No Frills, Just Service With a Screen
description: On the face of it, the idea seemed preposterous: Who would pay hundreds of dollars a month to subscribe to an Internet chat room?

description: Both coaches turned down the chance to do the post-game ''I'm going to Disneyland'' commercial, which pays $30,000 and comes with a trip to Disneyland.

title: Mayor Urges Separation of High Schoolers Past the Fifth Year
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that high school students who do not graduate within five years should be transferred to a separate program that would give them more time to obtain their diplomas.

title: Woodbridge, Australia's Last Hope, Is Upset by Escude
description: The roof snapped shut again over the stadium on a rainy morning at the Australian Open, the first bad sign on the Australia Day holiday. The host nation lost the sole survivor of its bumper crop of singles contenders when Todd Woodbridge, an unlikely choice as the last-gasp hope from Australia's talent pool, found himself drummed out of the action.

title: Delay in 'Capeman' Opening: A Tale of 'Tough Decisions'
description: In three days, the last of the winter's eagerly awaited big new musicals will open on Broadway: Paul Simon's $11 million ''Capeman,'' based on the true story of a Puerto Rican gang murder that became a tabloid sensation nearly four decades ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, CATHERINE
description: KRAUSS-Catherine. Age 78. A resident of Great Neck and Boca Raton, FL. Wife of the late Carl Krauss; mother of Marilyn, Philip, Barry and Sherry. Grandmother of nine; great-grandmother of two. Services today, 2 PM, at RiversideNassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Parnevik Gets First PGA Tour Victory
description: As he walked down the 18th fairway today, Jesper Parnevik lighted a victory cigar, relieved that he could finally exhale.

description: SACHS-Dr. Lucille H. Blum. Beloved mother of Stuart Blum and Abby Nusbaum. Loving grandmother of Jenny and Rachael Nusbaum and mother-in-law of Barbara Blum. Private services and interment were held.

The Cuban people therefore cannot be denied the contacts with other peoples necessary for economic, social and cultural development, especially when the imposed isolation strikes the population indiscriminately, making it ever more difficult for the weakest to enjoy the bare essentials of decent living, things such as food, health and

title: Clinton Wants to Use Surplus for Social Security
description: President Clinton plans to call in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday for using any Federal budget surpluses in coming years to get an early start on fixing Social Security, Administration officials said today.

title: Alan Millstein, 54, Consultant To Retail and Fashion Industry
description: Alan Gary Millstein, the affable, ever-quotable consultant to the retail and fashion industry, died Friday at New York Hospital. Mr. Millstein, who was 54, died of myelodysplasia, a bone marrow disease, said Robert Wolf, a family spokesman.

title: Shots Fall for Lopez, and the Good Times Follow
description: There was little drama for the resurgent St. John's men's basketball team yesterday, just lots of delirium. Madison Square Garden served as a personal driveway for Felipe Lopez and the Red Storm, while it was a personal dungeon for wayward Villanova in a game that was not competitive for long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LOUIS L.
description: ROSENBERG-Louis L. On January 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Sherry. Loving father of Michael and Karen. Adoring grandfather of David, Jenna, Joshua and Marissa. Devoted brother of Pearl Lamberg, Ruth Russ and Emanuel. Visiting Sunday 7-9 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Service Monday, 1 PM at Union Temple, 17 Eastern Pkwy., Brooklyn, NY.

description: FRANK-Jack. Renowned educator. Beloved husband of Beatrice, 65 years. Devoted father of Roberta, Gene, Henny and Arnie. Dear brother of Rose and Martin. Adored grandfather of Audrey, Alec, Mark, Jevin, Janine and Todd. Loving great-grandfather of Alison and Jaclyn. Graveside service Tuesday, 11 AM, Union Field Cemetery.

description: RUTGERS 87, PITTSBURGH 65

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the growing popularity of bottled water misidentified the type of plastic used for water bottles. It is polyethylene terephthalate, not polyurethane.

title: Essay; Speechwriter's Draft
description: My Fellow Americans:

title: A Cry of a Prophetic Voice In All That Sound and Fury
description: It's hard to believe that 13 years have passed since Larry Kramer's incendiary, blame-throwing AIDS drama, ''The Normal Heart,'' made its debut at the Public Theater, and all the more jolting because AIDS remains so much with us. When one of the gay men in this tensive and tender play breaks down because he has no way of knowing whether he somehow caused the deaths of his last three lovers, we are reminded of how cruelly primitive was the Stone Age of this epidemic, before scientists isolated H.I.V. and developed a reliable test for its detection.

title: Some Doubts on Lie Detection by Phone
description: Is your employee taking drugs? Has your mate had an affair? Is the check really in the mail?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHMORE, HARRY S.
description: ASHMORE-Harry S. Pulitzer Prize winning Editor of the Arkansas Gazette, courageous civil rights leader and brave crusader against segregation, for over 40 years was an active member of the Board of Directors of the National Committee for an Effective Congress. His colleagues at the NCEC will cherish his memory and miss his wisdom, his leadership and warm sense of humor. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Barbara and daughter Anne. Russell Hemenway

title: President Preparing Message On Policy, Not Predicament
description: Bill Clinton stood before a teleprompter this afternoon in a brown suit and green vest, practicing his State of the Union Message in the White House map room with a Roosevelt-era chart of the Allied forces as his backdrop.

title: Food Safety Critics Need Free-Speech Protection; Not Guilty, and Broke
description: To the Editor:

title: The film 'Blade Runner' lives on in a game, and maybe in our vision of the future.
description: THE sound of wind and rain are familiar; so is the sheen of advanced technology glinting through the mists of decay and dissolution. Some places remain untouched as well: the rooftop landing pads, the pyramids of corporate wealth, the garbage-strewn streets crammed with a polyglot populace. ''Blade Runner,'' the 1982 film that has become a cult classic, has been transmuted into a game on CD-ROM (it can be previewed at www.westwood.com), preserving the atmosphere of the original film in a medium that seems both more technologically advanced in its possibilities and more primitive in its achievements.

title: 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' Online
description: The Navy's move to dismiss a highly decorated sailor, Senior Chief Petty Officer Timothy R. McVeigh, for homosexuality shows the senselessness of the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy and the vulnerability of private information on the Internet.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: White House Prepares Plan On Internet Domain Names

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNAUGHTON, WILLIAM G.
description: CONNAUGHTON-William G. Of Fort Collins, CO. Died January 23, 1998. He is survived by his wife Phyllis Ainsworth Connaughton, three children, eight grandchildren and one brother. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society in his name.

title: Wide Net Is Cast to Confirm Accusations
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, has cast a wide net in Washington in trying to corroborate the secret tape recordings in which Monica S. Lewinsky allegedly claimed that President Clinton and his close friend Vernon E. Jordan Jr. had encouraged her to deny a sexual relationship with Mr. Clinton, lawyers involved in the investigation said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, PENINA
description: SPIEGEL-Penina. The entire Abraham Joshua Heschel School Community is shocked and saddened by the untimely death of Penina Spiegel, beloved and dedicated mother of our student Sabrina. We pray for you Sabrina, and for all the members of your dear family. Terry Krulwich, President Roanna Shorofsky, Director

title: Castro Out of Character
description: Fidel Castro did many unusual things during the Pope's visit. He wore a suit, went to Mass, and patted John Paul on the back. Page A9.

title: Continental Weighs Merger Bids From Both Delta and Northwest
description: The country's third- and fourth-largest airlines are vying for control of the fifth-largest carrier in a competition that could spark a new round of consolidation in the airline industry.

title: Unlike Microsoft, Intel Opts to Speak Softly on Antitrust Issues
description: It enjoys a near-monopoly on an essential technology of personal computing, bringing the company and its shareholders immense wealth. It is led by a brilliant, famous and notoriously competitive chief executive, and it is now being pursued by Washington's antitrust police.

title: Gatling Returns, Shoots And Shows Some Rust
description: When John Calipari beckoned Chris Gatling to report into the game Saturday night in Washington, the coach might have been feeling a little more nervous than the player. Calipari had spent much of the last six weeks anticipating the moment when he would have his whole team together for the first time all season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIORE, SALVATORE G., JR.
description: FIORE-Salvatore G., Jr. Of Greenwich, CT, on January 20, 1998. Survived by wife Evelyn, daughter Alison, son Nicholas, and four grandchildren who loved him in life and carry his memory. Services as St. Luke's Church, Darien, CT, January 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTCHINGS, SARAH WILLIM
description: HUTCHINGS-Sarah Willim. In her 59th year. Beloved wife of Neil of Paget Parish, Bermuda, mother of Carroll, and step-mother of Nathaniel and Nancy Hutchings. Also survived by her daughter-in-law Rachel, brother John Stone Willim II and his wife Louise in Florida; sister Mrs. Melissa Trask and her husband Fritz of Denver, CO. A memorial service will be held at Christ Presbyterian Church, Warwick, Bermuda, Wednesday, January 28, 4 PM.

title: The Singapore Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGLER, BARBARA
description: ZIEGLER-Barbara. On January 23, 1998 in New York. Daughter of the late Gladys Watson and William Ziegler. Survived by her brother William Ziegler III, her sister Helen Steinkraus and her niece Melinda Page. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: Rell Sunn, 47, Hawaiian Surfing Champion
description: Rell Sunn, the Hawaiian surfer who skimmed across the waves with such sure and natural grace that she sometimes seemed at one with the sea, died on Jan. 2 at her home in Makaha on the island of Oahu. She was 47.

title: Were the Guns Too Loud? Irish Soldiers Take Issue to Court
description: Irish soldiers, who have never in this country's 75 years of proud independence had occasion to fire a shot in defense of the homeland, are now engaged in war -- or at least extended skirmishing -- with their own Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSHUK, MARIANNE
description: SOSHUK-Marianne. On January 4, 1998 in Miami Beach, FL. Wife of Levi; mother of Rona and David, grandmother of Stephen, Daniel, Robyn and Rachel. Marianne taught history and social studies in Brooklyn public high schools. In retirement she travelled extensively, was active in Jewish and civic matters, and continued teaching in the Dade County adult education program. I miss you terribly, Mom.

title: Sports of The Times; Shakespeare's Quarterback Finally Wins the Biggest Game
description: WHEN he walked up the stairs to the platform near the huge balloon replica of the Super Bowl trophy, he smiled when he heard the ''El-way, El-way'' chant. And when Pat Bowlen accepted the silver Vince Lombardi Trophy, the Broncos' president lifted it and yelled, ''This one's for John.''

title: Corrections
description: A map on Saturday with an article about the new Bosnian Serb Government depicted the Eastern Slavonia region of Croatia incorrectly. It is no longer under United Nations administration.

title: Some Experts Are Faulting Counsel Law
description: Some legal scholars say they are concerned that the independent counsel law allows a standing inquisition of the President of the United States.

title: Davis Scores 3 Times as Broncos End A.F.C.'s 13-Game Slide
description: Even when they had him, the Packers could not hold him. Terrell Davis, the Denver Broncos running back who returned to his hometown and ran for glory, was the most elusive player of all of the elite tonight in Super Bowl XXXII. He became the first player to win the Super Bowl's most valuable player award in his hometown and the first to score three rushing touchdowns in a Super Bowl. The final one, a 1-yard burst with 1 minute 45 seconds left, pierced the heart of a champion, the Green Bay Packers, and created a new one -- the Denver Broncos.

title: George Wendelken, 'Our Gang' Actor, 81
description: George T. Wendelken, who played Freckles in the original ''Our Gang'' film comedies of the 1920's, died on Jan. 3. He was 81 and lived in Toms River, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINALE, STEPHEN D.
description: FINALE-Stephen D. On January 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Loukia. Father of Panayis, Nicholas and Victoria Lyras. Grandfather of Eric Woodhams. Dear cousin of Fannie Finale, Aphrodite Finale, Helen and Lucas Tzanides and Dr. Orestis Finale. Also survived by grand-nephews Dr. Elias Tzanides, Andrew Tzanides and families. Former assistant, General Council, New York Power Authority and former Chief Field Officer OSS. Reposing at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, today 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be celebrated at a High Mass, Tuesday, 12 noon, at St. Constantine and Helen Cathedral, 64 Schmerhorn St., Brooklyn. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

title: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHNEYER, WILLIAM A.
description: SHNEYER-William A. On January 24, 1998. Born April 2, 1921. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Flushing, NY. Beloved community leader and activist, National Executive Committee, past National V.P. of the American Jewish Congress. Past President Queens AJC. Editorial Board ''Jewish Currents'', founder of Queens Black-Jewish People to People Project. Active in PEARL, B'nai Brith, Americans for Peace Now, United Parents Association. Married for 55 years to his best friend and soulmate Hedy, proud father of Hannah (Joel) and Paul (Laura), grandfather to Elana and Danya, uncle to Gail and Howard, cousin to Sue and Evelyn. Services Monday, January 26, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. and Amersterdam Ave, at 1 PM.

title: Patents; The process of filing an application is slowly catching up with the technology available.
description: JUST a few years ago, the clerks in the Patent and Trademark Office's mail room added a new device to help them deal with the endless flow of applications that arrive every day: the fax machine.

title: Cautious Newsweek Reaps Much of the Credit
description: Until today, none of Newsweek's reporting had appeared in Newsweek magazine.

description: SHERBELL - Kenneth. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Devoted father of Gary and Laurel, and Suzanne Sherbell. Adored grandfather of Adam. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' 114-03 Queens Boulevard (corner of 76th Road), Forest Hills.

title: In Africa, Reality of Technology Falls Short
description: When Jean-Marc Angoran began setting up an Internet cafe here in late summer, he had the giddy feeling of catching a wave at just the right time. Indeed, for a while almost everything seemed to be going his way.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Mutombo Edges Out Ewing as All-Star Starter
description: It would have been quite a moment. Patrick Ewing could have stood in front of the Madison Square Garden crowd at the All-Star Game on Feb. 8 and been drenched with hometown adulation as his name was announced.

title: Williams and Davenport Stage Routs Under Roof
description: Thunderstorms erupted today at the Australian Open, dumping nearly two inches of rain. But that development justified the existence of the $100 million Melbourne Park's most unusual bell and whistle: the retractable roof that permits the show to go on, at least inside the main stadium.

title: POPE ASKS CUBANS TO SEEK NEW PATH TOWARD FREEDOM
description: With the images of both Jesus and Che Guevara looking down on him and a visibly moved throng, Pope John Paul II today stepped into Fidel Castro's favorite pulpit, the huge Plaza of the Revolution here, and urged Cubans to seek ''the new paths called for by these times of renewal'' and to avoid ''exclusion, isolation and conflict.''

title: Dealers in Secrets Reach for Record
description: Linda R. Tripp is a professional handler of secrets. Lucianne S. Goldberg makes a living selling them. They made an incendiary match.

title: Northwest and Delta Bid for Continental
description: Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines are vying for control of Continental Airlines in a competition that could touch off a new round of consolidation in the industry.

title: How the Irish Came Home To an Alien, Hostile Land
description: ''That was all the fun you knew,'' says one of the chroniclers who spin out ''The Irish in America: Long Journey Home.'' He is reminiscing about storytelling, the Celtic specialty that was happily imported to these shores a century or two ago and enriches the six-hour history that begins tonight on PBS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, HERBERT
description: SCHWARZ-Herbert. Father of Tom and Paul. Pop-Pop to Douglas, Elizabeth, Stephen, Susan and Joanna. Father-in-law of Barbara, Shirley and Susan. Greatgrandfather of Marcus and Julia. Former President and longtime bridge team captain of Fairview Country Club. Services Tuesday, January 27, 10 AM, Kol Ami (JCC of White Plains). Contributions to White Plains Hospital in lieu of flowers.

title: Presidential Advisers Are Preparing to Fight a 'Three-Front War'
description: After days of shock and confusion, President Clinton's legal and political advisers are organizing to fight what they are calling a ''three-front war'' to repel the threats -- criminal, civil and political -- that imperil his Presidency.

title: Four String Players As Conquering Heroes
description: Last year the Juilliard String Quartet celebrated its 50th anniversary and underwent a major shift of personnel. Robert Mann, who had played first violin since the ensemble's founding, retired. Joel Smirnoff, who had been the second violinist, moved up to first, and Ronald Copes joined the ensemble as second violinist. The violist Samuel Rhodes and the cellist Joel Krosnick, both veterans, remain in place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIGLIUCCI, MARIO
description: MIGLIUCCI-Mario. Restauranteur of Mario's Restaurant, Bronx, NY. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Bochino). Devoted father of Joseph and Diane Lentini. Also survived by six loving grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. Reposing Lucia Bros., 569 E. 184th St., Bronx. Mass Tuesday, 9:30 AM, Mt. Carmel Church. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-5, 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Cancer Society appreciated.

description: SHEERR-Alvin. 85. Of Greenwich, CT. January 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Vivian. Devoted father of Patricia, Phyllis and the late Clinton. Father-in-law of Donald and Deirdre. title: After a Tough Start The Broncos Don't Panic
description: All week, the Denver Broncos' defensive players talked about how they had to shut down the Green Bay Packers from the start, how they couldn't fall behind, how they had to contain Brett Favre. Then they went out and gave up a game-opening 8-play, 76-yard touchdown drive.

title: Even a Migraine Doesn't Slow Down Davis on His Way to the M.V.P.
description: The Denver Broncos led at halftime, but life inside their locker room at intermission of today's Super Bowl was turning into one giant migraine.

title: Minor League Stadium Planned for Waterfront
description: Developers have announced plans to build a 6,200-seat minor league baseball stadium along the Camden waterfront.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUTTER, JEAN D.
description: ZUTTER-Jean D., age 76, passed away January 22, 1998 in Tucson, AZ. He was born July 8, 1922 in Zurich, Switzerland. Jean spent the majority of his international banking career with the then Irving Trust Co. in New York and Paris, France, retiring in 1989. Most recently, Jean has served as a Director of the Board of the AXA Reinsurance Co. He is survived by his wife Clarice M. of Tucson; his sons John D. Jr., of Briarcliff Manor, NY, Alain S. of San Rafael, CA and four grandchildren. Also survived by his brothers Louis E. of Chesterfield, MO and Bernard H. of Torremolinos, Spain. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Philip's in the Hills Church in Tucson on Tuesday January 27, 1998 at 3:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the St. Philip's in the Hills Building Fund.

title: State Study Concludes Casinos Benefit Citizens
description: In a report that praised the state's gambling industry, state officials said Atlantic City's casinos had generated more than $7 billion in Federal, state and local tax revenue over the last 20 years and currently employ nearly 50,000 workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SIDNEY
description: SIMON - Sidney. Of Shaker Heights, OH. Died Saturday, January 17, 1998, at the age of 85. Former President of the M & D Simon Co., makers of Donegal Sportswear. Longtime leader in the Cleveland Jewish community. In his last years, led fundraising efforts for the HELP Foundation, a Cleveland charity and group home for the mentally disabled. Beloved husband of Nancy. Loving father of Wendy Zinn, Jonathan Simon, Barbara Simon. Dear brother of Edward. Adoring grandfather of five.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Jan. 15 about Ronald K. Brown/Evidence at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan misattributed the text read during ''Lessons.'' It was written by Sandye Brown alone; Colin Robinson and Essex Hemphill did not collaborate on it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Indonesian Currency Declines On Uncertainty Over Future
description: The Indonesian currency, the rupiah, lost as much as 15 percent in early trading today as no solution emerged to Indonesia's deepening debt crisis and international banks continued to freeze lending to the country.

title: Whatever Happened to Recess?
description: At my 9-year-old daughter's school, the morning begins with aerobics. The same bouncy tune is piped into each classroom, and the children -- 900 strong -- step, jump and spin. Although it seems rigid, the exercise has an impromptu, playful quality, unlike the regimented day that follows.

title: Paulina Ruvinska, 85, Concert Pianist
description: Paulina Ruvinska, a pianist known for her vigorous technique and the breadth of her repertory, died on Jan. 17 at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: A Popular Dictator?
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Safety Critics Need Free-Speech Protection; Dangerous Feed in U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; The State Of the State Of (Whatever)
description: STARQUEST was in fine form the other day, quizzing the audience on fables -- do you remember the one about the ant and the grasshopper? -- and showing slides of himself in Roman garb. He would not speak until everyone was seated, no doubt sensing that the crowd clustered around the door was planning to bolt early.

title: Real Life Intrudes On Political Movie
description: The film ''Primary Colors'' seemed destined for success.

title: A Bold but Incomplete Forest Plan
description: Nobody was entirely happy with the Clinton Administration's announcement last week that it will shortly impose an 18-month moratorium on new logging roads on millions of acres of undeveloped national forest lands. Western senators complained of a new ''War on the West'' and warned of great suffering in the timber industry and the towns that depend on it. Environmentalists were disappointed that the plan would not bar new roads in Alaska's Tongass National Forest and in some forests in the Pacific Northwest.

title: A Call for Elegantly Simple Software
description: MACHINE BEAUTY

title: The Pope's Message to Washington
description: Those who oppose America's obsolete trade embargo on Cuba found an eloquent ally in Pope John Paul II as he visited the island in recent days. It was not just John Paul's criticism of embargoes, which he had made before, but the attention he drew to humanitarian needs in Cuba that Washington has stubbornly ignored.

title: Charles Schucker, Abstract Painter, 89
description: Charles Schucker, a second-generation Abstract Expressionist, died on Jan. 17 at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn Heights. He was 89 and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Pope Captivates His Marxist Host
description: Fidel Castro has done many unusual things during the visit to Cuba by Pope John Paul II. He wore a business suit, which he almost never does on his home turf. He sat through a papal lecture on democracy. He went to Mass.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 17 about a Turkish supreme court ruling banning the country's largest political party attributed a quotation incompletely. The observations by Jenny B. White, an American scholar of Turkey who wrote that the ideological trend of the banned party was unclear, appeared first in Current History magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, ROBERT
description: FORREST-Robert. 75. Writer, broadcaster, winner of distinguished Peabody Award. Adored husband of Grace. Loving father and grandfather. We'll miss you.

title: P.& G. Decision Prompts a Change
description: The decision last week by the Procter & Gamble Company to dismiss Wells BDDP in New York has led to a change for a well-known name.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the News Summary on Jan. 16 about a withdrawal of United Nations peacekeepers from a region in the Balkans misidentified the region. It was western Slavonia (part of Croatia), not western Slovenia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLONDEK, SOL, M.D.
description: ZOLONDEK-Sol, M.D. Beloved husband of Edith. Loving father of Ronnie Bramesco and Judy Konrad. Brother of Sally Shakun and Deborah Linden. Grandfather of Loren, Jonathan and Caryn Ecker. Stepfather of Stephen, James and Maudie Baker, and step-grandfather of their eight children.

title: Jay Monahan Is Dead at 42; Covered Law For NBC News
description: John Paul Monahan 3d, a lawyer and NBC News legal analyst, died Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. The husband of Katie Couric, the host of NBC's ''Today'' program, Mr. Monahan was 42 and lived in Manhattan.

title: An Ex-Leftist Finds Rebirth in the Church He Forsook
description: Jorge Garcia stood on his toes in his open blue sandals and strained to see Pope John Paul II as he spoke today to thousands of followers in the Plaza de la Revolucion, the place Fidel Castro has used, until now, only for his own public speeches.

title: 'Talking Points' for Tripp Affidavit
description: Following are ''talking points'' that Monica S. Lewinsky, a former White House intern at the center of sexual accusations against President Clinton, gave to Linda R. Tripp, someone who has seen the document said. The ''points'' concern an affidavit that Ms. Tripp was to file in the sexual misconduct lawsuit filed by Paula Corbin Jones against Mr. Clinton, regarding Ms. Tripp's account of what a White House staff member, Kathleen Willey, told her about an alleged sexual advance made by Mr. Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, WERNER H.
description: SCHUSTER-Werner H. ''Butch.'' Of West Islip, on January 24, 1998. Beloved son of Werner A. R. and Doris Schuster. Loving brother of Veronica Schuster and Stephan Schuster. Loving grandson of Guillermo Byrt and Litzia Gomez de Byrt. Assistant Treasurer of Bayerische Landesbank, New York City. Reposing at The Frederick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway (1/4 mile west of Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Thursday, 9:45 AM, at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, LI. Werner's family will be receiving relatives and friends on Tuesday and Wednesday between 2-4:30 PM and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Where Are the Elixirs of Yesteryear When We Hurt?
description: ''Americanitis,'' trumpeted the advertisement for a 1903 patent medicine made by the Rexall company. Was Americanitis the disease or the cure? There was no way to tell from a first glance at the brightly colored sign, a complex tableau of landscape, people and magic symbols; there was no way to tell after 10 minutes of staring.

title: Surreal Air Envelops Capital As Some Change the Subject
description: It was Saturday night at the White House, and Hillary Rodham Clinton rose in the Family Quarters to welcome the guests joining her and the President for dinner and a movie.

title: Northwest Air Getting Control Of Continental
description: Northwest Airlines agreed to buy a controlling stake in Continental Airlines for $519 million yesterday, beating a bid from Delta Air Lines and creating a third domestic and international airline network to compete with the country's biggest carriers, United Airlines and American Airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, JONATHAN R.
description: FRANK-Jonathan R. On January 26, 1998 of Pleasantville. Loving husband of Sally B. Loving father of Brandon and Alison. Loving brother of Susanne Kirschner and brother-in-law of Neil Kirschner. Cherished uncle of Craig and Erika.
