Family will receive friends on Tuesday evening from 7-9 PM at Beecher Funeral Home, Inc., 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville. Religious Services will begin at 10:30 AM on Wednesday. Interment immediately following at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PALAZZOLA, KEITH DAVID
description: PALAZZOLA-Keith David. 1/21/ 56-1/27/93. Five years have passed and we miss you more and more. You continue to live in our hearts. Love, your best friend, Howell

title: Man Convicted of Killing Paterson Woman, 66
description: A man who beat a 66-year-old woman to death in 1992 after she let him into her Paterson apartment for a drink of water was convicted of murder yesterday, the Passaic County Prosecutor's office said.

title: Anonymous Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank of Japan Officials Voice Negative Views
description: The Bank of Japan's 33 branch managers think the Japanese economy has deteriorated from three months ago, with the Osaka region especially showing signs of drawing closer to recession. At a news conference yesterday at the beginning of a meeting in Tokyo, the Osaka branch manager, Eiichiro Kinoshita, said the economic outlook was increasingly unclear and the current negative sentiment would probably not reverse anytime soon.

title: Their Eyes Not on the Game
description: About 133.4 million people watched Super Bowl XXXII, but at least a dozen New Yorkers did not. They were fans of Virginia Woolf, and they gathered for high tea shortly before the kickoff.

title: GOTHIC ENERGY COMPLETES AMOCO PROPERTY PURCHASE
description: The Gothic Energy Corporation of Tulsa, Okla., said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of producing natural gas properties from the Amoco Production Company for $237.5 million. Amoco also received a warrant to buy 1.5 million Gothic shares for $3 a share. Gothic acquired interests in 705 wells and assumed operations of 296 properties in the Anadarko and Arkoma Basins of Oklahoma. It also received a license to use Amoco's advanced well-operating technology, which Gothic said might reduce operating costs. Amoco Production is a unit of the Amoco Corporation.

title: Henning Hired As Jet Assistant
description: Since 1970, when they were assistant coaches at Florida State, Bill Parcells and Dan Henning have been close friends. Yesterday, Parcells hired Henning as the Jets' quarterbacks coach and promoted Charlie Weis to offensive coordinator. Weis will continue to coach the Jets' wide receivers.

title: Tighter Rules for Towns Denying Phone Towers
description: The State Supreme Court unanimously ruled yesterday that local planning boards cannot deny applications for telephone towers without testimony from experts that they would damage the health and property values of neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAULTASCH, MANNY
description: MAULTASCH-Manny. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the passing of our beloved member, Manny Maultasch, and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife, Minna and family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Philip Adler

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELNUOVO, TEDESCO PIETRO
description: CASTELNUOVO-TEDESCO Pietro. James G. Blakemore Professor of Psychiatry, Vanderbilt University. Devoted husband of Lisbeth. Loving father of Diana and Costanza. Brother of Lorenzo. Visitation Tuesday January 27th, 4-6 P.M. at home, 103 Westhampton Pl., Nashville, TN. Memorial service Wednesday January 28th 4 P.M. at Benton Chapel, Vanderbilt University, Nashville. For information Roesch Patton Austin Bracey & Charlton, 1715 Broadway, (615) 244-6480. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Pietro Castelnuovo-Tedesco Memorial Fund, which will be dedicated to providing psychiatric care for those unable to afford it. The Pietro Castelnuovo-Tedesco Memorial Fund c/o gift records, 201 Alumnae Hall, Vanderbilt University, Nashville 37240.

title: Where Is Compassion in the Abortion Debate?; Know All the Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Medical Autonomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUN, ABRAHAM
description: BRUN - Abraham. Cantor of Temple Beth El of Long Beach. Members, Board of Directors mourn the loss of Cantor emeritus who served the community for four decades. Heartfelt expressions of condolences to wife, Hannah, children, grandchildren. Rabbi A. Kupchik-Presidium

title: Chemical Lunch for Termites
description: WHEN termites show up at a house for lunch, then stay for supper and breakfast, too, they may be following the aroma of carbon dioxide.

title: Surprised by Strategy
description: Mike Shanahan said he was surprised to hear that the Packers allowed the Broncos to score the game-winning touchdown in the final two minutes, hoping to preserve time on the scoreboard clock for their own final drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LOUIS L.
description: ROSENBERG-Louis L. We feel profound sorrow in the loss of our beloved Board member and former President. For 30 years he provided devoted leadership and wise counsel in behalf of the disadvantged and the disabled. Served by the Brooklyn Bureau Community Serice. His vigorous advocacy and generosity helped many thousands of persons to live with dignity and hope. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Sherry, his children, Michael and Karen, and his entire family. Charles J. Hamm, Chairman Donna Santarsiero Executive Director Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service

title: 2 Top Japanese Bank Inspectors Arrested and Accused in Bribery
description: Prosecutors arrested two high-ranking officials of the Japanese Finance Ministry on Monday on charges of having accepted bribes from banks they were regulating.

title: Alter Law on Contractors, Giuliani Urges Legislators
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a compromise today to a burdensome and widely unpopular law among some politicians that requires government officials to hire at least four separate contractors for certain construction projects.

title: Some Optimistic Words Break Democratic Silence on Clinton
description: After hearing a pep talk from Vice President Al Gore, a group of House Democrats expressed support for President Clinton today, breaking a virtual silence on Capitol Hill about the accusations that Mr. Clinton had an affair with a White House intern.

title: Raytheon Charge Results in Loss
description: Reflecting charges of $321.7 million for the restructuring it announced last week, the Raytheon Company said today that it had a net loss in the fourth quarter. Excluding those losses, however, the company said profits rose 31 percent.

title: Indonesia Introduces Key Banking Changes
description: With Indonesia's banking system slowing almost to a halt, the Finance Ministry announced a package of measures today that is intended to restart the flow of money into the economy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Deal for Chrysler Building Is Completed
description: Tishman Speyer Properties said yesterday that it had completed the purchase of the $250 million mortgage on the Chrysler Building and other properties from Fuji Bank.

title: Drums, Hymns And Airs Bound To Home
description: More than the New York Philharmonic's other guest conductors, and certainly more than its music director, Kurt Masur, Leonard Slatkin is devoted to the notion that the 20th-century American repertory is as concertworthy as the European core literature. His current program, which was heard on Saturday evening and is to be repeated tonight at Avery Fisher Hall, is devoted entirely to american works, with classics by William Schuman and Aaron Copland balanced against newer works by Joseph Schwantner and John Zorn, both Philharmonic commissions.

title: Where Is Compassion in the Abortion Debate?; Lives Have Been Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: Spinoff Is Planned For British Dairy Unit
description: Northern Foods P.L.C., a leading British food company, said yesterday that it planned to spin off its dairy business to shareholders, creating a separate company, Express Dairies. Under the plan, which was announced by the company on Friday, shareholders would receive one Express share for every two Northern shares.

title: President's Lawyers Seek Earlier Trial Date in Paula Jones's Sexual Lawsuit
description: President Clinton's lawyers sought today to move up the date of the trial on Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct charges, in a move to regain the initiative as accusations about the President ricochet across the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARAUDA, JOSEPH R.
description: PARAUDA-Joseph R. The Putney Twombly Family mourns the loss of our dear friend and respected Managing Partner who died on January 23, 1998. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Martina, their children and family. We share your loss. The Partners, Associates and Staff Putney Twombly Hall Hirson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALGLISH, KENNETH J.
description: DALGLISH-Kenneth J., of Glen Rock, N.J. on Jan. 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Mitchell) Dalglish. Devoted father of Susan Halata, Dorothy Hartley, Kenneth, James, and Tricia Dalglish. Adored grandfather of Katherine, Emily, Russell, Christopher, Patricia, and Kevin. Funeral mass Wednesday 9 A.M. at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Hawthorne, N.J. Cremation Private. The family will receive their friends Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Vander Plaat Colonial Home Inc., 13-31 Saddle River Rd., Fair Lawn, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Kessler Institute For Rehabilitation, 240 Central Ave., East Orange, N.J. 07018 would be appreciated.

title: Armed Man Is Killed as He Runs at Officer
description: A police officer shot and killed a 22-year-old man in Brooklyn early yesterday morning after he refused an order to stop and ran toward the officer with a semiautomatic handgun, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, FRANCES T. (NEE MCCORMACK)
description: FITZGERALD-Frances T. (nee McCormack). On January 25, 1998. Devoted wife of the late John J., beloved mother of the late Eileen Noone, loving grandmother of Frances Mahoney and Michael B. Noone, Jr. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday, 10:15 AM, St. Patrick's RC Church. Visitation Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 at McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97 St, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ROUBEN
description: MARCUS-Rouben. Beloved husband and companion of the late Frances, father of Richard, fatherin-law of Barbara, grandfather of Jay and Sam, brother of Esther Backer (Max) and Berta Weiner, loving uncle and great uncle. He was a veteran who served his country. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died January 25, 1998 in Silver Spring, MD. Funeral to be held at Wien & Wien Funeral Home, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ, January 27 at 12:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Misler Center for Jewish Senior Day Care, 1801 East Jefferson St., Rockville, Maryland 20852. His loving smile and quiet dignity touched us all. He will be dearly missed. May his memory be a blessing.

title: Police Identify Suspect In L.I. Strangulation
description: The police in Suffolk County said yesterday that they were seeking a 56-year-old unemployed Long Island man in connection with the strangulation of a mother of two from Islip Terrace last week.

title: Pedestrians in Peril
description: Ask New Yorkers if their city has grown safer under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, and the answer is likely to be a resounding yes. The drop in crime has been little short of spectacular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LAMBERT J.
description: GROSS-Lambert J. 82 of Stuart, FL. died January 25, 1998. Graduate of Mercerburg Academy, Princeton University and an MBA at UCLA. CPA in aviation industry, later Vice-Pres. Finance/Director General Dynamics and Combustion Engineering, Inc. Retired Stuart Yacht & Country Club, FL. Survivor wife Rheta Dellay Gross. Memorial services February 11, 1998, Stuart. Contributions: American Heart Association.

title: A Look at Trimming Aid to Israel by U.S.
description: The Israeli Finance Minister will meet with Congressional and Administrative officials this week to discuss phasing out America's $1.2 billion in economic aid to Israel starting in the year 2000, according to Congressional officials and Jewish organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIPODI, LOUIS A.
description: TRIPODI-Louis A. Of Franklin Lakes, NJ on January 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Gail (nee Ennis). Loving father of Pascal, William, Louis, James, Stephen, Michela, Gian, Christian, Blanid, Michael and Theresa Tripodi. Dear brother of Theresa Tripodi. Also survived by four grandchildren. Mr. Tripodi was an advertising executive with DDB Needham Worldwide, Inc. in New York City. Funeral services were held on Monday at Most Blessed Sacrament RC Church. For information Vander PlaatVermeulen Memorial Home, Franklin Lakes, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to American Cancer Society or American Diabetes Association.

title: Small Group Of Protestants Quits Talks On Ulster
description: Pressed by other participants in the precarious Northern Ireland peace talks, a small Protestant party with links to a paramilitary group that admitted killing three Catholics this month pulled out of the negotiations today.

title: Kovalev to Undergo Surgery
description: Aleksei Kovalev could do very little in 20 minutes of testing his sore right knee yesterday morning and will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow. Kovalev will be operated on by Dr. Barton Nisonson, the team physician, at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.

title: Yeltsin Sends Envoy to Iraq to Try to Finesse Crisis With the U.S.
description: Angered by what he considers needless intensification of tension between Iraq and the United States, President Boris N. Yeltsin today dispatched a special envoy to Baghdad with orders to end the mounting crisis over weapons inspections.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm worried that Saddam Hussein, not understanding America, might be confused by the difference between headlines and the national will. We as a people are unified in our opposition to terrorism, and we are unified in our opposition to Saddam Hussein developing weapons of mass destruction.''

title: Elderly, Too, Gain From Good Schools; Intergenerational Envy
description: To the Editor:

title: Port Authority Is to Consider Bridge Parallel to the Goethals
description: With traffic between New York and New Jersey growing and the 70-year-old Goethals Bridge between Staten Island and Elizabeth jammed to capacity, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is slowly pressing ahead with plans to build a twin bridge south of the existing one.

title: $200 Million A.I.D. Pact
description: The energy and environmental consulting company Hagler Bailly Inc. said today that it had received a contract worth up to $200 million from the United States Agency for International Development. Hagler Bailly, based in Arlington, will provide energy development and environmental services in developing nations that the agency assists. The three-year contract includes a two-year option.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, IDA
description: FEINBERG-Ida. Wife of the late Jack; loving mother of Howard; mother-in-law of Selma; great grandmother of Nicholas, died January 25, 1998 in her 100th year.

title: Aksum Journal; Found in Ethiopia: Keepers of the Lost Ark
description: Like many Ethiopians, the deacon who greets visitors outside St. Mary of Zion Church here has no doubt about the exact location of the Ark of the Covenant, the most sacred object of the Old Testament and the focus of one of the greatest mysteries of all time.

title: Agassi's Run Finally Arrives at Its Finish
description: Andre Agassi, who has a pronounced fear of sharks, had everybody believing that his latest renaissance had transformed him into the most dangerous floater who could defy logic and swim upstream toward an Australian Open final. But tonight he ran into a floater even more dangerous than himself. And went belly up.

title: Electrolux Net Off 33%; Problems Abroad Cited
description: Electrolux A.B. of Sweden said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 33 percent because the company, Europe's largest maker of household appliances, paid more tax than expected and took a charge to cut jobs in Brazil and Asia. Profit fell to 286 million kronor ($36.2 million), from 426 million kronor in the corresponding period of 1996. The tax rate in the quarter rose to 64 percent from 41 percent in the 1996 period.

title: Appellate Ruling May Return Woman to Jail in a Murder Case
description: In a split decision by an appellate court, a woman who had been declared innocent of first-degree murder last spring by a Philadelphia Federal judge came one step closer yesterday to being returned to prison.

title: Rules in Flux: News Organizations Face Tough Calls on Unverified 'Facts'
description: ''Caught in the Act'': It was a banner headline that tabloid newspapers found too good to resist, a story that some news organizations stretched traditional journalistic rules to run, a rumor that others tried to substantiate and finally could not.

title: 'Seinfeld' Producers Wonder, Now What?
description: In 1988, a year after a group of bright, aggressive Hollywood executives formed Castle Rock Entertainment, they experienced one of those serendipitous twists of fortune that defines the entertainment industry. Only this was one of the most amazing in television history, the beginning not only of a hot streak, but the sort of miracle the company could use now more than ever.

title: Clinton's Motion to Move Up Trial's Start in Paula Jones Sexual Harassment Case
description: Following is President Clinton's motion for moving up the start of the sexual misconduct trial of Paula Corbin Jones, which was filed yesterday by his lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, as provided by Federal District Court in Little Rock, Ark.:

title: Canadian Energy Concerns in Deals as Merger Pace Quickens
description: Two major takeovers involving leading Canadian energy companies were announced yesterday, a reflection of the competitive pressures causing a consolidation among midsized businesses in the energy industry.

title: People
description: * Audrey Steele, vice president and manager for strategic media resources at Zenith Media Services, New York, jointly owned by Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., has been promoted to senior vice president and director for strategic media resources. She assumes duties from Betsy Frank, now executive vice president for research and development at MTV Networks, New York, a unit of Viacom Inc.

title: Separate Jobs for Blind Spur a Spirited Debate
description: On the fourth floor of a factory in Long Island City, Queens, Clifton Harrell deftly handles heavy machinery to trim, bend and assemble toilet bowl brushes, 150 dozen a day. His hands are a blur; his body, a study in efficient motion.

title: From Estonia and Japan, in Harmony
description: New Yorkers used to catch up on regional ballet through seasons devoted to troupes from different parts of the country. Nowadays only the occasional company can afford to drop in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, ALAN G.
description: MILLSTEIN-Alan G. On Friday, January 23, 1998. Dear friend, former husband. A man of piercing intelligence, uncommon wit, unique perspective, with wide interests in art, theater, the cinema, and a love of New York City. I am eternally grateful to him for always making me laugh and for introducing me to a world of beauty and fashion and glamour, which changed my life only for the better. ''At the round earth's imagin'd corners, blow Your trumpets, Angells, and arise, arise from death ...and you whose eyes, Shall behold God, and never taste deaths woe.'' Anne Taylor Davis Millstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEU, HAROLD CONRAD, M.D.
description: NEU-Harold Conrad, M.D. Of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Husband of Dr. Carmen Neu, father of Maria Rorer, Harold A. Neu and Natalie Neu, M.D. Mass 10 AM Wednesday, St. Matthews Church, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Visiting Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford (Saw Mill Ext 17), Dobbs Ferry, NY Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorials to Harold C. Neu, M.D., Professorship at Columbia University preferred.

title: Yankee Pitcher on Lookout for Trade
description: Eric Milton, one of the Yankees' highly regarded pitching prospects, has compiled a mental scrapbook of trade rumors that include his name. First, he was discussed in a possible deal for pitcher Pedro Martinez. Now he is being talked about in negotiations with Minnesota, for second baseman Chuck Knoblauch.

title: As Hearings Open, Broader Issues Rest on Sprewell's Case
description: John D. Feerick, the dean of Fordham Law School, will begin to hear testimony Tuesday on Latrell Sprewell's one-year suspension by the National Basketball Association and the termination of his contract by the Golden State Warriors.

title: Black Football Coaches
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, HERBERT
description: SCHWARZ-Herbert. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Herbert Schwarz, a past President and Board Member. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest condolences to his family. Andrew J. Frankel, President Judith Weil, Secretary

title: Accounts
description: * Lyon's Restaurants, Foster City, Calif., to Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young, San Francisco, as agency of record on the account of the chain of 79 casual dining restaurants, which had been handled by Evans, Hardy & Young, Santa Barbara, Calif. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Green To Stay As Coach Of Vikings
description: The Minnesota Vikings and Coach Dennis Green have worked out an agreement in which Green, who threatened to quit, will return to the team for at least the 1998 season, according to Vikings officials.

title: Poetic Justice for Sylvia Plath
description: The publication this month of Ted Hughes's ''Birthday Letters,'' a book of poems about his marriage to the poet Sylvia Plath, has a millennial feel. In the war between men and women, art that reveals the intimate life of certain couples in literature sometimes achieves the status of relevant information (far removed though their experience is from the intimate lives of exclusively public figures).

title: G.M. Reports Strong 4th-Quarter Earnings
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that its earnings in the fourth quarter more than doubled to $1.74 billion, or $2.33 a share, from $786 million, or 91 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Despite the improvement, the numbers failed to wow Wall Street, since the results were roughly in line with analysts' expectations.

title: Former S.E.C. Lawyer Gets Jail Term
description: A former Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer was sentenced last week to 18 months in jail for taking part in a stock-fraud scheme he himself had investigated for the Government.

title: Randolph Symonette, Opera Baritone, 88
description: Randolph Symonette, a baritone who sang at the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera, died on Jan. 1 at Willow Place, a nursing home in Windsor, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FANSLER, JAYSON
description: FANSLER-Jayson. On January 25, 1998. Outstanding teacher, beloved friend. Your struggle is over. May God bless you. We love you. A memorial service will be held at Fashion Industries High School, 225 West 24 Street, New York City on February 26 at 3:30 P.M.

title: A Time and Place for Everything
description: Mike Shanahan danced on stage at the Broncos' post-Super Bowl victory party, celebrating the moment with all the team's employees well into the wee hours of the night. But while Shanahan spent time at the party with John Elway, he didn't ask his 37-year-old quarterback if he planned to retire.

title: 'Gay' Sailor's Dismissal Is Blocked
description: In a decision hailed by gay rights groups and advocates of electronic privacy, a Federal judge ordered the Navy today to halt its efforts to dismiss a highly decorated sailor because he posted a message on an on-line computer service that described his marital status as gay.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, misstated the role of Robert Redford in its formation. In 1985, Mr. Redford and his Sundance Institute took over the United States Film Festival, which had existed since 1978, and renamed it; he was not the founder.

title: Flyers Are the Wrong Medicine for the Islanders' Woes
description: Facing the Flyers, a team that has three of the top goal scorers in the National Hockey League, nothing less than the Islanders' best performance in more than a month would have sufficed.

title: The State of New York City's Parks
description: New York City's Parks Commissioner, Henry Stern, delivered a State of the Parks address last week and concluded that the state was very good. Thanks to thousands of workfare participants, cleanliness is up. Broken playground equipment has been replaced. The backlog of dangerous dead trees along city streets has dropped dramatically. Rollerblade Inc. has donated $1.6 million in cash and equipment to become the official in-line skate of New York City parks. The list goes on.

title: 'Who's a Jew' Puzzle Gets More Tangled
description: The bitter dispute over who can perform conversions to Judaism has deepened, with two competing proposals now before the Chief Rabbis of Israel.

title: Private Group Offers Bonus Pay As a Spur to City's Public Schools
description: Borrowing an idea from the boardroom to help New York City's troubled classrooms, one of the city's largest business groups announced yesterday that it would offer $30 million to fatten the salaries of hundreds of superintendents, principals and teachers if they are able to raise students' academic performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, REV. DR. SAMUEL
description: AUSTIN-Rev. Dr. Samuel. On January 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Naomi Austin, loving father of Samuel Austin, Jr., dearest brother of Ira Austin Tatum, and dedicated Pastor of the Brown Memorial Baptist Church for 24 years. Funeral service will be held Thursday, January 29, 12 noon at Brown Memorial Baptist Church, 484 Washington Ave, Brooklyn, NY. Visitation Wednesday 12 noon8PM at the Church. Interment Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo, NY. Merritt Green & Jefferson Funeral Home, 718-622-5964.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ESTHER R.
description: STEIN-Esther R. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of NY mourn the passing of Esther R. Stein, beloved mother of Martin M. Stein, a dedicated leader and generous supporter of UJA-Federation and a member of our Apparel Division's Executive Committee. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Stein family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P. Sheldon Ratner & Sy Bleckman, Co-Chairs, Apparel Division

title: Weapons Inspection Chief Tells of Iraqi Tricks
description: Last month in Iraq, United Nations weapons inspectors thought they were closing in on a long-sought prize: computer hard drives that contained the records of Iraq's entire program of weapons of mass destruction, the program at the center of the current standoff.

title: Mrs. Clinton in Harlem: A Portrait of Resilience
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton kept to her smiling round of tours in behalf of needy children today, offering the nation no revealing words but a steadfast bearing as her First Lady's defense of her scandal-embattled President.

title: Detective Mike Hoolihan? She's Tough
description: NIGHT TRAIN

title: Yankees Are Still Talking With Twins on Knoblauch
description: Stalled in attempts to trade for Randy Johnson, the dominant pitcher from Seattle, the Yankees have resumed their pursuit of Chuck Knoblauch, Minnesota's All-Star second baseman.

title: Endgame on Iraq
description: Saddam Hussein's efforts to keep United Nations inspectors away from his biological weapons programs have brought the United States to the edge of military action. Clinton Administration officials warn that a series of punishing air strikes could begin in a matter of weeks, if a last-minute campaign of intensified diplomacy and sanctions fails to force Iraq to obey U.N. Security Council resolutions. With a British aircraft carrier joining a powerful American naval task force in nearby waters, a credible capacity for heavy and sustained air attacks is already in place.

title: Davenport Ousts Williams After Scare
description: She as looking to improve on the Cinderella tale she created last summer at the United States Open, where she woke up stoked and found herself in her first tournament final. But Venus Williams failed to stay stoked today in her Australian Open quarterfinal match against second-seeded Lindsay Davenport.

title: How the Mighty Fell
description: Sunday's Super Bowl made the perils of overconfidence painfully clear. Touted as an incipient dynasty and a shoo-in for their second championship in two years, the Green Bay Packers waltzed into San Diego for a star turn. By the end of the day, they were beaten by a Denver Broncos team that had smoldered under Packer smugness and bristled at odds-makers who had buried them on paper.

title: Elderly, Too, Gain From Good Schools; Protection for Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Wins Tournament On Path to Women's Title
description: Alisa Galliamova of Russia won the Candidates Tournament for the Women's World Championship in Groningen, the Netherlands, Dec. 9 to 29, but that did not guarantee her a title match with Zsuzsa Polgar of Queens, the women's world champion.

title: After Steady Start, Romania's Centrist Government Begins to Falter
description: A former geology professor and trade union leader came to power here as President and Prime Minister more than a year ago, riding a popular wave of hope and pride.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Airlines Form Alliance

title: Investors Remain Cautious As Questions Cloud Markets
description: Wall Street and Main Street are locked in the cautious mode.

title: Last Half-Hour Rang the Nielsen Bell
description: Despite a counterprogramming challenge mounted by TBS's marathon showing of ''The Andy Griffith Show,'' NBC's Super Bowl telecast on Sunday eked by with a 44.5 national Nielsen rating, the 13th best in the game's history.

title: Where Heroes Camped, Ancient Cornmeal and Penguins
description: JUDGING from the look of things, the great British explorer Ernest Shackleton and his men left the place a mess when they set out from their hut here in 1908 for the South Pole.

title: Foreign Affairs; Character Suicide
description: I understand that Paula Jones is not a choir girl. I understand that Linda Tripp is motivated by an intense dislike for the President. I understand that Lucianne Goldberg was seeking more than just truth. I understand that Kenneth Starr is a partisan Republican out to get the President. I understand that Monica Lewinsky was a naive 21-year-old intern who may have exaggerated her relationship with Bill Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAHAN, JOHN PAUL, III
description: MONAHAN-John Paul, III. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of John Paul Monahan, III, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDLIN, STEVE
description: HINDLIN-Steve. Died January 26, 1998. Beloved father of Elizabeth Rinkus and Michael Hindlin, grandfather of Ryan and Mariel, husband of Joyce, brother of Yvette Heyman. Services Tuesday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Patterns
description: Effort Shifts for Bryant Park

title: Ben C. Morris, 67, Fashion Illustrator
description: Ben C. Morris, a professor of fashion design at the Savannah College of Art and Design who had an earlier career as a fashion illustrator, died on Jan. 5 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Savannah, Ga. He was 67 and lived in Savannah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOGGETT, PATRICIA (NEE MANNING)
description: DOGGETT-Patricia (nee Manning). Of Oldwick, N.J. On January 21, 1998. Survived by her husband, Albert K., daughters, Cynthia Ehrenclou and Shelby Mellick, son, Scott, and nine grandchildren. Memorial service January 30, 11 AM, Lamington Presbyterian Church, Bedminster, NJ. Memorial gifts Hunterdon Hospice, 2100 Wescott Drive, Flemington, N.J. 08822.

title: CIENA IN $52.4 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR ATI TELECOM
description: The Ciena Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire ATI Telecom International Ltd., which is closely held, for $52.4 million in stock to expand its telecommunications equipment and service business. Ciena, based in Linthicum, Md., said it would issue 890,400 shares of its stock for ATI, based in Norcross, Ga. Ciena's shares fell $4.375 yesterday, to $54.50 Both companies provide equipment and services to customers, including telephone companies, to help them increase the amount of information they can transmit through fiber optic networks.

title: GGT Is in Talks To Be Acquired
description: GGT Group P.L.C. in London acknowledged yesterday that it was in talks to be acquired, just days after the loss of an important client fueled speculation that the agency company might be purchased.

title: Clinton's Comments Denying an Affair
description: Following are comments over the last few days by President Clinton denying accusations that he had had a sexual relationship with a White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, including comments in interviews with ''The News Hour'' on PBS, National Public Radio and Roll Call, a newspaper that covers Capitol Hill:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, EDWARD
description: GOTTLIEB-Edward. Your generosity to the community at large was only surpassed by your generosity of counsel, caring and love to your family. We miss you and mourn the loss of our wonderful brother, uncle and cousin. Dorothy Gottlieb-Fox, Beatrice Fein, Marilyn Fein Schwartz and all the Gottlieb clan

title: Denver's Dot on Map Swells in the Afterglow
description: Cow town no more, Denver today was the Broncos' town.

title: Japan Property Concern To Liquidate Subsidiary
description: The Mitsui Fudosan Company, a Japanese real estate company, said yesterday that it would take a charge of 57 billion yen ($456 million) for the year ending on March 31 to liquidate its money-losing financial subsidiary. The company said it had given up on rescuing Mitsui Fudosan Finance Ltd. as competition from banks grew and as debt repayment by debtors dwindled. The company provided 80 billion yen to the unit, a housing loan subsidiary, four years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Sunday about a legal settlement between the Educational Testing Service and the Kaplan Educational Centers, arising from Kaplan's covert effort to demonstrate a potential security problem with the service's computerized exams, misidentified the test involved. It was the Graduate Record Examination, not the S.A.T.

title: Chelsea Clinton Cheers Consoler
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson spoke with President Clinton's daughter, Chelsea, twice over the weekend to cheer her up, Mr. Jackson's spokesman said today. But it was Mr. Jackson who was buoyed by the talks, the spokesman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MICHAEL
description: GORDON-Michael. On January 25, 1998. Chairman of Koret Inc. for 31 years. Beloved father of Lord, Robert and Jennifer and grandfather of Michael. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Thursday, January 29 at 1:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIN, BARBARA BETTY
description: HEIN-Barbara Betty. Of Thornwood, NY. On January 25, 1998. Beloved and devoted wife of Harold for fifty years. Cherished and loving mother of Richard, Robert, Steven and Loren and mother-inlaw of Julia and Michelle. Adored and adoring grandmother of Emily. Her warmth, intelligence and incomparable courage will be remembered by all who knew her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St on Tuesday between 7 and 9 PM. Services will be held there on Wednesday at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Lab of Leukemia Research at SloanKettering Memorial Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERR, FRANCES
description: SHERR-Frances. Congregation Kol Ami of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member, and conveys sincere condolences to her bereaved friends and family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark Hershey, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JABLIN, JULIAN N.
description: JABLIN-Julian N. of Skokie, IL. Beloved husband of the late Ann. Loving father of Lee. Service Wednesday 12 noon at Weinstein Family Services Chapel, 111 Skokie Blvd, Wilmette, IL. Interment Shalom Memorial Park, Arlington Heights, IL. Info: 847-256-5700

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR REBOUNDS. The dollar reversed early losses to rally sharply on President Clinton's more forceful denial of wrongdoing in the White House sex scandal and hints from a senior Bundesbank offical that German interest rates would not rise. In New York, the dollar rose 1 percent, to 1.7956 marks.

title: No Illusions for Historian and Friend of Bill
description: THESE are odd days for Taylor Branch, the biographer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and friend and occasional speechwriter to President Clinton. Mr. Branch has spent the last 15 years of his life on Dr. King, and more than most writers has thought about the public consequences of private behavior. Dr. King, after all, endangered both himself and his civil rights movement with sexual indiscretions that were recorded by J. Edgar Hoover's F.B.I. and used against him as blackmail.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CORP., Orange, Calif., a drug distributor, received a five-year contract from United Drugs, an independent drug-buying group, that could produce new revenue of more than $600 million annually.

title: Studying Aging in Space? Send an Aging Astronaut
description: BACK when John Glenn joined the astronaut corps, as the United States prepared for its first urgent forays into space, he and his fellow pilots took a notoriously dim view of the men in white, the doctors who could ground them for medical cause.

title: Listening to the President
description: There is no use pretending otherwise -- Bill Clinton's appearance before the nation tonight to deliver the State of the Union address cannot help but be an awkward occasion for the President and the American people. Much attention will be given to whether Mr. Clinton makes any mention of the accusations of criminal and sexual misconduct that have transfixed Washington for the last week. Everything from Hillary Rodham Clinton's expression to the level of applause in the House chamber will be closely watched. Neither the media nor the public can be blamed for this. They are not the ones who made listening to the chief executive into a semantic guessing game. Even so, it would be a disservice to the country if Mr. Clinton's policy statements are not closely attended to.

title: On My Mind; The Scandal and Iraq
description: The President and the prosecutor now have the same obligation to their country -- to deal with this nasty business fast, fast. The clock of highest national interest is running.

title: Pricey Theater Preview
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Is Compassion in the Abortion Debate?; Wisdom of Abstinence
description: To the Editor:

title: Losing Their Place
description: What a difference a month (and a fresh scandal) make.

title: All Eyes Find the Book Agent
description: ''I'm trying to decide, is it my party or Lucianne's party?'' the writer LINDA WOLFE was saying.

title: A Veteran Fighter Returns to the Ring, and Finds His Corner With Ease
description: When Gennifer Flowers sent the Clinton Presidential campaign to the precipice in 1992 with her account of a long-running affair with the Arkansas Governor, the candidate dispatched a loyal, pugnacious lawyer with a highly attuned political ear to rescue his drive in New Hampshire: Mickey Kantor.

title: Prices Rally After Friday's Sharp Selloff as Dollar Gains
description: Bond prices rallied yesterday and the dollar rebounded a little as investors seemed to shift their attention to the positive economic fundamentals supporting both markets.

title: Man on Work Release Charged in Girl's Rape
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl was raped last week by a family friend who was out of prison on a work-release program, the police said yesterday.

title: American Lugers Find Perfect Fit
description: When the season began, Mark Grimmette and Brian Martin were genuinely worried about making the American Olympic luge team. Two months later, they are one of the gold-medal favorites in doubles after winning four of the six World Cup races and the overall World Cup title.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SURGES. Crude oil prices, which have fallen nearly a third since Oct. 3, soared 7 percent -- the biggest rally since June 1996 -- after the United States said it was considering a military strike against Iraq. Crude oil for March delivery rose $1.08, to $16.82 a barrel in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURMAN, SALLY
description: GURMAN-Sally. On January 25, 1998. The wife of the late Joseph and dear mother of the late Eugene. Also loving mother of Evelyn Altman. Dear grandmother of Dr. Robin Altman, Andrew Altman, Elylm Gurman Altman and Gary Prish. Devoted great grandmother of Evan Joseph and Clara Alexis Prish. Family said, ''She was a great fighter''. Funeral services were held privately Monday at United Hebrew Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILER, GEORGE A.
description: WEILER-George A. 83. Of NY City and Garrison, NY on January 25. Beloved husband of Barbara Carroll, devoted father of Jane and John Weiler and Ellen Stiefler, loving grandfather of Zachary, Timothy and Robert Stiefler, Daniel and Joshua Schneider-Weiler and Margaret Weiler; born Deal NJ; graduate of Yale College, 1935, and Fordham Law School, 1941. He was a Deputy Assistant Corporation Counsel of the NYC Law Department, retiring 1987 after 37 years service as a trial defense counsel; a veteran of World War II; defense counsel in 1945 Japanese War Crimes Trials; in charge of procurement 1951 - 52 during Korean conflict in the Armed Forces Security Agency and the National Security Agency. Retired Lt. Colonel Army Signal Corps. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Parkinson Disease Fndn., Wm. Black Med. Rsrch Bldg, 650 W. 168th St., NY, NY 10032. Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, Feb. 20, 1:30 P.M. Private burial in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHMAWY, SEIF
description: ASHMAWY-Seif. The Board of Directors and staff of the Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding note, with sorrow, the passing of our cherished Advisory Board member, Seif Ashmawy. Seif, an Egyptian immigrant who came to the U.S. in pursuit of freedom, was a constant, vocal and courageous force for understanding and reconciliation betweeen Muslims and those of other faiths. Our hearts go out to his wife Maria and his son Omar, who we know will continue in his footsteps. Georgette Bennett, Ph.D. President

title: Republicans Back Clinton on the Use Of Force on Iraqis
description: The Republican leadership in Congress lined up behind President Clinton's Iraq policy today, saying the scandal absorbing the White House should not be allowed to affect America's response to a foreign-policy problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWALD, DOROTHY B.
description: ROSENWALD-Dorothy B. Died January 24, 1998, after a long illness in her Kings Bay, Tobago, home at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late James B. Rosenwald, she is survived by her daughter Patricia R. Heller and her husband Ben of New York City and Sharon, CT, her son James B. Rosenwald, Jr., and his wife Mimi of Ossining, NY, her sister Eleanor B. Handwerger and niece Blair Walker of Longmeadow, MA. She was a caring, loving grandmother of ten and great-grandmother of ten. A service in her memory is to be scheduled at a later date. Memorial contributions can be made to the Ackerman Institute for the Family or the Irvington Institute for Immunological Research, both of New York City.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Wednesday in the Footlights column of the Arts section about a festival next summer in the Paris suburb of St.-Denis misidentified a Robert Wilson rock operetta that is to be presented. It is ''Saints and Singing,'' not ''Saints and Sinners.''

title: Former Aide to Carey and Cuomo Enters Race for Governor
description: James L. Larocca, a former commissioner in the administrations of Governors Carey and Cuomo, formally declared his candidacy for governor today and said he would have enough support within the Democratic Party to guarantee him a spot in a statewide primary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, RALPH
description: NEUMAN-Ralph. Loving father of Elaine Reiser. Devoted grandfather of David Reiser, Barbara D'Innocenzo, Jonathan Reiser and Leonore Reiser. Adoring greatgrandfather of Krista and Patrick. Service Tuesday, 12 noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, GERALDYNE (NEE MURPHY)
description: WALSH-Geraldyne (nee Murphy). Of Riverdale, New York. Died January 25, 1998 at the age of 86. Retired Asst. Librarian at Elizabeth Seton College, Yonkers, New York. Beloved wife of the late Eugene. Dear daughter of the late Francis and Clara Murphy. Cherished aunt to Frank J. Murphy. Reposing Tues. 2-4 and 7-9PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue (at West 261 Street), Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 10AM at St. Gabriel's Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: In Harlem, Mrs. Clinton Wins Laurels For Loyalty
description: Some people may believe that Hillary Rodham Clinton ought to empty her husband's closets and toss his duds into the Rose Garden, but in the huge St. Nicholas housing project in Harlem, the First Lady was esteemed yesterday for being as constant as salt in the sea, as faithful as a sidekick in an old Western.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYNES, JOY HATTON.
description: HAYNES-Joy Hatton. Dear friends, we lost our Joy to cancer on January 10, 1998 at her home in Manhattan. She was a singer/actress to the cognoscenti; she was a wife and an agent/manager to her late beloved Tiger Haynes; and she was a loyal pal/ buddy/friend to a whole lot of people. You all know who you are. She is survived by her devoted sister, Betty Charland, of West Palm Beach, Florida, one niece and three nephews. Nobody was ever more suitably named than Joy, and nobody will be more missed. A Times critic once wrote that her act at Reno Sweeney was ''unusually well-rounded and provocatively realized''. We who loved her think her life was, too. A memorial event will be announced.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Before Super Sunday, Raids, Then Arrests
description: It was another eventful, if predictable, Super Bowl week in Brooklyn for Eddie Galanek. It did not involve touchdowns or 12-foot sandwiches. He did not win the office pool. The week, instead, brought what it always does for him: arrests.

title: Master Class for Budding Scientists
description: It is becoming a rite as certain as the ebb and flow of the tides of Long Island Sound just up the road.

title: Camden Hospital Begins Anti-Violence Effort
description: Starting next month, Cooper Hospital/University Medical Center in Camden will begin training members of the city's churches to counsel victims of violence against taking revenge on their assailants, hospital officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, THOMAS J.
description: CANNON-Thomas J. Of Montclair, N.J. On January 27, 1998. Husband of the late Mary. Father of Thomas J., III. Also survived by a grandson, Thomas J., IV. Brother of John B. and the late Jimmy Cannon. Funeral from the Huge M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park St, Montclair, Thursday, 9AM, then to Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair where, at 10AM, a Mass of Christian Burial will be offered. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. Visiting 79P.M. Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM Wednesday.

title: 4 Convicted in Corruption At Union for Transit Police
description: A Federal jury convicted four men yesterday of corrupting the union that once represented the city's transit police officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, HARVEY
description: BLANK-Harvey. The Society for the Advancement of Judaism records with profound sorrow the untimely death of our devoted member, Harvey Blank, husband of Shelley and father of Jeffrey and David. Julie Schonfeld, Rabbi Lawrence Budish, Bd Chairman

title: Clinton Emphatically Denies an Affair With Ex-Intern: Reports of Visit Despite Limits on Access
description: Monica S. Lewinsky met privately with President Clinton in the White House late last month, even though Administration officials had previously ordered that her access be restricted, according to both a former White House official and an associate of Ms. Lewinsky.

title: Review/Fashion; Touches of Spice In a Tepid Stew
description: In this city, where the skies have been as wan as the men's collections for fall that concluded here yesterday, designers struggled to find a place in the fashion firmament between powerhouse Italian tailoring and populist American sportswear.

title: Review/Fashion; French Couture Sets Pace Again
description: One could almost hear the computers tapping, faxes whirring, telephones ringing and photographers' cameras clicking as they raced to record a couture season more relevant than any in a long time. A newly energized couture has become a focal point again for inspiration and trends.

title: TMB AFFILIATE TO BUY A BUSINESS FROM ITT INDUSTRIES
description: ITT Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its precision die-casting business to Lester Precision Die Castings Inc., a Solon, Ohio, affiliate of the privately held TMB Industries of Chicago. Financial terms were not disclosed. The business, which makes structural castings for the automotive industry, had about $150 million in sales in 1997. ITT Automotive, the unit conducting the sale, said the deal was part of its strategy to shed noncore businesses. ITT Industries, a diversified manufacturing company based in White Plains, had 1996 sales of $8.71 billion. Its shares fell $1 yesterday, to $30.0625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, HENRY J.
description: CAMPBELL-Henry J. We mourn with sadness our past-chairman, and celebrate his tireless efforts on behalf of the Guide Dog Foundation and those we serve. Our hearts are with Betty and family. Board of Directors, Staff and Graduates Guide Dog Foundation For The Blind

title: An Unlikely Legal Team Puts the Ball in Starr's Court
description: After an agonizing week in which she huddled with her mother at their Watergate apartment, Monica S. Lewinsky emerged this morning, stepped into a black Lincoln town car and rode to a nondescript office building on K Street.

title: Compaq Is Buying Digital, Aiming Challenge at I.B.M.
description: In the largest takeover in the history of the computer industry, the Compaq Computer Corporation, the No. 1 maker of personal computers, agreed yesterday to buy the Digital Equipment Corporation, a declining maker of large corporate machines, for $9.6 billion in cash and stock.

title: $390 Million Ship Order
description: Costa Crociere S.p.A. ordered a $390 million, 2,100-passenger ship from Kvaerner A.S.A., a British-Norwegian construction and shipbuilding company, as the cruise line's new owners seek to increase its share of the growing European cruise market. The 82,000-ton ship will be the eighth in the fleet of the cruise ship operator, based here. The Carnival Corporation, which is based in Miami, and Airtours P.L.C., which is based in Manchester, England, bought 82 percent of Costa Crociere for $258 million in June.

title: In a First, Schools Report on Funds Spent, and Not Spent
description: For the first time, the New York City Board of Education released detailed reports of actual school spending yesterday, and the documents showed that school officials refrained from spending about $200 million last year because they were concerned about shortfalls this year.

title: Clinton Job Rating Remains High Despite Doubts on Moral Values
description: The accusations that President Clinton had an affair with a White House intern have not dimmed the public's view of how he is handling his job, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken over the weekend.

title: Executive Changes
description: SUN MICROSYSTEMS INC., Palo Alto, Calif., promoted Edward J. Zander, the head of its computer business, to chief operating officer, overseeing all its engineering, research and development, manufacturing operations, marketing, sales, service and support.

title: By Design; Flutterings of Summer
description: Butterflies and dragonflies were popular themes for Art Nouveau jewelry -- and are again this spring, for clothing designers like Giorgio Armani and Dolce & Gabbana. The beguiling insects are also alighting on a variety of accessories.

title: Clinton Proposes Spending $25 Billion on Education
description: President Clinton proposed today to spend nearly $25 billion over the next decade on reducing class sizes in elementary schools, building and renovating schools and addressing a variety of other problems in the nation's education system.

title: The Poetry of the Pharmacopeia: Often Subtle and Subliminal
description: ANYONE worried that managed care is pushing the poetry right out of medicine need only browse through the the 1998 Physicians' Desk Reference for a dose of quick relief. This 3,223-page guide to all the prescription drugs available in the United States attests to the deep wellsprings of creativity that still underlie the healing arts.

title: Where Is Compassion in the Abortion Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Inventively Sawing His Way

title: Atonality Inevitable? A Piece That Says So
description: Schoenberg can be heard in his Second String Quartet writing not just music but, at the same time, music history. His place in that history (and, still in his early 30's, he was absolutely confident he had a place in it) was to show how the development of music led inevitably to atonality.

title: PECO ENERGY TO REDUCE DIVIDEND BY 20 CENTS A SHARE
description: The Peco Energy Company, a utility that serves Philadelphia and southeastern Pennsylvania, said yesterday that it would cut its dividend from 45 cents a share to 25 cents a share effective with the first-quarter dividend, payable on March 31. Corbin A. McNeill Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said the cut was being made because of an order by the Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission to open the state to competition. He said the order would lead to a substantial loss in value of Peco's assets because it would not allow the utility to recover the decline in value of its generating plants. Shares of Peco closed yesterday at $22.50, down 18.75 cents.

title: Book Finds a Place
description: What's a nice diva like DAME JOAN SUTHERLAND doing having her autobiography published by Regnery Publishing, the conservative Washington house that has been linked to Ms. Goldberg?

title: A Divided Response To Hughes Poems
description: ''My silence seems to confirm every accusation and fantasy,'' the poet Ted Hughes once wrote, referring to his fierce, decadeslong refusal to discuss his relationship with Sylvia Plath publicly. ''I preferred it, on the whole, to allowing myself to be dragged out into the bullring and teased and pricked and goaded into vomiting up every detail of my life with Sylvia.''

title: American Sprinters Outline Goals
description: If Maurice Greene and Tim Montgomery had announced a year ago that they expected to break the world records for 60 meters indoors and 100 meters outdoors, most people would have laughed. They had hope, but few credentials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, FANNY
description: JACOBSON-Fanny. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Devoted mother of Myron and Miriam, Sanford and Phyllis. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Dear sister of Harry, David and Milton Schiffman and the late Miriam Newman. Services Tuesday 9:45am at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: ROCK
description: Chanteuse Who Carries

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some copies yesterday about a baritone who sang with the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera misstated his first name and misidentified the university where he was a professor. He was Randolph Symonette, not Ralph, and he taught at Florida State University, not at the University of Florida. A corrected obituary appears today on page A17.

title: A Deep Weariness in Little Rock
description: There is a pervasive weariness in this city and state so linked in identity to Bill Clinton, a bloodshot civic exhaustion as palpable as that in any hospital waiting room.

title: City Prohibits Firecrackers In Chinatown For 2d Year
description: Tomorrow is the beginning of the Year of the Tiger in the Chinese lunar calendar, but on the streets of Chinatown, it will be another New Year's celebrated in relative silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODEN, EDRITA. (NEE POKORNY)
description: ODEN-Edrita. (nee Pokorny) Died Jan. 25, 1998, at her residence in OKC. She was born in Shawnee, OK on Oct 29, 1931, the daughter of Edward and Arita Pokorny. She grew up in Ada, OK. She received her B.A. in Theater Arts at the University of Oklahoma, with an excellent record of achievement, including Mortar Board. She represented O.U. as a co-star with David Niven in a drama competition that was broadcast nationwide by NBC radio. She served Drew University of Madison, NJ as its alumni director, and later served as a public relations consultant. She was involved in the homeless mission work at her home church, Madison United Methodist Church, Madison, N.J. She is much loved and remembered especially for her quick wit, story-telling ability, and charity. She is survived by her husband, Thomas Clark Oden, whom she married on August 10, 1952, two sons, Clark, of OKC, and Edward, of Charlotte, N.C., and a daughter, Laura of Anchorage, AK. Funeral services were held in Oklahoma City, OK.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHENBERGER, ANDREE
description: REICHENBERGER-Andree. On January 23, in Los Altos, CA., formerly of Great Neck, N.Y. Loving and devoted wife of Fred, Dearly beloved mother of Dorothy and Bernice, grandmother of Sonya and Benjamin, great grandmother of Henry. Interment and service at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I., on Tuesday at 1 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Save the Children Federation.

title: A Rush Away From Judgment; Juror Who Helped Convict a Man Now Pays for His Appeal
description: Twice a week, June M. Briere drives two hours across the state to visit Adrian D. Santiago in prison. As they talk -- he in halting English, she occasionally correcting his grammar -- she fills him in on the appeal of his murder conviction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, REUBEN AARON
description: KATZ - Reuben Aaron. Died peacefully in his sleep from heart failure. Born in Manhattan, July 29, 1917, he served in the U.S. Army in WWII. Practiced for fifty years as an attorney in New York City until 1989 and, along with his surviving wife, Evelyn Katz, raised three children, Jeffrey, Steven and Andrew. Memorial services are to be held Tuesday, January 27th, 3:15 P.M., at Beth David Memorial Gardens in Hollywood, FL.

title: High Court to Hear Dispute On Opening Phone Markets
description: Warned by the Federal Communications Commission that the future of local telephone competition was at stake, the Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that sharply limited the commission's role in opening up the $100 billion market for local telephone service to new players.

title: Israelis to Discuss Phasing Out 1.2 Billion U.S. Economic Aid
description: The Israeli Finance Minister will be meeting with Congressional and Administration officials in Washington this week to discuss phasing out America's $1.2 billion in economic aid to Israel starting in the year 2000, according to Congressional officials and Jewish organizations.

title: Clinton Emphatically Denies an Affair With Ex-Intern: Lawyers Say He Is Distracted by Events
description: With eyes narrowed and one index finger stabbing the air, President Clinton angrily denied today that he had had sexual relations with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern whose tape-recorded accounts of an affair with him now threaten his Presidency.

title: Metro Business; Lipton to Phase Out Plant in New Jersey
description: Lipton of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said yesterday that it would close a manufacturing and distribution plant in Flemington, N.J., eliminating 575 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINSTEIN, HAIM
description: DINSTEIN-Haim. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University mourn the passing, in Israel, of Haim Dinstein, the beloved father of the President of Tel Aviv University, Professor Yoram Dinstein. Haim Dinstein was a distinguished Israeli lawyer who practiced law until his 90s. During his youth in Russia he was an ardent Zionist leader and was imprisoned for his Zionist activities. He came to Israel from Russia in 1924 and was one of the founding fathers of the pre-State Jewish community in Palestine. He was a man of great virtue and integrity who along with his wife, lived exemplary lives and bestowed upon their children a love of decency and a great respect for humanity. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, sons, daughter, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University Bernard Rapoport, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvin S. Taub, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Topchik, President Jules Love, Executive Vice Pres

title: International Herald Tribune Appoints 2 to Top Positions
description: The New York Times and The Washington Post companies announced management changes yesterday at The International Herald Tribune, their jointly owned daily, including the appointment of Peter C. Goldmark Jr., former president of the Rockefeller Foundation, as chairman and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHLER, ANDRE
description: HIRSCHLER-Andre. Peacefully, on January 25, 1998 at the age of 87. Beloved husband of Marion, devoted father of Charles and Philip, dear father-in-law of Marianne Rosenberg and Carina Alberti Hirschler, grandfather of Tatiana, Maia, Cecile and Pierre. Funeral arrangements are private.

title: The 40 Westinghouse Science Talent Search Finalists
description: Following are the 40 finalists in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, their schools and their hometowns.

title: Sports of The Times; The Broncos' Climb From Nowhere
description: THE man in the hotel elevator held up a football with John Elway's signature on it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IAMS, SAMUEL H.
description: IAMS-Samuel H. (Jack) 15/11/1910 to 27/1/1990

title: Elderly, Too, Gain From Good Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVKOV, RUTH
description: LEVKOV-Ruth. Age 102. Lover of life, loved by all, ready to laugh and play. Singer of songs, card player extraordinaire. Beloved of her husband Joe, daughter Renee, son Jerry, son-in-law Norman, grandchildren Andy, Harvey, Chip, Josh, Jessie, greatgrandchildren Amy, Robyn, Brian, Jacob and Kara. Hulya, hulya kinderlach spiel veil du kenst, vie zeit von zummertsu vinter gehet vie a katz-springt. Shiva from Tuesday to Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, DR. IRVING A.
description: BECK-Dr. Irving A. January 25, 1998. Residence 700 Smith St. Providence. Beloved husband of Edith (Woodhead) Beck. Devoted father of Louise Beck of Kinsington, NH. Ruth Beck of East Greenwich; Barbara D. Beck of Watertown, MA; and the late Stephen Milton Beck. Dear brother of Aaron T. Beck of Philadelphia, PA; Maurice Beck of MI. and the late Bernard Beck and Beatrice Beck. Loving grandfather of James and Kate Bahn; Allison and Spencer Longo; and Shimon, Jennifer and Michael Bashki. Funeral services were held Monday at the Max Sugarman Memorial Chapel, 458 Hope St. (corner of Doyle Ave) Providence. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Brown University Medical School. Shiva will be be observed at the Village at Elmhurst, 700 Smith St., Providence, Monday, 7-9 P.M. Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 P.M.

title: Building a Championship on a Loss
description: Their confidence was brimming, their egos were primed and their designs on winning the Super Bowl were well crafted. The Lombardi trophy seemed only a fingertip away. These were the Denver Broncos. But not the Broncos who beat the Green Bay Packers, 31-24, in Super Bowl XXXII on Sunday. These were the Broncos of 1996. After opening the season with 12 victories in 13 games and finishing with more victories (13) than any other American Football Conference team, they prepared for playoff action at home against the Jacksonville Jaguars.

title: Top Court Rules on False Denial of Guilt
description: The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that an untrue denial of guilt under questioning by a Federal investigator can be prosecuted as a crime under the Federal false-statements law.

title: AT&T Maps Its Battle Plan For Escalating Phone Wars
description: For the first time publicly explaining his strategy for revitalizing the AT&T Corporation, C. Michael Armstrong, the company's new chairman, said yesterday that he would not only reduce his work force by up to 14 percent but would also offer a panoply of new services, including cheap phone calls over the Internet and wireless phones that will receive calls free.

title: A Star Went to Find Inspiration: Little Did He Know
description: It was another sleepy Monday morning after eight performances in six days, and Hinton Battle had arrived at Penn Station in New York in a state of yawn. ''It's so early,'' he said as commuters scrambled by. ''I should still be in bed.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, ADELE (NEE SEGAL)
description: CHASE-Adele (nee Segal). Devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. We have all learned so much from the nobility of your selfless graciousness, that only grew as the easy trappings of joyful youth diminished. You are marvelous!

title: Picture Phone Finally Approaching a Clear Focus
description: THE idea of a telephone that can transmit moving pictures of the callers has long been integral to every self-respecting vision of the future. At the 1939 New York World's Fair, where television itself was a novelty, the Hall of Pharmacy's Drugstore of Tomorrow included an experimental television phone booth. At the 1964 World's Fair in Queens, visitors could place long-distance video calls to the year-round fair called Disneyland. But in 1970, when the AT&T Corporation rolled out the first commercial picturephone service in fair-free Pittsburgh, it found more interest from the press than from paying customers.

title: Possible Settlement Stalls In Crown Heights Lawsuit
description: Most of the Hasidic residents of Crown Heights who sued New York City over its handling of the 1991 racial disturbances there have recently discussed settling with the city, but the talks have bogged down over financial terms and possibly other matters, people close to the case said yesterday.

title: Graves's 2 Goals Help Depleted Rangers Tie
description: A great deal of whatever success the Rangers have had this season can be attributed to their effectiveness when they have the man advantage. With Brian Leetch and Aleksei Kovalev manning the points, the Rangers are among the league's leaders in power-play goals.

title: Just About Everyone O'Casey Ever Knew
description: Where do all those people come from, filling the stage when there is only one man on it, in ''Song at Sunset'' at the Irish Repertory Theater? Out of the slightest gestures, movements, glances and intonations of the Irish actor Niall Buggy, whose ability to shift characters faster than eye or ear can detect seems to expand with each play he takes on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISELS, ZELDA
description: MEISELS-Zelda. On January 25, 1998. Beloved wife of Raphael, mother of Deborah, Naomi and Anna. Cherished grandmother and great - grandmother. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospital for Special Surgery.

title: The Neediest Cases; Charting a Life's Course With the Help of a Suit
description: Like many 17-year-olds in New York City, Jayson Mines favors oversize trousers and clunky sneakers that look as if they house rocket boosters. But when it came time to find a part-time job last month, Jayson, a high school junior, knew his street clothes might not impress potential employers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERST, CRAIG CHARLES
description: HERST-Craig Charles. 31. Of Breckenridge, CO, passed away after a long illness on January 22, 1998. Craig is survived by his loving mother Terry S. Herst, father Perry S. Herst Jr., brother Perry III uncle Joseph C. Stamler and aunt Susan Stamler of Rumson, NJ; grandfather Perry S. Herst of Chicago, Ill and aunt Marilyn Karsten of Los Angeles. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send any donations to Craig Charles Herst Fund, Colorado College, 14 E. Cache La Poudre St., Colorado Springs, CO 80903. Craig was a gregarious and loving young man. His family urges Craig's friends to remember his joy for life, and to carry it on...into their lives.

title: Spreading Praise Around
description: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue made this assessment today of Sunday's game.

title: POSSIS MEDICAL HIRES SALOMON SMITH BARNEY
description: Possis Medical Inc. hired the New York investment bank Salomon Smith Barney yesterday to help bolster its vascular-graft business and address overall capital needs. Salomon Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers Group, was retained to help Possis, a Minneapolis-based maker of cardiovascular and vascular medical products, explore what the company called a ''wide range of strategic and financial alternatives.'' Possis did not elaborate on what this might include. Shares of Possis gained 62.5 cents yesterday, to $11.25, giving the company a market capitalization of $137.17 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREIER, BETTY
description: DREIER-Betty. Women's League for Israel is saddened by the death of our Honorary Vice President. For more than 50 years she devoted her energy and time to our work with young people in Israel. We will always remember Betty and her husband, Sam, for their support. We extend our condolences to her family. Harriet Lainer, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLOCK, BEATRICE ROBERTSON CULVER
description: HALLOCK-Beatrice Robertson Culver. On January 26th, 1998. A life-long resident of Southampton, Beatrice Hallock died yesterday at the age of seventy-eight. She was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton King Culver of Southampton. She is survived by her children, Mrs. James H. Logan of Barnsley, England, David Horace Hallock III of Huntington, Indiana, Peter Leslie Hallock of Southampton and New York City, and four grandchildren: Chelsea, Corinne Hallock of Huntington, Indiana, Sarah Elizabeth Logan, James David Phillips Logan and Jessica Culver Logan, all residing in England. Donations may be made to Southampton Hospital.

title: Merger? What Merger? Call It a Joint Venture
description: It's been more than a decade since the airline industry saw its last major merger. And if the alliance between Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines is any indication, it might be a while before the streak is broken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYDGATE, WILLIAM A.
description: LYDGATE-William A. The board of directors, other volunteers, and staff of United Hospital Fund mourn the loss of an esteemed former board member and supporter of New York's hospitals. During his 15 years of service to the Fund, he shared his wisdom and expertise and actively chaired the annual Campaign. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife and family. Howard Smith, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr., President

title: World News Briefs; European Union Urges U.N. Inquiry in Algeria
description: The 15-nation European Union called on Algeria's military-backed Government today to allow United Nations and other international organizations to investigate the continuing killing of civilians there, reportedly by Islamic militants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, SAMUEL
description: MAY-Samuel. The Board of Directors and Staff of the 92nd Street Y mourn the passing of Samuel May, beloved father of Peter May, a dedicated member of our Board and our dear friend. Our hearts and prayers go out to Samuel's wife Isabel, son and daughter-inlaw Peter and Leni May, daughter and son-in-law Linda and Stephen Sklar, grandchildren Jonathan, Leslie, Caryn, Marci and Kenneth, and great-grandchildren Jacob, Allison and Carlee. He will be missed by all who knew him. Philip Milstein, President Joseph Leff, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Securities markets reach a preliminary agreement on making circuit breakers less restrictive.
description: THE nation's securities markets reached a preliminary agreement yesterday on loosening the limits that can halt stock trading when prices plunge.

title: FULTON FINANCIAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE AMBASSADOR BANK
description: The Fulton Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Ambassador Bank of the Commonwealth, a commercial and consumer bank based in Allentown, Pa., for more than $65 million. Ambassador has assets of $275 million and eight banking offices. Fulton, based in Lancaster, Pa., has assets of $4.5 billion and more than 120 banking offices. Under the agreement, Fulton would exchange 1.12 shares of its common stock for each of Ambassador Bank's 1.9 million shares outstanding. Ambassador's shares rose 13 percent yesterday, gaining $3.625, to $31.125. Shares of Fulton dropped $1.0625, to $30.

title: Peugeot to Build Plant in Brazil
description: PSA Peugeot Citroen said today that it would build a $600 million car factory in Brazil as the linchpin of a plan to more than double Latin American sales.

title: Research Finds Risk In Early Test of Fetus
description: FOR a pregnant woman who wants to know whether she is carrying a healthy fetus, the wait for medical tests can seem endless. The most common test for genetic disorders, amniocentesis, is usually not done until the 15th or 16th week of pregnancy, and it takes another week or two to get results. The test involves removing a sample of the fluid surrounding the fetus in the uterus to obtain fetal cells for genetic analysis.

title: Kennelly Proposes Free-Tuition Incentive
description: In the first major proposal of her gubernatorial campaign, Barbara B. Kennelly, the Democratic challenger, said yesterday that top high school students should be allowed to attend the state's public colleges tuition free.

title: Data Show Recent Burning of Amazon Is Worst Ever
description: Recent destruction of the Amazon rain forest is the worst ever recorded, surpassing even the years of deforestation that set off an international outcry to save the forests, according to data issued by the Brazilian Government today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHNEYER, WILLIAM
description: SHNEYER-William. January 24, 1998. Worker for peace, worker for equality, worker for Jewishness. We loved you as our teacher and friend. These struggles will much harder without you. Laura and Harry Movchine

title: Operating Income Rises by 14%, But American Express Net Falls
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its operating income rose 14 percent in the fourth quarter, helped by strong demand for new types of credit cards.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Behind the Pose,

title: Home Resales Off in December, Up for Year
description: Home resales declined in December for the second consecutive month but set a record for the full year, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Robert Friend, 84, Poet and English Professor
description: Robert Friend, a poet, translator and educator, died on Jan. 12 in Jerusalem, where he lived. He was 84.

title: Teacher Groups to Merge, Creating Largest U.S. Union
description: The nation's two largest teachers' unions announced a preliminary merger plan yesterday that would create the largest union in the nation's history, with 3.2 million members.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: IN PERFORMANCE: JAZZ
description: A Spooky World

title: Sex Education Classes Will Get Federal Aid
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman came to a public school here today to announce that New Jersey would spend $4 million in Federal money on new sex education programs.

title: 10 Accused of Running Sports-Betting Ring
description: Four men from New Jersey and six from New York City have been charged with running a sports betting ring based in Bloomfield that earned millions of dollars a year for the Bruno-Scarfo organized crime family, the Essex County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: At AT&T, Taking News Of Cutbacks in Stride
description: From the unionized crews who dig the holes to lay AT&T's fiber optic lines to the executive secretaries in plush corporate offices, the announcement today by AT&T's chairman that the company would cut its work force by 15,000 to 18,000 jobs over the next few years was not nearly as traumatic as has been the case in the past.

title: A Tenor Stumbles, But Others Recover
description: Elegance and mishap marked the Metropolitan Opera's pension fund gala on Sunday. Elegant was a lot of the singing; elegant as well the man to whom the event was dedicated, Rudolf Bing. Bing was general manager of the Met from 1950 to 1972 and died last September.

title: Metro Business; Two Brokers Plead Guilty
description: Two New York stockbrokers pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal stock fraud charges, but denied the contention of prosecutors that they conspired with an associate of the Colombo organized crime family.

title: If Climate Changes, It May Change Quickly
description: IN the debate over global warming, there has been a widespread assumption that if humans are changing the earth's climate, the effects will be felt gradually and smoothly, making it easier to adapt to the change.

title: Lamar Odom To Stay in School
description: The former high school basketball star Lamar Odom will try to qualify as a student-athlete at the University of Rhode Island rather than play professional basketball, his lawyer said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, REBECCA HALPERN
description: PRATT-Rebecca Halpern. Of Rhinebeck, NY, formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY on Jan. 20, 1998. Wife of the late Lou Pratt.
