Beloved mother of Carol of Marin County, CA and Andrea Replansky of Rhineback. Adored grandmother of Jessica and Sonia Replansky, mother-in-law of Warren Replansky, sister of Bo Williams Loomer of E. Taghkanic, NY and the late Mildred Heinrich and late Allen Halpern. Donations to Rhinebeck Chamber Music Soc., Linus Pauling Inst., or Planned Parenthood of Dutchess County. She lived life fully and will be greatly missed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Shinichi Suzuki Dies at 99; Began Music Education Method
description: Shinichi Suzuki, whose revolutionary methods for teaching music led millions of youngsters around the world to study the violin using the ''Suzuki Method,'' died this morning at his home in Matsumoto, Japan. He was 99.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK -- ST. JOHN'S; Red-Hot Red Storm Vows to Stay Aggressive
description: The Red Storm (15-6, 7-3 Big East) will take a six-game winning streak into tomorrow night's Madison Square Garden matchup against last-place Rutgers (8-9, 2-7 Big East), but Coach Fran Fraschilla does not fear his team will be complacent. ''It's like I told the guys, I don't think the N.C.A.A. will take a team with 15 wins,'' he said. ''We're a long way from where we want to go.''

title: Menopause Begins Silently, Before Its Symptoms
description: I WAS in my mid-40's and still menstruating regularly when my gynecologist suggested that I start taking estrogen. But I thought he was jumping the gun since I would probably not enter menopause for five more years.

title: The Buttressing of Fortress Compaq; Deal for Digital Expands PC Leader's Footing in Computer Industry
description: To see just how much the personal computer industry has grown up from its scrappy, freewheeling origins only two decades ago, look no further than the 56-year-old chief executive of Compaq Computer, Eckhard Pfeiffer. His latest move, to acquire the troubled Digital Equipment Corporation, represents a coming of age as Compaq moves well beyond its roots to compete in the field of industrial-strength computing -- long the unchallenged domain of mainframe and minicomputer companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAER, ROSE
description: PAER-Rose. Born Rose Sussman, age 91, of Brooklyn, NY, died in San Jose, Calif., on Jan. 25th, 1998. Widow of Henry Paer. Mother of Beryl Richardson. Loving sister and aunt and friend. Retired school secretary NYC. Funeral service on Jan. 28, 10 A.M., Plaza Memorial, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

title: Earnings at Travelers Fall 35% As Asia Hurts Brokerage Unit
description: The Travelers Group said yesterday that operating earnings fell 13 percent in the fourth quarter, and net income declined 35 percent, as plunging financial markets in Asia dragged down trading revenue at its Salomon Smith Barney unit.

title: Health Watch; Socially Inhibited at Risk
description: Being impatient and quick to anger -- characteristics of the infamous ''Type A'' person -- and feeling overly stressed or depressed are not the only traits that may predispose someone to heart attack. Insecure, socially inhibited worriers may also be at a higher than average risk, a newly published study suggests.

title: After the Visit: Mission Lies Now With Cuban Church
description: Now comes the hard part. With Pope John Paul II back in Rome after a five-day visit, responsibility for carrying out his call for Catholics to play a larger role in Cuban society falls to a local church whose mission has been severely circumscribed under Communism for nearly 40 years.

title: Disabled at CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARINE, JOSEPH E.
description: MARINE-Joseph E. On January 25th, 1998. Of Oceanside, L.I. Former New York State Senator and N.Y. Yankees executive. Beloved husband of the late Josephine. Loving father of the late Dolores Kennedy and Dr. Edward Marine of Buffalo. Cherished grandfather of Joseph, Deborah and Patricia. Fond brother of Rachel Falerno. Reposing at Towers Funeral Home, Inc., Long Beach and Foxhurst Roads, Oceanside, Tuesday, 7-9 P.M. and on Monday 9-11 A.M. Interment will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, JACK C.
description: RICH-Jack C. Sculptor and author of ''The Materials and Methods of Sculpture'' and ''Sculpture in Wood''-both published by Oxford University Press, died January 25, 1998 following a long struggle with emphysema. Although he rarely exhibited, his sculpture had been shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Robinson Gallery, the A.C.A. Gallery and the Society of Independents. He leaves behind his wife Joy, daughters Judith Calagna and Jennifer RichPure, sons-in-law Tom and Kenneth, beloved grandchildren Vanessa, Jesse and Alex. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent in his name to Dwight Jordan at Cooper Union School of Art, 30 Cooper Square, 8th Flr, New York City 10003. A memorial service will be held at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, Friday, January 30th at 2 P.M.

title: Bullet Wounds Rider on a Train in Newark
description: A passenger aboard a New Jersey Transit commuter train was injured last night by a bullet that was fired from outside the train as the locomotive passed through Branch Brook Park in Newark, officials said.

title: British Food Company Sells Unit to 2 Buyers
description: The British food company Dalgety P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Spillers food ingredients business in two separate deals to Kerry Group P.L.C. of Ireland and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company for a total of $:359 million, or $600 million. Dalgety will sell the flour milling and food coatings operations to Kerry for $:335 million ($560 million) and the division's intellectual property rights and research to DuPont for $:24.5 million ($41 million).

title: Levi Strauss dismisses Foote, Cone from its domestic jeans account after 68 years.
description: ONE of the most closely fought reviews of an advertising account ended yesterday with another bitter loss for a longtime incumbent as Levi Strauss & Company dismissed Foote, Cone & Belding after 68 years and awarded its domestic jeans brand assignment, with billings estimated at $90 million, to TBWA Chiat/Day.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Compaq Computer Expands With $9 Billion Digital Deal

title: New Translation of Aesop Finds a Still Beastlier Side
description: A new translation of Aesop's fables by a couple in London purports to paint a very different picture of the benign tales that generations of schoolchildren have had read to them as bedtime stories. This month in Britain, Penguin Classics will publish a translation of 350 fables, 100 of which, it says, have never before appeared in English, and some of which are raw, brutal and scatological in content.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, GUSSIE
description: ROSEN-Gussie. Age ninety-nine, January 24, 1998. Longtime resident of Brooklyn. Devoted mother of Bernard and Harold. Beloved grandmother of Nina and David Rosen, Robert and Ruth Ann Rosend. Wife of the late Joseph Rosen. Owner of Peer Electric Company whose success was enhanced by her skills as charming hostess to his business associates.

title: GIBSON GREETINGS CANCELS UNIT SALE TO PAPER WAREHOUSE
description: Gibson Greetings Inc. said yesterday that it had ended an accord to sell its party-goods unit to the Paper Warehouse, based in St. Louis Park, Minn., after the companies failed to agree on the sale price. Gibson, of Cincinnati, said in December that it would sell the Paper Factory, a unit based in Appleton, Wis., to Paper Warehouse for $38.6 million, but the final price was expected to change. The deal, which would have created the country's largest retail party-store operator, unraveled after the unit generated sales and earnings that were higher than expected, Gibson said. Shares of Gibson rose 18.75 cents yesterday, to $22.0625; Paper Warehouse fell 75 cents, to $6.

title: Where Is Compassion in the Abortion Debate?; Smaller Family Size
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTERDAM, JACK
description: AMSTERDAM-Jack. On January 23, 1998. Chairman of the Board of Leviton Manufacturing Co. Beloved husband of the late Mimi Leviton Amsterdam. Devoted father of Dasha Epstein. Caring and loving grandfather of Robert and Danielle Epstein. Dear brother of Jean Ross. Loyal and best friend of Mimi Goodman. Service Tuesday 11 AM Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave. at 55th St.

title: Giuliani, Back in the Fold, Formally Endorses Pataki
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he would support the re-election of Gov. George E. Pataki, a political revelation that is slightly more complicated than the routine endorsement of one Republican by another.

title: Faulty Rivets Emerge as Clues To Titanic Disaster
description: EVER since the Titanic was discovered in the depths of the North Atlantic a dozen years ago, her steel plates melting into rivers of rust, expeditions have repeatedly probed the hulk. And investigators armed with a growing body of evidence have been working to solve riddles posed by the opulent liner's sinking.

title: Q&A
description: Mountain Sickness

title: Health Watch; Death Rates Highest on TV
description: DISARMING bombs, repairing tall steeples and racing Formula One cars can certainly be hazardous, but British researchers have found the country's highest mortality rates in the fantasy world of television.

title: A Festival of Works From Scandinavia
description: Tireless as he is, Joel Sachs, the conductor and new-music champion at Juilliard, cannot direct the school's annual weeklong Focus festival without a lot of help. Each year the festival brings attention to some less well-known area of contemporary music. And well before the rehearsals start, there is much to do, like examining innumerable scores, getting in touch with composers and assembling programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONG, BRIAN
description: KONG-Brian. On January 26, 1998. Beloved son of Carmen Kong, devoted companion of Frank Lanotte, brother of Dahlia DeJesus and Denise Kong Martin. Brotherin-law of Felix DeJesus and William Martin. Services on Thursday, 6 P.M., at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the GMHC.

title: Times Square Jolted Again, This Time by Falling Crane
description: The driver of a flatbed truck delivering several tons of granite to a construction site in Times Square apparently pulled away before a crane could lift the supplies from the truck, causing the crane's boom to buckle and crash into a building across the street yesterday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: LAIDLAW ENVIRONMENTAL ADJUSTS BID FOR SAFETY-KLEEN
description: Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc. increased the cash portion of its hostile offer for the Safety-Kleen Corporation to $18 a share, but the overall value of the offer remains $30 a share. Laidlaw, of Columbia, S.C., said that Safety-Kleen shareholders would also receive $12 in Laidlaw shares for each Safety-Kleen share and that the number of shares issued would be 2.24 shares to 2.80 shares. In December Laidlaw offered $15 a share in cash and stock worth $15 a share, which Safety-Kleen, of Elgin, Ill., rejected in favor of a lower offer of $27 a share in cash from a white-knight buyer, the Philip Services Corporation, of Hamilton, Ontario. Laidlaw's offer will expire on Feb. 13. Safety-Kleen was not immediately available for comment.

title: Knick Mastery Ends at 5 Years And 21 Games
description: Most of the ankles had been taped, and the food filling the training table had been picked at by the Knicks. Some players were talking, others were listening to music by their lockers. Typical pre-game mood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERR, ELIZABETH B.
description: SCHERR-Elizabeth B. On January 24, at home in Williamstown, MA Wife of Albert E. Scherr III, mother of Elizabeth, Albert, Alexander and Edward, grandmother of Anna, Charles, Elizabeth, William, Mackenzie. Assistant librarian at Williams College; Williamstown Library Trustee; member of the vestry of St. John's Church. Service Saturday, January 31, 2 P.M. at St. John's Episcopal Church, Williamstown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, CHARLES J.
description: HARRIS-Charles J. Of Shirley on January 26, 1998. Retired Senior Attorney with the NYS Dept. of Law. Graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law School. Beloved husband of Patricia. Dear brother of Mary Kendrick and the late John Harris. Reposing today and tomorrow, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Wesche Funeral Home, Inc., 495 Main St., Center Moriches. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 9:45 A.M. at St. Judes RC Church, Mastic Beach. Interment, Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Packers' Big Test Is to Keep Team Intact
description: If they thought losing a Super Bowl was tough, now comes the really hard part for the Green Bay Packers -- keeping everything intact.

title: Governor Ignores Tradition In Replacing Appellate Judge
description: After forcing out the chief appeals court judge for Manhattan and the Bronx because of his liberal rulings, Gov. George E. Pataki made an unusual reach across jurisdictional boundaries today to appoint a Queens judge to the post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, DR. LUCILLE H. BLUM
description: SACHS-Dr. Lucille H. Blum. The Trustees, staff and faculty of Postgraduate Center for Mental Health mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, Lucille Hollander Blum, Ph.D. Dr. Blum, a 1953 graduate of our Adult Psychoanalytic Training Program, had a distinguished career as an analyst and educator and authored numerous books and journal articles. She joined our Board of Trustees in 1984 and we will miss her wisdom and expertise. Our deepest condolences go to her family. The Trustees, Staff and Faculty Postgraduate Center for Mental Health

title: Iraqis Must End Defiance On Arms, Clinton Warns
description: President Clinton sought to intensify pressure on Iraq today, dispatching senior officials to consult with American allies in Europe and the Middle East and warning President Saddam Hussein, in the State of the Union address, that his defiance of the United Nations cannot continue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, ANNA V.
description: O'NEILL-Anna V. On January 25, 1998 at Isabella Geriatric Center. Devoted sister of Nora. Mass of Christian burial, St. Elizabeth's Church, on Thursday, 10 A.M. Entombment at The Trinity Church Cemetery. For more information call: The Albert R. Conner-Colonial Funeral Home (212 567-7800).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, E. JEROME, JR.
description: WEBSTER-E. Jerome, Jr. The Friends of Rock Hall express heartfelt condolences to our President, Margaret, on the death of her beloved husband Jerry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNDERWOOD, MARJORIE F.
description: UNDERWOOD-Marjorie F. Age 76, of Denver, CO. On January 23, 1998. Widow of Professor Kenneth Underwood, Wesleyan University and Yale Divinity School. Survived by daughter Valerie Underwood of Portland, OR; grandson Evan Hanau of Portland; granddaughter Mercer Hanau of Portland and son Keith Underwood of New York City. Memorial contributions may be made to Earth Island Institute C/O David Phillips, 300 Broadway, Suite 28, San Francisco, CA. 94133-4529.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CERIDIAN CORP., Minneapolis, an information-services company, said it would purchase the payroll operations of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Toronto, and Toronto-Dominion Bank. Ceridian will also acquire Toronto-Dominion's human resources services business.

title: Cendant to Start Tender Offer For American Bankers Group
description: The Cendant Corporation said today that it would begin a $2.7 billion tender offer for American Bankers Insurance Group Inc., topping the $2.2 billion that American International Group Inc. had agreed to pay for the company.

title: The Life She's Led After a Famous Case
description: As Norma McCorvey, better known as the Roe of Roe v. Wade, looks back on her life tonight, it is a search for some sort of appreciation, esteem, hugging. She succeeded in finding all of them, only to discover that she was being used first by her abortion-rights comrades and then, it appears, by her anti-abortion comrades for purposes that were not quite her own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMBERG, BERNARD
description: GOMBERG-Bernard. At age 68, on Jan. 27, 1998. Survived by wife, Grace Marlene Gomberg, devoted children, Suzanne and Mason, grandchildren, Ryan, Michael, Ariel and Jacqueline. Services Thursday, 1/29, 10:30 AM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Gates Goes on the Offensive During Silicon Valley Visit
description: After appearing to be making an effort to soften the company's rhetoric in recent weeks, Microsoft's chairman William H. Gates went back on the offensive during a visit to Silicon Valley today, saying repeatedly that he would not accept restrictions on his ability to add features to Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system.

title: Posada Wants Career to Enter Present Tense
description: There was serious exasperation and maybe even a sliver of desperation in Jorge Posada's voice as he discussed his status on the Yankees. Posada is a smart 26-year-old with a bright future, but he sounded miffed because he was tired of being called the catcher of the future.

title: The Relaxed Revolutionary of 'Ragtime'
description: ''Call me Stokes,'' he says, a deep, full-throated laugh coming right up from the basement.

title: TV Notes; Disney and Who?
description: A curious credit line appears at the end of the latest public television megadocumentary, ''The Irish in America: Long Journey Home,'' a six-hour series that began on Monday and ends tonight on PBS. It reads: ''Presented by the Walt Disney Studios in association with WGBH Boston.''

title: To Go; Takeout Treasures: Babka to Roti
description: AS I was walking along West 57th Street one evening, the last thing I expected to see was a Jamaican takeout shop, but there was HOLIDAYS , a bright, pleasant storefront that opened about a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURMAN, SALLY
description: GURMAN-Sally. On January 25, 1998. The wife of the late Joseph and dear mother of the late Eugene. Also loving mother of Evelyn and Sheldon Altman. Dear grandmother of Dr. Robin Altman, Andrew Altman, Emlyn Gurman Altman and Gary Prish. Devoted great grandmother of Evan Joseph and Clara Alexis Prish. Family said, ''She was a great fighter''. Funeral services were held privately on Monday at the United Hebrew Cemetery.

title: In the Case Against Clinton, Some Links to Conservatives
description: While no proof has been offered to support Hillary Rodham Clinton's allegations that a 'vast right-wing conspiracy'' is behind the accusations of sexual impropriety imperiling her husband's Presidency, several figures in the case against President Clinton have common ties in conservative groups and causes.

title: Oldtime Jazz From Cuba, Spacious and Dynamic, Takes a New York Bow
description: The ''Cuban jazz'' that developed in the 1940's had an amazing quality unto itself: intense, focused, rhythmically persuasive, it was built as furtive latticework, with pockets of open space shot through it. The music breathes at all times, and feels light upon you even as it urges you on.

title: More Security Demanded By a School's Teachers
description: About 65 teachers at Atlantic City's Albany Avenue School staged a boycott of an educational workshop yesterday to demand more security to combat what they say is an increasingly violent atmosphere at the school.

title: Gov. Wilson's High Energy and Low Prospects
description: Pete Wilson may have begun his last year as Governor of California, but he is not going gentle into the night. He still thinks nothing of staying up until the wee hours poring over a speech. His idea of relaxation is still a late-night workout on the Gravitron machine in his garage. His antidote to frustration is still deeper immersion in policy details.

title: Post-game analysis of Super Bowl statistics that really count -- commercial winners and losers.
description: MADISON AVENUE is poring over the post-game analyses of the ad bowl played during Super Bowl XXXII with all the intensity that the Green Bay Packers ought to have brought to San Diego.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have moved past the sterile debate between those who say government is the enemy and those who say government is the answer. My fellow Americans, we have found a third way. We have the smallest government in 35 years, but a more progressive one. We have a smaller government, but a stronger nation.''

title: Uzbek Leader Dampens Signs of Islamic Fervor
description: Anxious to contain displays of Islamic piety, President Islam Karimov has conducted a monthlong crackdown that local Muslim leaders say might prompt just the radicalism he fears.

title: Williams Finds Respect as All-Star
description: Jayson Williams has long been known for his sense of humor. But many are just finding out that this class clown can also play. Just check the National Basketball Association's rebounding leaders on a daily basis.

title: Metro Business; Lower Manhattan Tourism
description: More than three million people visited tourist attractions in lower Manhattan in 1997, an increase of 35 percent over 1996, said Heritage Trails New York, a nonprofit tourism organization.

title: The Pop Life; A New Season For the Zombies
description: If only every band had history on its side as the Zombies have. When the band broke up 30 years ago, it was known as a Beatles clone with only a couple of songs to its credit (the breathy piano pop hit ''She's Not There'' and the inanely catchy ''Tell Her No''). But a year after separating, the band found itself with a surprise hit, ''Time of the Season,'' which would go on to become its best-known song. More important, over the course of the ensuing decades, its final album, the accidentally misspelled ''Odessey and Oracle'' -- a beautifully arranged, harmony-drenched pristine pop paean to memory, the changing of seasons, the passage of time and lost love -- slowly began to be recognized as one of the greatest albums of the 1960's. In the minds of some subsequent musicians, like Paul Weller of the Jam and Eric Matthews, it was the greatest album of the time.

title: Solid Corporate Profit Reports Help Push Share Prices Higher
description: Stock prices soared yesterday after several blue-chip companies reported solid fourth-quarter earnings, ending a streak of disappointing results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHEOWITZ, FRANK
description: OSHEOWITZ-Frank. Of Lake Worth, FL. formerly of Rockville Centre, at age 85 on January 26, 1998. Loving husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Michael (Maria) and Audrey (Harvey) Rutheiser. Devoted grandfather of Charles, Caryn (Michael) Zacharia and Tania (Dr. Steven) Gold and Melita. Great grandfather of Lindsay, Jonah and Evan. Loving brother of Molly Wagner and Ceil Blau.

title: Bonuses for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bell Atlantic Asking F.C.C. To Allow Big Data Network
description: Mounting a novel challenge to the rules that keep the Bell local telephone companies out of the long-distance market, the Bell Atlantic Corporation asked Federal regulators yesterday to allow the company to build a wide-ranging high-speed data network.

title: 11 Hurt When Crane Hits Tram Car 240 Feet Above River
description: A construction crane working on the Queensboro Bridge slammed into a Manhattan-bound car of the Roosevelt Island tramway yesterday morning, terrifying commuters for a few tense moments as they feared that the wildly swinging car might plunge into the icy waters of the East River, 240 feet below.

title: Lost in Translation
description: Talk about timing.

title: Club Med Discloses Plan for Reviving Its Resorts
description: Club Mediterranee plans to raise 1.2 billion French francs ($201 million) in new capital and set aside another 1.45 billion francs to finance an overhaul of its far-flung, financially troubled resort empire.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUZUKI, SHINICHI
description: SUZUKI-Shinichi. The entire School for Strings familychildren, parents, teacher trainees, faculty, alumni and the Board of Trustees-deeply feel the loss of the great educator, Dr. Shinichi Suzuki, whose humanitarian principles and unwavering faith in the ability of children have inspired us for over 25 years. Louise Behrend Founder and Director Alexander Yudkovsky, Executive Director Sheila Keats Associate Director Emerita Melanie Shorin, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Journal; Full Court Press
description: If O. J. Simpson and Clarence Thomas can do it, why not Bill Clinton?

title: World News Briefs; Brazil Delays Vote On Environmental Bill
description: The Congress put off voting today on a bill that would have given Brazil's environmental agency power to enforce environmental protection laws nine years after the agency came into being.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, JANELLE
description: DOUGLAS-Janelle. On January 25, 1998. Beloved daughter of Elizabeth Douglas and the late Jackson, cherished sister of Noella, Theodora Aina, Stewart, Reed, Lawrence and Lamont. Also survived by a host of relatives and friends. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72 Street. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 11 AM, St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Bronxville. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Calling hours Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9.

title: Murder Is Suspected In Student's Death
description: A student at Rowan University was found dead in her off-campus apartment over the weekend in what is being investigated as a homicide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ERNEST S. ''PICK''
description: HELLER-Ernest S. ''Pick''. The Board of Composers' Showcase, is deeply saddened by the death of Pick Heller. His wisdom, loyalty and support will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to Red Heller, his beloved wife. Composers' Showcase Board

title: TEXAS UTILITIES SEEKS LARGEST BRITISH UTILITY
description: The Texas Utilities Company of Dallas confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to acquire an interest in Energy Group P.L.C., raising the possibility of a takeover battle for Britain's largest utility. Last year, Pacificorp, a major utility in the Western United States, made a $6 billion bid for Energy Group. Pacificorp's bid lapsed in August when it was referred to Britain's Mergers and Monopolies Commission. The commission endorsed the sale in December, and the company, which is based in Portland, Ore., is expected to renew its offer. Energy Group's main businesses are the British utility Eastern Group and the United States coal supplier Peabody.

title: The New Subway Map
description: There is something special about a map to a place that you enter through a hole in the ground, like the New York City subway. For one thing, such a map makes it clear that New York's streets and sidewalks are also boundaries between the surface world and its subterranean twin. Millions of New Yorkers cross that boundary every day -- so often, in fact, that the magic of going down into the long room where the trains run beneath the pavement has worn off for nearly everyone who has lived there longer than a week.

title: Food Stuff
description: A New Pastry Shop With a Light Touch

title: Gaels Get Victory; Attention May Follow
description: Iona is riding a 13-game winning streak, the third longest in the nation. Yet college basketball fans are still likely to ask, ''Who are those guys?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITBARTH, LAUREL
description: BREITBARTH-Laurel. In Westport, Conn., January 26, 1998. Loving wife of S. Robert Breitbarth. Devoted mother of Merideth Breitbarth and Jill Breitbarth. Cherished sister of Lester Stroh, Claire Lang, Dorothy Grossman, and adored grandmother of Zoe Adams. Services are on Thursday at 2 P.M. from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Road, Westport, Conn. Interment following at Temple Israel Cemetery, Norwalk, CT.

title: The Subtext Vs. the Text
description: Like Richard M. Nixon in the same ceremonial setting almost 24 years ago, Bill Clinton struggled tonight to convince Congress and the country that he has not already become a past-tense President.

title: M.T.A. Backs Plan to Build Mall Over Brooklyn Terminal
description: Transit officials have endorsed a private developer's plan to build a 450,000-square-foot mall over the Atlantic Terminal in downtown Brooklyn, the latest link in a chain of development that has transformed the area over the last decade.

title: About New York; When Drama Stirs Hope For Students
description: FRITZBERT JOSEPH likes to quote Shakespeare, so it's a good thing that he has a rich, lilting voice that can pull it off. He loves the power and romance of that language. Recently, he sat inside a Long Island City theater and recalled a favorite passage from ''Julius Caesar'' with enough emotion to transform the East River into the Avon.

title: Environment Advocates Seek Brookhaven Role
description: Environmental advocates should be on the governing board of the new entity taking over the troubled Brookhaven National Laboratory, the lab's new director said yesterday. But the new board's chairwoman had a more reserved reaction to the proposal.

title: Whenever Trouble Brews, Publisher Beams
description: ONE would think, having recently lost $3 million in a libel judgment, a fellow would be gloomy. But that is not the case with the publisher Lyle Stuart.

title: Layoffs Set at Apple Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would lay off 300 workers from its Claris software subsidiary in the latest in a series of job cuts by the computer maker. Apple said it would reorganize Claris to focus exclusively on its Filemaker Pro data base software. The unit will change its name to Filemaker Inc. and shed all products other than the Filemaker Pro line. Apple will take over development and distribution of the unit's Clarisworks productivity software on Feb. 1.

title: Flagship Stadium:Echo of the Ancient World : Stade de France Is Set for World Cup Debut
description: SAINT DENIS, France  Gleaming with lights on a winter's day at dusk, the gigantic national stadium that France has built for the 1998 World Cup soccer tournament looks like an ocean liner about to glide out to sea.

title: Governor's Inmate Estimates Were Too High, Memo Says
description: State prison officials said today that they had greatly overestimated how fast the inmate population would grow in the next few years, predictions on which Gov. George E. Pataki based his call for more prison construction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, RUTH
description: LEONARD-Ruth. Of N.Y.C., on January 27, 1998. Daughter of Frank Guralnick. Services ''Wien & Wien'', on Thursday 1:30 P.M., at Gramercy Chapel, Second Avenue, (9th-10th Streets).

title: Boeing Posts $498 Million Quarter Loss
description: The Boeing Company, still feeling financial pain from difficulties producing commercial aircraft and last year's merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $498 million yesterday, leading to its first annual loss in half a century.

title: Amoco to Split Stock 2 for 1
description: The Amoco Corporation said today that it would split its shares 2 for 1 and increase its dividend by 7 percent. The stock split will double the company's outstanding shares to 994 million but cut each share's value in half. The new shares will be issued on April 28 to shareholders of record as of March 31. A quarterly dividend of 75 cents, up from 70 cents, will be paid March 10 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 11.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CATTLE TUMBLES. Weaker demand for beef, bigger herds and a slowdown in the slaughter of animals caused a steep selloff in cattle futures. Live cattle for February delivery fell 1.5 percent, settling at 65.25 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the biggest daily drop in about four weeks.

title: Class Notes
description: As a school field trip, it was like stepping through a looking glass; the world was at once familiar and utterly different. At the American Museum of Natural History earlier this month, Dawn Muggeo's fifth grade class at Public School 15 entered the former Hall of Invertebrates, its entrance stripped down to bare walls and scaffolding. A guide drew aside some plastic sheeting, and the children were in a brightly lighted workshop that looked like a set for an enchanted forest.

title: Intimate Brands to Close Cacique Business
description: Intimate Brands Inc. said today that it would close its Cacique lingerie business, resulting in a pretax charge of $60 million to $70 million in the 1998 fiscal year.

title: Metro Business; New York City Leads Upstate in New Jobs
description: The disparity that emerged in New York State in 1997 between economic strength in the New York City region and protracted weakness upstate continued last month, highlighted by some of the starkest job numbers of the year, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: TV Notes; Ratings for a Crisis
description: The news was watched more heavily than usual last week during the first days of the White House crisis. Among the networks, ABC clearly benefited most from its coverage of the President's problems, ending its recent stint in last place by passing CBS and closing to within three-tenths of a rating point of NBC.

title: Why Programming Skill Is Cheap; A Missing Passion
description: To the Editor:

title: Grading the Independent Counsel
description: Kenneth Starr has used his role as independent counsel expansively. He put a body wire on Linda Tripp, so that she could tape conversations with her fellow Pentagon employee and friend, Monica Lewinsky, and he did so before a Federal court gave him permission to explore the matter. Later he put pressure on Ms. Lewinsky to record her own conversations, although it is not clear with whom. Did Mr. Starr overstep the authority of his office? Here, a few experts offer opinions:

title: Ex-Prime Minister of Norway Wins Top Job at W.H.O.
description: Former Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway was elected today as director general of the World Health Organization, the first woman to lead the troubled agency.

title: Commercial Real Estate; A Mayor's Prerogative: Rethinking the City's Street Furniture
description: Talk about waiting for a furniture delivery.

title: Connecticut Fights Off A Challenge
description: Their leading scorer had an off night from the floor and their head coach was given the rest of the night off after drawing three technical fouls, but the Connecticut Huskies managed to win anyhow tonight.

title: First Lady Attributes Inquiry To 'Right-Wing Conspiracy'
description: Delivering a blistering White House counterattack, Hillary Rodham Clinton charged today that the Whitewater prosecutor's sex-scandal investigation of her husband was part of a ''vast right-wing conspiracy'' dedicated to destroying his Presidency.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Auto Dealers Make Changes in Accounts
description: Ford and Mitsubishi dealers have made changes on their accounts.

title: With an Uneasy Look, President's Secretary Goes Before a Grand Jury
description: While her boss was gearing up to deliver his State of the Union Message today, Betty Currie, President Clinton's personal secretary, was in a Federal courtroom near Capitol Hill testifying before a grand jury that is investigating whether Mr. Clinton had an affair with a former intern, Monica S. Lewinsky, and urged her to lie about it.

title: J. C. Penney Shutting 75 Stores And Cutting 4,900 Employees
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would close 75 poorly performing department stores and dismiss 4,900 employees, or 2 percent of its work force, as part of a major restructuring of its retail business.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLBINDER, ARNOLD
description: PERLBINDER-Arnold. January 28, 1994. Mourned, missed, loved and remembered. Perlbinder Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEU, HAROLD C.
description: NEU-Harold C. The faculty, staff and current and past students and fellows of the Divisions of infectious Diseases in internal Medicine and in Pediatrics sadly mourn the passing of Harold C. Neu, M.D. He was a dynamic leader, a distinguished investigator in development and use of antimicrobials, a charismatic and innovative teacher, a dedicated physician, and a warm and generous person. We will always remember him. We send our sincere condolences to his loving and devoted family: his wife Carmen Ortiz-Neu, M.D., and children Harold A. Neu, Maria Neu Rorer, and Natalie Neu, M.D. and his granddaughter Katherine Rorer.

title: Colorado Board Limits Films in Classrooms to PG and PG-13, and Discontent Arises
description: High school history teachers here are no longer permitted to show the Academy Award-winning film ''Schindler's List'' to illustrate a lesson on the Holocaust or Oliver Stone's ''Platoon'' for a discussion of the Vietnam War.

title: Versatile Borscht, Humble No More
description: BORSCHT, the ideal cold-weather soup, easily serves as dinner on a frosty night, and it adapts itself to a number of accompaniments. Borscht is actually a category of soup, as there are literally hundreds of variations: meat-based or vegetarian, hot or cold, elegant or rustic.

title: Prices Tumble on a Report Showing Rising Labor Costs
description: Labor costs rose at the fastest pace in five years in the last quarter of 1997, bringing the annual increase in total compensation to 3.3 percent. The news, which immediately raised some inflationary fears, was enough to send bond prices sharply lower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIN, BARBARA BETTY
description: HEIN-Barbara Betty. Of Thornwood, New York. On January 25, 1998. Beloved and devoted wife of Harold for fifty years. Cherished and loving mother of Richard, Robert, Steven and Loren and mother-in-law of Julia and Michelle. Adored and adoring grandmother of Emily. Her warmth, intelligence and incomparable courage will be remembered by all who knew her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Tuesday between 7 and 9 P.M. Services will be held there on Wednesday at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Dr. M. Heany Research Group, at The Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital.

title: Leetch Hopes He Can Return to Play Soon
description: Brian Leetch walked across the Rangers' locker room today, without a trace of a limp or a grimace of pain, and even though he had not joined his teammates on the ice, his relative fitness was a relief to him and the Rangers.

title: Off the Menu
description: Arcadia's Lease

title: Expanded Jazz Season Announced
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center announced its 1998-1999 season yesterday, and the offerings reflected its rapid expansion. Rob Gibson, the program's director, said the number of events planned had doubled from last year.

title: Giuliani Plans Budget Seeking Modest Growth For Spending
description: Even though the local economy is expanding and tax revenues are growing, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to announce a relatively austere budget tomorrow that calls for New York City to increase most spending at less than the inflation rate, administration officials said yesterday. Under the Mayor's proposal, the city would squirrel away much of its current budget surplus to help close anticipated shortfalls in the next two years, the officials said.

title: Text of the Republican Response, by Senator Lott, to Clinton's Address
description: Following is the Republican response last night by the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, to President Clinton's speech, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CLINTON, WITH CRISIS SWIRLING, PUTS FOCUS ON SOCIAL SECURITY IN UPBEAT STATE OF UNION TALK
description: President Clinton, facing the gravest personal and political peril in a crisis-prone career, emerged from the darkness shrouding his Presidency for more than an hour tonight to proclaim the state of the Union sound and to propose a plan to rescue Social Security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, FRANCES
description: ZIMMERMAN-Frances. The law firm of Newman Schwartz & Greenberg is deeply saddened by the death of its beloved and esteemed bookkeeper and friend, Frances Zimmerman, and expresses its deepest condolences and sympathies to her brother, Gustave H. Newman, the firm's Senior Partner, for his loss.

title: Critic's Notebook; The New Film Hero: Twisted, Neurotic, Triumphant
description: If James L. Brooks's ''As Good as It Gets'' and Woody Allen's ''Deconstructing Harry'' are any indication, we've got a new kind of men's picture on our hands.

title: Drug Makers Post Banner Profits in Quarter
description: Buoyed by a strong demand for drugs that reduce cholesterol and treat diabetes and allergies, four major American drug companies reported strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, capping one of the industry's most profitable years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSMITH, ELFREEDA
description: GOLDSMITH-Elfreeda. Dear Mom, we miss you. Rest peacefully. Love, Rhoda and Bob

title: Sips; Beet Chips Meet Belgian Beer
description: THERE are few reasons to mess with the components of one of our nation's most successful gastronomic pairings, beer and chips. But the Belgian beer and beet chips at Quilty's provide an exception.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONG, BRIAN
description: KONG-Brian. On January 26, 1998. Beloved son of Carmen Kong, devoted companion of Frank Lanotte, brother of Dahlia DeJesus and Denise Kong Martin. Brotherin-law of Felix DeJesus and William Martin. Services on Thursday, 6 P.M., at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the GMHC.

title: ALLSTATE TO ACQUIRE CANADIAN INSURANCE COMPANY
description: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Pembridge Inc., a Canadian property and casualty insurer, for about $400 million (Canadian), or $276 million (United States). Allstate, based in Northbrook, Ill., is the largest seller of car insurance in the United States. It also provides property and life insurance. Pembridge, based in Toronto, specializes in providing insurance to customers with poor credit ratings. It said it had urged its shareholders to accept Allstate's offer, which is conditional on Allstate's receiving at least 90 percent of Pembridge's shares. Shareholders representing about 25 percent of Pembridge's shares outstanding have agreed to throw their stock behind Allstate's bid, the companies said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Scandal Forces Resignation Of Japan's Finance Minister

title: Giuliani Administration Negotiating for a Jazz Concert Hall on Site of the Coliseum
description: The Giuliani administration is negotiating a deal to create a concert hall for Lincoln Center's jazz programs, in a move that could jump-start the bidding process for the redevelopment of the New York Coliseum site, a project that has been mired in a variety of disputes for the last 14 years.

title: USA WASTE SERVICES TO BUY TRANSAMERICAN WASTE
description: USA Waste Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Transamerican Waste Industries for about $112.5 million in stock and assumed debt, broadening USA Waste's operations in Texas and other Southern states. USA Waste said it would issue .045232 share for each Transamerican share, making the stock portion of the transaction worth $69.5 million at Monday's closing price of $34.75 for USA Waste, or $1.57 a share. USA Waste will assume $43 million in Transamerican debt. USA Waste, based in Houston, said Transamerican operates in eight markets with populations of more than 250,000 where USA Waste does not provide services.

title: National News Briefs; Emory Business School Is Left Big Coca-Cola Gift
description: The estate of Roberto C. Goizueta, the late chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, has given $20 million to Emory University's business school. The donation was among the largest ever given to an American business school.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Slightly Lower on Nasdaq
description: Investors seem to have begun the year with a little more optimism.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Northwest Airlines' acquisition of a controlling stake in Continental Airlines misstated the role of Credit Suisse First Boston as a financial adviser. It worked for Continental, not Northwest.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about national academic standards misidentified the New York City public-school class shown. The children, from Public School 158 on the Upper East Side, were kindergarten pupils; they were with their teacher, Lauren Berman, who was standing, and the principal, Saudhi Vargas. The picture did not show Gwen Rukeyser, a fourth-grade teacher, with her class.

title: TV Notes; Show Could Be A Contender
description: The great debate inside NBC about what to do on Thursday night A.S. (After ''Seinfeld'') may get more complicated this week after ''Just Shoot Me'' gets its first shot in the midst of NBC's ''must-see'' Thursday lineup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, PATRICK WILLIAM
description: ROBINSON-Patrick William. Industrialist. On January 19, 1998. Peacefully, after a short illness at Sarasota Memorial Hospital, Florida. Husband of Ann. Father of Georgina, Lorraine and Fletcher. Much loved grandfather of George, William, Clara, Marcello and Olivia. A memorial service will be held in Lovington, Somerset, England later.

title: Fixing Social Security Should Come Before Any Surplus Free-for-All, President Says
description: Edging into one of the most politically combustible issues facing the nation, President Clinton urged Congress tonight not to spend any budget surpluses the Federal Government might enjoy in coming years until the two parties solve the Social Security system's looming financial problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAHAN, JOHN PAUL, III.
description: MONAHAN-John Paul, III. The Kildonan School expresses great sympathy to a good friend Katie Couric and to her daughters who have lost Jay, husband and father.

title: Mellon-Russell Venture
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation and the privately held Frank Russell Company said yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to provide investment-analysis services. Frank Russell, based in Tacoma, Wash., is an investment manager and consulting firm. Mellon, based in Pittsburgh, has $300 billion in assets. Mellon's operation includes the Dreyfus family of mutual funds. The new venture will serve plan sponsors, investment managers and consultants.

title: Sidewalk Living, Once Again; Homeless More Visible, but This Time, More Discreet
description: Joe Kratcho says he began sleeping along abandoned subway tracks on Manhattan's East Side last winter after the police swept him and scores of other homeless people from shanties in a park across the street from the United Nations.

title: The Chef
description: A TRICK in cooking venison is to think of fish. Like most fish, venison has a low fat content and needs to be seared quickly in a hot pan; you must be especially vigilant because it crosses the boundary into an overcooked state about as easily as a Swede slips into Norway. For me, the similarity of cooking venison and fish is a relief. I grew up eating very little meat (later, in fact, preparing it made me anxious, until I finally reached some level of mastery), and it's fish I always think of first -- a handicap when you're trying to run a well-rounded kitchen.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a building that partly collapsed on the Lower East Side of Manhattan misidentified an organization that renovated an adjacent apartment building. It is the Lower East Side People's Mutual Housing Association, not the Lower East Side People's Credit Union.

title: Top Woman in Iran's Government Once Spoke for Hostage-Takers
description: Massoumeh Ebtekar is the highest-ranking woman in Iran's Government, a symbol of President Mohammed Khatami's promise to promote women into high-profile positions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUZ, MEYER
description: GUZ-Meyer. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Doris Guz on the loss of her beloved husband. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: History Has to Wait as Sampras Stumbles in Quarterfinals
description: Just when Pete Sampras was beginning to think he would play the remainder of his career against a faceless opponent called history, he ran into a fresh-faced Slovak spoiler known as the Little Cat in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open tonight.

title: Tics and Gestures Steal the Show
description: Watching with a contagious interest in nuance and deportment as much as in words, in what was not said as much as what was, Americans reacted to President Clinton's State of the Union Message with varying enthusiasm for his agenda and equally divided opinions on the state of his composure.

title: Study Faults Communities Along Sound Over Pollution
description: After examining the records of 55 communities along Long Island Sound, a coalition of environmental groups has concluded that only two, Westport, Conn., and Smithtown, N.Y., are doing a ''very good'' job of stemming water pollution.

title: The Knicks and the Heat Aren't Quite Looking Back in Anger
description: It was a plush hotel room. Big pillows, soft robes and tranquil tropical views. Yet, Larry Johnson could not find comfort.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: GTE Profits Down 10% in 4th Quarter
description: The GTE Corporation said today that profits fell 10 percent in the fourth quarter as record sales by the company's local phone operations were offset by losses from its acquisition of the BBN Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICHEL, RICHARD B.
description: SICHEL-Richard B. Age 84. Passed away on January 27th. Beloved cousin and friend to many. No services.

title: Blair Attends Ulster Talks, Seeking to Combat Killings
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair intervened in the faltering Northern Ireland peace negotiations today, as a splinter Protestant paramilitary group opposed to the talks announced in Belfast that it would continue to murder Catholics.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, SAM
description: FRIEDLANDER-Sam. July 2, 1911-January 28, 1995. Remembered always. Ruth

title: Survivor With a Debt to the Iceberg
description: Last week, ''Titanic'' was the No. 1 movie at the box office, ''Titanic'' the musical was one of the top-grossing shows on Broadway, and ''James Cameron's Titanic'' was the nation's best-selling nonfiction paperback.

title: Republicans Seek to Seize High Ground as Democrats Begin to Rally Around President
description: Facing a weakened adversary, Republicans today sidestepped the titillating questions surrounding President Clinton and sought to present themselves as the stable, substantive political alternative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, JOHN OTTO
description: STEINBERG-John Otto. Age 95. Of Pomperaug Woods, Southbury, CT. Formerly of Garden City, NY and Heritage Village, Southbury, CT. On January 25.

title: Q. Who Lost In Continental Airlines Deal?
description: The following is a multiple-choice test.

title: RJR Operating Profit Rises, But Charges Cause a Loss
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported yesterday that profits from its operations rose 20 percent in the quarter, partly as a result of higher cigarette prices, but the company posted a $197 million net loss primarily because of one-time charges and expenses stemming from its tobacco business.

title: State of the Tamales Is the Message
description: If there was any place in America where President Clinton could have expected a rousing, fortifying ovation as he began his State of the Union Message tonight, it would have been the smoky front room of Doe's Eat Place, the fabled Little Rock restaurant that sustained Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign. It did not happen.

title: Free-Agent Pitcher, 16 Years Old, Is on Cusp of Riches
description: It is not unusual for a 16-year-old and his father to disagree. In this instance, Ricardo and Domingo Aramboles have different views about the possible impact of the $2 million or so bonus Ricardo will soon receive for signing with a major league organization.

title: More Prisons Limit Tobacco But See Little Early Trouble
description: It sounds like a recipe for trouble. Ban all forms of tobacco in a prison where 80 percent of the more than 1,200 inmates and half the guards smoke or chew tobacco.

title: AFC to Buy Seattle Coffee
description: AFC Enterprises has agreed to buy the Seattle Coffee Company for an undisclosed price as part of its plan to expand beyond the fried-chicken business. Seattle Coffee includes a roasting and packaging plant and 66 cafes that operate under the names Seattle's Best and Torrefazione Italia. AFC, which is based in Atlanta and owns Popeye's Chicken and Biscuits and Churchs Chicken, bought Chesapeake Bagel Bakery last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAER, ROSE
description: PAER-Rose. Born Rose Sussman, age 91, of Brooklyn, NY, died in San Jose, Calif., on Jan. 25th, 1998. Widow of Henry Paer. Mother of Beryl Richardson. Loving sister and aunt and friend. Retired school secretary NYC. Funeral service on Jan. 28, 10 A.M., Plaza Memorial, 630 Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Minimalist; A Fresh Guise For Parmesan
description: A COUPLE of years ago, on a trip to central Italy, I learned one more use for what I regard as the most flexible of all cheeses, the true Italian Parmesan. A cook in a trattoria was taking handfuls of the grated stuff, sprinkling them into a skillet and forming melted-cheese pancakes. While they were still warm, he draped them over the back of a cup, to form a crisp, edible container. He filled these with a mixture of zucchini, eggplant and tomatoes, and sent them out as a first course.

title: Milken's Probation Extended to March 2
description: Michael R. Milken's probation has been extended for the eighth time as the Government keeps talking with lawyers for the former junk bond financier.

title: Calendar
description: Sampling Scotch

title: Boston's Mid-Winter Bash on Ice
description: Because of the tournament's intensity, won-lost records mean little at the Beanpot, Boston's annual mid-winter salute to college hockey. Nevertheless this year's event, the 46th, seems a little special because three of the four teams are so good.

title: Settlement Proposal Is Expected In Women's Suit Against Merrill
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and lawyers representing several of its female financial consultants are expected to announce today in Chicago a proposed settlement of a sexual discrimination lawsuit against the firm. The settlement would allow employees to bring future complaints of discrimination to mediation and then to Federal court, instead of going to binding industry arbitration, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Wine Talk; Vineyard That Attracted a Special Breed of Winemaker
description: THE death of Richard Graff in a plane crash on Jan. 9 closed another chapter in the remarkable history of Chalone Vineyards, one of California's better-known sources of fine wines.

title: Pataki Aide Testifies In Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: One of Gov. George E. Pataki's closest advisers testified yesterday before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that is seeking to determine whether potential donors to Mr. Pataki's 1994 election campaign were promised favorable rulings from the State Parole Board for their imprisoned sons in exchange for contributions.

title: New Subway Map Still Leaves Us Guessing
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Looks Matter At the Border?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Catch to Make a Chef's Heart Leap
description: IN the window at Central Fish Company on Ninth Avenue lies the produce of the sea. Tiny cockles peek through the mounds of ice, as if buried in sand. Hulking catfish glare at the neat rows of shimmering sardines, and clams are piled up like rocks. At the center of this ordered tableau is a single glistening wild striped bass -- more than two feet long -- regally posed, a prince of the Atlantic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SYD ROSSMAN
description: GOLDSTEIN-Syd Rossman. In her 95th year. From 1958 to 1962, she was National President of Woman's League for Conservative Judaism. She was currently National Treasurer of the Torah Fund Campaign. She leaves a daughter and son-in-law. Arlene and Dr. Edgar Braunstein, daughter-in-law Barbara Rossman, brother and sister-in-law Harold and Leah Sher. Grandchildren Vicki Braunstein and Dr. Steven and Laurie Braunstein, Dr. Barry and Terri Rossman, Lauri and Paul Feldman and her beloved great - grandchildren, Melissa, Stephanie, Carly, Jake, Andrew and Michael. She was beloved by all who knew her. She was predeceased by her husbands, Dr. Herbert Rossman and Louis Goldstein and a son, Dr. Melvin Rossman. Funeral service on Thursday, 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: SAGE GROUP TO BUY STATE OF THE ART
description: Sage Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire State of the Art Inc. for $22 a share, or about $263 million. State of the Art, which is based in Irvine, Calif., said Sage would begin a cash tender offer within five business days. Its shares rose $5.1875 each, to $21.6875. Sage, based in Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, England, had revenue of $250 million for the 12 months that ended on Sept. 30. Both companies make accounting software for small and medium-sized businesses.

title: Why Programming Skill Is Cheap; No Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Dinner a Long, Lazy Day in the Oven
description: YOU could fly to Paris and eat dinner and breakfast en route in the time it takes Antoine Bouterin to prepare his specialty, agneau a la cuilliere, or spoon lamb. Mr. Bouterin, the chef and owner of Bouterin restaurant on East 59th Street, puts a boned shoulder of lamb with vegetables, wine and stock in the oven, hangs a DO NOT DISTURB sign on the oven door and leaves the lamb alone for seven hours.

title: A Day of Actions and Reactions
description: A NATION LOOKS ON -- Watching with a contagious interest in nuance and deportment as much as words, Americans across the nation reacted to President Clinton's State of the Union Message with a studied mixture of varying enthusiasm for his agenda and equally divided opinions on the state of his composure. They were never more minutely attentive to physical attributes, or lack thereof, as they weighed the personal with the political. Page A18.

title: Obeying Pope, German Bishops End Role in Abortion System
description: Caught between the doctrine of their church and the laws of their land, Germany's Roman Catholic bishops bowed to the wishes of Pope John Paul II today and agreed to withhold counseling certificates that play a central part in this country's legal procedures for abortion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLY, SAMUEL
description: BLY-Samuel. On January 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Sylvia (nee Ferber) formerly of New York City. Devoted father of Eleanor and Bill. Dear brother of Sylvia Leshnik. Loving grandfather of Deborah, Will, Sarah and Rebecca. Caring great uncle of Jeff. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Wednesday, at 11:30 A.M. precisely at Beth El Cemetery (Block 24 ), Paramus, N.J. For information Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael Sacks, Phila, PA.

title: Jack Amsterdam, 91, Corporate Executive
description: Jack Amsterdam, a manufacturer of electrical equipment and a philanthropist, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 91 and had residences in Ossining, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: Huber Is the Next Obstacle On Steady March by Hingis
description: Things may have gone haywire with the men's side of the Australian Open, but Martina Hingis preserved order in her domain today by reaching the semifinals at the event where she pocketed the first of three of her Grand Slam crowns in 1997.

title: Suspicions Of Murder In a Racial Microcosm
description: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE RIVER

title: A Speech in the Eye of the Storm
description: It was, by any measure, an extraordinary moment for Washington and the country. A suddenly embattled President delivered a State of the Union address filled with optimism to a Congress and nation uncertain whether he can retain the political strength to govern. Bill Clinton probably drew a record television audience for this annual occasion because so many Americans were curious how he would handle his association with Monica Lewinsky, the subject everyone was told he would not discuss. Yet on the national and international issues that he came to address, Mr. Clinton spoke eloquently and forcefully, outlining a constructive agenda for America.

title: Restaurants; A Fresh Act Invigorates an Old Room
description: THE three best meals I have had this year have all been at the same restaurant. Peacock Alley.

title: 3 Original Lawyers for Louima Resign, Leaving Case to Cochran
description: Abner Louima's original three lawyers have resigned from representing him as he sues the city for the beating he says he received in a Brooklyn police station, one of the lawyers said yesterday.

title: 20 Charged With Helping 13,000 Cheat on Test for Citizenship
description: Federal officials indicted 20 people today on charges of falsifying the naturalization examinations of more than 13,000 legal immigrants in 22 states over the last two years.

title: Player, 2 Coaches Testify At Hearing
description: Nearly two months after Latrell Sprewell's attack on his coach, P. J. Carlesimo, jolted the National Basketball Association, one of his teammates and two Golden State Warriors coaches testified today in a hearing that grew out of the altercation.

title: Retired Officer Is Slain Trying To Thwart Robbery in Harlem
description: A 59-year-old retired police officer was shot and killed yesterday afternoon when he tried to thwart an armed robbery at a copy store in the Harlem neighborhood where he grew up, the police said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Covering Asia With Cash; Banks Poured Money Into Region Despite Warning Signs
description: A little more than a year ago, several European banks helped Garuda Indonesia airlines lease six huge Airbus jets worth $630 million. The Indonesian economy was surging, and Asian airlines were rapidly expanding their fleets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE
description: GOLDBERG-Rose. On January 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Julius, devoted mother of Leonard, Harold and Ronald. Dear mother-in-law of Kathy. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey. For service information call Riverside Memorial Chapel 212-362-6600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, BERNARD
description: SACHS-Bernard. Beloved husband of Bernice. Loving father of Mark and Sherryl. Brother of Murray and Jerry. Grandfather of Joshua. Services will be private. Donations in his memory to the Alzheimers Association will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, HENRY A.
description: LOEB-Henry A. Died Tuesday, Jan. 27, at age 90. Survived by his wife, Louise Steinhart Loeb, his children, Jean and Raymond Troubh and Betty and John Levin, his seven grandchildren, his 11 great-grandchildren, and his sister, Margaret Kempner. Interment is private. Services to be held at Tishman Auditorium, The New School, 66 West 12th St., January 30th at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The New School, or to the Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

title: Struggling City Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey Jails A Dissident Who Praised Rebel Kurds
description: In a sign of Turkey's determination to limit public praise for Kurdish guerrillas, an outspoken essayist and political scientist has been jailed to begin serving a 10-month sentence.

title: $25 and Under; A Rough Beginning but a Smooth Ending
description: THE smoky bar at Velvet was packed on my first visit there one recent evening, and simply squeezing through it to the dining room in the rear was a bruising struggle. The loud music echoing off the high ceiling, the boisterous after-work crowd and the staff, which seemed more interested in directing traffic to the seductive lounge upstairs than to the dining room, did not fill me with hope for dinner.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Neediest Cases; After a Fire, a Crowded Life Gets More Crowded
description: Had Goldilocks happened upon the Valdez apartment in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, before last year, she would have been sorely disappointed. The first bed, where the three girls slept, was way too narrow. The second bed, where Ursula Valdez slept with her son, Peter, had a hand-me-down mattress with exposed springs. And the third bed?

title: Do Looks Matter At the Border?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MICHAEL
description: GORDON-Michael. On January 25, 1998. Chairman of Koret Inc. for 31 years. Beloved father of Lord, Robert and Jennifer and grandfather of Michael. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Thursday, January 29 at 1:30 PM.

title: Contempt From an Apartheid Leader
description: The apartheid regime that P. W. Botha ruled from 1978 to 1989 never permitted black South Africans to become judges. Now, in what must be one of his worst nightmares come to life, Mr. Botha is a defendant in a black magistrate's court. His trial, for ignoring subpoenas to testify before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, has been criticized by Mr. Botha's supporters as an act of revenge on apartheid's most reviled and least repentant living figure. But Mr. Botha has defied the law and should be brought to justice.

title: Nehru Spoke It, but It's Still 'Foreign'
description: In India, the English language is (a) one of the few things that bind the nation together and connect it to the wider world, or (b) an oppressive legacy of colonialism that robs people of their native heritage and identity.

title: KERR-MCGEE TO EXIT COAL BUSINESS
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said yesterday that its board had decided to get out of the coal business as part of a plan to focus on oil, natural gas and chemicals. Kerr-McGee said it was now the seventh-largest United States coal producer. The company hired Lazard Freres & Company as a financial adviser on the matter, but said it was too early to say how the move would affect the unit's 1,000 employees. Sales at the Kerr-McGee Coal Corporation fell to $323 million last year from $365 million in 1996. Shares of Kerr-McGee, which is based in Oklahoma City, rose $1.625 yesterday, to $61.0625.

title: Academics Over Athletics
description: It is refreshing to watch the poised and polished Marsha Harris operate on the basketball court during practice for New York University. Refreshing to see Harris execute a shooting drill with precision and accuracy that would make everyone from Reggie Miller to Cheryl Miller blink.

title: Meno and Sand Earn Right to Skate
description: Jenni Meno and Todd Sand will skate in the Nagano Olympics after all.

title: Ford Reports 4th-Quarter Earnings Surge
description: Buoyed by cost reductions and strong sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles, the Ford Motor Company reported today that it earned $1.8 billion in the fourth quarter, up 49.2 percent from a year earlier and surprising Wall Street analysts, who had expected a smaller gain.

title: Networks Take a (Short) Timeout
description: The television networks took a breather from the weeklong scrimmage of covering the White House sex scandal last night to consider President Clinton's State of the Union Message. The breather lasted about 75 minutes.

title: Man's Macabre Writings Can Be Used in Trial
description: The macabre writings of a Leonia man charged with brutally killing a nurse in 1995 can be used as evidence in his capital murder trial, a state appellate panel in Hackensack ruled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, DR. JOSEPH S.
description: MURPHY-Dr. Joseph S. On behalf of the Board, the members and the students of the Consortium for Worker Education, we express our profound sadness over the passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Joseph S. Murphy. He was a dedicated advocate and leader who never forgot the importance of educational opportunity for working men and women in the labor movement. His commitment to worker education programs in CUNY will long be remembered both within and outside of the classroom. His companionship, sense of humor and intellect will be deeply missed. We express our sincere condolences to his family. Barry Feinstein, Chairman Joseph McDermott, Exec. Dir.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 19 about Pope John Paul II's appointment of 22 cardinals misstated his tenure in the papacy. He is in his 20th year, not his 19th.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about management changes at The International Herald Tribune included an outdated reference to the Westminster Press group of Britain, where the new Herald Tribune president was formerly a director. It was sold by Pearson P.L.C. last year to the Newsquest Media Group.

title: Exploding Mousse and Other New-Oven Woes
description: ON Jan. 8, the Inn at Little Washington had a small accident in the kitchen. Each and every crab and spinach mousse exploded in the restaurant's new oven, covering the inside with shreds of crab meat, bits of spinach, dribbles of egg and cream.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CONSIDERS LAYOFFS TO CUT COSTS
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said yesterday that it might lay off employees or eliminate positions as part of a cost-cutting review in the next 60 days. Chase said no specific decisions had yet been made. Chase employs about 64,000 people. In an internal memo circulated to employees last week and first reported yesterday in American Banker, Chase said it was freezing new hiring in its corporate and business support units. Chase also said it planned to trim $70 million a year from its budget by declaring a ''moratorium on the use of all management consultants,'' reducing its sponsorship of events and other measures. The company's stock rose $3.125 a share yesterday, to $105.25.

title: Ameritech Sees Big Return in New Products
description: The Ameritech Corporation said today that it planned to triple revenue growth to about $300 million from new products and services in its phone operations in 1998.

title: Dueling Soaps
description: While pundits scramble to pin a name on the Clinton brouhaha -- ''Zippergate''? ''Sexgate''? -- LYNN LEAHEY, the editor of Soap Opera Digest magazine, has a question: How could MONICA S. LEWINSKY do it?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRK, B. CONSTANCE
description: KIRK-B. Constance. On January 26, 1998. Former Secretary to the late William J. Casey. Beloved sister of June Sada, Irene Stahman and Betty-Ann Kirk. Dear sister-inlaw of Albert Stahman, M.D. Loving aunt of Paul Stahman and Lila Corwin. Visiting Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM with religious service 8 PM. Funeral service on Friday at 10 AM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, JACK
description: FRANK-Jack. On January 24, 1998. Past President of The Retired School Supervisors and Administrators Local 1R AFSA. Jack Frank was a giant of a man. I am not speaking about stature, I am speaking about intellect, character and being a fine person. Jack loved life and he loved his work. He was respected and loved in the education community. He was a superb principal. His school ranked very high in achievement. He was an innovator and he knew just what the children needed to succeed in life. He was a teacher of teachers. He was loved by those of us who were fortunate to know him. He will be missed. I can only say goodbye old friend, we will always remember you. Leonard Blumberg, President of Retired School Supervisors and Aadministrators, Local 1R AFSA

title: Civilians Will Be in Harm's Way if Baghdad Is Hit
description: Two decades of experience have taught the citizens of Baghdad a simple military lesson: when bombs are aimed at military targets in this city, civilians die.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELINKER, NATHAN
description: MELINKER-Nathan. Born on January 17, 1923 in Brooklyn, died January 16, 1998 in Castro Valley, CA. He served in the Pacific during W.W. II and earned a Bronze Star and two Purple Hearts. He graduated from NYU in 1951 with a BSEd and was a licensed Physical Therapist. His beloved wife, Yolanda, predeceased him. He is survived by his daughter, Sharon Bond and three grandchildren; Fiona, Alana, and Michael.

title: Favors and Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNON, THOMAS J.
description: CANNON-Thomas J. Of Montclair, N.J. On January 27, 1998. Husband of the late Mary. Father of Thomas J., III. Also survived by a grandson, Thomas J., IV. Brother of John B. and the late Jimmy Cannon. Funeral from the Huge M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park St, Montclair, Thursday, 9AM, then to Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair where, at 10AM, a Mass of Christian Burial will be offered. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, N.Y. Visiting 79P.M. Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM Wednesday.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar fell to the lowest level against the yen in more than two months, hurt by continued anxiety about the scandal surrounding President Clinton, a sharp retreat in Treasury bond prices and rallies in Asian markets. In New York, the dollar cost 125.32 yen, down from 126.85.

title: Do Looks Matter At the Border?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fake Sanitation Officer Robs Restaurant
description: Though he claimed to be a sanitation worker carrying out his job, a man who walked into a Korean restaurant in Queens yesterday didn't clean up the place. As the police tell it, he and two accomplices cleaned it out, walking off with about $30,000 in the store safe.

title: Sir Anthony Glyn, 75, Author Known for Spirit and Diversity
description: Sir Anthony Glyn, the free-spirited British author of a dozen books of biography, fiction and travel memoirs, died on Jan. 20 at his home in the south of France. He was 75.

title: INSIDE
description: With Violence on Rise, Blair Steps Into Ulster Talks

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONSKY, MARILYN
description: DONSKY-Marilyn. Your beauty and spirit has sustained us for ten years. Happy Birthday, our beloved. Your adoring family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, SAMUEL D.
description: MAY-Samuel D. Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life mourns the passing of Samuel D. May, beloved father of our benefactor and Board of Governors member, Peter May. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Samuel's wife Isabel, his daughter Linda Sklar, and the entire May and Sklar families. Edgar M. Bronfman, Chairman, International Board of Governors Michael B. Rukin, Chair, Board of Directors Richard M. Joel, President & International Director

title: Principals' Union Attacks Proposal for Merit Bonus
description: A day after one of New York City's premier business organizations -- with support from Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew -- offered $15,000 bonuses to outstanding principals, their union denounced the proposal as unfair and divisive, saying it would lower morale for principals who did not qualify for the rewards, and even prompt them to leave the school system.

title: Forget New York Cool: Let's Get Whimsical
description: The esthetic of moody cool so defines New York jazz -- especially musicians under 40 -- that a break in the stereotype can sound like a new world has opened. Jean-Michel Pilc, a young French pianist who has been based in New York for a few years, is the antithesis of that cool.

title: Political News Takes the Cake
description: So what does SETH GREENBERG, who created the American-flag birthday cake for President Clinton's 50th birthday at Radio City Music Hall in 1996, have to say about the distractions in Washington?

title: Henry A. Loeb Dies at 90; Philanthropist and Financier
description: Henry A. Loeb, financier and philanthropist, died yesterday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 90.

title: In Their Words
description: ''I'm not Donna Reed,'' CYNDI LAUPER, the rock star who made ''Girls Just Want to Have Fun'' a marching song for the 1980's, declared at a party for the singer PATTI LABELLE at the Fifth Avenue apartment of the songwriter DENISE RICH.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHN, LUCY
description: KOHN-Lucy. On January 26, 1998 Beloved wife of the late Julius. Also survived by many cousins and friends. Services Wednesday 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stop Drugs at Source
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: EPSTEIN-William. Of Manhattan and Shenorock, N.Y. On January 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Janice (Kaufman). Adored father of Carla Silber and loving father-inlaw of Dan. Dear brother of Theodore, the late Dr. Alexander and Lillian Carlish. Brother-in-law of Mary Kaufman and Priscilla Epstein. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca and Abigail. Dear uncle. He was the long time President of Bookazine Co., Inc. and Chairman of the Board of the Jewish Book Council. Funeral service on Wednesday, January 28th, 12:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEFLIN, MURRAY
description: SCHEFLIN-Murray. On January 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Helen, devoted father of Alan and Larry. Dear father-in-law of Jamie and Toni. Loving brother of Ginger Grossman. Cherished grandfather of Scott and Hallie. Services are on Wednesday, 1:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Respect Grieving Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Several Agencies Named for Accounts
description: Several advertisers have named agencies to handle accounts.

title: Nets Laugh Their Way Past the Nuggets
description: Not so long ago, the Nets were the laughingstocks of the National Basketball Association -- the last three seasons quickly come to mind.

title: PAXSON TO EXPAND PLANNED FAMILY TV NETWORK
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Chicago television station WCFC-TV from Christian Communications of Chicagoland Inc. for $120 million, expanding the reach of its planned family-oriented network. Paxson, based in West Palm Beach, Fla., said the purchase also included the transfer of an option for the closely held Christian Communications to buy a television station that would serve the San Francisco market. The Paxson network, which is scheduled to start in August, intends to present such family-oriented shows as ''Touched by an Angel.'' PAX NET has rerun rights to several shows and is negotiating with programmers for others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAITIN, JEAN
