description: JAITIN-Jean. On Jan. 25, 1998. Wife of Maurice. Devoted mother of Gail Jaitin and Aileen Pierce. Services Wednesday, Jan. 28, 11:30AM, at Sinai Chapel, Flushing. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to your favorite charity.

title: Sports of The Times; Hamilton And Lopez Didn't Quit
description: FRAN FRASCHILLA remembers the first team meeting he called, back in April 1996, for the eight returning St. John's basketball players: ''Two guys don't show, one has a bag of Wendy's, one has a headset on, and I knew I had to grab the bull by the horns.''

title: Transcript of the State of the Union Message From President Clinton
description: Following is President Clinton's State of the Union Message, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Metro Business; Con Ed to Raise Dividend
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York said yesterday it would increase its dividend about 1 percent.

title: State Splits Use of Orange County Land
description: In a decision closely watched by environmentalists and business leaders, the Pataki administration announced today that it would allow development of roughly 1,200 acres of state-owned open space near Stewart International Airport in Orange County, while preserving 6,200 more acres for recreation.

title: Library LP's For Lending Bite the Dust
description: Many people who love music and are of a certain age -- that is, old enough to have grown up before compact disks -- share memories of an educational ritual. It involved browsing through canyons of plastic-encased LP's at the public library, reading the spines, scanning the liner notes and gradually collecting an armful for an afternoon's private exploration. We would take these treasures to a carrel, put on headphones, carefully cue up the tone arm and play through the stack of black, 12-inch vinyl disks. If the encounter proved unusually pleasant, we might take some disks home for a week or pick up a fresh copy of one at the nearest record store.

title: SINCLAIR TO SELL 7 RADIO STATIONS FOR $126.5 MILLION
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. agreed yesterday to sell seven radio stations in Portland, Ore., and Rochester to Entertainment Communications Inc. for $126.5 million in cash. Sinclair, which is based in Baltimore, has been buying and selling television and radio stations as it seeks to increase its share of the broadcast market while complying with Federal regulations prohibiting concentrated ownership in individual markets. The stations Sinclair plans to sell to the closely held Entertainment Communications are KKSN-AM, KKSN-FM and KKRH-FM in Portland and WBBF-AM, WBEE-FM, WKLX-FM and WQRV-FM in Rochester.

title: Japan Finance Minister Resigns, Opening Way to a Shift in Policy
description: Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka formally resigned today to take responsibility for a bribery scandal, in a move that raised the possibility of a shift in Government policy to stimulate Japan's economy and help ease the rest of Asia out of its financial crisis.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Gillette, long a favorite of investors, finds itself walking an edge as thin as one of its razor blades.
description: THE Gillette Company may nick investor enthusiasm in coming months.

title: Woman Who Called Daughter Possessed Pleads Not Guilty to Her Murder
description: Vivian Miranda, a 39-year-old Long Island mother who told the police she killed her 17-year-old daughter because she was possessed by a demon, pleaded not guilty today to murder charges.

title: Disney Profits Up 18%, Aided by Theme Parks
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that profit rose 18 percent in the latest quarter, more than expected, lifted by the company's theme parks in Florida and California and its hotels.

title: W. D. Edmonds Dies at 94; Author of Historical Novels
description: Walter D. Edmonds, the author of ''Drums Along the Mohawk'' and many other historical novels set in upstate New York, died on Saturday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 94.

title: It Can't Get Much Worse for Islanders
description: With a single victory in the last 16 games, the coach seemingly on the verge of being dismissed, the general manager eager but unable to make a trade, it's miserable to be an Islander.

title: Clinton Shelving '98 Trade Bill In Favor of New I.M.F. Funds
description: With the Asian financial crisis threatening the health of the American economy, the Clinton Administration has decided to make Congressional passage of $18 billion in new contributions to the International Monetary Fund a far higher priority this year than winning authority to negotiate new trade accords, according to senior Administration officials.

title: Carole Kent Kneeland, 49, Minimized Crime in TV News
description: Carole Kent Kneeland, vice president for news at KVUE-TV in Austin, Tex., and one of the first television news directors to de-emphasize sensational crime and introduce ''truth tests'' in news reports about political advertising, died on Monday at her home in Austin. She was 49.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, BARNETT
description: KAPLAN-Barnett. Beloved husband of Renee and the late Rosalyn. Loving father of Judith Kaplan, Barbara and Mitchell Davich and stepfather to Karen and Peter Blumenfeld, Alan and Sue Adler. Devoted brother of Ruth Schneider and Florence Abrams. Brotherin-law of Muriel Fisher. Cherished grandfather of Arlyn and Eric Davich, Michael, Dalis and Jaclyn Blumenfeld and Hillel Adler. A sensitive and caring man of many interests who will be missed by all. Services at 12 noon, January 28, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMBER, ESTA
description: KAMBER-Esta. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Edward and Stanley. Cherished grandmother of Lori, Dawn, Crystal and Scott. Great grandmother of Austin. Dear sister of Al Winer. Services today, 12 Noon at The Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Man Pleads Guilty To Undervaluing Gold
description: A production supervisor at a precious metals refinery in Lakewood pleaded guilty yesterday to taking part in a 12-year scheme that cheated customers out of as much as $40 million by undervaluing gold recovered from smelted scrap.

title: Talks Continue on Knoblauch
description: The Yankees continued to explore trade talks for Chuck Knoblauch, Minnesota's All-Star second baseman, yesterday and the Twins continued to insist on the inclusion of the top pitching prospect Eric Milton in any deal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURNETT, ELOISE SENIOR
description: BURNETT-Eloise Senior. 1/28/07-8/12/96. Dearest Mom, we love you and miss you very much. The Family

title: Liberties; The Slander Strategy
description: Inside the White House, the debate goes on about the best way to destroy That Woman, as the President called Monica Lewinsky.

title: Restless Music Fans Hungry for the New; Young Record Buyers Show Little Loyalty to Bands
description: At a sleepy Tower Records in the suburb of Encino, Andrea Stover, 13, was combing the aisles for CD's with her mother and her younger sister. In her hands, she had debut CD's by the rhythm-and-blues singer Usher and the pint-size pop siblings Hanson. Asked whether she would buy follow-up albums by these artists, Andrea responded, ''Why would I get the same group again?''

title: Business Travel; Proposed alliance between Continental and Northwest is expected to push air fares higher.
description: AIR fares for business and leisure travelers are likely to rise in the wake of the proposed alliance between Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines, travel and airline pricing experts say, but not necessarily steeply or for the long term. And joining the carriers' frequent-flier programs, which is expected by June 1, will open many new foreign and domestic destinations to members of both existing programs.

title: Bonuses for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Arnott Confronts Oilers And Jitters
description: Three weeks after the fact, Jason Arnott admits he still calls the Edmonton Oilers ''we.'' And he hears about it from his new teammates when he does.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Mrs. Clinton on NBC
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Hillary Rodham Clinton by Matt Lauer on the NBC program ''Today,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Bankrupt Wiz Chain to Be Bought by Cablevision in Surprise Deal
description: The Wiz, the consumer electronics retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection last month, staved off a going-out-of-business sale last night when it reached a deal with a surprise suitor: Cablevision Systems Corporation, which offered to buy the 36-store chain for about $100 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTERDAM, JACK
description: AMSTERDAM-Jack. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jack Amsterdam, a generous supporter of UJA-Federation. Through his generosity to our Capital Development Fund, he strengthened health-care services at Long Island Jewish Medical Center and Mount Sinai Medical Center, and improved six UJA-Federation-affiliated community centers on Long Island. We extend our sincerest condolences to his beloved daughter, Dasha Epstein; his grandchildren, Robert and Danielle; his sister, Jean Ross; and the entire Amsterdam and Leviton families. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Why The Rush To Ban Cloning?
description: Richard Seed, the retired physicist who scared the nation to death earlier this month with his talk of creating a brave new biological world, has inadvertently become the poster boy for regulating cloning. It does not seem to matter that Dr. Seed, who has none of the laboratories, technical skills, money or other tools requisite to harness this powerful and dangerous technology, will never clone anyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHLER, ANDRE
description: HIRSCHLER-Andre. He was much esteemed in the cooperative community in which he lived and served for many years as President of the Board and most recently as a Director. We found Mr. Hirschler at all times a man of understanding, sympathy, learning and integrity who always sought to do his duty honorably and justly and was recognized as one whose acts and deeds were worthy of emulation. May the bereaved family find solace in the inspiring memories of the exemplary life of Andre Hirschler. Fellow Coop Board members and Shareholders Fifth 912 Corporation

title: Hong Kong Journal; The Year of the Fortuneteller: Misfortune Abounds
description: At the turn of the Lunar New Year each year, Hong Kongers flood to the Wong Tai Sin Temple in northern Kowloon seeking help, advice, solace, wisdom, wealth and, not infrequently, luck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, GAVIN H.
description: WATSON-Gavin H., 91. Died on Saturday, January 24, 1998 at his home in Sullivan. He was born in Passaic, NJ, March 13, 1906, the son of William W. and Anne (Gay) Watson. Gavin graduated from Williams College in 1929, at which time he enrolled at Harvard Business School, graduating in 1932. Gavin was managing editor for the Value Line Investment Survey, and became president of Value Line Securities, Inc. in New York City, from which he retired in 1966. Following his retirement, he and his wife, Ruth purchased a farm in Sullivan called Flanders Reach, to become a gentleman farmer and private investor. Gavin became a Selectman of the town of Sullivan, eventually becoming First Selectman. He was a director of the Maine Seacoast Mission Society and the Robert Abbe Museum of Stone Age Antiquities. Gavin was active in and a lifelong member of the Republican Party. Gavin is survived by 2 sons, Gavin H. Watson, Jr. of Orlando, Florida, and William W. Watson II of Fayston, VT; four grandchildren, the children of his late daughter, Andrea Day, Amy H. Day, Fairfield P. Day III; and the children of his son, Gavin, Gavin H. Watson, III, and Whitney W. Anderson; 1 great grandchild, William W. Watson. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced in the summer. Gifts in memory of Gavin may be sent to the Maine Seacoast Mission, 127 West Street, Bar Harbor, ME. 04609, or to the Robert Abbe Museum, PO Box 286, Bar Harbor, ME. 04609. For information Bragdon - Kelley - Campbell Funeral Home, Ellsworth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, SAMUEL
description: HURWITZ-Samuel. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Samuel Hurwitz, beloved father of ADL Vice Chair, Judi Krupp, and father-in-law of Douglas, an ADL National Commissioner. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Judi, Douglas, and the Hurwitz-Krupp family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Dress Code: The Last Gasp
description: ADAM DOLLE was looking forward to a big night out. The date was Dec. 16, his 47th birthday, and Mr. Dolle, an interior decorator, had a dinner reservation at Le Cirque 2000 with his roommate. It would be an exaggeration to say he was dressed like a million bucks. He was dressed, to be precise, like 4,050 bucks, attired in a $700 Ralph Lauren pearl-gray-and-beige sport coat, a $30 Barneys T-shirt, a $300 gray cashmere polo shirt buttoned to the neck, a $200 pair of gray gabardine trousers from New Republic, a $20 pair of heathered McLaughlin socks, a $300 pair of suede Gucci loafers and a $2,500 Bulgari watch. It was a look that Mr. Dolle characterizes as ''urbanely chic'' and ''discreetly in the know.''

title: Why Programming Skill Is Cheap
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald Davis, 69, Actor in Challenging Roles
description: Donald Davis, the distinguished Canadian actor who played the title role in the New York premiere of Samuel Beckett's ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' died on Friday at Wellesley Hospital in Toronto, where he lived. He was 69.

title: If Only for an Hour, Playing By the Time-Honored Rules
description: What is usually a gladiator's arena was instead a soothing cocoon. With thundering applause rolling over him from both sides of the aisle, the President took command with a steady smile and smooth diction, and the suspense quickly ebbed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEFF, FRANCES L.
description: SCHEFF-Frances L. 89 years old. On January 25th, 1998. Widow of Samuel Scheff, mother of Trudy Brown and Joan Lipsitz, father-inlaw of Julius Brown and Paul Stiller. Devoted grandmother of Cathy, Susan, Annie, and Jonathan. Great grandmother of Gabby, Zoe, Lucy Kate, Aaron Jeremy, and Zachary. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Emily's List or the Children's Library of Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore.

title: Euro RSCG Unit In Reorganization
description: Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White in Salt Lake City and San Francisco is being renamed Euro RSCG DSW Partners to reflect a restructuring that includes the appointments of four additional partners.

title: A New Restaurant Replaces a Village Landmark
description: THE Coach House, which was founded nearly 50 years ago, has stood silent and shuttered on Waverly Place just off Washington Square since 1993. But for many New Yorkers, compelling memories linger -- of the days when people from all over the city, if they were feeling flush and celebratory, would head there as certainly as they do to Aureole or Le Cirque 2000 today. Residents of Greenwich Village thought of the Coach House as their own -- the rare, fine restaurant nearby. Then it went vacant. And stayed that way, abandoned and forlorn.

title: Partial Halt By Indonesia On Payments
description: Attacking one of its biggest economic challenges, Indonesia on Tuesday announced a ''temporary pause'' in payments on billions of dollars in private debt to overseas lenders, formalizing a halt on repayment that had already taken effect quietly among most corporations.

title: Turf; Gold Turns Up on Tar Beach
description: EVERY Manhattan neighborhood is cobwebbed these days with scaffolding; cranes are hoisting lanky steel girders up the sides of apartment towers as developers create yet another penthouse, as it were, out of thin air.

title: Ex-Head of a Police Union Pleads Guilty to Perjury
description: The former president of the defunct housing police union has pleaded guilty to lying before a Federal grand jury that was investigating a corruption case involving another union, according to documents unsealed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Now They Are Leading Creative Lives
description: Perhaps there was something funny in the water cooler at First Pennco, which was a big bond trading firm back in the 1970's. Maybe the firm hired extraordinary people. Or maybe working at a place that was on top one day and liquidated almost the next (the firm's parent bank ran into trouble) had some seismic effect on employees.

title: In America; The Feminist Dilemma
description: The initial public reaction of feminists and other women's advocates to President Clinton's latest trouble can most charitably be described as restrained. They have a problem:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRALLA, GENE
description: GRALLA-Gene. Loving father of Andy and Joan. Devoted brother of Edna, Arthur, Muriel, and Lynn. Caring uncle. Good friend to so many. Educator, Naval Officer and Volunteer. Memorial Service Sunday, February 1, at 2 P.M. at The Unitarian Church, Summit, New Jersey, and later at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Reeves-Reed Arboretum, 165 Hobart Avenue, Summit, NJ 07901.

title: Revenge? No, Remorse. Knicks Lose to Heat Again.
description: Tim Hardaway recreated a scene that played itself out last May. On that day, Hardaway scored 38 points to send the Knicks home for the summer, left to live with the frustrations of a suspension-marred playoff series for eight months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTERDAM, JACK
description: AMSTERDAM-Jack. The Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed life member and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Murray B. Hirsch, President Howard Ecker, Secretary

title: The First Indictments In Campaign Inquiry
description: In the first criminal charges in the long-running investigation, a Federal grand jury in Washington yesterday indicted two Democratic fund-raisers, including Yah Lin Trie. They were accused of illegally funneling contributions through people who were used to disguise the identities of the actual donors. No higher-ranking officials were implicated.

title: Pataki's Dairy Farm Plan Risks Consumers' Anger
description: The beleaguered dairy farmers of upstate New York have long demanded an increase in milk prices, warning lawmakers here that after years of rising costs and stagnant incomes, farms are going out of business at a startling rate.

title: German Bank Acts to Shield Itself on Asia
description: The Asian financial crisis reached into the heart of Europe's banking system today, when the biggest bank in Germany announced that it would set aside $777 million to cover potentially soured loans in the region.

title: Santa Fe to Add 4 Rigs
description: The Santa Fe International Corporation said today that it would add four rigs to its land rig fleet in Venezuela at a cost of $75 million. Santa Fe, based in Dallas, owns and operates 26 marine drilling rigs and 28 land drilling rigs in 16 countries and provides drilling-related services to the petroleum industry. Santa Fe said the $75 million expansion resulted from commitments by petroleum companies looking for oil in Venezuela.

title: Metro Business; Trump Casino Pays Fine
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts has paid a penalty of $477,000 for failing to file timely reports on currency transactions, as required by the Bank Secrecy Act, the United States Treasury said yesterday.

title: Israel Sketches Out an Overall Drop in U.S. Aid Over 10 Years
description: Israel's Finance Minister met with Administration and Congressional officials today to outline a proposal by the Israeli Government to phase out $1.2 billion in annual economic aid from the United States in exchange for a $600 million increase in Washington's yearly military aid package.

title: Signs of Progress in Bosnia
description: The pessimists about Bosnia have always found plenty of supporting evidence in the Serb Republic. While supposedly a part of Bosnia, this enclave of Bosnian Serbs has been dominated by followers of Radovan Karadzic, the virulent nationalist who has long thwarted any chance of a multi-ethnic Bosnian state. But that may be changing. Earlier this month a newly elected Serbian parliament chose as prime minister a moderate 38-year-old who has formed a coalition with Muslims. While the new leader, Milorad Dodik, has a precarious hold on power and faces great obstacles, his election suggests that lasting peace in Bosnia is more possible than it seemed a year ago.

title: A Consortium Bids On Italian Phone License
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that it was bidding for Italy's third mobile phone license through a consortium that includes five other companies. The consortium -- Picienne Italia S.p.A. -- also includes Mediaset S.p.A.; Telenor, Norway's national phone company; Banca Nazionale del Lavoro; Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni S.p.A., and Italgas. The group is willing to invest $:3 billion, or $4.93 billion, in the venture.

title: Best Buy to End Apple PC Sales
description: The Best Buy Company, operator of electronics and office stores in 32 states, said yesterday that it would no longer carry Apple Computer Inc. computers. But the company will continue stocking Apple software products, a Best Buy spokeswoman.

title: 2 Vintage Archetypes in a 60's Suite
description: Watching K. T. Sullivan and Jeff Harnar interact on the tiny platform stage of the Firebird Cafe (363 West 46th Street), a plushly ornate new cabaret in the theater district, it is possible to imagine you have been catapulted back to the polite nightclub world of the mid-1960's.

title: Study of Brains Alters the View On Path of M.S.
description: Medical scientists thought they understood multiple sclerosis. Its central feature, they said, was a relentless loss of the insulation that sheathes nerve cells, causing a short-circuit in the electrical signals passing through the cells.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Dracaena Rises Again

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIS, IRA EUGENE
description: PARIS-Ira Eugene. Beloved husband of Viviane. Father of Glenn. Loving step-father of Nicole Joy and Douglas Rubens. Grandfather of Alexandra and Molly. Special Gampi to his cherished Lexie. Service Thursday 10AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Conservative Talk Radio Finding Cause for Revelry
description: On G. Gordon Liddy's radio show, the question of the week is this: Will President Gore pardon Bill Clinton? (And the answer is no, Mr. Gore will probably learn from Gerald Ford's mistake and opt to improve his chances for election instead.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, SAM
description: GARSON-Sam. On January 28, 1998, at the age of 91. Father of Gerald P. Garson, Justice of the NYS Supreme Court. Husband of the late Eva Garson, a woman of valor. Grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle, devoted brother and to all who knew him, he was oneof-a-kind. Services today, 1 PM, Weinstein West End Funeral Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Starwood Approved To Operate Casino
description: State regulators yesterday conditionally approved Phoenix-based Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide as the new operator of Caesar's Atlantic City under Starwood's pending $13.7 acquisition of the casino's owner, the ITT Corporation. The so-called interim casino authorization granted by the Casino Control Commission would, if the ITT deal goes through, place Caesar's in the hands of a trustee for nine months while state gambling officials check the background of Starwood's principals, said Daniel Heneghan, a spokesman for the commission.

title: Independent Counsel Act Is Two-Edged Sword; Philosopher Presidents?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, BARNETT
description: KAPLAN-Barnett. Our condolences to the Kaplan, Blumenfeld, and Davich families on the unexpected passing of their loved one. H. L. Dalis Inc.

title: 2 Democratic Party Fund-Raisers Are Charged With Felonies
description: A Federal grand jury returned the first criminal charges today in the long-running campaign finance inquiry, charging two Democratic fund-raisers with illegally funneling contributions through people who were used to disguise the actual donors, law-enforcement officials said.

title: O'Meara and Woods on Center Stage
description: When Mark O'Meara thinks about Pebble Beach, he thinks about winning. Last year, O'Meara won the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am for the fifth time, more than any player in the tournament's history. So when Tiger Woods was looking for a playing partner this week, no wonder he asked to play the first three rounds with O'Meara.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR REBOUNDS. The dollar bounced back against the mark as the outlook for the German economy continued to look gloomy and a Bundesbank official said an interest rate increase was unlikely any time soon. The dollar ended in New York at 1.8120 marks, up from 1.7892.

title: Big Deal; If Only These Walls Could Speak
description: Manhattan

title: Knoblauch for the Moon?
description: When the Montreal Expos traded Pedro Martinez last fall, they received two minor league prospects from Boston for perhaps the best pitcher in the game. The Minnesota Twins, on the other hand, want five good young players in return for Chuck Knoblauch, the All-Star second baseman.

title: Celebrating Skitch
description: No one watched the President's speech at an 80th birthday party for SKITCH HENDERSON, the conductor and founder of the New York Pops (which is holding another celebration tonight at Carnegie Hall). But the host and hostess, the pianist GARY GRAFFMAN and his wife, NAOMI, were ready, just in case. Having been advised that WALTER CRONKITE was on the guest list, they resuscitated a long-dormant television set. Mrs. Graffman said that after fiddling with the antenna (no cable), she could tune in one station, WCBS-TV, the flagship station of Mr. Cronkite's old network, as opposed to WNBC-TV, the flagship station of Mr. Henderson's old network. He was the music director of the ''Tonight'' show with Steve Allen in the 1950's and again when Johnny Carson was behind the desk in the 1960's. Musicians still talk about the time Mr. Henderson rehearsed Van Cliburn and Louis Armstrong in the same hour.

title: Ex-Intern Said to Describe Clinton Advice on Evasion
description: Monica S. Lewinsky is claiming that President Clinton told her at a private meeting late last month that she could testify in the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit that her visits to him at the White House were to see his secretary. She says he also suggested that she could avoid testifying by being in New York City.

title: Monthly Drop For Durables Is the Biggest In Six Years
description: The aircraft industry's order book dried up in December, causing orders for durable goods to fall 6.1 percent, the largest monthly drop in six years. Outside of aircraft, though, orders rose for the first time since September, a sign that heavy industry remained healthy.

title: Expressions in Wood From Master Workers
description: There's not a salad bowl in sight, but 86 other wood objects are on view in ''Expressions in Wood,'' which opened Tuesday at the American Craft Museum. Often, decoration is intrinsic in the swirling grain of the wood, as in a spare but graceful vessel (above) by Dan Kvitka, who works in Portland, Ore. Through March 22 at 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535.

title: Buoyed by the Policy and Troubled by the Personal
description: At Philip's Luncheonette, where patrons still smoke with their coffee and dump salt on their fries, the waitress, Claire Stellou, had watched; so had the mailman stopping in, Fred Callahan. So had John Merian of Tuxedos by Merian across the street, and Ronald Manning at Exclusive Styles, the unisex hair salon nearby.

title: Bridge; A Top Women's Partnership Gets a Break and Uses It
description: Very few women's partnerships have a claim to being considered the best in the world. One is British: Nicola Smith and Pat Davies, who have two world championships each and many European titles. Last week they finished second in the prestigious Macallan Invitational in London. They had a score that would have won in some other years, and it was the best effort ever by a women's pair in an invitational event of this type, crowded with players of world caliber.

title: National News Briefs; Steven Spielberg Wins Plagiarism Case
description: A trial of the director Steven Spielberg on plagiarism charges ended in victory for him today as a Federal District Court jury here deliberated less than two hours before finding that Mr. Spielberg and his co-defendants did not steal the idea for their 1996 hit film ''Twister.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS INC., Parsippany, N.J., a packaged foods company whose best-known brands are Chef Boyardee, Bumble Bee Tuna and Gulden's Mustard, will buy Unilever Canada's Puritan line of canned stews and meats for an undisclosed price.

title: Correction
description: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about a deal between Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines referred incorrectly to a large Continental shareholder, David Bonderman. While Air Partners, the investment group led by Mr. Bonderman, is selling its stake in Continental, he will continue to own more than 800,000 class B shares, and will remain on the company's board.

title: Brazil, Its Forests Besieged, Adds Teeth to Environmental Laws
description: The Brazilian Congress voted today to give the federal environmental agency legal authority to enforce environmental protection laws, two days after Government figures showed destruction of the Amazon rain forest reached record levels in the mid-1990's.

title: Baghdad May Ask Court in Hague to Intervene in Inspection Crisis
description: Blaming the United States and the head of the United Nations disarmament commission for creating a ''fabricated crisis,'' Iraq said today that it was considering asking the International Court of Justice to intervene in the confrontation over arms inspections.

title: PMS Is Emotional, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: NOBLE BUYING OIL PROPERTIES FROM NEW ENGLAND ELECTRIC
description: Noble Affiliates Inc. said yesterday that its Samedan Oil Corporation unit had agreed to buy oil and gas properties from New England Energy Inc., a subsidiary of the New England Electric System, for $50 million, increasing its reserves in the Gulf of Mexico. Noble Affiliates, based in Ardmore, Okla., conducts operations throughout the offshore basins of the United States. The acquisition consists of interests ranging from 7.5 percent to 50 percent in 33 Gulf of Mexico leases and interests ranging from 3.2 percent to 50 percent in four oil and gas fields in Texas and Wyoming. The properties were being managed by Samedan in a joint venture with New England Energy.

title: Final Days, And Laughing All the Way
description: It's show night on Stage Nine at Studio City, and up in the bleachers above the familiar New York apartment set, the comic warming up the audience gets a big laugh when he calls himself ''The $5-million-dollar-an-episode man!''

title: Personal Shopper; Lamps Clad In Cloaks Of Invisibility
description: MAYBE it's an optical illusion, but a clear glass lamp seems to take up less table space than its size suggests. Howard Pasternack, a New York interior designer, even thinks glass table lamps give twice as much light. ''The glass itself glows,'' he said.

title: Confidence Grows in Clinton's Ability to Remain Effective
description: The State of the Union address appears to have bolstered the American public's view that President Clinton can continue to govern effectively and accomplish policy goals, but the public remains divided on the issues surrounding accusations of an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, according to several polls conducted immediately after the President's speech.

title: Our Towns; Frozen North Doesn't Jump For Hot News
description: WITH the news on the television at Kegler's Lounge and Restaurant, the lunchtime regulars were slightly distracted from their post-Super Bowl quarterbacking. Todd LaVere, behind the bar, heard President Clinton's name and gave a little smile.

title: Two Births Lengthen List In One-Man H.I.V. Spree
description: Two women infected with H.I.V. by Nushawn J. Williams have given birth to babies who are also infected with the virus that causes AIDS, raising the number of H.I.V. cases in western New York linked to him to 16, state health officials said today.

title: There'll Be Grazing In the Lobby's Herb Gardens (But for Chefs Only)
description: Imagine a Manhattan hotel lobby with lemon verbena, flowering chives, rosemary, lavender and thyme growing in large wooden planters. When renovations are completed this fall, the Doral Inn on Lexington Avenue at 49th Street will look like a spa -- there will even be a juice bar in the lobby. Gingko leaves will be pressed between panes of glass in frames around the windows, and handpainted silk will swathe columns.

title: Independent Counsel Act Is Two-Edged Sword; Congress Has Latitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUZUKI, SHINICHI
description: SUZUKI-Shinichi. The entire School for Strings familychildren, parents, teacher trainees, faculty, alumni and the Board of Trustees-deeply feel the loss of the great educator, Dr. Shinichi Suzuki, whose humanitarian principles and unwavering faith in the ability of children have inspired us for over 25 years. Louise Behrend Founder and Director Alexander Yudkovsky, Executive Director Sheila Keats Associate Director Emerita Melanie Shorin, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGART, ESTHER
description: BOGART-Esther, 72. Died Jan. 26, 1998. She lived in Douglas, MI. for the past five years, having moved from East Williston, LI. She had worked for Lord & Taylor, and Payne, Wood and Littlejohn. She was a member of the Brookville Reformed Church, Community Church of Douglas, and H.A.S.P. of Hope College. Surviving are a sister, Janet Wolbrink of Fennville; nieces and nephews. A celebration of thanksgiving for her life, will be held at the Brookville Reformed Church, Brookville, New York on Saturday, January 31, at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: A McGraw Is to Head McGraw-Hill Again
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies announced yesterday that Harold McGraw 3d, the company's president, would become chief executive in April. He would become the first member of the company's founding family to hold the position in 15 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HENRIETTA (NEE GOLD)
description: KRAMER-Henrietta (nee Gold). Worked as a telephone operator for the Furriers Union, 1935-1947. Was a loving wife, mother, grandmother, aunt. Funeral will be held at the Brett Schneider/Parkside Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY, today, 1 PM. Burial at Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Many Turn Deaf Ear to Scandal
description: Jack McHale, 80, does not believe it. Arvin Gee, 24, does not want to hear about it. And Tanya Lieb, 42, does not care.

title: Now It's a Numbers Game
description: The words written on the board outside Coach Colin Campbell's office today provided an important reminder to the Rangers.

title: Cuba's Protestant Churches: A Growing Flock
description: When Mercedes Garcia found herself drowning the emptiness in her soul with bottle after bottle of cheap golden rum, she turned not to the Roman Catholic Church, but to a lively Pentecostal congregation where worshipers call the Holy Spirit from the heavens three times a week to heal the hungry, the sick and the lost.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: G.O.P. Opens Attack on the President's New Spending Plans
description: Republican Congressional leaders today began a battle against President Clinton's new agenda, saying his spending proposals would revive the era of big government that he so dramatically declared dead just two years ago.

title: Valentin to Get $25 Million Contract
description: The yearlong disenchantment of John Valentin turned to economic satisfaction yesterday. His agent, Richard Moss, and the Boston Red Sox concluded negotiations on a new contract, agreeing to a four-year deal for $25 million.

title: Metro Business; WNBC Gets Quieter Copter
description: The television news operation of WNBC, Channel 4, said this week that it had leased a new helicopter designed, in part, to address the noise complaints of many New York residents.

title: Too Many Missing Judges
description: The new troubles at the White House will not make it any easier to overcome the obstructionism of a few Senate Republicans who have stalled approval of President Clinton's nominations to the Federal judiciary. But this does not alter the Senate's duty to rise above the ideological warfare that has led to vacancies in more than 1 out of 10 seats on the Federal bench.

title: Meciar Dominates Slovak Election
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  The red neon numbers glaring down from a Bratislava building near the gracious 17th-century presidential palace are a rude reminder to Slovakia's president, Michal Kovac.

title: Domesticating Indian Textiles for American Homes, Tastes and Sizes
description: Tie-dyed silks and cottons in a panoply of indigos and magentas, ochers and emerald greens are traditional in India. But seldom have those fabrics been turned into tablecloths that measure 70 by 90 inches (above, $175), or into cotton duvet covers that go up to king size ($350 to $450).

title: Willy A. Fiedler, 89, a Leading Missile Expert
description: Willy A. Fiedler, a German-born aerospace expert who was active in Nazi Germany's V-1 ramjet-powered missile program and helped design American submarine-launched missiles like the Polaris after the war, died on Jan. 17 at his home in Los Altos Hills, Calif. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITBARTH, LAUREL
description: BREITBARTH-Laurel. In Westport, Conn., January 26, 1998. Loving wife of S. Robert Breitbarth. Devoted mother of Meredeth Breitbarth and Jill Breitbarth. Cherished sister of Lester Stroh, Claire Lang, Dorothy Grossman, and adored grandmother of Zoe Adams. Services are on Thursday at 2 P.M. from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Road, Westport, Conn. Interment following at Temple Israel Cemetery, Norwalk, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, BEATRICE
description: FIELD-Beatrice. NCJW New York Section mourns the loss of Bea Field, a dedicated, devoted member constantly planning for the future. Her special interest in this organization will be very much missed. Bernice Friedes, Jean Krosner Co-Presidents Helen Caplin Heller, Exec Dir

title: Earnings Up at Philip Morris Before Extraordinary Items
description: The Philip Morris Companies reported yesterday that earnings before extraordinary items rose more than 10 percent in the fourth quarter, as higher cigarette prices helped to offset the negative effects of a strong dollar.

title: An Unnecessary Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: With a Sled in Tow, Treks Can Be Swifter
description: Ever wonder what it is like to schlep a dog sled through the snow without the dogs?

title: Carlesimo and Sprewell Face to Face Again
description: Latrell Sprewell and P. J. Carlesimo sat in the same room today for the first time since Sprewell attacked Carlesimo nearly two months ago, as Golden State Warriors players and coaches continued to give their versions of the Dec. 1 altercations.

title: Federal Express Now FDX
description: The Federal Express Corporation changed its name to the FDX Corporation today, after it completed its $2.25 billion purchase of the trucking company Caliber System Inc. on Tuesday. Caliber will help FDX better compete with United Parcel Services of America Inc. because it adds an extensive trucking system to Federal Express's airplane fleet. Caliber's RPS Inc. unit is the fourth-largest express package carrier in the United States.

title: VW Is Fined $111 Million in Antitrust Case
description: The European Commission has fined Volkswagen A.G. a record 102 million European Currency Units, or about $111 million, because its Italian dealers broke European Union antitrust law by refusing to sell cars to Germans and Austrians seeking lower prices.

title: Now, Grisham By E-Mail
description: Wednesday is Independence Day for the book community. That is, it's Grisham Day, which means that 2.5 million hardcover copies of John Grisham's latest novel go on sale in every bookstore in the United States and Canada, large and small, independent and chain, as well as every retail outlet that sells books, and every supermarket and airport and record-store bookstall. And that means joy, without a blush and almost beatific, for every store owner or manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, MARIE VIRGINIA (SINGLETON)
description: BURNS-Marie Virginia (Singleton), January 9. Resident, NYC 1909-1934; Huntington, NY, 1950-87. Widow, Grumman retiree, William J. Burns. Mother Patricia Spaltro, Lisbeth Fisher Burns, Claudia Burns and William J. Burns, III, Grandmother, Anthony Spaltro, David Coleman, and Christopher and Alec Burns. Graduate Julia Richman High and Hunter College. Memorial service at 10 A.M., on May 23rd, at Old First Church, Huntington. Interment 11:30 A.M., Nassau Knolls, Port Washington. Donations Salvation Army.

title: Feisty Women, With Men Too Cool to Notice
description: The best came last when the Washington Ballet breezed into the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night for a one-week season. Nils Christe's ''Sync,'' which ended the program, is a bright and sassy ballet for a group of modern-day ballet sylphs and the men who wander in and out among them. Set to propulsive, sometimes jazzily percussive music by Ludovico Einaudi, ''Sync'' deposits seven women in sleek crimson-and-black practice clothes in open space with a long, lowered lighting grid at the back.

title: A Gumbel Returns To Black Rock
description: Greg Gumbel will return to CBS Sports on March 1, in time for the network's broadcasts of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament. After a four-year stint with NBC Sports, Gumbel is following the American Football Conference contract from NBC to CBS.

title: Mobil Profit Hurt by Lower Demand in Asia
description: The Mobil Corporation said today that operating profit fell 8 percent in the fourth quarter as a drop in crude oil prices and falling Asian energy demand outweighed an improvement in refining profit margins in this country. Net income, reflecting charges, rose 5 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SYD ROSSMAN
description: GOLDSTEIN-Syd Rossman. In her 95th year. From 1958 to 1962, she was National President of Woman's League for Conservative Judaism. She was currently National Treasurer of the Torah Fund Campaign. She leaves a daughter and son-in-law. Arlene and Dr. Edgar Braunstein, daughter-in-law Barbara Rossman, brother and sister-in-law Harold and Leah Sher. Grandchildren Vicki Braunstein and Dr. Steven and Laurie Braunstein, Dr. Barry and Terri Rossman, Lauri and Paul Feldman and her beloved great - grandchildren, Melissa, Stephanie, Carly, Jake, Andrew and Michael. She was beloved by all who knew her. She was predeceased by her husbands, Dr. Herbert Rossman and Louis Goldstein and a son, Dr. Melvin Rossman. Funeral service on Thursday, 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANSON, SUSAN SHEPARD
description: SWANSON-Susan Shepard. On January 27 after a courageous battle against cancer. She is survived by her husband Eric; her daughter Jessica Malawski; her mother Louise Loud of Gloucester, Massachusetts; her father Alfred Oxenham of Willmette, Illinois; her brother Peter Oxenham of Stamford, Connecticut; and her brothers Richard and John Loud of Gloucester. Visiting on Friday, January 30, 4-6 PM at Morehead, Mc Kim, and Gallagher, 422 W. 51 Street. Funeral service will be at the First Presbyterian Church, 5th Avenue and 12th Street, N.Y.C. at 10:30 A.M., Saturday, January 31. Contributions in Susan's memory may be made to The Young People's Chorus of New York City, C/O the 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10128.

title: 2 Competitors Criticize Deloitte Survey on Pending Mergers
description: When Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, released a survey yesterday that said the majority of more than 600 executives around the world were opposed to the two pending mergers among their competitors, the firm's partners may not have been prepared for the response.

title: Albright Says U.S. Could Act Alone Against Baghdad
description: On the eve of a diplomatic mission to Europe and the Persian Gulf, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that the United States was ready to act alone, if necessary, to punish Iraq for its attempts to develop chemical and biological weapons.

title: Giuliani Moves Quickly to Defend Budget Before It Comes Out
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani moved swiftly yesterday to head off criticism of his new budget even before formally releasing it, defending his plan to channel most of an expected $1.2 billion surplus in the current fiscal year toward closing projected shortfalls in the next two years.

title: Banks in Accord to Extend $24 Billion in Korea Loans
description: South Korean banks and their international creditors reached an agreement late last night to extend payment on $24 billion in short-term loans, granting the country an important reprieve in the financial crisis that has afflicted much of Asia since last summer.

title: Of Gershwin as Kin of Schubert
description: If the classical music business could design its own centennial dedicatees, the prototype would assuredly be Brahms (1833-1897). Brahms's music is old enough not to threaten audiences and new enough to fit into modern concert halls. In the scheduling of Brahms symphonies across the land last year, managements could give listeners what they already knew and make it sound high-minded.

title: Two Groups Present Awards
description: Awards have been presented in two competitions sponsored by the New York Festivals.

title: Turner Broadcasting Appoints President
description: The Turner Broadcasting System, a unit of Time Warner Inc., said yesterday that it had promoted Steven Heyer to president and chief operating officer.

title: Independent Counsel Act Is Two-Edged Sword; Girls and Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Detective Is Shot in Leg While Arresting an Escapee
description: A police detective was shot in the leg last night by an escaped prisoner discovered hiding beneath a bed in a friend's apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said.

title: Titanic Wasn't the Only Leaky Ship at Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Minority Applications Rise In California, Easing Fears
description: Despite fears that abandoning affirmative action policies in California would sharply decrease the number of minority applicants to the University of California system, there has been a small but significant increase in applications from blacks, Mexican-Americans, Indians and Filipino-Americans, largely reversing a two-year decline, the university reported yesterday.

title: A New Chapter
description: ''I'm doing readings again,'' declared JEANNETTE WATSON, whose venerated Madison Avenue literary trove, Books & Company, closed last year. But now the readings -- a weekly fixture on customers' calendars for 20 years -- are being held down the avenue, at No. 457, the Municipal Art Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MICHAEL
description: GORDON-Michael. On January 25, 1998. Chairman of Koret Inc. for 31 years. Beloved father of Lord, Robert and Jennifer and grandfather of Michael. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Thursday, January 29 at 1:30 PM.

title: Independent Counsel Act Is Two-Edged Sword; Tarnished Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Slower Times at American High Schools
description: On a winter night in 1977, Kevin Byrne, a 17-year-old distance runner from New Jersey, brought a Madison Square Garden crowd of 18,235 to its feet with a record-breaking triumph in the national-invitation high school mile race at the Millrose Games indoor track meet.

title: Rocky Travel Times On Air Force One
description: Some trips are jinxed, even if the airline is the Air Force and the passenger is the President.

title: As President Takes to the Stump, His Former Chief of Staff Testifies
description: As President Clinton barnstormed in the Middle West to sell the policies he outlined in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, his former chief of staff Leon E. Panetta testified before a Federal grand jury here today that he was not aware of any relationship between the President and an intern who once worked in Mr. Panetta's office.

title: Educators Say Clinton's Plan On Class Size Faces Problems
description: President Clinton's plan to raise the achievement of schoolchildren across America by reducing the size of their classes to 18 from an average of 22 has the dramatic appeal of a simple idea.

title: On the Record, Arab Leaders Oppose U.S. Attacks on Iraq
description: As the United States intensifies its threat to use military force against Iraq, Arab leaders are once again voicing strong public opposition to that course. But some officials are reportedly hinting in private that they would not be altogether dismayed if the United States did carry out military attacks.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS KARP, MARJE
description: FIELDS KARP-Marje. January 27, 1998. Services Friday, 9:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. She is predeceased by her husband, Oscar Karp. Survived by her niece, Sue Ruskin-Mayher, her nephew, Marc Greene, two great-nieces, Nicole and Joanna Ruskin. In lieu of flowers, donations can by made to the Alzheimer's Association or the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital, NY, NY 10013.

title: Accounts
description: * Bayer Diagnostics, Tarrytown, N.Y., to Lehman Millet Inc., Boston, to handle advertising for the Diagnostics Laboratory and Point-of-Care testing units, which had been handled by CRE Communications, Indianapolis. Billings were estimated at more than $3 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, ROBERT E.
description: LEWIS-Robert E. Late of Port Washington, NY. A memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock, 48 Shelter Rock Rd, Manhasset, NY, Sat, Jan. 31 at 2 p.m.

title: French Bank Said To Buy Peregrine Unit
description: Banque Nationale de Paris S.A. will reportedly buy the equity division of Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd. in Hong Kong and in China. Banque Nationale de Paris is said to have signed an agreement for the acquisition from the failed investment bank and is awaiting approval.

title: Independent Counsel Act Is Two-Edged Sword; What Mr. Starr Wants
description: To the Editor:

title: Coca-Cola Profit Increases 7% in Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 7 percent in the fourth quarter, falling just shy of Wall Street estimates despite stronger-than-expected growth in soft-drink sales.

title: Massachusetts Is Seeking to Bar D. H. Blair
description: Regulators in Massachusetts have filed an administrative complaint against D. H. Blair & Company, a Wall Street firm, and Kenton E. Wood, its chairman, seeking to revoke their registrations in the state.

title: Former Louima Lawyer Says New Team Ignores the Big Issue
description: One of the three little-known Brooklyn lawyers forced off Abner Louima's legal team said yesterday that they had been pushed aside by Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. and his prominent colleagues, and he accused the remaining lawyers of showing little concern for the broad issues of police brutality raised by the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, NATHAN
description: SILVERMAN - Nathan. The Trustees, Officers and Staff of North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System express deepest sympathies to our esteemed CoPresident and CEO, Dr. David R. Dantzker, and his wife, Sherrye, on the loss of Sherrye's father, Nathan. We extend sincere condolences to Nathan's wife, Raye, their children, Joan and Daniel Silna, their grandchildren, greatgrandchild, and all the other members of the family. Saul B. Katz and Roy J. Zuckerberg, Co-Chairmen John S.T. Gallagher, Co-President and CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System

title: Fossil Shows Ants Evolved Much Earlier Than Thought
description: Researchers have found seven ants in amber that are among the oldest ever found, making it clear that what may be the world's most populous terrestrial creatures were underfoot and already diversifying when dinosaurs trod the earth.

title: The Bloated Look Is Back
description: What is it about political conservatives and debt? First, Ronald Reagan tripled the national debt in the space of a single Administration. Then Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey floated $2.75 billion in debt to finance the future debts of her state's pension system -- rather like the mythical animal that hid from danger by swallowing itself.

title: CONNECTICUT
description: Antric Klaiber, a key reserve for the University of Connecticut men's basketball team who was arrested on charges of drunken driving and speeding a week ago, will rejoin the team as a ''practice player'' today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD RALLIES. The February gold contract jumped $5.30, to $306.00, the highest since mid-November. The buying, which has pushed up the price of gold almost 10 percent in just over two weeks, has been fueled by the fall of the dollar, which has made gold cheaper for foreigners.

title: Walter Bishop Jr., 70, Jazz Pianist Who Rode Be-Bop's First Wave
description: Walter Bishop Jr., a jazz pianist who recorded with Charlie Parker, Miles Davis and others, died on Saturday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Stickley's Famous Magazine Enters the Age of the CD-ROM
description: For those who cherish Gustav Stickley's Craftsman magazine, published from October 1901 through December 1916, the days of scouring flea markets are nearly over. The complete run of The Craftsman is about to be made available on CD-ROM.

title: Sybase Restates Earnings to Show Loss
description: Sybase Inc. said today that it had lost money in the first three quarters of 1997 after removing revenues that were improperly recognized by its Japanese unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBELMAN, WILLIAM
description: GIBELMAN-William. Loving husband of Betty. Father of Susan Kleszewski and Margaret Gibelman.Step-father of Isabel Knott. Grandfather of five and greatgrandfather of three. Services Thursday at Yardley Funeral Home, Sag Harbor. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Sag Harbor Ambulance Fund appreciated.

title: U.S. Fines Weimar Bond Dealer $60,500
description: A Michigan brokerage house that sold investors some defaulted Weimar Republic bonds has been ordered by a Federal judge to pay $60,500 for failing to cooperate with a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into the bonds.

title: East Meets West, and a Woman Meets Herself
description: THE MAGICIAN'S WIFE

title: SBC Operating Profit Rises, but Net Falls
description: SBC Communications Inc.'s operating profit rose 22 percent in the fourth quarter, lifted by an increase in phone lines and wireless customers and cost restraints, but a large charge caused net income to decline.

title: ARGONAUT SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING POSSIBLE MERGER
description: Argonaut Group Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Credit Suisse First Boston to examine a possible merger that would help shareholders benefit from the combinations that are sweeping the insurance industry. Argonaut, which is based in Los Angeles, provides workers' compensation insurance and other forms of commercial coverage. Argonaut's stock rose $3.1875, to $36.25. The company has a market value of $864 million, based on 23.85 million shares outstanding in October. Argonaut said earlier this month in a report on 1997 earnings that businesses were choosing policies with bigger deductible payment requirements and lower premiums to trim costs. Rival insurers are also paring premiums to win business, it said.

title: When Architects and Buildings Are the Story
description: At ''Architecture on Screen '98,'' a film festival at the Brooklyn Museum of Art tomorrow and Saturday, the stars are architects. One highlight is ''Concert of Wills: Making the Getty Center,'' a 100-minute documentary about the 12-year evolution of Richard Meier's museum in Los Angeles. The film, one of 16, will be shown tomorrow at 7 P.M.

title: Tactics to Stabilize The Ship of State
description: PLAN TO FIGHT SUBPOENAS -- Administration officials, expecting the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr to call members of the Secret Service before a grand jury hearing testimony on allegations of a sexual encounter between President Clinton and a White House intern, are preparing to fight subpoenas that would have the agents tell the grand jury about the President's daily routine. Page A16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, SYLVIA P.
description: GORDON-Sylvia P. All of us at East Midwood Jewish Center profoundly mourn the passing of our Honorary Trustee and past Sisterhood President. Her intelligence, energy, love and concern for the Synagogue and for the Jewish people will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathy and our condolences to her children and all the members of her family. Dr. Alvin Kass, Rabbi Marsha Shlestein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, WALLACE WALTER
description: PRICE-Wallace Walter, on Friday, January 23, 1998, of Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Adrienne Price, father of Sandra, Wallace and Cathy. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, February 3, at 1 PM, Plymouth Congregational Church, 5301 North Capitol St NE, Washington, D.C. with interment at Arlington National Cemetery. A memorial service will be held at Teaneck Methodist Church, Degraw Avenue, Teaneck, New Jersey on Sunday, February 1, 1998. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice Care of D.C., 1331 H Street N.W., Suite 600, Washington, D.C. 20005.

title: World News Briefs; Winnie Mandela's Alibi In Murder Is Questioned
description: A former security officer testified today that telephone taps in Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's home appeared to refute her claim that she was out of town when members of her entourage tortured and killed a young activist, Stompie Seipei, in 1988.

title: F.C.C. Plans to Take Look at Free Political Broadcasts
description: Taking his cue from President Clinton's State of the Union Message, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that he would jump-start a process to require broadcast television stations to give political candidates free advertising time.

title: The Neediest Cases; Hard Times Spoil a Runner's Aspirations
description: Back in the Dominican Republic, Marta Cadena Flores was an accomplished long-distance runner who represented her country in meets throughout the Caribbean. But while trophies and medals crowded the shelves of her mother's tin-roof shanty in Santo Domingo, the cupboards were often bare.

title: Gamblers on a Roll: Seas as Heavy as the Action
description: A ship full of optimists set sail from Manhattan last night on the city's latest gambling venture, a 713-foot cruise ship that was the first to win a permit from the city's new gambling commission.

title: A Cuban Cinderella Awhirl To a Strauss Waltz Score
description: The dancers are vibrant, the production is good-humored, the set is witty and the music is by Johann Strauss 2d, the Waltz King. Only the choreography is inept in the ''Cinderella'' that the Ballet Nacional de Cuba brought to City Center on Tuesday night for its first New York engagement since 1979.

title: Solid Earnings Drive Dow Up In Busy Session
description: The stock market erased the vestiges of an early-year decline yesterday, surging for the second consecutive day after a broad array of big-name companies reported solid quarterly earnings.

title: Calendar; Antiques and Folk Art Sales
description: Antiques on Park Avenue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNSTEIN, JANETTE
description: ARNSTEIN-Janette. On January 28, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Seymour and Donald. Dear mother-inlaw of Joann and Janice. Loving sister of Hilda Bleichfeld, Gertrude Covett and Thelma Fixler. Cherisehd grandmother of Jesse, Mimi, Tammy, Michael and Matthew. Services Thurs. 12:15pm at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAYLE, MICHAEL
description: GAYLE-Michael. February 29, 1960 to January 29, 1996. Our hearts still ache in silence, and the secret tears still flow; what it means to lose you, only those who truly love you, really know. Sadly missed by mother, Dolores; father, Dudley; sister, Andrea; wife, Sonia; son, Christopher; Gladstone, nieces and nephew.

title: The Wooing Begins For Dominican Pitcher
description: The Yankees are in the chase, but the Mets are apparently out of it before it really begins. It's the chase for Ricardo Aramboles, the 16-year-old Dominican Republic pitcher who is expected to get close to a $2 million signing bonus. Rob Plummer, the free agent's agent, had set yesterday as the deadline for initial offers. He declined to say last night how many teams had submitted offers, but acknowledged that he had received them from the Yankees and the Mets.

title: Woman Is Released From Brawley Case Jury
description: A juror whose ability to be impartial had previously come into question was released from the jury in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial yesterday for what both the juror and the judge presiding over the case said were reasons of financial hardship.

title: A Second Stage in a Battle to Defend the President
description: Battle-ready in a deep blue suit, her shoulders squared with epaulets, Hillary Rodham Clinton implemented Stage 2 of her strategy today for quelling the maelstrom that threatens her husband's Presidency -- she carried on.

title: Independent Counsel Act Is Two-Edged Sword
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, RICHARD ALAN
description: MARCUS-Richard Alan. Of Fort Lauderdale died suddenly January 22nd. He is survived by his three children Barbara, Kimberly and Scott, his sister Joan Raffe and by his nieces and nephews. He was born in NY City, and graduated from City College of N.Y. and then received his law degree from the University of Virginia. He and his late wife Davys settled in Minneapolis, MN where he was Vice President and Corporate Counsel for Napco Industries a major defense conglomerate for 25 years. He was also an active participant with the Twin Cities Lacrosse Team while in Minneapolis. In 1986 they retired to Fort Lauderdale where he became director of Sea Ranch Condominiums. He will be remembered as a devoted husband, a loving father and a true friend. His honesty and genuine enthusiasm for the community he lived in will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a favorite charity.

title: Garden Notebook; Lavish Birthplace for a Rare Plant Nursery
description: DAN HINKLEY, the founder of the Heronswood Nursery in Kingston, Wash., and a legendary plantsman, was eating lunch one day earlier this week at the Museum of Modern Art, overlooking the garden. Its spare display of three weeping beeches plus some birches and London planes made it a strange habitat for this man who sells a wider range of rare plants than any other retail nursery in the country.

title: Arts Abroad; In India, Pioneers of Modernism Savor Their Success
description: The tapping and torching sounds of a sculptor at work spilled from a shed above the Bay of Bengal on a hot afternoon, signs that one of India's most ambitious experiments in modern art is still thriving after more than three decades.

title: Japan's Top Finance Bureaucrat Resigns, a Day After His Leader
description: The Finance Ministry's top bureaucrat said today that he was stepping down, creating a vacuum in the ministry as it tries to cope with a bribery scandal and steer the nation out of an economic quagmire.

title: OCCIDENTAL TO SELL VENEZUELA UNIT TO UNION TEXAS
description: Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc., based in Houston, agreed yesterday to purchase Occidental de Hidrocarburos Inc. for $204.5 million. Occidental de Hidrocarburos, a unit of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of Los Angeles, operates the Desarrollo Zulia Occidental field in Venezuela for the country's state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. The sale could include additional payments of $90 million over the next six years. With the addition of the Zulia unit, the Union Texas estimated production is expected to rise 25 percent, to 50 million barrels of oil equivalent, from 40 million barrels.

title: Sports of The Times; Who Needs Coaches, Anyway?
description: BILLY HUNTER, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, says that if the Golden State Warriors are allowed to terminate the contract of Latrell Sprewell for attempting to choke his coach, P. J. Carlesimo, at a team practice and then returning to the gym 20 minutes later to attack him again and threaten to kill him: ''This means basically no one has a guaranteed contract. Everybody becomes vulnerable.''

title: Strategy Seeks to Shield Agents From Testifying About Clinton
description: The Treasury Department is preparing to fight any subpoenas seeking the testimony of President Clinton's Secret Service detail, invoking a novel legal argument that the agents' ability to stay close to the President would be imperiled if they were forced to disclose what they see and hear, Administration officials said today.

title: $7 Million Michelangelo
description: One of the last Michelangelo drawings still in private hands was sold at Sotheby's in New York yesterday to an unidentified telephone bidder for $7.4 million, a record price for a drawing by the artist.

title: Events; On View: Bridges to Quilts
description: Architectural Installations

title: Unfair Visa Profiles
description: A recent ruling by Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin against the State Department sheds light on offensive, racially biased visa policies used in the American consulate in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and other consular offices around the world. Instead of defending these policies, the State Department should be working to eliminate them.

title: Grieving Pregnancy Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: GGT Group, battered by the loss of big accounts, has agreed to be brought into Omnicom's fold.
description: A WEEK after the big loss of its Procter & Gamble Company accounts plunged GGT Group P.L.C. into crisis, the agency company agreed to be acquired by a much larger competitor, Omnicom Group, for $234.2 million in cash.

title: For Two Longtime Enemies, The Mirror Always Cracks
description: Kenneth W. Starr and Hillary Rodham Clinton are both accomplished lawyers. They are both charming, when they want to be, with infectious laughs. They are both devoted parents and deeply religious.

title: Newly Jobless (and Newly Angry) Upset Indonesia
description: One by one, most of Minarsih's friends at an electronics factory here were taken aside and quietly fired. Too ashamed to tell her, they simply disappeared, returning to the villages they had left years ago in search of fortune in the big city.

title: U.S. Planning To Extend Tax Credit For Research
description: In a move certain to be greeted enthusiastically by Silicon Valley technology companies, Vice President Al Gore will announce here on Thursday plans to extend a $2.2 billion research-and-development corporate tax credit for one year.

title: White House Concedes Voter Appeal of Agenda
description: President Clinton's 1998 agenda is brimful of new Federal initiatives to allay the anxieties and address the needs of people of every age, from infants to baby boomers to frail elderly women.

title: Creating a Forum to Rake the Media's Muck
description: UNFORTUNATELY for Steven Brill, Content, his planned monthly spyglass on the media universe, won't begin publication until June. By then, it's just possible that the 24-hour coverage of the decade's most squalid political story -- the one redefining boundaries between high and low media, the one simply crying out for the detailed hindsight of what he calls ''the consumer guide to the information age'' -- will have died down just a bit.

title: Dr. Harold C. Neu Dies at 63; Warned of Antibiotic Overuse
description: Dr. Harold C. Neu, an expert on treating infectious diseases who warned early on of the growing bacterial resistance to antibiotics, died Sunday at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, LARRY
description: COHEN-Larry. FAIDE-Noel. Auxiliary Sergeants, NYPD. Fallen on January 29, 1989, but never forgotten. John W. Hyland, Auxiliary Police Benevolent Association

title: Martinez and Hingis Reach Australian Final
description: From poised to petulant and back again, Martina Hingis, the Australian Open's defending champion, let the score be the guide to her emotions and to her catalogue of facial expressions today in her 6-1, 2-6, 6-1 semifinal victory against 10th-seeded Anke Huber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICH, BERTHA (NEE SACK)
description: OESTREICH-Bertha (nee Sack). Of Bronx, NY. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel. Devoted mother of Selene Zamer and Dr. Hilary Oestreich. Loving grandmother of five and great-grandmother of two. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', corner Passaic and Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey today at 10 A.M. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Reproduction as Tribute And Legal Battleground
description: ONCE forgotten, the original sofas, chairs, tables and cabinets by the English designer T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings (1905-76) are now collectors' items, prized for their graceful simplicity, fine woodworking and classically inspired style. Just two years ago, Robsjohn-Gibbings's emblematic lounge chair sold for $200. Today, Paul Donzella, a New York dealer in 20th-century furnishings, can sell one, restored, for $2,400. Robsjohn-Gibbings's sofas, Mr. Donzella said, have soared from $200 to $2,000 -- if you can find one.

title: U.S. Says It's Ready To Strike Iraq Alone
description: On the eve of a diplomatic mission to Europe and the Persian Gulf, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said yesterday that the United States was ready to act alone, if necessary, to punish Iraq for trying to develop chemical and biological weapons.

title: Modern Times
description: ''It's probable that somebody could do this job without being married,'' said STACY MORRISON, but it is not an issue for the new editor in chief of Modern Bride magazine: she marched down the aisle three years ago. ''Planning my wedding was a major highlight of my life,'' she said. ''I found the dress I wore about a year before I met my husband.''

title: Essay; Whose 'Conspiracy'?
description: My first reaction to the recent unpleasantness was: If my fellow citizens could not be outraged by the President's raising of foreign money to steal re-election, then I wasn't about to get all worked up over any romance with an adoring intern.

title: Economic Scene; Some meaty stuff on monetary policy, from a former Fed hand.
description: ALAN S. BLINDER, widely seen as one of the brightest lights in academic economics, spent less than two years as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board before returning to Princeton in 1996. The unofficial explanation: With Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, virtually running the central bank as a one-man show, Mr. Blinder was deeply frustrated by his lack of impact on policy.

title: Starr on Reasonable Path, Experts Say
description: Lawyers here and across the country have begun to analyze the strengths and weaknesses of a criminal case that many say is unlikely ever to reach a courtroom: a theoretical effort by the Whitewater independent counsel to put the President of the United States on trial.

title: INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY GILLETTE'S JAFRA UNIT
description: Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc., a leveraged buyout firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Gillette Company's Jafra Cosmetics International. The price was not disclosed but was said to be about $200 million. Jafra, based in Westlake, Calif., sells cosmetics in 20 countries and had about $200 million in revenue in 1997. Gillette, which also makes razor blades, batteries, toothbrushes and deodorant, said the unit did not fit its ''long-term corporate strategy.'' Gillette also said its fourth-quarter profit rose 18 percent, to $470.9 million, or 84 cents a basic share, from earnings before a charge of $398.3 million, or 72 cents, a year earlier. The result matched analysts' expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, ROSE (FENSTERHEIM)
description: GROSS-Rose (Fensterheim). On January 27, loving mother of Elliot and Florey, Judith and Irvin Franklin, Eleanore and Burton Garfinkel; beloved wife of the late Simeon F. Gross and the late Harry Fensterheim. Matriach of a dynasty consisting of nine grandchildren and their spouses, 18 wonderful great grandchildren, as well as friends and relatives too numerous to count. Services at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY, January 29 at 10 AM, Shiva at 651 Wildwood Rd., West Hempstead, New York.

title: Mayor, Ordering City Hall Review, Delays Plan to Build Mall Over Brooklyn Terminal
description: Saying that City Hall needed to be more involved in the planning process, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday delayed by at least a month a plan to build a shopping mall over the Atlantic Terminal in downtown Brooklyn.

title: UAL's Profit Surged by 57% in 4th Quarter, Topping Expectations
description: The UAL Corporation said today that net income rose 57 percent in the fourth quarter, exceeding analysts' expectations, as the airline operator benefited from heavy passenger traffic, strong fares and lower fuel prices.

title: To an Ovation in Congress, Clinton Warns Saddam on Weapons : 'You Can't Defy the Will of the World'
description: PARIS  The State of the Union Message provided President Bill Clinton with a solemn occasion to deliver a warning about U.S. determination to destroy Iraq's missiles and biological and chemical arms and to root out the country's capability to rebuild them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCKINLEY, SELMA ANDERSON
description: McKINLEY-Selma Anderson. On your birthday, dearest Momma, our memories dance to the strains of your favorite waltz.

title: Decorator 101: The Clients Confess
description: JEAN FLEISCHHACKER tried doing it herself. It wasn't pretty. ''I couldn't pull it together,'' she said. ''I was having trouble choosing fabrics -- nothing worked out when I got it home.'' She tried sponge-painting her walls -- ''I had taken a class,'' Ms. Fleischhacker said. She gave herself an A for effort, but the result flunked.

title: Bettors Try to Ride the Tiger; Chinese Hope Good Luck Accompanies the New Year
description: Sue Ling cooked the Chinese New Year dinner for her family Tuesday night. She made shark's fin soup, roast pork and a coconut and red bean Jell-O mold. Her 10 grandchildren came to Chinatown from Boston and Fort Lee, N.J., and each was rewarded with the traditional gift of money in a red envelope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISON, JOSEPH SOUTHWOOD
description: TISON-Joseph Southwood. Of Wilton Road West in Ridgefield, CT., died at his home Tuesday, January 27, after a long battle with cancer. He was 54. Born June 23, 1943, in Savannah, Georgia, he was the son of the late Henry Lawton and Edna Williamson Tison of Savannah, GA. A graduate of the Savannah Country Day School, he received his Bachelor's Degree from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and his Master's Degree in Business from Old Dominion University. He served as an officer in the U.S. Navy. For the past fifteen years he worked in New York City as General Manager of the North American operations of Citrus Products, Inc. During this time he served as Chairman of the Membership Committee, Director, Treasurer, Secretary, and Vice President of the Brazilian American Chamber of Commerce in New York and as a member of the Board of Directors of Citrus Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange, Inc. An active member of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield, CT., he is survived by his wife, Sarah, and four children: Kate, Joseph, Lawton, and Fletcher, and his brother Henry and sister Lucy, both of Savannah, GA. Services will be held at 11 A.M. on Saturday, January 31st, at St. Stephen's Church. Burial will be at the convenience of the family in Black Swamp Cemetery in Garnett, S.C. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to St. Stephen's Church, Ridgefield; the Visiting Nurse Association of Ridgefield; or for cancer research to the Cornell University Medical College, C/O Dr. David Wolf, 115 East 61 Street, NYC, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYSS, HENRIETTE A.
description: WYSS-Henriette A. Passed away January 24, 1998. Resident of the Bronx. Former officer supervisor Department of X-Ray, Presbyterian Medical Center. Survived by her brother, Albert C. Wyss. Visitation Friday, 2 to 9 PM, Fox Funeral Home, 203 East 201 Street, Bronx. Funeral service Saturday, 9:30 AM, St. Nicholas of Tolentine, corner Fordham Road and University Avenue. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Van Horn Plays Hero in Return to Hometown
description: He is so unflappable almost all of the time, it is easy to forget that Keith Van Horn is still just a 22-year-old rookie making his first go-round through the National Basketball Association.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Agreement Is Reached On South Korean Loans

title: Designs by Teachers Of the Designers Of Tomorrow
description: Seniors at the Parsons School of Design usually show their furniture in the spring. Now, it's the teachers' turn. ''Hot House: Parsons Furniture Faculty Designs Domesticity'' contains 60 objects by 28 teacher-designers, including ''Over 40'' (right), a chandelier by Lyn Godley that resembles a bouquet of flowers with ''over 40'' crinkled-vinyl lamps in red, pink, yellow and orange. The show, at 2 West 13th Street, runs through Feb. 26. Information from (212) 229-8987.

title: Grieving Pregnancy Loss; Rituals Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Investigate Woman's Disappearance
