description: Morris County prosecutors are investigating the disappearance of a 19-year-old Rockaway Township woman who, according to her parents, left her home near midnight on Jan. 20 after receiving a disturbing phone call.

title: Nordic Countries Lose Phone Vote
description: A product developed by Ericsson A.B. of Sweden and Nokia of Finland that allows the high-speed wireless transfer of data like moving pictures failed to be elected the standard for the next generation of mobile-phone systems in Europe.

title: Buttonholing Clinton, Lobbyist Says, Led Aides to Return Calls
description: When Patrick J. O'Connor, an influential Democratic lobbyist, got the cold shoulder three years ago from White House aides he hoped would help kill a proposed Indian casino in Wisconsin, he went right to their boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORAUER, WILLIAM
description: FORAUER-William. Of complications following heart failure at 6:45A.M., on January 28, seven hours after his 74th birthday. His life's companion, Elmer Gross, died one year ago and so he leaves behind friends including the many people who used to visit him at the WEG Gallery for his endless good humor, his warmth, his open smile and his gentle enthusiasm. A memorial mass will be held at St. Thomas More on 89th Street, Saturday, Jan. 31, 9:45AM

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, celebrating the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today, tomorrow and Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Financing Expected for Brooklyn Hospital
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is expected to announce $148.5 million in new financing today to rebuild the troubled Interfaith Medical Center, which is one of the largest employers in the poor Brooklyn neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant, state officials said yesterday.

title: President Resigns At Sports Illustrated
description: Donald M. Elliman Jr., president of Sports Illustrated magazine in New York for the last six years, announced yesterday that he would leave to work on special projects for the magazine's parent, the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc. His departure comes two months before Sports Illustrated begins facing competition from a sports magazine to be published by the ESPN cable network.

title: Public Eye
description: IT'S a shame that there are no support groups for aging household icons -- the Mrs. Butterworths of the world who seem either charmingly anachronistic or somewhat out of the loop. Not every icon is like Betty Crocker, who has gone through seven face lifts since 1936 in order to stay contemporary.

title: Martin Receives Support on Capitol Hill for His PGA Suit
description: Casey Martin's fight to force the PGA Tour to let him ride a golf cart turned political today when two lawmakers crucial to the passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act aligned themselves with him.

title: Run Toward Triple Crown Opens Without Its Favorite
description: The ''big horse'' in the class, the undefeated Favorite Trick, is back in the barn at the Payson Park training complex 90 miles north of here, trying to get back on schedule. But his closest pursuers among this year's 3-year-old colts, notably Coronado's Quest and Lil's Lad, have gathered at Gulfstream Park for Saturday's Hutcheson Stakes, the first stepping stone to the Triple Crown races.

title: Senate Hearings Open With Talk of a Sweeping I.R.S. Shake-Up
description: Senate Republicans said today that they intended to take a tougher approach to revamping the beleaguered Internal Revenue Service, describing last year's House bill and the agency's own proposals as a good jumping off point in protecting taxpayers.

title: Devils Stage Slow Dance With Trading Partners
description: In the big homecoming game, it was a guy who might be headed out of town who stole the show.

title: James Bond, Then to Now: Agent of Cultural Change
description: James Bond is back. In fact, he will not go away. The James Bond films are the most successful movie franchise in history, with most of the movies among the top earners of the year. ''Tomorrow Never Dies,'' the current Bond film, opened on Dec. 19 and was still in the Top 10 at the box office last weekend, having earned $115.5 million, second only to ''Titanic'' among the current hits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ERNEST
description: HELLER-Ernest. On January 25, 1998. Husband of Rose Heller. ''Pickle,'' beloved by a vast number of family and friends. Memorial service Friday, January 30, 5PM at the Princeton Club. In lieu of flowers, a contribution can be made to the Pick-Red Heller Foundation, C/O Alan Scott, 300 East 42 Street, New York, New York 10017.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is the day that you set up your luck for the rest of the year. This is the one day of the year that I come to the casino.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLERAN, GWENDOLYN FISK
description: HALLERAN-Gwendolyn Fisk. In her 93rd year on January 26. Daughter of the late Pliny Fisk and Eleanor Small Fisk. Beloved wife of the late Thomas Augustus Halleran. Gwenny is survived by her sister, Eleanor F. Noall, her sister-in-law, Eileen Halleran Newman, her stepchildren, James H. Halleran and Susan Halleran Loveland, her step grandchildren, John Halleran and Julie Halleran Bliss, her nephews, Pliny Fisk III, David Fisk, Arthur J. Halleran, Jr., Leo B. Halleran Jr., David R. Halleran, Michael R. Halleran, John Murphy and J.D. McKeown, and her nieces, Pamela Fisk, Julie Halleran Donahue, Florence Halleran Ricca, Marcia Halleran Reidy, Karen Murphy Miller, Sheila Murphy Stuart, Priscilla Brockbank Griffin, Eileen Brockbank Hodgson, Margaret Brockbank Lowright, Susan Brockbank McCullam, Virginia Halleran Church and Nancy Halleran Killie. Services at Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st St and Park Avenue, NY, NY on January 31 at 10:30 A.M. Interment private.

title: What's in a Name?
description: Someone gave DENISE COX, a photo illustrator in Manhattan, an E-mail address for LINDA TRIPP, the tape-recording confidante of MONICA S. LEWINSKY. Before you could say log on in anger, Ms. Cox had fired off a strongly worded message. ''I said, 'Did you ever stop to think of the repercussions of what you started here?' '' Ms. Cox recalled.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Treasury Prices Mixed as Greenspan's Testimony Is Awaited
description: The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, getting a lift from the Commerce Department's report of a drop in orders for durable goods last month, but hurt by several other factors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODNICK, MARTIN
description: GRODNICK-Martin. The Board of Directors of The American-Israel Environmental Council (The Council for a Beautiful Israel) mourn the passing of Martin Grodnick, beloved husband of our dedicated Co-President Edythe Grodnick. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Edythe and the entire family. Mel Atlas, Co-President Dina Evan, Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIROLAMO, DR. ORLANDO
description: DiGIROLAMO-Dr. Orlando. Of Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey, on Monday, January 26th, 1998. Husband of Diana DiGirolamo (nee Matano). Father of Olana, Christopher and Arland DiGirolamo. Brother of Sue Peretti. Funeral Liturgy at Our Lady Mother of the Church, Woodcliff Lake, N.J., on Saturday at 10AM. Cremation, private. Visiting at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Memorial gifts to the Dr. Orlando DiGirolamo Scholarship Fund for Children, 19 Wright St North, Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey 07675 would be appreciated.

title: DuPont Earnings Rose 10% in 4th Quarter
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, in line with expectations, as increased shipments offset lower prices resulting from a strong dollar.

title: Hardaway Pours It On In the Fourth Quarter
description: Tim Hardaway paused ever so briefly tonight to consider whether he had benefited from the absence of Knicks point guard Chris Childs, who left with a concussion early in the second quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, HENRY A.
description: LOEB-Henry A. Died Tuesday, Jan. 27, at age 90. Survived by his wife, Louise Steinhart Loeb, his children, Jean and Raymond Troubh and Betty and John Levin, his seven grandchildren, his 11 great-grandchildren, and his sister, Margaret Kempner. Interment is private. Services to be held at Tishman Auditorium, The New School, 66 West 12th St., January 30th at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The New School, or to the Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: SUN COAST SHARES LEAP ON WORD IT WILL BE ACQUIRED
description: The stock of Sun Coast Industries shot up more than 51 percent yesterday after the closely held Kerr Group Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Sun Coast for $10.75 a share, or $44 million. Sun Coast, based in Dallas, makes plastic closures and lids. The sale of its specialty resins and compounds business to Borden Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, is pending. In the quarter ended Sept. 30, Sun Coast had revenue of $16.6 million. Kerr, based in Lancaster, Pa., produces plastic packaging. It is owned by Fremont Partners, a $600 million private equity fund based in San Francisco. Sun Coast shares closed at $10.4375, up $3.5625.

title: The Shadows of a Human Science
description: In 1897 the American Museum of Natural History, headed by Morris Jesup, commissioned a five-year anthropological expedition to Alaska and Siberia. Its ostensible purpose was to determine the geographical origins of American Indians, and its tools included the anthropometer (a special stick for measuring height), calipers (for taking skull and facial measurements), an early voice-recording apparatus and large-format cameras.

title: Clinton's Troubles Built TV Ratings
description: The questions surrounding President Clinton helped build the most public interest in his State of Union Message this year since Mr. Clinton's first address in 1993.

title: Ball Falls For Lopez, As Rutgers Just Falls
description: He is reaching the short list in St. John's basketball history. The ball is falling for Felipe Lopez these days. His team is winning at last.

title: Is There Life After Wall Street?; Tales of the Players Who Quit the Game
description: Shortly before Christmas, when visions of million-dollar bonuses danced in Wall Street's collective head, a funny if slightly plaintive advertisement appeared in a magazine that caters to traders.

title: State Increases Size of Rate Cut Expected Under Lilco Takeover
description: Electricity customers will save even more on their bills than the amount previously estimated under Gov. George E. Pataki's planned partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, state officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEU, HAROLD CONRAD, M.D.
description: NEU-Harold Conrad, M.D. With deep sorrow we acknowledge the passing of our esteemed colleague who was Chief of Infectious Diseases at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He has been an inspirational teacher, clinician, scientist and friend who has made numerous important contributions to the field of Infectious Diseases. We feel privileged to have known and worked with him. Michael H. Grieco, M.D. Michael Lange, M.D. Division of Infectious Diseases and Allergy, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Ctr New York, NY

title: Yes, a Surplus Would Help, But Tough Choices Remain
description: Applying projected budget surpluses to the financial problems of Social Security could help make fixing the retirement system easier than Washington had feared, but would not eliminate the need for politically excruciating choices, White House officials and members of both parties said today.

title: You Can't Libel a Steak
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, Harvard Sees the Light
description: There has been a breakthrough at Harvard Law School. It has hired Lani Guinier as its first tenured black female professor.

title: 6 Holiday Inns to Be Sold
description: John Q. Hammons Hotels Inc. has agreed to sell six Holiday Inn hotels for $42 million to the Circa Capital Corporation, a real estate group in Dallas. Two of the hotels are in Lubbock, Tex. The others are in Fort Smith, Ark.; Fresno, Calif.; Billings, Mont., and Cheyenne, Wyo. Hammons said the six hotels had annual revenue of $28.4 million. John Q. Hammons, based in Springfield, operates 50 hotels with 12,309 rooms in 22 states. It had 1997 revenue of $268.8 million.

title: Total and Petrofina Post Record 1997 Earnings
description: Total S.A. and Petrofina S.A., two of the biggest oil companies in Europe, said yesterday that a stronger dollar and higher refining margins had helped second-half profit, raising their respective 1997 earnings to records. Total, France's second-largest oil company, earned 3.6 billion francs ($595 million) for the six months, up from 3 billion francs a year earlier. Profit for 1997 as a whole rose to 7.6 billion francs, from 5.6 billion francs in 1996, Total said.

title: Hat Trick By Palffy Is the Icing On a Rout
description: The diminutive Zigmund Palffy zigzagged through the towering Flyers at Nassau Coliseum with such finesse tonight that he raised eyebrows, created smiles and evoked sighs of relief from admiring Islander fans.

title: Mexico City Journal; Capital's Downfall Caused by Drinking . . . of Water
description: In a plaza next to one of this city's most important shrines, the colossal Monument to the Revolution, a humble water pipe has become a curious monument of its own to what is, literally, Mexico City's continuing collapse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIHLRAD, JACK
description: MIHLRAD-Jack. May 17, 1914January 29, 1995. Dad dearest, so greatly missed and loved every day these last three years. Much love always, Diane and Mom

title: INSIDE
description: New Worries in Indonesia

title: Trenton Bill Would Require Abortion Wait
description: The leaders of both parties in the New Jersey Assembly said today that they expected to pass a law requiring women to wait 24 hours before having an abortion, and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she would support it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, DAVID
description: LEVINSON-David, 69. Resident of Manhattan, on January 28, 1998. Beloved and devoted husband of Barbara for 47 years. Adored father of Ellen and Stephen Gross of Paris, France and Lisa and Edward Satterthwaite of Philadelphia, PA. Grandpa Dave of Julian, Alex and Sacha of Paris, France. Devoted brother and uncle. David was a teacher at Lewis and Clark in Bronx, NY where he will be terribly missed by his colleagues and students. David was one semester from achieving his Master's Degree in Special Education at City College. Service today, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory: New York Foundling Hospital, C/O Valerie Gundersen, Director of Development, 590 Sixth Ave, NYC 10011 or Make A Wish, 85 Old Stone Road, Port Wash., NY 11050.

title: NEWMONT MINING SAYS IT WILL CUT WORK FORCE BY 11%
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 500 jobs from its United States work force as part of a plan to reduce spending this year by $250 million. Newmont Mining, based in Denver, owns 94 percent of the Newmont Gold Company, one of the world's largest gold producers. The plan calls for lower capital spending, a refocused exploration program, revised mine and production plans, reduced administrative spending and a cut in quarterly dividends. The 500 jobs being cut represent 11 percent of the work force. The gold mining industry has been plagued by low gold prices. For the three months that ended on Dec. 31, Newmont Mining earned $38.6 million on revenue of $412 million.

title: The Mets Go Traveling
description: When he left for the Dominican Republic Monday, Fred Wilpon's luggage was left behind in New York, but not his enthusiasm. Wilpon said yesterday from Santo Domingo that he was committed to building a full-fledged baseball complex for the Mets in the Dominican Republic.

title: Chinese New Year Begins Without Its Usual Bang
description: The Year of the Tiger made a quiet entrance in Chinatown yesterday, with residents and merchants blaming the Giuliani administration's ban on firecrackers for keeping revelers away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASANAS, GEORGE
description: CHASANAS-George. Born October 17, 1907 in Lithuania. Died after a short illness in New York City January 27, 1998. Beloved husband of Lilia and good friend to many.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, MINA
description: HIRSCH-Mina. The Board of Directors, participants, staff and friends of AHRC-NYC convey their deepest condolences to George Hirsch, Board member, Officer and Past President of the Association, upon the tragic passing of his wife, Mina. Our hearts and prayers are with you and your family. Marilyn Jaffe-Ruiz, President Michael Goldfarb, Exec Director

title: Hispanic Workers Revitalize a Town
description: Like a swaggering cowboy coming in off the trail of old, Dodge City is flush these days. Its economy, if not booming, is at least ''hitting on all cylinders,'' in the words of one business leader, and the muscle is being supplied largely by men and women from Mexico and Central America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATHANASSIOU, GLENNA DONAHUE
description: ATHANASSIOU-Glenna Donahue. On January 28, 1998. Survived by her devoted husband, Evangelos, loving children, Stevie and Evan, cherished parents, Neil and Kanani Donahue, and 11 siblings. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 83rd Street, Friday, January 30 at 9 AM.

title: Merrill Lynch Fails to Reach an Agreement in Women's Suit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company early yesterday morning unexpectedly failed to reach agreement with several female financial consultants on the settlement of a sexual discrimination case against the firm.

title: Transplants Approved At 3 More Hospitals
description: Hoping to encourage organ donations and make lifesaving operations more accessible to the poor, state health officials have approved heart, kidney and liver transplants at three more hospitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENZ, WALTER A.
description: RENZ-Walter A. On January 27th, at New York Hospital. Loving husband of Janet, devoted father of Penny (deceased) and Muffy, and grandfather of Jake and Delaney McDonough and is survived by his sister, Eleanor. His loss will be felt by many friends, his nieces and their families. Mr. Renz was a lawyer and the retired president of The American Railway Car Institute. He was a major in Air Force Intelligence in World War II and a long time member of the Harvard Club and the Shinnecock Golf Club. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAREL, E. FREDERICK III (GARY)
description: GAREL-E. Frederick III (Gary). An untimely, bewildering time in his life that we share. Survived by his father Fred Garel, stepmother Mimi Lamb, brother Vernon, sister Sharon Descautoux and his beloved nieces and nephews. For further information please call his father (212-874-5029).

title: Man in the Middle of the Schiele Case
description: Where's Ronald?

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A REIT with nursing homes adds a race track and so on. Growth is good, but is there a strategy?
description: WITH the population aging and the number of retirees surging, certain businesses stand to profit: nursing homes, horse racing tracks, hotels, golf courses.

title: Independent Counsel Act Is Two-Edged Sword; 'Don't Ask' Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. to Fix and Replace Aging Computers
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would hunt down and remove the ''year 2000'' bugs from 40 crucial, aging air traffic control computers, and then throw out the computers themselves.

title: Rohm to Sell Stake in Unit
description: The Rohm & Haas Company will sell its 50 percent interest in a joint venture that makes Plexiglas acrylic sheets to its partner, Elf Aquitane S.A. of France. Ato Haas, based in Paris, makes acrylic sheets and resins sold under the trade name Plexiglas in North and South America and Altuglas in Europe. The venture had sales of $500 million in 1997. Also, Rohm & Haas will buy Elf's 50 percent stake in Norso Haas, a venture that makes acrylic-based products for detergent makers.

title: Clinton Leaves Washington Controversy Behind to Talk Policy in the Midwest
description: Setting aside certain slight if metaphorically inconvenient mishaps -- notably when Air Force One got stuck in the Illinois mud -- President Clinton had a politically comforting day today after a very bad week.

title: Retracting a Retraction, Self-Defense and Revelation
description: The Dallas Morning News, the newspaper that made news by becoming the first news-gathering organization to officially retract a front-page story on the White House sex scandal, went itself one better yesterday and retracted the retraction. Sort of.

title: U.S. Spy Agencies Find Scant Peril on Horizon
description: While the world still bristles with weapons, the United States itself is relatively secure from the threat of war, the Government's top intelligence officials testified today.

title: Quarter and Annual Net Up at Banco Santander
description: Banco Santander S.A., the largest bank in Spain ranked by assets, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 21 percent, lifted by higher lending income. The bank's full-year profit was 110.63 billion pesetas ($719.55 million), up 29 percent, and in line with predictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILELLO, JACQUELINE GIARDELLI
description: BILELLO-Jacqueline Giardelli. On January 28, at her home in Manhasset. Beloved wife of the late Sylvester F. Bilello. Devoted mother to Maryann Bilello Schaefer and Barbara Bilello Stynes. Dearest sister to Lee DeSimone. Loving grandmother to Christopher Stynes, Kristin Schaefer, Darren Schaefer and Jeremy Stynes. The family will receive friends today from 3-5 and 7-9PM at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. Funeral Mass on Friday at 10AM, St. Mary's RC Church. Interment at Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions in Jacqueline's memory may be made to her favorite charity, Father Flanagan's Boys' Home, Boys Town, Nebraska 68010.

title: Tramless Days on Roosevelt Island
description: As Roosevelt Islanders spent a second day yesterday without their beloved tram, it once again became apparent that since the arrival of subway service on the island, the quirky gondolas had in many ways become obsolete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, DR. JOSEPH S.
description: MURPHY-Dr. Joseph S. District Council 37, AFSCME, AFL-CIO and its constituent locals mourn the untimely loss of Dr. Joseph S. Murphy, former Chancellor of the City University of New York and a strong advocate for working people's education. Our members who work for the City University system had great respect for his stewardship as Chancellor. His leadership in fighting for higher educational opportunities for working men and women and his knowledge of and respect for the labor movement is deeply appreciated by the Board, the staff and the members of our union. Our condolences to his family and many friends. Stanley Hill, Executive Director Victor Guadalupe, President Helen Greene, Secretary Robert F. Myers, Jr., Treasurer

title: Study Shows How World Banks Panicked Over Asian Troubles
description: After viewing Asia for years as a promised land for lending and investing, despite growing signs of trouble, Western and Japanese financial institutions panicked last fall and shut down the flow of new capital to troubled countries, according to a study prepared for the world's major banks made public today.

title: Jangle and a Thump Brightly
description: Not that anyone had to ponder it to have a good time, but the Derailers were squarely hitting their references at Brownies on Tuesday night. The quartet from Austin, Tex., has gotten so far inside the bright jangle and thump of the Bakersfield sound -- the guitar-driven country music made by Buck Owens, Red Simpson and others in the early 60's -- that at times they inhabit specific roles. Especially the group's lead guitarist, Brian Hofeldt: his surging leads, his piercing singing (pitched a third above the band's other vocalist, Tony Villanueva) and even his tall, spit-curled, western-jacketed appearance seemed like a homage to Don Rich, Mr. Owens's right-hand man in the Buckaroos.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, ROBERT E.
description: LEWIS-Robert E. Late of Port Washington, NY. A memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock, 48 Shelter Rock Rd, Manhasset, NY, Sat, Jan. 31 at 2 p.m.

title: Many Oldies Are New Again
description: It depends on the movies, of course, but people appear to be collecting fewer of them on video these days. This is not necessarily a cause for too much alarm, at least not yet. ''The average purchasing household (about 60 percent of all U.S. households) owned 41 videos in 1996,'' says a report from the Video Software Dealers Association, a trade group. On the face of it, that seems a pretty hefty number and indicative of consumers' tendency over the last several years to buy big new titles (an ''Independence Day,'' say) and build collections of older films.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, HENRY A.
description: LOEB-Henry A. Died Tuesday, Jan. 27, at age 90. Survived by his wife, Louise Steinhart Loeb, his children, Jean and Raymond Troubh and Betty and John Levin, his seven grandchildren, his 11 great-grandchildren, and his sister, Margaret Kempner. Interment is private. Services to be held at Tishman Auditorium, The New School, 66 West 12th St., January 30th at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The New School, or to the Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

title: U.S. Writers, Too, Drove Social Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Ralph Lauren's Stock: Why Has It Languished?
description: So what happened to one of the hottest initial public offerings of last year, that of Polo/Ralph Lauren?

title: Airtouch Renews Deal for U S West Unit
description: Reviving a dormant plan to acquire U S West Media Group's domestic wireless telephone operation, Airtouch Communications Inc. said yesterday that the two companies had reached a new deal worth $1.5 billion more than the agreement they scuttled last year.

title: A Lot of Rain Limits First Day to Nine Holes
description: As usual, people left Pebble Beach today talking more about weather than about golf.

title: Campbell Threatens A Shake-Up
description: Maybe it was an emotional reaction after he watched his team sleepwalk through two periods and then blow a 2-1 lead in the third. Or maybe he was quite serious and some veteran Rangers will face his wrath.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Zambia Gazes at the Power Elite's Dirty Laundry
description: When former President Kenneth D. Kaunda arrives at court each morning, up to 100 soldiers surround him and not only shove photographers back with rifle butts, but also jump like basketball forwards trying to block his face.

title: Fed Chief Sees Benefit to U.S. In Asia Crisis
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned today that Asia's financial crisis would soon be felt in the United States, but said the resulting slowdown in economic growth would reduce any remaining risk of inflation derailing the nation's seven-year expansion.

title: Literary Lions
description: SENATOR ALFONSE M. D'AMATO, who once called a news conference to announce that he was in love (with a woman he stopped seeing mere months later), was late to a very important date yesterday. Well, it wasn't a date in the conventional sense. But the encounter with the DUCHESS OF YORK left him sounding awestruck, starstruck or maybe something more.

title: Consortium May Abandon Rail Contract
description: London and Continental Railways will abandon its $8.3 billion contract to build a high-speed link to the Channel Tunnel and to run the Eurostar passenger train service after failing to raise more money, an executive of the troubled consortium said today.

title: Fans Wait for Real Wiz to Drop His Other Shoe
description: Chuck Dolan is now The Real Wiz. For years, the deal-making founder of Cablevision Systems was merely The Wiz of Long Island Cable. Then he stepped up to become The Wiz of All New York Sports when Cablevision purchased one-half, then nearly all, of Madison Square Garden.

title: Caribbean Fare
description: If you are reading this, you're probably not lazing in the Caribbean sun. But if you are yearning for a taste of the islands, try one of these restaurants. Caribbean food is generally robust and goes surprisingly well with cold weather. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Jordan Sees End in Sight
description: He's not billing it as part of the ''Michael Jordan Farewell Tour,'' but basketball's most prominent player said for the first time yesterday that his appearance in the All-Star Game in New York on Feb. 8 could be his last at the midseason affair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELENGUT, MORRIS
description: SELENGUT-Morris. Yeshiva University and its Sy Syms School of Business mourn the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Sylvia; father of Elkie (and Kalman) Adams, Zev Aryea (and Chani) Selengut, Chumi (and Reuven) Mandel, David (and Chaya) Selengut, and Yaacov (and Bruchi) Selengut; and brother of Rosalind Davis, YU Benefactor with her husband, J. Morton Davis, honorary alumnus, honorary member of the YU Board of Trustees, and member of the SSSB Board; and Rabbi Yitzchok (and Bryna) Selengut. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Trek in Remote Pakistan Leads to Hair-Loss Gene
description: It must have been one of the more unusual requests for scientific collaboration to reach Quaid-i-Azam University in Islamabad, Pakistan: a list of Dr. Angela Christiano's research credentials, along with a snapshot of three bald spots on her head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, CARMEN
description: McGUIRE-Carmen. On January 26, 1998. Beloved wife of Edward. Mother of Edward Jr. and Eugene. Grandmother of five. Donations to Connecticut College, 270 Mohegan Ave., New London, CT 06320. Gallagher Funeral Home, Greenwich.

title: Structures With Soul: Cubist Combinations of Multiple Fractured Images
description: For more than 20 years, Jenny Okun has trained her Cubist eye on buildings, creating images of startling verve and vitality.

title: French Judge in War Crimes Case Said to Be Related to a Victim
description: The trial of a former French functionary for complicity in German war crimes during the occupation in World War II ended its 58th session early today, mired in controversy about whether the presiding judge should step down after an unexpected assertion that he was distantly related to one of the surviving victims.

title: With a Date in Final, Just Call Him Air Korda
description: Forget the scissors kicks and the cartwheels, Petr Korda's standard routine for celebrating Grand Slam milestones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISSEN, LIBBIE
description: ISSEN-Libbie. At age 95. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Issen. Beloved sister of Sidney Simon and of the late Harry Simmons and Lois S. Rohr. Cherished aunt of R. Moshe Simon, Roger Simon, Ivor Simmons, Samuel Simmons, Ann S. Preston, David Simmons, Sara S. Valentine, Michael David Rohr, Linda R. Oken and Jonathan (Pinchos Osher) Rohr and many great-nieces and great-nephews. Funeral service at Beth El Cemetery, Westwood, New Jersey, on Friday, January 30, at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ERNEST
description: HELLER-Ernest. On January 25, 1998. Husband of Rose Heller. ''Pickle,'' beloved by a vast number of family and friends. Memorial service Friday, January 30, 5PM at the Princeton Club. In lieu of flowers, a contribution can be made to the Pick-Red Heller Foundation, C/O Alan Scott, 300 East 42 Street, New York, New York 10017.

title: A Luxury Ship, a Greedy Owner and Slimy Monsters
description: ''Titanic'' isn't the only sinker in town.

title: Metro Business; Mixed Signals on Economy
description: The rate of business activity in the New York metropolitan region slowed suddenly and sharply in January after a strong performance in 1997, a national business group said yesterday.

title: Red Storm's Fortunes Building a Bandwagon
description: Their coach said that someday people would be getting on their bandwagon.

title: Japan Shuffles Finance Ministry
description: Japan's Ministry of Finance announced a new lineup of senior officials yesterday after the Vice Finance Minister, Takeshi Komura, stepped down to take the blame for a bribery scandal involving the ministry's bank inspectors. The ministry named Koji Tanami, head of the Cabinet councilor's office and a former ministry official, to succeed Mr. Komura.

title: The Neediest Cases; Ready to Work, After Battling Mental Illness
description: Darius Hayward is between jobs. Almost a month has passed since his holiday-season stint as a Toys ''R'' Us stock clerk, and he does not relish the feeling of joblessness. On the other hand, he finds a certain pleasure in telling people he is temporarily unemployed, because until November, Mr. Hayward, 36, had never held a job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, MINA
description: HIRSCH-Mina. The Board of Directors, participants, staff and friends of AHRC-NYC convey their deepest condolences to George Hirsch, Board member, Officer and Past President of the Association, upon the tragic passing of his wife, Mina. Our hearts and prayers are with you and your family. Marilyn Jaffe-Ruiz, President Michael Goldfarb, Exec Director

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Killing Time'

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Listen, and you will instantly discover the most amazing thing about the new Atlantic Grill: Despite an enormous and vociferous crowd, the room is stunningly quiet. I wish that the person responsible for the amazing acoustics could be dispatched to fix the hundreds of noisy restaurants in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANSON, SUSAN
description: SWANSON-Susan. All of us at John Wiley & Sons, Inc., mourn the loss of Susan Swanson, Director of Journal Subscription and Fulfillment, and wife of Eric Swanson, Senior V.P., STM Publishing. Susan was well-known for her business knowledge and savvy, her contributions to industry efforts, and her charm and humor. We will miss her terribly. Our deepest condolences to Eric, her daughter Jessica, and their families and friends.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN WEAKENS. Corn prices fell after the Agriculture Department reported that exports dropped 35 percent last week. There was also speculation that some companies plan to import cheaper corn from Argentina this spring and summer. March corn finished down 2 cents at $2.755 a bushel.

title: The Power of 3 Isn't Enough to Save the Knicks
description: The Knicks went searching last night for somebody to pick them up after their emotional loss at Miami. They looked toward John Starks, of all teetering people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DR. SEMA JOY (NEE FICHTENBAUM)
description: MARKS-Dr. Sema Joy (nee Fichtenbaum). Age 55. Of Manhattan. Died on January 19, 1998 after a year-long battle with brain cancer. Sema's unique personality and broad background with IBM made her a valuable member of the BBN/GTE Internet organization. Sema held a Doctorate in Information Systems and Education from Harvard. Sema is survived by an aunt, Francis Kanarek, a number of cousins and numerous friends around the world.

title: Lil's Lad Will Skip Hutcheson
description: Only six horses were entered today in Saturday's Hutcheson Stakes, the first step on the road to the Kentucky Derby, when one of the favorites, Lil's Lad, was switched at the last moment to another race Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, TILLIE
description: WEINTRAUB-Tillie. On January 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late David, devoted mother of Philip and Barry, mother-in-law of Shelly and Karen, dear sister of Harry Cutler. Services Sunday 10:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Will the Armed Forces Abandon Suharto After So Many Years?: In Indonesia, All Eyes on the Military
description: SINGAPORE  As Indonesia's economy stalls, social unrest and ethnic tension rise and the long rule of President Suharto draws to an end, the role of the armed forces in maintaining stability in the world's fourth-most-populous nation is becoming increasingly critical, analysts say.

title: Te Kanawa's Final Bouquet at the Met?
description: This month, Dame Kiri Te Kanawa has been singing radiantly and moving audiences as the Countess in the Metropolitan Opera's production of Richard Strauss's ''Capriccio.'' The last of six performances will be tomorrow afternoon.

title: Metro Matters; An Aisle Seat In the House Or the Titanic
description: SOME prominent seats go to those with prominence. Others go to those with Sitzfleisch, like Representative Eliot L. Engel.

title: Investor Agrees to Pay $190 Million for Helmsley Skyscraper on Broadway
description: After several rounds of fierce bidding from developers, investment banks and real estate funds, the investor Larry A. Silverstein emerged yesterday with an agreement to buy the skyscraper at 140 Broadway from Leona Helmsley for more than $190 million, real estate executives said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLAUMEZ, KARNES, MARILYN E.
description: WILLAUMEZ - KARNES - Marilyn E. Of New York. On January 22, 1998. Mother of Jonah David Willaumez. Former member of the Fashion Group and the Bellevue Hospital Auxiliary Board. Her career included positions at Vogue Magazine, Burlington Industries and Celanese Inc. Memorial service will be held February 23rd.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Tale of Two Stories, This One With a Ms.
description: When filmmakers today talk about updating the classics, chances are they have a music video format in mind. That's the spirit of the new pop overhaul of ''Great Expectations,'' but the director, Alfonso Cuaron, also has lovelier aspirations. With the same visual enchantment he brought to ''A Little Princess,'' Mr. Cuaron does turn the famous story into one Charles Dickens would barely recognize, complete with a renamed Miss Havisham (Anne Bancroft) campy enough to suggest Baby Jane in Las Vegas. The directorial approach is so bold and vulgar that it has no business working. But often it does.

title: Mayor Seeks Change Of Colleges at CUNY
description: In a surprise attack on the City University of New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called for an overhaul of community colleges yesterday, declaring that they should shift the responsibility for teaching remedial courses to other institutions.

title: Op-Art
ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Vertical Time'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEY, MAURICE W.
description: KLEY-Maurice W. Architect, on January 22nd, 1998. Beloved husband of Gwendolyn, father of Elisabeth Kley Tsuchiya and Susan Neuman. Memorial service 3 PM, Saturday, January 31st, Congregational Church, Roxbury, CT.

title: From a Daughter, Scenes of a Life in Limbo
description: JULIA LOKTEV'S mother was certain the world would not be interested in the immense ritual of her own daily life, the repetitive acts of ministration that have defined her existence and that of her family for the last nine years.

title: Relish on the Side
description: It has come to this: the Manhattan Deli, at 611 Broadway, added two sandwiches to its menu yesterday: the BILL CLINTON (half ham, half baloney or turkey, a slice of American cheese and a tomato), and the KEN STARR (the same as above, without the tomato). Both are $3.95. ''I'm disgusted by what's going on on both sides -- we look like fools in the eyes of the world,'' said PHIL BEGOVOY, an owner of the delicatessen, ''and I wanted to show my disgust in a legal way. This is still legal, probably. The next thing you know, my phone is going to be tapped.''

title: Brookhaven Cancer Rate Is to Be Studied by State
description: The State Cancer Registry has agreed to study cancer rates for employees of the Brookhaven National Laboratory to determine whether they differ from rates elsewhere in the state, laboratory officials announced yesterday.

title: BRITAIN TO REOPEN ITS INQUIRY OF '72 IN ULSTER KILLINGS
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today that he was opening a new judicial inquiry into the killings of 14 unarmed civil rights marchers by British soldiers in Northern Ireland on ''Bloody Sunday,'' Jan. 30, 1972.

title: Admission on Stabbing Allowed in Murder Trial
description: The statement of a man who admitted to the police without a lawyer present that he had fatally stabbed a Bayonne High School student in March can be admitted as evidence in his murder trial, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINEK, HERBERT
description: SINEK-Herbert. On January 29, 1998, at age 73 at his home in Chappaqua after a long illness. Survived with enduring love by his wife Marion, his children Nicole Arnaboldi and Ronald Sinek, their spouses Leo and Jennifer, and his grandchildren Peter, Brenton and Andrew. The family will receive friends at home on Saturday and Sunday from 2-5 P.M. Contributions in his memory may be made to either the donor's favorite charity or Hospice of Northern Westchester and Putnam.

title: Time to Track Down Iraq's Missing Warheads
description: To the Editor:

title: With No Other 'Dollys,' Cloning Report Draws Critics
description: The credibility of the experiment reporting the cloning of Dolly the sheep from the cell of an adult ewe is being sharply challenged by a leading biologist, and other eminent scientists agree that the experiment needs to be repeated before it can be accepted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, SONDRA, PH.D
description: HELLER-Sondra, Ph.D, January 28, 1998 of Tarrytown, NY. Wife of Joel Frutkin, mother of Jenny and Jocelyn Dauphin and Jeremy Frutkin. As educator, scholar and mentor she devoted her life to children as Principal and Teacher at Yeshiva of Kings Bay in Brooklyn, Solomon Schecter High School in Brooklyn and for more than a decade dedicated her life to thousands of children as head of the N.Y. Childhood Center. In recent years she devoted her talents to the training of teachers as Coordinator of the Graduate Masters Program at Mercy College. Services private. In lieu of flowers, donations to RSHM Life Center, 32-34 Beekman Avenue, Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. 10591 would be appreciated.

title: A frenetic week on Madison Avenue continues as agencies merge, split and rename themselves.
description: THE frantic activity this week along Madison Avenue continued yesterday as advertising and public relations agencies announced a merger, a spinoff and ownership changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, BURTON H.
description: BRODY-Burton H. The former Chief Litigation Counsel for Nabisco until his retirement in 1988, died of a heart attack after a long illness on January 18, 1998, at the age of 72. He was an attorney in private practice in New York City for over 25 years, as well as being Adjunct Professor at NYU Law School teaching trial advocacy and also at New York Law School where he taught trial practice. He was a contributor to the Yale Graduate School and Yale Law School where a portion of the Lillian Goldman Library will be named in his memory, and where he supported constitutionally protected rights to privacy. He is a graduate of Yale Law School 1950, Yale College 1945W and Newark Academy. He was a Lt. j.g. in the U.S. Navy where he participated in the Naval Intelligence Chinese Program. He served in the South Pacific during World War II. He is survived by his cousin, Lois Gerber Friedman of Metairie, Louisiana, and her daughters, Anne and Rebecca Friedman. A memorial service is planned at Yale University and is tentatively scheduled for March 6th.

title: When It Says 'Don't Walk,' New Yorkers Do; The European Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Satellites Halted by Loral
description: Loral Space and Communications Ltd. of New York said yesterday that it had halted work on three satellites for Asian buyers and would cut as many as 300 jobs, or 9 percent of the work force, at its Space Systems/Loral unit in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Terrell Brandon Does the Right Thing
description: Is this man for real? Doesn't he yet understand that he's in the National Basketball Association, which gives him certain inalienable rights, like arrogance, egocentrism, conspicuous consumption and behaving like a goof?

title: Bomb Kills Guard at an Alabama Abortion Clinic
description: In what is believed to be the first fatal bombing of an abortion clinic in the United States, an off-duty police officer was killed and a nurse critically wounded in a blast early today at a clinic on Birmingham's south side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLBERGER, NEIL
description: MOLBERGER - Neil. Cherished son of Helen Gruber and the late Melvin Molberger. Beloved stepson of Murray Gruber. Adored brother of Sharon Draghi, Daryl Kulok and Barry Gruber. Loving uncle of Charlie, Georgia and Benjamin. Neil left us far too soon. He touched the hearts of all who loved him. We will never forget him. We love you, Neil. Services Friday 12 noon, Sunset Chapels, Northern Blvd, Manhasset, New York. No flowers, please
