description: National Black Fine Art Show

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL
description: FRIEDMAN - Samuel. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Richard. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather and good friend to many. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Sunday February 1 at 11AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZADEH, BLUMA
description: ZADEH-Bluma. Beloved wife of the late Jacques Issahar-Zadeh, devoted mother of Jeffrey, James, Robert and Ruth, dearest sister to Chana Liberman, loving grandmother to Adrian, Alan, Jacqueline, Mariano, David and Jennifer, beloved aunt to Judith, Shulamith, Gatriel and Smadar, beloved friend and companion to Misha Yablonsky and family. The family will receive friends today from 11AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, New Jersey after 1 PM.

title: Sports of The Times; Jayson Can Appreciate The Irony
description: JAYSON WILLIAMS has a survivor's sense of the ludicrous -- look what I'm doing here! Turning 30 in three and a half weeks would have been enough of a triumph, considering some of the nights he went out courting disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, GEORGE M.
description: JACOBS-George M. On January 28th, 1998, in Albany, New York. Beloved husband of the late Naomi C. Jacobs. Loving father of Marjorie and Kenneth Jacobs. Services at the Levine Memorial Chapel, 649 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY, on Friday, 2 PM. Interment will be in Albany, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHEOWITZ, FRANK
description: OSHEOWITZ-Frank. Of Lake Worth, Florida, formerly of Rockville Centre, at age 85 on January 26, 1998. Loving husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Michael (Maria) and Audrey (Harvey) Rutheiser. Devoted grandfather of Charles, Caryn (Michael) Zacharia and Tania (Dr. Steven) Gold and Melita. Great grandfather of Lindsay, Jonah and Evan. Loving brother of Molly Wagner and Ceil Blau. Services were held in Florida. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimers Association of Palm Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANNICK, JAMES J., JR.
description: BRANNICK-James J., Jr. 59. Of NYC. Died Monday, Jan. 26, 1998. Funeral Mass will be Saturday, January 31, 10 AM, St. Patrick's Church, Farmington, CT. Sheehan Hilborn Breen FH, 1084 New Britain Avenue, West Hartford, CT.

title: Stalled Train to Kennedy Airport
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has been dithering for months over whether to grant the Port Authority's request to finance a $1.5 billion light rail link from Jamaica, Queens, to Kennedy Airport with passenger-surcharge revenue. Yet the F.A.A. has ample precedent to let the project go forward.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: New Stock Fund Investments Are Slowing, Report Says
description: New investments in stock mutual funds appear to be slowing sharply this month, a research group reported yesterday, after a year in which a record amount was poured into such vehicles.

title: A Tragedy Reinterpreted With a Bored Homemaker
description: For the Classic Stage Company, it is, unfortunately, another bloodless coup.

title: A Spokesman With Admittedly Nothing to Say
description: First, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said he was out of the loop. Then he said there was no loop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIS, IRA
description: PARIS-Ira. The Trustees and staff of Intracoastal Health Systems, Inc., mourn the passing of their friend and supporter. Heartfelt condolences to his wife and family members.

title: A Story of a Boy And His Goose
description: To the French Canadian playwright Michel Marc Bouchard, an abused child is the most desperate of prisoners: he has no escape. So it is not surprising that when choosing a pet for Maurice, the mistreated boy in ''Tale of Teeka,'' he decided to use a creature incapable of freedom: a farm goose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEOMAN, DONALD C., ESQUIRE
description: YEOMAN-Donald C., Esquire. Died January 26, 1998. Survived by three children, Dona, Kevin and David; four stepchildren, Joseph, Josie, Denise and Michele; six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Memorial Friday, January 30, 2-9 P.M., La Paz Funeral Home, 285 East 149 St., Bronx.

title: Chronicle Publishing Selects Grant, Scott
description: The San Francisco Chronicle, which is published by the Chronicle Publishing Company, has named Grant, Scott & Hurley in San Francisco to handle its account, which had been handled for four years by another San Francisco agency, Wolfe/Doyle. Billings were estimated at $3 million. Grant, Scott was awarded the newspaper's account after a three-month review that also included Wolfe/Doyle; Butler, Shine & Stern in Sausalito, Calif., and Citron Haligman Bedecarre in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLERAN, GWENDOLYN FISK
description: HALLERAN-Gwendolyn Fisk. In her 93rd year on January 26. Daughter of the late Pliny Fisk and Eleanor Small Fisk. Beloved wife of the late Thomas Augustus Halleran. Gwenny is survived by her sister, Eleanor F. Noall, her sister-in-law, Eileen Halleran Newman, her stepchildren, James H. Halleran and Susan Halleran Loveland, her step grandchildren, John Halleran and Julie Halleran Bliss, her nephews, Pliny Fisk III, David Fisk, Arthur J. Halleran, Jr., Leo B. Halleran Jr., David R. Halleran, Michael R. Halleran, John Murphy and J.D. McKeown, and her nieces, Pamela Fisk, Julie Halleran Donahue, Florence Halleran Ricca, Marcia Halleran Reidy, Karen Murphy Miller, Sheila Murphy Stuart, Priscilla Brockbank Griffin, Eileen Brockbank Hodgson, Margaret Brockbank Lowright, Susan Brockbank McCullam, Virginia Halleran Church and Nancy Halleran Killie. Services at Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st St and Park Avenue, NY, NY on January 31 at 10:30 A.M. Interment private.

title: Brilliant, Epileptic And Deadly
description: Maybe this is just a matter of personal taste, but I think that if you've seen one film in which a beautiful dead prostitute is hacked in half, you've seen them all. In any case, Renee Zellweger plays the small, pivotal role of a good-looking human sacrifice in ''Deceiver,'' a film noir written and directed by twin brothers, Jonas and Joshua Pate. Hermetically sealed in a world of other, shrewder films and secondhand genre affectations, it shows off a cleverness that has nothing to do with wisdom.

title: Jailed Doctor's Wife Is Hoping the Pope's Words Sway Cuba
description: More than most Cubans, Caridad Pinon Rodriguez has cause to hope Fidel Castro will respond to Pope John Paul II's request to free those ''imprisoned for reasons of conscience, for ideas which though dissident are nonetheless peaceful.'' Her husband, Dessi Mendoza, is in Boniato Prison here, serving an eight-year sentence on charges of ''disseminating enemy propaganda.''

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYSS, HENRIETTE A.
description: WYSS-Henriette A. Passed away January 24, 1998. Resident of the Bronx. Former officer supervisor Department of X-Ray, Presbyterian Medical Center. Survived by her brother, Albert C. Wyss. Visitation Friday, 2 to 9 PM, Fox Funeral Home, 203 East 201 Street, Bronx. Funeral service Saturday, 9:30 AM, St. Nicholas of Tolentine, corner Fordham Road and University Avenue. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LEONA V.
description: HOFFMAN-Leona V., 95. Beloved mother of Richard and Kenneth Hoffman. Adored grandmother and great grandmother. The Hoffman family celebrate her long life that touched so many with her love and her gentle grace. We will cherish her memory forever. Services are today, 12 noon, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rte. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Intrigue Swirls Around Korean Debt Talks
description: On Jan. 8, as international banks discussed extending repayment on a pile of troubled loans threatening South Korea's solvency, J. P. Morgan & Company took the unusual step of notifying several big investors via E-mail about how well the meeting was proceeding.

title: 3 COMPANIES BUY BOC HEALTH UNIT FOR $1 BILLION
description: The diversified chemicals company BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain agreed yesterday to sell its Ohmeda Inc. health care business to three companies for $:640 million, or $1.05 billion. The Instrumentarium Corporation, a Finnish maker of anesthesia and intensive care technologies, will buy Ohmeda's medical systems and specialty products division for about $494 million. Becton Dickinson & Company of Franklin Lakes, N.J., will acquire Ohmeda's medical devices unit for about $452 million. Baxter International Inc. of Deerfield, Ill., will take the pharmaceutical products unit for about $104 million. Baxter also said its fourth-quarter profit rose 15 percent, to $182 million, or 64 cents a diluted share, from a year earlier.

title: Firefighter Is Sought In a Kidnapping
description: A firefighter with a history of arrests for assault is being sought in the kidnapping and beating of a man whom he suspected of robbing his home, the police said yesterday. The firefighter, Warren Hall, 36, of Asbury Park, abducted the man, Alonzo Maxin, from an apartment on Friday, after learning that Mr. Maxin might have been responsible for two burglaries at his home, Detective Mark Kinmon said.

title: Gotti's Son Is Said to Have Talked in Jail of Killing Co-defendant
description: Federal prosecutors said today that a jail house informant overheard John Gotti Jr. say in his Westchester County cell that he wanted to kill one of the co-defendants in the racketeering and extortion case against him.

title: Rowland Asks For Purchase Of Open Land
description: Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed spending $160 million to preserve more than 20,000 acres of open space in Connecticut over the next five years, a plan that in its first year alone would increase by nearly tenfold the money the state has spent on open space during his administration.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Bonnie Collura

title: Israelis Lining Up for Gas Masks as Officials Warn Iraq
description: Israelis, edgy after local press reports about Iraq's arsenal, lined up for gas-masks today, and the Defense Minister warned that Israel would defend itself if attacked by Iraq in retaliation for an American military strike.

title: Some Journalists Have Met the Enemy, and It Is Them
description: It has hit with a vengeance: The ''I-hate-myself'' moment.

title: MULTIPLE $500 MILLION BIDS SEEN FOR BANKAMERICA UNIT
description: The BankAmerica Corporation has received several bids that top $500 million for its mobile-home financing unit, according to investment bankers familiar with the sale. Bids for BankAmerica Housing Services, the second-largest mobile-home lender in the United States, may change when the potential buyers examine the unit's books in a second round of bidding, the bankers said. The subsidiary, based in San Diego, has about $9 billion in loans. Sale of the unit comes at a time of turmoil among ''subprime'' lenders, which offer credit to risky customers. The Green Tree Financial Corporation of St. Paul, the largest mobile-home lender in the United States, said this week that its profit had been hurt because it miscalculated how fast clients would pay back loans.

title: Union Leader in Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Brawley Trial Gets Timeout After Shouting By Lawyers
description: The patience of the judge in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial was stretched to new limits today as lawyers screamed at each other -- and at him -- so angrily that the jury had to be hurried out of the courtroom.

title: Observer; The Media in Trouble
description: Some fusspot, maybe Charles Baudelaire, once said he was unable to understand how any civilized person could pick up a newspaper without a shudder of disgust.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Drunken-Driving Standard May Shift
description: THE nation's drunken-driving death toll has been rising again since 1994, after more than a decade of declines. Alarmed by the upswing, Mothers Against Drunk Driving and Federal safety officials are urging a stricter definition of ''drunk'' that could be applied nationwide.

title: Fast-Growing PC Maker Out Of Business
description: The Power Computing Corporation, until last summer the fastest-growing personal computer company of the 1990's, has apparently gone out of business.

title: Reuters Unit Is Investigated Over Theft of a Rival's Data
description: Federal prosecutors are investigating whether an American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the news and financial data giant, commissioned computer specialists to steal confidential information from the corporate computers of a major competitor, Bloomberg L.P.

title: A New Era Of Wheeling And Dealing; Rising Competition Squeezes Car Sellers
description: When James Bordoshuk shopped for a Ford Explorer seven years ago, he lugged his young children to one showroom after another over several weekends and haggled for hours. He finally bought the sport utility vehicle from a dealership three miles away from his home -- one of 42 Ford dealers in metropolitan Chicago.

title: A Wild Ride, With No End Now in Sight
description: Just days ago, traumatized White House officials said their own polls suggested a sinking President. Prominent Democrats casually used the words ''impeachment'' and ''resignation.'' The central question inside and outside Washington seemed to be, How much longer can President Clinton hang on?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS KARP, MARJE
description: FIELDS KARP-Marje. Her fellow volunteers at the NYC Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association, the staff and Directors, mourn the passing of a good friend and courageous lady, Marje Karp. Likewise, the many AD caregivers she touched as a support group leader and Helpline volunteer. At this difficult time, our heartfelt condolences go out to her family. John A. Jager, Exec. Director Cynthia Roy, Volunteer Coord.

title: Movies as Teaching Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: When It Says 'Don't Walk,' New Yorkers Do; Enforce the Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: After Derailing Trade Bill, Labor Sets Ambitious Goals
description: Looking for new legislative successes after blocking President Clinton's fast-track trade bill last year, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. outlined an ambitious legislative agenda today that would raise the minimum wage and require employers to pay at least 75 percent of workers' health insurance premiums.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul Caponigro

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ESTELLE K. (KASANOF)
description: STERN-Estelle K. (Kasanof). Of Chestnut Hill, MA on Wednesday, January 28th, after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Devoted mother of Sidney R. Stern of Boston, MA., and Truro, MA. Leaves a host of friends and relatives. Services are on Sunday, February 1st. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to the Brandeis University National Women's Committee Library Fund, 415 South Street, Waltham, MA. 02254. For information Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA. (617-277-8300).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSHKIN, BELLE WINER
description: MUSHKIN-Belle Winer, 94, Bronxville, Jan. 17. Wife of late William Mushkin. Survived by son, Martin Mushkin of Greenwich, CT, brother Leo Winer of Hollywood, CA and granddaughters, Elena Mushkin of Atlanta, and Hillary Mushkin of Los Angeles.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Helen Torr

title: Family Business Gets New Home
description: Twenty years ago, there were dozens of family dynasties in the antiques trade in Manhattan. Now there are 15. That's why it's worth noting the reopening on Wednesday of the Blumka Gallery of medieval and Renaissance art, at 209 East 72d Street, its fifth home in Manhattan. Anthony Blumka, great-grandson of the founder, has transformed a town house into a soaring gallery to display bronze and wooden sculptures, Gothic enamels and ivories, Renaissance jewelry, and medieval and Renaissance furniture.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOOM, ELI
description: BLOOM-Eli. Our friend, father and grandfather. In our hearts he is remembered with more love each day.

title: BOWATER TO SELL ONE PAPER MILL AND UPGRADE ANOTHER
description: Bowater Inc., the nation's largest producer of newsprint, said it would sell a pulp and paper mill in Millinocket, Me., and spend $220 million to upgrade a mill in nearby East Millinocket. Bowater will then have the capacity to produce the same amount of paper at a much lower cost, a spokeswoman said. Up to 300 of the 1,500 workers employed at the plants will lose their jobs in the next three years. Bowater, based in Greenville, S.C., bought both mills from the Georgia-Pacific Corporation in 1992 for $415 million, including debt. Over all, Bowater owns five mills and 3.5 million acres of timberland.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, ROBERT D.
description: KLEIN-Robert D. 9/25/30-1/30/94. Bob, Daddy and Grandpa Bob: You are always in our hearts. Gerri, Patti and Ira, Richard and Dara

title: The Universally Magical Time of Childhood
description: It's the unusual film that captures the rhythms and moods of childhood with an intensity that transports you back in time. But when one does, you are reminded that every childhood is in some sense the same. The world looms much larger when you're small, and its emotional climate is tropical, as sunshine and cloudbursts follow each other with dizzying speed and unpredictability. The physical world is experienced with a raw hungry intensity that will never be felt again, and everyday objects often seem mysteriously animated with personality.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Richard Woods

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Newark's Mayor Pledges to Add 200 Police Officers and Cut Property Taxes
description: Proclaiming ''Newark is a city on a roll,'' Mayor Sharpe James, in a lofty State of City address tonight, pledged to increase the city's police force by 200 officers, to slash city property taxes by 5 percent and to carry out a host of other election-year initiatives including discounted water rates for elderly homeowners.

title: Movements by Balanchine, Flowing and Restless
description: Two stylistically contrasting ballets by George Balanchine were presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Metro Business; Lehman to Buy Back Stock
description: The Wall Street investment bank Lehman Brothers Holdings said this week that it would buy back up to 4.5 million shares, or about 3.6 percent of its common stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ALEX
description: WEISS-Alex. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the father of its esteemed member and past member of its Women's Club Presidium, Mrs. Caron Enlander, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres. Maidy Jeger Beryl Traum Women's Club Presidium

title: Girl Accused of Stabbing Boys With Needle
description: A 14-year-old girl was charged yesterday with assault, accused of stabbing nine students with a needle at a Bronx school, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: When It Says 'Don't Walk,' New Yorkers Do; Pedestrian Paradise
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing Iraq Isn't Enough
description: Saddam Hussein must go. This imperative may seem too simple for some experts and too daunting for the Clinton Administration. But if the United States is committed, as the President said in his State of the Union Message, to insuring that the Iraqi leader never again uses weapons of mass destruction, the only way to achieve that goal is to remove Mr. Hussein and his regime from power. Any policy short of that will fail.

title: Themes of the Romantic Era In the Scottish Highlands
description: George Balanchine's ''Scotch Symphony,'' which the New York City Ballet offered on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, combines choreographic charm with esthetic commentary. Its patterns are pleasant to behold. But the ballet is also a distillation of themes associated with the Romantic era in the arts, particularly the tension between the material and supernatural realms on which such great 19th-century Romantic ballets as ''La Sylphide'' and ''Giselle'' are based.

title: Cameron Clark, 53, a Manhattan Lawyer
description: Cameron Clark, a partner in the Manhattan-based law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison for more than two decades, died on Jan. 15 at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 53 and had homes on the Upper East Side and in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Seal Harbor, Maine.

title: Giuliani Demands Community Colleges Drop Remedial Help
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called yesterday for a drastic overhaul of New York City's six community colleges, declaring that they should shift the responsibility for teaching remedial courses to other institutions, a policy he said could essentially reduce the number of students in the system by at least 75 percent. He backed his proposal with a threat: If the colleges balked, he might withhold their city financing.

title: Samuel Austin, 62, a Pastor and Baptist Leader
description: The Rev. Samuel Austin, pastor of Brown Memorial Baptist Church of Brooklyn and a leader in his 8.5-million member denomination, the National Baptist Convention U.S.A., died last Friday in Los Angeles. He was 62 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: INSIDE
description: Navy May Make Deal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURASCH, MARTIN
description: KURASCH-Martin. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds deeply mourn the passing of Martin Kurasch, First General Counsel for Israel Bonds from 1951 to 1984. Since the Organization's inception, Martin's integrity, knowledge and kind heart earned him the respect of all who worked with him. His devotion to the Organization and to the State of Israel will long be remembered. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Burton P. Resnick, Chairman of the Board Gideon Patt, President Susan Weikers-Volchok, International Campaign Chairman Michael Siegal, North American Campaign Chairman Irwin Hochberg, National Campaign Chairman

title: TST Seeking to Sell Stake
description: TST/Impreso Inc., a maker of paper products, said today that it was negotiating to sell a stake in itself to a foreign paper company. TST said it had also agreed to market and distribute products made by the undisclosed company. TST had revenues of $33.6 million in 1997.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, celebrating the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Stocks of Four REIT's Sag on Report of Threat to Status
description: The shares of a handful of real estate investment trusts came under heavy selling pressure yesterday after a report that the Clinton Administration might propose to alter the way they do business significantly .

title: Greenspan's Reassuring Comments Cause Treasury Rally
description: Treasury securities rallied yesterday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said that Asia's economic crisis would give the American economy ''some breathing room from inflation pressures.''

title: Mr. Giuliani's Budget Choices
description: With sizable budget surpluses flowing from New York City's economic boom, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani could easily have proposed major new spending programs and tax cuts for next year. Instead, he has prudently chosen to stick with fiscal discipline. The financial plan outlined by Mr. Giuliani yesterday calls for selective new expenditures for education and anti-drug programs, as well as elimination of the sales tax on clothing and other modest tax reductions. But these would be paid for with spending cuts elsewhere. His projected $35 billion budget thus lays the groundwork for economic stability in the city.

title: Hardaway Scores 11 Off the Bench in Return
description: MAGIC 95, ROCKETS 88

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'No Ordinary Love'

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an interview with Richard Butler, the United Nations' chief weapons inspector for Iraq, quoted him incompletely on the subject of Iraq's arsenal of biological weapons and missiles. Mr. Butler said Iraq was known to have loaded biological weapons material onto warheads with enough capacity to ''blow away Tel Aviv, or wherever''; the published version omitted ''or wherever.'' Mr. Butler says he was not implying that Iraq had actually targeted Tel Aviv, only that Iraq had the ability to strike any city within range of its missiles. His Letter to the Editor appears today on page A16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANWANDTER, JORGE IGNACIO
description: ANWANDTER-Jorge Ignacio, 38. Emerging Markets, Investments Banker. Died of cancer Tuesday, January 27, 1998 at Greenwich Hospital, after a long and heroic struggle. Born on July 31, 1959 in Santiago, Chile, he was the son of Jorge and Eliana Anwandter. Mr. Anwandter married Patricia Beemer on March 24, 1984 and is the father of two children, Patricia Marcella and Jorge Nicolas. Mr. Anwandter graduated from the School of Business and Economics of the University of Chile in Santiago in 1981, and the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University in 1984. He initially worked for Banco Sud Americano in Santiago and New York and joined Citicorp Investment Bank in 1984, where he worked in corporate finance and subsequently in Latin American securities trading. In 1986, he joined the Dutch Bank NMB which became part of the ING Group in 1991 and acquired Barings in 1995. Mr. Anwandter was one of the pioneers of emerging-markets debt trading and played a significant role in establishing ING as one of the top emerging-markets institutions in the global market. During his 12-year career at ING he was involved in building ING's Mexican operation, corporate finance and more recently, in successfully establishing the localmarkets trading desk in New York. His family, colleagues and many close friends deeply regret this devastating loss. We will truly miss him. Visiting hours will be from 5-9 P.M. Friday, at the Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home at 31 Arch St. in Greenwich, CT. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 AM, on Saturday, at St. Michael's, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. Burial will follow in Middle Patent Cemetery in Armonk, New York.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Arne Svenson

title: Corrections
description: The Skiing Notebook article in the sports section yesterday, about a towing system for cross-country skiers, misstated the Internet address for a sled company, Ziffco. The address is: http://www.ziffco.com/olimits.htm

title: Accounts
description: Blockbuster Video, Dallas, a unit of Viacom Inc., to W. B. Doner & Co., Southfield. Mich., to handle a national consumer promotion to begin in the spring. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Excerpts From Reno Request on Expansion of Whitewater Inquiry
description: Following are excerpts from Attorney General Janet Reno's letter of Jan. 16 to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on the expansion of the jurisdiction of the Whitewater special prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, and the court's decision in the matter:

title: Navy May Resolve Gay Case by Letting Sailor Retire
description: The Navy is considering dropping its efforts to dismiss a highly decorated sailor accused of homosexuality after a Federal judge issued a permanent injunction today barring his ouster, Defense Department officials said today.

title: A Campaign Indictment, at Last
description: The 1996 campaign finance abuses may have been overshadowed in recent days by the accusations of sexual and legal misconduct by President Clinton, but they have not disappeared. The Justice Department this week produced the first indictment in its campaign fund-raising investigation -- a welcome step, but hardly one that makes up for the slow, timid character of the inquiry.

title: Two 'Bloody Sundays': Catalysts for Change
description: Jan. 30, 1972, was not the first day in the 20th-century history of Irish conflict to have gained the name Bloody Sunday and become a rallying cry for political change.

title: Exile Group Seeks More Aid for Cuba, With Strings Attached
description: In a move to undermine a bill that would allow the sale of food and medicine to Cuba, a leading Cuban exile organization said today that it would try to increase the amount of humanitarian aid to the island by having international relief agencies distribute such assistance.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bonds Rise Strongly On Greenspan Comments

title: Turning Up Discoveries In Handel
description: Some three decades since the Baroque revival began restoring an era's worth of forgotten works to the active repertory, Handel operas remain an acquired taste. They are long, typically about four hours, and for listeners who find the works' streams of da capo arias repetitive rather than enlightening, they can seem longer than they are. They also represent a daunting body of work: between 1705 and 1741, Handel composed 37 of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRYSTAL, MARJORIE
description: CRYSTAL-Marjorie. On January 26, 1998. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Bernard Crystal. Loving mother of Thomas, Bernard and Sydney and caring mother-in-law of Ann, Joan and Bill. Proud grandmother of Matthew and Joseph and of Michael, Paul, Susan and their partners, Karen, Sybille and Mark and great grandmother to Evan. She was an ardent New Yorker whose interest in the cultural life of this City never waned, a lady with amazing will and spirit. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, February 22, at 2 P.M. at the 92nd Street YMHA.

title: Lists, Lists, Lists
description: ''Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,'' the torrid and true crime-travelogue by JOHN BERENDT, has phenomenal staying power. As of Feb. 8, the gossipy Savannah story will have been on the New York Times best-seller list for 186 weeks, tying what had been the longest-lasting title in history, ''The Power of Positive Thinking,'' the DR. NORMAN VINCENT PEALE parable for the 1950's.

title: A Picture Album in an Archive Never at a Loss for Words
description: Did you want to look at an aardvark or an armored truck? A balloon or a battleship? A rare garden bug or a garden-variety politician? From her vast stock, Romana Javitz (1903-1980) could find you a picture of anything. As chief custodian and cultivator of the New York Public Library's Picture Collection from 1929 to 1968, Ms. Javitz helped it grow from a modest resource to a major repository of five million items that reflect the ever-changing shifts in popular taste.

title: Beating Victim Mends a Life That She Could Barely Recall
description: In the months after she was attacked in Central Park, the young piano teacher understood almost nothing about what was happening to her. She mistook her room at a rehabilitation center in East Orange, N.J., for her Manhattan apartment, pestering people about why they were not locking the door. She mistook the view outside the window for a freeway in California, a place she had not lived in for a decade.

title: Waste Management Stuck in Accounting Mire
description: Waste Management Inc. said late today that its problems with misleading accounting went back to 1992, two years earlier than previously announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, BEATRICE E.
description: FIELD-Beatrice E. On January 27, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leonard E. Field. Dearest sister of Florence Mainzer and Leonard Epstein. Beloved aunt of Ellen, Steven and Leslie Epstein and Jennifer, Eric, Brian, Rhoda, Susan, Stephen, David and Jeffrey. Funeral Service today at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the National Council of Jewish Women, NY Chapter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CICHETTI, CORA D.
description: CICHETTI-Cora D. On January 28, 1998, of Houston, TX, formerly of Tuxedo Park, NY. Retired in 1970 from Exxon Corp. in NYC. Loving sister of Anthony and Joseph Cichetti. Reposing Scarr Funeral Home, Rte 202, Suffern, on Sunday 1-4 PM. Mass Monday 9:30 AM Mt. Carmel Church, Tuxedo Park, NY.

title: Allen Johnson To Head Hurdles
description: Allen Johnson, the American who won the 110-meter hurdles in the 1996 Olympics and the 1995 and 1997 world championships, heads the 60-meter hurdles field announced yesterday for the Chase Millrose Games on Feb. 13 in Madison Square Garden.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Still Rhyming to a Salsa Beat
description: Sometimes good nights just happen, and at the Copacabana on Tuesday night Pete (El Conde) Rodriguez and his orchestra were putting all the parts together for a good night. Mr. Rodriguez, one of the most important singers to have come out of the Fania label during the 1960's, and the bandleader Johnny Pacheco's best singer, is still a vital improviser, and he and his band were there to make hard, powerful music.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Andy Warhol

title: Brooklyn Officer Faces Dismissal Over Child Pornography Tapes
description: A Brooklyn police officer faces dismissal from the force because he was caught during a Federal sting operation buying videotapes of child pornography, according to police documents.

title: Saving Brazil's Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: A Maverick Who Is No Friend of Bill
description: Perhaps the best description of Lucianne S. Goldberg, the New York literary agent who says she encouraged a former White House aide, Linda R. Tripp, to secretly tape her conversations with a young friend alleged to have had sex with President Clinton, is what she calls herself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTELLI, THOMAS (ESQ.)
description: CARTELLI-Thomas (Esq.). Founder and first president of the Columbian Lawyers Association. Beloved father of Laraine Botsacos and Thomas Jr. Loving grandfather of James Botsacos, Jr., Laura Botsacos, Stephanie Botsacos, Philip and Gregory Cartelli. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Avenue, Bronx from Sunday 2 P.M. until Monday 8:45 A.M. Mass of Christian Burial St. Claire's Church, Monday at 9:45 A.M.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ulrich Ruckriem

title: Auto Deal on Air Pollution Is Rejected by Three States
description: A complicated deal to reduce air pollution appeared to falter today, as New York, Massachusetts and Vermont rejected auto industry demands that they relax their emission regulations so that manufacturers could produce one standard, cleaner car for every state but California.

title: Operating Profit Falls 77% at MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, which is being bought by Worldcom Inc., said today that profit before charges fell 77 percent in the fourth quarter amid higher expenses. On a net basis, the long-distance phone company had a loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALKENSTEIN, PAULA
description: FALKENSTEIN-Paula. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Burton Falkenstein on the loss of his beloved wife and to children Howie and Noah on the loss of their beloved mother. May the the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: The Political Kidnapping Of an Ambassador Retold
description: What is the most effective way for a passionate opponent of a government that sponsors torture and death squads to fight back? ''Four Days in September,'' Bruno Barreto's semifictionalized recounting of the actual kidnapping in 1969 of the United States Ambassador to Brazil by a group of radical students during Brazil's military dictatorship, offers no comfortable answers.

title: World News Briefs; Royal Dutch/Shell Plans To Remove Oil Platform
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group announced plans today to remove an obsolete oil platform in Norway, ending three years of environmental arguments that touched off a boycott of the world's biggest oil company.

title: Now Is No Time to Relax
description: Tom Chorske, like most of the Islanders, spent little time yesterday savoring a 6-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers at Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday night. Impressive as it was, it was only the second Islander victory in the last 17 games, and Chorske was focused on tonight's visit by the Carolina Hurricanes, who defeated the Islanders in the last two meetings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEG, PROFESSOR MIRZA ABDUL BAQI
description: BEG-Professor Mirza Abdul Baqi. September 20, 1934 to January 30, 1990.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Bloody Sunday was a tragic day for all concerned. We must all wish it had never happened. Our concern now is simply to establish the truth and close this painful chapter once and for all.''

title: 2 Workers Seriously Injured In Explosion in the Subway
description: Two transit workers were seriously injured in a Brooklyn subway tunnel early yesterday morning when a drill they were using to repair a broken track came in contact with an electrified rail, causing a small explosion, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORTE, MARIA (NEE BRING)
description: KORTE-Maria (nee Bring). On 1/ 29/98. Beloved wife of the late Otto, devoted mother of the late Frank Rudi. Will be greatly missed by Margaret (Peggy) O'Reilly Korte, daughter-in-law, nieces and nephews in Germany and her many friends in the New York area. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St, NYC Friday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass 10 AM Sat. at St. Joseph's RC Church, 404 E. 87 St, NYC.

title: Hostile Time For Babbitt At Hearing
description: Under hostile questioning from Republican representatives, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt testified today that his department's decision in 1995 to reject a permit to build an Indian casino in Wisconsin was based on the merits of the case, not political pressure.

title: Asian Ripples Seen
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned that Asia's financial crisis would be felt in the United States, but said that the slowdown would reduce any risk of inflation and that the economy was sound.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Prequel? Wag the Tongue

title: Joseph Alioto, 81, Dies; Antitrust Lawyer Was San Francisco's Mayor in Boom Years
description: Joseph L. Alioto, the two-term Mayor of San Francisco during the city's most dynamic growth in the late 1960's and early 1970's and a lawyer who earned millions of dollars with the nation's largest civil antitrust practice, died yesterday at his home in San Francisco. He was 81 and had prostate cancer, but family members said he died of pneumonia.

title: Kadiapatti Journal; Trading Clan's Great Wealth Now Covered in Dust
description: All the Italian marble floors and Burmese teak columns in Krisnappan Chettiar's mansion, even all the colonnaded dining halls and upstairs bedrooms that have been shut for years, cannot give a true picture of the opulence in which the Chettiar community lived during its glory days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, MARTHA RICHARDSON
description: MOORE-Martha Richardson. Secretary to former President Herbert Hoover and among the first group of women to be commissioned as an officer in the Navy Waves during World War II, died at her home in Stamford, CT on January 25. She was 90. Born, Martha Richardson, 1907, in Norristown, PA, to Dr. William Waddle Richardson, a psychiatrist, and Lila MacDonald Richardson, Mrs. Moore graduated from Wellesley College in 1929. When she married Lt. Cmdr. Edward P. Moore, son of Hoyt A. Moore an attorney with Cravath, Swaine, & Moore in New York City, they became the first naval officers on active duty to be married. Mrs. Moore is survived by a son, Edward P. Moore, Jr., of Honolulu, Hawaii, a daughter, Lora M. Vezzosi of Florence, Italy, four grandchildren and a great granddaughter.

title: CLEVELAND REAL ESTATE COMPANIES IN $306 MILLION DEAL
description: The Associated Estates Realty Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire MIG Realty Advisors Inc., a privately held property management and investment company, for $306 million in stock and cash and assumed debt. Under the deal, Associated Estates will also acquire 11 multifamily apartment properties managed by MIG and three development properties in Florida. Associated Estates, a real estate investment trust, owns 88 properties and manages 32. MIG manages 36 multifamily apartment properties and is an adviser to institutional real estate investors. The companies are based in Cleveland.

title: Excerpts of Linda Tripp's Statement on Her Role in Case
description: Following are excerpts of a statement released to The New York Times late tonight by Linda R. Tripp through her lawyer, James Moody.

title: Tobacco Executives Wax Penitent Before House Panel in Hopes of Preserving Accord
description: Four years after top tobacco company officials denied before a Congressional committee that cigarettes were addictive, a new crop of executives appeared today before the same panel as supplicants, pledging to release secret company documents, combat teen-age smoking and acknowledge tobacco risks in an effort to gain protection from lawsuits.

title: Keen Grasp of the Elementary, and the Zany
description: The brilliant nerd hero from the Pacific Northwest is overdue in movies. So one finds his way into ''Zero Effect'' in the form of Daryl Zero, an aging hippie Sherlock Holmes with the household habits of a Howard Hughes. As played with wild-eyed foxiness by Bill Pullman, Zero is a wealthy recluse living in a penthouse on canned soup and tuna fish, whacking tunelessly at his guitar and occasionally calming down enough to play detective. His long-suffering Watson is Steve Arlo (Ben Stiller), who is a slave to Zero's whims and cordially hates his boss.

title: Dow Profit Falls 12.7%
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that its profit fell 12.7 percent in the fourth quarter as an increase in sales volume was offset by a decline in prices for its chemical products.

title: Imperial Delicacies From Japan
description: ''Twelve Centuries of Japanese Art From the Imperial Collection,'' at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery here, is a candy box of an exhibition -- or, more properly, a particularly lavish obento, or Japanese lunch box. Delicacies are served up in small portions; everything is exquisitely made; there's barely a gram of fat in the lot.

title: Time Is Running Out, Albright Warns Iraq
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said tonight that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq should know that ''we have all but exhausted the diplomatic options, and the time is fast approaching for fundamental decisions.''

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Zampese to Patriots
description: The New England Patriots named the Dallas Cowboys assistant Ernie Zampese, 61, their new offensive coordinator.

title: First Boston To Pay Fine in Orange County Bond Offering
description: Credit Suisse First Boston and two former employees agreed today to pay $870,000 to settle Federal charges that they misled investors in a bond offering connected to Orange County's 1994 bankruptcy.

title: Jones-Douglas for Heavyweight Title
description: Roy Jones Jr. will make his first foray into the heavyweight division against James (Buster) Douglas, the former undisputed heavyweight champion, on May 2 in Atlantic City.

title: In Search Of Bridges To a Time Long Lost
description: Our search for remote, exotic specimens of the covered bridge ends with a toast of the local lager: Here's to frosty mornings, icy streams and raindrops on hex signs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNSTEIN, JANETTE
description: ARNSTEIN-Janette. On January 28, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Seymour and Donald. Dear mother-inlaw of Joann and Janice. Loving sister of Hilda Bleichfeld, Gertrude Covett and Thelma Fixler. Cherished grandmother of Jesse, Mimi, Tammy, Michael and Matthew. Services Thursday, 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGASHIWALA, SUSHILA J.
description: AGASHIWALA-Sushila J. On Wednesday, January 28, 1998. Wife of the late Jasvantlal V. Agashiwala. Loving mother of the late Dinesh Agashiwala, and Mahesh Agashiwala, and Anjana Desai. Mother-in-law of Paulomi and Loma. Dear grandmother of Sanjiv, Rajiv, and Binita. For information Edward F. Carter Funeral Home, Montrose, New York.

title: Eli Lilly's Net Up 23% In 4th Quarter
description: Eli Lilly & Company said today that profit rose 23 percent during the fourth quarter as sales of its biggest drug, the antidepressant Prozac, rose 15 percent and sales of some other drugs more than doubled.

title: W. Wood Prince, 83, of Chicago; Businessman Adopted by Cousin
description: William Wood Prince, a prominent Chicago businessman and philanthropist, died on Jan. 22 at his home in Chicago. He was 83.

title: New Video Releases
description: Hercules

title: Port Authority Budget Includes Larger Car Lot at Newark
description: Travelers flying out of Newark International Airport who spent much of their Christmas holiday searching in vain for a parking space may have an easier time next Christmas. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to add 1,300 spaces at the airport, at least 500 of which are expected to be ready by Thanksgiving.

title: The Leaning Tower of Flushing; Evacuated Condo Owners Want Years of Ordeal to End
description: ''Magnificent'' Vista Tower is nearly deserted now, what with water damage to the ''plush'' wall-to-wall carpeting, drifting concrete slabs beneath the ''abundance of closets,'' hefty cracks in the walls of the ''gourmet kitchens'' and an errant, life-threatening lean to the ''showcase building'' itself.

title: From Lieder to Korean Songs (With a Touch of the Diva)
description: The Korean-born soprano Hei-Kyung Hong is well known to New Yorkers from her work at the Metropolitan Opera, most recently a highly praised portrayal of Liu in Puccini's ''Turandot.''

title: Sprewell Calmly Testifies In His Defense at Hearing
description: Having listened to two days of testimony about his actions last Dec. 1 and two months of speculation about his National Basketball Association career, Latrell Sprewell testified today in his arbitration case against the league and his former team, the Golden State Warriors.

title: Mid-60's America Gets a New Dream
description: PILLAR OF FIRE

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR MOVES HIGHER. The dollar rallied against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday, buoyed by rallies in the United States bond and stock markets. In late trading in New York, the dollar cost 125.67 yen, up from 124.75 on Wednesday, and 1.8280 marks, up from 1.8120.

title: HBO in Tow, Reid Believes His Time Has Come
description: Forget about being brought along slowly. If it were up to David Reid, he would be matched against the top junior middleweight contenders right now.

title: Regionalization Is Urged For School Districts
description: An advisory panel urged officials yesterday to consolidate some of the 618 school districts to lessen burdens on taxpayers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BUDGET GROUP INC., Daytona Beach, Fla., owner and franchiser of Budget Car and Truck Rental units, bought Cruise America Inc., Mesa, Ariz., a recreational vehicle sales and rental company, for $62 million in stock. It also assumed debt of $76 million.

title: Some CUNY Officials Are Cautious About Mayor's Proposal, but Others See Disaster
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's sharp attack on the City University of New York -- and his proposal to remove all remedial work from the community colleges, a cornerstone of the university's open access policy -- took officials there by surprise yesterday.

title: A U.S. JUDGE BARS LEWINSKY EVIDENCE IN JONES'S LAWSUIT
description: A Federal judge in Little Rock, Ark., ruled today that lawyers representing Paula Corbin Jones in her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton may not use any evidence involving former White House intern Monica S. Lewinsky, a setback in helping to make their case.

title: Talks Over Ex-Intern's Testimony On Clinton Appear to Bog Down
description: Negotiations between Monica S. Lewinsky's lawyer and Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, have stalled, lawyers say, partly because Ms. Lewinsky is not offering prosecutors as much detail about her conversations with President Clinton as she reportedly disclosed to a friend on secretly recorded tapes.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Daniel Oates

title: The Lure of Gang Violence To a Latin Beat
description: For those who regard theatergoing as blood sport, it promised to be the event of the season. A budget of $11 million; a world-famous composer new to the Broadway musical and openly contemptuous of its traditions; a protracted period of previews replete with tales of desperate last-minute revisions, a frenzied parade of advice-dispensing show doctors: ''The Capeman,'' Paul Simon's pop-operatic retelling of a street-gang murder in 1959, seemed to have all the elements that make theater-disaster cultists drool.

title: Conservatives Quietly Find Ways to Talk Of Scandal
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested today that the White House was becoming ''unstable,'' in part because of the sex scandal that threatens to engulf President Clinton.

title: High Costs and High Expectations
description: In elegant silence, Japan's speed skaters whispered over the ice this morning inside the Olympic oval, a magnificent building with a cascading roof called the M-Wave. Today, the arena was empty. Next week, when the 1998 Winter Games begin a 16-day run, the M-Wave will crest with noise and anticipation, and the Japanese skaters, tucked in their racing crouches, will bear the weight of their country's expectations.

title: C.I.A. Report Concludes Agency Knew Nothing of Drug Dealers' Ties to Rebels
description: The Central Intelligence Agency today released the first volume of an internal investigation concluding that the agency knew nothing about California cocaine dealers who claimed connections with rebels in Nicaragua backed by the agency.

title: Gustav Eyssell Is Dead at 96; Put Films In Famed Music Hall
description: Gustav S. Eyssell, a former treasurer of a Kansas City, Mo., vaudeville and movie house who rose to be president of Radio City Music Hall and later of Rockefeller Center, died on Wednesday at his home in Loudoun County, Va. He was 96.

title: Singapore's Finances
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDLEY, SOL J.
description: EDLEY-Sol J. Dearest Zovel, today would have been our fortyninth wedding anniversary. I miss you, I love you. Always, Your Poil.

title: Perhaps Shot, Perhaps Not
description: As familiar as Andy Warhol's image of Marilyn Monroe has become in the visual vocabulary of popular culture, the actual paintings the artist executed in the early 1960's rarely appear on the market. When they do, they generate a good deal of excitement among Pop Art collectors, which is the case with ''Orange Marilyn.''

title: Residential Real Estate; Park Avenue Hotel Being Converted Into Condos
description: Aiming for the top of the Manhattan residential market, the owner of the Mayfair Hotel at the corner of Park Avenue and 65th Street is spending $55 million to convert the 1925 building into 70 luxury condominiums.

title: Devils' Patience Accents Holik's Ascent
description: They did things differently in Jacques Lemaire's day.

title: Metro Business; Unit of Life Insurer Moving to New York
description: A division of the New York Life Insurance Company is moving back to Manhattan from New Jersey.

title: Bill Would Allow Use Of 'Megan's Law' Names
description: An amendment to ''Megan's Law'' that would let newspapers publish information about convicted sex offenders without fear of prosecution was introduced yesterday in the Assembly.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'The Oyster and the Wind'

title: Excerpts From Briefing at White House
description: Following are excerpts from today's White House briefing by Michael D. McCurry, President Clinton's spokesman, as recorded by Federal News Service, a transcription service:

title: Regulators Oppose End to Session if Dow Plunges
description: The nation's top financial regulators told Congress today that they oppose a proposal by securities markets to suspend trading for the day after stocks fall sharply, saying that the new rules would be too restrictive.

title: When the Avant-Garde Parted From the Rear Guard
description: The avant-garde is a quaint term. No one wants to be the 20th-century version of those 19th-century writers who failed to see that the future was with Gustave Courbet, not Adolphe-William Bouguereau. So now all the official organs of artistic power -- schools, galleries, museums, critics, collectors -- fall over one another to endorse whatever's new.

title: S.& P. 500 at Record Close On Low-Inflation Outlook
description: Expectations of lower inflation lifted stocks yesterday for a third consecutive session, propelling the Standard & Poor's 500 index to a new closing high.

title: Continental Shareholders Try to Block Deal
description: Some Continental Airlines Inc. shareholders have filed suit to block Northwest Airlines from buying a stake in the company, saying they would be shortchanged.

title: The Turkish Underworld
description: Turkey's secular leaders like to talk about the subversive activities of Islamic politicians and Kurdish separatists, but the gravest threat to democratic order in Turkey in recent years seems to have come from the secular leadership itself. An official investigation has found that between 1993 and 1996 the Government of Prime Minister Tansu Ciller connived with drug gangs, gambling moguls and right-wing hit men to assassinate enemies at home and abroad and sponsor a failed coup attempt in nearby Azerbaijan.

title: On Asian Crisis Balance Sheet, Credits and Debits for the U.S.
description: For drivers who pull into gasoline stations these days, the Asian crisis is a blessing. Falling demand for oil in Asia has helped to cut the average price of a gallon of regular gasoline in the United States to $1.08, from $1.20 last month. Not since 1989 has gasoline been so cheap. Home owners are similarly blessed. Thanks largely to the crisis, interest rates have fallen and the number of mortgage refinancings is higher than ever.

title: Cop, His Kid and a Killer: A Traumatized Hospital
description: Peter McCabe (Michael Keaton): evil killer. Frank Conner (Andy Garcia): San Francisco cop. Frank's son (Joseph Cross): suffering from leukemia, desperate for a transplant. The boy's bone marrow: just like McCabe's. Throw in a noble female surgeon (Marcia Gay Harden) and a lot of hospital mayhem, and you have the formula for ''Desperate Measures,'' a thriller that is unexpectedly fond of formulaic touches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEU, HAROLD C., M.D.
description: NEU-Harold C., M.D. The members of the New York Society of Infectious Diseases mark, with deep sadness, the death of Harold C. Neu, M.D., the first President of our Society. Dr. Neu was a most esteemed colleague and friend, who distinguished himself as a physician, educator and scientist. For these reasons, our annual scientific meeting is named ''The Harold C. Neu Symposium'' in his honor and memory. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Carmen Ortiz-Neu, M.D. and children Harold A. Neu, Maria Neu Rorer, Natalie Neu, M.D. and his granddaughter Katherine Rorer.

title: On My Mind; America's War Goals
description: Decision day on attacking Iraq is about three weeks away. But the Clinton Administration has not given the public answers to questions critical to how America will win, what it will win, to what ends, and for how long.

title: Wary Gore Confronts A Dilemma
description: Vice President Al Gore stood before television cameras on Wednesday and forcefully defended President Clinton. ''He is the President of the country; he is also my friend,'' Mr. Gore said in introducing the President at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. ''And I want to ask you now, every single one of you, to join me in supporting him and standing by his side.''

title: My Manhattan; Neon (Blink) Glow Of (Blink) Old 42d
description: Walking into the newly refurbished New Amsterdam Theater to see ''The Lion King'' was an extraordinary moment for me, one that might have given Thomas Wolfe pause.

title: W. B. Doner Shifts Top Management
description: Top management changes were announced yesterday by W. B. Doner & Company, an agency with offices in Baltimore and Southfield, Mich.

title: When the Questioning Voice Displays a Mind of Its Own
description: There is a tradition in American song, probably going back to Charles Ives, in which words are set to lines that often avoid the seemingly obvious next step in order to land somewhere else. The melody self-adjusts as it goes along; from moment to moment, it is thinking itself up. The singing persona that any song puts forward appears in such cases to be making its own decisions. The song comes from a voice with a mind.

title: EXCEL TO ACQUIRE 70% STAKE IN GERMAN AUTO SUPPLIER
description: Excel Industries, based in Ekhart, Ind., said it had agreed to acquire a 70 percent stake in the German automotive supplier Schade G.m.b.H., for an undisclosed amount in cash. Schade, which makes window modules, doors, outside trim and plastic components, has annual sales of $275 million and plants in Germany, Portugal, Spain, Britain and the Czech Republic. Excel, which also makes windows and doors for the automotive industry, had 1996 sales of $887.7 million. Hella KG Hueck & Company, a German supplier of automotive lighting and electronics, owns the remaining 30 percent of Schade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABBATINO, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: SABBATINO-Joseph, M.D. The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart and the Medical Staff of Cabrini Medical Center mourn the loss of their esteemed colleage who served the institution for thirty years. Dr. Sabbatino was a dedicated physician who always showed a sincere concern for his patients and for Cabrini Medical Center. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his family. Albert Ciancimano, M.D., Pres., Medical Staff Morton Davidson, M.D., Med Dir Wilfredo Talavera, M.D., Director of Medicine Jeffrey Frerichs, Pres., Cabrini Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOSAPIO, GREGORY A.
description: LOSAPIO-Gregory A. We mourn the sudden loss of a true and loving friend whose smile, kind words and gentle demeanor will be missed by us and his many friends. Our most sincere condolences to his heartbroken family. Patrick and Lia Grasso

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWERSEY, ESTHER
description: SWERSEY-Esther. Of North Miami Beach, FL on January 28, 1998, in North Adams, MA. The daughter of Leo and Bertha Rosen, she grew up in the Bronx. She met her husband Frank when he served her lunch in a Madison Avenue coffee shop. Married for fifty-three years until his death in 1985, they lived in the Bronx until 1970 and then in Miami Beach, FL. She was a secretary, bookkeeper, raised two children, and worked at Frank's Spa, her husband's Manhattan restaurant. Her husband, sons, brother Lewis Cahn, family and friends knew her as a funny, smart, sweet, sensitive, loving and beautiful lady who loved duplicate bridge, dancing, horse racing, the movies, good food, travel, politics and current events and great conversation. Her sons Burt and Arthur, grandchildren Bill, Sarah and Rachel, daughters-in-law Alice and Tricia, cousin Tootsie Bell, sisterin-law Belle Swersey, dear friend Ada Baker, nieces and nephews, family and friends will always remember Essie.

title: Nassau County Chief Wants New Arena Built for Islanders by 2001
description: After years of talk and false starts, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta urged today that the county get started this year on construction of a new arena for the New York Islanders and other sports teams as the centerpiece of a tourist and entertainment hub in central Nassau.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEILLIS, SR. JEANNE MARIE (R.S.M.)
description: NEILLIS - Sr. Jeanne Marie (R.S.M.). January 28, 1998. Visitation Friday 3-8:30 P.M. at Sacred Heart Church, Broadway at Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, New York. Mass of the Resurrection 8:30 A.M. on Saturday, Sacred Heart Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorials to the McCauley Scholarship Fund or the Ministry Fund, C/O Sisters of Mercy, 150 Ridge Road, Hartsdale, New York 10530 are appreciated.

title: Van Horn Stands Out In Forum He Cherished
description: Madison Square Garden may be billed as the World's Most Famous Arena, but not to Keith Van Horn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, NATHAN
description: SILVERMAN - Nathan. The Trustees, Officers and Staff of North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System express deepest sympathies to our esteemed CoPresident and CEO, Dr. David R. Dantzker, and his wife, Sherrye, on the loss of Sherrye's father, Nathan. We extend sincere condolences to Nathan's wife, Raye, their children, Joan and Daniel Silna, their grandchildren, greatgrandchild, and all the other members of the family. Saul B. Katz and Roy J. Zuckerberg, Co-Chairmen John S.T. Gallagher, Co-President and CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System

title: Echoes of Rock, Stravinsky and a Spacey Webern
description: The Juilliard School's annual Focus festival of contemporary music is always impressive for the scope of its offerings. Joel Sachs, the conductor who directs the festival and selects the repertory, is not one to do things halfway, and this year's festival, ''Scandinavia Today,'' is no exception.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNIZEK, JOHN EDWARD
description: SNIZEK-John Edward. January 28, 1998, in Largo, Florida, at age 81. Longtime resident of Bayside, NY, he is survived by his wife of 50 years, Nellie, and daughter, Jean Reddish, of Sherman, Texas, sons, Michael of Westfield, New Jersey, and Paul of Harrisburg, PA. Longtime meatpacker and employee of the Golden Packing Company of New York. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: White House's Familiar Battle Plan: Keep Silent, Strike Often and Soldier On
description: Paul Begala, one of President Clinton's more pugnacious advisers, popped up on television this morning, attacking ''false leaks'' that produced damaging stories about the President's relationship with a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Fast Life But Short, Portrayed In a Frenzy
description: Though some characters are composites, the story is true. In 1978, Gia Carangi, a middle-class girl from Philadelphia, was 18 years old and one of the world's top models. By the mid-80's, she was a heroin addict sleeping on the street. Soon after, she died of AIDS at 26.

title: Beyond Budget, Mayor Looks to Larger Stage
description: Wielding his steel pointer like a conductor's baton, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered an hourlong lecture yesterday on how his administration had transformed New York City's disastrous budget into a model of fiscal prudence. Then, just when another pie-chart display could have sparked audience rebellion, he energized the room by suddenly declaring war on the City University of New York -- a tangential budgetary issue at best.

title: David Hare Play Arrives in April
description: Last fall, as the Broadway season was kicking into high gear, it looked to be dominated by musicals, and so it has been. But what then seemed to be a dearth of straight plays is turning into a relative plenitude.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Ingo Meller

title: For Mideast, a Distracted Clinton
description: Neither Benjamin Netanyahu nor Yasir Arafat would admit it, but the scandal that broke in Washington last week in the midst of their separate meetings with President Clinton was a boon for the Israeli Prime Minister and a setback for the Palestinian leader.

title: GLOBAL MARINE TO ACQUIRE DRILLING RIG FOR $150 MILLION
description: Global Marine Inc., the offshore drilling company based in Houston, said that it had agreed to acquire a deep-water drilling rig from a unit of Coflexip Stena Offshore for $150 million. The rig, the Stena Forth, is operating in the North Sea under a contract with British Petroleum that is expected to generate about $68 million in revenue, the company said. It also said it had received a contract for its deep-water Vinlander rig to drill offshore Newfoundland. That one-year contract is expected to generate $68 million. Global Marine had 1997 revenues of $1.07 billion. Its stock rose $1.25 a share yesterday, to $24.125.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Angela de la Cruz

title: Clinton Renews Warning
description: As the focus of the confrontation with Iraq shifted today to diplomacy, President Clinton renewed his stern warnings to Saddam Hussein and, noting previous strikes at Iraqi targets, said again that the United States was prepared to use force if necessary.

title: During a 60's Interlude, Color Was the Content
description: Whatever weight it may carry in art history, the work of the Green Mountain Boys, now appearing at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, is wonderfully viewer-friendly. In fact, it might be argued that this show of Color Field abstraction from the early 1960's by Kenneth Noland, Paul Feeley (1910-1966) and Jules Olitski, in company with the sculptor Anthony Caro, is one of the handsomest gallery installations around.

title: When It Says 'Don't Walk,' New Yorkers Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Gebrselassie Earns Jesse Owens Award
description: Haile Gebrselassie, the 24-year-old Ethiopian who broke world records at 5,000 and 10,000 meters last year, was named yesterday as the winner of the annual Jesse Owens International Trophy Award.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Pamela Fraser

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, HENRY (HANK) L. JR.
description: ROSS-Henry (Hank) L. Jr. On January 26, 1998. in Palm Springs, CA. Born in New Haven, Conn., September 20, 1928. The son of Henry L. and Olivia White Ross. Graduate of Phillips Andover in 1946 and Yale University in 1950. Retired from Pfizer Pharmaceuticals as member Board of Directors and president Consumer Product Division. Survived by his wife Camilla P. Ross of Delmar, CA.; a step-son, Peter Ross; three daughters, Ripley Drury of Novi, MI; Wendy Carothers of Arlington, VA.; Kate Johnson of Newton, MA.; and a son Henry L. Ross III of Fairfield, CT; as well as thirteen grandchildren. Donations in Hank Ross' memory can be made to The Floating Hospital's HemOnc Clinic at the New England Medical Center, 750 Washington Street, Boston, MA. 021111.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Joan Fontcuberta

title: If You Never Slept, You'd Fall Apart Too; As City Crumbles, New Yorkers Adjust, but With Hard Hats
description: So the whole city is coming down, it seems, shamelessly crumbling on top of its citizenry.

title: For Whitbread Race, Ice and Angst on Starboard
description: Anxiety inched its way into Paul Cayard's psyche this week. But why wouldn't it? As skipper of the first-place boat in the Whitbread Round the World Race, he had the restart tomorrow from Auckland, New Zealand, to think about. Beyond that, he had the most forbidding stage of the eight-month race in full view.

title: Black Art Show's Goals: Recognition and Buyers
description: One part black art survey and one part eclectic art bazaar, the National Black Fine Art Show returned to the Puck Building in SoHo yesterday for its second annual show.

title: Is the Ex-Intern Getting Hostility or Sympathy?
description: Monica S. Lewinsky sure has a lot of sympathizers all of a sudden.

title: Reuters Unit Puts 3 Executives on Paid Leave
description: Three executives with an American subsidiary of Reuters Holdings P.L.C. were placed on paid leave by the company following the disclosure of an investigation into the possible theft of confidential information from the corporate computers of a big competitor, Bloomberg L.P., Reuters executives said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPOZZOLI, ADELE (NEE VALLI)
description: CAPOZZOLI-Adele (nee Valli). Of NYC. Beloved wife of the late Justice and former Congressman Louis J. Capozzoli. Devoted mother of Louis Jr., of Baton Rouge, LA, Christine Raso, of Holmdel, NJ, and Gloria Barbieri, of Franklin Lakes, NJ. Adoring grandmother of 7 and great grandmother of 9. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, February 2, at St. Catherine's Church, Holmdel, NJ. She will live forever in the hearts of those who loved her. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to the Catholic Center at NYU-Soup Kitchen, 58 Washington Square South, NYC 10012, would be appreciated.

title: Knicks See Margin For Error Shrinking
description: After suffering through an endless succession of might-have-been's against the Heat 24 hours earlier, the Knicks on Thursday were left with an uncomfortable view of what is. Their third straight defeat, to the Milwaukee Bucks, showed that they had better concentrate on details.

title: Sports of The Times; In the N.F.L., Justice Is Still Denied
description: IN THE fall of 1980, Jomills Braddock, a research scientist for the Center of Social Organization of Schools at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, volunteered to conduct a study for the National Football League Players Association. The association was engaged in a frustrating wrestling match with the N.F.L. over league owners' resistance to hiring African-Americans for coaching and upper-management positions.

title: Japan Names Outsider as Finance Minister
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto picked a former prosecutor today to be the nation's new Finance Minister, a surprise choice suggesting there may be further assaults on corruption and clubbiness in Japanese financial circles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, HENRY A.
description: LOEB-Henry A. Mr. Loeb was elected in 1955 to replace his father, Carl M. Loeb, on the Board of Valeria Home, later renamed, in 1975, as The Jacob and Valeria Langeloth Foundation. He took his duties as a Director with high seriousness. Always punctual, perspicacious and perceptive, he brought to our deliberations his wisdom laced with good humor. As Treasurer since 1959, he shared his broad experience in financial markets and surveyed and supervised our fiscal affairs with skills which will be difficult to emulate. The Directors of the Langeloth Foundation extend their collective sympathy to Mrs. Loeb and their children. John L. Loeb, Jr, Chairman George Labalme, Jr., President Adam Hochschild, Vice President Peter K. Loeb, Treasurer

title: No Joke: Woeful Canucks Beat Devils
description: The Vancouver Canucks might be a National Hockey League laughingstock, but the Devils did not get the joke tonight.

title: Panel Finds Officer Was Justified In Unarmed Man's Fatal Shooting
description: A police officer who shot and killed an unarmed man in a Brooklyn grocery store last month was cleared of all criminal charges yesterday by a grand jury that found his actions justified under a law governing the use of deadly force, the Brooklyn District Attorney said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: British Drug Giants In Talks on a Merger
description: SmithKline Beecham says it is in talks with a another British pharmaceutical giant, Glaxo Wellcome, on a possible merger that would be the biggest ever. SmithKline also said that merger talks with American Home Products had ended. A combination of Glaxo, which makes Zantac, and SmithKline, which produces Tums and Aquafresh toothpaste, would dwarf most of its competitors.

title: Ex-Chief Sues Federated: $16 Million Not Enough
description: When he retired as chairman and chief executive of the parent company of Macy's and Bloomingdale's last May, Allen I. Questrom received a $16 million thank-you from the board for a job well done. But like a disappointed paramour who expected diamonds and got chocolates instead, Mr. Questrom has sniffed at the payment and taken his affront to court.

title: Jones Judge Bars Subpoenas to Secret Service
description: The Federal judge in the Paula Corbin Jones sexual harassment suit against President Clinton today quashed subpoenas served on Secret Service agents, saying their testimony would not be essential.

title: Rios Ready To Test His Luck In Final
description: Marcelo Rios has been such a big-time loser at the blackjack tables in this casino-proud city that he was not sure he would repair his losses even if he was to pocket the $415,000 check earmarked for the Australian Open's 1998 men's singles champion.

title: A Historian Defends His Leap From Past To Present
description: Robert O. Paxton is a former chairman of Columbia University's history department, unknown outside academic circles in the United States, who spends quiet weekends on Long Island's barrier beaches watching millions of birds fly south. His two callings, birding and history, are not entirely unrelated, and Mr. Paxton is willing to concede that the study of flocks and their migrations is in essence the study of historical trends.

title: Chelsea Clinton Returns For Weekend With Father
description: Chelsea Clinton flew home from college on Thursday night to spend the weekend with her father, the President, while her mother, Hillary Rodham Clinton, is in Switzerland to attend an economic conference.

title: Derby Hopefuls Poised To Begin Early Runs
description: Favorite Trick, the early but uncertain favorite for the Kentucky Derby, will be waiting on the sidelines 90 miles away, but two other top candidates will open their pursuit of 3-year-old honors on Saturday in races at Gulfstream Park.

title: Judge Upholds Vote Limiting Bar Hours
description: A vote scaling back summer bar hours in the seaside town of Wildwood was upheld yesterday by a Cape May County Superior Court judge.

title: My Guatemalan Nightmare
description: Last week, reacting to reports that five students from St. Mary's College in Maryland had been raped in Guatemala, that country's Ambassador to the United States called the brutal attack ''an isolated event'' and said accounts of violence against tourists were exaggerated. Unfortunately, my sister and I know otherwise.

title: The Bombing of Abortion Rights
description: The bombing that killed an off-duty policeman moonlighting as a security guard at an abortion clinic in Birmingham, Ala., and critically wounded a nurse on her way to work is yet another reminder that 25 years after the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade, the right of women to control their reproductive lives remains a target of violence. Just a year ago, two bombs exploded an hour apart, injured six people and left an Atlanta clinic that performed abortions in ruins.

title: Rain Subsides, and Golfers Have Half Day in the Sun
description: Playing just nine holes bothered some players today, but not Tom Lehman.

title: Senator Urges Clinton to Quit If Sex Scenario Was a Reality
description: In the strongest language that a Republican member of Congress has yet used about the White House sex scandal, Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri said today that if President Clinton had indeed been sexually involved with a 21-year-old intern, he should resign.

title: For Billy Joel, A Reversion To the Cares Of His Roots
description: Anger seethes behind suburbia's placid facades: the resentment of people bored with their jobs, disappointed by their romances, chafing against dead ends. It surfaces in music from punk-rock to the slickest pop, and it's the most telling part of Billy Joel's songs. When he turns pugnacious, his songs are eloquent; when he's not, sentimentality takes over.

title: STANDOFF WITH IRAQ: SPLENDOR AND RUIN -- A special report.; As Hussein Builds, His People Struggle to Live
description: On a small hill overlooking Baghdad's zoo, where most of the animals have perished from hunger, a stupendous new palace is rising. It is a massive, brooding, domed extravaganza, the latest and perhaps grandest of the monuments that are steadily remaking the city's skyline to the glory of Saddam Hussein.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: CANADIAN DOLLAR REBOUNDS. The central bank of Canada raised its target for short-term interest rates half a percentage point and followed with intervention to support the Canadian dollar. After a string of record lows, the currency finally responded, rising to 68.97 United States cents from 68.67.

title: With Technology, Island Bookies Skirt U.S. Law
description: The reggae bands were warming up on Sunday evening for their daily ritual of entertaining the American tourists who line the beaches of this Caribbean island. But in the cozy back room of a modern house that once served as the Chinese embassy, past the lazy dogs in the yard and the bicycles in the driveway, Bob Eremian was entertaining Americans in a different way.

title: Mets Wait For Benes To Come To Them
description: Steve Phillips knows Andy Benes can be an All-Star-caliber pitcher whose presence could markedly improve the Mets' rotation. He knows Benes is capable of throwing 200 innings and winning 12 to 17 games. He knows Benes is the best free agent available.

title: About New York; A New Musical Opens, and With It, Old Wounds
description: A FAN lingered by the Marquis Theater's stage door on West 45th Street Thursday night, clutching a photograph in hope of snagging an autograph from a cast member of ''The Capeman.'' Around the corner on Broadway, Jake Locicero stood on the sidewalk holding a photograph, too. He displayed no interest in the beautiful people who smiled, waved and waded through the flash of paparazzi cameras as they arrived for the musical's premiere.

title: Rangers Endure Strenuous Workout After Lackadaisical Tie
description: Wayne Gretzky, weary from today's practice, dropped to his knees. Darren Langdon, leaning on his stick, threw off his helmet. Pat LaFontaine, hurt by a teammate's slash, fired a water bottle into the seats with his stick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, ALICE
