description: FRIED-Alice. On January 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Georg. Loving mother of Robert. Dear sister of Nelly, Edward and Edith. Adoring grandmother of Paul, Steven and Dennis. Great-grandmother of Carolanne, Ellen and Kelsey. Service Sunday, February 1st, 12:30 PM at ''the Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Breaks for Clinton Do Not Lift Cloud
description: In the last two days, the President got the best legal news he has had since the uproar over Monica S. Lewinsky began. Among other things, a Federal judge ruled that Ms. Lewinsky would not testify in the Paula Corbin Jones case. But legal analysts say the developments are far from easing the pressure on Mr. Clinton from the criminal investigation.

title: When Buildings Tumble
description: To the Editor:

title: Ahmed D. Kafadar, 82; Led Development of Triggers for Air Bags
description: Ahmed D. Kafadar, an entrepreneurial engineer who led the development of the explosive triggers used in automobile air bags, died of a heart attack on Jan. 17. He was 82 years old and lived in Englewood, Colo.

title: National News Briefs; Atlanta Census Chief To Act as Agency's Head
description: Commerce Secretary William M. Daley announced today that James F. Holmes, who has been director of the Atlanta office of the Census Bureau, has been appointed Acting Director of the bureau, effective immediately.

title: Poking Education's Sore Spot
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's threat to withdraw the city's contribution to remedial education at the community colleges of the City University of New York touches a sensitive area that is emerging as one of the biggest issues in higher education in the United States: what to do with the millions of students who enter college each year unprepared for college-level work.

title: Salo's Shutout Revives Isles' Playoff Hopes
description: Whatever playoff hopes the Islanders are harboring depend as much on luck as execution and circumstance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MOLLIE (NEE HOLTZMAN)
description: DAVIS-Mollie (nee Holtzman). Died on January 27, 1998 in Ft. Lauderdale. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Gladys and Ralph Blumberg, Cal and Fritzie Davis and the late Harriet Recht and Irwin Recht. Loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Graveside services on Sunday, February 1 at 11 AM, United Hebrew Cemetery, 122 Arthur Kill Road, Richmond, Staten Island, Holtzman Family Plot.

title: Aetna's Life Insurance Unit Is Reported to Be Up for Sale
description: Aetna Inc., one of the largest insurance companies, has begun trying to sell its life insurance business in the United States to further concentrate on its main line, health care.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Abortion Clinic Bomb Was Intended to Kill, an Official Says
description: For years, abortion protesters picketed the New Woman, All Women Health Care Clinic near downtown Birmingham, waving signs, screaming, blocking the sidewalk.

title: 24 at a High School Test Positive for TB
description: Twenty-four students at Clifton High School have tested positive for tuberculosis infection, city health officials said yesterday. The test results indicate only that the students have been exposed to tuberculosis, not that they have active cases, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAKOWITZ, HILDA
description: SAKOWITZ-Hilda. The residents of 230 West 105th Street mourn the sudden and tragic passing of Hilda Sakowitz, our warm, caring neighbor and long time building leader. Our hearts are with her husband Shelley and with her whole family.

title: Workers See Easing of Sexual Tensions
description: When the Monica S. Lewinsky scandal broke, the White House understood that if American women turned on Bill Clinton over reports of an affair with a 21-year-old intern, his Presidency could be destroyed.

title: Three in a Row: Chan Takes Von Zedtwitz Team Title
description: A group of six players has set a record by scoring three consecutive victories in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams. Lapt Chan, Jim Krekorian, Brad Moss and Elizabeth Reich, all of Manhattan; Jon Heller of Brooklyn and Phillip Alder of Manhasset, N.Y., took the 1997 title on Thursday. Playing at Honors Club, 117 East 57th Street, they defeated Mark Feldman of Manhattan and his team by 10 imps.

title: Clinton Seeks Tax Credits for Fuel Savings
description: The Clinton Administration is proposing generous new tax credits for consumers who buy advanced automobiles that use emerging technologies to go two or three times as far on a gallon of gas as today's models.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, PHYLLIS
description: ROSENZWEIG-Phyllis. Devoted wife of the late Hyman. Loving mother of Raymond and Mark. Beloved mother-in-law of Michaelanne and Susan. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Elizabeth, Emily and Naomi. Services Sunday 1:30PM, at Riverside Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: In Computer Industry, The Old Are in the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: In Setback, Prosecutors Forced to Drop a Key Witness in a Club Owner's Drug Trial
description: For the second time since the prominent nightclub owner Peter Gatien was indicted on drug racketeering charges, Government prosecutors suffered a significant setback this week when they had to abandon a witness they had hoped would provide important evidence against Mr. Gatien, court records showed yesterday.

title: Backing U.S., France Warns Iraqis to Yield on Arms Inspections
description: Reinforcing American threats of military action, France warned Iraq tonight that it faced ''very grave consequences'' unless President Saddam Hussein allowed United Nations inspections of suspected chemical and biological weapons sites to resume.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. and Japan in Deal To Increase Air Traffic

title: Senate Candidates Flaunt Campaign Bank Accounts
description: The clamor over the financing of Federal elections may have left the impression that politicians would recoil at being linked to aggressive fund-raising. But the pronouncements yesterday by the rival camps in the New York Senate race showed once again that candidates would rather be perceived as harvesting bushels of contributions than as having a sparse crop.

title: Foreign Affairs; America's Multiple-Choice Quiz
description: The U.S. faces a Hamletesque choice in dealing with Iraq today. It comes down to this: 2-b or not 2-b, that is the question. Does the Clinton Administration have an option 2-b? Everything hinges on that.

title: N.Y.U. Hospital Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: As Victories Pile Higher, So Do Nets' Hopes
description: In theory, the Nets have more than a little to shoot for in Vancouver on Saturday night. With a victory over the Grizzlies, the Nets (25-19) can match last season's total -- with three games remaining before the All-Star Game break.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Pop and Jazz Guide in Weekend yesterday, showing the saxophonist James Moody, who is appearing at Iridium in Manhattan through tomorrow, carried an incorrect credit. It was by Jack Vartoogian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTELLI, THOMAS. ESQ.
description: CARTELLI-Thomas. Esq. The Columbian Lawyers Association First Judicial Department, notes with deep sorrow the passing of our first president and founding father. We send our most heartfelt condelences to his family and thank them for their generous request that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Tom's name to our scholarship fund at 8 East 69th Street, New York, New York 10021. Louis L. Benza, President, Columbian Lawyers Association, First Judicial Department

title: Ethnic Violence Flares Anew After Election in Kenya
description: They laid 19 pine coffins in a row on the grass of a cattle market here today. It was a clear, breezy day more suited to a soccer match than a funeral. A choir sang hymns while thousands of people pressed close to see the rough-hewn boxes.

title: Drug Merger Studied, With New Partners
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. announced late yesterday that it was in talks with Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. on a possible merger that would be the largest corporate deal in history and would create the world's biggest pharmaceutical maker.

title: Lionel Wilson, 82, a Mayor Of Oakland for Three Terms
description: Lionel Wilson, who presided over a racial, cultural, economic and political revolution during three terms as the first black mayor of Oakland, Calif., then suffered shattering defeat when he sought another four-year term in 1990, died on Jan. 23 at his home in Oakland. He was 82.

title: A Display Of Gaiety And Delight In Dancing
description: It was not long after the vividly painted curtain rose on ''Cinderella,'' performed by the Ballet Nacional de Cuba on Wednesday and Thursday nights at City Center (131 West 55th Street, Manhattan), that it became obvious what the real attraction was. What elevates this somewhat simplistic production, which plays through tomorrow afternoon, is the dancing, pure and simple.

title: Journal; Hillary's Double Agents
description: The Bronco-chase-paparazzi-chase-skirt-chase phase of our latest national soap opera is over.

title: AMERISERVE FOOD AGREES TO ADD PROSOURCE
description: Ameriserve Food Distribution Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the food-service distribution provider Prosource Inc. for $15 a share, or $342 million. Prosource's shares doubled, shooting up $7.3125, to $14.25, in Nasdaq trading. The acquisition will create a company expected to generate sales of $9.4 billion. It will serve approximately 38,000 restaurants in the United States, Canada and Mexico, including Arby's, Burger King, Dairy Queen, KFC, Olive Garden, Pizza Hut, Red Lobster, Taco Bell and Wendy's. Prosource is based in Coral Gables, Fla. Ameriserve, based in Dallas, is one of the nation's largest food-service distribution companies. It is a subsidiary of Holbery Industries, a closely held service company based in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREVOST, ELIZABETH ''BETTY'' (NEE DURRIE)
description: PREVOST-Elizabeth ''Betty'' (nee Durrie). Of Shrewsbury, New Jersey. On January 30. Wife of the late Sterett. Mother of Maj. Sterett R. III, USAF Ret., the Rev. Edward S., and Dr. William D. Grandmother of six. Sister-in-law of Mathilde Schack. Funeral service Sunday, 3 PM, at Christ Church, Shrewsbury. Graveside service on Monday, 11:30 A.M., Evergreen Cemetery, Hillside, New Jersey. Visitation Saturday, 4:30-7:30, at the John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANBLATT, RABBI SANFORD D.
description: SHANBLATT-Rabbi Sanford D. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. After ordination, he was an army chaplain in Korea. He served congregations in Swampscott, and Pittsfield, MA., Buffalo, N.Y. and at his death was the rabbi of Congregation Melrose B'nai Israel Emanu-el of Cheltenham, PA. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Charlotte, his brother, Norbert and sons, Jonathan, Neal and Brian. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP, The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Get Outta the Way -- We're Dancing Here
description: Walking is New York -- a defining characteristic that has kept us a step ahead of other cities. Today, a century after the first subway trains rattled into Grand Central Station and the first automobiles puttered down Fifth Avenue, two-thirds of the journeys around downtown and midtown Manhattan are still made on foot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, PAULINE
description: COHEN-Pauline, 90. Beloved wife of the late Harris. Mother of Philip M. Cohen and Norma Barasch. Mother-in-law of Burton Barasch and Liliana Cohen. Sister of Marion Glickman. Grandmother of Elizabeth and Jane Barasch, Martha Stine, Amy Ziegelbaum, Susan Hirsch, and Patti Epstein. Great-grandmother of nine. Services at 10 A.M., Sunday, Parkside Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: In Computer Industry, The Old Are in the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Auto Exports To U.S. Fell in December
description: Japanese auto exports to the United States fell in December for the first time in 16 months as large manufacturers increased North American output to defuse trade friction. Exports to the United States fell 2.4 percent from the month a year earlier, to 90,239 vehicles, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said.

title: FLOWERS IN PACT TO ADD FRANKLIN BAKING
description: Flowers Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Franklin Baking Company of North Carolina for stock. Terms were not disclosed. Flower Industries, a baking company based in Thomasville, Ga., had revenue of $712.95 million for the six months that ended on Dec. 13. Franklin Baking, based in Goldsboro, N.C., has annualized sales of more than $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, MONIR
description: LAZAR-Monir. Of Plainview, NY, formerly of Forest Hills, January 29, 1998. Loving wife of 66 years to Nedjat Lazar. Beloved mother of Janine Jackman, Claude Lazar and the late Andre Lazar. Wonderful grandmother and great-grandmother. Cherished mother-in-law of Sheldon Jackman, Phyllis Lazar and Christine Lazar. Funeral services Sunday, February 1, 9:30 AM, at The Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York, at 76th Road. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Better AIDS Prevention Can Close Health Gap; Life-Style Factors
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Id al-Fitr, celebrating the end of Ramadan, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Linda Tripp's Statement on Role in Case
description: Following is a statement released to The New York Times late Thursday by Linda R. Tripp through her lawyer, James Moody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, IRMA LOUISE (NEE ENDEL)
description: SPITZER-Irma Louise (nee Endel), died on January 30, 1998 at Longboat Key, Florida after an extended illness that she bore with extraordinary bravery and always with a quiet smile. She was the devoted wife and best friend of James for sixty years, the dedicated mother of James Jr. and Sheri and Thomas and Caroline, the adoring grandmother of Ashley, Jessica, Jamie, and the dear sister of Albert M. Endel, Jr. and Mathilde E. Scheuer, both of Montgomery, Alabama. Her sweetness and love graced our lives and will always remain in our hearts and memory. Funeral services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, Sunday, February 1 at 11:30 AM. Interment private. If any contributions are desired to be made in her memory, it would be appreciated if given to Mt. Sinai Hospital for the Irma Louise Spitzer Parkinson Disease Research Fund, care of Dr. Seymour Gendelman, 5 E. 98 St, NY, NY 10029

title: Inflation Whimpers. What's Next for Fed?; New Stresses at Home and Abroad
description: When the Soviet Union collapsed, the makers of American foreign policy lost their lodestar. Similarly, the prospect of Federal budget surpluses after decades of deficits has transformed the debate over taxes and spending.

title: CONSOLIDATION CAPITAL PLANS 7 ACQUISITIONS
description: The Consolidation Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire seven electrical contracting and service companies for about $138 million in stock and cash. Consolidation Capital, based in Washington, D.C., seeks to acquire companies and build consolidated enterprises. Earnings and revenues figures were not available for the company, which went public in November. The purchase price will consist of 50 percent in stock, the company said. The companies being acquired have combined revenue of $276.9 million.

title: Drug Lords Infiltrated a Mexico Inquiry Into Disappearances
description: A Government investigation into the disappearance of scores of people in northern Mexico has been thrown into turmoil by the discovery that narcotics traffickers infiltrated one of their agents into the unit carrying out the inquiry.

title: EMERITUS ENDS ITS BID FOR ARV ASSISTED LIVING
description: The Emeritus Corporation ended its $313 million takeover bid for ARV Assisted Living Inc. yesterday, after a California court denied Emeritus's attempt to overturn a note conversion sale to Prometheus Assisted Living. The Seattle-based Emeritus, which said in October that it wanted to buy ARV, was offering $17.50 a share and assumption of debt for ARV, an assisted-living-services company based in Costa Mesa, Calif. ARV's shares fell $1.5625 each, to $12.875. Emeritus's shares rose 6.25 cents, to $11.375. ARV had said it preferred an agreement with Prometheus, a group of investors led by Lazard Freres & Company. ARV sold Lazard $60 million in convertible notes in October. ARV has 49 assisted-living communities and dominates the California market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANNER, GEORGE, M.D.
description: KANNER-George, M.D. January 30, 1998 of Garden City, N.Y. Beloved husband of Virginia. Loving father of Judith Medori, Deborah Sandler and David Kanner. Dear grandfather of six grandchildren. Loving brother of Nathan Kanner and Martin Kanner and the late Sylvia Schlager and the late Lillian Zimmerman. Visiting at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City 2-5 and 7-9 PM Sunday. Religious service 10 A.M., Monday at The Fairchild Chapel. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn New York.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE TUMBLES. Gasoline and oil prices fell after Defense Secretary William S. Cohen indicated that the United States was still considering a diplomatic solution in its dispute with Iraq over weapons inspections. February unleaded gasoline fell 2.24 cents, to 52.72 cents a gallon.

title: As Newark Bounces Back, So Does Mayor
description: This time a year ago the political fortunes of Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, were bleak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINQUE, JOSEPHINE F.
description: CINQUE-Josephine F. January 29, 1998. Sister of Albert Cinque. She is survived by numerous nieces and nephews and close friends who will all deeply miss her. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10AM, Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 Street, New York City.

title: Better AIDS Prevention Can Close Health Gap; Infant Mortality Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TURAK, NATHAN
description: TURAK-Nathan. January 31, 1983. We still miss you very much. Sadie and Alice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, SHANNON
description: WHITE-Shannon. The employees of the Four Seasons Hotel New York mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Shannon White. Her spirit, her energy and her determination inspired us all. Her smile will be forever remembered and her contributions will never be forgotten. To her parents Joseph and Maureen, and brother Patrick, we extend our heartfelt condolences.

title: Pataki Seeks a New Waiver Of Federal Food Stamp Limits
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today sought another waiver of Federal welfare rules passed last year that require able-bodied adults to work for food stamps, virtually guaranteeing that tens of thousands of needy New Yorkers will keep their benefits.

title: The Neediest Cases; This Year, a Record-Setting Sum Is Within Reach
description: As The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund enters the final month of its annual appeal, the tally of donations points to what could be the most successful drive ever.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROWAN COS., Houston, an oilfield services company, terminated its 49 percent interest in KLM ERA Helicopters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSINOW, LEO
description: ROSSINOW-Leo. 83. Died Jan. 23, 1998, in Delray Beach, FL, leaving his beloved wife Lorna, daughter Jayne Cantor and son David.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're licensed down here and we have a good reputation with our customers. People are more comfortable with us than with the illegal bookmakers. They know that when they win, we pay.''

title: An Endorsement for Congress in Queens
description: On Tuesday, Queens voters in the Sixth Congressional District will choose a replacement for the recently retired Rev. Floyd Flake. They will not get much help from party labels. Assemblyman Gregory Meeks is the Democratic nominee. State Senator Alton Waldon Jr., a Democrat, is running on the Independent and Conservative lines, even though he seems to agree with none of the Conservative Party's agenda. Barbara Clark, the 21st Century Party candidate, is a Democratic Assemblywoman who formed her own party for this race. Celestine Miller, a Republican and a district school superintendent, was also a Democrat until two months ago. The Republican Party is pouring resources into Ms. Miller's campaign. Her commitment to education is impressive, but on other issues she seems fuzzy. She can best serve Queens by continuing her important work in the schools.

title: Washington And Moscow Show Split Over Iraq
description: Russia and the United States displayed their sharp disagreements over Iraq today, with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright expressing deep skepticism that diplomatic solutions were possible and the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, saying that the negotiating process had just begun.

title: Tears, Joy and 1,000 Points
description: Jennifer Rogers, a 5-foot-7-inch junior guard, scored her 1,000th career point last night during a 19-point performance in Fort Hamilton's 66-39 triumph over its Brooklyn rival Lafayette.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MATTUS, JOHN D.
description: MATTUS-John D. 10/18/51-1/31/96. Remember-that which is given to God is never lost to man. Eternal memory, my dearest friend. Kevin

title: In Computer Industry, The Old Are in the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: At China's Colleges, a Rush To Party, as in Communist
description: In an era of business deals and fervent consumerism, when the M.B.A. is hot among graduating seniors, why do more and more of the better college students yearn to join a seemingly outdated club -- the Communist Party?

title: For Roosevelt Islanders, Tram Is a Lifeline; Safer, More Convenient
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Arrested at Hotel And Held in Bank Heists
description: A 31-year-old bank robber with a penchant for luxury hotels was arrested last night in an Upper East Side hotel a day after carrying out his 14th successive robbery, the police said.

title: 4.3% Growth In 4th Quarter While Inflation Stayed Tame
description: Economic growth accelerated in the fourth quarter of 1997 while inflation remained subdued, the Government said yesterday, capping a year full of statistical superlatives.

title: COLTEC WILL GET TEXAS COMPANIES FOR $40 MILLION
description: Coltec Industries said yesterday that it had acquired two Texas chemical companies and certain operations of Marine and Petroleum Manufacturing Inc. for a combined $40 million. Tex-o-Lon, based in Houston, manufactures polytetrafluoroethylene, or PTFE, products for the semiconductor industry. Repro-Lon, based in Burnet, Tex., reprocesses PTFE compounds for the chemical and semiconductor industries. Marine and Petroleum's manufacturing operations in Houston, Burnet and Freeport produce flexible graphite and PTFE sealing products. Coltec said the three companies had combined sales of about $32 million in 1997. Coltec, a Charlotte, N.C., diversified manufacturing company, had 1997 sales of $1.31 billion.

title: Dorothy H. Hirshon, 89, Dies; Socialite and Philanthropist
description: Dorothy Hart Hirshon, a glamorous figure in New York society from the 1920's through the 40's who later became active in social, human rights and political causes, died Thursday in an automobile accident while driving near her home in Glen Cove, on Long Island. She was 89.

title: Better AIDS Prevention Can Close Health Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: A Swiss Bank Raises Loss on Derivatives
description: Union Bank of Switzerland said today that it lost 350 million Swiss francs ($240 million) on equity derivatives last year, nearly twice what it had forecast. Still, it said, there was no need to revise the terms of its merger with the Swiss Bank Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RABBI JULIUS
description: GOLDBERG-Rabbi Julius. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1953, he served The Plainview Jewish Center for over four decades, first as senior then as rabbi emeritus. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Bette, children Rachel, Dr. Harry, and Rabbi Mordecai. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Loss of Baby's Remains Is Under Investigation
description: Jersey City authorities are investigating the disappearance of a stillborn baby who was delivered at the Jersey City Medical Center, the police said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHON, DOROTHY H.
description: HIRSHON-Dorothy H. Died suddenly Thursday, Jan 29, 1998 at the age of 89, following an automobile accident. She is survived by her son Jeffrey Paley and his wife Valerie; her daughter Hilary Paley Califano and her husband Joseph Califano; and her step-daughter Joy Briggs, all of New York City. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Scattering of the Ashes Ceremony will be private. A Memorial Gathering will be held at the Tishman Auditorium, The New School, 66 West 12th Street, NYC, March 5 at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributiions in her memory may be made to the New School or to Phoenix House.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Growth Accelerated

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREAVES, JEMIMA K.
description: GREAVES-Jemima K. On January 31, 1995. In loving memory of my beloved mother. Gone but not forgotten. Son Reynold & Family

title: Needle Attacks at School Leave Students Fearful
description: During his two and a half years at Intermediate School 183 in the Bronx, Andrew had become adept at dealing with the common fears of young students, but he had a greater worry yesterday, a day after he was pricked with a needle in a frightening prank.

title: Bill Would Allow Patients to Sue H.M.O.'s
description: A bill was introduced in the State Assembly on Thursday that would allow patients to sue health maintenance organizations for malpractice if they are denied necessary tests or procedures.

title: Paula Jones Team Largely Fails In a 3-Year Corroboration Hunt
description: Despite a relentless three-year investigation of Bill Clinton's personal life in Little Rock and Washington, lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones have been unable to find any credible new witnesses who are willing to swear under oath that they had a sexual relationship with him, witnesses and lawyers involved in the Jones case say.

title: This Time, Hopkins Will Give Brown No Comfort
description: After Simon Brown had sustained one of the most disheartening defeats of his career -- a sixth-round knockout by Vincent Pettway in 1995 that left him flat on his back and still throwing punches into the air -- one of the first people to call and console him was Bernard Hopkins.

title: With Freedom, Cairo Intellectuals Find New Stress; Pressures Squeeze Islamic Scholars As Well as Leftists and Liberals
description: For Arab intellectuals here, this is a time of opportunity, danger and above all, change. While many say that never have they known such freedom of thought as in Egypt today, they also complain that threats from militant Islamists as well as official, collegial and economic pressures have silenced independent voices and weakened what was once the Arabs' most luminous intelligentsia.

title: Sports Agency Chief Will Stay in His Post
description: Robert E. Mulcahy 3d will stay on at his current job as the president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority even though his contract officially expired yesterday. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman praised Mr. Mulcahy last month as the best choice to run Rutgers University's athletic program.

title: Monitors Praise Giuliani's Spending Plan
description: A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented a preliminary $34.3 billion city budget, most outside monitors who watch the city's finances reacted positively to his proposals, saying they struck a prudent balance between spending and revenues.

title: When the Murderer Is a Woman
description: Karla Faye Tucker, the double-murderer scheduled for execution in Texas next Tuesday, has asked that her gender not be an issue in decisions on her legal appeals or the commutation of her sentence. We think that she, like all others on death row, should serve life in prison. But her gender is the only thing that gives her a chance at this. If she were a man she would be a better candidate for execution than many on death row. There is no doubt about her guilt. She confessed to participating in two gruesome murders. She is neither retarded nor mentally ill. She wielded the murder weapon, a pickax, herself, and was an adult when she did so.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption in some copies yesterday, with a picture of Monica S. Lewinsky's exit from the Cosmos Club in Washington, referred incorrectly to the man with her. He was not Nathaniel H. Speights, one of her lawyers; he was unidentified.

title: A May-December, of Sorts
description: It's simple to understand the wide, easy appeal of a time-travel story. Fantasy runs up against reality in a comfortable way that everyone has experienced in dreams, waking and otherwise. But the best time-travel stories also include a huge element of anxiety: will the person who witnesses the past be able to change it? ''The Love Letter,'' a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation on CBS tomorrow night at 9, is an engrossing example of this tug of expectations.

title: Dow Loses Ground in January for First Time Since 1990
description: As January goes, so goes the year.

title: Amvescap of Britain To Buy Asset Manager
description: Amvescap P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy LGT Asset Management for $1.3 billion in cash and stock, creating a fund management powerhouse with $250 billion in assets. Amvescap said it would pay at least $800 million in cash and would issue $500 million in shares to buy the money manager, which is owned by Liechtenstein's royal family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, DR. ALAN S.
description: MEYER-Dr. Alan S. Cherished husband of Alice Nolen Meyer. Devoted father of Robert, Julie and Kenneth. Dear brother of Paul and Roger. Services Temple Beth El of Northern Valley, Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, NJ Monday, 11 AM. For information, ''Wien & Wien'' Englewood, NJ 800-322-0533

title: A Dense Brocade by a Trio
description: Notes bunch up in John Hicks's piano chords. They're always filling his fists, and he keeps a few fingers agitatedly moving around within the chords, keeping a bop pulsation constant through the wall of sound. He wears time loosely, letting himself fall behind the beat; his ideas scrabble around to become realized, and he makes thick, heavyweight brocades of music. There's not much flash or incident in his playing, but it's quickly mesmerizing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODNICK, MARTIN
description: GRODNICK-Martin. The officers, trustees and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee express their deep sorrow at the loss of Martin Grodnick, beloved husband of our devoted Board member, Edythe Roland Grodnick. Martin, together with Edythe, was actively involved for many years at Metro West Federation. We extend our deepest sympathy to Edythe. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Michael Schneider, Exec. VP Ambassador Milton A. Wolf Chairman of the Board

title: Pact on Air Traffic By U.S. and Japan To Lift Restrictions
description: The United States and Japan ended one of their largest outstanding trade disputes today by agreeing to remove most restrictions on air traffic between the two countries.

title: Liar, Liar: From Ruthless to Harmless
description: ''I was brought up with lies all the time . . . that's how you got along . . . I have lied my entire life,'' Monica S. Lewinsky has been quoted as saying in a transcript of a taped telephone conversation.

title: Religion Journal; A Portrait Of Those Who Enter Into Orders
description: In recent years, the most frequently heard news about people becoming priests, brothers or nuns in the Roman Catholic Church has been that, in the eyes of church authorities, there have been far too few of them.

title: Austin Rides a Winner: Technology
description: When cotton and cattle were king in Texas, Austin was never really part of the action. And when oil was the economy's linchpin, the deals were done in Houston and Dallas while this city basically remained, and proudly so, a laid-back college town on the edge of the pretty Hill Country.

title: More and Cheaper Flights to Japan
description: The airline agreement that the Administration announced yesterday with Japan will yield substantial benefits to American travelers. As recently as last week, the Administration appeared to be caving in to Japanese demands. But the final terms give American carriers enough new takeoff and landing slots in Tokyo and other cities as well as the ability to cut fares without seeking Japan's approval.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, EVE
description: COOPER-Eve. On January 29, 1998. Loving mother of Joanne Kirshenbaum, Marilyn Oser and Barbara and Malcolm Thomson. Beloved wife of the late Sidney Schiffman and the late Perry Cooper. Cherished grandmother of Scott and Andrew Kirshenbaum, Zachary Oser, Jean and Barton Hill, and Steven and Arthur Parker. Dear great-grandmother of Amanda and Clara Hill. Services Sunday 12 noon at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Sidney Schiffman Fund in the Long Island Community Foundation, The Alzheimer's Association or the M.S. Society.

title: China 'Somewhat More Tolerant' of Dissent, U.S. Says
description: The State Department reported today that China was ''somewhat more tolerant'' toward dissidents last year than before and that the Chinese authorities had taken other ''positive steps on human rights,'' even though serious problems remained.

title: Wilbert Morey, 70, a Pioneer In Shore Kitsch
description: Wilbert C. Morey, an amusement park entrepreneur who built a gaudy empire of candy-colored motels and kitschy pier-side entertainments on the Jersey Shore, died Jan. 22 in Los Angeles while awaiting a lung transplant. He was 70 and lived in Wildwood, N.J., an island south of Atlantic City that he helped transform from a quaint 50's-era Boardwalk community into a boisterous honky-tonk Miami Beach.

title: Damascus Journal; Poking Fun Must Be Artfully Done
description: As he must be in his craft and in this place, Ali Farzat is gifted, both in art and the art of the oblique.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LASKY, ESTELLE
description: LASKY-Estelle. Twenty-seven years. Always loved . . . always remembered. Your Family, George and Joyce

title: FIGURE IN SCANDAL ASSERTS SHE HEARD CLINTON ON PHONE
description: The Federal worker whose furtive tape recordings caused the investigation of sex-scandal charges against President Clinton broke her silence today to tell of an early-morning phone call she said Mr. Clinton made to the White House intern at the heart of the alleged affair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECKENBERG, GUSTAVE A.
description: STECKENBERG-Gustave A. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Carole and Lenore. Adored grandfather of Evan, Lloyd, Joshua, Loren, David and Richard. Great grandfather of Alexandra, Benjamin, Jonathan, Zachary, Abigail and Emily. Services will take place on Sunday, at 12 Noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to B'nai B'rith, 3000 Westchester Ave., Purchase, NY 10577.

title: A Phone Call Puts a Man On the Spot
description: This is about what happened when a man made a telephone call in the name of civic duty and, just perhaps, with a political motive in the back of his mind, and how things did not turn out well for him because of it.

title: MID-STATE BANK SET TO ADD BSM BANCORP
description: Mid-State Bank agreed yesterday to acquire BSM Bancorp for $90 million in stock, creating a stronger presence in two California counties. Mid-State, based in Arroyo Grande, Calif., will pay shares worth $29.37 for each BSM share, with the exchange ratio to be determined, in a tax-free pooling of interests. The combined bank will have more than $1 billion in assets, the largest in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties, both of which are on the state's central coast. BSM Bancorp, based in Santa Maria, Calif., has $344 million in assets. BSM's shares rose 50 cents each yesterday, to $27, in Nasdaq trading. Mid-State's stock fell 65 cents, to $26.60.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTKIN, HARRY MORRIS
description: PLOTKIN-Harry Morris. On Friday, January 30, 1998 at his residence. Husband of the late Esther Plotkin; father of Ira Lev Plotkin (Kay); Judith Deborah Wilkenfeld (Jonathan); brother of Melvin Plotkin (Esther); Norman Plotkin (Rosalind) and Lena Gordon. Also survived by his grandchildren, Noah Benjamin Plotkin, Joshua Robert Plotkin, Aria Micha Wilkenfeld (Melissa); Daniela Lisa Wiggins (Marcus) and Gilad Joseph Wilkenfeld. Funeral services will be held Sunday, February 1 at 1:30 P.M., at Adas Israel Congregation, 2850 Quebec Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20008. Interment Judean Memorial Gardens. The family will observe Shiva Sunday through Thursday evenings, 7 P.M. and Monday through Friday mornings, 7:30 A.M., at the home of Harry Plotkin. Contributions may be made to The Charles E. Smith Jewish Day School, City Lights or Jewish Primary Day School at Adas Israel.

title: KOLLMORGEN INCREASES OFFER FOR PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC
description: The Kollmorgen Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its unsolicited offer for the Pacific Scientific Company by $3.25 a share, to $23.75, or $294 million total. Kollmorgen also extended its offer to Feb. 13. Under its original offer of $20.50 a share, Kollmorgen said, just 52,409 of Pacific Scientific's 12.382 million shares outstanding had been tendered. Its latest offer is still below the recent stock price. Pacific Scientific, a Newport Beach, Calif., maker of electrical motors and aircraft equipment, has called the initial offer inadequate. Kollmorgen, with headquarters in Waltham, Mass., makes motion-control equipment, which includes generators, periscopes and gun directors. Pacific Scientific shares were up 50 cents, to $25.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, ARNOLD H.
description: GRAHAM-Arnold H. Beloved husband of Roselle. Devoted father of Stuart and Sandra, Joel and Gladys, and Jul and Sherry. Loving grandfather of Kevin, Iris and Jerald. Services are at ''BoulevardRiverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, Sunday at 11:30 A.M.

title: HOCKEY: Emotional Stop on a Long Journey; Recovering Konstantinov Leads Red Wings, Into White House
description: The moment came in private, before the official White House ceremony began. Vladimir Konstantinov, confined to a wheelchair, sat before the President. They were introduced and exchanged glances. Scotty Bowman, the coach of the Detroit Red Wings, stood and watched.

title: Guilty Plea in Scheme to Sell Answers to Admission Tests
description: A California man pleaded guilty in Federal court in Manhattan this week to organizing an elaborate nationwide scheme to sell answers to graduate school admission tests, using professional test-takers, coded pencils and long-distance phone calls to relay the precious information to the West Coast.

title: For Roosevelt Islanders, Tram Is a Lifeline; Where the Buses Are
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewullis Leads Tigers in Rout
description: PRINCETON 86, CORNELL 61

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Federal jury's conviction of four men in a corruption scheme involving New York City police unions referred imprecisely to the relationship between the Transit Police Benevolent Association and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. After the city police force merged with the transit police force, the P.B.A. absorbed the membership of the transit police union, but the two unions did not formally merge.

title: Hingis Defends Australian Open Title
description: Another pleasant day at the office, another Grand Slam title and its six-figure paycheck tucked into the ever-expanding piggy bank of 17-year-old Martina Hingis, the apparently peerless player who defended her Australian Open title this afternoon with a 6-3, 6-3 pasting of Conchita Martinez.

title: No Tie, No Lunch
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, BLANCHE L.
description: BERNSTEIN-Blanche L. Beloved wife of Abraham. Devoted mother of Francine Ehrlich. Loving grandmother of Matthew and Jonathan. Services Sunday, 12:45 P.M., at ''Gutterman,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with a chart about the evolution of the James Bond character in the movies misidentified the film in which Roger Moore was shown wrestling an anaconda. It was ''Moonraker,'' not ''Live and Let Die.''

title: Vandals Destroy Eighth Ave. Scaffolding
description: Vandals destroyed a six-foot stretch of an illegally erected sidewalk shed in midtown Manhattan yesterday, sending lumber and steel crashing to the ground, officials said. No one was injured in the early morning incident.

title: For Roosevelt Islanders, Tram Is a Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC and Turner Discuss an N.F.L. Rival
description: NBC and Turner Sports, which will not be broadcasting National Football League games for up to eight years, are discussing the formation of a new fall rival for the N.F.L.
